column2: Prominent members of the Associated Cycling Clubs of New York have expressed themselves as favoring the nomination of the association's President, City Magistrate Charles F. Simms, Jr., for Chief Consul of the State Division of the League of American Wheelmen, for which, to succeed Isaac B. Potter, the present incumbent, the regular committee has put up Walter S. Jenkins of Buffalo.

If our safety or our prosperity depended upon the possession of Hawaii we might annex or even seize the islands without troubling ourselves to prepare a satisfactory reply to the very candid and able letter sent to Secretary SHERMAN on July 10 by the Japanese Minister. High national policy does not bother itself about letters or logic, or very much about justice.

-- In cases where his clemency will be well advertised, Gen. WEYLER has of late shown an inclination to spare the lives of captured rebels, the object, of course, being to supply an occasional instance that will balance the stories of massacre that have been coming from Cuba for the last two years.

Over 300 policy holders in the Massachusetts Mutual Benefit Life Association of Boston met yesterday afternoon at the Equitable Building, to take final action upon the call of the association for extra assessments. The Rev. Thomas Heywood of Elizabeth, N.J., presided, and A. Edward Woodruff acted as Secretary.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- The President and Secretary Alger have decided to detail an army officer and a company of soldiers from the regular army for service in Alaska. The matter is yet in very indefinite shape, but details will be arranged as soon as possible in order that the soldiers may get into the vicinity of the gold country before navigation closes on the Yukon River.

At a meeting of the Park Board yesterday afternoon Chief Engineer Parsons of the Rapid Transit Commission appeared before the Commissioners. He said that he had the plans of the route of the commission for the loop in Battery Park. The board decided not to act on the matter until the Commissioners had looked over the plans.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., July 27. -- The Brooklyn Naval Reserve fleet, which is on its way to Fisher's Island for practice, arrived here last night, with the exception of three boats. They were in command of Lieut. Reid, Engineer Braine, and Quartermaster Hamilton.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 27. -- A Republican State Executive Committee is being evolved at the Neil House to-night. Members of the State Central Committee called together by Chairman Harry M. Daugherty for a meeting to-morrow are busy discussing feasible selections, locality being always kept in view, and it is probable that the function of to-morrow will be merely a series of formal announcements.

According to the observations of John C. Juhring of Francis H. Leggett Co., local patriotism is developing under the stimulating efforts of the Merchants' Association. "Since the newspapers of New York have explained the good work that this association is doing," says Mr. Juhring, "the merchants everywhere seem more patriotic.

Everything that Brooklyn has gained within the last fifteen years has been gained by the prevalence of non-partisanship in its municipal affairs. Most of the gain has been under Mayors who were the candidates of the Republican Party, but not one of these could have been elected on a strict partisan division.

Because "lawyers talk to waiters and poets to hostlers" on the steamers bound from Seattle to St. Michaels, in Alaska, a writer of big headlines in one of the newspapers assumes that "caste" is ignored by the adventurers going to the gold fields of the Klondike. Perhaps it is.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 27. -- Spear Street Dock was the scene of more excitement this morning when the steamer State of California sailed for the North than has occurred there for many years. Fully 1,200 persons gathered to witness the departure of the steamer, and the miners received an enthusiastic farewell.

The enacting clause of the Dingley Tariff act says nothing about a day, or any division or fraction of a day. "Be it enacted," so runs the clause, "that on and after the passage of this act, unless otherwise specially provided in this act, there shall be levied, collected, and paid" the rates of duty set forth in the various schedules.

CHICAGO, July 27. -- A party of men will leave Chicago on a special train next Saturday night for the newly-discovered Alaskan gold fields. There will be 150 persons in the party. The special train on which the party will travel will run directly through to San Francisco. There the gold hunters will remain three days to purchase mining supplies.

President Sheffield of the Fire Department is making a strenuous effort to have the present high rate of insurance in New York reduced, and in doing this he has gathered statistics covering the work of the department for the first six months of the past ten years. These show that while the number of fires have increased, the average loss per fire has decreased.

The rush of the brewers and tobacco men to take advantage of the last few days prior to the enforcement of the new tariff provisions has made a considerable increase in the receipts of the Internal Revenue Collectors for the month of July. Under the old law brewers were allowed a rebate of 7 1/2 per cent. on their beer stamps, but under the new law no rebate is allowed.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 27. -- Lewis Thompson, Walter Neville, and Rosa Binford, all colored, were taken this morning to Decatur from Birmingham, where they had been confined for safe keeping for a month. At Decatur Judge James J. Banks convened a special term of court, and the Grand Jury at once found true bills against the negroes, who will be tried Thursday for an attack on Miss Nellie Lawton, a reputable young white woman.

RICHMOND, July 27. -- The colored ministers in Virginia have determined to use every effort to prevent assaults upon white women by members of their race. This movement is probably due to a threat by the leading papers of this State that in the event that there is no abatement in this crime the colored people would have to support the public schools for their race.

The new sloop yacht Kestrel, which has been built by F. Wood at City Island for J.B. Mills, was to have been launched yesterday, and several friends of the owner journeyed to City Island to witness the boat take its first plunge into the water. Unfortunately a strong wind had blown against the water all day, and as a result the tide did not serve high enough to get the boat off.
Duff Rusher have sold for the estate of Joseph M. Valentine to a Mr. Livingston two lots on the north side of One Hundred and Fourteenth Street, 150 feet east of Amsterdam Avenue.

The silver market is a provoking mystery. Its present course is to the last degree exasperating to the champions of free coinage, but it also baffles expert and unbiased analysis. The price fell in London yesterday to 26 5/8 pence per ounce, the lowest ever reached.
It was only a telephone message, but it caused no end of trouble in the family of Dr. Charles F. Geissler.

-- Whether Lieut. Gov. WOODRUFF is to be the tie that binds Senator PLATT to Mr. JACOB WORTH, or whether he is to be a sort of buffer State, interposed between them like Siam between French Tonquin and British Burmah, his responsibilities will be equally great, and the dangers of his position no less in the one case than in the other.

What THE TIMES said yesterday of the significance of the Japanese protest is more than borne out by the comments upon it of the London papers. One of them pleasantly observes that the Americans" have such odd ideas of diplomatic language that they are no great authorities" upon its meaning.

LONDON, July 28. -- The Times this morning prints a dispatch from Simla which says yet another proof is given of the wave of fanaticism which is sweeping along the northwest frontier. The story is curious as showing how quick the tribesmen can be gathered and how readily they respond to the appeal of fanaticism.

SEATTLE, Washington, July 27. -- James Kelly, a young mining engineer, returned yesterday from Alaska on the steamer Topeka with an authentic account of the survey that has been made for the first railroad in Alaska, running from Dyea over the White Pass to Lake Togish, Lake Allen, and the headwaters of Hootlinqua River, emptying into the Yukon.

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- Assistant Secretary of the Treasury Howell had his attention directed to-day to the talk in THE NEW YORK TIMES of this morning with Deputy Collector Phelps upon the interpretation likely to be placed upon the clause of the new tariff law regarding the imposition of duty on imported personal effects exceeding $100 in value.

Dangerous and very interesting counterfeits of the five-dollar silver certificates of the new issue -- series of 1896 -- exist. They are apparently the work of one man or one set of men. For each counterfeit a two-dollar silver certificate of the new issue is used. The operation is technically known as "raising."

The best thing about the statement made by Commissioner CRUCER at the meeting of the Park Board on Monday is the evidence it affords that the board is sensitive to the opinion entertained of its proceedings by artists and the artistically cultivated classes. It has for some time seemed otherwise.
NEWPORT, July 27. -- The following yachts arrived here to-day: Sloop Philias, New York Yacht Club; sloop Sylva, owned by Mr. Metcalf.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., July 27. -- Armand Miller, aged twenty years, son of Prof. Miller, who resides at 35 Cortlandt Street, this city, was found last night asleep in the woods by Policeman Reeves of the Wakefield police. The young man, who is weak mentally, disappeared from his home on Saturday, and although a search had been made for him by the family they were unable to find him.

" Personal Liberty and a German-American for Mayor of Greater New York" is the motto on the banner raised by Herman Sulzer, and he has called a convention for this afternoon to nominate a candidate. If the fates are auspicious the Sulzerites may be the first party to, in sporting parlance, "shy its castor into the ring" and place its candidate in the field, as formally appealing for the suffrages of the voters.

By an almost unanimous vote yesterday, the Board of Aldermen passed ordinances defining the rules of the road. Acting Mayor Jeroloman expressed his approval of the measure and practically gave assurance that he will sign the ordinances within a day or two. When his signature has been added, what prominent wheelmen believe to be one of the most satisfactory codes of regulations governing the use of city streets in the country will go into effect.
LONDON, July 27. -- The St. James's Gazette, commenting upon Japan's protest in the Hawaiian matter, says:

Now that the bobolinks are beginning to make preparations for their Southern journey, it makes me sad to think that in a few short weeks these beautiful songsters will be shot to satisfy, not hunger, but the pampered appetites of those who long for a change of food, and also to make sport for the gunner.

BOSTON, July 27. -- At the same moment a bolt of lightning struck the building 40 Kilby Street Saturday afternoon Miss Alice Barrett, bookkeeper for Codman Codman, brokers, shot herself through the head. It was at first thought the lightning killed her, but this was disproved later.

PITTSBURG, July 27. -- Eighty-nine coal companies in the Pittsburg district were represented at the coal operators' uniformity meeting here to-day. The operators who ship by river and those owning mines in the Westmoreland field were not present. The river operators held a meeting at the Coal Exchange this afternoon and decided to take no part in the uniformity movement No attention was paid to the call by the Westmoreland people.
County Clerk Jacob Worth arrived in Brooklyn yesterday from his Summer home in Saratoga, and will return there this afternoon or to-morrow morning.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, July 27. -- Sheriff Insker received a letter, dated July 1, from Lake Linderman, Alaska, to-day. The letter is from L.R. Mackenzie of this city, who is at the head of a party which left here last April for the gold fields by the way of Juneau and Chilcat Pass. The letter is as follows:

YONKERS, N. Y., July 27. -- A fire, which for a time it was feared might be accompanied by considerable loss of life, broke out at 5 o'clock this afternoon in the blowing room of the hat factory of William Reed Co., on the lower floor of the Shethar Building, on Elm Street. Two large gas meters exploded immediately after the flames first burst forth.

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- The armor-producing companies having declined to furnish the Navy Department the armor needed for the three battleships now building at the price of $300 per ton fixed by Congress, Secretary Long has taken the second step in the line marked out by Congress, and has called upon the shipbuilding companies to submit propositions for procuring and fitting the armor.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 27. -- A local firm that is engaged in manufacturing gold-dust bags of sheepskin for Californian customers is working with double force on account of telegraphic orders received since the Klondike discovery.

BALTIMORE, July 27. -- The Democratic State Convention will meet at Ford's Opera House to-morrow at noon to nominate candidates for Controller and Clerk of the Court of Appeals. A new State Central Committee will be chosen, and its Chairman will be designated by the Chairman of the convention.

It is amusing that the moment a law officer of the customs takes a careful look at a provision of the tariff which has been four months in the hands of Congress, and which was studied by the Ways and Means Committee for nearly as long before its submission to Congress, he finds a clause in it so vague that he foresees a chance for evasion and does not foresee how it can be prevented.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 27. -- The Jewish Chautauqua session to-day was highly interesting. Papers were read and discussion held upon the "Jew as a Race -- Their Progress and Ascendency in the Commercial World" and as "The People of God."

CHICAGO, July 27. -- It has been decided by those in charge of the work on the new Post Office that piles will have to be driven 103 feet below the street surface before rock is struck on which to rest them. The site is over a bed of soft mud, and that is what caused the old building to fall in pieces.

LOUISVILLE, July 27. -- The Brooklyns developed a batting streak in the fifth and sixth innings this afternoon and piled up twelve runs off Magee. Miller finished the game after the seventh. The Colonels could not hit Kennedy. Score:

NEWPORT, July 27. -- The race between the thirty-footers to-day was most exciting, the winning boat, Vaquero III., being only 27 seconds ahead of the Esperanza. The wind was strong from the east and the Brig Ledge course of seventeen miles was chosen and the start made at 3:10. The Vaquero was the first across the line, and held the lead until the finish, although at one time the Esperanza was close upon her heels.

ALBANY, July 27. -- The midsummer meeting of the New York State Chess Association at Murray Hill, Thousand Islands, will have the greatest attendance of chess celebrities of this country that has been known for years. Steinitz, for thirty years champion of the world; Pillsbury, present champion of America, and Lipschutz, ex-champion of America will play for the Challenge Cup.

If the rainy weather that has prevailed for the past two weeks or more has been a relief to the city man by keeping down the temperature somewhat, it has caused great losses to many farmers, whose crops have been damaged or altogether ruined, while other farmers are praying for a let-up of the downpour and for a gradual rise of temperature lest their drops should rot in the ground before they can gather them.

BOSTON, Mass., July 27. -- The "Dooming Board," which has been sitting for three weeks, adjourned this afternoon. It will be two weeks yet before the schedule of valuations will be ready for public distribution. It is expected, however, from present indications, that more than $25,000,000 will be added to the taxable valuation of the city.

BRIDGEPORT, July 27. -- The Bridgeport detectives, who are endeavoring to apprehend the murderers of Marcus G. Nichols, who was killed at Daniels Farms last week, to-day made an arrest in the town of Huntington, a small place about five miles northeast of Trumbull. They took into custody John Weeks, not as a principal in the crime, but as one possibly possessing valuable information.

BOSTON, July 27. -- One of the most interesting international tennis matches ever seen on this side of the water was played this afternoon in the tournament of the Longwood Cricket Club, and resulted in a victory for the American expert over his British opponent after four brilliant sets had been played.

BOSTON, July 27. -- The dinner of the Boston business men to Secretary Gage at the Tuileries this afternoon was attended by about 150 of the leading men in the professional and commercial life in the city. An informal reception was held preceding the dinner, which occurred at 2:45 o'clock.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., July 27. -- Judge Thomas M. Cooley has been taken to a sanitarium at Flint, Mich.
WASHINGTON, July 27. -- The President to-day announced the following recess appointments:

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- The principal topic of discussion at to-day's Cabinet meeting was the legal aspect of the proposed establishment of a military post in Alaska, near the gold fields. In some quarters there is doubt as to the power of the Executive to establish a post without specific authorization by Congress, but the weight of opinion appeared to favor the exercise of such a right by the Executive as an emergency measure.

Aqueduct was treated yesterday to a sample of the bad weather which prevailed during the Brighton Beach meeting, for there was rain all the afternoon, which made watching the races from the grand stand anything but a comfortable occupation.

Clement Milton Rutter, one of the oldest members of the Stock Exchange, died of heart trouble early yesterday morning at his home in the Newport apartment house, 206 West Fifty-second Street. His death, while sudden, was not altogether unexpected to his family, but the news of it came as a shock to many of his associates and acquaintances in the down-town financial district.

The trial of Charles Kraemer for violation of the election law at the last general election was resumed yesterday before Recorder Goff, in Part II. of General Sessions. Kraemer was Tammany Captain of the Eighteenth Election District of the Eighth Assembly District, and is accused of having induced one Thomas Ferguson of Philadelphia to register falsely.

BALTIMORE July 28. -- Harmony prevailed at the Democratic State Convention here to-day and it was clearly demonstrated that Senator Gorman still has his hand on the lever that controls the movements of the organization. The candidates nominated by the convention were selected by him mud the resolutions were of his inspiration.

War has again broken out in the Police Board, and Commissioner GRANT threatens to resign. Last March he could see but three ways by which he could be got out of office -- "death, legislation, or giving me something better."

BOSTON, July 28. -- Senator Hoar is confident that a revival of business will follow the new tariff law. In a statement to-day he gives his reasons, and explains why he accepted the duty on hides. He says:

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, July 28. -- Three letters from Clark County (Ohio) boys in the Alaska gold fields were made public to-day. They are from Joseph Fitzgerald of 191 East Mound Street, who left here last Spring; William Berg of Clifton, who went away at the same time, and Thomas O'Brien, brother of Milt O'Brien, ex-President of Trades Assembly, who has been in Alaska for ten years.

RICHMOND, Va., July 28. -- The Democratic State Convention will assemble at Roanoke on Aug. 11. So far as the Governorship is concerned, the work of that body is already lined out for it. The result of the primaries for the election of delegates to the convention has indicated beyond the shadow of a doubt that the nomination for the place is in the hands of Major J. Hoge Tyler of Pulaski County.

Your National Guard notes in Sunday's TIMES, commenting on the behavior of the Guard in the great labor strikes of 1877, and also at Hornellsville and Buffalo, cause the military man to think that, except in the matter of drill and equipment, our State troops are in no better shape to take the field than they were in the early days of 1861.

Lord GEORGE HAMILTON, in answer to a question in the House of Commons on Tuesday why the Government had bought 7,708 tons of rails for the East Indian Railway of an American firm, returned a conclusive and interesting answer. He said it was because the American bid was less by 8,675 than the lowest British bid.

The London Chronicle is apt to be much better informed upon American affairs than most of its English contemporaries, as well as to take them much more seriously. The more amazing it is to read in that journal that what it calls the "dismissal" of President ANDREWS from Brown University is "the most serious blow the capitalist oligarchy has yet struck at social, economic, and intellectual liberty in America."

OTTAWA, Ontario, July 28. -- At the meeting of the Ministers last evening, Minister Paterson was authorized to send two more customs officers by the Islander, which sails for the north to-morrow. The officers will be taken from the Victoria Custom House, and will be accompanied by a couple of provincial police.

After many weeks of negotiation between the Brooklyn Heights trolley system (otherwise the Rapid Transit Company) and the Brooklyn Union Elevated Railroad Company, President Uhlmann of the latter road finally announced yesterday that the scheme of consolidation had been abandoned, with no definite prospect of its ever being resumed.

I have just seen a recent article concerning vivisection in your columns, and I beg the privilege of a few words of criticism of some statements therein contained. I trust you will be just and let both sides be heard, since you have had your say.

Samuel R. Trowbridge and Miss Caroline May Wentworth went to Jersey City Monday, and after considerable trouble found a Justice who made them man and wife. Yesterday they separated, Mr. Trowbridge returning to his work at the St. Lorenz Hotel, where he is manager, and Mrs. Trowbridge going to the home of her husband's mother, in East Sixty-second Street.

A thin, freckle-faced youngster, with a thatch of reddish hair and an expression of grief, sat among the stoical bluecoats in the dismal back room of the Oak Street Station yesterday afternoon, twisting a soiled handkerchief about his grimy hand, whimpering occasionally into his ragged cloth cap, and then glancing at a rusty iron chain, one end of which was padlocked to his ankle and the other fastened to a sixteen-pound steelyard weight.

ALBANY, July 28. -- Four railroad companies, which propose to construct electric roads in Greene County and vicinity, and which are to be managed by practically one body of men, were incorporated with the Secretary of State to-day.

Coroner Fitzpatrick yesterday concluded the inquest into the cause of the death of William Fraser and Jacob Jacobson, the two men who were killed by the collapse on June 3 last of David S. Brown Co.'s unfinished soap factory.

BOSTON, July 28. -- Another mysterious circumstance in the case of Miss Alice Barrett, who was found dead in the office of her employer on Saturday, was brought out to-day at the hearing which Fire Marshal Whitcomb is conducting to ascertain the cause of the fire which broke out just before the girl's body was found.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., July 28. -- Colorado Springs will be connected with the Cripple Creek gold camp by a short line electric road. The City Council has granted a franchise to Irving Howbert and associates and also the right to derive motive power from the city's water system. Work on the grades was begun to-day.

HAVANA, via Key West, Fla., July 28. -- Capt. Gen. Weyler, it is announced, will take the field in a few days to personally direct military operations in the Havana province against several bands of insurgents, from 50 to 200 strong. This step is due to an attempt on the part of these bands to reunite.

After a stubborn fight before the State Railroad Commissioners, and then before the Commissioner of Public Works, the Metropolitan Street Railway Company found itself free yesterday to begin work preparatory to the long contemplated change of motive power on the Fourth and Madison Avenue street railroad line from horse to underground electric.

It would be interesting to know just what kind of a pluvial demonstration would constitute a good, hard rain in the estimation of Acting Weather Forecaster Emery. He called the manifestation of yesterday "showers."

The police in their efforts to execute the orders of Chief Conlin to make New York a quiet city during the ordinary sleeping hours have accomplished some gratifying results, but have encountered several distinct snags of noise with which they are unable to deal -- nuisances of the sea, the earth, and the air which municipal ordinance can neither overcome nor punish.

Judge BANKS'S court in Decatur, Ala., may be, as he declares, a "white man's court," but this is not wholly "a white man's country," as the recent appointments of RUCKER to the Internal Revenue Collectorship and MORTON to the Postmastership of Atlanta, Ga., rather strongly prove.

RENO, Nevada, July 28. -- One of the worst wrecks in the history of the Central Pacific Railroad occurred at 9:48 this morning on Twenty-Five-Mile Hill, about six miles west of Reno. The engine was overturned and thrown to one side of the track, and the tender on the other, and the road was littered with the debris of the baggage, express and mail cars, which had been reduced to kindling wood.

WASHINGTON, July 28. -- The first copies of the Tariff act in law form for circulation have been received at the document rooms of the Senate and House. The law makes a pamphlet of seventy pages. The members of the House will have 25,000, the Senators 10,000, and the Senate Committee on Finance 15,000 copies for distribution, making 50,000 in all to be circulated by Congress.

The table of statistics prepared by President Sheffield of the Fire Department, and published in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday, for the purpose of reducing the present rate of fire insurance in New York, has stirred up the underwriters to a great degree. Yesterday the insurance men discussed President Sheffield's argument and his table of figures with a great deal of vigor.

Gen. C.H.T. Collis, Commissioner of Public Works, said yesterday that he was very much astonished to find that so much political significance had been attached to the dinner he gave to some of his political friends at the Claremont Hotel Tuesday night.

WASHINGTON, July 28. -- President McKinley has done a thing before leaving Washington for his Summer vacation which will be reassuring to employes of the Government in so amending the rules of the civil service as to require that no removals from positions subject to examination shall be made without "just cause" and upon written charges.

The sad story of Frank Schilling, the non-union painter, in Saturday's issue of your paper appeals strongly to all. It would seem that those of the working class who so loudly denounce the "monopoly of capital" have in their "monopoly of labor" a more dangerous element, since it is capable of causing ruin and death to those of their fellow-workmen who are unable to fulfill-its claims.

LONDON, July 28. -- A dispatch from Bombay says that Gangadhar Tilak, a native member of the Legislative Council, was arrested last evening on the charge of inciting the natives to disaffection. He was formally arraigned in the Bombay police court this morning, after which the hearing was adjourned.

Will you kindly advise me whether there is at present, or has been, any railroad or steamboat propelled by compressed air, either in this country or in Europe, and if so, where and when, and is it a costly or cheap motive power?

At the meeting of the Police Commissioners yesterday Col. Grant made positive announcement of his intention to resign from the Police Board as soon a the Mayor would accept his resignation. After the meeting he said he had come to that decision because he found it impossible to do the work required of him as a Police Commissioner and at the same time live up to the traditions in which he had been reared.

MADRID, July 28. -- A special dispatch from Oporto, Portugal, says that the political situation, already grave, has been aggravated by the strong measures taken by the Government to intimidate the Republicans and to force them to give effect to its financial proposals. The Ministerial organs warn the Republicans that they will be "rigorously dealt with."

MEDFORD, Mass., July 28. -- Both Robert J. (2:01 1/2) and John R. Gentry, (2:00 1/2,) the famous pacers, were able to lower their records, or that of the track, (2:04 1/4,) at Combination Park this afternoon, and none of the 2,500 or more spectators who braved the cold, raw, northeast wind had the slightest idea they would be able to do so.
Stock markets strong.

NEW ROCHELLE, July 28. -- Mrs. Williams, mother of A.E. and E.A. Williams of Passaic, N.J., who had such a narrow escape from being drowned in Echo Bay, this village, last night, was able to go to her home in Passaic this evening. At the same time Mrs. Williams was nearly drowned, Edmund Sinclair Williams, the one-year-old son of Mr. and Mrs. A.E. Williams, also had a narrow escape.

Lieut. Gov. Woodruff and Jacob Worth played hide and seek yesterday, and dodged one another around Brooklyn in the rain for several hours. Incidentally, the Lieutenant Governor did most of the running. Mr. Woodruff's object was to bring Senator Platt and Worth together, and thus bring peace to the warring elements of the Republican Party in this city and Kings County.

WASHINGTON, July 28. -- The preliminary report of the Commissioner of Internal Revenue for the year ended June 30, 1897, shows that the total receipts during that period were $146,619,508, a decrease as compared with the previous year of $211,106. The receipts from the several sources of revenue together with the increase or decrease as compared with the fiscal year, 1896, are stated as follows:

Col. A.P. Ketchum, Chairman of the Board of Trustees of the College of the City of New York, and Commissioners Wheeler, Little, and Eustis, appeared before the Board of Estimate yesterday with a proposition to purchase forty-one lots at One Hundred and Thirty-ninth and One Hundred and Fortieth Streets, Amsterdam Avenue and St. Nicholas Terrace, as part of a site for the College of the City of New York.
WHEELING, West Va., July 28. -- As a result of the conference of labor leaders held here yesterday it is said that the coal miners' strike will be won or lost within two weeks.
WASHINGTON, July 28. -- President McKinley has promulgated the following important amendment to Civil Service Rule H.:

SARATOGA, July 28. -- The race meeting which opened here to-day gives promise of being the best held at the famous old racing resort in twenty years. Because there was no racing here last year, the Spa did not prove a great attraction for visitors, but to-day the place is crowded with people from the East and West, most of them followers of the turf.

Uncle Sam's coffers were filled with over $3,000 yesterday from the first real application of the clause in the new tariff law which levies customs duties on all articles of wearing apparel, personal adornment, and toilet effects purchased abroad, exceeding $100 in value, of travelers returning to this country.
Coming from the counsel of the Society for the Prevention of Crime these statements, made by Commissioner Moss at the meeting of the Police Board yesterday, are somewhat significant:

Wallace's Baseball Park, Halsey Street and Wyckoff Avenue, Ridgewood, will for the balance of this season be free on Saturday afternoons to commercial, shop, and amateur baseball nines, either for match or practice games. Teams desiring to play at the Ridgewood grounds need make no previous arrangements, as there is plenty of room for all, with diamonds, dressing rooms, , free.

Referring to your interesting article on the National Guard in the railroad strike of 1877, I beg leave to say that the Fifth Maryland Regiment was also a "notable exception" to the general uselessness of the National Guard. You will remember that the strike and attendant riots first broke out in Baltimore, and this regiment was the first of the National Guard to be in service.

The reported excitement among the Kansas farmers about the importation into their State of poor children from New York is not exactly justifiable, but it is partly understandable. Much of what may be called the "documentary evidence" of New York's social and moral condition that goes out into other States is of an alarming character, and doubtless the Kansas farmers, who are, after all, merely human and therefore gullible, regard this whole town as diseased.

SARATOGA, July 28. -- It is cold here; outside doors are kept closed, and wraps are in demand; but, in spite of the weather, there was a lively meeting of the inhabitants of the Realms of the Rose in the United States Hotel ballroom this morning.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 28. -- In the thirty-footers' race this afternoon there were four entries. In a stiff east wind, the Wa Wa won. The results were:

WASHINGTON, July 28. -- Public men in Washington were generally surprised when the announcement was made in the cable dispatches a few days since that the question of the Clayton-Bulwer treaty had been raised in the British Parliament in connection with the proposal to annex the Hawaiian Islands to the United States, and also were consequently prepared for the response of the British Government that the lone question was not involved in the other.

If Marquis ITO really said to the Paris correspondent of The Herald what the correspondent reports him as saying, it is evident that he has lost his head or that he will lose it soon after his return to Japan.

BOSTON, July 28. -- The Allan Line steamer Scandinavian arrived this afternoon from Glasgow and brought with her the four survivors of the crew of the British barkentine Florence, Capt. Olsen, which was sunk in a collision with the Scandinavian last Saturday while in a dense fog twenty miles south of Cape Race.

If what Prof. Chandler is reported to have said in an interview said to have been published in The New York Evening Post on Feb. 9, 1878, be true, then the talk of Mr. J. Fanning O'Reilly and of Purist is humbuggery.

A number of importers whose goods from abroad were entered at the Custom House last Saturday propose to contest the official ruling that all importations arriving subsequent to midnight of Friday are subject to the duties imposed by the new Tariff bill. It has been estimated that at this port alone four or five hundred thousand dollars are involved in the final interpretation of the enacting clause of the new law.

WASHINGTON, July 28. -- President McKinley left Washington to-day for a vacation that may keep him away from the city for six weeks. He was accompanied by Mrs. McKinley, Secretary and Mrs. Alger, Secretary Porter, Assistant Secretary Pruden, and Executive Clerk Cortellyou, together with the White House steward and a maid.
N. Brigham Hall and John H. Dye have sold for Wallace Stuart to Domenico Cella for $21,000 the three-story and basement brick dwelling 124 West Thirteenth Street, 20.10 by 103.3.
LOUISVILLE, July 28. -- The Colonels played poorly this afternoon, and the Brooklyns won without the slightest trouble. Fisher kept the home team's hits scattered, while Frazer was hit hard. Score:

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 28. -- Brewers and maltsters in this city deny being interested in the proposed combination of brewing interests reported in a dispatch from New York this morning. No such deal has been proposed to any of the nineteen large brewing firms here, nor to the officers of the local brewers' association.

BOSTON, July 28. -- The third round of the Longwood tennis tournament was played to-day and consisted of three matches between Americans and one between two of the Englishmen. The interest centred in the latter match, which was played this afternoon, and quite a crowd saw H.A. Nesbit, who is rated in England as ninth in the list of tennis cracks, defeat Dr. W.V. Eaves, who is rated third, in three straight sets.

WASHINGTON, July 28. -- Secretary Long has taken the preliminary steps toward the creation of a Board of Naval Officers to ascertain the cost of a Government armor plant. Two members of the board have been selected -- Commodore Howell, Commandant at the League Island Navy Yard, and Capt. McCormick of the Norfolk Navy Yard.

The sinister-looking man was execrated on all sides. The feminine screams, the swishing of skirts, and the sudden exit from the car of men and women, brought forth only a sardonic laugh. But when reprisals were threatened, the sinister-looking man disappeared. And, after all, a little pug dog caused all the trouble.

PITTSBURG, July 28. -- The "True Uniformity" conference of coal operators of the Pittsburg district ended its work tonight at 9:15, after a two days' session of close and persistent work. The twenty-one sections of the uniformity agreement were thoroughly discussed and adopted section by section.

A stalwart bull and a confident believer in coming Wall Street activity is Mr. J. Fletcher Shera of the Stock Exchange house of Townsend Shera. Mr. Shore expects to see a very much higher level of prices before the year is out, believing that we are to have a bull market for some months to come.

CINCINNATI, July 28. -- There was a sensational accident in the first race at Oakley to-day. Corie Lynn, a maiden two-year-old, tumbled at the three-quarters pole and went down in the middle of the bunch, breaking her neck. "Jimmy" Dupee, her jockey, fell under the horse and was badly shaken up, but not seriously injured.

The President's acceptance of the principle of civil service reform is genuine, practical, and gratifying. His order that within the classified service removals are to be made only on charges and after a hearing creates an important bulwark of the merit system.

YONKERS, N.J., July 28. -- The firms which were burned out last evening were this morning figuring up their losses. The report that a watchman and a woman were missing was denied. The police said that every one had been accounted for. The ruins are still smoldering.
The address of Secretary GAGE at Boston is plainly intended as an urgent appeal to the business men of the country, in what he regards as a serious situation.

POUGHKEEPSIE, July 28. -- The romantic courtship of Miss Minnie Reimer, the nineteen-year-old daughter of Adolph Reimer, the wealthy promoter of Dover Plains, by "Archie" Hoffman, the young bank clerk of the same village, ended yesterday with their elopement and marriage by the Rev. Mr. Burnett, a Baptist minister at Lithgow.
WASHINGTON, July 28. -- The President has made the following recess appointments:
Are the tables about to be turned?

CLEVELAND, July 28. -- The Giants made enough runs in the first inning to-day to win an ordinary game. They fell on Young's curves for eight hits. The latter, however, settled down after the first inning and kept the visitors' hits scattered. The Cleveland players took a strong liking to Seymour's curves from the start, and he was compelled to retire in favor of Meekin after the second inning.

LONG BRANCH, July 28. -- Paul Grant, Robert Zimmers, and August Brandt, who conduct a bicycle store in the Brighton Flats, in the West End, were arrested to-day by Fire Marshal Emanuel, who charges them with arson.

The Campaign Committee of the Republican Club is getting ready to throw brickbats at the Citizens' Union. It has prepared resolutions declaring that as the anti-Tammany vote is chiefly Republican, the next Mayor should be a Republican, and that "all schemes for forestalling the action" of the Republican Convention, and "all efforts to force any particular action upon the Republican Party" should be discouraged.

BOSTON, July 29. -- Fire Marshal Whitcomb to-day resumed his investigation of the fire at the office of Codman Codman last Saturday afternoon, where the body of Miss Alice M. Barrett of Waltham, the firm's bookkeeper, was found with a bullet through the heart. P.J. Collins, a Water Street business man, testified that before Miss Barrett's death she tried to borrow $1,200 from him at 5 per cent. interest.
Lemuel E. Quigg, Chairman of the Republican County Committee, took a hand in the work of the Campaign Committee of the Republican Club last night and received an indirect but decided rebuff.

Predictions that Klondike enterprises would continue to be launched in this city are becoming verified. It was stated yesterday on the Mining Exchange that $50,000 had been raised to send agents out there. John A. MacPherson, ex-Chairman of the Mining Department of the New York Consolidated Exchange, is the prime mover in a new enterprise which has been announced.

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- A representative of the brewery owned by Senator Murphy, in Troy, called on Internal Revenue Commissioner Forman this morning, and said that Friday last Mr. Murphy deposited with the Internal Revenue Collector $200,000 to pay for a supply of beer stamps. The stamps were not to be had on that day, and by the time they reached the Collector in Albany the new law had gone into effect.

BOMBAY, July 29. -- Word has been received that the natives in large force made a second attack on Camp Malakand yesterday. Thirteen of the British were killed and thirty wounded, the latter including Lieut. Castello. The tribesmen lost 100 men.

PLATTSBURG, N. Y., July 29. -- President McKinley and party arrived at Bluff Point Station at 6:50 o'clock this morning on their special train over the Delaware and Hudson Railroad. The party was driven to the Hotel Champlain shortly after 7 o'clock, the President having breakfasted in his car before starting for the hotel.

Within the next ten days out-of-town buyers will begin coming to this city on the reduced railroad rates arranged by the Merchants', Association, and they will continue coming for several weeks. They will find plenty to interest them in the way of business and amusement, and they will be made welcome in the spacious and convenient headquarters of the association at Broadway and Leonard Street.

The lower part of the East River directly above the Brooklyn Bridge was more than usually crowded with vessels at 11 o'clock yesterday morning, when the battleship Maine arrived at that point en route from New London to the naval anchorage off Tompkinsville, S.I. A very strong ebb tide was running at the time and the big vessel was slowly feeling her way down the river, keeping well in toward the New York shore.
Mandelbaum Levine have sold to Angelo Alpi the five-story brick tenement, with stores, 141 Thompson Street, 25 by 100.

Miss Josie MacDonald of 9 West Forty-fifth Street is lying at her home in a pitiable condition as a result of a twenty-minute exposure to X rays during the latter part of last month, when an X-ray photograph of her upper left jaw was taken by a man whose name is supposed to be O'Connor. The young woman had for some time previous been suffering with intense pains in her jaw.

CINCINNATI, July 20. -- After watching his filly, Taluca, win the Ohio stakes in the hardest kind of a drive, Dr. E.F. McLean, one of the best known horsemen on the American turf, was attacked with heart disease and died a short time afterward at the Oakley race track, this afternoon.
The spoilsmen asked Mr. MCKINLEY for bread and he has given them a stone -- "in the neck," as their own choice phrase is.

The excellence of New York's drainage and sewerage systems was illustrated by the condition of the city yesterday morning, after the deluge of the night before. During the twenty-four hours ending at 8 o'clock yesterday morning the rainfall was 2.56 inches. Practically, all of this came in eight hours.
NEWPORT, July 29. -- Mrs. William Astor opened the season, socially speaking, when she gave a dinner to-night at Beechwood to twenty-five of the leading cottagers.

LONDON, July 30. -- The Times this morning publishes a dispatch from Simla saying that the road from Mardan to Malakand seems free, as an officer with an escort of only four men passed safely along the road to the camp on Wednesday.
MOBILE, Ala., July 29. -- This city was in a turmoil to-day as the result of three murders which occurred last night.

An admirer of MAX PINE, the young man who has just come into great prominence in the lower east side neighborhoods of this city as the leader of what is called the "knee-pants strike," declares that certain of his features indicate that he is a man "lacking in power to earn money and without any ability to save it."

RAHWAY, N.J., July 29. -- Rahway has been flooded for the last twenty-four hours as it has not been before since 1882. About 8 o'clock last night a cloudburst deluged the city, and in an hour six inches of rain had fallen. Milton Lake filled to overflowing, and ran into the river from one section.

Coroner Dobbs and a jury held an inquest yesterday into the cause of death of Abram Myers, fifteen years old, who died at his home, 423 East One Hundred and Twenty-third Street, July 19 of lockjaw. The boy shot himself in the left hand July 5 with a blank cartridge. He was treated at the Harlem Hospital and the wound apparently healed.

Importers in this city who purpose contesting the ruling of the Collector of Customs regarding the application of the new tariff law to goods which arrived here from foreign countries last Saturday and were entered at the Custom House before the close of the business day, are awaiting the official liquidation of their entries before filing their protests.

As a representative and influential citizen of Poverty Hollow, "Gus" Gloistein is now only a memory. This morning he will awake robbed of his glory to be once more only a very humble East Side publican.

Senator GORMAN'S Maryland platform is a document of unmistakable historical importance. It marks sharply the line of division between Western Populism and Eastern Democracy, and inflicts upon the party and the cause of Bryanism the first reverse it has suffered at the hands of the regular Democratic organization in any State.

Some of the decisions reported to have been arrived at by the Government of the Dominion in regard to mining in the Klondike are very surprising. That the Government should reimburse itself out of the proceeds of the mining for whatever of expense it has been or may be put to in consequence of the discoveries of gold is entirely just and reasonable.

PITTSBURG, July 29. -- Oak Hill, in the vicinity of the Turtle Creek, Plum Creek, and Sandy Creek mines of W. P. De Armitt, was invaded early this morning by an army of strikers, who came to attend a mass meeting held near the mines to-day. By daybreak there were several thousand miners encamped upon the hills surrounding the property of the New York and Cleveland Gas Coal Company.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 29. -- Domino, the famous race horse, died at the farm of James R. Keene, at 3 o'clock this morning from meningitis. He was taken ill yesterday, and six veterinaries were unable to save him. Domino was foaled in 1891, and had won over $100,000 in stakes and purses.

CHICAGO, July 29. -- The Wholesale Grocer will publish to-morrow answers from jobbers all over the country to questions regarding trade. The replies were from jobbers in twenty-seven States, and 50 per cent. show an increase in the volume of business for the first half of 1897, as compared with the same period last year; 30 per cent. report the volume about the same, and 20 per cent. note a decrease.

" Before you build, sit down and count the cost" is a homely old maxim that Secretary LONG has wisely heeded in appointing a commission to ascertain the expense of establishing Government armor-plate works. When he has received and read the report of Commodore HOWELL and Capt. MCCORMICK he will probably conclude not to build.

NEWARK, N.J., July 29. -- Last night was one of the most uncomfortable and alarming in the history of this State. Overflowing rivers and sewers, flooded streets, bursting dams, and an occasional landslide were the incidents that made the night memorable.

DOBBS FERRY, N.Y., July 29. -- During the heavy storm last night a bolt of lightning struck the barn on the Summer home of J. Jennings McComb, the millionaire, and destroyed the building. Two horses which were in the building were instantly killed. William H. Hurst, the President of the Stock Quotation Company, leases the place from Mr. McComb and occupies it during the Summer months.
WOODBRIDGE, N. J., July 29. -- A house occupied by a Hungarian family was carried away by the flood here last night. The grown people escaped, but left a baby in an upper room, and it was drowned.
WASHINGTON, July 29. -- The President has made the following appointments in the Consular Service:

The Board of Control of the Joint Traffic Association met yesterday at 143 Liberty Street, and Chauncey M. Depew, President of the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad, presided, as Chairman of the board, at morning and afternoon sessions. There was a full attendance of railroad Presidents and executive officials of the roads in the association.

-- Among the hitherto unnoted benefits conferred upon humanity by the bicycle is the development in women of a tendency to observe "the rules of the road," not only when riding their wheels, but on the elevated railway stairways, while passing along crowded sidewalks, and in many similar places where, until recently, the feminine habit has been to inconvenience other people as much as possible.

It is probably true that the rising in India is the result of the effect produced throughout the Mohammedan world by the victories of Turkey over Greece. The fanaticism thus aroused has in India been rendered especially acute by the celebration of the Queen's jubilee. This was, among other things, a celebration of the subjection in India of the crescent to the cross, and was, of course, infuriating to devout followers of the Prophet.
WASHINGTON, July 29. -- Assistant Secretary Howell of the Treasury Department, speaking to-day of the compensation to informers in customs cases, said:
PARIS, July 29. -- The will of Edmond de Goncourt came before the Court of Probate to-day for construction. The court will give judgment on Aug. 4.

The half-mile track of the Parkway Driving Club at Parkville, L.I., never looked better than yesterday afternoon, when the midsummer meeting was started after one postponement. The 300 persons present saw some close and exciting racing. Frank Cramer, ex-President of the club; Henry Hughes, and James Gormley occupied the judges' stand, and E.C. Walker officiated as starter.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 29. -- In the continuation of play at the annual tournament of the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club to-day one of the visitors was Laurence Curtis of Boston, the successor to the late Theodore A. Havemeyer as President of the United States Golf Association.

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- According to the latest information in the Navy Department concerning the prices paid abroad for armor plate for warships, the highest price is paid by Italy, which gave as high as $600 a ton in 1896 for plates. The Bethlehem and Carnegie Companies received something like $575 a ton in 1896.

Another day of disappointment for the reactionists -- another day in which security markets have grown broader and stronger. Yesterday's record was in many senses satisfactory. Not merely were quotations added to, but there was importance and there was influence in the fact that further defeats were meted out to the raiding contingent which lately has undertaken to possess itself of the Stock Exchange and all its machinery.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 29. -- The damage here from the flood of last night was from $30,000 to $50,000. It was afternoon to-day when the hole under the railroad tracks was cleared of water and trolley cars were able to resume their trips. A few years ago the city depressed its streets near the crossing of the Pennsylvania and Central Railroads, and the railroads elevated their tracks.

The week of golf in the wind and wet on the rolling sandhills of Shinnecock has had no result that will materially affect the status of the game in this country. With an easterly gale blowing most of the time, very fine and brilliant play was almost impossible, especially on links so exposed on every side and lying so near to the ocean.

For the first time in many weeks the army of racegoers who follow the Metropolitan racing circuit watched racing in the sunshine. There was plenty of the latter at Aqueduct yesterday, and it dried out the track, which in the morning was very heavy from Wednesday night's rain.

After all the bids for city bonds had been opened yesterday afternoon, Controller Fitch said: "It looks like Vermilye Co. I think the bonds were worth more money." Later the Controller said the bonds would probably be awarded to-day to Vermilye Co. and Kuhn, Loeb Co., who made a joint bid for the entire issue at 105.912.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., July 29. -- Mr. and Mrs. William Webb have been indicted and jailed on a charge of attempting to blackmail the Citizens' Railway Company. Mrs. Webb boarded a car several days ago and fell in the aisle. She alleges that the fall injured her spine, and sued for $25,000 damages, after a fruitless attempt to compromise the matter.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 29. -- A change of importance to the manufacturing interests of this coast has been made by the new tariff law, if the understanding now entertained is the correct one. Its importance is suggested in a note of instruction given by Collector Jackson to the Deputy Collectors in the following communication:

CHICAGO, July 30. -- The monthly issue of The Corn Belt to-morrow will have the following to say in regard to crop conditions in Kansas, Nebraska, Iowa, and Missouri. The territory covered is tributary to the lines of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad:

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- The State Department has received from a Philadelphia tobacco firm the note found in a bale of tobacco from Cuba, stating that three Americans were confined in Morro Castle, and were unable to communicate with their friends outside. The note will be forwarded to Consul General Lee at Havana, but the officials do not attach much importance to it in view of the internal evidence of its bogus character.

There is not a sane adult in the State of New York who does not know that the indorsement, by the Democrats of the State, of the Chicago platform will overwhelm the party. Yet there is an association which calls itself "the Loyal League of Democratic Clubs" which has been addressing to the Democratic State Committee an appeal to commit this very form of suicide.

SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y., July 30. -- James A. Tyng won the President's Cup to-day in the most interesting and remarkable game of golf ever played over the Shinnecock links. Unusual interests attached to the final match, as the unexpectedly brilliant showing of Foxhall Keene made many knowing golfers predict that he would defeat Tyng, whose prowess is well known.

Veterans of the civil war and members of the various religious orders connected with the Catholic Church throughout the United States are much interested in a movement which was started this week by the members of the religious orders affiliated with the famous monastery of Notre Dame, La Porte, Ind., who fought in the war.

Samuel Taylor Coleridge occupies a unique place in English literature. The epithet, "myriad-minded man," happily used by him in speaking of Shakespeare, might with proper pertinency be applied to him. He was, indeed, not one, but legions --
A correspondent of Le Figaro in Milan writes as follows concerning the recent reports of the ill health of Verdi, the composer:

Are there ever people who, adopting a motto, keep up to it? Mr. Stead has been trying to collect the mottoes of leading English people, literary and other, addressing them directly with "Please return by post, and find stamp inclosed." Mr. Rhodes's reply was:

At sight of a book cover with a map for decoration and a preface that announces the intention of telling "stay-at-homes" how to venture forth and "hire furnished," one thinks of statistics, and fairly expects to find them somewhere in the body of the book. Mrs. Wright, however, is more lively than statistical. She has none of Mr. W.H. Bishop's art of combining a keen humor and a delicate sentiment with crystal facts.

It is certain that the sciences of archaeology and history will receive fresh illumination through the projected researches of M. de Morgan among the ancient ruins of Persia. The field offers to the explorer a soil almost virginal, although rich with relics of great capitals, mighty empires, and enlightened civilizations, that extend backward to the very beginning of human society.

CINCINNATI, July 30. -- The Chicago Express on the Cleveland, Cincinnati, Chicago and St. Louis (Big Four) Railway, due in this city at 7 A.M., was wrecked at Thorntown, Ind., at 2:30 o'clock this morning. Two trainmen were instantly killed, and two tramps from Cleveland, who were stealing a ride on the front platform of the mail car, received fatal injuries.

Between now and Jan. 1, 1898, the counties, towns, villages, and districts which are to become parts of Greater New York will have the right to issue bonds for various purposes, which Greater New York will be compelled to pay. The manufacture of these bonds has become a flourishing local industry, and the indications are that it will continue to boom.

It is not known definitely how many of the books in Part I. of the Ashburnham library were secured for American collectors. Those New York dealers who had representatives present at the sale which was so emphatically the bibliographical event of the year were in a taciturn mood recently when approached on the subject.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 30. -- Relief Council, No. 40, O.U.A.M., of New Brunswick, N.J., had its twenty-seventh annual excursion to-day by the steamer Sirius of the Iron Steamboat Company, to Coney Island and Rockaway. One thousand five hundred and fifty excursionists, composed of members of the order and their friends from New Brunswick, South River, and South Amboy, participated.

ATLANTA, Ga., July 30. -- The appointment of Henry Rucker, colored, as Revenue Collector for Georgia is likely to create a social row in Atlanta. Many of the leading citizens of this city indorsed the application of Rucker for the office, for which Major William H. Smythe was also a candidate. The excellence of Rucker's indorsement secured the post for him, to the chagrin of the Major.

That indefatigable traveler, Mrs. Isabella Bishop, and Miss Byrd undertook last year a most difficult journey into Western Sze-Chuan. To understand the task performed by this enterprising woman, it must be borne in mind that she had to pass over an almost unknown spur of the Himilayan Mountain range.

Col. Frederick D. Grant at 11 o'clock yesterday sent his resignation as Police Commissioner to Mayor Strong. The Mayor received the letter about noon, but did not open it until he ate luncheon, at 2:30 o'clock, At 4 o'clock he had accepted the resignation, to take effect to-day; had picked out a new Commissioner, and had a promise from the man chosen that he would accept the office.

PARIS, July 16. -- In this broiling weather it is not in their studios that the majority of our artists are to be met. At Laurent's or Ledayen's, in the cool environment of trailing vines and great fuchsias, you may find them lingering long over the liquors, or later in the day at the Pavilion d'Armennonville, in the fragrant Bois, listening in the intervals of dinner to the strains of the Tzigane Band.

What should be aimed for is sense, not sensationalism, in all pulpit procedures. There is to be noted a present-day tendency among young preachers to exploit the Gospel by all manner of extravagances of expression. The spirit of yellow journalism appears to have infected even some supposably steady-minded clerics, who seek to attract by astounding and to obtain a hearing at the cost of self-respect and of all sobriety of thought.

BENNINGTON, Vt., July 30. -- Superintendent Bennett of the Lebanon Springs Railroad issued orders to-day to close the road in accordance with the order issued by Receiver Sweet several weeks ago. All regular train service ceased to-day. No passengers will be carried, and no freight will be received for transportation.

Senator Platt, Chairman Quigg, and President McKinley were warmly discussed last night by a meeting of 300 colored Republicans, in the hall of the Society of the Sons of New York, 153 West Fifty-third Street. Charles F. Butler, President of the Republican colored county organization, was Chairman of the meeting, and made several speeches.

It is the uniform practice to construe tariff laws in favor of the Government and against the consumer. In all cases of ambiguity and doubt the higher duty is imposed, and of all possible interpretations that one is accepted which inflicts the severest penalty upon the crime of importation.

Some remarkable finds have been made in Yorkshire, at a place called Danesdale, near Duffield. In a mound a number of graves were discovered, which leading English archaeologists believe are the remains of the men who were buried there 2,000 years ago. The bones were those of the ancient Britons, who lived a thousand years before the conquest.

SALEM, Mass., July 30. -- A local paper has received a letter from an aged woman, which, if the contents are true, has a most important bearing upon the famous Ross-King controversy, which has been in Rhode Island and New York courts for some time. The writer, whose name the paper withholds, is seventy-five years old, and says that the uncle of Mrs. Ross was considerably older.

SARATOGA, July 30. -- Alternating showers and short periods of sunshine kept many who would otherwise have gone to the races from the race track to-day. Those who did go out, however, were rewarded when they reached the track by seeing a clear sky overhead, and plenty of sunshine to bask in.

Dealers in diamonds, rough and uncut, and polished and cut, are well satisfied with the new tariff law and are prophesying a big revival in their trade. Under the Wilson bill the duty on cut diamonds was 25 per cent., and on rough diamonds 10 per cent. Under the Dingley law rough diamonds are free and cut diamonds are taxed at 10 per cent. ad valorem.
BERLIN, July 30. -- Ambassador White is just now giving close attention to a matter which promises to involve some diplomatic complications.

TROY, N.Y., July 30. -- The yacht Hermione was in collision with the steamer Saratoga of the Citizens' Line about 8:30 o'clock last night off Stony Point Light. A hole ten feet long was torn in the starboard side of the Saratoga aft the forward gangplank. The bar was wrecked and John Gorman of Troy and F. Delysle Smith, a lawyer of New York, were slightly-injured.

KANSAS CITY, July 30. -- ffudge Walter I-L Sanborn of St. l>8,ul held brief sessions of the United States Circuit Court to-day in this city and Leavenworth, Nan., at ?hich he formay entered decrees in The matter of the 13nion Pacific foree!oure for the dttriers of Missouri and ICansas. The decrees entered are similar 4o 'those recorded at Omaha yesterday.
Bishop Potter, who sailed from Liverpool by the Germanic on Wednesday and is due here on Aug. 4, will find a great deal of work awaiting him that has accumulated during his absence.

At Broadstairs a series of fetes has just taken place in honor of Dickens, the object being to establish a clubhouse for the working people and the fisher folk. This little village on the Kentish coast, Dickens delighted in. "Bleak House," it is thought, owed its origin to a house in Broadstairs, where the author lived during a Summer.

NEWPORT, July 30. -- The following yachts arrived here to-day: Steamer Electra, owned by E.T. Gerry; steamer Nourmahal, owned by J.J. Astor; steamer Ituna, owned by A.V. Amour; steamer Fedalma, owned by F.L. Osgood; steamer Now Then, New York Yacht Club; steamer Wadena, owned by J.H. Wade; schooner Monrive, Atlantic Yacht Club; schooner Montegan, owned by C.A. Miller; sloop Katonah, owned by F.L. Ames; sloop Sirocco, New York Yacht Club.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- It is evident that the United States Government will be obliged to make some changes in its diplomatic and consular assignments to Central America, for five of those countries are prepared to try the experiment of being considered one nation, and to be represented by one Minister, and it is apparently the expectation that the experiment will prove to be but the trial of a permanent practice.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- The Republican National Committee is maintaining its headquarters here during the Summer and keeping a force of employes at work getting out documents for use in those States of which the campaign next Fall will be of a National character. The States are Iowa, Maryland, and Ohio.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 30. -- Dr. John J.H. Love of this place died suddenly this morning after assisting Dr. Levi W. Chase in performing an operation. Dr. Chase picked him up at once, but the doctor was dead. The body was removed to the doctor's residence, at 54 Fullerton Avenue.

The Giants signalized their return to the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon, after a fairly prosperous trip in the West, by scoring a decisive victory over Brooklyn. Nearly 6,000 admirers of the team were on hand to help Joyce's men do the trick, if any rooting was necessary. Amos Rusie was never in better shape, and the way he acquitted himself brought joy to the hearts of every New Yorker present.

There is a certain amount of fun being poked at the Omar Khayyam Club, of which Mr. Barrie is a distinguished member. The praises of the Persian were lavished at a dinner given lately at the Crown Inn, near London, where sherbet and bitter beer were absorbed and beef and pomegranates devoured.

Supposably Buddha was born sometime between 562 and 552 B.C., and died at the age of eighty. As the founder of a belief, which has to-day millions of followers, and as a code of morality has influenced all civilized mankind, any further information in regard to Buddha, if authentic, deserves particular attention.

HAVANA, July 30. -- Manuel Fernandez Chaqueilo, the young American who was tried here by court martial on July 22, on the charge of filibustering, under the third article of the protocol of 1887, Consul General Lee being present, has not yet been sentenced, although the Prosecutor asked for the imposition of the death penalty.

Some one in The Spectator writes this about dust on books: "Dust is a delusion. You should never dust books. There let it lie until the rare hour arrives when you want to read a particular volume; then warily approach it with a snow-white napkin, take it down from its shelf, and, withdrawing to some back apartment, proceed to cleanse the tome."

LONDON, July 30. -- With reference to the denunciation of the German commercial treaty, The Times again compliments Canada and Sir Wilfrid Laurier, the Canadian Premier, upon paving the way for further consolidation of the empire, and expresses the hope that the German friends of the empire will not be angry enough to refuse to negotiate another treaty.

At a meeting of the Directors of the Third Avenue Railroad Company yesterday the action of President A.J. Elias and General Counsel Edward Lauterbach in negotiating for the purchase of the Dry Dock, East Broadway and Battery Railroad was unanimously approved. This action ratifies the contract of purchase which gives the Third Avenue company full control of the lines of the Dry Dock system on Aug. 23.

The only racing attraction of importance for the New York and Long Island district to-day is the National circuit meet of the Riverside Wheelmen, which will be run in the afternoon on the Manhattan Beach track. The programme furnishes an interesting list of events, for which a strong array of professionals and the pick of the fast amateur riders have entered.
WASHINGTON, July 30. -- Fourth-class Postmasters were appointed to-day as follows:

BOMBAY, July 30. -- The indignation of the natives against the Government for its summary policy of repression increases. They say that the Government is going to convert India into a second Ireland by a programme of coercion, and that no one is safe.

It is an archaeological fact that originally the one tool was put to many usages. An aboriginal stone implement with an edge to it was a knife, a scraper, or served to dig roots. Primitive man had to be a jack-of-all-trades, and without special tools. Therefore his dexterity must have been great.

After the courts have awarded heavy money damages in a few cases of injury and disfigurement by the X ray, the manipulators of that mysterious energy will probably employ the precautions which experience has already shown to be necessary.

A volume with the title "Cromwell's Place in History," by Samuel R. Gardiner, just published by the Messrs. Longmans, is based on a series of six lectures by Dr. Gardiner delivered last Autumn at Oxford. The book shows in complete outline and with considerable detail what the man was and what he did and probably expresses the final and general English judgment of educated men on both.

CHICAGO, July 30. -- Judge Horton discharged the receiver of the Suburban Construction Company, which is in fact the Suburban Railroad Company, to-day, and simultaneous with his discharge there was a complete change in the official composition of the Suburban company, the new officers being Yerkes men.

TACOMA, Washington, July 30. -- Twenty-four hours after Prof. McClure's fall to death down a 300-foot precipice on Mount Rainier, Tuesday, two other climbers had terrible experiences. H.A. Ainslie and George Rogers of Portland, Oregon, got lost in a manner very similar to McClure's experience, and fell forty feet into a crevasse on Cowlitz glacier.

In some important particulars the Benham murder case resembles the well-remembered case CARLYLE W. HARRIS. Perhaps no reader of the newspapers who has closely followed the reports of the trial at Batavia, N.Y., doubts the justice of the verdict of "Guilty" pronounced against HOWARD C. BENHAM by twelve of his fellow-men Thursday.

An enthusiastic meeting of the Directors of the Merchants' Association was held yesterday afternoon, in the rooms of the organization, at Broadway and Leonard Street. This is the first meeting of the board since the active, aggressive work of the association began. There were present William F. King, President; John C. Juhring, First Vice President; Charles H. Webb, Treasurer; John Claflin, William E. Tefft, and S. Christy Mead, Assistant Secretary.

Susie Grunelt, fifteen years old, was arrested in Central Park last night and turned over to the Gerry society. She had been living for almost a month past in a little cave in the Park, near Seventy-second Street. She is a Bohemian, the daughter of Joseph and Mary Grunelt of 312 East Seventy-first Street.

A steady stream of callers demanded the attention of Mayor Strong yesterday when he resumed executive duties in the City Hall after his vacation at Richfield Springs. He was in a good humor, and he came down to his office at 9:30 o'clock, walking jauntily without either crutches or cane. He said he was "feeling tiptop," and that his gout was much relieved.

In the Review of Books and Art of July 3 the Rev. N.H. Chamberlain's "Samuel Sewall and the World He Lived In" was reviewed. The book reminds one of the interest which anything relating to the eccentric though lovable Puritan Judge possessed for the late Henry F. Sewall of this city.

Cloudy skies and a balmy breeze brought out a much larger attendance at Parkville yesterday afternoon, the second day of the midsummer meeting of the Parkway Driving Club. A fair sprikling of ladies' toilets on the clubhouse veranda and balcony enlivened the scene. Chris Fitzgerald, Dr. Gill, and James Gormley occupied the judges' stand, and E.C. Walker gave the word.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., July 30. -- Walter Wilmot, ex-manager of the Minneapolis ball team, has signed with the New Yorks. He will leave to join the Giants Monday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 30. -- The speakers at the Jewish National Chautauqua to-day again devoted themselves to Biblical subjects. Dr. M. Jastrow of Philadelphia continued his discourse upon "The Analysis of the Books of the Bible."

-- There was no real basis for the mingled astonishment and apprehension created yesterday by the appearance and color of the sky. Unfamiliar as its blueness and distance were to most of us, a little inquiry addressed to elderly persons would have quieted the general fears, for it would have elicited the information that once such phenomena were by no means rare, and that they were not portents ominous of destruction and misfortune.

Can we appreciate sound by means of the eye? We know the wonderful ways of the deaf, who, by watching the lips of a speaker, understand the word as it is uttered, and can even imitate it. Is it possible to go even further than this? If the deaf-mutes can see, not the sound itself, but the mechanism of it, could they be made to feel sound?

Hall J. How Co. have sold for Ottinger Brother to a builder for improvement the plot, 100 by 100, at the northeast corner of Morningside Avenue and One Hundred and Twentieth Street. The adjoining plot of the same size, at the southeast coffer of Morningside Avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-first Street, was sold by the same brokers for Ottinger Brother to Michael McCormick a week ago.
What will an undoubted Stradivarius in good order fetch?

This is a very practical little book, and one that anticipates, so far as we can see, every need of the amateur in starting upon the study of insects. There is no reason why it should not stand in the place of a teacher to any intelligent boy or girl, although it is not simplified down to words of one syllable.

An enthusiastic bibliophile entered a humble East-end tobacco shop at the end of last week in order to be directed to a street in the vicinity he wished to find, when he was horrified to perceive the proprietress tearing wrappers from a black-letter book. He snatched the mutilated volume from her, and found that it was the "Goode Huswife's Jewell," published in the reign of Elizabeth.

To be firmly planted to the very shoulders in a sea of soft Hoboken mud was the share of the Misses Mary Coster and Katie Van Dusen in last Thursday night's bad weather. Mary is sixteen years old, and lives at 333 Jefferson Street, Hoboken, while her companion is eighteen years of age and lives at 170 South Street, Jersey City Heights.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., July 30. -- The large dam confining the water of Wilcox's reservoir, located on the Durham road, about two miles from the centre of the city, burst without warning on account of the recent heavy rains at 8 o'clock this morning, and let down tremendous volumes of water, doing damage estimated at $25,000.
At the meeting of the International Library Conference in London, beginning on July 12, Sir John Lubbock presided and delivered the following address:

Secretary of the Treasury Lyman J. Gage reached this city yesterday afternoon on his way to Washington, after a short visit to New England, and went to the Windsor Hotel. He said he has no business to look after here, and will leave for the capital at 11 A.M. to-day.

The Roman correspondent of the New York Freeman's Journal has cabled the following letter from Cardinal Jacobini, proposing a plan to all Roman Catholic Bishops throughout the world for extraordinary religious services in commemoration of the close of the nineteenth and the opening of the twentieth century.

During the month ending last Saturday the deposits in the Clearing House banks of this city increased from $597,094,600 to $622,525,700, or almost $25,000,000. During the year ending last Saturday the increase was from $493,358,200 to the sum above given, or about $129,000,000.
Is it an anthropometric law that the intelligence of the individual is restricted by the size of the skull case? In other words:

J.C. Webster writes from Montreal to The Critic an interesting account of Robert Louis Stevenson's unsuccessful candidacy for the post of Professor of History and Constitutional Law at Edinburgh University, an incident in his life that is little known. Stevenson was then living at Kinnaird Cottage, Pitlochry, Perthshire, where he wrote "Thrawn Janet" and "The Merry Men" and projected a volume of bogie stories in collaboration with his wife.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., July 30. -- Capt. Laurel L. Olmsted, commanding the Sixth Battery, National Guard, has wired Adjt. Gen. Tillinghast protesting against the match between the First and Second Batteries of New York for the Napoleon trophy prize, offered by Lieut. Flanagan of the Second Battery.

CLEVELAND, July 30. -- Prof. Henry W. Elliott of the Smithsonian Institution tonight gave out the complete text of his recent letter to Judge Day, the Assistant Secretary of State, regarding the seal fisheries. It is as follows:

CHICAGO, July 30. -- Eight Chicago men who do not care to encounter the dangers and hardships of the Klondike gold fields have thoroughly equipped three more adventurous men, who will leave for the new Eldorado next week to dig gold for themselves and their backers, all sharing alike. H.O. Wright of Stratford, Canada; R.B. Taylor of Wheaton, Ill., and W.H. Snell, a Chicago bank clerk, are the men who will go to Alaska.

From the time of the earliest collector known the gathering of books has been a personal pleasure to the bibliophile. He may have collected with or without system. He may have been a cool and calculating buyer or a man possessed of a mania. But, whatever spirit swayed him, he enjoyed the indulgence of his passion, and found his greatest gratification in discovering for himself what he added to his library.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 30. -- The Hawaiian Minister of Foreign Affairs, Henry E. Cooper, has given out a synopsis of the correspondence in the Japanese immigrant controversy in deference to the wishes of the supporters of Hawaii, who were at a loss to know why this Government made an offer to arbitrate with Japan.

HOTEL CHAMPLAIN, N.Y., July 30. -- The day has been a delightful one here, the clouds having cleared away and the sun bringing out all the beauty of lake and mountain scenery. The President and Mrs. McKinley have greatly enjoyed the surroundings of their new home and the quiet afforded them by the hotel management.
