The review of the New York and Brooklyn battalions of the Naval Militia at Fort Hamilton yesterday, virtually ending their cruise of a week, was made particularly interesting and pleasant by the enthusiastic praise given to the men by Assistant Secretary of the Navy Roosevelt, and by his broad hint that next year they will probably be put in actual charge of a real first-rate man of war and allowed to work her.

Max Muller in Cosmopolis drifts naturally into "royalties," for the Jubilee period carries him fairly into the swim. He begins by making a nice distinction between royalty, that bedecked personage, hatted with a crown, who habitually wields a sceptre, and the lesser privileged personages. Max Muller has been thrown in with Grand Dukes, Dukes, Princes, Landgraves, Electors, The "" here really seems promiscuous, quite undignified, with no savor of omnipotence about it.
WATERVILLE, Me., July 30. -- Prominent farmers of central and northern counties claim the rains of this season have damaged crops to an extent to be computed in the hundreds of thousands of dollars.

" Ginx's Baby" had once a success, and precisely why, save from the strange title, no one can tell. Mr. Edward Jenkins has written another book, called "Pantalas, and What They Did with Him," and it is published by Bentley. It has to do with human suffering and the inadequate means of relief. Pantalas is a human monstrosity, one-eyed, one-legged, one-armed, and represents the "submerged tenth." The Salvation Army is introduced into the story.

The question has been asked by us: "Did the Greek sculptor of the best period make reins for his horses?" A ready answer to this may be found in a superb article of Walter Paters, entitled "The Beginnings of Greek Sculpture." He wishes to explain how impossible it is for us to-day to appreciate the complete grandeur of Greek art since its surroundings have been changed.

The Springfield American remarks that there is perhaps nothing in our social structure more noteworthy than the vigorous Americanization of the Jews. That the Americanism of the Jews is robustly vigorous is one of the many notable facts in our social structure, but it is not a new development, nor is there anything strange about it.

LONDON, July 30. -- The British Foreign Office notified Ambassador Hay this morning that Great Britain accepted the proposition of the United States for an international conference on the question of pelagic sealing in the Bering Sea, to be held in Washington during the coming Autumn.
LONDON, July 31. -- A dispatch from Malta says that 400 Welsh fusiliers started for Crete this morning.

After more than twenty years of continuous residence in the United States Erastus Wiman has become a citizen. In September, 1877, he declared his intention of becoming a citizen, and yesterday at 9 A.M. he took out his naturalization papers before United States Commissioner Lyman.

The annual regatta of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club, which was sailed yesterday off Greenwich, was full of incidents. The Sirene and Montauk lost their masts, the E.Z. Sloat parted her throat halyards, and the home mark boat dragged her anchors and made serious trouble. The racing was good, and, much to the surprise of all, the half-rater Yola gave the Paprika a bad beating.

SEA CLIFF, N.Y., July 31. -- The special regatta for cabin mainsail yachts, sailed under the auspices of the Sea Cliff Yacht Club this afternoon, was perfect, from a sailor's point of view. A brisk westerly wind got the seven competitors over the line in a body when, at 2:35, the whistle on the Melba, the judges' boat, blew for the start.

A squadron of vessels will rendezvous in the pretty harbor of Glen Cove to-morrow morning which will, in point of numbers, rival that which was anchored off Spithead a few weeks ago on the occasion of the Queen's Jubilee. It will differ from the Jubilee squadron in that, while the vessels in English waters were all warships, those that will assemble to-morrow will all be pleasure craft.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 31. -- James Young, a student at the Batavia School for the Blind at Batavia, N.Y., is visiting his father, Edward Young, in this city. Today while crossing Tulip Street he was saved from death or injury by the action of a tramp dog.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 31. -- Recent New York arrivals here include Mrs. M.E. Spaulding, Miss Marie Spaulding, M.E. Vinton, and Miss Myra Jenkins. Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Moran and Mrs. F.P. Abbott of Brooklyn also arrived this week.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 10. -- The proverbial politeness of the French sinks into an icy chill when compared with the broad and genuine cordiality of the Swedes toward foreigners. The hearty welcome given to their foreign guests is the fact that strikes most forcibly the traveler in Sweden for the first time.

In addition to the usual vows of celibacy taken by the priests of the Roman Catholic Church, the holy fathers belonging to the orders of the Paulists, the Redemptorists, and the Jesuits take a vow of poverty. Each one, upon entering the priesthood, relinquishes absolutely all personal interest in this world's goods.
LONDON, July 31. -- The cricket match between the Gentlemen of Philadelphia and an eleven representing Surrey, which was begun on Thursday, was concluded to-day. Surrey won the match by 154 runs.

BOSTON July 31. -- Why Alice Barrett committed suicide will never be known. A clue came out to-day, however, when some of her letters were found. They were written within the last six months and show that she was dissatisfied with her lot and hungered for riches and a better place in the world.

LONDON, July 31. -- John W. Foster left for New York by the St. Louis from Southampton this morning, having completed his negotiations in regard to the coming conference to consider the sealing question. Ambassador Hay and the members of the United States Embassy were at Waterloo Station to bid him farewell.

People in silver countries well understand the difference between their money and ours. When I was in China and Japan two months ago often a shopkeeper would say, after giving his price, that it was only half as much in gold. My firm imports large quantities of sisal hemp from Yucatan, and buys, with Mexican dollars costing in our money about 47 cents each, at 5 cents per pound.

PITTSBURG, July 31. -- A number of coal operators who congregated at the Monongahela House to-day expressed themselves very forcibly on the strike situation. They were all in favor of the strikers, and said they hoped the miners would win. They were strong in their denunciation of Sheriff Lowrey for issuing the proclamation ordering the strikers at the New York and Cleveland mines to retire to their homes.

There was a surprising disturbance of the public peace and public peace officer in Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon. The primary cause of it was a rat, the propelling cause was an inoffensive citizen named Peter Drapp, the victim was a policeman, and a pair of shears figured incidentally, but prominently.

LONDON, July 17. -- Those dreadful things called the sights of London may be avoided for a time, but sooner or later the visitor has to face them. It is not so much that strangers really want to see the Tower and the picture galleries and St. Paul's and so on, I imagine, as that they want to be able to say that they have seen them.

The fish elect, whose names greet the eye daily and in varying order in the windows of both English and Italian eating houses, are salmon, sole, turbot, brill, whiting, mackerel, whitebait, and eel. Of these the mackerel and whiting are of all our sea fish almost the quickest to decompose, and are therefore, the mackerel more particularly, peculiarly unfitted for consumption in inland centres.

PARIS, July 20. -- The dinner given to the Colonial Premiers by the British Chamber of Commerce has had a certain political importance attributed to it, mainly owing to the plain speaking of Sir Wilfrid Laurier, the Canadian Premier. Sir Wilfrid speaks perfect French, with a strong American accent. He resembles Sardou and also Joseph, that famous chef who was once in the domestic service of Mr. Vanderbilt.

SUPERIOR, Wis., July 24. -- Engine 207 of the Lake Superior Division of the Northern Pacific Railroad is draped in mourning, and the engineer and fireman are wearing narrow bands of black crepe around their hats, out of respect to the memory of one of the most faithful little railroad employes that ever rode a box car or sat in an engine cab.

Unusual interest will attach to the annual banquet of the Chamber of Commerce, which will be held about the middle of next November. In the first place, it will be the opening event of the new Delmonico's, at Fifth Avenue and Forty-fifth Street, and in the next place it will probably be the first important assemblage of public men following the election of a Mayor of Greater New York.

GRAND RAPIDS, Minn., July 31. -- Henry Helms is a prosperous farmer of Itasca County, this State, and lives some four miles south of this thriving village, Mr. Helms has given his attention principally to stock raising, and, among his flocks and herds, which are numerous, prides himself particularly upon his fine breeds of hogs.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 31. -- The first handicap golf tournament of the season on the Kebo Valley Club links occurred this morning, followed by a putting contest over the same course in the afternoon. There was a large number of entries in both competitions, and the play was close and exciting throughout.

We say much in our press of militarism being a heavy burden to Germany. We mean usually that the cost of maintaining half a million men in times of peace is something of a burden to a sandy country with a poor population. True enough; but that cost is cheerily paid even in Germany, for it represents to the unthinking the insurance of their National independence.

Policeman Thomas H. Devine of the East One Hundred and Fourth Street Station, shortly after 11 o'clock last night, shot and instantly killed Cornelius O'Keefe, twenty-seven years of age, of 227 East One Hundred and First Street. The officer acted in self-defense.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- Expert Samuel C. Dunham of the Federal Bureau of Labor left here to-day for the gold belt of Alaska where he will make an investigation and report in time for the projected Spring migrations.

" Ring your bell," called the bicycle man to the girl on the wheel to whom he was giving a road lesson. "Oh, I don't dare let go the handle bar enough," she cried in terror. "Ring your bell, or you'll run over him," he called again, riding up as fast as possible: "Oh -- I -- don't -- dare -- " she begun, and then she ran over the dog.

From the cozy corners of the big clubhouses, as well as from a thousand and one private homes, for the past week and a half has risen a storm of grumbles -- basso profundo grumbles and others pitched in the shrillest feminine notes, keen disappointment, expressed in all keys and variety of intensity.

Scrambling through a creek choked with bulrushes many times higher than our heads, we climbed up the clay bank and attempted to push through the dense undergrowth in the direction of the turmoil. More easily said than done!

HE New York City Room in the Woman's Building at the Tennessee Centennial Exposition is admittedly the most attractive room there. It is notable for its consistency in color scheme and its practical lesson to interior decorators, to workers in carved wood, and to artists -- particularly to those who work in underglaze.

Another fine day brought out a good crowd at Parkville yesterday afternoon. It was the last of the three days' meeting of the Parkway Driving Club. In the judges' stand were A. Benson, L.A. Burke, Secretary of the Driving Club of New York, and Christopher Fitzgerald. John F. Cornell acted as starter, and managed admirably the large fields in both races.

ON Sunday, July 11, Salomon August Andree and his two companions, Nils Strindberg and Knut Hjalmar Ferdinand Frakel, set out on their remarkable balloon journey from Amsterdam Island, of the Spitzbergen group, in quest of the theoretical site of the north pole.

The king of Australian fishes is undoubtedly the schnapper. We speak not now of the trumpeter of Tasmania nor of the blue cod of New Zealand, about which the inhabitants of these colonies are not unnaturally proud. Judging by his shape, the schnapper is an ugly fish. His color is good, but his proportions are not fair, as he lies on the slab of the fishmonger.

In India, at Nowgong, Capt. Jay Gould saved a soldier of the Fifth Cavalry Regiment who bad been bitten by a krait, (Bungarus caeruleus,) which was killed on the spot. The Captain at once made a ligature to prevent the poison from spreading, and rode full speed to obtain the serum. The injection was made, and the soldier was saved.

The steamship St. Paul arrived here yesterday morning after a trip of six days eleven hours and fourteen minutes, with 388 cabin and 205 steerage passengers on board. She was delayed the night previous just outside the bar, and did not reach her dock until after 8 o'clock yesterday morning. She started from Liverpool about the same time as the Lucania, but lost some four hours during her first day out.

The resident membership of the Merchants' Association of New York has increased to a greater extent in the past week than during any previous week of its existence. Interest in the purpose and work of the association is now more widely diffused than ever before, and the local business men are beginning to comprehend the advantages of union and concentrated effort.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- Nothing can be done more than already has been done toward marking the boundary line between Alaska and the British possessions along the one hundred and forty-first meridian until the Senate passes upon the boundary treaty now before it.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- Secretary Wilson of the Department of Agriculture will spend his vacation, which he will take in August, in traveling through Colorado, Utah, Wyoming, the Dakotas, and Montana, with the object of studying the resources of these States for rearing horses suitable for the European armies.

ALBANY, July 31. -- Lieut. Gov. Timothy L. Woodruff was in Albany this morning on his way to the Adirondacks, to make a personal examination of some large tracts of land which have been offered for sale, and concerning which the Forest Preserve Board will probably take definite action at a meeting to be held in Albany on the 5th and 6th of August.

There was an old lady who had bought a parrot and came back to a bird shop to complain of her purchase. "That parrot I bought from you yesterday," she complains, "uses dreadful language." To which the dealer replies sympathizingly, "Ah, mum, you should be very careful what you says afore it; it's astonishing how quick them birds pick up anything."

PROBABLY the worst thing that can be said about "The French Mald" to prejudice American playgoers against it is that it was put together and composed by Basil Hood and Walter Slaughter, the same persons who made "Gentleman Joe," a British musical farce, that was injured by transplanting and soon perished on American soil.

THROUGH byways more or less intricate and uncertain (after the fashion of Paris streets) may be reached the Rue de Sevres, No. 44, where Frederick MacMonnies has established his studio. It is a little, low house, sitting back in a courtyard, unmistakably French, with its diamond-paned casements and stucco walls, and undeniably picturesque, tangled vines running riot all over it, and drooping in long, waving tendrils over doorway and windows.

In every branch of business except one where merchandise of any kind is sold custom has fixed a uniform price which competition restricts to a reasonable profit. That one exception is the retail drug trade. Custom has never fixed any uniform price in that trade nor has competition been able to restrict to a fair or reasonable profit.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- With the departure of the President for Lake Champlain the White House flag has disappeared, and the crowd of office seekers that has thronged the upper corridor so densely and so constantly that the floor is reported to have sagged four inches from the true level, has gone somewhere, leaving the White House in the care of the engineer officer whose duty it is to keep the building in repair.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- The comparison of the present tariff law with the Wilson act, authorized by Congress, has been completed. It was made by Charles H. Evans, who has been engaged in some capacity in the preparation of all the Tariff bills with which Congress has dealt since 1872. The comparison is made in rates expressed in ad valorem terms between the present law and the Wilson law.

According to Chaucer, the more well-to-do of the working classes evidently spent a vast deal of time at the public house, eating and drinking, telling idle tales, playing at skittles when the weather was fine, singing rhymes of "Robin Hood," or listening to fiddlers and pipers, or to gleemen and janglers of jests -- that is to say, ballad singers and professional story tellers.

You have seen by the papers that I have determined to go home by India, China, and Japan. This will not probably delay my return, but it will land me in San Francisco about the time I expected to reach Philadelphia -- say the last of June. If we get to San Francisco as early as that or nearly so, I shall want to remain on the Pacific coast six weeks or two months.

YONKERS, N.Y., July 31. -- A lawn tennis tournament was played this afternoon on the courts of the Yonkers Lawn Tennis Club, the contestants being the Yonkers Lawn Tennis Club against the Sleepy Hollow Tennis Club of Tarrytown for a silver cup valued at $50.

A team of horses attached to a big truck belonging to a Brooklyn dry goods firm ran away in that city yesterday morning and did considerable damage on Fulton Street, and also narrowly missed killing or injuring several persons. The most serious damage was the breaking of a big plate glass in Milkman's millinery store at Bridge and Fulton Streets.

JOPLIN, Mo., July 31. -- A rich lead mine has been struck in Main Street, within a few blocks of the business centre of the town. H.D. Graves and Sam Vaughan, two miners who found it, took out at the depth of seven feet over a ton of ore. Machinery will be put in and the mine will soon be in operation right in the heart of the city.

In the life of a modern business community a man must beware of too much wisdom. The specialist is the man who succeeds, and having once set his hand to an occupation one dare never leave it, under penalty of failure in what he has chosen as his lifework. In the West all this was different. Versatility was a necessity.
LONDON, July 31. -- At the Rochdale events to-day, in the 600-yard dash E.C. Bredin defeated Charles E. Kilpatrick by four yards, the time being 1:12 3-5.

It will be remembered that Min-Yong-Hwan, the Corean Ambassador, on his way to the Czar's coronation, passed through this city, in May, 1896, staying for three days at the Hotel Warwick, on Broadway. His presence was noted by the New York newspapers, and the fact that he and his fellow envoys devoured, during their sojourn, nearly $20 worth of ice cream was variously commented on in easy humor.

Col. George Moore Smith of the Sixty-ninth Regiment will be sworn in to-morrow as Police Commissioner, succeeding Col. Frederick D. Grant, who retired from office yesterday. The appointment was announced by the Mayor at 10:30 o'clock yesterday. Col. Smith is at the head of the regiment in which the Mayor's son, P. Bradley Strong, is Adjutant, and is one of the young man's closest friends.

Now that about all the good Federal appointments pertaining are made or promised, and most of the self-assumed prominent original McKinley men are placated in fat places, it will not be obtruding to say a word on the subject of "Brass Assumption and Cheek in Our Politics," which I would like to have you place as the heading of this letter.

BAR HARBOR, July 31. -- The Ladies' Club, which was organized last week, formally opened its doors with a large and brilliant reception Tuesday afternoon. The clubhouse presented a handsome appearance. The tearoom was especially attractive, with its dainty cups and saucers and table decorated with a profusion of choice flowers.
It is said that the inhabitants of the Hawaiian group are enthusiastic lovers of cycle racing, and that a third-mile track to be built at Honolulu.

WASHINGTON, July 24. -- The fifth volume of the first series of the "Official Records of the Union and Confederate Navies in the War of the Rebellion" will soon be issued, the Government printing office having the work so well in hand that advance copies are in possession of the new Superintendent of Naval War Records, Prof. E.K. Rawson, United States Navy, who has succeeded Lieut. Commander Richard Rush in that work.

In addition to the fact that August is noted for its dog days, it also vies with November in the prominence of its meteoric showers, as the very beautiful phenomena that we sometimes call shooting stars are called. Each of these shooting stars was a small body, perhaps as large as a paving stone or larger, more often, perhaps, not as large as a marble, moving around the sun.

BOSTON, July 31. -- The Longwood tennis tournament rounded out this afternoon with two of the finest matches seen in the East this Summer, which resulted in a defeat of the champion, R.D. Wrenn, by William H. Larned in five exciting sets, while at the same time Mahony and Nisbet, the two British players, won the Eastern championship in doubles by defeating G.L. Wrenn and Whitman in an equally brilliant five-set match.

LONDON, July 31. -- A Spanish diplomatist who is in close touch with Senor Canovas del Castillo, the Spanish Premier, informs a correspondent that it is useless longer to attempt to disguise the fact that the Spanish Ministry is in a very tight place. He says:

SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y., July 31. -- The Shinnecock Hills Golf Club tournament just ended will go down in the annals of golf as one of the most remarkable on record, the meteoric burst of Foxhall Keene beingthe chief features. Mr. Keene by his play took the golf seacres by surprise and narrowly missed walking-of with one of the finest cups offer this year.

COLORADO SPRINGS, July 24. -- The practice of sending consumptives to the West has been steadily increasing, but unfortunately the results have been largely disappointing. One reason, perhaps, is ignorance on the part of both physician and patient as to the various climatic conditions to be found in that large section of the country known as "the West."

To the cyclers of the entire country, all roads lead to Philadelphia this week. The National League of American Wheelmen meet on the Willow Grove track will be attended by delegations from the East, the South, and even some of the Western States, and the Quaker City will be filled with-cycling and cyclers for a week and a day,

THE historic New York church which is known technically as St. Paul's Chapel (instead of church) is often visited by those who study the past and cherish its monuments. Architecturally, St. Paul's has been admired in every generation, and admired most by those who know a good piece of design when they see it.

KINGSTON, July 31. -- The mystery in the case of Thomas Telford of this city, who suddenly disappeared in London July 8, while on his way to secure a legacy which he claimed had been left him by the death of an aunt in Scotland, is partly cleared up by the receipt of a letter written to De Witt Brothers, insurance agents of this city.

The number of professional dyers in India is fast diminishing. Aniline dyes and cheap European goods are killing their trade. They are being compelled to turn their attention to new handicrafts, just as French competition and the vagaries of fashion caused, the ribbon-makers of Coventry to seek a new livelihood in the manufacture of bicycles. Aniline dyes have made every man his own dyer.

Even WILLIAM SHAKESPEARE made mistakes. His sombre comedy called "Measure for Measure," for instance, keeps that fact alive. In excellence of workmanship and in the charm and eloquence of its language it is beyond the reach of any other dramatic poet. Its characters are as true to human nature as it was the poet's wont to make them in all his plays, and its exalted aim is not to be questioned.

MONTREAL, July 31. -- The excitement over the discoveries of gold on the Yukon continues unabated, but the actual exodus of fortune hunters east of the Rock Mountains has been very slight. The published warnings of those who have been there, and the caution urged by the Interior Department at Ottawa, have had their effect, and most persons have decided to wait till next Spring before setting out for the North.

A baseball game is never lost until the last man is retired in the ninth inning, no matter how great the opposing team's lead may be. This was demonstrated at Eastern Park yesterday afternoon before a crowd of more than 12,000 enthusiasts, when the New Yorks won the game from the Brooklyns at the eleventh hour.

NEWPORT, July 31. -- Newport is to see no dog show this year. Dr. Huidekoper, who was advocating the show has decided that it is too late in the season to get the affair up properly, and has therefore abandoned it until another year.

Mayor STRONG has been very fortunate in his selection of a successor to Col. GRANT, Col. GEORGE MOORE SMITH fulfills the condition that the appointee shall be a Republican. He may justly be described as a partisan Republican, having an intense conviction of the impeccable and invincible excellence of that party and of its principles and policies. But he is also a man of the highest personal character and a sound standard of public duty.

Capt. William J. Maidhof of Company B. Twenty-second Regiment, an officer familiar in National Guard circles during twenty-six years of continuous service, has been placed upon the retired list of National Guard officers of New York, to date from July 7 last, at his own request.

One of the most recent festivities given in New York was an ice cream party. The affair was given in one of the private rooms of an establishment which is comparatively little known in the city, and which is of a kind that it has always been said New York did not possess and for which many unsuccessful plans have been laid.
LENOX, July 31. -- Mrs. Frank K. Sturgis has for guests this week Miss Coster and Mrs. Flint of New York. They are driving through the country after Mrs. Sturgis's beautiful strawberry roans.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- The misunderstanding and contentions regarding the laws that are applicable to Alaska, so far as lands and claims are concerned, were set at rest to-day by a statement made by Commissioner Hermann of the General Land Office. Many inquiries on this question have come to the Interior Department, and numerous applications have been made for copies of the public land laws, which, however, do not apply to Alaska.
It was a favorite and oft-iterated remark in the long rainy spell of July, which now, as Mr. KIPLING aptly remarked of the Queen's Jubilee the day after the show,

GLASGOW, July 21. -- The arrival of the Emperor of Germany's cutter Meteor has been a relief to the sad prophets who were lamenting over the decadence of yacht racing which they cannot associate with any yacht under a hundred tons.

With the revival of business, and particularly with the return of prosperity to agriculture now certain, we shall see a gradual extension of the business of loans on bonds and mortgages. This, indeed, may at any time become rapid, for there is no form of property, contrary to the general notion, in which speculation is apt to be more tempting.

THIS book has been a surprise to the many people who have known its author as a prominent politician and that political rarity, a Virginia Republican, as well as a successful lawyer and an entertaining after-dinner speaker.

The cynosure of all eyes at the American Line pier when the St. Paul had landed her passengers was a healthy-looking, ruddy-cheeked modest youth, who stood among a crowd of men and women, fairly blushing under their fond, admiring gaze. He was Edward H. Ten Eyck, champion amateur oarsman of the world and winner of the Diamond Sculls at the Henley Regatta.

The market has reached a stage in its forward movement where differences of opinion develop among operators who heretofore have all been united on the bull side. This was clearly evidenced by its irregular movement in the early part of the week, when Sugar broke sharply and for a time threatened the general list with a pronounced set-back.

VIENNA, July 1. -- I have covered a very large territory since I wrote you last from Berlin, the German capital. I went from there to Stettin, the largest German port on the Baltic, where shipbuilding, with the careful assistance of the German Government, is brought to such perfection that the Germans are fast becoming large competitors of the famous English works on the Clyde.

ON a picturesque woodland ridge, a few miles beyond the historic town of White Plains, N.Y., stands one of the most beautiful as well as one of the most notable houses in the country. It is a house with a most interesting history, the home of Mr. Whitelaw Reid, ex-Minister from the United States to France and editor of The New York Tribune.

WHEELING, West Va., July 31. -- The first act of violence in this vicinity since the mining strike was inaugurated was committed at 3 o'clock this morning, when a small bridge on the Wheeling and Lake Erie Road, between the mining settlements of Dillonvale and Long Run, was fired. Employes of the company saw the blaze and extinguished it, but not until the structure had been half destroyed.
AMESBURY, Mass., July 31. -- The cotton mills of the Hamilton corporation here shut down to-night for one week.

THOUSAND ISLANDS, CLAYTON, N.Y., July 30. -- The international park at the Thousand Islands bids fair to become an accomplished fact next week, when the States Commission on Forestry, Game, and Fisheries meets, Wednesday, with the St. Lawrence Anglers' Association to make the final selection of the points and islands to be purchased with the $30,000 recently appropriated by the State for that purpose.

An Alaskan midsummer day is a day without night. In the extreme northern portion of the territory the sun does not set for weeks, and even as far south as Sitka and Fort Wrangel it sinks only a few degrees below the horizon, so that the rosy colors of the evening blend with those of the morning, leaving no gap of darkness between. Nevertheless, the full day opens slowly.

POUGHKEEPSIE, July 31. -- Howell C. Rees was discharged from the Hudson River State Hospital at noon to-day. Justice Barnard signed the order for his discharge on the agreement of all parties interested.

MADRID, July 31. -- A hundred, Cuban prisoners, who were recently pardoned, have arrived at Gibraltar, whence they will proceed to New York. The Government organs express the opinion that they will rejoin the insurgents.

Since 1861 the Queen has governed less than she did before. She has done better in just being a guiding influence in home affairs and a standard of international morality to her Ministers. Nevertheless, she has attended industriously to routine business. In the course of a visit to the chalet she staid at near Lucerne I was taken to a spacious rustic kiosk.

SARATOGA, N.Y., July 31. -- A composite picture of the Saratoga woman would be a failure. There is no doubt that if a representative photograph of the kind were taken it would be very composite. That would be the trouble with it; it would be all composite and no photograph.

A counter piled high with tumbled dress goods showed that a customer had been there. The flushed face and disgusted expression of the young saleswoman showed that the customer had bought nothing. "Plague take the sympathetic cranks, anyhow," muttered the tired girl, as she set about restoring the rolls of goods to their proper form and place.

ALBANY, July 31. -- The Albany Gold Mining and Prospecting Company was formally organized here Thursday. It will apply for incorporation papers, being capitalized at $3,000. Its purpose is to send a representative to the Klondike region to stake off a syndicate claim. The representative is to receive one-quarter of the profits and will be bonded heavily.

Nothing is more notable or more significant touching the return of confidence to the financial world than the fact that they who share most in this confidence, they who largely have led in its establishment, are men of more than ordinary business consequence.

The French Line steamship La Champagne, which left Havre July 24, arrived at her pier yesterday morning. The vessel brought 87 cabin and 203 steerage passengers. The former were confronted on the way up from Quarantine by a detachment of Customs Inspectors, who entered into a lengthy explanation of the requirements of the new Dingley tariff law regarding the taxing of effects of persons arriving from foreign countries.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- Owing to a variety of causes, the recent order in regard to the tariff of fees to be charged by consular officers of the United States seems to have been misunderstood. The new tariff does not take effect until Oct. 1. Like the tariff made out by the former Administration the new one provides that all fees must be paid in gold or its equivalent.

WESTFIELD, Mass., Aug. 1. -- Hiram C. Burlingame, aged ninety-six, was shot and probably mortally wounded at noon to-day at his hut on Hampton Plains, about three miles north of Westfield Centre, by Edward Fitz, aged twenty. Three shots were fired, two taking effect, one in the old man's breast, and the other in his abdomen.
It was an ideal day for rowing and Harlem River oarsmen made good use of it and were in the water early and late yesterday, in both pleasure and racing craft.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 1 -- Thomas Cushing, a molder, aged thirty-three years this afternoon stood before the mirror in his boarding house and cut his throat with a razor. When taken to the operating room on the third floor of a hospital, he made a rush for a window and threw himself out, falling fifty feet to the roof of the engine room.

Three weeks of the great midsummer tournament for the sulkies proves conclusively that the speed of the harness racers continues to increase with every season. The flights that were possible prior to 1892, when the bicycle wheel was first employed, are now so completely eclipsed that the old-time feats are quite forgotten.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 1. -- Vice President Hobart and Mrs. Hobart were the guests of honor at the luncheon given by Chauncey M. Depew at his cottage, Pinard, 4 Narragansett Avenue, this afternoon.
RAHWAY, Aug. 1. -- Charles Schilling, Captain of the Star Cycle Club of this city, was killed last night while riding his wheel on St. George's Avenue.
SIMLA, Aug. 1. -- Dispatches to the Government show that reinforcements with abundant supplies of ammunition arrived at Dargai at noon to-day.
The Anarchists who belong to the autonomist group, of which Emma Goldman was the chief, and which always reviled trades unions, are now making advances to these organizations.

Nearly fifty years ago Harvey Hevner and his wife Sarah were married. He was then twenty-one years old, and she a few years younger. Yesterday he died by his own band, rather than live longer without sight and hearing.

No conference on State or city politics was held yesterday at the Oriental Hotel, Manhattan Beach. There was not even a remnant there of the "Sunday school class" which Senator Platt's friends have made famous throughout the Empire State. The Senator, Chairman Quigg of the Republican County Committee, and Collector Bidwell, who are guests at the hotel, enjoyed the ocean breezes with slight interruption by political callers.

BERNARDSVILLE, N.J., Aug. 1. -- The extensive stables on the Round Top Stock Farm at Bernardsville were destroyed by fire this morning and a large quantity of hay and grain was destroyed. There were about 100 horses in the stables, many of them valuable brood mares, when the fire broke out, but they were at some distance from the flames, and were all gotten out in safety.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- In the late number of the Congressional Record containing speeches on the tariff conference report is a speech by M.N. Johnson of North Dakota in which he makes a compilation of the protests received by the State Department from representatives of foreign Governments against certain duties imposed in the Dingley Tariff bill while that measure was pending.

There is instruction to be had from a comparison of the conduct of the President of the United States and that of the Governor of the State of New York with regard to the principle of civil service reform.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1. -- The eighteenth National meet of the League of American Wheelmen, for which preparations have been going on for over three months, will be held in this city during the coming week, and the largest influx of out-of-town wheelmen ever attending a National meet is expected.

As the blood of the martyrs is the seed of the Church, so the fatalities of aerial navigation seem to stimulate further ventures with balloons and flying machines. ANDREE'S fate, if, as is now supposed, he has met his death in the attempt to reach the pole, will probably not deter some other daring aeronaut from attempting the same feat. Success will be challenged by avoiding his mistakes.
LONDON, Aug. 2. -- The denunciation by Great Britain of the commercial treaties with Belgium and Germany is the chief theme of discussion in the European newspapers.

Mrs. J. Frazer, sixty years of age, of 118 Duffield Street, Brooklyn, is in St. Mary's Hospital, in that city, suffering from a severe scalp wound and concussion of the brain. The physicians do not think that she can recover.

Some of our bimetallic friends now announce that the business men of Mexico are very much pleased with the recent slump in the price of sliver, because they foresee that it will discourage importations and tend to foster native industries. Under the benign influence of steadily declining value in their currency they look forward to a career of development like that of the United States.

Mr. Wirt H. Fuller, one of Boston's veteran financiers, and a member of the newly formed New York Stock Exchange firm of Fuller, Blair Co., talked on Saturday to a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES regarding stock market conditions and prospects. Mr. Fuller looks for some slight recessions from the present price level, but he believes in ultimately higher prices, and a long period of speculative activity. Mr. Fuller said:
Probably 5,000 men and boys returned to New York last night from North Beach without a cent in their pockets other than the amount necessary to pay their passages on the cars and ferryboats.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Aug. 1. -- William A. Bellwood, who was arrested in New York on July 17 for swindling a jewelry firm in that city and who, on Saturday admitted his identity as Guillaume Balensi, the Paris banker, who fled from France after the Lebaudy scandal had been aired, conducted a curio establishment on Walnut Street, in this city.

TACOMA, Washington Aug. 1. -- Capitalists of this city and Port Townsend have organized an expedition to explore rich gold and copper fields known to exist along Copper River, in Western Alaska, 800 miles northwest of Sitka. For many years gold, copper, and furs have been brought out of that region by Copper River Indians, and exchanged with traders for firearms and food.
I read in your issue of July 29 an article which, under the heading "Against Vivisection," stated that no good had come from vivisectional experiments, and that none could reasonably be expected.

HOTEL CHAMPLAIN, N.Y., Aug. 1. -- The weather was sufficiently pleasant to-day to enable the President to attend church in Plattsburg. A large crowd of persons filled the Methodist Episcopal Church in that village.

A group of business men active in the dry goods district stood in the headquarters of the Merchants' Association in the New York Life Building at noon on Saturday discussing the situation. "Things are beginning to look better," said one, conservatively. "Yes, the work of this association has knocked out midsummer dullness," remarked another.

Mrs. Kate O'Reilly has no more money than she needs; she has none to burn, so when her little nephew, Tommy, threw her pocketbook into the kitchen stove, and gleefully watched it in flames, Mrs. O'Reilly was sorrowful, and when Tommy left her embrace he felt as though a hundred-odd hornets had stung him. The incident occurred on July 24.

Charities Commissioner Burtis of Brooklyn is very much exercised over the condition of Harry Heath, a prisoner at the Kings County Penitentiary. Heath is believed by the Commissioner and Warden Hayes to be on the verge of insanity, as a result of close confinement and no work. About five weeks ago he was arrested for sleeping in a coal hole, and was sent up for two months on a charge of vagrancy.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 1. -- The new church building of the parish of the Blessed Sacrament of which, the Rev. Thomas McLaughlin is rector, was dedicated to-day. The Right Rev. Bishop Farley of New York officiated. Twenty-six priests occupied places within the altar inclosure.

Joseph Mason, a fifteen-year-old boy who works for a printer in Twenty-third Street, amused himself for a part of yesterday afternoon breaking bottles on the asphalt pavement of West Twenty-sixth Street, to the great annoyance of passing bicyclists, whose tires were punctured by the wholesale when they struck the broken glass.
Trolley car No. 64 of the North Hudson Railway jumped the track while going down the hill at West New York last night and ran on the sidewalk for some 200 feet before it could be stopped.

Several thousand people witnessed the tragic death of Prof. Arion, who has been giving nightly performances on a slack wire in Ridgewood Park, in Queens County. He was in the act of performing one of his marvelous feats, that of riding a bicycle on a wire which was charged with electricity furnished by the Brooklyn Heights Railroad Company, under whose auspices it was said the performances were given.

You have at all times stood up manfully for the City of New York; you have defended her against egotists, spoilsmen, and defamers; you have sharply censured those who marred her beauty through ignorance or rapacity, and you have invariably supported every enterprise which aimed to raise her to a higher rank among the cities of every land.

The Rev. E.E. Franke of the Seventh Day Adventist denomination has been for five weeks conducting a series of meetings in a tent at Saratoga Avenue and Macon Street, Brooklyn, and yesterday he publicly immersed twenty-seven of his converts at the foot of Fifty-fifth Street, South Brooklyn. He says many more are ready for the ceremony, but for various reasons failed to appear.

The orders issued by the Pants Makers' Union on Saturday evening for a general strike in contractors' shops were carried out yesterday. A strike committee of thirteen was appointed, with Moritz Rudwick as Chairman, and these called at the shops early in the morning and ordered out the men who had gone to work and had not attended Saturday's meeting.

For a good many years, whenever any complaint was made of any sluttish practice that was allowed to go on in New York, the ready answer on the part of those who committed the offense or profited by it has been that "New York was a business city." Therefore any atrocity that might happen to be an incident of anybody's business was to be tolerated.

A rather curious mishap befell the Al Foster excursion steamer last evening, and considerably excited the women among her passengers, besides blocking all traffic to and from the Greenpoint ferry at Twenty-third Street for nearly an hour.
LONDON, Aug. 1. -- The money market shows no changes and the prevailing cheapness of loans continues. There is not likely to be much rise in discount rates.

Admiral Sicard's squadron of war vessels, consisting of the armored cruisers New York and Brooklyn and the battleships Massachusetts, Indiana and Maine, will sail at 9 o'clock this morning from the anchorage off Tompkinsville, S.I., for Newport, and is expected to arrive there to-morrow morning, where the new battleship Iowa awaits them.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 1. -- All roads led to Turtle Creek to-day. Marching miners from all over the district were converging toward Camp Determination, and if all those reported as being on the march reach the scene before morning, there will be at least 6,000 diggers present at the big meeting scheduled for 11 o'clock, at McCrea's School House. The miners expect 8,000 to be on hand.

In talking of the stability and permanency of the present upward movement in the stock market, ex-president William L. Bull of the New York Stock Exchange said to a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday:

CLEVELAND, Aug. 2. -- All departments of the Cleveland Rolling Mills opened today. About 2,000 men were given work. Several departments, which shut down at the beginning of the coal strike, resumed operations.

-- Diplomats carry their determination to be unlike other people to the point of having a language as well as morals for their own exclusive use. Every once in a while a word or a phrase of this language flutters down from the diplomatic heights into the world of real life, and then it is always examined curiously by folks whose habit it is to say more or less nearly what they mean.
President Andrew Freedman of the New York Baseball Club will sail for Europe this morning. He will return before the close of the baseball season.

The appearance yesterday of that part of Broadway between Thirty-eighth and Forty-second Streets, known as the chief theatrical centre of the city, was much more lively than it has been for many years. Notwithstanding the general bad business of last year, more bookings are made and more traveling companies organized than in any like period within the past five years. Indications point to the return in many cities to the stock-company system.
PITTSBURG, Aug. 2. -- The striking miners have broken all records, both as to numbers attending their mass meetings and the excellent order and law-abiding behavior they have exhibited.

Chairman Charles W. Hackett of the Republican State Committee, came to the city yesterday to consult with Senator Platt about various matters, and specially about the date for the holding of the State Committee meeting, at which a candidate or Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals, the only State officer to be elected this year, will be nominated.

BOMBAY, Aug. 2. -- Fort Chakdara, in the Chitral district, which was besieged by a large force of insurgent natives, has been relieved by the British force under Gen. Blood. The relief forces advanced in two columns, commanded respectively by Cols. Goldney and Meiklejohn, at dawn to-day and brilliantly attacked and routed the enemy surrounding the fort.

Theodore Lockwood, twelve years old, of 155 Van Wrinkle Street, Jersey City, is likely to lose his right arm as the result of a foolhardy act to secure a plate of ice cream. He and George Tier and Thomas Madden, two lads of the same age, were playing yesterday in the rear of Simon Wolf's confectionery, at 7 James Avenue.

Word was received by the Merchants' Association yesterday that the Old Dominion Steamship Company had determined to place on sale tickets between Southern points on its line and New York at reduced rates, regardless of the refusal of the Southern Traffic Associations to co-operate with the New York merchants.

HOTEL CHAMPLAIN, N.Y., Aug. 2. -- The review of the Twenty-first United States Infantry, under the command of Col. McKibben, held on the hotel grounds, and the reception of the guests of the hotel were the chief events of the day for President McKinley and party. The day was clear and dry, but the sun was none too warm for the President and his fellow-guests.

Commodore J. Pierpont Morgan, on the steamer Corsair, arrived in Glen Cove on Sunday evening, and was ready for the yachts of the New York Yacht Club as they reached the rendezvous yesterday morning preparatory to starting on the annual cruise of the club to the eastward. The yachts began to arrive soon after dawn, and after colors were made at 8 o'clock guns boomed every few minutes.
POUGHKEEPSIE, Aug. 2. -- The Coroner's jury returned a verdict to-day in the case of Selma Larsen, the pretty parlormaid of Mrs. Clarence Dinsmore of Staatsburg.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2. -- Wheelmen by the hundreds are invading the city by nearly every train for the National meet of the League of American Wheelmen, which will be opened formally on Wednesday. All of to-day's arrivals were from near-by points. The clubs and delegations from a distance are not expected until to-morrow night and Wednesday morning, when the reduced rail road fares will be in effect.

SARATOGA, Aug. 2. -- The crowd of turfmen here was augmented to-day by the arrival of several hundred who had waited in New York until the close of the Aqueduct meeting last Saturday before starting for the Spa. Their arrival was welcomed by those already here, especially by the "layers," for among the arrivals were some big bettors.

If the Brooklyns expect to part company with the tail-enders in the league race they will have to brace up and play better ball than they did at Eastern Park against the New Yorks yesterday afternoon. They practically handed over a victory to the Giants. The home team took a lead at the start, but poor fielding placed the Giants ahead in the third inning.

The simultaneous reports of the conflict between Portuguese and natives in East Africa seem curiously contradictory. A dispatch from Lisbon sets forth that a small force of Portuguese has routed 7,000 rebels in Gazaland. A dispatch from Cape Town sets forth, on the authority of the natives, that a Portuguese force has been annihilated in the Bileni district, north of Delagoa Bay.

I had quite abandoned the hope of ever again appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES as an opponent of vivisection, but as you published, on the 29th ult., an article from the pen of the Vice President of the New England Anti-Vivisection Society I think it may be possible that you will give space to some comments (on your editorial referring to this article) from the Anti-Vivisection Society in your own State.

Col. George Moore Smith, the new Police Commissioner, took the oath of office yesterday and entered at once upon the performance of his duties. He arrived at the Mayor's office from Sayville, L.I., about 10:30 o'clock.

Whether the death of Mrs. Augusta Mahler of 304 West Forty-second Street shall be called suicide or murder is a question to be decided by the Coroner. The woman was killed by a bullet early yesterday morning in the third-floor flat at the number given, where she lived with her husband, August Mahler.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 2. -- The last of the wage differences in the Birmingham district was settled this morning, when the Blue Creek miners of the Tennessee Coal, Iron and Railway contracted with the company for a year to dig coal for 28 cents a ton. The miners had contended for 30 cents and the company for 27 cents.
" I am glad that the press has started this investigation, and I make no pretense of showing ignorance that gambling devices have been in operation in this vicinity.
Frederick D. Underwood, General Manager of the Minneapolis, St. Paul and Sault Ste. Marie Railway, may be chosen as President of the Northern Pacific Railway Company, to succeed Edwin W. Winter.

The first protest received by the Board of United States General Appraisers against the operation of the new tariff law comes from Memphis, Tenn., which is officially known as an "immediate transportation" port of entry. The protest is filed by Morriss Brothers of Memphis, and it relates to the importation of a single piece of marble statuary from Carrara.
The pulpit yields to the demand for modern improvements. It is permitted even to have its silly season, like the newspapers, and like humanity in general.

VIENNA, Aug. 2. -- Reports from the flooded districts show that the situation is even worse than was at first feared. The greatest damage has been done in Bohemia. At Trautenau thirty houses have been destroyed and twenty-five persons drowned. Corpses were to be seen flooding down the streets with every kind of debris, even a cradle with a crying infant, which, fortunately, was rescued.

The will of Mrs. Frances U. Lorillard, wife of Jacob Lorillard and sister-in-law of Pierre Lorillard, the rich tobacconist, has been filed for probate with the Surrogate of Hudson County. She died in August last. Her will, executed on July2, 1896, contains this clause: "Whereas my son Jacob has disgraced me, I totally disinherit him from any part of my estate."

LONDON, Aug. 2. -- The Marquis of Salisbury, replying in the House of Lords to-day to the Liberal leader, the Earl of Kimberley, who questioned the Government as to the state of the peace negotiations between Greece and Turkey, outlined the status of the Constantinople exchanges of views, occasionally referring to them in sarcastic tones.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Aug. 2. -- George Draper of Salt Point is the hero of an exciting adventure that occurred yesterday, in which he and his wife and fifteen-year-old daughter Pearl were the participants. A stream flows near the Draper mansion, which the recent heavy rains have swollen into a rushing torrent.

The Central Labor Union of this city a Sunday or two ago adopted a resolution denouncing the nomination of POWDERLY to a Federal office as "an insult to organized labor." As a matter of fact, POWDERLY was the most conspicuous representative that organized labor has ever had in this country, and by far more powerful than any one of his successors.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- The Navy Department has received a report from Admiral Beardslee, commanding the Pacific station, dated Honolulu, July 17. He says the Japanese warship in the harbor scrupulously observed not only the Fourth of July, but the Hawaiian Independence Day as well.
" People like to be humbugged;" an expression attributed to P.T. Barnum, was used by him probably out of a sense of humor, for the people spent their money to be humored and they were humored.

Papers demanding the extradition to France of Guillaume Balensi, alias William A. Bellwood, who is confined in the Tombs awaiting trial for swindling Marcus Co. out of $25,000 worth of jewelry, are being prepared by Joseph Kling of the law firm of Coudert Brothers on behalf of the French Consulate.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 2. -- The tax levy is complete. It was thrown open for inspection to-day. Justice Martin J. Keogh lives here, and it was he who called the attention of the Grand Jury to the lax methods of assessors throughout the county and caused a reformation.

A monster parade, confined to members of the New York State Division of the League of American Wheelmen as a substitute for the next semi-annual race meet has been suggested to the Consuls of the State Division and is under consideration. The idea has found favor with a number of local members, who say the Consuls do not regard it as altogether visionary.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 2. -- Twenty-four of the thirty-seven professors and assistant professors have signed an open letter to the corporation of Brown University protesting against the action of that body relative to the case of President Andrews. The letter says

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- The monthly statement of the public debt issued to-day shows that the debt, less cash in the Treasury, at the close of business on July 31 was $993,446,646, an increase during the month of $6,790,560, which is accounted for by a corresponding decrease in the cash in the Treasury.

One of the most remarkable facts in connection with the new navy is Uncle Sam's neglect to provide money in small-arm practice by the crews of the expensive battle ships. It is not likely that many people know this fact, and in the State of New York, which expends thousands of dollars yearly to maintain the Creedmoor range and to qualify the men of the State Militia as marksmen, it will create no little surprise.

SEATTLE, Washington, Aug. 2. -- The scene of the next big mining in the newly discovered placer fields of the Northwest Territory will be on Stewart River. Hundreds are now on their way to the new district, about which only the vaguest accounts have been received. Enough, however, is known to induce the belief that the Stewart River district will be a larger producer of placer gold even than the now famous Klondike.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- "The Marquis of Michigan," a new comedy by Glen McDonough and Edward Townsend, was produced here last night at the Columbia. Theatre, and was well received. The authors have collaborated, Mr. McDonough supplying some very original dialogue and Mr. Townsend, of "Chimmie Fadden" fame, lending the situations and plot.

WOODBURY, N.J., Aug. 2. -- Sheriff Collins of Gloucester County is angry over information which was brought to him to-day, and it is likely many of the special officers now on the rolls of the county will lose their shields, if they do not have to answer before a trial jury. Washington Park, on the Delaware, is frequented by thousands every week, and attracts many crooks from Philadelphia.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 2. -- The champions won from the Philadelphias to-day in a game of no special interest. A double play by Doyle and Jennings was the only feature of the game. Score:

The title of the Dingley tariff law is "An Act to Provide Revenue for the Government, and to Encourage the Industries of the United States." This is the first time that a tariff law has been placed upon the statute books that contained the least intimation on its face that it was laid for "protective" purposes.

LONDON, Aug. 2. -- Mr. Herman Liebes, President of H. Liebes Co. of San Francisco, one of the firms composing the North American Commercial Company, lessees from the United States of the Pribilof Islands seal rookeries, has addressed a letter to The Times, in which, among other things, he says:

A pitched battle with supposed robbers enlivened the closing hours of Sunday in Fordham. About a dozen shots were fired, and stones were used besides as weapons of defense, and when the intruders were put to flight more than a hundred citizens turned out in volunteer posses and searched the neighborhood till toward daybreak.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2. -- The family of the man calling himself William A. Bellwood, who is under arrest in New York, charged with swindling, and who is said to be Guillaume Balensi, has disappeared. The lavishly furnished house occupied by Bellwood, at 1510 Diamond Street, is closed and empty. The furniture was removed last week.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 3. -- On June 9 the Chinese at Vuchen attacked and destroyed the mission of the Plymouth Brethren and were about to attack the Catholic Mission when the soldiers interfered. The attack on the Plymouth Mission was brought about by the report that the missionaries had killed a child.

VASI-IINGT(>,N', Aug. 3. -- The errors made by the Senators in the first game to-day allowed the Bostons to win easily. In the second game Sw. aim proved somewhat of a surprise ana the fielding of the loeals improved. Nichols replaced Sttvetts in the box at the end f the seventh, the latter going to centre. Scores:

-- Though the British are contending in Chitral with foes at once more numerous and more redoubtable than the Cuban rebels, and are doing it with a force that would be regarded as an inadequate bodyguard by Gen. WEYLER, yet the campaign there is progressing toward its inevitable and speedy end with a precision that comes as near as anything could to making war admirable.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 3. -- Frederick Treichler, thirteen years old, and John Flynn, who was a year older, engaged in a boxing match at noon to-day with bare fists. Flynn was struck just over the heart and dropped dead. Both boys were employed in a factory on Gerrabrandt place.

John M. Forbes of Morristown, N.J., and Lorenzo Semple of this city have been appointed receivers for the property in this State of the American Publishers' Corporation, of 312 Sixth Avenue by Judge Pryor of the Supreme Court on the application of Mr. Forbes, who was also appointed receiver in New Jersey, as it is a New Jersey corporation.

The first real steps taken by the police looking toward the suppression of indecent shows and illegal games on Coney Island were made by Police Captain Collins yesterday, acting under orders from headquarters.
Douglas Robinson Co. have sold for A.S. Sherwood to L. Horn the three-story brick dwelling, 53 East Ninth Street, 25 by 92.3, Sailors' Snug Harbor leasehold.

Lieut. Michael Moore, the oldest retired soldier of the United States army, died yesterday morning at his home, 20 Seventh Avenue, Brooklyn, at the age of ninety-seven years. His death was due to old age. Lieut. Moore had been on the retired list since 1872. He was born in this city July 4, 1800.
In your issue of July 30 I notice that in referring to the letter of Dr. Preston on vivisection you speak of the "vain imaginings" of those people who denounce that practice.
CHRISTIANIA, Aug. 3. -- The Storthing to-day passed a bill placing a duty of 30 ore (about 8 cents) on foreign flour.

NEW LONDON Conn., Aug. 3. -- It was noon to-day before the hoodoo which has been hovering over the yachtsmen of the New York Yacht Club was dispelled. Then the yachts were able to make a fair start for New London, and with a favorable breeze were able to reach port about sundown.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- The importations of breadstuffs into the Ignited States, as reported by the Bureau of Statistics, during the fiscal year ended June 30,1897, amounted, in the value of the various products grouped under that head, to $2,774,763. Barley and wheat furnished the principal items, the former aggregating 1,271,787 bushels, valued at $394,749, and the latter 1,176,337 bushels, of the value of $1,176,337.

Another one of the many depositions which have been taken in the suit brought by Mrs. Sarah Ann Angell to establish her claim as the widow of the late Jay Gould was filed in the County Clerk's office yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 4. -- A dispatch to The Daily Mail from Madrid describes the very grave state of affairs in Portugal. According to this correspondent the Portuguese Government is setting the constitution at defiance and adopting the most stringent repressive measures.

During the last week in July, 1895, the number of shares of stock bought and sold on the New York Stock Exchange was 1,453,497. During the last week in July, 1896, it was 999,388. During last week, the last week in July, 1897, it was 2,189,262.

Arrangements for the consolidation of the Brooklyn City and Newtown Railroad (the De Kalb Avenue line) and the Coney Island and Brooklyn Railroad (Smith Street line) have been completed, and notices will probably be sent to the stockholders of the last-named road within a day or two requesting them to deposit their holdings with the Mercantile Trust Company of New York which is practically the owner of the De Kalb Avenue line.

TACOMA, Washington, Aug. 3. -- For the fourteenth time since 1716 the volcano of Mayon on the Island of Luzon, one of the Philippines, is in eruption, and its streams of lava are carrying destruction through valleys for many miles around. Without the usual accompanying earthquake, Mayon burst out with tremendous force on June 26.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 3. -- Before Senator M.A. Hanna left Washington the Fall campaign in Ohio, so far as it relates to speakers, was entirely planned and a list of prominent men had been secured.

CHEYENNE, yoming, Aug. 3. -- The express on the Cheyenne Northern reached here to-day seven .hours late. The cause of the delay was a big washout at Islay, twenty-five miles north of here. Six hundred feet of the main track and the siding at that station were completely washed away.

At an early stage of the coal miners' strike THE TIMES pointed out that the work of adjustment seemed to be rendered difficult by the lack of adequate organization among the operators. This difficulty is now in a fair way to be removed.
NIAGARA FALLS, Aug. 3. -- A head-end collision occurred this afternoon between two cars on the Great Gorge Route. Twenty or twenty-five persons were injured, some quite severely.

We printed yesterday the gist of the very well written and forcible protest of about two-thirds of the professors of Brown University against the course taken by the Trustees in respect to President ANDREWS. We cannot regard it as a fair statement of the case, but we are quite sure that its authors and signers believed it to be so.

LAKE GEORGE, Aug. 3. -- Mrs. A.H. Humphreys, mother of Willard Humphreys, Professor of German in Princeton University, was drowned here last night, and Prof. Humphreys also would have lost his life but for the bravery and skill of Samuel Hoadley, who in spite of his sixty years swam to the rescue.

The Government finances for the month of July showed the effect of the new revenue bill by an increase in customs and internal revenue receipts of about $5,000,000 each, or $10,000,000, as compared with the same month last year. Had the expenditures been kept down this marked increased would have given the Government the novel sensation of being able to make both ends meet for at least a month.

Surrogate Abbott of Brooklyn yesterday sustained the will of Mary Jane Oates and dismissed the petition of the contestants with costs. Mrs. Oates was a widow with two children. She died last October, leaving an estate estimated at from $60,000 to $100,000, and was one of the heiresses of the old Wheeler estate,

George McAneny, Secretary of the National Civil Service Reform League, was asked yesterday to give his views on the effect of the changes made in the civil service rules by President McKinley. Mr. McAneny said:

No wise Democrat, certainly no Democrat who has not despaired of saving his party, will join in denunciation of the platform of the Maryland Democrats as an attempt to "dodge" or straddle the silver question. As a body of positive doctrine Senator GORMAN'S platform declarations for "the gold and silver money of the Constitution" and for international bimetallism are as unsatisfactory to us as they are to any other convinced believer in the gold standard.

In speaking of business conditions and stock market prospects, Mr. Benjamin Graham of the well-known Stock Exchange house of Cuyler, Morgan Co. said yesterday to a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- The following statement was issued to-day from the Treasury Department:

A reader of THE NEW YORK TIMES writes that he considers the article published in it Aug. 2 in relation to calfskins and containing ex-Appraiser Bunn's opinion that Congress did not intend to make calfskins dutiable as hides "all astray." With this criticism he sends the following.
The Principal of one of the public schools of Rochester gave the new Tariff act as published in The Post Express a thorough reading, and addresses a communication to the editor, in which he says:

HONOLULU, July 25. -- The arrival of the steamship Mouna from San Francisco, due here July 29, means much for Hawaii. In official circles it is generally understood that United States Minister Sewall will carry out the instructions received in the last mail, said to be to this effect: If the Mouna brings word that Congress failed to pass the annexation treaty Minister Sewall is to declare, a protectorate and raise the American flag.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3. -- The Chicago agent of the Travelers' Insurance Company of Hartford, Conn., has received instructions from his home office not to insure any person going to the Klondike region. It is a risk that the company does not desire to take on account of the extreme hazard, and because when death takes place the difficulty of obtaining the facts to make settlement of claims impracticable.

Two protests were filed at the Custom House yesterday against the levying of import duties under the new tariff law on goods which arrived in this port and were entered on Saturday, July 24, prior to the closing of the Custom House at 4 o'clock. The first protest was filed by Curie, Smith Mackie of Exchange Place, representing the owners of a consignment of merchandise brought over on the steamship Paris.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 3. -- Fair faces and gay Summer costumes imparted a social character to the National circuit race meet, held under the auspices of the American Cycle Racing Association on the North Asbury Park Athletic grounds yesterday afternoon. "Eddie" Bald was the lion of the day, and well sustained his claims to distinction by winning both heats and finals in the two events in which he appeared.

The disinterested fervor with which some of Mayor STRONG'S appointees are advocating his renomination indicates that the new charter has been attentively studied in the public offices where the business of this municipality is carried on. The next Mayor will distribute the most interesting and attractive batch of patronage that it has ever fallen to the lot of any executive outside of the Presidency to dispense.

LEWISTON, Me., Aug. 3. -- Nelson Dingley, father of Congressman Nelson Dingley, Jr., died at his home, in this city at 9:20 o'clock this forenoon. Death was due to a stroke of paralysis, aggravated by old age.

LOUISVILLE, Aug. 3. -- Indications multiply that Gov. Bradley is to have a lively fight if he secures an indorsement of his administration from the State Convention, which meets here next Tuesday. His agents are at work in Louisville and in various counties and cities in the State to secure delegations, but so far without much success.

LOUISVILLE, Aug. 3. -- A large number of distillers met to-day and filed objections to the regulations for bottling whisky in bond. Their objections will be transmitted by the Revenue Collector here to Commissioner Forman.

The opening day of the International Lawn Tennis Tournament at the grounds of St. George's Cricket Club, Hoboken, yesterday, boded well for the success of the tournament. The sport was spirited from first to last. The weather was extremely hot, and the only relief was an occasional breeze from the south which blew over the courts.

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., Aug. 3. -- The likelihood of the coal strike continuing has led Chicago and Alton officials to consider the advisability of using oil for fuel in locomotives. The Wabash is making experiments with oil, and the results have been highly successful. The expense is about 10 cents to the mile, while coal costs but 3 cents.

NEWPORT, Aug. 4. -- J. Rogers Maxwell's schooner Emerald defeated the Colonia today, and was the first schooner to finish, in addition to winning the regular class prize, a cup given by Vice Commodore L. Cass Ledyard for all schooners. The Vigilant, finishing first of the whole fleet, won the Vice Commodore's Cup for sloops.

A great deal of space on the ground floor of the New York Life Building, at Broadway and Leonard Street, has been attractively and conveniently arranged by the Merchants' Association for the reception of the 12,000 out-of-town business men who are expected to take advantage of the cheap excursions to New York with in the next six or eight weeks.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4. -- Representatives of the oats milling interests outside of the American Cereal Company, at their meeting here to-day, advanced the price of rolled oats 40 cents a barrel and 20 cents a keg. The advance will not affect the general market, as outside millers have been about 40 cents a barrel under the American Cereal Company's prices.

The Brooklyns met a team in their class at Eastern Park yesterday afternoon and won after an eleven-inning game, which was rather dull until the Washingtons scored a run in the seventh inning and made the score "one all." Then the players of both teams put some life into their work.

LONDON, Aug. 4. -- The Secretary of State for the Colonies, Joseph Chamberlain, answering a question in the House of Commons to-day on the subject of the denunciation by the Government of Great Britain of the treaties of commerce with Germany and Belgium, said the denunciation was the unanimous wish of the self-governing colonies, who desired to deal with the United Kingdom on preferential terms.

SING SING, N.Y., Aug. 4. -- The Board of Village Trustees met last night to consider the assessment roll, which the property owners consider excessive. One hundred and fifty of the 300 assessed in the village appeared before the board and entered a protest against the amount of their assessment.

Col. George Moore Smith, successor to Col. Grant, attended a meeting of the Police Board as a Commissioner for the first time yesterday morning and by his vote enabled Commissioners Moss and Andrews to pass a resolution of censure of the Bureau of Detectives, against the vigorous opposition of Commissioner Parker.
September contract wheat made a new record yesterday on the Produce Exchange, at one time touching 86 cents -- 1 cent more than was predicted at the close of the market on Tuesday.

LONDON, Aug. 4. -- The South African policy of the British Government was subjected to an attack in the House of Commons to-day by Sir Wilfrid Lawson, Liberal, member for the Cockermouth Division of Cumberland and President of the United Kingdom Alliance for the Suppression of the Liquor Traffic, who also gave Cecil Rhodes a sharp prodding.

---- In the pending controversy over the distinction between "hides" and "skins," and the propriety of classing the covering of calves with the one or the other, there is so much of similarity to a recent civil service problem that the simplest way of settling the matter would be to leave it to Gov. BLACK and the other etymological experts who established a difference between "merit" and "fitness."

Edward M. Shepard, who will sail for Europe this morning, said yesterday that he expected to return home in time to register and vote at the November election. He characterized the report that his trip at this time was intended to escape certain political responsibilities duringthe coming campaign as utterly absurd.

HOTEL CHAMPLAIN, N.Y., Aug. 4. -- Vermont people were exceedingly enthusiastic in their greeting to the President and Vice President to-day. The two breakfast parties arranged for the women and men of the Presidential party were both very exclusive affairs. Mrs. McKinley, Mrs. Hobart, Mrs. Alger, Mrs. Bailey, and Mrs. Flagg were the guests of Mrs. L.C. Clark, a daughter of Col. Le, Grand B. Cannon.
St. Paul sold yesterday at 90 1/2 for the first time since June, 1887, having sold previously at 95 in May of that year, from which price it declined to 69 5/8 in October.

ADDEVILLE, S.C., Aug. 4. -- Senator Tillman spoke at the Farmers' Institute here to-day, delivering the first speech he has made in the State since the opening of the present Senatorial campaign. He indorsed the tariff views of Senator McLaurin, and said that, while himself not a protectionist, if there was any stealing going on, he wanted his State to have its share.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4. -- Close, sultry weather characterized the opening day of the eighteenth National meet of the League of American Wheelmen, but it did not lessen the number of arrivals. The roll of wheelmen already registered is far greater than at any previous two race meets, and every railroad train to-night brought additional visitors.

" The whole subordinate service is now in a fair way to reach the basis of permanence and good discipline that is essential to the best administration, and the President, in adding to the system of appointment for merit the guarantee of retention for merit, has made that basis possible."

That which you say under head "Mr. Moss's Strategy" in to-day's issue is entirely correct. I remember an expression of THE TIMES in a very significant editorial soon after the Haymarket trials, in Chicago, and when the New York anarchists were on the "rampage" on account of the result of those trials: "To incite to crime is itself a crime."

ALBANY, Aug. 4. -- The Superintendent of Public Works has appointed William Keough of New York City to be the Second Inspector of Steamboats and Vessels on Inland Waters of the State under the new law passed last Winter.

It may be that the age is sadly lacking in veneration for ideals, whether high or not, and it may be that a fine sense of chivalric honor is inconsistent with a triumph of republican ideas. It is certain, however, that there is a new code of honor, and it bears the mercantile label, "made in France."

Why shouldn't Minister SEWALL run up the United States flag over the Government Building in Honolulu and declare a protectorate over Hawaii? Our latest advices from the islands report that he was to take this action on Aug. 2 if the San Francisco steamer due on that day brought the news that Congress had adjourned without ratifying the treaty of annexation.

The names of the architects who are to take part in the second competition of plans for the proposed building of the New York Public Library -- Astor, Lenox, and Tilden Foundations -- were announced yesterday at the office of the Secretary, G.L. Rives, 32 Nassau Street. They are:

Mrs. Clara Jaeger, a Trilby in real life, with a magnificent voice and no ear, and married to one of the finest teachers of vocal music in the world, killed herself on Tuesday night, after having first visited a Coroner and got information as to the proper method of reporting her own suicide.
ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 4. -- Two hundred women and girls employed at the Fulton Bag and Cotton Mills, in this city, struck this morning because of the employment of negro help by the management.

LONDON, Aug. 4. -- The Royal Commission on Agriculture has issued a report suggesting various palliatives for the existing depression in agriculture, which the commission attributes mainly to the general and persistent fall of prices and to foreign competition which is not likely to abate.

Westchester County taxpayers are not the only persons complaining about high assessments. In several Long Island villages there has been much dissatisfaction expressed. In Glen Cove the owners of country homes have suffered the most. Among the changes between this and last year's assessment claimed to he particularly high are:

WICHITA, Kan., Aug. 4. -- A party of Spiritualists from Fort Smith, Ark., gave a seance at Sallisaw, Indian Territory, last night, which was attended by many Indians, half-breeds, and a few whites. The mediums used a trumpet for the conveyance of messages from the spirit land, which was arranged so that the muzzle of it protruded through an opening in the curtain.

The Rev. Dr. Douglas, pastor of the West Fifty-first Street Presbyterian Church, was greatly impressed with the value of the reform movement at Coney Island after reading the article on that subject in THE NEW YORK TIMES of yesterday.
