Acting upon this inspiration, he sent this letter to District Attorney Backus of Brooklyn:
In your paper of the 16th ult., under the heading "Market Glutted with Tea," you show me an excuse for troubling you with the following:

The naval fleet which Rear Admiral MONTGOMERY SICARD has taken to Newport is one of which this country has especial reasons to be proud. It is only five or six years since we viewed with pride the North Atlantic squadron commanded by Rear Admiral JOHN G. WALKER, and felt that in it we possessed the nucleus of a navy which would in time be of incalculable value to the country.

W.A. Larned continued his winning streak, and R.D. Wrenn retrieved his defeat of Tuesday in the second round of the International Tennis Tournament at Hoboken yesterday. G.L. Wrenn again lost his match, through no inferior playing on his part, however. In fact, though the score of sets stood 3 -- 1, his opponent, Eaves, won by the smallest kind of a margin.

The decision of Justice BEEKMAN that money, i.e., personal property, invested in or owing for non-taxable imports cannot legally be deducted from personal property subject to State and city taxation seems to the lay mind sufficiently in harmony with the plain language of the law as amended in 1892.

NEWPORT, Aug. 4. -- This was the day of Newport's great fete in honor of the New York Yacht Club and the North Atlantic squadron. The feature of the forenoon was the cutter races in the harbor, between the crews from Fort Adams, the Newport Naval Reserve Torpedo Company, seamen gunners from the torpedo station, apprentices from the training station and the Old Colony repair shop, for prizes offered by Oliver H.P. Belmont.
Frederick Zittel has sold for Wagner Wallace to Charles Edey, for $42,000, the five-story American basement dwelling 8 West Seventieth Street, 21 by 60 by 100.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4. -- Chicago capitalists are interested in the Westminster, a family hotel to be erected at a cost of $1,000,000 in Copley Square, Boston. Henry E. Cregier, the Chicago architect, has been engaged to draw the plans, and considerable work will be let to Chicago builders.

Mr. EDWARD M. SHEPARD is a Democrat who, while he would be incapable of political action that would tend to bring about "a relapse to some unforgivable things of the past" in the Democratic government of New York and Brooklyn, is one who "looks with great hostility upon the recent trend of Republican legislation and administration."

BOSTON, Aug. 4. -- A meeting of the merchants of this city was held in the Chamber of Commerce to-day for the purpose of forming an association, to be known as the Boston Trade and Transportation Association, its object being to secure lower railroad fares and other concessions for the buyers trading in Boston, in the same way as it, has already been done in New York.

ST. PETERSBURG, Aug. 4. -- A dispatch from Krementchug, in the Province of Poltava, on the River Dneiper, says that the floods have destroyed a swimming bath in the river and that 200 women have been drowned.

SEATTLE, Washington, Aug. 4. -- A letter received here to-day from D.J. McKinney, who sailed for Dyea and the Yukon July 23, says that many of those then at the White Pass were not supplied with food enough to last them half way to the Klondike. Six men had three months' supplies and $50 each.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5, -- During the progress of the count and weighing of the silver in the vaults of the Treasury to-day incident to the transfer of the Government funds to the new United States Treasurer, Thomas Martin of this city, a colored laborer engaged in handling the bags, was arrested upon a charge of abstracting silver from the vaults.
CHICAGO, Ill., Aug. 5. -- Seven, and probably eight, lives were lost in an explosion which took place this evening during a fire in the Northwestern grain elevator at Cook and West Water Streets.

Funeral services for Lieut. Michael Moore, the oldest veteran of the United States Army, were held at his home yesterday, at 20 Seventh Avenue, Brooklyn. The funeral was attended by Mrs. Moore, widow of Lieut. Moore, his son, five daughters, five grandchildren, a delegation from the Military Order of Foreign Wars of the United States, and a large number of friends.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- The Navy Department has picked out the name "Plunger'' for the submarine boat now being built for the navy at the Columbian Iron Works, Baltimore. The craft will be ready for service next Spring.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 5. -- Philadelphia defeated New York to-day in a twelve-inning game. It was a stubborn contest from start to finish. The winning run was scored on Lajoie's drive to left field, which Holmes dropped, allowing the man on third to score. One of the features of the game was Cooley's batting.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5. -- According to George R. French, who has been here managing this end of the bull clique in wheat, his backers have netted $600,000 and controlled not less than 4,500,000 bushels of July wheat.

BOSTON, Aug. 5. -- The Baltimores won the game to-day by bunching their hits at opportune times. The visitors made more runs off Nichols than any other club has done this year. The Bostons had eighteen men left on bases, and were twice retired with the bases full. Doyle and Kelly led in the batting.

TRENTON, Aug. 5. -- Elwood Leary, a prominent Newark lawyer, is made defendant in divorce proceedings filed in the Court of Chancery. His wife, Susanna Leary, alleges excessive drinking and inhuman treatment. Leary and his wife were married in New York by the late Dr. Deems in 1891. Both are well connected.

The Tammany General Committee of the Seventh Assembly District, of which James W. Boyle is the leader, held a meeting at the headquarters, 232 West Fourteenth Street, last night and listened to an address by Lawyer James D. McClelland, which was in the nature of a bitter attack upon the Police Department.

The announcement of the formation of a "gas trust," with a capital of $100,000,000 and Consolidated Gas as a rallying point, was generally criticised in Wall Street yesterday as a "hit or miss" guess on corporation mysteries. The stock market refuted the story. Consolidated Gas stock, for instance, closing with a net loss of 7 points.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Aug. 5. -- Old Strathmore, the famous stallion, died yesterday, owing to the excessive heat.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 5. -- Miners' Day was observed in this city to-night by a meeting on Duquesne Wharf, where a crowd of from 8,000 to 10,000 people assembled to hear Eugene V. Debs, Mrs. Jones, and several local speakers make addresses. The speakers were given a hearty reception, and the sentiments expressed were loudly cheered, especially when allusions were made to the unrighteousness of the suppression of free speech and lawful assemblage.

SOUTH ORANGE, Aug. 5. -- Since Vailsburg cut itself loose from South Orange Township, two years ago, it has had some troubles, but the latest development is sending chills down the spinal columns of the police force, which is composed of public-spirited citizens who don the policeman's shield and protect the thriving borough whenever their services are required, being paia at the rate of $2 a day when on duty.

NEWPORT, Aug. 5. -- Royal Phelps Carroll won his second Goelet Cup to-day, defeating the Vigilant by 1 minute and 1 second elapsed time. It was a most exciting race from start to finish, and the Navahoe won through superior handling. The Colonia sailed over the course without a competitor for the thousand-dollar cup for schooners.

Smith Stewart have sold for John H. Watson to Oliver H.P. Belmont, for $150,000, the vacant plot at the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Seventy-seventh Street, having a frontage of 27.2 feet on the avenue and a depth of 120 feet on the street. Mr. Belmont will erect a residence for his own occupancy on the plot in the near future.

After a morning of rain and threatening weather, the sun broke through the clouds just as time was called in the third days' play of the international tennis tournament yesterday at St. George's Cricket Club grounds in Hoboken. The game was the exhibition match in doubles and was won by the American team after a magnificent exhibition.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 5. -- The heavy rain of Wednesday night was responsible for many withdrawals from to-day's originally attractive racing programme, but enough was left in the several events to bring forth spirited contests.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- The completed comparison of the tariff bill prepared by Charles H. Evans, the tariff, expert, was made public to-day. The following are some of the comparisons, in addition to those given last week:

The Trustees of Brooklyn Bridge met yesterday and settled the question of the elevated and trolley roads of Brooklyn crossing to this city. A resolution was passed calling for the execution of the contracts by Aug. 23.

ROCKVILLE, Conn., Aug. 5. -- During a heavy thunderstorm last evening lightning struck the house of C.R. Beckwith, at Windsorville, and Charles, the nine-year-old son of the family, was instantly killed. Mr. Beckwith was painfully burned by the bolt.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 5. -- It is reported that a Klondike syndicate of 100 men is being formed here by residents of Bay Shore, Sayville, and Northport. Each man is to advance $1,000. They will cross the continent, purchase a boat, man it with their own men, and sail from the Pacific coast, taking a year's provisions with them, so it is reported.

-- As knowledge of the Klondike region increases it will probably be discovered that to live from the resources of the country is not impossible or even especially difficult. From time immemorial men have managed to subsist in places fully as cold and much more sterile. Most of the Yukon Valley is heavily wooded, and wherever trees grow there are animals and the possibility of raising at least a few rapidly maturing crops.

Prof. Frederick De Forest Allen, the head of the classical philology department of Harvard University, died Wednesday evening from the effects of a paralytic shock which had occurred a few hours before while the professor was riding from Cambridge to Boston. He expired at the Cottage Hospital, Cambridge, without regaining consciousness.

The pamphlet just issued containing the "terms of competition for the building to be erected for the New York Public Library" gives evidence of a great deal of patient, intelligent, and disinterested labor. In the preliminary competition it was made quite plain that the building was to be what is known as "a librarian's library," in contradistinction to "an architect's library."

The awakened local interest in the work of the Merchants' Association is bringing into that organization many influential members, and trade prospects are growing brighter as the work progresses. John E. Searles, Treasurer of the American Sugar Refining Company and President of the Western National Bank, has caused both of these institutions to be enrolled as active members of the Merchants' Association.

LONDON, Aug. 6. -- The Times, in its financial comments this morning, admits its inability to explain the persistent weakness of silver, but thinks it due perhaps to a well-grounded belief that the results of the American Bimetallic Commission headed by Senator Wolcott are not likely to prove satisfactory to silverites here and in the United States.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 5. -- The bustle and excitement which have prevailed at the National Headquarters of the League of American Wheelmen since Tuesday continued to-day, despite threatening clouds and occasional showers. League members are still arriving in large numbers, and keep the officials in the registration department hard at work.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- The abstracts of reports of condition of national banks on May 14 is accompanied by a diagram prepared jointly by the Controller of the Currency and the Chief of the Bureau of Statistics. The diagram displays graphically the growth and changes in the principal items of resources of National banks from 1864 to 1896 inclusive.

Patrick H. Flynn, the owner of 346 shares of Coney Island and Brooklyn Electric Railroad Company's stock, yesterday obtained a temporary injunction restraining the Coney Island and Brooklyn Railroad Company from consolidating with the Brooklyn City and Newtown Railroad Company.

The predictions of pessimists that the racing during the current cruise of the New York Yacht Club would be without features of interest have failed to obtain verification. Although the fickle winds disappointed the hopes of the yachtsmen on Monday, the runs of Tuesday and Wednesday brought out some pretty work and gave some ground for judgment as to the comparative abilities of important yachts.
COLUMBUS, Aug. 5. -- At the meeting of the State Central Committee of the National Democrats to-day it was decided to hold a State convention in this city Sept. 8 and 9 to nominate a State ticket.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 5. -- The fullrigged German ship Otto, Capt. Bruhl, from Stettin for New York, grounded about halfpast 2 o'clock this morning on the beach off Sagaponeck. She was burning a Coston signal as she rode the bar. The lifeguards launched their boats and were soon under the lee of the vessel.

The ravening tax Assessors of some of the rural counties near New York have decided that the rich men from the city there resident must pay all the expenses of highways, police, lighting, schools, and other public undertakings. They have accordingly raised the assessments upon the property of New Yorkers lying within their reach to figures which will reduce to a minimum the tax contributions of the native villagers and farmers.

" We'll have a fine day," was the jubilant shout of 500 patriotic Hibernians as the sun appeared to shine on the grand picnic and games of the Irish Nationalists and Irish National Alliance of Greater New York, held yesterday afternoon and evening at Ridgewood Park, Brooklyn. It had been arranged to gather athletes of world-wide renown, who were to show their prowess to admiring throngs in a number of good Celtic events.

SEATTLE, Washington, Aug. 5. -- Awful tales of death in the frozen Alaska country have reached civilization in recent years, but none of them surpasses, and few compare with, the one which has just come to this city, involving the death of three men, Charles A. Blackstone, George Botcher, and J.W. Maliningue.

Of all the passengers on the steamship Germanic, which arrived yesterday from Liverpool, Bishop Potter was the most worried. A well-meaning friend in Scotland had sent him just before he left England a quantity of liquor of unusual excellence. The Bishop was dreadfully embarrassed. He could not gracefully decline the gift. He could not with propriety consume it on the voyage or have it consumed.
The situation in Westchester County resulting from the general and heavy increase in the assessments of property for taxation is likely to become serious.
Smith and Clearman of the Nassau Boat Club are entered in the double shell event in the National regatta.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 5. -- Another glorious morning, with just enough breeze to make the day perfect, greeted the inhabitants of the Champlain Valley to-day, greatly to the delight of the President and his party. The dress parade by the Twenty-first Infantry, United States Army, under command of Lieut. Col. McKibben, was again repeated at 11 o'clock on the lawn to the west of the Hotel Champlain, immediately fronting the Presidential and Vice Presidential quarters.
Justice Pryor was a peacemaker yesterday in Part II. of the Supreme Court, and made a tender ending to a domestic drama in which an estranged husband and wife and a baby were the principal actors.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Aug. 5. -- William Collier, the young Memphis divinity student, who plotted to assassinate Dr. Hale, came to the Pier from Boston about ten days ago and hired a room of Mrs. Stephen Knowles. He staid in his room nearly all of the time and wrote incessantly.
CHICAGO, Aug. 5. -- The roads of the Central Passenger Committee have decided to place interchangeable mileage tickets on sale by Sept. 1, or as soon after that date as they can be printed.

Edward F. Hartley, formerly a wellknown haberdasher up town, who has been adjudged insane on several occasions, paid a rather unexpected visit to his wife Wednesday night, and frightened her so that she appealed to the police for protection.
William H. Owen, the popular Brooklyn rider, is suspended until Oct. 1, 1897, for unfair dealing in connection with cycle racing.

Announcement will probably be made within the next few days of the deal which for some time past has been in course of negotiation touching the affairs of the New York, Susquehanna and Western Railroad.

That rough and savage wood tenanted by terrifying wild beasts that DANTE found at the entrance of the Inferno was a grateful and inviting bower compared to the asperities that beset the traveler to the Klondike. DANTE didn't have to carry a year's provisions, he found very little snow, and he had VIRGIL to shoo the beasts away and show him the place.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 6. -- Artist Kemble and Actor Francis Wilson, both residents here, are erecting an imitation fort around the Soldiers' Monument in Main Street, and it was the scene Thursday night of the culmination of a boys' feud.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 6. -- To-day was replete with surprises at the Columbus Driving Park, but the greatest was the free-for-all race. There were four starters, Joe Patchen, Star Pointer, Lottie Lorrain, and Badge and last night Star Pointer sold in the pools at $100 to $20 against the field.

The filing for probate of the will of Elias Stern of this city has brought out an answer to the petition of Max W. Mayer from David Stern, a half-brother of the decedent, which opens a contest likely to be interesting. The value of the estate, which consists of Government bonds, merchandise, and other personal property, is estimated at from $150,000 to $300,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6. -- The opening races of the eighteenth annual meet of the League of American Wheelmen were held to-day at Willow Grove Park, fourteen miles from this city, before 15,000 spectators. Several State records were smashed, and Arthur Gardiner, the Chicago crack, came within two-fifths of a second of breaking Hamilton's world's record for one mile paced.

SEATTLE, Washington, Aug. 6. -- Clarence King, the mining engineer, is here investigating the Klondike. He is outfitting an expedition for the Stewart and Klondike Rivers, and it is understood has an unlimited amount of cash to spend in purchasing or locating properties in the new gold fields. He said to-night:

A warrant was issued yesterday by Judge Teale of Brooklyn for the arrest of William H. Moger, who is charged with fraudulently obtaining a dozen Nassau wheels from Beuhler Platt, proprietors of the Columbia Machine Works.

In the suit of Mrs. Sarah Ann Angell to establish her claim to dower rights as the widow of the late Jay Gould, another deposition was taken yesterday in the County Clerk's office. The deposition is that of Lawyer Melville C. Brown of Laramie City, Wyoming, where he has lived for thirty years.

Will not some of the pugnacious brethren who are hustling about with chips on their shoulders, eager for a war with Japan, Spain, or any other nation, pause to reflect for a moment? It is admitted that Spain has not very many battleships, but it is conceded that she has some; and as for Japan, she has a few and is soon going to have some more.

John Sherman, the Secretary of State, hurried through New York yesterday forenoon on his way from Amagansett, L.I., to Washington. His vacation was over, he said, and he was returning to his duties refreshed and invigorated in body and spirit. He was accompanied by his secretary, Mr. Babcock.

A curious story is reported in the lay press which involves an important medico-legal question. Some burglars are stated to have entered a dwelling house at Clayton-le-Moors. Accrington, and to have chloroformed the inhabitants as a preliminary measure to successfully looking the house. The alleged victims of this outrage were a grown-up son of the householder, two adult daughters, and two young children.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- Secretary Sherman returned to the city this afternoon from a rest of two weeks at Amagansett, L.I. He appears refreshed and improved by his respite at the ocean. His face is tanned, and he says he feels the absence of that lassitude and fatigue which he felt while in the city.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- The advance sheets of the summary of exports and imports as reported by the Bureau of Statistics of the Treasury Department, ending with June, completing the fiscal year, show that our exports have exceeded those of any former year, and that the exports of manufactured goods have been $276,357,861, an increase over the previous phenomenal year of $47,286,683.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 6. -- Judge Thompson, in the City Court to-day, decided against that branch of medicine known as osteopathy. Dr. Byron Axtel, an osteopathist, was fined $50 by Judge Thompson for practicing medicine without a license.
B.M. Strauss Co. have sold for Dr. Lucien C. Warner the five-story double apartment house, 168 West Ninety-sixth Street, 50 by 100.

A day's rest seemed to have the desired effect upon the Brooklyns, and they gave the Washingtons a trouncing at Eastern Park yesterday afternoon. It was an old-fashioned batting matinee, in which the home team used up two of the visitors' pitchers. There were two and three baggers aplenty.

President William Berri of the Bridge Trustees was enthusiastic yesterday over the result of the meeting on Thursday, wherein the crossing of the bridge by the surface and elevated roads of Brooklyn was made possible.

CITY OF MEXICO, Aug. 6. -- The drop in silver yesterday sent exchange on New York to its highest point (132) after banking hours. Merchants have largely canceled foreign orders, and will await something like permanency in exchange. The Government is making all its estimates based on even lower prices for silver.

SARATOGA, Aug. 6. -- For the first time since last Fall, when his entries were refused at Gravesend because of the inconsistent running of his horse, The Winner, the colors of "Will" Wallace, who was restored to favor by The Jockey Club recently, were seen to-day on an Eastern race track.
LONDON, Aug. 6. -- The British Government has informed the American Bimetallic Commission that it will probably reply to the proposals of the Commissioners on behalf of the United States in October.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6. -- The Quakers were powerless before Seymour to-day. For seven innings they could not hit the ball outside the diamond. Cooley's home run in the eighth inning saved the home team from a shut-out. Score:

Isidor Robin, aged twenty-two, was arrested yesterday for the theft of fifty suits of clothing from Kulzman Brothers of 743 and 745 Broadway. He was formerly employed in the house, which is a wholesale establishment, and it is thought he had hidden himself in the place before it was locked up the evening before.

BUFFALO, Aug. 6. -- Commander McConell of Columbia Post, G.A.R., of Chicago, who is in this city, to-day received the following acceptance by President McKinley of the invitation to a banquet to be held by the post in this city:

TRINIDAD, Col., Aug. 6. -- The old adage that murder will out is again proved true by the arrest in the San Isidro country a few days ago of Macedoneo Archuletas, Manses Frayter, Juan Duran, Nestor Martinez, Dave Hodges, Luperto Archuletas, and two women, Lucia Archuletas and Luza Duran, all charged with the murder of Deputy Sheriffs William Green and William Kelley, in April of last year.

It has for some time been quite plain that the Turk would yield to the will of Europe only so far as he was compelled to do so by the show of force or the evident intention to employ force. Also he must be watched at every point to see that he does not backslide or deceive his mentors.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug. 6. -- H.A. Dailey, a well-to-do Jenison man, shot his wife last night. This morning he took poison and died while in charge of officers who had arrested him. The woman may possibly recover. Dailey left a note indicating that he had contemplated suicide by drowning.

LONDON, Aug. 6. -- The Parliamentary bye-election to fill the vacancy in the Brightside Division of Sheffield, caused by the death on July 21 of the Hon. Anthony J. Mundella, who had represented the division since 1885, took place to-day, and resulted in a victory for the Liberal and Radical candidate, Frederick Maddison, who polled 4,289 votes, against 4,106 polled by the Conservative candidate, James Fitzalan Hope.

Shakespeare does not scruple to rhyme "come" with "tomb," "debt" with "let," "doting" with "nothing," besides using such false rhymes as "voice -- juice," "guest -- feast," "wrong -- young," "replenish -- blemish." Wordsworth gives us "hymn" and "trim," "home" and "comb," "lamb" and "am," and "folk" and "oak," as well as "Erin -- steering," "coming -- omen," "truly -- July," "echo -- cuckoo," some of which fairly make a "layman" shudder.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 6. -- Two more signed scales were received at the Amalgamated Association headquarters to-day. One was from Cornes Son, operating a rolling mill at Massillon, Ohio, and the other from the Great Western Tin Plate Company of Joliet, Ill. President Garland is pleased with the outlook, and says all the union mills in the country will likely be in operation before the end of next week.
Wall Street heard sensational reports after yesterday's stock market closed.

Manhattan Elevated Railway stock cut some lively capers in Wall Street yesterday. It opened around 95. At the close it sold within the slightest fraction of 100. Practically all this advance came in the last hour, and incidental to it many sensational reports went circulating round the Stock Exchange district.
Yesterday was a day of falls and some escapes that were little short of miraculous in Hudson County.

The trolley lines will probably be running across the Brooklyn Bridge by the end of the year and the cars of the elevated roads ought to be making continuous trips by midsummer next year, and probably by Spring.

Eight hundred spectators fairly went wild as the deciding point was won by Larned, the American, in the last day's play of the international tennis tournament. The struggle was one of the most stubborn seen on a tennis court in many years, and the international feature of it made the match doubly interesting.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 6. -- Gov. Leedy and the other State officers, including Webb McNall, Superintendent of Insurance, have grown very bitter since Judge Williams of the United States court issued an injunction restraining them from interfering with the business of the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York. The Governor said today:

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 5. -- The Government has just received dispatches giving the first full details of the great battle fought on June 30 in Cocorobo, near Canudos, between the Government troops, under Gen. Savagit, and the fanatics under Conselheiro.

At the Frederickson sale in May a book was sold for $615 -- not because it was the first edition of "Queen Mab," and one of a few copies printed without the title, but because Shelley had presented it to Mary Wollstonecraft Godwin, who had then written on a fly leaf: "This book is sacred to me."

In her address proroguing the British Parliament the Queen says: "I have given notice to the King of the Belgians and the German Emperor to terminate the treaties of 1862 and 1865, whereby I am prevented from making with my colonies such fiscal arrangements within my empire as seem to me expedient."

Nathan Straus, whose philanthropic task of distributing medicated milk at a nominal cost among the east side poor, has proved so effective for good, has decided to extend the work to a magnificent degree. He purposes to build for the city a laboratory, complete in all equipments, to prepare this milk in quantities sufficient to supply all New York's poor.
Emanuel Friend of Friend, House Grossman, counsel for Mrs. Nack, has had no little amusement over the efforts of detectives of Acting Inspector O'Brien's staff to find Guldensuppe's head.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- Under the direction of Secretary of Agriculture James Wilson, Willis L. Moore, Chief of the Weather Bureau, gives out the following:
The managers of the Citizens' Union do not appear to realize that "time is of the essence of the contract" they have entered into with their supporters.

The victory of the Navahoe over the Vigilant in the contest for the Goelet Cup off Newport on Thursday substantiates the opinion expressed in these columns that Mr. ROYAL PHELPS CARROLL'S big sloop was decidedly it the same class as the former cup defender. The race was sailed in a fresh northeasterly wind and something of a seaway, and was of a sort to delight the true sailor.

OAKLAND, Cal., Aug. 6. -- The Brig Pitcairn, which was built and used as a missionary craft in the South Seas, has been purchased from the Seventh Day Adventists by a syndicate of treasure seekers, who will at once fit her up for the voyage to Alaska.

The dispatch published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Thursday, announcing the successful operation of the new steel plant at the Birmingham Rolling Mill, has again revived the question of whether steel can be produced to advantage from the low-grade Southern ores.

MURRAY ISLE, N.Y., Aug. 6. -- The New York State Chess Association tournaments were all finished to-day except the cup contest. In the team match, New York vs. Pennsylvania, the New York team won by a score of 25 1/2 to 23 1/2.

PARIS, July 19. -- Dieppe is that dull little seaside resort in Normandy which, being the terminus of the sea voyage across the Channel from New Haven, is very largely frequented by English-speaking people. It is not quite such a refuge for social outcasts as Boulogne, and it has retained to a greater degree its French characteristics.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 6. -- President McKinley had an enjoyable time at Isle La Motte to-day. The steamer Moquam left the hotel dock at 11 o'clock to convey the President to the midsummer meeting of the Vermont Fish and Game League, held at the island home of the Lieutenant Governor of the State.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 5. -- The proposed campaign of the strikers against the coal mine owners of Westmoreland County and the operators of Central Pennsylvania is now an assured fact. The strike leaders decided on it definitely at a camp conference to-day, and a big move will probably be made next Wednesday.

With a view to learning as clearly as possible the conditions existing in the various sections of the country and the outlook for Autumn and Winter business, The Dry Goods Economist has just completed an exhaustive canvass of the United States. This was done through subscribers to The Economist, 1,610 replies having been received.
ISLIP, L.I., Aug. 6. -- The Assessors of Islip have just completed the assessment rolls for the town.

As a constant and admiring reader of THE TIMES I cannot pass your editorial article "The Rural Tax Pirates" in the issue of to-day without calling your attention to its complete misstatement of facts, which are fairly enough stated in the news article on the first page. As a Summer resident and taxpayer of White Plains, I, too, am interested in the assessment books.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Aug. 6. -- South Carolina given ever to the unexpected and inexplicable, is just now reveling in that rare form of recreation supplied by a heated and complicated political campaign. The experience is one to which probably no other State in the Union would voluntarily subject itself in midsummer.

Little "Barty" Welch, aged seven, is looked upon in his neighborhood as a sharp, shrewd youngster. He assisted in the capture of a man who broke into his father's house, at 130 State Street, Brooklyn, last evening, and for this act of precocity Barty was highly commended by the police.

There are seventeen entries scheduled for the track and field championship meeting of the Metropolitan Association of the Amateur Athletic Union at Columbia Oval to-day. The entries include some of the best-known amateurs in the metropolitan district. The events with the entries are as follows:
SING SING, Aug. 6. -- The devil is going to have troubles of his own the next eight days if the weather holds good, for a mighty, and aggressive army of Methodists is encamping against him here.

The races that to-day inhabit Hellas, speaking generally, have all the faults and few of the good qualities of the old Greeks. Their chicanery, as much as their inveterate indolence, has cramped the commerce and retarded the progress of the country. English merchants and traders declare that it is almost impossible to do business with the Greeks, so corrupt is the administration of the customs and so frail is the commercial morality of the people.
LONDON, Aug. 6. -- Parliament was prorogued until Oct. 23. The proceedings terminated at 3:15 P.M.

BOSTON, Aug. 6. -- Congressman Joseph H. Walker of Worcester has given out an open letter which has a bearing on the controversy between the Faculty of Brown University and the corporation of the institution, of which Mr. Walker is a member, over the resignation of President Andrews. He calls it a "reply to certain members of the Faculty of Brown University by one of the corporators," and says:

The late Jean Ingelow (giving the "g" in the surname a softened sound) was born in 1820 in Boston, Lincolnshire. Her father, who was a banker, moved to Ipswich, and The Academy says that "banking and Evangelicalism have conspicuously run together in certain families, and they did in hers.

Herbert Spencer says: "He that with men is a success must begin with being a firstclass animal." The Abbe Roux quotes a lecturer in Notre Dame as saying: "If one wishes to preach well one must have the devil in one's body." If he had added, "and God in his heart," we should have seen more clearly his point.

BRUSSELS, Aug. 7. -- The International Conference to Promote Arbitration was opened to-day in the hall of the Chamber of Deputies. British, American, French, Austrian, German, Italian, Spanish, Danish, Swedish, Dutch, and Roumanian delegates were present. M. de Bernaert, President of the Chamber of Deputies, was elected Chairman of the conference.

ST. LOUIS, Mo. Aug. 7. -- What is known in this State as the Breeders law, under which poolselling and bookmaking are prohibited excepting on race tracks, was pronounced unconstitutional to-day by Judge David Murphy of the Court of Criminal Correction. This probably will have the effect of reopening down-town poolrooms.

NEWPORT, Aug. 7. -- Newport's Fete Day this year was as grand an affair as was ever known of its kind, and to the promoters, O.H.P. Belmont, Congressman Bull, and State Auditor Landers, much praise is given. For three years Fete Day has been the event of the Newport season, and each year it has increased in magnitude, until now it seems as if it would be impossible to extend it any further.

The practice of music differs so far from the practice of certain other professions that it Is absolutely open to any one to enter upon it. This is, indeed, one of the chief resons for the overcrowding, about which we are hearing so much in these day. There are no prohibitive restrictions to set as a wholesome check.

Each person helps himself in the "quick lunch" restaurant, and each person is apparently thrown on his honor to pay for exactly as much as he eats. No person without a proper sense of honor would be safe, however, in trying to cheat the proprietor more than once or twice, for watchful and suspicious eyes are on the lookout from various points of view.

Inferior playing brought about the Washingtons' downfall again at Eastern Park yesterday afternoon. Not unlike Friday's contest, the Brooklyns did not have to let themselves out to win. About 4,000 persons watched the Senators make some ludicrous plays, which brought forth cries of derision.

LONDON, Aug. 7. -- The leading question in Continental political circles is. Will the visit of Emperor William of Germany to St. Petersburg result in a German-Russian-French understanding directed against Great Britain? Such a consummation is undoubtedly devoutly wished for in Germany, where the denunciation of the treaty of commerce between Great Britain and Germany has rekindled anglophobism.

AUSTIN, Texas, Aug. 7. -- The Attorney General to-day filed eight suits against the Houston and Texas Central Railway, charging discrimination in freight rates. The cases are the first of several hundred that are to be filed against different roads.

IF Valentine Seaman lives until the 30th of next September he will be in his ninety-sixth year. He was born within a block of where the present TIMES Building stands, in 1802, and he still has a clear recollection of his birthplace, which was in Beekman Street, almost opposite the Old Brick Church.

Championship honors over all the crack athletic clubs of the metropolitan district were won by the New York Athletic Club on the Columbia Oval, at William's Bridge, yesterday afternoon in the championship games of the Metropolitan Association of the Amateur Athletic Union. An incontestable victory it was, for the brawny Hercules disporting the winged foot scored nearly double what the next most powerful club, which was the Knickerbocker Athletic Club, could gain.

The programme relative to the formation of the maltsters' trust, outlined in a dispatch to THE NEW YORK TIMES recently, has been carried out, and the trust is now an accomplished fact. The details were arranged at a meeting held in the Manhattan Hotel, at which representatives of the following houses were represented:

In the current number of The Nineteenth Century Prince KRAPOTKIN gives an account of the progress which has been made in the anti-toxic treatment in a department to which it seems especially applicable. Most people are probably unaware that it has been successfully applied to the cure of the bites of venomous serpents at all.

CLAYTON, N.Y., Aug. 7. -- Ex-Commodore William R. Huntington was the officer of the day in the camp of the American Canoe Association here to-day. Among the arrivals to-day were delegations from the Brooklyn, Rochester, and Irondequoit Clubs. The Rochester men brought a war canoe. Prominent members who have just arrived are ex-Commodore Robert T. Wilkin and Percy Hogan of Brooklyn, Thomas Hale, Jr., of Yonkers; Parry M. Stewart, and J.R. Stewart of Rochester.

LAGGAN, Northwest Territory, Aug. 7. -- Three of the Alpine Club and Appalachian Mountain Club party, now staying at Lake Louise, with Peter Sarback, the Swiss guide, yesterday made the first ascent of the great white peak at the head of the lake, known variously as Mount Green, or Victoria Peak, in the Canadian Rockies.

In London alone it is calculated there are close on 1,200 orchestral players, and of these there are probably not more than a hundred, if, indeed, the number is so great, whose income from orchestral vork is over u250 a year. The ordinary pay of the player at concerts is a guinea per performance, one rehearsal-being thrown in gratis, the leaders and soloists receiving extra.

Stewart Tupper, Q.C., son of Sir Charles Tupper, a former Cabinet Minister of Canada, figured yesterday in a most unenviable light. Mr. Tupper was among the arrivals on the Cunard Liner Etruria yesterday morning. As the eminent Canadian barrister stepped from the steamer's gangplank to the pier he was stopped by Customs Detectives Donohue and Hanley.

Trashy piano music, with thin harmoniesit gives the lion's share of what effort it necessitates to the right hand, while of the left is required but a feeble thrumming. Alll good, v-ell-written music, whether difficultl or easy, makes equal demands on both hands. The faithful teacher should see to it that the student does such music justice by training the left hand to equal skill with the right.

His Excellency Chang Yen Hoon, who represented the Chinese Empire as Special Ambassador during the jubilee ceremonies in England, talked freely yesterday of his observations and experiences in Europe. He did not say so, but it is evident that the English and Russian Governments vied with each other in doing honor to the representative of the Emperor of China.

The Kakhyen houses are totally unlike those of the Chinese, Burmese, or Shans. and are very much superior, both architecturally and in interior arrangement to any of the three. They reminded me of the best Fiji houses more than anything else. They are of enormous length, frequently over 100 feet, and are divided in a very practical and ingenious way.
CORNING, N.Y., Aug. 7. -- Moses E. Banks, a well-known produce dealer, who lived just outside this city, was lured from his home last night by four men and killed on the Rose Hill Road.
NEWPORT, Aug. 7. -- The engagement of J. Nicholas Brown of Providence to Miss N. Nattalie Dresser, daughter of the late Mr. G.W. Dresser, was announced here this morning.

Two young women -- schoolgirls, in fact -- stood in one of the wards of the Flower Hospital in this city not many days ago and watched with intent interest the deft fingers of a surgeon as he treated and bandaged the broken arm of an adult patient. The girls were not there because of mere curiosity, but by appointment to take a practical lesson in the application of splints and bandages.
TRENTON, Aug. 7. -- Gov. Griggs is a candidate for the United States Senate, and the indications are that there will be a hot fight between him and John Kean, who also a candidate.

BERLIN, Aug. 7. -- The cloud bursts and inundations which have recently devastated the eastern parts of Germany were the worst which have occurred since 1870. According to the local statistics, 150 persons were killed in Silesia alone, and in Saxony the number of killed will not fall short of 180. The financial losses foot up over 150,000,000 marks.

Manhattan Elevated Railway stock sold on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday at 108. An excited market prevailed. The stock's opening price was 4 or 5 points above 99, the closing price of the day preceding. About 25,000 shares of stock were traded in. The closing price was 106 1/2, a gain of over 7 points for the day.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 7. -- All roads in Saratoga lead to the race track, and apparently every vehicle in town is bound for the same place every racing day from 12 to 2 o'clock.

SPRINGVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 7. -- Armed posses of citizens are scouring the surrounding country for the murderer of Mrs. Sarah Widrig, who was shot and instantly killed at her home last night. Suspicion points to the husband of the woman as the murderer. Mrs. Widrig was shot through the breast, and another bullet grazed the wrist of a Miss Ware, who was calling on Mrs. Widrig.
ALMOST unconsciously, even to its members, the Tuxedo Club has grown to be considered the representative country club of America.

We have published during the week some very interesting letters relating to the peculiar title of the lately enacted tariff law: " An act to provide revenue for the Government and to encourage the industries of the United States." It was first stated, and the statement was very near the truth, that this is the first bill which has avowed in its title a purpose other than the raising of revenue.

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 7. -- The second handicap golf tournament of the season on the Kebo Valley Club links took place this morning. It was followed in the afternoon by a putting contest, mixed doubles, over the same course. Both events were close and exciting throughout, and showed some very clever playing.

He is one of the city's busiest men and his acquaintances were greatly surprised when they saw him wandering down the street at a leisurely gait, utterly refusing to discuss anything in which he was interested in a financial way.

ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 7. -- The Orange Athletic Club easily defeated the Oritani Field Club at Orange Oval this afternoon. A large crowd witnessed the game. The visitors did not have Fishel, their star pitcher, with them, and Carsey, who took his place, was batted all over the field. The home team played well.

Slims is slow to anger, but when he gets there his company is not to be coveted. Having an important matter on hand the other day, he retired to his inner office with the hope of a few hours of uninterrupted quiet. His first trial came from the man who avoids the law against begging by offering cheap lead pencils for sale. A wave of the hand and a scowl disposed of him.

After months of comparative idleness the many theatrical booking agencies in this city became suddenly active last week, and hundreds of actors were engaged for productions this season. As stated in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Tuesday, more bookings have been made and more traveling companies organized than in any like period within the past five years.
SARATOGA, Aug. 7. -- Ideal racing weather brought a large crowd to the track to-day, including many society people, who wished particularly to see the gentleman jockeys in the Hunters' Steeplechase.

A bulky document, consisting of the depositions of Benjamin D. Silliman and James Bancker to determine the respective rights of Mrs. Eugenia A. Ross and William Dehon King under the will of William Henry King, was filed yesterday in the County Clerk's office.

LONDON, Aug. 7. -- Lole Fuller and her company made their appearance at the Shaftesbury last Thursday for a four weeks' engagement. She is to be followed by the production of "The Wizard of the Nile."

Dr. Woods believes hydrophobia to be a mimetic disease, caused by expectant dread. In Italy peasants used .to fear dire consequences from the bite f the tarantula, and fell, when bitten, to dancing with "delirious grotesquerie." Now, when they have ceased to think much of the tarantula they are bitten again and again with impunity.

That Senator Thomas C. Platt's candidate for Mayor is Cornelius N. Bliss, Secretary of the Interior, has been plain for some weeks. While Mr. Bliss has stated positively that he would not be a candidate under any circumstances, Mr. Platt and his friends are still nursing the hope that Mr. Bliss may reconsider as he did in the matter of going into the Cabinet and consent to allow his name to be used.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, July 24. -- According to admissions of the police authorities, at least two heavily equipped and important filibustering expeditions to Cuba have recently left these shores. It is, of course, a notorious, although not proved, fact that expeditions of one sort or another are continually going and coming between the Cuban insurgents and the Junta in Jamaica.

In Africa alone Germany has nearly a million square miles of colonial possession--an area nearly five times as large as the whole German Empire in Europe. For thirteen years she has expended vast sums for the purpose of giving the black people of these territories the same minute and paternal administration that it dispenses in Brandenburg and Pomerania.

SEATTLE, Washington, Aug. 7. -- In response to a query from this city, the following telegram was received from the Treasury Department: "Miners can land their effects and go to British Columbia territory from Dyea under customs supervision without payment of duty and without giving bonds."

Now that St. Swithin has seen fit to lock the floodgates which played such havoc with the first Summer meeting of the Brighton Beach Racing Association, there seems to be no good reason why the second Summer meeting, which opens at the race track by the sea to-morrow, should not be a success.

A wake was held Friday night over Mamie Monahan, the child who fell out of the fourth-story window of the tenement at 85 Carmine Street Thursday. Yesterday she was buried, and many friends of the family were at the house.

NORTH ADAMS, Mass., Aug. 7. -- A double murder was discovered in this city to-day, when the bodies of Henry J. Reed, a money lender, aged forty-five years, and his sister, Blanche M. Reed, aged fifty, were found in their home, on Webster Avenue, both having evidently been killed by burglars.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- Assistant Secretary of the Navy Theodore Roosevelt has submitted a report to Secretary Long on the condition of the naval militia, which he recently inspected. Mr. Roosevelt, after visiting the War College and Torpedo Station at Newport, went to Mackinac and cruised to Detroit with the First and Third Divisions of the Michigan State Naval Brigade.

Chesterman Moore, who was bookkeeper and cashier for the German-American Provision Company of 342 Washington Street up to two weeks ago, was arrested yesterday on a charge of grand larceny and falsifying his books. The amount of his shortage is placed at $355. Manager Henry Hoeningberger of the Provision Company said that Moore had confessed his guilt.

THIRTY years ago there was but one "Studio Building" in New York City, and not to know that this one was in Tenth Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, was indisputable proof of the Philistine; it was almost as bad as ignorance of the sign of the Mitro, in Dr. Johnson's time.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 7. -- Prof. Henry W. Elliott read to-day the interview with John W. Foster, Commissioner sent by President McKinley to England to confer with Lord Salisbury relative to the Bering Sea matter, and replied hotly to Mr. Foster's intimation regarding the animus which actuated Elliott to write his two recent letters. He said:

LONDON, Aug. 7. -- The close of the session of Parliament leaves neither of the political parties in an altogether enviable frame of mind. The latent antagonism of the different schools of Ministerialists has threatened more than once during the past six months to bring about civil war in the tory camp, and the recess leaves considerable numbers of Conservatives in a state of high indignation and resentment.

MURRAY ISLE HOTEL, THOUSAND ISLANDS, N.Y., Aug. 7. -- In the cup contest of the New York State Chess Association, which ended in a tie between William Steinitz, Staten Island Chess Club, and Lipschuetz. Manhattan Chess Club, the committee has decided that three more games shall be played, the first at Staten Island, Aug. 11; the second at Manhattan, Aug. 18, and the third at Staten Island, Aug. 25.

GRAND RAPIDS, Minn., Aug. 3. -- Joseph January, Jr., is the only son of Joseph January, Sr., an old Chippewa Indian warrior who lives in the woods seven miles south of this place. Miss Amie Brenner is the pretty daughter of Adam Brenner, a St. Paul German who is said to be an officer of some brewing association operating in that city and in La Crosse, Wis.

It is customary in the vacation schools, which are conducted in this city during the Summer months by the Society for the Improvement of the Condition of the Poor, to read a story or a poem to the classes occasionally, and require the pupils to submit written descriptions of what they have heard.

The murder of Master at Arms Thomas J. Kenney by Seaman Philip F. Carter on board the United States warship Indiana, while the latter was moored at the Navy Yard, on June 30 last, has caused discussion regarding the disposition to be made of Carter in case of his conviction. The State law requires death by electricity. The Federal law provides that the death penalty must be inflicted by hanging.

The relation of pork and pig iron, corn and wheat to amusement enterprises is perhaps one that does not instantly suggest itself to the wayfaring man; but it is, nevertheless, one that is very real and highly important. Amusement managers cherish the plausible theory that the first luxury which the average man gives up in hard times is the theatre.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 7. -- The venerable Dr. Sayre, whose name has been famous in the annals of American surgery for nearly half a century, and Gen. Patrick A. Collins of Boston, the particular Irish-American whom President Cleveland delighted to honor, are probably the most distinguished visitors in Richfield this Summer.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7. -- Isaac Wolf, a jewelry peddler of New York City, was arrested today by a detective as he was entering the city on a Big Four train. The charge is that of embezzlement, and the arrest was made at the request of the New York police.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Aug. 7. -- The Naval Academy crews will have every facility in the future to keep their place among college crews. A new boathouse, 100 feet by 50, is to be erected on a line with the present boathouse, with the float from which the boats are launched into the river extending between the two houses.

Tickets were placed on sale yesterday at all points within the territory of the Joint Traffic Association for the benefit of nonresident members of the Merchants' Association who desire to visit New York at reduced rates of fare. Many strangers have arrived in this city through the medium of independent excursions within the past few days, but the Merchants' Association excursions will begin next week.

THE Atlantic Yachtsmen have made their home at Bay Ridge since 1880. In that period they have had two houses. One was an old farmhouse which they leased and fixed up for a clubhouse. This house still stands on the bluff.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- The Treasury Department is considering the advisability of withdrawing the Treasury agent stationed at Panama to supervise the transshipment of goods over the Isthmus, in transit from New York to San Francisco and from San Francisco to New York. It is thought that this service, which has always been considered important as a protection to the revenue, may be satisfactorily performed by the United States Consul.

Gen. Joseph Wheeler, the well-known Representative of the Eighth Congressional District of Alabama and member of the House Committee on Ways and Means, and who was also a member of the Tariff Conference Committee, is in the city. Gen. Wheeler is one of the most distinguished advocates of tariff reform and a master of the intricacies of the Dingley bill.
" Superstitions? Why, the merchant marine is full of them. Not so much as before the days of steam, perhaps, but there's enough left to make the Captain's life a merry-go -round."

LONDON, Aug. 7. -- The trouble in the engineering trades is apparently not a whit nearer settlement. The employers declare they will not permit the union men to return to their shops unless they undertake to work amicably with the non-unionists. Large numbers of ex-soldiers and ex-policemen are employed to prevent any interference upon the part of the engineers' pickets with the men remaining at work.
GLASGOW, July 24. -- The Royal Irish Yacht Club completed the first day of its regatta in Dublin Bay in weather which spoiled the racing records. The day ended in a thunderstorm and a deluge of rain.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 7. -- The striking coal miners continue to gain accessions to their ranks. The 150 men employed at the Horner Roberts mine at Elizabeth refused to go to work this morning, and about 75 miners at the Equitable mines in the same locality also struck. Both mines were paying the district rate.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 7. -- A legal battle has begun in a Justice Court here that promises to become notable in character. Some of the best attorneys in Ohio have been engaged, and it will not stop this side of the Supreme Court.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 7. -- The day has been quiet and uneventful for President McKinley. He went to the bowling alley and had a test of skill in knocking down the pins with the Vice President, the latter winning, 187 to 152. The political tongues were set going by the arrival of Whitelaw Reid, accompanied by Mrs. Reid, at noon, and of Warner Miller this evening.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 7. -- The Knickerbocker Trust Company of New York, as trustee for $10,000,000, of the bonds of the Cleveland, Canton and Southern Railway, filed a cross bill in the United States Court to-day, in a suit in which the road defends a foreclosure proceeding brought by the International Trust Company.

They who have been predicting that 1897 is to be a duplication of 1879 -- that American prosperity's most famous epoch is to be now reproduced, perhaps surpassed -- were but a little while ago regarded as visionaries, amiable, but not much gifted with business perceptions. To-day in Wall Street they are put in the list of conservatives.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Aug. 7. -- As the Assessors' books in the Long Island towns are open to view, they show that there have been increases all along the line. In this town, while there are no wealthy residents, assessments have been raised in some instances 300 per cent., or up to the full value of the property. The same state of affairs exists in all of the towns of the county.

NEWPORT, Aug. 7. -- The following yachts arrived here to-day: Sloop Syce, owned by Mr. Hoyt; sloop Ilderim, owned by C. Vanderbilt, Jr.; sloop Carmita, owned by W.K. Vanderbilt, Jr.; steamer Seneca, owned by Mr. Fletcher; steamer Indolent, owned by Mr. Rhodes; steamer Albatross, owned by J. Ruppert, Jr.; steamer Armorica, owned by Mr. Havelin; sloop Gretchen.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 7. -- The Plunger, a sub-marine torpedo boat of the Holland type designed for the United States Navy, was successfully launched at the yards of the Columbia Iron Works here to-day. The ceremonies were simple, consisting merely of the customary christening and a few impromptu speeches.

LIVERPOOL, Aug. 7. -- The Marquis Ito, the ex-President of the Japanese Council of Ministers, and Lord Kelvin, the inventor, who is to attend the annual session of the British Association for the Advancement of Science at Toronto, are among the passengers who sailed from here to-day for New York on board the Cunard Line steamer Campania.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., July 17. -- The recent scandalous episode in this town, familiar now to all newspaper readers in the United States, discloses peculiar elements in the strange mixture from which Southern California society was evolved. The almost universal sentiment here, expressed freely by both men and women, was something like this:

CHICAGO, Aug. 7. -- A combination of companies to control insurance in all the States between the Alleghany and the Rocky Mountains in all probability will result from the meeting of representatives of forty non-union companies at the Auditorium Friday. This union will have absolute supervision over the rates, forms, compensation, inter-insurance, and all matters appertaining to the indemnifying of property against fires in all the Western States excepting those beyond the Rocky Mountains.

HAVANA, Via Key West, Fla., Aug. 7. -- About 200 insurgents, under command of the local leader Vicente Jorge, recently attempted to enter the cultivation zone at Mayabon and Macagua, in the Matanzas Province, but their expedition was without important results. The same band made an attack upon and entered Coral Nuevo, a small town, and plundered several stores.

Shortly after 11 o'clock last night, the people living in the vicinity of the Tombs Prison were startled by a terrific crash. The ground trembled and the thought of an earthquake suggested itself. Men and women from all directions ran toward the Tombs to learn what had happened, and they found a large gang of laborers working under Contractors Refrano and Brown had thrown over the Centre Street wall.

NEWPORT, Aug. 7. -- The thirty-footers raced to-day over a triangular course of fifteen miles, the Vaquero, sailed by H.B. Duryea, winning by eleven seconds.
CHICAGO, Aug. 7. -- A private telegram received in Chicago to-day from Edwin Gould said:
" Seventy dollars for bicycle paths." That was one of the items in a report of the work of the "Woman's Association for Greater Saratoga" made at a meeting last week in Saratoga.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- The report on the Yukon gold region by Joseph Edward Spurs, the geological survey expert, who headed a party that made a thorough investigation in Alaska last Summer, giving new facts and figures about the interior of the territory, was made public to-day. It is a comprehensive document and reviews in detail the work in the various districts.

There was tumult there on Friday night, and a good deal of feminine shrieking and talk of burglars, the performance being assisted by two bicycle policemen and the man on post and a chorus of several hundred assorted citizens who packed themselves in the street.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 7. -- This has been the finest week of the season for outdoor pleasures. The golf links have been in constant use; there has been a great deal of driving through the woodland roads, and the young people have had much sport boating and swimming at Mahkeenac Lake. Dinners and informal dances have been given at several of the country houses.

GEORGE ROGERS BIDWELL, recently appointed Collector of the Port of New York, was born at Buffalo, N.Y., Nov. 8. 1858. His father was Charles S. Bidwell of the shipbuilding firm of Mason Bidwell, who was for many years, and until his death, a prominent figure in the business, social, and political life of Buffalo.

Too much personal curiosity was not good form, and met with many discouragements.

The news of the assassination of Senor Canovas del Castillo at Santa Aquada by the hand of an Anarchist aroused a feeling of profound consternation in the minds of prominent Spaniards in this city yesterday, and the impression that their country had suffered a calamity in his death was general.

With the setting of Saturday's sun there was an exodus of gamblers from North Beach, and yesterday not a game was to be seen at Bowery Bay, and fortunately for the 75,000 persons who spent their Sabbath at the place not a dollar was hazarded at a gaming table.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8. -- The Schiller Theatre has completed all its arrangements, and will put in a dramatic stock company for the Fall and Winter to produce new plays. It will open in September with a dramatization of Capt. Charles King's novel, "Fort Frayne." Two other plays have been accepted, and part of the company decided upon.

-- Gen. GEORGE WASHINGTON CUSTIS LEE, son of Gen. ROBERT E. LEE, has presented to Washington and Lee University, the ancient seat of learning at Lexington, Va., of which he is President, two portraits as valuable, perhaps, as any two ill America. One of them is a picture of WASHINGTON, the other of LAFAYETTE, and both are the work of the distinguished Maryland painter, CHARLES WILLSON PEALE.

Local cricketers are having a hot struggle for the championship of the New York Cricket Association. The Brooklyn, Paterson, and New Jersey second teams are all bunched in the lead, and the final resting place of the pennant is a very open question indeed.

BORDENTOWN, N.J., Aug. 8. -- James Robinson, who about a year ago was committed to the Trenton Asylum for the Insane as a homicidal maniac, late last night killed his wife, and then tried to kill himself. It is probable the attempt upon his own life will result fatally.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- The United States Government probably has already received the formal notification of the assassination of Premier Canovas, but if so, it is locked up with other dispatches in the State Department, and will not be known until Secretary Sherman reaches the department to-morrow morning.

The American investor has been a heavy buyer in Wall Street during the past week. The British investor is getting ready to buy. A curiously dull incredulity has up to the present time made the Briton an exceedingly shy purchaser. He has dabbled, he has speculated, but he has not bought to hold.

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 8. -- Percy Chubb's grand old cup defender Vigilant has added another mug to her already large collection of trophies, winning Commodore Morgan's two-thousand-dollar prize for big sloops in the long run of the New York Yacht Club cruise, which ended off the whistling buoy off Baker's Island shortly before 5 o'clock this afternoon.

The old fight between the Knights of Labor and the American Federation of Labor is being dragged into the Central Labor Union. The cause of the quarrel is a motion that was made at the previous meeting to give $50 to the organizer of the State Branch of the American Federation of Labor to carry on the work of organizing.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 7. -- The plague of mosquitoes that has been torturing New Jersey ever since the July rains has brought a flood of letters to Prof. John B. Smith, the State Entomologist, who has his laboratory ill the State Experiment Building in this city. The letter writers beg the professor to devise some means of ridding the State of the pest.

The Citizens' Union may be a large gainer of votes by what is generally thought to be a recent sharp move on the part of Tammany Hall. This will be definitely decided upon, it is supposed, when the Progressive Democratic League holds its monthly meeting next Sunday.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 8. -- Yesterday the Dauntless slipped off the Marine Railway track and took a turn in the river. She was about to go by the cutter Boutwell, but that vessel blew her four blasts by way of inquiry. The Dauntless failed to answer and the Boutwell blew again. Again no answer and a third signal was blown.

TACOMA, Aug. 8. -- A letter dated June 17 has been received from Mrs. Chester C. Adams, who went from here to Dawson City, Alaska. The writer says miners were coming into Dawson City with all the gold dust they could carry. Many were bringing 100 pounds each as the fruits of seven and eight months' working. Some men brought from 200 to 500 pounds of gold dust.

It is just the opposite of that. It is an extension of the principle of freer trade.

" Gifts, the Pope of Rome, and Stephen Merritt" was the subject of the sermon of the Rev. Dr. Frank Rogers Morse, associate pastor of Calvary Baptist Church, in West Fifty-seventh Street, yesterday morning.

The fourth and last consignment for this season of fish from Bermuda waters for exhibition in the Aquarium arrived yesterday on the steamship Orinoco. This completes the work of the biological expedition of the University of New York, which established a station at Hamilton Harbor, Bermuda, last May for the collection and study of marine life along the Gulf Stream.
The steamship La Normandie of the French Line, which arrived at her dock, Pier 42 North River, yesterday morning, brought 285 passengers. She had a comfortable and uneventful voyage.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 8. -- Although today was considered a day of rest among the strikers, most effective work among the Plum Creek miners was performed, and as a result the strikers have been assured that considerable less than 200 men will be at work to-morrow at that mine.

The fishing excursion steamer Paul Koch, which left the Battery yesterday morning with 700 passengers bound for the fishing banks was forced to anchor off Sandy Hook owing to an injury to one of her shaft bearings. She finally abandoned the trip and returned to her pier.

Daniel Kennedy, who was arrested early yesterday morning and charged with being one of the men who caused the death of Louis Bawlasek, a tailor, of 266 Avenue B, was arraigned in Yorkville Police Court and remanded to the custody of the Coroner pending an inquest.

There were many mishaps among the cyclists yesterday; some were painful, some were funny, and some will serve as warnings to be held before the eyes of the young men and young women who try to ride a mile at a two-minute pace. While the accidents were numerous none was fatal, and the scorchers were legion, but only a limited number were captured.
Mr. PRESTON, the Director of the Mint, estimates that the gold product for the current year throughout the world will reach $240,000,000.

The work of preparing the rooms of the association, at Leonard Street and Broadway, for the reception of the out-of-town merchants has practically been completed. These are spacious, easily accessible, and the association has spared no expense in making them attractive and convenient. A large book has been provided for the registration of the names, addresses, firm name, line of business, and date of last visit to New York of all the non-resident members.

The family and friends of Benjamin Dickenson of 340 West Twenty-first Street, who disappeared suddenly Friday afternoon, are now convinced that he has taken his life. For a month he had been worrying over supposed business troubles, and on the day of his disappearance left his watch, pocketbook, and keys at home, and also his glasses, without which he was unable to read.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 9. -- The Republicans of Kentucky will assemble in this city, at Music Hall, to-morrow afternoon in State convention, to adopt a platform and nominate a candidate for Clerk of the Court of Appeals.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- Assistant Secretary of State A.A. Adee, who was Secretary of Legation at Madrid in 1870, and afterward Charge d'Affaires at different periods until his transfer to this city, in 1877, was well acquainted with Senor Canovas del Castillo. He says of him: "He was an admirable, strong man; the strongest man in Spain.

The skirmish line of the army of 16,000 out-of-town merchants, who have enlisted under the banner of the Merchants' Association, reached this city yesterday morning. When the mails closed Saturday there were 15,000 enrolled non-resident members. The mails yesterday morning brought news of the enlistment of 1,000 more; and early in the day the first line of the advance guard marched into the headquarters, at Broadway and Leonard Street.

Police Commissioner Andrews has been confined to his home, 231 West One Hundred and Thirty-eighth Street, with an attack of diphtheria since last Friday. He is attended by Dr. John Brown Cook of the Board of Health.

The Brooklyns scored an easy victory from the Baltimores at Eastern Park yesterday afternoon in a game that was noted for heavy batting. It fairly rained base hits at several stages of the game, and it was one of the heaviest hitting combats played in the East this season.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9. -- George Foster Peabody of New York arrived here at 10 o'clock to-night to attend the meeting of the Executive Committee of the Sound Money Convention, appointed last January at Indianapolis. Mr. Peabody is the first of the out-of-town members to arrive, and he came without Mr. Orr, who was detained in New York by business connected with the Rapid Transit Commission.

Wall Street has never abated confidence in the belief that there have been for a long time in contemplation comprehensive plans for the rejuvenation of the anthracite coal trade. PITTSBURG, Aug. 9. -- Appeals for food were numerous at the headquarters of the miners' officials in this city to-day. The appeals are now coming in from the families, the heads of which are at the various mining camps using their influence to keep other men from working.

Foster, ex-Secretary of State and Special Seal Commissioner, who recently returned from London and St. Petersburg, arrived at the Hotel Champlain to-day from Washington, where he had been in conference with Secretary Sherman on the seal question. At 9 o'clock he went to President McKinley's apartments.

ST. PETERSBURG, Aug. 9. -- Upon the occasion yesterday of the presentation by the municipal authorities of St. Petersburg of bread and salt to the Emperor and Empress of Germany, the Chief Burgomaster expressed the joy of the inhabitants at the visit of their Majesties to Russia, and heartily welcomed them to the capital.

Ryder, issued a statement this evening calling upon the policy holders to stand by the association. -- It is all very well for The London Chronicle, in commenting on the murder of CANOVAS, to say that "mere repression of Anarchy by force is no cure," and to urge upon Spain the necessity of reform, but didn't England put her own users of dynamite and daggers safely out of the way before attempting to remedy the economic and Governmental evils that had caused their activity?

Senator Hawley sailed for Europe Wednesday on the St. Paul to join Mrs. Hawley and the children. They expect to return in September. The Senator was in Hartford a few days before sailing, but was very busy with a multitude of final errands and duties. A Courant reporter found him for a few moments one afternoon and drew an interview out of him.

All friends of good government will be glad of the opportunity to read the report that Assistant Secretary of the Navy ROOSEVELT has made to Secretary LONG concerning the administration of the New York Navy Yard, the result of which was briefly announced to have been the complete exoneration of Naval Constructor BOWLES from the charge of making political dismissals.

BERNE, Aug. 9. -- John L. Peake, the retiring United States Minister to Switzerland, handed his letters of recall to President Deucher to-day, and John G.A. Leischmann of Pittsburg, Penn., the new Minister, presented his credentials.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- It is predicted here that Spain will call for a disavowal from this country of the comments of Secretary Sherman on the financial conditions in Spain. The Secretary is quoted in the dispatches sent from here last night as saying:

Five boys escaped from the House of Refuge on Randall's Island yesterday. They are Thomas Brady of 349 East Thirty-first Street, the leader, who has tried twice before to escape, but who was captured each time; James O'Connor of 115 Monroe Street, George Davis of 331 East Thirty-first Street, William Kelly of 250 Columbia Street, Brooklyn, and John Chinney of 320 East Eighty-seventh Street.

SARATOGA, Aug. 9. -- The fact that Brighton Beach opened its second meeting today did not materially lessen the attendance at the track here. Only a small percentage of the regulars left for New York. The weather was all that could be desired, and the contests were well fought out. The card, however, which was originally a good one, was almost ruined by scratches.

An alliance is to be formed to-morrow night, at 1,188 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, to demand that the Democratic City Convention reaffirm the Chicago platform and declare for the municipal ownership and operation of certain franchises. The alliance will also boom Supreme Court Justice William J. Gaynor for Mayor.

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 9. -- A ball was given at the Malvern this evening in honor of the yachtsmen who are in port with the large squadron of the New York Yacht Club. There were a large number of dinner parties given preceding the dance, and the yachtsmen came ashore in great numbers. The dressing of the women was especially brilliant.

OTTAWA, Aug. 9. -- The Dominion Government has made application to the United States Government to be permitted to build a telegraph line from a navigable point on the Lynn Canal to Tagish, across the summit, a distance of nearly 100 miles, so that communication may be had with the interior of the Yukon all the year round.

PARIS, Aug. 9. -- The French newspapers say they do not anticipate any political complications in Spain as an outcome of the assassination of the Spanish Premier, and they do not think the Conservative Government will be displaced.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9. -- Knusi Oppen is minus a portion of his breathing apparatus since Saturday, when the physicians at the County Hospital cut out his left lung. He was treated for a gunshot wound in that organ. Pus was removed through a tube secured by safety pin, which became unfastened and slipped down into his lung.

Justice Stover, in the Supreme Court, yesterday continued a temporary injunction restraining Augustin Daly from interfering with Sir William Jardine and his cousin, William Harvey Jardine, in producing the musical comedy "The Geisha" pending the argument for a permanent injunction, which will be heard in a few days.

CAIRO, Aug. 9. -- The column of troops commanded, by Col. Hunter of the Anglo-Egyptian expedition up the Nile, which Jeft Merani on July 29, attacked Abu Hamid at 5:30 o'clock on the morning of Aug. 7, after eighteen hours' march. Some severe house-to-house fighting followed, and the place was captured by the expeditionary force.

The horrible murder of Senor CANOVAS is a notification that the spirit which produced the promiscuous murders in France, including the assassination of CARNOT, and the massacres in Spain is not extinct. It has been scotched, not killed. We ourselves have had, in GUITEAU, a typical illustration of the Anarchistic temper, which may be said to be compounded of vanity and malignity.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 9. -- The ball in honor of Admiral Sicard and his officers took place at the Casino to-night, and was a successful affair from every point of view. The expense was borne by the cottagers by popular subscriptions, $5,000 being raised for the purpose.

MADRID, Aug. 9. -- The assassination of the Prime Minister of Spain, Senor Canovas del Castillo, who was shot and killed by the Italian Anarchist whose name is believed to be Michele Angine Golli at the baths of Santa Agueda yesterday afternoon, was undoubtedly premeditated. Golli deliberated watched for an opportunity to kill the Spanish statesman, and he only fired when he had no chance of missing.

Patrick Jerome Gleason, Mayor of Long Island City and the solitary declared candidate for the honor of being the first Mayor of Greater New York, personally conducted yesterday the biggest excursion ever carried on the waters surrounding this city.

LONDON, Aug. 9. -- At Stanford Bridge today the second of the series of three races between Charles E. Kilpatrick, the American champion runner, and F.C. Bredin, the English champion, was decided in favor of Bredin. The distance was half a mile. Bredin won by three yards. His time was 1 minute 55 3/4 seconds.

VASHI'GTON, Aug. 9. -- The special xN-a,ral :loard appointed by Acting Secretary Roosevelt for the purpose of preparing for the information of Congress estimates of the cost- of establishing and operating a Government plant for the manufacture of armor met at the 'avy Department today. Before proceeding with the work of organization the members of the board called upon Acting Secretary Roosevelt and ,had a long talk with him respecting the undertaking before them.
Mayor Strong made a suggestion yesterday which, if carried out by the persons directly concerned, will provide for the metropolis a thoroughfare park in one of the most appropriate districts.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 9. -- The Salvation Army invaded Asbury Park in great force to-day. It is estimated that over 1,000 persons came down on the steamer Tauris and landed at Long Branch. There a bicycle parade was formed with about sixty wheels, all elaborately decorated in colors.

William G. Read, Jr., a popular member of the New York Stock Exchange, shot himself through the head in a toilet room in the Edison Building, at 44 Broad Street, shortly before noon yesterday. The only reason for the act which his friends assign is ill health. There was a rumor that he had recently lost heavily by speculation in Manhattan and wheat, but it was not verified.
BOSTON, Aug. 9. -- United States Senator William Lindsay of Kentucky, who was in Boston to-day, said:

Peter Jay Munro Van Cortlandt, a lineal descendant of Chief Justice Jay, a sportsman of note and a gentleman of the old school, died on Saturday at the home of Mr. Richards, in Spokane, Washington, who is President of the Trust Company there.
