His death was due to exhaustion after an attack of gout, from which trouble he had suffered for thirty years.

" I am in favor of anything," said Mayor Strong, "that will relieve the monotony of street after street without a break and that will add to the beauty without taking from the usefulness of the city's thoroughfares."

It was bargain day at Eastern Park yesterday, the Brooklyns and Baltimores playing two games, and nearly 7,000 persons took advantage of the cheap bill and saw the home team easily beaten in the first game, while a draw was the best either club could get in the second game.

At the tenth annual convention of the New York State Hotel Men's Association at the Murray Hill Hotel yesterday, E.L. Merrifield of the Continental Hotel was elected President and Simeon Ford Secretary. Fifty new members were initiated, one of whom is Mrs. E.E. Charman of Larchmont.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 10. -- The anti-fusion delegates to the Populist State Convention sprang a political coup to-day. All the arrangements for the convention had been made by a committee composed principally of fusionists, and were calculated to further the fusion plans, but the anti-fusionists discovered to-day they had a majority of the delegates.
BAR HARBOR, Aug. 10. -- Amorita won the handicap race for schooners to-day and Wasp the race for sloops. In addition to the club prize, Amorita won $200 given by Percy Chubb.
The appointment of a commission in behalf of the Sound Money Convention that met in Indianapolis last January is required by both expediency and duty.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 10. -- A crisis is approaching in the miners' movement against the New York and Cleveland Gas Coal Company. The next few days should determine whether or not the strikers' object will be realized. There was no material change in the situation to-day.

DETROIT, Aug. 10. -- To-day's proceedings before the Association for the Advancement of Science were enlivened by a criticism of Gov. Black by William H. Hale, Ph.D., of Brooklyn, before the Section of Social and Economic Science. Dr. Hale's subject was "Civil Service Reform." He said, in part:

BOSTON, Aug. 10. -- While attempting to escape from the State prison at Charlestown, just before noon to-day, Herbert Willis, a young Taunton desperado, who was recently sentenced to life imprisonment for the murder of Fred N. Strange, was fatally injured and his brother Everett, who assisted him in his break for liberty, was seriously wounded by the guards.

LONDON, Aug. 11. -- According to a dispatch to The Daily Mail from Copenhagen, Capt. Mortensen of the bark Ansgar, bound from Dublin to Ortega, at the mouth of the Ortega River, on the White Sea, reports that on July 13, when about two days' sail east of North Cape, the northernmost point of Europe, then being in arctic waters, he saw a collapsed balloon, which he believes to be Herr Andree's.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- The August report of the Statistician of the Department of Agriculture shows the following average conditions on Aug. 1:

Two burglars entered the saloon of Frank Stuttgen, 250 Ocean Avenue, Jersey City, early yesterday morning. They were heard by the proprietor, who shot one of them dead as he was apparently in the act of drawing a revolver. Stuttgen's saloon is at Ocean and Bostwick Avenues, and is called the "New Senate."

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 10. -- The Republican State Convention, held to nominate a candidate for Clerk of the Appellate Court, was called to order at 2 o'clock this afternoon. A good many colored delegates were present. United States Senator Deboe was the temporary Chairman. Judge George Denny of Lexington was the permanent Chairman.

B.M. Strauss Co. have sold, for Leopold Loewus, to John S. Ames, the three-story frame dwelling 58 East Seventy-ninth Street, on a lot 24.6 by 102.2. The buyer will remove the present structure and erect a stable on the plot.

NEW BRUNSWICK, Aug. 10. -- A.W.W. Evans of this city, a member of the New York Athletic Club and of the New Brunswick Bicycle Club, started out at 6:22 this morning to break the twenty-four-hour bicycle road record of 347 miles. The course is between Highland Park, just out of this city, and Elizabeth, a distance of twenty-five miles.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10. -- Chairman H.H. Hanna of the Executive Committee of the Indianapolis Sound Money Convention, now in session here, said to-day: "The commission to be selected to prepare a plan for the revision of the currency law will be the outgrowth of a broad-gauge movement to secure a stable currency system.

At the meeting of the Health Board yesterday, Dr. Martin, Chief Inspector of the Division of Food Inspection, Offensive Trades, and Mercantile Establishments, made a report as to the present condition of Madison Avenue from Fifty-ninth Street to Ninetieth Street, based upon complaints made during the Winter of 1896 and 1897 as to offensive odors of gas and sewage leaking into the cellars of their houses.

A few dauntless Bryanites, disgusted by the behavior of Chairman DANFORTH'S Democratic State Committee, will to-morrow organize themselves into a State Committee of the Loyal Democratic League. They will then begin an agitation to make Bryanism and the free coinage of the forty-three-cent silver dollar the leading issues of the Fall campaign.

ONEONTA, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- Three armed and masked burglars visited the hovel of Ray Green, aged sixty years, in a lonely spot three miles from here, last night, broke in the door, and demanded that he should tell where his money was hidden. When he refused they held burning brands against his feet and legs, and burned his beard, his hair, and his eyebrows.

CORNING, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- A lamp exploded in the barber shop of J. Herkin, at Greenwood, Steuben County, at 8 o'clock to-night, and by 10 o'clock all the business portion of the town except two hardware stores was burned to the ground. Two fine residences were also destroyed.

DENVER, Aug. 10. -- The announcement was made this evening that on Aug. 20 freight rates between Colorado and Utah points and the Atlantic coast would be so adjusted that the war carried on between the Morgan, Mallory and Lone Star Steamship Lines will have no effect on freight rates.

The Park Row Construction Company, of which William M. Ivins and F.J. Fredericks are President and Treasurer, respectively, has mortgaged the property known as 13 to 21 Park Row, 13 Ann Street, and extending through the block to Theatre Alley, to the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States for $2,250,000.
Stock market stronger.

The second day's session of the commission appointed to decide upon the practicability of the proposed rapid transit railroad route was taken up by the testimony of William B. Parsons, Chief Engineer for the Rapid Transit Commission, and Alexander E. Orr, President of the commission.

SARATOGA, Aug. 10. -- Cloudy weather this morning kept many at their hotels who otherwise would have gone to the track, and the result was the attendance was light. The sport was interesting, and in most cases high class. One of the attrac tions to-day was the race for the Citizens' Stakes, for three-year-olds and upward, at a mile and a quarter.

BELMONT, Mass., Aug. 10. -- Henry F. Marcy, President of the Fitchburg Railroad, was found dead in the bathroom at his home here to-day. His death was due to apoplexy. He had been in failing health for some time.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 10. -- A sudden and violent storm swept over this city about 11:30 to-day, and within fifty minutes more than two inches of rain fell. The wind did much damage. The Passaic River was swollen to great proportions, and at one time threatened to invade the low-lying streets.

BOSTON, Aug. 10. -- Years ago there sailed out of New London, Conn., a fleet of vessels which engaged almost exclusively in the search for sea elephants. This species of the seal family, the largest of the procidae, is found in the Southern Atlantic and Indian Oceans and about the desolate and uninhabited islands far south of the Cape of Good Hope.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10. -- Prof. A. De Senarders arrived at the Auditorium Annex Hotel to-day from Liege, Belgium. He at once made inquiries for Dr. Younger, who, he says, is the only man in the world who can make the teeth that will exactly fit and suit a Princess. Her name, as nearly as could be learned from the broken English of the professor, is the Princess Banjel.

-- Sunday was blessed with a clear sky and a gentle wind, so the yachtsmen as well as the amateur sailors pulled up their anchors and made the run to Bar Harbor. It must have been a terrible experience, however, for some of the gallant Captains when they found themselves eighty miles at sea, in real deep water, and with no excursion steamers or Summer hotels anywhere in sight.

Under the tax laws of this State the Assessors, when they have completed their roll, are obliged to make oath that in their appraisals of real estate they have estimated the value "at the sums which a majority of the Assessors have decided to be the full and true value thereof and at which they would appraise the same in payment of a just debt due from a solvent debtor."

The naivete with which Senator HAWLEY of Connecticut allowed a reporter of his own paper to catch him the other day and "draw an interview out of him" is only equaled by the simplicity with which he described the tremendous difficulties met by the framers of the Dingley tariff.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- President McKinley to-day visited the Cliff Haven Catholic Summer school, the grounds of which adjoin the Hotel Champlain. The President was accompanied by the Vice President, Secretary Porter, and Gen. E. C. O'Brien. They drove to the grounds at 11 A.M. A large arch of evergreens and golden rod had been erected at the entrance of Champlain Avenue, and the road was well decorated with the National colors.

The second day of the visit of out-of-town merchants proved even a greater surprise and a source of greater satisfaction to the association than the first day. Many more of the visitors registered at the headquarters yesterday than on Monday, and far more of them reached the city and plunged into the real business of their visit, the purchasing of goods.

DETROIT, Aug. 10. -- William McLean, a collector for the Grand Trunk Railway, has begun suit against Joseph M. Bresler, former Chief Consul of the Michigan branch of the League of American Wheelmen, for $50,000, for alleged alienation of Mrs. McLean's affections. Bresler was arrested to-day on a civil process, and gave $10,000 bail.

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 10. -- To-night will be remembered on Mount Desert Island as one of the gayest in its history. What with the illuminations of the harbor and fleet, innumerable private dinners, and the grad Domino ball at the Kebo Valley Club, society had plenty to keep it busy to-night.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 10. -- Interest in the twenty-fifth annual regatta of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen, which will be held on the Schuylkill River course next Friday and Saturday, was heightened to-day by the arrival of E.H. Ten Eyck, the winner of the Diamond Sculls at Henley.

The form players rounded into shape at Brighton Beach yesterday by picking the winners of five of the seven races. One of their selections, which went through, was Concord, who has tried hard for two seasons to win a race. The wonder of the day's racing was that, after so many failures in equally poor company, Col. Ruppert should at last win. He did so cleverly in the opening race.

The capture of ABU HAMID is a most important step in the British occupation of the Soudan. It would perhaps be better to call it the British civilization of North Africa. The expedition of Lord WOLSELEY was the result of a national effusion of resentment over the death of GORDON.

Who would think that a little bird could cause such consternation that people would be invited to come and see it from far and near? I was passing through the village when one of the natives, who knew that I was studying birds, asked if I wouldn't go up and see what kind of a bird it was.

One effect of the sensible and energetic policy of the Merchants' Association which, perhaps, had not been fully foreseen is that the merchants of New York are both learning and teaching some things about the trade of the country, and of particular sections, that formerly were not known or known rather vaguely.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 11. -- A check for $25, drawn on the Ohio National Bank of Washington in favor of Hugo Preyer of Cleveland, an ardent middle-of-the-road Populist, dated Aug. 9, and signed by Charles Dick, Secretary of the Republican National Committee and accredited manager for M.A. Hanna, was exhibited at the Populist State Convention to-day as evidence to prove that Mr. Hanna bought up some sentiment in favor of a separate Populist State ticket.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- Acting Secretary of the Navy Theodore Roosevelt makes public to-day the approval of the department of the report made by Commander C.H. Davis of his recent investigation of the New York Navy Yard, which follows the lines of the report made in May by Mr. Roosevelt of his investigations of the same allegations -- that Naval Constructor Bowles had practiced discrimination in making dismissals from the working force of the yard.

There is no question that the world is very well rid of the man MORRIS, who does not seem ever to have made any better use of his brains than when he blew them out on Tuesday. The newspapers have contained of late some particularly bitter doses for those who desired to think well of their kind.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11. -- Larned and Eaves played to a draw to-day in the only match in which an English expert was pitted against an American. The affair was called on account of darkness, after each had secured a set. In the other matches, "Bob" Wrenn won two straight sets from Collins, the Western champion, and Nisbet showed a bit of his Longwood form by winning two out of three from Mahony.

SAGINAW, Mich., Aug. 11. -- About 150 miners of the Saginaw Coal Company struck to-day for a raise of 15 cents per ton. The strike was started by thirty-five miners, who came here from Ohio last week and were given work.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- The Secretary of the Treasury to-day issued the following circular, providing for the enforcement of the provisions of the Executive order of July 27, 1897, as to removals from the classified service:
LONDON, Aug. 11. -- The Right Henry B. Whipple, Bishop of Minnesota, who has been in attendance upon the Lambeth Conference, has written the following views of the conference:

Mora out-of-town merchants reached the city yesterday than on the two previous days of the excursion rates. About 100 registered at headquarters, while more than 200 others were reported as arriving. It is now estimated that at least 4,000 persons have already come to New York as the result of the low rates obtained by the Merchants' Association.

The work of straightening the track and reducing the grade at Tabbs station on the second division of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad was completed on Monday afternoon and the first train to use the new line was the New York and St. Louis flyer. A heavy grade and three bad curves have been eliminated.

There is evidently need in this country of much more extensive instruction in the rudiments of civilization. According to BURKE, the very first principle of civilization is that a man shall not be Judge in his own case. A West Virginian, whose wife had run away with another man, erected himself into a Judge of the case, sentenced the other man to death, and endeavored to execute the sentence.

Vice President Clarence A. Henriques of the Brooklyn Bridge Trustees has announced a scheme to make use of the waste space under the Bridge arches on the Brooklyn side of the river. His idea is to build free swimming baths on the property, and by connecting pipes with the power house under the bridge pump water from the East River.

ST. PETERSBURG, Aug. 11. -- At 11 this morning their imperial Majesties of Russia and Germany started on board the Russian imperial yacht Alexander for Cronstadt Roads, where Emperor William and Empress Augusta Victoria were to re-embark upon the German imperial yacht Hohenzollern.

Commissioner Andrews was not able to attend the meeting of the Police Board yesterday morning, being still confined to his house by diphtheria. He sent word that he was much better, but that he would not be able to go out for several days.

The proposition to establish small parks on the unsightly asphalt triangles at the junction of Broadway and Seventh Avenue has met with general approval. Residents of the section to be benefited by the improvement are enthusiastic about the matter, and preparations were begun yesterday for a house-to-house canvass for signatures to a petition for presentation to the Board of Estimate and Apportionment.

The three games which the New York State Chess Association ordered Steinitz and Lipschutz to play to determine the possession for a year of the Challenge Cup of the association, the contest over which was tied at the Thousand Islands meeting, were subject to the following agreement, which was served on all parties:

ROANOKE, Va., Aug. 11. -- The Democratic State Convention was called to order at noon to-day in the Academy of Music. As Chairman of the State Committee, J. Taylor Ellyson, is a candidate for Governor, it was called to order by Gen. George J. Hundley. The convention may last two days. The declaration in the platform for silver and other Chicago planks will be unequivocal.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Aug. 11. -- There is great excitement at Coxsackie over the discovery of an apparently inexhaustible mine of gold right under the noses of the villagers. In excavating for the new Welsh icehouse just below the village, workmen uncovered rock with a vein of yellow metal in it. Mr. Welsh took specimens up to the village and the inhabitants pronounced the yellow metal gold.

The instant hearty response made to the suggestion that a foliage park be created in the asphalt waste of Long Acre is a good augury for the comfort and happiness of the people of this city. It shows that both public officers and private citizens give hospitable welcome to any proper and sensible project for beautifying the streets and open spaces.

CAIRO, Aug. 11. -- Official dispatches from Assouan, on the Nile, near the First Cataract, give details of the capture of Abu Hamed on Aug. 7, by the Anglo-Egyptian troops under Col. Hunter, after on eighteen hours' march from Merawi.

Mr. Russell Sage authorized yesterday the publication in THE NEW YORK TIMES of the following statement of his position upon the stock market, and more especially his position touching what in Wall Street are popularly recognized as Gould-Sage stocks -- Mr. Sage being now outspokenly bullish, though the gossips of the Street have been trying to make it appear that his views are bearish:

Chief Engineer William B. Parsons was the only witness yesterday afternoon before the special commission appointed by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court to determine whether the plan proposed by the Board of Rapid Transit Commissioners shall be adopted by the city and the tunnel constructed without waiting to gain consent of property owners along the route.

VICTORIA, B.C., Aug. 11 -- The steamer Topeka, which arrived here last evening, reports that the Pacific Coast Steamship Company's steamer Mexico, on Aug. 5 at 4:30 A.M., while going into Dixon entrance from Sitka in a heavy fog, struck West Devil's Rock. After two hours the steamer sank in 500 feet of water, stern first.

The Baltimores won two games from the Brooklyns at Eastern Park yesterday afternoon. The champions played in championship form, while the Brooklyns only played two alleged baseball games. It must have been monotonous for the 6,000 persons, including a number of ladies, who witnessed the double bill, to see an almost steady procession of Baltimore players making a circuit of the bases.

Senator Stewart of Nevada is one of the latest convents to commercial optimism. He is a "bull" on everything except silver. He is engaged in a vigorous campaign in Wall Street, and said yesterday that he had heard so much about better times that he has determined to "gather in a part of the prosperity which is not only rampant in the Street, but throughout the land."

Mr. W.J. BRYAN is going to Mexico to study the silver question in a country where silver is the standard money and full legal tender. Mr. BRYAN is said to be studying the Spanish language, hoping to be able to make a speech to the Mexicans on the subject of silver.

The response of Dean WAYLAND of Yale, a member of the corporation of Brown University, of the manifesto of the younger members of the Faculty of that institution, is forcible and pertinent. The members of the Faculty who presumably do not sympathize with the protest which they have failed to sign might very well, in the interest of the institution, mark their dissent more emphatically.

It is only at rare intervals that every favorite on a day's racing programme wins, but such was the case at Brighton Beach yesterday, and when the seventh race was over the bookmakers wended their way from the track with wry faces and depleted bankrolls, while the followers of form were happy because they had more of the bookmakers' money in their pocketbooks than they have carried away for a long time.

A hearing was given by the State Railroad Commissioners in the Aldermanic Chamber, City Hall, yesterday on the petitions of the Second Avenue Railroad Company, a leased line of the Metropolitan Traction Company, and the Forty-second Street, Manhattanville and St. Nicholas Avenue Company of the Third Avenue system for changes of motive power.

SEVEN RIVERS, N.M., Aug. 11. -- Recently at a neighborhood dance eight prominent young people went through a mock marriage ceremony. An hour later it developed that the man who performed the rites was a Justice of the Peace, and to make the contract binding the next day he filed the certificates of marriage with the County Clerk.

The sharp criticism of GOV. BLACK before the Association for the Advancement of Science by WILLIAM H. HALE, Ph. D., of Brooklyn, will probably confirm the Governor in his well-known animosity to the scholar in politics. The criticism was clearly scientific, since it was a logical generalization from known facts in accordance with established laws.

SARATOGA N.Y., Aug. 11. -- A heavy rainfall last night converted the track into almost a quagmire, and this state of affairs was responsible for a light attendance at the races to-day. The programme was good one, and the sport was exciting.

MARSEILLES, Aug. 11. -- Prince Henry of Orleans has arrived here on his return from Abyssinia. His seconds -- M. Leontieff, a Russian officer, and M. Raoul Mourichon, a traveling companion -- will meet in Paris the seconds of Gen. Albertone, the Italian officer who has challenged the Prince to fight a duel on account of the latter's strictures upon the conduct of the Italian soldiers in Abyssinia.

CHICAGO, Ill., Aug. 11. -- Camp Harrison of the Associated Cycling Clubs, which will open at Winnetka next Saturday night at 8 o'clock, will be the first and only wheelmen's camp ever held in America.

DYEA, Alaska, Aug. 4,. via Seattle, Washington, Aug. 11. -- The British steamers Islander and Gees have arrived with about 500 prospectors, which increases the number on the Dyea and Skaguay trails to fully 1,500. Later reports have come in to the effect that the Skaguay route is open to the lakes and that it is about forty-five miles long.

Louis E. Rossie, paying teller of the Bedford Bank in Brooklyn, was arrested yesterday on a warrant charging him with the embezzlement of about $6,250. Previous to his arrest he made full confession to Eugene G. Blackford, President of the bank, and afterward gave signed statement to the same effect to Lawyer Wheeler of the American Surety Company, which is on his bond.

Twenty-five representatives of the Commercial Travelers' Club of New York and the Commercial Travelers' Sound-Money League of America called on Col. Frederick D. Grant last night, at his home, 25 East Sixty-second Street to announce that they would make a concerted effort to have him appointed Minister to China by the President.

The effort in some quarters to make it appear that the fight between Senator Platt and Jacob Worth will result in the Kings County leader bolting the City Convention this Fall, and thereby precipitating the Republican Party in Greater New York into a state of chaos, is looked upon by Republican leaders in this city and in Brooklyn as the political chaff of the hour.

It is very much to be hoped that the adoption by the Park Commissioners of the modified designs for the Botanical Garden in Bronx Park will not be accepted as a finality. In form, of course, the decision was final, but there is altogether too much at stake to allow a formality to prevail.

Nearly 500 first and second class cabin passengers arrived on the steamship Teutonic yesterday morning from Liverpool. The trip was made in good weather and lasted five days eighteen hours and two minutes. When the Teutonic was docked a small army of notables marched across the gang planks to fall into the arms of the customs officials.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 12. -- The police of this city arrested a man at the Market Street Station in this city to-night and took him to the Third Precinct Police Station. The man refused to say anything about himself, and gave the name of John Doe. It was rumored that the prisoner was wanted in Philadelphia for a twenty-thousand-dollar gold robbery.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12. -- The Illinois Trust and Savings Bank to-day turned over $2,000,000 to the Glucose Trust, whose representatives met here. These funds are for use in pushing the business. The decision dissolving Mr. Harding's injunction against the trust resulted in this meeting.

The men at work on the foundations of the new twentystory Empire Building, at Rctor Street and Broadway, and the Washington Life ]3uilding, at, Liberty Street and Broadway, have reached bed rock, and are about to start laying the iron and concrete foundations proper. They found bed rock at Rector Street at 60 feet below the street level and 35 feet below water level, and at Liberty Street 80 feet below the street level.

SEATTLE, Washington, Aug. 12. -- Despite the warnings sent out that men already at Dyea and Skaguay are unable to get across the pass, and that only few of the men there will get to the mines this year, several hundred men are in waiting at Victoria to take passage for the north on the steamer Bristol, and all of the accommodations on the Islander, which sails on Monday, have been taken up.

SARATOGA, Aug. 12. -- "Lawn Day" at the race track brought out a large and fashionable crowd, with everybody, including jockeys, attendants, and race-track employes, in gala dress. Details of the racing are as follows:

Our esteemed contemporary The Sun is deeply touched and grieved because our other esteemed contemporaries which it calls the "originators of the yellow school of journalism" are promoting the candidacy of Mr. Low. That, says The Sun, with its tongue, as usual, in both cheeks, settles it: "Mr. Low's candidacy has been made impossible."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- The Attorney General has rendered an opinion to the effect that the Secretary of the Treasury may annul for cause the contract with Gen. Daniel Butterfield of New York, doing business as "The Brooklyn Annex," for the Ellis Island immigration station and the Barge Office, New York Harbor.

LONDON, Aug. 12. -- Dispatches received here from Vienna show that the Austro-Hungarian Government is intensely indignant at the utterances of M. Stoiloff, the Bulgarian Premier, and at the latter's refusal to apologize for them. The Pesther Lloyd, in an inspired article, says:
Two highwaymen fired on A.L. Jordan, a wealthy resident of Yonkers, with revolvers after having unsuccessfully attempted to stop him in Van Cortlandt Park early yesterday morning.
CHICAGO, Aug. 12. -- For a few moments this afternoon it looked as though there would be no Trilby to die in the last act at Hopkins's Theatre.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 12. -- The Oyster Bay Democratic Town Committee has unanimously adopted resolutions, denouncing the increased assessed valuations in the town. The assessed valuation of the real property of Queens County for the year 1896 was $82,872,661, and that of the Town of Oyster Bay, as equalized, was $6, 303,329.

One of the most prominent silver leaders was asked the other day if it was not highly desirable that the Tammany Democrats should indorse and reaffirm the Chicago platform in their convention this year. "What difference does it make?" he replied. "They are not for silver anyway."

The manufacture of "shoddy" is one of the new industries that is fostered, and may be said to have been created by the new tariff. Shoddy is sometimes euphemistically termed "artificial wool." Whenever there is a heavy duty on genuine wool or on foreign made carpets and other woolen stuffs "shoddy" flourishes.

Interviews with Washington business men indicate that President McKinley's latest order amending the civil service regulations is generally accepted as a step forward toward the improvement of the Government service and the betterment of local conditions.

DENVER, Aug. 12. -- Railroad men are greatly interested in the discovery, which is alleged to have been made at La Junta, Col., that the Santa Fe Railroad Company is shipping coal to Eastern points in refrigerator cars. According to the report, four refrigerator cars were side-tracked at La Junta for repairs.

NEWPORT, Aug. 12. -- The following yachts arrived here to-day: Steamer Conqueror, owned by F.W. Vanderbilt; steamer Hermione, owned by Mr. Thomas; steamer May, owned by Mrs. J.V. Fell; steamer Haleyon, owned by H.C. Smith; steamer Seneca, owned by Mr. Comstock; steamer Stranger, owned by Mr. Lewis; steamer Satanella, owned by E.W. Bliss; sloop Thistle, owned by Mr. Ford; sloop Ladona, owned by W.B. Wood; sloop Choctaw, owned by M. Strong.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12. -- Suit in assumpsit was begun to-day by the Indianapolis, Anderson and Marion Railway Company against the Fidelity and Deposit Company of Maryland and Louis Enricht, Cook County Surveyor, in which the plaintiff company asks $40,000. The defendant Enricht, the plaintiff says, contracted to build a street railway for it.

Before the first meeting at Brighton Beach opened, owners and trainers were loud in their complaints about the smallness of the purses hung up by the racing associations. The Brighton Beach Racing Association at the second meeting, which opened on Monday, accordingly started out to give seven races each day, so that owners and trainers could have a better chance to earn money.

Readers of THE TIMES'S financial page are already abundantly aware that Mr. RUSSELL SAGE is satisfied with the recent course of Manhattan in the stock market. But we regret to observe in yesterday's interview a trace of acerbity inconsistent with the previous complacent and benevolent utterances of the good man.

TROY, Aug. 12. -- Gov. Black has concluded his vacation in the Adlrondacks and returned to Troy yesterday afternoon. This afternoon he left for Bluff Point to consult with President McKinley in relation to the latter's visit to Troy on Friday, Aug. 20, to attend the reunion or the Society or the Army of the Potomac.

Charles Sanger Mellen will, on Sept. 1, begin his duties as President of the Northern Pacific Railway Company, and have for associate as Vice President Col. Daniel S. Lament, ex-Secretary of War. President Edwin W. Winter, who tendered his resignation last Spring, will retire Aug. 31.

The indications in Westchester County Are that there will be much less resistance to the increased assessments of property for taxation than has been expected, and that the action of the Town Assessors there may bring important changes in the system of assessment and in the tax laws throughout the State of New York.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12. -- The August number of The Rand-McNally Banker's Monthly contains an article by James H. Eckels, Controller of the Currency, on "Bank Consolidations,'' in which he expresses himself unhesitatingly in favor of the tendency toward consolidation which has been developing during the past six months.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12. -- Speaking of the 10 per cent. discriminating tariff clause, Collector Russell said to-day: "American importers who have patronized Canadian railroads because they were given lower freight rates will be compelled to ship over American lines, and the railroads will reap the benefit.

At the offices of Louis F. Haffen, Commissioner of Street Improvements for the Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth Wards, at Third and Tremont Avenues, bids for the paving of Jerome Avenue were opened at 11 o'clock yesterday morning. The remodeling of three sections only of the thoroughfare was offered for bids, and the paving of their aggregate length will cost the city $136,505, exclusive of engineers' fees,
PARIS, Aug. 12. -- The following semi-official communication has been issued:

The New Yorks and Bostons played two games at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon, and the Bostons cleared the boards in both games, and 15,000 loyal supporters of the Giants filed through the gates when night was just setting in, muttering threats against the umpire, and saying uncomplimentary things about Park Wilson and "Cy" Seymour, who were the chief offenders in the downfall of the Giants.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12. -- Edward H. Ten Eyck, who recently defeated Blackstaffe at Henly and brought the diamond sculls to this country will not compete in the national regatta, to be held on the Schuylkill River to-morrow and Saturday. His father came to this positive determination this afternoon.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12. -- September wheat today reached the best price of the year, selling at 84 1/2c. The pit was badly congested at the opening, and September was bid up from 81 5/8c to 84c in the first five minutes on light trading. A reaction followed to 82 5/8c, and then, principally on the advance at Paris, the market broadened perceptibly and scored the top price of the day.

Jefferson de Angelis denies emphatically that Lillian Russell intends leaving the triding Day." This denial was caused by by a report circulated in the theatre district yesterday that the singer had sent a letter to the managers of the company resigning from the cast.
The Gates estate has sold to a Air. Aeyer, or about $10,500, the property 717 East ,qinth Street, a brick '.ble on a plot 25 y 93.

The statistics of exports of principal articles for the seven months ending July 31 have just been published by the Bureau of Statistics. They make a better showing for the Port of New York than previous statements, and indicate that this city is getting a distinctly larger share of the increasing trade.

V;ere it not for the'vexatious question of bloomers the success of the women's expedition to leave New York in March next for the Klondike gold fields would be guaranteed. Mrs. Sarah Wright McDaunold will "personally conduct" the .brave venture. In the prospectus, among the suggestions for personal equipment arc "bloomers, $10 each."

JACK FISH, Ontario, Aug. 12. -- Senator Mark A. Hanna and the party of pleasure-seekers accompanying him on a cruise of the great lakes had a thrilling experience to-day on the wild northern coast of Lake Superior Their yacht, the Comanche, a stanch steel vessel, went aground in Nipigon Straits and stuck fast in the rocks that abound in that region for sixteen hours.
Four persons were badly bruised ill a trolley car accident on tile Bcnsonhurst division of the Brooklyn Heights Railroad Company yesterday morning.

September wheat made a new high record, 90 5/8c, at the Produce Exchange yesterday. This quotation was 2 1/2c higher than the closing price of Wednesday, then the new high record of the season. Prior to this 86c, reached on Aug. 4, was "top notch."

Officers of the Good Roads Association of Hudson County are preparing a circular which will be distributed next weel throughout the county, asking that the control of the Hudson County Boulevard be taken from the Board of Freeholders and vested in a commission of prominent citizens to be appointed by a Justice of the Supreme Court of ew Jersey.

SEATTLE, Washington, Aug. 12. -- It will require an inquiry by the Government Inspector of Hulls, Capt. J.W. Bryant, to determine the facts in regard to the wrecking of the steamer Mexico, at the entrance of Dixon's Sound. It is said that the rock which was the cause of the wreck is West Devil Rock, and that it is shown on the charts.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 12. -- A bill for an injunction against the United Mine Workers was filed in the County Court to-day by counsel for the New York and Cleveland Gas Coal Company. The defendants named are the United Mine Workers of America, Patrick Dolan, President; Edward McKay, Vice President; William Warner, Secretary and Treasurer, and others.

More visiting merchants registered at the Merchants' Association headquarters yesterday than on any of the three previous days. Among them are men from South Carolina, Minnesota, and Idaho, besides the usual quota from Texas, Arkansas, and the Central West.

All homeless cats and dogs are cordially invited to the side yard of Mrs. Mary B. Paillard's home, at 341 West Forty-fifth Street, at any time after dark, and partake of a liberal free lunch. This consists of stewed calves' liver, cut in small fragments, and for side dishes calves' lungs on calves' heart treated in the same manner.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12. -- The American tennis experts scored a clean sweep against their English rivals to-day, capturing every one of the three matches played in the Wyandotte invitation tourney. The victories were by no means easy, but that fact only added to the enthusiasm. Larned lowered the colors of Nesbit, and Mahony and "Bob" Wrenn defeated Eaves.

Postmaster Van Cott has received a letter from James Keating, charging that his brother, Roundsman Michael C. Keating of the King's Bridge Station, who was found dead in Delafield Woods one year ago today, by a mushroom gatherer named Ropetti, who informed Sergt. Hatton as he was passing, was murdered.
ROANOKE, Va., Aug. 12. -- The Democratic State Convention completed its State ticket to-day by the nomination of a candidate for Attorney General. The full ticket is as follows:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- Commissioner Powderly of the Immigration Bureau has rent the following letter of instructions to Immigration officials at New York, Boston, Philadelphia, Baltimore, and Quebec, Canada, relative to the anticipated arrival in this country of Spanish Anarchists:

Commissioner Collis of the Department of Public Works said yesterday he was opposed to the establishment of oases on the triangles of Long Acre, and that they will never be laid out there with his consent. He said the plans made and approved provide for the use of those triangles as platforms where persons awaiting cars may find shelter from the rush of traffic.

Two big cycle racing meets, both possessing many attractions, are offered for this afternoon within the metropolitan district. A National Circuit meet will be held under the management of the Atalanta Wheelmen on the Waverly Park track, Newark, and the third-mile amateur National championship is one of the events of a strong card.

An amusing question came up for decision before the United States General Appraisers last Saturday. It was whether "sprats" are sardines. This question involved the broader one as to what are "sprats," "shaddines," "pilchards," "brislings," and other queer fishy things that are now playing so conspicuous a part under the new tariff.

The Giants turned on the Bostons yesterday at the Polo Grounds and gave them an over-quantity of their own medicine. The local team went at the leaders from the start, and had them whipped before they were fully aware they were factors in a baseball game, to the delight of nearly 6,000 adherents, whose enthusiasm was not damped by the team's poor showing of the previous day.
PITTSBURG, Aug. 13. -- The first bloodshed during the coal miners' strike resulted from an encounter between Deputy Sheriffs and strikers, about 5 o'clock this morning, near Plum Creek tipple.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 13. -- President Dole and his coterie of sugar-planter advisers were pretty thoroughly exposed by the exclusive publication in THE NEW YORK TIMES of the interview with Minister Cooper relative to annexation and Asiatic labor. That interview was suppressed in Honolulu because the Hawaiian Government feared to have its real purposes and hopes known to the public.

Three horses from as many different stables, but all owned, or trained, or in some way connected with the chief promoter of the Association of Nervous Friars were starters in the Speculative Stakes for two-year-olds at Brighton Beach yesterday, and between them they had things pretty much their own way.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13. -- Selling to secure profits caused a setback in the grain markets to-day. Wheat, for September, closed 1 5/8c lower. The cash demand fell off perceptibly and cables failed to respond to yesterday's advance here.

MADRID, Aug. 13. -- The funeral of Senor Canovas del Castillo to-day was a most touching and solemn ceremony. All the troops of the garrison lined the route along which the cortege moved; the flags were lowered and the public buildings, embassies, Consulates, and clubs were heavily draped with crepe.

Patrolman Matthew D. Hefferon of the Tenderloin Precinct, who was appointed on the police force in 1892, had twice in his five years' service given up his shield in order to resign. Intervention of friends each time saved him from the consequence of the act. Yesterday he made his retirement from the force irrevocable by firing a bullet through his brain.

WHITESTONE, L.I., Aug. 13. -- Dr. Edward Griffin and his wife of this place celebrated their golden wedding at the home of their son, Dr. A.C. Griffin, last night. Dr. Griffin married Mary Moore in 1847 in the Friends' Meeting House in Schenectady County. Mrs. A.C. Griffin's parents celebrated their golden wedding in October, 1895.

The course of Walter B. Atterbury, now an avowed Willis man, in coming out yesterday in a statement repudiating Seth Low for the Mayoralty nomination and calling him a free trader, is likely before the campaign is over to prove a boomerang.

Justice Conlan, in the City Court, yesterday granted an order appointing John Burt, Jr., of 50 Broadway, referee, to take testimony and report concerning the charges made by J. Bronson Ker, an attorney, of 132 Nassau Street, against William Stainton, who is accused of acting in collusion with the legal department of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company in the settlement of a damage suit against the road.

The experienced observer of politics in Massachusetts who writes for The Evening Post under the signature of "London" reports a very strong feeling in that State for the formation of a new party, the fundamental principles of which shall be sound currency and a tariff for revenue only.

NEWPORT, Aug. 13. -- The Vaquero III, again won the race of thirty-footers to-day against a field of seven starters. There was a strong southwest wind, affording a quick race. The start was made at 3:16. The Esperanza led until the windward work began, when the Vaquero III, showed her heels to all the fleet.

A case of smuggling was detected yesterday when the Fuerst Bismarck arrived against a man who looked anything but a smuggler, and the discovery astonished even the customs officials, used as they are to attempts of this kind by persons in all walks of life.

READING, Penn., Aug. 13. -- The Summer meeting of the Reading Trotting Association opened to-day with a large attendance. In the second heat of the first race a collision occurred, in which W.H. Grant of Trenton, driver el Erie, was thrown, but escaped with slight injuries. W.B. Biggs of Middletown, Del., driver of May, was dragged some distance, and had a miraculous escape.

The dispatch from San Francisco which we printed yesterday and that which we print to-day are very important contributions to our knowledge of the motives and workings of the scheme for Hawaiian annexation. They bring us very close to the true inwardness of the job. At least they exhibit the Hawaiian end of it.

The West Side branch of the Young Men's Christian Association, at 318 West Fifty-seventh Street, which has nearly completed its first year's work, is making large plans for the coming Fall and Winter. The splendidly equipped building opened in November last at an expenditure of $540,000 is admirably adapted to the needs of the large number of young men in that section of the city, for whom the branch was established.

NEWPORT, Aug. 13. -- The seventeenth annual championship tournament of the United States National Lawn Tennis Association will begin at the Newport Casino next Tuesday. There are sixty-two entries, which is six more than last year. The best-known players of America and England are on the list, which is as follows:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- The dispatch in to-day's TIMES from San Francisco about the reluctance of the Dole Republicans of Hawaii to surrender the advantage of imported contract labor as the price of annexation to the United States, has been read by State Department officers with interest, but none of them, from the Secretary down, will talk about it.

The steamer Campania of the Cunard Line arrived yesterday, with one of the largest passenger lists of the season. There were 246 first cabin, 296 second cabin, and 391 steerage passengers. A large crowd assembled at Pier 40, North River, to see the liner dock, and to catch a glimpse of two notables on board, each of international fame, though of widely different spheres of activity.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 13. -- Col. W.R. Kerr says the erection of fortifications at Key West, the key to the Florida straits and to the entrance of the Gulf of Mexico, is a direct result of the recent Spanish war talk. The fortifications are being pushed to a state that will afford some degree of protection, though the plans of the War Department will not be fully carried out at present.

The result of the excursions of Southern and Western buyers, who have been attracted to this city through the efforts of the Merchants' Association, is being felt already in a large increase in trade. The visitors are making extensive purchases everywhere. They are calling upon the local dealers and discussing prices and buying their Fall and Winter stocks.

There never was a charge more baseless and malicious than that Christianity dwarfed and narrowed human life. In its most perverted forms, in the hands of the most selfish and depraved men, Christianity has been a force for enfranchising human life. Guizot has shown us that even in the most corrupt ages of Romanism it never wholly lost this effect upon the masses of men.
HOLLYWOOD, N.J., Aug. 13. -- There was another big crowd at the Monmouth County horse show to-day, and fully as much interest was shown as on the initial day. The judging by classes was as follows:

There was considerable excitement in East Harlem yesterday morning over the non-arrival of the steamer Guide, which had started for College Point Thursday evening on a moonlight excursion with the members and friends of the Alpine Social Club of 433 East One Hundred and Twenty-third Street aboard.
SARATOGA, Aug. 13. -- To-day's racing card was made up of over-night events. The track was in poor condition. Details of the racing follow:

READING, PENN., Aug. 13. -- Without doubt silver will be the war cry of the Democratic Party in the political campaign in Pennsylvania this Fall. The Harrity m n will be in the minority in the State Convention held in this city Aug. 13, and they will propose a compromise ticket and platform, with a silver man for Auditor General and a gold man for State Treasurer.

" I sighed as a lover. I obeyed as a son." How often has not that phrase been repeated and Gibbon held in lower esteem for the utterance of it! But then, the whole sentence should be read to its close: "My wound was insensibly healed by time, absence, and the habits of my new life, and my cure was accelerated by a faithful report of the tranquillity and cheerfulness of the lady herself."

A test swim from Coney Island to Sandy Hook Lightship yesterday may have resulted in the death of the swimmer and two men who accompanied him in a boat. At least they have not reached their destination, and whether they are somewhere out at sea or on board a friendly boat was not known.

The predicted reaction in the wheat market came about yesterday. Taking the extreme range of prices for September, contract wheat, the quotations varied to the extent of 2 1/4 cents, while the net loss of the day's trading was 1 5/8 cents. The market was top-heavy on Thursday, and the quotation had run beyond the limits of export trading.

The social event in Chinatown to-day will be a dinner given by Robert Mitchell Floyd to Prof. Charles G.D. Roberts at the restaurant of Me Hong Low, which is beneath the fashionable Joss house at 14 Mott Street. Tun Farr, who is of B.L. Wing Co., 10 Bowery, is involved in the affair in some curious Oriental way.

PARIS, July 26. -- The recent exhibition of portraits at the Ecole des Beaux-Arts drew the attention of Parisians to the superiority in many respects of Reynolds, Gainsborough, Lawrence, and the English school to many of the great French portraitists, Nattier, Greuze, and others, who had formerly received most honor in their own country.

The recent observations of QUIGG would be of grave import if they were made by the boss himself. Mr. PLATT has the power to make good all of his threats and most of his promises. He will control the Republican City Convention. There is some loose talk about shaking him off, but it will come to nothing.
The United States Board of General Appraisers has prepared its Fall docket for 1897. Hearings will be commenced Aug. 31 and will continue through to Oct. 6.

A south-bound cable car crashed into and everturned a Harlem Hospital ambulance at 6 o'clock last night on Third Avenue, between One Hundred and Twenty-fourth and One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Streets. Dr. Armstrong, who was in charge of the ambulance; his assistant, Dr. C.F. Bulson, who is connected with the hospital corps, but lives at 242 West One Hundred and Thirty-fifth Street, and the driver, Peter Stander, were hurled from the ambulance and badly injured.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Aug. 13. -- Residents of this place are protesting against a reduction in the cost of shipping goods to this place by freight. This state of affairs is probably not equaled anywhere else in this country.

The collision which occurred yesterday near Pittsburg was trifling in itself. It is noteworthy, however as the first departure from the rule of obedience to law which has thus far been observed by the strikers. Technically the proceeding may have amounted to a riot, but the good sense of the strikers prevented it from becoming a riot in the ordinary use of the word.

The approaching substitution of motor power for horses as a means of traction in several of the principal streets of the city suggests some interesting speculation. That increased facility of travel will result, might go without saying, were it not that New Yorkers have so long seemed to be blind to what every small city in the country has known from experience for a long time.

Senator STEWART announces with the fervor of the female Micawber that he will never, never abandon the "unlimited coinage of silver by the United States independently of any other nation and at the ratio of 16 to 1." He looks confidently to see that cause triumph, and very shortly.

J. Clarence Davies Co. have sold for Henry Lewis Morris, to the Warren-Scharfe Asphalt Paving Company, a plot of about twenty-five lots on the east side of the Harlem River, commencing 100 feet south of One Hundred and Fiftieth Street, and having a depth of 500 feet, and a frontage of 160 feet on the river.

RAHWAY, Aug. 9. -- The City of Rahway will soon possess the largest dome in the East. It is to be erected over the New Jersey State Reformatory. The dome will be 120 feet in diameter, and will be sustained by solid brick walls four feet thick. Springing from the top of these walls, seventy feet above the ground, the dome will rise sixty feet further, making a total height of 130 feet.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13. -- A new alliance between the Amateur Athletic Union and the League of American Wheelmen has just been signed and will go into effect at once.

The compressed air workers who struck at the caissons of the new East River Bridge were still out yesterday, and held a meeting at Delancey and Mangin Streets. A committee was sent to Contractor Flynn to ask him again whether he would pay the wages they demanded, but he refused.

The mystery of the disappearance of Benjamin Dickenson, who left his home at 340 West Twenty-first Street, Aug. 6, was cleared up yesterday by the identification of his body at Norwalk, Conn. The body of a drowned man with his throat cut was found floating in the bay off Norwalk, and was buried Wednesday without being identified.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13. -- The first day's races in the Silver Jubilee regatta of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen were rowed to-day over the National course on the Schuylkill River, in Fairmount Park. To-day's events consisted of trials in intermediate singles, senior four shells, intermediate singles, senior singles, international four shell, and the final and only heat in the intermediate eights.

Devoid of images, the temple was full of worshippers. In our churches we ordinarily see only women, as if the worship they render there were not a virile religion, but were framed only for them and for their sons prior to the adult age. There were no women here -- these pray in the neighboring oratories -- but there were men, 2,000 men.
The report that Democrats of influence in the councils of the party are seeking to persuade Mr. J. EDWARD SIMMONS to accept the nomination for Mayor of Greater New York is a good sign.
"' Senor! senor!" cried Diego, between a sob and a shout, "culebra!"

On Monday 734,410 shares dealt in, on Tuesday 524,345, on Wednesday 635,221, on Thursday 758,221, on Friday 550,926, on Saturday 275,267. This is the New York Stock Exchange record for the week -- a total of 3,478,390 shares. Coincidentally, the smaller Exchange of Wall Street -- the Consolidated -- has had transactions averaging 100,000 shares per day.

" It doesn't seem to me that the young doctors have the get up and go that I had when I started in," declared the old practitioner who had just been requested to take a chair in the Faculty of a new college of medicine. "I started in a little town without money or friends, and I was not long in getting all the business in my line that was to be done.

The diplomatic strain, even coming so near to a rupture, between Austria and Bulgaria is not in itself or in its probable political consequences a very important matter. It may serve to indicate to us, however, how very touchy European States are upon even the unofficial remarks of officials one about the other.

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 14. -- The weekly handicap golf tournament on the Kebo Valley links this morning was won by George T. Newhall, the Philadelphia Country Club crack, who went over the eighteen-hole course with a gross score of 84 strokes, equalling the bogie score of the Kebo links. He started 10 strokes behind scratch.

An illuminated banner with a picture of a man with whiskers and a legend proclaiming "Richard W. Croker, a fit and proper man to be Mayor of Greater New York" was swung out amid some enthusiasm yesterday in the heart of the Sixth Assembly District of this city, which is a stronghold of Tammany Hall.

NEWPORT, Ky., Aug. 14. -- An alleged "ringer" was run at Newport to-day, and all bets on the race he appeared in are held back pending an investigation by the judges. The horse is Waban, a chestnut colt, four years old, by Sir Joseph-Hulda, and was entered in the name of Spragg and Lydy. Waban won the second race under a pull, beating the heavily backed favorite, Whyota, and several others.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 14. -- The information is obtained at the office of the Chief Inspector of Grain that the wheat of Minnesota and North and South Dakota would run 30,000,000 bushels short of expectations. The inspection department, which two weeks ago thought the crops of the three States would be at least 180,000,000 bushels, now places it at 130,000,000.

ON the 9th of April, 1839, an eighteen-year-old boy having crossed the Irish sea from Kingston to Liverpool, wrote to his mother in the town of Trim, County Meath, Ireland: "I preserve as good courage now as I had on leaving Kingston, and I will, I hope, until I arrive at that goal for which my heart so ardently glows."

TANNERSVILLE. N.Y., Aug. 14. -- Three boys, Walter Arden, living in Cincinnati, Ohio, and Frank and Willie Renwick of New York, who were spending their vacation with some relatives near East Jewett, had an adventure on Round Top Mountain a couple of days ago. The summit of Round Top is a corona of almost perpendicular cliffs, in some places over a hundred feet in height.

The Giants were again successful against the Bostons at the Polo Grounds yesterday, and 17,000 persons saw a game that was close and interesting and replete with brilliant fielding. Capt. Joyce was taking no chances, and sent Rusie in to pitch. The big fellow was in good form, and would undoubtedly have shut out the Bostons had it not been for something that happened in the seventh inning.
SARATOGA, Aug. 14. -- If there is one thing that Saratoga illustrates it is the delight people the world over have in "taking something.'"

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- Although yellow fever is more widely prevalent throughout the islands of West Indies generally this year than usual, not a single case has yet reached the shores of the United States. Cases of yellow fever have reached our quarantine stations on the Southern Atlantic and Gulf coast, and also on the Pacific coast, but in every instance the infected persons have been stopped there.

BOMBAY, Aug. 14. -- There is general military activity in India in view of the concentration of strong reserves of troops on the northwest frontier. Detachments of troops from distant cantonments are moving northwestward, and the railroads are kept busy transporting soldiers toward the scene of the threatened troubles.

In no other country is the devotion to duty so evident as among the serious, law-adoring Prussians. While affairs move slowly, they move surely, and it can be depended upon that everything needful will be done and that no mistakes will be made. Every department of the City Government exhibits thoroughness and honesty.

THE Fall coaching season promises to be a brilliant one so far as Long Island is concerned. Already a number of long-distance trips have been arranged by several of the most expert drivers of four-in-hand equipages. As a never-falling source of outdoor enjoyment and as a medium for expert and artistic handling of the "ribbons," coaching remains the most fancied sport of the wealthy folk who make their Summer homes on Long Island.

The New York Yacht Club cruise was hardly the success the yachtsmen had hoped it would be. Two things -- the fickle wind and the Regatta Committee -- caused trouble from the time the yachts reached the rendezvous at Glen Cove until the fleet disbanded at Bar Harbor. The weather, of course, had to be taken as it came, and the Regatta Committee -- well, they had to be taken as they were.

LONDON, Aug. 14. -- The Post Office officials here are deeply interested in the experiments in telegraphy made by Prof. Crehore of Dartmouth College and Lieut. Squier of the Military School of Fort Monroe, who claim that their device enables messages to be transmitted with extraordinary rapidity. The inventors said to a representative of The Associated Press:

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 14. -- A woman who gave the police the name of Mary Anderson is under arrest here for selling forged railroad mileage books. She and a well-dressed man arrived in the city Thursday and registered at the American House as R.H. Lucas and wife of Pittsburg. She sold three Baltimore and Ohio one-thousand-mile books to as many brokers yesterday.

GALVAY, N. Y., Aug. 14. -- The forty-eighth anniversary of P.H. Meehan's appointment as Postmaster at Galway was celebrated today by the citizens of the place, who presented Mr. Meehan and his wife with handsome tokens of their appreciation of long and satisfactory service.

There seems to be a disposition in some quarters to belittle the importance of the currency reform movement, as represented by the Executive Committee of the Indianapolis conference of January last, and to create the impression that the Administration is not in sympathy with it. No well-informed person can hold this view, and no Republican paper can entertain it without being out of party line.

A Chinese dinner of twelve courses was served yesterday afternoon in honor of Prof. Charles G.D. Roberts, the Canadian novelist and poet, who is one of the founders of the Canadian Club of this city. Col. Robert Mitchell Floyd was the host.

Two of the Bald-Cooper-Kiser triumvirate rode in the National Circuit Meet, held under the auspices of the Atalanta Wheelmen on the two-lap track of Waverly Park, yesterday, and formed the chief attraction on a card of hotly contested races for which crack professionals from all over the country and the speediest of the American amateurs had entered.

Alcohol clearly predisposes to criminality by lowering and paralyzing the higher brain centres which preside over consciousness of right and wrong. The imme ate effect of spirits is to cause impulsive, petty acts. For the present moment such acts might materialize into serious crime, but it would depend upon favorable conditions and surroundings.

Gen. COLLIS is evidently intent upon poulticing with asphalt all the open spaces within his jurisdiction. His belief in asphalt as a cosmetic was most powerfully shown when he proposed to slice off the lower end of Central Park and make a nice level place where the militia could drill and citizens gasp in the sun.

A memorial service in honor of the murdered Premier of Spain, Don Antonio Canovas del Castillo, will be held in the Church of St. Vincent de Paul, Twenty-third Street, near Sixth Avenue, at 11 o'clock Wednesday. The service will be under the auspices of the Junta Patriotica Espanola, representing the Spanish residents of New York.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 14. -- As William Pehrick Perry, a wealthy Summer resident of Tivoli, was driving last Wednesday with his coachman out of the Bard place, at Annandale, the horses took fright and started to run away. The men were in a high dogcart. Mr. Perry took the reins from his coachman.

NEWPORT, Aug. 14. -- The ball given at the Casino Monday night was a grand affair. It would be a hard task to describe the pretty little theatre on that night and do it credit. Over 1,500 hydrangeas and 3,000 American Beauty roses were used in the decorations, besides palms and bay trees.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 14. -- Despite the orders of the miners' officials, the campers at Sandy Creek and Turtle Creek attempted to march on the mines this morning, but the deputies were on the alert, and both bodies were forced to break ranks and return to their camps.

The theatrical season of 1897-8 will be ushered in to-morrow evening with the reopening of Daly's Theatre and the revival of "The Circus Girl." The theatre has been closed for a few weeks, just long enough to give the players a much-needed rest. The theatre, it will be remembered, closed with "The Circus Girl," and in the reproduction of this play the cast will be practically the same as it was in June.
The night dress of Bessie Jackson, who lived in an apartment at 136 West Thirty-third Street, caught fire early yesterday morning.

IN the low-ceiled living room of a small thatch-roofed cottage standing on the border of a Suffolk heath a woman sat alone by the side of a wood fire, which gave out the only light that relieved the gathering gloom of a Winter's night.

From Monday to Friday inclusive the daily transactions on the Stock Exchange averaged over 635,000 shares. On no day did they fall below half a million, and on Monday and Thursday they were over 750,000 and 740,000 respectively. The transactions in bonds were on a similar scale. If this record is not without precedent on the Exchange, it is nearly so.

The man who invented the expression "passionate press agent" had a very pretty fancy. The theatrical press agent is, indeed, a person of passionate ambition, but he is not always fertile in expedient. He proceeds on the theory that newspaper men are the most gullible of human creatures, and he is apparently justified in his belief by the actions of some of them.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14. -- The featureless trial events of yesterday's silver jubilee regatta of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen were more than compensated for to-day by the finals, nearly all of which were close and rowed in good style. The local rowing clubs won four out of the eight events pulled off.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- The first stage robbery ever reported in the Yellowstone National Park occurred to-day. Col. Young announced it to the Secretary of the Interior in the following telegram:

The laudable effort to revive interest in the class of racing which was popular in this country when racing was a sport pure and simple, and was indulged in unselfishly by wealthy men, has not met with the assistance of the latter-day trainers. The idea was conceived by Secretary Sass of the Brighton Beach Racing Association, and the first of the series of long-distance races at a mile and a half was decided yesterday.

In the recent discussion that has been had by conservative Democrats in reference to a Mayoralty candidate, there has been considerable talk about President J. Edward Simmons of the Fourth National Bank as a possible candidate.

One day we were at luncheon, although it was 6:15 P.M., when a lady was announced and ushered in at once. She was apparently an old friend of the family, and she opened fire without losing a moment. "I am so glad, M. Ralli, that you are Prime Minister of Greece, and my George, won't he be delighted, too! You remember him, don't you? He is at the front, you know, working wonders.

That indefinite period known as the height of the season is by all precedent reached at the leading Summer resorts, with the exception of Newport, Southampton, and possibly Bar Harbor, this morning. It seems almost a mockery to speak of the height of a season that has hardly thus far developed even the slightest characteristics of a real season.

LONDON, July 31. -- "That is all very well for an American," said one of my London friends. "You Americans can get whatever you want in England. But I should like to see an everyday Londoner get one of these."

In the wake of the excitement incidental to the week of the great Philadelphia meet has followed a comparative calm. Even the customary casualty and death list for the East has been satisfactorily small. The meet was a huge success; enthusiasm was the order; everybody gazed, took impressions, and went home to talk it over.

The American Line steamship Paris, which was sighted off Fire Island at 11:55 Friday night, made quick time coming up from Quarantine, and reached her dock at 7:50 o'clock yesterday morning. Nearly all the cabins were filled, and a very pleasant voyage was reported.

Sea lion hunting was the popular sport of many men and boys along the East River from Eightieth Street to Astoria Ferry all day yesterday. It was a peculiar hunt, take it all in all, because the majority of the hunters had only a hazy idea of a sea lion at best. This was indicated by the choice of weapons, which ranged from a hook and line to a small brass cannon.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 14. -- There was an interesting foursome match at the golf links this week, an eighteen-hole handicap. Miss Nellie Barnes, Miss Curtiss, Nelson Robinson, Jr., S. Parkman Shaw, S. Howland Robbins, J.W. Burden, H. Godwin, and D.W. Bishop, Jr., were among the players. The prizes, silver cups, presented by Warren E. Dennis, were won by David W. Bishop, Jr., and Joseph W. Burden, who were scratch players.

The wheat market yesterday was dull, broad, and very strong. Its strength was best seen in the extreme range of September contract wheat, which was within a, one-cent limit, and the leading future closed with a net advance of 1 1/4 cents.

IN the western part of New York State, near the crest of the watershed between the St. Lawrence and the Mississippi, and embosomed amid beautifully rounded hills, lies Chautauqua Lake, the most elevated navigable body of water in the United States.

BOSTON, Aug. 14. -- Within a very short time, by the 1st of September it is expected, Boston's much-talked-of subway will be in partial operation. The completion of the work will not only call attention to a feat of engineering exceedingly expensive -- for the subway represents an outlay of over $5,000,000 -- but difficult as well, for its course has been laid through the business portion of the two principal streets, Tremont and Washington.

Young Mr. ATTERBURY has discovered with comical surprise that Mr. LOW is "not a Republican; he is a free trader." As a Mayor of New York Mr. LOW will have nothing to do with levying or collecting taxes on imports, or with interpreting the tariff law. His views on these subjects have no more to do with his qualifications for the Mayor's office than his views on co-education or vivisection.

NEWPORT, Aug. 14. -- The new polo field at the Country Club was used for the first time to-day, when the Westchester team defeated the Myopias by a score of 8 1/2 to 5 goals. The Myopias were outplayed at all points, their opponents being better mounted and more accurate in their drives the Waterbury boys in particular doing some very brilliant work.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Aug. 14. -- Henry Nygreen, the Swede, an assistant keeper of the lighthouse at Whale Rock, was brought ashore in irons by Officer Champlin this forenoon and placed under restraint. His examination will take place on Monday.

OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 14. -- The influences that have had a tendency to place Nebraska in the public eye all point to a season of returning prosperity. The traveler to-day, whose vision is confronted by fields of waving corn and herds of sleek-looking cattle, is apt to call it the garden spot of America.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., Aug. 14. -- Time was when the farmers of Middlesex and Monmouth Counties assembled at Spring Lake every Aug. 15, or on the Saturday before, when, as this year, that date fell on a Sunday, with their wives and families, and disported themselves in the salt water. Then they came dressed in their best and usually that best was of the vintage of years before.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- Attorney General McKenna to-day gave a hearing to those interested in the question involved in Section 22 of the new tariff act. Some days ago the Secretary of the Treasury received information from the Collector of Customs at Chicago that a large invoice of teas and other goods from Japan had been received at that port over a Canadian railroad.

When William J. Donegan entered his flat, at 1,808 Second Avenue, about 9 o'clock last night, he was happy. He hadn't had steady employment for some time, and last week the little savings had begun to show signs of disappearing entirely. There had been no real want in the house, there were only two mouths to fill, and now and then he got an odd job.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 14. -- Fifty or more burglaries have been committed in New London and vicinity during the month without a single arrest being made. The latest case reported is that of the Hotel Mohican, the new hotel belonging to Frank A. Munsey, the publisher.
That disagreeable joke about St. Swithin's Day has had a great run in the newspapers this year. St. Swithin's Day is June 15, and the old rhyme says:

Albert Bial, formerly President of the Koster Bial corporation, died yesterday afternoon, at his home, 134 West Forty-eighth Street. He had been ill since February with nervous prostration, brought on by overwork while traveling through Europe last year in search of attractions for the music hall.

BOSTON, Aug. 14. -- The Democratic State Committee has issued its call for the State Convention to he held at Worcester Sept. 28. In it the "Democrats of Massachusetts and all others who voted for the Democratic candidate for President last November, and all voters who intend to support the candidates nominated and the principles adopted at the State Convention hereby called, are requested to send delegates."

HE vast business ever accumulating in the First Judicial District lays a heavy hand on all the Justices in its borders. As Is well known, the Appellate DiViSiOn from time to time has drafted able Judges from the various judicial districts of the State to hold Equity Terms in the First District.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, July 26. -- It was a remarkable, and withal rather weird, scene that met my eye as I reached the "Revival Balm" station of Mother Ackinson, in search of which I had been wandering in the tracks of an uncertain black urchin guide among the far mountain fastnesses of the parish of Westmoreland.

BERLIN, Aug. 14. -- During the coming week the Emperor will attend the naval exercises near Dantzic. He will witness the unveiling of a monument to his grandfather at Magdeburg on Aug. 25, and will attend the dedication of a colossal monument at Coblentz, at the confluence of the Moselle and the Rhine, on Aug. 30.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 14. -- English capitalists are willing to build the Pittsburg and Lake Erie Canal, which has been surveyed and declared a feasible route to the lakes. John E. Shaw, Secretary of the Canal Commission, admitted that the rumor was true to-day and said the commission had authorized the printing of 5,000 reports of 300 pages each, with 100 illustrations.

Let us trace the cost of carrying a sack of coffee, which weighs about one-sixteenth of a ton, from the plantation on which it is grown to the seaboard. As the best coffee grows at not less than 3,000 feet above sea level, it must go an average of about eighty miles on muleback before reaching the river; this means $8.50 paper for the mule.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- Everybody in Washington who is at all interested in the civil service, which means a great many thousands of persons, besides those in Government places, is reading The Congressional Record of Wednesday, Aug. 11. The Record did not cease publication with the adjournment of the Congress, but continues to emerge at irregular intervals, with speeches alleged to have been delivered at different dates.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 14. -- Twelve hundred tons of coal dropping suddenly upon iron steam pipes plunged this city into darkness to-night, and Paterson does not know herself All the evening teams of horses have been hard at work clearing the streets of stalled trolley cars, and merchants have been besieging the grocery and crockery stores for lamps and oil.

LONDON, Aug. 14. -- The Prince and Princess of Wales are attending the musical festival at Baireuth this week as Lord and Lady Renfrew. Among the others present are the Grand Duke of Hesse, Ladies Lonsdale and Battersea, and A.J. Balfour. The performances of 1897 have been characterized by the presence and influence of many of London's smart set.

THE NEW YORK TIMES pointed out at the beginning of the present year that '97 was but a transposition of '79, and suggested that a resemblance more pronounced might be found in the forthcoming months. How far this forecast has proved correct it is not necessary to mention. The months have rolled around and the resemblance to 1879 has grown into a likeness, and the likeness into an identity.
Jealousy was the cause of a serious stabbing affray between two butchers yesterday afternoon which will probably result in murder.

CLOQUET, Minn., Aug. 14. -- There is not a section on the Duluth and Winnipeg Railroad that is kept in better condition than No. 5. This plain assertion carries nothing of importance to the general public, but when taken in connection with the fact that this particular six miles of road is under the direct supervision of a woman, there is really something remarkable in the statement.

IS the gold coming from the Klondike altogether unexpected? In "The Story Of The Mine," published by the Messrs. Appleton last year, Charles Howard Shinn presaged the discovery of gold there. He wrote of the American prospector as busy "revealing new treasures in the Islands of Unga and Unalaska, in camps along the Yukon, in the south coast Alaskan gold fields, in the British Columbian districts, such as Cassiar, Caribou, and Rossland."
HOLLYWOOD, N.J., Aug. 14. -- Fully 5,000 persons assembled in the park this afternoon to witness the last day's exhibits at the Monmouth County Horse Show.

PARIS, Aug. 3. -- President Faure may very likely be accused of high treason on his return from the meridional fetes in which he has been reveling for the past few days. He has been charged already with so many other crimes that are much more serious that his peace of mind will probably not be greatly disturbed in consequence.

One of the most characteristic as well as interesting features about golf this season has been its wide popularity in our leading Summer resorts. Attention has been drawn to this fact recently in view of the big open tournaments which the more pretentious of these rural clubs are arranging to give at the close of the season.

Notwithstanding the favorable weather, the attendance at the Creedmoor shooting was much smaller yesterday than on the preceding Saturday. Still, more than 300 soldiers put in an appearance, and practiced faithfully all day. High scores were the exception rather than the rule, both at the marksmen's and at the sharpshooters' ranges, owing to the strong breeze that blew all day in the wrong direction.
The essential purpose of the Citizens' Union was stated with great clearness and simplicity in its "Declaration of Principles" at the time the Organization was undertaken. It is as follows:

BERLIN, Aug. 14. -- From Duke John Albrecht of Mecklenburg, who has just visited Prince Bismarck, it is learned that the Prince disapproves of Emperor William's visit to the Czar, and its accompanying features, as calculated to arouse hopes in the Russian mind which Germany, later, may be unable to fulfill, especially in the matter of further Asiatic conquests.

LONDON, Aug. 14. -- It is hardly possible that clear-headed Frenchmen can attach any serious importance to those fairy realms of hazy Bourbon finance called Ethiopian equatorial provinces, of which M. Leontieff, Prince Henri's companion, is so triumphantly proclaimed by the grace of King Menelek the future Governor.
