BOSTON, Aug. 14. -- Eddie McDuffee this afternoon rode in Charles River Park the fastest mile ever ridden by a bicyclist, his official time being 1:38 1-5. The previous record was 1:39 1-5, made by Hamilton at Denver last year.

SOME eighty miles from New York eastward down the Long Island shore, and only a few miles west of the eastern end of that sandy island, Montauk Point, between the ocean beach on the south and the still waters of Peconic Bay on the north, lies the village of Southampton.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Aug. 14. -- D.C. O'Malley, proprietor of The Item, was shot by ex-Recorder Edwards Whitaker, this evening. The paper recently published some severe articles about Whitaker, and when he approached O'Malley this evening to ask redress, the latter struck him with a cane. Whitaker drew a revolver and began shooting.

AMERICAN CANOE ASSOCIATION CAMP, Grindstone Island, Thousand Islands, Aug. 14. -- The eighteenth annual meet of the canoe men is now about half over. The site of the camp is the same that was occupied last year, but many improvements have been made for the comfort and convenience of the members.

There was sadness throughout Coney Island last night because of Capt. Davis Dalton, the life saver and professional swimmer, who started from the iron pier on Friday morning, saying that he intended to swim to Sandy Hook Lightship, fourteen miles away. He returned yesterday morning to West Brighton with the two men who had accompanied him in a rowboat, and reported a desperate struggle of thirty hours with the deep and deadly sea.

TAMPA, Fla., Aug. 14. -- Some of the mill-men engaged in rafting lumber here narrate a very unique and peculiar battle that occurred on a timber tow at the mouth of Little Manatee River recently, in which a huge tarpon, weighing 200 pounds or more, had a set-to with two men on the raft.

TAMPA, Fla., Aug. 14. -- Mrs. P.J. Minnick, living a mile or so down the Hillsborough River, has a flock of Pekin ducks she takes great pride in. A few weeks ago, while standing on the bank and watching some of them feeding near by, she was no little astonished to see one of them disappear under the water, quacking loudly and making every endeavor to escape from an unseen foe.

It is known to only a few people that the Devil once had a daughter -- that was many years ago. The Lord be praised, she lived only a short time. She was cut off in her youth. She came to this world in the guise of a graceful kitten, and I, Mr. Thomas Katgut, was destined to have my fate intermingled with hers.

The religious world has recently been interested by the report of a plan for the re-establishment of Palestine as a Jewish State at the hands of certain German leaders. The notices appearing in the newspapers of the United States have reflected the opinions of individuals, but in vain have readers looked for a statement of the full scope of the project and the problem which is to be solved.
William E. De Verna, maker of theatrical properties, died yesterday at his home, at Sixty-fifth Street and Third Avenue, Bay Ridge, of acute gastritis.

It is known to only a few people that the Devil once had a daughter -- that was many years ago. The Lord be praised, she lived only a short time. She was cut off in her youth. She came to this world in the guise of a graceful kitten, and I, Mr. Thomas Katgut, was destined to have my fate intermingled with hers.

The religious world has recently been interested by the report of a plan for the re-establishment of Palestine as a Jewish State at the hands of certain German leaders. The notices appearing in the newspapers of the United States have reflected the opinions of individuals, but in vain have readers looked for a statement of the full scope of the project and the problem which is to be solved.
William E. De Verna, maker of theatrical properties, died yesterday at his home, at Sixty-fifth Street and Third Avenue, Bay Ridge, of acute gastritis.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 15. -- This was one of the most exciting days in the history of surf bathing at this place. There was a tremendous crowd on the beach, and more than 20,000 bathers entered the surf between 8 o'clock this morning and 8 this evening. Fully 120,000 visitors arrived here during the day and last night.
The Progressive Democratic League held its usual shindy yesterday afternoon at Flannery Hall, at Hudson and Leroy Streets.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 15. -- Mrs. W.L. Scruggs, wife of the ex-Minister to Venezuela, yesterday afternoon, mistaking the vestibule door opening to the car steps for the entrance to the toilet, stepped off a moving train near Chattanooga, and sustained injuries which will probably result in her death.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 15. -- The latest news from Dyea and Skaguay comes from Harry Hunt, one of The Chronicle's men in the North. Under date of Skaguay Bay, Aug. 7, he says: "The price to-night over Chilkoot Pass to Lake Linderman is 35 cents a pound. At the rate it has increased of late, it will be 50 cents before a week, and packers hard to get at that.

BLUFF POINT, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- President McKinley, Vice President Hobart and Mrs. Hobart, Mrs. Alger, and Master Hobart comprised the Presidential party which attended services at Trinity Episcopal Church this morning. The President attended Trinity Church on the invitation of the Rev. Hobart Cooke, the rector, and John M. Wever.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Aug. 15. -- The regulations formulated by the Dominion Government covering the collection of a royalty on gold mined in the Yukon are published in the Official Gazette, issued yesterday. They are as follows:

READING, Penn., Aug. 15. -- Under the direction of J.H. Brown, the American inventor, the United States Government is building at the Reading Scott Iron Works a ten-inch wire gun which marks another era in the development and advance in war implements, Congress made an appropriation last year for the construction of this gun.

The two "royal" youngsters really fought yesterday, and no one can accuse them of getting up a theatric show or of dodging the consequence of their mutual long-talk. It turned out that the Italian was the better swordsman. That does not prove that the Italians were courageous in Abyssinia or that the Frenchman who said they were cowardly said what was not so.

The Bostons and Baltimores are making an interesting struggle for the pennant of 1897. Last week the champions did not look like very formidable opponents, but three victories out of five games played in Brooklyn and three consecutive victories in Philadelphia have enabled them to pass Cincinnati and get within dangerously close range of the Bostons, who won four of the seven games with New York last week.

PARIS, Aug. 15. -- The Count of Turin and Prince Henri of Orleans fought a duel with swords at 5 o'clock this morning in the Bois de Marechaux at Vancresson. M. de Leontieff acted as umpire. The fighting was most determined, and lasted twenty-six minutes.

Dogs die and some dogs reform, but there are always dogs that bay the moon. Notwithstanding the fearful backsliding of STEWART and JONES from the silver slopes of Nevada into the maelstrom of avarice, therefore, we shall expect to hear the howl of the Populist smite the busy air for some time to come.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Aug. 15. -- Habeas corpus proceedings have been instituted by John Tazwell against the Brothers of Nazareth, whom he charges with abducting his wife, Linda Tazwell, his eighteen-year-old daughter, Gladia E., and his son, Littleton L., aged six. John Tazwell lives near Millbrook, and was formerly Superintendent of G. Howard Davison's stock farm.

MONTICELLO, Aug. 15. -- Ira Simms and John Honziger of White Lake were drowned in Black Lake last night at 10 o'clock, while rowing. Martin Sprague, who was with them, swam ashore. The bodies were recovered to-day.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- Not until after the Attorney General of the United States has given to the Treasury Department his opinion of the meaning of the Dingley tariff law touching the importation of goods in bond through a contiguous country will the people to be affected by it really appreciate the force of a few lines of legislation enacted by the Conference Committee of the last session of Congress.

-----An interesting person of the once gentler sex has been moved to tell the Advancers of Science, assembled at Detroit, that wealthy people are cutting into profits of professional writers by contributing gratuitous articles to magazines and newspapers, and that this is a wicked practice and ought to be stopped.

Dr. E.C. Spitzka was asked yesterday what had been accomplished in the fields of medicine and science through the medium of vivisection. He replied that very little of what is now done for the relief of disease and scarcely anything of what is done for the maintenance of public health would be possible but for the vivisection operations of the past.
The campaign of education in the practical application of the Dingley tariff was resumed yesterday on two steamship piers.

The clubs which form the New York Cricket Association are having a great struggle this season for the pennant of that organization. The Brooklyn Club now leads by the smallest possible margin, while Paterson and the second team of the New Jersey Athletic Club are tied for second place.

The Citizens' Committee of Fifty will meet at the Academy of Music, Brooklyn, to-morrow evening to take steps to promote the candidacy of Seth Low for the Mayoralty of Greater New York. The committee will formally organize and the first movements made will be to ascertain the sentiment of the Republican leaders in every election district in the city and from now on to work untiringly for the support of Mr. Low.

In the presence of nearly 5,000 persons, and assisted by a number of priests and acolytes, Archbishop Corrigan yesterday blessed the new chimes of St. Patrick's Cathedral. The ceremonies were solemn and impressive.

ROME, Aug. 15. -- The news of the result of the duel has been received here with the greatest enthusiasm. Crowds fill the streets, cheering for the Count of Turin and the army, and calling upon the bands in the public square to play the Royal Hymn.

TACOMA, Washington, Aug. 15. -- Nearly every Klondiker leaving Tacoma provides himself with a copy of the Bible and Shakespeare. Booksellers here say their supply of these books has been entirely exhausted during the last two weeks, and orders for a larger stock have been placed by telegraph. Twelve miners from Missouri who bought their outfits here yesterday took with them eight copies of the Bible and twelve copies of Shakespeare.

In obedience to the orders of Immigration Commissioner Fitchie of this port, the immigration Inspectors yesterday made special search among the cabin and steerage passengers of La Bretagne for Palanas and Tarrida Marmol, Spanish Anarchists, who have been ordered to leave Europe since the assassination of Canovas and are expected here.

FLUSHING, L.I., Aug. 15. -- About 8 o'clock this morning three young men brought a fourth to the hospital and left him there, saying he had been hurt. The man they left was unconscious. The physicians could at first find no injury, but later found a bullet wound in his side, which indicated the bullet had entered the intestines.

The police made an effort yesterday to see that the Raines law was observed to the letter, and consequently adventures of an undesired nature befell those who came under their suspicion. In the arrests of the day there were many incidents of interest. Policemen Breen and McMann of the Morrisania Station employed a tramp to aid them in their work.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 15. -- Late this afternoon an employe of the Metropole Hotel, at 299 Market Street, was attracted to a room on the second floor by a peculiar odor. He tried the door and found it locked. He then got a ladder, and climbing up and looking over the transom, saw the dead body of a man lying on the floor.

The Merchants' Association will start the work of the second week of excursions by sending out to-day 35,000 copies of a new circular directing attention to the second series of reduced rates for merchants coming to New York. These rates are placed in effect in the Trunk Line Association's territory.

VICTORIA, B.C., Aug. 15. -- There were in Victoria this morning close upon 1,000 men, of every class and from every part of the world, who were wildly anxious to get started on the long trip to the new Eldorado. These men had tickets which will carry them to Skagway Bay on the big collier Bristol or on the steamer Islander, both of which sailed to-day.

One of the most thrilling scenes ever witnessed on the Greenville shore of New York Bay occurred yesterday morning near the Greenville Yacht Club house, at the foot of Linden Avenue, Jersey City. Shortly after 9 o'clock Miss Lillian Roeder and her brother Charles left their home on Linden Avenue, near Ocean Avenue, to go crabbing in the bay.

The following is a comparison of the average of bullion in the principal European banks last week and at the corresponding date a year ago. These figures are received weekly by cable by The Commercial and Financial Chronicle:
The Bureau of Statistics publishes this morning the figures, corrected to Saturday, of the exports and imports for the seven months ending July 31 in the years 1896 and 1897.

If the remaining seven days of the Brighton meeting remain as clear as the days of last week, and the racing continues to be as high class as it has been up to date, the management will be amply repaid for its big outlay of money in fitting up the track, and in offering larger purses than the other racing associations.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 15. -- A leaden sky and fitful showers contributed to the feeling of depression which existed at the miners' camps at Turtle and Plum Creeks to-day. The men huddled together for shelter under the commissary tents. The spirit of aggressiveness has largely died out. Sunday has usually been devoted to missionary work among the working miners.

We print in another column a criticism of THE TIMES by that excellent Republican newspaper, The Post-Express of Rochester. We have no complaint to make of it, though it is far from just. The Post-Express has lately done such good work in criticising the mischievous measures and men of its own party that a tilt against an independent judgment of the pet measure of that party may strengthen it with its purely partisan readers.

ALBANY, Aug. 16. -- John, the five-year-old son of Michael J. Conway, the night train dispatcher, was abducted while playing in front of his house on Colonie Street, about 8 o'clock this morning. Two hours later a letter was handed to Mrs. Conway, in which it was stated that unless $3,000 was sent to the abductors and the utmost secrecy maintained the child would be killed the same as Charlie Ross.

Golfing has been rather dull on the links of the Dyker Meadow Golf Club, Brooklyn, during the past month, but the Fall activity will be started to-morrow with the August monthly handicap. A number of the members will compete in the matches at the Norwood Field Club, near Long Branch, later in the week.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16. -- Commercial travelers in the territory west of Chicago are likely to secure soon a long-fought-for concession from the Western roads in the form of a 1,000-mile interchangeable ticket, good over twenty-eight railway systems.

The Special Commissioners appointed by the Supreme Court -- John Sabine Smith, Gorge W. Young, and Arthur Williams -- to pass upon the practicability of the rapid transit plan met yesterday afternoon. Albert B. Boardman, counsel to the commission, introduced in evidence one map about 15 feet long, and twenty-five small ones.

HAZLETON, Penn., Aug. 16. -- Matters at the Lehigh and Wilkesbarre collieries in the Honey Brook district are growing serious. Thirty-five drivers went out on Saturday for an increase in wages. This morning 2,500 miner joined them. The Italians and Hungarians, who were the last to go out, are the most aggressive, and fears are entertained that they cannot be controlled.
September contract wheat touched a new Produce Exchange high-record mark yesterday -- 92 1/4 cents, 3 cents higher than the closing price of Saturday, 89 1/4 cents.

WALKERTON, Ind., Aug. 16. -- A bold attempt was made at this place last night to wreck an excursion train on the Lake Erie and Western Road, which was returning from Chicago heavily loaded with passengers.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 16 -- Mrs. Nancy McKinley, mother of President McKinley, is in the city. She is visiting her daughter, Mrs. A.J. Duncan, 59 Bell Avenue. Miss Helen McKinley came with her mother.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- The Canadian Government has submitted formal proposals to this Government to establish communication with the Klondike region, in Alaska, by the construction of a telegraph line from the head of Winter navigation, on the Lynn Canal, into the centre of the Klondike district. The proposals have been taken under Advisement.

Daly's Theatre reopened last night with a revival of that sprightly and diverting burletta "The Circus Girl," which was the last piece presented before the closing of the house in June. With the exception of May Young, who has taken the place of Blanche Astley as Lucette, the cast of the piece is the same as it was before the vacation.

It was claimed by many racing men last week, after Michael III. made a very good showing, that the colt was one of the cracks of the year; that he was a stayer, and a weight-carrier as well. On the strength of this opinion, Michael III. was made 1 to 4 favorite in the handicap for two-year-olds at three-quarters of a mile yesterday.

Preliminary reports on the foreign trade of the United States for the twelve months ending June 30, 1897, made it evident some weeks ago that our commerce had undergone the most remarkable development ever experienced during any similar period of its history. The completed statistics now make it possible to measure the results achieved during the past year.

DETROIT, Aug. 16. -- The twenty-third annual meeting of the American Bankers' Association, which will open in this city to-morrow, promises to be the most largely attended of any in the history of that body. More than 100 delegates have already arrived, and Secretary Branch estimates that 1,000 or more will be present at the opening session.

The contest which was expected in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday over the consolidation of the Brooklyn City and Newtown Railroad and the Coney Island and Brooklyn Railroad did not take place.

-- Sunday was a day of drowning accidents, while the wheelmen and wheelwomen managed to keep out of any serious trouble. To be quite fair, the fatalities that occurred, or were narrowly escaped, should now be made points in an indictment of the dangerous bathing suit, and should furnish a new subject to the people who have written or spoken so much about the perils of bicycling.

LONDON, Aug. 17. -- The Times publishes a two-column special article to-day reviewing the effects of closing the Indian mints, in connection with the visit of the American Bimetallic Commission. It says:

OAKLAND, Cal., Aug. 16. -- M. Ayer, a real estate man of Oakland, promises to establish balloon service between Juneau and Dawson. He is an old balloonist, and says the scheme is practicable. He says the trip from Juneau to Dawson City ought to be made in twenty-four hours.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 16. -- Animosa, a three-year-old brown filly, was stolen from the Newport race track early this morning. Some one saw a colored man riding her on a gallop from the stables of Adams Turner, her owners. It is thought the theft is for the purpose of entering her under another name. She recently broke the track record at Newport, and is valued at $5,000.

LONDON, Aug. 17. -- According to a dispatch to The Daily Mail from Paris it is rumored that the death at Teheran, Persia, of Dr. Tholozan, the physician of the late Shah, was caused by poison administered at the instigation of the reigning Shah, because Tholozan knew too many State secrets.
I dislike very much to suggest anything less than infallibility on the part of the editorial writers of THE NEW YORK TIMES, but "Garbage for Fuel," (Aug. 16,) is a little too strong for me.

Yesterday's market opened extremely active and very strong. Scarcely a stock on the list failed to score an advance. The rapid pace so started did not keep up throughout the day, however; instead of exciting enthusiasm there developed in the later part of the day a quiet, determined confidence which simply took stocks wherever offered without trying to bid up quotations. In this policy there are elements of safety.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 16. -- A calf frustrated an attempt to take a bird's-eye view snapshot of this city last Saturday. George K. Parsell, an architect, who is an enthusiast in photography, made the attempt to photograph New Brunswick from the clouds. A box kite was to convey the camera high in the air, and then, by means of a string, Mr. Parsell was to click the camera.

It was remarked by Sir WALTER SCOTT that a rider who is run away with by his horse presents so ridiculous an appearance that nothing can save him from becoming a laughing stock to the spectators except some serious injury. If the man be a great stickler for his personal dignity, Sir WALTER intimates that his safest course is to get himself killed outright.

According to figures furnished yesterday by the Citizens' Union, there are in Greater New York 103,598 individual voters who favor the nomination of Seth Low for Mayor, and the number is constantly increasing. The Low ballots themselves figure up 82,261, and the enrollment in the Union, now officially announced for the first time, figures up 21,387.

The heat of yesterday made almost certain the fulfillment of the prophecy that a shower would come to bathe the fevered city at nightfall. It came with a blare and glare, and while at times between 7:30 and 8 the sprinkle was emphatic, the pomp of its approach was its most conspicuous feature.

Jeremiah Cunningham, an engineer on the Third Avenue elevated railroad, was instantly killed by his own engine at Eighty-fourth Street and Third Avenue yesterday morning. He was waiting to jump aboard his train while it was in motion, but was struck, crushed, and mangled to death.

L.J. Phillips Co. have sold for James W. Whitney of Rochester, N.Y., to Albert Flake, of Flake Dowling, for about $100,000, the five-story American basement dwelling, with four-story extension, 184 Riverside Drive, on a lot 37 by 108.6 by 35 by 105. This house adjoins the residence of John H. Matthews, at the northeast corner of Riverside Drive and Ninetieth Street.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- Acting Secretary Roosevelt to-day issued the following order to Lieutenant Commander W.W. Kimball, who will be the commanding officer of the torpedo boat flotilla:

Two men who had evidently seen better days were yesterday arraigned before Judge Fitzgerald, in General Sessions, charged with grand larceny, and both pleaded not guilty. They were said to have been patrons of the Tenderloin and frequenters of the races, where they are said to have lost a great deal of money.

President William F. King of the Merchants' Association estimates that the buyers whom that organization will bring to New York will spend from $60,000,000 to $100,000,000 in replenishing thier stocks.

The statement of Mr. JOHN BRISBEN WALKER about his new university sheds a good deal of light backward upon the resignation of President ANDREWS from Brown. For it seems that at the time when President ANDREWS offered his resignation to Brown he had already received a liberal offer to take the direction of Mr. WALKER'S new university to be conducted in connection with Mr. WALKER'S magazine.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Aug. 16. -- South Carolina is about to witness the enforced abandonment of its famous liquor dispensary system. The story of the rise and fall of this system is curious and interesting.
MADRID, Aug. 16. -- Michele Angiolillo, the Anarchist assassin of Premier Canovas del Castillo, who was tried by court-martial yesterday, at Vergara, was found guilty and was sentenced to death.

LONDON, Aug. 16. -- A special dispatch from Rome, published to-day, says it is reported there that the Pope will excommunicate Prince Henri of Orleans and the Count of Turin, as dueling is forbidden by the Roman Catholic Church.

We print this morning the report of the Citizens' Union Committee on Enrollment and District Organization. It is the Union's reply to Mr. Low's demand for more evidence of the popular desire for his nomination. It speaks for itself.

Forty policemen and one Roundsman of the West One Hundredth Street Station yesterday hired a craft, otherwise known as the tug Harlem River, No. 1, and treated themselves to a trip on Long Island Sound. Beside the police the tug carried a number of Italian musicians, engaged at the princely fee of 82 per diem.

The Quakers did not make a remarkable showing against the New Yorks at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon, and were beaten rather easily. The visitors did not display much life, and toward the last played as though there was no hope to win.

The annual display of August meteors, due about the 9th-11th, is usually preceded and succeeded by a few outlying wanderers. This month some of them have been of unusual brilliancy. One of those fell to the earth near here, accompanied by unusual demonstrations from Jupiter Tonans during the wild electric storm of Sunday night.
LONDON, Aug. 16. -- The Mark Lane Express, in its weekly review of the grain situation, says:
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 16. -- William C. Wilson, aged about fifty-five years, proprietor of Wilson's Circulating Library, at 1,119 Walnut Street, was murdered to-night in his place of business.

MONTREAL, Aug. 16. -- Glencairn II., the Canadian defender, defeated Momo, the American challenger, to-day in the second of the series of races on Lake St. Louis for the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Challenge Cup. The weather conditions to-day were the reverse of those of Saturday, a stiff breeze blowing from fifteen to twenty miles an hour, and the Canadian boat fulfilled the expectations that had been reposed in her as being the better heavy-weather craft.

One of the Salvation Army kind of devices to lead sinners to repentance is to daub on rocks and fences along the highways scraps of Scriptural text and fragments of religious exhortation. The idea is to reach the heart of the way-faring man against his will, so that he may not "roll darkling down the torrent of his fate."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- There were presented to the Treasury Department to-day for redemption two $1,000 7-30 notes of the issue of June 15, 1865. The persons making the presentation were a business firm of Louisville, Ky. Upon examination, the notes were found to be counterfeits, being a part of a very large issue which appeared in the bond markets about 1865 and 1867.

Almost everybody who visited the race track at Brighton Beach yesterday wanted to know all about how George E. Smith (Pittsburg Phil) won $75,000, as was published in a daily paper yesterday morning. The fairy story was the only topic of conversation, but it was tabooed after the young plunger had shown by his betting book that he had won only $6,000 on the day.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 17. -- Milwaukee operators say that a wealthy syndicate has been formed in Chicago for the purpose of cornering barley. A number of helpless shorts, who thought 36 cents was a high price for No. 2 barley a few weeks ago, are now frantically bidding 10 cents higher, in their efforts to cover and retire at a considerable loss.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 17. -- The jury in the Davis will contest returned a verdict early this morning finding that the disputed testamentary document was genuine. If the will is now admitted to probate by Judge Coffey, an estate valued at over $1,000,000 will be divided between Mrs. Belle Curtis and her sister, Lizzie Muir. Mrs. Curtis is the wife of ex-Assemblyman John Curtis.
HOTEL CHAMPLAIN, Clinton County, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- The President and his immediate friends accepted an invitation to a yachting party to-day, given by the owner of the yacht Washita, Mr. Putnam.

" Resolved, That the Republican County Committee hereby recommends to the Republican City Committee of the City of New York that it propose a conference with all organizations opposed to the rehabilitation of Tammany Hall with a view to the selection of the same day for the holding of all anti-Tammany nominating conventions, so that entire harmony and ready conferences may be assured in the selection of candidates and the promulgation of principles."

That is a most pregnant announcement which is made by the Board of Health that the death rate for the last week is the lowest for twenty-five years. That means the lowest since our vital statistics have been accurately kept, and since the Board of Health has been put upon its present footing and clothed with its present powers.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Aug. 17. -- Advices received here to-night from Senator McLaurin's physicians at Bennettsville are to the effect that his condition is worse than heretofore. He is reported to be suffering from great physical prostration attended by grave symptoms of impending cerebral trouble. In view of this his medical advisers insist upon absolute quiet as essential to his recovery.

LONDON, Aug. 17. -- "The Sleeping Partner," an English adaptation of Miss Martha Morton's comedy. "His Wife's Father," with which Mr. W.H. Crane is identified in the United States, was produced here this evening at the Criterion Theatre, and scored a palpable hit.

Mayor Strong sent a veto message to the Board of Aldermen at its meeting yesterday expressing his disapproval of the section in the rules of the road ordinance permitting cyclists to trundle their wheels on the sidewalk. After much discussion the ordinance was finally passed over the Mayor's veto.

The commission appointed by Justice Fitzgerald of the Court of General Sessions to consider and report upon the question of the sanity of Claude S. Farrington, former Superintendent of the National Academy of Design, held its final hearing in the library of the new Criminal Court Building yesterday.

The reported remarks of various Republican leaders respecting the Citizens' Union in general and Mr. Low's nomination in particular must strike the average grown-up voter as childish in the extreme. One is reminded of one's boyish days when the question of who was "it" in a game of "tag" gave rise to much squabbling, often followed by a free-for-all fight.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 17. -- Mr. Hussey is one of the oldest citizens of Montgomery. He owns valuable real estate throughout the State. He is a shoemaker by trade, but gave up work many years ago. He is a bachelor, and lives alone. He stands well in the community.

Wall Street bears yesterday had a jubilee. Pouncing upon the market at its opening, they snarled at it all day long. Before the close they had succeeded in knocking down quotations throughout the list. Thirty different issues went down a point or more. This record has a gruesome sound. Yet, as a matter of fact, it really does not represent anything very grave.

Westchester County's tax war, which has so far been carried on chiefly in the newspapers, resulted in an open engagement yesterday. The Boards of Assessors which had tripled estimates of the value of real property and multiplied personally assessments by five or six faced hundreds of indignant taxpayers and received an unprecedented volley of protests against their action.
North Carolina reports that its crops this year will exceed in quantity and value any produced in the State in the past thirty years or more.

-- A Chicago man now in this city told a friend yesterday that he and his fellow-townsmen were quite content with the present business situation and delighted with existing business prospects. "Trade is already good," he said, "and the currency problem is all that needs excite any uneasiness.

The number of persons that are brought to the city daily by the excursions of the Merchants' Association is beginning to tax the capacity of the regular commercial hotels. Several hundred Southerners arrived Monday and dispersed over the city seeking hotel accommodations. At one hotel fifty were turned away, as every room was occupied.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- The secret marriage of Sidney H. Perham, grandson of ex-Gov. Perham of Maine, is announced here. The ceremony was performed May 29 last at Rockville, Md., some twenty miles from Washington, and has been concealed from the family until this time.

Chief Engineer Parsons of the Rapid Transit Commission was under cross-examination by Lawyer Zabriskie for the third day yesterday at 256 Broadway before the special commission appointed by the Appellate Court. All general questions have been abandoned and the detail work has been begun.

Some excitement still continues over the seizure of the Clara Ward photographs. The retail sellers of such trifles are in distress, for the pictures of the ex-Princess de Chimay had come to them as a boon and a blessing, just as certain English pens were supposed to have been made for the benefit of mankind.

MONTREAL, Aug. 17. -- In a wind that blew fully twenty miles an hour and in a heavy sea, Glencairn II. to-day won her second race from Mono, on Lake St. Louis. With one more victory the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Challenge Cup will remain in Canada for another year. To-day's contest was the third of the series, in which Momo has won one race.

Yesterday was "grievance day" in Westchester, and all the discontented taxpayers in that county submitted their proofs and arguments to show that the operations of the Assessors had borne with peculiar hardship upon themselves.

HAZLETON, Penn., Aug. 17. -- The strike situation in the Honeybrook district of the Lehigh and Wilkesbarre Company's collieries was unchanged to-day. No attempt was made to start work at the mines this morning. Unless a compromise is effected the tie-up will be a prolonged one. The Coal and Iron police are still guarding the mines, but thus far they have not had occasion to arrest a single striker.

John Townshend, as counsel for Mrs. Marie M. Coudert, served notice on Probate Clerk Benjamin A. Jackson in the Surrogate's Office yesterday that he would contest the probate of the second will of Charles Coudert, filed July 28 last.
NEWPORT, Aug. 17. -- The following yachts arrived here to-day:

James Bamberg, thirty-six years old, of 228 West Sixty-fourth Street, who had threatened many times to jump off the roof of his house, quarreled with his wife about midnight Monday, went to the roof, and was fund dead yesterday morning in the yard. Bamberg lived with his wife and two children, both very young, on the fourth floor of the house.
Mr. JACOB WORTH forgets or does not want to remember that the Citizens' Union was not organized to be the lapdog of the Republican Party.

The Giants administered another defeat to the Philadelphia team at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon, but, unlike Monday's game, it was not a walk-over. The Quakers became a little too aggressive in the last inning, and for a time they piled up runs with such alarming regularity that the 3,000 spectators were given a bit of a scare.
" Hope? Hopeful? Does the West hope? Are the Western agriculturists hopeful? No; they are not hopeful. They don't hope. They are past hope. It's realization."

The World published yesterday morning an article supplementary to its recent review of the chief departments of the City Government under the reform administration. It was devoted to the system of education, was presented as a "semi-official" statement, and was prepared at the request of Mayor STRONG.

DUBLIN, Aug. 17. -- The Duke and Duchess of York will arrive here to-morrow to pay their long-expected visit to Ireland. They will be the guests of Earl Cadogan, Lord Lieutenant of Ireland, and Countess Cadogan, and will he entertained at the Vice-regal Lodge.
The New York Realty Company has sold to Charles Buck, the builder, for improvement, the plot on Riverside Drive, 62 feet north of Seventy-sixth Street, 40 by 100.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 17. -- Every seat in the Detroit Opera House was occupied this morning when, at a little after 10 o'clock, President Robert J. Lowry called to order the twenty-third annual convention of the American Bankers' Association. Prayer was offered by the Rev. Henry A. Schapman, S.J., President of Detroit College. Mayor Maybury then welcomed the delegates to Detroit.

Albert V. Sugden, twenty-three years old, an Englishman, formerly employed as a valet by Richard T. Wilson, Sr., the father-in-law of Cornelius Vanderbilt, Jr., was arrested by Central Office detectives yesterday for the theft of $130 in money and some $2,000 worth of jewelry from Mr. Wilson's home, 511 Fifth Avenue, on June 23. The jewels were recovered intact. The motive for the deed seems to have been revenge rather than greed.

Under the agreement made by the New York State Chess Association with Steinitz and Lipschutz the second game of the match for the possession for a year of the Challenge Cup of the Association will be played this evening at the rooms of the Manhattan Chess Club, in the United Charities Building, Fourth Avenue and Twenty second Street.

There is clearly a chance of a certain reciprocity of trade with France, and the conference which it is reported is to be held by our State Department with the French Ambassador has some basis to work upon.

ITHACA, Aug. 17. -- The candidates for the Cornell football eleven have been notified by Capt. William Mckeever to appear for practice at Percy Field on Monday, Sept. 13. G.S. Warner of Buffalo, a Cornell graduate and former Captain of the eleven, has been engaged to coach the team during the coming season. He is to be assisted by Capt. Beacham of the '96 eleven and other old players.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17. -- Notwithstanding all denials, it is asserted here by persons who profess to know, that. C.O. Scull, recently General Passenger Agent of the Baltimore and Ohio, soon will be appointed General Passenger Agent of the New York Central, vice George H. Daniels, who will be promoted to the position of Passenger Traffic Manager.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 18. -- The Twenty-first Infantry paraded in full strength on the lawn of the Hotel Champlain to-day before President McKinley, Vice President Hobart, Secretary of War Alger, and the women of the Presidential party. The occasion was the presentation to the regiment of the national colors, the gift of Mrs. McKinley, Mrs. Hobart, and Mrs. Alger in appreciation of the service of the regiment during the sojourn of the President's party here.

NEWPORT, Aug. 18. -- The following yachts arrived hero to-day: Steamer Seneca, owned by C.F. Fletcher; steamer Marjorie, owned by A.S. Van Winkle; steamer Augusta, owned by J.B. Herreshoff; steamer Giralda, owned by E.S. Renwick; steamer Sultana, owned by J.R. Drexel; schooner Harbinger, owned by H.G. Russell.

A rather serious breach in the hitherto peaceful relations existing betweeen the State and Local Tax Commissioners was made yesterday when the State Board in a body paid a visit to the local office without any previous notification and demanded the privilege of examining the books of the city and county commission:

BERLIN, Aug. 18. -- The Vossische Zeitung says that Gen. Stewart L. Woodford, the new American Minister to Spain, will impress upon the Spanish Government that autonomy for Cuba must be preceded by the withdrawal of the Spanish troops from the island. If Gen. Woodford's mission fails, President McKinley has decided to take further steps which he will announce by a special message to Congress.

The annual report of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company, the financiering organization of the Brooklyn Heights and the Brooklyn, Queens County and Suburban Railroad Company, has been issued. The tabulated statements follow:

LONDON, Aug. 18. -- The North German Lloyd steamship Saale, Capt. Blanke, which arrived at Playmouth last night from New York for Bremen, reports that on Aug. 17, in latitude 50, longitude 8. she passed the steamship Barbarossa of the same line, which sailed from Southampton Aug. 1 for New York, and that the Barbarossa had lost a blade of her propeller.
SIMLA, Aug. 18 -- 4 P.M. -- The whole frontier seems to be in flames. This is the startling announcement made here this afternoon.

A straw suggesting somewhat the new life in the railroad world appears in a statement made yesterday by a director of the New York Air Brake Company, that during the first fourteen days of this month that corporation did more business, received more orders, turned out more work, than during the entire month of August last year.

QUIGG will presently be seen chasing the panting Citizens' Union through this town beseeching the favor of a five minutes' interview. A month ago he was riding a mighty high horse. The Union was a hostile organization with which the Republican County Committee could have no dealings. It was trying to overreach and humiliate the Republicans.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Aug. 18. -- The city is almost in a panic to-night over the news of bomb explosions attempted or accomplished this afternoon at three different points. The explosions are attributed to the Armenians. At 3 o'clock a bomb was thrown just outside the Police Headquarters, in the Pera District. It failed to explode.

-- It is painful to record that two scientists have been arrested out in Oregon for grave robbing. To be sure the scientists were from Chicago and the graves they robbed were those of Indians, presumably prehistoric, and certainly not taxed; therefore the offense is, on the one hand, not so surprising as it might have been, and, on the other, it hardly reduces the perpetrators to the grade of common body-snatchers.
Paul Mayer has sold for Henry Rothschild for about $50,000 the five-story stone-front flat at the southwest corner of One Hundred and Thirty-fourth Street and Seventh Avenue, 25 by 75.

It was reported last night that the present members of the piano manufacturing firm of Steinway Sons had consummated a deal whereby the extensive business of the concern passes into the hands of an English syndicate. The price paid was $6,000,000. For some time after the death of William Steinway a report of the sale of the property to an English syndicate was circulated.

BOSTON, Aug. 18. -- A cable dispatch received in this city from Buenos Ayres says that Capt. J.W. Whitman and Mate William Hansburgh, of the schooner Olive Pecker, which sailed from this port on June 27, have been murdered by the crew.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 18. -- The announcement that Controller of the Currency Eckels would make an address drew to this morning's session of the Bankers' Convention an audience unusually large. When Controller Eckels stepped forward a most generous round of applause greeted him. He said:

A handsome young Spaniard stood on the North German Lloyd pier in Hoboken, when the steamship Fulda docked yesterday afternoon. He was awaiting some one with ill-concealed agitation, which was sufficiently explained when a young woman with very big, soft black eyes, bewitching dimples, an olive complexion, enhanced by rosy cheeks, rushed down the gangplank and into his arms.
A full-grown tornado struck a half mile past of the village of Valley Stream, L.I., yesterday afternoon.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 18. -- At Yaddo, the country seat of Spencer Trask, was held to-day a protracted session of the subcommittee of the Executive Committee created by the recent sound-money conference at Indianapolis.

An entirely innocent use of paris green and his inability to speak caused John Ditmar, a deaf mute of 235 North Tenth Street, Brooklyn, a bad, surprising, and demoralizing quarter of an hour yesterday, and resulted in the innermost recesses of his nature being searched with a stomach pump engineered by an enthusiastic surgeon and directed by a philanthropic policeman.

LOUISVILLE, Aug. 18. -- Thomas Gardner, aged twenty, and Rosa Hughes, who is just eighteen, spent several hours yesterday in trying to get married, but the girl's stern father, mounted on a bicycle, overhauled them. They first went to Jeffersonville, but hearing of Mr. Hughes's presence, got in a carriage and drove to New Albany.

MONTREAL, Aug. 18. -- Glencairn II. again, for the third consecutive time, showed herself a better boat than Momo in a stiff breeze, and by her win over the latter secured to Canada for another year the handsome challenge cup of the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club.
NEWPORT, Aug. 18. -- The National lawn tennis tournament at the Casino began to-day. At 10 o'clock in the morning the preliminary round in the singles was called.

The President of the French Republic has departed from Paris on his visit to the Czar, and the Czar will receive him, apparently, with as splendid ceremony as was accorded last week to the Emperor of Germany, and with even more display of national and political friendship.

It does not appear whether the Assessors of the various towns in Westchester have acted independently or in concert. It seems unlikely that they should all have simultaneously and spontaneously and for the first time looked at the statute which requires them to assess real estate at its true value, and to guess conscientiously at personalty.

BOSTON, Aug. 18. -- Judge Lathrop of the Supreme Judicial Court to-day appointed as temporary receivers of the Massachusetts Benefit Life Association Alfred S. Woodworth, President of the Eagle National Bank of this city, and Arthur Lord of Plymouth. Bonds in the sum of $25,000 each will be required.

A case of unusual theatrical interest has been begun in Part I. of the Supreme Court by Harrison Grey Fiske, the author of "The Privateer," who seeks to enjoin Lewis Morrison and Edward J. Abram from producing that play, which is announced to open at the Star Theatre Saturday night for four weeks.

SARATOGA, Aug. 18. -- The attendance at the race track to-day was the largest of the meeting, and but for cloudy, threatening weather it is probable the attendance would have been the largest in years. This was "ladies' day," and as women are admitted free on such days the grand stand was crowded.

CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Aug. 18. -- The nomination this afternoon of L.M. Shaw of Crawford County as the standard bearer of the Iowa Republicans in the coming campaign ended one of the most protracted and interesting contests in the history of Iowa politics.

The abduction of the Conway child in Albany has already taken a place in the list of noteworthy mysterious crimes, of which, by the way, our own city has had more than its share lately. JOHNNIE CONWAY has only been missing from his home in Albany since Monday, to be sure, but there is, at this moment, not the slightest clue as to his whereabouts or the identity of his abductors.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 18. -- The decision reached by the operators of the Pittsburg district at their conference here last night to open their mines regardless of consequences probably will cause serious trouble. According to local coal men, it is the intention of the Pittsburg operators to engage Pinkerton men to protect their non-union men.
The Citizens' Union will hold no conference with the Republican or with any other political organization.

Dollar wheat was no goal yesterday. The staple passed this line of value. No. 1 Northern's cash price reached $1.00 1/4 in a bull market that culminated in the recording of the highest price of the season -94 5/8 cents -- for September contract wheat, and 94 cents for the December option. These futures made net gains in the day's trading on the Produce Exchange of 4 1/2 cents and 5 cents, respectively.

VICTORIA, B.C., Aug. 18. -- The steamer Queen arrived last night from the north. According to Purser Carroll, but a few of the 1,500 men in camp at Skagway and Dyea will get over the pass this Winter. The men had started to build a new trail, but found it would take 300 men three weeks to complete it, and abandoned the idea.

Controller Fitch went back to the Adirondacks last night to finish his vacation. As soon as he and President Jeroloman of the Board of Aldermen return to the city Mayor Strong will call a meeting of the Board of Street Improvement, and a resolution will be presented for the establishment of small parks on Long Acre
The speech of the Controller of the Currency before the American Bankers' Association yesterday will be found in THE TIMES this morning. It is worth the careful reading of all business men.

DUBLIN, Aug. 18. -- The Duke and Duchess of York arrived at Kingstown, from Holyhead, at 9 o'clock this morning, The weather was glorious and all the ships in the harbor were brilliantly decorated for the occasion. The Guard Ship Melampus fired a royal salute as the Royal Yacht Victoria and Albert entered the harbor.

The New Yorks fought a grand battle at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon, and succeeded in winning their third consecutive game from the Philadelphias. The Quakers again became aggressive toward the last, and at one stage of the eighth inning it looked doubtful for the Giants. But, as in Tuesday's combat, a series of opportune base hits gave them the victory.
CHICAGO, Ill., Aug. 18. -- The prospectus of the Arctic Mining and Development Company (Limited) has been prepared and is about to be circulated among would-be investors.

When the knowing members of the Association of Nervous Friars entered the Brighton Beach race track yesterday they looked in at the betting ring and then went off to the paddock, their faces wreathed in smiles. It seemed strange that all should be smiling, when the rain was pouring down in sheets, and not one of the number had a mackintosh or an umbrella with him.

The Merchants' Association received a new impetus yesterday. A large crowd of visitors reached the city and filled the headquarters, after overflowing all the down town hotels; a big batch of non-resident membership received a large and important increase. In addition to this, President King brought good news from the South.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18. -- September wheat to-day sold at the highest point reached since 1891, and closed, amid great excitement, at 88 1/2c -- an advance of 4 3/4c since yesterday. Corn advanced 5/8c and oats 1/4c. Provisions closed at advances ranging from 2 1/2c for lard to 30c for pork.

Questions of technical detail consumed a large part of the time of yesterday's examination of Chief Engineer Parsons of the Rapid Transit Commission before the special Commission appointed by the Appellate Court. The examination was conducted by George Zabriskie, counsel for property owners opposed to the underground road at 256 Broadway.

September contract wheat made a new record for the season, 95 3/4c, at the Produce Exchange yesterday, but it closed at 94c, one quarter of a cent net loss for the day, the closing quotation for Wednesday having been 94 1/4c. The scope of trading on Wednesday in the leading future was 95 5/8c to 91 1/4c; that of yesterday was 95 3/4c to 93 1/4c.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19. -- Commencing Oct. 1 two new transcontinental routes for second-class travel will be established between Pittsburg and San Francisco. The first route will be by the Southern Pacific, San Francisco to Ogden; Rio Grande Western, Ogden to Grand Junction, Col.; Colorado Midland, Grand Junction to Colorado Springs; Rock Island, Colorado Springs to Omaha; Milwaukee and St. Paul, Omaha to Chicago, and the Pennsylvania Railroad from this city to Pittsburg.

READING, Penn., Aug. 19. -- J.H. Carpenter, founder of the Carpenter Steel Works of this city, of which he was formerly General Manager, has prepared a statement showing that steel armor plate can be furnished to the Government at a trifling figure compared with what is now paid.

Everything is now in readiness for the celebration of the. nineteenth annual carnival of fire at Nfanhattan Beach. If the weather t fine to-morrow it will be celebrated in a manner not heretofore attempted. The fireworks programme is so long that the Graeco-Turkish war spectacle will be curtailed, and only the great battle scene will be given as a finale to the exhibition in the amphitheatre.

Mayor Wurster and Controller Palmer are confronted with the problem of how to meet an estimate of municipal expenses of $1,871,719.76 when the present borrowing capacity of the city is but $1,731,398.76. In addition to the estimated amount there are requisitions on hand for bond issues aggregating $294,000. Controller Palmer's tabulated statement is as follows:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- Secretary Sherman has acknowledged the recent overture of the French Government, through Ambassador Patenotre, to negotiate a reciprocity treaty between the United States and France under the reciprocity clause of the new tariff law, and the Secretary adds the assurance that he hopes to take up this important subject at an early day.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19. -- All-rail rates on flour and grain products between St. Paul and Minneapolis and New York will be advanced to 22 1/2 cents per 100 pounds Sept. 1. This is an advance of 5 cents per 100 pounds from the present tariff figures.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 19. -- The Argonaut, a submarine vessel, was launched at noon to-day at the yards of the Columbian Iron Works. Miss Miriam Lake, daughter of the inventor of the strange craft, christened it in the usual manner as it glided from the ways into the water.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 19. -- Cleveland to-day treated Baltimore to its first shu6-out of the sean. It was a well-played game, and but for two eosMy errors on the part of Stenzel and Amele of the home team, neither side would have tallied during the nine innings.

Without doubt the present uprising against British rule on the Afghan border is the most extensive and formidable that has occurred since the Mutiny, now just forty years ago. The causes of it lie upon the surface and have been explained before. Certainly it does not amount to impeachment of the justice or beneficence of British rule.

DETROIT, Aug. 19. -- Pingree Smith's shoe factory, the only union shoe shop in the city, was tied up at noon to-day by a strike of the bottomers. About 700 hands are affected. The firm is willing to arbitrate the differences, but the men claim they have always been worsted, in arbitration, and demand an increase in the price of work on certain grades of shoes.

Tow Cromwell, M.F. Dwyer's son of Bramble and Fonsie, has grown to be such an erratic performer that speculators who like anything else in a race in which he is a starter are afraid to bet on their choice, and those who have figured Tom Cromwell a winner cannot bet on him, no matter how poor the company, for fear he will give them one of his frequent upsets.

The new air locomotive, No. 400, was given a trial on the Sixth Avenue Elevated Railroad last night, and every one connected with the American Air Power Company, who had charge of the trial, was very well satisfied.

That the Sultan deserves his troubles ought not to make us overlook the fact that he has them, and that they are very serious. The Government of the Caliphs has not been a despotism tempered by so much assassination as the Government of the Czars. What murders of Sultans there have been have come out of dynastic intrigues rather than popular revolts.

KINGSTON, Aug. 19. -- Brick manufacturers in this neighborhood think it extremely probable that fully 90 per cent. of the yards along the Hudson will shut down early in September, at least a month before the usual time. This is on account of the low prices of the product, which now sells for from $4 to $4.50 a thousand, delivered in New York.

The business part of the town of Huntington, L.I., was much disturbed yesterday by a phenomenon which was without precedent in the annals of local tradition or the memory of the oldest inhabitant, consisting of a rain of cats.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19. -- For the first time in its history Cook County had a lynching to-day. Shortly after noon a tramp appeared at the back door of Carl Fenske's farm cottage farm, in Leyden township, and by his display of jewelry and his jovial manner soon gained the confidence of the Fenske children. Mr. Fenske was thrashing wheat some distance from the house.

NEWPORT, Aug. 19. -- All of the matches in the first round in the tournament of the National tennis championship in singles, at the Casino, were played to-day. Barring two or three of the contests, the play attracted little attention.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 19. -- The twenty-third annual convention of the American Bankers' Association came to an end at 1 o'clock this afternoon. According to precedent, First Vice President Joseph C. Hendrix of New York was raised to the office of President George H. Russell of Detroit received a large majority of the votes cast for First Vice President, although the Nominating Committee had recommended F.W. Tracy of Illinois for the honor.
LONDON, Aug. 19. -- The Westminster Gazette this afternoon, commenting upon the "demoralized silver market," says:
RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 19. -- The question of utilizing the immense water power here for the distribution of electric power is attracting general attention among electric companies of the country.

There was nothing so easy about the Louisvilles at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon, and the New Yorks were very fortunate to win. It was a battle of pitchers, and the 3,500 spectators enjoyed the exhibition thoroughly. "Dad" Clarke, who was only recently traded for McCreery, worked the local batsmen in remarkable style.

-- A little vigorous action, as might have been prophesied, has proved to be vastly more effective at Coney Island than was the large amount of sternly virtuous intention upon which reliance for reforming that resort has hitherto been placed. Already the foul birds of various sorts that have nested on the island have taken to their bedraggled wings, and are flying about with discordant cries.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- Secretary Sherman has submitted to the Japanese Government an answer to Japan's last note relating to the annexation of Hawaii to the United States. The answer was delivered to Mr. Hoshi, the Japanese Minister, last Saturday. It is in reply to Japan's note of July 10, which up to that time had not been acknowledged.
There was a small riot on Tenth Avenue at Fifty-second Street last night, which made it necessary to call out a section of police reserves.

Wednesday the Merchants' Association announced that it had arranged for the opening of additional territory in the South Atlantic States. Yesterday it announced that it had succeeded in having still more territory opened in the Southwest. This latter extension has been made possible through a concession granted by the Mallory Steamship Company, whose boats ply between this port and Galveston, Texas.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- Lewis Jerome Edward Blanc, an American citizen, has filed a claim against the Government of Ecuador for $200,000 for false imprisonment and ill treatment over twenty years ago.

It is a Georgian and a Colonel who has done more to bring his fellow-citizens to a right way of thinking about lynching than could be done by all the Northern moralists and essayists for a generation to come. The Georgian who has done this inestimable public service is Col. JONES of Rock Springs.
District Attorney Backus announced his intention yesterday of investigating the charges of malfeasance in office now being made against Coroners Coombs and Nason.

DULUTH, Minn., Aug. 19. -- The whaleback steamer Everett, now at Calcutta, India, will shortly sail for Philadelphia, where she will unload and then proceed to New York to take on supplies for the Klondike.

The case of MAMIE STEINHAUS, an inmate of Bellevue Hospital, has lately amazed a few physicians and made a lot of good, sentimental "copy" for the readers of some of the newspapers, but the most important and interesting aspect of the case seems to us to have been missed altogether.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 19. -- A cool breeze greeted the golfers who gathered this morning on the links of the Norwood Field Club to compete in the first open tournament ever held by the club.

George F. Schloss, a wholesale liquor salesman, of 54 West Fifty-fourth Street, made a complaint yesterday against Policeman Carl Stedman of the West Thirtieth Street Station, whom he charges with assault and using vile language. The complaint was lodged in the Jefferson Market Court.
DES MOINESS, Iowa, Aug. 19. -- The Middle-of-the-Road Populists, who are opposed to fusion with the Democrats, at a State Convention held here to-day nominated the following ticket:

ALBANY, Aug. 19. -- John Conway, the five-year-old son of Michael J. Conway, who was abducted last Monday morning while playing in the vicinity of his home on Colonie Street, was restored to his parents to-day. The child was found and rescued from his abductors through the efforts of private detectives and newspaper reporters, and upon information furnished by them two men have been arrested by the police for complicity in the abduction.

George Finck, a lawyer, at 31 Nassau Street, has just leased the plot of land at the southeast corner of Nineteenth Street and Fourth Avenue, belonging to the Edward Matthews estate. Mr. Finck, in the negotiations, is acting for a syndicate. The lease is for 105 years, dating from Oct. 1, 1897.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- Commissioner of Pensions Evans has had a statement prepared on the number of applications for pensions filed since July, 1896. The comparison shows that in July, 1896, applications for pensions aggegated 2,898; while in June, 1897, there were 40,169, largely for increases and for widows and minor children.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- The Canadian Government and the United States have agreed upon co-operation in augmenting the postal facilities for the Klondike region, and the result will shortly be evidenced in a substantial doubling of the mail service from the coast into that district. The reply of Canada to Acting Postmaster General Shallenberger's proposition to establish an exchange of mails at Circle City and Dawson City reached here to-day.
MORRISTOWN, N.J. Aug. 19. -- Herbert G. Torrey, United States Assayer at New York, was arrested at Stirling last night, with his son, J. Gray Torrey, and Abraham H. Cornish, a New York lawyer.
President Wilson of the Health Board yesterday gave out the advance sheets of that portion of the annual report for 1896 which related to the inspection and consumption of milk in New York City.

President BARKER of the Tax Department is to be applauded for the stand he has taken with reference to the State Tax Commissioners. That stand he has taken in defense of the interests of the city and also in maintenance of right and justice. The State Commissioners demanded the books of his department.

Six grizzled, tanned, and weather-beaten old farmers from Sleepy Hollow or of that vicinity, three lawyers, and four or five townsmen met with the Mount Pleasant Board of Assessors yesterday afternoon in North Tarrytown to hear testimony in the Rockefeller tax grievances. Justice of the Peace Daniel Armstrong sat in his raised seat, leaning on his desk overlooking the court they were holding, and listened and nodded and dozed over the testimony.
SEATTLE, Washington, Aug. 19. -- The steamer Alki, which arrived in port yesterday, brought the following letter from Skaguay, Alaska, dated Aug. 4:

The cross-examination of Chief Engineer Parsons of the Rapid Transit Commission was continued yesterday before the special commission of the Appellate Court, sitting at 256 Broadway. Mr. Zabriskie, counsel for objecting property-owners, conducted the examination.

As announced exclusively in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday, the great business and plant of the piano manufacturing firm of Steinway Sons has passed into the hands of a syndicate of English capitalists. The sale involves one of the largest cash transactions recorded in England in many years. The purchase price, in round numbers, is 1,080,600, or more than $5,400,000.

Gen. COLLIS'S notion that asphalt and ornamental lampposts are much pleasanter to look upon than trees and sward does not command the approval of anybody except its author. We trust, in his own interest and behalf, that it has already ceased to command even his own. At any rate, no voice was raised on behalf of it at the last meeting of the Board of Estimate.
LONDON, Aug. 19. -- Calderon Carlisle of Washington, counselor to the Spanish Legation in the United States, arrived here to-day from Spain.

" The State Committee was authorized by the State Convention of New York to nominate a candidate for Judge. This was the power conferred upon it, and this alone. It has no authority to do anything more than nominate some person for Judge. Then all the duty conferred upon it is at an end."
LONDON, Aug. 20. -- The Daily Graphic publishes the following dispatch from Berlin:

Hiram Rinaldo Brother have sold for Mandelbaum Lewine to M.F. Cusack the five four-story brick tenements, 63 to 71 Mangin Street, 125 by 100. The sellers bought this property on Aug. 12 from the Washington Life Insurance Company, this corporation having acquired it about a month ago as the result of foreclosure proceedings.

The Sun, in this morning's issue -- leading article -- quotes THE TIMES as saying: "The Citizens' Union stands for a great deal more than the defeat of Tammany Hall by the election of a Republican Mayor," and therein, uncandidly, as it seems to me, seeks to convey the idea that the Citizens' Union was organized primarily to oppose the Republicans.

When a highly educated Cambridge professor was asked to vote for Thackeray, the novelist, then running for Parliament, the professor in reply to the request said: "Thackeray? Thackeray? And, pray, who may be Thackeray?, Another of these tradesmen with radical ideas, I suppose."
In addition to its troubles from mysterious incursions of stray and strange cats, the village of Huntington, L.I., is worried by Alonzo Brown's bulldog.

The interview with Mr. CALDERON CARLISLE, counsel to the Spanish Legation, which was published yesterday, makes more tangible and definite than before the assertion that Spain will "press her claims" against the United States. In the opinion of Spain, these claims will be more than an offset for our own claims against Spain founded on the destruction of the property in Cuba of American citizens.

There has been some discussion as to where the collection bequeathed to the English people by Lady Wallace should be placed. The Government had recommended the purchase of Hertford House, where the collection now is, and the cost was estimated at u80,000, such alterations as are necessary being included in this sum.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 20. -- The little village in the southern part of Middlesex County known to the Post Office Department as Weber is rent with a hot struggle as to whether that name or the old one of Keasbey shall prevail. The Weberites are somewhat in the minority, but they believe that they have Uncle Sam on their side.

WASHINGTON Aug. 20. -- The declared will of the late Pom K. Soh, the former Corean statesman, but a naturalized citizen of the United States, was filed for probate to-day. The estate, consisting of property and personal effects valued at about $8,000 was left to Bong Sun Pak, a cousin now residing here.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Aug. 20. -- An unknown war vessel passed this city to-night apparently in pursuit of a fleeing filibuster. The pursuing and pursued vessels were distinguished in the offing by their lights and the great clouds of smoke which shot up from their funnels.

CHICAGO, Ill., Aug. 20. -- The wheat market had another remarkable, advance to-day, September closing at 93 and December at 92 3/8 c, showing gains of 5 7/8 c and 5 3/8 c, respectively. A sensational advance at Liverpool and poor crop reports were responsible for the jump, which was accompanied by scenes of excitement almost unparalleled.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20. -- It looks to-night as though the New York clique back of the bull movement in wheat stood to make what is known as a "big killing." The syndicate represented here by Mr. French of New York yesterday held 8,000,000 bushels of wheat, 10,000,000 bushels of corn, and 3,000,000 bushels of oats. All of the wheat was purchased at from 80 to 84 cents.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- A letter received from Senator Cullom this morning announces that he had a pleasant voyage across the ocean, and that his health has been improved. Mr. Cullom will return Oct. 10, and at once enter the Ohio campaign. He will make a number of speeches in Senator Hanna's interest.

In his description of Gray's library, which forms one of the interesting "Eighteenth Century Vignettes," Austin Dobson refers to that laborious collection of music that the poet compiled in Italy, "while frivolous Horace Walpole was eating iced fruits in a domino to the sound of the guitar." "Zamperelli."
