Ayme was the French teacher of the present Emperor of Germany and he kept note of certain conversations he had with the then Prince William. The youthful Kaiser expressed himself in this way about Socialism:
SARATOGA, Aug. 20. -- This was the last free day at the Saratoga race track, and the grand stand was crowded with women. The racing was good and the track in excellent condition. Summaries:

It was decided at a meeting held at Eastern Park yesterday afternoon to take the Baltimores and an all-American team on a tour through the United States at the conclusion of the championship season. Manager William Barnie of Brooklyn and Frank G. Selee of Boston will have control of the players during the trip.

TRENTON, Aug. 20. -- This is the time of the year when the dates of the county fairs are announced and when the agriculturists look over the farms for premium producers. The schedule of fairs in New Jersey this year is so meagre as to attract attention and almost to warrant the declaration that the county fair in New Jersey has outlived its usefulness.

Proceedings against Dr. J.N. Butler of East Thirtieth Street before Magistrate Crane, in the Yorkville Police Court, yesterday began an exposure of the private life of the late William R. Roberts, once a wealthy and prominent dry goods merchant and politician here, and Minister to Chile during Mr. Cleveland's first administration.

The Public Art League of the United States has performed a public service in its recent publication of a pamphlet containing the text of the bill to be presented to Congress at its next session providing for the establishment of an art commission, and which also has a clear and cogent argument for the bill, with a carefully prepared synopsis of previous efforts at legislation on this important subject.

MASCOTTE, Fla., Ang. 20. -- Mascotte has a snake story which is vouched for by several reliable witnesses. In Sunset Lake, directly south of town, a monster snake has been observed by a number of persons within the last four weeks.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- A carriage containing H.O. Claughton, a well-known attorney of this city, and Miss Villa Custis, a daughter of Dr. W.G.N. Custis, was run down by a train on the Baltimore and Potomac Railroad at Deanwood, a short distance from the city, about 7 o'clock to-night. Both persons were injured so seriously that they died while being brought to the city. Claughton was a widower, and left four children.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 20. -- The National Executive Board of the United Mine Workers adjourned to-day after having issued a call for a conference of labor leaders to be held in St. Louis Aug. 30. The board rejected the proposition of the Pittsburg operators for a conference to arbitrate the wage dispute in that district, claiming that such action would be prejudicial to the interests of the miners at large.
The prospectus of the evening and day classes of the Twenty-third Street Branch Business Institute, just issued, states the courses of study arranged for the coming Fall and Winter.

Ralph Bernal was a famous English connoisseur, and knew everything having to do with pictures or prints, for his historic and artistic lore were perfect. Mr. F.S. Robinson, in "The Connoisseur," describes Bernal. It was Bernal who found what is called "King Lothair's Magic Crystal." It turned up first in a small bric-a-brac shop in Brussels, and the dealer was glad to take $2.50 for it -- 10 shillings.

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 20. -- The preliminary rounds in the handicap tournament for the Hinkle Cup were played to-day over the regular course of Kebo. The conditions were 18 holes, handicap hole play. The course was fairly good, although in the morning the rain of Thursday made the greens very slow, and there were numerous temporary lakes.

An interesting fact in connection with the publication of Washington Irving's works by G.P. Putnam's Sons is that they are now preparing a new Knickerbocker edition in forty volumes containing all his writings. This is significant, because it was just about fifty years ago, in 1848, when Mr. George Palmer Putnam, the founder of the house, first began to publish Irving's works.

While a few of the members of the Citizens' Union are not opposed to conferring with the Republicans in order to bring about the indorsement or nomination of Seth Low for Mayor by the Republican City Convention, the majority of those who have engaged prominently in the movement for non-partisan city government are unalterably opposed to conferring with the Republicans or any other political party.

The Merchants' Association, in seeking means for attracting to New York the out-of-town trade of this country, has revealed unsuspected opportunities for securing a large trade from Canada. While it has always been recognized that the most prosperous portion of Canada lies naturally as much within the commercial sphere of this metropolis as do the Eastern, Middle, and Southern States, yet it was taken for granted that England controlled absolutely the trade of the Dominion.

Reverence is a trait inborn and felt for material things. Tracking backward to man's most primitive conceptions, the closest association existed between the stock or the stone representative of the deity he worshipped and the god itself. With human advance the incised stone or the papyrus with the written character were endowed with sanctity.

LONG BRANCH, Aug. 20. -- At Norwood Park to-day the golf tournament for the Norwood Field Club cup was brought down to the final round. This will be played tomorrow morning between W.G. Stewart of the Seabright Golf Club and W.J. Travis of the Oakland Golf Club, Bayside, L.I.

There are very respectable Republicans who cannot understand why the Citizens' Union cannot "confer" with the Republican Convention and arrange a ticket on which all the opponents of Tammany can "get together." In the light of past experience and from the party point of view this is not unnatural.

When the New York College of Veterinary Surgeons opens for the term on Sept. 27 it will have a women's class, the first in the country and the first in the world. So says Dr. Edward N. Leavy, lecturer in hygiene and breeding, and assistant in materia medica in the college, who has been assigned by the Faculty to take charge of the class.

The affairs of the Massachusetts Benefit Life Association of Boston, having been placed in the hands of receivers, the association's Committee of the Board on Reinsurance, composed of Carroll D. Wright, Louis Windmuller, and John Henry Rolker, have submitted the appended report, announcing the reinsurance of the association in the New York Life Insurance Company, and stating their reasons therefore after considering the propositions submitted by other companies.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Aug. 20. -- Recent troubles in Atlanta, Ga., over the employment of negro labor in the cotton mills, coming upon the heels of newspaper discussion of that subject in this and other Southern States, bring to the surface a question which is likely to engender much feeling in this section as the mills multiply.

DANVILLE, Ill., Aug. 20. -- Police Magistrate W.R. Timmons, who sentenced a woman to the rock-pile for thirty days, to-day imposed as a punishment on three boys, Harry Sidler, Carl Schmit, and Ed Calberg, an hour's reading of the Bible each day at the police court.

There is a flavor, certainly, of more than usual merit in this chronicle of life in the Yorkshire dales. Perhaps the very choice of such a subject may prejudice even one who has never been there in favor of the book. It means a certain breeziness of landscape background and a direct simplicity of character in the figures set against it.

NEWPORT, Aug. 20. -- The second round of the all-comers' tournament in the National tennis championships was played today and one result of the eight-matches was the defeat of H.S. Mahony, a former English champion by Malcolm D. Whitman of Brookline, who beat the foreigner by a score of 9 -- 7, 6 -- 3, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 1.

That very busy Frenchman, M. Jules Claretie, traveler, journalist, novelist, dramatist, critic, member of the Academy, and doyen of the Comedie Francaise, has just made another journey and written another novel. His journey was to Christiania to see Ibsen and Bjornson. His novel is entitled "L'Accusateur," and arrays an old scientific myth in new clothes of mystery and speculation.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 20. -- Farmers in Iowa are in a better frame of mind than they have been before in years. They are getting out of debt. This is not shown so much by the public records of mortgages paid off as it is in the experience of the loan companies and the banks that conduct a real estate loan business.

SOUTHAMPTON L.I., Aug. 20. -- The second day of the horse show was favored by fine weather, and the success of the events of yesterday drew a large crowd. All the cottagers were present and hundreds of the town folk were also on hand.

The troubles of the Massachusetts Benefit Life Association of Boston, which have been aired in the press at considerable length during the past three months, have culminated in a recommendation by a committee of the Trustees to the members to apply for new policies in one of the leading regular life insurance companies.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Aug. 20. -- There are in the southern part of South Carolina cattle ranges as large as many in the great West, covered with cattle as wild as any that ever roamed over the prairies. This region was, in the days before the war, the most prosperous in the South, the home of the rich rice planters.

ALBANY, Aug. 20. -- Popular interest in the abduction and rescue of John Conway, the five-year-old son of Michael J. Conway, has not yet abated. It was increased, if anything, to-day by the arrest in Schenectady of H.G. Blake, the alleged accomplice of Joseph Hardy in the abduction of the letter's nephew.

NEWARK, Aug. 20. -- There was a dog case on trial to-day before Judge Lambert. It came up on Tuesday before Acting Judge Freeland, who, after hearing a portion of the case, decided to let the matter go over until Judge Lambert returned from his vacation.

TROY, Aug. 20. -- The twenty-eighth annual reunion of the Society of the Army of the Potomac, which was held here to-day, was made memorable by the presence of President McKinley. The public buildings, business houses, and many residences were handsomely decorated with the National colors, and the President received an enthusiastic welcome.

Chinese Inspector J. Thomas Scharf went to Saranac Lake a few days ago on his annual vacation. Yesterday, ten days before his time was up, he returned to the city, having detected and rounded up fifty-two Chinese whom he found temporarily unprovided with the legal documents and registration papers which the Inspector holds are required by the Federal statutes.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 20. -- There was no material change in the coal-strike situation in this vicinity to-day. The operators still declare that it is their intention to start up all the mines in the district as soon after next Monday as new men can be engaged, unless the strikers consent to arbitrate the matter with reference to the Pittsburg district alone, without regard to the situation in other States.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- A statement prepared by the Treasury Department shows that for the first time in the history of trade relations with Japan, the United States is entitled to be considered as a serious competitor with Europe. A recent British report from the legation at Tokio reviews the foreign trade of Japan during the past year, in the supply of machinery walls, nails, and pig iron, the United States assumed a leading place.
In October next The Atlantic Monthly will celebrate its fortieth year of existence, and on the 20th of September it will issue a special October number.
ANSONIA, Conn., Aug. 20. -- The following letter has been received at The Sentinel office from Charles Bonai, the alleged Nichols murderer:

Jimmy Michael's great thirty-three-mile paced match race against J. Frank Starbuck and all world records up to the distance is the paramount cycle racing attraction for to-day. This event will be the star of a meet at Manhattan Beach track, in which there are two amateur races and a contest for the numerous pacemakers which the lions will employ.

STAMFORD, N.Y., Aug. 20. -- As the result of a daring and foolhardy attempt to ride down the road leading from the summit of Mount Utsayautha, Miss Lillian Arnold is suffering from a badly sprained ankle. Her companion in her wild ride, George Van Graveness, was unhurt. Several days ago the two started to climb to Mount Utsayautha's summit, intending to leave the wheels at the foot of the mountain while they made the ascent.

NEWPORT, Aug. 20. -- The following yachts arrived here to-day: Steamer Electra, owned by E.T. Gerry; steamer Admiral, owned by Mr. Comstock; steamer Jathhniel, owned by Mr. Thomas; steamer Hermione, New York Yacht Club; schooner Naoira, owned by H.K. McHoag; sloop Rosalin, owned by Mr. Whiting.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20. -- After losing twelve straight games the Quakers broke their losing streak by winning the first contest from Cincinnati this afternoon. The game was'marked by constant wrangling, during which several of the visitors were fined, and-Ehret, who sueeeeded Dwyer in the second inning, was retired to the bench.

The site of the Tennyson beacon is at Freshwater, in the Isle of Wight, which was for so many years Tennyson's home. The day of his birth, Aug. 5, was most appropriately taken for the dedication of that beacon, which is in the form of an Iona cross. The exact place selected is in the crest of the High Down, and here Tennyson often came, his house at Farringford, being near.

CONSTATINOPLE, Aug. 20. -- There was another explosion here yesterday. It occurred on a hill behind the suburb of Buyukdere, and is believed to have been caused by a bomb. There was no loss of life and nobody was injured, but several Armenians were arrested, and the police captured documents which are said to be of an incriminating nature. Otherwise, there was no disturbance of public order.

BOSTON, Aug. 20. -- Boston men rather deride the auction sale held in New York this week. One of them, who "kept tabs," says that instead of 3,000,000 pounds being sold the actual sales were 100,000 pounds of pulled wool, 43,000 pounds of other lots, 145,000 more probably sold, and 190,000 on which the sale is doubtful. And as to that 100,000 pounds of pulled wool, thereon hangs a tale.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 20. --William C. Whitney is becoming a large landed proprietor in this region. It seems that he has the "abandoned farm" habit, and no one can tell where his acquisition of such property will stop. Up to this Summer he had purchased over 7,000 acres, which was almost half the township of Washington.

The formation, with the proper ceremonies and solemnities, in Auburn, Ind., of the W.L. Meese Marriage Association, is an event of too great significance to be passed over lightly or subjected to the flippant treatment of the professional jester.

For the coming September Century the Count Pierre de Courbelin has contributed an article entitled "Royalists and Republicans." The Court around the Count de Chambord is described, and also the leading French republicans. The article will be illustrated by Castaigne.

Mr. James Payn, who is a veteran among English literary people, and who always goes straight to the point, finds some fault with the official registry of books in the English Stationer's Hall. The matter involved is that of "titles." Now, whether our own system is a good one we do not know.

The resident membership of the Merchants' Association has passed the 800 mark, and the non-resident membership has gone beyond 22,000. This rapid growth of such an organization is said by the officers to be unprecedented. So far as the local membership is concerned, there has been, up to this time, no organized effort, t to increase it.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20. -- Clyde Showalter, a printer and a nephew of Judge Showalter of the Federal Bench, was arrested to-day on the charge of assault with intent to kill, the complainant being James Miller, another printer.

An excellent idea to copy for towns and villages which lack the essentials of a good circulating library is the plan which has been in successful operation in Yonkers for nearly twenty-four years. This is the Yonkers Book Club, which is really a circulating traveling library, limited, however, to the members of the club and their families.

LONDON, Aug. 21. -- The Times publishes this morning a letter from an occasional correspondent, who asserts that India is still all extensive purchaser of silver because 99 out of 100 natives are ignorant of the fact that the mints are closed. They believe they can exchange their ornaments for rupees at any moment. When the truth becomes generally known it will be a grievous cause for disaffection. The correspondent adds:

Superintendent Rider of the Colored Home at Sixty-fifth Street and First Avenue yesterday took eighty inmates of the home to Coney Island for an outing. When he got the party back to the institution last night Nancy Westbrook, an old woman, was missing. He reported the matter to the East Sixty-seventh Street Station, and from there a general alarm was sent out for the woman.

DUBLIN, Aug. 20. -- This morning the Duke of York received a number of addresses at Dublin Castle. On his way there from the Viceregal Lodge the Duke was cordially greeted by the people. He proceeded to the Throne Room, and remained standing while a large number of congratulatory addresses from the _Magistrates of the city and county, and from the business, professional, and other associations and societies were read to him.

Yesterday "September" wheat crossed the dollar line and "cash" wheat sold for $1.06 7/8. This means a good deal to the farmers who last year gave their votes to BRYAN and "free" silver, in the desperate hope of relief from debt and hard times. How much it means a few figures will show.

The story of a revolt of American Jews at Jerusalem against the distribution of funds sent from this country for charity, told in a special from Denver, Col., is exaggerated. Myer S. Isaacs of 27 Pine Street, this city, Secretary of the Palestine Society, said yesterday that he was sure there had been no serious trouble, and no misappropriation of funds by Rabbi Salant, who is a man of the highest character.

Permit me to call your attention to an article in your issue of the 18th inst. entitled "Who Decides on Duties?" in which I am most incorrectly reported as having made statements concerning the dutiable classification of silk ribbons.

-- Birmingham, Ala., is a town that knows the value of advertising, and it has press agents adroit enough to get every one of its numerous achievements into print, usually several times. There probably isn't a paper in the country that has failed to mention Birmingham's new steel mill and to expatiate on the merits and cheapness of its output.
Panic, with narrow escape from disaster, marked the embarkation of a free excursion given yesterday under the auspices of the Grand Street Board of Trade of the Eastern District, Brooklyn.

President Pulliam of the Louisville Club made several wagers before leaving his native town that his team would prove a bit of a surprise to Gotham's "rooters" and win some games from the Giants. That he was not talking shop was clearly demonstrated at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon.
Trap-shooters are not sportsmen -- and it may be questioned whether elegant gentlemen in approved tailor-cut coats; having valets to load their pieces for them at the battue, are sportsmen, either.

BOSTON, Aug. 20. -- A cable dispatch from Buenos Ayres says that only meagre details of the murder at sea on board the three-masted schooner Olive Pecker have as yet been received there. The crew of six men are at Bahia, over 1,000 miles from Buenos Ayres, and will be sent to the United States for trial at the earliest possible date.

The reader of Hall Caine's "The Christian," if he be an American, will wonder at the essentially novel Cockney dialect found in this remarkable book. It is peculiar, for the "e's" and the "a's" are quite transmogrified. An enterprising reporter of The London Daily News interviewed Mr. Hall Caine, and asked him how it was that he had the cocaigne dialect so pat.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 20. -- Judge Clark of the Federal Court, in the case of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad Company and other lines entering here, against the ticket scalpers of this city, rendered a decision against the scalpers, which will prevent them from manipulating the cheap round-trip tickets on sale to the Nashville Exposition, and will close every broker's office in the City of Nashville.

A colored man was reclining against a fence near the brick yard on a sunny afternoon, playing a mouth harmonica. He was oblivious to his surroundings. His soul soared with his melodies into the distant blue. To the white man who chanced to pass it did not occur that the musician, having solved for himself the problem of happiness without riches, was entitled to enjoy the benefits of his discovery without interruption.

It is apparently certain that the question of a system of subways for the pipes, conduits and tubes in underground New York will be urgently presented before the next session of the Legislature. Senator Foley of the Twelfth Senate District said last night that he was satisfied that action could not be further postponed.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 21. -- A host of golfers kept the links of the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club busy all day, and some low scores were made and many exciting matches played. The Challenge Cup, one of the important trophies of the year, was won in fine style by T.M. Robertson in 86 strokes, the second best amateur record made over the course this season.

The French Government in 1820 levied taxes of 939,000,000f.; in 1840 this sum had risen to 1,235,000,000f.; in 1869, to 1,962,000,000f.; in 1880, to 3,130,000,000f., and in 1895 the sum reached 3,375,000,000f. It has been calculated how much Government in France has cost per hour at various periods in this century. Under Napoleon I. the hourly expenditure was 150,000f.; under Louis XVIII., 119,000f.; under Louis Philippe, 150,000f.; under Napoleon III., 249,000f., and in 1882, 463,000f.

LONDON, Aug. 21. -- The fact that the price of wheat has reached $1 a bushel in the United States has produced considerable excitement among grain speculators and others in London. The Secretary of the Baltic said:

LONDON, Aug. 21. -- The Marquis of Salisbury's definite committal of Great Britain to the policy of insisting upon the evacuation of Thessaly by the Turkish troops, whether the Greek indemnity is paid or unpaid, is universally approved by the British press, and is equally condemned by the Continental newspapers. It is difficult to foresee the outcome of the impasse.
To do this work and to remove the 2,500 cubic meters of rubbish, there are 149 brigades of sweepers, numbering 3,345, in conjunction with 550 rubbish carts, and 1,075 horses.

PINE HILL, N.Y., Aug. 21. -- Two youths Fordyce France of New York and William Jennings of Syracuse, had an exciting experience recently at the top of Slide Mountain, in the Catskills. The boys, equipped with stout alpenstocks to aid them in their climb, started early in the morning and did not reach the summit until late in the afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- The previous record for the largest number of Postmastership appointments in one day was almost trebled to-day, when 466 names of new fourth-class Postmasters were announced. It represents an accumulation of cases during a vacation of Fourth Assistant Postmaster General Bristow.

THE same avowed motive that caused Li Hung Chang to visit New York is said to be the influence that impels the King of Siam to come hither -- that he may place a mourning wreath upon the tomb or his dear friend, Gen. Grant.

The working of iron is certainly the most advanced art in this region of Africa. The ore is mined, smelted, and fashioned by the natives with great skill. Outside many of the villages stands the village smithy, merely a roof of shade boughs and grass supported by stakes. Here congregate the village gossips, who justify their presence by an occasional turn at the bellows.

LONDON, Aug. 21. -- The Carl Rosa Opera Company, which is one of the standard British institutions, began its twenty-fifth season at Liverpool this week. Most of the season's stars are new comers in the company, and several of them are Americans. The American mezzo-soprano, Mlle. Theo Dorre, made her first appearance in England Monday, singing the role of Carmen.

A day at Creedmoor is always eagerly looked forward to by the average member of the National Guard of the State of New York. Not because there is so much fun in it -- for there isn't -- but because it is the ambition of every boy in blue to wear the marksman's badge, and, if possible, the sharpshooter's and expert's medal.

ST. GINGOLPH, Aug. 2. -- Just across the lake from Vevey -- on the Lake of Geneva -- closed in by frowning rocky heights, with a rushing, roaring stream dashing them asunder, stand the two St. Gingolphs -- one town in two countries. "La ville Suisse" lies somewhat eastward of the stream. "La ville Francaise" consequently is somewhat west.

LIMA, Ohio, Aug. 21. -- An eastbound extra freight train on the Lake Erie and Western Railroad crashed into an excursion train on the Detroit and Lima Northern at the junction of the roads two miles northwest of this city at 10:40 o'clock last night. The engine and three cars of the freight train and two of the passenger coaches were wrecked and fully forty passengers were injured, several fatally.
SARATOGA, Aug. 21. -- The Saratoga racing season closed to-day. A large crowd was at the track. The races resulted as follows:
In his weekly review of the financial situation, Mr. Henry Labauchere, in the latest number of his Truth received here, has the following things to say apropos of the American stock market:

ST. PETERSBURG, Aug. 21. -- President Faure, who will arrive at Cronstadt on Monday next, will occupy the same apartments at the Peterhof Palace as were assigned to Emperor William of Germany. Each evening the park will be illuminated by 400,000 lights, and the illuminations of this city in honor of the French President will be most splendid.

LARCHMONT yachtsmen are very proud of their clubhouse, and they have every right to be, for it is the handsomest house of its kind in the world. There is no clubhouse for yachtsmen on this side of the Atlantic that can compare with it in any way, and it is much better than the Castle of the Royal Yacht Squadron at Cowes, England, or the other British yacht clubhouses.

Rusie's consistent pitching, aided by some timely batting, enabled the New Yorks to score a decisive victory yesterday at the Polo Grounds in their final game with the Louisvilles. A crowd of 9,000 enthusiasts saw the contest.

The new Produce Exchange record for September contract wheat, made yesterday, is $1.05 5/8, or an advance on the former highest record, $1, made Friday, of 5 5/8 cents, and on the curb record of Friday evening, $1.01 1/2 of 4 1/8 cents. The leading future closed yesterday at $1.05 1/2, a net gain of 6 1/8 cents.

BOSTON, Aug. 21. -- Pittsburg would have won to-day's game but for Donovan's error in the ninth inning. After two men were out the Boston's made two singles and three doubles, and this, aided by Donovan's muff, piled up 6 runs and won the game. It was a slugging contest, and four pitchers were required during the game. The Pittsburgs outbatted the home team, but their fielding was execrable Score:

Next Saturday the Fall yacht racing will begin and the yachts that have been contesting for supremacy in the different classes during the earlier part of the season will renew the struggle and try to settle conclusively which yachts are the best, before going into Winter quarters. The schooners Emerald and Colonia will meet again, and some rattling good contests will be witnessed.

IF the thousands of sightseers who constantly stream into New York and go away with the impression that the rich men of the city live in dull and dreary-looking mansions, crowded into what is known as the fashionable quarter, few if any take the trouble to go just a little beyond the city limits and see the residences that for picturesque situation and beauty of landscape rival the far-famed manors on the Rhine or Thames.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 21. -- A transaction in County Judge Smith Lent's court to-day results in making a boy a brother to his father and a son of his grandmother. It was the adoption by Mrs. Julia C. Stivers of the son of her son, Harold M. Wise, by a former husband.

In all Barnato's mining and industrial operations there was not a single feature of the working, a single apparatus or process used, with which he was not perfectly familiar. In all his company undertakings, such a thing as a speech prepared by others for him to read was absolutely unknown, and no man ever labored more patiently or with more uniform success to convert the refractory when it was advisable.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 21. -- An entertainment with the unique name of the "C -- See" carnival was given at the Casino under the direction of Miss Fanny Pomeroy Wednesday eyening. The proceeds were for the benefit of fhe Casino. The afternoon teas at the Casino are well attended every Thursday, but interest in the Saturday night hops is not what it would be if there were a larger proportion of men.

MISS JULIET THOMPSON is one of the most promising young artists of the day. She developed a decided taste for art when quite a child, and was never happier than when allowed to use her paint brush or crayons.

Granted that the chainless wheel does not swamp the market next year to the exclusion of all other styles, one of the features of next season's cycle equipment will probably be the gear case. English riders have employed the contrivance almost since the wheel came into vogue, but the weight and general ugliness of the English models has militated against their introduction on the Western Hemisphere.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Aug. 21. -- The steamer Coptic, which arrived to-day from Yokohama, via Honolulu, brought the following Japanese advices:

The liquor business does not stand on the same footing with other occupations. It always tends to produce criminality in the population at large and law-breaking among the saloon keepers themselves. It is absolutely necessary to supervise it ridgidly, and to impose restrictions upon the traffic. In large cities the traffic cannot be stopped, but the evils can at least be minimized.

NEWPORT, Aug. 19. -- This has been a gay week in Newport. Each night has seen a large number of dinners, and dances have been held on three nights. There also have been musicales and receptions, and the hops at the Casino, which, by the way, have been poorly attended ever since the big ball given in honor of Admiral Sicard.

The handsomely ornamented elevator in the building at 251 Fifth Avenue has been gradually disappearing for several days. Piece by piece the brasswork has vanished, and on every succeeding morning the elevator looked leaner and less capable of doing its day's work. The ground floor of the building is occupied as a jewelry store by Messrs. Black, Starr Frost, while the upper stories are used as bachelor apartments.

Some new faces were seen at Creedmoor yesterday when Commander Stayton marched a detachment of the Second Naval Battalion down to the shooting range. This battalion has only lately been mustered in, and yesterday some fifty members made their debut in front of the targets. They did well, too, most of them qualifying with little difficulty, thanks to the untiring efforts of their commander, who was at every man's elbow, coaching and teaching.

Miss Elizabeth Emmett of New Rochelle sailed yesterday afternoon on Arthur Iselin's small yacht Hope. She acted as the crew, and the boat started in the annual regatta of the Huguenot Yacht Club, which was sailed off New Rochelle. Miss Emmett is a first-class sailor, and has often sailed on the Hope before, but she never had the experience she had yesterday.

The nineteen bells which comprise the chimes in St. Patrick's Cathedral were blessed last Sunday by Archbishop Corrigan with appropriate ceremonies. When the bells are in position the Cathedral will have the largest set of chimes in the city, that of Trinity consisting of ten bells, and that of Grace Church of but nine.

The work of laying out a Colonial garden surrounding the old Van Cortlandt Mansion in Van Cortlandt Park was begun Aug. 11 by Samuel Parsons, Jr., Superintendent of Parks. Five thousand dollars was appropriated for this work by the Park Department and, according to the plan prepared, the garden will have numerous narrow paths, with artistic designs, bordered with low boxwood hedges.

THE new electric fountain on the Prospect Park Plaza, in Brooklyn, which was started a few days ago, has proved an instantaneous success. On the first night fully 20,000 persons viewed it with pleasure and delight, and since then the crowd has increased so much that the two railroads running to the Plaza, the Flatbush and Vanderbilt Avenue lines, have been taxed to their utmost capacity.

Michael Fitzsimmons, thirty-five years old, of 41 West One Hundred and Thirtieth Street, New York, was shot and died from his wound in Jersey City yesterday. The pistol was fired by James Masterli, twenty-one years old, of 31 Centre Street. So far as Fitzsimmons is concerned, the affair seems to have been accidental, as the weapon was not fired at him.

They have short memories or bear the Citizens' Union no good will who urge it to go into conference with PLATT'S Republican committee. They glibly speak of conference and union as though in this relation those words bore their common and laudable meaning; as though a conference with PLATT to save the city were comparable to a conference of two earnest religious bodies seeking by union of effort to save more souls.

Years ago, when racing was sport indulged in by wealthy men, solely for the recreation it afforded them, a cup race would call forth the greatest amount of enthusiasm. It mattered not if the spectators were lucky enough to back the winner, they combined to give him a hearty welcome when he returned to the judges' stand, and in that manner attested to their enjoyment of the contest.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 21. -- The wholesale dealers, jobbers, and manufacturers of this city met to-day and perfected an organization modeled on the plan of the Merchants' Association of New York. The object of the association is stated to be the preservation to Atlanta of the trade which should be controlled by this market, and to prevent the inroads of other markets by the inducement of low rates.

AMONG the great engineering feats of this century the Trans-Siberian Railroad, now in progress of construction, is likely to prove the greatest. When completed it will place Europe in direct communication with the extreme East, at present only accessible by the long route through the Suez Canal and across the Indian Ocean.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 21. -- Thieves whose work indicates that they are skilled professionals invaded three houses in Larchmont Manor last night and stole property valued at $5,500.

ROME, N.Y., Aug. 21. -- The first convention of sugar beet growers ever held in the United States is in progress in this city this afternoon. It was called by the First New York Beet Sugar Company, which has just established a factory here, and for which about 900 farmers in the sugar beet belt are raising beets.

The few politicians who could be found in Brooklyn yesterday had little to say regarding the reported meeting between Senator Platt and Jacob Worth. Many surmises were made as to its result, but no one could be found who either could or would volunteer any authentic information.

Mr. PLATT has abandoned his attempt to persuade Tammany to make the municipal fight on the issues of Bryanism and free silver. He worked hard and appears to have made liberal expenditures to accomplish it, but the plot was more creditable to his cunning than to his intelligence. "Do you think we are fools enough to take up the issues the Republicans want us to take up?" asked a Tammany chief.

The workmanship of the printer in his own proper field is wonderful when we regard the circumstances under which it was done, but it would not satisfy the requirements of a modern publisher or bookbuyer. It is of its own time, with the faults of that time in manner and matter. The promise of legibility which seem warranted by the bold and black types is delusive.

From 1887 the gold-mining industry expanded by leaps and bounds. Those who are not witnesses of the almost magic growth cannot appreciate the feverish activity, the inventive capacity, and the habit of rapid decision which such a condition of life rears. The whole atmosphere is foreign to Boer traditions and manner of thought, which are obstinately opposed to progress.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21. -- Mr. and Mrs. Ernest A. Whitney, who were married secretly in July, and who, the marriage having been discovered, disappeared Tuesday evening, are at Niagara Falls on a wedding tour. The bridegroom's father, A.V. Whitney, received the news to-day in a brief note from his son.

They had just got the new scheme for inspecting baggage by X rays in operation, and the haughty young woman who had just got off the steamer was waiting to have hers inspected. Furthermore, she thought there had been more delay than was necessary, and she was somewhat provoked. Consequently, when one of the officials motioned her to step a little to one side she declined to move.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21. -- The past week has brought revelations of the most barefaced frauds in the Water Works Department of the city. A conservative estimate gives $500,000 as the sum of which Chicago has been robbed during the last two years. But, in addition to direct stealing, there can be no doubt that through lax methods of administering the department the city loses more than $1,000,000 each year, and that is a low estimate.

The Emperor Charles V., being curious to ascertain the opinion of his subjects regarding himself and his government, often departed incognito to public and other resorts to glean information. His boots needed repairs, and one night at Brussels he wended his steps to the establishment of a cobbler. Unfortunately, it was St. Crispin's Day, and instead of discovering the cobbler engaged in his work he found him with his acquaintances celebrating his patron's festal day.

LONDON, Aug. 21. -- At the second day's racing of the Nottingham Summer meeting to-day the Lorillard-Beresford Stable's three-year-old brown filly Belisama won the Bentinck Plate.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 21. -- The news of the week to the Summer colony is the announcement of the engagement of Miss Annie Griffen of New York to Bernard Baruch of the same city. Miss Griffen has spent several seasons at Maplewood, and is very well known and popular in the young society set. She is spending the Summer here, and Mr. Baruch often comes up from New York for a few days' stay.

Gen. James Jourdan, President, of the Kings County Elevated Railroad, announced yesterday a proposed consolidation of railroad interests in Brooklyn which he confidently predicted would greatly increase the value of his line. The plan as presented will give the Kings County line a number of new and valuable feeders.

NEWPORT, Aug. 21. -- The Meadowbrooks defeated, the Rockaway Seconds this afternoon on the old polo lot for the Newport Cups for teams whose handicap does not exceed 20 goals. The play was good, but the Meadowbrooks were too strong for their opponents. During the game the ponies of Mr. Franklyn and Stanley Mortimer had a collision, and Mr. Mortimer had his right leg broken.

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 21. -- According to a telegram received by Admiral Upsher from Rear Admiral Sicard, the North Atlantic squadron will be at Bar Harbor Tuesday, and will remain until the 30th. What will be done for the officers of the fleet when they arrive is not yet decided upon. It is probable the Directors of Kebo will arrange a grand subscription ball in their honor.
RUTLAND, Vt., Aug. 21. -- Vermont sportsmen are anticipating with pleasure the opening of the deer season in October -- the first open season in two decades.

One of the most thoroughly unhappy and uncomfortable men in Brooklyn on Friday was Isaac S. Remson of Grand Street, his trouble being caused by the fact that he drew a baby as a prize package during the free excursion of the Grand Street Board of Trade on that day.

LONG BRANCH, Aug. 21. -- Many exciting and amusing incidents, the presence of Gov. Griggs of New Jersey, the defeat of the expert English golfer, W.G. Stewart, by W.J. Travis of Bayside, L.I. -- an amateur of less than two years' experience -- and the award of half a dozen handsome prizes were among the characteristic features of the open golf tournament of the Norwood Field Club, which closed to-day.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21. -- The 15,000 people who went to the Washington Park course this afternoon saw the fastest first heat ever paced, and probably the fastest fourth quarter. The conditions were good for fast time. The track was springy and fast, and the weather was warm, but during the earlier part of the afternoon there was quite a little breeze, which the pacers had to breast on the back stretch.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 20. -- T.A. Lewis of this city has a plan for reaching the north pole. He spent several years on a whaling vessel and was shipwrecked in Cumberland Inlet, passing the entire Winter on its shores.

Russia is the choirmaster, and none dare oppose her wishes with regard to the Eastern question. If she had not been able to threaten India, the Armenian troubles might have been quickly settled by the appearance of our fleet at Constantinople, but we dared not send it there after Russia had said she would permit no interference with Turkey.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 21. -- Walter S. Smith of Roselle was arrested here to-day by Detective Donovan of the First Precinct on the charge of swindling "Thad" Doane, Jr., of Plainfield out of $75. The arrest was made on a bench warrant issued by the Court of General Sessions of New York on Aug. 12.

The tribunal of the Board of United States General Appraisers, whose jurisdiction extends over the arid realm of tariff questions, could hardly be imagined as humorous in itself or as the cause of humor in others. And yet, from the very complex nature of the questions that come before it, there frequently arises from the decisions of the Board the unmistakable aroma of humor.

There are a great many importers in New York who assert that the United States Government owes them money which they cannot collect. The amounts thus claimed to be due range all the way from $5 to $200,000, and the alleged aggregate is several millions of dollars. This floating indebtedness of the Government represents import duties collected by customs officers, which the courts have decided to be illegal.

CHARLESTON, Aug. 21. -- One of the most important matters to come before the Grand Army of the Republic at its encampment in Buffalo next week will be a proposition for the establishment of a sanitarium for the veterans of the army and navy of the United States at Castle Pinckney, Charleston Harbor.

" I am ashamed of you, Jonathan," said the Judge, who is perpetual President and acknowledged oracle of the Ancients' Club, to me the other evening. "A man of your ago and experience ought to be incapable of writing infantile nonsense about nonpartisanship in city government."
SARATOGA, Aug. 21. -- A hop is a funny thing.
" Clean Streets" is the title of Pamphlet No. 2 issued by the Citizens' Union in its series of campaign documents. The argument is summarily expressed in this text, printed on the front cover:

Sprinting swiftly ahead of the big pacing sextet, pedaled by a half dozen of the speed-test of professional racers, who had failed to distance him. Jimmy Michael jumped the tape a winner against J. Frank Starbuck in the greatest match race of the season on the Manhattan Beach track yesterday afternoon.

LONDON, Aug. 21. -- The Spanish Government has prohibited the publication in Spain or the telegraphing abroad of the details of the execution at Vergara yesterday of Michele Angiolillo, the Spanish Anarchist, who shot and killed Senor Canovas del Castillo, the Premier of Spain, on Sunday, Aug. 8. Letters, however, have been received here containing details of the execution.

Pupils of Boys' School No. 35, who attended there during the years 1835 to 1869, are to have a reunion in this city, and at the same time will give a dinner and reception for their former Principal, Thomas Hunter, now President of the Normal School.

WEYMOUTH, Aug. 21. -- In the regatta here to-day there was an exciting race beween Bona, Meteor, and Aurora. A good breeze was blowing. Bona saved her time by half a minute and won. Aurora was second, beating Meteor by four seconds on time allowance.

ALBANY, Aug. 21. -- The developments of the day in the Conway abduction case have been few, the only important one being the alleged establishment of the identity of the man called "Knapps" as Albert Warner, the New York lawyer. It is said the several notorious New York crooks were tools of Warner in a wholesale kidnapping plot.

When the Cunarder steamship Umbria arrived yesterday she brought as a second cabin passenger a man giving his name as M. Planas. Immigration officials had recently been notified to look out for and detain a Spanish Anarchist of that name, who had been ordered to leave France.

VIENNA, Aug. 8. -- The "new course" reaction in Germany has been inaugurated by a bold attempt on liberty made by the Junker party. But the attack has failed. A bill was submitted to the Prussian Diet providing that the police may dissolve meetings at which revolutionary tendencies are manifested, and that it may dissolve societies which pursue such objects.

A quarrel between Frenchmen in a room they shared at 19 Minetta Street, ending in the stabbing of one of them by the other, with probably fatal effect, early yesterday morning. The injured man, who lies in a critical condition in St. Vincent's Hospital, is Emile Murra, forty-seven years old, employed as a kitchen hand in a Thompson Street restaurant.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Aug. 21. -- One of the most enthusiastic matches, though far from the closest, of the season, was played on the links of the Morris County Golf Club to-day, between a team of thirteen from Baltusrol and thirteen of the best players of the Morris County Club. It resulted in a victory for the Morris County Club by 14 holes. The score was:

MIDDLETOWN, N.J., Aug. 21. -- One of the most interesting historic buildings in Monmouth County is Christ Church, in Middletown. Precisely how old the church organization is the records do not show, but it is said to be the pioneer Episcopal Church of New Jersey.

The dealings of the last few days, while not numerous, or involving large amounts, have been of a substantial sort, that show improving market conditions. Several good-sized transactions are in sight in all stages of development, from the vaguest rumor to "all but closed."

Mr. Frank S. Bond, Vice President of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad, was a little surprised last week to learn that the wheat crop along the 6,000 miles of the St. Paul system had suffered terrific damage. Other officials of the St. Paul were equally surprised to learn of the melancholy failure which had overtaken the crops they had thought to be ripening in their territory.

Among the cottagers at Ocean Grove each Summer can be seen a unique and interesting old lady, whose name is known in Sunday school and church circles the world over, and who can safely say that she has more hymns to her credit than any mortal, living or dead.

The Temple of Humanity, the pet hobby of the aged Lazarus Morgenthau, has come to an end, and it is said that Mr. Morgenthau has exhausted his liberal means in a philanthropic enterprise in which he failed to secure the support he had looked for.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 21. -- This was baby day in Asbury Park, and the eighth annual parade of infants was decidedly successful. The baby parade was first started by Senator James A. Bradley eight years ago, and since that time it has been looked forward to as the most important event in the Summer's entertainment.

Every available rock and spot of green sward of the crescent that forms the pretty little Horseshoe Harbor at Larchmont was occupied yesterday afternoon by the spectators of the annual aquatic sports of the Horseshoe Harbor Club. Over 1,000 persons were there, and, as only club members or their friends were entered, the rivals in the contests for the most part were well known, and the applause so much the more hearty and genuine.

In the foregoing statement is ample refutation of sensational tales surfeiting Wall Street during the past week. Marvin Hughitt, foremost among the railroad men of America, a man of probity and without speculative relationships, a man upon whose word every other man in the financial world can depend to the ultimate, says prospects for crops and business are excellent, crop destruction reports wholly unwarranted.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- Among a few Republicans in office and out of it -- the latter hoping to get in -- there has been shown a disposition to predict an early overthrow of the civil service law as the result of the President's recent order requiring that the grounds for dismissal shall be preferred in writing against every person to be dismissed from the classified service.

The Alabama took in coal at ten different ports, and from first to last she consumed 1,786 tons, about 133 tons going to the bottom with her after the combat with the Kearsarge. Between August, 1862, and June, 1864, she took on board stores (in all departments) to the total value of $28,093, and the amount of property she destroyed upon the high goes was estimated at $5,000,000.

The two kinds which reach London, red deer and fallow, are in season at different times, and probably need some difference of treatment in preparing for the table. The season for red deer venison opens in the beginning of July, is at its best in August and the first fortnight of September, and closes, or ought to close, when the stags begin roaring at the end of that month.

LENOX, Aug. 21. -- Arrangments have been completed for the golf tournament, which will be held the week commencing Sept. 20. John E. Alexandre has offered a cup and Mrs. De Heredia has given a cup for the women's tournament, which will be contested for on Monday. On Tuesday play will begin for the Lenox Club Cup, which was won last season by A.H. Fenn, and which he must win again in order to keep.

Several men of Southern birth who are now residents of this city recently met together at the house of one of their number for a social evening. The conversation at one time drifted back to the war, and stories reminiscent of those days were told. Among them was this, related by a Tennesseean:

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 21. -- William Malone, aged twenty-two years, a patient at the Hudson River State Hospital with suicidal tendency, made a daring escape from the men's department early Friday morning. Malone broke the heavy iron bars in his window, and when an opportunity to escape offered he pried the broken bars apart and leaped thirty feet to the rocks below.

There seems to be nothing that men are so afraid of as religious enthusiasm. I do not quite understand it. If there is an election pending, all those who have any interest in the election set to work to create enthusiasm. They write articles in the newspapers, make speeches on the platform, organize military and semi-military companies, plan barbecues, scatter tracts.

The Merchants' Association is now beginning its third month of active work. It was incorporated June 19. Three months ago it was difficult to get any one to believe in it. Many merchants of this city, when asked to take an interest in the work of organization, declared that the whole project was chimerical. Some said it would have been a good thing fifty years ago, but was out of the question now.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- A board of officers to consist of Col. John I. Rodgers, Fifth Artillery; Lieut. Col. Henry C. Hasbrouck, Fourth Artillery, and Capt. Crosby P. Miller, Assistant Quartermaster, is appointed to meet here Sept. 1, for the purpose of considering the question of the location and distribution of the present force of the artillery arm in the care and preservation of the seacoast armament and material.

ORANGE, Aug. 21. -- A heavy shower drove a large number of golfers off the links of the Essex County Country Club's course in Hutton Park this afternoon, and spoiled several matches which gave promise of being interesting. A close match game between Alexander Finlay and Edward F. Burke was won by the former with one hole up.
PARIS, Aug. 22. -- Gen. Lopez Dominguez, who was Spanish Minister of War in the last Cabinet of Senor Sagasta, is now in Paris.

The physicians of the city are apparently unanimous in the opinion that the digging up of the streets for repairs to underground pipes and conduits and other purposes is a serious injury to the health of the public, and that a system of subways would prevent much of the sickness from which the people now suffer, and would diminish the death rate.

Fifteen persons, men and women, were more or less seriously injured last evening in a collision between a trolley car of the Marcy Avenue line and a tally-ho coach loaded with the members and friends of the John Palmer Association of Brooklyn returning home from a day's outing at Plum Beach, via Sheepshead Bay.

In making that offer the Republicans will show to the public the sincerity of their desire to create harmony among the friends of good government. Everybody will recognize both their single-mindedness and their good sense. No organization really desirous of beating Tammany will refuse to join in a conference so obviously essential to the accomplishment of the end.

Everything is in readiness now for the Futurity of 1897, which will be decided tomorrow at Sheepshead Bay at the opening of the Coney Island Jockey Club's Fall meeting. Accumulated subscriptions, together with the $8,750 added by The Jockey Club, make the value of the stake $39,610, and, with the entrance money of $250 each for starters, the stake will probably be worth $43,000.
" Bossism" in politics, in business, in social life, and in ecclesiastics, was the subject of a sharp rebuke at the hands of the Rev. Dr. F.R. Morse, in the Calvary Baptist Church yesterday.

William Dunn, forty-two year old, of 444 West Forty-second Street, was found by James Regan early yesterday morning sitting on the stoop of a house at the southeast corner of Twenty-seventh Street and Eleventh Avenue. The man was bleeding from a wound in the abdomen. A policeman was called, who summoned an ambulance from Roosevelt Hospital, where the man was taken.

Let us suppose that Mr. CUTTING and Mr. QUIGG, Mr. LAROCQUE and Mr. GIBBS, Mr. PINE and Mr. GRUBER were met in some convenient and neutral place of assembly for conference about a union of forces. Mr. QUIGG would draw a horrible picture of the evils of Tammany government, and appeal with moving eloquence for the amalgamation of all the anti-Tammany organizations.

The tremendous speed of the little Welsh wheelman, MICHAEL, lends some confirmation to the theory that the combination of light weight and a strong pair of legs ought to produce a fast rider. MICHAEL weighs 100 pounds, and his leg muscles are like steel. He rides easily, but his great speed is made easier by his trick of riding close up to the quartet that "paces" him.

BUFFALO, Aug. 22. -- Buffalo is ready for the army of veterans which is on its way here to attend the thirty-first annual encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic. During the night hundreds of veterans and their friends arrived, and to-day they are coming in by thousands. It is estimated that nearly 8,000 strangers were in town yesterday, and that from 15,000 to 20,000 came in to-day.

The painting of the Saviour, with the name of Guido Reni inscribed upon it, which was found on Third Avenue on Saturday afternoon, remained in the East One Hundred and Fourth Street Police Station all Saturday night unclaimed, while Capt.Creeden and his men pondered over the mystery surrounding it. The explanation lay within their grasp, however, all the night.

Last week the Bostons increased their lead in the pennant race by 9 points. The Baltimores started out by defeating the Pittsburgs three straight games, and on Thursday morning were within 3 points of the leaders. The unexpected then occurred, and, while the Clevelands were trouncing the champions in two games, the Bostons were benefiting by their series with Pittsburg. It was a most disastrous week :for the Baltimores.

Col. Walter Katte, one of the Commissioners for the Park Avenue improvement above One Hundred and Sixth Street, has decided to fight the resolution adopted by a majority of the Commissioners removing him from his place as superintending engineer of the work. The resolution presented by Commissioner Ernest Harrier was adopted at a meeting of the commission on Aug. 17.

ORANGE, Aug. 22. -- Mayor John Gill of this city announced yesterday that he is a candidate for the office of County Register. He is the third candidate in the field from the Oranges in the Republican ranks, the other two being Joseph Ellor and Edgar Williams of East Orange.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 22. -- Unity, a camp of negro workmen employed in building the new Pittsburg, Bessemer and Lake Erie Railroad, is keeping up its reputation for riot and bloodshed. The report comes from there to-night of a small riot during the day and three or four individual fights, in which one man was fatally shot and wounds inflicted on a large number of others.

Dr. Paul Gibier of the Pasteur Institute at 1 West Ninety-seventh Street arrived on the French liner La Gascogne yesterday after six weeks spent in studying the French methods of treating tuberculosis. Dr. Gibier shared his time between the School of Medicine of the University of France, at Paris, and the Bacteriological Institute, at Lisle.

TENNILLE, Ga., Aug. 22. -- Andrew Green, a negro desperado of this place, while under the influence of whisky this afternoon, shot at his wife, fatally wounding another woman. In an attempt to escape he shot George Heath, a wealthy planter. Then he attended service at a church a few miles from the scene of his crimes.

PILSEN, Bohemia, Aug. 22. -- The disturbances begun on Friday by the fanatical opponents of the Jews were resumed yesterday. They arose out of a quarrel between a German Jewish student named Hartmann and a Bohemian student named Schmidt. While the police were escorting Hartmann from the Town Hall an anti-Jewish mob attacked them and then smashed all the windows in the synagogue, the Jewish schools, and the houses of the best-known Jews.

Harlem oarsmen turned out in large numbers yesterday both for the purpose of pleasure and in order to select men and train those already selected for the Middle States regatta, which is to be rowed on Labor Day.

TORONTO, Ontario, Aug. 22. -- At the foot of Cherry Street there is a float, or raft, made of rough timber, kept for conveying workmen from the mainland to the breakwater, a distance of about 100 yards. This afternoon twenty-one children, boys and girls, ranging from eight to thirteen years of age, crowded on the raft for the purpose of going to bathe at the breakwater.

The imagination of Mr. KIPLING, which has lately endowed the steam locomotive with mind and heart, and his facile literary art which has translated its puffing and snorting into forcible idiomatic English, may in time be lent to the idealization of the new mechanical wagon with the awful name -- automobile. For that thing has come to stay.
LONDON, Aug. 23. -- The Daily Chronicle announces this morning the settlement of the long-pending strike in the famous slate quarries of Lord Penrhyn, in Wales.

WHITESTONE, L.I., Aug. 22. -- According to John Lathan, keeper of the New York Yacht Club's station, Miss Juliette Mienell, who has been spending the Summer at the Park Hotel here, to-day succeeded in swimming the East River from a point near the boathouse. Lathan says the young woman entered the water at 3:30 o'clock and reached the pier line in New York City at 4:35 o'clock.

The railway situation in the Southwest is a subject of acute interest in Wall Street at present. Advices as to the earning capacity of the roads doing business in this territory are of the most encouraging sort.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 22. -- Both sides in the coal miners' strike were apparently resting to-day, but it was developed that at the conference to-morrow there will probably be trouble. By many it is believed that M. D. Ratchford, the National President of the miners' organization, will not be present.

President Andrews, in resigning his chair as the President of Brown University, laid stress upon liberty of opinion as of more importance to a university than large gifts, where such freedom was withheld. He here assumes the position that personal judgment alone must determine what constitutes individual liberty and self-respect.

PORTLAND, Oregon, Aug. 22. -- Dr. David Starr Jordan, Commissioner in Chief of the fur seal investigations, and George A Clark, Secretary of the commission, arrived in Seattle on the revenue cutter Rush, Capt. W.H. Roberts commanding, and passed through here to-day, going to San Francisco. The party left Unalaska on the morning of Aug. 13.

MONTVALE, N.J., Aug. 22. -- Mrs. Jacob Turkyle is defending St. Paul's Episcopal Church against an officer of the law. Borough Marshal White has a writ of attachment against the organ used in the church. The return of the writ is due tomorrow, but it is as yet unserved, and it is predicted it will be returned unsatisfied.

To the relief of some and the secret disappointment of others of the residents of the tenements in Fifty-seventh Street, west of Tenth Avenue, nature has ended the Boran-Lenahan feud. For nearly ten months it has annoyed the neighborhood, while it also furnished gossip for it, but now it is over, and the ordinary, everyday incidents of tenement life will again receive their due share of attention.
Mr. Low's candidacy is in visible danger from his delayed announcement of purpose and from the persistent rumors of negotiation with the Platt leaders.

LONDON, Aug. 22. -- Money is abundant, although the rates rose sharply at the beginning of last week on the expectation of the withdrawal of gold for the United States. The quick response of the Continental exchanges indicated that if the United States wants gold the Continent is ready to supply it, and, as a consequence, rates eased off again.

WOODSTOCK, Vt., Aug. 22. -- Thomas C. Seaver, Judge of Probate for Windsor County, was shot this morning by William W. Lawrence while standing on the piazza of his residence, the ball penetrating his right lung, lodging under the shoulder blade. The wounded man is reported to be resting quietly to-night, and the attending physician thinks he will recover, although his age, beyond sixty years, will tell against him.

It would not be fair for a citizen of the metropolis to gird at the village of New Rochelle because of any supposed artistic deficiencies in its Soldiers' Monument, which stands conspicuously on the triangular green in front of the Presbyterian Church at the junction of Main and Huguenot Streets. Few of our own public monuments are much to brag about.

Mrs. Rachel Ellis, an eccentric old woman, was found dead yesterday morning on the kitchen floor of her apartment, at 146 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn. She had been dead for several days, as the body was badly decomposed, and the odor which came from her rooms led to its discovery by Mrs. Mary Lowery, one of her neighbors.

BOSTON, Aug. 22. -- Edward Parker Deacon, the descendant of an old and once distinguished family of this city, the man who on Feb. 17, 1892, killed M. Emile Abeille in Mrs. Deacon's apartments at Cannes, France; the man whose exploits and actions have been the talk of society in France, England, and America, and have created considerable public interest, was on Saturday committed to the McLean Hospital at Waverly.

The meeting held last Monday night in Clarendon Hall to glorify the death of Canovas by Golli, the Anarchist, was discussed last night at 1,524 Avenue A. There were twenty-five persons present, a majority of whom were Anarchists. The most prominent one was Emma Goldman, who made a speech in which she reiterated her statement that she was glad that Canovas was dead.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 22. -- The Press will say to-morrow:

A Jersey weather sharp predicted a cyclone for yesterday, but this did not prevent nearly every able-bodied person in Greater New York from getting out to enjoy the phenomenally fine weather of the day, nor did it diminish the parade of wheels on every street, avenue, and road where the wheel is accustomed to spin.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22. -- The National Association of Merchants and Travelers had possession of Chicago last week. Thousands of merchants bought at least $5,000,000 worth of goods. This is the lowest estimate of the sales of one week, and a similar gathering is to be held one week in September, when that sum, it is expected, will be surpassed.

For an hour yesterday it appeared as if Coney Island was to be reformed, but it was only for that hour, and afterward the good old times prevailed. The temporary purity was due to the fact that at Police Headquarters some one discovered an old law which prohibits everything at Coney Island with the exception of life itself.

The Merchants' Association begins the third week of excursions with the promise of bringing to New York even a greater number of buyers than in either of the previous weeks. Some new territory has been opened in the South and Southwest, and it is expected that it will result in the coming of several hundred buyers. Besides, the old territory is still open, and many new excursions will be started Friday.

Tammany leaders who have counted for months on the support of the German-American voters in the coming municipal campaign on the personal liberty and open Sunday issues had their hopes partially confirmed yesterday by an interview with Oswald Ottendorfer cabled from Carlsbad to The World.
CHICAGO, Aug. 22. -- William T. Baker, President of the Chicago Board of Trade, and other operators were interviewed today in relation to the immense rise in the price of wheat. President Baker said:

NEWPORT, Aug. 22. -- The following yachts arrived here to-day: Sloop Varena, owned by A.E. Morrison; sloop Swanonoa, owned by S.A. Lewis, steamer Foinette, owned by Mr. Preston; steamer Josephine, owned by P.A. Widener; steamer Marietta E., owned by H.B. Moore; steamer Sovereign, owned by M.C. Borden; steamer Free Lance. owned by F. Schermerhorn.

The leaders in the race for the batting prize of the Metropolitan Cricket League altered their positions considerably by the games played on Saturday. C.H. Clarke now tops the figures with the splendid record of 95.75, and J.F. Curran goes back to second place with 54.25. Mr. R. Cobb moves up among the leaders, his figures being advanced from 15.60 to 34.50.

BUFFALO, Aug. 22. -- The city is profusely decorated. Bunting of the color of the flag, draped, suspended, woven, and festooned; floats everywhere. Here and there a knot of black crape stands out in sombre relief from the profusion of gay colorings, telling its story of those whom death has mustered from the long line of blue.

It is an old complaint as to New York that its citizens will do little that requires united effort, that they have little of that public spirit which has done so much for other cities of population, resources and interests far less than those of New York. The criticism has in the past been well founded. It is not hard to see why. The reasons may be summed up in one word -- size.

HASTINGS-ON-THE-HUDSON, N.Y., Aug. 23. -- The Assessors of the town of Greenburgh met in the corporation rooms here to-day to hear any persons who felt aggrieved at their assessments and who had previously filed an application for a reduction with the Assessors. The board is through receiving applications, and is now devoting its time to getting further information concerning the property on which reductions are sought.

In the issue of Aug. 19 of The Silver Knight-National Watchman, published at Washington, D.C., "Senator WILLIAM M. STEWART, Editor," we find the following remarks attributed to Senator STEWART, and described by that newspaper as a denial of the report of an interview with him recently published in THE TIMES:

" I am heartily in favor of a system of subways," said President Wilson of the Board of Health yesterday. "If we had these subways now," he added, with a smile, "there would be some means at least of passing along the streets and avenues that have been torn up for repaying so long. But, seriously, I consider the subways an absolute necessity in our advanced state of growth and development.
P.S. Treacy has sold to Joseph L. Stanton the brick building 2,345 Broadway, 25 by 96.
TERRE HAUTE, Aug. 23. -- E.V. Debs issued a call to-night for a convention in St. Louis Aug. 30 in the coal miners' interest.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23. -- Samuel Burg, the young Danish barber who was put into a hypnotic sleep Sunday afternoon by "Prof." William Held for a sleep of seven days, had his slumbers rudely interrupted to-day by members of the Police Department, acting under the direction of Chief Kipley.

ALBANY, Aug. 23. -- Attorney General Hancock has denied the application of P.B. Armstrong for the commencement of an action to remove the officers of the Mutual Fire Insurance Company of New York, on the ground that the company was a mutual company transacting a stock corporation business and that the management of the company was unduly extravagant.

This will be a lively week for golf players, as an uncommonly large number of important events are scheduled, but nearly all are outside of New York. The most important event is the women's championship, at the Essex County Club, near Boston. The outcome of the struggle among the women golfers will be watched with keen interest throughout the country.

The Commercial Travelers' Sound Money League of America, which held meetings at Prince Street and Broadway during the last campaign, organized yesterday as a permanent political association to fight the free silver issue. There were thirty-five members of the temporary association present when Charles G. Braxmar called the meeting to order in the old quarters in Prince Street and explained the object of the call.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 23. -- At the semiannual meeting of the New Jersey Division, L.A.W., this evening, the Secretary and Treasurer, James C. Tattersall of Trenton, reported that 2,752 new members had been enrolled since Dec. 1, and that 2,831 members had renewed their membership. There are now 6,280 members in the division.
Charles A. Sherman, the Secretary of the Race Committee of the Seawanhaka-Corinthlan Yacht Club, has returned from Montreal, where he went to see the races between the Glencairn II. and iVfomo.

There was unceasing bustle and hum of voices in the headquarters of the Merchants' Association yesterday, and the comfortable reception room wore the appearance of a Summer hotel office just after the arrival of a well-filled train. Out-of-town merchants, from far and near, called to enroll their names on the non-resident members' register, which last evening contained about 1,200 signatures.
READVILLE, Mass., Aug. 23. -- The grand circuit of light-harness horses began on the Readville track to-day with the atmosphere raw and the track heavy.

SOUTHOLD, L.I., Aug. 23. -- Some interest has been aroused here by the announcement of the wedding of Harry M. Payne of the historic whiskers, and Miss Annie A. Allis, originally of Arlington, Mass., who was his teacher at school.

The Exchanges reflect one aspect of the amazing spectacle which this country now presents to itself and the world. The talk of the railway managers reflects another. Some of them argue that they have made such provision that there is no danger, so far as their roads respectively are concerned, that the burden thrown upon our system of transportation by the movement of the crops may be greater than we can bear.
LONDON, Aug. 24. -- A dispatch to The Times from Simla says:
PARIS, Aug. 23. -- Much bunting was displayed here to-day in honor of the meeting in Russia of President Faure and the Czar.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23. -- The upward rush of the wheat market was stopped to-day. The September option was sold as high as $1.02 1/2 per bushel on the curb but broke badly on 'Change under a flood of realizing sales, declining to 95 cents in the first five minutes' trading and closing at 96, a decline of 4 1/2 cents since Saturday.

Two more theatres opened their doors for the Fall season last night, the Garrick and the Knickerbocker. The threatening weather helped rather than hurt the theatrical business all over the city. The audiences were invariably large.

It was reported yesterday that the decision arrived at on Saturday to advance the price of spirits 1 cent a gallon had gone into effect, and that the ruling price was 11 cents per gallon, as against 10 cents last week, which was an advance of 1 cent over the price that governed the market ten days ago.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- Postmaster Van Cott of New York City was here today, and conferred with Postmaster General Gary and Assistant Postmasters General Heath and Shallenberger. Mr. Van Cott wants a branch station established at the New York Central Station; wants the sub-station on Dey Street put in its old place, a short distance away, and a sub-station established at either Broadway and Grand Street or Broadway and Howard Street.

A report by Sir George Bonham of the British Embassy in Madrid on Spanish finance has been issued by the Foreign Office. The budget for 1896-7, as finally passed in the Cortes, showed a revenue of 30,771,450, and an expenditure of 30,456,584, and the balance thus estimated was in fact slightly exceeded by the actual results. For the current financial year the estimated expenditure is 34,954,635 and the revenue 35,331,150.

Seth Low will not submit his letter of acceptance to the Citizens' Union Executive Committee at its meeting this afternoon. That ceremony has been indefinitely postponed. The Executive Committee will not even make him the formal offer of the nomination. That ceremony has also been indefinitely postponed. Both postponements are due to the conflicting views of Mr. Low's friends in Brooklyn and Mr. Low's friends in New York.
SARATOGA, Aug. 23. -- None of the Tammany politicians who have been here would admit to-day that any conference had been held with Leader John C. Sheehan.

MIDDLESBOROUGH, Ky., Aug. 23. -- It is reported here that George H. Steel, ex-Sheriff, and Samuel Young, Deputy Sheriff of Leslie County, were both killed in a combat at Hyden yesterday. Both men fought to desperation, and both fell dead in the fifth round. Young had three bullets through him, and lived two hours. Steel was a Democratic leader, and Young a Republican leader, and they quarreled over politics.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- Consul Jarnigan of Utilla, Honduras, has sent to the State Department a report on an important concession by the Honduras Government granted to the Honduras Syndicate. This corporation is composed, says the Consul, of well-known capitalists and financiers of the United States, mostly located in New York.

" The cause of the present boom in the West is undoubtedly due in a great measure to the large crops and high prices caused by the failure of crops in other countries. But the fact that prosperity has set in in the East cannot be accounted for in any other way than by the wise policy of the Republican Party in restoring a protective tariff.

ST. PETERSBURG, Aug. 23. -- From early this morning there has been a scene of great animation here and a steady flow of people toward the quays, where they embarked on profusely decorated steamers in order to meet President Faure, who arrived at Cronstadt on the French warship Pothuan at 11:30 A.M. After a rainy night, splendid weather prevailed.

BOSTON, Aug. 23. -- The Bostons climbed two more rounds of the pennant ladder today by winning both games from the Louisvilles. Errors gave the Bostons all their, runs in the first game. Louisville made two hits off Nichols in the first inning, and only one more in the ninth. In the second game the Bostons batted "Dad" Clarke's curves at will.

Criticism by out-of-town wool merchants and wool commission men generally will not deter the managers of the Wool. Exchange from holding more wool auctions. They acknowledge that the auction of last week may have had several objectionable features, but that was due simply to inexperience and not to the impracticability of the plan.

NEWPORT, Aug. 23. -- The biggest surprise of the tennis season was the defeat to-day of William A. Larned, the acknowledged leader of the game in this country, by Hugh A. Nisbet of England in the semi-final round of the all-comers' tournament for the national championship. Larned was twice within one point of winning the match.

Wall Street attributed consequence to the reappearance in Wall Street of Mr. J. Pierpont Morgan yesterday. There is no doubting where Mr. Morgan stands. It is amply recognized that he is never at any time a stock market boomer, but his confidence in the quality of the new good times needs no announcement.
The wheat market reacted yesterday on lack of export business and vast liquidation to obtain profits, Chicago, as during last week, giving the cue to New York.

If the clerk of the weather can be induced to allow the sun to shine up to noon to-day it will probably cast its beams on one of the largest crowds that ever journeyed to the Coney Island Jockey Club's pretty track at Sheepshead Bay, for this afternoon there will be decided there the richest stake on the American turf -- the Futurity.

It is not infrequent that the sequence of events forms in itself an admirable comment on the incident which gave origin to the series. Following things out to their logical conclusion is not a bad way of demonstrating their lack of value, and the reductio ad absurdum is by no means the worst of arguments.

ISLIP, L.I., Aug. 23. -- William K. Vanderbilt, whose estate, known as the Idle Hour, at Oakdale, in the town of Islip, is one of the finest on Long Island, is the latest millionaire to protest against his assessment this year. He is down on the books of the assessors of this town this year for $250,000, an increase of more than 200 per cent. over last year.
