The New Yorks won from the Clevelands at the Polo Grounds yesterday when defeat appeared certain, and the rain played a prominent part in landing the victory. It began to rain when the visitors took their turn at the bat in the sixth inning. The score was 5 to 2 against the local team when the Clevelands were all out, and the rain was falling fast enough to warrant the calling of "Time."

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 23. -- Richard Croker disposed of the remnant of his breeding stock at this place at auction to-day. The sale was by orders received from London, and embraced twenty head of trotters, ranging from 1897 colts to the famous brood mare Belle Medium and the stallion El Noro.

" Resolved, That the Chairman of this committee be, and he is hereby, instructed, in behalf of this committee, to confer with the officers of all political organizations opposed to Tammany Hall, with a view to the selection of the same date for the holding of all anti-Tammany nominating conventions, so that entire harmony and ready conference may be assured in the selection of candidates and the promulgation of principles.
ALBANY, Aug. 23. -- Supreme Court Justice D. Cady Herrick of this city to-day announced that he was a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 23. -- William Woodward of New York defeated C.L. Tappin, the St. Andrew's Club crack, in the finals of the Kebo Valley Handicap golf tournament to-day, winning the two-hundred-dollar cup offered by A. Howard Hinkle of Cincinnati.

The Brooklyns won two games from the Pittsburgs at Eastern Park yesterday. In the first game the home team won almost as they pleased through superior batting. The second game, which was called at the conclusion of the seventh inning on account of rain, was a battle between the pitchers, Kennedy and Hoghey.

When the Turkish Government undertakes to influence public opinion, it goes about the business with the awkwardness of a novice. The "confession" which has avowedly been squeezed out of the two Armenian prisoners by the police of Constantinople has evidently been dictated by the exigencies of Turkish politics.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- Some interest attached to statements relating to the gold region in Alaska and the reindeer experiment there are made in the annual report of United States Commissioner of Education Harris, submitted to-day. The report says the reindeer stations ought to be able to furnish at once 500 reindeer trained to the harness for the use of the miners on the upper Yukon River.

The Games Committee for the annual championship meeting of the Amateur Athletic Union, to be held at Manhattan Field Saturday, met last night and passed favorably upon the list of entries received. T.E. Burke will be allowed to compete for the New York Athletic Club, sufficient evidence having been presented to prove him a resident at the New York Athletic Club Summer home at Travers Island, the stipulated thirty days.

BUFFALO, Aug. 23. -- The first formal exercises in connection with the National Encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic were held to-day. They consisted of the arrival and reception of Commander in Chief T.G. Clarkson this morning, the opening of Camp Jewett in the afternoon, and a civic parade and a public reception to the Commander in Chief in the evening.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- Appraiser Wakeman has been here to-day in consultation with Assistant Secretary Spaulding to enlist his interest in the proper equipment of the new Appraisers' Stores in New York, which Mr. Wakeman hopes will be occupied in January. He submitted to Mr. Spaulding a proposition for the construction of a complete telephone outfit for the buildings.

France is not entirely independent of "abroad" for its food supply, though it is much more so than England. Moreover, the French farmers really get the benefit of what there is of protection in France, unlike the American farmers, who are always the victims of our protective tariff.

SIMLA, Aug. 23. -- A large force of Afridis has just been reported to be advancing down the Khyber Pass, and the so-called Mad Mullah, or fanatical priest, who is inciting the natives of that territory against the British, is said to have collected the Mohmands for an attack upon Michel and Shabkadr.

Ex-Police Captain Nathaniel R. Mills, an inmate of the Chapin Home for Aged People, at Sixty-sixth Street and Lexington Avenue, was instantly killed yesterday in a remarkable manner. He lost his balance in a Fire Department supply wagon and fell between the horses, which were standing at the Fire Department training stables, at 135 West Ninety-ninth Street.

BOSTON, Aug. 23. -- Dispatches from New England manufacturing centres to-day announce that many cotton mills which have been idle resumed operations this morning. During a part of July and August thousands of spindled were not operated in this section owing to unsatisfactory conditions either in the finished goods or new cotton market, or to the need of repairs.

Mme. Maretzek, the widow of Max Maretzek, the famous pianist, is in danger of becoming totally blind. Mrs. Maretzek is living at the family homestead at Pleasant Plains, S.I. She is over seventy years old. The sight of one eye is totally gone and the other nearly so.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 24. -- Thomas Sharpe and associate stockholders in the Spathite Iron Company of Lawrence County, Tenn., have bought the Vanderbilt furnace at Birmingham and will begin manufacturing spathite iron, which commands from $1.50 to $2 more per ton than standard Southern iron on account of its superior ductility and fluidity.

BUFFALO, Aug. 24. -- President McKinley and his party, including Secretary of War Alger and Gov. Black, arrived here from Lake Champlain at precisely 3 o'clock this afternoon. The party at once entered carriages, and, escorted by a squadron of mounted police, was driven to the Hotel Niagara. The President, with bared head, bowed repeatedly in response to the cheers of those assembled on the sidewalks.

It is the avowed purpose of a very large number, probably of a majority, of the Grand Army of the Republic to secure from the next Congress a per diem pension for every person enlisted in the Union Army during the war.

-- Referring to the possibility that MARTINEZ CAMPOS may be put again in command of the Spanish forces in Cuba, an English critic says that the plan is hopeless. The Marshal, he declares, though once a great soldier, was always a wretched politician, and there is every reason to believe that now his fighting capacity has decreased, with no gain to his statesmanship.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Aug. 24. -- The tournament for the women's golf championship of the United States was begun on the Essex County Club's links to-day, in spite of very adverse weather conditions. The matches to-day were those of the preliminary round, for which medals had been offered and from which the best eight players were to be selected for to-morrow's events.

Lena Schwartz, eleven years old, was found wandering about the Bremen steamship pier at Hoboken yesterday. She said she wanted to go back to her home in Austria. She had 91 cents with which to pay her fare.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Aug. 24. -- Martin Heermance, Chairman of the State Board of Tax Commissioners, to-day gave out a statement regarding the increase in assessments for which the board has been held responsible. The Chairman says the law that requires all property to be assessed at its full value was not changed in 1896, but is now and has been in force for many years.

The effort of the Citizens' Union to nominate Seth Low remains to-day, after a conference for harmonious action between the New York and Brooklyn wings of the organization, and after a long session of the Executive Committee, in almost exactly the same state of uncertainty it was in yesterday morning.
SKIBBEREEN, Aug. 24. -- The potato crop in North Cork and Limerick has been partly destroyed by blight, and it will be the worst year in those districts for potatoes in the last half century.

OTTAWA, Ill., Aug. 24. -- E. Hakes, owner and operator of the coal mines at Rutland, a few miles southwest of here, was in the city to-day. He went before State Attorney Stead and swore out warrants for twenty men, who, he charged, had threatened to kill him and destroy his property.

SIMLA, Aug. 24. -- Fort Maude has been captured by the Afridis. The garrison was composed of a few native levies. The fort was afterward burned by the enemy. The garrison retired at 10:30 P.M. yesterday and the fort was burned at 11 o'clock the same night. The garrison reached Col. Westmacott's relief column, coming from Kohat, at 11:30 P.M.

BUFFALO, Aug. 24. -- The thirty-first annual encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic has turned out more men than ever before attended a National encampment, and this is true also of the ex-Prisoners of War Association, the Naval Veterans, and the women's auxiliary bodies.

The matter of farm colonization of the surplus labor and population of the East on the fertile lands of the South, and especially of Alabama, where lands are relatively cheaper and more productive than in most of the other States of that section, is just now attracting very wide attention. This is due in part to the editorials that have appeared in The Philadelphia Times and The Press of that city on the subject.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24. -- The American Window Glass Association will be the outcome of the meeting of the glass manufacturers held here to-day. It will take the place of the old trust which went into voluntary liquidation four years ago this Fall. But it will be stronger than the old body. It is proposed to organize along the line of the Pittsburg Plate Glass Company the corporate title of the plate glass men.

The denunciation by the Ameer of Afghanistan of the revolt against the British upon the border where his dominion marches with theirs may not be sincere. Lord ROBERTS is perhaps the best judge living of what the revolt means, and he has published his opinion that it could not have gained its actual dimensions without the connivance and encouragement of the Ameer.

The Sunday beer issue is not of itself broad enough for a party platform in the municipal canvass. As one feature, however, and a most oppressive and exasperating one, of the Republican policy of keeping this city of 3,000,000 people under the regime of laws that are sanctimoniously approved and surreptitiously violated in Herkimer and Cattaraugus Counties, the Raines law is fit material for denouncement in a home-rule platform.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- The Saratoga Golf Club's National open tournament began to-day. Despite the rain play began at 10 o'clock and continued throughout the day. There was a good attendance, considering the weather. Following are the scores:

Rain in such volume as to suggest a cloudburst deluged the eastern central part of New Jersey early yesterday morning, and did much damage. In the cities and towns streets and sewers were overflowed and houses and factories flooded. Throughout the country car tracks were inundated and along the railways there were many serious washouts.

Miss Lizzie Murphy, twenty-seven years old, a servant girl in the employ of Dr. Francis Valk, at 146 East Thirty-seventh street, was attacked by a burglar last night, bound hand and foot, and tied to a bed in the doctor's room. She was not discovered until nearly midnight, and then was taken to Bellevue Hospital unconscious.

The Brooklyns played a consistent game at Eastern Park yesterday and took their third straight game from the Pittsburgs. The game was marked by heavy batting, but although the visitors made the more hits they did not make them at the right times. The home team, on the contrary, made their hits count, placing the ball in safe territory when the bases were occupied.

LONDON, Aug. 25. -- A special dispatch from Bombay says there is an unconfirmed rumor in circulation there that the Afridis have attacked Fort Ali-Musjid with great determination. The garrison made a sortie in full force, endeavoring to disperse them, but met with a desperate resistance and lost three hundred killed.

LONDON, Aug. 25. -- The special dispatches to The Times and other London morning papers all remark the spontaneity and the boundless character of the enthusiasm quite unusual among the Russian people which has been evoked by M. Faure's visit, in strong contrast to the reception tendered Emperor William.

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 24. -- Arden Robbins of New York and Herbert Leeds of Brookline, Mass., defeated George T. Newhall and Mr. Wright of Philadelphia by 4 up and 2 to play in one of the most exciting foursome golf matches ever played on the Kebo Valley links. The two bye holes were also played, and were won by Robbins and Leeds, making the final score 6 up.

That the American mines are to-day furnishing as good steam coal to the transatlantic ships as can be obtained from any of the English or Welsh mines is a fact that is not generally known. A popular idea has existed that many of the big ships do not use the American soft coal.

Henry Crank, Jr., was granted an order yesterday by Justice Beekman, in the Supreme Court, to change him name to William Henry Woodruff after Sept. 25. Mr. Crank is a young lawyer of Houston, Texas, who is at present living at 122 East Twenty-eighth Street. He has come to New York to win fame and fortune.

BOMBAY, Aug. 24. -- The report that when the Mohmunds attacked Fort Shabkadr they burned all the sacred books of the Sikh Temple there has excited the greatest indignation among the Sikhs throughout the province, and has greatly incensed the Sikh troops on the frontier.

There was a time when a Canadian racing yacht was an object of ridicule. The Atalanta, which came down to get the America's Cup, was beaten by the Mischief, and the Countess of Dufferin thoroughly demonstrated that all but the first two syllables of the final word of her name were superfluous.

Heinrich Conried, the manager of the Irving Place Theatre, returned yesterday from a three months' trip through Germany, Austria, France, and England. He was a passenger on the steamship Normannia, and brought news of the engagement of a number of theatrical luminaries of more or less magnitude for the coming season, and incidentally had to pay $99.70 to get his twenty-four pieces of baggage past the officials of the Custom House.

The nomination of the Citizens' Union candidates cannot be much longer deferred either with honor or with safety. It is its first and urgent duty to keep faith with the public and its members and supporters by doing at once what it set out to do in June and what it can no longer have any good and sufficient reason for postponing.

" If 'twere done when 'tis done, then 'twere well 'twere done quickly." That is an appropriate reflection upon the present condition of this torn-up town. Three or four of its main avenues and an uncountable number of its cross streets are now in the hands of the paviors, the sewer builders, the "big-pipe men," and the builders of the lines to be operated by the underground trolley.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- The French Government has asked for the extradition of William Balensi, now in prison in New York for offenses committed in that city. Extradition cannot be granted unless the local authorities waive any claim to him and sufficient proof of his alleged crime in France is shown to the United States Commissioner. Balensi is also known under the alias of William A. Bellwood.

LONDON, Aug. 24. -- It is admitted even in official circles that the news from India is of the gravest description. All those who are familiar with the situation attach the greatest importance to the rising of the warlike Afridis, who are estimated to muster 25,000 fighting men. The Afridis, however, form only a portion of the insurgents the British must put down.

The Polo Grounds resembled a miniature lake yesterday as a result of the rain of the early morning. Two games with Cleveland were scheduled, but playing was an impossibility. The field was submerged to within a few feet of second base. The management promises to have the grounds in condition for two games this afternoon.
BUFFALO, Aug. 24. -- The Presidential party, which arrived here at 3 o'clock this afternoon, had reached Utica at 10:10 this morning, stopping there only to take on Gen. Terry of Gov. Black's staff.

ATLANTA, Aug. 28. -- The fate of the little Cuban patriot, Evangelina Cossio y Cisneros, now confined in the Cassa de Ricogidas, (House of the Scrapings,) in Havana, and whose trial by court-martial is exciting the interest and sympathy of Cuban sympathizers in the United States, is told by the writer exactly as he heard it from her lips.

Many merchants from Bermuda are now in this city, and most of them take a zealous interest in the work of the Merchants' Association. In the latter part of July the Quebec Steamship Company announced that it would make special rates to merchants in Bermuda who were members of the Merchants' Association and who desired to visit the New York market for the purpose of making their purchases.
DOBBS FERRY, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- The Greenburgh Town Assessors met to-day to hear explanations and further grievances.

ROCHESTER, Aug. 24. -- The opening session of the annual conclave of the Knights of Rome and the Red Cross of Constantine in the United States, the most exclusive Masonic body in existence, was held to-day in Masonic Temple. The conclave was one of the most important which has ever been held in this country, as at the session this morning it was decided to make Master Masons eligible to membership in the order.
H.H. Cammann Co. have sold for Sarah J. Burby the two three-story brick flats, with stores, 261 and 263 Hudson Street.

One of the largest single deals ever made in real estate on the New Jersey coast has just been consummated by the transfer to a syndicate of capitalists and railroad men of the entire ocean frontage between Elberon and Deal Lake, and practically all the unimproved building sites between those points, extending back a considerable distance from the coast line.
The permanent organization of the Commercial Travelers' Sound Money League of America has more significance than might at first be attached to it.

Commander and Mrs. Frederick de Latour Booth-Tucker returned from their London trip yesterday on the White Star Line steamship Majestic. Nearly five hundred members of the Salvation Army went down the bay on the steamboat John Lenox to greet them as the steamship came in to Quarantine.

BUFFALO, Aug. 25. -- Late last evening President McKinley, accompanied by Commander in Chief Clarkson, visited the camp fire at the Delaware Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church, where he was received with the greatest enthusiasm. The President spoke briefly as follows:

-- What is a "unifying force," anyway? t would seem reasonable, just in the interests of accuracy, to confine the application of the phrase to forces that produce a real and permanent combination of elements or ingredients, and not extend it to those able at best merely to form an emulsion.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- A new phase of the discriminating duty controversy has been presented to the Treasury Department, and will probably arrest the attention of the Attorney General before he renders his opinion on the meaning of the words of Section 22.

Many details in regard to the largest real estate transaction of several months became known yesterday. Horace S. Ely Co. have sold for Julien T. Davies, to Edward H. Van Ingen, the plot bounded by Broadway, Sixth Avenue, and Thirty-sixth Street, having frontages of 105.9, 98.9, and 159.4 feet, respectively, on these streets, and measuring 197.2 1/2 feet on its northerly line.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 25. -- The first National Convention of the American Party, a new political organization which, as the call, issued from Detroit, says, will be devoted to the restoration of the spirit and sentiment of the original Federal Constitution, met to-day in Druids' Hall, with about fifty delegates present from nine States and one Territory.
ST. PETERSBURG, Aug. 25. -- The Czar, Czarina, and President Faure and their respective suites witnessed a march past of 50,000 troops at the Krasnoe Selo Camp today. The spectacle was most imposing.

BABYLON, L.I., Aug. 25. -- The ancient solitary reign of "Fatty" Wicks, the police force of this village has been disturbed. The village authorities, in the selection of a force, followed the principle of Julius Caesar, who wanted about him men that were fat; sleek-headed men, who sleep o' nights, and Mr. Wicks's service was one continued picnic.
SEATTLE, Washington, Aug. 25. -- The steamer Willamette pulled into the Ocean Dock from Alaska to-day, carrying the following passengers:

BOSTON, Aug. 25. -- Judge Putnam of the United States Circuit Court has dismissed the suit of Christine Hokking vs. H.J. Pfaff, Jr., the millionaire, on the ground that the decree of the South Dakota court on which the suit is based is void. The alimony sued for will not be paid.

-- There is cause for disquieting reflection in the statement on which Justice KEOGH bases the demand for a reduction of his personal assessment. It should be decreased from $40,000 to $16,000, he says, because mortgages which he recently held, amounting to $24,000, have now been "canceled," or, in other words, paid.

PEAPACK, N.J., Aug. 25. -- The Peapack Smiths are among the few aristocrats of the world who can and do have annual family reunions, reviews, registrations, and displays of themselves. The ancestors of the Peapack Smiths came in 1740 from Holland to Peapack, in Somerset County, N.J., and near the end of the Passaic and Delaware branch of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad.
IRVINGTON-ON-HUDSON, Aug. 25. -- The Greenburgh Town Assessors met here to-day to hear further grievances concerning tax assessments.

MANCHESTER - BY - THE - SEA, Mass., Aug. 25. -- The second day of the women's championship golf tournament at the Essex County Club brought much more favorable weather conditions than was the case yesterday. The early hours to-day were not promising, but during the forenoon the sun came through the clouds and by the time play began the weather was all that could be desired.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 25. -- Burglars last night entered the home of Mrs. Mary S. Swift, on Academy Street, in this city, and, after ransacking it from top to bottom, carried away a large quantity of silverware. Mrs. Swift is at Sansfield, Mass., and the house has been unoccupied for several weeks.

Peter Conlin, Chief of Police, appeared in person before the Police Board yesterday morning and presented a written application to be retired. The board granted the application at once, and retired him on a pension of $3,000 a year. Acting Inspector John McCullagh was appointed to succeed Chief Conlin, but whether as Chief or Acting Chief of Police is yet to be determined, the matter having been referred to Corporation Counsel Scott for his opinion.

Amateur racing has suffered considerably, especially during the present season, from "ringers" whose presence was not discovered until it was too late to regain the prizes captured. In the novice races particularly riders have entered under assumed names, won the race with ease, and after securing the prize departed with the booty before protests were made.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25. -- Albert Warner, the New York lawyer who is wanted at Albany for complicity in the kidnapping of little Johnny Conway, was in Philadelphia last night, but he gave the detective department the slip and has not yet been apprehended.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 25. -- The Republican State Convention, which will meet at Ocean City to-morrow, promises to be one of the liveliest in the history of the party in Maryland. The convention will nominate candidates for State Controller and Clerk of the Court of Appeals. A new State Central Committee will also be elected.

Chairman HEERSMANCE of the State Board of Tax Commissioners has published a statement of the intentions of his board. He points out that the law requires that taxable property throughout the State shall be assessed at its full value, and declares that Assessors who do not execute the law will be prosecuted.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Aug. 25. -- The Pacific Advisory Board of the American Kennel Club has vindicated James Mortimer, the New York dog judge, in the matter of charges made against him by H.T. Payne of this city. Resolutions have been adopted declaring the charges unfounded.

BOSTON, Aug. 25. -- Cycle racing stars were plenty at the National Circuit meet at Charles River Park, although Bald and Kiser failed to put in an appearance, and Cooper was unable to ride on account of a sore knee. Arthur Gardner's easy riding occasioned much favorable comment. The time made in the various races was exceptionally fast, and standing records came near going to the wall in several instances.

Rain again interfered with the programme at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon, and only one of two games the New Yorks were scheduled to play against the Clevelands was decided, but the game resulted in a victory for the Giants.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 25. -- Coal operators of the Pittsburg district, made a decided change in front since yesterday. Internal dissensions mixed with fear on the part of some caused a split in their forces and a change of base.

What is Mr. Low waiting for? He wrote in June that he should like to see some evidence that his candidacy would be a "unifying force." After two months' diligent labor the Citizens' Union put before him the evidence that more than 100,000 voters were united in wishing him to run for Mayor.

PARIS, Aug. 25. -- Premier Meline, addressing the delegates to the Council General of the Department of the Seine and the Municipality of Paris, to-day, on the rise in the price of wheat, declared he would submit the question to the Cabinet, adding that he would not hesitate to reduce the tariff if the rise was genuine and not speculative

HARRISBURG, Penn., Aug. 25. -- There seems to be no doubt of the nomination of Major Levi G. McCauley of Westchester for Auditor General and James S. Beacom of Greensburg for State Treasurer by the Republican State Convention to-morrow. There are a few other aspirants for these offices, but none of them is making an active campaign and none gives evidence of much following.

While non-resident members of the Merchants' Association continue to make their presence in New York known by subscribing their names in the big register at the association's headquarters, Broadway and Leonard Street, President King and his associates are devoting their efforts to securing reduced railroad rates for the faraway Southern and Western merchants who desire to come to this city in September.

President McKINLEY has had an enviable success as a stump speaker. He has a clear, high, penetrating voice, and the casual pedestrian who goes within two blocks of the platform is sure to hear something. Usually he will hear a glittering generality, which, uttered in those ringing tones, sounds oracular.
MONTEVIDEO, Aug. 25. -- During the national fete which was held here to-day President J. Idiarte Borda was shot and killed by an assassin.

L'Alouette's victory in the Futurity at Sheepshead Bay on Monday is another striking illustration of the uncertainty of racing. The filly was the least thought of the three candidates from the stable of L.S. W.P. Thompson, and up to an hour before the start it was by no means certain that she would be a starter.

EUGENE V. DEBS is steadily working his way toward West Virginia, where he threatened to go and defy the injunction of Judge JACKSON. He has reached Terre Haute, Ind., and on the line he is traveling has only some 24,820 miles to go before he will encounter the Judge and begin his defying.

PRETORIA, South African Republic, Aug. 25. -- At a meeting of the Volksraad to-day, President Kruger delivered a speech which is likely to cause the greatest excitement in Great Britain. During the course of his remarks, the President said that the relations between Great Britain and the South African Republic were regulated at the convention of 1884.

One thousand votes cast for a man who had the convictions and the courage to face the people standing squarely upon the platform of the Citizens' Union would be worth more to the cause of non-partisan City Government than two hundred thousand votes for SETH LOW as a bargain candidate of PLATT and the Union.

LONDON, Aug. 20. -- The important news that the Ameer has sworn fidelity to Great Britain and read the dispatches which have passed between Cabul and Simla at an open public durbar has a reassuring effect both in India and here as tending to remove any doubt as to his loyalty.
In order to remove the misconceptions which may be likely to arise from the article in this day's TIMES, I desire to make the following statement:
An account is given by The Commercial Advertiser of how the 10 per cent. discriminating duty got into the Tariff bill. Here it is:
WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 25. -- The main objections to the assessments here are filed on personal property. It is said that about $l,000,000 will be Stricken from the roll as the result of the protests.

BOMBAY, Aug. 25, (11 P.M.) -- The latest dispatches received from the front indicate that the situation on the frontier is getting worse. It is evident that the Indian Government must face a grave crisis, involving heavy expenditure and probably great loss of life.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- The forthcoming annual report of the Bureau of Statistics will show the percentages of the aggregate exports of the United States for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1897, at seventy of the principal customs ports. It is shown that the exports from the Port of New York have fallen off from 40.32 per cent. of the whole in 1895, to 37.27 in 1S97.

BUFFALO, Aug. 25. -- The parade of the Grand Army of the Republic, with President McKinley at the right of the column, took place to-day. It is estimated that over 45,000 veterans were in line. The decorations of the city were appropriate and elaborate.

Chauncey M. Depew, who returned from Newport yesterday, said: "There is a general revival of business all over the country. Dollar wheat and the output of unexpected quantities of gold have not only given us an enormous increase of National and individual wealth, but have restored confidence.

RISON, Ark., Aug. 25. -- All day posses of Deputy Sheriffs and citizens have been scouring the country in search of the negroes who participated in the bloody riot near this place on Sunday, in which Mr. T.T. Johnson was killed and another white man badly cut. Six prisoners were brought here and lodged in jail last night, and it was thought at one time that the entire gang would be lynched.

PORT TOWNSEND, Washington, Aug. 25. -- The steamship Portland is due to arrive from the mouth of the Yukon River tomorrow, and it is expected she will bring several tons of gold from the Klondike gold fields.

LONDON, Aug. 26. -- The Governor General of India, the Earl of Elgin, has telegraphed to the Government here confirming the news of the capture of Fort Lundi-Kotal, adding that one native officer was killed and one wounded. The Governor General announces that nearly all the garrison of Fort Ali-Musjid has reached Jamrud.

About 2,500 admirers of the Brooklyn team watched the once despised Louisville team defeat the Grooms at Eastern Park yesterday without an apparent effort. The Colonels found Payne, the home team's pitcher, just to their liking, and increased their batting average as a result. Cunningham had the home team guessing, with the exception of the eighth inning, Score:

But for the absence of any apparent motive, the police of the East Thirty-fifth Street Station would decide that the story told to them Monday night by Lizzie Murphy is a tissue of falsehoods. As it is, they have ceased to take any active interest in the case.

At a meeting of the Directors of the American Fire Insurance Company of New York, held at the company's building, 42 Cedar Street, yesterday, it was decided to accept the offer made in June by the Manchester Fire Assurance Company of England to purchase the New York company's stock at $100 a share, the stockholders agreeing. The par value of the company's

The latest development of the Eastern question is by no means the least interesting or significant. Upon the phase of it which has now arisen England, France, and Russia are arrayed upon one side and the Dreibund upon the other. Such a division of Europe would of itself bode ill for the Dreibund.

The Autumn Maiden Stakes for two-year-olds and the Dolphin Stakes for three-year-olds were the features of the programme at Sheepshead Bay yesterday, but only in the latter was there anything like an exciting finish. Lady Marian, August Belmont's speedy filly, tip-toed her field in the Autumn Stakes, and won in a canter by three lengths.

During the past week our Republican neighbor The Sun has become a zealous advocate of the Quigg policy of conference and fusion. "This conference and the subsequent conferences contemplated," it predicts, "will lead to the nomination of a ticket in whose support all the opponents of Tammany will be joined."

STRATFORD-ON-AVON, Aug. 26. -- A numerous company, including Mme. de Navarro, (Mary Anderson,) Mr. William Winter, and many other Americans, assembled to-day on the sward in front of the Shakespeare Memorial Theatre to witness Augustin Daly's company in a performance of "As You Like It." The weather was threatening and the play had scarcely begun when steady rain fell.

SAYVILLE, Aug. 26. -- This is the year for the vindication of the oyster. There has been a popular impression that, whatever his other good qualities might be, he lacked enthusiasm. He has been accused of being cool and ultra conservative, and wrapped up in his own affairs and interests, and of concerning himself little with the common defense and general welfare of the country.

PORT TOWNSEND, Washington, Aug. 26. -- The schooner Fred E. Sanders arrived early this morning, thirty days from St. Michaels, Alaska, with six passengers from the Klondike country. They are J.S. Dinsmore, a merchant of Eureka, Cal.; Charles Vest of Portland, Ore.; James McNamee, Juneau; J. Lowe, a miner of Puget Sound, and Henry Ash and wife of Dawson City.

Governors Island is to have a new ferry, more in keeping with its importance as a military station, and better equipped for the needs of the larger garrison which, under the present policy of the War Department to concentrate troops about the great centres of population, has already been installed on the island.

John C. Juhring of the firm of Francis H. Leggett Co. and First Vice President of the Merchants' Association, related the following experience yesterday afternoon: "One of our visitors this morning was Mr. W.J. Kinsey of Nashville, Tenn., who said to me that this was his first trip to the metropolis during his business experience.

ST. PETERSBURG, Aug. 26. -- At the luncheon given to-day in honor of the Czar on board the French cruiser Pothuau, which conveyed President Faure to Cronstadt, the Czar, in proposing a toast to the French President, said.

VICTORIA, B.C., Aug. 26. -- The expedition of Prince Luigi of Savoy to the summit of Mount St. Elias has fixed once for all the height of the mountain at 18,120 feet. The figures are subject only to such slight corrections as may change the total thirty or forty feet either way.

To every man, no matter what may be the peculiar traits or characteristics of his distinction on the one hand, or the conspicuous marks or prefigurements of his commonplaceness on the other, there comes a time when he can give neither verbal utterance nor written expression to any thought whatever; for the all-sufficient reason that he is wholly bereft of thought; he is in a condition of unwakable silence; he is inanimate.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 26. -- All the prominent negroes of this country, led by Bishop Abraham Grant of this place, are organizing to hold an anti-lynching convention in Atlanta during October. Bishop Grant has recently returned from the North, where he consulted the leading men of his race and secured their co-operation in the projected enterprise.

ALBANY, Aug. 26. -- This was the day set by the State Railroad Commissioners to hear the application of the New York and Ottawa Railroad Company for permission to construct an eighteen-mile railroad within the State of New York, from Moira to the St. Lawrence River.

Twelve-year-old Henry Steffens of 151 Dupont Street, Brooklyn, is in St. John's Hospital, Long Island City, in a serious condition as the result of injuries received Wednesday night in a peculiar manner. A chowder party landed at the Third Street dock, Long Island City. There is a gate which leads on to the dock, used to keep people out.

VICTORIA, B.C., Aug. 26. -- The steamer City of Topeka, which has just arrived here, left Juneau just after the arrival there of Joe Berch, James McKay, and Archie Shelp, who made the trip from Dawson City to Dyea in twenty days. They did not come any further than Juneau, but intend to go back to the mines.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Aug. 26. -- John Mumby, the bicycle hater of Wading River, was arrested yesterday on complaint of Frank Thompson, a wheelman, on the charge of drawing a pistol on him, and the accused will have an examination to-morrow before Judge Lawson in St. James. Mumby is fifty years of age and deaf and dumb.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 26. -- Fire here to-night resulted in the death of two firemen, probably in the death of two small boys, the serious injury of another fireman, and caused the loss of $165,000 worth of property. The fire originated in a building at 637 Smithfield Street, occupied by Edmundson Perrine.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 26. -- All is not harmony in political circles at Lincoln, the new town about five miles from here. The spirit of dissension to-day is yet in a nebulous state, but there is no telling how soon it may crystalize and darkness overshadow the municipal government.

The total foreign commerce of China rose from 315,000,000 haikwan taels ($245,700,000) in 1895 to 333,600,000 taels ($260,208,000) in 1896, of which 202.,590,000 taels ($158,301,000) were in imports and 131,081,000 taels ($102,243,180) in exports.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 26. -- The members of the American Bar Association this morning listened to an excellent annual address by Gov. John W. Griggs of New Jersey on "Legislation and the Needs of Reform in Lawmaking," and adopted a resolution which committed the association to an effort to bring about international treaties with all enlightened nations of the earth.

Lizzie Humphrey, a laceworker twenty-six years of age, was shot last evening and probably fatally injured by an insane young man who was infatuated with her. The shooting occurred at the home of Mrs. Julia Hallenbeck mother of the young man, on the third floor of the building at 155 Broadway, Williamsburg.

GREENVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- The Greenburg Town Assessors took a long flight from the Hudson River to this hamlet, near the New York and Harlem Railroad, to-day to hear grievances from the residents of the town.

DAVY CROCKETT used to say: "Be sure you're right, then go ahead," Gov. BLACK was sure he was right, and he refused to go ahead. It was in the parade of the Grand Army of the Republic at Buffalo, and the committee desired to put Gov. BLACK in a carriage at the head of the line. President MCKINLEY was to appear later.
Slawson Hobbs have sold for Mrs. Alice S.C. Montgomery to a client of Morris Steele, the four-story American basement dwelling 317 West Seventy-fourth Street, 27.6 by 60 by 71.

The fact that the National Sculpture Society has addressed a letter to the Park Board condemning the model for the new statue of Gen. Bolivar, recently completed by the sculptor Turini by order of the Venezuelan Government, to replace the present statue of the South American hero now in Central Park, does not necessarily mean that the statue will not be cast and erected.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 26. -- The second day's play in the scratch golf tournament for the Hinkle Cup took place to-day. Those entered in the contest are M.R. Wright of Philadelphia, George T. Newhall of Philadelphia, Arden Robbins and C.L. Tappin of New York, and Herbert Leeds of Brookline, Mass. In the morning Newhall and Wright, the two Philadelphians, were matched against each other.

It is well understood that influences are at work throughout this country and abroad in the vain endeavor to minimize the significance of the business improvement upon which the United States has just entered. The theory is advanced that these new good times, the signs of which are witnessed on all sides, are only built on a foundation of speculation, and that they do not represent actual and stable conditions.
SIMLA, Aug. 26. -- Fort Lundi-Kotal, situated at the extreme end of the Khyber Pass and garrisoned by 300 men of the Khyber Rifles, was attacked and burned by the Ifridis on Tuesday.
BOSTON, Aug. 26. -- The whaling bark Swallow, Capt. Cleveland, sailed this afternoon on her long cruise on the Southern Atlantic and Indian Oceans in search of sea elephants, seals, and whales.

BUFFALO, Aug. 26. -- The thirty-first annual encampment of the Grand Army of the Republic was formally opened this morning in Music Hall. Commander in Chief Clarkson called the encampment to order. At the morning session speeches were made by Commander in Chief Clarkson, Gov. Black, Edgar B. Jewett, Mayor of Buffalo, and Col. A.D. Shaw.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- Minister Stuart at Montevideo has cabled to the State Department an official announcement of the assassination of President Borda of Uruguay.

The gas supply of nearly every important city in the United States is directly or indirectly controlled by the Standard Oil Company, which has not only made tremendous profits by issues of new securities of gas companies and the increase of the prices of these securities, but has provided a permanent cash market for nearly 18,000,000 barrels of its own product which is unavailable for general commercial purposes.

President DEPEW during our financial difficulties was so resolutely hopeful and cheerful that he is now entitled to the utterance of a word of caution, if only to give him a chance to be heard in a world where his habitual optimism is now general. Here is his warning:

BUFFALO, Aug. 26. -- The President of the United States was refused admittance to the Grand Army camp this morning, although he had come at the special invitation of the veterans and everything was in readiness to receive him. The incident proved one of great mortification to the Grand Army leaders and excited great indignation among the members of the local committee.
The New Yorks won from the Chicagos with ease at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon in a game which was noted for heavy hitting. It is a long time since the New York team had such a batting picnic.

The present complex and heterogeneous system of underground piping in the streets of this city has been the cause, according to the public officials and physicians, of almost every kind of nuisance, inconvenience, and bodily discomfort.

It is an interesting fact that in every large machine shop there are one or two men to whom their comrades turn when they get flying splinters of steel or other substance in their eyes. These men through long experience become as expert as many oculists. There is at least one such man at the Springfield Government Armory, and he has become very skillful.

The news that Mrs. Charles Stebbins and her daughter, Miss Ethel Stebbins, are seriously ill with typhoid fever at Southampton, L.I., and that their illness is attributed to drinking impure water at the Shinnecock Golf clubhouse, the most fashionable place of daily assemblage at Southampton, has made a decided sensation.

Mayor Hoos and the Finance and Street and Water Commissioners of Jersey City held a conference yesterday to consider a proposition that was submitted by a syndicate that seeks to acquire possession of the South Cove property. The proposition was submitted by William D. Edwards, former Corporation Counsel, through whose efforts the property was secured to the city after many years of litigation.
WEST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 26. -- Social exigencies in this town have disastrously hoisted a political engineer and made the election laws a mockery.

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 26. -- It was left with a New York man to give the largest and most brilliant event of the season in honor of Admiral Sicard and officers of the North Atlantic Squadron, now at anchor in the harbor.

BOSTON, Aug. 23.-A question which has been raised by the failure of the Massachusetts Benefit Life Association is as to the liability of policy hol'ders to assessment to meet outstanding liabilities at the time of the appointment of a receiver. In the case of the mutual lire Insurance companies In this State, this obligation is plainly set out in the policy.

The railway returns for the United Kingdom relative to 1896, prepared by the Commercial Labor and Statistical Department of the Board of Trade, were issued the other day as a blue book, with summary tables for each year commencing with 1854. The total number of miles of railway open at the close of last year was 21,277.

NEWPORT, Aug. 26. -- Robert D. Wrenn of New York defeated William V. Eaves of London, England, to-day for the tennis championship of this country in one of the finest matches ever seen on the Casino courts. Eaves played by far the better game, but Wrenn's generalship carried the day and won for him and for American tennis a famous victory.

The impudence of QUIGG is his most interesting quality. He scatters his invitations broadcast on the assumption that he has but to raise the cry of Tammany to bring all the organizations opposed to the Wigwam huddling around his conference table. He takes it for granted that his hidden guests have no memories and are always gullible.

War is imminent between the Italian bootblack in the Commercial Buildings, on Broadway, between Waverley and Washington Places, and the guardian of the peace who patrols that beat, otherwise William Fitzpatrick, of the Mercer Street Station. Joe Cherula, the party of the first part, is yet an infant, in the eyes of the law, but looks forward to being a citizen, and is meanwhile a stanch advocate of his own rights.

Wheat was strong and active yesterday in a market where there was no cash demand, and cash quotations were nominal, with little export business. The advance movement was prompted by Chicago and stimulated by high and strong European cables.

At the meeting of the Brooklyn Committee of Fifty last night, which had been called to give its sub-committee on conference full power to act in conjunction with the other conference committees of the Citizens' Union in the different boroughs, there was an altercation between John K. Creevy, Chairman, and ex-Mayor Schieren that threatened a serious rupture in the organization.

A letter reached the West Forty-seventh Street Precinct Wednesday afternoon telling of the kidnapping by gypsies of the child of wealthy parents. The letter was in the unformed handwriting of an illiterate woman and gave many details of the case. It said that the child and the gypsies were living in West Forty-ninth Street; that the child was ill treated and forbidden to leave the house of those who had it in charge.

ASBURY PARK, Aug. 26. -- Riders from the New York district were the chief figures in a race meet held this afternoon under the auspices of the New Jersey Amusement Company on the grounds of the Asbury Park Athletic Association. A card of amateur races was run off, salted with three professional match races. About 3,000 people attended the meet, most of them being Summer visitors to this resort.

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 26. -- Prof. D.G. Lyon of Harvard has no faith in the claim made for the relics discovered by Seton-Karr, who says they are from the original Garden of Eden. His opinion may be fairly taken, perhaps, to represent those men whom a study of anthropology and kindred topics has made more or less familiar with relics of different ages and their significance.

New York's cabmen are waging an internecine war. They have already come to blows over the question of reducing the fare, as was the case when the dignified Joseph Thompson found it necessary to remove his silk hat, descend from his high perch, and whip another dignified driver who stood on Madison Square and reviled Thompson for wanting to ride the gilded youth and others at 25 cents a mile.

OCEAN, CITY, Md., Aug. 26. -- By a vote of 61 to 56 the delegates to the Republican State Convention to-day refused to indorse Senator George L. Wellington and his views as to the leadership of the party in Maryland. Senator Wellington, as Chairman of the State Central Committee, in calling the convention to order, delivered a long address in defense of his position in the party controversy in Baltimore.

BUFFALO, Aug. 27. -- The second day's session of the Grand Army Encampment was opened at 9:15 o'clock this morning. Gen. Clarkson presided. The session, like that of yesterday, was strictly private. The election of officers, from Senior Vice Commander down, was taken up under the order of business.

A road race after the style of tie Irvington-Mlllburn road even,ts will }, run at Trenton, N. J., starting at 3 o'clock thi -fternoon, q_'wenty-fl{'e miles is the distance', and the course will be six and a quarter miles in length out from Trenton. About thirty entrtes have been received, including some of the best roadsters of New York and Philadelphia.

In your usually just criticism of the Dingley tariff you have omitted to give our generous legislators the credit they deserve for the one kindhearted proviso in it, to which I desire to draw your attention. In Paragraph 680 of Vandegrift's Digest I find that every one, "without regard to race, color, or previous condition of servitude," is allowed to bring his teeth into the country free of duty.

Jersey City, also, has dreams of a "Greater Jersey City." It is beginning to look forward to a time when it will be a great port, the haven of commercial fleets, and the cynosure of all who go down to the sea in ships.

HAZLETON, Penn., Aug. 27. -- The threatened strike at Vanwickle's Coloraine and Beaver Meadow collieries took place this morning. The Hungarians and Italians are masters of the situation, and 2,000 men are idle pending the decision of the foreign element. Last night the foreigners held a meeting, and at a late hour they visited the homes of their countrymen, pulled them out of bed, and delivered the edict.
CHICAGO, Ill., Aug. 27. -- The Corn Belt, a paper issued by the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad Company, will publish to-morrow its September crop report, which contains the following:

The Protest Committee of the Metropolitan Association of the Amateur Athletic Union took testimony in about forty protest cases last night in a meeting held at the St. George's Athletic Club, Sixteenth Street, east of Third Avenue. All the cases were laid over and will be submitted to the Board of Managers of the local union.

It is not entirely a matter of surprise that the National Sculpture Society has in a letter to the Park Board of New York condemned the model of the new statue of Gen. Simon Bolivar, with which, when cast, the Venezuelan Government had intended to replace the present ridiculous statue of the South American hero in Central Park.

Senator WELLINGTON has been called "the Quay of Maryland." The epithet fits his character fairly well; it does not fit his capacity to run his party. The Republican Convention, which he himself called to order and exhorted as to his authority as a boss, practically disbossed him, declared the primaries in Baltimore vitiated by his outrageous management, ordered new primaries to be held Sept. 11, and adjourned to Sept. 15.

QUETTA, Baluchistan, Aug. 27. -- The anxiety experienced here over the rumors that the uprising of the tribesmen of the frontier will extend to this district was increased to-day by the discovery that the telegraph line through the Bolan Pass has been cut.

The movement which Ferrier Golden, Catskill brick manufacturers, recently set on foot by a circular letter, asking the various brickmakers of the Hudson River, who supply this city's market, to combine in a temporary shut-down of their yards, in order to raise prices, is not making much headway.
If I had noticed the letter in THE TIMES inquiring about the feeding of puppies, I would have answered sooner, but I only saw the answer mentioning poisoning, and your item in to-day's issue.

PARIS, Aug. 9. -- It is a strange, and at the same time a deplorable, fact, that European literature should be so poor in authoritative works on contemporary history. To judge from the output one might be led to think that the history of our continent ends with the French Revolution. England is, perhaps, poorer in this respect than any other country, and, outside of Europe, America is undoubtedly the richest.
James A. Frame Son have sold to a Mr. Nicoll the four and a half story American basement private dwelling, 271 West Ninetieth Street, 18 by 58 by 100.

The statement made in these columns August 24, that Seth Low had acted upon the advice of his Brooklyn friends to postpone his definite reply to the offer to nominate him for Mayor, was verified at yesterday's meeting of the conference committees of the Citizens' Union from the different Boroughs in Greater New York.

The officers of the Merchants' Association are much elated over the action of the Southern Railway Company in agreeing to sell reduced rate tickets from all Southern points on its line to Washington, Richmond, and Norfolk. This action opens new territory to merchants in the South who desire to purchase their Fall goods in New York City.

The hearing on the application of the Forty-second Street, Manhattanville and St. Nicholas Avenue Street Railway Company and the Metropolitan Street Railway Company for permits to open the streets in order to lay conduits for a change of motive power was held at the Department of Public Works yesterday morning.

Senator GALLINGER of New Hampshire has unwittingly done the cause of honest politics and good government a considerable service. Having made a series of partly malicious, partly ignorant, and wholly inaccurate statements about the civil service law, its application and the motives of its advocates, these were clearly and plainly exposed by the Secretary of the National Civil Service Reform League, of which Mr. CARL SCHURZ is the President.

The Brooklyns turned the tables on the Loulsvlllo Colonels at Eastern Park yesterday afternoon, and won the game handily. Dunn, .the home team's pitcher, was very effective. La Chance was in good batting form, making a three-baggeri a double, arid two singles. Stafford gave a wretched exhibition' at short for the visitors.

After three days' hard competition at Creedmoor, the twelve men who are to constitute the New York State team to represent the National Guard in the Inter-State and Hilton Trophy matches at Sea Girl, N.J., next week, have been selected. Their names and aggregate scores were announced yesterday, as were the three substitutes.

Now that the great sale of pictures in London is about closed for this year, the prices of these pictures by the masters can be examined and compared. With certain notable exceptions, pretty generally there has not been an advance in price. Four figures have been rare, save for some of the great English masters.

LONDON, Aug. 27. -- A special from Simla Says that the Daulatzai tribe of Afridis near Kohat descended from the hills in strong force during Thursday night and attacked and captured the village of Ublan, setting fire to the buildings, nearly all of which were destroyed. Gen. Biggs, commanding the forces at Kohat, having heard of the Afridis' plans, had prepared a force and went out on Friday morning and attacked the enemy.

Morris Greis, thirty-six years old, of 123 Rivington Street, is a baseball enthusiast. Last evening when the baseball edition of the afternoon papers appeared on the street, he bought one and made for the nearest lamp post, where he stood reading the score. New York had passed Cincinnati, and was in third place, and he was interested at once.

The confusion now existing as to the location of piers on the North and East Rivers will soon be dispelled. The Department of Docks has approved the suggestion of the New York Board of Trade and Transportation, and very soon the "old" and "new" numbered piers will be things of the past, and instead piers will be known by the names of the streets ending at or near them.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 27. -- It is announced in this city to-day, on reliable authority, that the Tilden Mine at Bessemer, Mich., one of the greatest ore producers on the Gogebic range, has been sold to the Carnegie-Oliver syndicate, which last Winter bought the Mountain Iron Mine on the Mesaba range, in Northern Minnesota.
CHICAGO, Aug. 27. -- An inspection of the works of the Illinois Steel Company will be made by Commander J.A. Howell, President of the United States Armor Factory Board, and staff, beginning Monday.

The exhibition of baseball which the New Yorkers served up to the 6,000 spectators at the Polo Grounds yesterday, when they won two games from the Chicagos, made "Uncle Anse" think of the days of 1885-86, when the famous Chicago White Stockings took nearly everything in sight. Ten years, however, have brought about many changes, and the Chicagos of yesterday were like pigmies before the Giants.

Work is soon to be resumed on the new building of the Washington Heights Baptist Church, at Convent Avenue and One Hundred and Forty-fifth Street. The plans have been finished and contracts awarded. The church is to be erected on the lot bought by the Trustees last Spring for $48,000.

Yielding to the persuasions of the Brooklyn Committee of Fifty, the Citizens' Union has put off until Wednesday the nomination of its candidate for Mayor. We take it there will be no further postponement. In the language of the resolution adopted yesterday the Joint Committee on Municipal Nominations adjourned until Sept. 1, at noon, "upon the understanding that final action shall then be taken in regard to nominating a candidate for the Mayoralty."

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 27. -- A warrant was issued to-night for the arrest of Peter Crozer, who is charged with defaulting in the sum of $90,000 from the Mercer and the Mechanics' Building and Loan Associations.

MANCHESTER-BY-THE-SEA, Mass., Aug. 27. -- Miss Beatrix Hoyt of the Shinnecock Golf Club. Southarnpton, L.I., defeated Miss N.C. Sargent of the Essex County Club, Manchester, Mass., in the tournament for the ladies' golf championship here to-day by 5 up 4 to play. Miss Hoyt is the present champion.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27. -- Wheat furnished another sensation to-day. This time it was the bulls who suffered. September closing 5 7/8 cents lower and December at a decline of 3 7/8 cents after a session remarkable for small trading and extremely violent fluctuations. Weak foreign markets and reports of re-selling by foreigners were ostensibly the reasons for the decline, but there were plenty of rumors of a "bear" combination formed to break the market.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 27. -- The Chairman of the Monetary Executive Committee, Hugh H. Hanna, returned to the city this evening after an absence of three weeks, during which he has traveled pretty much all over the country. In his travels Mr. Hanna found encouragement from all sides for the work of the currency reform.

From The St. Louis Republic, (Silver, Dem.) Evidences multiply daily of the rapid disintegration of Populism. The forces that a short while ago co-operated under this name are seeking natural channels and forming alliances with established agencies for, the promotion of good government and the working out of reforms.

There was a selling flurry in the wheat market yesterday, and notable declines resulted while the supply and demand situation was not changed a whit. Indeed, the question appears to be how much Europe and other markets need, and what the United States can spare out of the surplus over domestic needs.

The victory of Mr. WRENN over Dr. EAVES in the match for the championship of the United States at lawn tennis will naturally please all Americans. The inhabitants of this country entertain the same dislike which Englishmen have to being defeated in any game requiring pluck, strength, and skill, and tennis requires all three.
KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- Joseph Depew, a negro employed on a horse railroad in Rosendale, this morning committed an assault on the six-year-old daughter of Michael Doody at Hickory Bush.

A company recently formed in this city, styled the Klondike Transportation Express and Commercial Company, proposes the removal of all obstacles in getting to and from the Alaskan gold fields by the operation of a system of transportation the cars of which will be propelled by a steam engine mounted upon specially constructed running gear.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 27. -- The opening session of the National Bar Association to-day was devoted to suggestions from members of the Committee on Commercial Law, and under this head Walter S. Logan of New York offered a report urging the enactment of legislation to enable a creditor of a debtor who is squandering his property to secure the interposition of the courts to protect his rights, although the debt may not yet be due.

BOSTON, Aug. 27. -- The Women's Educational and Industrial Union has leased two houses on St. Botolph Street and proposes to attempt a solution of "the great American problem," the sevant girl question.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 27. -- President McKinley surprised the people of Cleveland by his arrival from Buffalo this morning. He became the guest of the people of this city, and will remain such until next Wednesday.

Patrick Jerome Gleason was interrogated yesterday evening concerning a story printed in The Brooklyn Eagle that he was a candidate for Mayor of Greater New York merely to trouble the Democrats and in fulfillment of a bargain made with Thomas C. Platt, who had agreed to rush the special Long Island City legislation asked for by the Mayor on condition that the latter would perturb the pelucid stream of the municipal Democratic canvass.
NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- The Mount Pleasant Town Assessors were in session here to-day.

TACOMA, Washington, Aug. 27. -- Five more towns have been wiped out and not less than 400 people have been killed since last reports were received of the eruption of Mayon volcano, in Luzon Island, one of the Philippine group. Widespread devastation and ruin have resulted in towns and villages situated around the base of Mayon for fifty miles.

Ex-Secretary Carl Schurz, who is spending a portion of the Summer at Lake George, has addressed the following open letter to Senator J.H. Gallinger in reply to some recent comments by the New Hampshire politician on the civil service law and its supporters:

BOSTON, Aug. 27. -- Much interest is manifested in the engagement which is announced of Miss Mary B. Higginson, eldest daughter of Francis L. Higginson, the banker on State Street, and Philip S. Sears, twin brother of Herbert M. Sears of Commonwealth Avenue.

LONDON, Aug. 28. -- The Times's Paris correspondent declares that a definitive treaty has actually been signed by a curious distribution of parts -- on Russian soil and on French soil, so to speak, the deck of the French cruiser Pothuau.

The Cunard Line steamship Lucania, after a remarkably fast run of a little over five and a half days, arrived at her pier late yesterday afternoon. She had a large passenger list, there being 382 saloon passengers, 320 second-cabin passengers, and 570 steerage. Sir Donald Smith, who, as Canadian High Commissioner attended the Queen's jubilee and was elevated to the peerage, was, among the passengers.

Naturalization papers are still bought and sold in the Italian colony. Officers of the Citizens' Union of the Second and Thirty-third Assembly Districts believe they have discovered a regular trade carried on by brokers in these certificates of citizenship, which are altered as to names and dates to suit their customers.

The police raided two alleged bucket shops yesterday, and arrested the supposed proprietors and all the employes. The first raid was made on the establishment of William M. McMillan, in the Lord's Court Building. Detective Sergeant Wade and about a dozen detectives visited the place, mingling with the regular customers until they had learned who were employes and who visitors.

Through the papers I have succeeded in reaching the public's sympathy in a most fortunate way for a line of work that I believe will grow into widespread usefulness. I mean the nursing by persons of intelli gence and tenderness of incurably diseased poor people.

Western owners of good race horses are more in evidence on the Eastern circuit this season than in many years before, and their determination to carry away a good share of the money offered by the Eastern racing associations this Fall is becoming more evident every day. The Westerners are represented in almost every race on the card, whether it be a stake race or an overnight selling affair.

When the name of John McCullagh, now Acting Chief, was first presented to the Police Board for promotion to an Inspectorship two years ago Commissioner Parker objected. His objection broke up the apparent friendship or armed neutrality in the board, and left all the Commissioners at odds.

MATTEAWAN, Aug. 27. -- The comparatively new buildings for insane criminals at Matteawan, which were first opened for the reception of patients only five years ago, are now alarmingly overcrowded. At that time it was supposed that there would be room to spare for several years to come for all who might be committed there.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 27. -- Ferdinand May, who fled from Germany with nearly $1,000,000, intrusted to him by clients, is supposed to be in Australia. The steamer Mariposa, which has arrived here from Australia, was carefully searched before her departure, the Australian authorities suspecting that the criminal would attempt to escape to the United States.
HAVANA, Aug. 27. -- The Diario de la .Marina has been fined $125 for printing an editorial headed, "Those Wee.ping -- Those Laughing."

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 27. -- Banker David J. Seligman died at the Hollywood Hotel at 11:30 to-night as a result of an operation performed on him Wednesday for appendicitis. He withstood the operation at first, but to-night a change for the worse appeared, and he sank rapidly.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28. -- First Assistant Postmaster General Heath has issued special instructions to Postmasters throughout the country providing for the expedition of transient mail in cities, the instructions being intended specially to benefit commercial travelers and theatrical companies.

" I regret to see that you gentlemen have been yielding to the most pernicious of all human failings," said the Captain at a symposium of the Ancients the other evening. The Captain, it may be explained, was retired from the army for a physical disability which he said did not exist, and has been somewhat of a pessimist ever since.

George E. Smith, better known to the patrons of the turf as "Pittsburg Phil," seems to have been born under a lucky star, which is still in the ascendent. Starting with a capital of $15 a few years ago, he has amassed money until conservative men who know him well rate him as worth at least $500,000.

WERE all the cargoes brought into the harbor of this metropolis of the Western world open to inspection, and the boxed, baled, crated, and barreled exports exposed to view, the water front of New York would be a comprehensive and ever-continuing exhibition of the products of the earth.

SOUTHOLD, L.I., Aug. 28. -- "Honest Dan" Grattan of this place has more adventures and financial entanglements with women than any other honest man on Long Island. Only a few months ago he was sued for $100,000 damages, alleged to have been inflicted upon the character of two females by utterances of his in his own cornfield in response to civil questions asked by a couple of strangers.

BOSTON, Aug. 28. -- In to-morrow's Journal will appear a rosy story of prosperity, based on reports from correspondents all over New England, and on interviews with commercial travelers who have returned from trips in different sections of the country.
PARKERSBURG, West Va., Aug. 28. -- Evidence of a murder and cremation was brought to light to-day by Emily Roberts, nine years of age, while passing through a small patch of woods near her home.

TROY, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- The title of champion marrying minister of the United States belongs not to the Rev. W.L. Meese of Auburn, Md., but to the Rev. Dr. George C. Baldwin of this city. By actual count during his fifty years as a Baptist minister he has joined 3,000 couples together for better or for worse.

Thro are, said Disraeli, two Englands, rich and poor, and Emerson, commenting on that saying, declared that the two Englands were the England of justice, of liberty, of humane ideas and noble insight, and the England of narrowness and unreason. Now, there are several Americas, not only geographically as in the well known generalizations of East, West, and South, but still more ethically, intellectually, from the point of view of culture and ideas.

The end of the contest at the Polo Grounds yesterday, where 10,000 enthusiasts saw the New York and Chicago teams play a tie game, was entirely out of place in this city. Patrons of the Polo Grounds never before saw a squad of police take possession of the field to prevent a disturbance, which seemed imminent after Umpire Emslie had called the game on account of darkness at the conclusion of the eighth inning.
Mayor Strong has received the following letter from I. Augustus Johnson, President of Good Government Club E:

Most divorcees and most of the married misery that does not end in divorce are due to the fact that people marry who have no moral right to do so. Mankind is reared in the belief that the right to marry is as inalienable as the right to "life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness."

NEWPORT, Aug. 28. -- The thirty-footers raced to-day for the cup offered by J. Stillman, Sr. The race was won by the Carolina. The start was made at 3:15, a triangular course being sailed over once in a light wind from the southwest. Mrs. Morgain sailed on the Puck, Miss Stillman on the Wawa, Payne Whitney on Dorothy II., and W.B. Duncan on Vaquero III.

The Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences will open its new season on the evening of Sept. 30 under more favorable auspices than during any previous year in its history. A year ago the first section of the Museum Building, on Prospect Hill, was far from completion. Now it is open to the public, and is visited daily by between 500 and 1,000 persons.

HAVANA, via Key West. Fla., Aug. 28. -- No one here believes that Gen. Azcarraga, the Spanish Premier, will remain permanently at the head of the Government. It is thought that the Liberals will come into power, in which case Capt. Gen. Weyler will not remain in Cuba, even though the Liberals request him to do so.

Much local and general interest is attached to the approching nup-tials of Miss Fanny Hayes of Fremont, only daughter of the late President Rutherford B. Smith, United States Navy, who is also a Fremont boy.

LONDON, Aug. 28. -- Senator Cullom of Illinois, Mrs. Cullom, their daughter, Mrs. Ridgely, and Senator Gray of Delaware, and the latter's family have been traveling in England this month. The Grays sail for home Tuesday next from Southampton on the New York. The Culloms have gone to the Continent.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 28. -- The record for the Irvington-Millburn course was broken here this afternoon in the True American twenty-five-mile road race by William Spree of Brooklyn and Harvey Rogers of this city. Spree's time was 1:07:23, and Rogers's 1:07:54.

The performances of the harness racers last week were of a character to sustain and, if anything, increase the popular interest in the sport, and excite the liveliest anticipations regarding the remainder of the season. Especially is this true of the four great pacers upon which have rested the hopes of reaching the two-minute mark this year -- Star Pointer. Joe Patchen, John R. Gentry, and Robert J.

Senator CHANDLER'S indignation over the 10 per cent. discriminating duty is perfectly justified. The bitterness of his self-reproach at not watching for the swindle is natural. "Having had experience with conference reports," he groans, "which should have warned me to read every word of this report, I have no excuse to offer for not doing so.

The mystery of a vanishing burglar; or who shot Guion Barrill? is the latest problem the Police Department has to solve. Detectives of the Grand Central Station have a theory. It took them only two or three hours to formulate it, and decide that it was the most plausible explanation of the known facts in the case.

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 28. -- This has been the gayest week Bar Harbor has had for a long time. The arrival of the North Atlantic squadron, under command of Admiral Sicard, on Tuesday has given the season a momentum that will carry it well into September.

Some months ago it appeared in the columns of THE NEW YORK TIMES that Stewart Co., the Wall Street bankers, had successfully made a negotiation of $3, 000,000 worth of bonds with an English syndicate for the purpose of developing an immense electrical and byraulic power plant to be conducted by the St. Lawrence Power Company of Massena, N.Y.

No straws point more accurately the course of general business affairs than the statistics of the Post Office and the telegraph companies. Languishing or dormant commercial conditions result in diminishing correspondence and fewer telegrams. On the other hand, in times of business activity, when the employment of capital assures handsome returns, correspondence is compulsory, while economy of time, necessitated by acute and stirring business situations, encourages lavish use of telegraph facilities.

DUBLIN, Aug. 28. -- The fears that the warm welcome accorded the Duke and Duchess of York in this city would not be repeated in the southern counties, where the opposition to the Government is most bitter, were dispelled to-day, when their Royal Highnesses finished their visit to the Irish capital and proceeded by special train 200 miles to Killarney.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28. -- State's Attorney Deneen to-day began preparations for the presentation of the evidence in the Luetgert murder case to the jury next week. Four veniremen, the number necessary to complete the jury, were tendered to the prosecution by the defense. They are S.S. Barber, salesman; W.R. Cudworth, farmer; J.H. Heickhold, insurance agent; John P. Bechmiller, farmer.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 28. -- George T. Newhall of Philadelphia was beaten by Leeds of Brookline, Mass., to-day by 8 up and 7 to play in the scratch golf tournament for the Green Cup on the Kebo links. Arden Robbins of New York, who has won every match, now leads Wright. Tappin and Leeds are out of it.

Uneasiness, intense excitement, and wild delight were the sentiments that in sequence animated several thousand persons at the track and field sports of the Amateur Athletic Union at Manhattan Field yesterday afternoon.

The Brooklyns were beaten in two games yesterday by the Louisvilles at Eastern Park, in the presence of 5,000 persons. The Colonels found a great deal of fault with Umpire Carpenter's decisions in the first game, but after he fined and ordered Clingman out of the game, they accepted his decisions in silence.

The publication of the details of a transaction which in the amount of property involved is the largest that has been closed in several months has added much interest to the dealings of the last few days. Judging from reports of what the two properties in Mr. Van Ingen's trade have been held at, a rather variable standard, to be sure, the valuations of the two parcels in the deal may be regarded as satisfactory.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 28. -- President McKinley spent a very quiet morning at Windmere, Senator Hanna's Summer home. He said it was one of the quietest which he has had since his vacation began. He did not leave the house at all, and only a few of the neighbors called.

Racing men of the New York district have recently had their attention forcibly directed to the necessity of a larger corps of competent track officials to see that amateur racing is kept on a respectable footing. Especially in the novice events "ringers" have put in appearances, pocketed their booty, and fled before those in charge of the track had discovered the offense or had time to take action.

When the Supreme Court of California the other day upheld a decision of a lower court which involved a declaration from the bench of justice that the law does not recognize hypnotism, one of the Judges, Mr. Justice MACFARLAND, while not dissenting from the opinion as it applied to that particular case, expressed his disagreement with the theory involved.

WITHOUT a doubt the most conspicuous figure among all the notabilities which the Queen's diamond jubilee celebration assembled in London was Sir Wilfrid Laurier, the Canadian Premier. "The Colonial Lion," the English papers have called him, and the appellation sticks.
BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 28. -- "Kebo is not what it used to be."

Frederic G. Mason, assignee of the United Press, has filed schedules showing liabilities of $129,415, nominal assets of $129,415, actual assets of $38,040. The latter consist of cash in New York, $7,968; cash in hands of fiscal agents, $9,617; furniture and fixtures of various offices, $7,883; accounts due, $12,571; the nominal value being $103,946.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28. -- The problem of communication by telegraph with a moving train anywhere on the line has been solved by George W. Trott, a young Chicago inventor. Mr. Trott has devised a system, which will shortly be given a trial on the Pennsylvania Railroad, by which every train on the line is in constant communication with the station next ahead, and, when desired, with the train dispatcher or any public telegraph station.

Security market conditions improve. Market values advance. The business situation shows further actual betterment. Wall Street is no longer speculating upon cheerful anticipations; the stage of development has been reached where confidence finds warrant positive and tangible.

NOTHING in the Business world of to-day more closely resembles the ancient guilds than does the system of pilotage. Like the goldsmiths and silk weavers, and all the other guilds of the twelfth, thirteenth, fourteenth, and fifteenth centuries, the pilots keep a constant number of men in the profession; just enough to do the work and no more.
