CHICAGO, Aug. 28. -- The unusual spectacle of a capitalist falling all over himself in his haste to secure the insertion of taxable property to the value of over half a million dollars on the Assessors' list, where previously it had been conspicuous by its absence, was one of the interesting incidents of last week in Chicago.

BOSTON, Aug. 28. -- Lucien Lesna defeated J. Frank Starbuck by one and one-half laps in their twenty-five-mile match race, which was run off this afternoon at Charles River Park. Lesna's time was 47:52, which beats the American competition paced record for the distance. Lesna, in fact, broke all the American records of this description from three to twenty-five miles.
THE Merchants' Association, which has already accomplished so much for the permanent benefit of New York, was organized early in the Summer through the efforts of William F. King.

ANTWERP, Aug. 14. -- If you speak English you get along very well in Antwerp; if you speak nothing but Dutch you still have no trouble; if you speak French that is perhaps a little better than either. In most of the business houses and all the hotels there is some one who speaks English. In the Post Office is an interpreter who smilingly answers a thousand questions a day.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 28. -- The annual coaching parade, in which the greatest interest centres and which brings together the finest vehicles and the most fashionable Summer residents of Newport, took place this afternoon.

Mayor Wurster of Brooklyn yesterday appointed Benjamin W. Wilson, Howard Patterson, Frank M. Thorburn, and Clinton De Witt as members of the Board of Assessors. Mr. Wilson succeeds himself. The others take the places of John McNamara, Michael Ryan, and Robert E.L. Howe. The appointees are all Republicans except Mr. De Witt, who is a son of William C. De Witt. The men retired are all Democrats.

That is a very interesting and suggestive interview, which THE TIMES published last week, with the President of the Metropolitan Traction Company. In the application of electricity to locomotion New York has been much behind, not only much smaller cities, but suburban and even rural districts.

WICHITA, Kan., Aug. 28. -- The wealthy cattle men of Clark County have banded together in an association whose object is to prevent settlers from coming in and buying or leasing land in that county for farming purposes, and their high-handed methods have aroused the people of that section to the highest pitch of excitement.

Between 600 and 700 soldiers came down to Creedmoor yesterday for supplementary rifle and pistol practice, a marked improvement over the attendance of the Saturday previous. The showing made, however, was comparatively poorer, a smaller percentage of both marksmen and sharpshooters qualifying.

Riders of note in the professional ranks assisted a list of amateur racing men a little better than the average in providing an afternoon of good cycle racing sport yesterday on the half-mile track at Waverly Park, Newark, in the meet of the Atalanta Wheelmen, The events were interesting, but were not the most exciting run in these parts, and the attendance was smaller than it should have been.

VICTORIA, B.C., Aug. 28. -- A letter from John Frank, who left Victoria on July 18 for Dawson with fifty-four head of cattle and fifteen horses, has just been received. It is dated Clackman, twenty-five miles up Chikat River. He writes:

PARIS, Aug. 16. -- A red-letter day for the monarchists! Three banquets, a shower of telegrams to Prince Victor Napoleon in his retreat at Brussels, to the Duc and Duchesse d'Orleans in Austria, and the duel between Prince Henri of Orleans and the Count of Turin were the outcome of Saint-Napoleon's Day, the once glorious 15th of August, and rarely have the monarchists in France had such an innings all together and all at once.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 28. -- Golf prospects in Stockbridge are very good, and the experts are continually on the links, preparing for a gand tournament, which will take place during the week beginning Monday, Sept. 27. A number of valuable cups have been offered, and the tournament will be the principal event at this resort this Fall.

SIMLA, Aug. 28. -- News has just been received here of another insurgent success. The Daulatzais on Thursday last captured the police post at Mahomedzai, which was garrisoned by a detachment of the border police. The garrison retreated to a new post, held by a detachment of the Second Punjab Infantry, reaching there the next morning.

BARRE, Vt., Aug. 28. -- At the Granite City Trotting Park this afternoon John R. Gentry reduced the State harness record of 2:11 1/4, made by Nelson, to 2:07, while Robert J. was one second behind. The weather was fine and the track in excellent condition, which enabled the fast pacers to make the time without effort.

BERLIN, Aug. 28. -- An unpleasant surprise has been created by the naval correspondents of the Kreuz Zeitung and other Conservative newspapers, as well as the correspondent of the Deutsche Zeitung Rundschau, reporting the naval manoeuvres near Dantzic during the past fortnight. They describe the evolutions of the German war vessels as having been total failures so far as quickness and manoeuvring ability to resist torpedo attacks are concerned.

LONDON, Aug. 28. -- The Indian troubles have let loose a flood of acrimonious criticism which blamer everybody connected with the Government. Sir Ellis Ashmead-Bartlett, the Conservative member of Parliament and Anglo-American friend of the Sultan of Turkey, in a virulent letter just published, declares that a spirit of fanaticism has been aroused which will be most difficult to quell, adding:

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 28. -- The Young Men's Diocesan Union held its annual field day games this afternoon at Caledonian Park before fully 1,000 people. The games were between clubs belonging to the union. The Institutes won the banner given for points handily. The 100-yard event was won by James Brown, C.Y.M.A., in 0:10 2-5.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, Aug. 28. -- The open golf tournament under the auspices of the Point Judith Country Club was continued at the links at the Wild Field Farm to-day. A feature of the match was a round made by Mr. Barker in a play against Mr. Mauron, tying the score of the links and making a record of 79. The summary:

CHICAGO, Aug. 28. -- Both bulls and bears in wheat were given a breathing spell to-day, and the market was the quietest in two weeks. A much smaller amount of trading also characterized the other grain markets. At the close wheat was unchanged to 1/2 cent lower, corn 1/2 cent lower, and oats 1/4 cent lower. The strain in the wheat market was slackened very much.

The Woman's Klondike Expedition Syndicate, which is to start March 1, is to be "personally conducted by Mrs. Sarah Wright McDannold and son." Its object is to prospect and locate claims on the Klondike and other tributaries of the Yukon River, as the circular says, and to establish a new mining camp and hospital and equip a complete commissariat train.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 28. -- Plans are being rapidly perfected for the opening of the Autumn season. Those who own country places here have nearly all returned from Newport, Bar Harbor, the Adirondacks, and other resorts, and by another week everybody will be here. The fact that all the prominent cottagers are here this year insures an interesting season.

The Manhattan Theatre, which used to be called the Standard, has been handsomely refitted and redecorated by its new manager, Mr. Woodhull. The electric light has been introduced, and both the heating and ventilating apparatuses are new and modern. The revailing colors in the auditorium are salmon pink and gold.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28. -- Assistant Secretary of the Treasury Howell has received a reply from Thomas J. Phelan of the Board of Tea Experts to an inquiry which was sent to Mr. Phelan a week ago, based upon representations made by Representative Wilson of New York, who came here on behalf of some of his Kings County constituents.
" If we don't have from now on three or four or five years of as good times as America has ever seen, then I'm wrong in what I believe, in what I am convinced of."

When Andree proceeded last year to his starting point in Spitzbergen, the public skeptically wondered what would happen. Unfortunately, the elements were against the gallant explorer. The wind refused to blow in the required direction, and nothing remained for him but to return.

More than 200 applications were received at the headquarters of the Merchants' Association yesterday for non-resident membership. The larger proportion of these applications came from the South, and were in response to circulars mailed from here to points in the Southern States about a week ago.

READVILLE, Mass., Aug. 28. -- The Chicago pacing stallion, Star Pointer, owned by James A. Murphy, to-day wiped out forever the two-minute mark and ended the controversy which has been going on for years as to the speed qualities of the light harness horse.
In the September Harper's Magazine "A Twentieth Century Outlook," by Capt. A. T. Mahan, is an article of major importance.

The annual regatta of the Young Men's Christian Association Boat Club took place yesterday afternoon on the Harlem River. There were five events -- four rowing and one swimming -- on the card, all of which were hotly contested. The first event was a single gig race for novices. There were ten entries, of which six qualified.

THERE is no lack of theatrical talk now, though as yet nothing has been done in the theatres to justify much talk. The subject of most of the talk is what is going to be done, The silent is listener can learn a great deal from this of the tremendous genius of theatre men for advertising their business at all times and in all places, and their general defiance of the probable in their announcements.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- An Erie passenger train, while going at the rate of sixty-five miles an hour, struck a wagon containing five people at a crossing near Cheektowaga, just outside of the city limits, to-night. Melville H. Valentine, thirty-eight years old, was instantly killed, and M.O. Weider, Mrs. M.O. Weider, Eddie Weider, four years old, and George Cole, thirty-seven years old, were all severely injured. Mrs. Weider and George Cole may die.

PARIS, Aug. 29. -- The city is growing into a frenzy of enthusiasm over the welcome to be extended to President Faure on his return on Tuesday next from his visit to Russia. Already the principal streets and buildings are decorated with flags and bunting. A group of tradesmen held a meeting yesterday and resolved to erect a grand stand and a triumphal arch, and committees are busy in all quarters of the city.

A genuine Bavarian "Kirmess," or "Jahrmarkt," was transplanted yesterday with all its accessories to Sulzer's Harlem River Park. It was the first day of the "Twenty-fourth Grand and General Bavarian Volksfest, arranged and held under the auspices of the Bavarian Volksfest Verein of New York," which is to continue today and conclude next Sunday.

Complaint is made by the Merchants and Manufacturers' Board of Trade that the law as to the tax on wearing apparel of returning travelers is not thoroughly enforced. This organization was very influential in securing the passage of the law and has taken much interest in watching its administration.

The Methodist preacher who denounced the wearing of low-necked dresses at Ocean Grove on Thursday night may be entitled to respect for his motives. But he cannot be congratulated either upon his good sense or his good taste. No edict had been issued against the wearing in the Auditorium of such garments as are usually worn at public assemblages on Summer evenings, and many of the female singers in the chorus were thus clad.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 29. -- This city suddenly became densely dark this evening. The experience of two weeks ago, when, by the breaking loose of 1,200 tons of coal in the bin above the fireroom at the Edison Electric Station, the current was shut off, was repeated so far as the public was concerned.

The championship of the New York Cricket Association is all but decided, for by the victory of Saturday the Brooklyn Club is insured the pennant. The Paterson Club, which last year gained the championship, will probably finish in second place, and the New Jersey Athletic Club should be third.

Policeman Farrell of the Twenty-second Police Precinct, Brooklyn, working under great difficulties, saved the lives of many, passengers of a Brighton Beach Railroad train last light. He did this at the risk of his own life and the lives of two boy prisoners, whom he had caught in an attempt to wreck the train.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 29. -- Although the only State office to be filled in Kentucky by election this year is that of Clerk of the Court of Appeals -- a place that pays a good salary, yet has no political significance -- four political parties have held State Conventions and are making as active and earnest a canvass as was made last year when a President was elected.

A letter from an evidently well-meaning gentleman was received in answer to a communication in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 26. He calls me "a sophist" because I said there that New York has no longer the choice between dependence and independence, but must now simply choose between the bosses of the two great political parties.

Fire was discovered yesterday afternoon in the six-story factory building at 478 and 480 Pearl Street, and before the flames were under control the building was practically gutted and the Baxter Street tenement district was threatened with destruction.

PORT ANGELIS, Washington, Aug. 29. -The steamer Portland, from St. Michael's, which touched at this port last evening, brings the news that the remarkably rich claims on Eldorado Creek will number 140.

The Republicans are now hopeful of holding the Citizens' Union in check. The one point, and a most important one, which the Union yielded when, out of "courtesy" to the Brooklyn Committee of Fifty, it postponed the nomination of candidates, makes them confident that they will make it yield other points and ultimately all.
Flatbush is now in a feverish condition of mind over a watch which Charles Graves, who lives near the Park entrance, bought in some unknown street in New York City.

A steer had a great deal of sport in Eleventh Avenue and some other streets yesterday afternoon, and contrived to promote the activity and stimulate the interest of Charles Cochrane of 631 Eleventh Avenue.

When Spicer McNeeley brought a bicycle home to the McCormick tenements last May it was the most exciting event that had occurred for many a day in the neighborhood of Fifty-seventh Street, west of Tenth Avenue. Not that events of an exciting nature are infrequent in that locality. The gong of an ambulance is often heard there.
ALBANY, Aug. 29. -- Erastus Corning, one of Albany's wealthiest and most prominent citizens, was stricken with apoplexy at a late hour to-night, and little hope is entertained for his recovery.
TACOMA, Washington, Aug. 29. -- The Northern Pacific steamer Columbia arrived here this afternoon, bringing news of great loss of life in Japan on Aug. 5 and 6.

Cab fares are going to come down. The charges of the baggage express companies are the next thing to be reduced. They are unreasonable and extortionate. They are absurdly out of proportion to the cost and value of the service performed, measured by other similar services which the same money will procure.

BOMBAY, Aug. 29. -- Little fresh news has been received here from the frontier. An attack has been made on Shinwari, in the Samana range, but the attacking force was repulsed, losing five killed and many wounded, There is considerable excitement among the tribes along the Bolan route to Quetta, and the telegraph wires have again been cut.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 29. -- President McKinley attended divine service this morning at Epworth Memorial Methodist Episcopal Church, where he has a pew. He was accompanied by James F. Rhodes, the historian, and Mrs. Rhodes. The church was crowded to its utmost capacity.

Estimates of the amount of trade brought to New York through the efforts of the Merchants' Association range from $30,000,000 to $50,000,000. President King believes that the Summer and Fall buying by out-of-town merchants will reach $60,000,000. The influx of visitors who are buyers of merchandise of various kinds has thus far been greater than any year since 1892.

SEATTLE, Washington, Aug. 29. -- The steamer Portland arrived here at 3 o'clock this morning. It was fourteen hours after the Portland was sighted off Cape Flattery before she arrived here. The Portland carried thirteen miners, each of whom brought only a small part of his stake. Although reports that the Portland had brought a great treasure have been made, the actual value of the gold dust on board is perhaps $575,000.

The London Spectator remains in "a state of mind" regarding the United States. In its latest issue it follows up its previous articles in the same tone by one on "Canada's Opportunity," in which occurs the following passage regarding the United States:
John G. Moore is home from his long Maine outing this morning, a stalwart bull, who will be promptly heard from.

That was a courageous constable who saved Ulster County the disgrace of a lynching on Friday. The circumstances were those which so often bring about mob violence. The criminal, a negro, had behaved most atrociously. Of those who assembled to put him to death without warrant of law there were doubtless some who were merely carried out of their power of reflection for the time being by the impulse of indignation.

BUDA-PESTH, Aug. 29. -- The Ministry of Agriculture has issued its annual estimate, in which it describes the world's harvest as extraordinarily light. The total yield of wheat is placed at 573,760,000 metric hundredweight, while the present annual requirements are estimated at 655,150,000 metric hundredweight.

COATESVILLE, Penn., Aug. 29. -- In a fit of ungovernable rage this afternoon, Ralph Moore, a young man, fired a shotgun into a group of four men at Mortonville, instantly killing his sixty-five-year-old grandfather, Reuben Segner, and seriously wounding Victor Segner, his uncle, and Charles and Benjamin Moore.

MONTREAL, Aug. 29. -- The British Medical Association will meet in this city on Tuesday. The gathering will be the largest in the history of medicine on this continent. An attendance of 1,500 is expected, of whom 300 will be members of the British Association in Great Britain, 600 American guests, and 700 Canadians.

If any doubt exists in the mind of any person given to following the political journeyings of Senator Platt and Jacob Worth that there is no ill-feeling between those two leaders it must certainly have been dispelled by the events of Saturday night at the Oriental Hotel.

There is joy in the camp of the local baseball "rooters" just at present; wild, exultant joy produced by the wonderful showing of the New Yorks during the last two weeks. Veteran "rooters,' whose enthusiasm waned because of the poor position of the local team in the pennant race during the first part of the season, are again on deck.

The Anti-Tammany wing of the Progressive Democratic League met yesterday at Teutonia Assembly Rooms, in Third Avenue, near Sixteenth Street, and completed the work of removing from office those officers who remained with the Tammany faction when the split took place in the league two weeks ago, and also of expelling the clubs that did not come over.
NEWPORT, Aug. 29. -- The following yachts arrived here to-day: Schooner Water Witch, owned by David Banks; steamer Nourmahal, owned by J.J. Astor; steamer Conqueror, owned by F.W. Vanderbilt.

Acting Chief McCullagh paid a hurried visit last night to Capt. Chapman of the West Thirtieth Street Station. The Chief arrived at 10 o'clock. He seemed to be in a hurry, and, after shaking hands with Sergt. Tims, he walked without ceremony into the private room of Capt. Chapman. He closed the door with a bang.

William Callahan, a driver, of 232 East Tenth Street, was held in $1,500 bail in the Yorkville Court yesterday on a charge of stabbing Lawrence Belger of 629 Lorimer Street, Brooklyn. Bolger's left arm was cut from elbow to wrist. He and James McKinney of 223 East Fourteenth Street were accosted by Callahan at Third Avenue and Fourteenth Street at 1 o'clock yesterday morning.

The Rev. Dr. Frank Rogers Morse, associate pastor of the Calvary Baptist Church, West Fifty-seventh Street, completed yesterday evening a series of sermons upon "Knowing Our Friends in Heaven." His theme was: "Some of the Uses of the Doctrine," and in the course of his remarks he referred to the supreme importance of forming only Christian friendships.

WEST POINT, Aug. 29. -- The cadets were elated to-day at the news from Washington of the probability of a football game with the Naval Academy this Fall. Few, however, believe that the game will take place. The Military Academy authorities are not in favor of a game between the two National institutions, and their opinions have great weight in Washington.

ALBANY, Aug. 29. -- Active preparations are being made to fight the operation of the so-called Anti-Scalpers' law, which takes effect on Wednesday, Sept. 1. The new measure will make it a penal offense for any person to issue or sell any passage ticket or a berth or stateroom in any vessel unless he is an authorized agent of the owners or consignees of such vessel, or of the company running such train.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- The Treasury Department is conducting an investigation of charges that Chinese are being smuggled into the United States at Port Townsend, Washington. The reports upon which the investigation is based were received here about a week ago, and Assistant Secretary Howell immediately ordered Special Agent Cullom to proceed to Port Townsend.

READING, Penn., Aug. 29. -- There is a positive determination on the part of the majority of the delegates to the Pennsylvania State Democratic Convention, to be held here on Aug. 31, to oust National Committeeman Harrity.

When we remember how slight was the plurality of MCKINLEY in Kentucky last year -- a change of 1 vote in 3,000 would have given the Electoral vote to BRYAN -the situation in the State this year is peculiarly interesting.

The Harlem oarsmen had a perfect day yesterday in which to finish their Sunday practice spins on the river for the Middle States Regatta. The river was like a millpond, and the weather was all, that could be desired. From early in the morning until long after dark the river was thronged with barges, gigs, shells, and working boats of the different clubs.

FREMONT, Ohio, Aug. 29. -- The first and second days of September will have noted events here, at both of which President McKinley will be in attendance. Sept. 1 occurs the wedding of Ensign Smith and Miss Hayes, the daughter of the ex-President, and on the following day occurs the reunion of the regiment in which Hayes and McKinley served during the war.
The Transvaal Blue Book, published in London in April, 1897, gives Article IV, of the London convention as follows:

There used to be a popular idea that the big railroad station on East Forty-second Street would surely be abandoned some time or other by the railroad companies using it as a New York terminal for their passenger traffic. Its use cuts a big slice of very valuable land out of a particularly valuable part of this crowded city, but that is the only thing that can be said against it.
LYNN, Mass., Aug. 29. -- A double drowning occurred at Flax Pond this afternoon, the victims being Thomas Hayden, thirty-two years old, and Nicholas Gabarino, an Italian, of Barret Street, Boston.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 30. -- Dr. Charles Smith, who was arrested last week charged with polluting the water supply of this city by having patients at his skin disease sanitarium bathe in one of the brooks which feed the supply, was arraigned to-day. After the bathing had been proved, Dr. H.R. Baldwin of the Board of Health testified that the bathing was likely to contaminate the water.

BOSTON, Aug. 30. -- "A Man of Ideas," Sydney Rosenfeld's new comedy, was received with much pleasure by a typical first-night audience at the Boston Museum to-night. Both the author and the chief actor, Mr. Roland Reed, were called before the curtain and made acknowledgments.

NIAGARA ON THE LAKE, Ontario, Aug. 30. -- The international tennis tournament was continued to-day. The best tennis of the tournament was shown, and there are now left in the open singles only Whitman, Ware, Fischer, and Bond. Whitman plays Fischer and Ware plays Bond. In the handicap singles Ware went down before Neely, to whom he owed fifteen.
ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 30. -- Senator Benjamin R. Tillman speaking here to-day at a gathering of the Patriots of America, dwelt caustically upon State politics. Some of the remarks were as follows:

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 30. -- The Greenburgh Town Assessors held the first of their concluding series of grievance meetings here to-day. There are still about 150 of these complaints to be heard, and the board will not complete its work this week.

A point which the testimony of President McKinley may be necessary to decide was raised before the Board of United States General Appraisers yesterday on a hearing of protests against the Treasury Department's construction of the retroactive force of the new tariff law. Counsel for the protesting importers were proceeding on the assumption that it was a conceded fact that the new tariff law was signed by the President at 4:04 o'clock P.M. July 24.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 30. -- The Labor Congress called to consider measures in the interest of the striking coal miners met here to-day. Several of those expected were not present at the opening session, including Samuel Gompers, President of the American Federation of Labor.
LONDON, Aug. 30. -- The bicycle race for the gold vase which was begun at Catford on Saturday, when A.E. Walters beat Stocks by one mile in six hours' riding, was continued this evening.

SEATTLE, Washington, Aug. 30. -- In speaking of the Klondike gold fields, William Ogilvie, Dominion Surveyor for the Northwest Territory, discourages all strangers from going into the bleak country. He denies that any difference regarding the boundary line exists between Canada and the United States. He says:

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Aug. 24. -- Advices just to hand from the northwest territory of British Guiana tell of an attack made on an English settler and his party by the Venezuelan frontier police. George H. Moore is a grant holder on the English side of the Amacura River. The other day he left his residence with a party of Englishmen for a fishing and hunting expedition to Barima.
One of our yellow contemporaries printed in its issue of last Sunday an article on the kidnapping of children, of which we reprint the first paragraph:

HAVANA, Aug. 30. -- After leaving Havana yesterday morning, Captain General Weyler proceeded to Calzadar, Jesus del Monte, Vibora, Calvario, Arfroyo, and Apolo. Thence he went to Chorrera, thirteen kilometres distant, the last of the line of Havana fortifications, and from there proceeded to Cantarana, in the direction of Lechuga, arriving at the village of Villa Real, near Guines, at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon.
CHICAGO, Aug. 30. -- The trial of Adolph Luetgert for the murder of his wife was opened for the State to-day by the taking of testimony.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- The Southeastern Railway Association has arranged for a series of excursions from all parts of the South traversed by its lines to Washington, Norfolk, and Richmond, at one fare for the round trip, commencing Sept. 1.

The City Magistrates met last evening in the new court building in West Fifty-fourth Street to elect a new Chief Clerk, and thus incidentally open the new police court, but they were treated to a surprise which prevented them from taking the action intended, and induced them to postpone the opening of the court for another month, at least.

When Natty Bumppo, Chingachgook, Uncas, and Major Heywood were on the trail of Cora and Alice Munro, abducted by the "accursed Mingo," Magua, Uncas noted that one of the horses of the pursued party had a unique gait. This beast advanced both the feet on the same side of the body at once, his starboard feet, fore and main, both going ahead while both his port feet were going astern.

Up to yesterday, the racing associations, with the exception of Brighton Beach and Aqueduct, excluded Monday from their racing programmes, considering it the worst day in the week to attract a fair-sized attendance. The experiment of racing on Monday was made yesterday at Sheepshead Bay, but if the opening work-day of the week has any lessening effect on the racing attendance, the size of the crowd did not show it.

An iron window bar which accidentally fell from a house in course of erection at Myrtle and St. Nicholas Avenues, Ridgewood last evening, struck John Miller, thirty-two years old, of 1,453 De Kalb Avenue, on his head, fracturing his skull.

-- A young man who toils diligently enough six days out of every seven to deserve as well as to desire a rest when the seventh arrives, came home about 9 o'clock Sunday evening, pale and haggard with weariness, and he threw himself into a big chair with this exclamation: "Thank Heaven I don't have to work as hard on week days!"
MADRID, Aug. 30. -- At a Cabinet Council held to-day it was decided to summon the next class of 80,000 reserves, 27,000 of whom will be sent to Cuba and 13,000 to the Philippine Islands.

TACOMA, Washington, Aug. 30. -- Skaguay is not to be a great town of Alaska after all. People have been saying that in six months it would be larger than Juneau and hundreds of men are now madly endeavoring to buy lots there at prices that will enable them to reap big profits by Spring.

WORCESTER, Mass., Aug. 30. -- United States Senator George Frisbie Hoar was seventy-one years of age yesterday, and he observed the anniversary quietly at his residence, 34 Oak Avenue. A few intimate friends of the family called, but there was no formal celebration.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 30. -- Two Deputy United States Marshals are dead, two are seriously injured, and two more are missing, as the result of an attack on a posse of officers by a band of moonshiners in Pope County yesterday. The dead are B.F. Taylor of Searcy County and Joe Dodson of Stone County. Two Renfrew brothers are wounded.

READING, Penn., Aug. 30. -- By a vote of 53 to 26, the Democratic State Committee to-night adopted a resolution declaring vacant the seat of William F. Harrity of Philadelphia in the Democratic National Committee. The committee met in the rooms of the Americus Club, by direction of the Executive Committee, to consider the question of the vacancy in the National Committee.

Eight young, Cheyenne Indians, dressed in the gaudy costume of the red man at peace, dined in the public room of the Imperial Hotel yesterday with three white men, and attracted general attention. The Indians arrived in the city Sunday on their way to Washington to visit the officials of the Department of the Interior.

PESHAWUR, Aug. 30. -- A strong force of Afridis, it is just announced, has closed the Kohat Pass, and, therefore, the proposed advance of a column of British troops through that pass has been countermanded.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 30. -- M.P. Carrick, President of the Brotherhood of Painters and Decorators of America, says that a proposition is to be presented at the St. Louis Convention to mobilize the army of the unemployed of the country in the vicinity of Pittsburg in the event of a determined effort on the part of the operators to start the mines with imported labor.

Mr. POULTNEY BIGELOW, writing from Berlin to Harper's Weekly, makes a very significant and suggestive statement about the relations of the German Government to German literature. A German scholar told Mr. BIGELOW that an accurate history of Germany by a German not only did not exist, but could not be produced.

The vinegar and pickle factory occupying the five-story building at 417 East Seventy-sixth Street was destroyed by fire last night. The damage is estimated at $20,000, and is fully covered by insurance. Charles Pape was the owner of the factory. The building was destroyed, save the walls, which remain standing, but are in danger of collapse.
Among the passengers who arrived yesterday on European steamships were the following:

COBLENTZ, Aug. 30. -- At a banquet given this evening in connection with the army manoeuvres, Emperor William, in the course of a long address, delivered an eloquent panegyric upon William the Great and the historic scenes connected with Coblentz.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- Among the ten thousand or more maps which are being transferred from their old quarters in the Capitol Building to the new Congressional Library are many possessing great historical value. They have been buried for a generation in the crypts of the Capitol and their existence was unknown to the world.

The Chicagos won yesterday from the New Yorks at the Polo Grounds in the play off of the tie game of Saturday. The game was marred by senseless and useless kicking against the umpire's decisions. The visitors, including Anson, who usually behaves well in that regard, were the chief offenders, but the local team were by no means blameless.

SOMERSWORTH, N.H., Aug. 30. -- Daniel G. Rollins died at his Summer home on Beacon Street this afternoon, aged fifty-five years. Four weeks ago he came to the old homestead here ill with diabetes, to which he succumbed. The funeral and burial will take place here on Thursday at 1 o'clock.

It was somewhat of a coincidence that just as a friend and myself were discussing the prevailing extortionate charges for local baggage delivery we should have run across your article in this morning's TIMES.

Twelve non-commissioned officers and privates of the army have been ordered to report at Fort Leavenworth to-day to undergo their final examinations for commissions. The Sun has pertinently commented on this evidence that, although some West Point graduates are without places in the army, the Government does not wish to interrupt the pursuit of its wise policy of encouragement to the rank and file of the military service.

Jacob Worth said yesterday afternoon that the Citizens' Union would make no mistake in nominating Seth Low for the Mayoralty in advance of any other nomination, as he believed Mr. Low's entrance into the field would crystallize public sentiment in his favor. Mr. Worth added that he was daily more convinced of the growing strength of the independent movement in favor of Mr. Low.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- The Post Office Department has been startled by the uncovering of a novel scheme to rob the Government, which it is said has been put into execution by Dr. R. Colburn, a Washington sub-Postmaster. Colburn, according to the story, devised the plan of issuing postal money orders to fictitious persons in nearby towns and cities and then going in person and collecting them, making fraudulent representations as to his identity.

BOSTON, Aug. 30. -- Robert F. Straine and Charles S. Lamson, President and Treasurer of the United Telegram Company, were arrested to-day on a charge of conspiring to defraud the company. The amount named in the complaint is $73,371.17, and the prosecution is at the instance of New York stockholders.

WICHITA, Kan., Aug. 30. -- It developed to-day that ex-County Treasurer John A. Doran, who died recently at Geuda Springs, was a defaulter, and, though the experts have only completed the examination of the books during his first term, it is acknowledged that his shortage will reach $40,000. The Treasurer who succeeded Doran found enough irregularities in the books during Doran's second term to warrant an investigation.

Articles of agreement have been signed for a match middle distance race between Lucien Lesna and Jimmy Michael on the Manhattan Beach track on Sept. 25, according to a member of the American Cycle Racing Association, under whose auspices the match will be run. By the terms of the indenture the distance is to be thirty-three miles, and both men are to be paced by separate relays.

With a light export trade on the Produce Exchange yesterday the wheat market was in the same condition as on Saturday, inactive and featureless. It was termed, not inaptly, a waiting market, obedient to the laws of supply and demand, and all quotations trending to a lower level, biding the inevitable -- a rush to buy by countries that cannot do without our cereals.

The conference between Chairman Quigg and a few anti-Tammany organizations at the Manhattan Hotel last night was held in secret, and lasted from 8 to 12. At midnight it adjourned, with nothing accomplished, to meet at the Astor House to-morrow at 11 A.M. The Citizens' Union was not represented. It declined to confer.

BASEL, Switzerland, Aug. 30. -- At to-day's session of the Zionist Congress the delegates present unanimously adopted, with great enthusiasm, the programme for re-establishing the Hebrews in Palestine, with publicly recognized rights.

Mr. Perry Belmont, before going to Europe in May last, declared in a tone as peremptory as words can express, that his name will not be among those presented to the voters next November for the office for Mayor of "Greater New York."

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Aug. 30. -- The Southern Pacific Company has formally entered the field as a purchaser and consumer of California petroleum. It is reported that the management of that company has had seven locomotives changed to crude oil burners within the week just closed, and that purchases of 30,000 barrels of oi1 in bulk have been made.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- The decision of the Attorney General in the matter of the Canadian discriminating duty clause of the Dingley tariff law will not be announced for several days. It had been expected to-day.

The Park Commissioners yesterday denied the application of the Rapid Transit Commission for permission to tunnel Battery Park for the end of the proposed underground road, holding that the original plans of the commission would injure the park beyond repair, and that the Rapid Transit Commission has no power to make an agreement to modify those plans.
Morris Steinhardt has sold the block fronting on the east side of Madison Avenue, between One Hundred and One Hundred and First Streets, 200 by 100.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 30. -- Erastus Corning, a well-known citizen and President of the Albany City National Bank, died at 2 o'clock this morning. He was one of the wealthiest men in the State, and his charities were numerous. Death was caused by apoplexy. He was seventy years old.

" The Citizens' Union and the Republicans have but one common ground of opposition to Tammany Hall, namely, opposition to the Chicago platform. No other basis of union exists, or can be made while the Chicago platform exists.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- Herman W. Van Senden, private secretary to Secretary Carlisle in the last Administration, and Dennis J. Canty, formerly a clerk in the office of the Inter-State Commerce Commission, were arrested to-day on warrants charging them with the embezzlement of $4,887 from Wilkins Co., a brokerage firm.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Aug. 30. -- Late Saturday night two strangers, one short and the other tall, and both well dressed, rowed into Inni's slip in a stolen rowboat, and walked up town to Levi Melhado's store, where they pawned a valuable breech-loading double-barreled shotgun for $3. They acted nervous, and, after pawning the gun, walked hurriedly back to the river and tried to sell the stolen boat for $15.

An unusually large number of out-of-town merchants were registered at the headquarters of the Merchants' Association yesterday. They included a hundred or more who arrived from the West Saturday night and Sunday. They were eager to obtain official recognition from the Merchants' Association, and crowded into the office as soon as the doors were opened yesterday morning.

Acting Inspector Stephen J. O'Brien was relieved from the command of the Detective Bureau yesterday afternoon by Acting Chief of Police McCullagh. Sergt. George W. McClusky of the West One Hundred and Fifty-second Street Station, formerly a Detective Sergeant, takes his place at 8 o'clock this morning. O'Brien, deprived of his brevet, goes as Captain to the Leonard Street Station.

NEWPORT, Aug. 30. -- The following yachts arrived here to-day: Steamer Margarita, owned by A.J. Drexel; steamer Marjorie, owned by A.S. Van Winkle; steamer Josephine, owned by P.A. Widener; schooner Wayward, owned by Mr. Thomas; schooner Intrepid, owned by C.O. Iselin; schooner Amorita, owned by W.G. Brokaw; schooner Hildegarde, owned by G.W. Weld; schooner Monhegan, owned by Mr. Clarke; steamer Black Pearl, owned by E.B. Sheldon.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 31. -- The labor congress which met here yesterday to consider the situation of the striking coal miners concluded its work to-day. The only sensational incident was a speech by Eugene V. Debs, in which he vehemently attacked capital and the Federal courts and intimated that the present industrial conditions would lead to bloodshed.

The American Malting Company is practically in existence. At the office of its financiay agents, Moore Schley, yesterday it was said that an announcement that the organization of the trust was completed would be premature, while the statement that no obstacle exists to its formation would be correct, as the last concern which demurred has come to terms.

HAVANA, Aug. 31. -- Gen. Linares, in the Province of Santiago de Cuba, has been engaged with an insurgent force. The enemy lost two men killed and the troops lost thirteen men killed, including two Captains. The horse of Gen. Linares was struck by two bullets and killed.

-- Those young Cheyennes now in this city declare that they never saw so fine a metropolis as this, and our kindly Mayor, not to be outdone in courteous compliments, told the braves that they were the finest specimens of their tribe that he had ever had the pleasure of meeting. This interchange of opinions reminds one of the fact that

Edward B. Cuthbert, in the banking and brokerage business, on the fourth floor of the Johnston Building, 30 Broad Street, made an assignment yesterday to Ernest H. Ball, counsel for the concern, which was known as E.B. Cuthbert Co., although since last April Mr. Cuthbert has had no partner.

Although the spirit of belligerency hovered dangerously near the office of the local Tax Commissioners yesterday, it caused no breach of decorum during the conference between the members of the State Board of Tax Commissioners and the New York City Tax Commissioners, Martin Heermance of Poughkeepsie.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31. -- When the Luetgert murder trial was resumed this morning the defense asked the court to compel the State to set forth by what means, according to the theory of the prosecution, the life of Mrs. Luetgert was taken before her body was placed in the vat. Judge Vincent said the indictment, which contains twelve counts, does not state the manner of Mrs. Luetgert's death.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31. -- Through information furnished by ex-American Consul in Cuba Henriquez it was learned that Eduardo Otasa, an American citizen and brother of Dr. Joaquin Otasa of 137 West Thirty-eighth Street, New York City, was recently taken from his plantation in Guayabal, Cuba, and ruthlessly slain by a squad of Spanish soldiers. Otasa was a Spaniard by birth and at one time resided in New York with his wife and five children.

PROVIDENCE, Aug. 31. -- The meeting of the Advisory and Executive Committee of the corporation of Brown University was held this afternoon at the university. Routine business of very little public importance was transacted in preparation for the larger meeting of the corporation to-morrow. The letter of President Andrews resigning his position was read and will be presented to the corporation.

READING, Penn., Aug. 31. -- The Democratic State Convention met in this city today and nominated Walter E. Ritter of Lycoming County for Auditor General and M. E. Brown of Blairsville for State Treasurer. The matter of the selection of candidates was entirely overshadowed by the fight to force the retirement of William F. Harrity from the National Committee.

TORONTO, Aug. 31. -- Advisers received here report that by to-night all of 25,000,000 bushels of wheat in Manitoba will be out. There has been no frost sufficient to damage the wheat in Manitoba this season, and next week will probably see the bulk of the wheat thrashed. The crop will be the largest in the history of the Canadian Northwest.

It has always been one of the troubles of Lieut. Gov. WOODRUFF that he could not get his fellow-citizens to take him seriously. He takes himself very seriously indeed, but the levity of the community continues to be in inverse proportion to his own gravity.

WORCESTER, Mass., Aug. 31. -- All of the National circuit riders were here to-day, participating in the bicycle races held in connection with the opening of the Massachusetts Grange Fair. Interest centred in the professional events in which Bald, Kiser, the Butlers, Meriens, Johnson, and Taylor were entered. Eddie Bald of Buftale won the mile professional open, beating Johnson and Taylor, the latter after hard struggle in the final beat.

There was another hearing and a second arrest yesterday in the case of James Connor, the notary public who was arrested Saturday, accused by Rocco Romano, an Italian bootblack and keeper of a fruit stand at One Hundred and Twentieth Street and Third Avenue, of selling him a forged naturalization certificate.

We wonder if the respectable Republicans of New York realize the condition to which their party has been reduced by the rule of PLATT. Do they understand why QUIGG'S conference was an ignominious failure? Do they clearly see in what a light he has exhibited their party?

CHICAGO, Aug. 31. -- A handsome young woman whose real name is unknown killed herself this morning in the Victoria Hotel, where she was a guest. The suicide was evidently carried out with the utmost deliberation, as the young woman had apparently slept in the bed during the night, taken a bath in the morning, made up the bed, and then swallowed morphine.

MONTREAL, Aug. 31. -- The opening service of the sixty-fifth annual meeting of the British Medical Association was held at noon to-day at Christ Church Cathedral. The sermon was by the Bishop of Niagara. It was full cathedral service.

PARIS, Aug. 31. -- President Faure arrived at the Northern Railway Station from Dunkirk at 6 o'clock this evening. He was received there by the President of the Chamber of Deputies, M. Brisson; the President of the Senate, M. Loubet; the General in command of the Paris garrison and his staff, and the Municipal Councilors.

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 31. -- Arden Robbins of New York defeated G.T. Newhall, the Philadelphia crack, to-day in the finals of the Green Cup scratch golf tournament on the Kebo Valley links by 8 up and 7 to play.

It is a significant thing for The London Times to publish, as it did yesterday morning, a carefully prepared statement by one of its correspondents in this country giving the encouraging facts regarding American railways. These railways furnish the bulk of all the American securities dealt in in London.

It is generally agreed that the Summer vacation season is over on Sept. 1. Those who have been away in the mountains or at the seaside trying to recruit their depleted physical forces come trooping into the city and settle down for another long stretch of hard work. The children prepare for school and there is a general furbishing up of faculties which have been permitted to lie fallow during the warm weather.

The programme at Sheepshead Bay to-day is a promising one, and if there are no scratches to mar the Flight Stakes, and especially if Hamburg is one of the starters, visitors should be well repaid for a visit to the track. They will have an opportunity of seeing the acknowledged champion two-year-old of the year, John E. Madden's Hamburg, compete with older horses at a distance of seven furlongs.

John C. Sheehan, Chief of Tammany, arrived home from his Saratoga trip yesterday and spent part of the day at Tammany Hall. He said his recent trip had nothing to do with politics, and he refused to talk for publication about the political events that have happened during the last few days.

At their meeting yesterday morning the Aldermen slightly revised the rules of the road ordinance at the suggestion of Mayor Strong. After their session the Mayor assured Louis Rosenfeld, who was present on behalf of the wheelmen, that he would sign the amended ordinance to-day. As soon as he does the rules will become operative.

With little or no ceremony, Sergt. George W. McClusky stepped into the rank of Acting Captain yesterday and assumed charge of the Detective Bureau at Police Headquarters. His promotion and appointment were announced on Monday evening at the same time that the transfer of Acting Inspector O'Brien to the command of the Leonard Street Precinct was posted.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- The Post will to-morrow print an interview with Gov. Charles T. O'Ferrall of Virginia, who last Fall declined to support the nominees and platform of the Chicago Convention, and who is the recognized head of the Gold Democrats of Virginia. Gov. O'Ferrall announces his determination not to support, under present conditions, the Democratic State ticket recently nominated at the Roanoke Convention, and gives his reasons for reaching this decision.

Another concession from the Southern Pacific Company in favor of merchants living in Texas who are members of the Merchants' Association was reported at the headquarters of the association yesterday. At first it was proposed that the Atlantic system of the Southern Pacific Company should sell tickets from all points in Texas reached by the lines of that system to St. Louis between the dates of Aug. 27 and Aug. 31, inclusive.

NEWPORT, Aug. 31. -- The second round in the thirty-footer race with pair starts was sailed to-day, the winners being the Vaquero III, and the Dorothy II. The starts were made at 11 and 11:05 o'clock, the pairs being the Vaquero III. and the Carolina and the Dorothy II, and the Musme.

MATAWAN, N.J., Aug. 31. -- The citizens of this place are indignant over the fact that a large schoolhouse is being moved through the main avenue of the town and is seriously interfering with traffic. An injunction was issued by Vice Chancellor Emory of Newark and served to-day upon Foreman Matthews, who has charge of the job, with the result that the building now stands in the centre of Main Street, shutting off traffic.

When the Executive Committee of the Citizens' Union separated yesterday afternoon after a two hours' session in their assembly room, 32 Liberty Street, the members expressed confidence that Seth Low would be formally nominated this afternoon as the Citizens' Union candidate for Mayor.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- Senator Lindsay pronounces the action of the Democrats of Pennsylvania in voting to expel W.F. Harrity from the National Democratic Committee absolutely absurd and void.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31. -- The first letter mail to be dispatched from this country to the Klondike region under the new reciprocal arrangement with Canada, effected by establishing an international exchange between Dyea, Alaska, and Dawson City, will be forwarded from Seattle by a steamer leaving there Sept. 11.

A pathetic scene was witnessed in the office of United States Commissioner Linsley Rowe at Jersey City yesterday morning. George B. Richter, pastry cook of the Hamburg-American steamer Columbia, was arrested on July 4 for smuggling fifty pounds of phenacetine. He was bailed in $300, his brother, George Richter of 34 West Ninety-ninth Street, this city, becoming his security by depositing his bankbook, representing $300, and an order for the money.

Police Capt. Lees of the Stagg Street Station, Williamsburg, thought for awhile yesterday that he had in custody a man who could throw light on the murder of George Stelz, the assistant sexton of the Church of the Most Holy Trinity, in Montrose Avenue. The prisoner was John Efflein, an innocent-looking German, who was arrested early in the morning near a restaurant not far from his house, at 205 Moore Street.

Douglas Robinson Co. have sold for McCafferty Buckley the five-story American basement dwelling. 6 East Seventy-seventh Street, 25 by 102.2. The buyer's name could not be learned, but it was said that the price was something over $100.000. Benjamin Knower purchased 2 East Seventy-seventh Street, a similar dwelling, through the same brokers about two weeks ago.

A woman whose real name is Julia McGrew, but who has been long known as Julia S. Campbell, fired a shot from a forty-four calibre revolver in the office of George B. Moore, a real estate agent, 26 East Forty-second Street, at 9 o'clock yesterday morning. Whether she intended to kill Moore is not known.

SEA GIRT, R.J., Aug. 31. -- But for a strong north wind, which blew directly across the rifle range, to-day would have been an ideal one for the matches being held here under the auspices of the New Jersey Rifle Association. Nearly all of the teams entered in the matches have arrived.

BOMBAY, Aug. 31. -- Great relief is felt in official circles here at the news that the tribesmen who yesterday blocked the Kohat Pass have been dispersed. Col. Gordon's column of troops proceeded toward Kohat from Peshawur this morning.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 1. -- The second day's play in the golf tournament on the Newport links brought out many spectators, and some good golf was witnessed. The result of the day's play was as follows:

The Clevelands lost another game to the Brooklyns at Eastern Park yesterday afternoon mainly through their inability to solve Kennedy's curves. The latter was never in better form and allowed the visitors only two base hits. Both teams fielded in brilliant style. Score:

HONOLULU, Hawaii, Aug. 24. -- Francis M. Hatch, Minister to Washington, arrived Aug. 20, with special information which will require the attention of both Government and Senate, and a secret notice has already been issued to the members of the latter body calling upon them to meet in extra session Sept. 6 to consider the question. Meanwhile Minister Hatch is in almost constant consultation with President Dole and his Cabinet.
PARIS, Sept. 1. -- President Faure, referring to his visit to Russia, is quoted as saying that everything passed off wonderfully well, and that one could not dream of anything better.

LARCHMONT, Sept. 1. -- The funeral arrangements for the burial of Mrs. John Drew have not yet been made. The body still rests in the vestry of St. John's Church, where it was taken last night. The arrangements are under the direction of the sexton of St. Mark's Church, New York City. John Drew will arrive from the West to-morrow.

LOUISA DREW, who died Aug. 31, in her seventy-eighth year, had been before the world as an actress nearly seventy years, for she was barely eight years old when she took a small part at Liverpool in a performance of "Timour the Tartar," and she never formally retired from the stage.

Boston perhaps will congratulate herself that she is recovering lost ground now that one of the largest publishing houses, heretofore a stranger to her, has opened an office in that city. The house is the Macmillan Company of New York.
About 100 members of the Lincoln Club held a short, but stormy meeting last night at 56 Clinton Place, the headquarters of the club. Postmaster Cornelius Van Cott presided.
GALVESTON, Texas, Sept. 1. -- The annual trade review of the Galveston News for September places the Texas cotton crop for the scason of 1896-7 at 2,177,025 bales.

Douglas Robinson Co. have sold for Frederick D. Tappen and others trustees of the Ellen E. Ward estate, to Thomas H. Barber, for about $50,000 cash, the four-story brownstone-front dwelling 45 East Sixty-eighth Street, 25 by 102.2.

The new lien law passed by the last Legislature went into effect yesterday. In general, it is a codification of the various lien laws which have been on the statute books, but there are changes here and there which have attracted considerable attention.

NORTHEAST HARBOR, Me., Sept. 1. --Seth Low, the Citizens' Union candidate for Mayor of Greater New York, was seen to-night at his cottage at Northeast Harbor. He had of course heard the news of his nomination unofficially, but would reply to no questions asked him as to his decision to accept or decline the nomination.
NORTHPORT, L.I., Sept. 1. -- Hope of an enduring boom for Northport has given place to an enduring gloom and an atmosphere of suspicion, and a tendency to inebriety prevails.

A decision rendered yesterday by Civil Justice Stiner in the Eighth District Court practically terminates the lease of the present tenants of the Casino, Canary Lederer, which was to run until 1900, and restores possession of the property to the Aronson people, the Casino Company, who were ejected from it over two years ago.
CONSTANTINOPLE, Sept. 1. -- The following official statement regarding the reported disturbances near Van, Armenia, was issued to-day:

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1. -- Since the arrival here from Paris last Monday of Dr. Thomas W. Evans, the dentist, with the body of his wife, an old rumor, although a rather interesting one, has again been current.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- The Inter-State Commerce Commission to-day in an opinion by Chairman Morrison has "recommended'" reductions of freight rates to Eureka Springs, Mo., over the Eureka Springs and St. Louis and San Francisco Railways.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1. -- James Wilson, Secretary of Agriculture, has returned from a trip through the Western States, where he has been investigating the system of irrigation in Western Nebraska, Colorado, Wyoming, Utah, part of Idaho, Montana, and North Dakota, and the result of his observations will be fraught with interest to Western agriculturists.

Seth Low was yesterday nominated for Mayor of the Greater New York by the Citizens' Union of the Boroughs of Manhattan, the Bronx, Queens, and Richmond. The representatives of the Borough of Brooklyn did not participate in the nomination.

SEA GIRT, N.J., Sept. 1. -- The big matches of the New Jersey Rifle Association opened this morning in the presence of a large number of visitors. As usual, the Georgia boys came in for the largest share of applause, but when the gray uniforms of the Seventh of New York were seen across the field the applause was deafening.
It seems that Seth Low meant his candidacy to be a unifying force against partisan City Government. It might be just as well to look a little closer into this question.

As a result of the lively trade spirit aroused throughout the South, chiefly by the work of the Merchants' Association of New York, the Ocean Steamship Company announced yesterday that it had arranged to sell excursion tickets to the North from all points in Georgia and Alabama. These tickets will be sold from Sept. 1 to 4, and from Sept. 10 to 14, each ticket being good for return within thirty days.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 1. -- The corporation of Brown University voted to-day after a long meeting to request President Andrews that he withdraw his resignation as President of the institution. The request was embodied in a resolution containing the following letter:

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 1. -- In the person of Sir Harry Westwood Cooper, M. D., now confined in the city prison, Chief of Police Lees believes that he has behind the bars one of the most notorious bank swindlers who ever operated in this or any other country, despite the fact he is under thirty years of age.

When Greater New York absorbs Richmond County it will acquire Daniel Dempsey, his multifarious occupations, his boom for Sheriff, his resemblance to Grover Cleveland, and his aspirations for the Presidency.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- The second report of Attorney Calderon Carlisle of this city, the legal adviser of the Spanish Government in this city, to Senor Dupuy De Lome, the Spanish Minister, on the subject of the Cuban question in this country, with particular reference to filibustering expeditions, was made public to-day.

The Citizens' Union has now demonstrated that its independence is not a transitory phase of existence, but a permanent estate. It has escaped the fate that usually befalls citizens' reform movements. Their common destiny is to be swallowed up by one of the political parties.

MONTREAL, Sept. 1. -- The regular work of the British Medical Association began this morning when the sections opened. The section in medicine had for its President Dr. Stephen Mackenzie of London, England. Among the American guests contributing papers to-day were Dr. Henry M. Lyman of Chicago, Dr. J.M. Fussell, Dr. John H. Musser, and Dr. James M. Tyson of Philadelphia.
LONDON, Sept. 1. -- The following notice was posted in the Bank of England to-day:

It gives me some pain to see in your causerie of Monday, your "Topics of the Times," that your inquiry as to what to feed a little dog has been uncomprehended. My eldest son, a small dog who has a good heart, implores me to send you these verses expressive of his sentiments and those of other small dogs of good race.

George Davis was the hero in yesterday's game between the New Yorks and the Cincinnatis at the Polo Grounds. It was his timely base hit which won a victory for the Giants, when defeat seemed almost inevitable, and sent about 5,000 persons to supper with visions of Temple Cup games being played at the Polo Grounds.

In the absence of Commissioner Parker, who did not arrive until the regular meeting had been in session more than half an hour yesterday, the Police Commissioners adopted a resolution to amend the civil service rules of the department, which are now awaiting the approval of the State Board.

LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 1. -- The triparty alliance of the Nebraska free-silver forces was given good headway to-day by three large conventions held, respectively, by the Democrats, Populists, and Free Silver Republicans.

Hamburg, the crack two-year-old of the year, had his colors lowered in the Flight Stakes at Sheepshead Bay yesterday, but there was no stigma attached to the defeat, for he was beaten by Requital, who is two years his senior. The two-year-old gave away tons of weight to everything in the race, when weight for age is considered.

CARLSTADT, N.J., Sept. 1. -- As Conductor James Blauvelt's train on the New Jersey and New York Railroad was on its way from Jersey City last night, and when near this place, the passengers in the forward cars were suddenly startled by a jolting which clearly indicated that the train had run over something on the track.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 1. -- Application was made to-day to Controller Roberts by David Wilcox and Attorney Conkling, representing the New York Central and Erie Railroad Companies, for a reduction of the amount of corporate tax levied on those roads by the Controller.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 1. -- Candidates for the Naval Academy reported to-day to the number of 85. This is within seven of the number who, according to the information of the Secretary of the academy, have received appointments entitling them to try the present examinations.

LYNBROOK, L.I., Sept. 1. -- The country village is traditionally the hatching place of genius in which greatness incubates until it suddenly bursts forth to brighten and dazzle the world and roost upon the towering pinnacle of the Temple of Fame. William Turner of Lynbrook is not unknown to the world.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 1. -- A letter has been published here from Charles Haines, dated Dawson City, July 26. Mr. Haines is a well-known newspaper writer, and his letter is the first written by a trained newspaper man to come out of the Klondike gold regions. He says:

At a meeting of the New York City Consulate of the League of American Wheelmen, held last evening at the Oriental Hotel, Fifty-eighth Street and Eighth Avenue, it was proposed that the League of American Wheelmen members of this city demonstrate their strength by a cycle parade confined exclusively to their ranks and devoid entirely of advertising or similar features.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1. -- The interest in the Luetgert murder trial was unabated to-day. Attorney Vincent began the cross-examination of Bialk, and put to him questions regarding his connection with the police since May 16. Bialk testified that since May 16 he had been with Officer Klinger, living at the latter's house and paying no board.

It has been my good fortune to stumble across a document of rare value, which is in the keeping of a family of the Belgian nobility at Antwerp. The document in question describes the first loan ever contracted by the United States of America, and is signed by George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, and the statistics certified to by Alexander Hamilton.

SPRING VALLEY, Ill., Sept. 1. -- The Spring Valley schools opened to-day guarded by the entire city police. The wielders of clubs patroled the school yards, while crowds on the outside peered at them through the fence pickets.

The attempt of the Pennsylvania Democratic Convention to oust Mr. HARRITY from the National Committee was an act of mere senseless spite. Neither the convention nor the State Committee, whose action it indorsed, has any authority in the premises. Mr. HARRITY will remain, by party usage, a member of the National Committee unless the committee itself shall expel him.

The Republican leaders of Brooklyn, including Jacob Worth and Sheriff Buttling, it was learned last night, held a secret meeting yesterday and decided to call the Kings County Convention about Sept. 21, or within seven or eight days of the City Convention. So far as could be learned, the move is one of the shrewdest that the Worth and Buttling combination has sprung in a long time.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 1. -- The thirty-footers raced to-day in a southwest wind for the cup offered by Mrs. H.B. Duryea, which was won by the Esperanza. There were nine boats to start, the Vaquero not entering. The start was at 3 o'clock, the Veda leading, but the Hera soon took the lead and turned the mark at Dyer's Island first, but in the windward work the Esperanza outfooted her.

Attorney General McKENNA may have been vexed, during his experience as a United States Judge, with knotty problems, but it is difficult to imagine him applying his legal knowledge to the interpretation of a more troublesome proposition than that of the Secretary of the Treasury, that he shall clearly decide what was the intent of Congress in adopting Section 22 of the Dingley tariff.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1. -- The President has awarded the following medals of honor:

Trading in wheat on the Produce Exchange yesterday was on substantial foreign orders and still more satisfactory news that there was abundant inquiry of lots for export. Information was also received of the engagement of 32,000 bushels for shipment to Argentina. The export business here was 240,000 bushels of wheat, 100,000 bushels of corn, and 35,000 bushels of oats.
TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 1. -- The tax grievances yet to be heard will occupy the time of the Greenburgh Assessors until Tuesday.
TROY, Sept. 2. -- Gov. and Mrs. Frank S. Black, accompanied by their son Arthur, left Troy this morning for a ten-days' visit to the Governor's former home in Maine.

The Citizens' Union is teaching the people of New York as they were never taught before that the Government is theirs, and that it does not belong to any organization of politicians of either party. This teaching is done in a great variety of ways, but especially in bringing to the knowledge of the people the details of each branch of the city affairs as directly or indirectly affecting them.

Prince Luigi of Savoy, much sunburned and still aglow with enthusiasm over his recently accomplished feat of climbing Mount St. Elias, the most formidable of the Alaska range of mountains, arrived in this city yesterday. He was accompanied by his aide de camp. Lieut. Cogni of the Royal Italian Navy, who was with him when he made the ascent.

Sixteen detectives, who for some time past have been attached to the Chief's office at Police Headquarters, were yesterday sent back to precinct duty by Acting Chief McCullagh. The men and their new stations are as follows:

SEATTLE, Washington, Sept. 2. -- The steamer Farrallon arrived at 1:30 this morning from Skaguay, having left there Aug. 26. The Farrallon brings confirmation of the reports that the trail has been almost impassable on account of rain and mud. A letter on the Farrallon says that one day last week 100 men sold their outfits at a sacrifice and started back.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 2. -- Premier Laurier reached Ottawa last evening, and a magnificent reception was given to him, 20,000 persons turning out to greet him. Addresses of welcome were read to Sir Wilfred on Parliament Hill. The Premier left for his country home to-day for a rest.

CORTLAND, N.Y., Sept. 2. -- Train No. 4, the south-bound vestibule train on the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad, was wrecked at Blodgett's Mills at 10:15 o'clock this morning. The train consisted of an express car, a combination baggage and smoking car, a day coach, and a Pullman parlor car.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 2. -- Col. W.P. Rend to-day met his thousand miners through a committee of twelve men selected for the purpose at McDonald, Penn. There was an immense gathering of miners and their wives and children about the place of conference.

The ticket scalpers have begun their fight against the law which went into effect on the 1st of this month forbidding the sale of passenger tickets except by the authorized agents of the railway train or vessel which is to furnish the transportation. Pending a decision on the constitutionality of the law by the courts the scalpers will practically suspend business.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2. -- Wheat to-day added 1 5/8c to the value of September, and 1 1/8c to the December delivery. The market was strongly influenced by the sharp advances in foreign markets, and both of the prominent futures sold well above 96c for a time. The other markets were strong early, but yielded later in the session, and wound up with declines of 3/5c in corn and 1/4c in oats.

NIAGARA-ON-THE-LAKE, Sept. 2. -- The final surprise occurred in the tennis tournament, this morning, when M.D. Whitman of Harvard was beaten by W.S. Bond, three sets to two. Bond's constant running to the net puzzled Whitman.

ALBANY, Sept. 2. -- A hearing was given by the State Railroad Commission to-day on the application of the New York and Ottawa Railroad Company for permission to construct a railroad from Moira, Franklin County, to a point on the St. Lawrence River eighteen miles distant.
It is not easy to explain the nomination of HENRY DEMAS as Naval Officer in New Orleans on any theory creditable to the Administration.

FREMONT, Ohio, Sept. 2. -- The reunion of the survivors of the Twenty-third Regiment of Ohio Volunteers, infantry, was held here to-day. President McKinley, who was a member of this regiment, and many other distinguished survivors, were in attendance. The city was in gay attire last night for the wedding of Ensign Smith and Miss Hayes, at which the President and other distinguished visitors were guests.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2 -- It was definitely announced at his trial to-day that Luetgert will be a witness in his own defense. The big sausage maker said the matter had been discussed between his attorneys and himself, and when the time comes he will take the witness stand and tell the jury about his actions on the night of May 1.

DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 2. -- Little Jimmy Michael, the Welsh cycling wonder, set a new mark for the hour record at the Detroit cycle track this evening. The weather was fine, and the track fast. Michael was paced by a sextet, two quads, and a triplet, seventeen pacemakers taking part. The Welshman tired out all of his pacemakers, and was fresh at the close.

Franklin Bien, who was appointed receiver of the Casino Company through the influence of Rudolph Aronson when the latter was ejected from the Casino two years ago, denied yesterday that the decision rendered by Justice Stiner in the Eighth District Court would have the effect of terminating the Casino litigation or would restore the property to Mr. Aronson and the Casino Company, of which Henry B. Sire is the principal stockholder.

State Senator Joseph Mullin was found dead in his bedroom at the University Club yesterday morning by the servant who went to awaken him. He retired about 1:15 A.M. He was known as an early riser, and when he was not seen at breakfast a servant was sent at 10:50 o'clock to learn the cause of his tardiness.
MONTREAL, Sept. 2. -- In two days over 150 papers have been read to specialists before the delegates attending the different sectional meetings of the British Medical Association.

BOSTON, Sept. 2. -- The Dominion Line steamer Canada, from Liverpool, which arrived at this port to-day, brought a large number of passengers, among whom was Gen. Charle's J. Paine, who, with United States Senator Wolcott of Colorado and ex-Vice President Adlai E. Stevenson, formed the Monetary Commission appointed by the President to visit Europe in the interest of bimetallism.

-- Customs officials are naturally a suspicious lot, but, it was hardly necessary for them to doubt the word of those glove importers who say that a certain consignment of No. 8's is for the use of Western women and not for that of Eastern men. How do the Appraisers know that it is not a habit out West for society leaders to put both hands in the same glove?

Republican leaders in conference yesterday confirmed the report that they intend to nominate a straight party ticket. They are looking to Mayor William L. Strong to lead them. They believe he would secure the full machine and a large independent support, and are asking his friends to urge him to accept the nomination.

Mayor Strong signed the rules of the road ordinance yesterday, and the rules became operative an hour after noon. They probably will not be strictly inforced until the public has had a reasonable time to become informed on the substance of the ordinance. Wheelmen from all parts of the country have evinced great interest in the code, since the League of American Wheelmen Consuls first submitted their draft to the Aldermen's Law Committee for consideration.

Strikes in another branch of the clothing trade were announced yesterday. About 4,500 waistcoat makers have gone out on strike for an advance in wages and a reduction of the hours of labor. There are about 7,000 persons employed in making waistcoats in New York, Brooklyn, and Brownsville, and about half of them are girls.

SHAKOPEE, Minn., Sept. 2. -- One morning seven years ago the entire Minnesota Valley was horrified by the news of a murder in this quiet little city the night before. Mr. and Mrs. Spierman, an aged couple, occupying, with their little grandson, one of the stone houses built during the period of Indian troubles back of the town and on the Minnesota River bluffs, were all found dead, each one shot in head and body.
The Tribune's advice to its party is sound and sensible:

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 2. -- The National Race Council, which was called by several prominent negroes for the consideration of matters of interest, met yesterday at St. John's Church. There were present members from Florida, Alabama, Texas, Arkansas, Massachusetts, and other States. The conference elected Prof. Counsill of Alabama Temporary Chairman and George T. Robinson of Tennessee Secretary.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2. -- At the Port of New York the collections on the docks on baggage of incoming passengers for the month of August, 1897, amounted to $46,892, while for the same month in 1896 they amounted to only $15,081, showing an increase under the new law of $31,811.

Herman Otten, a Swedish sailor, eighteen years old, living at 138 Lincoln Place, Astoria, jumped from the Brooklyn Bridge yesterday. He was picked up alive a few moments after striking the water, and, according to the physicians of the Hudson Street Hospital, where he was taken, has a good chance for his life. .

The letters which were sent to Seth Low at Northeast Harbor, Me., notifying him of his nomination for Mayor by the Citizens' Union, and which were carried to Mr. Low by Secretary John C. Clark of the Citizens' Union, were given out for publication last night, after a long session of the Union's Executive Committee at the headquarters, 39 East Twenty-third Street.

NIAGARA-ON-THE-LAKE, Ont., Sept. 2. -- The international golf tournament began here this morning, with a large attendance of players. The first event was the open handicap, in which there were thirty-four entries. The scratch men, S.O. Powers of Oswego and A.P. Scott of Toronto, did not play, while D. Servos of Niagara, a very brilliant young player, entered and went around the links, for which the best score was 90, in 86.

HAVANA, Sept. 2. -- It was officially announced to-day that a force of 200 Spanish infantry, commanded by Capt. Cesario Ponton, surprised, at sunrise yesterday, an insurgent force which was camped on the Heights of Joro, Province of Pinar del Rio, killing twenty-six of the enemy and wounding several others.

A small comedy of errors developed yesterday in the court of Justice Maes at Jersey City. Charles Singerwald of West Hoboken was arraigned on a charge of assaulting Oliver Simmons, a conductor on a West Hoboken trolley car. It transpired that Singerwald had had a quarrel with Frederick Simmons, also a conductor on the same line.
Under the circumstances it behooves the New York Republicans to continue their part in the great National business on hand with undiminished hope, but with redoubled energy.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2. -- The Taxpayers' Defense League, which has been making a sturdy fight upon tax shirkers, and also against unjust assessments, has addressed an open letter, through its President, Z.S. Holbrook, to George M. Pullman.

Mr. Joseph Walker, one of Wall Street's veterans and head of the Stock Exchange house of Joseph Walker Sons, talked yesterday to a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES regarding stock market prospects. Mr. Walker is a bull and a believer in the coming of generally prosperous times both for the country at large and for Wall Street. Mr. Walker said:

Jacob Worth's policy in calling the County Convention in Kings County a week before the City Convention will doubtless result in one of the stormiest gatherings ever held in Brooklyn, where exciting conventions in past years have been more the rule than the exception. At least, this is what several alert politicians said yesterday, men who are watching the gathering storm with the keenest perceptions.

Owen Cassidy, Dr. F. W. Smith, and Dr. George B. Fowler, the committee appointed by the State Board of Health to inquire into the alleged nuisances at Barren Island, met yesterday in the office of President Wilson of the local Board of Health.
