John W. Phillips, Inspector of Offensive Trades, submitted a report, in which he named the five fertilizing establishments on Barren Island and explained their methods.

Alexander E. Orr, as President of the Rapid Transit Commission, has written to the Park Commissioners in reference to their decision not to approve the plans for the tunnel in Battery Park. Mr. Orr complains not so much of the decision as of the unnecessary delay entailed on the work for rapid transit by the dilatoriness of the Park Department.

Telegrams were sent yesterday to the members of the sub-committee of the Democratic Conference Committee of the Greater New York summoning them to meet at the Hoffman House at 8 o'clock to-night. The General Conference Committee authorized this sub-committee to select the time and place for the Democratic City Convention.

TOPEKA, Kan., Sept. 2. -- Bank Commissioner Briedenthal said to-day: "Kansas is to-day the most prosperous State in the Union. Kansas farmers, will pay off the mortgages on 40,000 homes this Fall. As these mortgages average $1,000 each, this means the expenditure of $40,000,000.

PARIS, Sept. 2. -- The Minister of Commerce, M. Boucher, is quoted in an interview printed by The Gaulois to-day as saying that the Governments of France and Russia are anxious to make every effort compatible with their economic interests to develop commercial intercourse between the two countries.

The comments of men upon their own callings are usually indicative of the fitness of the men for the vocations. Cynical novelists, like our more or less amiable friend Ouida, are fond of telling us that men are enthusiastic about the things in which they succeed, but sounder philosophers in fiction, like THACKERAY, would have told us that men are most likely to be successful in the things about which they are enthusiastic.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 2. -- The miners' officials at 11:20 o'clock this morning, having held a secret conference, adjourned to hold a joint secret conference with a special committee of operators, representing substantially all of the operators of Pittsburg.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 2. -- Fourteen tramps waylaid Henry Dunham and Jacob Zeigler of this place this afternoon on their way home from Metuchen along the railroad tracks. A burly negro thrust a revolver into Zeigler's mouth, near Stelton, and another secured $25 from Dunham.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2. -- The young woman who committed suicide at the Victoria Hotel Monday night by taking poison has been identified as Anna Maria Esseman of Louisville, Ky., by her grandfather, Stephen Diehlman. According to the story of the grandfather, who reached the city from Louisville early this morning, the girl was the daughter of respectable Germans in comfortable circumstances.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 2. -- Joseph Rafferty met with a tragic death a short distance east of the railroad station on the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad last night.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 2. -- The State Executive Committee of the Jeffersonian, or gold, Democrats to-day decided by a vote of 17 to 10 not to place any candidate in the field for State Treasurer and Auditor General. This decision was arrived at after a general conference of the State Committee and a large number of prominent gold Democrats from all parts of the State.

What was originally a most attractive racing programme was spoiled yesterday at Sheepshead Bay by the wholesale scratching in the several events on account of the heavy rainfall of the morning and the consequent softness of the track. When the sun came out it dried the top dressing, but left the going very heavy, so that slow time was made in all of the afternoon's events.

It was again found necessary to use two registers at the headquarters of the Merchants' Association yesterday to dispose of the long lines of out-of-town buyers who desired to have their names enrolled on the association's list of non-residents. The daily arrivals have been increasing steadily in number during the last ten days.

The house 27 Walker Avenue, Jersey City, has been visited by burglars four times during the Summer. On June 3 a butcher's shop on the ground floor, kept by William Horn, was entered, but the thieves secured no money, nor did they disturb the contents of the ice-box.

In the Athenaeum some information is given relating to Trelawny during his stay at Usk, in the County of Monmouth, where he arrived about 1845. There really is little that is prepossessing in Edward John Trelawny's character. He was a type of the egotist, and if he were an unconscious one that makes him none the less responsible. In his marital relationship Trelawny was worse than bad.

Once on a time those three verse makers, Dora Greenwell, Christina Rossetti, and Jean Ingelow, must have had their disputation as to their respective ability with needles. Maybe, as The Athenaeum suggests, when the propriety of darning stockings was considered as one of woman's particular duties, somebody had probably chivvied the writing woman generally and howled at her "Go spin, ye jades; go spin!"

Dr. E.B. Andrews, President of Brown University, came over from Providence Thursday afternoon to confer with John Brisben Walker about plans for the new university, of which the former is to be President. He saw Mr. Walker at the Murray Hill Hotel shortly after his arrival, and saw him again yesterday at Irvington.
The following is the text of the letter of explanation sent by President E.B. Andrews to the Corporation of Brown University, Wednesday:

Twenty years ago Dr. Brocca called attention to the curious fact that trephining was practiced in the Stone Age. The question in dispute is to-day: Did primitive man trephine in a purely surgical sense, so as to relieve human suffering, or did he practice it so as to procure amulets, supposably endowed with magical qualities, or was the operation performed so as to produce epileptics? these epileptics being supposedly endowed with powers of prophecy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3. -- George M. Coffin, Acting Controller of the Currency, is confident of a most prosperous financial season for the United States in the near future. In an interview with a reporter to-day, he said:

The neighborhood of Sixth Avenue and Broadway was excited yesterday morning by the appearance of a bird of prey flapping its broad wings under the shadow of the elevated railroad tracks, just clearing the tops of the street cars. The largest and only birds usually seen around there are English sparrows, and in less than half a minute a mob was following the new comer.

Whatever report may be made by the board of naval officers appointed by Secretary LONG to consider plans for an armor plate Plant it is to the last degree improbable that the Government will engage in that business.

The New Yorks lost the first game as easily as they won the second at the Polo Grounds yesterday. The Cincinnati's victory in the first contest was the first that the team has won since their Eastern trip began, and they were so elated that they did not seem to care whether the second game was won or lost.

LONDON, Sept. 3. -- The British steamer Windward, having on board the Jackson-Harmsworth expedition, which has spent three Winters near Cape Flora, Franz Josef Land, arrived here to-day from Franz Josef Land, with F.G. Jackson and his colleagues. All the members of the expedition are in good health. They report having explored Franz Josef Land thoroughly with the exception of some odd corners.

Mr. Low's statement to the public on accepting the nomination of the Citizens' Union clearly and definitely describes his position. It is an honorable one, consistent with his career, faithful to the aims he professes, which are those of the Union, and fitting the demands of the time and the situation.

LEWISTON, Me., Sept. 3. -- According to The Lewiston Evening Journal, Nelson Dingley's paper, the originators of Section 22 of the tariff law did not intend it to affect the bonding privilege under which foreign merchandise can be forwarded through Canada. The Journal editorially says:

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 3. -- Extraordinary precautions to-day were taken to take care of the President on account of the Mayor having received an unsigned note telling him to be on guard against a proposed assassination of Mr. McKinley because of the appointment of Mr. Powderly.

NORTHEAST HARBOR, Me., Sept. 3. -- President Seth Low of Columbia University to-day accepted the nomination of the Citizens' Union as candidate for Mayor of the Greater New York. He was officially notified of his nomination at his cottage here by J.C. Clark, a special messenger of the Citizens' Union, just before 11 o'clock.

FLORAL PARK, L.I., Sept. 3. -- Passenger train No. 10. city-bound, and carrying a light load, stopped here as usual early this morning. At this point a branch track connects with the main track by means of a long curve. Passengers were still getting on board, when a gravel train of eight loaded cars came around the curve and a head-on collision resulted.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3. -- H. Russell Ward, the Englishman who created a sensation a short time ago by eloping with the wife of Millionaire John Bradbury of Los Angeles, Cal., committed suicide early this morning by throwing himself from a Chicago Northwestern Railway train. The fact was not known until hours later, and as the result of a search which was immediately begun the body of Ward was found at Wheatlands, Iowa.

Shortly before noon yesterday a big, black-hulled, two-masted coast-line steamship backed into her moorings by the Ocean Steamship Company's dock at the foot of Canal Street, in the North River, and showed to the gaping onlookers a huge sheet of canvas loosely hung before a jagged hole in her starboard side some fifty feet abaft the engine room.

STOCKHOLM, Aug. 10. -- The Exhibition of Arts and Industries at Stockholm has many features common to all such affairs; every new enterprise of the sort attempts to present some novelty or other; so, by the time the century has quite spun itself out, Paris will be put to her trumps to offer a spoiled world au grand fin de siecle, anything that is really fresh and hitherto unseen. What can Stockholm offer meanwhile?

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3. -- It is already apparent that a determined effort will be made in the next Congress to repeal the civil service law. The House of Representatives will be the battleground, as the Senate stands ready to promptly pass a repeal bill. The association known as the Anti-Civil Service League, recently organized in Washington, is receiving support at the hands of influential members of Congress.
DENVER, Sept. 3. -- The Republican State Convention to-day renominated Charles D. Hart for Justice of the Supreme Court. He is a Silver Republican. The platform contains the following:

LONDON, Sept. 4. -- The Berlin correspondent of The Times says The Zukunft publishes what is undoubtedly an authentic interview with Prince Bismarck, probably obtained by Count Limburg-Stirum, who recently visited the ex-Chancellor on behalf of the Conservative Party. Prince Bismarck expressed himself as very skeptical regarding the alleged Franco-Russian alliance, and declared that the Czar's toast really committed Russia to very little.

Nearly 3,000 out-of-town merchants have thus far visited the headquarters of the Merchants' Association and inscribed their names on the big registers. These 3,000 signatures represent persons who have actually come to New York, at the instigation of the Merchants' Association, to buy goods.

Deputy Sheriff Whoriskey has received an attachment against S. Schuldenfrei Co., manufacturers of women's silk waists and skirts at 107 Greene Street, from Myers, Goldsmith Bronner for $609 in favor of the H.B. Claflin Company for goods sold to the firm in March last. The attachment was obtained on the ground that the Messrs. Schuldenfrei have departed from the State.

According to The Pall Mall Gazette, a number of letters having to do with the editorship and management of Household Words and All the Year Round have come to light. Charles Dickens's factotum was Mr. W.H. Wills, and through him came instructions to contributors from "the Chief."

Several important additions have been made to the New York Public Library during the Summer months, but by far the most interesting and valuable is a collection of books, pamphlets, autograph letters, prints, caricatures, and other material relating to John Law and the South Sea Bubble.

Hall J. How Co. have sold for the estate of Edward J. King, to Jared W. Bell, four lots, southwest corner of Seventh Avenue and One Hundred and Twelfth Street. 109 by 100, and have resold the plot for Mr. Bell to a builder for improvement.

A number of interesting golf matches will be played on local links to-day, but most of the clubs are holding off their tournaments for Labor Day, which promises to be one of the biggest golfing days that have ever been seen in the vicinity of New York. Practically every club has something on hand, and thousands of players will be out on the links.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 3. -- Thomas Cunningham, Superintendent of the Birmingham (Ala.) Rolling Mill, arrived in Pittsburg to-night seeking to employ several hundred ironworkers. The Birmingham Mill, he says, has been closed one year, owing to trade conditions, and their former employes have scattered over the country.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 3. -- Mr. and Mrs. Louis J. Tallinger rode on their bicycles to visit Mrs. Tallinger's mother, at Croton, N.Y., last Saturday, accompanied by Mrs. Tallinger's brother. They started out on Wednesday on the return trip. They had made part of the distance, and were riding fast out of Moravia, when Mrs. Tallinger suddenly cried out, and lifted her hands to her head.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 3. -- The end of the great miners' strike is in sight. This afternoon the National Executive Board of the United Mine Workers agreed to recommend to the miners a proposition from the Pittsburg operators for a straight price of 65 cents a ton, to continue in force until the end of the year.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 3. -- The champions won as they pleased to-day, batting Donahue out of the box and hitting Coleman at will. The heavy batting was the sole feature.

Several members of the Jersey City Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals were victimized by a grim sort of joke on Thursday night. George M. McCarthy, President of the society, who in his leisure moments is a theatrical advertising agent, was the prime mover in the affair. He called at the society's office and told Agent Arthur McDonald that Alonzo Calhoun, another agent, was dead.

As a result of the recent arrest of one of the employes of Nathan Straus's milk depot, at the Hebrew Institute, in East Broadway, by the Board of Health Inspectors, on the charge of selling milk below the required standard, Mr. Straus yesterday decided to step the sale of raw milk. Five booths in the different parks were removed yesterday, and the remaining one, in the City Hall Park, will be taken away this morning.

Considerable interest is evinced in theatrical circles as to the result of Franklin Bien's appeal from Judge Stiner's decision, and his efforts to get possession of the Casino for himself. The entire bonds of the Casino Company are controlled by Henry B. Sire and J.V. Jordan, who, it is said, may agree to some terms regarding the lease.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3. -- It is semiofficially stated that the question of appealing from the decree of the United States Circuit Court at Omaha for the sale of the Union Pacific, which the Attorney General has under consideration, is not predicated upon a desire of the Government to increase the upset price.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3. -- John G. Brady, Governor of Alaska, has sent to Secretary Bliss a personal letter, in which he gives some interesting facts about the rush for the Klondike region. Gov. Brady has been identified with Alaskan interests most of his lifetime, and is known to be very conservative in his opinions. Writing from Juneau, he says:

The Saturday Review of Books and Art has had articles of interest concerning book clubs for some weeks. Will you give space to an account of the one which was the parent of the Yonkers Club, of the first book club started in Albany, and of many others in all parts of the Union?

Peter and William Jessup, tinsmiths, were engaged a few days ago to do a small amount of work in the plant of the Edison Electric Illuminating Company at 115 West Twelfth Street. The brothers were single and lived, it was said, at 114 East One Hundred and Seventeenth Street.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3. -- "I have been frozen out of the Presbyterian Church and starved out of the People's Church, all in one year, and I am through with preaching," said the Rev. Frank B. Vrooman, co-pastor of the People's Church. "I am going to the Klondike."

The Democratic City Convention to nominate candidates for Mayor, Controller, and President of the Council of Greater New York will be held in this city Thursday, Sept. 30. This was decided at the meeting of the sub-committee of the Democratic Conference Committee of Greater New York, which was held last night in the Moorish Room of the Hoffman House.

MONTREAL, Sept. 3. -- The meetings of the different sections of the British Medical Association were continued to-day. In the section in Public Health, Dr. Montizambert, Superintendent of the Canadian Quarantine Stations, read a long paper covering the whole subject of maritime and inland quarantines. Among other things, he said that the general considerations of infectious diseases in connection with the subject of this discussion divides itself naturally under two heads:

Six-year-old Charles Binner, who lives with his parents at 307 East One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, had a miraculous escape from injury by a cable car last evening. The child, with others of his age, was playing in the street near his home about dusk, and had started to run across the street just as Cable Car No. 477, eastbound, came along at a rapid rate.

Bishop J.J. Clancy of Sligo, Ireland, will be in New York City next week. He is the youngest member of the Irish Episcopate, a graduate of Maynooth College. He was appointed Coadjutor to Bishop Gilhooly, and on the latter's death succeeded to the see of Elphin. Many of his schoolmates and fellows came to New York, and are well known here.

A flurry in Electro-Pneumatic Transit stock yesterday morning caused almost a panic among the "curb-stone" brokers in Wall Street. It was precipitated by a publication to the effect that the charter of the company, which is a New Jersey corporation, had been declared void, and that the Transit Company has no legal existence.

-- How is it that in Northern Siberia and most other arctic countries practically all traveling is done after Winter begins, while in the Yukon region all activities must cease with early Fall, to be resumed only when Summer is well advanced? There, as elsewhere, one might suppose that the snow Would make it easy to traverse the rocky or swampy ground with comparative ease, but such does not seem to be the case.

PARIS, Aug. 15. -- For the past decade managers, authors, and critics in France alike have been wringing their hands over what they call the krach of the drama. Its causes have been variously defined. The manager has attributed the decline in his receipts to the custom which prevails on so large a scale of distributing free tickets right and left, and to the ever-increasing popularity of the music halls.

It seems pretty certain that the Hon. David J. Brewer, Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court, will be chosen successor to the Rev. Dr. Richard S. Storrs of Brooklyn as President of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions at the annual meeting of the board at New Haven in October.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3. -- The French Ambassador, M. Patenotre, called on Secretary Sherman to-day relative to the proposed reciprocity treaty between the United States and France. The subject was discussed in a general way, but owing to the importance of the questions involved, it is not expected that final results will be reached until the return of the President, who takes a personal interest in reciprocity negotiations.

Dr. Herzl does not profess to be a religious Jew. With most of his followers he maintains only to he a Jew by nationality or race. He has not the least intention to benefit Judaism. He is a politician, loyal and patriotic, no doubt, as so many politicians profess to be, and works to set up a Judenstadt, not a religious congregation at all. Religion is at present out of the question altogether.

The Middle States Regatta, which will be held to-morrow on the Harlem River, promises to be one of the most interesting events of the reason in rowing circles, as it will bring together an uncommonly large number of crack amateur oarsmen who have not previously met. Several New York crews have been training for this regatta ever since the season opened, and as a consequence some close finishes and broken, records are looked for.

DUNELLEN, N.J., Sept. 4. -- The special election for members of the Lincoln Common Council this afternoon resulted in the election of Miss Mattie Moire and T.W. Sheldon. Thirty-five women and thirty-two men voted. Sheldon received 67, Miss Moire 47, and the third candidate, Mrs. Catherine Meyers 20.

Almost any bee which we may catch at random upon a milkweed gives perfect evidence of his surroundings, its toes being decorated with the tiny yellow tags, each successive flower giving and taking, exchanging compliments, as it were, with his fellows. Ordinarily this fringe can hardly prove more than an embarrassment; but we may frequently discern an individual here and there which for some reason has received more than his share of the milkweed's compliments.
There was a good deal of cricket played in the vicinity of this city yesterday, the knights of the wollow getting in all possible practice before the big English game next week.

Then, when the blood was apt to boil through one's veins, and the dogs were supposed to go mad, were the halcyon and vociferous days of the impotent but declamatory hero, the heroine of the unfilleted and wind-blown locks, and the villain who could never swim.

The Richmond County Wheelmen held their first bicycle race meet on the old Staten Island Athletic Club track, West Brighton, yesterday. The meet had an L. A.W. sanction, but the majority of the entries were Staten Island cyclers. In spite of a slow track the races were well contested, and there were some hot finishes.

GREENLAWN, L.I., Sept. 3. -- The medical profession of the country will probably suffer seriously this Winter from diminution in the demand for night visits resulting from a shortage in dyspepsia and temporary, but enthusiastic, internal disturbances. The salting vats of this section where most of the cucumbers for the New York market are pickled are nearly empty, it is alleged, in consequence of the perfidy of the farmers.

LONDON, Sept. 4. -- Public attention still centres in the dual alliance, though it has been interrupted by the shoutings of Emperor William of Germany. England remains apathetic, in spite of the fact that the centre of gravity in European affairs has been shifted to St. Petersburg. Commenting upon the political situation, The Spectator remarks:

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 4. -- Amateur theatricals were among the chief attractions of the week, and a number of young people gave an interesting play on Wednesday evening in the Schermerhorn Assembly Room. The play was a clever two-act comedy, "Mr. Bab." Mrs. H. Neill Wilson of Pittsfield was the coach. A large number of the cottagers were present, and two four-in-hand parties came down from Pittsfield.

BERLIN, Sept. 4. -- Emperor William's Coblenz rhodomontade has been received abroad with derisien. Even the Roman press cannot swallow the Emperor's Vice Regency of heaven, and is describing the blast at Coblenz as the blaring of a war horn of the ancient German gods. Austria manifests considerable uneasiness on the subject, and throughout Germany a more significant note of danger has been sounded.

The Fifth Avenue Theatre, of which Mr. Edwin F. Knowles, long associated with Brooklyn theatricals, is now the lessee and manager, was opened for the new season last night. The quality of the audience denoted that the Autumn is, indeed, at hand, and the vacation season over. Most of the "first-nighters," whose faces are well known to each other, were in their accustomed seats.

Charles A. Hauser has been elected Captain of the Clinton Wheel Club. Arrangements are making for the club's annual road race on October 7, the course to be from Newark, via Elizabeth, Plainfield, and Metuchen, to Highland Park and return.

It was quite the result of accident that what may be called the last home of the mammoths -- for we can hardly credit the Indian tales of live specimens -- became known to a white man. The redskins of Kwaquihuilette, a village on the Yukon River, have long known of the spot, but of the value of the ivory they have been totally ignorant.

PRINCESS VICTORIA KAIULANI is the daughter of the Hon. A.S. Cleghorn, a gentleman of British ancestry, but long a resident of the Hawaiian Islands, and the Princess Miriam Likelike, the last-named being a sister of Kalakaua, who reigned as King for seventeen years, and also of Liliuokalani, whose reign of two years was brought to a close by the action of the United States authorities on Jan. 17, 1893.

BOSTON, Sept. 4. -- Senator William E. Chandler of New Hampshire, who a few days ago started a lively discussion by stating that the discriminating clause of Section 22 of the Dingley Tariff bill was passed by a "trick of legislation," to-day replied to Senator Frye, who a few days ago declared that he could not tell how the amendment was passed.

IN "The Good Mr. Best," a somewhat invertebrate variety force now current at the Garrick Theatre, Josie Sadler has made a hit as a helpless, muddled, German serving maid, who descends the "slippery day stairs" in the manner of the clown in the old pantomimes and thereafter remarks "That's the first time I've sat down to-day."

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Sept. 4. -- The Assessors of the town of Cortlandt have completed their labors and are now preparing the corrected assessment roll and book. About seventy-five persons were examined, nearly all of them in regard to personal property.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Sept. 4. -- James A. Tyng was the centre of golfing attraction to-day on the links of the Morris County Golf Club, for he has decided to go to Chicago as a championship competitor. He will start for the West next Tuesday, so as to have some time to practice over the Chicago links before the big games commence Sept. 13.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 4. -- S.S. Oates, a well-to-do merchant and planter of Autauga County, was assassinated this afternoon, near Wadsworth, by Frank Hill, a neighbor, with whom he had had a trivial difficulty over some stock. Oates spent the morning in Montgomery, returning to Hollins Station, live miles from his home, by the afternoon train.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 4. -- District President Dolan of the United Mine Workers returned from Columbus this morning and went at once to the headquarters, where he held a consulataion with the other district officials.

CHICAGO, Sept 4. -- The removal of Mrs. Florence Kelly from the office of Factory Inspector by Gov. Tanner is another one of those slaps at the better sentiment of the State for which its Executive has made himself notorious. Mrs. Kelly is a philanthropist with whom the duties of the office were a labor of love, and no mere hired official can replace her.

CONCORD, Mass., Sept. 4. -- John W. Harris of Waltham shot and instantly killed Mrs. George S. Butters at her home here this afternoon. He also shot her son, Carleton T. Butters, twenty years old, twice in the face, inflicting probably fatal wounds. He then turned the revolver upon himself, inflicting a dangerous wound in the forehead.
Every resident of Brooklyn knows that the expressman of the city is a pompous individual, who, when his services are required, must be interviewed early and also that Sunday is his day of rest.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Sept. 4. -- Local occult theosophists are interested in the question whether Weithorn has returned to this village queerly reincarnated. Weithorn disappeared fifteen years ago as a Frenchman. If he has reappeared it is as an Irishman, calling himself Charles Smith. The unbelievers contend that no Frenchman could have a new birth and reappear in fifteen years with a brogue and galways.

THE steam yacht Vidette, M.C.D. Borden's craft, was built at Newburg in 1878, and although comparatively an old boat, she is a very comfortable one. Mr. Borden last year had the fine steamer Sovereign built, and now uses that yacht in preference to the smaller one, which has been used, though, by other members of Mr. Borden's family.

Agriculture, in the opinion of many, is considered to be a form of industry more laborious and less attractive to natural man than hunting or herding, and that it is consequently only undertaken under constraint, this being generally due to pressure of population on available means of subsistence. We cannot accept this conclusion in its entirety, as place must always condition work.

IT has been said by some experts that the wealth of the City of New York, or its equivalent, passes through the Surrogate's Court once in every thirty years However this may be, millions and millions of doliars' worth of property, real and personal, are adjudicated in the Surrogate's Court every year.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, Sept. 4. -- The hunting set in New York society promises to take possession of Richfield Springs this month. Such prominent society men as J. Craig Wadsworth, of the Genesee Hunt Club; Charles Mather, of the Radnor Hunt Club; P.F. Collier, of the Monmouth County Hunt, and J. Lee Tailer, of the Walontha Hunt, have already engaged accommodations for themselves and friends.

The Larchmont Yacht Club opened its Fall racing season yesterday with a regatta for fifty-one-foot sloops and cabin catboats. The chief interest in the regatta was in the contest between F.M. Hoyt's Syce and H.M. Gillig's Vencedor, in the fifty-one-foot class. John F. Lovejoy sailed on the Vencedor, and with Mr. Hoyt on the Syce were Commodore C.A. Postley and his Captain, Charley Barr.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 4. -- A bath was given to Kate Stanton, an aged insane woman, in the City Hospital to-day. According to her own statement, it was the first she had received for ten years.

It is no uncommon thing for women interested in church work to endeavor to raise money for philanthropic purposes by individual or organized labor within their special fields. Instances have been related of how women, animated by worthy objects, have fulfilled voluntary pledges of earning specified sums within certain specified periods.

LONDON, Sept. 4. -- The troubles on the northwest frontier of India are occupying men's minds here almost to the exclusion of any other news; even an exceptionally brutal murder or a deadly railway collision fails just now to attract the gentle British public, who are to be seen at street corners poring over maps of the disturbed districts and discussing the summary vengeance to be taken on the insurgent tribes.

On the second floor of the big tenement at 345 East One Hundred and Thirteenth Street, right in the heart of "Little Italy," lives the Brando family, consisting of Joseph, the father, twenty-six years old, and Pauline, his wife, twenty-four years old. Until 3 o'clock yesterday they had a little son Tomaseo, pretty, lively, and intelligent.

THREE of the best-known of the rowing clubs which have their houses on the Harlem River are the Nonpareil Rowing Club, the Dauntless Rowing Club, and the Union Boat Club. Their houses are on the west bank of the Harlem River, and extend from One Hundred and Forty-fifth Street to One Hundred and Forty-seventh Street.

The entrance to Russia's Baltic ports is blocked by ice for a great part of the year.

At a meeting of the Parade Committee of the Associated Cycling Clubs of Long Island at the clubhouse of the Logan Wheelmen, on Sixth Avenue, Wednesday, the special Committee on Marshals reported, through Robert W. Dye, that it had appointed Lieut. Gov. Timothy L. Woodruff as Grand Marshal, and he had accepted.

Last week was productive of some disappointments to lovers of harness racing, the weather having interfered with the sport at various tracks and caused numerous postponements. The pleasure of the horsemen attending the Grand Circuit meeting at Hartford was marred by the rain, which made a heavy track on Thursday, and interrupted the programme, sending the events of the day, including the special race between Star Pointer and Joe Patchen, over to Friday.

After now nearly a quarter of a century of touring, we can say with authority that there are three or four things of special importance to be remembered. If you look for perfect and absolute freedom on your tour take every bit of luggage you want with you. Buy what you have not got as you go on, throw away or send home what you have. By the end you will probably be comfortable.

BAR HARBOR, Sept. 4. -- On Tuesday morning the ships of the North Atlantic squadron hoisted their anchors and steamed slowly out of the bay. They took with them the best part of the season's life, and social gayety here will soon be ended.

Some believe a coalition with the Citizens' Union is the only salvation of the party in the metropolis, and such leaders are quietly advocating the nomination of Seth Low for Mayor.

There is a fund held by the Department of State that is sometimes referred to as the "secret fund," but to the department and the President it is known as money appropriated "for emergencies arising in the Diplomatic and Consular Service." The last Congress appropriated for this fund $40,000.

MAPLE, Wis., Sept. 4. -- During the past few days the Finnish settlement, a few miles south of Maple, has been in a state of great excitement over a remarkable succession of events. There are about two hundred residents in the settlement -- all farmers, thrifty and nearly all in comfortable circumstances.

A well-known officer of the New York National Guard who was a visitor at the camp of the Connecticut National Guard at Niantic a few days since was not altogether favorably impressed with some of the things he witnessed. In speaking of his visit, he said: "The discipline and military courtesy were of the poorest description and did not begin to compare with those observed at the New York camp.

Now is he joyous season of the year to bicyclists. Comfortable days and cool evenings make the pleasures of wheeling threefold more attractive. From September's opening day to about the middle of November the carnival may be expected to continue, unless the weather magnates prove erratic. Labor Day sets a fine example for the rest of the Autumn season.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Sept. 4. -- Judge Brownlee of the Howard County Superior Court has appointed Richard Ruddell, President of the Citizens' National Bank of Kokomo, receiver for the Eel River Railroad, and declared the charter forfeited. The Eel River Railroad is now operated as the Logansport-Detroit division of the Wabash, the latter road being the real defendant in the long years of trial just ended.

Security market values continue to advance; trade conditions throughout the country make bigger advances. With all its buoyancy, Wall Street does not catch up with National business developments. Wall Street, with all its enthusiastic inclinations, is not overdiscounting the future; it is attempting merely to reflect what are inspiriting facts.

BARCELONA, Sept. 4. -- The Chief of Police and the Assistant Chief, who directed the investigation into the Barcelona bomb outrages, were shot at and wounded seriously last night by a supposed Anarchist, who was subsequently arrested.

Within the past month two thriving drug stores on the upper west side of this town -one in Eighth Avenue and the other in Columbus Avenue -- have discontinued the sale of ice cream soda, on the ground that "there is no money in it." One of the establishments had been selling ice cream soda for 5 cents glass and the other had demanded 8 cents.

LONDON, Sept. 4. -- A friendly and enthusiastic audience witnessed the initial performance at the reopening of Her Majesty's Theatre this evening of an operatic version of the old story of Rip Van Winkle. The opera was handsomely staged, and there was some good music, though the action was ragged.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 4. -- A grand parade of horses, drawing stylish equipages of every description, and driven by devotees of the animal from ten different States, or carrying smartly gowned riders of both sexes, was the principal attraction at Fairmount Park this afternoon, when the third annual horse show opened here.

In the changes that are being proposed by the architect of the Department of Public Works in the interior of the City Hall there is one that will surely be objected to by persons who are interested in the old things of New York. It is the suggestion to cut off the eastern portion of the Governor's Room to make room for the Aldermanic Chamber of the new Municipal Assembly.

William F. King, President of the Merchants' Association, says: "I am satisfied that a reasonable estimate of the purchases made in this city throughout the month of August, in all lines of goods, would show an aggregate expenditure of nearly $150,000,000. This is a very large total, but when you consider that the purchases of some individual firms run from $50,000 to $100,000, you will see that the estimate is not wide of the mark.

NEWPORT, Sept. 4. -- The second day's yacht racing under the auspices of the Newport Yacht Racing Association was held to-day and furnished one of the closest contests ever held between the two big sloops Navahoe and Vigilant. Everybody expected the Vigilant to win, and she did, but it was by a narrow margin.

PARIS, Aug. 24. -- The sentence of the Correctional Police Court upon Baron de Mackau and MM. Bailac and Bagrachow, for homicide, by negligence in connection with the terrible fire at the Charity Bazaar early this Spring, was pronounced to-day. It was about as mild a sentence as could well be imagined.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 4. -- The positive announcement was made to-day by the friends of both parties concerned that the marriage of Miss Ellen Dortch to Gen. James Longstreet would be celebrated at noon next Wednesday, at the Executive Mansion in this city.

It has been often and truly remarked that but once in a generation does a real phenomenon appear in any branch of athletics, and during his career the star is invariably "miles ahead" of anything else in the game. Such has always been the case in sprinting, but the present period is a noticeable exception. Wefers is a phenomenon, but Maybury and Rush are entitled to a peg in his niche of fame.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 4. -- The week just closing has been very brilliant socially, more events being crowded into it than in any other week during the entire season. The most important of all was the wedding of Miss Edith Blight to William Page Thompson, which was performed on Wednesday last at All Saints' Chapel, and which was attended by all the cottagers.

SEA GIRT, N.J., Sept. 4. -- The seventh annual shoot under the auspices of the New Jersey State and National Rifle Association came to an end this evening. It was most successful. Before the shoot was resumed this morning. Capt. W.W. Williamson of the Georgia team received the following telegram from Gov. Atkinson.

Several surprises augmented the interest taken by a moderate number of spectators in the star work of a list of track meteors at the first half of the two days' race meet of the Quill Club Wheelmen on the Manhattan Beach track yesterday. Most startling of these was the fact that neither Tom Cooper nor "Wallie" Sanger was able to qualify for the finals of the big two-thousand-dollar Quill Club's two-mile handicap.

SANTA FE., N.M., Sept. 4. -- From Cochiti comes news of an important free gold strike in the Puzzle mine, owned by T.H. Benson. The streak is twelve inches wide and is full of free gold. It is estimated to be valued at $1,000 per ton. The camp is celebrating the discovery.

@'IAGARA-OiN'-THE-L@AKE, Ontario, Sept 4.--The international golf trophy was won this afternoon by G. T. Brown of London, Ontario, a @.ew Canadian player, whose play over the Xiagara links and his defeat of A. P. Scott of Toronto, probably the best ,n]atch player in Canada, stamps him as a golfer of high ability.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 4. -- Two frightful explosions of natural gas occurred in Broad Ripple, a suburban village six miles north of here, at 10 A.M. to-day. Seven are known to have been killed, and twenty or thirty seriously injured. The business part of the town was set on fire, and the largest buildings in it destroyed.

ATLANTA, Aug. 21. -- The convict system of Georgia is to be radically changed. The lash is to be abolished, more humane methods of control substituted, the parole system and degrade system established, and indeterminate sentences adopted. With a view to recommending a plan for disposing of the 2,400 convicts to be returned to the State by the present lessees, the Governor and the principal keeper have visited the penitentiaries of several States.

When a thoroughbred has repeatedly demonstrated to the satisfaction of the racing public that he is a horse of remarkable speed, with weight-carrying ability, and, moreover, that he is possessed of genuine gameness, he at once becomes a little idol, on which the racing public centres whatever affection the betting ring has not trampled out of its heart.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 4. -- The family of Jeremiah Somers, living in the northern part of Lamar County, became violently ill after supper last night, and before morning Emma and Mary Somers, four and fourteen years old, respectively, were dead. Mr. and Mrs. Somers and two other children are still very ill, but the timely use of emetics has probably saved their lives.

The English team of cricketers, which is to play a game against All New York on Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday, Sept. 13, 14, and 15, sailed from Southampton yesterday. Active preparations are being made for the game here, and the ground of the Staten Island Cricket Club, where the game will be played, is undergoing a special preparation for the match.

Dog stories are plentiful, as are also fish stories, but here is a genuinely true one, vouched for by Manager Will J. Davis and Myron B. Rice, which alone should be sufficient evidence of its truthfulness. Mr. Davis is a fancier of dogs, and he is continually bothered by his friends for young specimens. During the Summer Mr. Davis had a kennel of bulldogs which were unusually fine.

Mr. Sothern begins his eleventh annual engagement at the Lyceum Theatre tomorrow night. Among his associate actors, besides Virginia Harned, (Mrs. Sothern,) are Rowland Buckstone, Morton Selten, A.R. Lawrence, Roydon Erlvnne, C.P. Flockton, Owen Faweett, Daniel Jarrett, George E. Bryant, Tully Marshall, Rebecca Warren, Kate Pattison-Selten, and Blanche Weaver.

The Brooklyns made a "Garrison finish" in the game with the Colts at Eastern Park yesterday afternoon, and Won the game when it seemed as if the Colts were going to win. Sharp fielding kept the score down to the eigh, th inning. In the Chicago's half of tile eighth they scored two runs and took the lead.

The members of the Club of Ancients regard public affairs from the superior height of a long experience of failures. There is a fixed conviction pervading the club that whatever is is wrong, but that it is hardly worth while trying to set it right, because in the process there is apt to be developed so much presumption, hypocrisy, and, self-sufficiency as to make the former state seem desirable by comparison.

WHEN telegraphy was in its infancy a keen, progressive, and energetic young man in Ohio became interested in it and gave to the study of its principles and practical adaptability the zealous attention of a rare and comprehensive Intelligence. He foresaw in a measure its great value to civilization and as fast as opportunities enabled him to do so he mastered its mechanical requirements and possibilities.

The sale of thoroughbred yearlings, the property of the Preakness and McGrathiana Studs, in the sale paddocks at Sheepshead Bay yesterday, attracted a number of well-known horsemen. The highest price brought was $2,500 for a chestnut colt by Hanover-Despenia. The colt was afterward bought by J.E. Madden, who is on the lookout for all of the yearling get of Hanover in the hope that he will find another Hamburg.

THE HAGUE, Aug. 25. -- A pale yellow setting sun, round and full, and because of its paleness one can see clearly the form and look into the sun's face unflinchingly. The waters of the North Sea, on this delightful midsummer evening, are of those tints belonging to the rainbow. Silver network along the golden brown sands shows the line of the breakers, which hardly deserve that name.

NEWPORT, Sept. 4. -- The finals were played to-day at the Newport Golf Club for the President's and the Consolation Cups. The former was won by W.B. Cutting and the latter by J.A. Stillman. There was a large attendance at the play, and the weather was fine.

When the length of the life of other animals is contrasted with that of the giant tortoise, it is clear that the latter must enjoy some special advantage, either of structure or of habit, conducing to longevity. One hundred years is a good old age for an elephant, and no other animals, except certain birds and reptiles, reach half this span of years.
CHICAGO, Sept. 4. -- When the trial of Adolph Luetgert for wife murder was resumed to-day additional witnesses appeared to identify the rings found in the vat.

The pyrotechnic career of William Botto, after illuminating, amusing, and amazing half a dozen cities, has been quenched, for a time at least, in the gloom of a cell in Police Headquarters in this city, where so many pyrotechnic careers have been concluded.

Leaving out of the account Mr. PLATT'S organization, which is still in perplexity as to its course, the lines on which the Mayoralty canvass will be conducted and the apportionment of the forces may already be foreseen.

PORT TOWNSEND, Washington, Sept. 4. -- F.D. Heustis, the new Customs Collector of the Puget Sound district, has refused admittance to seven Chinese who arrived from Victoria, B.C., on the ground that they had departed from other ports when leaving this country.

Seth Low having accepted the nomination for Mayor, the next business of the conferrees who named him will be to complete the city ticket. None of the members of the Citizens' Union is yet ready to say when this will be done. The conferrees of the four boroughs participating in the nomination of Mr. Low adjourned on Wednesday subject to the call of the Chairman, Joseph Larocque.

Frederick Burns, twenty-eight years old, of 432 West Thirty-second Street, was detected yesterday in the act of robbing the grocery store of Mrs. Bongiarno at 117 Elizabeth Street. Two confederates who were with him made their escape.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 4. -- John Balthus has just got back from the war. His wife meanwhile married John Winkeljohn, five children being the result of the union. Before her second marriage the woman obtained a pension and $1,400 for the loss of her husband.

There are girls and girls, and probably all girls are pretty much alike in many ways, but they also differ greatly in different parts of the country, is what Miss Jessie A. Fowler says, and Miss Fowler has been for some time past making a study of girls from a phrenological point of view. The New York girl is -- well, the New York girl, which puts it all in a nutshell; the Boston girl,

LONDON, Sept. 4. -- The supporters of the Rational Dress Congress had arranged with seven ladies' cycling clubs to make a bloomer demonstration by wheeling from London to Oxford, where the dinner of the congress, which is under the Presidency of Viscountess Harberton, took place. The movement was under the patronage of Ladies Colin-Campbell, Randolph Churchill, Richardson and Henry Somerset, the Countess of Warwick, Lord Coleridge, Sarah Grand, W.T. Stead, and others.

Much tawdry criticism projects itself to the front just now, oracularly proclaiming that security market conditions have become dangerous, that the strength manifest is unnatural, market foundations artificial, the upward trend of values a matter of manipulation merely.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. -- No official information could be obtained here regarding the return of Gen. Lee, but it is expected that he has been granted leave of absence by the State Department, with permission to return to this country. The business of the Consulate will be in charge of the Vice Consul General during his absence.

Some conductors on the Broadway and Columbus Avenue cable road accept Canadian ten-cent pieces in payment of fares and other conductors do not. A large proportion of the cable line conductors deal out these Canadian coins in making change, consequently there is often friction between conductors who refuse to accept the foreign dimes and passengers who, having received such coins on the cable cars, try to pass them back.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- The Treasury Department has prepared the regulations governing the sampling and classification of imported sugars and molasses under the new tariff law, and they will be promulgated formally to-morrow. One of the principal and most important of the changes made in the old regulations, which were made in 1883, is a provision requiring that the "resample" of sugar shall be taken at the time the original sample is taken.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 5. -- For the first time in five years, Birmingham district is short of labor and agents are in the field to secure help needed at coal and ore mines, and furnaces, and for railroad and industrial construction. The mines have been obliged to refuse large contracts offering at good prices because unable, in spite of running on full time, to supply the demand.

Two burglars who must have been familiar with the habits and surroundings of the people they robbed forced an entrance into the house of David R. Ryers at Grant City, S.I., early yesterday morning. They forced Mrs. Ryers, under threats of burning the house over her head, to give up her gold watch and between $3 and $4, all the valuables she had.

The Rev. Milton F. Negus of Owego, N.Y., who recently accepted a call from the First Baptist Church, at Lee Avenue and Keap Street, Williamsburg, and who entered into his new field of duty Wednesday last, preached his first sermon yesterday morning before a large congregation. He succeeds the late Dr. Eddy.

" Mr. Low's Candidacy" was the subject yesterday morning of the Rev. Thomas Dixon's first sermon at the Academy of Music, Fourteenth Street and Irving Place, to the congregation of the People's Church, after a ten weeks' vacation. The orchestra and first balcony of the auditorium were well filled.

MILLVILLE, N.J., Sept. 5. -- The glass furnaces of the country went into blast on Wednesday, as is their annual custom. The demand for bottles is a good thing by which to estimate the country's prosperity. Beer bottles and whisky flasks are now a drug on the market. The demand for patent medicine bottles was never heavier; the orders for prescription bottles never lighter.

Supported by the newspaper Don Chisclotti, a subscription has been opened, the result of which is to be divided between those who on Jan. 1, 1900, will have seen three centuries -- that is to say, those who, having at that time at least 100 years and two days, can boast of having lived in the eighteenth, nineteenth, and twentieth centuries.

Thomas Jones, twenty-one years old, of Chicago, and Peter Schwarz, thirty-one years old, of Cincinnati, were arrested Saturday night at the Central Railroad Station in Jersey City for stealing a ride on a freight train. As they were dressed in new suits and carried heavy valises it was thought they were able to pay their fares.

RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 5. -- The first hundred miles of the single, double, and triple century of the Rutherford Wheelmen ended at Rutherford to-night, the first rider getting in at 6:50 o'clock. During the hour allowed for supper most of the eighty-seven starters arrived, including Mrs. Hallie White and Miss Hummel, two of the five women who began. Both started on the second century at 8 P.M.

The Harlem River was alive with oarsmen yesterday in all classes of racing craft, taking a final spin before to-day's big regatta, for which they have been training for the last six weeks. The balconies of the boathouses which line the river were crowded with members, and the Middle States regatta which will be rowed over the regular mile straightaway course was the principal topic of conversation.

Hermann Reubold, twenty-five years old, left his family in Germany two years ago and came to this country because of a quarrel. He worked on a farm in Pennsylvania until a few weeks ago, and then, losing his position, started for this city to see his aunt, Mrs. Lena Ott.

Concerning some of the numerous presents which M. Faure will take to St. Petersburg, an official of the Sevres porcelain manufactory states that a first consignment has already been made to Russia through the Minister of Foreign Affairs. It consists of two magnificent vases, marvelously decorated and designed by Mme. Apoil.

Has the field club, the hotel veranda, the bicycle run, the seashore excursion, the concert, or ramble across country, the right of way over all Sabbath observance, church worship, and religious living generally? The young people of America need to ask themselves this question in all seriousness, since they are in great danger of being swept into a very whirlpool of gayety and giddiness.

Bicycle Policeman Gillis wheeled alongside the wagon driven by Daniel Lowly, a peddler, of 321 East Sixth Street, on Eighth Avenue, Saturday night, and told Lowly his horse was going too fast. Lowly replied by urging the horse still faster. The policeman made a grab at the reins and the horse stopped, reared up and came down with his fore foot on the bicycle, throwing the policeman to the asphalt and wrecking the wheel.

For nearly three years fragments of this story have been lying around McCormick's tenement and in the neighborhood of Fifty-seventh Street, west of Tenth Avenue, neglected and forgotten by their owners.

Mr. James Whyte, Secretary of the United Kingdom Alliance, desires to prove that a teetotaler, as a general rule, lives longer than a person who uses alcoholic liquor. He writes: "Nearly a quarter of a century ago Dr. William Farr, who at that time was the Medical Assistant to the Registrar General, wrote as follows:

At Providence Hospital John Anderson lies dying. Over his emaciated and unconscious form bends a friend who has shown more faithfulness than is seen every day. At the close of this cynical and selfish nineteenth century people are apt to read the story of Damon and Pythias, of David and Jonathan, then smile incredulously, and say such things may have been in ages gone by, but not now.

A typical Fourth Ward mob of nearly 1,000 persons attempted to rescue a prisoner from some policemen of the Oak Street Station last night. Failing in that they attempted to stone the station house, and were only driven away when a number of other policemen made a charge on them. Their object was to secure the release of the prisoner.

DENVER, Col., Sept. 5. -- The action of the Democratic State Convention to be held in this city to-morrow in regard to the nomination for Justice of the Supreme Court is problematical. Some of the prominent workers of the Democratic Party have been agitating for an indorsement of the nomination of Judge Charles D. Hayt, the candidate of the Silver Republicans.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 5. -- The jury in the case of the State against Jesse F. Hurd, who was charged with murder, returned a verdict of not guilty at 10:15 o'clock last night. The trial lasted four days and was removed from this city to Perryville, twenty-five miles from here, on a change of venue.

Not since the organization of the Merchants' Association has there been so great an influx of out-of-town buyers in New York as there was last week. The clerks at association headquarters were kept busy every day from 9 A.M. until 6 P.M. registering the visiting merchants, and tradesmen throughout the city experienced with satisfaction the strong stimulus given to business by the presence in town of so many strangers.

SEATTLE, Washington, Sept. 5. -- All efforts to break the blockade at Skaguay have failed utterly. Advices received by the steamer Rosalie, which left Skaguay Monday last and arrived here yesterday are that when the trail was opened Monday morning 2,000 men and horses were striving to get over.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 5. -- The United Labor League of Western Pennsylvania at a largely attended meeting to-night broke into revolt against Samuel Gompers. President of the American Federation of Labor, and adopted resolutions censuring him. The trouble originated in unkind criticism by Gompers on the recent convention of labor leaders at St. Louis.

About 7,000 vestmakers in New York and Brooklyn have struck work to secure an advance of wages. The strikers are discussing the condition of the vestmaking business with great freedom, and some of them already have reached the conclusion that the wages of vestmakers are too low because there are too many makers of vests.

Besides establishing a President's right to quit French soil, M. Faure's voyage is settling some nice questions of constitutional etiquette. When the Czar visited this country last October, although Parliament was not in session there was some jealousy lest it should be unrepresented at the festival and lest M. Faure should, so to speak, monopolize the imperial guest.

TRENTON, Sept. 5. -- The question of State supervision for building and loan associations has been revived because of the wrecking of the two Trenton associations, and the wall of discontent that comes from Newark, because associations there are discounting notes and doing a banking business.

The changes made in the school system of New York are a definite, concrete example of the working of the principle of non-partisan city government, to which the Citizens' Union and its candidate, Mr. Low, are pledged. Though much remains to be done, much has already been done by the application of that principle.

GETTYSBURG, Penn., Sept. 5. -- The veterans and friends of the Seventy-third and One Hundred and Twenty-fourth New York Regiments and the Veteran Firemen of New York spent to-day on the battlefield. In the afternoon the veterans of the One Hundred and Twenty-fourth held an informal meeting at their monument at Devil's Den.

For the first time in many years Labor Day will not count among its features a big parade. When this was prophesied last year, many persons were loath to believe that the one day set apart for the laboring masses by the laws of the State would not be characterized by processions of trade unions. To-day, however, there will not even be the semblance of a parade.

Major George N. Bomford, U.S.A., retired, died of a kidney affection yesterday afternoon at his home, 214 West Fourteenth Street. The deceased was born in New York fifty-six years ago, and came from a family noted for its good soldiers. His grandfather, Col. George Bomford, joined the army as a Lieutenant of Engineers in 1805, and was a Major of Engineers during the war of 1812.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Sept. 5. -- The three-masted schooner Agnes I. Grace of Bangor, Me., capsized and sank this morning twenty miles east of Tybee. Her crew later came ashore in a boat and landed at Warsaw Island.
One Stock Exchange firm, not much inclined to counsel purchases in the security market at the moment -- Messrs. Howard Lapsley Co. -- write to customers as follows:
Political discussions keep cropping up in the Central Labor Union, and may grow warmer and more acrimonious, notwithstanding the fact that politics are by rule tabooed at the meetings of that body.

Firemen fought an obstinate cotton fire for three hours on board a lighter in the Fall River Line slip, in the North River, at the foot of Murray Street, yesterday afternoon. Although five or six fire engines and two fire boats turned all their force upon the flames, as a last resort the lighter, with its cargo still smoking, was towed over to the Jersey City flats and sunk.

As the almanacs would word it, "About this time of year look out for plain men who think for themselves." These plain men are called all kinds of names by political party managers, and in the campaign for the election of a Mayor of the Greater New York they will be roundly abused.

NEW BRUNSWICK, Sept. 5. -- Tramps committed another outrage near this city early this morning. The victims were Charles Smith, aged twenty-eight years, whose home is at 96 Vesey Street, New York, and William Hines, aged twenty-six, of Philadelphia, who were riding on a Pennsylvania freight train to Jersey City.

RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 5. -- A movement has been started here to erect monuments over the graves of the Southern soldiers who died in Northern prisons. Strange to say, the suggestion came from a Northern man, a veteran of the Federal Army.

TRENTON, Sept. 5. -- Peter W. Crozer, the defaulting Treasurer of the Mercer and the Mechanics' Mutual Building and Loan Association, is still at large. Yesterday a further shortage of $2,000 was discovered in Class 12 of the Mercer Building and Loan Association. At the time Crozer's books were examined they showed no receipts for this class, and Crozer volunteered the information that the projected class had never been formed.

ATLANTA, Sept. 5. -- The week just past has been a crucial one in the South. The new cotton season begins officially on the 1st day of September, and with it the commercial world of the cotton States catches its breath, and takes a fresh start. It is a time for turning over new leaves, financially speaking, squaring up accounts, comparing past performances, and preparing for fresh conquests.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Sept. 5. -- In a few more years the last wall will be leveled of the old-style country houses on the Middle Hudson, which less than half a century ago were regarded as the acme of elegance and comfort, but which, with the advance of modern ideas, have become distinctly out of date.
HOMBURG, Sept. 5. -- Emperor William, in proposing the toast to King Humbert at the banquet at the Kurhaus last evening, said:

More golf will be played on neighboring links to-day than has been seen in a long time. There is not a golf club within twenty or thirty miles of New York that has not arranged something in the line of a tournament for to-day, and the game will be kept lively from early morning until the setting sun prevents the golfer from seeing his ball as he sends it through the air.

Only four more days of racing this season remain for the Coney Island Jockey Club, but if all signs do not fail, this, the closing week at the club's cozy track at Sheepshead Bay, will be one of the most successful in years. The week's racing will begin to-day with the Twin City Handicap and the Autumn Stakes as the features, both of which have filled well, and promise well-fought contests.

After thirty years' service, including a full quarter-century of experience as a leading detective, Frederick Jarvis, Chief Inspector of Scotland Yard, enters upon his well-earned retirement next month. It would be difficult to find an officer more diametrically opposed to the popular conception of a detective.

" The people of Sondrio have been treated to a wonderful exhibition. Prof. Edoe recited the whole of Dante's 'Divina Commedia' in twenty continuous hours, without being prompted and without making a single mistake. The recitation lasted from 6 P.M. one afternoon to 2 P.M. next day." So says our correspondent at Rome, on the best authority, no doubt.

Admiral SICARD'S success in sending communications from his squadron at sea to the Navy Department by pigeons is apparently a slight matter, but it is an achievement which in time of emergency might become of the greatest importance. The navy owes the suggestion of this plan to the newspapers.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Sept. 5. -- Elaborate preparations are being made in this city for the coming celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of the city's incorporation, which is to take place Oct. 10-14, although as a matter of fact the act of incorporation was accepted March 9, 1847.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 5. -- Coal-mining circles are encouraged over the probable resumption of work in the mines throughout the country. In anticipation of a settlement at Columbus next Wednesday, a plan has been suggested by a representative of one of the largest operators which will be agitated immediately after the men return to work.

SEATTLE, Washington, Sept. 5. -- Serious as is the situation at Skaguay Bay and the White Pass, as protrayed by letters and by men returning from the camp, and appalling as is the condition of the trail over the mountain barrier between the 6,000 gold hunters and the Klondike, the accounts published from time to time have but faintly portrayed the actual condition of affairs.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 5. -- One of the richest pockets ever found in this State was taken out of the Mascot Mine, near Sonora, last week. The strike was made during the working hours of the night shift ad was so extensive as to necessitate the men working overtime to secure all of the precious metal.

Following the comparatively recent examples of Hungary and Russia, Denmark has now adopted the "zone system" on all the State railways. The new system was quietly introduced during the present Summer, and to-day Denmark is probably the cheapest country for railway traveling in the world.

The arrest of Owen McCaul of 195 Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn, Friday afternoon, charged with withholding the pension certificate of Edward J. Foss, an army veteran, who lives at the corner of Broome and Hudson Street, this city, marked the beginning of a systematic crusade against alleged pension swindlers who are said to operate all over this district.

If the Glencairn II. should win one of the remaining two matches the cup will remain in Canada. Whichever country wins we hope that a chance will be given to a British club to challenge for next season. It will be remembered that last year the moment the decisive race was over an American challenge was immediately delivered, so that no opportunity was furnished for any other country to challenge.

-- "Jealousy of Newport News and other Southern ports," according to The Richmond Dispatch, is what prompts the New York papers to criticise the rule by which vessels bound for the same destination and over the same course are heavily fined if they start from ports a few miles above, instead of a few miles below, a certain point on the coast.

WARSAW, N.Y., Sept. 6. -- The Wyoming County Republicans to-day nominated the following ticket: County Clerk -- E.M. Jennings, Warsaw: Superintendent of Poor -- James W. Ives, Java; District Attorney -- E.E. Charles; Coroners -- H.H. Sharp. Arcade, and Dr. L.C. Broughton, Castile; Assemblyman -- Daniel B. Whipple, Wethersfield.

While the bad Republicans are berating the Citizens' Union for its impudence the good Republicans deplore its lack of regard for what they call the "difficulty" of their situation. Our evening contemporary The Mail and Express is quite unable to believe that "the Citizens will endanger union at this critical stage by making other nominations."

A large proportion of the down-town wholesale houses were open for business yesterday, and in most instances proprietors and clerks were as actively employed as they have been on any day since this business boom began. It is safe to say that on no previous legal holiday have the wholesale merchants of New York been so busy. The out-of-town buyers were hard at work from morning till night.

Too many lives and too much money have been sacrificed by halting and feeble and ignorant encounters with yellow fever in this country to make it at all doubtful what course should be adopted to meet and check the disease if it has really broken out at Ocean Springs, Miss.

HIGHLAND FALLS, Sept. 6. -- While Robert Armstrong, Superintendent of J. Pierpont Morgan's kennels, was walking through the kennel grounds yesterday morning, looking for a young collie, which had been missing for several days, his attention was attracted by a lot of birds flying excitedly through the air. High above them soared five large eagles.

Nearly a thousand soldiers took advantage of yesterday's holiday and the perfect weather to do some shooting at Creedmoor. Every regiment in New York and Brooklyn was represented, besides a good many members of the naval militia. The one drawback, however, was the fierce glare of the sun, which made long-range shooting very difficult, and in consequence comparatively few sharpshooters qualified.

While F.E. Roth of 511 East Seventy-fifth Street was taking home a vicious mustang, after having had it shod at a blacksmith's shop in his neighborhood yesterday afternoon, the animal broke away from him and went down the street at a rattling pace, striking terror to the hearts of many women and children on the way.

The British Medical Journal is alarmed by the prevalence of the appetite for cooling drinks. It declares that thirst "leads to many accidents." This is an assertion which cannot be refuted. No one who reads the records of Monday morning's police courts can fail to note that many accidents result from thirst.

The Citizens' Union Executive Committee will meet this afternoon at 32 Nassau Street. Some of the members expect that Seth Low's letter of acceptance will get here in time to be received at the meeting, but it was said at the headquarters, 39 East Twenty-third Street, last night that this was very doubtful.

GAINESVILLE, Ga., Sept. 6. -- When Gen. James Longstreet was asked to-day about his rumored intention to marry Miss Dortch he said: "I'll bet Ham has been talking too much down there in Atlanta. Did he tell you anything about this thing?"

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Sept. 6. -- Labor Day was celebrated in this city with a big bicycle parade, in which there were clubs from all Parts of Westchester County, New York, Brooklyn, and other places. The city was decorated with flags and banners.

With the friendly roar of 8,000 throats his cars, Fred J. Titus of the Riverside Wheelmen of this city jumped from a bunch of the fastest races on the American cycle track and won the final heat of the Quill Club's two-mile handicap race yesterday on the Manhattan Beach track. Straining and forcing himself as he has seldom done before, "Eddie" Bald, the King of racers, was hard put to win fourth place.

The double holiday passed, Wall Street resumes business again this morning. The bulls will start in enthusiastically again, the strength of the markets of Friday and Saturday in the face of the profit-taking movement having convinced them that they have at their back an outside buying power even larger than was believed.
Chairman Elliot Danforth of the Democratic State Committee yesterday issued the following call:

The McKinley Administration's Collector of the Port and the McKinley Administration's Postmaster are taking an active part in the struggle of the Platt machine to force the Citizens' Union into a surrender and deal.
SKAGUAY, Aug. 20. -- We arrived at this port this morning at 11 o'clock, but were unable to land until three hours later, the delay being caused by some deliberations with customs officers.

-- There is no particular cause for surprise in the fact that the English have met with some apparent reverses on the Indian frontier. Many examples could be given in support of an assertion that revolts doomed to failure always begin with a few little victories, while those destined to succeed have dark days at first.

Katherine Grey appeared with difficulty in "A Southern Romance," at the Fifth Avenue Theatre, last night. She was suffering from extreme hoarseness, and delivered her lines in a distressing manner. Dr. Quinlan was in constant attendance upon Miss Grey during the entire performance, spraying her throat at every opportunity to enable her to proceed with her part.

What is probably the last meeting the Grand Circuit stables will ever attend at the Fleetwood Park course began yesterday. It is pretty certain that the growth of the annexed district will wipe out the old landmark this year. The programme now on also ends the great Summer tourney. The contests yesterday were sharp, short, and rather one-sided.

The sun was beating down very hot into Battery Park yesterday afternoon, and hardly a breath of air was stirring, when an elderly-looking man sought rest on a bench beneath the shade of a locust tree on the main walk, just west of the music pavilion. Loungers in the park changed their seats as the burning rays of the sun found their shelter.

Mr. Sothern began his annual engagement at the Lyceum Theatre last evening, in the presence of the customary fine-looking and amiable audience, in a new romantic play in five acts, called "Change Alley," after a famous English picture, and dealing, in a somewhat fantastical and not very powerful way, with the bursting of the South Sea Bubble.

JAMAICA, L.I., Sept. 6. -- There was considerable excitement in this place this evening when a trolley car loaded with soldiers passed through the village. The soldiers were firing their rifles and making an awful disturbance. At Queens they did even worse.

At the picnic and games of the First Regiment, Irish Volunteers, every foot of space in Sulzer's Harlem River Park was crowded from noon until almost midnight. It was with difficulty that a sufficient arena could be kept clear for the athletic games, while men, women, and children engaged in open-air jigging contests in the real old Irish style.

Favored by clear skies, a smooth courses, and a long entry list, the eighth annual regatta of the Middle States Regatta Association was held yesterday on the Harlem River. Thousands of persons flocked to the banks of the river to view the events, and good positions on the bridges were at a premium.

The Giants won two games from the tail-enders yesterday. There were not more than 3,500 persons at the morning game, but those who staid at home missed a rare treat. Even though the Browns are not in a class with the local team they gave them a bad scare. George Davis made a timely base hit which brought in the winning run after two men were out in the ninth inning.

A sodden, sullen, sorry party represented the Anarchists of Greater New York at a park behind a barroom at Fort Wadsworth, S.I., yesterday, and the most completely sodden, the most ferociously sullen, and the sorriest of them all was Herr Johann Most, whose farewell day in New York it was. He is going to Buffalo to be editor of a daily German newspaper.

The complaint which our news columns record against the interruption to business caused by the existence of a legal holiday on the first Monday in September is of itself a striking illustration of the return of good times. For the past three or four years it has been of very little consequence to merchants whether or not the men in their employ were entitled to take the first Monday in September "off."

OCEAN SPRINGS, Miss., Sept. 6. -- Representatives of the Health Boards of Alabama, Louisiana, and Mississippi, who have been here since yesterday inquiring into the nature of the epidemic of fever which has been prevalent here for several days, to-day pronounced the disease to be yellow fever.

Chairman Quigg of the Republican County Committee returned from Fisher's Island Sunday night, and yesterday afternoon went to Manhattan Beach to confer with Senator Platt, whom he had not seen since Seth Low accepted the Citizens' Union nomination for Mayor. The County Chairman declared with much positiveness that under no circumstances would the Republican organization accept Mr. Low as its candidate.

Abraham Dorfmann, thirty years of age, of 82 Avenue C, this city, was shot and almost instantly killed shortly after 2 o'clock yesterday morning by Roundsman Gaughran of the Twenty-seventh Precinct, Brooklyn, while making his escape after committing burglary in a Brownsville tailor shop.

Nine thousand persons were present yesterday at the forty-first annual games of the New York Caledonian Club, held in Ambrose Park, South Brooklyn. An extensive programme, including over twenty-five events, had been prepared, and the games, which were all for cash prizes, were in progress from late in the forenoon until long after 6 o'clock.

The Brooklyns and Chicagos broke even at Eastern Park yesterday. The early contest was like a practice game for the grooms. They made so many base hits that the visitors were nearly exhausted. The Colts secured the second game through superior batting, aided by ludicrous errors by several of the Brooklyn players.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Sept. 6. -- The picturesque links of the Morris County Golf Club were crowded to-day with enthusiastic players. Two records were beaten -- the record for number of contestants and that for the best amateur score. Fifty finished the tournament.
SIMLA, Sept. 6. -- The Swatis up to the present have surrendered 2,000 guns, 1,000 swords, and 70 breech-loading rifles.
Thomas Ryan has sold for Mrs. Sarah A. Smith to Lawrence Gaffney, for $10,700, the three-story and basement dwelling 156 East One Hundred and Twenty-seventh Street, 20 by 99.11.

RUTHERFORD, N.J., Sept. 6. -- There were thirty survivors in the open triple century run of the Rutherford Cyclers. They began to arrive here at 7:15 to-night. Among the first to arrive was Miss Tillie Hummel of the Triumph Wheelmen, who was carried into Blake's Restaurant in the arms of one of the riders.

SAULT STE. MARIE, Mich., Sept. 6. -- The party of gold seekers on the yacht Mary Bell returned from Michipicoten last evening, having been in the gold fields but three days. They say the newly discovered Eldorado is fully as rich as has been reported. There were fourteen in the party, all responsible business men of this city. Each of them secured claims, upon which the gold quartz promises big returns.

SUMMIT, N.J., Sept. 6. -- Peter Johnson, the Unionville hermit, who died yesterday, was buried in the old Connecticut Farms churchyard, near Unionville, this afternoon. There were but few mourners at the grave, and the services were simple.

ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 6. -- The Orange Athletic Club played two games with the Cuban Giants at the Orange Oval to-day. In the morning game Wilson, the first baseman of the visitors, was struck by a pitched ball, and had to be carried off the field. It is feared that he has sustained serious injuries.
