The Labor Day Committee of the Central Labor Union met in Clarendon Hall early yesterday morning to make the final arrangements for the games and dancing at the picnic at Silver Lake Park, Tompkinsville, S.I., toward which the members and unions of the Central Labor Union were already hastening.
MONTREAL, Sept. 6. -- The Right Hon. Lord Chelmsford, G.C.B., a retired General in the British Army, arrived in Montreal from London to-day on an interesting mission.

The arrival of two policemen prevented a howling throng of people from doing violence to a young colored man on Broadway, near Fifty-first Street, at 9 o'clock last night. The colored man was James Rees, twenty-three years old, of 756 Seventh Avenue. He was held a prisoner by Policeman Lieber, while Policemen Kerr shouted "Make way there!" and forced a passage for Lieber and his prisoner.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 6. -- President Oliphant of the Louisiana Board of Health sent a telegram to the office of that board in this city to-day confirming the report that the physicians at Ocean Springs had declared the prevailing sickness there undoubtedly yellow fever. The doctors of three States came to this conclusion after holding an autopsy on the body of a person who died yesterday.

TORONTO, Sept. 7. -- The international cricket match between elevens representing the United States and Canada resulted to-day in a victory for the Canadians, the eighth victory of Canada in the twenty-five games played.

The Reading stocks were all strong in the early dealings yesterday, and the common showed much activity. It sold as high as 28 3/4, the highest quotation made for some time. The first preferred was also strong, selling at 56 5/8. The second preferred sold at 34 3/4. Closing quotations showed that each of these stocks had made a net gain for the day of one-half of 1 per cent.

In this morning's issue of THE TIMES I notice a communication from a person who signs his name as "Davis." It is evident from the tone of his letter than "Davis" has been touched in a sore place; if not, his letter proceeds from pure malice.
COLUMBUS, Sept. 7. -- Friends of Judge John H. Clark of Youngstown are urging that he be nominated for Governor by the gold Democratic convention, which will be held here to-morrow and Thursday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7. -- Two strong points were scored by the prosecution in the Luetgert trial to-day, and unless the defense is able to impeach the testimony of the witnesses their evidence is likely to have considerable weight with the jury.
The New Yorks played off two postponed games with the Clevelands at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon in the presence of 7,000 persons, and were victorious in both contests.

LONDON, Sept. 7. -- The Duke and Duchess of Rio Grande were arraigned in the Marylebone Police Court this morning charged with defrauding hotels and boarding houses. The Duke is said to be a Brazilian nobleman.
TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 7. -- The Greenburgh Town Assessors held another session to-day in Town Clerk Purdy's office to hear grievances of property owners who objected to their assessments.

The Republican Organization of the City and County of New York, of which William Brookfield is the leader, has broken away from the Republican-Anti-Tammany combination and entered the political field as a pacificating factor.
LEWISTON, Me., Sept. 7. -- A report here is that James Mitchell, who has the contract to build the Washington County Railroad, says that work will be begun in two or three weeks.

The first actual test of strength in the municipal campaign in Brooklyn has resulted in a decided victory for Jacob Worth. At the meeting last evening of the Executive Committee of the Republican General Committee, the Worth faction fixed the dates for the primaries and several conventions after Sheriff William J. Buttling rode rough-shod, but pleasantly, over the scattering Willis men present, and good-naturedly adjourned after a session lasting but twenty-five minutes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- In addition to Dr. Guiteras of the University of Pennsylvania, Drs. Murray and Carter, also yellow fever experts, have been ordered by the Marine Hospital authorities to the scene of the epidemic at Ocean Springs. Dr. Guiteras will reach there to-morrow. The following order was telegraphed today to Passed Assistant Surgeon Wasdin at Mobile:

What was it that Minister WOODFORD dreaded as he contemplated the task he had undertaken for the President at the Court of Madrid? "The more I reflect," he said, a short time before he sailed for Europe, "the more reluctant I become to encounter the difficulties of the position I have consented to accept."

National Guard circles axe exercised over the disgraceful scenes enacted in Queens and Jamaica, L.I., Monday, by men who are said to be members of that organization, and if the offenders can be identified there is no doubt that they will be summarily dealt with by the officers in command.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Sept. 7. -- A nest of yellow jacket hornets which had been established on the farm of Rudolph Sammis, at West Neck, is now gone, but not forgotten. The colony was rather a small one, left after the wear and tear of the Summer, and was resting from the season's work.

The idiosyncracies of Long Island people were illustrated in red paint on the roof of the Savoy Theatre annex and on various places in the neighborhood yesterday morning. Louis Beasza and Frank Unrein, both from Turan, L.I., had been given the job of painting the roof. As soon as they began the natural sensitiveness and jealousy of the artistic temperament developed.

Hall J. How Co. have sold for Isaac A. Lawrence to Cumming Ferguson, the builders, for immediate improvement, five lots on the north side of One Hundred and Third Street, 100 feet east of Columbus Avenue, 125 by 100. It is said that the price is about $65,000.

Many of the National Circuit chasers who figured in the Manhattan Beach cycling of last Saturday and Monday will remain in the neighborhood to take part in the National Circuit meet, which will be the feature Friday of the New Jersey State Fair at Waverly Park. Newark. A programme of seven events has been arranged.

READING, Penn., Sept. 7. -- At an entertainment given by the North End Athletic Club of Reading at Woodvale Park to-day, Harry I. Huber of Reading was seriously injured by a blow given by Jack Becker of Brooklyn in a ten-round boxing bout.

It seems that Mr. BRYAN, with the assistance of Senator ALLEN and Cyclone DAVIS of Texas, JERRY SIMPSON of Kansas, Congressman HARTMAN of Montana, and other hairy and bimetallic statesmen from far and near, has at last succeeded in amalgamating all the silver parties in Nebraska.
PARIS, Sept. 7. -- The French press is still greatly exercised over the effect that the Franco-Russian alliance will have upon European politics.

-- Those reports from Jamaica, L.I., of outrages committed on Monday by members of the Twelfth and Forty-seventh Regiments will be immediately investigated by the proper authorities, it is fair to assume, and no doubt the drunken scoundrels who thus tried to disgrace the National Guard will suffer the punishment of instant and dishonorable dismissal, which they so thoroughly deserve.

CYGNET, Ohio, Sept. 7. -- An explosion of nitro-glycerine here this afternoon at 3 o'clock caused the deaths of six people, whose names are known, and several others, at present unknown. Those known to be dead are Samuel Barber, Allen Fallis, John Thompson, Charles Bartel, Henry Lansdale, and a boy named Havens.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- The full text of the formal acceptance by the Japanese Government of the proposal to arbitrate its differences with Hawaii has been received in this city and a copy was to-day delivered to Secretary Sherman by the Secretary of the Japanese Legation, Mr. Matsui. It is from Count Okuma, Minister of Foreign Affairs, to H. Shinamura, Japanese Minister to Hawaii.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 7. -- The breaking out of yellow fever at Ocean Springs, New Orleans, and other places has caused widespread alarm in the South. Alabama commenced yesterday a rigid quarantine against the infected places. Birmingham appointed a special corps of officers who compel all persons coming on trains from the infected territory to go on.

The discovery of gold appears to have become fashionable. The Klondike fever is spreading through the country and already a spirit of rivalry has been developed. The telegraph wires are growing warm with the reports of new finds, and the estimates of assays are going up as the thermometer goes down.

An enthusiastic determination to "push things" was manifested at a meeting of the Advisory Board of the Merchants' Association yesterday. This was the first meeting of the full board since July, and the work and prospects of the association were discussed with a great deal of interest. There was a unanimous sentiment in favor of continuing the efforts to bring out of town buyers to this city. President King presided.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 7. -- The efforts to evict the striking miners of the Pittsburg and Chicago Gas Coal Company at Orangeville, one and a half miles from Gastonville, resulted in a riot and the failure of the company to accomplish its object.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 7. -- Lawrence Liedwiett was arrested in this city last week for intoxication. On Thursday last he became violent, and the doctors decided to give him medicine. About a pint of whisky and the medicine were mixed up and then given to Liedwiet in doses. Liedweit did not awaken on Thursday night, and continued to sleep.

Thirty applicants, most of them women, for positions as special teachers of manual training will meet in the College of the City of New York to-day to take a competitive examination which will establish an addition to the New York public school system such as no city in the country has had before. It will mean an increased expenditure of $20,000 a year for the city.

In treating of this subject, I have no idea to proceed on lines such as, per example, The New York Sun follows, or, rather, rudderlessly flounders in. That paper sports the name of a beneficent luminary, whose rays give light and heat and growth through all terrestrial nature and perpetually build up and change and sustain the harmonious unit we admire as the organic world.

In an open letter to Mr. Low which appears in congruous environment upon the editorial page of our neighbor The Sun Mr. CHARLES F. HARPER slates the Platt position with an unaffected narrowness of view and a simple faith in the potency of flapdoodle that should at once win for him the place of ship's writer aboard the Platt craft.

ALBANY, Sept. 7. -- The State Board of Equalization held its annual meeting in this city to-day and adopted the table of equalization prepared by the State Tax Commissioners. Tile Board of Equalization is composed of Lieut. Gov. Woodruff, as Chairman; Speaker James M.E. O'Grady, Secretary of State Palmer, Controller Roberts, Attorney General Hancock, State Engineer and Surveyor Campbell W. Adams, State Treasurer Colvin, and Tax Commissioners Heermance, Adams, and Jenkins.

The wheat market was as firm yesterday at good advances in quotations as it has been on any day since the demands on the United States as a furnisher of cereals to other countries became evident. The trading was not active; in fact, it sagged in the early afternoon, but it was based on strong sentiment and the knowledge of excellent export business.

On paper the card for the second day of the Grand Circuit meeting at Fleetwood looked promising. There were sixty-one names on the card for the three purses, which amounted to $7,000, but the fields narrowed down to about a third of the total number eligible.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- The Treasury Department to-day made public the following letter, dated at Dyea. Aug. 22, received from a Government official now in Alaska, on the way to the gold helds. The department states that the writer of the letter, whose name is withheld has been twelve years in the Government's service, and is thoroughly reliable.

The New York Post Office Department is being visited by Postmaster General James A. Gary, who is making a tour of the important offices of the country in the interests of improved mail facilities in the large cities.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 7. -- It is unofficially announced that Dr. Andrews will insist upon the acceptance of his resignation from the Presidency of Brown University. This decision was arrived at after a conference this afternoon between Dr. Andrews and the Advisory and Executive Committees of the corporations. His connection with the Cosmopolitan University, it is thought, will take up too much time to permit of his devoting his attention to both universities.

Because a carpenter charged too much for some repair, Richard Wolff, forty-one years old, of 318 East Eighteenth Street, the owner of a dozen tenement houses and a large fortune in Government bonds, lost his reason last night and is now a raving maniac in the insane pavilion at Bellevue Hospital.

LENOX, Sept. 7. -- The Lenox golf links were thronged to-day by an enthusiastic company which watched the rounds of the sixteen players who qualified yesterday to play for the Ambassador's Cup given by Baron Thielmann. A large number of the cottagers and their guests followed the players around the links.

MATAWAN, N.J., Sept. 7. -- The community of Morristown, three miles west of this place, comprising School District No. 1 of Madison Township, Morris County, is wrought up with excitement over the burning of its new schoolhouse some time last night. The building was in the hands of Contractor David B. Arrowsmith, and would have been turned over to the Board of Trustees either to-day or to-morrow.
The American Line steamship New York, which arrived yesterday from Southampton, brought a large number of returning American tourists, many prominent persons being among them.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7. -- Secretary Wilson was at his desk in the Agricultural Department to-day for the first time for a month, having just returned from his tour of the trans-Mississippi States.

The Rev. Richard Carroll, Sunday school missionary of the American Baptist Publication Society, one of the most widely known colored ministers in the South, was in New York yesterday. He said that in South Carolina and Florida, in which States he travels constantly, there is a remarkable increase of prosperity among the people of his race.

It is very curious how the Cretan question, which six months ago seemed to constitute the Eastern question, has dropped to an insignificant incident of that question. The announcement that the blockading fleet will be withdrawn, since a satisfactory settlement has been arrived at, if it had been made in the beginning, would possibly have saved all the trouble and all the bloodshed that have occurred since.

Assistant Secretary of the Navy Theodore Roosevelt has received this letter from S. Spencer, President of the Southern Railway Company, in which the latter sets forth the claim of Birmingham for the proposed location of the Government's new armor-plate plant. The letter follows:

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 7. -- City officials are considering the question of inviting refugees from the infected yellow fever districts to come to Lookout Mountain. It is claimed that the disease cannot exist at that elevation, and that it would be the part of humanity to provide a place of refuge for the frightened Southerners.

NEWARK, Sept. 7. -- Charles H. Rosseter of 935 Bergen Street is awaiting the result of an assayer's examination to find out if he has found a gold mine in this city. He owns property on Murray Street, and some time ago began to excavate. The contractor went down through nine feet of ordinary sand, which was sold for building purpose.
SEATTLE, Washington, Sept. 7. -- After an examination of thirty days of the Skaguay trail, R.H. Stretch, mining engineer, of this city says:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- Senator Foraker of Ohio and Senator Harris of Kansas, who are members of a sub-committee appointed by the Pacific Railroad Committee of the Senate last May to inquire into the Sinking Fund of the Union and Central Pacific Railroads and other minor questions, held an informal meeting here to-day.

DUBOIS, Penn., Sept. 8. -- The striking miners of the Clearfield and Jefferson Coal Mining Company held a meeting to-day and received the report of the committee which conferred with General Manager Robinson yesterday. The agreement entered into by the committee and Mr. Robinson was ratified by the miners and they will return to work to-morrow morning.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- In his last report to the Surgeon General of the Marine Hospital Service Sanitary Inspector Brunner, at Havana, complains of the number of persons who apply for certificates to go to the United States, but who are not admissible under the regulations. He gives the following illustration:

Stock market strong. Jiust before the close of yesterday's business on the Stock Exchange the room trading element, still bearish, made a concerted raid on the whole list, with the result that a slight reaction was brought about, leaving final figures somewhat irregular, though relatively nine out of ten of the important changes were advances.

The Jersey City Street and Water Commissioners yesterday received a proposition to rent the South Cove property for the storage of boats during the Winter. The Commissioners refused to give the name of the person who made the offer, but said he was a prominent owner of tugboats and barges and offered a liberal rental. Pending other arrangements a lease will probably be given to him until next Spring.

It is rather surprising to find so reasonable a man as Mr. PROCTER, the President of the Civil Service Commission, coming out as an advocate of Hawaiian annexation. Yet this is what he does, in the current number of The Forum, in an article entitled "Hawaii and the Changing Front of the World."

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 8. -- The match between the eight winners of yesterday's games at the golf links to-day was very interesting and exciting. Earnest Thomson and John S. Hoyt played off their draw game early in the morning, and Thomson was the winner.

FAIR GROUND, L.I., Sept. 8. -- The interposition of a material husband and an actual and active club last night left Mrs. Mortimer Brown of this town a depressed and subjugated woman, and gave her reason to be thankful during the remainder of her life.

The steamship Teutonic docked early yesterday morning, having arrived in port the preceding night, after the remarkably fast run of 5 days 17 hours and 22 minutes from Daunt's Rock to Sandy Hook Lightship, covering a course of 2,784 knots.

FREEPORT, L.I., Sept. 8. -- When B. Frank Rhodes of this village went to call on a young lady to whom he is much devoted on the evening of Labor Day, he found a rival in possession of the premises and of the girl's attention.

WASHINGTONG, Sept. 8. -- Before September has passed the Lighthouse Board expects to have in position on the Diamond Shoals, off Cape Hatteras, the new light vessel which has just been fitted out at Staten Island, N.Y.

About a dozen protests relating to the application, under the old tariff law, of duties on imported paintings and statuary were laid before United States General Appraisers Somerville, Wilkinson, and Ham --- comprising Board A -- at their stated hearing yesterday. H.H. Meier imported from Berlin last July a number of squares and ovals of porcelain on which there were paintings in oil.
Mr. Archer Brown of the firm of Rogers, Brown Co., who is regarded as an authority on iron trade conditions, said yesterday to a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES:

There are several versions of the story about the misbehavior of National Guardsmen returning from the rifle range at Creedmoor a few days ago. None of these stories was originally very definite in its statement of the facts in the case, but there is good ground for believing that some soldiers, few or many, were guilty of conduct which was a disgrace to the service.

FALL RIVER, Sept. 8. -- Miss Grace Hartley, a Vassar College girl, a member of a prominent family here, (a granddaughter of Cook Borden,) has been bequeathed property to the value of about $30,000 by her father, Dr. J.W. Hartley, who died Aug. 2 last. Miss Hartley's two brothers were cut off with a legacy of $1 each, and her mother is left nothing, (save by a previous settlement.)

I have long indulged in the suspicion that there was a growing Teutonic revolt against the arrogant assumptions of the Wagnerians. In years past in Northern and Central Germany I had often heard doubts expressed about the staying power of the compositions of their din-producing god, but was not prepared for unfavorable comment by the wholesale, such as I lately heard at Munich while the Mark-catching show was in progress at Baireuth.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 8. -- Supreme Court Justice J.O. Dykman to-day filed his decision in the matter of the suit of John E. Drake against the New York Suburban Water Company. The plaintiff has succeeded, by assignment, to all of the rights of the owner of ten shares of the capital stock of the New York and Mount Vernon Water Company, which was organized to supply the then village of Mount Vernon with water.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8. -- The defense in the trial of Adolph L. Luetgert for wife murder was surprised by a move of the State today. What is considered to be one of the strongest pieces of evidence in the trial was introduced, Mrs. Christine Feldt, who was once Luetgert's sweetheart, was called to the stand by the State for the third time.

One million and seventy-eight thousand pounds of wool of all grades were sold at the second auction sale, held yesterday, at the Wool Exchange, and the amount realized footed up in the vicinity of $300,000. The attendance at the sale was not so large as at the one previous, which took place Aug. 18, but there were present more actual buyers and fewer onlookers.

SANTA FE, Sept. 8. -- Major Neerdstrom, Pueblo Indian Agent, returned to-day from Zuni, where he examined the reported torturing case. He says that the outrages have been committed by Chief Niope and the fanatics known as the "priests of the bow."

The scandal-loving Hungarians have a sensation now which is just after the heart of that "paprika" eating nation. The sacred bones of their ancient Kings have gone astray from the vaults in the old "Kronungsstadt" of Stuhlweissenburg, and no one seems to know where they are. This plundering of the royal tombs has been going on for years without any steps being taken to prevent it.

BIRMINGHAM, England, Sept. 8. -- The Trades Union Congress at its session today adopted a resolution setting forth that the conspiracy laws, as applied to workers, are "indefinite, ambiguous, and generally unsatisfactory," and urged the Parliamentary Committee to promote a bill having for its object the reform of the jury system, so as to make it possible for all workers having no legal disabilities to act as jurymen in all civil and criminal cases.

It will cost nearly $7,000,000 to run the schools of the City of New York during the year 1808. The Finance Committee of the Board of Education reported to the regular meeting of the board yesterday that, owing to the extra work involved by the new salary system, the establishment of high schools, and the introduction of manual training into the curriculum, the budget would not be ready for report until the next meeting.

Richard Croker was at Sheepshead Bay yesterday, to take up his broken thread of American turf matters. He was the centre of attraction in the clubhouse, where he was surrounded by a crowd of friends who welcomed his return, and during the better part of the afternoon he was kept busy telling of his racing and other experiences abroad.

The City Tax Commissioners gave the Deputy Tax Commissioners their instructions yesterday morning, before the latter started out to assess real and personal property for the taxes of the coming year. They were called into President Barker's office and were addressed in turn by Mr. Barker and Commissioners Wells and Sutro. Mr. Barker said, in part:

Jesse C. Bennett Co. have sold for James and William Bradley to a Mr. Woodward, for about $67,500, the five-story American basement brick and gray stone dwelling now in course of construction on Riverside Drive, 62 feet north of Eighty-sixth Street. The house is 23 by 60, with an extension 10 by 16, on a lot 23 by 100.

Sunday cycle racing may be recognized by the League of American Wheelmen next season if several recent developments may be so interpreted. President Isaac B. Potter of the L.A.W. is expected home a week from to-day, and it is more than probable that he will try for renomination to the League Presidency.

Register William Sohmer, who has been talked of so much as the possible Democratic candidate for Mayor, did not preside last night at the meeting of the Tammany Committee on Organization, of which he is Chairman.

Ten men vested with the power to increase or diminish at their pleasure or caprice the burden of taxation imposed upon the people of this State sat about a table in Albany on Tuesday and in a very few minutes "equalized" the assessed valuation of four and one-half billions of dollars' worth of real estate belonging to the inhabitants of the sixty counties of the State of New York.
EMPORIA, Kan., Sept. 8. -- One of the worst wrecks in the history of the Santa Fe Railroad occurred three miles east of here at 7:30 o'clock to-night.

As soon as the Citizens' Union Executive Committee shall have received Seth Low's letter of acceptance, action will be taken in regard to the nomination of a Controller and President of the Council. Unlike the nomination of a Mayor, which was made by union conference committees representing the Boroughs of Manhattan, the Bronx, Queens, and Richmond, the vacant places on the municipal ticket will be filled by the Committee of Organization.

The varnishers yesterday began their fight to enforce the payment of union wages on buildings, and strikes were ordered in the shops of Baumgarten Co., D.S. Hess Co., Kimball Co., and Pottier Stymus. Should any non-union varnishers be put to work the Board of Walking Delegates will order general strikes.

There was a fatal affray on the Bowery at Chatham Square, early yesterday morning in which William C. Sayers, who had been enjoying a spree, killed with a blow of the fist a man who had helped to rob him.

The New York ball team made another "hurricane finish" in its game with the Pittsburgs yesterday afternoon, winning out when a defeat seemed imminent. It was not exactly a "grand contest." There were too many errors. The fielders of both teams made some ludicrous misplays on easy chances, but the finale was the redeemable feature of the game.

In regard to the extensive underground electrical construction now being carried on by the Metropolitan Traction Company, President Vreeland said yesterday: "We have 6,000 men at work on the Fourth and Madison Avenue line, and expect to have electric cars in operation from Astor Place to the Grand Central Station and to reopen the remainder of the line with horse cars temporarily next month.
SARATOGA, Sept. 8. -- The Saratoga County Republican Convention to-day renominated Assemblyman George W. Kavanaugh of Waterford.

The delay of Col. McCoskry Butt of the Twelfth Regiment in forwarding to State headquarters the resignation of Capt. Bleecker S. Bernard of Company D of that regiment is causing comment among the men. The comment is only among the men, for as a general thing the officers know the reason for it.

The plan of union of the Equitable Gaslight and New York and East River Gas Companies and the agreement incident thereto with the depositary for securities, the Central Trust Company, was issued yesterday.

A session of the New England Passenger Association was held in the rooms of the Transportation Club, at the Hotel Manhattan, yesterday, for the purpose of considering an application for reduced rates from all New England points to New York for the benefit of non-resident members of the Merchants' Association.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- Surgeon General Wyman says the yellow fever situation looks decidedly more hopeful to-day. No new cases have been officially reported to him, although there are newspaper reports of three new cases at Biloxi, Miss., but this afternoon he received the following reassuring telegram in answer to a message asking Dr. Lemon, President of the Board of Health at Biloxi, concerning the report:

It is really a matter for National pride that the eastward and westward records between Southampton and New York are now both held by American-built ships. The St. Paul has for more than a year held the latter, and the St. Louis, by the fine passage which was concluded yesterday morning, takes the other.

CONCORD, N.H., Sept. 8. -- Senator J.H. Gallinger of New Hampshire has made public an open letter in reply to a communication from Carl Schurz, recently published, in which Mr. Schurz took issue with Mr. Gallinger on statements made by the latter bearing on civil service reform.
MONTREAL, Sept. 8. -- It is possible the Canadian Government will take action to restrict the exportation of nickel to the United States.

Consul General Fitzhugh Lee, accompanied by his son, Fitzhugh Lee, Jr., arrived yesterday from Havana on the Ward Line steamship Seguranca. They left at once for West Point to call on the General's son, George M. Lee, who is a cadet, and they were to return last night to proceed at once to Washington.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 8. -- The Inter-State Miners' Convention adjourned this evening until to-morrow without having taken a vote on the question of accepting or rejecting the proposed settlement of the strike.

WEST PORTAL, N.J., Sept. 8. -- No money came to-day to pay the Italian laborers who have been working on the mysterious wall and building which were to be erected on Dr. Petrie's place. This morning about 500 of the Italians refused to go to work, and threatened trouble. They made all kinds of threats, and went to the railroad station, about which they gathered.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 8. -- When the Board of Health met to-night Dr. Oliphant had no additional cases of fever to report to that body as having occurred in New Orleans, and was able to say that the local situation had vastly improved, and that there were no present prospects of evil results following the death of the Gelpi child.

It was evident before the Grand Circuit meeting at Fleetwood Park had fairly begun that the fields would be rather light for the last week of the series. The purses, with two exceptions are on the installment plan, and the horses were named several months ago, when the first payments were made.

BOSTON, Sept. 8. -- St. Louis could not hit Klobedanz effectively after the first inning to-day. The latter was magnificently supported, while just the opposite was the case with Pitcher Hart. The redeeming feature of the visitors' playing was the fine work of Cross at short. Lowe, Hamilton, Stahl, and Duffy excelled in fielding, and Lowe and Tenney did the best batting for the Bostons. Score:

The Venezuela Boundary Commission was less than a year in existence, having been appointed Jan. 1, 1896, and notified by Secretary of State OLNEY on Dec. 28 of the same year, with the assurance of the highest appreciation by the President of "the diligence, skill, and effectiveness" with which its labors had been conducted, that there was no further occasion for the prosecution of those labors.

An insidious and cruel, and therefore reprehensible, method of promoting departure to the Klondike appears to be receiving encouragement from sundry newspapers supposed to be animated simply by a spirit of enterprise and openhanded generosity. An offer is made by the practicers of this method of travel to the Klondike to send to that section of the far Northwest the persons receiving the largest number of ballots cut from purchased copies of the enterprising newspapers.

The sub-committee of the Republican Conference Committees of Greater New York met at County Committee Headquarters, 1 Madison Avenue, last night, and issued the following call for the City Convention:
Charles Griffith Moses has sold for the Ernst-Marx syndicate the two four-story American basement dwellings, 183 and 185 Convent Avenue, each 16 by 40 by 50.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- Churchville, a small village a few miles west of Rochester, was aroused early this morning by a burglary, and what will probably prove to be a murder. Mrs. George Smith was shot, the bullet passing through the ear and lodging in the back of the head. When discovered she was in a very critical condition.
TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- The Greenburgh Town Assessors held their last session to-day.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., Sept. 9. -- The Tower Cottage, a well-known boarding place here much patronized by New York people, has been the scene of exciting episodes and complications during the last three days.

William Higbie, twenty-six years old, a negro, who for the past year has been employed as butler by the Rev. Edward Wallace Neil, rector of the Episcopal Church of St. Edward the Martyr, at Fifth Avenue and One Hundred and Ninth Street, and living at 14 East One Hundred and Ninth Street, is under arrest at Police Headquarters.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 9. -- Sheray Seymour died at 1 o'clock this morning at Ocean Springs of the prevailing fever. As soon as his death was reported, arrangements were made to hold an autopsy this morning. Doctors Guiteras, Murray, Carter, and Wasdin, of the Marine Hospital Service, and Doctors Lehman, Dunn, Gant, and Bailey were present.

BIRMINGHAM, England, Sept. 9. -- The trades Union Congress to-day adopted a resolution recommending all societies affiliated with the congress, by all means possible, to restrict or abolish overtime in their respective trades. The following resolution was then passed:

The Citizens' Union Executive Committee met last night and received the resignation of C.C. Nadal as Chairman of the Committee on Speakers and Meetings. Mr. Nadal's reason for resigning was that he will not have time to attend to the duties of the place now that the campaign is open and the Chairmanship will demand constant attention.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- Dr. Guiteras, the yellow fever expert, telegraphed late last night from Ocean Springs to Surgeon General Wyman as follows: "Have seen to-day 25 cases of dengue. Will withhold opinion about three other cases. There are 38 sick in town. Three new cases."
Some of our Canadian brethren appear to be in full possession of their senses while reading the stories of wonderful gold finds in the far Northwest.

The Cincinnatis lost yesterday's game to the Brooklyns at Eastern Park because of their inability to solve Kennedy's curves. Rhines also pitched a good game, but he was poorly supported at critical periods. Score:

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 9. -- News just received from Guatemala is to the effect that the country is in a bad way financially and politically. During last month the following failures were reported: Frederico Chacon, $800,000; Lorenzo Eissen, $1,700,000; Enrique Mentze, $1,300,000; Ascoli Co., $1,000,000; Bauer Co., $800,000, and Victor Mattheus, $2,000,000.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- The three offices in this city of the International Commission Company, bankers and brokers, of which John C. Allen is Treasurer, were closed to-day. Mr. Allen was seen later and said he had decided to close out his business. If his customers would give him a little time, he said, they would be paid in full.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Sept. 9. -- George Akin, aged twenty-four, was instantly killed last night at Hudson by taking hold with his bare hands of a ratchet handle used to lower electric lamps to the street to insert new carbons. Akin and several young friends stood in front of the saloon of Timothy, McGraw, on North Second Street, and watched some boys playing around the corner, where a lamp is located.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Sept. 9. -- The first steps in a bitter struggle between the Erie Railroad and John B. Lozier, a millionaire resident of Oradell, have been taken by the latter. The Erie Railroad recently obtained control of the New Jersey and New York Railroad. The single track of the New Jersey and New York Railroad passed in front of the property of Mr. Lozier.

FORT MONROE, Va., Sept. 9. -- The Dolphin returned to Hampton Roads to-day with Assistant Secretary Roosevelt, who has just completed an inspection of the North Atlantic squadron at sea and while under full fleet manoeuvres. This is the first inspection made in recent years under such conditions, and the results were highly satisfactory.

It is understood that the naval officers recently appointed by Secretary LONG to prepare plans for the erection of an armor plant to be operated by the United States Government are prepared to make their report. If the Government is earnest in its purpose to enter upon a new field of manufacture it is open to the sharpest criticism.

J.M. Ward, assistant to the Corporation Counsel, will at once commence suit for the city to procure a mandamus compelling the reconvening of the State Board of Equalization to hear the protest of New York against the increased assessment of $88,988,103. As Mr. Ward has charge of the tax division of the Law Department, the case against the board naturally falls into his hands.

WAVERLY, N.J., Sept. 9. -- There was an exciting scene this afternoon in the first heat of the 2:26 class trot at the Waverly State Fair. Manassa Boy of the Windsor Stock Farms of Farmingdale, Penn., was trotting well and steadily and traveling fourth as the horses scared the quarter pole. William E. Smith of Middletown, Del., was in the sulky. Behind him were seven other horses, and the whole eleven were bunched well.
LONDON, Sept. 10. -- Mrs. Mary Anderson Navarro, according to The Daily Mail, may appear on the concert platform in London this Autumn.

The Republicans of New York held two State Conventions in 1896, one in this city on March 24 to choose delegates at large to the National Convention, and one in Saratoga on Aug. 25 to nominate candidates for State offices.

An indignation meeting of west side citizens and property owners to protest against the use of four surface car tracks in Amsterdam Avenue was held last evening in the new parish house of St. Michael's Church in West Ninety-ninth Street. The meeting, which was a very lively one, was attended by about 500 citizens, and all the public institutions in the vicinity were represented.

There is serious discord in the Ninth Regiment, National Guard, between Col. William Seward and Capt. S.S. O'Connor, commanding Company A, the largest company in the regiment. The present trouble resulted from an investigation on a charge of fraudulent scoring, made by some members of Company K against Company A at Creedmoor last Spring.

James R. Willard Co. of 55,280, and 1,227 Broadway, a firm that advertised as bankers, brokers, and commission merchants of Philadelphia, Buffalo, Chicago, Washington, Toronto, Montreal, and New York, collapsed on Wednesday. Yesterday it was announced that the firm had assigned to its chief bookkeeper, James L. Starbuck, with preferences for $20,000 to William H. Osterhout of Ridgway.

-- With the kindly intention, no doubt, of proving our possession of prophetic powers, The Tribune agonizes beautifully over Lord KELVIN'S suggestion that Niagara should and will be harnessed and set to work. It says all the proper and inevitable things about the cataract's aesthetic value, and does its best to denounce any further utilization of the river's energy without condemning the amount of utilization already accomplished.

Jockey Sims has shown an inclination in most of his races recently to bear in on horses that might prove dangerous at the finish, and this habit cost Archduke the purse money in the first race at Sheepshead Bay yesterday, and incidentally called down upon the jockey's head the anger of thousands of spectators.

Capt. R. Hoag, Inspector of Rifle Practice of the Twenty-third Regiment, N.G.N.Y., who arranged a contest of marksmanship between a team chosen from the regiment and some Georgia regimental marksmen, said last night the match would be shot on the regular range of the Georgia men, near Savannah, on Thanksgiving Day.

Has the State Board of Equalization been guilty of trickery as well as of injustice? There is pretty good ground for the belief that its table of equalized values was made up without that inquiry into the facts that the law requires and was adopted not after the usual deliberation, but at a "snap" session in order to deprive the New York City Assessors of the opportunity of appearance and protest.
BUDA-PESTH, Sept. 9. -- Francois Aurele Pulszky, the archaeologist and publicist, is dead.

Exhilarated from an outing with a merry party of nimrods, Druggist George S. Stolzenburg of 290 East Fifty-second Street went whistling into his apartments over his drug store yesterday. He carried a string of fish with him, and in his exuberance of feeling over his excellent sport was prepared to regale his wife with narratives of the day.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- Mary Crowley, who keeps a saloon at Penny Bridge, a short distance from this place, is in a precarious condition as the result of a beating she received last night at the hands of a burglar who was searching her house for money.

The double bill between the New Yorks and Pittsburgs did not result in a double victory as most rooters expected. The Pirates are not so easy after all, and they captured the first game after a close struggle.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- Beautiful weather, clear and warm, favored the shooters at Fort Niagara to-day. The firing was at 200, 300, 500, and 600 yards. Sergt. Branham, Sixth Infantry, made the top score of the day, 184 out of a possible 200. At the 200-yard range Sergt. Linder, Corps of Engineers, made the maximum score, and Corp. Smith, Seventeenth Infantry, made nineteen successive bull's eyes.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 9. -- Mrs. Jane Murphy, a widow, forty-nine years old, living at White Plains Park, was brought to the hospital here this afternoon. She had received a charge of No. 6 shot in the left side of her face, left arm and hand. For some time she had been annoyed by men and boys who had been stealing her peaches.

Justice Andrews of the Supreme Court has appointed N.B. Hoxie special guardian of some of the heirs to the estate of Henry Keteltas, who have been declared incompetents, in a suit brought against the heirs of the Keteltas estate by Eugene K. Smith, one of the heirs of John Gardner, to recover his proportionate share -- $230,040.39 -- which, he asserts, the city paid to Keteltas for grouted used for Corlears Hook Park.

Several good golfers in the big tournament of the Westbrook Golf Club, at Islip, L.I., had to drop out of the competition for the Westbrook Cup yesterday. Of the sixteen who qualified on the first day for the trophy, the finish of the contest yesterday saw only four left, but they are all expert players, and will make the semi-final round to-day a hot one.

Superintendent Jasper said yesterday that probably 7,000 or 8,000 applicants for admission to the public schools will be turned away Monday for lack of room. The crowding is in the tenement districts, where new and larger schools are in course of construction. He corrected his estimate of the day before by saying that he anticipated a first-day enrollment of nearly 225,000.
COMO, Italy, Sept. 9. -- The trial of fraudulent bankrupts in connection with the liquidation of the Bank of Como was brought to a conclusion to-day.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9. -- The attention of Senor Julio Rengifo, the representative of the Republic of Colombia, was called to-day to reports that Colombia had granted a concession to England to complete the Panama Canal, thus transferring that enterprise from French to English hands. Senor Rengifo said he had received no information from his Government on the subject, as the canal project did not come within the jurisdiction of the representative in Washington.

Nearly all the cycle racers who were attracted to this section by the Quill Club's big meet have remained near the city and will be seen to-day in the National Circuit meet on the Waverly Park track, Newark, in competition for purses offered by the New Jersey Agricultural Society to provide a feature for its annual State Fair.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 9. -- A local newspaper this afternoon published an interview with Edward H. Dillon, of the firm of E.H. Dillon Co., Bridgeport, on the political campaign in New York. Mr. Dillon was a passenger from England on the steamer with Mr. Croker.

A respectable minority always has a right to be heard, and of all minorities none is more respectable than that which is opposed to the musical works of RICHARD WAGNER. It has the respectability of conservatism and of attachment to artistic standards once believed to be the highest in opera.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 9. -- The work of evicting the striking miners at Plum Creek and Clarksville was begun to-day, and as the result of two evictions serious trouble is threatened by a mob of women, who are armed with clubs and baseball bats, and are awaiting the arrival of Superintendent De Armitt and the Deputy Sheriffs.

We were greatly edified but somewhat startled to read in the issue of THE TIMES for Sept. 6 a resolution passed by the Woman's Rescue League (appalling name) of Boston, on the "American Bachelor Politician." We had no idea two such unique evils existed. Our sympathies, we confess, are all with the bachelor politician.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 9. -- One of the most interesting features of the Gold Democratic Convention to-day was the address of William D. Bynum of Indiana on the money question. The address was received with great favor by the convention.

The General Democratic Conference Committee of the Greater New York met last night in the large ballroom of the Hoffman House, adopted the report of the sub-committee calling the City Convention for Sept. 30 agreed upon last week, and selected the Industrial Building, (Grand Central Palace,) Lexington Avenue, Forty-third and Forty-fourth Streets, as the place for the convention.

The cereal market was stronger yesterday than it has been for a fortnight, and every staple made a notable advance. Satisfactory expert business and urgent inquiry for prompt offers of wheat offset lower cables. The demand for wheat in Russia was a factor as well as the knowledge of the non-fulfillment of contracts for export by several local concerns.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 9. -- It is possible that at some early future date it may be "Chattanooga, Ga.," instead of "Chattanooga, Tenn." In 1818 a survey was made by civil engineers representing Georgia and Tennessee, and the boundary established about one mile and twenty-eight rods south of the banks of the Tennessee River.

EMPORIA, Kan., Sept. 9. -- Eleven known dead, one missing, and fourteen injured, two of whom probably will die, is the record of last night's collision on the Santa Fe. The first lists were inaccurate because of the confusion attending the wreck. Even to-night it is not certain that the list given is complete, as it is believed that several persons were burned to death and nothing was left by which they could be recognized.

The visit of Postmaster General Gary to this city, which has been the occasion for a thorough inspection of the New York postal service, was brought to a close yesterday morning when, accompanied by his wife and family, he left for Washington.

Mrs. Grace Mann, thirty-five years old, of 354 West Fifty-sixth Street, and her servant, Walter Wieckes, thirty-seven years of age, were arraigned in Yorkville Court yesterday, charged with stealing gas from the Consolidated Gas Company. An Inspector for the gas company testified that Wieckes had met him and a collector of the company at the door of Mrs. Mann's flat on Aug. 27, with a gas meter in his hand.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 9. -- The miners' convention remained in executive session until late this afternoon, adjourning until tomorrow morning without having taken a vote on the proposed settlement. President Ratchford said to an Associated Press representative to-night:

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 9. -- The furnace operators have announced another advance in pig iron, which brings No. 1 foundry to $7.75. With another 25 cents' raise the miners will get an advance of 2 1/2 cents, according to the sliding scale contract between them and the operators. Mill iron stocks are low, owing to the resumption of work at rolling mills and the advance in finished iron has stimulated pig.

Mr. John W. Doane, one of the receivers of the Union Pacific system, and a business man whose wide experience and large interests are everywhere recognized, talked yesterday to a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES regarding Western business conditions. Mr. Doane is confident of further improvement throughout the country, although deprecating a too rapid expansion of trade. Mr. Doane said:

BURLINGTON, N.J., Sept. 9. -- The Coroner's inquest in the case of August Mueller, alleged to have died three weeks ago, brought in a verdict to-day of death from apoplexy caused by excessive drinking.
Handicapper Vosburgh has assigned the following weights for the Great Eastern Handicap, of $5,000, for two-year-olds, to be run over the Futurity course at Sheepshead Bay to-morrow:
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 9. -- The National Democrats of Ohio in their convention to-day nominated the above State ticket.

The ancient Kingdom of Judea was overthrown by the Romans in the year 70 A.D. The entire country of Palestine was annexed to the Roman Empire, its Government was abolished, its surviving inhabitants became politically merged in the general population of the empire; Judea ceased to be a nation.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 10. -- Some important testimony was taken in the Gould-Angell case here to-day before McDonald Vanwagner, referee, in the presence of Miss Helen M. Gould, her private secretary, and her counsel, D.D. Duncan, of Dillon Hubbard of New York, and E. Fowler, local counsel.

On Mr. Robert C. Leslie has devolved the duty of adding to that excellent biography written by his father, C.R. Leslie, R.A., which presented the life of John Constable, the well-known English landscape painter. It so happens that Mr. Robert C. Leslie, who is an artist, was in his youth a favorite of Constable's.

Time, says the Latin poet, is the consumer of things. It ever eats up opportunity. It is rather rapidly making way with the opportunity of the Citizens' Union to complete its nominations and get its full ticket into the field under the most advantageous conditions.

BOSTON, Sept. l0. -- The American Board of Foreign Missions, whose eighty-eighth annual meeting will be held in New Haven Oct. 12 to 15, has received the last annual report of its Madura Mission, in Southern India. The report shows that the work of this mission covers an area of 10,700 square miles.
SARATOGA, Sept. 10. -- It was 92 in the shade, the warmest September day on record for Saratoga.

The New Yorks and Pittsburgs played a draw game at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon before 2,000 perspiring "rooters." When Umpire O'Day called the game at the end of the ninth inning on account of darkness, with the score 2 all, the players of both teams thought it was the best decision O'Day had made during the entire game, as they suffered considerably from the heat.

Before the war -- 1856, 1859, 1860, and so on -- I used to dine very often with Mr. and Mrs. Bancroft at their delightful villa is Newport, which was always the scene of an elegant and quiet hospitality. I now recall (with the aid of my little book) one dinner at which Mme. de Limburg, (Belle Cass,) the daughter of Gen. Cass, was present.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 10. -- According to expectations, George A. Smith, husband of the woman who was shot at Churchville yesterday morning, was arrested at 9 o'clock to-day. The arrest was made by Deputy Sheriffs Salyerd and Hawley and Detective Muir on the complaint of Sheriff Schroth. Smith was taken before Justice J.D. Wright, and was charged with assault in the first degree.

PARIS, Aug. 23. -- The publication of M. Maurice Barres's novel, "Les Deracines," is a political as well as a literary event. For a year or two past, it has become the custom in France to write novels in which living or recently deceased personages are referred to under a thin disguise. The stage has also received numerous contributions of this sort.

HOMBURG, Sept. 10. -- Emperor William to-day personally commanded the attacking force in the army manoeuvres, all the troops being engaged against an imaginary army. After the manoeuvres the Emperor decorated Gens. von Schuffen, von Haeseler, and von Wittich with the Order of the Black Eagle.

The most striking development yesterday in the political situation in Brooklyn was that indicated by the cry of "Treachery" in the State organization raised by the Platt leaders against Jacob Worth. Up to yesterday the charge was spoken of only by way of inference; yesterday Woodruff and Willis openly declared that Worth had tried to disrupt the State organization. Seth Low's Candidacy for the time being became a secondary consideration.

Last week the Buffalo Public Library was formally opened. This is the first free public library that city has ever had. The library itself has been in existence several years, under the management of a Young Men's Association, and it was largely through the public-spirited acts of its members that it was turned over to the city for the free use of the public.

OTTER POINT, B. C., Sept. 10. -- The steamer Cleveland has arrived from St. Michael, bringing with her from the Yukon gold fields a lot of miners who tell a story of distress and disaster which the officers of the ship confirm.

On the summit of Mont St. Michel on the French coast, there will be placed a gigantic statue in bronze of an archangel. It may be remembered how Impressive was the model of this, executed by M. Fremiet, exhibited in the Salon of 1896. There always has been a statue on this Mont St. Michel, and it is supposed that Milton's line.

BOSTON, Sept. 10. -- An early passenger train on the Fitchburg Railroad was partially wrecked near Union Square, Somerville, this morning. The accident resulted from a collision between a switching engine and the engine of the passenger train, and both engines and several cars were damaged to an amount of $18,000. Some delay to traffic resulted.

At Urbino, his native place, a statue of Raphael was unveiled on Aug. 22 in the presence of the Italian Ministers of Public Instruction and a large gathering of people. The statue is the work of the sculptor Belli of Turin. The figure of Raphael stands upon a massive granite pedestal. He is represented in his working dress in the attitude of contemplating from afar the effect of one of his works.

-- Georgia and Tennessee, instead of arguing about the ownership of Chattanoonga, a process that will decide nothing, should take the steps necessary for settling this eminently interesting question. It is, fortunately, a very simple one. The boundary between the two States is the thirty-fifth parallel of latitude, and any sea Captain, active or retired, could determine in ten minutes whether the city is north or south of that line.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 10. -- The National Encampment of the Sons of Veterans this afternoon took up for consideration the question of history, as taught in the public schools. A resolution proposed by Past Commander Armstrong of Indiana, was unanimously adopted, declaring that there is necessity for reform of a radical nature in the school histories, to the end that the story of the rebellion may be related without prejudice in favor of the South.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10. -- The United States Treasury is actually threatened with an embarrassment of gold. The gold reserve now amounts to $145,000,000, and in the natural order of events the stock will be increased during the next six months. At the same time the National revenues are failing short of expenditures, and the total available surplus is being eaten into at an uncomfortably rapid rate.

There will be no scarcity of interesting reading material for children during the coming months, for most of the publishers are now announcing attractive books for the holiday season. E.P. Dutton Co., who make a specialty of artistic books, have a number of excellent ones which will shortly be seen on the market.

President Moss of the Police Board said yesterday that he had almost completed a thorough investigation of the poolrooms in New York, and had in a measure succeeded in closing them up. He was led to make the investigation, he said, because he had received complaints of the places, in which charges were made against police officers.

BOSTON, Sept. 10. -- Bernard Treacy, the well-known turfman of Lexington, Ky., who was injured by an accidental fall in this city Wednesday night, was resting comfortably at the City Hospital to-day, although his ease is still considered critical.

UPSALA, Sweden, Aug. 29. -- That air of provinciality which lies heavy on a country university town pervades the cobblestone streets of Upsala, once the stamping ground of heathen kings and priests; then the abode of mediaeval Catholic ecclesiastics; later a stronghold of Protestantism. The students have a look of subdued piety which forms a strong contrast to youth of similar pursuits and a like age in the United States.

The very pointed and timely editorial article in your paper to-day on the fact that New York City has no representative on the Board of Equalization, and the treatment which the city has therefore received, emphasizes what has been said as to the necessity of the Controller of the Greater New York being from the present City of New York.

The announcement of an extra dividend of 1 per cent. on the stock of the St. Paul Railroad has had the effect of raising the price of the stock to the highest point it has reached in fifteen years. But there is much more in it than that. The Board of Directors which declared the dividend does not include any stock gamblers.

A building for a library and museum has been given to Campbeltown, Scotland, by James M. Hall, a native of that place. Mr. Hall offered this building on the understanding that the Free Library act should be adopted by the burgh, in order to provide for the maintenance of the institution, and that condition having been implemented, the mason work of the erection is now half finished.

LONDON, Sept. 11. -- The Times this morning, in an article from a special correspondent, in whose accuracy, it says, it has reason to place confidence, makes the announcement that the Bank of England Directors have consented to hold one-fifth of the bank's reserve in silver.

The true Celtic "brooch," the simplest form of an object used to secure a garment, finds its development in the safety-pin of to-day. All of the ancient world used this particular form of brooch. With the Celts it was a favorite ornament. In many old Scotch families of the present time a brooch belonging to their ancestors has been preserved as the most precious of relics.

The beautiful examples of savage art shown below form only a detail of an elaborate plastic composition carved out of wood. When constructing this harmonious ornament the savage artist-artisan first defined the line for circle-centre-progression. This regular spacing by revolution results in overlapping circles, whose boundaries intersect.

ALBANY, Sept. 10. -- Justice Putnam, writing the opinion of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, Third Department, to which all his associate Judges concurred in, deciding the law unconstitutional which compelled the branding or labeling of convict-made goods, as such, in the case of Thomas Hawkins, who was indicted for selling a scrub brush made in an Ohio prison which was not branded as a convict-made article, says among other things:

Among the many important books announced for publication this Fall by the Messrs. G.P. Putnam's Sons are Moses Colt Tyler's "Literary History of the American Revolution," Washington Irving's "Astoria; or, Anecdotes of an Enterprise Beyond the Rocky Mountains," illustrated by F.S. Church, Zogbaum, C.H. Eaton, T.C. Baird, and others, and Irving's Complete Works.

HAZLETON, Penn., Sept. 10. -- This region is in a turmoil to-night over the shooting of a number of striking coal miners at Lattimer this afternoon by a posse of deputies and coal and iron policemen, and there is no telling what the outcome will be. Over a dozen strikers were killed outright, and fully forty were wounded, of whom many will die. They are Hungarians, many of them having large families.
The note of Democracy rings clear and true in the admirable platform of the Gold Democrats of Ohio:

Further details of the murder of Capt. J.W. Whitman and Mate William Saunders of the American schooner Olive Pecker, on the South Atlantic, and the arrest of the crew at Bahia, Brazil, were learned yesterday from Capt. Jardine of the steamship Strabo, now in port, who was in Bahia at the time of the arrest.

As Baron Gabriel A. Portuge de Laurant, who lives at the Hotel Metropole, was on his way to keep an appointment with ex-District Attorney De Lancey Nicoll last night, in a cab driven by John Obbenbrush of 120 East Thirty-second Street, the horse knocked over two bicyclists, a man and a woman, at Lexington Avenue and Sixty-second Street, without, however, doing them any serious harm.

Frederick W. Whitehead, a clerk in the employ of the tea firm of Bennett . Co., at Fulton Street, has fallen heir to a fortune, a portion of the estate of a maiden aunt, in Manchester, England, the sister of his mother. The amount which is coming to him his fellow-employes put at $117,000. Mr. Whitehead says that the sum has been greatly exaggerated, but declines to say what it really is.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 10. -- William Hurley, the young amateur bicycle rider who dashed into an electric light pole on the Buffalo Athletic Field last week and fractured his skull, died last night.

Our recent lessons have revealed to us the great fact that when "the love of God is shed abroad in the heart by the Holy Ghost," it affects character, conduct, and condition. In character, the man becomes new within. In conduct, he is new without. In condition, he is in fellowship with Christ now, and hereafter shall be with Him, and like him forever.

Another day of heavy trading and of strength; over 600,000 shares dealt in, and practically every active stock a strong one. Sugar Trust shares were an exception to this rule, but Sugar Trust is temporarily under manipulation by operators who have bigger interests in it now than hitherto.

This city is now the great market for buyers, and they are coming from all sections of the country. It is estimated that there are from 10,000 to 15,000 representatives of out-of-town business firms in New York looking for goods for the Fall and Winter trade. From present indications this influx of buyers will continue through October.

In advance of Pension Commissioner EVANS, whose annual report on the operations of his office must soon be made up, the Auditor of the Treasury for the Interior Department reports that in the fiscal year ended June 30 there was paid out in pensions $141,200,551, or $1,747,761 more than was expended in pensions during the fiscal year 1895-6.

OTTAWA, Sept. 10. -- Secretary Sherman of the United States Government has written to the British Government asking for copies of the reports of Baron Hamilton, the British expert, and Mr. Macoun, the Canadian expert, who have made a study of seal life in Bering Sea.

To us it really would make no great difference whether we accepted "Oxcush" as the proper pronunciation or spelling of Oskosh, but it seems to be a subject of great annoyance to steady-going Englishmen when their Cawnpore becomes "Khanpur," Lucknow, "Lakhnao," and Mceret, "Mirath." "The Bagpipes of Lucknow," the squeal of the pibroch, would not have its proper agonizing sound did we call the city "Lakhnao."

Assistant Secretary ROOSEVELT'S glowing report of the performance of the North Atlantic squadron at sea, published in yesterday's papers, must have caused many a patriotic breast to glow with pride. To be sure, the report consisted of glittering generalities, and thoughtful persons would have welcomed a few more of those dry facts which are essential to profound conviction.
LONDON, Sept. 11. -- The morning papers comment upon the increasing difficulties of the position of Spain. The Daily Chronicle says:

Judge Aspinall, in the Kings County Court, yesterday, confirmed the report of sale in the suit of George Lott against John Y. McKane and others, to foreclose a mortgage of $3,500, covering land at the northeast corner of Stewart's Lane and the road from Sheepshead Bay to Gravesend. George Lott bought in the land for $5,000.

MADRID, Sept. 10. -- News was received here to-day of the capture by the Cuban insurgents of the town of Victoria de las Tunas, Province of Santiago de Cuba. The report caused great excitement. The Cabinet Ministers were summoned to meet this evening to consider the situation.

BOSTON, Sept. 9. -- Having "come to forty year," the Atlantic Monthly indulges in a little retrospect, and the October number will contain a sketch of its history, the history of a magazine founded in the faith that "literature is one of the most serious concerns of men, and that the highest service to our National life is the encouragement and the production of literature."

WILLETS POINT, N.Y., Sept. 10. -- Without apparent cause a guy rope which was one of the supports of a big derrick used in building the fortifications here parted this morning and the derrick crashed down into a pit where fifteen men were working in an excavation for a disappearing gun. Two of the men were killed. Two others were so badly injured they may die.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10. -- There was considerable progress in the Luetgert trial to-day, particularly during the afternoon session. The day was devoted to hearing expert testimony. It was shown that matter collected in the crevices of the pocket knife given by Luetgert to his former sweetheart, Mrs. Feldt, on the evening of his arrest, consisted of blood and particles of muscular tissue.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Sept. 10. -- Two highwaymen attempted to rob George Burke, an employe on the F.W. Vanderbilt place at Hyde Park, yesterday morning as he was driving along the Hyde Park Road near the same spot where John Clury, a Rhinebeck photographer, was robbed a week ago. There was a dance at the Horning House at Hyde Park Wednesday night, and Burke came to this city with the musicians.
Charles E. Schuyler Co. have sold for George Schweigler, for $12,000, the lot on the north side of One Hundred and Tenth Street, 200 feet east of the Boulevard, 25 by 91.
CHICAGO, Sept. 10. -- The Hopkins-Thayer-Hight Company, which held the lease for the Great Northern Theatre, made an assignment in the County Court to-day to Frederick A. Rowe.

A conference of organizations representing the free-silver-Chicago-platform sentiment in Greater New York was held at the Hotel Holland, Fifth Avenue and Thirtieth Street, last night. Invitations had been issued by the United Democracy, of which ex-Sheriff O'Brien of the Young Democracy and A.B. Cruikshank and Robert Stewart of the Democratic League of Kings County are the leaders.

Western Union was one of the strong stocks yesterday, selling as high as 96 5/8. Over 30,000 shares changed hands. There are to be heard vague rumors -- uncorroborated -which suggest that through Mr. Sage further Vanderbilt interests are soon to appear in the Western Union Directory.

You would have to be specially gifted, did you try to give in words the elegance, the grace, the exceeding suppleness, the perfect tone, the color quality Mr. Henry Wolf has produced with his graver and bit of boxwood in the September Century, where his print, "The Sonata," embellishes the first page.

READING, Penn., Sept. 4. -- At Harleysville, Montgomery County, lives a farmer bibliophile, who enjoys the well-earned reputation of having in his possession as large a private collection of rare books as is probably to be found in this country -- at least on a farm.

The policy of silence which has been adopted by John C. Sheehan and his associates for the present stage of the Tammany campaign was diligently followed out at last night's meeting of the General Committee. It was routine itself.

Henry Demas, ex-Senator from St. John and one of the most offensive of the negro politicians who came to the front in the reconstruction saturnalia, was yesterday appointed United States Naval Officer at this port. The office is not one of great importance, but the appointment is none the less an affront and an insult to the respectable people of Louisiana.

WAVERLY, N.J., Sept. 10. -- Despite a number of bad spills and the procession of ambulances they necessitated, one of the most interesting features of the New Jersey State Fair was the National Circuit fixture run off by professional and amateur wheelmen on the Waverly Park track yesterday afternoon.

BOSTON, Sept. 10. -- The gold Democrats of the State, as a party organization, have issued an appeal to the people of Massachusetts on the issues to be met in the coming political contest, arraigning at the same time the Republican Party on its financial policy and its administration of National affair. The appeal says:

Three big steamships arrived at their docks last night, and, owing to the inadequacy of the force of customs inspectors the passengers were subjected to the same annoyance and hours of delay that occurred on Wednesday, and which, indeed, have marked the arrival of many steamers lately.

There was another sudden and strong rise in Manhattan Elevated Railroad stock yesterday, illustrating the strength of the conviction of the Street that a plan for the consolidation of the Manhattan and the Metropolitan Street Railway Company has been practically completed or is so far advanced that its success is assured.
SEATTLE, Washington, Sept. 10. -- The steamer Cleveland, which arrived to-night, brought news of the probable loss of the old steamer Eliza Anderson, which left this port Aug. 10 for St. Michael.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Sept. 10. -- John P. Elkin of Indiana County, Chairman of the State Republican State Committee, said to-day that he had resigned by request as Deputy Attorney General, and that his resignation has been accepted. It is thought Mr. Elkin's connection with the indemnifying bond, which led to the resignation of Gen. Reeder, had much to do with it.

How did the Park Board ever come to pass that ridiculous resolution authorizing the formation of a brigade of licensed and uniformed candy peddlers in Central Park? The pretext of the resolution is that candy and other unwholesome refreshments are now peddled in the Park by unlicensed persons.

The currency plank of the National Democrats is as sound as the tariff plank. But it is too vague to be accepted as a programme. It calls for the maintenance of the gold standard and the retirement of the greenback. But it does not tell us how the greenback is to be retired.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 10. -- Dispatches from Biloxi to-day say that the situation there is becoming unbearable. Drug stores are running out of medicines. President Lemon of the Biloxi Board of Health has wired President Oliphant urging him to see that the requests for drugs are promptly attended to.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 10. -- The finals in the match for the Ambassadors' Cup were played on the links to-day, the contestants being David W. Bishop, Jr., and William A. Taylor. Bishop won over Taylor by a score of 6 up with 4 to play. About 350 people were at the links when the play was in progress, and many of them followed the players around the course.

SUMMIT, N.J., Sept. 10. -- All day the search of the country within several miles radius of Stony Hill, where James C. Pitts was beaten to death last night by men who evidently expected to rob his home and make a big haul, went on without ceasing. Mr. Pitts, an aged resident of Summit, was murdered in the kitchen of his home.

James B. Reynolds, Chairman of the Citizens' Union Executive Committee, said yesterday that the Union Mayoralty ticket would be at once filled out; that a full municipal ticket would be nominated, and that the Union, to insure itself against a loss of strength through split voting, might even indorse a nominee for Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals and nominees for the Assembly.

The manner in which the State Board of Equalization shifted from the shoulders of the rural counties to the shoulders of this city a burden of $89,000,000 was described yesterday by R.S. Guernsey, President of the New York State Tax Payers' Protective Association. Mr. Guernsey witnessed the process.

Thomas Sheehan, the proprietor of a saloon at Twenty-sixth Street and First Avenue, had a narrow escape from being killed last night by Patrick Kearns of 341 East Twenty-fifth Street. Kearns fired several times at Sheehan at close quarters.

The name of M. Henry Harrisse is familiar to every student of the early voyages of discovery in the Western Atlantic. He has made this extensive field of research peculiarly his own by virtue of his tireless and ingenious labors, and he is to-day the recognized master of all knowledge that relates to the earliest records of the American continents.

The "Young Pretender," and the Cardinal Duke of York -- James III., Charles, Edward, and Henry, the last scions of the hapless Stuart race, whose beautiful marble monument is in the church above, lie here in peace at last. Rome was kind indeed to these royal exiles, for she gave them a shelter here in life when all things earthly failed them, and in death a sepulchre close to the Prince of the Apostles.

Three million shares of stock were traded in in Wall Street during the past week, and there were transactions in bonds of a par value of $20,000,000. Hardly a single notable decline was recorded in bond values, while in stocks many significant advances were scored. In every essential way the security market situation shows improvement.
The special orders issued from General Headquarters, State of New York, provide for the following disposition of rifles,
BAY SHORE, L.I., Sept. 11. -- A sanitary reform has been brought about in this town by the incineration of hair.

Charles Stewart Smith, Vice Chairman of the Citizens' Union, yesterday called attention in an interview to the fact that in 1894 Oswald Ottendorfer was Chairman of a committee which asked Seth Low to be a candidate for Mayor. Mr. Smith also discussed the present and future purposes of the Union. He said:

ONCE on the mountains and in the forests of Thessaly were Centaurs, and Mr. Sullivant has drawn them, but there have been later modifications of these creatures, showing the bovine not the equine crossing, and if Mr. Frederic Remington is their illustrator, Mr. Alfred Henry Lewis is their annalist.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Sept. 11. -- The Savannah marksmen, the winners of the principal trophies at the National matches at Sea Girt, N.J., last week, have returned to this city, bearing worthily the honors that were bestowed upon them. They were escorted into Savannah by a large delegation of citizens, and the champion teams are today the toasts of every man, woman, and child in Georgia.

The Bank of England is about the last place where we should expect a favorable answer to be given to the appeal to "do something for silver." The general incredulity with which the report that the Governors of the bank had consented to keep one-fifth of their reserve in that metal has been received gives evidence of the firm public opinion that it is an uncompromising adherent of gold.

BOSTON, Sept. 11. -- One of the most interesting bits of yachting news during the week was the sale of the twenty-one-foot knockabout Cock Robin by C.H.W. Foster to C.S. Eaton, her original owner. In exchange for the Cock Robin Mr. Eaton gives his Herreschoff knockabout Cockatoo and $700 to boot, which shows just how badly he wanted his old boat and how much he thinks of her.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11. -- The announcement that the Directors of the Bank of England had consented to hold one-fifth of the bank's reserve in silver was something of a surprise to Treasury officials, many of whom doubt the accuracy of the report.

PARIS, Sept. 11. -- During the intervals in the discussion of the prophecy of Herr Falb of Vienna that the world will come to an end on Nov. 13, 1899, the Paris newspapers are still most busily engaged in shaping up the future of France in company with the Russian Bear.
Brooklyn Has Nearly 150 Schools, but Needs More -- Thirteen Kindergarten Institutions in Readiness -- Patriotic Singing Ordered.

The wheat market yesterday was weak and dull. Foreign quotations were lower than on Friday and without stimulus, and the Government crop report was regarded as showing an increase in the wheat yield and more favorable corn conditions. There was little export demand, and the usual Saturday selling was large, because of a belief that wheat stocks would show an increase to-morrow.

HAVANA, Sept. 11. -- Through the courtesy of Admiral Navarro, the Spanish naval commander in Cuban waters, the correspondent of The Associated Press here has been able to obtain details from Santiago de Cuba of the grounding on the Colorado Shoals, off the harbor of Santiago de Cuba, of the Ward Line steamship Niagara, Capt. Crocker, from New York, Aug. 26, via Nassau Aug. 30, for Guantanamo, Cienfuegos, and other ports.

Still another bicyclist story, and this one has a real heroine, the kind of a heroine who, if the story was a romance, would convert a father and brother and two or three sneering men cousins to the belief that the bicycle is essentially a womanly belonging. This not being a romance, there were no fathers, brothers, and young men cousins to be converted, but the heroine was a heroine just the same.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Sept. 11. -- Elmer H. Lawall, General Superintendent of the Lehigh and Wilkesbarre Coal Company, who went to Hazleton early this morning, telegraphs to R.R. Morgans, the general outside Superintendent of the Lehigh and Wilkesbarre collieries in this section, that he expects the trouble between the company and the strikers in the Hazleton region will be amicably settled by Tuesday.
HARRISBURG, Penn., Sept. 11. -- On account of the slaughter yesterday afternoon at Lattimer, the Governor to-night issued the following proclamation:
John D. Crimmins acted the part of the good Samaritan yesterday by relieving the immediate wants of many of the strikers on the Madison and Fourth Avenue underground trolley line.

In view of the frequency with which importers of paintings and statuary attach to their entry papers "certificates of originality," signed by artists residing at the port of shipment, the United States Treasury Department detailed special agents some time ago to investigate the character and reliability of the documents.
