Lawyer Thomas Smith, who has been summering at Long Island with his family, returned to his home, 148A Hull Street, Brooklyn, Friday night, and as he opened the front door of the house he was met by two raccoons, which at once attacked him.

In deference to the golf championships which begin to-morrow on the links of the Chicago Golf Club, the Metropolitan League has arranged no large tournaments, so the coming week will be devoted to watching the result of the Western contests, speculating on the next amateur champion, and incidentally playing a few club matches and team contests.

IN the American banking world no other post is so high as the Presidency of the New York Clearing House -- its occupant the chosen representative of the associated banks of the metropolis. Strong men have held this place; he who is worthy of it needs to be a forceful man, and a broad man.

The primal cause of the accident to elevator No. 6 in the Tract Society Building, by which two lives were lost, Friday evening is still unexplained. A representative of an elevator manufacturing company said yesterday that it would probably never be known.

COMMACK, L.I., Sept. 10. -- The farmers of Suffolk County have of late years rather encouraged the fox crops with the idea of attracting some of the hunt clubs. A hunt club is rather better than a share in a gold mine in a rural neighborhood, because the members not only spend money freely, but pay liberal damages when in their enthusiasm they ride over ground supposed to be under cultivation.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Sept. 11. -- In a fit of jealous frenzy, accentuated by drink, Harry Gillam, a molder, aged twenty-three years, to-night shot Mrs. Dora Sutherland and her daughter Ida. The latter received two bullets, one just above the heart and the other in the arm. Her injuries are fatal. The mother was shot in the arm.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11. -- Secretary Gage expects to begin the preparation of his first annual report the last of the month. Pursuant to his orders, his subordinates are rushing work on their reports and probably will have them in by the time the Secretary needs them.

MASSAPEQUA, L. I., Sept. 11. -- This place has recovered from a shock and is now congratulating itself that it has had the only surprise party in social history which was really and beyond all question a surprise.

A glance over the reports of last week's dealings is sufficient to show the region of activity, geographically speaking. The sales and trades of the week have been confined so largely to one locality that we can almost hunt in vain for the record of any transaction south of Forty-second Street or east of Fifth Avenue.

The "one-design" class of the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club for next year has started off in a very promising manner. The Race Committee of the club held a meeting recently and discussed the different designs that were submitted. There were several of these, and the merits of each were fully discussed and the plans and estimates carefully examined. It was finally decided that the design of W.B. Stearns of Marblehead should be accepted.

The showing the New Yorks made against their intercity rivals, the Brooklyns, in the presence of 8,000 persons at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon did not cast any credit on the local team, and the Brooklyns won rather easily. It was either the oppressive heat, or the fact that the Giants are practically out of the fight for second place, that made the players give such a wretched exhibition.
RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 11. -- Gov. O'Ferrall is out in a rejoinder to Senator Daniel's reply to the Governor's recent interview concerning the Senator's course at the Chicago Convention.

PARIS, Aug. 31. -- We are in the thick of the popular demonstrations that have been arranged, very hastily, to celebrate the solemn incorporation at Peterhof of the Franco-Russian alliance and to greet the homecoming of M. Felix Faure. Paris is aflicker with multi-colored flags, and most of the shops are closed.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 11. -- The best the champions could do was to play a tie game with the Colts to-day. It was a pitchers' battle, and the home team had the game won in the eighth, but threw away its chance by the weakest kind of batting. In this inning Dahlen was hurt sliding to second and was replaced by Callahan, Connor going to second. Umpire McDonald called the game on account of darkness. Score:

The Local Anzeiger of Berlin says that Turkish newspapers are not allowed any liberty to discuss either internal or foreign polities. Now and then they have "inspired" articles. Occasionally certain articles are ordered to be printed in the Turkish papers, of which all European papers in the capital are forbidden to publish translations, lest foreigners should read what is intended for the Turks.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 11. -- The great miners' strike, which was declared on July 4, was brought to an end this evening, so far, at least, as Western Pennsylvania, Ohio, Indiana, and West Virginia are concerned, by the action of the inter-State convention of miners, which has been in session here since Wednesday.

LADIES' hats have prevented many a man from seeing a stage performance. Now there is a fear that ladies' hatpins are preventing some poor fellows from ever seeing anything again, by causing blindness.

The Colonia won the Larchmont Cup for schooners yesterday in a rather tame race. The Amorita was her only opponent. The winds early in the day were light and shifting, but just when all hope of the race's being finished in the required time had been abandoned a fresh breeze sprang up from the northeast and enabled the Colonia to finish with a few seconds to spare.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 11. -- The steamer Gaelic, which arrived to-day from Yokohama and Hongkong via Honolulu, brought the following Hawaiian advices under date of Sept. 4:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11. -- About sixty miles away from this city, and a short railroad ride to the north, brings the visitor to the little village of Keedysville, lying at the western side of the South Mountain, with the blue lines of that mountain stretching away on the east and the lower lands of the winding Potomac and the hills of Virgina at the west.

POUND BROOK, N.J., Sept. 11. -- The Mayor and Town Council of Lincoln, the new town two miles from here, will attend the meeting of municipal officials at Columbus, Ohio, on Sept. 26 in a body. They decided to do so at the regular Council meeting this afternoon. President of the Council Emma Egel and the members, Mrs. Hazard and Miss Mattie Moore, are all in a flutter in consequence.

EASTON, Penn., Sept. 11. -- Gen. Frank Reeder, late Secretary of the Commonwealth, who was forced by Gov. Hastings to resign this week, and the Hon. Webster C. Weiss, Republican member of the Legislature from this county, were arrested in the former's office in this city late this afternoon on very serious charges preferred by the adherents of John Wanamaker.

SMALLEST of all the "quarters" of New York -- if "quarter" it may fairly be called -- is the Indian colony of Broome and Spring Streets and West Broadway, a region half commercial, half the abode of the poor, where tall tenements are not and little houses half a century old fill up the side streets.

HAZLETON, Penn., Sept. 11. -- Twenty-one men are dead thus far as the result of the two volleys fired by Sheriff Martin's deputies upon the striking coal miners at Lattimer yesterday afternoon, and of the forty wounded miners now in the Hazleton hospital it is expected that five will die before morning.

Rich men in Great Britain have been slow to emulate Americans in gifts for public uses. Our annals contain nothing more familiar, or more striking, than the bestowal by private citizens of great sums for founding public institutions -- colleges, libraries, museums, and hospitals.

ANTWERP, Aug. 19. -- This flat country reminds me of the story of a London friend who was explaining how impossible it is to make a Hollander understand what a real hill is, or a cataract, or anything that involves elevation. He was riding through Holland one day in a railway train with a native, and as there was no scenery they naturally fell to talking about it.
THOUGH barely nineteen years of age, the little Cuban patriot girl Evangelina Cossio y Cisneros has managed to leap into world-wide prominence.

HAVANA, Sept. 11. -- Official details of the capture of Victoria de las Tunas by the insurgents show that the garrison stationed there consisted of 350 men, 135 of whom were rendered unfit for duty by illness. The town was first attacked on Aug. 14 with a brisk musketry fire, and on the 26th the insurgents laid siege to the place.

Though forbidden by law and punishable by imprisonment in a fortress, dueling is very common among the officers of the German army. Until recently they have been bound by the military code of honor to accept challenges, though they were not allowed to fight a tradesman. In 1887 an officer was expelled from the army for refusing to accept a challenge.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 11. -- Lenox is awaiting the arrival of Prince Alexander of Teck. The Prince, who is described as a charming young gentleman, will sail from Southampton next Wednesday on the Majestic, in company with Mr. and Mrs. A.R. Shattuck, son and daughter-in-taw of Mrs. W.B. Shattuck, at whose country house, Brookhurst, the Prince will remain while here.

One of the most picturesque buildings in New York is on State Street. Possibly there are people in New York who do not even know where State Street is. People who are going to the extreme lower end of the city are more apt to say that they are going to the Battery than to any particular street.

Some of the finest swimmers in America figured in an aquatic meet at Bath Beach yesterday afternoon to compete for a set of silver loving cups offered by E.C.M. Fitzgerald. A course of smooth water hemmed in with flag and pennant decked yachts and a flotilla of small craft formed a picturesque setting, which nearly 1,000 spectators enjoyed in addition to watching the briny contests. A strong current rolling westward somewhat impeded the swimmers.

BERLIN, Sept. 11. -- This week's ever boiling pot of German politics contained political developments for which the army manoeuvres are an excuse, although everything was done at Homburg, at King Humbert's request, to safeguard French susceptibilities. But Emperor William's reconsecration of the Drei-Kaiserbund was triumphantly begun, and at the same time the King of Italy's wishes were gratified.

HIGHLAND FALLS, Sept. 11. -- The Church of the Holy Innocents celebrated its fiftieth anniversary yesterday. This is the church which was used by the professors and officers at West Point before the cadet chapel was erected, and where J. Pierpont Morgan, John Bigelow, Major Charles F. Roe, and a score of other celebrated men attend each Sunday.

Three children of the tenements, two little girls and a boy still in dresses, wandered into a fashionable cross-town street near Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon. They were all ragged and they were all dirty; one of the girls had a most disreputable-looking doll, and the boy dragged a stick on the sidewalk.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Sept. 11. -- In ordinary times the population of this section divides its attention, according to seasons and conditions, between water and land harvests. When the farming is bad, the farmers become baymen and go afloat; when the bay is barren or unprofitable the baymen become farmers and go ashore.

LONDON, Sept. 11. -- The important announcement made by the Times this morning, in an article from a special correspondent, to the effect that the Directors of the Bank of England have consented to hold one-fifth of the Bank reserve in silver, has caused much excitement on the Continent.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Sept. 11. -- Howard C. Benham was sentenced by Justice Laughlin this morning to be executed at Auburn Prison during the week beginning Nov. 1 for the murder of his wife, Florence Tout Benham, who died from the effect of prussic acid poisoning on the 4th of January last. Benham was found guilty by a Genesee County jury on July 29.
BAR HARBOR, Sept. 11. -- Mrs. Frederick Gebhard gave a clambake Friday at the Ovens to a party of twelve.
LONDON, Sept. 11. -- The theatrical season has fairly blossomed and the first-nighters are overwhelmed with a surfeit of farce-comedy and melodrama.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11. -- AdJt. Gen. Ruggles was retired to-day on account of age and Col. Samuel Breck was made a Brigadier General and appointed Adjutant General of the army.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11. -- Alderman Bennett says the police are protecting illegal saloons and gambling places. He also insinuates that Chief of Police Kipley is accepting bribes from the same. The Chief says the Alderman is a liar. If it were a hanging matter, the circumstantial evidence in the case would put Chief Kipley in serious peril of his life.

LONDON, Sept. 11. -- The rise in wheat to 40s has dragged up the price of bread to 6 1/2d and 7d, and in the poorest quarters of London, where bread is sold in slices, the loaf is fetching 1s. On top of this the Millers' National Union has started a demand for fewer hours of labor, with a threatened strike if their demand is not accorded.
Marksmen and experts occupied the grounds at Creedmoor yesterday, and the attendance was by far the smallest seen on the ranges this year. All told, there were barely 200 men present.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11. -- The prospect of viewing the gruesome exhibit of flesh, bones, slime, and canvas gunnysacks reeking with what the prosecution assert is the dissolved body of the wife of A.L. Luetgert, drew an unusually large crowd this morning to the entrance of the Criminal Court Building. In the courtroom there was the usual flutter of excitement when the big prisoner was led in by the colored bailiff.

It seems to be entirely safe to assume that President MCKINLEY will renew the appointment of Medical Director J.R. TRYON to be Surgeon General of the Navy, whose tour of service expired on Sept. 3. The friends of Dr. TRYON have manifested some natural concern in the matter, but these friends should not conclude that the President will be indifferent to the arguments made in Dr. TRYON'S behalf.

The death of the founder of The London Spectator is an event of considerable importance to readers who appreciate what a force, and upon the whole how beneficent a force, that journal has been. It is, indeed, rather curious, considering the abundance in England of competent writers, that only two weekly journals should have come to be established in England which had distinct individualities of their own.

ROSLYN, L.I., Sept. 11. -- War on the advertising sign has been opened on Long Island, which has been hung, plastered, benailed, festooned, covered, and bewildered with those evidences of misguided enterprise Whenever a new liver pill has appeared on the market, Long Island has broken out in a bilious rash of green and yellow.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11. -- The Surgeon General sent orders to-day to Dr. Wasdine at Ocean Springs to begin an investigation of yellow fever on Sanarelli's method. Sanarelli is the eminent South American, who claims to have discovered the germ of yellow fever. A full bacteriological outfit has been shipped to Dr. Wasdine for the purpose of this scientific inquiry.

The Rivista Italiana di Filosofia contains an article by Dr. Marpillero on children's ideas of life and death, describing how he questioned a number of young children on these subjects at an elementary school at Rovigo, and the answers he received. We quote some of the most curious.

Whether or not the dainty palate of New York is to be feasted with the delicious meat of the fresh anchovy depends entirely upon itself. If it demands the tasteful morsel, its wish shall be gratified. If it does not make its wish known, the markets will have none to offer. Anchovy sauce and the salted anchovy of commerce, which are imported, are not always of the true anchovy.

With few exceptions the proprietors of the new stands situated near the down-town stations of the elevated railroads, have been for years in the habit of keeping a supply of elevated railway tickets in stock for the accommodation of their customers. Business men hastening up town at the close of the day have found it very convenient to buy their railroad ticket at the same time that they bought their evening papers.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 11. -- The principal item of interest here to-day is the fact that towns on every trunk line running into New Orleans have declared quarantine against Louisiana. Burgs in Mississippi, Louisiana, Texas, and Alabama have declared that no people shall get off trains at their stations who come from this city.

THE INDIAN is very popular at the American Museum of Natural History. When he arrives in town he is introduced to the sculptors' studio on the top floor of the building, and if he proves to be a fair type of his family or tribe he is at once engaged to pose.

Mrs. Charles Ewald of 513 Communipaw Avenue, Jersey City, is seriously ill with heart disease. She is a Catholic and her husband is a Protestant. A story was circulated yesterday that two priests who went to the house to administer the last rites were refused admission. When Mr. Ewald was asked about the matter, he admitted that it was practically true.

One of the busiest portions of the South Long Island coast is the territory occupied by Jamaica and Sheepshead Bays during the oyster season. It is not widely known that Brooklyn oystermen carry on a big industry in the "r" months, and that a large proportion of the oysters sold in this city and shipped to outside points from here are marketed from the City of Brooklyn.

MADRID, Sept. 11. -- The excitement caused by the capture by the Cuban insurgents of Victoria de las Tunas, Province of Santiago de Cuba, continues here. The Imparcial describes it as a catastrophe for Spain.
SKAGUAY, Alaska, Aug. 28. -- Still raining. There has been no let-up for six days, and the barometer is falling. The trail will be closed for two days more.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11. -- The following fourth-class Postmasters have been appointed:

The Riverside Yacht Club sailed Its Fall regatta in a light, flukey wind yesterday off Greenwich. Fourteen yachts started, and twelve finished. The Acushla met the Anoatok and Vorant II. in the thirty-six-foot sloop class, and, leading all over the course, won easily.

Mr. Worth has made the statement to his friends that he has secured beyond a doubt the support of Register Granville W. Harman, Congressman Fischer, Naval Officer Sharkey, and Mayor Wurster in his fight for the control of the Republican Party in Kings County.

By their remarkable performances in their respective races at Sheepshead Bay yesterday, these horses demonstrated that they are really great racers. Hamburg performed a task greater than had ever been performed by a two-year-old, and Ben Holladay sent flying all previous records for a race at two miles, except Ten Broeck's effort against time.

RICHARD CROKER has been pretty well toughened by a life of political vicissitudes, but even he might be moved to protest against the newspaper treatment to which he has been subjected since his return from England. Not being a fool, Mr. CROKER has never for a moment entertained the notion of nominating himself for Mayor this Fall.

The effort on procuring for District Attorney W.M.K. Olcott the nomination for Mayor of the Greater New York was systematically begun last night. The director of this preliminary movement is Abraham Gruber, leader of the Republican organization in the Twenty-first Assembly District, and the active campaign of Mr. Olcott was inaugurated in Lion Park by Mr. Gruber and a majority of the Chairmen of the forty-seven election districts.
He unfolded the map carefully, and spread it out. "That's what I like about a map," he said. "You never need to ask your way. It makes you so much more independent. Doesn't it, darling?"
Several women in Chicago have organized the Women's Civic Reform Association, whose special purpose it is to fight gambling. Men are eligible to membership.

Full knowledge of Western business conditions is just at the present time of vital importance to Wall Street. So much of the country's prosperity depends upon the West, with its large crops, that the views and opinions of men in close touch with the Western situation are not only instructive, but necessary to a proper estimate of the general condition of affairs.

President Moss of the Police Board said yesterday the affidavits charging Capts. Grant and Thomas with conniving at the existence of poolrooms were not substantial enough to justify putting them on trial. He said there was a leak at Headquarters, and the poolroom men were informed when action was to be taken against them.

LONDON, Sept. 11. -- As the result of the visit of the Duke and Duchess of York to Ireland, a royal residence will in all probability be established in that country, and, in addition, the early abolition of the Viceroyalty is everywhere accepted as a fact. The Duchess won all hearts, and the Duke was almost as popular, though he did not escape criticism.

Criminologists have a theory, supported by abundant observations and experiences, that even the most thorough-bred scoundrels have some weak point, some cause of oversight, or forgetfulness, , by which they themselves furnish the means, often proofs, of their guilt and rascality. It seems there are people who would not like to be classed as criminals who do the same thing, sometimes.

Mr. George J. Gould will be in New York on next Saturday, when (according to expectations in important Wall Street circles) there may be a history-making conference between him and Mr. Russell Sage. Mr. Sage and Mr. Gould are believed to have come to an agreement by which they part with the control of the Manhattan Elevated Railroad.

The Superintendent of the Aquarium, after a day spent seining in Gravesend Bay, made known yesterday the result of his labors. He found a large variety of fish. The news of the existence of not a few of them probably will surprise many anglers who have fished in Gravesend Bay for years. Dr. Bean's seining was done on the bars between the mouth of Coney Island Creek and Norton's Point, Coney Island.
Poverty seems to have passed by Illinois agriculturists. One of them recently paid $5,100 for Poland China hog.

MUSICAL directors are born not made," once said a famous musician of the Old World, a trite saying, borne out by a close observation of many musicians of conspicuous ability who have signally failed at the conductor's desk. A popular impression seems to be that a person possessed of musical talent must of necessity be able to direct, but no greater fallacy was ever known.

To the strangers whom we are just now attempting by novel methods and with a high degree of success to attract within our gates New York must present a wonderful sight. Nay, the spectacle is such as to impress with a sense of strangeness and novelty the most hardened inhabitant.

This promises to be a hard Winter for the grumblers. The high hat for the theatre is very generally put down, sleeves are reduced to a normal size, and unless women bestir themselves they will lose one of their most valuable attributes of being something to be growled about, an outlet for the effervescing bad temper, or "I am better than thou" sort of egotism, of the world.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., Sept. 11. -- The case of the Fish and Game Protective Commission against George Von Buhren of New York for imprisoning five robbins in a cage was tried to-day before Justice Austen of Mount Bethel. Von Buhren was released, but Joseph Delmotts, the hired man, was fined $100, as the birds were found in his possession.

ST. PETERSBURG, Sept. 1. -- At last the great sentence has been pronounced. The France-Russian alliance has been twice proclaimed by the Czar and by President Faure. The men of this generation are naturally inclined to skepticism, but in presence of such a result, skepticism is out of place. Henceforth the France-Russian alliance must be officially recognized, and European history enters upon a new era.

Madeline Lucette Ryley is the author of the new play in which Effie Shannon and Herbert Kelcey will appear at Wallack's Theatre to-morrow night. She seems to be the most prolific of contemporary playwrights, and another of her light and pleasing plays, "The Mysterious Mr. Bugle," will be current this week at another theatre.

Senator Platt's principal visitors at Manhattan Beach yesterday were Charles W. Hackett, Chairman of the Republican State Committee, and Lieut. Gov. Timothy L. Woodruff. The Lieutenant Governor arrived at the Oriental Hotel early in the day. He was accompanied by Joseph R. Clark, President of the Board of Aldermen of Brooklyn, and together they discussed the Kings County situation with Senator Platt.

When the ferryboat Sag Harbor of the Long Island Railroad Company was in midstream at 2 o'clock yesterday morning on the way from Long Island City to the Thirty-fourth Street slip the passengers and deckhands were aroused by cries for help coming from the river immediately ahead of the boat.

Papers were filed with Sheriff Heller at Jersey City on Saturday in a suit brought by James Whitelegge against Henry Heye for $5,000 damages for defamation of character. The men are members of the Letter Carriers' Union, and the difficulty is alleged to have arisen at the Labor Day picnic. Whitelegge, it is said, was intrusted by a merchant with a prize umbrella to be competed for in the games.

Though the light-harness steppers have completed the tour of the Grand Circuit, their occupation is by no means gone for the season. There are important meetings yet to come all over the country, the Northern and Middle States still contributing their share to the sport which began about three months ago.

Hugh O. Pentecost began yesterday a series of ethical meetings in Carnegie Music Hall which will be conducted in somewhat the same manner as those which he formerly held in Chickering Hall. Mr. Pentecost, however, has introduced some novelties in this latest movement of his.

A meeting of the Tammany wing of the Progressive Democratic League was held yesterday afternoon at the organization headquarters, 420 Hudson Street, for the election of officers and the transaction of other business. Eight new clubs were elected to membership, including the Clothing Cutters' Union, the Workingmen's Political Club of the Fourteenth Assembly District, the Silver Club of the Thirtieth Assembly District, and the Democratic League of the Thirty-fifth Assembly District.

An officer of the law is justified in using just so much force as may be necessary to compel obedience to law, and no more. The only question that may properly be asked concerning the shooting of the riotous miners at Lattimer by Sheriff MARTIN'S deputies is whether any milder measures could have been employed that would effectually have prevented acts of violence.
MADRID, Sept. 12. -- The official dispatch from Havana, giving details of the loss of Victoria de las Tunas, says:

There is a great deal of foolish talk about the excellent game of golf. Some of it emanates from devotees of the sport, who declare that it is the finest known to mortal man, and some of it reechoes from the voices of those who have walked around in the broiling sun looking at others play, but who have never themselves indulged in the pastime.

The result of yesterday's meeting of the anti-Tammany wing of the Progressive Democratic League tended to show that it and the Democratic Alliance of Silver Clubs, with which it has affiliated, will fight Tammany Hall in the campaign, as that organization will not make concessions to those who insist that the Chicago platform and municipal ownership of franchises shall be prominent features in the campaign.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 12 -- During the last fortnight two events have taken place in the Twin Cities, which have made it possible to obtain a very correct estimate of the present conditions prevailing among the farmers of the whole country, and among the Northwestern farmers in particular. The first of these was the Farmers' National Congress, which was held in St. Paul, and which was attended by representatives from nearly every State in the Union.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12. -- James J. Corbett will appear in an exhibition at the Second Regiment Armory to-morrow night for the benefit of the striking miners. The entertainment will be given under the auspices of the Federation of Labor. The programme was arranged by "Parson" Davies, and Malachy Hogan will act as referee. Among the other boxers to appear are Bob Armstrong, Joe Choynski, Frank Hartridge, George Kerwin, Jack Moffatt, and Frank Fitzsimmons.

SEATTLE, Washington, Sept. 12. -- One hundred thousand dollars will not buy four sacks of flour in Dawson City to-day. However, if a miner is starving, a sack of flour and a can of canned beef will be given him. That is all. Those who cannot pay fabulous prices for even these plain necessaries must get out of the country.

Harlem River oarsmen were not overactive yesterday, the threatening weather keeping most of them away from the boathouses. However, what rowing was done was for pleasure, as the racing season is now over and all crews have quit training.

Francis McWilliams, a boilermaker, of 523 Court Street, Brooklyn, was out bicycle riding last night. At the corner of Henry and Sackett Streets his wheel collided with that of Elijah Barry, sixteen years old, of 289 Union Street. The boy was thrown from his wheel and slightly bruised.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- Replying to a letter by Mr. Bryan, in which he said that free coinage at 16 to 1 would fix a mint price for silver, Secretary Gage said:

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 12. -- Shortly before noon to-day the Board of Health officially declared six of the suspicious cases of fever on St. Claude Street to be yellow fever. Shortly afterward the board announced another case of yellow fever at Mire and Esplanade Streets, also in the lower part of the city, but a mile or more way from the infected square.

CHICAGO, Sept. 12. -- Andrew and Jacob Mignot, Seven and five years old, will start alone on a journey to their home in Belgium to-morrow to see their anxious mother, who for three months has been searching the entire world for tidings of her missing children. They will be placed under the care of agents of a transatlantic steamship line and will be turned over to the United States Consul at Ghent.

The fund for the projected new building of the Church of the Strangers was enriched last week by the gift from a stranger of a house and about twenty acres of land valued at several thousand dollars. The donor, a woman, made the gift absolutely, with the single condition that her name should not be made public.

ALBANY, Sept. 12 -- The State Branch of the American Federation of Labor has completed its record of the last Legislature, including the personal record of each Senator and Assemblyman on all labor measures. The report adopted by the federation says:

OAKLAND, Cal., Sept. 12. -- Chief of Police Lloyd received a telegram announcing the death at Juneau of J.C. Boatman, formerly private secretary to Congressman Hillborn and recently appointed Fish Commissioner of Alaska. He was a native of Ohio and forty-six years old.

The Rev. Thomas Dixon, Jr., in his talk preliminary to the regular sermon, at the Academy of Music yesterday morning, called forth considerable applause from his large audience by declaring that Mr. Low's candidacy for the Mayoralty on the Citizens' Union ticket would be a disunifying force; that this was no time for venting political spite, and that Mr. Low ought to withdraw.

SOMERSET, Penn., Sept. 12. -- This morning the President and Attorney General McKenna attended service at the Methodist Church, of which the Rev. H.N. Cameron is pastor. They were accompanied by Abner McKinley and his daughter Mabel; Dr. and Mrs. A.J. Endsley, Col. Alfred Cushing of Washington, and W.K. Endsley.

TACOMA Washington, Sept. 12. -- Minute Creek, on the American side, is the latest Yukon stream to attract attention as a gold producer. Between sixty and one hundred men now have claims there, and are sure of making fortunes this Winter. From the surface down the sand and gravel yields from fifty cents to $4 and $5 per pan.

The Rev. John L. Scudder, pastor of the Congregational Tabernacle, Jersey City, last night prefaced his sermon by reading a paper entitled: "Shall Race Track Gambling Return to New Jersey?" It had reference to the special election to be held on September 28, upon the anti-race track gambling amendment to the Constitution.
Great causes never fail to enlist the zeal and devotion of great men. The struggle for American independence and that for the abolition of slavery are examples.

Occasional reports from Washington concerning appointments, promotions, reinstatements, and dismissals have made it apparent that the heads of Government departments have regarded the civil service law in the letter with greater respect since the enunciation by the President of his rule against dismissals from the classified service without charges and opportunity for defense by the subject of a discharge.

ST. PETERSBURG, Sept. 12. -- It is the general opinion, reflected in the press of St. Petersburg and of Warsaw, that the visit of Emperor Nicholas II. to the latter city has sensibly diminished ill-feeling and paved the way for a reconciliation with the Old Poles.

The complaints in the Astoria section of Long Island City are becoming more vigorous each day because of the scarcity of the water supply. Many of the larger houses are all right because they were prepared for the condition of things which followed the shutting down of Pumping Station No. 2 of the city's system.

Towering over thirty feet above the ground and composed of every variety of fruit raised in all parts of the world the fruit column at Sulzer's Harlem River Park yesterday looked down upon as picturesque a scene as has been witnessed at that resort in many a day. It was the opening of the Cannstatter harvest festival, which is to last three more days -- to-day, to-morrow, and next Sunday.
The friends of Charles H. Ebbetts, Secretary and Treasurer of the Brooklyn club, will tender him a benefit at Eastern Park next month. The Brooklyn team will meet some strong team on the occasion.

HAZLETON, Penn., Sept. 12. -- The situation here to-night is graver than it has been since the affray of Friday afternoon. There is strong reason to fear a conflict between the strikers and the militia to-morrow, and there is an indication that from five to seven thousand more miners will join the malcontents.
LONDON, Sept. 13. -- Henry Riversdale Grenfell, Director of the Bank of England and a former Governor, has a letter in The Times this morning, in the course of which he says:

LONDON, Sept. 12. -- By invitation of the Rev. Canon Eyton, M.A., Canon Farrar's successor, the Rev. Dr. George R. Van de Water, Rector of St. Andrew's, Harlem, and Chaplain of Columbia University, preached in St. Margaret's, Westminster, this morning. His text was: "Be still, and know that I am God." A large congregation, including many prominent Americans, attended.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. -- The documented Merchant Marine of the United States on June 30 last numbered 22,633 vessels of 4,769,020 gross tons, an increase of 65,400 tons over June 30, 1896, and a decrease of 275 vessels. The tonnage of the Atlantic and Gulf coasts is 2,647,796, a decrease of 20,000 tons.
Our neighbor The Sun lifts its voice in devout thanksgiving at the delivery of the Republican organization from besetting temptations and great peril:

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 13. -- The finding of a case of yellow fever in the city hospital at Mobile has added to the excitement incident to the epidemic, making people fear it may come still further North. State Health Officer Saunders has officially announced the case at Mobile, but has thus far held it not necessary to establish a quarantine against Mobile, because it is thought the case there is isolated.
The following is Seth Low's formal letter of acceptance of the nomination of the Citizens' Union for Mayor of the City of New York:

NEWCASTLE, Ind., Sept. 13. -- A company of farmers were at work drilling a gas well near here yesterday, when a terrific explosion occurred, wrecking and burning the rig and burning nearly every one of the fifty men and boys about the derrick. Three men and a boy were fatally burned.

-- Too hearty commendation could hardly be given to the Federal and State authorities for the way in which they are handling the outbreak of yellow fever in Louisiana. On the one hand, they have avoided the danger of creating a needless panic, while, on the other, the gravity of the peril has been clearly and frankly recognized, and not only vigorous measures, but the best measures, have been taken to combat and remove it.
PRINCETON, Sept 13. -- The schedule of football games arranged by the Princeton athletic management was made public this afternoon as follows:

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 13. -- At a meeting of the Ministerial Union this morning the Rev. Alfred W. Wishart of the Central Baptist Church, though a leading reformer, preached in opposition to the race-track amendments which are to be voted upon on Sept. 28. Mr. Wishart said he thought the amendments unnecessary and harmful.

The English cricket team, under the lead of P.F. Warner, the young Middlesex amateur, opened its American tour yesterday at Staten Island, and the exhibition the players gave insures their success in this country.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 13. -- When people in New Orleans summed up matters to-day and found that there were nine imported cases here, and that they had been warned as to most of them, they decided to wait until the situation should become more aggravated before making a break for other parts. There was, therefore, no heavy outgoing travel and very little incoming.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- The following relating to the wheat situation is an extract from the complete monthly report of John Hyde, statistician of the Agricultural Department, which will be issued to-morrow:

CLEVELAND, Sept. 13. -- A formal tender of the services of the National Republican League to assist in his election to the United States Senate was made to-day to Mr. Hanna by John J. Sullivan and Melville Hayes, acting as a committee for the Executive Committee of the league. The two gentlemen were received by Mr. Hanna at his office, where Mr. Hayes presented to him the following statement:

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 13. -- C.W. Gates of the ranch firm of Vail Gates, Los Angeles, Cal., and Arizona, who is in the city, has just received an interesting letter from C.W. .Anderson, whom he grubstaked to go to the Klondike country. The letter is dated Skaguay Pass, dug. 17, and says, in part:

Ali Omar, an Algerian; his wife, Salla Allie, and Ali Ben Khelil, a native of Hindustan, were arrested yesterday and taken to Police Headquarters on suspicion of having committed a number of robberies in this city. The Orientals live at 96 Washington Street, in the Syrian colony. The woman's gown was fitted with large pockets, such as are used by shoplifters.

In the Summer of 1877 there was a railroad strike, extensive and desperate, organized by English-speaking employes who believed that they were being oppressed by the burdens of long hours, short wages, irregular payments, company stores, and other injustices that protest would not alleviate.

Cleo de Merode, premiere ballet dancer of the Grand Opera in Paris, the admiration of the Parisian boulevardier, the prized model of sculptors, and the protegee of a King, is here. She arrived on the steamship Spree yesterday morning, accompanied by her mamma, Maurice Forbee, manager of the Folies-Bergere, her personal representative; one maid, nine trunks, and a dog.

The Rapid Transit Commission appointed by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court met yesterday at 12:30 P.M. The Commissioners were all present. George Zabriskie appeared as counsel for the property holders affected by the construction of the rapid transit system, and A. B. Boardman as counsel for the commission. Mr. Zabriskie continued his examination of the heads of the city departments to show the cost of contemplated public improvements.
The Queens County Grand Jury will tomorrow investigate the alleged murder of William Guldensuppe in Woodside by Martin Thorn and Mrs. Nack.

If the gold discoveries at Lake Wawa turn out to be as important as the present reports indicate, it will be about the first time on record that this delightsome metal has been found in considerable quantities elsewhere than in a place several thousand miles from anywhere or anything except savage mountains and a few men and beasts as fierce as circumstances -- chiefly alimentary -- will permit them to be.

TACOMA, Washington, Sept. 13. -- Inspector Strickland of the Canadian Mounted Police makes the cheering statement that of the miners leaving Lakes Bennett and Linderman, twenty-five will probably reach Dawson City all right. He has spent two years on the Yukon and made the late trip by himself last Fall.

The hints of the free use of "campaign expenses" which have been current in Brooklyn during the past few days were brought to a head last evening by an open charge of attempted bribery by a Worth delegate against representatives of Lieut. Gov. Woodruff.

The Democratic Alliance met last night at 54 West Twenty-third Street, and by a unanimous vote decided to call a convention for Oct. 1, to nominate an independent Mayoralty ticket and adopt a platform which should reaffirm the Chicago platform and include planks declaring for municipal ownership and control of public franchises and direct employment by the city.

HOUSTON, Texas, Sept. 13. -- A severe hurricane visited the towns of Port Arthur and Sabine Pass, last night, inflicting considerable loss of life and property. The number of the dead is variously estimated at from twenty to thirty.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- The Cuban question and Section 22 of the tariff law will be the leading topics for discussion at the Cabinet meeting to-morrow.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13. -- The court by which Adolph L. Luetgert, the sausage maker, is being tried for alleged wife murder, adjourned abruptly at 11:30 this morning until 9:30 Wednesday on account of the illness of Juror John E. Fowler. He is suffering from malaria. If he becomes so ill that he has to retire from the jury it will mean a retrial of the entire ease.

For an hour and a half yesterday afternoon Central Park was the scene of wild and acrobatic fishing by men, women, and children of every age, race, and size. It was successful fishing, too, for the catch is estimated at several thousand white perch, which had been carefully raised and protected by the Park Commissioners.

The Citizens' Union and its candidate are of one mind and in full affinity as to the main issue of the Mayoralty contest, the principle of non-partisanship. The Union hewed true to the line unmoved by partisan solicitation and defiant of partisan threats in its method of nominating Mr. Low, and he accepts its nomination with a reiterative and emphatic assertion of his purpose to be completely independent of party if he is elected Mayor.

Senator Platt and County Chairman Quigg emphatically denied yesterday that there was any truth in the report that State organization leaders, among them Superintendent of Insurance Louis F. Payn and George W. Aldridge, Superintendent of Public Works, had advised the local leaders not to nominate a partisan Mayor, but to indorse the Citizens' Union nominee.

SIMLA, Sept. 13. -- The insurgents this morning captured the Sarhargarti police post. The post was attacked by a thousand Orakzais. A gallant defense was made by the garrison of twenty-one Sikhs, who, for six and a half hours, sustained three furious assaults. In the third assault the Orakzais forced the door.

COLUMBUS, Sept. 13. -- The Rev. G.F.B. Howard has escaped from the Ohio Penitentiary. He was a famous United States prisoner from Tennessee. He was trusted in the front office of the prison and walked away.

In constant communication with representatives of the various Southern interests, and closely acquainted with what is taking place in farming and industrial centres in the great States of the South, Mr. Emanuel Lehman of the firm of Lehman Brothers has had exceptional opportunities to observe the business conditions of that section of the country.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Sept. 4. -- It is feared that "the yellow flag" has been hoisted in this city, although the health authorities strenuously discredit any such suggestion. To the experienced eye, however, all the indications of the presence of the dread yellow jack are visible.

ALBANY, Sept. 13. -- The law relating to mileage books passed by the Legislature of 1895 will be subjected to a test as to its constitutionality. The law was made to compel all railroads operating over 100 miles of track in this State which charged over 2 cents a mile, to sell mileage books at the rate of 2 cents a mile.

Coroner Emil W. Hoeber addressed a largo number of Germans at a Citizens' Union meeting, at Broadway and Steinway Avenue, Long Island City, last night. He spoke first in German and then in English, and was frequently applauded.

HAZLETON, Penn., Sept. 13. -- Trouble has broken out at Coxe Brothers colliery at Eckley. Two hundred miners at Buck Mountain, which is about three miles from Eckley, went on strike this morning and started toward the Eckley mine. The Superintendent of the Eckley colliery telegraphed to Gen. Gobin for troops, but later in the day the request was withdrawn, the Superintendent notifying the General that the striking miners had stopped marching.

William W. Russell, United States Secretary of Legation at Caracas, Venezuela, has sent the Department of State a translation from the journal of the Venezuelan Chamber of Commerce, which shows the difference between the old and new tariff laws of the country.

TACOMA, Washington, Sept. 13. -- Mrs. E.A. Henderson, the first newspaper correspondent to take the trip to Dawson City, arrived on the Cleveland from St. Michael and is visiting friends in this city. She spent some months in the mining district, and gives some interesting experiences in the far north.

The Hudson County Grand Jury filed into court at 6 o'clock last night. Judge Lippincott was waiting to receive. He expected the Grand Jury to hand up an indictment against the managers of Little Monte Carlo in accordance with his instructions last week. Max Staples, the foreman, said the Grand Jury had found no additional indictments.
When the east side clan of the Sulilvans congregate there is sure to be what is known on the Bowery as a hot time.

HAZLETON, Penn., Sept. 13. -- Contrary to general expectation the burial of the miners shot by the Deputy Sheriffs at Lattimer Saturday passed off quietly. There was no trouble between the authorities and the miners, and despite the failure of the priests to enforce the agreement they had made with Gen. Gobin, the military kept their agreement to the letter, and did not intrude upon the funeral parties.

SEATTLE, Sept. 13. -- The steamer Humboldt arrived this morning from St. Michael. She brings fourteen passengers and about $15,000 in gold. The Humboldt also brings news that the side-wheel steamer Eliza Anderson, from Seattle, which was reported lost, is safe in Dutch Harbor.

To compare present prices in the stock market with the prices one year ago is like looking down from the mountain slopes to the valley. The interesting tables published on the financial pages of THE TIMES of yesterday exhibited not only the fluctuations of the past week, but gave for comparison the prices on Sept. 12 one year ago.

Wallack's Theatre, the interior of which has been completely renovated and transformed, was opened for the season last night. The prevailing tints in the mural decorations of the auditorium are now cream white, salmon pink, and gold. The floor of the parquette has been raised so that people in the front stalls are not compelled to stretch their necks to see the stage.

SAN SEBASTIAN, Sept. 13. -- The retiring United States Minister to Spain, Hannis O. Taylor, was received in audience by the Queen Regent to-day, and presented his letters of recall. Soon afterward the new United States Minister to Spain, Gen. Stewart L. Woodford, was received by her Majesty and presented his credentials.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 13. -- President McKinley returned to Washington this afternoon from Somerset, Penn. The special train which carried the Presidential party consisted of President Cowen's private car Baltimore, the Pullman chair car Abigail, which served as a reception car at the various stopping places on the way, and a combination car in the lead.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 13. -- Emma Haas and three other women were arrested for marching at Plum Creek this morning, by Sheriff's Deputies. The attempt to make the arrests precipitated a riot, in which the Deputies fared badly. No one was hurt seriously, but hardly a Deputy escaped a clubbing.

Ware Gibbs have sold for Walworth Ward to a Mr. Mackey the five-story American basement brownstone-front dwelling 133 West Seventy-second Street, 22 by 1022. This was formerly the residence of Ferral C. Dinniny, but was-given by him to Mr. Ward about three months ago in part payment for the house at the southwest corner of Riverside Drive and Ninety-first Street.
CHICAGO, Sept. 14. -- The first round in the amateur championship golf tournament of the United States was played on the links of the Chicago Golf Club at Wheaton to-day.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 14. -- Sabine Pass suffered greatly from the storm. All of the small shipping at both the new and the old town was destroyed. The old town was wrecked, and many of the larger vessels were badly damaged. Only the large buildings in the new town remain standing. During the storm six feet of water covered the town.
The catboat Edwina has been stolen from her moorings in front of the Huguenot Yacht Clubhouse at .New Rochelle. Her owner, J. Nelson Gould, has been unable to find any trace of her.

Rumors that a conflict will arise among the members of the New York State Division of the League of American Wheelmen over the election of Chief Consul are considerably agitating the cycle world at present, the sentiment of which is controlled largely by the big organization.

COPENHAGEN, Sept. 14. -- Joseph L. Harris of New York, an alleged incendiary, is under arrest here charged with attempting to swindle a hotel keeper. His identity was discovered by reference to a cable dispatch sent to the Prefectures of Police throughout Europe in 1894, describing the prisoner as a man for whose arrest a reward of $2,500 would be paid in New York City.
PROVIDENCE, Sept. 14. -- President Andrews of Brown University has written the following letter withdrawing his resignation:

The war of PLATT on WORTH in Brooklyn possesses a deep psychological as well as a political interest. WORTH is not a moralist or a reformer. He is in politics for the most practical reasons, and it was not sentiment or lofty principle that brought him in collision with PLATT.

CHICAGO, Sept. 14. -- Wheat made a great show of strength for about two hours to-day, but slumped and closed with a modest advance of three-eighths of a cent for the December option. It showed 2 1/4 cents' advance at one time. Foreign crop shortages caused the early advance, and a large visible supply increase was responsible in the main for the subsequent decline.
There is not a child in this city who cannot have a desk in a public school, according to a statement made yesterday by Superintendent Jasper of the Board of Education.

After having had a long conference with Senator T.C. Platt, Chairman Quigg of the Republican County Committee gave out the following statement yesterday in regard to Seth Low's letter of acceptance of the Citizens' Union nomination for Mayor:

To avoid collision with a small coal schooner, the Atlantic Transport Line steamship Mississippi, bound in from London, ran her nose into the mud south of Fort Wadsworth at 7:20 o'clock last night, and at a late hour was still fast, with little prospect of being hauled off before high tide this morning.
The New Yorks lost the game with the Brooklyns at Eastern Park yesterday afternoon by making rank errors on easy chances at critical periods.

The United Loan and Investment Company took title yesterday to the old Bank for Savings property, on the north side of Bleecker Street, 150 feet east of Broadway. The consideration is reported to be in the neighborhood of $200,000, for $150,000 of which amount the purchasers give a mortgage, payable in three years.

A writer in a recent number of The Boston Transcript, evidently a writer familiar with the conditions of cotton manufacture in New England, discusses with unconcealed anxiety the prospect of an early loss of a goodly portion of the cotton goods export trade that has been cultivated assiduously during the past few years.

The Democratic State Committee will meet at noon to-day in the Hoffman House, and if the present plans of the leaders are not changed it will nominate Supreme Court Justice Alton B. Parker of Kingston for Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals. It probably will adopt no platform nor reaffirm the Chicago or Buffalo doctrines of last year. The plan is to leave the matter severely alone.

At irregular intervals the question of establishing what is called a "National naval reserve" is agitated, and occasionally something of a practical nature is suggested. More frequently something unpractical, or at least extremely uncertain in value, is put forth. One of the most unpractical suggestions made recently is that, the National naval reserve being formed, the naval militia organizations of the various States should be merged in it.
A large proportion of the out-of-town merchants and buyers who visited the headquarters of the Merchants' Association yesterday were from places in this State, in Pennsylvania, and in Delaware.

HAZLETON, Penn., Sept. 14. -- Despite a variety of alarming rumors and a morning movement by a body of miners which looked formidable, to-day passed off without serious disturbance in the strike region. Matters still wear such an uncertain aspect, however, that Gen. Gobin declares that the removal of the troops, or any portion of them, has not been contemplated.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 14. -- Edward Calahan, the alleged leader of the Ku-Klux, which organization has waged a relentless warfare on the Red Strings in Breathitt County, has been removed as Chairman of the Democratic County Committee of Breathitt by Major Johnston, Chairman of the State Central Committee.

County Clerk Jacob Worth of Kings lost control of the General Committee at its meeting last night, in the Johnston Building, at Flatbush Avenue and Fulton Street, Brooklyn, to determine when the primaries and conventions should be held. The vote on the resolution offered by Silas B. Dutcher to change the dates tentatively fixed by the Executive Committee, which was controlled by the Worth faction, stood: For, 107; against, 98.

Enthusiastic views as to the condition of business affairs in the West have been frequently published for some weeks past. Many of the opinions so expressed have represented the results of the observations of railroad men, and in some quarters there is a tendency to think that -- notwithstanding this reliable index to what is going on generally -- the railroad interests are the principal gainers through the advent of these good times.

Some of the Republican newspapers express the opinion that by saying "I am a Republican, and expect to remain one," Mr. Low has made it easier for Mr. PLATT'S organization to accept him as its candidate. Possibly Mr. Low had the Republican organization in mind when he penned that phrase.

A wonderful deal of work has been accomplished during the last year in the way of providing school accommodations for the children of New York. It is not to the advantage of Tammany that children should be educated, and for many years the schools had been regarded by the politicians as pretexts for the disbursement of money and for the distribution of "patronage."

A tall, well-dressed young man has lately been carrying on operations with forged orders purporting to come from the American News Company, and by means of which he has obtained a good many dollars' worth of merchandise.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept 14. -- The Republican Town Convention held here this evening to select delegates to the County Convention, to be held at White Plains on Tuesday, was the warmest gathering that ever assembled in the village. Well-known villagers swore at each other, called each other names, and threatened each other with all kinds of bodily harm until the police arrived.

BOSTON, Sept. 14. -- The will of Nathan Springfield, one of the wealthiest colored men in Boston, was contested in the Supreme Court to-day before Justice Lathrop and a jury. Springfield was born in Virginia in the year 1812, a slave. Dec. 16, 1896, when nearly eighty-five years of age, he died, leaving property valued at between $30,000 and $40,000.

LIVERPOOL, Sept. 14. -- The White Star Line steamship Majestic, Capt. Smith, which sails from this port for New York to-morrow, will take among her passengers the Marquis of Ailesbury, Justice and Lady Barnes, and Mr. and Mrs. Bancroft Davis.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- Several prominent New York Republicans arrived in Washington to-day. Among the number was Senator T.C. Platt, who came down to have an interview with President McKinley on the subject of several New York appointments which are still "hanging fire."

The attendance at our exposition is increasing daily, and nothing can prevent the ultimate success of this great enterprise, unless it be an erroneous impression which may be allowed to grow in the East regarding Nashville's proximity to the yellow fever district.

It is of no use for Lady Burton, along with many others, to give advice to wives, or for N.L.S., your correspondent in the Monday issue of THE TIMES, to counsel husbands, American or otherwise, on how to treat their wives.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 14. -- Considerable "loafing," with intervals in which fairly good time was made, were the features of the first day of the big three days' race meet of the Springfield Bicycle Club, which was devoted to running the trial heats on the famous Hampden Park track before a large crowd and under excellent weather conditions.

HARTFORD, Sept. 14. -- De Koven and Smith's new musical comedy, "The Paris Doll," had its initial performance at Parsons's Theatre, here this evening before a crowded house The production was under the stage management of Max Freeman, and was witnessed by Reginald De Koven and Harry E. Smith, the authors.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 14. -- United States Senator George L. Wellington to-day resigned the Chairmanship of the Republican State Central Committee, thus relinquishing the leadership of the party in this State, which he has held for the last three years. This action was taken at a meeting of the committee, and was the result of the Senator's defeat at the recent convention in Ocean City.

The Metropolitan Traction Company, having accomplished the object of its organization by uniting in one system a large proportion of the surface railroads in this city, was formally dissolved yesterday.

Mr. Low must make haste to get his responsibility on exhibition or else Mr. ERNEST HARVIER will not vote for him. Mr. HARVIER'S mind is troubled, not to say harrowed, by the contemplation of Mr. Low's "non-responsibility." That is what Mr. HARVIER calls it, and as he is the person who is suffering from it, he ought to know its name.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Sept. 14. -- Another chapter has been added to the Brown elopement case, which set all the residents of this town and Fair Ground to laughing last week. At that time the pretty twenty-year-old wife of Mortimer Brown became interested simultaneously in a Summer novel and a pair of mustaches belonging to one Charles Ward McDevitt.

BERLIN, Sept. 14. -- Round No. 5 of the Berger schedule was adopted to-day for the second round of the international chess tournament, now in progress at the Architekton Haus, Wilhelmstrasse, in this city. The following was the pairing:
Can you spare me space for a point or two concerning the current criticism of the Citizens' Union and its policy?

George M. Judd, an attorney until recently in the employ of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company, was arrested yesterday, accused of misappropriating about $15,000 paid to him on account of the company. The arrest was made by Detective McNaught of the District Attorney's office, at the office of the company, 146 Broadway.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- Judge Cox of the Supreme Court of the District of Columbia to-day dismissed the bill of complaint of John G. Wood, Superintendent of Mails at Louisville, praying that Postmaster General Gary and Assistant Postmaster General Heath be enjoined from removing him from office. The case has been considered in the nature of a test of the power of removal.

Careful observers of simple facts have frequently expressed the opinion that the comparative immunity of this city from house flies and the general disappearance of the sparrows are to be attributed to the system of street sweeping established by Col. WARING, assisted, in a measure, by the substitution of cables and electricity for horses on some of the street railways.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 14. -- A face slapping occurred in the corridor of the Monongahela House this evening, between coal mine operators, which ended in a challenge to fight a duel. Col. W.P. Rend of Chicago, the millionaire operator with mines in Ohio and Pennsylvania, was the belligerent.

When the followers of the turf left the Gravesend track on the last day of the Spring meeting they saw an infield barren save for a well-grown crop of clover. The Fall meeting opened there yesterday, but those who looked for the old infield were surprised to find that it was dotted here and there with the whitewashed fences of one of the best steeplechase courses in the country.

Eugene Gondier, a prisoner at Jefferson Market Court, yesterday afternoon tried to kill himself by beating his head against the bars of the prison pen door. When discovered by the court attendants he was dripping with blood and soon fell unconscious. He was taken to Bellevue Hospital, where it was found that his wounds were superficial.

A meeting of the Law and Order League of Hudson County was held at the Bergen Reformed Church, Jersey City, on Monday night to adopt plans to insure the success of the constitutional amendments at the polls on Sept. 28. The Rev. Cornelius Brett, Vice President of the league, presided.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 14. -- It is rapidly becoming apparent that the estimate of 150,000,000 bushels as the wheat crop of Minnesota and the Dakotas, made recently by Col. G.D. Rogers, Secretary of the Minneapolis Chamber of Commerce, is too great by at least 20,000,000 bushels, and probably by 25,000,000 bushels.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14. -- The last game of the season on the Washington grounds was poorly played by both teams, but full of the uncertainty which keeps up interest. The llnlsh, when four singles and a base on balls brought in the winning xm, was one of wild excitement. The game was called at the end of the sixth inning on account of darlcness. Score:

SAMLA, Sept. 14. -- There are now 59,000 men and ninety guns, including Maxims, mobilized on the frontier and in the garrisons. Everything is ready for the advance from Shabkadr. The men are in splendid condition.

SEATTLE, Washington, Sept. 14. -- Capt. Joseph Whitesides of the lost whaler Navarch, his wife, and several of the vessel's crew came here on the steamer Humholdt, which arrived from St. Michael's today. They tell the story of the wreck, of which a first account was received a few days ago.

Judging from the shrinkage in the fields at the Fall meeting of the Parkway Driving Club yesterday the early-closing plan of arranging events for the harness racers does not work any better across the bridge than it did at Fleetwood. Out of 28 entries in the two classes on the card for the opening day, only eight appeared.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 132 -- The champions w(m their final game with Chicago to-day. Of the twelve games played Baltimore won hint,. The. game was noted for brilliant phtys. Score:

Confirmation of the nominations made by the Board of Superintendents, the approval of two sites for new schools, and the discussion and adoption of the report of the Finance Committee, presenting the budget for the ensuing year, took up nearly all the time of yesterday's meeting of the Board of Education.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 15. -- The steam yacht Mayflower arrived at 2 o'clock this afternoon from Cowes, England, with the body of Ogden Goelet, who died on board the vessel while at anchor there several weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- Senator Platt of New York arrived at the White House shortly before noon to-day, and was immediately shown to the Cabinet room, where the President was receiving callers. With the Senator were Representative Odell of Newburg, N.Y., and Capt. J.M. Dickey, who is a candidate for the position of Shipping Commissioner at New York.

An uncommonly large number of out-of-town merchants registered at the headquarters of the Merchants' Association yesterday, carrying the total registration of visiting buyers above 3,000. Nearly one-half of this number have already been furnished with certificates for reduced-fare tickets on their homeward trips.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 15. -- A day of interesting racing was closed by Jimmy Michael's victory over the well-known Frenchman, Lucien Lesna, in a twenty-mile paced match race for a purse of $1,500, in which the midget Welshman, after one of the finest races in his career, crossed the finish line 150 yards ahead of his competitor, lowering the American record for the distance by 23-5 seconds.

TACOMA, Washington, Sept. 15. -- The Northern Pacific steamer Tacoma has arrived, bringing Oriental advices up to Aug. 27. Count Matsu died of consumption Aug. 24. On the Sunday previous he was promoted by imperial favor to the first class of the second grade in Court rank, and it was then known that the end was at hand.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15. -- The fortifications which are intended to protect Philadelphia from foreign invasion are situated thirty-four miles down the Delaware River, at old Fort Delaware, and consist of one main battery, with supplemental batteries almost as powerful on the adjacent shores of Delaware and New Jersey.

The exhibition at the Cooper Union last night to demonstrate to the public the practical workings of the Street Cleaning Department was largely attended. Most of the street-cleaning force was present. There were not more than a dozen empty seats in the hall. Mayor Strong called the meeting to order, and told the story of his selection of Col. Waring to be Commissioner of Street Cleaning.

More than 600 of the 807 delegates elected at the primaries of the German-American Reform Union in June assembled last night at the Grand Central Palace for the purpose of organizing and electing officers for the ensuing year. The meeting was slated for 8 o'clock, but it was 9 o'clock before President E.J.H. Tamsen took the chair.

Martin Korker keeps a grocery at Bull's Ferry Road and Hudson Avenue, Guttenberg. The second floor is occupied by M.A. Gillardoni, an artist. He placed a sign on Korker's coal-box and Korker tore it down. Gillardoni complained that the coal-box, which stood on the sidewalk, was a nuisance, and Charles Stell, the owner of the building, had the box moved to the rear of the store.

Gas consolidation -- the combining of all the New York companies -- was the talk of Wall Street yesterday. All gas stocks scored advances on the Stock Exchange and the curb. But the most extraordinary increase in quotation was that of Consolidated Gas, whose range was from 224 to 237 1/2, the net advance being 17. It closed on Tuesday at 220 bid, 221 asked, and last evening at 237 1/2 bid and 240 asked.

When Senator GORMAN had fulfilled the measure of his iniquity by coming out for BRYAN, the good people of Maryland avenged themselves upon him by turning the State over to the Republicans. One of the consequences of this transfer was the election of Mr. GEORGE L. WELLINGTON to the Senate to succeed a Democrat, unfortunately not GORMAN.

There was a very brief session of the Police Board yesterday. Commissioner Andrews had received notice of the death of his father in Massena, N.Y., and the business was hurried through to enable him to catch a train for that place. Mr. Parker did not reach Headquarters until after adjournment at 10:30 o'clock.
Alton B. Parker of Ulster County was nominated for Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals by the Democratic Committee yesterday at its meeting in the Hoffman House.

-Ir. George J. Gould's return from Europe is likely to be followed by disclosures, no his friends say, of -A new disposition on his part to take a more active interest ill Wall Street matters than he has ever shown before. Some of the largest financial interests in tile country are said to htLve talked plaihly to Mr. Gould, and brought to his attention the exceptional opportunities opening up before him.

BOSTON, Sept. 15. -- Delegates to the National Convention of Colored Baptists, which opened in the Ebenezer Church here to-day, have been arriving in town on different trains all day, and already there are about 500 in town. The convention represents nearly 2,000,000 of colored Baptists.

P.F. Warner's English team of cricketers came very near to being defeated by the New York eleven yesterday at Staten Island. Lack of time, however, made it a draw. The New Yorks batted splendidly, bowled well, and their fielding was vastly improved over that of the previous day.

JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 15. -- The State capital is depopulated, its business houses are closed, and its newspapers suspended. Seven cases of yellow fever are officially announced at its very doors, with many suspected cases at various points, an embargo has been placed on the railroads; and there are grave apprehensions that the dread disease has obtained a foothold in numerous parts of the State.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 15. -- The White House was thronged with official visitors to-day, and the President was kept busy from an early hour with the steady stream of callers. The first was Judge Day, Assistant Secretary of State, who came at 8:15 o'clock. He and the President conversed for some time, presumably in relation to Cuban affairs and Gen. Leu's visit, although no information as to the nature of the call was obtainable.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15. -- Illinois, Indiana, and Iowa are parched. Until last evening Kansas was in the same condition, but rain came. Weather Bureau men say grateful showers are due in the other States in a few days.

BERLIN, Sept. 15. -- To-day the third round of the international chess tournament was played at the Architekten Haus, 92 and 93 Wilhelmstrasse, in this city, when Round 4 of the Berger schedule finished the pairing, which was as follows:

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 15. -Josephine Carson and John Shanaphy were married in jail here to-day. Josephine was arrested about three months ago, on the charge of disorderly conduct. Shanaphy was arrested for stealing an anchor from the docks at Perth Amboy. He was held for the Grand Jury to decide upon his case.

The steamer Catskill, Capt. Joel Cooper, bound for Catskill and way points with forty-seven passengers and freight, was run down and sunk in the North River at 7 o'clock P.M. yesterday by the excursion steamer St. Johns, Capt. Jacob Braisted, of the Sandy Hook Line.

Several Republicans of National prominence, men who are equally friendly with President McKinley, Seth Low, and Senator Thomas C. Platt, have begun to exert a powerful influence toward the effecting of a compromise between the Republican Organization and the Citizens' Union, based upon Senator Platt's indorsement of Mr. Low for Mayor. Secretary of the Interior Cornelius N. Bliss, it is said, is one of these men.

The Stock Exchange firm of Seymour Brothers made a general assignment without preferences yesterday afternoon to ex-Judge Charles Donohue. The document was filed in the County Clerk's office at 3:53 P.M. only a few minutes before the office closed for the day. The failure was not announced on the Exchange, which had closed nearly an hour before the assignment was filed.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 15. -- The Republican State Convention, which adjourned from Ocean City on Aug. 26, reassembled in this city to-day for the purpose of completing the work begun at the previous session. In the interim many things have happened that materially alter the political situation in Maryland and render the outcome of the election in November more doubtful than ever.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 15. -- The long-overdue steamer Excelsior, which left St. Michael, Alaska, for this port six weeks ago, but was compelled to put back to Unalaska for repairs, after having broken two blades of her propeller, arrived here this morning with sixty-three passengers and, it is reported, with a large amount of gold.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 15. -- The State Civil Service Commission to-day met in this city to pass upon the rules submitted for the governing of appointments to the Police Department of New York, also appointments in Albany, Yonkers, and Long Island City.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15. -- The prosecution in the Luetgert trial is nearing its end, and the announcement was made to-day that it would probably have all of its witnesses on the stand by Saturday noon. The evidence given to-day weighed heavily against Luetgert, and no more damaging testimony has been given against him than that from Prof. George A. Dorsey, from the Field Columbian Museum, who was on the stand this afternoon.

CHICAGO, Sept. 15. -- The National golf tournament, on the links of the Chicago Golf Club, at Wheaton, was somewhat handicapped by a strong wind and hot weather to-day. The preliminary round to determine the four players for the semi-finals brought out the sixteen honor men.

A modest appearing young woman entered a drug store in Madison Avenue one morning recently and walking to the end of the counter nearest the prescription department mutely held out both hands toward a clerk who chanced to be standing in that particular place. This clerk, equally mute, reached behind a screen and brought out a blue-glass bottle from which a brush handle protruded.

The trophy which goes to the winners of the Adjutant General's Match will remain in the hands of its present possessors -- the Thirteenth Separate Company, Jamestown, N.Y. The match was shot off at Creedmoor yesterday, ten teams of three men each competing.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 15. -- It was estimated to-day that fully 5,000 coal diggers are already at work in the Pittsburg district. The mines of Robert Jenkins, the Ella Coal Company, and the Webster Company, on the Lake Erie Railroad, and the mines of the Allen Coal Company, on the Pittsburg, Virginia and Charleston Railway, were in full operation yesterday. A number of diggers have gone to work at other mines on these roads.

Nearly 300 manufacturers of knit goods, representing every part of the country where such goods are made, met here yesterday and resolved on an immediate advance of from 15 to 40 per cent. in prices and a continued advance, if it is necessary, to insure a profit at the prices paid for wool and cotton.

Carrying coals to Newcastle is in our day an understatement of the apparent absurdity of importing steel for Birmingham. Yet our news columns yesterday bore witness that this latter feat has been accomplished. A rolling mill in Cleveland, Ohio, has received an order for 1,000 tons of bar steel from manufacturers in Birmingham.

Our German neighbor the Staats-Zeitung sums up the results of the Republican passage at arms in Brooklyn on Tuesday evening in a manner at once subtle and lucid: "At first blush the outcome of the war between WORTH and PLATT gives the impression that both sides have won and lost and that the battle is still undecided."

VICTORIA, B.C., Sept. 15. -- Dr. Franz Boaz, who for ten years has been making a study of British Columbia Indians for the British Association, is again in this city, with Dr. Farrand. He came down from the north on the steamer Tees. Dr. Farrand made a study of the customs and traditions of Chilkoot Indians at Port Essington.

HAVANA, (via Key West, Fla.,) Sept. 15. -- During the last two days the inhabitants of the City of Havana have been without meat. Milk also is very scarce. Only the sick in the hospitals are supplied regularly with either article

SEATTLE, Washington, Sept. 15. -- The golden stream from the Klondike, which set in last July with the arrival of the steamers Portland and Excelsior with $1,500,000, shows no signs of approaching cessation. Add to the sum brought down by the various steam and sailing vessels from St. Michael the fifty-thousand-dollar cargo of the schooner Volante, arriving to-day, and the round total is $3,000,000.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 15. -- The tramps who were to have been placed in the chain gang this morning went on strike, and would not allow the shackles to be placed on their legs. They refused to leave their cells in the county jail. Two of them thought better of it after a few minutes and presented themselves for work, and were out all day.
It is now thought that Nicholas Heinlein of 260 Vap Sicklen Avenue, who was found dead, face-down, in three feet of water in a pond at Kingston Avenue and President Street, Brooklyn, was murdered.

SIMLA, Sept. 15. -- The operations of the troops under the command of Gen. Yeatman-Biggs, undertaken for the purpose of relieving the Samana posts, have been entirely successful. The police post at Sarhargarti has been recaptured by the British forces, the troops carrying the position by assault.

HAZLETON, Penn., Sept. 15. -- A calm pervaded Hazleton to-day, and no disturbances were reported. The strikers maintain silence and good order. An extra guard has been placed about the company store at Lattimer in consequence of a rumor that the foreigners were plotting to blow up the building with dynamite. They have ceased dealing there, and are now buying their supplies in Hazleton. Some of them are moving into town.

Slawson Hobbs have sold, for James Carlew, the four-story brownstone-front dwelling, with extension, 323 West Eighty-eighth Street, 20 by 58 by 100.8. This is the second house sold by Mr. Carlew of the row of five which were completed about three months ago.

LONDON, Sept. 15. -- Mr. John Henniker-Heaton, Member of Parliament for Canterbury, an authority on postal reform, and one of the projectors of the recent cable chess match between teams representing the House of Commons and the House of Representatives at Washington, is making arrangements for a Parliamentary cricket team to make a tour of the British Empire in 1898.
