OSGOOD, Ind., Sept. 15. -- Incensed by numerous depredations, repeated burglaries, and daylight robberies, the people of Ripley County. Ind., last night lynched five men who had long been a terror to the citizens of the county. When the citizens of Versailles, the county seat, arose this morning they found the bodies of the five men dangling from as many limbs of an elm tree in the centre of the public square.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Sept. 16. -- The semiannual meeting of the Hunters' Association of Suffolk County was held to-day at their home, comprising an acre of ground on the shore of Great Pond, near here.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 16. -- Reginald De Koven and Harry B. Smith, the authors of the operatic comedy "The Paris Doll," which closed a two nights' engagement in this city to-night, will consult counsel in New York to-morrow in reference to the securing of an injunction to restrain Oscar Hammerstein from producing his new piece, "La Poupee," at the Olympia.

It is a great pity that National characteristics and influences cannot be aken into consideration in dealing with labor disorders in this country. Our system is one designed to agree with the nature and purpose of a republican Government, but there have been many indications that it is defeated in its workings by the utter lack of ability on the part of foreign laborers to understand the spirit of republicanism.

Three days before the schools opened on Monday Superintendent Jasper estimated the first day's enrollment of children at about 200,000. He said that all but 7,000 could be accommodated, and before Sept. 20 those who could not find seats would be received in half-day classes.

ROME, Sept. 16. -- The Oneida County Republican Convention here to-day nominated W.H. Reese of Utica for Sheriff, G.D. Frank of Utica for County Clerk, Louis Mittenmaier of Rome for Superintendent of the Poor, and Thomas G. Nock of Rome for Coroner.

Two letters of significance were received by the Merchants' Association yesterday. One was from L.P. Farmer, Commissioner of the Passenger Department of the Trunk Line Association, informing President William F. King that his formal application for additional excursion rates in October had been placed on the docket for consideration on the 21st of this month.

HAZLETON, Penn., Sept. 16. -- The American Federation of Labor has taken up the cause of the mine workers in this region. Their organizers are at work here, and a uniform scale will be formulated and presented to the operators. There will be no marching or anything in the way of a demonstration, and no attempt will be made to bring about sympathetic strike movements.

JACKSON, Miss., Sept. 16. -- No more persons are leaving the city, for two reasons -- there are very few left here, and none of these can get out on account of the rigid quarantine thrown around the town. Business is dead, the town having gotten rid of the excitable persons (to the number of several thousand) the chances of those remaining are correspondingly increased should trouble occur and the people are, therefore, feeling easier.

A young man with a buggy-shaft piercing his body just below the heart was taken to Bellevue Hospital at 12:30 o'clock this morning. He was unconscious, and was immediately taken into the operating room and his injury attended to by the surgeons.

At the conclusion of Mayor Carter H. Harrison's visit to Mayor Strong yesterday morning he was asked about the trouble that he had with the Pennsylvania Railroad in regard to passes for himself and party from Chicago to New York. He replied:

CHICAGO, Sept. 16. -- The day was given over to expert testimony in the Luetgert trial, and the attorneys for the defense and the witnesses for the State wrangled vigorously regarding femurs of human beings femurs of sheep, and of hogs. When court adjourned for the day the fight was still on an will be resumed to-morrow morning. When court opened this morning the defendant came in upon a pair of crutches.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 16. -- Democratic caucuses were held in most of the towns and cities in Western Massachusetts to-night. There were no contests, little interest was taken, and they were poorly attended. The delegates were instructed in only one or two instances.
Henry D. Winans May have sold, for the estate of Alfred Roosevelt, the twenty-five-foot American basement dwelling, 805 Fifth Avenue, between Sixty-first and Sixty-second Streets.

NEW BRUNSWICK, Sept. 16. -- Five of the ten men who are in jail under sentence under the tramp act, still refuse to work. Three were at work to-day, and two are ill, and were excused from work. The five who are rebellious and refuse to work no longer enjoy the comforts of the nice warm cells of the jail proper, but live and sleep in the old workhouse building.

BERLIN, Sept. 16. -The fourth round of the international chess tournament was played in this city at the Architekten Haus to-day, when the eleventh round of the Berger schedule was adopted for the pairing, which read as follows:
The sinking of the steamboat Catskill, which was rammed in the North River off West Fifty-eighth Street by the steamboat St. Johns Wednesday evening, is now thought to have cost at least three lives.

NEWPORT, Sept. 16. -- On the steam yacht Mayflower this afternoon funeral services were held over the body of the late Ogden Goelet. Only members of the family of Mr. Goelet were allowed on board the vessel.

CITY OF MEXICO, Sept. 16. -- An attack was made shortly after 10 o'clock this morning on President Diaz as he was proceeding from the palace to the Alameda to distribute medals to the survivors of the war. The city is in a fever of excitement over the matter, and many conflicting stories are in circulation.
RALEIGH, N.C., Sept. 16. -- Avery Butler, a well-known convict of Sampson County, and a relative of Senator Marion Butler, has been pardoned by Gov. Russell.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 16. -- Record-breaking was the feature of the last day of the great race meet of the Springfield Bicycle Club on the Hampden Park track to-day. Incited by the cheering of thousands of spectators, competition was fierce among the swift riders who had survived the pace of the trials to fight out the finals, and the times were remarkably good.

The suit of the New York and Westchester Water Company against the Hotchkiss Gun and Joseph Richardson estates, involving $6,000,000 in investments, has been settled. The litigants, with the assistance of Moses R. Crow, one of the plaintiffs, accomplished a settlement which, practically, turns over the entire water works properties to the widows and heirs of the above estates for future developments.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 16. -- President C.C. Shayne of the New York Merchants and Manufacturers' Association spoke here to-day at a meeting held for the formation of a similar organization. Among other things he said:

JAMAICA, L.I., Sept. 16. -- The Jamaica Volunteer Fire Department to-day made its one hundredth and last public parade, and was assisted in the function by volunteer firemen from other parts of Long Island. Jamaica will be part of Greater New York. The separate existence, the Fire Department, police force, and bonded indebtedness of this venerable village are all to be absorbed.

SIMLA, Sept. 16. -- The Second Brigade of the Mohmand punitive force, commanded by Gen. Jeffreys, reached the foot of the Rawat Pass on Tuesday last. During the night the British troops were attacked by the enemy, who kept up a heavy fire for six hours. Lieuts. Tomkins and Bailey were killed. Lieut. Harrington was dangerously wounded, two privates were killed, five privates were wounded, and twenty-five horses and mules were killed.

Tghy should a Republican newspaper worry about the color of a two-cent postage stamp when it Is grappling with so momentous a problem as that of getting a Plait ticket that can be elected? The postage stampmbe it green or red or black and blue---will stick as well and carry a letter as far.

It is not probable that Madden's great two-year-old Hamburg will be seen in a race again this year, for after he had won the Excelsior Stakes at Gravesend yesterday he pulled up lame. It was discovered that his foreleg had filled up, but no serious results are expected.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16. -- Well-defined rumors were current on La Salle Street to-day to the effect that an end had been reached in the war of the biscuit companies and a plan of consolidation, embracing the New York Biscuit Company, the American Biscuit Company, and the United States Biscuit Company, agreed upon. These companies have a combined capital stock of $3,000,000, and practically control the biscuit output of the United States.

ALBANY, Sept. 16. -- Gov. Black has appointed William N. Cohen of New York City as a Justice of the Supreme Court for the First Judicial District, to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Judge John Sedgwick.
Activity on the Stock Exchange did not diminish yesterday, but in a number of quarters there appeared indications suggestive of a growing disposition among traders to be exceptionally prudent.

CHICAGO, Sept. 16. -- The most sensational event of the National golf tournament occurred to-day when W.R. Betts of the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club beat C.B. MacDonald of the Chicago Golf Club. MacDonald was the 1895 champion, being displaced by Whigham in 1896, and was confidently expected to regain the championship this year.

Richard Croker left town yesterday and said that he would not be back for a week. He did not leave word at his office where he was going, and it is thought there that he had gone to Elberon to visit Senator Murphy. It was said afterward by one of Mr. Croker's friends that he had gone for a trip on Col. Jacob Ruppert, Jr.'s, yacht.

Although partisan Republicans, including Mr. PLATT and our neighbor The Sun, are disappointed and chagrined at the determination of the New York Democrats to let the dead past bury its dead, every good citizen whose patriotism is not stifled by party bias will rejoice that the Democratic State Committee baffled the silver men and ignored Bryanism.

At the meeting of the Park Board yesterday morning, Corporation Counsel Scott submitted an opinion to the effect that money derived from the sale of buildings condemned for the making of new parks should go to the city. The law says that money derived from the sale of condemned material shall go to the Park Police Pension Fund, and it has been applied there heretofore.

NEWARK, N. J., Sept. 16. --Mayor Maybaun of the Borough of Vailsburg, where the grounds of the Newark Baseball Club are situated, has reconsidered his determination to stop Sunday ball games, and has given permission for the game at Shooting Park next Sunday between the Newarks and Baltimores.

The fact that John McCullagh took the oath of office as Chief of Police, under the directions of President Moss, as soon as it was learned that the State Civil Service Board had approved the regulations and amendment sent for their approval by the local Police Department does not make him Chief of Police, nor does it entitle him to the salary of that office.

Olga Norr, twenty-one years old, of 235 East Thirteenth Street, committed suicide last night by inhaling gas. She was a widow only three weeks, and killed herself because she could not bear to live without her husband, William Norr, a well-known newspaper writer, the man who is said to have discovered "Chuck" Connors of Chinatown.
MOBILE, Ala., Sept. 16. -- The Board of Health reports one new case of yellow fever to-day, making five cases in all declared. Anotone Hagan died of yellow fever this afternoon.

We printed yesterday a temperately expressed defense of lynching from a Georgian correspondent. Perhaps he would object to having it called a defense, but it is at least safe to describe it as a sympathetic explanation. When he says that "the only ground of objection to this mode of dealing with these criminals is the fear that the innocent might suffer," we take issue with him.

When Brooklyn and Washington meet on the ball field a close game is invariably the result. Yesterday was no exception to the rule, and the Grooms defeated the Senators at Eastern Park in a game that was replete with brilliant plays.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 16. -- Nine million dollars of the stock of the Cincinnati, Indianapolis and Louisville Railroad Company (the Monon) was represented at the annual meeting of stockholders here yesterday. E.C. Field, the general counsel of the company, presided, and W.H. Lewis was Secretary. New Directors were elected and classified as follows:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- Commissioner Butterworth and Assistant Commissioner Greely of the Patent Office are engaged in putting in shape amendments to be offered to the treaty existing among the leading nations of the world for the protection of industrial property. A meeting of the representatives of these nations has been called to convene in Brussels next December, and it is the purpose of this country to secure certain modifications of the present agreement.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- President McKinley and the members of his Cabinet to-day attended the cornerstone laying of the handsome new synagogue to be erected by the Washington Hebrew congregation on Eighth Street, near H.
What is the Platt-Quigg Party? How much is there left of it? Is there any left of it but the empty framework of the organization, a staff without an army, leaders without a following?

The Rapid Transit Commissioners were all present yesterday at 12:30 p.m., and more evidence was taken as to the expensiveness of a system of underground railway. Almost the entire examination of witnesses was left to Mr. Zabriskie, counsel for the objecting property holders, and the testimony brought out was to show that the cost of the system had been greatly underestimated.
LONDON, Sept. 16. -- At the semi-annual meeting of the Bank of England to-day, the Governor, Hugh C. Smith, said:

ANNAPOLIS, Sept. 16. -- Over a score of September cadets admitted during the present examinations have qualified and entered upon their arduous duties at the Naval Academy. The academy authorities now lose no time in taking a firm grasp on the successful candidates. Formerly, after a cadet had successfully passed his mental and physical examinations in September, he was permitted to wait until the school opened, on Oct. 1, to report.

By th8 resolutions of the General Committee the German-American Reform Union demands a host of good things, and pledges itself "to support only as its candidate for {ayor a man who by his honesty, probity, and statesmanship has shouh that he will carry out the principles herewith enunciated."

According to the Bureau of Statistics of the Treasury our foreign customers are not yet so vexed by our newly devised law for restricting commerce that they have refused, during the first month of the operation of the Dingley tariff, to buy from us, althpugh they have sold us the smallest August bill of goods since 1879.

There has lately been and still is such a demand for labor that all unskilled laborers find ready employment at good wages in this city, and in some departments of work it is apparently impossible to hire the amount of skilled labor that is needed. In speaking yesterday of the labor conditions in New York John D. Crimmins said:

Seth Low had nothing to say yesterday with regard to the political situation and his candidacy for Mayor. Shortly after 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon he met the newspaper reporters in the lobby of the Plaza Hotel and said:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16. -- A denial from what is regarded as authoritative source is given to the report sent from here to New York that the President yesterday urged Secretary of the Interior Bliss to consent to the Republican candidate for Mayor of New York.

The Twelfth Regiment, National Guard, covered itself with glory yesterday at the Creedmoor shooting ranges. Not only did the team selected by the regiment win the First Brigade match and the State match, but in the latter it broke all previous records by 16. The highest score ever made by a team in the State match was 1,635, while the Twelfth Regiment team rolled up 1,051.

At the meeting of the National Democratic County Committee in the Grand Central Palace, Forty-third Street and Lexington Avenue last night, in the absence of the man himself, the name of Williaim R. Grace was applauded every time it was mentioned. Cheers were given for him, and the shout, "He's the first Mayor of Greater New York" resulted in one of the loudest demonstrations of the evening.

One of the avowed objects of President Isaac B. Potter of the League of American Wheelmen in making the European trip on which he is still absent was to secure partial affiliation of the league with the great European cycling organizations, with a view of exchanging privileges. Letters received from the President say he is meeting with a fair degree of success.

Interest in the work of the New York State Credit Men's Association was attested by a large attendance of business men at the annual meeting in the Central National Bank Building yesterday. More than forty firms were represented. M.E. Bannin, of Converse, Stanton Cullon, presided, the retiring President, Charles Biggs, being absent in consequence of sickness.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- The President to-day made the following appointments:

Titles for books on Africa seem to tax the invention of explorers, and so this volume, "The New Africa," tells of portions of that vast continent which, according to the authors, Aurel Schultz and August Hammar, had never been tracked over before. The new ground was the country in the region of the Chobe and Okovanga Rivers.
Some of the parishioners of the Church of the Holy Nativity, at One Hundred and Thirty-sixth Street, near Seventh Avenue, refuse to attend the services because they are becoming so "high."

QUEENSTOWN, Sept. 17. -- The overdue Anchor Line steamer Circassia, which left New York on Aug. 28 for Glasgow, and which should have reached that port on Thursday, Sept. 9, was sighted this morning off Kinsale Head in tow of the British steamer Memnon, Capt. Bales, from Montreal on Sept. 3, for Avonmouth.

MONTREAL, Sept. 17. -- Sir Wilfrid Laurier, as Premier of Canada and the representative of Canada to the Queen's jubilee, was entertained last night by the Board of Trade, at the Windsor Hotel, at a banquet, there being over 500 present. His speech contained many statements worthy of note.

Gen. YEATMAN-BIGGS fully deserved the compliment which Lord WOLSELEY paid him and his troops upon the successful conduct of the campaign against the tribesmen. In fact, the whole series of operations since the tribes first rose has been very creditable to the British Army and shows that army, in India at least, to be a very efficient and businesslike force.

The first protest filed against the application of the penalities and forfeiture clause of the new tariff law is now before the United States General Appraisers. It was filed by a New York importer, and involves not more than $100, but it brings out a new feature of the law which importers declare is harsh and unjust.

In the recent death of William Spohn Baker of Philadelphia the country loses one of its most devoted students of Washington's life. Few men had devoted so much time to the subject. He was an indefatigable collector of Washingtoniana, as well as an able compiler of information. He compiled the "Itinerary of Washington," but to collectors his most serviceable and valuable work is "The Engraved Portraits of Washington."

Charles P. Kirwan has sold the Laonia, a new six-story apartment house occupying the block front on the south side of One Hundred and Fifty-third Street. between St. Nicholas Avenue and St. Nicholas Place, 160 by 25. A tract of land in New Jersey is taken in part payment, but the consideration is largely in cash.
LONDON, Sept. 18. -- The Times this morning publishes the gist of the correspondence between Secretary Sherman and Lord Salisbury in the Bering Sea controversy.

BERLIN, Sept. 17. -- Round second of the Berger system served for the pairing of the fifth round of the international chess masters' tournament, which was played at the Architekten Haus, in the Wilhelmstrasse, in this city to-day. The pairing was:

The police boat Patrol was called upon yesterday afternoon to go to the Italian bark Speme, at anchor off Staten Island, to remove an insane sailor. The matter had been reported to the Italian Consul by Capt. Frazego, who said that the man had become violently insane and had threatened the lives of several sailors, making it necessary to put him in chains.
SING SING, N.Y., Sept. 17. -- Justice of the Peace John Gibney of this town has come out as a candidate on the Democratic ticket for member of Assembly from the Third District of Westchester County.

In the corner of the parish churchyard at Grasmere, in the lake district of England, the most charming in England, nearly parallel to the roadside, lie the remains of Hartley Coleridge, eldest son of Samuel Taylor Coleridge, born Sept. 19, 1796, died Jan. 6, 1849. Around the circular headstone to his memory is sculptured in old English this simple inscription -"By Thy grace and passion, good Lord deliver us."

Reports from all the schools opened on Monday received yesterday at the office of Superintendent Jasper show as the total on the register in 253 departments, 213,133, with 1,803 in the high schools, a grand total of 214,936. For lack of room admission was refused to 6,913 applicants. All those who could not be received will be admitted during the coming week to half-day classes.

DENVER, Sept. 17. -- After repeated experiments a cure for cattle fever has been found. Dr. V.A. Norgaard of this city is the discoverer. The plan for dealing with the fever is primarily to exterminate the insect known as the "tick," which abounds on fever-stricken cattle, and by means of which the disease is communicated.
LONDON, Sept. 18. -- All the morning papers comment upon the British reverse north of Camp Anayat.

In view of the recent admission by a British technical journal of authority of the fact that British manufacturers are notoriously unable properly to equip an electrically worked railway, every contribution by American experts to the literature of applied electricity to solve problems of transportation becomes interesting.

A valuable gift has just been made to the New York Historical Society, which is a worthy addition to its rich collection of paintings. This is the large oil painting of the Yosemite Valley by Thomas Hill, who was about the earliest artist to paint scenes of the Yosemite. His California landscapes have become famous.

George S. Greene, Jr., chief engineer of the Dock Department, sails for Europe to-day on the steamship Campania. While the expenses of his trip will not be borne by the city, his tour of the principal seaport cities of England and the Continent will be devoted to the thorough investigation of the foreign methods of wharf building, with a view to adopting in New York such innovations as may be found practicable.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- The reports of an uprising in Guatemala are felt to jeopardize the prospects of a consummation of a union of the Central American republics. Guatemala and Costa Rica are the only countries remaining out of the union, and it was expected that they would be brought in under a treaty recently made.

The impulse to lynch the assailant of President DIAZ was a natural demonstration of the attachment of the Mexican crowd to the Government. The attempt made in the heat of anger failed by reason of the fidelity of the police. It was only when it was renewed in cold blood that it succeeded. So far the story might have been told of almost any American community, angered by a public outrage such as ARROYO committed.

BOSTON, Sept. 17. -- Boston defeated New York to-day in the most one-sided game of ball seen here this season. Sullivan could not control the ball in the first inning, and Zearfoss was way off in his throwing. Three hits, three bases on balls, a wild pitch, and wild throws by Sullivan and Zearfoss gave the Bostons six runs in the first inning and settled the result then and there.

At a special meeting Monday afternoon the Executive Committee of the Citizens' Union will consider the selection of candidates for Controller and President of the Council. A resident of New York will be nominated for Controller and a Brooklyn man named for President of the Council. No action will be taken until later with regard to the nomination of a full county and district ticket.

The County of Ripley, in the State of Indiana, is provoking general denunciation, in Indiana and out of it, in consequence of the summary hanging by a mob of five men who had not committed capital crimes. The unfortunate wretches had been arrested, were in jail, and ought to have been adequately punished in course of time.

SANTA FE, N.M., Sept. 17. -- A telegram from Raton received here says that the company store at Blossburg, owned by the Raton Coal and Coke Company, has been blown up with gunpowder. The building and contents were destroyed. Coal miners are accused of the act.

In the French portion of "Cosmopolis" Mr. Paul Bourget writes a pretty story in that series which he calls "Voyageuses." How far there is a foundation of fact for the episode we do not know. "Si non e vero ben trovato."

The recently organized publishing house, the Doubleday McClure Company, has ready a fine set of Shakespeare in eighteen volumes, edited by Prof. Henry Morley. To each play are added extracts from the books Shakespeare used, with old histories, ballads, and stories, so that the volumes make a complete Shakespearean library.

We offer Mr. PLATT our congratulations. He has maintained the integrity and aloofness of his organization. Defied and flouted elsewhere, there he is lord paramount. The Citizens' Union treated him in a manner that would have been disrespectful from an Emperor to a tramp. Tammany with ostentatious incivility rejected his urgent advice to praise BRYAN and indorse free silver.

MADRID, Sept. 17. -- The Bishop of Majorca, Balearic Islands, has excommunicated the Spanish Minister of Finance, Senor J. Reverter, for taking possession of the Treasury of a church in his diocese. The Minister proposes to appeal against the Bishop to the Holy See.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17. -- The cricket match between Capt. Warner's team of British amateurs and a team of twenty-two "colts," selected from the junior members of the various Philadelphia cricket clubs, was begun at noon to-day. Robert S. Newhall, the veteran player, acted as Captain for the "colts."

ALBANY, Sept. 17. -- Under the $1,000,000 appropriation for the purchase of land within the boundary of the proposed Adirondack Park the buying of woodland has been progressing steadily. The Commissioners expect to obtain a greater area in the aggregate than was expected when the law was passed. They intend to spend the entire $1,000,000 appropriation, for which they will get about 200,000 acres, and place the title in the State.

EAGLE, Wis., Sept. 17. -- This portion of the State is infested with an entirely new species of bug, resembling a large bee, that preys upon growing corn, destroying crops by the acre in a very short time, leaving the cobs clean shelled on the stalk.

In racing circles to-day attention will be divided between the great three-event meet at Manhattan Beach under the management of the American Cycle Racing Association, and the annual race meet of the New Jersey State Division of the L.A.W. on the Waverly Park track, Newark. The big cycle parade in Brooklyn this afternoon will also attract many clubs and unattached riders.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17. -- Lyman J. Gage, Secretary of the Treasury, accompanied by Mrs. Gage, arrived in Chicago to-day for a three-weeks' rest. The Secretary is enjoying good health, and apparently likes his Washington life.

BOSTON, Sept. 16. -- The Lowell lecture is a Boston Institution, with a very large and severely unornamented capital letter for institution. The tickets are distributed to applicants on esoteric principles and without charge, and the best seats invariably fall to persons too stupid to attend more than twice in a course.

On Sept. 2, in Turin, in his ninety-fourth year, died Thomas Vallauri, who has been called the Nestor of Latinists and the greatest master that Italy had of Augustan prose. He was a contemporary of Cesare Cantu, with whom he had more than an intellectual point in common. He died not from old age, but as the result of a fall.

It is a singular fact that a marine disaster very seldom furnishes a competent witness when the hour of investigation arrives. The statements of officers of the vessel or vessels involved in the mishap have to be accepted, and as they are all interested parties and are eager to tell conflicting stories it is not always easy to arrive at the precise truth.

HAZLETON, Penn., Sept. 17. -- Over 10,000 coal miners are now on strike here, with no apparent prospect of a settlement of the trouble. Sporadic outbreaks of violence are occurring near the outlying collieries, and the withdrawal of the troops is not only not considered, but the guard lines of several of the camps are being strengthened and the wisdom of bringing more cavalry is discussed.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Sept. 17. -- John Smith Rice, the wealthy Wall Street broker who disappeared mysteriously from his home in Passaic, N.J., on May 3 last, is at the Ampersand Hotel here, with his wife and sister-in-law, Miss Gorhmann, and a party of friends.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17. -- At to-day's Cabinet meeting, which lasted over two hours, the situation in Alaska was discussed. Secretary of War Alger had a report from Capt. Ray, who has just arrived at St. Michael, which furnished the basis for the discussion and the course which was decided upon.

LONDON, Sept. 17. -- The letter of the Governor of the Bank of England strengthens the impression among the bankers who have hitherto not entertained it that the Governments intends to accede to the bimetallic proposals later, and it is also interpreted as a reply to a request from the Government to the bank, asking the latter to co-operate with the former.

PARIS, Aug. 29. -- The late M. Henri Meilhac has left behind him, in addition to a very respectable fortune and a vacant seat in the French Academy, an unpublished comedy in five acts, entitled "Realite," which he requested his executor to give to the world after his death, so that the aesthetic views of young man fifty years ago might be compared with those of his successors of the Theatre Libre and elsewhere.

Max Muller continues in the September number of Cosmopolis his reminiscences of royalties. His first impressions of distinguished people were derived from Dessau and the Duke and Duchess thereof. When Max Muller went to the University of Berlin the Duchess gave him a letter of introduction to Alexander von Humboldt.

" Mary Hasty, County Mayo, Ireland, through to Mrs. Kneu, Sheepshead Bay, L.I., N.Y., U.S.A.," was the inscription on a tag on an eight-year-old girl, who arrived on the steamship Britannic Thursday night. She was passed through the Barge Office after answering the usual questions. Her occupation, she said, was "going to school," and her capital was "10 cents," which some one had given to her.

CITY OF MEXICO, Sept. 17. -- A sensational sequel to yesterday's attack on President Diaz occurred this morning, when Anulfo Arroyo was lynched by a band of the common people, determined on revenge. It was an act unprecedented in the history of the country.
LONDON, Sept. 18. -- The Times, commenting editorially upon the correspondence, says:

For some time France has led the fashion as the subject of historical romance, and in spite of her great advantages in the liveliness of her political life, it is very pleasant to turn by way of contrast to Germany. "Barbara Blomberg" is, as the title indicates, a story of imperial life during the latter part of Charles V.'s reign.

The general public may be assumed to possess a vital interest in the business affairs of booksellers -- at any rate that portion of the public which buys books. The following article, written by "one behind the scenes," printed in The Pall Mall Gazette, sheds a good deal of light on the difficulties under which these men in England have been laboring:

I have read with considerable interest your articles which try to justify the horrible deed of the Sheriff of Luzerne County, Pennsylvania, and to present the miners afflicted by the tragedy as a "lawless mob." I have just returned from Hazleton, where I have thoroughly investigated the situation and the facts, and rely upon your sense of justice that you will publish my letter, which is intended to correct some of your statements.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 17. -- The attempt to kill Postmaster Loftin of Hogansville on Wednesday night turns out to have been a carefully planned crime, which only failed of its purpose through faulty marksmanship. Loftin received a decoy letter asking him to meet some friends at a designated place. As he left his house he was fired upon, and when he turned to run into the house the door was filled with shot.

-- "Georgia," whose defense of lynching took up considerable space in Thursday's TIMES, must have been moved to readjust his premises when he read in yesterday's dispatches the news that in his own State a negro had been shot for teaching school, and that hanging was the penalty incurred by one in Arkansas for the crime of getting an appointment as Postmaster!

The Supreme Court special Rapid Transit Commission heard the testimony of only one witness yesterday. Foster Crowell, the expert civil engineer, occupied the stand during the entire session. He continued the explanation which he began the day before as to how and in what particulars Mr. Parsons, the chief engineer of the Rapid Transit Board, had failed in his plans and estimates.

CAMP ANAYAT, VIA PANJKORA, Sept. 17. -- (8. P.M.) -- Severe fighting has taken place between the Second Brigade of Gen. Sir Bindon Blood's division and the Momunds. The British loss was 140 killed and wounded.

What is the motive of the announcement made by the Governor of the Bank of England that the bank would consent to keep one-fifth of its reserve in silver? The English banking and financial public is as much in the dark as we are. The proposed change of policy is universally condemned by financiers and by the English press.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17. -- The prosecution will rest its case in the Luetgert trial to-morrow. It will close with some strong evidence tending to prove the motive for the alleged crime. The State will endeavor to show that infatuation for Mary Slemering, the servant girl in the Luetgert household, was the cause of the murder.

Harry Kimball of Brooklyn, a clerk formerly employed by the Royal Baking Powder Company, got up early on the morning of July 26 and quietly left town to make his fortune in the Klondike country, omitting to inform his wife that he was going. He had only a few dollars in his pocket.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 17. -- Zena Braunner, of Webster and Second Streets, Carrollton, died to-day. The case was reported as suspicious on Sept. 13 by Dr. Bell, and was later declared one of yellow fever. Eight new cases of yellow fever have been reported here.

When a fellow writes a book that somehow attracts persons beyond the circle of long -- or short -- suffering friends, he is deemed a fit object for illustration in the countless periodicals. They print his picture, sandwiched in between two paragraphs of biography: Sometimes they honor him with an interview, the theme of which usually is, "How I Wrote My First Novel," or, "Literary Men Whom I have Known."

The position of the leaders of the regular Republican organization in this city was pretty clearly defined by Congressman Lemuel Ely Quigg, in a spirited address to the West End Woman's Republican Association, delivered at their headquarters, 102 West Eighty-second Street, yesterday afternoon, urging them to lend their efforts to vigorous campaign work.

George Washington probably dimly imagined how responsible he would be for the future fame of Morristown when he selected that delightful locality for one of his numerous headquarters, and it will be an enduring credit to Morristown that she had a number of patriotic citizens who were public spirited enough to come to the rescue of the line old place when it was sold several years ago.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17. -- Joseph Lloyd, the professional from the Essex County Golf Club of Manchester-by-the-Sea, Mass., won the open golf championship for 1897 on the links of the Chicago Golf Club at Wheaton this afternoon. His total score was 162. William Anderson, the phenomenal young player from the Misquamient Golf Club, Watch Hill, R.I., was a close second, with 163.

ATLANTA, Sept. 18. -- The interest in the Hogansville Post Office affair has now veered around from the wounded negro Postmaster to the former incumbent, who has continued to exercise the functions of the office, despite the fact that his successor has been commissioned.
MONTREAL, Sept. 18. -- Two challenges have been received for the Seawanhaka Cup, one from J. Arthur Brandt, the owner of Spruce IV., and one from the Seawanhaka Club.

The polo teams of the Westchester Country Club and the Rockaway Club met in the first game for the championship on the Parade Ground at Prospect Park yesterday afternoon. The Westchester players, after a hard-fought game, won by a score of 6 3/4 to 5.

Dr. Alfred Riedel, who is attached to the Eastern District Hospital, Williamsburg, was suspended yesterday by Superintendent Wiegand of the institution, pending an investigation of alleged conduct unbecoming an attache of the hospital.

The racing at Gravesend yesterday afforded great pleasure. The weather conditions were perfect, the fields were of a fair size, and the finishes in most of the events were well calculated to arouse enthusiasm. There was a little frostiness in the atmosphere which set one's blood a-tingling, and there was that in the racing which kept it in a tingle, if the spectator was a speculator.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18. -- Henry James Whigham of the Onwentsia Club still holds the title of amateur golf champion of the United States. W. Rossiter Betts, the Yale junior, who came to the tournament as the representative of the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club, was defeated with ease by the champion in the finals played at Wheaton this afternoon.

LONDON, Sept. 18. -- Kyrle Bellew and Mrs. Potter made their debut to-night in "Francillon." It is a three-act comedy, by Alexandre Dumas, fils, which was performed the first time in 1887 at the Thetre Francais. It has never been seen in London except in French, although Mr. Bellew and Mrs. Potter entertained the Australians with it last year. Being French, the play of course deals with marital infidelity.

SEATED in the library of his pleasant suburban home at Yonkers, the other day, the Rev. D.W. Morehouse, Secretary of the National Unitarian Conference and Superintendent of the American Unitarian Association for the Middle States and Canada, spoke of the work expected from the approaching conference of his denomination to be held at Saratoga on to-morrow, Tuesday, and Wednesday.
He was an honest clergyman, who preached a sermon in a remote county in England, and the parishioners liked the sermon, and entreated him to publish, and so he went to London, says an English paper.

LONDON, Sept. 18. -- Interesting figures have been furnished in the report just issued of the Inspector of Inebriates' Retreats. They show that the effect of legislative intercession to reform drunkards is a machinery which is still experimental and wholly inadequate. About one-third of those entering these retreats are entirely cured.

In the early period of railroading in this country some novel expedients were resorted to in preventing collisions and in otherwise safeguarding the trains. For several years locomotives were without headlights, and it was seldom that trains were run any distance at night. The first method adopted of illuminating the track ahead of a moving train was by building a small bonfire on a platform car, which was shoved in advance of the locomotive.

TROY, Sept. 18. -- Besides being the oldest letter carrier in point of active service, Frederick Wolfe of this city has probably walked more miles than any other living man. He has been a letter carrier forty-two years, and in that time he has walked 357,380 miles for Uncle Sam -- a distance equal to more than fifteen times around the globe.

Although the Autumn season has hardly yet opened at Lenox and in the suburbs, owing to the warm weather, which again visited the land during the past week, there is beginning to be much talk, even at Newport, in the country clubs, and among the New York club men who have returned to town, of the prospects for the coming Winter season.

Prof. Albert S. Bickmore returned last week from a three months' tour through the West and Northwest, where he has been gathering information and illustrations for a series of lectures he will deliver in connection with his department at the Museum of Natural History during the Fall and Winter months for the benefit of the teachers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- Gen. Fitzhugh Lee, Consul General to Cuba, had a long consultation with the President at the White House to-day. He saw the President by special appointment, and all visitors were excluded during the progress of the conference except Secretary Alger, who came over from the War Department, and remained until after Gen. Lee's departure.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 18. -- It was expected that this would be an off week in Lenox owing to the fact that there was no golf tournament, but early in the week a number of people put their heads together and suddenly organized a floral tub parade, which was held on Thursday. The parade was the first one held since 1893, and, in consequence, it created a great deal of interest.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 18. -- The entries to the fourteen purse races and the Transylvania Stake, to be trotted at the coming meeting of the Kentucky Trotting Horse Breeder' Association, closed to-night Secretary Wilson says it will be the latter part of next week before all of the entries which were mailed to him to-day will be received.

Through the columns of THE NEW YORK TIMES recently, representative business men from all sections of the country have expressed opinions regarding the general business situation. Unanimously, they have reported with positiveness that business conditions show improvement. Unanimously, they have agreed that the general outlook for further improvement is of the very brightest and best.
Says The Commercial and Financial Chronicle in discussing the security market situation of a property which has recently been receiving much increased Wall Street attention:
The Baltimore .mertcan in its report of the proceedings of the ?,'Iedical and Chirurgieal Faculty of ik[aryland at Ocean City recently says:

Where do the snakes go in Winter? used to be a familiar question among schoolboys, who were not equally troubled about the Winter quarters of the fly. After the recent Summer most men will wonder where the mosquitoes go in Winter, but that is a painful topic whose discussion is best left to cold and callous scientists.

AMONG the many creditable achievements of the Board of Education appointed by Mayor Strong, the introduction of the high school system will probably rank the highest. It will stand as long as the public schools endure as monument to the farsighted policy of the progressive element of the board and as a reproach to earlier boards who declared the system unprofitable and unnecessary.

" Dayton Dumpling" Kiser beat out. "King" Bald by half a length in the all-star invitation mile race on the Manhattan Beach track yesterday afternoon, and the new amateur cycling meteor, John S. Johnson, captured the victor's palm from a field of the speediest youngsters on the American track. The downfall of the racers popular with the New York enthusiasts was the sensation of the meet.
During the week just ended Wall Street security markets have broadened. They have been active, and throughout have shown strength. All the notable changes of the week are on the side of advances.

Members of the Quartet Club of Hoboken were talking yesterday of an alleged disagreement between Dr. Samuel A. Helfer and F.A. Osten, a former President of the club, on Thursday night. Several members alleged that blows were struck, but this was denied by both Mr. Osten and Dr. Helfer.

PLATT'S Republican State Committee backs up PLATT'S local Republican organization and ferociously assails the Citizens' Union for its offish and unsociable behavior. The committee's address exultingly drags into the municipal contest all the National issues it can lay hands on and denounces as "silly" the doctrine held by Tammany and the Citizens that in the Mayoralty canvass National affairs should be ignored.

ITHACA, Sept. 18. -- President Schurman of Cornell, on learning of Mr. Sage's death, called a special meeting of the Executive Committee of the Board of Trustees, which voted to express to the family of Mr. Sage the sense of the Trustees that Mr. Sage's body be buried in the main building of Sage Chapel, and that the remains of Mrs. Sage should be removed thither also.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- The President to-day made the following appointments:

Whitman was certainly a striking-looking man, and would attract the attention of people in any city of the world. I think Whitman was a little too well aware of his fine appearance. There was a strong element of individuality mixed up with his personality, and he did not have occasion to experience what the Arkansas Colonel did in walking up and down Broadway.

Dr. BARAES, whose letter concerning the shooting at Hazleton we printed yesterday, assures us that he has made a "thorough investigation" on the spot. He gives us the results of this investigation. If his statements are justified, it appears that the Sheriff's posse made an unprovoked and murderous attack upon certain citizens who were peacefully "moving on a public road" and committing no offense whatever.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18. -- David Henderson of Chicago, W.J. Gilmore of Philadelphia, and Charles H. Yale of Boston have organized a partnership, to be known as the Inter-State Theatre Company, the object of which will be the production of spectacular, operatic, and musical plays.

When Acting Inspector McCullagh was placed in command of the police force, to succeed Chief Conlin, on Aug. 25, it was expected that a general shifting of the commanding officers of precincts would follow. In reply to questions, however, McCullagh has several times announced his intention of moving slowly. Yesterday the following transfers were announced from headquarters:

ST. PETERSBURG, Sept. 18 -- The official Messenger confirms to-day the announcement made from this city yesterday, saying telegraphic message received here from Krasnoyarsk, in the interior of Siberia, said that on, Sept. 14, at 11 P.M., the inhabitants of the village of Antzifirowskoje, in the District of Yeniseisk, Arctic Russia, saw for about five minutes a balloon believed to be that of Prof. Andree, the Swedish aeronaut.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- For many years the first object to arrest the attention of the visitor to Washington on approaching the capital city was the dome of the Capitol. While still many miles away that dazzling white object, familiar to every student of geography or history, appeared out of the distance, while all lesser structures were hidden behind trees or hills.

LONDON, Sept. 18. -- The Duchess of Marlborough, formerly Miss Consuelo Vanderbilt, gave birth to a son at 3 o'clock this morning at Spencer House, the London residence of the young couple. Both mother and son are doing well, according to the latest reports from the attending physicians.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 18. -- The world's pacing race record was broken here this afternoon by Star Pointer in his match race with Joe Patchen. The weather was perfect for the contest. There was but one heat of the race to be paced, each horse having taken a heat on the afternoon previous.

There are many pretty gowns at the theatres this Fall, and some smart up-to-date gowns showing the Winter styles. Some pretty specimens of these are worn by the Gaiety girls at the Knickerbocker. One thing that they emphasize in particular is the pouch bodice, which enters so largely into the gowns this season, and the lack of fullness in the sleeves.

The Montgomery Advertiser, after an apparently careful compilation, is authority for the statement that Alabama is now producing 1,000,000 bales of cotton, 50,000,00 bushels of corn, 1,000,000 tons of pig iron, and 6,000,000 tons of coal, and that the State can easily increase these productions to 2,000,000 bales of cotton, 100,000,000 bushels of corn, 5,000,000 tons of pig iron, and 25,000,000 tons of coal, and maintain this rate of production for an indefinite period.

The season's prospectus of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences has been issued. It contains announcements of the anniversary meetings, addresses, lectures, exhibitions, department meetings, concerts, schools, courses of instruction, and the other work which the institute and its departments will conduct during the year 1897-8.

Mr. Washington E. Connor chatted entertainingly with friends yesterday, comparing what is developing in the present stock market with what the magnificent record was in 1879 -- the period to which Wall Street veterans are likening current developments. Mr. Connor at that time was the partner of Jay Gould, his closest stock-market associate, and naturally had intimate relations with what was most important in the buoyancy which has made 1879 historic. Mr. Connor said:

This is one of the articles in the constitution of a woman's club which was organized quite recently. It comes under the head of "Discipline." It reads: "One of the considerations of the club shall be to maintain a continual spirit of harmony among its members. It is therefore earnestly requested that any dissatisfied member shall resign."

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 18. -- Bert Ripley covered himself with glory to-day at the annual meeting of the New Jersey Division of the League of American Wheelmen, at the Waverley Park track, by winning all but one of the State championships offered.

Campaigning with pictures illustrating the improved condition of this city under government administered with regard for the most efficient discharge of duty by every officer will unquestionably prove an interesting undertaking by the Citizens' Union, and no one who appreciates the power of adequate illustration will have any doubt about its effect.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 18. -- Newport has been called upon the past week to entertain a distinguished visitor, in the person of Sir Noel Salmon, V.C., K.C.B., an Admiral in the English Navy, and in command of the fleet at Portsmouth at the Queen's jubilee. He was accompanied by his wife, Lady Salmon, and they were the guests of Admiral and Mrs. George Belknap, at their cottage on Narragansett Avenue.

The difference between the dealings of last week and those of the week immediately preceding was one of quantity rather than of quality. The down-town market has as yet given no signs of a revival, and the buying of residences in the upper sections of the city continues to be the only branch of the business in which there is an apparent and well-defined activity.

MONTREAL, Sept. 18. -- George Waldron, one of the two survivors of the "Noble Six Hundred" on this continent, who was in the famous charge at Balaklava, died in this city last night as the result of a blow on the head with a cane struck by his wife. The only remaining Balaklava veteran in America is John Harris, a resident of Washington.

Criticism, censure, and ridicule are poured out upon the management of the Bank of England by the English press and public, but nowhere do we see or hear any rational explanation of the bank's action in offering to keep one-fifth of its reserve in silver. It is a mystery that deepens the more its solution is sought.

THE aim of the author of "The Annals of Switzerland" is to present a condensed narrative of the struggles, progress, and attainments of a race of freemen, and to depict the development of a democracy which had its beginnings before the Reformation. The early story of Switzerland is purely mythical.

BOSTON, Sept. 18. -- Seymour's erratic pitching and Boston's superior fielding were responsible for the home club's victory to-day. Klobedanz was steady, except in the first inning, and he had good support. The fielding of Lowe, Tenney, and Collins for Boston, and Gleason and Gettig's work for New York were features of the game.

ALBANY, Sept. 18. -- Among the appropriations made by the last Legislature was one for $25,000 for needed repairs to the State House, which faces on the square containing the City Hall, the High School, the Capitol, and the Albany Academy. This structude was built in 18-10-42 at a cost of $350,000. Its exterior was constructed of white stone from Sing Sing quarries, and was used as an experiment for its use in building.

Excitement as to the various matches at Creedmoor has subsided, and the regiments have buckled down to hard work again. Nearly 300 men practiced on the ranges yesterday, and of these 172 qualified as marksmen and sharpshooters.
JOHN McCULLAGH, Chief of the uniformed force and executive officer of the New York Police Department, has an interesting personality.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Sept. 18. -- Superb golfing weather, with just the proper invigorating tone to the atmosphere, greeted the golfers of the Morris County Golf Club this morning as they assembled at their delightful clubhouse for the bi-monthly competition for the Ballantine silver cups. The tournament went on all day, and thirty-five finished, although nearly seventy-five members played on the links.

A decrease of .$1;,773,G50 n the surplus reserve of the 'ew York banks, an actual diminution of .q,q,000,000 in their cash holdings, cuntaining heavy sh'ipments of go!d to the interior and an advance in the money rate here, together with a weak exchange market, are signs that point unmistakably to gold imports.

While the daily volume of business is at large as ever, and larger for the length of time it has been running than Wall Street ever knew before, the general list has continued to move upward by groups or sections after the fashion of all bull markets. At one time the granger group have been specially active and strong, at another the Vanderbilts; the coal stocks have had their day, and the gas stocks theirs.

The Controller and the Corporation Counsel performed a public service at the meeting of the Board of Estimate on Thursday in holding up the appropriation for the building of the Botanical Museum. The reference of the matter to the Corporation Counsel was determined by some doubt of the legal status of the project. But apart from that, any delay is to be welcomed that gives opportunity for reflection.

DENVER, Col., Sept. 18. -- Papers in a suit involving the title to about 100,000 acres of land situated along the line of the Union Pacific, between Denver and Cheyenne, were filed in the United States District Court to-day. The plaintiffs are Robert E. Carr and others of St. Louis, Mo.; D.H. Moffat, Walter S. Cheesman, and the heirs of the late ex-Gov. John Evans of Denver.

Harry Persky, eighteen years old, had a nightmare a week ago, and was sent to Bellevue Hospital yesterday a raving maniac. The physicians pronounced it one of the most peculiar cases they had ever seen.

Sol Smith Russell is a comedian whose popularity in some cities is second to none; he has made a large fortune in the practice of his art. Yet in spite of this -- or because of it, as they say in Chicago -- he has never secured a firm footing in this city. His engagement at the Garden Theatre, beginning to-morrow night, however, promises well.

There is to be a strong current turning in favor of domestic affairs and the discussion of household questions with reference to their betterment this Winter, and the New York Household Economic Association will be one of the chief channels for the work.
There is an American echo in the Vatican every time the Pope sneezes. He gets snuff from Baltimore.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 18. -- A turn has been called in the execution of lynch law in Georgia by the action of the Grand Jury of Clayton in the Flagg indictment against eight men who have participated in an attempt at lynching. A white man who was charged with killing his wife, and a negro who admitted a criminal assault upon a respectable white lady were the objects of wrath of the lynchers.

LONDON, Sept. 18. -- The most cheering news from India is that rain has fallen just at the right time and so abundantly that there is rich promise of fine harvests and India may have wheat to export a few months from now. As to the frontier movements it is little wonder that impatient critics are eagerly asking when vengeance is about to be wreaked on the tribes.

MRS. RYLEY' Saudacious disregard for common sense in the fabrication of her plots, and her fondness for a few unlikely theatrical expedients, which she employs over and over again, are, I fear, constitutional and incurable. Certainly the defects due to these causes in her newest play, "A Coat of Many Colors," are not to be remedied.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 18. -- Five new cases of yellow fever were reported to the Board of Health to-day. None of the cases under treatment has terminated fatally today, and the sick, except in one or two instances, are doing well. The condition of Dr. Sevell is far from satisfactory.

The new, pastor of the Bedford Heights Baptist Church, corner of Rogers Avenue and Bergen Street, Brooklyn, the Rev. William M. Tinker, is a native of Northwestern Pennsylvania, and is not quite thirty years of age. He was educated in the common and high schools of Greenville, in Mercer County, and was graduated at Thiel College with a Bachelor of Arts degree at the age of twenty.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 18. -- A mixed team match was played on the links of the New Brunswick Golf Club, near New Brunswick, this afternoon, between teams of the Morristown Field Club and the New Brunswick Golf Club. It was a return match, the two teams having played in a similar contest at Morristown a few weeks ago.
BERLIN, Sept. 18. -- The sixth round of the international chess tournament was played to-day at Architekten Haus, 92 and 93 Wilhelmstrasse in this city, the pairing being as follows:

BOSTON, Sept. 18. -- The Populists of Massachusetts held their State Convention here to-day. Only sixty-two delegates were present. George F. Washburn, who acted as temporary Chairman, said that the silver question would cease to be an issue within a year and that then the people would have a chance to consider the broader demands of the Populists.

Discussing the scheme by which the Bank of England would hold in silver one-fifth of the bullion held against its note reserve, Maurice L. Muhleman, Deputy Assistant United States Treasurer and Cashier of the Sub-Treasury, said yesterday:

As Mr. Tegetmeier's denial of the possibility of the return of Andree's pigeons seems to have roused considerable interest, and as their non-appearance may unnecessarily increase the anxiety as to the explorer's safety, it may be worth while referring to the results of the experiments last year. Herr Andree then took seventy pigeons to Spitzbergen, and released several at intervals during the Summer.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- Oren W. Weaver, Acting Commissioner of Labor, to-day gave out for publication a copy of a letter containing a most graphic account of the terrors of the trip across Alaska to the Klondike gold fields.

TEKAMAH, Neb., Sept. 18. -- Vigilantes lynched Eugene Cummings at Dawson City last Spring. Fred Cummings, the dead man's brother, says the case was clear murder. He is hastening to Washington, D.C., in the hope of securing an investigation, and if not the punishment of the lynchers, at least his brother's exoneration of the offense for which he suffered.

During the last week there has been somewhat of a lull in interest in the performances of the harness horses. Many of the leading campaigners have been laid up temporarily, while others are participating in the races held in connection with State and county fairs throughout the country. The principal meeting of the week was at Indianapolis, where several of the best horses of the Grand Circuit season were entered in the various events.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18. -- The Treasury deficit for September will be very much smaller than that of either July or August, and may fall as low as $4,000,000.

A manual of the United States customs duties, as altered by the Dingley Tariff bill, which is calculated to be of use to importers and other persons interested in knowing the present provisions of the amended Customc Administrative act, has been issued in cloth binding by R.F. Downing Co.

Clever girls who wish to undertake the trials and tribulations, pleasures and profits of self-support, without looking in the face that bugbear requirement, "previous experience,'' can do so at the Castle of Silence.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 18. -- The death of Henry W. Sage occurred last night about 12 o'clock at his residence on East Hill. Mr. Sage had been ill for many months, resulting from rheumatism, feeble circulation, and weak heart action. Once or twice within the past year his condition has been critical, but in each instance his wonderful vitality was sufficient to enable him to rally.

TEN years ago last Friday Richard Katzenmayer, who was then President of the Arlon Club, unlocked the door of the house that stands at the corner of Park Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street with the big gold key that hangs in the clubhouse now.

ST. PETERSBURG, Sept. 4. -- Society in St. Petersburg is very different from that of Berlin, Vienna, London, and Rome. One finds in the Russian capital neither the loose morals prevalent in the German capital, the aristocratic exclusiveness which characterizes Vienna, the feverish activity of London society, nor yet the engrossing love of pleasure which predominates in the City of the Popes.

The events of the next ten days will determine whether the name of Seth Low will head the Republican Mayoralty ticket. Despite the fact that the Republican State Committee, the County Committee, and a number of Republican machine district organizations have adopted resolutions condemning the Citizens' Union, there is still a strong belief among conservative Republicans that Mr. Low will be indorsed.

Racing at Gravesend this week should be of a class high enough to satisfy even the most fastidious followers of the sport, for not only are the stake events well filled, but the overnight events are for purses of a size well calculated to bring out the best of the performers now in training.

Charles O'Brien of 303 East Fifty-second Street was locked up in the East Twenty-second Street Police Station yesterday, charged with having run over a child with his bicycle. O'Brien turned the corner of Twenty-second Street and First Avenue at a high rate of speed, and ran into William Farrell, seven years of age, of 383 First Avenue.

Commenting upon some recent observations of ours on "the old Democratic doctrine" of opposition to protection, The Rochester Post-Express quotes from the Secretary of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers the assertion that belief in the protection doctrine is spreading in the South and West, and says:

If Congressman Dingley is not fully capable of producing a book or pamphlet of medium dimensions with the title of "Perplexities" of his own construction, we do not know who could surpass him in that line, or be more self-pleased to be the possessor of such a species of cleverness as may make the typical American furious.

NORTH ADAMS, Mass., Sept. 19. -- The people of this place are interested greatly in the approaching visit of President McKinley, Secretary Long, Secretary Alger, Attorney General McKenna, and members of their families as the guests of W.B. Plunkitt. The principal public event will be their presence at the Hoosac Valley Agricultural Society's cattle show and fair in this city next Wednesday or Thursday.

Senator QUAY is a man who has acquired a reputation for reluctance in answering questions touching his motives for action, but we are unwilling to believe that he will heartlessly or silently turn away from a series of earnest inquiries put to him at the meeting in Grange Park, Centre Hall, Penn., on Thursday last.

ATLANTA, Sept. 19. -- The recent shooting of the negro Postmaster at Hogansville threatens to entail no end of trouble for the people of that town. A Post Office Inspector has finished a three days' investigation of the shooting, and it is stated to-night that as a result of his work two of the most prominent business men in the town will be arrested this week on a charge of attempting to assassinate the Postmaster.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 19. -- This week bids fair to be one of the most interesting during the exposition. Tuesday will be Irish-American Day. There will be a street parade, followed by public exercises. Addresses will be delivered by Gov. Taylor, ex-Senator Patrick Walsh of Augusta, Ga.; John F. Finerty of Chicago, and others.

Gen. CoLLIS has already without doubt been made aware that he is quite alone in his opinion that he is an intelligent, vigilant, and satisfactory Commissioner of Public Works. The object lesson which is afforded by a comparison between his official method of doing important work and the unofficial method of the Metropolitan Company is altogether conclusive.
LONDON, Sept. 20. -- Commenting on the communication from the Colonial Office to the Foreign Office on the dispatch of Secretary Sherman to Ambassador Hay, The Standard says:

TACOMA, Sept. 19. -- Mail advices from China state that in no part of that empire has there been such a development since the war with Japan as in the Province of Hengting, better known as Manchuria. This ancestral home of the ruling dynasty for many centuries had been left to a sparse population of agriculturists, although a few cities had become populous in the southern part of the province.

CHICAGO, Sept. 19. -- William Faversham, the Gil-Berault of the Empire Theatre Company's "Under the Red Robe," now playing at Hooley's, can, when the occasion warrants it, shed real tears. Faversham's dog, "Woodcote Balsamo" for long and "Turk" for short, was shipped from New York by express last night. Faversham had found life unbearable without his pet, and telegraphed one of his New York friends to send on the animal by the fastest express.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- The officials of the State Department are not disposed to comment on the fur-seal correspondence given out by the British Foreign Office and summarized in The London Times further than to say it shows that the object sought by the Government of the United States for the last three years has been attained by the agreement of Great Britain to participate in the conference to be held in October.

To a full congregation the Rev. Dr. R.S. MacArthur last night delivered, at the Calvary Baptist Church, West Fifty-eighth Street, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues, a sermon on "Political and Religious Duty in the Municipal Crisis."

The Akista and Eidolon raced off the Atlanta Clubhouse at Bay Ridge on Saturday for the cup offered by Vice Commodore F.T. Adams. The Akista took the lead at the start, but at the first mark Eidolon led by four minutes, and the continued in the lead all the way round. The Akista was disqualified by not turning the buoy off Red Hook, and the Eidolon was awarded the cup.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 19. -- Jeff Joiner, constable of Wiley Township, in Randolph County, and Lee Jarrett, a well-known resident of that neighborhood, are in jail at Pocahontas on the charge of murder, and 500 enraged citizens are prepared to swing them up to a tree should the law fail to punish them.

When PLATT'S Republican State Committee rails at the Citizens' Union and commends the "constant and sincere" efforts of PLATT and QUIGG to form a union against Tammany, the spectacle reminds one of a lot of old topers sitting down in a tavern to growl at the Judges, the lawyers, the ministers, and all the decent people in the town.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19. -- Acting Secretary Roosevelt, as an answer to recently published reports that the battleship Indiana was injured while in the Halifax dry dock, has made public the following report received from Capt. Henry Taylor, commanding the vessel, made shortly after the docking:

It is evident that the silverites of Ohio are not taking comfort from the English reports concerning the safely qualified conditions upon which the Bank of England will "do something for silver," even if it be only to hold one-fifth of the reserve of the Bank of England in silver, provided the United States and France will agree to "resume" the free coinage of silver.

IMLAYSTOWN, N.J., Sept. 19. -- The business section of this village was almost wiped out by fire this morning. The fire is supposed to have been started by burglars after they had looted a store, in order to cover up their robbery.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 19. -- The yellow fever situation has undergone little change since yesterday. At 6 o'clock to-night the record in the Board of Health office showed six new cases and one death. There are three cases under investigation.

NEWARK, Sept. 19. -- Acting under instructions from the State Republican Committee, a sub-committee, with Vice President Garret A. Hobart as consultor and adviser, prepared an address in regard to the constitutional amendments which are to be voted on Sept. 28, and last night, after completing its labors, gave out the address, which is signed by Franklin Murphy, Chairman of the State Committee.
In eleven police precincts the Captains who were transferred on Saturday by Acting Chief McCullagh "for the good of the service" took formal command yesterday at the 6 o'clock roll call.

Asked by a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES as to the probable effect of the rise in prices of American pig iron upon the growing export trade, Mr. Archer Brown, who has just sailed for Europe to promote American iron trade interests, stated that in his opinion the temporary effect will be to check the movement.

Some seventy-five members of the Young Ladies' Charitable Society, graced by the presence of five male members, constituting its Board of Directors, gathered in Terrace Garden yesterday afternoon for the semi-annual election of offices. The society includes over 200 attractive young women, who are banded together for the indiscriminate dispensation of charity, "without regard to religion, race, or creed."

The announcement was made in Brooklyn yesterday that Jacob Worth, seeing the hopelessness of trying to force Seth Low upon the City Convention, has abandoned his fight for him, and will henceforth put forth his efforts to regain his old-time place in the State organization and save his friends on the county slate from utter annihilation in the County Convention.

A circular issued by the Law and Order League of Hudson County in relation to the race track amendments and the special election on Sept. 28, and another on the same subject from the Rev. Dr. Kempshall of Elizabeth were read in nearly all the Protestant churches of Jersey City yesterday, and in the evening several ministers made the amendments and the election the subject of a prelude.

The Tammany wing of the Progressive Democratic League, which met yesterday at Flannery's Hall, at Hudson and Leroy Streets, had a row over the snub that its Conference Committee got from the Democratic State Committee when it asked that body to reaffirm the Chicago platform. However, the strong Tammany adherents present were numerous enough to make the league accept what the State Committee had done
Charges and countercharges of political trickery were the order of the day at yesterday's meeting of the Central Labor Union.

Very little rowing was done on the Harlem River yesterday, owing to the fact that the majority of the oarsmen attended the annual dinner and reunion of the Harlem Regatta Association, held at College Point, L.I. The dinner was given to celebrate the close of the most successful rowing season in the history of the organization, and about 200 members of the various clubs along the river attended.

Mack Westfield, colored, who lives in One Hundred and Twenty-first Street, near First Avenue, was held in $1,000 bail, in the Harlem Police Court, yesterday, charged with felonious assault. Westfield is known as a "police fighter." He started a fight yesterday morning in "Nigger Alley," which extends from One Hundred and Thirtieth Street to One Hundred and Thirty-first Street, between Park and Madison Avenues.

-- Tact of a highly characteristic sort is displayed by the local members of the Prohibition Party in adopting, as a means of winning votes, the plan of making a free distribution of soap among voters. Now, soap, like strict temperance, is an admirable thing, and a vast number of voters would not be harmed, but benefited, by the one as by the other.

BOMBAY, Sept. 19. -- The advices from the front show that the various columns are advancing against the Mahmoukis from Panjkora and Shabkadr. As yet they have met with no serious opposition, but the difficulties of transportation in a mountainous and almost pathless country are immense. Another formidable obstacle in the way of rapid movement is the lack of water.

" What is behind it?" Don't you know, really? Well, let me tell you. When England or England's esteemed "headlights" throw out startling blazes that surprise the whole financial world, they do so only after brainy deliberation and great foresight as to benefits that must accure to England thereafter.

In a communication to the State Department, Consul Read, who is stationed at Tien-Tsin, China, has inclosed a letter from an American firm in that city in which attention is called to the brilliant prospects for the advancement of American trade in China. That country, the letter states, is anxious to do something for America in recognition of the assistance rendered by this Government in bringing about peace between China anti Japan.
The American Yacht Club sailed its Fall regatta off Milton Point on the Sound on Saturday. The wind was light from the south, and the start was made at 1 o'clock. The table follows:

DENVER, Col., Sept. 19. -- The Silver Republican Convention of Mineral County adopted resolutions refusing to ratify the nomination of Judge Hayt for Justice of the Supreme Court by the Republican State Conviction, because he accepted the nomination of the administration Republicans. It is expected the other County Conventions will do likewise, taking their cue from Senator Teller, who has declared that he will not make a speech in support of Hayt during the campaign.

Augustus Cook, the actor, who last Friday night assaulted his wife, Evelyn Cook, and his servant, Lizzie Brown, in his apartment, 19 West One Hundred and Second Street, and who was held without bail to await the result of their injuries, was arraigned in the Harlem Police Court yesterday morning.

One of the most important series of games in the League schedule will begin at the Polo Grounds this afternoon, when the Baltimores and New Yorks will play their final engagement of the series. The games are of vital importance to the champions and the Bostons, who are at present running neck-and-neck for the honor of winning the much coveted pennant.

The Virginia Republicans will not have a State ticket this Fall, if the decision of the State Executive Committee be not balked by the obstinate demand of Col. LAMB of Norfolk and a hundred thousand or so of Republicans, that a convention be held and a full ticket be given to the voters, who will otherwise be obliged to support Bryan Democrats or Populists or both.

LONDON, Sept. 19. -- The conditions of the money market remain substantially unchanged, though discount is somewhat easier. The future of the market depends mainly upon the question of gold withdrawals for the United States. The Bank will doubtless advance the rate in the event of an important American demand; otherwise the present low discount rates promise to continue.
" Old Tammany has troubles of her own these later days."

The approach of the college football season suggests several considerations of more or less importance. The prospects of the leading teams are already under discussion in the columns of the various papers, and for a few cents one can purchase as many different opinions as he may choose to read. In all probability the practical championship will lie, as usual, between Princeton and Yale.

HAZLETON, Penn., Sept. 19. -- Absolute quiet prevailed in the entire strike district to-day. Vice President Maguire of the Federation of Labor left for Washington to attend the meeting of the Executive Council, which is to consider the situation, and George Chance of the United Labor League went to Scranton to attend a similar meeting of labor men there.

The reason we have not annihilated the free-silver craze is because there has been enough fallacy in some of the sound-money literature to feed the silver heresy and keep it alive. The strength of "16 to 1" is not in Mr. Bryan's arguments, but in the weakness of some of the sound-money teachings. The silver movement, of course, could not live without an argument.

DEFIANCE, Ohio, Sept. 20. -- Chester Childs, a broom maker of Toledo, is here to prosecute his mother-in-law, Mrs. Daniel Farner, of Hicksville. Ohio, on a charge of defrauding him out of $1,170 by interrupting mail and by false pretenses.

There was a big blaze and a life was lost yesterday afternoon in the Morton Boarding Stables, at Washington and Morton Streets. Adam Schubert's anxiety to save his tools induced him to rush into danger, and his life paid the forfeit.

R. King Lee of 127 St. Mark's Place, Brooklyn, has been missing since Tuesday from the hotel at Niagara Falls where he was stopping, and his family fear that he may have been the man who was washed over the falls on that day. Mr. Lee is seventy-six years of age, and on Sept. 7 left Brooklyn on a business trip, but he expected to return by Sept. 12.

Joseph Rogers, for the last twenty-three years with Fayerweather Ladew, leather dealers, as office boy, clerk, assistant bookkeeper, and finally as head bookkeeper, was arrested yesterday, charged with having stolen about $18,000 from his employers. The money was taken in small amounts -- from $10 to $50 at a time -- and the thefts extended over a period of more than twelve years.

Watching the races at Gravesend yesterday was a decidedly unpleasant task for those who were unfortunate enough to visit the track without a top coat. A chilling wind swept over the grand stand, giving a purple tinge to the noses of those who did not move about much, and to add to the discomfort there were frequent showers.
