WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- Secretary Alger spent some time this morning in conference with President Weare and Michael Cudahy of the Alaska Transportation and Trading Company, at his office in the War Department. They announced their intention to make every effort to get as much of the supplies at St. Michael up the Yukon as possible, and it is expected that three more steamers can be run up before the river closes entirely to navigation.

A good many gold Democrats found it hard to vote for WILLIAM McKINLEY last November. Some couldn't vote for him. They either took to the woods or voted for PALMER. But we never heard of a gold Democrat demanding that McKINLEY and PALMER should withdraw in order that with a new candidate there might be a union of all the forces opposed to BRYAN.
Jacob Worth yesterday denied in the most emphatic terms that he had abandoned his fight for Seth Low's nomination, or that he had any intention of doing so.

At a meeting of the Executive Committee of the Citizens' Union, held yesterday afternoon in the assembly room on the third floor of the Mutual Life Building, 32-34 Nassau Street, the following resolution was unanimously adopted:

It is often asserted that the Chinese invented all of our best inventions thousands of years ago. It now appears that they have a Minneapolis and St. Paul feud of their own. But they have thei own way of conducting those affairs over there. They do not do it in the way that our Western cities do at all.

The first report of a dispatch by carrier pigeon from ANDREE'S balloon was found to be false, and probably a cruel and silly hoax. With most readers this fact sufficed to bring discredit upon subsequent messages purporting to be from the balloon. Incredulity may be as deceptive as credulity.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Sept. 20. -- The Newfoundland Legislature will be dissolved to-morrow. Sir Herbert Murray, the Governor, announces in his proclamation that Oct. 28 next is the date for the election of the new Parliament.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 20. -- The Belle Ellen mines at Blocton, Bibb County, are on fire. The following miners are known to be dead: Herman Kramer and Hubbard Foley, white; Henry Reeves, Frank James, and Bill Fairfax, colored. Several others are missing, but their names cannot be learned because of the confusion attending the calamity.

WHEELING, West Va., Sept. 20. -- The feature of interest in the opening of the September term of the United States Court for the District of West Virginia was the application of ex-Gov. A.B. Fleming of Fairmont to make the injunction against Eugene V. Debs and others perpetual.
SYDNEY, C.B., Sept. 20. -- The steam sealing bark Hope, with Lieut. R.E. Peary and party on board, returning from North Greenland, arrived here at 5 o'clock this afternoon. All on board are well.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20. -- Emma Davis, who has gained a National reputation as "The Child Slave," and whose coming from California has been looked for daily by the officers of the Young Women's Christian Association, arrived in Chicago this morning. The girl, who is twelve years old, was met at the station by Mrs. L.R. Favor, who took her to the home of the society on Michigan Avenue.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20. -- Chicago is to have its street cleaners in white uniforms, just as New York. Not a few, but a whole army of them, and Chicago is to have them soon. Mayor Harrison promises them within a few days, and he said to-night this was no idle promise, but something he fully expected to keep.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20. -- State's Attorney Deneen to-day asked the County Board to appropriate $2,500 more to help him carry on the Luetgert murder case, on trial before Judge Tuthill. Expert witnesses, Mr. Deneen finds, will not work for love or glory, and, besides, he asserts there are several persons he desires to bring here from New York to testify for the State.

HAZLETON, Penn., Sept. 20. -- Unless unforeseen developments occur, the anthracite coal strike in this region is ended. To-day 1,200 men, half of the full complement, returned to work at the Honey Brook collieries of the Lehigh and Wilkesbarre Company, as did 300 of the 1,300 at Pardee's Lattimer mines, while the Cranberry, Crystal Bridge, and Harwood collieries of the same company, and Coxe's collieries in the Drifton district, remained at work.

HAVANA, Sept. 20. -- The Spanish columns under Gen. Luque and Col. Moreno had a sharp engagement with the insurgents who were trying to capture the fort at Los Bajos de la Brechosa, near Holguin. The cavalry charged, killing seventeen insurgents. The columns lost five killed and fourteen wounded.

COPENHAGEN, Sept. 20. -- A dispatch received here from Hammerfest, the northernmost town of Europe, in Norway, says the whaling ship Falken has brought there the third alleged pigeon dispatch from Prof. Andree, the aeronaut who left the Island of Amsterdam in a balloon on July 11 last in an attempt to cross the polar regions. The message brought by the Falken reads:

Golf tournaments at Tuxedo are always among the enjoyable golf events of the season, and the annual open tournament announced for this week by the Tuxedo Golf Club will attract a large number of our local players. Many of the contestants will remain at Tuxedo during the week as guests of the cottagers.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20. -- Evidence has fallen into the hands of members of the Executive Committee of the Educational Board of the Presbyterian Church which shows that Charles M. Charnley, the defaulting and missing Treasurer, attempted last Spring to secure a life-insurance policy of $50,000 from the New York Life Insurance Company.

As one who believes in clear-cut statements and accurate reasoning from true premises, I wish to say that Mr. Piper's letter in to-day's issue of your paper deserves commendation for its clearness and logic. The money question is one, it seems to me, in which all depends on "the state of mind" of the commercial world -- meaning thereby all those who buy and sell goods, wares, merchandise, and labor.

BERLIN, Sept. 20. -- Play in the international chess tournament was resumed to-day at the Architekten Haus, when the eighth round of the Berger schedule was adopted for to-day's seventh round of the tournament, the pairing being as follows:

As it appears on the Supreme Court calendar, the bald title, "Berliner vs. Scharlin," is more communicative than the principals in the case, pretty Annie Berliner and Jacob Scharlin, in the ordinary method of vocal conversation. Both are deaf-mutes, but Annie says this fact did not prevent Jacob from wooing her and plighting an unspoken troth, which he has refused to keep, thereby damaging her to the amount of $50,000.
" The Girl from 'Frisco" is the name of a comedy that George C. Jenks is rehearsing for an early production at the Star Theatre.

CHICAGO, Sept. 20. -- The depositors of the Globe Savings Bank have little chance of getting any dividends for several months unless the courts decide not to grant the petition of the University of Illinois for leave to file a lien on the assets of the defunct institution.

Sol Smith Russell began a long engagement at the Garden Theatre last evening in presence of a numerous and cordial, if not particularly demonstrative, audience. A lack of noisy demonstrations on a theatrical "first night" in this town generally indicates that the proportion of intelligence in the audience is unusually large.

Recent action by the Canadian Wheelmen's Association has given assurance that the Canadian body will support the League of American Wheelmen in its fight against the outlawed racers of the Pacific Coast, who have threatened to attain a strength that would be used to deprive the league of its control of racing.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 20. -- "A Virginia Courtship" was given at the Baldwin Theatre to-night by W.H. Crane for the first time on any stage. The comedy is in three acts, and, being set in the early portion of the century, presents opportunity for handsome and picturesque costuming, which the producer was careful to take advantage of.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 20. -- The largest number of cases reported on any one day since yellow fever first made its appearance in New Orleans, two weeks ago, was recorded on the books of the Board of Health this evening at 6 o'clock, although at that hour not a single case had proved fatal during the day.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- The War Department has made public the report of Second Lieut. James A. Moss. Twenty-fifth Infantry, who commanded the bicycle corps which made the long journey from Fort Missoula, Mon., to St. Louis last Summer. The document is filled with information of the greatest value to bicyclists who contemplate making long trips awheel.

The Republican primaries in the Thirty-second Election District of the Thirty-fourth Assembly District, last night, caused the death of Hieronymus Breisacher, seventy-two years old, of 5 East One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street.

The Republican organization made a clean sweep at the primaries last night. At midnight the returns from the Twenty-seventh Assembly District, the only one in which the friends of Seth Low made any determined stand, indicated that the machine would control the District Convention by a majority of about fifty votes.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20. -Philadelphia defeated Washington to-day in an interesting game. Taylor pitched a superb game. AicJames was very effective when men were on bases, but gave eight bases on bails. Dowd's base runninir was a feature. Score:

The anti-Tammany Democratic organizations have an unusually lively week before them. They are busy arranging for conventions, and discussing candidates; some are making efforts to bring the Wigwam into line with their policy, while others have despaired of united action, and are preparing to make an independent campaign.

LENOX, Sept 20. -- The first day of the annual tournament of the Lenox Golf Club brought together the largest number of well-known golfers ever seen in Lenox. The playing was excellent, considering the condition of the links, which were wet, especially at the heartbreakers. It was a poor day for playing.

Several Wholesale merchants in this city have made it a point to talk with their out-of-town customers within the last few days regarding the individual experiences of the visitors. In most cases the non-resident merchants are enthusiastic over the extent and possibilities of this market, and all agree that business men generally have been benefited by the work of the Merchants' Association.

News of the death of Carolan O'Brien Bryant, in Sligo, Maryland, on Sept. 8, and the subsequent destruction by fire of a costly mansion which he had nearly completed in Sligo, has just reached this city.

TRENTON, Sept. 20. -- The New Jersey Court of Errors and Appeals to-day sustained the decision of the Supreme Court which held to be unconstitutional the legislative act of last Winter providing for charter elections in Jersey City and Newark in the Fall instead of the Spring.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20. -- The impression is gaining ground that the occasion of the Attorney General's long delay in announcing his decision on Section XXII. of the Tariff law is due to the positive change of mind on his part since his first consideration of the case. It was then whispered on pretty good authority that he would sustain the duty.

BROCKTON, Mass., Sept. 21. -- The big strike of lasters is settled. The strikers express themselves as well satisfied with the result. About 1,000 workmen were concerned in this town and neighborhood.
P.S. Tracy has sold, for H.B. and A.M. Goodwin, to Joseph L. Weed, the three-story brownstone-front dwelling, 149 West Sixty-third Street, 17.3 by 100.5.

Frederick N. Blanc, who some time ago obtained an absolute divorce from his wife Elizabeth, moved before Justice Russell, in the Supreme Court, yesterday, to punish her for contempt for her continued use of the name and title, "Baroness Blanc," in defiance of the judgment of divorce, which prohibited her from using the name of Blanc.

Old Sol had hid his face behind a black bank of clouds in the west and night was about to throw its pall over the Polo Grounds last evening when Amos Ruzie, the Giants' crack pitcher, and the idol of every baseball "rooter" in this town, made a clean base hit into left field and sent in the run which enabled his club to defeat the champion Baltimores.

The interesting letter from a correspondent in Bolivia which we publish in another column supports by its date one of the reasons which it gives for the comparative dullness of our trade with South America. A place geographically so near us as Potosi, and postally so far from us that it takes two months for a letter to pass, evidently cannot be in the line of a very active trade.

Edward H. Fuller and William Clark Wilson, who did business as bullion dealers at 29 Wall Street under the style of Fuller Wilson, and with a working capital of $40,000, made an assignment yesterday to William H. Fleet of 92 Gold Street, with a preference to James B. Colgate for $6,000. The assets and liabilities amount each to between $40,000 and $50,000.

BUDAPEST, Sept. 20. -- Emperor William of Germany arrived here at 10 o'clock this morning, and was welcomed by Emperor Francis Joseph, the Cabinet Ministers, and the civil and military authorities. The approach of the imperial train was heralded by a salute of twenty-four guns, and when it steamed into the railroad station all those present on the platform loudly cheered his Majesty, and the band played "Heil dir Kaiser."

-- Long and constant experience with infectious diseases has developed in the residents of Havana the unfortunate ability to face any ordinary epidemic with composure, but even in that city there may well be a panic if dredging operations are begun in the harbor. This must be done, it seems, if the floating dry dock just purchased in England is to enter and lie under the guns of the Cabanas.
LONDON, Sept. 21. -- The Pall Mall Gazette this afternoon, commenting in its financial article on the fall of three-quarters in Spanish fours on heavy sales for Continental account, says:

It is not without importance that the prices of Spanish securities have fallen on the Bourses of Europe in consequence of the dispatch to Le Temps, Paris, regarding the interview of our Minister with the Duke of TETUAN. It is not necessary to suppose that the propositions of Mr. WOODFORD were accurately stated in that dispatch.

Will "Concessionist" please define the word dollar? Will he tell us how he would know the exchangeable value of an article unless he could measure its value in some standard of monetary value? Having measured the monetary value of wool in gold, should we not also measure the monetary value of gold in gold?

CHICAGO, Sept. 21. -- The direct evidence in the Luetgert case is in, and the State has rested. Shortly after 2 o'clock this afternoon the last witness of the prosecution was heard. This witness was Mrs. Louise Miller Johnson. She came into court supported by Capt. Herman Schuettler.

BAY SHORE, Sept. 21. -- As John L. Coe left the cars here yesterday he was arrested by Constable Towns on the charge of being drunk and disorderly, the warrant having been obtained by a member of his family.

NEWARK, Sept. 21. -- A delicate surgical operation was performed at the German Hospital last evening, by means of which hatpin five and one-half inches long was removed from a child's stomach. The subject of the operation was Lena Strippe, three and one-half years old, the daughter of August Strippe of Harrison.

Cold weather will not end cycle racing for the year in the New York section, according to plans given out by persons who have arranged large sporting events in past years. The six days' race was planned long ago by the same management which recently has decided to arrange for a series of indoor race meets during the Winter.
Vice President Garret A. Hobart, Senator Thomas C. Platt, and Chairman Quigg of the Republican County Committee had a conference yesterday forenoon in Senator Platt's office, 49 Broadway.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- Joseph Ladue, the Alaska pioneer, who came to Washington to consult with Secretary Alger about methods for the relief of the destitution which he and others who comprehend the situation believe will overtake those who have crowded into the Klondike without adequate supplies, called on President McKinley to-day.

William Gantz, a feeder in the pressrooms of the Manufacturers and Publishers' Printing Company, at 218 William Street, and who lived with his wife at 1,014 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, jumped from the Brooklyn Bridge yesterday shortly before noon, thus apparently carrying out his boast that he could do it and survive without serious injury, and that, after all, it was by no means a difficult feat.

Vanderbilt brokers made no attempt to support their specialties yesterday. They stood aside and watched the bears hammering and bringing about stop-order selling. Their attitude was in accordance with telephone messages from Forty-second Street. Said one of these messages:

The J.B. Schuyler, a side-wheel fishing boat, caught fire in the slip at the foot of East Twentieth Street, at 11 o'clock last night, and was burned to the water's edge. Sarah A. Holland og 206 Sullivan Street, the stewardess, and Hannah Matson of 434 East Sixteenth Street, the cook, both colored, were on the boat at the time, and were rescued by the police.

At their regular meeting yesterday the Trustees of the Normal College approved the new course of study as recommended by the Faculty and approved by the Executive Committee, and received the report of President Hunter as to the condition of the college.

Henrietta Heins, who was implicated with Lawrence Waters in abandoning two of his children at Haverstraw on Saturday last, was arrested yesterday at Waters's home at Eighty-fifth Street and Fourteenth Avenue, Brooklyn, by Officer Michael Connolly of the Central Office squad. When arrested Mrs. Heins was attending to her duties as housekeeper for Waters, who, until his arrest on Monday night, was employed as foreman in the repair shops of the Brooklyn Heights Railroad.

LENOX, Sept. 21. -- Fenn was the centre of attention to-day at the second day of the Lenox golf tournament. The playing was preliminary to the match for the Lenox Cup, now held by Fenn. Large crowds followed Fenn around the course four times, and applauded his brilliant playing. He was in much better form than yesterday, and in several instances made drives well up to the 200-yard line.
The Tammany primaries passed off uneventfully last night. There were no contests and no excitement.

BUDAPEST, Sept. 21. -- At the State banquet given to-day in honor of Emperor William of Germany Emperor Francis Joseph, in cordially proposing his Majesty's health, referred to him as "my faithful friend, ally, and unwearied fellow-laborer in the great work of peace, to which may we ever devote our best powers."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 21 . -- The Republican County Convention met here to-day, and, to the surprise of all, the threatened bolt of the Ward-Robertson faction from the Burns-Fairchild faction, which claims to be the regular organization, did not materialize. William V. Molloy of New Rochelle was nominated for Sheriff, and Coroner Charles E. Birch was renominated.
A raid as daring as was ever made in the far West was successfully and safely executed last evening in the heart of the most crowded part of New York.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21. -- Marina Comenol Orbi Hozae Rizal, the widow of Dr. Hozae Rizal, who was butchered by Gen. Polaviejo on Dec. 6, 1896, is now in Philadelphia. Dr. Rizal was the acknowledged leader and instigator of the revolution in the Philippines, which had been smoldering since 1894.
LONDON, Sept. 21. -- Hannis Taylor, the former United States Minister to Spain, arrived here yesterday evening and called at the United States Embassy to-day. In an interview Mr. Taylor said:
Dr. Stephen Smith was appointed a Commissioner of Charities yesterday by Mayor Strong, to succeed Silas C. Croft, who has been appointed Surveyor of the Port.

Florence B. Harmon, who was arrested on Monday in the jewelry shop of Hamrick Co., on Broadway, near Eighteenth Street, on the charge of having stolen a ring set with diamonds and an opal from Oliver M. Farrand, a jeweler at 3 Maiden Line, on Friday last, was released yesterday morning on bail by Magistrate Cornell, in the Jefferson Market Police Court.

NEW BRUNSWICK, Sept. 21. -- Hereafter the Pennsylvania Railroad office in Jersey City will be able to keep in touch with the men who patrol its tracks at night. A checking system will be employed, the track walkers being used as the patrols.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Sept. 21. -- Work has been in progress for six weeks on board fence twenty-two feet high in the yard of Mrs. Charles Herold on Broad Street. It is located within a few inches of the fence dividing the Herold yard from the one adjoining, and, according to Mrs. Herold, is to prevent a family named Koppleman from throwing dishwater into the Herold yard.

BERLIN, Sept. 21. -- Before resumption of play in the international chess tournament now in progress at the Architekten Haus, in this city, it was announced this morning that Zinkl and Caro drew their game, left unfinished in the seventh round yesterday.
LONDON, Sept. 22. -- The Berlin correspondent of The Standard says:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21. -- Lieut. Commander Kimball has received from Acting Secretary Roosevelt final instructions for the movements of the torpedo boat flotilla, and all is now ready for the start of this novel expedition.

Why do the Platt organs keep up this nonsense about Mr. Low's "withdrawal"? Mr. Low accepted the nomination for Mayor because 127,000 of his fellow-citizens had in effect asked him to do so. The collection of so many votes through the machinery provided by the Citizens' Union supplied the evidence for which he had asked that his candidacy would "prove a unifying force among the friends of good government in the city."

NEWBURG, Sept. 21. -- Whenever the under classes at West Point think that the tactical officers are working them too hard they either spike the reveille gun or carry it off. This trick is nearly as old as the academy, and seldom it is perpetrated without one or more cadets getting into trouble.
A fight between the State of North Carolina and the Southern Railway Company, for possession of the North Carolina Railroad, was temporarily transferred to this city yesterday.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 21. -- Communion services at the morning session to-day of the National Conference of Unitarian and other Christian Churches were conducted by the Rev. Rush R. Shippen of Brockton, Mass., assisted by the Rev. J.P. Forbes of Taunton, Mass. The meeting was called to order by the President of the association, George F. Hoar of Worcester, Mass., in a few words of welcome.

The Baltimores showed some of their true form yesterday and scored a decisive victory over the Giants at the Polo Grounds. The local team, on the other hand, did not play the game they are capable of, and some very ragged fielding helped the champions to a few unnecessary runs. The champions outplayed the Giants at every stage of the game.

CHICAGO, Sept. 21. -- The management of the Horse Show to be held in November has secured a rate of $25 per horse between New York and the Coliseum. New York horses may be exhibited here and returned in time for the New York Horse Show.

NORTH ADAMS, Mass., Sept. 21. -- Preparations for the reception and entertainment of President McKinley and party, who will arrive to-morrow, are quietly progressing and little change has been made in the programme outlined yesterday. Business houses, hotels, and private residences are being decorated to-day, the bad weather of yesterday having delayed this work.

ALBANY, Sept. 21. -- The report of the public libraries, division of the University of the State of New York, written by William R. Eastman, the Inspector of Libraries, has just been printed. In the course of the report Mr. Eastman says:

More frequent reduced-rate excursions from interior points to New York are desired by the out-of-town buyers. A record kept of the number of visiting merchants who have said that they would come to this market oftener if they could get lower rates on the railroads shows that a large proportion of the persons who have called at the headquarters of the Merchants' Association feel in that way.

On the 29th of September, 1894, a highly authoritative statement was made of Republican doctrine and policy in regard to non-partisan city elections. It was contained in an address signed by all the Republican members of the State Constitutional Convention, which had just closed its labors.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 21 -- Nine new cases of yellow fever were reported to the Board of Health to-day. There were no deaths recorded, and the doctors all agreed this evening that the situation was improving steadily. The fever at present, instead of developing into a malignant type, is, if anything, milder than when it first appeared.

HAZLETON, Penn., Sept. 21. -- Peace has been restored in the anthracite region and nearly every colliery worked to-day. Included in these were the Lehigh and Wilkesbarre Company's Audenreid mines, employing 2,500 men. The strike was inaugurated by them and their return to work yesterday caused a stampede of the other strikers.
Jesse C. Bennett Co. have sold, for the estate of Mary T. Kane, for about $85,000, the four-story brownstone-front dwelling 14 West Seventy-second Street, 25 by 70 by 102.2.

Now that the season of most of the Summer resorts is over, it may not be amiss to consider briefly the effect of the excursionist upon them. Those who have watched Newport during the Summer just ended have been made aware of a state of affairs which threatens the social supremacy of that admired city by the sea.

FLEMINGTON, N. J., Sept. 21. -- Three burglars made a desperate attempt to kill Chief of Police Charles Peterson last night. The burglars had already entered the blacksmith's shop of A. J. Bellis, where they stole several sledge hammers and other tools. Armed with these they entered the Post Office, but the safe was empty.

A suit for breach of promise between deaf-mutes is a proceeding rare enough to be interesting in itself. But the interest is intensified and complicated when it appears that the parties have different modes of communication, and, in the words of the late Mr. BRYANT, "speak a various language."

-- By threatening with severe punishment anybody who spreads an inaccurate report that there is yellow fever in Atlanta, the authorities of that city will further its interests only so long as not a single case of the disease exists there. If the infection does come in, however, this strange regulation will be a great source of peril.

Seth Low, nominee of the Citizens' Union for Mayor of Greater New York, has made this statement to James B. Reynolds, Chairman of the Citizens' Union Executive Committee, with regard to the report that he intends to withdraw from the race:
Permit me a word of comment on your personal criticism of me in this morning's issue of your paper. You say that I defend machine politics and denounce attempts at reform.

The steel viaduct at One Hundred and Fifty-fifth Street which carries the roadway from the high level of St. Michael's Avenue down to McCombs Dam Bridge is being cleaned of the accumulated rust so fatal to steel structures by a new process, which, it is claimed, will preserve the metal from further corrosion for years.
NORTH ADAMS, Mass., Sept. 22. -- New England gave President McKinley a warm welcome to-day.
No wonder is it that the Government withheld to the latest hour the publication of the total vote registered on the Hawaiian Islands for the next election.

John P. Mount, forty-eight years old, for the last twenty years an employe of Simpson, Crawford Simpson, dry goods merchants, committed suicide last evening in the Occidental Hotel, Broome Street and the Bowery, by shooting himself in the left temple.

Ni Yama, the Director General of the imperial stud of Japan, who is on a tour of the world with a view to obtaining stallions for breeding purposes in the Mikado's stud, was one of the visitors at the Gravesend track yesterday. He was much interested in the racing, especially in the speculative part of it, for in Japan the Mikado has forbidden betting on horse races.

Gold imports from Europe have begun in an unexpected way. The officers of the National City Bank announced yesterday that there had been shipped for its account $1,000,000 in United States gold coin, taken from the Bank of England, and $500,000, possibly in bullion, which will come from Genoa, Italy.

CHICAGO, Sept. 22. -- Richard Croker, ex-leader of Tammany, and State Senator Jacob A. Cantor arrived in Chicago this morning. Mr. Croker came to invite Mayor Harrison to make the closing speech in the Mayoralty campaign. Mr. Harrison accepted at once. He will speak in Cooper Union on the night of Nov. 1.

READING, Penn., Sept. 22. -- Word has been received in Reading, Penn., that Dr. T.M. Angstadt, a native of Berks County, had committed suicide at Mahone Bay, Lunenburg County, Nova Scotia, under unusual circumstances.

BERLIN, Sept. 22. -- The ninth round of the international chess tournament was begun this morning at the Architekten Haus, 92 and 93 Wilhelmstrasse, in this city. The pairing, which followed round one of the Berger system, was as follows:

HAVANA, via Key West, Fla., Sept. 22. -- According to advices from Puerto Principe Senor Bartolome Masso has been elected Vice President of the Cuban Republic, Gen. Maximo Gomez Minister of War, and Calixto Garcia has been appointed Major General, Gen. Gomez remaining commander in chief of the army of liberation.

-- Rye, a town where wealth is almost as abundant as it is in any part of Westchester, the stamping ground of millionaires, and where the claims to great social eminence are even more numerous than the dollars, has just distinguished itself by sending "BOB" FITZSIMMONS to represent its aristocrats at a Republican County Convention.

The meeting at the London Clearing House yesterday is a striking evidence of the strong feeling of the financiers of England in regard to any possible disturbance of absolute confidence in the gold standard. Not since the stormy times in the early part of the century has any action by the Bank of England or by any of its officers been so strongly criticised.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Sept. 14. -- The political horizon in the the Black Republic (Haiti) is again becoming very cloudy, and those foreigners who are watching the signs of the times and are au fait with the state of the country, predict that before a very short time has elapsed the scenes of a few years ago will be re-enacted.

Even Senator ELKINS, Mr. JOSEPH NIMMO, and Senator MORGAN, the three persons most conspicuous in precipitating the dispute about the discriminating duty of 10 per cent., and particularly Senator MORGAN, ought to be willing to admit that they have contributed, by their share of the blundering of Congress with the Tariff bill, to just the adverse opinion that Attorney General MCKENNA has rendered.

Collector Bidwell yesterday began a much-needed and long-delayed improvement in the system of collecting customs duties from passengers on incoming steamers. The reform initiated is that of having two Deputy Collectors at the piers to look over the passengers' declarations and collect the duty.
Senator Platt and the Republican organization have withdrawn District Attorney Olcott from the Mayoralty race. This was decided upon yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- The Navy Department has just made public the proceedings of the court-martial in the case of Lieut. C.S. Stanworth, charged with intoxication on duty on board the Adams at Port Angeles, Washington.

Although fiercely contested and replete with instances of skillful mallet work and masterful horsemanship, it was a one-sided game which decided the championship of the Polo Association in favor of the Meadowbrook Club of Westbury, L.I., against the Country Club of Westchester on the Parade Ground of Prospect Park, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon.

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 22. -- It begins to look now as if Fenn would keep the coveted Lenox Cup. He showed some remarkably fine golf in the second round of the tournament for this trophy, played this afternoon. His opponent was Abram Barker of Agawam, and he beat him in an eighteen-hole match, three up, two to play.

New Jersey women's clubs have decided to interest themselves in the preservation of the Palisades. Yesterday about fifty members of the New Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs took a sail on the steam yacht Marietta, offered to them by the owner, Harrison B. Moore, for the purpose of observing the condition of those imposing natural features of the west shore of the Hudson.

As a long-time reader of THE TIMES I wish to congratulate you upon the high state of perfection to which you have brought it, and, at the same time, to congratulate the citizens of New York upon now having a real, an ideal newspaper, that they can be proud of, rely upon, and enjoy from every point of view.

SARATOGA, Sept. 22. -- "The Old Theology and the New" was the topic taken up at the morning session of the Unitarian Conference. "Theology in Relation to History and Philosophy," was the subject of the Rev. Dr. John W. Chadwick of Brooklyn. He confined himself to one aspect of the new theology -- the unique divinity of Jesus. After reviewing the different systems of philosophy from this point of view, he said:

CHICAGO, Sept. 22. -- All the grain and provision markets turned very pretty flip-flops to-day, starting weak and closing strong. Wheat made a very substantial advance. The strength of the cash wheat situation in the Northwest and confirmatory reports on the Russian crop shortage were factors in a one-cent gain.

After being in the stone dry dock for more than a year the cruiser Chicago was floated into the Vallabout channel at the Brooklvn Navy Yard yesterday. The vessel has been thoroughly overhauled. She -as taken from the dry dock and nloored to the derrick wharf, for the purpose of having the large boilers nd engines put in place.
Seth Low will not withdraw as a candidate for Mayor of Greater New York unless the Citizens' Union, which nominated him, shall request him to retire.
CHICAGO, Sept. 22. -- Ex-Judge Vincent, attorney for the defense in the Luetgert murder trial, twice startled the prosecution this morning. The second statement that he made was the more astounding.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 22. -- Plans for a gigantic window-glass monopoly were completed here to-day. H.B. Smith of Hartford City, Ind.; A. Hastings of Wilmington, Del.; W.A. Gorby of Marion, Ind.; T.M. Hart of Muncie, Ind.; W.L. Loeffier, and James A. Chambers of Pittsburg, the Committee of Window Glass Manufacturers appointed to arrange for a combination or trust, practically completed their work to-night.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Sept. 22. -- An unusually fine array of golfers turned out on the Tuxedo Golf Club links to-day to compete in the opening rounds for the three handsome trophies offered in the annual tournament. The round in the morning was it scratch event, and by their scores the golfers were arranged in classes for the different prizes, according to their ability.

ALBANY, Sept. 22. -- All that remains to expiate the kidnapping of little John Conway is the capture and conviction of Albert S. Warner, the New York lawyer who abetted in the commission of the crime.

AUSTIN, Texas, Sept. 22. -- Yellow fever has appeared in Texas. Gov. Culberson received a telegram from State Health Officer Swearingen to-day announcing that a genuine case of yellow fever was in existence at Beaumont.

Ethel Middleton, a curly-haired, bright-faced child of ten years, was arraigned with her mother in the Gates Avenue Police Court, Brooklyn, yesterday. The child was charged with having robbed the private mail box of Henry B.N. Disbrow, at his home, 914 Jefferson Avenue. Upon Ethel's statement that her mother had told her to take the letters, Mrs. Middleton was also taken into custody.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 22. -- The official record in the Board of Health Office to-night at 6 o'clock showed a total of twelve cases since 6 o'clock yesterday evening, and two deaths. The new cases are for the most part widely scattered.

-- There is no longer room for doubt that large quantities of gold exist in the Yukon country, and that fact makes certain a rapid growth of its population. The newcomers will have to live, somehow or other, and it is for the interests of the whole country, as well as for those of the miners, that the living should be somewhere between endurable and comfortable.

Hall J. How Co. have sold for Francis M. Jencks, to a syndicate of builders, represented by Gunn Grant, for about $200,000, the entire block front on the Boulevard between Ninetieth and Ninety-first Streets, west side, 201.8 by 100. The buyers will erect a number of first-class, elevator-equipped apartment houses on the property.

As the period of the second series of merchants' excursions to New York draws to a close the arrivals at the headquarters of the Merchants' Association gradually diminish in numbers each succeeding day. Visiting merchants continue to arrive, but a larger number of merchants who have completed their purchases are going away.

WILKESBARRE, Sept. 22. -- The taking of testimony in the preliminary hearing of the Commonwealth vs. Sheriff Martin and his deputies was concluded to-day. Many of the Commonwealth's strongest witnesses admitted, on cross-examination, that their object in going to Lattimer was to get the men at work there to quit and join them.

EDWARDS, Miss., Sept. 22. -- New cases of yellow fever are reported as follows: J. B. Howie, Benton Howie, Alta Howie, C.R. Knox, J.E. Boxtel, Miss Downing, R.M. Perry, W.L. Smith, Miss Rosalie Howell, Harris Howell, Mrs. Rossman -- total, 11. Total to date, 83; deaths, 2 -- S. Nathan, Miss Anna Henry. Total deaths, 4.

READING, Penn., Sept. 22. -- Ida Becker, a pretty girl of Lititz, Lancaster County, was courted by John Lamon. Business called him from the village, and in his absence John Thurman became a suitor for Ida's hand.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22. -- Copies of the new Cuban tariff law, as recently gazetted at Madrid, have been received here. They show in detail the manner in which the trade between the United States and Cuba will be affected and the basis on which reciprocity can be secured. The preamble recites:...

It was as though a pall had fallen over the Baltimore players and about 200 "rooters" who accompanied them from the Monumental City when they filed through the Polo Ground gates last evening. The Giants were the main cause of this feeling, having defeated the champions when a victory was of vital importance to them.

Mr. Low makes a candid appeal to the sense, the conscience, and the manliness of the Republicans of Greater New York. We have no doubt that as citizens they will respond to it, nor any doubt, if the organization of their party fairly represents them, that it will respond by the nomination of Mr. Low.
HONOLULU, Sept. 14. -- The vote by which the Hawaiian Senate ratified the treaty of annexation to the United States was unanimous.

Chairman Ashley W. Cole and Commissioner Frank M. Baker of the State Board of Railroad Commissioners heard a motion yesterday for a rehearing of the applications of the Metropolitan Street Railway and the Third Avenue Railroad Company for permission to make a change of motive power on their respective lines.

Notwithstanding his failure to pass the civil service examination and the consequent refusal of the Civil Service Board to approve his nomination, A.W. Edson, the recently appointed Assistant Superintendent of Schools, was assigned to duty yesterday afternoon by Superintendent Jasper. Mr. Jasper said Wednesday, when first informed of Mr. Edson's failure, that there was no doubt of his scholarship and ability, and that the examination was more a matter of form than anything else.

Tammany will demand both the Mayoralty and Controllership and will offer Brooklyn the Presidency of the Council on the municipal ticket. The chief reason that impelled John C. Sheehan and his lieutenants to this decision is that at this juncture they cannot afford to desert Controller Ashbel P. Fitch.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23. -- Expert locksmiths are trying to open the safe in George Reichhold's gambling house, 175 West Madison Street, while the proprietor and his son Walter anxiously wait to learn if the safe-blowers who tried to open it yesterday morning secured the $7,000 it contained.

HAZLETON, Penn., Sept. 23. -- Coroner McKee this afternoon began the inquest into the deaths of the striking miners who were shot by a posse of Sheriff's deputies at Lattimer. A two hours' session was held, during which a score of witnesses were examined.

Delegates representing more than 340 German, Swiss, Swedish, Polish, Hungarian, and Slavonic societies in Greater New York met at the Astor House yesterday afternoon and decided to advocate the candidacy of William Sohmer for first Mayor of Greater New York.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept 23. -- About 3,000 people attended the opening meeting of the Democratic campaign at the Auditorium tonight. Several thousand special invitations had been sent out by the local committee. Allen W. Thurman presided.

ADAMS, Mass., Sept 23. -- President McKinley received this morning a number of gentlemen headed by Major Charles A. Stott of Lowell, President of the Home Market Club. Together they inspected the immense plant of the Berkshire Cotton Company.

Old railroad men say they never heard before of an accident like one that occurred on the Staten Island Rapid Transit Railroad yesterday morning, where a locomotive took advantage of the temporary absence of its engineer and ran away.

RALEIGH, N.C., Sept. 23. -- J.W. Wilson, Democrat, and S. Otho Wilson, Populist, Railroad Commissioners, were suspended to-day from office by Gov. Russell. Three weeks ago notice was served on the two Commissioners by the Governor to show cause why they should not be suspended because they had become disqualified to serve by reason of their having acquired an interest in the Southern Railroad Company.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 23. -- The local yellow fever situation did not show any improvement to-day. There were fewer cases than were reported yesterday, but there was one more death than in the previous twenty-four hours, and at least four of the patients were reported at 6 o'clock to be in a dangerous condition. The number of deaths to-day was three, and nine new cases were reported.
The trial of Dr. Otto H. Albanesius, charged with setting fire to his house at 376 Central Avenue, Jersey City, was continued before Judge Hudspeth yesterday.

SEATTLE, Washington, Sept. 23. -- One of the passengers who arrived in the city to-day on the steamer Queen, from Alaska, was Burton F. Bennett, who was sent north by President Cleveland to fill the office of United States District Attorney for Alaska.

It would not be easy to find eleven gentlemen more competent to study and report on the currency question than those who form the comission appoint- ed by the Sound Money Convention and now in session Washington. They are as follows:

Fire losses in this city during the months of May, June, and July, according to the statistics of the New York Board of Fire Underwriters, were nearly twice as great as those in the corresponding period of the previous year. This fact is much commented upon by fire insurance men.

Mr. QUIGG is fond of making assertions, and he makes them with an air of authority. But a politician, especially one who stands with so much assurance upon the record of his party, ought to have a very good memory. Mr. QUIGG, in the campaign for the Mayoralty of Greater New York, is worried lest the wheels of his political foster father's State machine may be clogged.

At a meeting of the Directors of the National Board of Trade of Cycle Manufacturers at their headquarters, 320 Broadway, yesterday, it was decided that a guarantee of sixty days only would be allowed on bicycles next year. The meeting was held behind closed doors, but according to Secretary Ernest R. Franks the decision on the guarantee question was unanimous.

The Home for Aged Men, in Classon Avenue, Brooklyn, appears to be a solemn kind of an institution. Its inmates are apparently well cared for, but there is an iron-clad code of rules evidently made by a body of women managers who do not know much about aged men or men of any other kind.

When the steamship Pentagoet which reached this port yesterday from Eastport, Me., was about eighteen miles off Mt. Desert, Me., Sept. 21, the Second Officer, Andrew Haughie, sighted what he supposed was a portion of a capsized schooner. It was making such extraordinary leeway that he soon decided it was no ordinary piece of wreckage, and Capt. Oakes put the steamer back to investigate.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- The fourth day of the Unitarian Conference commenced with devotional services, conducted by the Rev. F.C. Southworth of Duluth, Minn.
Mr. QUIGG refers to the Republican Party as the "party from which must be drawn nine-tenths of the anti-Tammany vote."

Jacob Worth is a fallen chieftain. He was beaten in the Kings County Republican Convention last night at the Clermont Avenue Rink, Brooklyn, by a vote which leaves no doubt as to the potency of Senator Platt in New York Republican politics.

LENOX, Sept. 23. -- A.H. Fenn, the Palmetto Club golfer, beat Thorp in the semi-finals in the golf tournament at Lenox to-day, and W. Bayard Cutting beat Devereux Emmett, leaving Fenn and Cutting to fight it out to-morrow. If Fenn wins he will keep the beautiful Lenox Cup, now in the custody of his club, which he won last year.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 23. -- Josiah C. Stevens of 768 West Cross Street shot and dangerously wounded his son, Robert J. Stevens, aged twenty-three, in a quarrel this morning over the letter's intended marriage, which was to have taken place to-night.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- In spite of the wet weather to-day, the players in the second-day matches of the Tuxedo Club tournament showed great enthusiasm, and the contests were marked by a laudable zeal, if not by superb brilliancy of play. The steady drizzle made the greens very heavy, requiring the most careful putting not to lose at a critical stage of the game.
The steamer that brings the news that the Senate of Hawaii has approved the treaty of annexation to the United States also brings some curious information about political conditions in that republic.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23. -- To-day's proceed-ants in the Luetgert murder trial were full of interest. In the face of the circumstan-tial evidence that had been produced to prove that lrs. Luetgert met. death in her husband's sausage factory May 1, three witnesses testified to-day that they saw the woman alive on May 3 and 4.

Yesterday was the last day of the fifteenth annual convention of the State Wine, Liquor, and Beer Dealers' Association of New York at Coney Island. The day was spent in discussing the report of the Committee on Resolutions. In the report is included a denunciation of the Raines law as follows:
WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 23. -- At the little town of Lewisboro, Westchester County, last night, James Kelly shot and killed Charles Mead, with whose daughter he recently eloped.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- The Monetary Commission resumed its sessions here to- day with ex-Senator Edmunds presiding. W.B. Dean of St. Paul arrived last night, making nine of the eleven Commissioners present, namely, Messrs. Edmunds, Leighton, Fairchild, Patterson, Bush, Fries, Dean, Taylor, and Laughlin.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23. -- Argument was resumed to-day before Judge Pennypacker in Common Pleas Court upon the demurrer to the bill in equity filed in 1806 by W. W.. Kurtz against the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company and J. Pierpont Morgan and others, composing the firm of J. P. Morgan Co.

The General Committee of the National Democratic Party of Kings County met last night in the Johnston Building, at Nevins Street and Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, with Walter Burton in the chair and Charles A. Webber as Secretary.

The shipment to this country of $1,500,000 in gold from London for account of the City National Bank, and of $1,000,000 from Paris for the Hanover National Bank, with the arrival in San Francisco of $4,000,000 from Australia, are the first striking signs of the effect of the great change in trade conditions brought about during the last nine months.

Gold imports in sight last evening amounted to $6,500,000. Of this $2,500,000 is to come directly to this city. The Hanover National Bank followed yesterday the lead of the National City Bank, which on Wednesday was informed of shipments of $1,500,000 from London and Genoa.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23. -- The San Francisco, with Admiral Selfridge aboard, arrived to-day at Gibraltar from Tangier, and it was stated at the Navy Department that she would probably start eastward, cruising slowly up the Mediterranean, until she reached the coast of Syria. If she had any punitive mission in view when she crossed the straits to Tangier, the fact was carefully concealed at the Navy Department. The former claims referred to

ALBANY, Sept. 23. -- "The lands of the State, now owned or hereafter acquired, constituting the preserve as now fixed by law, shall be forever kept as wild forest lands. They shall not be leased, sold, or exchanged, or be taken by any corporation, public or private, nor shall the timber thereon be sold, removed, or destroyed," -- Section 7, Article VI., of the State Constitution, as amended in 1894.

The final test of the new apparatus for steering torpedoes, which have been going on at Sag Harbor for some time, was concluded yesterday, and is not only voted a success by the naval officers and experts who have had charge of it, but is looked upon as being of the greatest importance and will completely revolutionize torpedo warfare.

At the weekly meeting of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday Controller Fitch read a communication from State Superintendent Skinner of the Department of Education, to the effect that the board is delaying the taking of the biennial school census, and intimating that it is within his power to do this and charge the expense to the city.

Workmen engaged in the construction of the underground trolley lines on Madison and Fourth Avenues have discovered during the past two days that in a number of places where the bed rock reaches to or near the surface the pipes and mains, which were laid six years ago under contracts made by Tammany Commissioners, are not more than two inches below the paving stones.

WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 23. -- The fourth and fifth concerts of the fortieth annual Worcester music festival were given to-day. In the afternoon Rafael Joseffy played Brahms's concerto for piano, No. 2, and the audience was almost frantic in its demonstration of applause.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23. -- According to an opinion written by Justice Carroll, "a leading man" on the stage does not ruin his professional reputation by playing minor parts. The decision was made in a suit brought by Francis Carlyle, a well-known actor, against Frederick Belasco, manager of the Alcazar Theatre, to recover his salary of $100 per week on the ground of breach of contract.

VIENNA, Sept. 23. -- Premier Badeni, upon the reassembling of the Reichsrath to-day, opened the Unterhaus amid a hostile demonstration of the members of the Schoenerer group, which is a section of the German opposition. The Premier then called for cheers for the Emperor, and Herr Schoenerer shouted, "Hoch for the German people!" The cheers asked for by Herr Schoenerer were vociferously given by the German Left.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- Attorney General Hancock has handed down a decision relative to the exemption of the Chief of Police of the City of New York from the civil service regulations of that city as a reply to a letter written by Clarence B. Angle, Secretary of the Civil Service Commission.

Mrs. Mary Valentine Yale Bissell, the wife of Eugene V.N. Bissell, was examined in supplementary proceedings yesterday in a room in the Supreme Court by Mayer C. Goldman, attorney for Revilion Freres, who hold a judgment against her for $323 for services rendered in making her dresses.

John M. Thompson has sold for the Nich-olas Low estate to Mandelbaum Levine, for $65,000, the plot of land, with old three story buildings, at the nOrthwest corner of West Houston and Hancock Streets, (formerly Cottage Place,) 114.6 on Houston by 100 on Hancock Street. It is reported that several modern tenement buildings will be erected on the property.

The speckled hen that roosted on Vanderbilt's mansion Tuesday afternoon at the corner of Fifty-first Street and Fifth Avenue, and which gave Policeman George J. Kettler so much trouble, made a bold break for liberty yesterday afternoon and came near succeeding. The speckled hen ever since its capture on Tuesday afternoon had been in a cell in the East Fifty-first Street Station.

HAVERSTRAW, Sept. 23. -- Truman Mathers, aged about twenty-one years, lost his watch and other valuables, including about $50 in money, and had a narrow escape from death as the result of a visit of horse thieves last night to his home near Mount Ivy, a small station on the New Jersey and New York Road about four miles west of this place.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 23. -- President Jacob G. Schurman of Cornell University this afternoon delivered his annual address to the students in Armory Hall, which was overcrowded. He commented upon the results of last June's boat races at Poughkeepsie. He said he had heard it from all quarters that, while Cornell won, she maintained her victories with dignity and honor.

The Executive Committee of the Citizens' Union met last night at 8 o'clock at 39 East Twenty-third Street and discussed minor nominations and the adoption of an emblem. No emblem was selected. Two have been suggested to the committee -- the Brooklyn Bridge and the Statue of Liberty.

Ex-Secretary of the Navy Benjamin F. Tracy is the successor of District Attorney W.M.K. Olcott as the Republican favorite for Mayor of Greater New York. At his own request and to meet, it was said, the exigencies of a situation changed by Seth Low's declaration that he will not withdraw, Gen. Tracy will be asked to accept the Republican nomination.

DENVER, Sept. 23. -- James H. Eckels, Controller of the Currency, arrived here yesterday on his way to Washington, and to-night was the guest of the Denver Clearing House at a banquet at the Brown Palace Hotel. All of the leading bankers and commercial men of the city were present, covers being laid for 200. After being introduced by Platt Rogers, the toastmaster, Mr. Eckels said:

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Sept. 24. -- President McKinley and the party accompanying him on his visit to this State arrived here at 1:15 o'clock this afternoon. There was an immense crowd about the station to meet them, and cheer after cheer was given for the President and Mrs. McKinley when they appeared upon the platform.

Mrs. Humphry Ward is writing a new novel, and for this purpose has rented the country house where the action of the story takes place. We can picture her peopling the rooms with her fancy's creations, can see her watching Marcella -- or Marcella's successor -- passing through the dimly lighted halls, delving in the great library, or from an oriel window viewing the landscape dotted with the happy homes of independent

The New York and New Jersey Telephone Company has nearly completed experiments with a new system of making connections between central offices. The experiments are said to have been successful, and the new device, it is expected, will be in operation at all the down-town branch exchanges before Oct. 15.

PARIS, Sept. 6. -- A conversation between Alphonse Daudet and his son Leon on the subject of imagination cannot fail to interest all who have appreciated the brilliant work of both these writers. Of the two I should be disposed to think that the elder Daudet has a greater power of distinct imagination, combined with extraordinary genius of observation.

Elsewhere in to-day's issue of THE REVIEW OF BOOKS AND ART is printed a list of 200 books recommended to the schools of Iowa by the State Superintendent of Public Instruction. In Iowa has probably been given greater attention to village and school libraries than in any other of the Western States.

Arabella Stuart, child of Charles Stuart, (Earl of Lennex, Darnley's brother, and uncle of James I.,) and her sad story furnish one of this tragic themes in English history. As a close relative of Elizabeth, Arabella's existence was always an obstacle in the Queen's way. There was a plan to marry Arabella to a Lord Esme Stuart, which Elizabeth would not allow.
SARATOGA, Sept. 24. -- Lord and Lady Kelvin of England were last night the guests of Mr. and Mrs. Spencer Trask of New York City at Yaddo, their Saratoga country seat on Union Avenue.
COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- At the Otsego County Republican Convention, this afternoon, Leland M. Cowles of Unadilla was nominated for member of Assembly.

Commissioner Collis stopped the work of street-railway construction in Columbus Avenue, between Fifty-ninth and Sixty-fifth Streets, yesterday. The first thing Gen. Collis did upon reaching his office was to call up John D. Crimmins on the telephone. Mr. Crimmins is the controlling spirit of the firm that has the contract for relaying the tracks of certain lines of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company.

Republican conventions were held last night in the thirty-five Assembly districts to elect delegates to the City and County Conventions and District Campaign Committees. There were no contests that caused the organization leaders any uneasiness, and 191 machine delegates to the City Convention and 430 delegates to the County Convention were elected.
Gen. Benjamin F. Tracy is in the hands of his friends. If they shall see fit to nominate him for Mayor of Greater New York he will not decline the honor.

How to provide accommodation for the 6,000 children who are unable to find room in the schools near their homes is the problem that is worrying City Superintendent Jasper and the Board of Superintendents. There is plenty of room in the schools for all the children of the city, but the children are not evenly divided, and in some districts the schools are overcrowded, while in others they are comparatively empty.
In the October number of Harper's Magazine appears Capt. A.T. Mahan's "The Strategic Features of the Gulf of Mexico and the Caribbean Sea."

The author of that excellent and in some ways remarkable book, "Oliver Cromwell, A History," published some three years ago, Mr. Samuel Harden Church, has again delved in that comparatively neglected field by writers of historical fiction, the times of Cromwell, for his last work -- " John Marmaduke, a Romance of the English Invasion of Ireland in 1649."

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 24. -- The yellow fever situation in this city assumed a serious aspect to-day. There was an increase in the number of fatalities, and for a time early this morning a portion of the city was under the control of a mob of panic-stricken citizens.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 24. -- Lieut. R.E. Peary, the arctic explorer, arrived in this city last night. Speaking to-day concerning his late expedition and his plans for next year, Lieut. Peary said:

LENOX, Sept. 24. -- The best golf ever played on the Lenox links was seen to-day in the match between A.H. Fenn and W. Bayard Cutting, Jr., who played the finals in the contest for the five-hundred-dollar Lenox Cup. The same players were pitted against each other last year, when Fenn won the cup for the first time.

PORT TOWNSEND, Washington, Sept. 24. -- The tug Pioneer, which left Puget Sound on Sept. 12, with the bark Shirley in tow, for Skaguay, returned at 1 o'clock this morning, having made the run down in ninety-six hours. The Pioneer brings a report of a landslide which occurred near Sheep Camp, on the Chilkoot Pass, last Sunday morning, in which eighteen men are said to have lost their lives.

SARATOGA, Sept. 24. -- It was announced to-day that there would be a hearing before the Appallate Division Sept. 30 on the Attorney General's appeal from the order of Justice Chester vacating his previous order directing the Presidents of certain coal railroads to appear before a referee to answer questions concerning an alleged combination in violation of the anti-trust law.

In behalf of American art education a card of questions was published under the general heads of "Form" and "Art," among which the following heads were not the least important: "What is Form-Construction? Its Elements and Processes are What? What is Beauty, and What are the Laws of the Beautiful?"

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- The Monetary Commission resumed its sessions here today. When the commission resumes work next week, it is expected that there will be a full attendance of members, and such an advance made in preliminary arrangements that the sub-committees can be announced and their work begun.

The logic of Gen. TRACY'S telegram to QUIGG is even worse than its politics. "If in the grave crisis which now confronts all friends of good government in Greater New York," he says, "it is necessary in the judgment of the Republican Convention to nominate me for the Mayoralty I shall not resist the judgment of the convention."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- Commissioner Forman of the Internal Revenue Bureau to-day gave a hearing to counsel for the United States Brewers' Association in opposition to the collection of the seven-and-one-half-cent rebate on beer stamps sold after midnight Friday, July 23, 1897, the time, as held by the Secretary of the Treasury, when the new tariff act went into effect.

LONDON, Sept. 24. -- Lord Farrer has a three-column letter in The Times this morning on bimetallism and the Indian mints. He says: "In my opinion the ultimate solution of the question will be found in the adoption of the gold standard in India."

The Brooklyn Democratic leaders are up in arms over the announcement by John C. Sheehan that Tammany will demand for the Borough of Manhattan the right to name both the Mayor and Controller of the Greater New York. Yesterday they openly threatened revolt and said that if Tammany wants the whole ticket it will have to elect it without the assistance of Brooklyn Democrats.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 24. -- W.S. Fielding, Canadian Minister of Finance, left to-day for England to float a $10,000,000 loan. Five millions of this amount will go to the payment of the Crow's Nest Pass Railway and the deepening of the Canadian canals.

CITY OF MEXICO, Sept. 24. -- Ex-Inspector General of Police Eduardo Velasquez today committed suicide in Belem Prison, where he was confined on a charge, to which he had pleaded guilty, that he caused the death of Arroyo, the man who attempted to kill President Diaz.

HAZLETON, Penn., Sept. 24. -- It was the intention of Gen. Gobin to-day to order the withdrawal of part of the militia, but the rain interfered. Battery C of the artillery broke camp to-day and returned to Phoenixville, and to-morrow, weather permitting, the Twelfth and Thirteenth Regiments will leave.

Matthaus Bantel obtained a peremptory writ of mandamus against Charles H. Morgan and others, Election Inspectors, directing them to count for the relator certain votes for the office of Trustee of the village of New Rochelle on two ballots which were voted at the village election last Spring. The order was affirmed by the Second Appellate Division as to one ballot and reversed so far as it applied to the other.

Complaint will be made this week to the Grand Jury that the Tax Commissioners and Deputy Tax Commissioners of this city have committed a crime in assessing far below its actual value the real estate of certain corporations. The complainant is the Central Labor Union, and it alleges, it is said, that the tax officials have been guilty of perjury in willfully and knowingly making false returns.

Here's food for mirth! Gen. E.C. O'BRIEN, LL. D. and President of the Department of Docks puts Controller FITCH on a superheated gridiron before the Citizens' Union and publicly broils him to a cinder. You must not put this man on your ticket, says the General, LL. D. He is full of "pure cussedness."

Mrs. Sarah Hatfield, wife of Owen R. Hatfield of 921 Park Avenue, Hoboken, died on Thursday night of consumption. Mrs. Hatfield became ill three years ago. Several physicians who were called were greatly puzzled by the case. They agreed that the disease was consumption, but there were features for which they could not account.

ALTON, Ill., Sept. 24. -- In response to an appeal from the colored citizens of this place, Gen. John M. Palmer has accepted a call to assist the City Attorney in the fight with the local School Board for equal school privileges with white pupils.

READING, Penn., Sept. 24. -- The "Schwenkfelders," a religious sect found only in Eastern Pennsylvania, celebrated its one hundred and sixty-third anniversary of the arrival of their ancestors in this country yesterday at their meeting house in Clayton, Washington Township, Berks County, Penn.

" If the facts do not agree with the theory," said a student in presenting his belief, "so much the worse for the facts," thus proving himself a consistent and loyal logician, charmingly frank. If Prof. Brander Matthews and Mr. Howells would not so persistently overlook the fact of Scott's popularity, their interesting theory might be heard with greater forbearance; or, if they would boldly come out with a positive declaration.

LENOX, Sept. 24. -- President McKinley, with his wife and other members of the party who for the last four days have been visiting in Adams, arrived here at 2 o'clock this afternoon. They are the guests here of John Sloane, who met them at Pittsfield with carriages and conducted them thence across country to his magnificent residence in Lenox.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Sept. 24. -- Exciting contests amid varying conditions of weather marked the third day's play in the Tuxedo Golf Club open tournament to-day. This was an important day, for it determined the winners of the three handsome trophies that the golfers have been fighting for on the links since Wednesday.

The Executive Committee of the Citizens' Union met at 32 Nassau Street yesterday afternoon. The following members were present: J. Kennedy Tod, John C. Clark, James B. Reynolds, Edward A. Drake, Henry R. Kunhardt, John Claflin, James Loeb, George Tombleson, John Frankenheimer, Charles C. Nadal, John B. Pine, James W. Pryor, Richard Watson Gilder, Thomas Clegg, Charles T. Barney, and W. Harris Roome.

The annual convention of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York will begin in the Church of the Incarnation, Madison Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street, next Wednesday morning, Bishop Potter presiding. The convention sermon will be preached at 10 A.M. by Canon Gore of Westminster, London, at the invitation of the Bishop.

BOSTON, Sept. 23. -- "All indications point to a heavy output of books this Winter," remarked a veteran book reviewer this week, and the activity already to be observed among the publishers certainly seems to support his prophecy. The separate houses have out their earliest announcements, and among them are books by several favorite authors.

John N. Golding has sold for Mrs. Helen N. Knickerbocker to B. Winthrop and J.J. Wysong, on private terms, the vacant plot on Fifth Avenue, 30 feet north of Sixty-fourth Street, 70 by 110. The property adjoins the 65-foot plot on Sixty-fourth Street which Mrs. Knickerbocker recently sold to Orme Wilson for the site of his new residence.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 24. -- Martin Collins of this city was brought to Syracuse to-day with a bullet in his thigh.
Love and lucre mingle strangely in a civil action brought by Lena Weinstein against Leib Goldforb to recover $500. The case was heard by Judge Freedman, in the Supreme Court, yesterday.

BERLIN, Sept. 24. -- The eleventh round of the international chess tournament was begun in this city at the Architekten Haus, 92 and 93 Wilhelmstrasse, this morning, when Round 7 of the Berger schedule was adopted for the pairing, which was as follows:
Will you please tell me who was Beckford and what was the book he wrote called 'Vathek'? I am unable to find the book in the stores where I usually purchase books. It seems to be out of print.

In Godey's Magazine for September Mr. V. Robard writes an appreciative notice of Mr. T.S. Sullivant's work as a caricaturist. It is as an artist in Life that Mr. Sullivant's sketches have been mainly observed. The talent of the man is unquestionable. With an even broader scope than Tenniel, Mr. Sullivant is the Englishman's rival.

Mayor Patrick J. Gleason was standing in front of his office, in Long Island City, yesterday, when David Horn of the Steinway section, who is one of those whose water supply was practically cut off when the Mayor ordered Pumping Station No. 2 closed, approached. He demanded to know why his water taxes were so high while he received no return for them.

Commissioner Parker of the Police Board differs from Attorney General Hancock as to the liability of a nominee to the office of Chief of Police to examination under the civil service provisions of the Constitution and statutes. These declare that all promotions shall be made by seniority, merit, and fitness, after competitive examination, except where examinations are not practicable.

The furious campaign already instigated, though not avowedly carried on by Senator PLATT, is a campaign against a single candidate. Mr. LOW is the only candidate in the field. He is also the only candidate who has any chance of beating Tammany. To strengthen him is to weaken Tammany.

A gas main in the sub-sidewalk cellar of 203 West Twenty-third Street, broke suddenly yesterday afternoon, and the escaping gas overcame Jacob Winters, who was at work in the place. He became unconscious and died, before the arrival of an ambulance, which had been summoned.

Under favorable weather conditions, cyclists who have followed racing this year expect to see world's records lowered to-day in the great thirty-three mile match paced race between Jimmy Michael and Lucien Lesna at Manhattan Beach. Both men are confident of victory and claim to be in the pink of condition.

SCHENECTADY, Sept. 24. -- The Rev. Dr. E.N. Potter, who was in this city to-day, said that he had accepted the Presidency of the Cosmopolitan Educational University Extension. Dr. Potter has begun his new work, and will shortly take up his residence in Irvington-on-the-Hudson, which will be the headquarters of the institution.

Orders have been received by Admiral Sicard, commanding the North Atlantic squadron, to have the vessels of the fleet assemble as quickly as the repairs to the vessels now at the Brooklyn Navy Yard will permit. The Navy Yard is crowded with vessels waiting for or undergoing repairs. There is no more mooring space along the docks for the other ships of the fleet which are coming to this station for repairs.

Some little time ago Mr. Henry Cabot Lodge published a paper entitled "Certain Accepted Heroes," and it now gives its name to a volume of pleasant historical essays, of which it stands first. It is, briefly summarized, a criticism of the Greek heroes of Homer and a comparison of their alleged valor with the bravery of the Nibelungs and of the North American Indians, and it leaves none of them either courageous or civilized.

Ludwig Lehman of 18 St. Mark's Place mounted his bicycle last night and started to visit his sweetheart, at 38 West Sixty-first Street. Turning into Sixtieth Street from the Boulevard Lehman ran into a bicycle ridden by Lawyer Eugene Frayer of 333 West One Hundred and Fourth Street.

SEATTLE, Washington, Sept. 24. -- Soldiers and civilians mingled together in a busy crowd on the dock where preparations were being made for the sailing of the steamer Humboldt for St. Michael, Alaska. The Humboldt started on her journey at 8 o'clock last night. Lieut. Col. Randall, with his twenty-five men from Fort Russell, looked fit to cope with the rigors and hardships of the Winter confronting them in the Yukon.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 24. -- The final fifteen minutes' play to-day in the international cricket match between the Philadelphia and English teams was sensational in the extreme, the four batsmen for the Englishmen being retired without scoring a run. This is the first of two three-day matches to be played between a picked team of Philadelphians and Capt. Warner's team of amateurs.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 24. -- Magnificent fielding on the part of the Bostons, weak batting by the Orioles at critical moments, tell the whole story of the champions' downfall to-day. It was truly a battle of giants, and the "rooters" of Baltimore, usually so unresponsive to the exigencies of a baseball situation, turned out by droves to see the crack teams contest.

That is an interesting and suggestive announcement which has been made by cable, and repeated in our columns this morning, that The London Times and Messrs. HARPER BROTHERS are concerned in the preparation of a weekly review of which the subject matter is sufficiently indicated by its name, "Literature."

LENOX, Mass., Sept. 25. -- The play to-day in the semi-finals for the President's Cup, offered by W.D. Sloane, was made very exciting by the defeat of A.H. Fenn, the crack Palmetto Club man, by S.D. Bowers of St. Andrew's. The grounds were wet from the rain of yesterday. It was not until the second tour of the course was made that Fenn seemed to lose his nerve.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- An interesting ceremony occurred at the Chilean Legation at 3 o'clock this afternoon, when for the first time treaty relations were established between Chile and Japan. Minister Gana of Chile acted as the plenipotentiary in behalf of his country and Minister Hoshi acted for Japan.

Consul General McIvor, at Kanagawa, Japan, has reported about the increase in the natural production of kerosene oil in Japan. He quotes from a recent issue of the Chugai Shogyo, a Japanese periodical, as follows:

IT was a pretty occasion that took the young Queen of Holland to Dordrecht for the first time. The "Teutoonstelling" -- a small World's Fair -- has been on since June, and on Wednesday, Aug. 25, its attractions reached their height, as it had been announced that the two Queens, Emma the Regent and Wilhelmina the prospective, with the Hofdames and Herren, would honor the exhibition by a visit.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25. -- The resignation of James Butcher as Collector of Internal Revenue for the First District of New Jersey has been received at the Treasury Department.

Some important and influential additions to the active membership of the Merchants' Association were made yesterday, including the First National Bank of this city, the old firm of Phelps. Dodge Co., Cyrus J. Lawrence of the New York Stock Exchange, Brown Seccomb, Martin Rothbarth Co., Campbell Thayer, and H.S. Hall. There are now nearly 1,000 resident members of the association.

READING, Penn., Sept. 24. -- Mrs. Catharine McLaughlin, who lives with her daughters at Waterbury, Conn., is said to be 109 years of age. She arrived yesterday at Gerardville, Penn., to visit her son, Justice of the Peace John McLaughlin.

AMSTERDAM, Sept. 14. -- The extensive gulf formed by the North Sea, between Northern Holland and Friesland, and which the Dutch call Zuyder Zee, is relatively of recent origin. At the beginning of the Christian era the two provinces now separated by the Zuyder Zee formed a continuous stretch of land.
Bertha Margaret Spahn, in the Report of the New York Institution for the Instruction of the Deaf and Dumb, says:

Throughout the week security markets have been under pressure. On some days this pressure had aggressive manipulation identified with it. At no time has there seemed to be any organized or pronounced effort upon the part of the market's strongest friends to repel the attacks of the bear speculative contingent.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24. -- President McKinley has not lost his roving disposition by coming to the White House. As President, he is showing himself to be as great a traveler as he was when Governor of Ohio. During his four years in the Gubernatorial office he journeyed some 50,000 miles, and was out of the State more than half the time. He bids fair to eclipse that record as President.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Sept. 25. -- An Innovation that promises to develop into a permanent custom is that of holding street fairs in country towns throughout the Northwest. These have already been tried in many sections of Minnesota and the Dakotas with such satisfactory results that they promise to supersede the old-fashioned county fair, with its horse races, "fake" shows, and swindles.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25. -- The financial report of Receiver McNulta of the Whisky Trust was referred to-day by Judge Showalter of the Federal court to Special Master in Chancery Patton for confirmation. This practically ends the receivership. The report covers the entire transactions of the receivership from Jan. 28, 1895, when the bill was filed in court, to June 30 of this year.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 25. -- The Yukon expedition left at 2 o'clock to-day, with Clifford Sifton, the Minister of the Interior, at its head. Major Walsh, who is traveling a couple of days ahead, was at Port Arthur yesterday, where he engaged some experienced boatmen. He has other business to attend to at Winnipeg, and will await the expedition there.

Arrangements for an uncommonly active and varied Fall and Winter campaign have been completed by the management of the West Side Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association, in Fifty-seventh Street, near Eighth Avenue. William M. Kingsley is Chairman of this committee, and Dr. D.E. Yarnell is Secretary of the executive force.

Three years ago The Times drew attention to the subject of surcharged stamps in a lengthy article. Lord Ripon had caused a circular to be sent from the Colonial Office in order to put down the abuses connected with the sale of "surcharged stamps." which had proved a temptation to Postmasters and Treasurers and other public officers, by making irregular profits in dealing with stamp collectors and others.

The marine observers at Fire Island and Sandy Hook will be on the lookout to-day for the biggest steamship afloat. It is the North German Lloyd Company's new steamship, the Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse. She may arrive to-day, but it is thought, as this is her first trip, she may fall behind the time she is expected to make when her engines have become smooth. She is more likely to be reported to-morrow.

BOSTON, Sept. 25. -- The racing in the twenty-one-foot knockabout class has been by far the most interesting of any class in Boston waters this season. There have been seven new boats and one old boat, the Cock Robin, which have followed the schedule very closely, and the fleet has kept together, whether the racing was at Marblehead or in Boston.
