KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 25. -- It Is now about twenty years since much of the land in the Southern Catskills which had been denuded of its valuable bark properties and stripped of such timber as could be gotten out to market or for firewood to feed the insatiable maw of the brick yards along the river was, with its dense growth of underbrush and new forest added to the State Forestry Preserve.

Peter Beckman of Bucksport, Me., has invented a new kind of craft, in which he had a novel experience last week. The craft is built to roll on the water, and is similar to the boat being built by a Frenchman, who says it will revolutionize the marine world. This craft of Mr. Beckman's had made several excursions off the Maine coast, and had reached Bar Harbor.

The Washington Star prints as follows the summary of results given by Lieut. James A. Moss in his report to the Adjutant General concerning the bicycle trip of twenty-one men of the Twenty-fifth Infantry, commanded by himself, and accompanied by an Assistant Surgeon, from Fort Missoula, Mon., to St. Louis, Mo.

Consul Mantius, writing from Turin, says: "Prominent physicians and laymen are at present busily engaged in preparing an exhaustive report, with exhibits, on the subject, of 'Apparent Death and Premature Burial.' This report will be the striking feature of the medical department at the National Exposition to be opened here in April, 1898.

Since the very beginning of last Spring every newspaper cur in town, Jew and Gentile, has been barking and yelping at the heels of Thomas C. Platt. "Plattism!" "Bossism!" has been the continual, monotonous cry of the whole concert. The Low boomers have kept up the refrain, "Plattism!" "Bossism!"
CHICAGO, Sept. 25. -- All the grain markets suffered to-day as the result of heavy receipts and general neglect. Wheat declined 1 1/3@1 1/4 c, corn 1c, and oats 5/3@3/4c.

THE "atmosphere" of literature and art in "A Bachelor's Romance," reminds me of Tom Victims," old play called "The Victims," in which Owens used to act Joshua Butterby. Miss Morton imitates life in this play with much the same measure of facility as she employed in "Brother John."

THE recent announcement that the Rev. Dr. George H. Houghton has concluded to shift the heavier routine duties of the rectorship of the Church of the Transfiguration upon the younger shoulders of his nephew, the Rev. George C. Houghton, was in all likelihood read with interest by more people throughout the United States than the announcement of a change in any other church would be.

ADAMS, Mass., Sept. 25. -- President McKinley and party returned here on the 2:39 train this afternoon. They drove from Lenox to Stockbridge in carriages and came by train the remainder of the distance. The party, on arriving here, went at once to the house of W.B. Plunkett. At 4 o'clock the President laid the cornerstone of the new Memorial Library Building.

Purely as a concession to public opinion, the bull interests consented to sell some stocks the past week. It was obviously necessary to meet the increasing pressure of conservative public opinion that a reaction in the market was at this time a proper thing to have. The only way to satisfy this demand was to sell stocks, and they were sold.

The new St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church, at Eighty-sixth Street and West End Avenue, the Rev. George P. Eckman, pastor, will be formally opened on Sunday, Oct. 3. The dedication services will continue throughout the week, and include Sunday, Oct. 10. On the morning of Oct. 3 there will be a sermon by Bishop Foss, followed immediately by the dedicatorial service, conducted by Bishop Foss, assisted by Bishop Foster.

LIBERTAD, San Salvador, Sept. 24. -- Barrios shot Juan Aparacio in Quezaltenango on the day that the revolutionists took San Marcos. A telegram received to-day by one of the leading merchants of this city gives the news that Morales and his 12,000 or 15,000 victorious troops are in Antigua.

Get up at 5 A.M. and go with Mr. Brodie to see the Green-market at Covent Garden. This an unusual and very astonishing scene; perhaps the first green-market of any in the world; and three times crowded every week, Saturday being the principal day.

This is a true burglar story. It was told, in the first place, by the mother of the family herself; it is now told by her daughter, and it will probably be told in years to come by generations still unborn. As the veracity of every one concerned in it -- including that of the burglar himself, in his regenerate condition -- is quite unimpeachable, the facts can be vouched for.

The Republican slate for Greater New York has been completed. It is subject to campaign contingencies and possible changes, but the leaders yesterday gave out with virtually the weight of an official announcement that they had agreed upon these nominations to be made by the City Convention:

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 25. -- The Cincinnatis were victorious in both games to-day, the Browns not being dangerous at any stage. Breitenstein pitched the first game for the Reds, and kept the home team's hits well scattered. The Reds batted our victory In the ninth inning. Only five innings were played in the second game. Scores:
LONDON, Sept. 25. -- The Spectator, accepting as a fact the report that the United States has admonished Spain, finds it difficult to think war can be avoided, adding:

LONDON, Sept. 25. -- One may doubt very much if history will confirm the title of Wilhelm der Sieger which the loyal portion of the Berlin press is conferring upon the young Emperor, and yet one feels compelled to admit that circumstances give some sort of a warrant for its use.

COLUMBIA, Mo., Sept. 25. -- The first legal bout between the heirs of the estate of John C. Conley of Boone County, and the curators of Missouri University, has closed in favor of the university. Judge Hutzler of the County Probate Court has decided to assess the estate to the amount of $25,000, the money to go to the university.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25. -- R. E. Fishburn of the Chicago Athletic Association, Vice President of the Amateur Union, yesterday declared that Caspar Whitney's attempt to establish professionalism against B. J. Wefers, the great sprinter, will prove a failure.

Maude Adams will make her debut as a star actress at the Empire Theatre to-morrow night. The medium of her appearance will be a comedy in four acts, by James M. Barrie, treating, in a vein of romance mingled with humor, of rural life in Scotland, and called "The Little Minister." This play is, obviously, founded on Mr. Barrie's novel of the same title.
NEW ORLEANS, La., Sept. 25. -- The Harrison Line steamer Craftsman has arrived here, with two passengers, which they picked up from the bark May Flint.

L.C. Farwell of Chicago is, with his wife, making a tour of the West for pleasure. Mr. Farwell is a young man, and, as this is his first trip to the West, he was anxious to take back with him some of the peculiar products of Western civilization in the shape of curios, mineral specimens,

Cuba, though narrow, is over six hundred miles long from Cape San Antonio to Cape Maysi. It is, in short, not so much in island as it is a continent, susceptible under proper development of great resources -- of self-sufficingness. In area it is half as large again as Ireland, but, owing to its peculiar form, is much more than twice as long.

The correspondence in your columns between Gen. Piper and "Concessionist" is certainly interesting, but Mr. Piper appears to have the best of the argument so far. Mr. Piper says truly that the sound-money newspapers are at sea on the sound-money question and do not elucidate the points at issue as well as they ought between gold and silver.

Before the Engineers' Club of Philadelphia recently Charles F. Scott tried to find a homely illustration of what the 6,000,000 horse power that might be developed by Niagara Falls represented. He did it in this way: "Suppose pumps be placed below the falls for pumping the water up again to its former level.

Where do they stand now, the two hundred and fifty gallant gentlemen and lion-hearted reformers who signed the pledge of the Citizens' Union last February and accepted places on its Committee of Organization? They stepped forth to do battle for non-partisan city government. Did they enlist for six months? Or during the war?

TRENTON, Sept. 25. -- It is expected the anti-gambling amendment to the Constitution, which will be voted on next Tuesday in this State, will be adopted. The amendment has been indorsed by the Citizens' League of New Jersey, which practically means the clergy and the laymen, the Republican and Prohibition Parties, the Christian Endeavor and Epworth League, and Good Citizen organizations in the various parts of the State.

ALTHOUGH the officially inspired organs of Vienna and Budapest have denied the reported marriage of Archduke Francis Ferdinand, heir presumptive to the Austro-Hungarian throne, to a housekeeper of Herr Krupp, the famous iron manufacturer and cannon founder of Essen, Germany, the news has created a profound sensation at the Austrian Court.

The German press in general is now discussing a paper read by Dr. Mendelssohn at a meeting of the medical society, in Berlin, on the medical view of bicycle riding. Consul Keenan, at Bremen, in a report has given the chief points of the paper, which are:

NEWPORT, Sept. 25, -- 2k great change has come over Newport in the last week, the cold weather driving many of the cottagers to the cities, and the Avenue and city have been practically deserted. There has been hardly a pleasant day all week. Chauncey M. Depew, who, with his son and niece, has been spending the season at the Pinard Cottage, will leave here for the city to-day.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25. -- Alderman Mangler furnished the sensation of the week by voluntarily appearing before the Grand Jury and telling all about the alleged attempt to secure his vote by bribery in the interests of the General Electric Street Railway. Having thus purged himself of contempt of court, the sentence to a fine of $1,000 and imprisonment for ninety days will not be enforced.

GREENPORT, L.I., Sept. 25. -- Mrs. Jane Clark, seventy years old, who lived alone for many years at First and Broad Streets, was last night found dead in bed. She had not been seen by her neighbors for two days, so a number of citizens forced the door. A verdict of death from heart disease was rendered by the Coroner's jury.

Conventions in the twenty-one Republican Assembly districts of Brooklyn to send delegates to the City and Judiciary Conventions were held last night. In the City Convention there were four or five contests which must be straightened out by the Contest Committee of the City Convention.
ISLIP, L.I., Sept. 25. -- Carl S. Burr, Jr., Assemblyman from the Second District of Suffolk County, was renominated by the Republican Convention here to-day.

The question of non-commissioned officers is in itself a serious one, as the French have long recognized. So apparently distasteful is the military life to the average Frenchman, that when his short period of service is over, he can with the greatest difficulty be induced to re-engage to complete a longer period as a "sous-officer."

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 25. -- The State Board of Claims to-day awarded John Roberts of Brooklyn $7,500 in his action for damages against the State for false imprisonment, in which he made a claim for $168,976, including costs and expenses.

For exhibition at the Congress of Orientalists, it is said that the French Minister of Public Instruction offered the Sultan 3,000 for the loan of the Koran of Haroun-alRaschid, to parade at the reception and then to have it copied. He refused. This unique volume stands in the tombhouse of the Sultans at Constantinople at the foot of Mahmoud II.'s coffin.

BERLIN, Sept. 25. -- The reported American "ultimatum" to Spain has been received with pronounced displeasure by the entire German press. The official denial from Washington is generally disbelieved here, and the denunciation of "jingoism," "Yankee insolence," and the ridiculing of the Monroe doctrine have filled the newspapers.

PARIS, Sept. 14. -- The King of Siam is overjoyed with his visit to Paris. What pleased him most were the Eiffel Tower and the toys. When he arrived in his official carriage, with its cockaded coachmen, between the four colossal legs of iron from which the giant tower rises to strike the sky, he gave vent to an exclamation of surprise and delight.

After seventeen years of existence, the League of American Wheelmen has passed the 100,000 mark in membership. This grand total more distinctly emphasizes the power and numerical strength of a body in which an organization of great comparative closeness and a general sympathy of interest among all its members, wherever located, has combined to accomplish more for wheelmen's rights than any aggregation of men of any nation.

As I have already explained, the Club of Ancients restricts its membership to men of mature middle age, and will have nobody on its rolls who has not forsworn the desire to obtain public office or any other kind of notoriety. It was the evident intention of the founders of the institution that it should be made the abode of peace, and that all evil passions should be excluded from it.
The Citizens' Union has finally completed its preparations for the nomination or indorsement of a full ticket, one that may be voted for by marking a cross in the circle under the party emblem.

Capt. A.T. MAHAN, the eminent authority on naval strategy, publishes in the October number of Harper's Magazine an article on "The Strategic Features of the Gulf of Mexico and the Caribbean Sea." The article possesses a timely significance which is not contained in its plain statements.

Probably the oldest railroad station agent in the country in point of service is James A. Gary, Postmaster General of the United States. He was appointed agent at Alberton, Howard County. Md. on the Baltimore and Ohio Road forty-four years ago, and his name still appears on the pay rolls of the company.

LONDON, Sept. 25. -- The average Britisher has come to the conclusion that he is the arbitrator of the fate of Europe and holds the balance of power. It must be confessed that the changed tone of the Continental politicians and newspaper writers, from abuses to caresses, encourages this assumption.

AN industrial colony has been in active progress at Gardiner, N.Y., since July 1. Its managers strive by every possible means to make those in their care understand the principles of the Republic under which they live, the ultimate purpose being to develop honorable and serviceable citizens.

DENVER, Col., Sept. 25. -- The Union Pacific, Denver and Gulf Railway will Jan. 1 next take its place among Colorado lines as an independent system. The Reorganization Committee has called upon the holders of securities of the Gulf and kindred interests to deposit their securities with the Central Trust Company of New York.
As a further claim to the right of annexation, Hawaiians put in as an exhibit their ability to coin such a word as Klondikitis as an appropriate name for the prevalent gold fever.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25. -- R.W. Petty, Western representative of a wholesale drug firm of New York, has disappeared from the Edinburgh Hotel, Twenty-second Street and Michigan Avenue. The matter is a mystery, and the police at detective headquarters are working on the theory that Petty has been murdered for his money and jewelry.

Coincident with the many improvements that are making at the navy yard in Brooklyn, one of its old landmarks is undergoing destruction. This is the storehouse at the foot of Main Street, near the coal wharf. The building is one of the oldest in the yard, having been erected seventy-five years ago. It was three stories high and of brick.

The Brooklyn Democratic leaders were angry yesterday over the determination of Tammany to seize both the Mayoralty and Controllership nominations. The talk of bolting was more in the air than ever, but none of the principal leaders had anything to say on the subject. All the bolting talk emanated from the small fry, who, however, usually reflect what they believe to be the views of the leaders.

Larchmont yachtsmen may have a big bonfire any night now. Ex-Commodore H.M. Gillig's sloop Veneedor was beaten so badly by the Syce in the match race yesterday that they expect that her owner will take this easy method of getting rid of the boat. The Veneedor was also beaten by the Acushia, Anoatok, and Vorant.

" In 1867 Miss G., aged eighteen, died suddenly of cholera in St. Louis. In 1876 a brother, F.G., who was much attached to her, had done a good day's business in St. Joseph. He was sending in his orders to his employers (he is a commercial traveler,) and was smoking a cigar, when he became conscious that some one was sitting on his left with one arm on the table.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Sept. 25. -- A glorious day marked the close of the four-day Tuxedo Golf Club tournament to-day, and a small army of golfers took advantage of the sunshine and invigorating atmosphere to enter the big open handicap event. The prize was a cup in the shape of a horn, silver mounted, one of the prettiest trophies offered at a golf event this season.

Major Lane Is one of the jokers of the Louisville (Ky.) bar, and his fondness for humor will occasionally crop out in the courts. A couple of weeks ago he was intrusted with the defense of one Edward Quinlan, who had been sued for $10,000 damages by a lad named Allen. The boy had fallen into a cistern on Quinlan's property and claimed negligence on the part of the owner of the cistern.

A recent explorer in a part of Alaska as far removed from the newlydiscovered Klondike region as Washington is from Boston has said "That country is onehalf made; the glaciers are slowly doing their work, the mountains are smoking, and the rivers are vomiting out quantities of quicksand." What is true of the Cook's Inlet country of Southern Alaska is also true, in a measure, of the valley of the Yukon.

ASTORIA, Ore., Sept. 25. -- The steamer Elder has arrived from Skaguay and Dyea, bringing twenty-three passengers. Thick weather delayed the steamer, and she had to put into Namado for coal; otherwise the passage was uneventful.

PARIS, Sept. 17. -- Major Moses P. Handy, the Special Commissioner from the United States for the Exhibition of 1900, has lost no time in beginning work, although he has been in Paris only a few days. Major Handy is assisted by Lieut. Baker, who was connected with the Chicago Exhibition as Assistant Chief of the Foreign Transportation of Exhibits, and by Col. Chaillet-Lory, who is Secretary of the Special Commission.

VIENNA, Sept. 25. -- A pistol duel was fought this morning between Count Badeni, the Austrian Premier, and Dr. Wolff, the German Nationalist leader, arising from insults addressed by the latter to the Premier during yesterday's session of the Unterhaus. Count Badeni was wounded in the right hand.

" I cannot promise to conform to your ways, nor to bend to your wishes, though I will try to do so. I cannot promise to assume cordial relations with your relatives, nor accept your friendships as binding upon me. I cannot promise to be faithful to you until death, but I shall be faithful so long as I fill the relation of husband to you.

The storm wind of the equinox descended on the Atlantic and its western shores the past week and vexed the beaches and the hills with winds and rain. The storm beat upon the late loiterers at Southampton, Newport, and far-away Bar Harbor and housed all but the golf players at Lenox, Tuxedo, and Virginia Hot Springs, and other far and near Autumn resorts.
LONDON, Sept. 25. -- Theatrically the week has been dull.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 25. -- Owen McGarr, United States Consul at Cienfuegos, Cuba, has arrived here, having left Cuba Aug. 28. As to the condition of affairs on the island, the Consul does not agree with the Cuban Junta in New York, but confirms Gen. Weyler's utterances in so far as his experiences have gone.

The writer once knew a collier named the Rye Merchant, built at the Port of the Rye in the year of Waterloo. Her burden was eighty tons, and her rig was that of a snow, though she was subsequently converted into a schooner. This venerable vessel was reputed to have been ashore upon every shoal and sand off the coast of Britain between the North Foreland and the Tyne.

Of all the strange crimes and people the New York police have had to deal with, the most fantastic intellectual and moral distortion they have ever encountered is that of John H. Staats, assistant manager of the Hotel Waldorf who is now in Jefferson Market Prison awaiting trial for theft.
The steel rail and car manufacturers of the United States have had their attention called to projected railways in the Malay Peninsula. Consul General Pratt at Singapore has reported:

ALBANY, Sept. 25. -- Charles H. Peck, the State botanist, who puts in from ten to fourteen hours a day in his dingy room under the eaves of the Capitol, says vegetation has been exceptionally healthy the past season, with the exception of potatoes, which were rotted by too frequent rains, and apples, the scarcity of which is caused by the "off year" and some climatic influences.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 25. -- James K. Jones, Chairman of the National Democratic Committee, in reply to a communication from The Constitution asking a statement from him concerning the comments on his letter read before the recent meeting of the New York State Democratic Executive Committee, has telegraphed as follows:

It is perhaps in discipline more than in anything else that the Greek soldier is lacking. Even the Evzoni, however good at guerrilla warfare in the mountains, would probably feel this defect in a regular campaign. It is no uncommon thing to hear the word of command disputed or discussed on the parade ground or on the march; it probably would be the same on the battlefield.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25. -- The University of Pennsylvania and the Franklin and Marshall team of Lancaster, opened the football season on Franklin Field this afternoon, the Quakers winning the game by a score of 33 to 0.
A surgical operation has given Mrs. Sophie Golderer, forty years old, the wife of a machinist living at 28 Bartlett Street, Williamsburg, a new nose. The operation was performed in Bellevue Hospital.

All minors, male or female, attain their majority by marriage in Iowa, Texas, and Louisiana. In Nebraska, when a woman over sixteen years old is married her minority ends. In most of the States, however, children male or female, become of age at twenty-one, as provided by the common law of England.

HAVANA, via Key West, Fla., Sept. 25. -- Just as the American steamer Concho was leaving Havana harbor yesterday, the Police Inspector of Vessels, under orders from the Chief of Police of Havana, boarded the boat and placed under arrest a former insurgent Captain known by the names of Jacinto, Gonzalez, and Gutierrez, who recently surrendered to the Spanish authorities.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25. -- Adolph L. Luetgert, the alleged wife murderer, suffered so much pain from the injury to his right leg this morning that a masseur was called in to give treatment. When court opened he hobbled in, with the aid of his crutch, in much better humor than he had shown during the early morning hours.

It is perhaps in discipline more than in anything else that the Greek soldier is lacking. Even the Evzoni, however good at guerrilla warfare in the mountains, would probably feel this defect in a regular campaign. It is no uncommon thing to hear the word of command disputed or discussed on the parade ground or on the march; it probably would be the same on the battlefield.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 25. -- The University of Pennsylvania and the Franklin and Marshall team of Lancaster, opened the football season on Franklin Field this afternoon, the Quakers winning the game by a score of 33 to 0.

The taxes which now press with such grinding severity on every class in Italy do not spare the poverty on every class in Italy do not spare the poverty-stricken peasant. Rural Italy pays 300,000,000 lire, out of returns not exceeding 1,000,000,000. An interesting estimate has been made of the degree to which taxation affects such a budget as Luigi Poletti's.

Interest especially centres in stock market transactions wherein the Vanderbilt name and the Vanderbilt influence are counted upon -- and there is growing importance in that connection, for Vanderbilt investments are developing in many new quarters. There is a larger Vanderbilt interest in both Western and Southern stocks than ever hitherto, and in some quarters this interest is being unexpectedly disclosed.

PORT TOWNSEND, Washington, Sept. 25. -- Charles Finn, assistant engineer of the tug Pioneer, which arrived from Alaska yesterday, confirms the report that eighteen persons were killed by a landslide on the Chillkoot Pass. Finn believes that one of the glaciers which are to be seen hanging along the mountain sides was washed out by the heavy rains, and that it came crashing down the hill.

The River Tees, seventy miles long, in the northern part of England, runs through towns with plenty of opportunity for contamination. There are hundreds of out- houses discharging into the river underneath, and during dry weather there is quite an accumulation of it running down through a number of towns.
An interview was published recently in a morning paper with Bourke Cockran, in which he was represented as being uncertain about the attitude that he would assume during the present campaign.

LONDON, Sept. 25. -- A decided sensation has been caused in diplomatic circles here by Great Britain's notification to the United States that she cannot participate in the sealing conference at Washington if Russia and Japan take part in it.

SALT-LADEN breezes, fresh from the restless ocean, continually blow through the open doors of Cedar Croft, the Summer home of Russell Sage, at Cedarhurst, on the southern shore of Long Island, and fill the airy abode of the veteran financier with briny fragrance.

Three thousand children helped Mayor Strong and the members of the Dock Board to open the new recreation pier, at the foot of East Twenty-fourth Street, yesterday afternoon. Although still in need of some finishing touches at the hands of the contractor, this great, double-decked pier was in gala attire, and presented an inviting appearance.

NEW BRUNSWICK, Sept. 21. -- Students at Rutgers College are enthusiastic over the movement now on foot to establish an intercollegiate bowling league. Rutgers for many years has been obliged to take a back seat in athletics, for she has been unable to bear the expense which the maintenance of a strong baseball or football team entails.

LONDON, Sept. 25. -- A decided sensation has been caused in diplomatic circles here by Great Britain's notification to the United States that she cannot participate in the sealing conference at Washington if Russia and Japan take part in it.

SALT-LADEN breezes, fresh from the restless ocean, continually blow through the open doors of Cedar Croft, the Summer home of Russell Sage, at Cedarhurst, on the southern shore of Long Island, and fill the airy abode of the veteran financier with briny fragrance.

Three thousand children helped Mayor Strong and the members of the Dock Board to open the new recreation pier, at the foot of East Twenty-fourth Street, yesterday afternoon. Although still in need of some finishing touches at the hands of the contractor, this great, double-decked pier was in gala attire, and presented an inviting appearance.
Oil wells in Canada are doing well, according to the report of Consul Dickson, who reports from Gaspa Basin, July 30, as follows:

NATCHEZ, Miss., Sept. 25. -- The New Orleans and Northwestern Railroad has restored its burned bridges, and is again carrying freight and mall, but no passengers. The Board of Health of this city has appointed Inspectors in the surrounding country, whose certificates of non-infection of cotton and drivers of wagons will gain them access to Natchez.

Judge WILLARD BARTLETT ought to be renominated for the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial District, and it would be of good example if his name should be placed upon the tickets of the two political parties and of the Citizens' Union. A good Judge should be kept upon the bench as long as he is able and willing to serve.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 25. -- Yale has begun her training for the annual football games, and, while there have been over thirty men at the Yale field during the past four or five days, undergoing the preliminary drilling in kicking and running with and falling on the ball, it is impossible to form any idea what kind of a team the raw material now on hand may develop into.

The nomination of Walter B. Atterbury to head the Republican ticket in Kings County recalls certain political combinations of the past. Mr. Atterbury was a member of the Executive Committee of the now defunct League of Loyal Citizens, which for a year and a half made one of the most remarkable political fights in the history of the State to defeat the Greater New York project.

Seth Low's friends in Brooklyn were not so jubilant yesterday as on Saturday night over the relative strength of their candidate in the Brooklyn delegation. The comparison of Low and anti-Low delegates revised yesterday by an intimate friend of Jacob Worth is as follows:

President Low should have consulted Mr. BOURKE COCKRAN before writing his letter of acceptance. The letter displeases Mr. COCKRAN not more by what it contains than by what it omits. In the opinion of this candid critic non-partisanship is a myth and civil service reform is a humbug.

Not since 1889 has the finish of the baseball season aroused so much enthusiasm as the present struggle for pennant honors between the Baltimores and Bostons. In 1889 the Bostons and New Yorks had a neck-and-neck finish, in which the Giants came out with flying colors, with only 11 points to spare, and, not unlike the present struggle, the decision rested with the final games.

The Executive Committee of the Citizens' Union has prepared a pamphlet on "Home Rule." It will be distributed as a campaign document. The information which it contains was compiled from the proceedings of the Constitutional Convention.

-- Two large consignments -- some 10,000 packages in all -- of American fruits of the distinctly perishable sort reached the London market in good condition last week, and were sold at auction at prices eminently satisfactory to the shippers. This marks the success, and on a large scale, of an enterprise that never would have, been undertaken by persons not possessed of much courage or carried through except by those with much persistence.

LONDON, Sept. 27. -- John Burns, Radical member of Parliament for Battersea, has a two-column letter in The Times this morning in reply to the statements of the American engineer, who a few days ago in the columns of The Times discussed with an English engineer the conditions of work in England and the United States.

Mr. W.L. Stow of the Stock Exchange is one of the confident believers in a continuation of the upward movement in stock market prices. Mr. Stow has been an enthusiastic bull throughout the present market improvement, but during the past week or two he has been rather inclined toward conservatism, believing that a reaction was due and bound to come.

More evidence of the bad weather at sea was brought to port yesterday by incoming vessels. Eight shipwrecked seamen were brought in by the four-masted schooner Goodwin Stoddard. Their vessel, the schooner Katie J. Irelan, was a victim of the gale which swept the Southern coast last week.

The Law and Legislative Committee of the Central Labor Union reported yesterday to that body what progress it had made in securing evidence against corporations, which, it said, had sworn away the taxes on their property. This committee consists of Delegates Daniel Harris, William J. O'Brien, John S. Henry, James O'Neill, and James Fitzgerald. Delegate Harris said the property owners were able to do this through the connivance of the Assessors.

The big steamer Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse has come up to the best expectations, and she finished her maiden trip last night a record-breaker. Over a 3,050-knot course she came from Southampton at an average hourly speed of 21.39 knots, and lowered the time between ports 1 hour and 46 minutes.

ADAMS, Mass., Sept. 26. -- President McKinley rested very quietly to-day at the Plunkett mansion, his only exertion out of doors being his attendance at the Congregational Church in the morning and a drive later in the day.

The returns of the Bureau of Statistics show a continuance of the rapid advance in domestic exports. The following are the figures for the eight months to Sept. 1 for the past three years, (000 omitted:)

Agents who sell clocks and other such articles on the installment plan had better keen away from the second floor of the rear tenement at 16 Spring Street, as they are liable to get hurt. Pietro Michele and his numerous progeny who live there have taken a solemn oath to throw any installment plan agent who may come there out of the window and to decorate his face besides.

The United German Societies, who were given the cold shoulder last week by Sheriff Tamsen because, he said, they were not a genuine political organization, inasmuch as they were not organized on the Assembly district association plan, held a large meeting yesterday afternoon at Teutonia Hall, Third Avenue, near Sixteenth Street, and unanimously decided to insist on the nomination of William Sohmer as the regular Democratic candidate for Mayor.

TACOMA, Sept. 26. -- Thousands of men who are unable to get home are now at Skaguay and Dyea, scattered along the trails. They cannot possibly get started for Klondike this season. Many of them have had all their provisions spoiled by storms, and most of these are now blockaded along the trial, where it is next to impossible to get out.

TRENTON, Sept. 26. -- All through New Jersey to-day the anti-race track amendment to the Constitution was the subject of discussion in the churches and in mass meetings held by persons and associations who desire that the amendment shall be adopted by a vote of the people Tuesday. The general expectation is that the amendment will prevail.

SEATTLE, Washington, Sept. 26. -- The first authentic news concerning Washington's new Eldorado near Mount Baker, and how to get there, is brought to Seattle by E.W. Saportas, who, with Frank Crydo and Gus Wagner, experienced miners of Dawson City, went to the scene of the latest excitement last Saturday.

PLATT has got all his organs and his emissaries in and about Tammany to talking silver again. The Democratic platform is to reaffirm that of Chicago. The candidate will be a man who voted for BRYAN. Repudiation will be the issue. This is the gossip which has wonderfully revived since PLATT nominated Gen. TRACY.

The shame and pain which have wrung from Mr. GLADSTONE so passionate a protest will be the recurring affliction of civilized Europe until the concert shall have been destroyed by the uprooting of absolutism in the German Empire and the extinction of militarism in Central and Eastern Europe.

HAWESVILLE, Ky., Sept. 26. -- Raymond Bushrod, a negro who yesterday brutally treated fourteen-year-old Maggie Roberts at Petrie Station, was lynched here this evening by a mob of about 800 persons. The lynching took place in the Court House Square and the body was left hanging to the limb of a tree.

Experience is a great teacher. We have been brought up on this maxim, and it therefore seems strange that the good citizens of this town should have ignored so persistently the sound teachings of experience in their attempts to obtain good municipal government.

Mrs. Mamie Hilderbrand, twenty-nine years old, who lived with her husband, Julius, at 39 Parker Street, Williamsburg, became despondent after her three-yeear-old son Julius died a year ago. She threatened to make way with herself so often that little attention was paid to the threat.

Excursionists to Fort Lee, who took advantage of yesterday's ideal weather to make a trip up the Hudson, missed an old landmark, which though sadly disfigured some time ago, still presented a picturesque appearance, and was counted among features of the Palisades as viewed from midstream. The rough old crag known for many years as Washington's Head, about one mile north of Fort Lee, is no more.
GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 26. -- E.C. Benedict and a party of New York gentlemen left yesterday on Mr. Benedict's yacht Oneida for Gray Gables to visit ex-President Cleveland.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 26. -- To-day was the quietest of the week in New Orleans, and the fever situation, in spite of the appearance of a rather large number of new cases, may be said to have shown much improvement. Fifteen cases were recorded by the Board of Health, but there were no deaths.

A lively week in the golf world was closed at Tuxedo on Saturday. The contestants all had an excellent time and saw some grand golf. The two players who stood out with particular prominence were, of course, Foxhall Keene and R.P. Huntington. Both have demonstrated their ability to be classed among the foremost golfers in America.

Out-of-town buyers who have taken advantage of the lessened transit rates obtained from the transportation companies by the Merchants' Association are still enthusiastic over the benefit conferred by the latter upon traders generally throughout the regions that are reached by its efforts.

The members of the New York Volunteer Life Saving Corps were in their glory yesterday at Ulmer Park, Brooklyn, where they were admired by more than 5,000 more or less amphibious persons. Some of the life savers wore nice uniforms, and some of them wore very little of anything, but all were petted and praised and made much of -- especially by the girls.

HAZELTON, Penn., Sept. 26. -- Nothing new developed to-day in the strike region and the day passed off quietly and without incident. All the collieries will resume tomorrow, some for the full week, others for part of the week. Gen. Gobin and his staff rode to Audenried this afternoon, and this evening the Ninth Regiment gave a dress parade.

VICTORIA, B.C., Sept. 26. -- The steamship City of Seattle, which arrived here yesterday, brought the news of a murder and suicide at Skaguay. The night of Sept. 21 George Buchanan, foreman of the Skaguay Bay Improvement Company, shot and killed Mrs. Stella Kossuth, the proprietress of a lodging house and restaurant, and then killed himself.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 26. -- The "Reds" won two well-played games from the "Browns" today. Both games were replete with brilliant fielding. Hoy gave a wonderful exhibition. Beckley got three home runs in the first game. Beecher, the new fielder of the "Browns," made a good impression.

Michael H. Cross. Michael H. Cross, an organist of high reputation in Philadelphia, died yesterday. He leaves a wife and one son. At the age of fifteen he began his professional career as organist at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church, Philadelphia. From there he went to St. Augustine's Church in the same city, and for eighteen years was organist at the Cathedral.
LONDON, Sept. 27 -- The Vienna correspondent of The Daily Mail says this morning:

The address of Mr. ECKELS, the Controller of the Currency, at Denver last week was an incident of more than momentary interest. The Controller has been a very active, able, and efficient advocate of the gold standard, and of a reform of the currency that would leave no chance for any kind of money depending for its value upon the flat of the Government.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26. -- The benefit tendered "Fred" Pfeffer to-day was a success, and it is estimated that "Dan" O'Leary, Chairman of the managing committee, will be able to turn over to Pfeffer between $2,500 and $3,000. About 8,000 persons attended the benefit.

The Republican leaders of Greater New York met at the Hotel Manhattan, Forty-second Street and Madison Avenue, yesterday morning and held a conference with regard to the City Convention and the nomination of Gen. Benjamin F. Tracy for Mayor. The convention will be held to-morrow in Carnegie Hall.

The Rev. Thomas Dixon, Jr., of the People's Church, Academy of Music, again devoted his preliminary talk yesterday morning to Mr. Low. He was frequently applauded in his attack on the Citizens' Union candidate. Something like half a dozen persons in his audience, however, showed that they did not relish his discourse by getting up and going out.

MADRID, Sept. 26. -- The arrival of United States Minister Woodford from San Sebastian has made a sensation. The programme of the United States has been ascertained. This does not contemplate a declaration of war if Spain rejects mediation, but, according to report, an "ostentatious proclamation to the world of disapproval of the Cuban regime by suspending diplomatic relations with Spain and withdrawing the United States Minister."

SIMLA, Sept. 26. -- The operations against the Mahmunds are proceeding satisfactorily. Gen. Westmacott has completely demolished the headquarters of the Hadda Mullah in the village of Jarobi, blowing up all the fortifications. While this was being done a body of Sepoys was caught in ambush in the defile and sharp fighting ensued. But the Sepoys succeeded in retiring with but slight loss.

" Through all our constitutional history the tendency has been to enlarge the power of localities in the management of such local affairs as are usually intrusted to their administration. This policy has been developed not merely by conferring the power of local election or of appointment by local authority of the officers on whom the duties of local administration are conferred, but also by the gradual enlargement of those duties.

HAZLETON, Penn., Sept. 27. -- The Coroner's jury, which investigated the death of the striking miners at Lattimer, met in Deputy Coroner Cowman's office this evening, and after an hour's deliberation rendered the following verdict:

Papers were signed yesterday whereby Edward S. Stokes disposed of his interest in the Hoffman House to a syndicate headed by Graham Polly of Brooklyn. The price is said to have been more than $200,000, and possession will be taken to-day.

The Executive Committee of the Citizens' Union met yesterday afternoon at 32 Liberty Street and discussed candidates for Controller and President of the Council. It was reported that one of these men will be named for Controller: J. Harsen Rhoades, Henry W. Cannon, or Ashbel P. Fitch. For President of the Council, ex-Mayor Schroeder. Mayor Frederick W. Wurster, or Edward M. Shepard of Brooklyn will, it was said, be chosen.

Favored by a handicap of five goals, the team of the Myopia Hunt Club of Hamilton, Mass., was able to defeat, by almost the smallest margin possible, the four of the Meadowbrook Club of Westbury, L.I., the champion team of the Polo Association, in a sharply-fought contest, on the parade ground of Prospect Park, Brooklyn, yesterday, in the second game of the tournament for the prizes offered by the Riding and Driving Club of Brooklyn.

The Tammany slate which, barring accidents, will go through the convention on Thursday next, was made up yesterday. Word that this had been done reached the leaders of the various districts in the afternoon. The list of accepted candidates was not given out, but became known by degrees.
" The request of Gen. COLLIS that the City Convention indorse Mayor STRONG'S administration was rejected with a bang." -- The Sun.

GIRARDVILLE, Penn., Sept. 27. -- At least nine men received fatal injuries and possibly two score others were more or less seriously wounded in a bloody riot here late last night and early this morning. The battle was the outcome of a quarrel over the Hazleton troubles.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- Sir Julian Pauncefote, the British Ambassador, is expected to return here from his London trip about Oct. 15, notwithstanding reports that he would not be back in time for the Behring Sea conference. The staff of the British Embassy, now at Manchester-by-the-Sea, will return next week, and, according to present plans, the entire British representation will be here when the seal conference is held.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 27. -- The American Warehousemen's Association had a hearing to-day before Inter-State Commerce Commissioner Prouty. The association claims that forty-one railroad companies named in the petition have violated the inter-State commerce law by permitting large shippers to use their frieght houses for warehouse purposes free of charge, thus interfering with the business of the warehousemen and discriminating against small shippers.
Two thrilling stories of wreck and disaster at sea reached port yesterday by incoming steamships that followed in the wake of the hurricane that swept along the Atlantic coast last week.

COLUMBUS, Ohio. Sept. 27. -- The first National Convention of the Mayors and Councilmen of the United States and Canada will open here to-morrow morning. The convention will cover four days, and coincident with it in a neighboring hall will be held the second annual convention of the National Street Lighting Association, organized in New Haven, Conn., in 1896. In some instances the same municipal officers are delegates to both conventions.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27. -- The leading event of the day in the Luetgert murder trial was the evidence of William Charles, Luetgert's business partner. He explained why, as he claimed, the caustic potash in which the body of Mrs Luetgert is alleged by the prosecution to have been dissolved was bought.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- Secretary Wilson of the Agricultural Department, has secured an order from the Post Office Department permitting the agents of the Agricultural Department to attach the department frank to packages of sugar-beet seed to be sent from growers to the experiment stations throughout the country for analysis.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 27. -- Warmer weather the last two or three days has had the effect of increasing the number of new cases of the prevailing type of yellow fever, but it also has had the effect of sending down the death rate. There were twenty-three new cases on Saturday, seventeen yesterday, and up to 6:30 o'clock to-day twenty-one.

Alderman Parker, Chairman of the Railroad Committee of the Board of Aldermen, said yesterday that the Tammany members of the board had been instructed by Tammany Hall to vote against the application of the Third Avenue Railroad Company that the King's Bridge franchise be put up at auction. The matter has been pending several months.
MADRID, Sept. 27. -- The United States Minister, Gen. Stewart L. Woodford, paid a visit of courtesy this morning to the Spanish Premier, Gen. Azcarraga.

HAVANA, Sept. 27. -- Alleged details of the capture of Victoria de las Tunas, Province of Santiago de Cuba, by the insurgent forces, have been issued from the Palace here. They say that after the Spanish troops surrendered the insurgents began plundering the stores and private residences, and committed many brutal acts with women and girls, "not even respecting the sisters of Gen. Vicente Garcia," an insurgent leader of the last war.

The leading editorial in yesterday's TIMES affords another gratifying proof of the almost marvelous faculty and facility which your journal so generally evinces in saying just the right thing at the right time. The admirable and opportune article here referred to is in the form of an interogation concerning the Executive Committee and other leading gentlemen of the Citizens' Union, and is in these words: "Where Do They Stand?"
At their regular meeting yesterday the ministers of the Methodist Episcopal Church of New York discussed the question of curtailing the power of the Bishops in regard to the transfer of clergymen.

Sir JOHN EVANS'S doubts about the antiquity of the chipped stone implements found in the glacial gravels at Trenton are in a fair way to be removed by a fuller consideration of the evidence than he had ever been able to give prior to his address at the recent meeting of the British Association at Toronto.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- Sanitary Inspector Brunner, in his last report to the Marine Hospital Service concerning the health situation in Havana, says:

The bribery talk in Brooklyn has grown stronger ever since the Republican primaries were held. Quarantine Commissioner Schroeder was quoted yesterday as saying that a man named William Wacher, in the Sixth Assembly District, had told him that he was to receive $75 from a leader of the anti-Worth forces if he and the other delegates from the district voted the Woodruff-Willis ticket.

Columbia Typographical Union No. 101 of the District of Columbia is regarded by its members as the leading organization of printers in the United States. Its influence is great, for good or ill, throughout the country, and while its action is not always approved by associate unions, it is widely observed and commented upon.

There is something pathetic about the chronic Canadian effort, which during the present Administration seems to have become acute again, to convert Montreal into a port trustworthy all the year round. Nature will be as successful in resisting this effort as she has been before.

BERLIN, Sept. 27. -- Before the beginning of play in the international tournament of the German Chess Association this morning Englisch stated to the committee that he was compelled to retire on account of ill health. The committee thereupon decided that all of the unplayed games of Englisch and Bardeleben should be scored for their opponents, and the scores of the players were revised.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Sept. 27. -- The tugboat John A. Woods was destroyed by fire on the Hudson River last night. The boat was proceeding down the river with a long raft of piles, en route from Troy to Brooklyn, and when opposite Camelot, four miles south of this city, fire was discovered under the boiler.

The tremendous acclaim with which mediocrity is received in the theatre nowadays (on "first-nights" shrewdly managed) and the almost hysterical enthusiasm unseen but too frequently heard persons in the auditorium, on such occasions, manifest when either the play or the performance, or both, are really a little better than mediocre, may be a good thing for the theatrical business -- or it may not.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., Sept. 27. -- Mrs. Ann Jacoby of Port Jervis, whose husband disappeared twenty-two years ago from their home, in Greene, Chenango County, N.Y., and from whom nothing had since been heard, has just received information from the Pension Department that her husband is living in Buffalo.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27. -- Wheat was firm today in spite of a large array of bear news, December closing at one-quarter to three-eighths of a cent advance. Drought reports are beginning to attract a great deal of attention, and were influential to-day in causing the slight advance. The dry weather was also a feature in the corn market, which closed one-quarter to three-eighths of a cent higher. Oats advanced one-quarter of a cent.

LONDON, Sept. 27. -- At Bow Street Police Court to-day "Captain" J.H.I. Cruickshank was again arraigned on remand, charged with defrauding Lady Randolph Churchill and her sisters, Mrs. Moreton Frewen and Mrs. Leslie, out of the sum of $7,750, and with defrauding other women out of sums varying from $500 to $18,000, the whole amount totaling up about $50,000.
There was an exciting scene in Part III., Supreme Court, in Brooklyn, yesterday.

SING SING, Sept. 27. -- An attempt was made to-day to burn the storehouse and offices at the State Prison. It failed because of the prompt discovery of the flames by a convict. A few minutes later there would have been no one about to discover them.

" An easy way out of the present political dilemma, and one which would insure the defeat of Tammany and the election of the full Republican ticket for municipal, county, and legislative officers, would be the nomination of SETH LOW by the Republican convention and the indorsement by the Citizens' Union of every other candidate named by the Republicans.

JAMAICA, L.I., Sept. 27. -- The Queens County Republican Borough Convention was held here to-day and unanimously nominated Felix Fritsche of Astoria for President of the borough. The nominations for Councilmen and Aldermen will be made by districts on Wednesday. The presiding officer was William F. Wyckoff of Jamaica, and the Secretaries were Frank H. Griflin of Flushing, and Harold B. Christensen of Woodside.
Republican City Convention, Carnegie Hall, Fifty-seventh Street and Seventh Avenue, at Noon.

The performance of the new German steamship Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse marks, not a new departure in steamship building, but a stage in its direct development. The problem of increasing the speed of transatlantic steamships is not, as it is in sailing craft like yachts, so much a question of hull designing as it is of acquiring driving power.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 27. -- Francis Larkin, Jr., was chosen a delegate today by the Third Assembly District Democratic Convention of Westchester County to the judicial convention to be held in Brooklyn.

LONDON, Sept. 27. -- An announcement was made this afternoon, confirming the dispatches of Saturday last, that the Marquis of Salisbury has not withdrawn from the Bering Sea Conference, but has simply objected to the presence of Russia and Japan. Negotiations on the subject are proceeding.

For the first time in her life Cleo de Merode appeared last evening as premiere danseuse. It was at Koster Bial's Music Hall; the audience was the largest that the house has contained for many years; it was a particularly representative one; it came expectant, eager, prepared for a surprise. It got it; so did Mlle de Merode. Both were disappointed.

There was loud talking in the Grand Jury room yesterday, when Dr. W.J. O'Sullivan, counsel for the Central Labor Union, presented a part of the evidence on which he seeks to have the Tax Commissioners and their deputies indicted for perjury in falsely swearing to the values of certain properties owned by corporations, for tile purposes of taxation.

The presence of the steamship Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse attracted crowds to the piers of the North German Lloyd Steamship Company in Hoboken yesterday. They were eager to see the largest vessel in the world. They were permitted to view her mammoth proportions and fine lines only from the bulkheads.

The President of the Merchants' Association wrote a few days ago to the Maine Steamship Company, plying between New York and Portland, asking if that company would sell tickets from Portland to New York at one fare for the round trip, good for members of the Merchants' Association living in Maine and contiguous territory.

Delegates from the sixty-one Assembly districts of Greater New York, representing twenty-three silver associations in the four counties, met in convention in the Lenox Lyceum last night and organized as the United Democracy. A platform and emblem were adopted and a full city ticket was put in nomination.

The World yesterday contained an interesting interview with Alderman PARKER, Chairman of the Railroad Committee in the Board of Aldermen, respecting the grant to the Third Avenue Company in perpetuity of the King's Bridge Road franchise. The matter will come up for action before the Board to-day, and Alderman PARKER is warmly in favor of confirming the franchise for various reasons.

-- Whether a man is or is not "a Polish pig," he must be annoyed when this title is applied to him in public and a loud voice, and, whether the description is accurate or inaccurate, the impulse toward doing something vigorous is both natural and reasonable. In such circumstances, Count BADENI challenged the dealer in epithets to a duel, and on the first exchange of shots received a bullet in the arm.

ALBANY, Sept. 27. -- William Barnes, Jr., the Republican organization leader of Albany finds himself in much the same predicament as Mr. Platt regarding the political situation. Like Mr. Platt, Mr. Barnes is confronted by a citizens' movement and its candidate. Mr. Barnes would like to nominate an out-and-out Republican for Mayor, but he dare not do so.

ADAMS, Mass., Sept. 27. -- The plans of President McKinley and the members of his party were changed to-day on account of unpropitious weather conditions and the slight indisposition of Mrs. McKinley. Rain fell at intervals until nearly noon, and the trip to Williamstown, which had been planned for to-day, was deferred until to-morrow.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Sept. 27. -- Harry Tolerton, twenty years old, son of E.W. Tolerton, a wealthy attorney of this city, has been traveling in Southern Europe with Prof. D.J. Holmes of Allegheny College, Meadville, Penn., since early last June. They expected soon to go to Berlin to enter the university there.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27. -- The September monthly statement of the Government receipts and expenditures will show a material decrease in the deficit as compared with August. Treasury officials say the increase that will be shown in the receipts from internal revenue sources justifies the expectation that by Jan. 1 the deficit will have been reduced to a nominal amount.

The Evening High School for Women was formally opened last night by President Charles B. Hubbell of the Board of Education. The High School is held in Public School No. 50, 211 East Twentieth Street. It was expected that Mayor Strong would be present, but he sent regrets, saying he had to go to Newport to be present at a wedding at which he was to give the bride away.

Several visiting merchants were in the rooms of the Merchants' Association yesterday and quite a number of return railway tickets were supplied to homeward-bound buyers. Nearly all the excursionists from Joint Traffic territory have gone. The last of the trunk-line excursion tickets will not expire until Oct. 13.

The Secretary of the Treasury will soon order the Philadelphia Mint to resume experiments in the use of alloys in the five-cent and one-cent pieces. This will be done under a House resolution. The test will be to determine whether it is advisable to substitute pure nickel in these coins in place of the alloys now used.

YONKERS, Sept. 28. -- The Democratic primaries for the selection of delegates to the County, Judicial, and Assembly District Conventions, were held last night. There was a contest for the county delegates between John J. Broderick of this city, and Mayor Edwin Fiske of Mount Vernon. Both are after the nomination for Sheriff, Broderick got thirteen out of the eighteen delegates to the convention, which will be held in White Plains on Oct. 6.

The farmers of Westchester County went to White Plains yesterday to witness the annual exhibition of the Westchester County Agricultural Association. They had their cattle, ponies, pigs, poultry, and farm produce in the shape of fruits and vegetables on hand, while their wives and daughters furnished attractions in the way of homemade pies and cakes and preserves. Society, too, was represented by the members of the 400 who have country seats in the county.

Mayor Strong and President John Jeroloman and members of the Board of Aldermen were yesterday served with a preliminary injunction restraining them from taking any further action in the granting of the King's Bridge street railway franchise. Final action was to have been taken yesterday, but instead the matter will be reviewed by Justice Lawrence, in the Supreme Court, at 10:30 o'clock this morning.

The Tammany situation yesterday was very much confused. The action of the United Democracy in nominating Henry George and the refusal of the German-American Reform Union to indorse the Tammany "slate" caused the district leaders a great deal of uneasiness.

The only plea that respectable men venture to make for failing to support the Citizens' Union and its candidate is that Mr. Low, if elected, would be "responsible to no party." Responsibility to a party would not help the city, unless the party itself could be held responsible.

It is rather encouraging to read that Mr. EUGENE V. DEBS has come to the conclusion, which he has announced at a "National Labor Conference" in Chicago, that "strikes don't pay." Because there is nobody who has done more to stir up strikes nor perhaps anybody who has done so much to make them ferocious and spiteful.

-----Down in the West Indies they will hear with extremely complex emotions the news that the English Government, with the intention of furthering the interests of the sugar planters, will try to negotiate reciprocity treaties under the provisions of our new tariff law. The colonists are in this curious and embarrassing position: If such treaties are not made, they will be shut out of the American market entirely.

The editorial on "Rich and Poor," in your edition of Sunday, Sept. 26, is in danger of misconstruction. The writer thinks Carroll D. Wright, from whom he quotes, is more interested in "making out a case" than in conveying information. He says: "There is a large number who cannot, and a larger number who do not, earn enough to live in comfort, or even in decency.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Sept. 28. -- The two fastest miles ever paced over a track in one day and the fastest quarter ever paced were made here to-day, and yet the world's pacing record stands as Star Pointer made it at Readville. In point of track and weather the conditions were just right, but there were unfavorable circumstances connected with the speed trials of both Star Pointer and Joe Patchen to-day.

WURTSBORO, N.Y., Sept. 28. -- Wallace J. Christian, who yesterday shot and killed Horace F. Pritchard of New York at the Sullivan County Club, five miles from here, is still at large. Thomas J. Manny, the constable of this place whom Christian shot after killing Pritchard, is still alive, but will die. Officers are searching for the missing murderer.

All day yesterday the bear traders of Wall Street kept the stock market under adverse pressure. They invented and circulated abounding tales intended to create distrust, and nervousness. They were able in some quarters to force recessions. Many stocks declined a point apiece; few went down more than that. Of stocks traded in to the extent of 1,000 shares each, a great majority declined only fractionally.

The Glucose Sugar Refining Company's stock, both common and preferred, declined yesterday, and the demand became perceptibly weaker on persistent rumors that the trust would encounter strenuous opposition from dealers.

PASSAIC, N.J., Sept. 28. -- The initial trap shooting tournament of the reorganized New Jersey State Sportsmen's Association began at the Clifton Race Track this afternoon, and will continue until Oct. 1. Nearly all the crack shots throughout the United States were on hand when the first event began.

In Mr. PLATT'S convention last night the band at least knew its business. It played "Hail to the Chief" as the great boss entered the box from which during the session he was a witness of the mechanical precision with which his orders were carried out. There never was an assembly of freemen more abjectly obedient to a master or held more unresistingly in thralldom to one man. Strict prearrangement governed all the proceedings.

The Tribune is authority for the statement that Mr. QUIGG supports and Mr. PLATT approves the movement for the pardon of JOHN Y. McKANE. We are not surprised, but even these hardened hucksters in politics should be ashamed of favoring such an outrage.

ALBANY, Sept. 28. -- The first attempt of the State to obtain possession of thousands of acres of valuable Adirondack lands, the title to which has been lost through the cancellation by former State Controllers of tax sales, on which the State's title was based, was made by the Fisheries, Forest and Game Commission to-day before Controller Roberts.

The new burlesque, or extravaganza, at the Casino is as big and showy, as frank and noisy, as highly colored, glittering, and audacious as the best of its predecessors. It is called "The Belle of New York," and the gentleman who signs himself Hugh Morton wrote the text, with no great attempt at original wit in the prose dialogue, but with a few characteristically happy turns in the lyrics.

Senator Platt, with Mrs. Platt and a party of men and women, sat in a box at Carnegie Music Hall and smiled at what he saw. He was entitled to smile. He saw 348 delegates from the four counties of Greater New York, and knew that a vast majority were there merely to do his bidding.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- The special board appointed by the Navy Department to consider the needs of the navy in the matter of new dry docks submitted its report to Acting Secretary Roosevelt to-day. The board is composed of Commodore Bunce, Commander Chadwick, and Constructor Dashiell, with Civil Engineer Parks as recorder The board finds that five new docks are urgently necessary, while one (the Port Royal (S.C.) dock) should be enlarged immediately.

The verdict of the Coroner's jury in the case of the killing at Hazleton, Penn., is practically of no value, since the jury disagree. Part of them find that the action of the Sheriff's deputies was unnecessary and therefore unwarranted, and part of them find just the contrary. The verdict, after such investigation as was possible, reflects very fairly public opinion formed with no investigation, on the reports of the newspapers.

HALIFAX, N.S., Sept. 28. -- The Provincial Exhibition opened here to-day. All the buildings are new and the display made in the different departments excels that of any previous show of the kind held in Nova Scotia. At the formal opening addresses were delivered by Lord Kelvin, Vice Admiral Fisher, Lieut. Gov. Daly, and others. The attendance promises to be large.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 28. -- Martin Kinneman, an alleged "green goods" man, is in the Tombs. The charge pending against him is that of being a suspicious person. Kinneman was turned over to the police by Charles Weber, a saloon keeper. It is alleged that Kinneman attempted to work off a quantity of "green goods" on the saloon keeper.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28. -- When the report of the Committee on Resolutions of the National Labor Convention was presented to-day a big row ensued. A resolution was handed in yesterday approving the free coinage of silver at the ratio of sixteen to one, and the free silver people in the convention felt certain that the resolution would be embodied in the committee's report.
The confiding character of Brooklyn people and the dignified methods of the Brooklyn burglar are illustrated by an incident which was reported to the police yesterday.

Although, after the first few hours of M. Cordang's ride at the Crystal Palace track, it was seen that, all being well, the famous Dutchman would beat the world's record, it was not thought that he would be able to accomplish so grand a performance as he did. The feature of the ride was the remarkably even speed at which he traveled during the first half of the journey.

COLUMBUS Ohio, Sept. 28. -- The first annual conference of the Mayors and Councilmen of the United States, Canada, and Mexico was called to order at 11 o'clock this morning by Mayor Black of this city, about 160 regularly accredited delegates being present in the auditorium. The Mayor's opening remarks were brief, and he closed by introducing Gov. Asa S. Bushnell of Ohio, who delivered an address of welcome.

Col. Robert A. Ammon of Grymes's Hill, S.I., former President of the Mining Exchange; Lawyer William A. Sweetser of 40 Exchange Place, and Lawyer William Woods of 211 West Fifty-eighth Street, were arrested late on Monday by Central Office detectives, charged with blackmail.
BOSTON, Sept. 28. -- Assistant Engineer Knight of Lieut. Peary's ship Hope said to-day that positive proofs of cannibalism were found at Lieut. Greely's camp at Cape Sabine by a landing party.

BERLIN, Sept. 28. -- Two games, left unfinished in the thirteenth round of the international chessmasters' tournament now in progress at the Architekten Haus, 92 and 93 Wilhelmstrasse, in this city, were announced to be concluded this morning. Caro and Janowski had drawn, while Winawer had beaten Metger.

ADAMS, Mass., Sept. 28. -- There was nothing about the weather to-day to prevent President McKinley and the members of his party who are the guests of W.B. Plunkett from carrying out any outdoor programme they might wish. The trip to Williamstown during the afternoon was the chief event.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 28. -- The application of James J. Smith of Pumptown, a hamlet near Metuchen, N.J., for a license to sell liquors at his "Wheelmen's Rest" failed to meet the approval of Judge Strong when presented this morning, and, at his suggestion, was withdrawn.
The vote on nominations for Mayor was: Tracy, 297; Low, 49; Schroeder, 2. That was the ticket nominated last night at the Republican City Convention in Carnegie Music Hall.

ROME, N.Y., Sept. 28. -- The Oneida County Democratic Convention to-day made the following nominations: Sheriff -- Michael Doll of Utica; County Clerk -- Joseph Wurz of Utica; Superintendent of the Poor -- Edward J. Pepper of Floyd; Coroner -- Dr. T.P. Scully of Rome. The convention reaffirmed the Chicago platform.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 28. -- There was no material change in the yellow fever situation in this city to-day. Two deaths resulted from the disease, and twenty-one new cases were reported. There was one death at Biloxi, Miss., to-day, and ten new cases are reported from Edwards. Four suspicious cases in one family at Clinton, Miss., are under observation, but have not yet been declared to be yellow fever.

The will of Ogden Goelet, who died on his yacht at Cowes, England, on Aug. 27, was filed for probate yesterday. No public or charitable bequest of any kind is made, and the entire estate is left to the widow and two children, except that the testator gives to his sister-in-law, Lelia Belle Herbert, wife of Michael Henry Herbert, $50,000, and to Robert Alexander Roberts, son of the late Robert G. Roberts, $5,000.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28. -- There was a stormy meeting at the Post Office Department yesterday afternoon between Postmaster General Gary and National Committeeman Kerens of Missouri.

NORTH ADAMS, Mass., Sept. 29. -- The Presidential party left Adams to-night in a blaze of red fire. Two bands furnished music, and about 3,000 people were present to witness the departure. The special train was backed down the track to a point in front of the Plunkett residence at 10 o'clock, and in a few seconds the party had boarded it.

BERLIN, Sept. 29. -- This morning the committee of the international chess masters' tournament, now being played at the Architekten Haus, in this city, announced that the Walbrodt vs. Metger game, left unfinished yesterday, had resulted in a win for Walbrodt.

The committee representing residents of the upper west side who are vigorously fighting the use of four trolley tracks in Amsterdam Avenue by the companies which claim possession of that thoroughfare have sent a letter to the State Board of Railroad Commissioners, setting forth the more significant points in their case.

The Republican County Convention will meet to-night at 8 o'clock in Lyric Hall, 723 Sixth Avenue. It was determined yesterday afternoon at a caucus of district leaders, to adjourn the convention until Monday evening, after perfecting an organization. Gen. James M. Varnum, or Alexander T. Mason, will be chosen permanent Chairman. Four hundred and thirty delegates will respond to the roll call.

LONDON, Sept. 29. -- The result of the election yesterday in the East Division of Denbighshire, for a member of Parliament to succeed the late Right Hon. Sir George Osborne Morgan, Bart., Liberal, deceased, is a Liberal victory with an increased majority.

BERLIN, Sept. 29. -- Oswald Ottendorfer, prietor of the Staats-Zeitung of New York, who has been in Europe for some time past, will return to New York this week. During the course of an interview on the political situation in New York City he said:

While Joseph McShale, a stone mason, thirty years old, was at work on a narrow swinging scaffold at the front of the twelfth story of a new building at 594 Broadway yesterday afternoon, he made a misstep or a stumble which resulted in his falling to the street below after a few moments of agonizing struggle.

The Citizens' Union Organization Committee will meet to-morrow evening at 8 o'clock at Hardman Hall, 2 West Nineteenth Street, to nominate a Controller and a President of the Council, and to make arrangements for putting a complete ticket into the field.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment gave a public hearing yesterday in the matter of the Bronx Park Botanical Museum. The hearing was begun at 11:30 A.M. Paul Dana and others who have opposed the appropriation of $500,000 for the museum were present. Several of the Trustees of the garden and residents of the north side were also present to offer arguments in favor of the appropriation.

I saw in yesterday's morning Sun a letter signed "George Fentrick." I, too, joined the Citizens' Union before I even knew of you as a candidate for the office of Mayor of Greater New York. I joined it for the simple reason that I thought I saw, what I have long been looking and hoping for, a good City Government, which should be entirely divorced from National and State politics.

A partition suit has been brought in the Supreme Court, which, while ostensibly asking for a sharing of twelve pieces of property situated between Fifty-first and Sixty-fourth Streets. Sixth and Madison Avenues, really attacks the validity of the will of Miriam A. Osborn, mother of Howell Osborn, involving an estate of over $5,000,000, and may result in making Fay Templeton, the actress, whom Osborn married, richer by $100,000.

BOSTON, Sept. 29. -- The trial of a divorce case, which is of considerable interest to all society people in Boston and in other large cities of the country, will begin on Monday. Mrs. Anna .M. Rydingsvard, who has been known to society for several years past as the Baroness von Rydingsvard, is suing for a divorce from her husband, Karl A. Rydingsvard, who has passed as a Baron.

HONOLULU, Sept. 22. -- Congressmen J.G. Cannon of Illinois, H.C. Loudenslager of New Jersey, A.S. Berry of Kentucky, and J.A. Tawney of Minnesota, and their families leave for San Francisco to-day. Senator Morgan will remain several weeks longer.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 29. -- The attendance at the Westchester County Fair increases. Fully 5,000 people were present today, everything on the ground was thoroughly inspected, and everybody was liberally patronized.

A large list of racers received punishment through this week's bulletin of Chairman Albert Mott of the National Racing Board, League of American Wheelmen. Announcement was made that the suspension placed on Willi Arend, the mile champion of the world, had been removed. Suspensions on Adrian Winter of Hoboken, N.J., and Emil Pister of the same locality have been removed.

LONDON, Sept. 29. -- There is a rumor in Canadian circles that the Government of the United States has made overtures to the Government of Denmark with the object of acquiring Greenland from the latter country.

READING, Penn., Sept. 29. -- It became known to-day that the mission at Sendai, Japan, in charge of the Rev. W.E. Hoy, formerly of Lancaster County, Penn., was robbed seven years ago by armed natives of $5,600 in gold. Mr. Hoy did not report the loss to the Reformed Board of Foreign Missions, but, to avoid embarrassing the board, has toiled all these years to make up the loss by his own efforts.

An orderly and every-day kind of a horse which was driven before a load of brick to the new sky scraper in Park Row, near Ann Street, yesterday afternoon probably told his stable companions last night that he had had the experience of his life.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29. -- The University of Pennsylvania football eleven ran against the strongest proposition they have tackled this year in the Washington and Jefferson teams of Washington, Penn. After two twenty-minute halves they succeeded in defeating their opponents only by a score of 18 to 4; six in the first half and twelve in the second.

A suit has been brought in the Supreme Court by Nathalie P. Nachtel, a young woman who until recently has been pursuing her studies in England, against her father. Dr. Henri Nachtel, in which she seeks to recover from him $82,000, which she alleges he obtained from her by fraud and the exertion over her of a powerful influence.

The injunction action brought by Leopold Gusthal against the Mayor and Board of Aldermen to restrain them from granting to the Third Avenue Railroad Company a franchise for the King's Bridge railway extension through St. Nicholas Avenue, One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, and the King's Bridge Road, took an unusual turn in the Supreme Court yesterday when Corporation Counsel Scott refused to appear further as counsel for the Board of Aldermen.

The annual convention of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York was begun yesterday morning in the Church of the Incarnation, Madison Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street, and will be continued there today. The convention was preceded by services conducted by Bishop Thomas U. Dudley of Kentucky.

A bogy handicap competition was played yesterday by the members of the Dyker Meadow Golf Club, at South Brooklyn. The prize was a silver cup given by Albert G. Jennings, and it was won by J.F. Blandy, who tied with bogy. Each player was allowed two-thirds of his medal play handicap, and each contestant played against the same imaginary score, which was: Bogy .................. 6 4 5 5 5 5 6 4 5 -- 45

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 29. -- A feature of the morning session of the National Conference of Mayors and Councilmen that aroused great interest among the delegates was the reading of a paper contributed by Nathan Straus of New York on "The Influence of a Pure Milk Supply on the Death Rate of Children."

The latest number of The Spectator of London contains an interesting article on "England's Isolation." It is a strong statement by a writer singularly free from the bitter party feeling with which such topics are usually treated and still more singularly free from the international prejudices in which Englishmen, despite their modern tendency to cosmopolitanism, are often so deeply steeped.

THE NEW YORK TIMES occupies the distinction of having the handsomest supplement issued by any American newspaper. The Illustrated Weekly Magazine, which accompanies without charge the Sunday edition of that newspaper, is attractive in every way. Its letterpress and illustrations bear on live topics -- subjects relating principally to New York and New Yorkers.

The local Legislature of Greater New York is in some respects the very weakest and most dangerous point in the framework of government. It is, therefore, of the greatest importance that it shall be made up of the strongest men that can be got. The Citizens' Union can do no better work than in the Municipal Assembly districts.
