WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- Fire broke out in the central power station of the Capital Traction Company, a few minutes before 11 o'clock to-night, and in thirty minutes the magnificent six-story structure was doomed. The building occupied the entire block from Pennsylvania Avenue to C Street, and from Thirteen and a Half Street to Fourteenth Street.
The Bostons won the first game of their final series with the Brooklyns at Eastern Park yesterday afternoon and took a step nearer to the championship goal.

On the morning of Saturday, Sept. 18, about 9:30 o'clock, a representative of Printers' Ink, on his way down town, passed through Twenty-third Street and stopped at the newsstand on the southeast corner of Sixth Avenue to buy a copy of THE NEW YORK TIMES. For more than thirty years this particular Printers' Ink representative has been in the habit of reading THE TIMES every morning.

Work on the repairs of the second-class battleship Texas is rapidly nearing completion, and she will be ready to join the squadron next week. She was taken out of the timber dry dock yesterday at the Brooklyn Navy Yard and moored at Cob Dock. Both the bow and stern torpedo outfits are being removed.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 29. -- The semi-finals for the Stockbridge Cup were played this morning. The links were in superb condition, and the weather was perfect for good golf, as the wind had entirely subsided. The best golf of the tournament was played by W.T. Gray of St. Andrew's Club, who broke the record of the links, reducing it to 41 for nine holes.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 29. -- Ex-Gov. Will S. Cumback, President, and John B. Conner, Secretary of the committee appointed by the Indiana Convention of Laymen of the Methodist Episcopal Church recently held here, to issue a report to the laymen of the church in the United States, to-day sent out the following:

Bernard Vierneger, forty-nine year old, who was for twenty-three years employed as a bookbinder in the factory of D. Appleton Co., publishers, at Kent Avenue and Hewes Street. Williamsburg, died yesterday at his home, 1,031 De Kaib Avenue, from the effects of carbolic acid, taken his family say, in mistake for spirits of nitre.

It would be unfortunate if the Mayor's good nature should get the better of his sense of public duty in the case of Gen. COLLIS. Of course, it is an ungracious thing for a Mayor to discharge a Commissioner of Public Works, when neither of them has more than three months of his term remaining.

SPRINGFIELD, L.I., Sept. 29. -- At the Springfield crossing of the Long Island Railroad Mrs. Clara Gray was instantly killed by a train this afternoon. At the same time Mrs. Rosina Nelson and her son, Harold, three years old, and Edna Gray, daughter of Mrs. Gray, two years old, were seriously hurt.

PASSAIC, N.J., Sept. 29. -- The second day of the New Jersey State shoot was favored by fine weather and a larger attendance than on its opening yesterday. The contests to-day were at inanimate targets. There were thirteen events on the programme, five of which were reserved as State events and the other eight were open to all.

When Jacob Worth left Carnegie Hall Tuesday night after the adjournment he had little to say regarding the treatment of the Brooklyn men on the floor of the convention. Yesterday he was asked what he thought of the strength of the ticket.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29. -- The three days' session of the National Labor Convention ended this afternoon in a climax of incendiary speeches. E.M. Bannister of St. Louis, Chairman of the convention, resigned the gavel to introduce a resolution advising strikers in general to arm themselves for resistance when necessary.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29. -- The Pennsylvania Railroad Company's statement of comparison of earnings and expenses for the month of August and eight months of 1897 with the same period of 1896, is as follows:

BOSTON, Sept. 29. -- The Republican State Convention was a large and enthusiastic gathering. There was not a contest or difference of opinion to mar the harmony of the occasion. The entire list of State officers was named by acclamation for re-election, and the platform is merely an indorsement of the platform of last year.

LONDON, Sept. 30. -- A dispatch to The Times from Berlin says that the Emperor William has sent to the North German Lloyd Steamship Company the following congratulatory telegram upon the record made by the new steamship Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse from Southampton to New York:

" Gov. Flower has been selling stocks by wholesale. He started in to sell on discovering that one of his closest business associates had already sold a tremendous line of long stock -- the liquidating associate being Mr. D.O. Mills."

Two thousand six hundred and thirty-seven bales of wool, the gross weight of which was 1,037,800 pounds, were sold at auction yesterday on the floor of the Wool Exchange by Wilmerding, Morris Mitchell, auctioneers, and nearly $200,000 was realized. Every seat in the exchange was occupied.

Mr. BOURKE COCKRAN'S swaggering criticisms of President Low will be read nowhere with such intelligent and sympathetic interest as among his old friends in Tammany Hall. They understand perfectly his point of view. Mr. COCKRAN has talent and ambition. His great need, the thing he yearns for, is opportunity -- an emplacement, so to speak, for his abilities.

H.H. Cammann Co. have sold for M. Rowan to the Church of the Holy Communion, for $33,500, the five-story English basement brick and stone-front dwelling 45 West Twentieth Street, 20 by 92, adjoining the parsonage of that church.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 29. -- The Washingtons were defeated by the Champions to-day in a well-played contest. The game was characterized by the sharpest kind of fielding on both sides, Wrigley and Jennings carrying off the honors. Nops, while hit freely, was very effective when things looked squally, while McJames's six bases on balls and two wild pitches helped the Champions to victory.
MADRID, Sept. 29. -- The Spanish Ministry has resigned. It was constituted as follows:

The few hundred local enthusiasts who went to the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon to witness the struggle between the New Yorks and Philadelphias were treated to an excellent exhibition of pitching. It was probably Rusie's last game for the season, and he was anxious to end one of the most successful seasons he has had with a victory.

TRENTON, Sept. 29. -- The returns from Tuesday's election in New Jersey are coming in very slowly, and only the larger counties have their totals nearly completed. The returns received by the different County Clerks indicate a much closer vote on the anti-gambling amendment than the earlier returns promised.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29. -- The news of the Spanish Cabinet crisis was first brought to the attention of the officials of the State Department and diplomatic officials through The Associated Press dispatches from Madrid, and up to a late hour to-night from no other source was any information on the subject forthcoming.

Wilmer and Addison Hanan won the third and last of the sweepstake races for the thirty-six-foot class of sloops off Larchmont yesterday. The Acushla won every race, and the Anoatok, Oswald Sanderson's yacht, was second in each event, and George Tyson's Vorant II, third. Yesterday's race was sailed in a light, shifting wind, and the Acushla had somewhat the better of the luck, particularly on the last leg of the course.

BUFFALO, Sept. 29. -- The Democratic County Convention to-day reaffirmed the platform adopted by the National Convention at Chicago in 1896. The following ticket was nominated: Sheriff -- Andrew Kilgallon; County Treasurer -- Jacob J. Lang; County Clerk -- Otto Wende; District Attorney -- William P. Colgate; Superintendent of Poor -- Ransom J. Savage; Keeper of Almshouse -- John Stengel; Coroner -- Dr. Jacob Goldberg.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 29. -- To-day has been a record breaker in the number of cases of yellow fever reported, while the deaths equaled in number those of any day since the yellow fever was first discovered in the city. The increased number of cases has caused no general alarm, because the increase of deaths has not been in proportion.

The Democratic Conference Committee of Greater New York, consisting of John C. Sheehan, Bernard J. York, John H. Sutphen, James McCartney, Dr. J.S. Feeney, and J.J. Martin, after a three hours' session at the Hoffman House last night succeeded in making up a possible slate that was at least acceptable to the men present.

A professional match was played yesterday on the eighteen-hole course of the Ardsley Club between John Shippin, the colored lad, who learned his game on the Shinnecock Hills course, and Valentine Fitzjohn, a Scotch professional, who has recently come to America. The contest was thirty-six holes, and the morning round of eighteen holes was the closest, although lower scores were made in the afternoon.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Sept. 29. -- A wagon, in which were seated Alexander Steel, Henry Steel, and John McNulty, was struck by the Scranton flier on the Delaware and Hudson Railroad at the Parsons Crossing to-night.

LONDON, Sept. 29. -- The Rome correspondent of The Standard says that his Holiness the Pope has sent President McKinley a copy of fine illustrated work descriptive of the so-called Appartamenti Borgia at the Vatican, which were recently restored.

The Independence Hall Democracy held its County Convention last night at Walhalla Hall. Its stated purpose was to nominate candidates for Mayor, Controller, and President of the Municipal Council, but the Executive Committee, which had been for the time being also made a Conference Committee, decided that it would be inexpedient to make independent nominations at this stage, and that part of the programme was postponed.

LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 29. -- To-day's session of the National Irrigation Congress was held in the State University Chapel. The following officers were elected by acclamations. President -- Joseph M. Carey, Cheyenne, Wyoming. First Vice President -- S.A. Cochran, South Dakota; Secretary -- Thomas E. Frost, Minneapolis; Minute Clerk -- O.S. .McCutcheon, Michigan.

The public inspection of the new steamship Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse proved to be an occasion probably unparalleled of its kind in the history of this port's shipping. Thousands of persons yesterday visited the piers of the North German Lloyd Line in Hoboken to see the monster ship.

The Democratic Judiciary Convention of the Second District was held in the Brooklyn Court House yesterday, and renominated Justice Willard Bartlett. The convention of the National Democratic Party was held in another part of the building at the same time, and Justice Bartlett was its candidate also.

MALONE, N.Y., Sept. 29. -- In the 2:35 pace at the Franklin County Fair this afternoon, Gipsey J., a valuable horse, owned by Frank Helmer, fell by catching her foot in the harness, and was injured so badly that she was shot. The driver was also badly cut and bruised. The horse just behind fell over the wreck, but regained her feet, and, rushing on without driver, came in third in the race.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 29. -- During the past two months votes for the artists who will serve on the international jury to award medals, honors, and the very liberal prizes offered by the Carnegie Instsitute have been sent to Pittsburg by painters residing in America, England, Scotland, France, Germany, Holland, and Switzerland.

The way of the pedestrian is hard. If any one doubts this fact, let him go up to the corner of Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street and see for himself. There the Department of Public Works has erected one of its many typical and attractive fortresses for the obstruction of traffic and the encouragement of profanity.

It has been definitely decided to nominate Henry George at the convention of the Democratic Alliance, to be held to-morrow. This decision was reached yesterday after a committee representing the Alliance had called upon Mr. Sheehan and demanded that a silver man should be nominated.
MALONE, N.Y., Sept. 30. -- Gov. Black was present to-day at the Franklin County Fair. He was escorted to the grounds by the Twenty-seventh Separate Company of Malone.

A Ministerial crisis is the accepted name for such a situation as that presented in Spain by the resignation of the Cabinet headed by Gen. AZCARRAGA. But in fact the Spanish crisis is not an acute but a chronic condition. It is not the Conservative Cabinet alone, it is Spain itself, which has undertaken a task beyond its powers.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 30. -- The slight chance that Baltimore had to win the pennant for next season no longer exists. It vanished early in to-day's game, when the Senators fell upon Dr. Pond's curves, batted him out of the box, and took a good long lead in the fourth inning, after which the home team seemed to lose heart and played listlessly and without ambition.

At Gravesend, yesterday, M.F. Dwyer made his colt Ben Eder the medium of a big plunge in the fifth race, a handicap at a mile and a quarter. Tom Cromwell, in the colors of his new owner, H.T. Griffin, who took him away from Mr. Dwyer in a selling race recently, was also a starter, and by beating his former stable companion he cost Mr. Dwyer a lot of money.

Joseph A. Burr, Corporation Counsel of Brooklyn, was yesterday nominated for Justice of the Supreme Court to succeed Justice Willard Bartlett, by the Republican Judiciary Convention held in the Kings County Court House. He received 155 out of 232 votes on the first ballot, his nomination afterward being made unanimous.

Contractor William P. Baird, who, it is alleged, is responsible for the present condition of Fifth Avenue, appeared in Yorkville Police Court yesterday in answer to a summons obtained by Adolph S. Audrain, a merchant of 261 Fifth Avenue, and issued by City Magistrate Mott, charging that he was maintaining a nuisance in unlawfully obstructing a public highway and rendering the street dangerous for passage.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 30. -- While the miners employed in the Madison Coal Company's shafts at Edwardsville, Ill., were going to work to-day they were attacked by a mob of strikers, who were influenced by thirty or more women sympathizers. The strikers threw stones and cayenne pepper, and beat their opponents with clubs, but no shots were fired, and nobody was killed.
SANTIAGO DE CHILE, Sept. 30. -- Gen. Baquedano, Commander-in-Chief of the Chilian Army, is dead.

Some new features have been introduced into the plan of Fall and Winter work mapped out for the college students' classes in Bible work in this city. This is the second year in which systematic work has been conducted under the general supervision of the Intercollegiate Bible Study's Committee of the Students' Club, and the field has been considerably extended since last Spring.

Vice President Garret A. Hobart and Whitelaw Reid were at the Horse Show of the Westchester County Fair Association yesterday. They were very much interested in the show, and Vice President Hobart made notes for use in the show of the Morristown Club, which is to be held next week.

While Edward Jonson, a good-natured and able-bodied Swedish sailor, living at 10 Bowery, was carrying home a comfortable load of assorted beverages Wednesday night, he met a stranger, also a sailor, who had taken on more cargo than his Plimsoll line justified, and was not quite able to keep steerage way.

PASSAIC, N.J., Sept. 30. -- This was the third day of the annual shoot at live birds and clay pigeons which is being held at Clifton race track, Clifton, N.J., under the auspices of the New Jersey State Sportsmen's Association. To-day and to-morrow live birds are used in the State and open events, namely, time Individual' State Championship and State Team Championship, Phoenix Introductory, and Clifton Sweepstakes.

We have already pointed out the opportunity that will be offered by the Paris Exposition for diffusing knowledge of our most important food crop. Throughout at least two-thirds of Europe the value of Indian corn for human food is unknown. Where American corn has been introduced, its introduction has for the most part been procured by active missionary efforts.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30. -- Wheat to-day more than recovered from yesterday's tumble. The December option closed at 1 5/8 c advance. The market was badly rattled during the forenoon by the sharp break in Spring wheat, which became irregular to-day, but heavy shipping engagements from here, presumably of this same grade, put the market on its feet again.

The second day's session of the annual convention of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, in the Church of the Incarnation, Madison Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street, was preceded yesterday morning by divine service, conducted by the Rev. F.F. German of St. Thomas's Church, Mamaroneck. The Rev. Dr. Morgan Dix presided over the convention in the continued absence of Bishop Potter, who is still confined to his bed.

The circumstances of the suicide yesterday morning of John Eucher, a tailor, of 182 Central Avenue, Brooklyn, probably illustrated the causes of his failure in life. He had been out of work a long time, and he talked about killing himself for months. When he did it at last it was a remarkable instance of wasted energy.

The Democratic City Convention has, as was expected, furnished a parallel case to the Republican. It is asserted that a difference existed, in that Croker's rule did not remain unassailed as did Platt's; on the contrary, that preceding the convention a struggle took place between Croker and Sheehan, in which Sheehan came out second best.

Golfers flocked in large numbers yesterday to the course of the Meadow Brook Club at Westbury, L.I., and kept the links lively in the opening rounds of the annual Fall tournament. The number of players who finished yesterday in the preliminary round to qualify for the Meadow Brook Cup was thirty-six.

With the defeat of the Southampton team by the Myopia four on the parade ground of Prospect Park, Brooklyn, yesterday, the polo season in the East ended. Yesterday's game was the final event in the tournament for individual prizes offered by the Riding and Driving Club of Brooklyn, in which the Southampton, Rockaway, Myopia, and Meadow Brook teams were entered, Rockaway withdrawing, and Meadow Brook losing to Myopia.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 30. -- John W. Caldwell of Russellville, who for several years was a member of Congress, and who has been probably the most consistent advocate of the free coinage of silver in Kentucky, has deserted the Chicago platform and will henceforth vote the ticket representing the Gold Democrats.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30. -- A meeting of the employes of the Chicago City Railway Company is to be held after midnight to discuss the advisability of going on a strike. The meeting in all probability will last until nearly morning. The chances are that a strike will be declared.

BOSTON, Sept. 30. -- The National Democratic Party, in its convention held here today, nominated the following State ticket: Governor -- William Everett of Quincy; Lieutenant Governor -- James E. Cotter of Hyde Park; Secretary of State -- B.M. Wolf of Boston; Treasurer and Receiver General -- H.P. Tobey of Wareham; Auditor -- Harry Douglass of Great Barrington; Attorney General -- W.W. McClinch of Chicopee.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- It is stated by persons familiar with Nicaraguan Canal affairs that either the United States or the Nicaragua Canal Company will institute an inquiry concerning the recent grant by Nicaragua to the Atlas Steamship Company, a British corporation, of exclusive rights of navigation for the next thirty years of the San Juan River and Lake Nicaragua.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30. -- Zephania H. Jones, one of the oldest and most respected builders and contractors in the city, was killed to-day by injuries resulting from collision with a middle-aged bicyclist named Reuben F. Gray, who is employed as a clerk in one of the branches of the Government Printing Office.

The United Democracy met last night at the Murray Hill Lyceum to nominate candidates for county offices and to adopt a platform. They adopted the platform, but referred the matter of nominations to a committee of twenty-five. Then the meeting became simply an ovation to James O'Brien. When the veteran politician addressed the meeting the cheers were almost hysterical.

BERLIN, Sept. 30. -- The game left unfinished yesterday, between Cohn and Walbrodt, in the fifteenth round of the international chess masters' tournament, now in progress at the Architekten Haus, 92 and 93 Wilhelmstrassse, in this city, resulted in a win for Walbrodt.
It seems to be the belief among Republicans that Gen. Tracy will withdraw from the field in favor of Seth Low, assurances from Chairman Quigg and other Republican leaders notwithstanding.

READING, Penn., Sept. 28. -- A case that is considered remarkable by medical men in this section is that of Uriah Shunk of Lebanon, Penn., who, in July last, dived into a stream of water three feet deep, and stuck in the soft sand at the bottom. Fellowbathers rescued him, but when brought to land he could not walk, and since has been wasting away gradually, until he is a skeleton.

Gallinger of New Hampshire on civil service reform, in the course of which he said: "You have chosen to continue our public conversation, and so be it. Your reply to my 'open letter' strikingly presents the spectacle of the defendant after conviction making faces at the Prosecuting Attorney.

Lieut. Robert E. Peary's arctic steamer Hope, in command of Capt. John Bartlett, arrived from Boston yesterday with a number of Peary's party, who spent the Summer in Greenland, aboard. Securely stored in the vessel's hold is the famous one-hundred-ton Greenland meteorite.

Van Wyck's misfortune that the minor and modest character of his judicial duties has thrown no light upon his executive qualifications or upon whether he has the courage, the wisdom, and the needful weight of moral power to make a political organization his instrument, instead of himself its humble, obedient, and grateful servant.

W.J. Gibson, counsel for the Treasury Department in cases before the United States Boards of General Appraisers, has completed his brief in the matter of the time of going into effect of the new tariff act, which question is pending before Board A of the General Appraisers. A large number of protests have been presented by New York and Boston importers, and the hearing on them will be resumed within a few days.

PINGREE did, without exciting the alarm of the people of their own States, not to speak of those in other Commonwealths.

Collins Collins, together with William H. Carpenter, have sold for Mrs. Sarah H. Yates to Matilda E. Goodwin the four-story brownstone front dwelling 564 Fifth Avenue, near Forty-sixth Street, 18.4 by 76.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 30. -- There were 3 deaths from yellow fever here to-day and 24 new cases were reported. The contagion seems to be slowly spreading into all sections of the city, but up to this time the authorities have been able to carry on their work of quarantine with some success. To-day's record was noteworthy from the fact that the fever crossed the river, one case being reported from Algiers.

The remaining games to be played by the Boston and Baltimore teams will have no bearing on the ultimate result.

The German-American Reform Union, through its Executive Committee, last night indorsed Seth Low for the Mayoralty, after waiting in vain for Tammany to recognize the organization and nominate a candidate the Union could support. The Executive Committee met in Maennerchor Hall, at 205 East Fifty-sixth Street.

Justice of the Peace Frederick J. Stuke of Bergenline Avenue, Union Hill, N.J., was offended by the utterances of clergymen against race tracks, during the campaign over the proposed Constitutional amendments. He is preparing a bill for introduction in the next Legislature making it a misdemeanor, punishable with fine and imprisonment, for clergymen to discuss politics in the pulpit.

The leaders of the Citizens' Union assert that there will be no fusion with the Republicans. "We shall put a full ticket in the field," said Secretary John C. Clark yesterday. "The Organization Committee will arrange for this at its meeting next Monday night. Our nominating meeting was postponed from Oct. 1 to give an opportunity to the Committee of Fifty of Brooklyn to make nominations on the same night."

CHICAGO, Oct. 1. -- Wheat made a great showing of strength during the early hours of the session to-day, but gradually changed around and closed at 1/2@5/8 cents decline. Drought news was again the prominent bullish factor, but weak Liverpool cables and anxiety to realize ultimately wiped out the advance occasioned by the dry weather. Corn followed wheat, starting strong and closing weak and 1/8 cent lower. Oats declined 1/4 cent.

The great size of the crowd which went to view the Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse on the day previous to her departure from this port is a striking evidence of the immense interest of Americans in ocean travel. Perhaps a more important evidence, however, was the recent visit of Mr. W.J. PIRRIE, Lord Mayor of Belfast and a member of the shipbuilding firm of HARLAND WOLFF.

The Rev. Father Casimer Zeglen of the Redemptionist Brotherhood, in Chicago, has invented a bullet-proof cloth, in which he has so much confidence that he stands as a target for bullets with only a small piece of his armor-fabric as a shield.

On Monday, Sept. 20, Bangs Co. opened the book auction season of 1896-7 with a sale which was finished on the following day. On Wednesday and Thursday, Sept. 22 and 23, an English consignment of books was disposed of, and some interesting prices were realized. Chief among these, perhaps, was the $43 obtained for Robert Louis Stevenson's "Some College Memories," privately printed in Edinburgh in 1886 for members of the University Union Committee.

Although there will be no large race meets until the indoor season begins, various cycling organizations have scheduled a number of minor competitions during the Fall. To-day the coasting contest, under the auspices of the Brooklyn Bicycle Club, will be run on the Seventy-ninth Street hill. W. A. Shockley, Thomas F. Tally, and R.A. Greene of Massachusetts, Louis De Rango of Syracuse, F.F. Ives of Bayonne.

ST. PAUL, Oct. 1. -- An Ingenious and valuable contrivance for the saving of life by preventing railroad accidents through forgetfulness of trainmen has been invented. The machine has Just stood a very severe test on the Great Northern Railway, after having been previously operated successfully on the St. Paul and Duluth Railroad.

Any one of them would probably have said that his purpose in making the appointment was to secure the best man for the place who would consent to take it.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1. -- The monotony of the scientific and painfully technical proceedings of the Luetgert murder trial to-day was relieved by a hearty laugh at the expense of Dr. Allport, the chief osteological expert of the defense, during the afternoon session. Dr. Allport had identified a piece of bone as the temporal of a human being.

With a shelving and storage capacity of nearly 2,000,000 volumes, the new Columbia University Library takes rank among the foremost in the world. Not only in respect to book capacity is its prominence thus signalized, but in beauty of architecture and grandeur of proportion.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1. -- The three-day cricket match which began to-day between the English and Philadelphia teams has resolved itself into the great society outdoor event of the season. The match is being played on the picturesque grounds of the Merion Cricket Club at Haverford. The attendance this afternoon numbered about 4,000, of whom at least 600 were women.

Even if VAN WYCK is a weak candidate, he must be beaten in the usual way by polling more votes against him than can be polled for him. Contemptuous remarks about his size and strength will not beat him. Hard work will beat him; hard, unflagging campaign work night and day until election day at 5 P.M.

Dr. Robert M. Flagg of Yonkers, who was married in that city on Thursday and came to New York with his wife, jumped from the window of their bedroom in the Murray Hill Hotel yesterday morning and was mortally hurt. His skull was fractured and his left leg was broken in two places.

Karoline Rivinius, wife of Robert Rivinius a soldier stationed at West Point, killed herself and her four children with gas in the West Shore Hotel, at Eleventh Avenue and Forty-second Street, late on Thursday night or early yesterday morning. The children were Laura, fifteen years old; William, thirteen; Albert, ten, and Elizabeth, three.

The rumor that Gen. Tracy would be withdrawn as the Republican Mayoralty candidate remains persistently current. Senator Platt denied yesterday, however, that there was the slightest intention on the part of the organization to take Gen. Tracy out of the race.
MADRID, Oct. 1. -- Senor Sagasta says he is willing to undertake the construction of a Cabinet, and it is hoped that the crisis will be solved to-morrow.
WHEELING, West Va., Oct. 1. -- The case of Mrs. Myria Atkinson wife of Gov. George W. Atkinson, on the charge of forgery, in the Circuit Court of Gilmore County, was begun to-day.

When Robert C. Winthrop, who to the younger generation of Americans has been for many years past "the old man eloquent retired," died in Boston, on the 16th of November, last year, the Massachusetts Historical Society, over which he had formerly presided for thirty years, and of which he had been a member more than half a century, in accordance with usage, appointed one of its associates to prepare a memoir.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 1. -- Mercer Engine Company of this place celebrated its fiftieth anniversary by unveiling a memorial to Gen. Hugh Mercer of revolutionary fame near the house where he died.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Oct. 1. -- The exhibition of the Orange County Horse Show Association was opened here to-day, and will be continued to-morrow. The dual inducements of ideal weather and a large entry list attracted a big crowd to the Goshen Driving Park, and this afternoon over 2,000 spectators were on the grounds.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 1. -- The Tennessee Legislature in February passed a law making it a misdemeanor to sell or to bring into Tennessee for the purpose of selling any cigarettes or cigarette paper.

The ungracious, ungenerous gossip that was once called forth by the printed evidence of the friendship between Robert Burns and Agnes Craig (Mrs. McLehose) received further rebuke in a volume recently published in Edinburgh, entitled "Burns's Clarinda," compiled by Dr. John D. Ross of New York.

NEW ROCHELLE, Oct. 1. -- Mrs. Philip Doatcher was married last Saturday to George B. Cross. It was not known before that Mr. Doatcher was dead or that his wife had obtained a divorce, Mr. Doatcher was a famous scenic artist ten years ago. At that time he lived in New York and owned a splendid mansion here.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 1. -- The political campaign in this State has opened in earnest. On the outcome depends the future of the National Democracy on the one hand, while the control of affairs in years to come by the Republicans is at stake on the other. The camp.tign of the National Democrats is well under way.

Although the art season proper will not open much before Nov. 1, as the dealers are still absent and the artists have pitched their easels through all the countryside to transfer the glories of the Autumn foliage to their canvases, there is already, even at this early day, much stir in art circles, which gives evidence that the season's opening is not far distant.

WEST POINT, Oct. 1. -- It was learned to-night that Mrs. Rivinius went to New York with a view to entering a hospital for treatment, expecting to stop with her sister, Mrs. Kayser, of 318 Pearl Street. Why she went to a hotel is a mystery.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Oct. 1. -- The National Society of Holland Dames of New Netherland and Knights of the Legion of the Crown held its first reception and conference to-night at the residence of Mrs. Leonard Fosdick. About 200 dames and knights were received by Mrs. Fosdick, assisted by her three daughters.

WHITE PLANS, N.Y., Oct. 1. -- The attendance at the Westchester County Horse Show and Fair to-day, while very large, was considerably smaller than yesterday. Thursday being always the star day for attendance.

It appears from an article in The Toronto Mail and Empire that some of our Canadian brethren are unduly excited over the prospect of the Yantic's advent in the waters of Lake Michigan. The Canadian Government's attention is invited to the fact that this powerful warship is to be placed upon the lake, and the journal referred to seems to hope that an official protest will at once be made.

PARIS, Sept. 13. -- The week has been given up to a discussion of the merits of Henri Murger, whose "Vie de Boheme" has been revived at the Comedie Francaise. The question has been enlarged into a general estimation of what Bohemianism in Paris amounted to, where it still exists, and what is the attitude that literary and artistic people should adopt toward it.

TRENTON, Oct. 1. -- In case the canvass of the votes cast at the election last Tuesday in New Jersey should show that the amendment relative to gambling was defeated there is every probability of an appeal to the courts. The friends of the amendment in Camden are firm in their resolve to push the matter there, and they expect that many ballots will be thrown out.

The first annual regatta of the First Division, Second Battalion of the New York Naval Militia, was held yesterday on Gravesend Bay. Arrangements for the third annual convention of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs are being made satisfactorily, and it is expected that Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday, Nov. 10, 11, and 12, will find a large and more interested body of club women gathered in Syracuse than has been seen at any of the previous conventions.

LONDON, Oct. 2. -- The managerial career of Mr. Fitzroy Gardner was auspiciously inaugurated at the Avenue Theatre this evening with a bill of three one-act plays. One of them was the musical fantasy, "The Mermaid," which, following the divers' scene in "The White Heather," represents the bottom of the sea.

James A. Bailey has decided to take "The Greatest Show on Earth" to London, where it will open at the Olympia Dec. 11. At the close of the Philadelphia engagement on Saturday the show will be taken to the Winter quarters at Bridgeport, Conn., where it will be put in order for the voyage to England.
RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 2. -- Major Lewis Ginter, the millionaire tobacco manufacturer, died shortly after 11 o'clock to-night at Westbrook, his country home, near this city.

The plant of the New Amsterdam Electric Light and Power Company, which is at the foot of South Ninth Street, Williamsburg, has been put into operation The company has wires laid along Broadway as far as Gates Avenue, and has already obtained contracts with many of the large business firms to light their buildings.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 2. -- The principal result of Yale's first football game of the season, that with Trinity at Hartford on Wednesday, is the proof that the New Haven University has, in the forty or more candidates for positions, the making of a really strong team. While the score of 10 to 0 is not a large one, there were only twenty-five minutes of actual playing time.

PORTLAND, Me., Oct. 2. -- Gen. Neal Dow, the "Grand Old Man in the Temperance Cause" died in this city at 3:30 o'clock this afternoon He had been critically ill for a fortnight. He retained the use of his mental faculties almost until the very last. His passing was peaceful, only once in his last moments did he speak; then he said, "I am very weary. I long to be free."

St. Stephen's congregation has purchased and will henceforth use the Transfiguration Chapel in West Sixty-ninth Street.

LONDON, Oct. 2. -- A special dispatch received here from Madrid says that Lieut. Gen. Weyler has been recalled from Cuba.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2. -- The bears ran the wheat market to-day, in spite of the help the bulls received from the drought. Paris was unaccountably very weak, and this encouraged the selling, which resulted in a decline of three-quarters to seven-eighths of a cent in December. Corn was firm and advanced one-eighth to one-quarter of a cent. Oats were unchanged at the close.
So many and so singular are the vagaries of the modern woman that one may say in sober truth. "These are the times that try men's souls."

HASTIERE, Belgium, Aug. 28. -- If you listen you will hear fifty little throats singing a French song. The throats belong to fifty little girls who are marching like soldiers, four abreast, over the railway track and down the road toward the mountain. They look as happy as larks, and sing louder than larks, though not quite as well.

Louis Gelben of 24 Delancey Street was arrested yesterday, charged with robbing his old friend and schoolmate, Max Silverman, of $3,064. Silverman came recently from Russia. His parents had just died and left him 68,000 rubles, and he came to America to invest his fortune. He found quarter's in a lodging house.

The first section of the Museum of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences was dedicated yesterday afternoon in the room to be used eventually as the sculpture gallery. A large number of representative citizens of Brooklyn were present, including the members of Grant Post, who attended in a body.

Incoming steamships yesterday reported very rough passages. Among them were the American Line steamship St. Paul, from Southampton; the Cunard Line steamship Etruria, from Liverpool and Queenstown, and the French Line steamship La Touraine, from Havre.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 2. -- The Orange Athletic Club opened its football season at the Orange Oval this afternoon in a game of two fifteen-minute halves with the Montclair Athletic Club team. The visitors were considerably lighter than the Orange men, but they succeeded in holding the home team down to ten points.

MAMMOTH HOT SPRINGS, Yellowstone Park, Wyoming, Sept. 26. -- Dr. W. Seward Webb of New York, President of the Wagner Palace Car Company, is still down in the Jackson Hole country hunting for big game. How long he will remain depends entirely on how soon he and his companions grow tired of their outing.

MADRID, Oct. 2. -- Senor Sagasta, the Liberal leader, has been intrusted by the Queen Regent with the task of forming a new Cabinet, in succession to the Azcarraga Ministry, which resigned on Wednesday last.
GOSHEN, N.Y., Oct. 2. -- The Orange County horse show closed to-day. Fifteen hundred people were in attendance. Following were the winners of first prizes:

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Oct. 2. -- The schooner Lizzie M. Stanwood arrived here this morning, having on board the crew of the shipwrecked schooner William Thomas, lumber-laden, bound from Calais, Me., to New Bedford, Mass. The shipwrecked men were Alexander Morrison, Captain; John Waitt, mate; Frank Porter and William Mullen, crew.

Will Man Wyck be withdrawn? is the question the Democratic leaders of the various Assembly districts are asking of Mr. Sheehan. If the rank and file of Tammany are consulted, he will be taken down inside the next few days. All day yesterday Mr. Sheehan listened to discouraging reports from the few men who visited Tammany Hall.

Miss Anna L. Bicknell, author of "Life in the Tuileries Under the Second Empire," contributes an article to the October Century on "Marie Antoinette as Dauphine." She has availed herself of new material from the State papers in Vienna, among which is an interesting document written by Marie Antoinette to her mother, Maria Theresa.

It is unfortunate that Mr. Mansfield and Mr. Willard should begin their New York engagements this season on the same night, especially as both have new plays -- Mr. Willard's, "The Physician," by Henry Arthur Jones, being new to this town, while Mr. Mansfield's, "The Devil's Disciple," by that distinguished Irish wit, cynic, vegetarian, and dress reformer.

Keith Wakeman, who will play a prominent part in "The Physician" at Wallack's to-morrow night, is a daughter of Capt. Ned Wakeman, who was identified with the development of the Pacific coast, and well known for many years as a commanding officer in the Pacific Mail fleet. Miss Wakeman's first stage experience was gained in the company of Edwin Booth.
From the September Educational Review.
The New Yorks closed the season as they began it, with a defeat at the hands of the Philadelphias.

READING, Penn., Oct. 2. -- The improvement in the iron industry in this section is very marked. In a few days the anthracite coal miners in the Reading Coal and Iron Company's thirty-five collieries will be paid their wages, 5 per cent. above the $2.50 basis, which will be the largest pay the men have received in a long time.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 2. -- Mrs. W.E. D. Stokes's much-talked-of negro ball came off to-night, according to programme, in her new ten-thousand-dollar barn, on the Patchen Wilkes Farm, three miles from this city.

The winning of the championship by Boston after three consecutive victories for Baltimore is of course the most striking event of the baseball season now closed. On June 1 Boston was only in fourth place, and owes its advance to steadier work than has been done by any of the other clubs. The finish was close enough to keep the interest up to the point of excitement.

Mrs. Louis Lutz, who was sleeping at her home, 2,220 Morris Avenue, at 2 o'clock yesterday morning, dreamed that the house was on fire. The dream was so vivid that she ran to the rear window. As she looked out she saw that the roof of the stable behind the house was a mass of crackling flames.
ITHACA, Oct. 2. -- Cornell defeated the Syracuse University team in the football game played on Percy Field to-day by a score of 16 to 0. The weather was fine and about 600 persons saw the game.
CHICAGO, Oct. 2. -- Mrs. Adrian C. Anson will give a dinner to the players of the Chicago Baseball Club, at the home of the Captain and manager, 163 East Thirtieth Street, londay evening.

ARDMORE, I.T., Oct. 2. -- Ten United States Deputy Marshals under Chief Stowe have started from here in hopes of capturing the bandits, news of whose bold robbery of a Rock Island passenger train yesterday near Chickasha was telegraphed East last night.

William P. Baird was in Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday charged, on complaint of Adolphe L. Audrain, a merchant of 261 Fifth Avenue, with maintaining a nuisance by his methods of delaying the work of laying mains on Fifth Avenue, for which work Baird is the contractor. Mr. Audrain had obtained a summons for the contractor on Thursday.

The native Hawaiian is a gentleman of leisure. Life to him is a perpetual holiday, and, as a native of paradise, why should he fret about the dull cares of this world? Nature has spread a bounteous feast for him, and, like Adam of old, he has only to pluck the fruit which grows without toil, eat, and breathe.

BERLIN, Oct. 2. -- The entire German press is speculating upon the new Naval bill which is now being considered by the Cabinet. Both Dr. Miquel, the Vice President of the Council of Ministers, and the Bundesrath have approved the measure, but before it reaches the Reichstag it may still be somewhat changed.

BOSTON, Oct. 2. -- The Middlesex Club met at Young's Hotel this afternoon and ratified the Republican State ticket. After addresses had been made by ex-Gov. Brackett and Lieut. Gov. Crane, Senator Henry Cabot Lodge was introduced. He spoke in part as follows.

It has been said again and again that New York is one of the most charitable cities in the world. This assertion bears upon its support of great public institutions, in which it is very rich indeed. But this city shares with the rest of the world that general distribution of charitable feeling which goes so far toward the alleviation of want and suffering.

SEATTLE, Washington, Oct. 2. -- The steamer Farrallon arrived here to-day from Skaguay, Alaska. The Farrallon had on board 110 returning prospectors, among the number being Louis Long, direct from Dawson City, which place he left Aug. 26, coming out on the Dalton trail. He stopped at Juneau. In an interview Mr. Long said:

The interest of lovers of harness racing was divided last week between Terre Haute and Readville, where two of the principal stake events of the year were decided. The Sidewheeler Stake of $5,000, for 2:18 pacers, which was on Tuesday's card at Terre Haute, resulted in a hard-fought contest of six heats, and was won finally by Sallie Toler.

Why should it be considered strange that an animal depending on its "nose" as much as the dog does should be able to distinguish one scent from another, when mankind can do the same to fully as delicate a degree? A friend of mine told me he could lean over a kettle of boiling glue stock (horrible smelling stuff) and distinguish any perfume from any other on a handkerchief.

SEVERAL months ago several dry goods merchants and some newspaper men identified with trade journalism decided that a new luncheon club was a necessity in the wholesale dry goods district. These gentlemen formed the nucleus of what is to-day the Dry Goods Club, with its elegantly appointed apartments in the sky-scraping Williams Building, southwest corner of Broadway and White Street.

A large proportion of the persons who attended the funeral services for Isaac Bell in the Church of the Transfiguration yesterday afternoon were venerable New Yorkers who had been associated with the dead philanthropist either in business or public affairs more than a quarter of a century ago. The Rev. Dr. George H. Houghton, rector of the church, although in ill health, conducted the services in token of affectionate regard for his old friend.

The interrogative or hypothetical method of hurling epithet and denunciation was employed with unusual success by Henry Yonge of the Brooklyn bar before Judge Dickey in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday. Tile target of the verbal bombardment was Mirabeau L. Towns, whose reply was direct and lacking in the florid ornamentation and fine imagination usually expected in the utterances of the poet lawyer of Kings County.

ONE of the prettiest towns within a hundred miles of New York is Morristown, N.J. A site of great natural beauty among the wooded hills of Morris County has been improved by every means which educated taste could suggest and unlimited money command, and the result is Morristown, which has been chosen by hundreds of families of wealth and social prominence, either as a Summer home or a permanent place of residence.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 2. -- A large number of golfers turned our on the links of the Morris County Golf Club to-day to play in the usual fortnightly competition for the Ballantine Silver Cup. Mrs. William Shippen, the woman champion of the club, won in fine style with a net score of 78. Her actual record of 105 established a new woman's record for the eighteen-hole course. Her score was:

ANNAPOLIS, Oct. 2. -- The Naval Cadet team lined up this afternoon for the first time against opposition players, the Hustlers, their scrub team, being the defending force. They proved very capable opponents, and it was only after an hour's play that the regular team was able to score, and that was when Powell crossed the line for a touchdown.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 2. -- Seventy-six contestants started from Cleveland in the big Cleveland-Pittsburg road race at 7:30 o'clock this morning. A crowd of fully 10,000 persons saw the start. The riders were composed of representatives of teams from Pittsburg, Cleveland, Buffalo, Akron, and Collinwood, Ohio.

Lieut. Robert E. Peary's ninety-ton meteorite, which was brought from the arctic regions in the hold of the steam Whaling vessel Hope, is now resting on solid earth at the Navy Yard in Brooklyn. It was taken out of the vessel at that place yesterday by the large floating derrick and landed on the ordnance wharf.

A remarkable change in weather conditions was the most noticeable feature yesterday morning, when the final contests in the Meadow Brook Club's open tournament, near Westbury, L.I., began. On the previous day the golfers were kept in a state of violent perspiration during their rounds over the links, but yesterday morning the cold breezes sweeping over the Westbury meadows were keenly suggestive of Winter, and the outlook was gloomy enough.

J M. BARRIE, who is powerful and strikingly original as a novelist, and as such ranks with the foremost in this era, is distinctly a minor dramatist. But his wit and humor serve him well in his playmaking, and he is never distressingly conventional, even when he follows the formulae of melodrama.

Half a dozen savings banks of this city were visited yesterday by a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES, and talks with officers of these institutions proved conclusively that the wave of improvement which has swept over the entire country is being substantially felt by the people in this vicinity.

WOULD the reader understand the cowboy and why he exults in his calling, let him read Mr. Hough's volume. Mr. Hough explains his condition in a single sentence, anthropological in its bearings: "He rises in the morning with his 'fists full of strength,' exulting in the sheer animal vigor of perfect health, the greatest blessing that can come to any man.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2. -- J. Frank Starbuck of Philadelphia this afternoon defeated "Jimmy" Michael, the "Welsh Wonder," in a twenty-five-mile paced race on the one-third-mile board track at Willow Grove by the narrow margin of six yards.

LONDON, Oct. 2. -- The theatrical season, which began so well, is not fulfilling expectations. Bad business is the rule at many theatres, and the managers are coming to the conclusion that there are too many places of amusement. The public is distracted by the multitude of attractions. The managers produce pieces which are universally praised.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Oct. 2. -- The report from Columbia, S.C., that ex-Congressman T.E. Miller (colored) contemplates bringing suit against Eastman College of this city for refusing admission to his daughter to take the college course was shown to President Clement C. Gaines of Eastman College to-day.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2. -- The first meeting of the City Council after the Summer's vacation makes it manifest that the majority of the Aldermen, like giants refreshed, are prepared to pursue their evil courses with unimpaired vigor. The leader of the gang crooked his finger, and by a majority vote the resolution to investigate the street railways in their relation to the city was postponed till Oct. 11.

The Republican City Committee yesterday met, and after an hour's conference in regard to the routine work of the organization, discussed the political situation for several hours. Previous to the meeting Mr. Platt was seen in regard to the situation, and asked whether Gen. Tracy would withdraw.

" I have accepted the nomination for Mayor," said Henry George last night, "and I am in the race to stay to the end. There is a great and growing movement in favor of the principles for which I stand, and I expect to be elected. Tammany is disintegrated and is falling to pieces.

There are probably few parents of those who know enough to realize how very little they know to whom teachers of their children are not sometimes a sore trial because of a certain overconfidence, a certain cockiness, in their mastery of what they call the "principles" of their profession.

The efforts of Mrs. Bertha Best, forty years of age, of 357 West Twenty-third Street to have an interview with Lawyer Irwin C. Stump of the firm of Stump Childs, in the Mills Building, have destroyed his peace of mind for some time. They culminated yesterday in an exciting scene at his office, which resulted in Mrs. Best's arrest and incarceration.

LONDON, Oct 2. -- The question, ironically asked by the Conservative press relative to the whereabouts of the Liberal leaders, has been answered in trip-hammer style during the past week by the speeches of John Morley, the former Chief Secretary for Ireland; H.H. Asquith, the former Home Secretary, and George W.E. Russell, former Under Secretary of State for India.

The announcement that Gen. WEYLER has been recalled from Cuba is so circumstantially made that it is difficult to doubt it. And yet it is a startling announcement. It is very likely, indeed it is inevitable, that a Liberal Spanish Premier, undertaking a new policy with respect to Cuba, should insist, as the very first step in such a policy, upon removing the most conspicuous representative of the old policy.
WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 2. -- This was the last day of the Westchester County Fair and Horse Show, and successfully ended a successful week, the attendance being good to the last.
Northern Georgians are so frightened over the yellow fever that some of the ignorant ones are eating dried tumblebugs' eyes as a "hoodoo" for the plague.

Plans are on foot for the opening of the new $3,000,000 hotel, the Astoria, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, which will take place on Nov. 1. The work of interior decoration is rapidly approaching completion, and on the opening day every room in the vast building will have been finished, and will be thrown open for inspection.

American newspaper readers are excusable if they have received of late an impression that next to the wheat crop the most notable product of this country this year has been homicide. The country is big, and it accords with reasonable expectation that in one part or another of it killing should be in progress all the time.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- Ex-Gov. Hoadly, counsel for the United States in the matter of the Union Pacific Railway foreclosure sale, spent several hours to-day in close conference with Attorney General McKenna arranging the details of the sale on Nov. 1 and the subsequent transfer of the Government's interest in the property to the highest bidder.

Upon this bare plain, devoid as it is of cover, it is hopeless to attempt a stalk, and indeed at all times these wary and suspicious creatures are not easily to be approached on foot. It is not long before some of the hartebeest have got the hunters' wind. These, early alarmed, lose no time in cantering steadily off at a right angle, and are presently lost to sight.

BERLIN, Oct. 2. -- The flattering attentions paid the Czar during his recent visit to Warsaw, and the rumors of an improvement in the political status of the Poles subsequent thereto, are brought into connection with the revolt of the Slav-speaking Bohemians against the assumptions of the Germans in Austria.

PRINCETON, Oct. 2. -- The football season at Princeton was opened this afternoon in a one-sided but exciting game between the Tigers and Lehigh, in which the lusty sons of old Nassau smothered the Pennsylvanians by a score of 43 to 0 in two hard-fought fifteen-minute halves. Lehigh showed unexpected weakness and a comparatively light team, and the Tigers' work loomed up in contrast.

The commission representing the Indianapolis Monetary Convention of last January has now settled down to its work. Our reports from all parts of the country are that business men, regardless of political divisions, are earnest in the support of this movement for a sound and stable currency.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- The British Blue Book on the Bering Sea issue was received here to-day, and was scanned with interest by the few officials to whom it became available, owing to the controversy on the subject, in which not only this country and Great Britain, but also Russia and Japan, have taken part.

I am unable to trace any reliable evidence of English watches having been made until quite the end of the sixteenth century, although German and French productions were imported earlier. Derham, in the second edition of his "Artificial Clockmaker," published in 1700, mentions an eight-day watch which he was told belonged to Henry VIII.
From "Indian Gup." The Rev. J.R. Baldwin.

A first view of the mural paintings executed by Mr. E.H. Blashfield and Mr. C.Y. Turner, respectively, for the ceiling of the ballroom and the frieze of the restaurant of the new Astoria Hotel, was given in the galleries of the Fine Arts Building, 215 West Twenty-seventh Street, yesterday afternoon and evening.

The Conference Committee of the Citizens' Union has completed the ticket for Greater New York and the County of New York. The ticket will be presented to the Executive Committee to-morrow, and if acceptable to it will be made public at the meeting of the Organization Committee, which meets in Hardman's Hall to-morrow night at 8 o'clock.

BOULDER, Col., Oct. 2. -- Prof. Guy V. Thompson, formerly a member of the Yale Faculty, and a prominent educator, died here to-day of consumption. He was married to former Ambassador Uhl's daughter, at Berlin, in January, 1896.

Because of a combination of circumstances a plain but observant citizen learned much a few nights ago of the actual internal working of the Police and Fire Departments of this city and of their relations with each other, and found himself exalted to remarkable heights of temporary but glorious glory.

The Kings County Democratic Convention, held in the Jefferson Building, Brooklyn, last night, was a scene of such turbulence and disorder that at one time the Chairman threatened to have the gallery cleared. Long before the convention was called to order there was such a babel of noise from the gallery that delegates could not hear each other speak.

Two old Westchester County churches which in the long-gone days of their youth and weakness, while this country was yet new, used to help each other despite denominational differences, will during October celebrate the attainment of age which is vigorous while venerable. They are the First Reformed Protestant Dutch Church of Tarrytown and the Presbyterian Church of White Plains.

Getaway day at Gravesend was productive of some of the liveliest racing of the year. While none of the cracks of the year was on the programme, still the events were well filled, and brought out fine finishes. The weather conditions were perfect for racing, for there was an Autumn sting in the air that caused the blood to circulate, and topcoats were in demand.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Oct. 2. -- A well- dressed young man with a pleasing address, who gave his name as Harry Reed, went to the store of W.H. Aldrich, a bicycle dealer of this place, yesterday afternoon and hired a tandem machine. He rode away to Amityville on it, and there called on King Brothers, bicycle dealers, and offered to sell it to them for $20.

The cotton platform at the gates of the cotton warehouse and compresses on the banks of the Savannah River, by the Charleston and Western Carolina Railroad, is the largest in the world, being 1,700 feet long and 40 feet wide, covering an area of 68,000 square feet.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- In order to relieve apprehension caused by the notice of the loss of one of their ships bound for the Klondike, the Northwestern Transportation Company has telegraphed the War Department here that the last vessel, the schooner Kuenema, did not carry passengers.

As the first of a series of pamphlets descriptive of the methods used in conducting and governing the different administrative departments of the City of New York, the City Club has caused to be issued a treatise on "The Recent Administration of the Department of Public Works."

The handsome edifice at the northeast corner of Eighty-sixth Street and West End Avenue, the new temple of the St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church, was formally opened yesterday morning with a service of dedication. It was the first of several dedicatory exercises during the present week, and to include one on Sunday, Oct. 10.

The twenty-first season of the National League came to a close yesterday after one of the most successful campaigns on record. The fight between the Bostons and the Baltimores was a struggle of giants, and the best club won. A decision was not reached until the very last.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 3. -- The "Browns" and Chieagos divided honors to-day in the two games they played. The home team voon the first game by batting Grifiith hard in the closing innings In the second game Thornton "fooled" the home team badly. The game was called on account of dark-nuss at the end of the seventh inning. Score:

The American people showed by the way they voted at the election last Fall that they want good money. We want all to be worth 100 cents on a dollar wherever the stream of civilized exchange flows. This feeling is certainly most commendable. But while we want good money we are inexcusably complacent in the use of filthy money.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 3. -- Capt. William O. Perry and a crew of five men were rescued to-day from the dismasted schooner Henry May of Portland, Me., bound from Newport News to Portland with piling.

Golfers are now having all the excitement and fun which they want in their favorite game, for the season of open tournaments is at its height, and for over two months there will be no cessation of activity. Meadow Brook was the big attraction last week, and St. Andrew's will demand the attention of golfers this week.
The admirers of college football have already begun to figure on the chances of their favorite teams in the big games that are to be played this Autumn.
DENVER, Col., Oct. 3. -- Receiver Trumbull of the Union Pacific, Denver and Gulf Railroad has returned from New York City, where he attended a meeting of the Reorganization Committee. He said to-day:

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Oct. 3. -- The prairie fire which raged all over the country yesterday, being fanned and driven by a gale of wind, died out during the night, having left a path of death and devastation. Farmhouses, implements, crops, and live stock were everywhere consumed and many farmers lost their all.
NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 3. -- Twenty-seven cases of yellow fever were reported to-day and two deaths.

LONDON, Oct. 3. -The condition of the money market the past week was uneventful. Further gold shipments to the United States are not expected. Discounts are steady, and bar silver Is l/ld. per ounce higher, with a small speculative demand.

The coming of "the public" into Wall Street is not an unmixed blessing. It makes brisk trading and broadens the range of transactions. It runs the Stock Exchange sales up to three-quarters of a million shares a day. But it makes a market that yields like putty to the rumor-monger and the raiding bear. It invites reactions and "slumps" that affect unfavorably the business of the entire community and country.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3. -- Dr. W.C. Gray, editor of The Interior, declares that the Presbyterian Church is lagging behind other denominations, and has lost its great birthright because of fighting among its members. The Doctor calls upon the Church to throw aside the "weight of austere and forbidding philosophies" that hamper it in its work, and in the coming century to stop bickering over creed non-essentials and show greater results in distinct religious service.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- Secretary Wilson of the Department of Agriculture recently, after a consultation with the Chief of the Weather Bureau, decided to make use of some of the great fund of meteorological information contained in the Weather Bureau by having a monthly marine meteorological chart issued for the benefit of the mariners of the Great Lakes.
Democratic Council Conventions to nominate three Councilmen each in the Sixth, Seventh, and Eighth Districts, Brooklyn.

People flocked from all parts of the city yesterday to "The Little Church Around the Corner," formally known as the Church of the Transfiguration, in Twenty-ninth Street, near Fifth Avenue. The occasion was the forty-ninth anniversary of the founding of the parish by the Rev. George C. Houghton, D.P.
LONDON, Oct. 4. -- The Madrid correspondent of The Standard says:

Several of the booth managers at the late Irish Fair having been dilatory in making their financial statements to the Board of Trustees of the Irish Palace Building Fund, a meeting of the latter was held at the Morton House, Broadway and Fourteenth Street, yesterday in order to expedite matters. Gen. James R. O'Beirne presided and Edward O'Flaberty acted as Secretary.

The biggest century run which ever started from New York City, and the second largest on record, was that of the Firemen's Cycle Club, held yesterday. The fire laddies expected that three or four hundred wheelmen would take part, but 780 entered.

SCHUYLER, Neb., Oct. 3. -- A physician was called to-day to the home of Frank Davis, nine miles from here, to attend members of the family who had been poisoned. The doctor found four of the seven children in the family and their mother dead, a fifth child in a dying condition, and a sixth victim very ill.

There has been much speculation as to why Tammany has put up so weak and poor a ticket and why the Platt machine, with so formidable an opposition among decent Republicans, has made so stubborn a resistance to the Citizens' movement.

Mr. Russell Sage is in no wise discouraged by the recent reaction. He says it has gone far beyond its legitimate limits.

Mr. C. WOOD DAVIS contributes to the current number of The Forum a very interesting paper under the title of "The Impending Deficiency of Breadstuffs." His thesis is that the demand for bread is increasing at a much greater rate than the supply; that already the supply is insufficient to the requirements of consumption, and that the insufficiency threatens to increase.

Mr. Low has become a unifying force among the friends of good government. They are with him, heart and soul, the men of all parties and of none who have more pride in a well-governed city than in a successful party. He has brought them together. The conditions imposed in his June letter visibly exist.

The address of President ELIOT of Harvard University at the dedication of the completed portion of the Brooklyn Institute Building on Saturday was, as his addresses are sure to be, able and pertinent. His subject was "Democratic Education," and he defined what the education of a democracy should be to fit the conditions a democracy imposes.

Calvary Baptist Church, in West Fifty-seventh Street, was thronged to the doors last night when the pastor, the Rev. Robert S. MacArthur, delivered the first of a series of sermons on the Bible and its interpretation.

The Executive Committee of the United German-American Societies held a meeting yesterday afternoon in the Teutonia. Assembly Rooms, at Third Avenue and Sixteenth Street, Chairman Adam Keller presiding at the meeting. The purpose of the meeting was to receive a report from the sub-committee appointed at a previous meeting held by delegates representing 105 different German-American societies to present to the Tammany Hall leaders resolutions favoring the nomination of William Sohmer for Mayor.

Romeo Weisenberg, eleven years old, became violently insane yesterday afternoon at the home of his parents, 153 Ludlow Street, from constantly brooding over his inability to get into one of the public schools, and was taken to Bellevue Hospital and placed in a ward.

Seth Low, after formally opening the one hundred and forty-fourth academic year of Columbia in its new home, near One Hundred and Sixteenth Street and Amsterdam Avenue, yesterday morning, attended a meeting of the Board of Trustees of the University at 63 Wall Street, in the afternoon, and submitted his resignation as President of the institution.

Regular followers of the racing circuit in the vicinity of New York who attended the midsummer meeting of the Queens County Jockey Club at Aqueduct, were greatly surprised yesterday when they reached the track. At the midsummer meeting there were long lines of empty seats in the grand stand, and the chairs in the betting ring were occupied by strangers, to whom the general public hesitated to intrust their money.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct, 4. -- Thousand of visitors are pouring into the city fronl every direction, to attend the Fall festivities connected 'lth the annul event ou Pallas Athene and her attendant priests. Carnival week proper will open to-morrow, with a parade o, gorgeously decorated floats, and will be followed every day during the week with a suucesion of special events.

But for all practical purposes the earlier removal was much the more radical departure.
