TACOMA, Oct. 4. -- The steamship Victoria, which arrived at Tacoma on Sunday, brings details of the severe storm that prevailed over Japan last month and attained the form of a typhoon.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 4. -- John J. Shipherd, the local capitalist and member of the firm of Charles H. Potter Co., was arrested this morning by Constable Hudson of Justice Bauder's court. The warrant, which charges him with embezzlement, was issued on allegations sworn to by Frank De Haas Robison.

The Committee on Organization of the Citizens' Union, acting as a nominating convention, met last night in Hardman Hall and selected candidates for the various city and county offices other than that of Mayor, to complete the ticket headed by Seth Low. There was much enthusiasm, and every reference to Seth Low was warmly cheered.

TRENTON, Oct. 4. -- The Canvassing Boards of the twenty-one counties of New Jersey met to-day and went over the returns of the constitutional amendment election of last Tuesday. The work was completed in every county except Hudson, where one town did not turn in the record in proper shape, and the returns had to be sent back for correction by the local board.

-- Now that "OSMAN DIGNA is retiring on Khartoum" one gets once more the pleasure of knowing that the Soudan campaign is to be conducted on the good old lines, and the more enterprising of our contemporaries can get advance information of an absolutely accurate character from the scene of operations by the simple process of going through their own files for 1896, 1884, or almost any old year they choose to select.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 4. -- It is probable that when Sam Jones opens his big revival at Henderson, Ky., Oct. 14, he will be assisted musically by thirty-five women members of the Marie Bell Opera Company. The troupe will be in Henderson that day, and Frank Small, its manager, has offered Mr. Jones the use of his singers' voices for the occasion.
Organization Republicans persist in the assertion that Gen. TRACY will not withdraw. Why not?

BOSTON, Oct. 4. -- The new champions won the first game for the Temple Cup to-day, defeating the Baltimores in a close contest more through a combination of lucky hits and daring base running, assisted by darkness in the last two innings, than by any great superiority of play. Neither team showed championship form, while the work of the home team was at times very much below the mark.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., Oct. 4. -- A big sea puss caught a pound boat off this place this morning and swamped it. Four men were drowned. Their three mates were saved. The drowned men were:

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4. -- The three days' cricket match begun on Friday last between a picked eleven of Philadelphia amateurs and Capt. Warner's English amateur team was concluded to-day, and resulted in a victory for the Englishmen, with seven wickets to spare.

Two hundred and ten delegates attended the convention of the United Democracy of Kings County, in the Atheneum, Atlantic Avenue and Clinton Street, Brooklyn, last night, for the purpose of nominating candidates for county offices. The ticket agreed upon finally was as follows:
For President of the Borough of Brooklyn -- FREDERIC W. HINRICHS.

-- Spain, as is well known -- especially in Wall Street -- is so haughty a nation that she would eagerly risk her existence in a war with the United States rather than undergo the humiliation of our interference in Cuba; but she is also so wise a nation, it seems, that she will do of her own accord about what we desire, and so avoid the necessity of backing up her pride.

John N. Golding has sold for Sidney Dillon Ripley and Robert Maclay, trustees, to a client of D.E. Seybel, the plot on the north side of Seventy-sixth Street, 120 feet east of Fifth Avenue, 50 by 100. It is understood that the buyer will erect a handsome residence on the site.
BUENOS AYRES, Oct. 4. -- The Argentine Congress has just passed a law imposing a tax of 1 centavo, gold, per ton register on vessels entering the port of Buenos Ayres.

Notwithstanding the efforts of Henry George and of the committee of his friends who are trying to bring about the formation of a union ticket on his behalf, he may find it necessary to run on three separate tickets.

The theatrical programme was exceptionally brilliant last night in the matter of novelties. Two of the plays then acted for the first time in this country were found to be serious works of unusual merit. One of them, "The Devil's Disciple," produced by that gifted and original dramatic artist, Richard Mansfield, at the Fifth Avenue Theatre, had never been acted on any stage.

Magistrate Hedges, in Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday heard testimony for the prosecution on the complaint of Adolphe L. Audrain, a dealer in bric-a-brac at 265 Fifth Avenue, against William P. Baird, whom he charges with maintaining a public nuisance on Fifth Avenue, while laying a water main there under contract with the city.

President Warner Van Norden of the National Bank of North America talked yesterday to a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES regarding the general business and financial outlook. Mr. Van Norden is confident of continued improvement, believing that the United States have head of them many years of substantial prosperity. He said:

In the current number of The North American Review Mr. CHARLES H. CRAMP writes with an array of interesting statistics on "The Coming Sea Power." According to him, that is Japan, and if he had begun the title of his paper with the indefinite instead of the definite article, no one would have had reason to disagree with him.

Edith Baker, seventeen years old, lives with her parents on the outskirts of Yonkers. On Sunday night she and her sister, thirteen years old, attended church, and, while going home on a lonely thoroughfare, a strange man accosted them. The girls ran, and the younger one escaped, but the man grabbed Edith.
LONDON, Oct. 4. -- Abram S. Hewitt of New York, speaking to-day of the political situation in New York, said:

At the executive session of the Park Board yesterday, a resolution was introduced by President McMillan and carried by him and Commissioner Cruger, against the vote of Commissioner Ely, approving the plans of the Rapid Transit Commission for a railroad route. The resolution is as follows:

It is chronicled with great gravity that H.R.H. the Prince of WALES has a new hat. This is good to hear, not because his royal highness needs a new hat -- his every-day one is good enough to last him till Christmas -- but because there are so many young men in this country who have more money than hats.

The Republican campaign will begin Friday night at a mass meeting in Cooper Union. Ex-President Benjamin Harrison will, it is expected, either preside or deliver an address, and Senator Joseph B. Foraker of Ohio has been invited also to speak. Addresses will be made by Gen. Benjamin F. Tracy, Ashbel P. Fitch, and R. Ross Appleton, nominees, respectively, for Mayor, Controller, and President of the Council.

The chief matter of public interest which came before the semi-annual meeting of the New York Presbytery yesterday was the appeal of Hermann Warszawiak from the judgment of the session of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, which on June 17 suspended him from the communion of the church.
CHICAGO, Oct. 4. -- The seventh week of the trial of Luetgert, the alleged wife murderer, opened to-day with an undiminished crush of people at the Criminal Court building.

It is more than likely that John C. Sheehan, leader of Tammany Hall, will resign his position to-day. For more than two hours yesterday it was undecided whether Mr. Sheehan would resign or not. He wished to do so, and stood ready to tender his resignation to the Executive Committee.

Slawson Hobbs have sold, for Mortimer Fargo, President of the American Express Company, to Mrs. Alice M. Allen, for $20,000, the three-story dwelling, with extension, 249 West Seventy-first Street, 17 by 56 by 102.2.
ATHENS, Oct. 5. -- The Boule met to-day, but its proceedings attracted little interest.
LONDON, Oct. 5. -- The condition of Edward Langtry, the former husband of Lily Langtry, the actress, is the same this morning as when he was admitted yesterday into the Asylum for the Insane.

The entire capital stock was voted yesterday at the annual meeting of the stockholders of the Northern Pacific Railway Company, and this Board of Directors was elected: Edward D. Adams, Charles H. Coster, D. Willis James, Oliver H. Payne, Robert M. Gallaway, Eben B. Thomas, John G. Moore, Charles S. Mellen, Francis Lynde Stetson, Daniel S. Lamont, Samuel Spencer, Dumont Clarke, Brayton Ives, James Stillman, and Walter G. Oakman.

About fifteen members of the Westchester Hunt Club took part yesterday afternoon in the first meet of a series to be held this month over a good stretch of steeplechase country outside of New Rochelle. It was a propitious day for a ride after the hounds, and the hunt was a great success in every particular.
Papers have been filed in a breach of promise case involving two women and a man, whose combined ages are 197 years.

MADRID, Oct. 5. -- Senior Moret, the Minister for the Colonies, it is semi-officially announced, has decided to apply so soon as possible all the measures which are comprised in the programme of the Liberals regarding the Antilles, including all that is necessary for the application of autonomy for Cuba, in the form permitted by the circumstances.
The Democrats of Kings County last night nominated the following candidates for the Assembly and for Aldermen of Greater New York:...
The position of the organization Republicans is politically impossible and tactically absurd.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- The October term of the United States Supreme Court will begin next Monay. There are now 466 cases on the docket as against 616 at the beginning of the October term in 1896, of which 383 came over from the last term and 83 have been added during the court's vacation.

Members of the committee of Amsterdam Avenue property owners who are opposing the laying of four street railway tracks in that avenue, have made some measurements which satisfy them that the new underground trolley tracks of the Metropolitan Street Railway are not being laid according to the specifications. The permit granted by the Department of Public Works limits the method of doing the work to the specific plans filed.

PRINCETON, Oct. 5. -- Ex-President Grover Cleveland will deliver an address on Oct. 22 at the celebration of the one hundred and fifty-first anniversary of the granting of the charter to Princeton University. Prior to the sesquicentennial of last year, no celebration had ever marked the day, but it is the intention of the Trustees and Faculty to give this celebration a regular place in the academic calendar.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- In the Cabinet to-day the Spanish-Cuban situation was considered in a desultory way, in connection with a cablegram received from Minister Woodford, announcing the formation of the new Sagasta Cabinet. The cablegram, however, contained no new information, and the discussion was largely in the nature of comment and an exchange of views as to the effect of the change of Government in Spain on the Cuban situation.

Certain heaven-born financiers are now flooding the country with their eloquence and erudition on questions of finance, and are particularly addressing persons who live by their labor as to the great blessings they will enjoy in case our Government would ever adopt the free coinage of silver at the ratio of 16 to 1.
The Republican machine leaders are trying to use Mr. HENRY GEORGE as a "spectre." Let us see what that amounts to.

TACOMA, Washington, Oct. 5. -- The steamer Victoria brings news of the most disastrous floods that have visited China for many years. Sixty villages near Tung Chou, containing over 80,000 inhabitants, have been destroyed by floods, and the people drowned or forced to flee. There is no means of finding out how many thousands have been drowned, but the number is estimated by Chinese authorities at from 15,000 to 20,000.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 5. -- Harvard's tennis players met with disappointment here this morning. When the drawings in the intercollegiate tennis tournament were announced it was found that they were all drawn in the first half of the matches, bringing the three crimson representatives together as soon as the first round was played.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5. -- Extremely hot weather for the month of October is now prevailing in this section. In the last twenty-four hours the thermometer in this city went up to 86, and, according to the Signal Service records, this is the highest point that has been registered for the month of October in twenty-seven years.

At the session of the Aldermen yesterday afternoon the report of the Law Committee upon the proposed amendment to the section of the rules of the road compelling vehicles, licensed trucks excepted, to display lights after dark was postponed one week, in view of the absence of Alderman Lantry who opposed the existing section.

Cooper Union never held a larger assembly within its walls than that on which Charles O'Conor Hennessy looked down when he came to the front of the platform to nominate the Chairman of the meeting. Not alone was every seat occupied, but men and even women stood twenty deep around the walls, and every aisle was full in spite of the spasmodic efforts of the police to keep them clear.

LONDON, Oct. 5. -- The news from the Indian frontier is favorable. Sir William Lockhart's forces will commence the advance on Tirah, the Summer headquarters of the Afridis and the Oralzais, from Peshawur on Friday next, moving in three columns. Sir William Lockhart and Major Gen Lord Methuen have already arrived at Kohat.

ALBANY, Oct. 5. -- The Court of Appeals has decided against "Riley" Grannan in his suit against the Westchester Racing Association, whose Board of Stewards disbarred him from the track. Grannan was accused of giving $500 to Jockey Taral, in violation of the rules of the New York Jockey Club, and was ruled off the track.
-- Pittsburg is a city where, more than almost anywhere else, the citizens must take frequent and thorough baths if they are to retain either the semblance or the substance of respectability, ...

ALBANY, Oct. 5. -- The wedding of Miss Alice Martin, niece of Mr. and Airs. Bradley bIartin, and daughter of Henry T. Martin, to Benjamin ...lcAlpin, son of Gen. Edwin A. MeAlpln, is to be one of the notable events of the early Fall.

The district organizations of the Citizens' Union have completed their nominations for Aldermen, members of the Municipal Council, and Civil Justice. Only nine independent nominations for Assemblymen have been made; in the remainder of the districts the ticket will be filled out by indorsement.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 5. -- Charles E. Wilson, the Governor's private secretary, in the absence of the Governor, has spent the greater part of to-day trying to make it plain that there is no occasion for alarm over the quarantine steps taken by the State officials yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA Oct. 5- At a meeting of the Executive Committee og the National Municipal League, held here to-day, the Mayoralty campaign in New York was discussed and a sub-committee was appointed to arrange a plan to promote the election of Seth Low.

The Detective Bureau and the police of the West Thirtieth Street Station have not in a long time been confronted with such a case as they are working on now. In it are elements that point to the handiwork of professional burglars, while others seem to indicate mere tyros of a decidedly convivial disposition.

At the annual meeting yesterday of the Clearing House Association, J. Edward Simmons, President of the Fourth National Bank, who presided, was re-elected President of the association. Stuart G. Nelson, Vice President of the Seaboard National Bank, was re-elected Secretary. William Sherer and William J. Gilpin, manager and assistant manager, were reappointed.
The time within which the Rapid Transit Commission is to make its report has been extended by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court until Nov. 8.

The letter of Corporation Counsel Scott declining to appear for the Board of Aldermen at the hearing on the injunction to restrain them from granting the King's Bridge franchise was read at the meeting of the board yesterday afternoon. Alderman Goodman introduced a resolution authorizing John Jeroloman to act as counsel.

CROOKSTON, Minn., Oct. 5. -- It was announced here to-day that work will be commenced this week on the Great Northern direct line from Duluth to Red River Valley, connecting with its transcontinental line at Grand Forks and giving the great wheat fields in this section and the Dakotas practically an outlet to tidewater.

Argument was heard before Board A of United States General Appraisers yesterday on the numerous protests by importers against the Treasury Department's retroactive interpretation of the new tariff law. Ex-Judge Henderson M. Somerville presided, and more than a score of New York and Boston importers either were present or were represented by counsel.

The new Spanish Ministry is for the most part made up of names unfamiliar outside of Spain itself. Senor SAGASTA has for a great many years been the acknowledged and indeed unchallenged leader of the Spanish Liberals. In Parliamentary adroitness and political experience he has, since the death of CANOVAS DEL CASTILLO, no rival, and he, in fact, "imposed himself" upon the Queen Regent when the competition was closed by the assassin's bullet.

Richard Croker has again openly assumed absolute control of Tammany Hall, and from this time on will direct in detail the fight of Justice Robert Van Wyck and the other candidates on the Democratic ticket.

The people of San Diego, Southern California, are much exercised over the proposal to appropriate $2,900,000 of the National funds for the construction of a deep water harbor at San Pedro. The arguments which they advance against the scheme are direct and cogent, and unless there is some good argument on the other side -- which does not appear -- they ought to be convincing.

Republican County Chairman Lemuel E. Quigg appeared before the Woman's Republican Union League, in the Johnston Building, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, in defense of the present position of of the Republican Party of this city. A good part of the League is in favor of straight Republicanism, and it showed due appreciation of the honor of Mr. Quigg's visit, but there happened to be a vigorous sprinkling of Low sympathizers in the audience also.

At a mass meeting in Cooper Union last evening Henry George formally accepted the nomination for Mayor of Greater New York, formally offered to him by the representatives of four Democratic factions, united as the Jeffersonian Democracy.

Some of the offices to be contested for at the coming election are in themselves rich enough to furnish a comfortable fortune for the incumbent during the term of office. Not alone are the pecuniary rewards large, but the amount of patronage attached to the county places is so extensive that in each case it would be a sufficient prize to a wideawake politician without the salaries or fees of the place.
LONDON, Oct 5. -- Prof. Francis William Newman, the author and philosopher, is dead.

ALBANY, Oct. 5. -- The Court of Appeals has decided against John B. Doris in his appeal from an adverse decision upon his application for an injunction restraining the New York police from interfering with and prohibiting the production of the play called "Orange Blossoms." The play was alleged to be immoral.

What is commonly regarded as the most solemn day of the year to followers of the Jewish faith was ushered in at sundown yesterday, when Yom Kippur, or Yom Norah, the Day of Atonement -- sometimes called the Great White Fast -- began.

The electors of New York never deliberately vote like lunatics when the nominating conventions offer them the choice of voting like sane men. They have rarely put unworthy men in the Mayor's chair, and then only when they were honestly deceived or had but a choice of evils.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 5. -- The twenty-fifth annual meeting of the Kentucky Trotting Horse Breeders' Association began here to-day. The attendance was large, every State being represented by leading breeders and track managers. The track was good without being especially fast.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5. -- The defense in the Luetgert murder trial rested its case today, after two witnesses had testified. Luetgert did not go on the witness stand in his, own behalf. His counsel feared to call him, and he reluctantly accepted their advice.

HAVANA, Oct. 5. -- The retiring Minister for the Colonies, Senior Castellanos, sent an official cable message yesterday to Gen. Weyler, notifying the latter of the formation of a new Spanish Cabinet, under the Presidency of Senior Sagasta, the Liberal leader, and bidding farewell to the Spanish authorities, clergy, army, volunteers, and loyal inhabitants of Cuba.

GLENVILLE, West Va., Oct. 6. -- The trial of Mrs. Atkinson was resumed to-day. The preliminary proceedings were begun and a jury sworn The trial opened with the reading of the indictment, which charges Mrs. Atkinson and Joshua P. Owens, a prominent farmer, with being jointly engaged in a felonious uttering of certain receipts alleged to be forged.

What was scheduled to be the greatest three days' voting contest in the history of New York politics began on Tuesday evening at 9 o'clock in the convention of the Republicans of the Eleventh Judicial District, at 201 West One Hundred and Thirty-fourth Street.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 6. -- Another large crowd witnessed the second day's sport at the meeting of the Kentucky Trotting Horse Breeders' Association. The weather was perfect and the track fast. The event of the day was the five-thousand-dollar Futurity, for two-year-olds, won in record-breaking time by Janie T., by Bow Beils, dam Nida, dam Leone, who held the yearling race record of 2:28 1/4 in 1892. Janie T. won in straight heats. Summary:
Richard Van Cott, son of Postmaster Cornelius Van Cott, has sold the family residence, 77 Washington Place, a four-story brick dwelling, on a plot 22 by 97.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 6. -- The eleventh annual convention of the New Jersey Christian Endeavor Union, which began in this city this afternoon, is marked by the decoration of every Protestant church in this city. Orange and black bunting distributed throughout the city marks a regular pathway from the several stations to the Young Men's Christian Association Building on Ellison Street, which is the headquarters of the Endeavorers.

ALBANY, Oct. 6. -- The Court of Appeals to-day heard arguments in a case which has "hung fire" before judicial tribunals in this State for nearly twenty years, and which not only involves a claim for damages of $150,000, but also develops interesting history concerning the establishing of the station of the Central Hudson Railroad Company in Yonkers.

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 6. -- The Democratic County Convention was held here this afternoon for the purpose of nominating candidates for Sheriff and Coroner, the only county offices to be filled in the coming election. Daniel Warren of Rye was made permanent Chairman. John J. Broderick of Yonkers was nominated for Sheriff after a big fight. There were six aspirants for the nomination.

President Isaac B. Potter of the League of American Wheelmen held a conference with the Directors of the College Point Ferry Company, which operates between East Ninety-ninth Street and College Point, yesterday relative to the toll exacted of wheelmen. To Mr. Potter's request that the company should carry wheels free, they urged that their boats had six-mile trip and for nine months of the year were almost idle.

LAPORTE, Ind., Oct. 6. -- There is fear that the town of Wilders, this county, will fall prey to the fires that are raging. The entire population of the Kankakee region has turned out to fight the fires that are extending in every direction. Fire is also raging in the marshes east of this city and loss of property is threatened. The loss in the different counties is estimated at $75,000.

LONDON, Oct. 6. -- Charles Wyndham produced "The Liars," a new four-act comedy by Henry Arthur Jones, at the Criterion Theatre this evening. The play was received with every mark of favor and promises to be a great success.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- President Nick Young of the National Basebaal League has made public the list of players reserved by the League clubs for the season of 1898 as follows:

The regular monthly meeting of the Merchants and Manufacturers' Board of Trade was held at 241 Fifth Avenue last night. C.C. Shayne presided, and nearly 100 members were present. The report submitted at the meeting showed that the association is in excellent condition. One hundred and thirty members joined it during the last month, making the total more than 400.

ST. MICHAEL, Oct. 6. -- Six men have probably lost their lives here as the result of a foolhardy attempt to sail up the 1,850 miles of river, which in some places runs down at the rate of eight miles an hour. The men, two of whom are named Abercrombie and Tate, were last seen drifting out of the mouth of the Yukon to sea in distress.

Mr. Croker's assumption of the control of Tammany Hall, from all appearances, seems to have had an opposite effect than that intended. Instead of the hall being crowded, as it is generally the day before a convention, yesterday a few of the faithful were the only occupants of the room the greater part of the day.

RIO JANEIRO, Oct. 6. -- Canudos, the stronghold of the fanatics under Antonio Conselheiro, has fallen. It has been captured by the Government troops after a desperate engagement with the revolutionists. Antonio Conselheiro has been taken prisoner.

The Supreme Court's Rapid Transit Commissioners have now heard the testimony of the only two men in the United States who have had practical experience in constructing subways like the one proposed for this city.
MILES CITY, Mon., Oct. 6. -- The Maqueen I-Iotel was burned last night. Loss, $50,000. [ JAi%{ESTOWN, N. Y., Oct. (. -- Flr. e this. morning caused a loss of about $5,000 in The [ Journal office. [

This community has experienced a noteworthy loss in the death of WILLIAM A. STILES. Until three years ago Mr. STILES was scarcely known at all to the general public. To the special public which is interested in horticulture and arboriculture he was known as the editor of Garden and Forest, the most influential and authoritative periodical in those specialties that has been established in this country.

For the first time in a career of much utterance Mr. GEORGE'S utterances are vague. It is in vain that friend or foe (if he has any foes) will search his speech of Tuesday night to find one clear statement of a single specific doctrine, or purpose, or desire.
NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 6. -- Thirty-eight new cases of yellow fever were reported today, and five deaths. These figures break the record.
HAVANA, via Key West, Fla., Oct. 6. -El Dlario de la Marina, the organ of the Reform Party, commenting on the new Spanish Cabinet, in its leading editorial to-day, says:

DULUTH, Minn., Oct. 6. -- Forest and prairie fires are raging in Southern Manitoba, near the North Dakota line, and many fatalities are supposed to have occurred, together with heavy property loss to the settlers. Seven lives are known to have been lost, while several persons are missing.

Taking advantage of the issues which the Henry George movement has raised, the Republican Campaign Committee is now making preparations for a fight along National lines and of Presidential year magnitude. The most prominent men in party affairs have been, or will be, invited to take the stump for Gen. Tracy.

If the size of the crowds which have attended the meeting at Aqueduct since it opened on Monday can be taken as an indication of the success or failure of the meeting, from a financial standpoint there will be enough money in the treasury when the meeting closes to build the new grand stand and make the other improvements contemplated for next Fall.

For the second time this week Cooper Union was packed last night by a monster mass meeting. Only an inspection of the audience revealed any marked difference from the crowd of the evening before. On both occasions, the hall and all available space about it was jammed with people.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, Chief Justice Van Brunt presiding, and Justices Patterson, Barrett, Rumsey, and Williams also sitting, heard argument yesterday on the appeal of Ammi W. Wright from a verdict of $43,089.36, obtained against him in March last by Sir Roderick Cameron for alleged breach of contract.

Argument was heard by Justice Smyth in the Supreme Court yesterday on the motion in behalf of Leopold Gusthal, a taxpayer, for the continuance of a temporary injunction restraining the Board of Aldermen from granting to the Forty-second Street, Manhattanville and St. Nicholas Avenue Railroad a franchise enabling the company to extend its line along King's Bridge Road.

HAVANA, Oct. 6. -- In spite of Lieut. Gen. Weyler's prohibition, a notable demonstration took place here to-day in his honor. The Bourse was closed, as were also the principal stores and the tobacco and other manufactories. All the main streets were gayly decorated.

METUCHEN, N.J., Oct. 6. -- The second day's session of the Elizabeth Presbytery was held here to-day. The report of the Committee on Temperance threatened to disrupt the Presbytery, and at one time it seemed as though a split was imminent. The committee referred to the saloon element as stalking into the homes of the land and squatting in the classic halls of all schools and universities.

Sheriff Doht of Long Island City has made public the clandestine correspondence which has been carried on between Martin Thorn and Mrs. Nack, the alleged slayers of William Guldensuppe. Two letters one written by Mrs. Nack and the other by Thorn, prove conclusively that the pair have been contemplating death by their own hands.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 6. -- Mrs. Mary Sammon and Mrs. Jennie Layton, colored women, were arrested to-day on suspicion of being concerned in the deaths of three children, all of whom died in circumstances requiring a Coroner's certificate.

It is announced from Richmond that Consul General LEE, when he returns from Havana, is likely to enter the lists for the seat in the Senate now held by Senator JOHN W. DANIEL, whose term expires in March, 1899, and whose successor will be chosen by the Legislature elected next year.

The Navy Department has issued a summary of the reports from the various States which maintain naval militia forces. These show a steady growth of this branch of the volunteer service. In October, 1891, the total strength of the naval militia in the United States was 1,149; on Jan. 1 of the present year it was 4,037.

BOSTON, Oct. 6. -- A meeting of the certified holders of first mortgage bond interests in the Central Vermont Railroad was held here yesterday. Moorfield Storey, counsel for the Reorganization Committee, explained the scheme for the exchange of the first mortgage bonds with the Grand Trunk Railway, according to the plan that has already been published.

As instructed by you, I have investigated, with care, the conditions attending the construction of sewers, the laying of water pipes, and the repaving of Fifth Avenue. Several persons were startled and severely shaken by the unexpectedly rapid descent and sudden stoppage of an elevator car in the Bowling Green Building, in Lower Broadway, yesterday afternoon. John Scanlon of 10 West Ninetieth Street, a passenger, was thrown violently against a side of the car and his right kneecap was dislocated. The injury was treated at the Hudson Street Hospital, after which he went to his home.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 6. -- Referee Daniel W. Guernsey of Poughkeepsie filed his report to-day on his investigation of the management of the Westchester Temporary Home for Destitute Children at this place and of the charges of cruelty against Superintendent James W. Pierce.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 6. -- Harvard men kept on winning their matches in the intercollegiate tennis tournament this morning. The play consisted of a single match in the semi-finals of the doubles and several in the third round of the singles. In the doubles Ward and Davis, Harvard, defeated Noyes and Hackett, Yale, easily, the score standing 6 -- 2, 6 -- 4.

Three of the new automatic letter-registering mail boxes, invented by Count Castello di Brazza, have been installed in this city by offer of Postmaster General Gary for a six weeks' trial. One is in the Registry Bureau of the General Post Office, another in the arcade of the Equitable Building, and the third is at the sub-station at Park Avenue and Forty-second Street.

The Ancient Order of Hibernians are invited by the branch in Washington to unite in bringing pressure upon Congress to have the name of THOMAS MOORE inscribed among those of the poets on the walls of the Congressional Library. We can hardly suppose that this movement is based on a critical estimate of the late Mr. MOORE'S gifts as a poet.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- The celebrated case of Julio Sanguily is presented in a semi-official form in a pamphlet issued today by Sanguily's counsel here, Jose Rodriguez. It tells the story in detail and gives a number of letters passing between Secretary Olney, Senator Sherman, Consul General Lee, and the United States Minister at Madrid, Mr. Hannis Taylor, not appearing in the State Department publications.

PLYMOUTH, Oct. 6. -- The North German Lloyd steamer Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse, Capt. Engelbart, from New York for Bremen, arrived here at 3:05 o'clock this afternoon. The time of passage from New York to Plymouth was 5 days 15 hours and 10 minutes, the big ship's average speed was 21.91 knots per hour and her biggest day's run was 519 knots.

OTTAWA, Ont., Oct. 6. -- Fierce forest fires are burning along the line of the Canada Atlantic Railway, in the neighborhood of Casselman, South Indian, and Cheney. The fire includes so far an area twenty-five miles square

Park Commissioner William A. Stiles died early yesterday morning, at 241 Tonnele Avenue, Jersey City Heights, the residence of his sister, Mrs. E.H. Davey. Abdominal cancer was the cause of death. He had been in failing health for some years, but it was not until two months ago that he was forced to take to his bed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6. -- The Inter-State Commerce Commission will shortly decide upon the question of the extension of time in which the railroads of the country engaged in inter-State commerce must equip their trains with train-brake systems and automatic car couplers. The act compelling the railroads to so equip their trains was passed in the closing hours of the Harrison Administration after a protracted and bitter contest.

BOSTON, Oct. 6. -- The third game of the Temple Cup series was as dull and uninteresting a contest as has been seen here for many a day. The Baltimores won with ridiculous ease, and closed their engagement here by ,practically exhausting the pitching talent of the Boston nine.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Oct. 6. -- In a number of instances within the last few months the Justices' courts of this State have thrown out suits brought by wheelmen for damages done their wheels upon Sundays, on the ground that the riding of a wheel for pleasure was a violation of the law. The law under which this action was taken was passed in 1805, and amended so as to include gunning and hunting in 1854.

In view of the large exports of corn from the United States this year, the following account of the introduction of that staple into Belgium and Germany, which is from the unpublished autobiography of the late Col. William H. Robertson, then United States Consul at Bremen, will be found of general interest:

BOSTON, Oct. 7. -- The special commission on taxation appointed by Gov. Wolcott has made a majority report, which is signed by Judge James R. Dunbar, Frank W. Taussig, T.J. Coolidge, and ex-Councilor Barrus. The minority report of the remaining member, George F. McNeil, will be submitted later.

FORESTBURG, N.Y., Oct. 7. -- Six new buildings are being erected in this village by the Sisters of St. Dominick, connected with the Church of the Holy Trinity, Montrose Avenue, Brooklyn. They are to be used as a sanitarium during the Summer season for patients from St. Catharine's Hospital, Williamsburg, and as a perpetual home for incurables.

The first public test in this city of the pneumatic mail service of the Tubular Dispatch Company was made yesterday, when the branch line from the general Post Office to Station P., in the Produce Exchange, was opened. The test was in every respect a success, and was under the management of John E. Milholland.

One of the points made by Col. WARING in his report on the excavations of Gen. COLLIS, printed in yesterday's NEW YORK TIMES, throws some light on the value of non-partisanship in City Government, and thereby makes the letter, without intent of its writer, a valuable contribution to the educational literature of this thoroughly educational campaign for the Mayoralty of the Greater New York.

Mr. Low stands for direct responsibility of the Mayor to the people of the city. If elected, he will hide behind no party. What he does well or ill he will be known, as Mayor, to do. If he does well, the voters can continue him in office, or can get the same kind of service by electing the same kind of man.
PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Oct. 7. -- Patrick Conway murdered his brother, James, in cold blood last night and eluded capture.

American shares were higher in the London market. The principal changes were: Advanced -- Canadian Pacific, 1 1/2 to 83 7/8; Reading, 1/2, to 13 1/2; St. Paul, 3/8, to 99 5/8; Atchison, 1/4, to 15 3/8; Illinois Central, 1/4, to 106 3/4; New York Central, 1/4, to 114, and Erie, 1/4, to 17 3/8. Louisville and Nashville sold at 61 1/2 and Erie first preferred at 42 1/4.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- Diplomatic circles are much exercised over the refusal of the German Government to issue an exequatur to F.W. Neumann of Chicago, appointed Consul to Cologne. It is understood that the same influences which worked to render Neumann persona non grata are operating to discredit Max Bouschein of Chicago, who went to Barmen as Consul.
Strong Ireland have sold for J.W. Mack to a Mr. Hall the lot on Riverside Drive seventy-five feet south of Seventy-eighth Street, 25.2 by 120.
A small blaze, caused by children igniting matches in the third story of 125 East One Hundred and Tenth Street, caused much excitement, but the damage was confined to one room.

BOSTON, Oct. 7. -- Henry N. Whitney, President of the Dominion Coal Company, to-day confirmed the report that a syndicate is about to begin the manufacture of gas in competition with the existing companies which are controlled by the Standard Oil Company. He said:

HAMBURG, Oct. 7. -- At to-day's session of the Socialist Congress Herr Auer, the Socialist leader, and editor of the Vorwaerts, organ of that party, made a speech lasting two hours, during which he advocated the Social Democrats participating in the elections for members of the Provincial Diets of Prussia.

Arthur Augustus Zimmerman, former champion of the world, and probably the most popular rider who ever raced under the American colors, after practically abandoning racing for several years has signed a contract to race in France next year. The agreement is made with the owners of the Parc du Princes of Paris, and calls for his appearance in open competition, match races exhibitions, and record trials.

The Holland Dames of the New Netherlands and Knights of the Legion of the Crown presented to the City of New York yesterday a bronze tablet, placed on the wall of the building at the southeast corner of Pearl and State Streets. The building stands on the site of the "Stadhuis," or City Hall, of New Amsterdam, built in 1636.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 7. -- To-night Gov. Holcomb, William J. Bryan, and Senator Allen of Nebraska arrived here, accompanied by many members of Gov. Holcomb's staff and other military and civil officers of the State. An immense crowd was at the station, and the visitors were greeted with cheers. There was no speaking.
Chicago Gas dominated the stock market yesterday. It dropped 5 points and offset all encouraging developments elsewhere in the market.

The business end of Mr. PLATT'S management of his machine seems to be in the surety company of which his son is an active official. The influence of bondsmen over the action of contractors, saloon keepers, and others for whom they have assumed pecuniary responsibility is very great.

While five favorites won at the Aqueduct track yesterday, the "talent" fared badly, for in every race most of the "wise money" was bet on some horse which failed to land the purse. In the first race, the seekers after "good things" received a setback when they watched the manner in which Willie Martin played fast and loose with Yankee Doodle.

The disrupted condition of Fifth Avenue was again the subject of judicial inquiry in Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday, when Magistrate Hedges heard further testimony in the action brought by Adolphe L. Audrain against Contractor William P. Baird, whom he charges with maintaining a nuisance on Fifth Avenue by his dilatory method of pursuing the work there.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- The annual report of Mr. Chamberlain, the Commissioner of Navigation, which has just been submitted to the Secretary of the Treasury, shows that the total documented tonnage of the United States on June 30, 1897 -- 4,700,020 tons -- was the largest for twenty-one years, except in 1893, when it was 4,825,071 tons.

MONTREAL, Oct. 7. -- A matter which just now is very largely engaging the attention of the shipping and business interests of Montreal and of the entire Dominion, as well as that of the Dominion Government, is the proposed enlargement of the elevator and wharfage facilities of the port of Montreal.

MORRISTOWN, Oct. 7. -- There was a fashionable and critical gathering at the Morristown Driving Park this afternoon to witness the opening of the Horse Show, held under the auspices of the Morristown Field Club. The classes are open to all, with the exception of about a dozen competitions, which are restricted to entries from Morris, Essex, Union, and Somerset Counties.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7. -- The Executive Committee of the National Association of Manufacturers met this evening at the Manufacturers' Club to consider plans for future work in various lines. President Theodore C. Search presented a review of the work done by the association since the last annual convention, which was held in Philadelphia in January last.

SALEM, Oregon, Oct. 6. -- A year ago to-day the entire Pacific coast was listening to the voices of prophets of evil -- heralds of calamity -- who summed up all the woes that could visit a people and denounced those who couldn't believe in free and unmitigated silver as enemies of humanity and the cause of all the financial horror of the time.
The City Convention of the National Democracy at Cooper Union nominated Seth Low for Mayor, Charles S. Fairchild for Controller, and John H. Schumann for President of the Council.

Emmet C. Gibson, said to be Vice President of the Akron, Ohio, Street Railway Company, and a promoter of street railway companies, was arrested yesterday by Central Office detectives, on the charge of giving a bogus check for $640 at the Imperial Hotel, this city, on Aug. 26, 1896, and defrauding it in addition of a board bill of $265.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7. -- The Gottschalk Company of Baltimore to-day filed a bill in equity in the United States Circuit Court in this city against James Hartley, Trustee, and the Mutual Distilling Company of Uniontown, Ky., which has an office in Philadelphia, asking to have declared void an alleged whisky pooling agreement upon the ground that it is in restraint of trade.

The predictions at the present time of the result of the Mayoralty election, though made by prominent men, differ widely, but not strangely. Why? Because they are made through ignorance or for effect. The truth is, the status in quo affords no criterion as to the status in future, the status that will exist during the fifteen days next preceding the election.

The Democratic County and Borough Conventions, held yesterday at Tammany Hall, resulted in the nomination of the above ticket. The slate which was finally put through at the convention was not decided upon until thirty minutes before the hour for calling the convention to order. It was principally the work of Richard Croker, although in making the selections he was guided and influenced largely by the views of the sub-committee of the Executive Committee.

The Republican County Convention met last night at 8 o'clock in Lyric Hall, 723 Sixth Avenue, and nominated, with one exception, a straight partisan ticket. Charles H. Van Brunt, who was indorsed without opposition for Supreme Court Justice, is the only nominee whose record is not strictly organization.

READING, Penn., Oct. 7. -- There is not a hatter in Reading who cannot obtain work to-day if he wants it. Next to the iron and, possibly, the cigar industries, the manufacture of hats is the most important business in this section of Pennsylvania. Millions of wool and fur hats are made here annually, and on the prosperity of the hat factories depends the subsistence of a large percentage of Reading people.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- The Bureau of Statistics has issued tables showing the exports and imports for August, the first full month under the new tariff law. These figures show for that month the largest exports of domestic merchandise of any August in the history of the Government. The exports were $79,490,264, against $66,689,981 for August, 1896.
Leaders of the various organizations that have united in the nomination of Henry George have been in almost uninterrupted conference since Wednesday evening.

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 7. -- Although detectives of both Kansas City and Independence have worked hard to-day to gain some clue to the robbers who last night stopped a Chicago and Alton train near Evanston, a suburb, their success has been indifferent. The train was stopped at Evanston siding by the explosion of torpedoes which had been placed on the track.
LONDON, Oct. 7. -- E.C. Stanton, former manager of the Metropolitan Opera House, New York, has been declared a bankrupt, with liabilities amounting to 852, ($4,260,) and no assets.

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 7. -- The National Council, by a vote of 98 to 29, has adopted a bill providing for the purchase of the five principal railroads of Switzerland at a cost approaching a milliard of francs, (about $200,000,000,) for which purpose a loan is projected.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- The friends of reciprocity are encouraged to believe that the selection of Senor Moret as Minister of the Colonies in the new Spanish Cabinet will lead to an improvement of the commercial relations between the United States and Cuba. Moret is the recognized exponent of reciprocity in Spain, and he first came into public notice by embracing the views of Bastiat and urging complete free trade.

The election law gives the voter a full three weeks for the study of the candidates. That time will barely suffice this year to make the public acquainted with the respective qualifications of the bewildering array of aspirants for office whose names will appear upon the four tickets.

It is really a pity, in the interest of symmetry and completeness, that GRADY should not have been put on the Tammany ticket. There would then have been no possible doubt about Mr. CROKER'S confidence that this was a yellow-dog year for "the organization." But that deep and lurid orange chrome, as of a Hawaiian sunset, with which the name of GRADY would have suffused the list upon which it appeared is still wanting.
DETROIT, Oct. 7. -- The fire which began in the Detroit Opera House this morning did from $600,000 to $700,000 damage. Five large buildings and two smaller ones were destroyed.

LONDON, Oct. 7. -- At the final meeting to-day of the committee of the Indian Famine Fund at the Mansion House, the Lord Mayor, Sir George Faudel Philips, announced that the total subscriptions amounted to 549,300, (2,746,500,) adding that out of every pound (20s.) 19s. 11 1/2d, had been remitted to India demonstrating that the expense of administering the fund had been most minute.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7. -- Col. George H. North, a well-known stock broker, a member of the Union League, and an officer on the staff of Major Gen. Snowden of the Pennsylvania National Guard, is confined in Moyamensing Prison on commitment of Judge Hanna of the Orphans Court, for contempt.

In the confusion caused by municipal politics and other minor matters, a question of great ethical, industrial, and sociological interest has been curiously slighted. We refer, of course, to the strike of the tinners and dusters of the New Castle Tin Plate Works, in Pennsylvania, to the number of 175 men and boys.

The guests of the Prison Association of New York crowded the reception rooms, at 135 East Fifteenth Street, yesterday afternoon to listen to the first of the series of three conferences on penological matters which accompanies their "prison exhibition" in the headquarters during the last three days of this week.

The only substantial contribution Great Britain has it in its power to make to international bimetallism is the reopening of the Indian mints to the free coinage of silver. This would not amount to nearly as much as the bimetallists now say that they think it would, and it is only recently that they have attached any value to it at all.
MALONE, N.Y., Oct. 7. -- A curious case of alleged "spirit rapping" has caused Thomas Tallman of this place to change his religion, and has caused a good deal of excitement about town.

It was reported at a late hour last night that Richard H. Adams, nominee of the Citizens' Union for Register, will withdraw from the Hardman Hall ticket; that Austen G. Fox, nominee for District Attorney, will be named to fill the vacancy, and that William M.K. Olcott, nominee of the Republicans for District Attorney, will be indorsed by the Citizens' Union.

ALBANY, Oct. 7. -- As soon as the Court of Appeals met this morning, it took up the appeal on behalf of District Attorney Backus of Kings County from the decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, declaring that his term as District Attorney expires at the end of the year, and that the act declaring it to be four years in duration is invalid.

Many exciting finishes marked the contests yesterday in the second day's play of the St. Andrew's Club open tournament. The long eighteen-hole course at Mount Hope, Westchester County, was filled with a large number of enthusiastic golfers, and the usual number of ladies and other guests were present.

-- Nobody can have failed, since the rapid transit hearings began, to remark on the curious unanimity with which experts working in the interest of surface and elevated lines of transportation have claimed, first, that an underground road couldn't be built, and second, that it would cost unnumbered millions more than its advocates suppose.

MADRID, Oct. 7. -- It is semi-officially announced that the note which Gen. Stewart L. Woodford, the United States Minister, communicated to the Duke of Tetuan, the Spanish Minister for Foreign Affairs, is no more an ultimatum than it is a comminatory document. In spirit and textually it is couched in friendly terms.

One of the most protracted and stubbornly contested fights in the history of the local politics of this city was ended last night, when the Republican Convention of the Eleventh Judicial District, on the one hundredth ballot, and after more than thirty hours of sitting and balloting, nominated Francis J. Worcester for District Justice over John P. Davenport, the incumbent.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Oct. 7. -- The Clinton County Republican Convention, held here Tuesday, resulted in the nomination of George Henry Beckwith for member of Assembly and a victory for the faction led by ex-Congressman Wever. Wever and Beckwith carried eight of the fourteen towns at the caucuses a week ago, and the faction led by State Committeeman Moffitt was successful in six towns.
GLENVILLE, West Va., Oct. 7. -- Twenty-seven witnesses have been examined by the prosecution in the Atkinson forgery trial, in which the wife of Gov. Atkinson is the defendant.

ALBANY, Oct. 7. -- The New Rochelle Electric Railway Company was incorporated to-day with a capital stock of $80,000. The termini of the road will be at Cooper's Corners, on North Street; at the junction of Pelham Road with Davenport Avenue; at Glen Island dock, end of Morgan Street, and on Winyah Avenue, at the village line in New Rochelle.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7. -- A relay of six thoroughbred horses from the stables of Thomas W. South raced live miles to-day on the Tioga bicycle track against four crack bicyclists, and the horses won in nine minutes and fifty-two seconds, with the wheelmen only five yards behind. The race was the feature event of an afternoon's programme of amateur bicycle races.

It is generally recognized that THE NEW YORK TIMES has undergone a marked increase in circulation within the last twelve months. This is noteworthy when it is recalled that the past year was one of the most disastrous in the history of American newspapers; when those who did not suffer heavy losses in circulation deemed themselves fortunate in being able to hold what they had.

It is generally recognized that THE NEW YORK TIMES has undergone a marked increase in circulation within the last twelve months. This is noteworthy when it is recalled that the past year was one of the most disastrous in the history of American newspapers; when those who did not suffer heavy losses in circulation deemed themselves fortunate in being able to hold what they had.

Among the passengers on the North German Lloyd steamship Barbarossa, which should arrive at her dock in Hoboken this morning, is Carl Faber, cashier of the importing department of Oelrichs Co., 2 Bowling Green. Oelrichs Co. are agents of the North German Lloyd Line, but their importing business is separate from that of the steamship's agency.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- At the Cabinet meeting to-day a confirmation was given of the report that the Union Pacific syndicate had agreed to increase its bid to the Government to $50,000,000, and that the Attorney General, in view of this fact, had decided not to appeal the case, but to allow the sale to proceed.

PORT TOWNSEND, Washington, Oct. 8. -- Passengers who returned on the schooner Sailor Boy, from St. Michael, to-day, report that Mayor Wood of Seattle, manager of the Humboldt expedition, and D.K. Howard, who had charge of the Eliza Anderson party, are practically prisoners in the hands of their irate passengers.
John R. McPherson, one time Democratic leader in New Jersey and United States Senator from that State, from 1877 until 1895, died at 11:30 last night in his room at Taylor's Hotel in Jersey City.

The statement that a syndicate has been formed in London for the purpose of "cornering" Whistler's artistic works is suggestive of an interesting future. If it is commercially wise and pardonable now and then to corner wheat, will there not be greater advantages in cornering the work of a painter?

While an ever-increasing majority of the American people are opposed to the free and unlimited coinage of silver at any ratio, it is true at the same time that any legislation conducive to the increased circulation of silver would he welcome. A few suggestions on this line may not be amiss.
HAVANA, Oct. 8. -- The escape of Senorita Evangelina Cossio y Cisneros has caused a sensation in Havana.

The expert accountants appointed by Controller Fitch who have been at work investigating the records and accounts of the Borough of Brooklyn report the books of the City of Brooklyn and the County of Kings inaccurate in detail and faulty in method. They claim to have found many discrepancies and to have been unable to find certain important records of the County Treasurer's office. Their report is as follows:

-- If one yielded to impulse he would express wonder -- delighted or sorrowful, according to his definition of the word "temperance" -- on learning that the bankers of Kentucky, assembled for their annual banquet, warmly complimented the bankers of Frankfort, their hosts, for placing no wine on the table.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 8. -- To-day was a record-breaker in the yellow fever epidemia, he reports to the Board of Health showing five deaths and forty-six new cases in this city. Among the persons stricken to-day is Dr. Howard Oliphant, a brother of President Oliphant of the Board of Health, who had been engaged in visiting the sick.

Gov. Hazen S. Pingree of Michigan, formerly Mayor of Detroit, arrived here yesterday from Venezuela on the steamship Venezuela. He disappeared six weeks ago, having slipped away without telling anybody but his family where he was going.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 8. -- The annual Fall regatta of the Cornell class crews was held here to-day, and resulted in a victory for the Juniors. The weather was cloudy, with a light wind blowing down the course, making the conditions favorable for fast time.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 8. -- Perfect weather and large attendance marked the fourth day of the Kentucky Trotting Horse Breeders' meeting. The Transylvania Stake of $5,000 for 2:14 trotters, in which The Monk had won the first two heats, Bush the third, Tommy Britton the fourth, and Rilma the fifth, was finished in short order, Rilma taking the sixth and seventh heats in 2:11 1/4 and 2:12.

MONTREAL, Oct. 8. -- Contrary to natural expectation, the approach of the Winter season sees no abatement in the rush of Canadians to the Klondike, and new expeditions are being organized to go north without waiting for the Spring. The Edmonton route will be used by them as presenting the fewest obstacles.

Being practically without newspaper support, Tammany is forced to buy advertising space to give publicity to its campaign arguments. It has put up in the cars of the elevated railroad this sum in subtraction:

The Pennsylvania Bankers' Association at its annual meeting has indorsed with emphasis the work of the Monetary Commission, and pledges its assistance "in every effort of theirs that has in view the establishment of a currency system sufficient and secure."

PEORIA, Ill., Oct. 8. -- The Bradley Polytechnic Institute, to which Mrs. Lydia Bradley has given $2,500,000, was dedicated this afternoon. The dedicatory address was delivered by Lyman J. Gage, Secretary of the Treasury.

Hall J. How Co. have sold for Nicholas Murray Butler to Frederick Wachsmuth three lots on the south side of One Hundred and Thirteenth Street, 250 feet east of the Boulevard. The buyer will improve the property by the erection of private dwellings.

The decision of the Henry George managers to indorse the county ticket of the Citizens' Union in New York, and probably that of the McLaughlin Democrats in Kings blocks the game of Mr. PLATT as to a George panic among men of property.

MADRID, Oct. 8 -- Midnight. -- The Cabinet has decided upon the immediate recall of Gen. Weyler from Cuba. A decree will be issued appointing Capt. Gen. Blanco y Arenas, Marquis of Pena-Plata, Governor General of the island. The Queen Regent will sign the decree to-morrow.

Ernst Lundgren of 38 Park Row, who was President of the Swedish American Jubilee Committee that sent a beautiful silver group to King Oscar II, as a token of respect and good will and in commemoration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of his reign, has received from Thomas B. Ferguson, United States Minister to Sweden and Norway, an account of the presentation of the group to his Majesty and its reception.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8. -- Arthur M. Sewall of Maine, who was associated with William J. Bryan on the Presidential ticket last Fall, arrived in this city to-day, accompanied by his wife. Mr. Sewall said: "There is certainly more business being done this year than last, but I do not attribute it to politics.

Three thousand three hundred and twenty-five pieces of American and foreign black, colored, and fancy silks were sold yesterday at a peremptory auction sale by order of Schwarzenbach, Huber Co., through Townsend Montant, at the salesrooms, 87 and 89 Leonard Street. Buyers from every large city in the United States and representing the largest houses, retail and wholesale, were in attendance, and the sale was successful in all respects.

The principle for which SETH LOW stands is the only one in this campaign that will stand discussion. Mr. Low is the only candidate whose election would really advance the principle for which he professes to stand. In these circumstances the thorough discussion of the next three weeks ought to place Mr. Low well in the lead.

HONOLULU, Oct. 4. -- The Supreme Court has affirmed the decision of the lower court in the case of the steamship China, and at a late hour yesterday G.W. MacFarlane secured a Hawaiian register for the vessel. Now that the China case has been disposed of, the Pacific Mail Company will send the Baracouta, now plying between Central American ports, and will make application for a Hawaiian register for her.

The trouble in the George camp was balm to Tammany yesterday. Every move that was made was reported to the leaders and hailed with delight. They reasoned that defection in the George camp was certain to result in the election of Van Wyek. The leaders agreed that no man who left Tammany to follow George would swallow the Citizens' Union ticket in the county and districts.

Another of the old as well as one of the most dangerous vessels built for the United States Government will shortly be removed from the Brooklyn Navy Yard. The vessel in question is known as "The Intelligent Whale," and was one of the first submarine boats to be constructed after the war.

A deal was made yesterday between Tom L. Johnson, representing Henry George, and the candidates of the Citizens' Union, whereby the county ticket of the Citizens' Union may appear upon the official ballot under the Henry George ticket, which will be known as the Democracy of Thomas Jefferson.

In the great struggle which he is waging to repress the rising tide of Anarchism by turning over the government of Greater New York to Tammany Hall, Senator PLATT naturally exerts himself toward directing the attention of the inhabitants of the city to points as remote from it as possible.

HAVANA, Oct. 8 -- Gen. Weyler gave to-day an emphatic and absolute denial to the reports that he would resist removal from his command in Cuba, and in certain contingencies might espouse the Carlist cause.
HONOLULU, Oct. 4. -- Senator John T. Morgan of Alabama addressed a large number of natives Sept. 30. He spoke of the benefits annexation would bring to Hawaiians.
The registration in this city began yesterday, and the returns from all the election districts but three, the latter in the Thirty-fourth Assembly District, were all in by 2 o'clock this morning.

The popular demonstration in favor of Gen. WEYLER at Havana was a very curious performance. In the amusing official account of it that was cabled, it was set forth that the demonstration occurred in spite of his efforts to prevent it. When we consider the chances of any open demonstration in Havana for any purpose that WEYLER was believed to disapprove this official statement becomes a grim joke.

In the November number of The Journal of the Military Service Institution of the United States will appear an article of serious import by Gen. GEORGE W. WINGATE, on "The Urgent Necessity for an Increase in the Artillery." Gen. WINGATE points out the fact that the long-continued demands of military authorities, supported by the newspapers, have resulted in the adoption of a plan of coast defense on modern lines.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 8. -- The Committee of Seventy of the Gold Democrats, which was active here last Fall in the sound-money movement, met to-day to consider what action should be taken in the present campaign.

Interest in the penological exhibit at the headquarters of the Prison Association of New York and in the second of the series of "prison conferences" held there this week was constant yesterday. There were several speeches from men prominently connected with the care of prisoners, and the display of convict products was augmented by some new exhibits from Massachusetts.

LONDON, Oct. 8. -- The St. James's Gazette this afternoon, referring to the formal announcement of Great Britain's declination to take part in the Bering Sea conference with Russia and Japan, says: ...

BOSTON, Oct. 8. -- The Boston Public Library is always an interesting place. Its structural massiveness, its artistic designs and its never-failing adaptability to one's literary wants are things of which the resident Bostonian never wearies. But in these particular days it is interesting in another way.

Players of form again had much the better of the game at Aqueduct yesterday, for in four of the six events the favorites captured the money. The day was an ideal one for racing, and the crowd was, as it has been every day since Monday, a very large one.

Senator Platt stated positively yesterday afternoon that there would be no withdrawals from the Republican ticket. "Mr. Tracy is in the field to stay," he said. "It has been said that I would rather see the Tammany ticket elected than Seth Low, and that I had said as much to friends. There is absolutely no foundation for that story.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 8. -- Three thousand persons saw the Bostons and Baltimores play an exhibition game at Hampden Park this afternoon, which resulted in an easy victory for the Baltimores. The champions' defeat was largely due to the poor work of Pitcher Klobedanz in the third inning. He was very unsteady, and when he did manage to get the ball over the plate the ex-champions hit safely.

Hot matches and exciting finishes were continued yesterday in the final contests on the St. Andrew's Golf Club links for the St. Andrew's and the Harry Holbrook Cups. The large number of spectators who flocked to the links saw an exhibition of golf which well repaid them for their labor.

ALBANY, Oct. 8. -- The independent nomination of Charles Frederick Adams for Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals on the ticket of the United Democracy was filed in the office of the Secretary of State shortly before midnight last night by two Republicans. The document was received by a watchman, and was on file this morning.

With the present issue, THE REVIEW OF BOOKS AND ART enters upon its second year. When this supplement was started, THE NEW YORK TIMES, for several years, had been giving very special attention to books and art, believing that all its readers were in some degree interested in those subjects and that many of them were deeply interested. No American daily newspaper for several years had reviewed books with equal promptness and fullness.
CHICAGO, Oct. 8. -- The State to-day completed the presentation of its testimony in the Luetgert murder trial, and an adjournment was taken until Monday.

A decision sustaining the protests' of importers against the retroactive interpretation of the new tariff law was given by the Board of United States General Appraisers yesterday. The opinion was written by ex-Judge Henderson M. Somerville, Chairman of Board A, and is based directly on the wool case of Stoddard Haserick, Richards Co. of Boston.

Lovers of Carlyle will be grateful to Mr. Ashbel P. Fitch, the Controller of New York City, for placing within easy reach a comparatively, and perhaps entirely unknown essay by the famous Scottish writer. The essay in question is perhaps his earliest effort in the criticism of German literature, and was first published in the New Edinburgh Review of January and April, 1822.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 8. -- The final match in singles in the intercollegiate tennis tournament was played here this morning and was won by S.G. Thomson of Princeton. He met J.D. Forbes of Harvard, and the best play of the tournament followed. A five-set match was necessary to decide the championship, although Thomson had the match within one or two points nearly a dozen times.

How much of Mrs. Inchbald's inner life did her unsympathetic biographer. Boaden, give us? If only the author of "The Simple Story" had not destroyed her own autobiography, what a most entertaining history we would have had! "The Simple Story" is a touching and pathetic tale, one once much beloved of our great-granddames.

Tennyson's "Charge of the Light Brigade" was recently declaimed in the school where I hope to be graduated next Summer, and the remark was made that a survivor of this charge had just died in Montreal. Can you tell me if this is true?

CHICAGO, Oct. 8. -- The gross receipts of the Illinois Central from traffic for the month of September are estimated at $2,259,423, an estimated increase of $389,369 over the same month of last year. For the two months ended Aug. 31 the net earnings of the road were $1,946,090, an increase of $300,769

WEST UNION, West Va., Oct. 8. -- An epidemic of fever six miles south of here is causing considerable consternation among the inhabitants. Physicians differ in their opinions as to the kind of fever, some claiming that it is typhoid, while others assert that it is a mild type of yellow fever. Thirty-one deaths have occurred in the last eighteen days.

It is reported on very good authority that the British Minister returns to Washington with some definite instructions as to the renewal of the attempt at a treaty of arbitration with this country. We have the assurance of President McKINLEY himself that the Administration sincerely desires and will earnestly seek a treaty that can be ratified.

Dr. Lewis A. Sayre, the oldest of the famous surgeons of the United States, is enjoying life at the age of seventy-eight. He has been for more than half a century a participator in and observer of those surgical operations which have made the American scalpel renowned for skill and audacity.
MADRID, Oct. 9. -- The Cabinet to-day held a four hours' session, during which the decision previously arrived at regarding the recall from Cuba of Lieut. Gen. Weyler was confirmed.

A discussion on "Existing Relations Between Elementary and Secondary Schools" was the feature of the monthly meeting of the Schoolmasters' Association of New York and its vicinity in the law schoolroom of the New York University yesterday. President H.F. Towle delivered an address which described the situation and contained suggestions for bettering some of the present methods.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 8. -- In a letter to his father, J.S. Verner, former Controller General of South Carolina, the Rev. Phillips Verner, Presbyterian missionary in the Congo Free State, Central Africa, gives interesting information about the slave trade, and tells how slaves may be freed.

LONDON, Oct. 9. -- The American bay colt Diakka, four years old, by The Sailor Prince, out of Rizpah, owned by the Lorillard-Beresford Stable, won the Duke of York Stakes to-day at the Kempton Park October meeting. Fourteen horses ran.

MRS. A.E. PAUL, who has lately been placed in charge of the street-cleaning work of the business district of Chicago, is no novice at her task. As far back as 1894 she was making a minute study of the work of cleaning city streets and of sanitation in general.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 9. -- Charges of cruelty are made in connection with the management of the De Peyster Home for Orphan Girls, an institution conducted by a Methodist society at Tivoli, N.Y., and it is likely that an investigation will be made either by the town authorities or the conference officials.
Tom L. Johnson yesterday announced the George city ticket as follows:...

A good programme of bicycle events and baseball and football games was enjoyed by about 3,000 friends of Charles H. Ebbets, Secretary-Treasurer of the Brooklyn Baseball Club, to whom a testimonial was tendered at Eastern Park yesterday afternoon in commemoration of his fifteen years' service with the club.

The visit of Dr. Thomas W. Evans, the famous American dentist of Paris, to this country will be memorable for an announcement authorized by the doctor before he sailed away yesterday on the steamship La Touraine. It is that a major portion of his wealth -- and he is reputed to be worth more than $30,000,000 -- will be devoted to educational and charitable purposes, during his lifetime and under his direction.

This has been a sort of Chicago Gas week. The start of the general market last Monday was quite spectacular on the bull side, for Manhattan opened up half a dozen points. Northwest three, and all the leading speculatives higher than their Saturday's close, but -- the first dash was all there was in it.

BOSTON, Oct. 9. -- The British steamer Honiton, Capt. Hudson, on board of which three persons died during her voyage from Progreso, Mexico, from yellow fever, reached quarantine in Boston Harbor at 9:15 o'clock.

OF ALL social organizations in the City of New York there is, perhaps, not one toward which the public is more kindly disposed than the Lambs Club, that small but select organization which, after many wanderings, has within the last few months found rest in its own fold at 70 West Thirty-sixth Street.

IT is due to the efforts of Andrew H. Green more than to those of any one else that the City of New York enjoys its present system of public parks. It was he who first became the master spirit in their development, and it was he who beyond all others, devoted the necessary energy and talent which made Central Park one of the four most noted parks in the world.

BOSTON, Oct. 9. -- Public works constitute, as a general rule, a very reliable indication of the progress a city is making in the line of practical civilization. It is not enough that a town boasts of its universities and ancient origin. Your citizen of energy asks, "How about the streets, lighting, sewerage, or transit facilities?"

CHICAGO, Oct. 9. -- Just to emphasize their remarks, several Principals of Chicago public schools have acquired the habit of stamping their feet and addressing their subordinates in adjectives. It is even said that in one case the teacher was roughly shaken.

The North Fifth Street Methodist Episcopal Church, near Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, will begin to-day its semi-centennial celebration. Among the members of the Committee of Arrangements are the Rev. Edward H. Dutcher, the pastor; John McEwen, Joseph Barradell, John L. Whitacre, Mary H. Parks, and Mrs. W.W. Wilson.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9. -- If ever there has been another man in this country holding an elective office of great prominence who possessed Gov. Tanner's faculty for making himself obnoxious to his constituents regardless of party, history has remained silent on the subject. It is simply marvelous how many different things this man can do to call forth the most cordial execrations of all classes of people.

An experiment of considerable interest to brick manufacturers and dealers, and to builders as well, was tried yesterday at Roseton on the Hudson, about four miles above Newburg. The kilns and yards of the Rose Brick Company are there, and under the direction of the Standard Oil Company fuel oil instead of wood or coal was used to burn a kiln of bricks.

Several interesting events were decided yesterday on the grounds of the Carteret Gun Club, at Garden City. After a preliminary handicap, in which Leonard, McAlpin, and Dolan tied, with five kills each, the first cup of the day was shot for. All the contestants stood at thirty yards. W.A.H. Stafford won the cup, and Stafford and Edey divided the stakes.

MARVELOUS changes indeed have taken place in the City of New York in my day. There is nothing to compare with it in the history of the world, either as regards the fabulous increase in wealth and real estate values or in population and territory.

Henry Lauren Clinton, the well-known lawyer of this city, has put some of his interesting recollections into a book entitled "Celebrated Cases," which will issue from the press of Harper Brothers on the 15th inst. Mr. Clinton is the author of "Extraordinary Cases," which was published some time ago by the Harpers.

An intimate friend of Mr. PLATT, a clergyman, is reported to have said that Mr. PLATT admitted that he opposed Mr. Low and the Citizens' movement because their success would break the power that he has over the Legislature. We hardly think that Mr. PLATT has confided this view of the situation to any minister of the Gospel, however intimate a friend.

" All things considered, I look upon it as the very proudest moment of my long life when the widow of Alexander Hamilton, the great patriot of the Revolution, made a call on me in company with her granddaughter, and gave me a little chat about the stirring days when she was young."

LONDON, Oct. 9. -- W.S. Gilbert announces to an Edinburgh interviewer that he will write no more plays. He says he is disheartened by the erroneous point of view from which criticism is written, adding:

The old German-American Burger-Bund, the faction of the German-American Reform Union which bolted when that organization went over to Tammany Hall in 1895, met at the Citizens' Union Headquarters in East Twenty-third Street, yesterday, in response to the call of John B. Pannes, their former President, and effected a reorganization in their ranks by accepting the old constitution of the Reform Union.
" Oh for an orator!" said the Philosopher, apropos of nothing, at the club the other evening.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct 9. -- Within a few days a contract will be awarded to Delaware River shipbuilders for the construction of two, and possibly four, of the fleetest coasting steamships flying the American flag.

Who cares to hear TRACY and VAN WYCK spout their second-hand ideas and inspired opinions? Give us the originals. Let us have the Republican and Tammany policies from the primary source. Away with the understrappers! Let the bosses take the stump. The people want to hear PLATT and CROKER expound the issues.

He was a bright colored man, about thirty-five years old. He was only "about" that old as far as he knew, and that was one of the reasons which prompted him to visit "Miss Jo." Wasn't Miss Jo a Southern woman, if it was her misfortune to live in the North, and hadn't she known his family, root and branch, from slavery times, and he could depend on Miss Jo?
Lorin A. Thurston, ex-Minister from Hawaii, has issued a "Handbook on the annexation of Hawaii" of 88 pages in pamphlet form.

Dr. Austin Flint presided at yesterday's conference, one of the daily features of the Prison Exhibition in the rooms of the Prison Association of New York, at 135 East Fifteenth Street. The general subject of the conference was announced as "Criminal Types -- Disease and Crime."
