For the first time in this campaign. Seth Low took occasion, at the great meeting in the Brooklyn Academy of Music last night, to reply to the personal assaults which have been made upon him, and to tell of the inside history that led up to his acceptance of the Citizens' Union nomination.

NEWPORT, Oct. 9. -- The condition of many of the streets of New York is largely the cause of Newport's extended season, villa owners here hesitating to open their city houses with the possibility of disease lurking about their door steps. The cottage colony here is almost intact, and each night, though it is October, at least a half dozen dinners are given, something heretofore quite unheard of at this time of the year.

ROME, N.Y., Oct. 8. -- The first beet-sugar factory ever started east of the Mississippi River has been established here, and the machinery was set in motion last week. The first samples of granulated sugar may now be seen at the company's office, which bears the name of the First New York Beet-Sugar Company.

AMSTERDAM, Sept. 25. -- This is the season of fair sights and good times. While Dordrecht sees the young Queen of Holland, enjoying with girlish delight the "show" she gave, a ship sets sail from Amsterdam and follows the shores of the remarkable little river Tj -- (which flows six meters above the land) -- to the busy little town of Zaandam.

The largest crowd the Aqueduct race track has ever known turned out yesterday to witness six well-contested events. What was lacking in class was amply atoned for by the spirited manner in which most of the races were fought out.

President William H. Baldwin of the Long Island Railroad Company returned on the steamer St. Louis on Friday might, after a two mouths' tour in Europe, during which he inspected tunnels and underground railways with a view to the proposed building of the Atlantic Avenue subway and the East River tunnel.

LONG before the Citizens' Union, by that name, made public the declaration of its principles and invited public co-operation there was a growing sentiment that partisan direction of municipal affairs was not for the best interests of the city or of the citizens.

That seems, we will not say a fool's errand, but at least a wild-goose chase which the Commissioners for the Soldiers and Sailors' Monument to be erected at the Southeastern corner of Central Park have gone upon to the battlefield of Gettysburg. It appears that, for one reason or another, they are not satisfied with any of the schemes that have been submitted them.

A correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, writing from Salt Lake City, incloses an article published in The Salt Lake City Daily Tribune, of Aug. 20, under the caption "Story of Two Decades -- Silver-Lead Miners Making More Money To-Day." The article says:

BERLIN, Oct. 9. -- In spite of the semiofficial denials, the relations between the Imperial Chancellor, Prince von Hohenlohe, and Emperor William are very strained, and the Prince has made his remaining in office for another brief spell contingent upon two things -- the presentation to the Reichstag of the Military Trial Reform bill and no new taxes for purposes of larger naval appropriations.

Only two members of the First Brigade, National Guard, appeared on the Creedmoor shooting grounds yesterday for supplementary practice, all the others, to the number of about 150, belonging to the Second Brigade. This was due to the fact that nearly every regiment of the First Brigade had its full strength mustered at Van Cortlandt Park for Field Day.

Now that President Isaac B. Potter of the League of American Wheelmen is back in New York and re-established in official routine after his European trip, he has announced several concessions obtained by him while abroad calculated to win back disgruntled constituents and gain others. Since returning he has formally announced that he would be a candidate for renomination as the Chief Executive of the League of American Wheelmen.

Another week of dealings in lots and dwellings, a large proportion of them above Fifty-ninth treet, has been closed, and there is absolutely nothing by way of analysis or comment that has not already been said in connection with the vast number of similar transactions which have constituted the bulk of business for the last month.

To-night the hunters moon will hang full in the heavens and flood land and sea with its silvery light. It has brought a succession of perfect days and nights through all its waxing, and has made glad the hundreds of men and women who are lingering at Lenox, Newport, and in the suburbs to enjoy the outdoor life of midautumn.

At the American Museum of Natural History, in Central Park, yesterday morning Prof. Albert S. Bickmore began his Autumn series of lectures to the teachers of New York City and State, under the auspices of the State Department of Public Instruction, with a study of Greece, the particular subject being Athens.

The Republican State, city, county, and borough nominations were ratified last night by a mass meeting in Cooper Union. The hall was crowded to the doors, and hundreds of men and women were standing in the aisles, unable to find seats. There were enough people refused admission to make a fair-sized overflow meeting on the sidewalk without.

The celebration of the centenary of the birth of the frigate Constitution, affectionately called "Old Ironsides," might "point a moral and adorn a tale," but the presence of steel-armored modern warships to do honor to her battered hulk suggests rather the sharp contrast between the old and new.

" COMMODORE" Cornelius Vanderbilt and his friend the Rev. Dr. Charles F. Deems were conversing in the sitting room of the Comomdore's residence, in Washington Place, one evening, a few years before the sturdy millionaire's death, when the latter suddenly exclaimed, "I'd give a million dollars, doctor, if I only had your education."

Nobby belts for outing gowns are in the natural leather color and studded like dog collars with round nail heads, three rows of them, the larger in the centre and the smaller nearer the edge. Other belts for the same use have a plain square buckle, like a serviceable trunk strap buckle.

LONDON, Oct. 9. -- The biography of the late Lord Tennyson, Poet Laureate, which is attracting so much attention just now, is contained in two thick volumes full of interest and repeatedly emphasizes the poet's regard for the United States and his earnest desire that the parent country and its offshoot shall ever dwell in unity.

MORRISTOWN, Oct. 9. -- The horse show held here under the auspices of the Morristown Field Club closed to-day. The three days of the exhibition have been marked by fine weather and large attendance, and the success of the enterprise has been so gratifying to the managers that there is little doubt that the effort will be repeated next year.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9. -- Thomas A. Dillon, President of Cavanagh Co., distillers and wholesale liquor dealers, jumped into the lake and was drowned. Early this morning Mr. Dillon left his residence, 354 Erie Street, and walked to the lake shore, where he stood for hours looking into the water.

LENOX, Mass., Oct. 9. -- Lord and Lady Kelvin, who recently came to Lenox from Canada, are the guests of Mr. and Mrs. George Westinghouse. Monday evening a reception was given for them at the beautiful Westinghouse place. The driveway, which is paved with marble, was lined with electric lights, and colored lights were placed about the grounds.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- The Japanese delegates to the Bering Sea Conference are expected to arrive at San Francisco to-day or to-morrow. With them will come ex-Assistant Secretary of the Treasury Charles S. Hamlin, who with John W. Foster, has had charge of Bering Sea affairs in behalf of the United States.

The pigeon shooting season is now open, and the crack shots are busily engaged bringing down the birds. The new grounds of the Carteret Gun Club were opened a week ago, and George Work, the President of the club, won the first big contest of the year in good style. Mr. Work had some idea of going to Europe this Winter and trying for some of the big prizes offered there.

GIVET, France, Aug. 31. -- It was entirely through Jack that this boating trip on the River Meuse was undertaken. Had Jack not arrived at the Hotel d'Hastiere at precisely the right moment, the Belgian bateau, Le Vent du Sud, would still be rocking lazily in the wash of the canal-boats that creep past Hastiere on their way toward the sea.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 9. -- If the Bostons do not win the next three games from the Baltimores, the Temple Cup will remain in Baltimore for another year. For the fifth successive time the Orioles defeated the Bostons to-day, and as three of the games count in the contest for the silver trophy, it looks very unfavorable for the Boston contingent.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 9. -- If the Bostons do not win the next three games from the Baltimores, the Temple Cup will remain in Baltimore for another year. For the fifth successive time the Orioles defeated the Bostons to-day, and as three of the games count in the contest for the silver trophy, it looks very unfavorable for the Boston contingent.
TOPIAKA, Kan., Oct. 9. -- The scores of letters now coming to State Bank Commissioner Briedenthal from Eastern capitalists indicate that another Western boom may be looked for.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct 9. -- The past week at Yale has been an unusually interesting one, not so much because it ushered in the work and activity of the college year as that it has seen a revival of the dormant Yale spirit in athletics. Then, too, some startling rumors affecting Yale's pet athletic interest -- the 'Varsity crew -- have been circulated, discussed, denied, and finally found to have an ingredient of fact.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 9. -- Three thousand people saw the Princeton-Naval Cadet football game this afternoon. The home team was outclassed from the start, and, while the men kept up courage and played pluckily, at no time did they come near scoring. The feature of the game was the kicking of Baird of Princeton, who made the three goals, two goals from the field -- one from thirty-five yards and the other fifty-five yards.

It is a fact not generally known that Baltimore supplies the ships of all nations with sails. That city is the centre of the cotton duck industry of the world, and not only furnishes sails for foreign navies, but tents for foreign armies, the production of its twelve factories being greater than the product of all other factories in the world combined.

A party chiefly composed of Brooklynites started for the Klondike at 2 P.M. yesterday, all making the first part of their journey in the fishing schooner Nellie G. Thurston from the Erie Basin. They do not intend to go to Alaska before March.

ICHICAGO, Oct. 9. An important change in the affairs of the big vaudeville combine directed by essrs. Kohl, Hopkins Castle of this city, and controlling the vaudeville interests of nearly the entire territory west of New York, was xnade here yesterday, when the Orpheum circutt of the Pacific coast was dropped.

The twenty-fifth annual meeting of the Kentucky Trotting Horse Breeders' Association, which began at Lexington last Tuesday, and will continue until next Friday, is likely to be remembered as one of the greatest meetings in the history of the American trotting turf. The purses offered for the thirty events on the programme aggregate $75,000.

A WEEK which brought forth three such plays as "The Devil's Disciple," "The First Born," and "The Physician" will be held long in grateful memory by the habitual theatregoer. Bernard Shaw's play reveals him as a dramatist, a real dramatist, as well as a wit with a fondness for paradox and irony.

For two hours early yesterday morning four relays of the Fire Department were at work subduing an obstinate fire that caused damage to the amount of $58,000. The location is just north of the northeast corner of First Avenue and East Fifty-fourth Street, where a network of tenement houses, filled with sleeping people, and factories combined with the Henry Elias Brewery to furnish material for a considerable conflagration.
WASHINGTON, D.C., Oct. 9. -- The Attorney General to-day gave out the following statement relative to the sale of the Union Pacific Railway:

OMAHA, Oct. 10. -- General Manager Dickinson of the Union Pacific, just back from New York, says that the Reorganization Committee will buy in the road, and that S.H.H. Clark will be President. He adds that the proposed traffic contract with the Oregon Short Line Company has been rejected.
LONDON, Oct. 11. -- The Times, commenting editorially this morning on the Cuban situation, says:

WHEELING, West Va., Oct. 10. -- What is believed to be a land swindle similar to that which has been worked in some Western States is being operated by some parties outside of the State. In West Virginia there are large tracts of undeveloped timber and coal lands lying in the interior.

There are few more attractive personalities -- certainly no more attractive monarch -than Oscar II. King of Sweden, whose twenty-five years of reign are now being fittingly celebrated at Stockholm with the greatest enthusiasm. Little did Prince Oscar the sailor in his early days dream of his ever succeeding to the throne of Sweden.

Clara Barton, George H. Pullman, and Dr. J.B. Hubbell of the National Red Cross arrived yesterday on the French Line steamship La Bretague on their return from the sixth international conference of the Red Cross, held at Vienna Sept. 19-24. Nearly two hundred delegates, representing all the nations included in the treaty, were present, and made reports in their respective fields since the conference in Rome in 1892.

Perhaps against no abuse or deviation from the Gospel is there greater need of protest or resistance than the habit, in act or thought, of substituting some externalism for the spirituality of the Gospel. Poor human nature finds one easy, the other a "cross." Under the influence of this desire and tendency all sorts of rubbish are piled up around the New Testament and simple Christian worship.

Senator PLATT denies, with some heat, that he has made the remark attributed to him by one of our esteemed contemporaries that he would prefer the triumph of Tammany to the election of SETH LOW. His denial will be generally accepted. He is much too discreet and experienced a politician to say such a thing in any company in which there was a chance of its being repeated.
Gen. TRACY will come out fourth, below GEORGE, but probably ahead of WARDWELL.

About the most uncomfortable people in the city yesterday, notwithstanding the splendid weather that prevailed, was the little band of Eskimos imported from remote Greenland by Lieut. Peary, and at present housed in the basement of the Museum of Natural History, at Eightieth Street and Central Park West.

Twelve more racing days on the calendar of the metropolitan racing circuit, and then New York will know no more racing until the Spring of 1898, when all of the race tracks will be within the limits of the Greater New York.

Several of the delegates to the anti-Tammany wing of the Progressive Democratic League went yesterday to the meeting of that organization in Flannery's Hall, at Hudson and Leroy Streets, with much unwillingness. They were not in favor of the Tammany ticket. Some were for Henry George and some for Seth Low, and yet they knew that the Tammany men would be there in force, and would push through at least most of the Tammany ticket.

A great crowd gathered at Amsterdam and Columbus Avenues yesterday morning. Park Policeman Baldwin was there, holding up a shabby man, who was apparently very ill, and repeated over and over, "Give me somethin' to eat."

VICTORIA, B.C., Oct. 10. -- Two Chinamen who were mining in the Cassiar district, British Columbia, arrived here on the steamer Seattle to-day. They took out $40,000, and have drafts of the Hudson Bay Company to show for it. There is much excitement in Chinatown.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 10. -- The fever situation here is no better to-day. Early in the evening there was a promise that yesterday's record would be equaled, if not exceeded. Thirty-six new cases appeared in various portions of the city, many of them, however, being reported in houses where there was already infection.

The keen business rivalry at present existing between Alphonso Masuci of 711/2 Mulberry Street and Gluseppe Apicello of 82 Bayard Street is full of picturesque incident and is an affair of neighborhood interest to "Little Italy." Both men are fish dealers, and as fish is a prominent article of Italian diet the desire to be the purveyor in chief of that necessity has naturally engendered ill feeling, at present confined to business.

Three boys who apparently intended to open a bicycle store with stolen goods were arrested on Saturday by Roundsman Schuessler and Detective Neggesmith of the bicycle squad. The culprits are John Valentine of 437 West Fifty-second Street, John Mackintosh of 780 Amsterdan Avenue, and Frederick Carl of Fifty-fifth Street and Seventh Avenue, each sixteen years old.

DUBLIN, Oct. 10. -- To-day is the sixth anniversary of the death of Charles Stewart Parnell. Five thousand Nationalists paraded the streets to the bleak Glasnevin Cemetery, where they heaped high the grave of their famous and lamented leader with flowers brought from all the counties of Ireland.

CITY OF MEXICO, Oct. 10. -- Judge Chapital of the Federal District Court has granted a stay of proceedings in the case of the Monterey and Mexican Gulf Railway Company, which was ordered to deposit $4,000,000 as a guarantee to creditors, among whom are Americans. This case is an important one, and will now have to be revised by the Supreme Court.
There must be many German hearts filled with shame and indignation by the autograph letter from their Emperor to the Sultan.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 10. -- A resolution to indorse Henry George's candidacy for Mayor of Greater New York was defeated almost unanimously at a meeting of the United Labor League this afternoon.

Beset on all sides by one-time friendly organizations, reviling them, accusing them of treachery and political dishonesty, the position of the managers of the Henry George campaign yesterday was not an enviable one.

The Brooklyn Citizens' Committee of Fifty has perfected its plans for the campaign, and work has actually been begun in some wards. The plan of organization adopted on Thursday night provides for the appointment of one member of the committee in each ward to take charge of its organization. Thirty of the ward organizers had been appointed Saturday, leaving only two yet to be named.

Dr. Lyman Abbott preached in Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, last night a sermon attacking the traditional view of religion, salvation, and heaven. His text was from First Timothy, iv., 8, "Having the promise of light that now is." He said in part:

The evidence accumulates that the mission of Senator WOLCOTT and his associates in Europe is doomed to failure. Some of the British bimetallists having sought to bring pressure on the Government by the declaration that Mr. WOLCOTT had made a rather peremptory demand for an answer to the proposals submitted in August, he hastened to deny that he had done anything of the sort or intended to.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- the United States Board on Geographic Names, which meets here at stated intervals, has just rendered decisions determining the spelling of 149 geographic names. These include a number in Alaska, significant at this time in view of the Klondike excitement. Many variations of nomenclature for the same place are encountered and the board's action settles the uniform usuage.

When seen yesterday by a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES, with whom he discussed the business outlook in a manner that showed confidence that the country will enjoy continued prosperity, Mr. C.H. Thayer of she United States Express Company, whose words will be given due weight as coming from a man of large experience, said:

Senator PLATT'S municipal canvass is obviously directed to holding as many as possible of those who voted for MCKINLEY last year to the support of the Senator's personal candidate for Mayor this year. If the Senator's candidate can get all the votes that were cast for MCKINLEY, the Senator's control of city and State is assured.

There will be no lack of golfing activity this week, and the players who failed to win prizes at St. Andrew's last week will have two large tournaments in which to test their winning abilities. The Oakland Golf Club of Bayside, L.I., will commence its first open tournament to-day, and play will be continued through Wednesday.

One of the boldest and cleverest robberies which has come to light in some time was planned, executed, and carried almost to a successful termination in Orange, N.J., on Friday last, and the thieves were captured, with their plunder, in a house at 256 West, Forty-third Street, this city, early on Saturday morning and locked up at Police Headquarters.

HAMBURG, Oct. 10. -- In the debate in the Socialist Congress yesterday which preceded the vote abrogating the prohibition against participation in elections of members of the Diet, Herr Liebknecht, in an uncompromising speech, stoutly opposed participation or the making of any semblance of alliance with the Radicals.

Theodore Millbacker of Morris Park and Bicycle Policeman McFarland of Brooklyn are, in their places, two unfortunate men. Millbacker languishes in jail and the policeman is laid up with hemorrhages. And the way of it was accidental on both sides.

GAINESVILLE, Ga., Oct. 10. -- The failure of Capt. Mayne, the Englishman who organized the British-Georgia Gold Mining Company, with a capital stock of $5,000,000, to return to this country, has destroyed many fond anticipations of wealth. Gold mining in Georgia was given a wonderful impetus when the British and Georgia corporation. Limited, of London, with a capital stock of 1,000,000, was chartered by the Superior Court of Hall County.

BAYONNE, N.J., Oct. 10. -- Some successful experiments in kite flying, for the purpose of ascertaining comparative temperatures and weather conditions, were conducted here yesterday by W.A. Eddy, with W.W. Hotchkiss, Dr. W.H. Mitchell, and Henry L. Allan as observers.

ALBANY, Oct. 10. -- Elliot Danforth, Chairman of the Democratic State Committee, through his attorney, J. Newton Fiero of this city, has filed objections with the Secretary of State against his placing the name of Charles Frederic Adams of Brooklyn on the State ticket as the independent nominee of the United Democracy, on the ground that the petition placing him in nomination is defective and illegal.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Oct. 10. -- New Bedford's semi-centennial celebration began to-day. All of the public buildings are covered with decorations, and many private business houses and residences are masses of color.

Citizens Union Headquarters, 39 East Twenty-third Street, were open yesterday, and the Committee on Speakers and Meetings, and the sub-Committee on Certificates of Nominations were in session until late in the evening. Seth Low will be at headquarters this afternoon, and daily until the end of the campaign. Mr. Low's "office hours" will be between 3 and 5 o'clock.

According to the official estimates of the Director of the Mint, the stock of gold in the United States has now reached the unprecedented amount of $712,660,417. The additions made since the 1st of August are nearly $16,000,000, and more is sure to be imported. This increase is due to trade conditions, which are entirely natural and wholesome, but some of which will necessarily not be permanent.

While walking in the woods near Van Cortlandt Park yesterday Charles Hunstock of 424 East One Hundred and Twenty-fourth Street found the body of a well-dressed young man, apparently a suicide. It was in a thick clump of bushes near Moshulu and Jerome Park Avenues. There was a hole in the right temple, and a revolver lay close by.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 10. -- The General Chapter of Royal Arch Masons will assemble here to-morrow in triennial conclave, and on Wednesday the centennial anniversary of the founding of the Grand Chapter in the United States will be celebrated. Prominent Masons from all over the world will be present, and the sessions will continue during the week.

Lack of harmony among the stockholders of the American Grocery. Company has brought that concern to a peculiarly deplorable condition. Practically all of its trade has fallen away, and the running expenses -- now comparatively small -- are eating up its -assets, but its managers are unable to go into liquidation because differences of opinion prevent their getting the necessary consents of two-thirds of the stockholders to such a step.
A great part of the Central Labor Union's time was spent yesterday in talking politics.
" What do you think of 'Reform'?" On one of its elevated railroad advertising panels Tammany puts that question to the people of New York.

The Rev. Dr. M. Woolsey Stryker, President of Hamilton College, occupied Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst's pulpit, in the Madison Square Presbyterian Church, yesterday morning, and preached a sermon dealing with independence in politics, with particular reference to the Greater New York Mayoralty campaign. Dr. Stryker's text was from Isaiah, xlvii., 7:
Police Captain Schmittberger of the West Forty-seventh Street Police Station last night stripped the badge from one of his own policemen, locked him in a cell, and refused to allow him to give bail.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Oct. 10. -- The charge that three girls, inmates of the Orphan Home for Girls at Tivoli, were confined in a pigpen by way of punishment, was not denied by the Superintendent, E.F. George, when he was asked about it to-day. He says that three girls were thus punished for what the doctor said was laziness, and that the punishment cured them.
A water main under Madison Avenue burst early yesterday morning at Forty-eighth Street, making a geyser in the roadway and flooding the cellars and basements of ten neighboring blocks.

The eighteenth annual meeting of the Hebrew Sheltering Guardian Society was held yesterday morning, in the Orphan Asylum Building, One Hundred and Fiftieth Street and Eleventh Avenue. Samuel D. Levy, the President of the society, was in the chair, and an unusually large number of members was present.

A bold and philosophical small girl named Gussie Mantel, living at 82 Attorney Street, caused the capture of Samuel Bernstein, thirty-two years old, of 56 Norfolk Street, who was held in default of $1,000 bail for trial for burglary by Magistrate Kudlich, in Essex Market Court yesterday.

Mme. Lilian Nordica, who is to be the star of the musical festival of the State of Maine, which will take place in Bangor Oct. 14, 15, and 16, and in Portland Oct. 18, 19, and 20, arrived here yesterday on the French line steamer La Bretagne, with her husband, Zoltan Dome, and Mrs. George Walker, her sister.

The Central Park Dancing Academy has been in operation about a year at 919 Eighth Avenue, Frank L. Remey being the proprietor. Detectives Sweet, Chandler, and Mann of the West Forty-seventh Street Station went to the academy on Saturday night to investigate stories that liquor was being sold there.

-----Until human nature is subjected to mighty changes of which there is now no immediate prospect, the payment of taxes must remain a task whose performance is more or less painful. Most people know, and all people think, that their contributions to the public revenue would be smaller if everybody else paid what he should, and no possible system of taxation would do much more than weaken this general opinion.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 11. - P.M. Arthur, Chief of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, departed to-night for Peoria, Ill., to attend the conference of railroad men to-morrow. At this meeting there will be present representatives of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen, and the trainmen, telegraphers, and conductors' organizations.

Allegations supported by affidivat have been made that the Metropolitan Street Railway Company, at the same time it is putting conduits in to change the motive power of forty-five miles of its system, is also putting in conduits to run a general electric business throughout the city.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 11. -- Mariano Lopez, one of the prominent citizens of Nicaragua, now in this city, has received the following dispatch from the leaders of the insurgents in his native land:

At the navy yard in Brooklyn yesterday the men employed in preparing stone for street paving went on strike, and unless the trouble is settled quickly the paving will have to be stopped, as there is no more stone ready.

Seth Low is a soldier, a savant, a statesman. He is also, we may safely assume, a seemly scorcher; for he says himself that he rides the bicycle; and we may rest assured that he rides it well, and with grace and dignity, habituated as he is to doing everything sagaciously and becomingly and thoroughly.

CANNES, Oct. 11. -- It is announced here that the President of the Defender syndicate has notified the French Yacht Club that the American yacht Defender, which defeated Lord Dunraven's Valkyrie III. in the last series of races for the America's Cup, will take part in the next Cannes Regatta, that of the early part of 1898.

L.J. Phillips Co. have sold for the Beadleston estate to Wesslau Hogenauer the plot on the north side of One Hundred and Eighteenth Street, 185 feet east of Lenox Avenue, 75 by 100.11. It is understood that the buyers will improve the site by the erection of three five-story flats.
HAMBURG, Oct. 11. -- Herr August Bebel, the famous German Socialist, has been nominated as the candidate of the Hamburg Socialists in the forthcoming Reichstag elections.
There is being published in this Territory by Populist papers and in other ways the following, credited or charged to THE TIMES:

E.C. Seymour, a member of the Century Wheelmen of New York, has created a record for systematic long-distance riding during the last six months which is probably unparalleled. Since March 1 he has ridden 7,930 miles, and up to September he had completed thirty-six centuries; on the last eight Sundays he has completed double centuries.

ROME, Oct. 11. -- A large procession of tradesmen, headed by the Pro-Syndic of Rome and the President of the Chamber of Commerce, marched to the office of Premier Rudini, the Minister of the Interior, this afternoon, to protest against and confer with the Government regarding the increased taxation.

HAMBURG, Oct. 11. -- The editor in chief of The Hamburg Echo, Herr Rheinhold Stenzel, charged with lese majeste against Leopold, King of the Belgians, was tried here to-day, convicted, and sentenced to eight months' imprisonment. The proceedings were taken at the request of Baron Greindl, Belgian Minister at Berlin.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 11. -- This afternoon in the Auditorium on the Tennessee Centennial Exposition grounds there was celebrated tile founding of Vanderbilt University, the greatest educational institution in the South. The chief features were the presentation of a heroic bronze statue of Commodore Cornelius Vanderbilt by the citizens of Nashville to the university which he founded, and an address in commemoration of this gift by Chauncey M. Depew of New York.

" We will now waive further discussion on topics of religion, and let in the reporters," said the Rev. Dr. Granville Hunt, Chairman of the Colored Preachers' Meeting, yesterday afternoon in St. Mark's Methodist Episcopal Church. These meetings take place weekly, and the pastors discuss business or problems of Scripture. Those who attend include Baptists, Presbyterians, Methodists, and Congregationalists.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11. -- Rain is falling generally to-day throughout the parched belt of the Western States, and the long, disastrous drought has at last been broken. Reports from Kansas, Nebraska, Iowa, Illinois, Missouri, Arkansas, and Minnesota show quite general rains are still falling, with indications of continuing during the next twenty-four hours.

Edward Mitchell, ex-United States District Attorney, was appointed a Park Commissioner yesterday by Mayor Strong to succeed William A. Stiles, who died on Wednesday. As soon as he was informed of his appointment. Mr. Mitchell went to the City Hall with Park Commissioner Cruger and took the oath of office.

As the elevators of tall office buildings, hotels, and apartment houses have become indispensable in the daily life of a great many people, it is not to be questioned that elevator builders are endeavoring in every way to insure safety in their operation. Nevertheless, the number of serious accidents which have occurred within a short time indicate that much remains to be done, and are disquieting in the extreme.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 11. -- Dr. Theodore Todd Munroe of Union, S.C., and Dr. Jerome G. Going came to Atlanta yesterday to consult physicians regarding Dr. Munroe, who had become a slave to the morphine habit. Dr. Munroe retired, but had not been in bed a moment when he called Dr. Going to him.

For months the streets of New York have been reeking with poisonous odors, and this is also true of most cities in America. These deadly gases have come from the exposed sewer pipes, gas pipes, and from the turned-up soil saturated with malaria. Every breath drawn has carried some of these death germs into the body.

TACOMA, Washington, Oct. 11. -- The Chilkoot Railroad and Transportation Company of Tacoma to-day contracted with the Trenton (N.J.) Iron Works for the construction of an eight-mile tramway over Chilkoot Pass, Alaska, the same to be completed by Jan. 1. The Bleichert Tramway system will be used, over fifty of them being in successful operation in this country.

The break in the water main on Madison Avenue, which occurred Sunday morning, letting over 8,000,000 gallons of water rush through the streets and into the basements of houses in the neighborhood, was repaired last night. A new section of 48-inch pipe was fitted into the main to replace the broken portion, and at 10 o'clock the water was again turned on in the main.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 11. -- Brooklyn Day was celebrated at the Tennessee Centennial Exposition to-day. The observance began with a very creditable parade of the Brooklyn visitors, with the Nashville Reception Committee, through the principal streets. Upon arrival at the exposition grounds the procession was escorted to the Auditorium by a body of Centennial Guards.

Dr. BARTH, the editor of The Nation of Berlin, is well known in this country as a man of broad mind and liberal opinions. Hardly any other journal published in the German Empire is so impressed with the qualities of reasonableness and independence of view, and no other is more acceptable to the American reader.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- It is understood that the State Department is going over with Consul General Lee and Hannis Taylor, ex-Minister to Spain, the effect of the recent Cabinet changes, the result of Gen. Weyler's withdrawal, and his succession by Gen. Blanco, and other new phases developed by the accession of Premier Sagasta.

Among the possibilities of the next few days is the withdrawing of the name of Col. Waring from the Henry George ticket as Controller and the substitution of that of Charles W. Dayton. Close friends of Mr. Dayton have been at work with him for the last twenty-four hours trying to induce him to accept a place on the ticket.

Gen. Tracy and the Republican cohorts opened the campaign in Brooklyn last night with a mass meeting in the Academy of Music. Ex-Mayor Schroeder presided, and Gen. Tracy, R. Ross Appleton, and Senator Thurston, Chairman of the Republican National Convention at St. Louis, made addresses.

The practicability of the plans and the adequacy of the estimate of cost for the construction of the proposed rapid transit subway were again the subjects of examination by the Supreme Court Rapid Transit Commission at its meeting yesterday. There will be but one more meeting of the special commission for the purpose of taking testimony.

An interesting and close mixed foursome golf team match was played yesterday on the links of the Country Club of Westchester. Two pairs were on each side, representing the home club and the Knollwood Country Club, near White Plains. The most exciting match was that between Mrs. W. Butler Duncan, Jr., and Harry Havemeyer against the Knollwood pair, Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Harriman.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Oct. 11. -- A salute fired at sunrise by the United States monitor Amphitrite, which is anchored in the harbor, formally opened the celebration of the semi-centennial anniversary of the City of New Bedford to-day. The weather was threatening, but notwithstanding the prospect of rain, the city was thronged with visitors.

It was officially announced at Citizens' Union headquarters yesterday afternoon that Richard H. Adams, nominee for Register, had withdrawn and that Paul Goepel, President of the Liederkranz, had consented to take his place on the ticket.

WALLINGFORD, Conn., Oct. 11. -- Word was received here to-night of the arrest at Halifax, Nova Scotia, of Willis A. Trask, Treasurer of the Borough of Wallingford and teller of the First National Bank of this place.
A report made by Superintendent Bauer, as the result of his investigations of the various institutions which receive support from the city, was adopted yesterday by the Commissioners of Charities.

SEATTLE, Washington, Oct. 11. -- Among the passengers on the steamer City of Seattle, which has arrived here from Dyea, were George C. Bounds and wife and William Mizner of San Francisco, who left Dawson before the Galvin party, which arrived here on Saturday. The amount of gold brought by them does not exceed $5,000.

ALBANY, Oct. 11. -- This city has made an innovation which Mayor Thacher believes other cities will follow. It is a "meridian line," and has aroused curiosity among Albanians. The "meridian line" is being placed in position diagonally across the sidewalk at the southwest corner of the City Hall.

WEST POINT, Oct. 11. -- The steam yacht Idle Hour was stranded on the rocks where the Hudson rounds West Point, on the north side, at 6 o'clock last night. That the boat is not now at the bottom of the river is due wholly to chance.

The actual vote polled at the last three or four elections within the territory that will include the consolidated City of New York after Jan. 1, 1898, is tabulated below. In addition to the votes for President and Governor, those for Mayor are given in New York and Brooklyn, and also the vote for some county officer where it may be considered a typical or normal poll of each party.

We are told in Commissioner COLLIS'S report for 1896 that in the present City of New York "the daily consumption of water averages about 225,000,000 gallons"; also that "our people consume 110 gallons per capita per day."

Men identified with large banking and commercial interests continue to express themselves confidently as to the outlook for business and to predict that the great progress of the last few months will be much eclipsed when Fall and Winter trade returns become known. Commodore Alfred Van Santvoord, who is actively occupied with the affairs of prominent Vanderbilt corporations, is one of those who have faith that business prospects will further brighten.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11. -- Three young Russian Jewesses, Sarah Brakie, Rachel Seitzler, and Jennie Seitzler, of 786 South 6th Street started to work this morning in the combing department of Campbells' cotton mill, at Twenty-first Street and Washington Avenue. The mill employs about 500 hands, but these three girls are the first foreigners who have dared to join the ranks.

JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 11. -- Gov. McLauren telegraphed to-night from his home in Brandon that he had appointed Senator-elect Hernando De Soto Money as United States Senator to fill the vacancy caused by the death of the late Senator J.Z. George, whose term would have expired in 1899.

GALVESTON, Texas, Oct. 11. -- The yellow fever situation to-day is practically unchanged. Dr. Edward Randall reported to the Board of Health two cases in his practice, with a request that the board send experts to make an examination. One of the Cases is George D. Morgan, 810 Post Office Street, bookkeeper for Peter Gengler.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11. -- The Luetgert trial came to a sudden and unexpected close to-day. Witnesses which the defense had called in sur-rebuttal failed to respond when their names were called, and finally ex-Judge Vincent announced to the court that the case of the defense was all in.

MADRID, Oct. 11. -- Gen. Ramon Blanco, the new Captain General of Cuba, announces that he will act with great energy against the insurgents, and will employ all political means to restore equality of treatment in the various sections of the community. The Captain General adds that he has the greatest desire to end the horrors of war and to establish peace by the system which he adopted in 1879.
Col. George E. Waring, Jr., has declined the nomination for Controller on the Henry George ticket.

The editorial article entitled "Platt's Destructive Genius" in to-day's TIMES carries a point sharp enough to penetrate the densest stupidity; but it also seems to do grave injustice to Mr. Wardwell and the Prohibitionists. That article is, to a certain extent, suggestive of comparison between the attitudes of Gen. Tracy and Mr. Wardwell and their respective parties in the present campaign.

The caucus leaders of the Republican County Committee met at headquarters, 1 Madison Avenue, yesterday afternoon and discussed he status of the Mayoralty campaign. Each leader made a report as to the situation in his Assembly district, and it was said that the majority of the reports were favorable to Gen. Tracy and the ticket.

The fall of a passenger elevator from the seventh to the ground floor in the Hotel Waldorf on Friday afternoon, when the two occupants of the car, Michael Clark, the elevator man, and Paul Schuber, the head accountant in the restaurant, were seriously injured, has had the effect of making the proprietors of the big hotels doubly solicitous concerning the safety of their elevator appliances.

A pretty house wedding yesterday was that of Miss Marie Gitz, who was united in marriage to Charles H. Darmstadt of this city, at the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Gitz, 358 East Sixty-ninth Street, at 6:30 P.M. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Nicholas Bjerring, pastor of the Sixty-second Street Lutheran Church.

The work doing by the Women's League in this campaign is effective. Though they have no votes, the women have a big stake in the election. The issue is one of city housekeeping in its largest sense, and the women have clear and practical ideas of what that involves. They know the value of honesty, intelligence, training, system, and devotion to the task in hand.

The following is the Citizens' Union ticket as filed in the Bureau of Elections at Police Headquarters. It is complete, save for eight Assembly nominations. No one at the Citizens' Union headquarters at midnight, when the Bureau of Elections closed, could say why those nominations had not been filed. At the bureau it was said that that the time for filing independent nomination does not close until midnight to-night.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Oct. 12. -- White Sulphur Springs, Sullivan County, was visited by a windstorm to-day which blew down and unroofed many of the dwellings and business places. The wind was accompanied by terrific rain.

PENSACOLA, Fla., Oct. 12. -- Charles W. Jones, formerly United States Senator from Florida, died at Detroit this morning, after an illness of several weeks. His remains will be brought here for interment on Friday.

Trinity Chapel, in West Twenty-fifth Street, was the scene of a notable wedding yesterday, and it was the means of drawing a number of visitors to New York from Southern cities. Miss Margaret E. Jones, daughter of Mrs. Theodore F. Jones of this city, was the bride, and the bridegroom was Dr. I. Ridgeway Trimble of Baltimore.

-- There are usually two ways of looking at a thing. For instance, take the report just presented to the Commissioners of Charities in regard to a marvelous decrease in the list of the city's dependents -- a decrease made by the simple process of striking out the names of those unentitled to municipal assistance or undeserving of it.
" If Gen. TRACY should fall out of the canvass, the country would be filled with the gravest anxieties." -- The Sun.

The Governors of the New York Stock Exchange, after business hours to-day, will convene to receive a report of the Stock Exchange Committee on Stock List, in the matter of the application of the People's Gaslight and Coke Company of Chicago -- the successor corporation to the Chicago Gas Trust -- seeking to have listed $25,000,000 capital stock.
Stock market weak. In yesterday's stock market practically every stock on the list went down.

Walter J. Travis, the champion amateur golfer of the Oakland Golf Club, added another notable victory yesterday to his list of triumphs on the links. By defeating M.R. Wright of the Philadelphia Country Club in the final round for the Oakland Challenge Cup, his club will hold the trophy for the coming year, while Travis takes the gold medal as an emblem of his skill.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12. -- The Republican campaign outlook in New York is the most exciting topic of conversation here, and also the most absorbing one. Information concerning the prospects of the rival candidates for the chief municipal office is gleaned eagerly, and every sensational report provokes a degree of concern greater than has been yet observed in the city itself.

Notwithstanding the heavy rain of yesterday morning the attendance at the Aqueduct races was as large as it has been on any day since the Fall meeting opened. There was not much rain after the first race, but a fogbank hung low over the track all afternoon, and blotted out the colors of the jockeys on the upper end of the track.

SEATTLE, Washington, Oct. 12. -- The steamer City of Topeka arrived here last night from Juneau, Alaska, bringing several miners returning from the Klondike region and $300,000 in gold. Among her passengers was John F. Maloney of Juneau, who came out from Dawson with the Galvin party. In an interview Mr. Maloney said:

Mr. Low is making a strong canvass in the spirit required by our democratic system. He pleads the cause in which he is engaged directly before the voters in as many places as he can possibly reach. .nd his pleading is to good sense and conscience, not to prejudice or party passion or greed.
The young voters will determine this election, as they have determined every election in this State and city for the last five years.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 12. -- Mrs. Emma Zane, aged seventy-eight years, and her daughter, Mrs. Sallie Shaw, aged forty-two, were killed by burglars who are supposed to have entered their residence, at 242 Line Street, about 4 o'clock this morning. This is the story told by Mrs. Shaw's son, Eli, aged twenty-two, who says he witnessed the shooting of his mother and grandmother.

A wedding that attracted unusual attention in many parts of this country as well as abroad took place at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Owston, of 337 West Eighty-fifth Street, at 8 o'clock yesterday evening, when their daughter, Miss Agnes Douglas Owston, became the wife of William Jenkin Higgs, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Higgs of Cleveland, Ohio.

In your REVIEW OF BOOKS AND ART Oct. 3d, 1897, commenting on the book "The Training of Teachers," by Frederic Burk, the editor says: "But we desire to call attention to the clearness and force with which he sets forth the mischief done by the prevalence of the notion that pedagogy, as it is called, is a science that has been 'closed up,' the generalizations of which are final and not to be disputed.

It is reported that the American sloop Defender will go abroad to enter into competition with the crack racing cutters of the Old World. The report at present lacks definiteness, and may prove to be unfounded, but at the same time it must be admitted that it has floated about New York yachting waters so long and with so much persistency that a sudden announcement by cable from Cannes reads like a practical verification.

The Fall conventions of the Board of Trade and Transportation were begun yesterday at 1:30 P.M. in the rooms of the board, 203 Broadway. President Darwin R. James presided. The conventions will sit Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday of each week until Oct. 29.
Every public utterance of Judge TRACY shows that it is not Tammany, but SETH Low and non-partisanship, that he and his friends are bent on defeating in this canvass.

Unless there is a challenge for the America's Cup and arrangements for an international race are made for next Summer, the yacht Defender will probably be raced abroad next year. C. Oliver Iselin a few weeks ago, when talking to friends, expressed a desire to take the yacht to Europe and show how far superior she is to anything afloat there.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 12. -- "Les Miserables," Victor Hugo's masterpiece of fiction and sociology, has been barred out of the Girls' High School of this city on the ground that it is impure. An animated discussion preceded the decision of the committee of the Board of Education. William D. Rorer, Principal of the school, presented to the committee a list of textbooks required by it.

" Jimmy" Michael has no intention of quitting cycle racing at the end of this year, as has been reported. "Dave" Shafer, his manager, yesterday admitted that Michael was planning for another season of racing, which he intended to make much more brilliant than his work this year. "Jimmy has had good offers to ride horses," said Mr. Shafer.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 12. -- New York Day at the Tennessee Centennial Exposition will be memorable, not from any distinctive New York feature of the programme nor for the number of New Yorkers present, but for the scholarly addresses delivered. The opening events were much like those of Brooklyn Day, except that the weather was more propitious.
The Board of Aldermen yesterday unanimously adopted the following resolution in reference to the Amsterdam Avenue situation:

" He says he is my friend. But was it the feeling of a friend to say that if I were elected Mayor the real Mayor would be found in the United States Senate at Washington? What act in my public life does Mr. Low find that warrants such an insinuation as that?"

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 12. -- The eighty-seventh annual meeting of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions opened at 3 o'clock this afternoon in the Hyperion Theatre in this city, and will continue four days. After devotional exercises an address of welcome was delivered by Prof. George P. Fisher, D.D., of Yale University, to which the President, the Rev. Dr. Richard S. Storrs of Brooklyn, responded.

Finance, art, and that interesting body which selects itself from the community and calls itself society, will grace the opening of the new grand ball room at the new Astoria Hotel, set for Nov. 4, and from present indications it promises to surpass any event of the kind held in this country in many years, and one that will be marked in the history of New York City.

LAKE GEORGE, Oct. 12. -- A great dam, 300 feet long, 33 feet high, and 36 feet wide on the base, will be built by the Indian River Company at the headwaters of the Hudson, and be finished by Jan. 1, 1899.

AUSTIN, Texas, Oct. 12. -- This afternoon at 5:30 o'clock, within twelve miles of the limits of this city, the south-bound "cannonball" train on the International and Great Northern Railroad, consisting of mail, baggage, and express cars, and three coaches filled with passengers, was held up by four men and robbed.

The first meeting of the Board of Estimate and Apportionment to consider the provisional estimates of the various city departments and make up the budget for 1898 was held yesterday in the Mayor's office. It will require a month to complete the work.

BATTLE CREEK, Mich., Oct. 12. -- The Civic Philanthropic Conference was opened this evening with an address by the Rev. Dr. S.G. Smith, pastor of the People's Church, St. Paul, and Professor of Sociology in the Minnesota State University. Dr. Smith is President of the conference. He spoke as follows:
William T. Wardwell has accepted the nomination for Mayor tendered him by the Prohibition Party, in the following letter:
The fourteenth annual meeting of the New York State Medical Association was called to order yesterday morning in the Mott Memorial Hall, 64 Madison Avenue, by the President, Dr. Charles Phelps.
The fourteenth annual meeting of the New York State Medical Association was called to order yesterday morning in the Mott Memorial Hall, 64 Madison Avenue, by the President, Dr. Charles Phelps.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Oct. 12. -- The Monmouth County Republican Convention, held yesterday at Freehold, renominated William H. Reid of Tenent, Oliver H. Brown of Spring Lake, and D. Elsworth Van Wickle of Matawan for the Assembly. Benjamin B. Ogden of Keyport was nominated for Surrogate.

ELIZABETH, Oct. 12. -- A partly finished two-story and attic dwelling house on Atlantic Street, near Second, was blown down by , tornado this afternoon. John Clark. a hod carrier, living in Bayonne, who was at work on a house being erected across the street, had taken refuge in the building with a companion, when it collapsed.

Henry H. Cook has sold to a Mr. Fletcher, through Henry D. Winans May, the plot at the southeast corner of Seventy-ninth Street and Fifth Avenue, 32 by 100. The buyer will erect a handsome residence on the site.

ELIZABETH, Oct. 12. -- A partly finished two-story and attic dwelling house on Atlantic Street, near Second, was blown down by , tornado this afternoon. John Clark. a hod carrier, living in Bayonne, who was at work on a house being erected across the street, had taken refuge in the building with a companion, when it collapsed.

BATTLE CREEK, Mich., Oct. 13. -- The second day of the Civic-Philanthropic Conference was a great success, "Health and Sanitation" being the theme. In the morning Dr. H.B. Baker, Secretary of the Michigan State Board of Health, opened with an address on "State Boards of Health: Duty of National, State, and Municipal Governments in Relation to Public Health; Purity of Water Supply."

CHICAGO, Oct. 13. -- The entire day in the Luetgert murder trial was taken up by Attorney Phalen, who spoke for the defense. He made an impassioned plea for his client, accused the police of intimidating the witnesses for the defense, and denounced the testimony of those who had appeared for the State as perjury.

The October term of the Criminal Branch of the United States Circuit Court was opened in the new courtroom in the Federal Building yesterday morning by Judge Asa W. Tenney. The roll of Grand Jurors was called and the oath was administered to them.

LONDON, Oct. 13. -- J. Bennett Stanford, who has just returned from taking part in an expedition to Somaliland, brings news of the annihilation, at the end of June, of an Abyssinian army of 3,000 men under the famous Gen. Ras Mackonnen's, of which only 69 men escaped.
NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 13. -- Nine deaths from yellow fever were reported to-day and thirty-six new cases. The greatest number of deaths reported any previous day was six.
Among the things for which Republicans are now asked by Mr. PLATT'S organs to seek by voting for TRACY is safety for the "rights of property."

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 13. -- The new Tulane Athletic Club was opened last night at the big benefit for indigent yellow-fever patients and families in the city. An attractive programme, including boxing bouts, was arranged, and among these was a contest between Jack Cummings and Walter Griffin. Both are local men, and both had been training to fight for a long time.

LENOX, Mass., Oct. 13. -- An open women's golf tournament was played on the Lenox links to-day. There were thirty entries, representing the best golf clubs of Boston and New York, and eighteen handed in scores. The day was an ideal one for the popular game, and the clubhouse was crowded with distinguished guests.

Assistant Secretary of the Navy Roosevelt has reported that the drills of the North Atlantic squadron, which are now being concluded, have been most satisfactory, and that the warships have shown themselves to be as stanch and good as any in the navies of the world.

The Democrats of Harlem held a mass meeting in the hall at One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street and Third Avenue last night. It was expected that Judge Van Wyck would make his debut there as a candidate for the Mayoralty, and an assortment of fireworks was set off in the streets in honor of the occasion.
The contest is between Low and VAN WYCK, GEORGE and TRACY together will not get as many votes as either one of these two.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13. -- "Christian missionaries are not converting the Mohammedans," said Dr. E. Benjamin Andrews, President of Brown University, at Providence, R.I., as he sat in his room at the Palmer House to-day and chatted on a number of topics.

HAVANA, Oct. 13. -- To-day's Official Gazette publishes an edict signed by the Military Judge calling upon Evangelina Cossio y Cisneros to present herself for a term of fifteen days in jail, and ordering all civil and military authorities to endeavor to apprehend her, and, if captured, to send her to Havana jail.
TOPEKA, Kan., Oct. 13. -- Populists in a dozen towns in Kansas are subscribing to a fund for the Henry George campaign in New York City. A paper is in circulation upon which appears the following:
LEXINGTON, Oct. 13. -- The racing to-day resulted as follows:

Justice Gaynor, in the Supreme Court, in Brooklyn, yesterday granted an order further restraining Patrick J. Gleason, Mayor and President of the Water Board of Long Island City, and others, from carrying out a contract alleged by some of the taxpayers of that municipality to be fraudulent and contrary to the city charter.

A mighty effort is making this week to prevent a Republican landslide to Low. Republicans of high character and great influence have been persuaded by PLATT to engage in this rescue work. The most urgent appeals are made to party loyalty, and the Citizens' Union movement is depicted as one of special hostility to the Republican Party and a menace to the city itself.

BUFFALO, Oct. 13. -- Delegates to the convention of the International Brotherhood of St. Andrew are beginning to arrive in large numbers. This morning a number of business meetings of National Councils and of the International Committee were held behind closed doors. This afternoon devotional exercises known as "Quiet Hours" were held at St. Paul's Church, presided over by Canon Gore of Westminster.

By the mere force of events the tension in the relations between Spain and ourselves is increasing. We do not yet know exactly what Gen. WOODFORD was authorized to say to the Spanish Government. But apparently we do know what reply the Spanish Premier will submit to his Cabinet to-day.

The usual reports from the various football teams at the great universities are now circulating through the land, and wide is the amazement thereat. Yet there should not be any surprise at the nature of these reports, for they are printed from the same old stereotyped forms kept at Yale, Harvard, and Princeton, and handed down from generation to generation.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 13. -- The Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott of Brooklyn, who is attending the convention of the American Board of Foreign Missions in this city, speaking today on the political situation in New York, said:
PRINCETON, Oct. 13. -- Princeton to-day beat the Pennsylvania State College at football by a score of 34 to 0.

The second session of the first week's convention of the New York Board of Trade and Transportation was held yesterday afternoon in the board's headquarters, 203 Broadway. Although the attendance was somewhat larger than at the previous meeting there was less than a score of delegates present.

The Supreme Court Special Commission on Rapid Transit yesterday resumed the taking of testimony at its rooms, 256 Broadway. It was intended that the last of the testimony should be completed at the hearing yesterday, but Lawyer Zabriskie announced at the close that he desired to put on the stand Engineer Foster Crowell to testify again against the proposed plans, and the Commissioners decided to hear him on Monday at 12:30 P.M.

John Armstrong Chanler, lawyer and clubman, and great-grandson of John Jacob Astor, the founder of the Astor family in this country, was committed to the Bloomingdale Asylum about the middle of last February because of his alleged tendency to hallucinations, and the manifestation of symptoms of a nervous collapse.

MOHONK LAKE, N.Y., Oct. 13. -- The fifteenth annual meeting of the Mohonk Conference, friends of the Indian, began here to-day with a large attendance. Phillip C. Garrett of Philadelphia, member of the United States Board of Indian Commissioners, presided. At the morning session a review of the situation of Indian work was presented by Gen. E. Whittlesey, Secretary of the Board of Indian Commissioners.
P.H. Flynn yesterday gave out figures which he said represented the vote Mr. Low would get in each ward in Brooklyn. He allowed Mr. Low a total vote of 15,650.

In the absence of Commissioner Parker, whose attitude had prevented the filling of the vacancies in the list of Inspectors of Police, five officers were promoted to that rank at yesterday's meeting of the Police Board. The new Inspectors are Walter Thompson, Adam A. Cross, Nicholas Brooks, and John J. Harley, who had been Acting Inspectors for some time, and John H. Grant, who, as Captain, was in charge of the East Sixty-seventh Street Station.

The second Republican ratification meeting of this campaign, attended by about 1,000 persons, including four women, was held last night at the Windsor Theatre in the Bowery, between Canal and Bayard Streets. While the pit of the theatre was well filled, the balcony and the gallery showed large patches of empty seats.
S. Wang, a licensed auctioneer, was before Mayor Strong yesterday, charged with buying out small dealers whose liabilities were large and moving their stocks to a convenient place and selling them.
A cablegram to the International Navigation Company announces the arrival at Southampton at 5:30 yesterday morning of the steamship St. Paul, which left here last Wednesday.

An uncommonly large number of wool buyers from various parts of the country attended the fourth and last sale of the first series of wool auctions, in the Wool Exchange, in this city, yesterday afternoon. The sale was one of the most important held here in recent years, and the prices obtained were satisfactory.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 13. -- Golfers in Morristown mere fortunate in having the pick of the weather to-day for the first contest in the series of members' events at the Morris County Golf Club. As a result a large percentage of the enthusiastic club membership turned out on the links to play in the mixed foursome tournament.

Col. J. Thomas Scharf, Chinese Inspector for the Southern District of New York, has sent to the Secretary of the Treasury his resignation, to take effect on Oct. 15. He says that in his opinion, based on four years of practical experience and close observation, the Chinese Exclusion act is a farce and has resulted in the corruption of the Treasury Department.

The bridge car traffic for September averaged 125,002 passengers -- or, more properly speaking, passages -- per day. This is equivalent to the transport both ways of 62,500 people, and as there are relatively few passages in one direction only, this may be taken as substantially what takes place.

Mr. R.T. Wilson is another Wall Street man of long experience who regards the present stock market weakness as only temporary, and who is confident of an early renewal of the upward tendency. To a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday Mr. Wilson said:

Cornelius N. Bliss, Secretary of the Interior, in a letter sent from Washington under date of Oct. 12, to Gen. Benjamin F. Tracy, Republican nominee for Mayor, declares his allegiance to the party ticket. Secretary Bliss was one of the original Low men, and until his letter was received yesterday he had been classed by the public as a negative supporter of the Citizens' Union nominee.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- Archbishop John J. Keane, who is on a visit to the United States from Rome, was the guest of honor at a banquet at the Shoreham Hotel to-night. Over 100 persons participated, and the gathering included many prominent in the National and local Government, and the Roman Catholic Church.

" Skeets" Martin, the jockey, was justly criticised for his lethargic riding of Perseus and Percy F. at Aqueduct on Tuesday, but not until yesterday did he show that he paid any attention whatever to criticism. He engaged himself on Tuesday to ride six horses in yesterday's races, which was the last day of the Queens County Jockey Club's meeting, but he failed to put in an appearance.

One of the greatest curiosities of this curious municipal campaign was Gen. Tracy's speech in Brooklyn last evening advocating, in reality, the election of Mr. Seth Low for Mayor of Greater New York. The success of Gen. Tracy's effort was shown very plainly by the enthusiastic cheers which greeted his mentions of Mr. Low's name.

The east side was again the scene of Seth Low's personal canvass last night. He attended three meetings and made an address at each. The meetings were in East Broadway, Broome Street, and East Eleventh Street.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Oct. 13. -- Great preparations have been going on to-day on the links of the Baltusrol Golf Club for the ladies' open tournament to-morrow. Beside the big event for which the club offers a handsome prize to the winner, there will be several smaller contests, and in the afternoon the ladies of the club will serve tea to their guests.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- Justice Stephen J. Field of the United States Supreme Court, it is believed by many of his friends, will announce his retirement from the Supreme Court bench some time during the present term, though he himself would say nothing about the matter for publication when newspaper men called at his residence to-day.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 13. -- The delegates in attendance at the annual meeting of the American Board of Foreign Missions were greatly in evidence to-day, despite the fact that meetings were held both morning and afternoon. Many of the delegates that are now visiting this city for the first time improved the delightful weather conditions to see the many points of interest.

ALBANY, Oct. 13. -- The Court of Appeals handed down a decision to-day affirming the decision of the Appellate Court in declaring that the term of office of District Attorney Backus of Kings County expires on Jan. 1, 1898, and the act of the Legislature of 1896 extending his term of office two years is unconstitutional.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13. -- Corporation Counsel Thornton to-day prepared a club which the discontented street car men hope to get their Aldermanic friends to use over the heads of the street car people. The Corporation Counsel says:

Willis J. Abbot and E. Lawson Purdy of the Executive Committee of the Democracy of Thomas Jefferson announced early this morning that ex-Postmaster Charles W. Dayton had consented to accept the nomination for Controller on the George ticket -- the place made vacant by the declination of Col. George E. Waring, Jr.

LONDON, Oct. 13. -- "Mr. Jersey's" (Mrs. Langtry's) Merman won the Cesarewitch Stakes at Newmarket to-day. There was additional interest in the race, owing to the fact that two American horses, August Belmont's Keenan and J.R. Keene's St. Cloud II.; one French horse, Count de Berteux's Friolera, and an Australian horse, Prince Soltykoff's South Australian, were among the horses starting.

Here is the whole case in a nutshell. Men in Wall Street who are betting not for political effect but to make money recognize clearly what a sham is the ticket to which Gen. TRACY has lent his name. They see that Senator PLATT is running it, without the slightest chance or hope of electing it, to prevent the election of Low and to secure the victory of Tammany.

The brownstone districts, as usual, are far behind in registration. A canvass of 300 houses in the Murray Hill quarter made by the Citizens' Union showed that nearly 50 per cent. of them were closed, the occupants not having returned from the country or from Summer travel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- The ninth statistical report of the Inter-State Commerce Commission, for the year ended June 30, 1896, gives information concerning the mileage, equipment, number of employes, capitalization and valuation, accidents, and earnings and expenses of railways in the United States for the year named.

Two papers of popular interest were read before the New York State Medical Association in Mott Memorial Hall yesterday. The one, by Dr. Frederick S. Dennis of New York, dealt with "Antitoxin in the Treatment of Tetanus," and the other, by Dr. Arthur Y. Bennett of Erie County, treated of "Massage as an Occupation of the Blind."

The Dispatch is enabled this morning to make an announcement that will carry joy,to the hearts of thousands, cause many a despondent one to take a brighter view of life, and perhaps materially increase the revenue of the State. That announcement is that an eminent expert, after long and patient study and exhaustive and varied experiment, has found that the oyster of the Chesapeake and its tributaries is not "pathogenic."

On the face of it, the combined strike and lock-out in the engineers' trade in England seems to be a senseless struggle for supremacy in which both sides are bound to be badly hurt without reaching a conclusive result. This, in fact, is the view taken of the struggle by most of the London papers, which, presumably, are fairly informed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- The international court of arbitration which is to pass on the British-Venezuela boundary has been completed by the selection of M. Maertens, a distinguished Russian jurist, as umpire, and arrangements are being made for the assembling of the court at Paris during the late Summer or Fall of next year.
Sampson Oppenheimer have sold for S. Hoffmann for $13,000 the three-story brick dwelling 157 East One Hundred and Fifteenth Street, 13.4 by 100.11.

John Hickey, twenty-four years old, of 2,049 Second Avenue, is locked up in the East One Hundred and Fourth Street Station, charged with having caused the death of his uncle, James Gallagher, who died in the Harlem Hospital on Monday of a fractured skull.

BOSTON, Oct. 14. -- One of the most representative educational audiences that ever gathered in Music Hall was present to-night at the exercises in memory of the late Francis A. Walker, President of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, the well-known statistician and economist.

The Brooklyn Board of Elections was kept busy yesterday receiving declinations from candidates. One of the first received was that of Coroner George H. Nason, who declined a renomination on the Republican ticket. He is a Worth man. Thomas L. Fogarty, a candidate for Coroner on the United Democracy ticket, also declined.

TOPEKA, Kan., Oct. 14. -- There are scores of school districts in Western Kansas where one or two families constitute the entire population. State Superintendent Stryker has discovered a remarkable system adopted by these "Short-Grass" settlers to get away with their share of the State school fund.

The contest over the will of Sir Richard Tighe, who died at his residence, on Union Square, in May, 1896, leaving real estate worth $130,000 and $1,500,000 in personal property, was resumed before Surrogate Fitzgerald yesterday. Sir Richard, who was an aged man of many eccentricities, willed all his property to his wife's relatives.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 14. -- Capt. Herring of the revenue cutter Corwin, which arrived here from the north last night, says that many of the steamers going up the Yukon are unseaworthy, and he strongly advises prospectors, especially those from the East, not to buy tickets on any vessels until they are satisfied they will be able to make the trip.

SHORT HILLS, N.J. Oct. 14. -- It was women's day to-day on the links of the Baltusrol Golf Club, and a merrier, livelier, more enjoyable day has never been seen at the club since its organization, about two years ago. The perfect weather brought out a host of competitors for the women's open tournament, and the games were full of excitement and variety.

ETNA, N.J., Oct. 14. -- Benjamin Franklin Pearce, who has lived in a little hut in this village for many years, surrounded with his favorite drove of dogs, chickens, and pigs, was to-day arrested and committed to the county jail at Hackensack on a charge of shooting, with intent to kill, at Adolph Buckner, a neighbor.
LEXINGTON, Oct. 14. -- Following is the summary of to-day's racing:
Republicans are told that to vote for Low is going over to the enemy. Is Mr. Low the enemy of his own party? Where is the evidence that the Citizens' Union is hostile to the Republicans?

Without work, despondent, and unable to pay his rent, William Woolsey shot and killed his wife and then tried to end his own life. The tragedy took place in their fiat at 250 West Fortieth Street early yesterday morning. The woman's body and the unconscious man were not found until late in the afternoon.
BUFFALO, Oct. 14. -- The international convention of the Brotherhood of St. Andrew was opened this afternoon by Silas McBee of New York, Chairman of the International Convention Committee.

For the second time in the present campaign Seth Low returned last night to the city he has twice served as Mayor to speak in behalf of his candidacy for that office in the Greater New York, and for the principles which he has been selected to champion in the municipal race.

John M. Golding has sold, for Clarence Kelsey and Frederick Potter, trustees, to George A. Penniman, the lot on Fifth Avenue, 26 feet north of Eighty-eighth Street, 30 by 125, with an "L" extending to Eighty-eighth Street, 25 by 55.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- The resignation of Chinese Inspector J. Thomas Scharf of the Southern District of New York was accepted to-day by the Treasury Department according to the request of the Inspector.

In Wayne County lived a Quaker farmer with a worthless son. The latter, awkwardly driving a heavy load, struck a gatepost and was thrown. "To h -- ll with that post," he exclaimed. "But," mildly remarked the father, "there it might upset thee again." Col. ASA BIRD GARDINER -- or GARDNER -- will understand this simple tale, though he will not enjoy it.

Business was brisk to-day at Democratic headquarters, and the reports from the various sections were reassuring to the managers of the campaign, who were extremely happy over the rumors that there would be a heavy Republican vote cast for the Democratic city ticket. The rumors were said, to have emanated from Republican sources and were given credence in Brooklyn.

Emma Seitz, sixteen years old, of Sixth Street, Guttenberg, was arraigned before Recorder Mager Wednesday night, charged with burglary. The complainant was Mrs. Barbetta Topler, a neighbor, who alleged that Miss Seitz climbed into her house through an open window and stole a silver watch, 10,000 embroidery needles and $1.50.

There was an air of almost joyousness in the Henry George camp, in the Union Square Hotel yesterday. Tom L. Johnson's expansive smile was reproduced on the faces of all who are fostering the George movement, and Henry George expressed the feelings of his friends when he said that he had felt sure of his election before, but that now he was doubly certain.
TACOMA, Oct. 14. -- John Spurgeon and Robert Hennig of Cincinnati bring news that they have discovered another Klondike on the east side of the mountain about opposite the Klondike region.
" These Bowery boys are certainly with us." -- Gen. Tracy in The New York Herald.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 14. -- The opening of the new cycling track at Honolulu next month has attracted the attention of California riders, and three of the most prominent will leave here this afternoon on the steamer Monowal, accompanied by the trick rider, Harry Fowler. Those who will go are George Sharock of Tacoma, champion of the coast; A.N. Jones, the Olympic Club crack, and D.E. Whitman of Los Angeles.
The fourteenth annual meeting of the New York State Medical Association, which opened in Mott Memorial Hall, 64 Madison Avenue, on Tuesday morning, was brought to a close there at noon yesterday.

A ratification Citizens' Union mass meeting of voters of the Third Assembly District was held last evening in Macdougal Hall, 22 Macdougal Street. Charles S. Fairchild, ex-Secretary of the Treasury, the Citizens' Union candidate for Controller, was the chief speaker at the meeting. Short addresses were made also by ex-Assemblyman Robert Miller, J.H.C. Nevins, and others.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 14. -- At the next term of the State Supreme Court a decision is expected which will definitely determine the responsibility of railroad companies in the State for failing to maintain gates or employ flagmen at grade crossings outside of cities. There seems to be no doubt of the right of minor municipalities and first-class counties to pass ordinances compelling the railroad companies thus to protect travelers.
PRINCETON, Oct. 14. -- Manager Hall of the Football Association announced the completed schedule of games for the season to-day as follows:

The Democratic ticket was indorsed from top to bottom last night at the ratification meeting in Tammany Hall. The names of the candidates were received with hearty cheers, which were repeated as the different speakers referred to them, and allusions to the candidates of other parties were hissed and groaned at. Once a cheer was started for Henry George, but a vigorous chorus of hisses drowned it before it assumed any great proportions.

The Dock Commissioners at their meeting yesterday inspected the plans of their consulting architect, Edward H. Kendall, for the creation of Winter gardens on the recreation piers at the foot of West Fiftieth Street and East Twenty-fourth Street. An outline of the plans has been heretofore published.

JOHNSTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 14. -- To-morrow will be a day of historic interest, not only to this city, but to the whole of Central New York, as it is the one hundred and twenty-fifth anniversary of the transition of St. John's Episcopal Church to its present location, and the sixtieth anniversary of the consecration of the present building.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- It was announced in the Supreme Court to-day that Justice Stephen J. Field of California had notified President McKinley of his intention to retire as a member of the court, and had informed his colleagues of this fact. The members of the court, after adjournment at 4 o'clock to-day, called in a body on the retiring Justice to pay him their respects.
