ALBANY, Oct. 14. -- Shortly before noon today Secretary of State Palmer received a certificate from the committee designated by the United Democracy to fill vacancies on their ticket, announcing that they had decided to place the name of Lawrence J. McParlin of Lockport on the State ticket as candidate for Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals to fill the vacancy caused by the declination of Charles F. Adams.

The letter received by Gen. Benjamin F. Tracy from Secretary of the Interior Cornelius N. Bliss on Wednesday recalls an interview in which, on Jan. 28, 1896, he spoke his mind freely about Senator Platt and his methods. Mr. Bliss had been a leader of the anti-Platt Republicans all through the campaign, but up to that time had declined to enter into a personal controversy or make any personal comments on Mr. Platt.

The ordinance regarding lights on vehicles has again reached the hands of Mayor STRONG. Although it comes pretty near what he has already advocated, he ought to veto it. It is absurd and will prove mischievous in practice.

The practically unanimous support which Lord SALISBURY receives from the London press in the position which he has taken upon the sealing question is doubtless indicative of the state of British opinion. This in turn has been influenced by our own conduct. It is true that the Secretary of State cannot be held responsible for the publication of his dispatch to Mr. HAY.
MOHONK LAKE, N.Y., Oct. 14. -- At the second day's session of the Indian Conference there was an increased attendance, many new delegates having arrived.

The estimates of Chinese immigration which -- according to an interview published in to-day's TIMES -- are made by Col. Scharf, Chinese Inspector for the Southern District of New York, will not generally be accepted as correct by those who have before them the figures given in the United States censuses.

LONDON, Oct. 14. -- At the semi-annual meeting of the stockholders of the Grand Trunk Railroad of Canada to-day the attendance was large and harmonious. Sir Charles Rivers Wilson, President of the road, congratulated the stockholders on the announcement that the accounts showed a surplus of $13,540.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- Secretary Alger to-day received the report of an inquiry conducted by Capt. Richards into the alleged brutal treatment of Private Hammond by Capt. Lovering, at Fort Sheridan, some days ago. Capt. Richards examined a number of persons, including Capt. Lovering and Hammond.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- Although formal conferences on the Bering Sea question will not open until after the arrival of the Japanese delegates, yet the presence here of two of the Russian delegates has permitted the authorities to inform themselves quite thoroughly as to the attitude of Russia on the protection of the seals.

O partisanship, how many good men strangle their pride, cast away their self-respect, and give up their liberty in thy name! CORNELIUS N. BLISS is a very good man, and he has fought the good fight against PLATT. He seemed an implacable foe, and was ready to swear eternal hate in the presence of any one who would listen.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14. -- The President to-day appointed John A. Kasson of Iowa a Special Commissioner with plenary powers to carry into effect the reciprocity provisions of Sections 3 and 4 of the Tariff act, approved July 24, 1897.

HAMPTON, Va., Oct. 14. -- There is an unusually large attendance at the Hampton Normal and Agricultural Institute, which opened, for its thirtieth year, last week. Two hundred and twenty negro students have entered this year, and forty Indians. The total enrollment will number nearly 650, and the full capacity of the school is taxed to the utmost.

BILLINGS, Mon., Oct. 14. -- Engineers are at work on the survey for the Billings Canal, to be built by the State Arid Land Commission, and as soon as this work is completed, contracts for construction will be let. The canal will be constructed substantially, the design being to make it an improvement that shall last as long as Yellowstone Valley itself. Its head gates and outlets will be of solid masonry.

The convention of the Board of Trade and Transportation held its third session yesterday afternoon in the board's headquarters, 203 Broadway. Attendance at these sessions is growing larger daily, and the delegates are taking more interest in the matters discussed.

Attorney General McKenna has sustained the customs officials in their contention that diamonds imported through Canada from a country not contiguous to Canada must pay a discriminating duty of 10 per cent.

Property owners and residents along Amsterdam Avenue filled the spacious parish house of St. Michael's Church, at the corner of Amsterdam Avenue and Ninety-ninth Street, last night, to emphasize their protests against the occupancy of Amsterdam Avenue by the four-track underground trolley systems of the Metropolitan and Third Avenue Companies.

-- One of the papers read at the State Medical Convention this week called attention to massage as a trade or profession in which the blind could put their specially developed sense of touch to such good advantage that in time they would monopolize this important and valuable method of treating disease, and render themselves much more than self-supporting.
GLENVILLE, West Va., Oct. 14. -- Gov. Atkinson, who has hitherto kept still about the trial of his wife, has made a statement of which the following are the principal points:
NEW HAVEN, Oct. 14. -- The American Board of Foreign Missions to-day elected the following officers:

CHICAGO, Oct. 14. -- The news that John D. Rockefeller has determined to provide ships which will carry most, if not all, the iron ore from his iron mines in the Lake Superior region, has caused consternation among vessel owners. It was only a little over a year ago that Mr. Rockefeller entered the field of lake shipping.

HUNTINGDON, Penn., Oct. 14. -- An attempt at train wrecking was made last night near Newton Hamilton, twelve miles east of here, on the Pennsylvania Railroad. Frank Noe, one of the culprits, was arrested, and is now in the Mifflin County Jail. It is believed that others were engaged with him in the work.

At no season of the year is the splendid race track of the Westchester Racing Association at Morris Park so attractive as in the Fall, for at that time the thousands of trees which surround the big tract of ground are dressed in their gayest foliage, the infield and lawns wear their brightest green coats, and the odor of new-mown hay from the near-by fields lends a delicate perfume to the atmosphere.

Minnie Seligman Cutting, the actress, was a vivacious witness in the Supreme Court, before Justice Bischoff, yesterday, in her own suit against Harry C. Miner, the theatrical manager, for $5,000 damages for breach of contract.

Under the auspices of the Brooklyn Institute Prof. Frederick W. Osborn of Adelphi College read a paper yesterday on "Some Recent Aspects of Child Study," to a large audience, in the lecture room of the Young Men's Christian Association, at 502 Fulton Street, Brooklyn. The majority of those present were Brooklyn or New York school teachers. Prof. Osborn, in part, said:

The cable dispatch from Paris which relates to the arrest of a German suspected of being a spy at the French camp at Chalons, appears, with curious significance, at the same time with a dispatch from Paris, via London, setting forth that an association has been formed in this country to secure the escape from his prison in Guiana of Capt. DREYFUS.

CARTERSVILLE, Ga., Oct. 14. -- Three weeks ago David A. Roberts shot and killed his father-in-law, James W. Casey, and severely wounded his wife. He fled into a swamp, and a posse of men and dogs which pursued him was unable to dislodge him, and gave up the chase after several days of hard work.
LANCASTER, Penn., Oct. 14. -- W.D. Eaton's new romantic play, called "Iskander," founded on a novel by Disraeli, was produced here this evening by Frederick Warde and his company.

I have not troubled you for some time with my communications on Cuban matters. There was no occasion for it. Today, however, I again seek the hospitality of the columns of your valued paper for a few remarks which, possibly, may interest your readers.

BATTLE CREEK, Mich., Oct. 14. -- Mayors' Day at the Civic-Philanthropic Conference was a great success, many city executives of Michigan and adjacent States being present or sending representatives. The audience was large, cultured, and appreciative, manifesting great interest in the subjects.

The two prominent characters in this lesson are Paul and Felix. They are not only remarkable men in themselves, but they are typical men, standing for great classes. One was noted for his religious character; the other for his wickedness. One was the most eminent preacher of the Gospel the world ever saw; the other the Governor of Judea.

Lieut. H.D. Wise of the United States Army broke the record for road riding from Washington to New York by completing the distance of 239 1/2 miles yesterday morning in 27 hours and 39 minutes. The best previous record known was 36 hours and some minutes. The ride was under the auspices of the New York Athletic Association.

ALBANY, Oct. 15. -- The Board of Railroad Commissioners has denied the application of the Commissioner of Public Works of New York City and New York citizens living on and near Amsterdam Avenue for a reopening and rehearing of the application of the Forty-second Street, Manhattanville and St. Nicholas Avenue Railway Company for permission to change its motive power from horses to the underground system of electricity.

The coal area of the United States is, approximately, 200,000 square miles. Of this 600 square miles is anthracite, 180 in Virginia and the rest in Pennsylvania. The coal surface is about equal to the combined scope of the New England States. New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Delaware, Maryland, and the two Virginias.

Honest men are proverbially indebted to the fallings-out of the other kind. But they are also, on occasions, indebted to the occasional bursts of candor to which even experienced politicians are prone and to which inexperienced politicians are almost certain to give way at the most inopportune seasons.
Gov. Frank S. Black has consented to speak at the mass meeting at Lenox Lyceum Wednesday night, at which Secretary of the Interior Cornelius N. Bliss will preside.
LONDON, Oct. 15. -- The Very Rev. Charles John Vaughan, M.A., D.D., Dean of Llandaff since 1879, died at Llandaff this evening.

DENVER, Oct. 15. -- John A. Gordon, Democratic nominee for Justice of the Supreme Court, yesterday tendered his resignation as such candidate to the Executive Committee of the party. The resignation was accepted, and J.H. Gatsbart, the Populist candidate, was indorsed for the position.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15. -- It was a day of action and reaction in wheat, with the bulls having the better of it in the end to the extent of a seven-eighths of a cent advance. A feature of the day's news was the renewal of drought reports, which, coming so late in the season, had no small influence in the closing strength.

Col. Asa Bird Gardiner's assertion at the meeting at Third Avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street Wednesday night that a million of dollars was stolen annually in the Street Cleaning Department has awakened a storm of protest from the officers immediately concerned. Deputy Commissioner Francis M. Gibson, who is a retired army officer, after consultation with Col. Waring and Major Cushing on Thursday, wrote to Col. Gardiner demanding an explanation.

In THE TIME'S Saturday Review of Books and Art of Oct. 8 I read with much pleasure Mrs. Sherwood's article on Gen. Scott. But I think the title of "Old Fuss and Feathers" very appropriate, as you will see if you take the trouble to read the copy I have made of a letter written by him to my grandfather, who was Gen. Brown's aide de camp, and subsequently his son-in-law.

LONDON, Oct. 15. -- At the conference of the Northern Union of Conservative Associations at Berwick-on-Tweed to-day Lord Londonderry tendered his resignation of the Presidency of the union. His reasons were set forth in a letter to the Executive Committee, in the course of which he said:

SMITHTOWN, L.I., Oct. 15. -- The relations between native human beings and the native oysters of Smithtown are to be judicially investigated in connection with the arrests of George Thompson of this place and William Risley of Setauket.

Capt. Sheehan and a detachment of police from the West Thirtieth Street Police Station raided an alleged gambling club called the Nevada Club in the Hotel Metropole last evening, and arrested six men.

MADRID, Oct. 15. -- The Spanish Cabinet to-day discussed the case of the American schooner Competitor, which was captured in Cuban waters on April 25, 1895, a case which, owing to the fear which Premier Canovas del Castillo had of stirring up action upon the part of the Congress of the United States, was postponed by the late Government.

By a vote of 382 to 99, and after four hours of acrimonious debate that lasted until after midnight, the General Committee of the German-American Reform Union last night indorsed the City, County, and Borough of Manhattan ticket of the Citizens' Union, headed by Seth Low.

The retirement of Judge FIELD from the bench of the Supreme Court marks the close of a judicial career unequaled in length, as he himself points out in his letter of resignation, by any of his predecessors or colleagues in that tribunal. The fact of long service is in itself a great advantage to a Judge.

LONDON, Oct. 15. -- To-day were presented to Sir Michael HicksBeach, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, the memorial which has been in process of signature among the leading banking houses and financial and mercantile enterprises in the City of London, and also telegraphed resolutions adopted by the Canadian Bankers' Association against bimetallism on Oct. 6.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15. -- Chief of Detectives Colleran and four of his men have captured four of the most daring burglars of the United States and Canada, and stolen property valued at $25,000 is in the hands of the police awaiting identification. The men under arrest are "Sheeny Joe" Rubenstein, the leader of the gang; Harry Rogers, James Flaherty, and James Williams.

The Banda Rossa is a military band of the first class, and is well worth hearing by those who are fond of music performed by such organizations. Evidently there are many such person, for the first concert of the band in this country, given at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, was attended by a very large audience, which was largely Italian, both in its personnel and its fecundity of bravos.

A fire, discovered at 3 o'clock yesterday morning, in a two-story brick building at 547 West Forty-third Street, destroyed that structure and two frame buildings adjoining, causing a loss of $20,000. Six horses stabled in the frame buildings perished in the flames, and Night Watchman Henry Ahrens, who was asleep on an upper floor, was rescued with difficulty by Fireman Keenan, who carried him out in an unconscious condition.

ALBANY, Oct. 15. -- The celebrated contest of Mrs. Elsa Forster to obtain $170,000 of the estate of Salvatore Cantoni, consumed nearly the entire day in the Court of Appeals to-day upon an appeal from a decision of the Appellate Division, allowing Mrs. Forster to continue her suit against Cantoni begun in his life time, with his executor, Louis E. Bomeisler.
The George campaign may now be said to be fairly under way, and according to the Executive Committee there will not be a moment's "let-up" until the polls close on election day.
Some of our contemporaries treat the appointment of the Hon. JOHN A. KASSON as a Special Commissioner in matters of reciprocity as a mere case of patronage giving. We cannot so regard it.

CHICAGO, Oet] 15. -- In the Luetgert murder trial to-day ex-Judge Vincent continued his address to the jury in behalf of the de fense. The buiden of his plea was that there was no evidence that Mrs. Luetgert had been murdered. He repeatedly accused the police of manufacturing evidence for the State.
There was a "hot time in the old town" last night, and it was centralized on the top floor at 153 West Fifty-third Street, where the Colored Republican County Organization held a special meeting.

Theodore H. Price of the Stock Exchange house of Price, McCormick Co. talked yesterday on stock market conditions to a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES. Mr. Price believes in the soundness of things commercial, but thinks the pace in speculation has been more rapid than was warranted by existing conditions.

An alcohol lamp and a tiny steaming kettle were features, yesterday morning, of the trial of Minnie Seligman Cutting's suit against Henry C. Miner for $5,000 damages for breach of contract, in the Supreme Court before Justice Bischoff.

A number of students of the class of 1900 in Columbia University had a good deal of fun yesterday with some unfortunate freshmen who did not know enough to keep out of their way. They caught six of the latter, and, taking them up to the Boulevard, near Morningside Heights, forced them to don baby caps and wheel each other up and down that thoroughfare.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15. -- The Korean Legation received an official cable to-day stating:...

BOSTON, Oct. 15. -- The United States Circuit Court of Appeals to-day ordered a mandate to issue in the case of the Western Union Telegraph Company vs. The American Bell Telephone Company, in accordance with an opinion filed by the Court in September, 1895.

NEWPORT, Oct. 15. -- Closely following the marriage of Miss Natalie Dresser to John Nicholas Brown comes the announcement to-day of the engagement of Miss Pauline Dresser, Mrs. Brown's sister, to the Rev. Mr. Merrill of Tuxedo.

BOSTON, Oct. 15. -- Mr. E.C. Stedman's "Poems Now First Collected," to appear next Wednesday from the press of Messrs, Houghton, Mifflin Co., contains the verses of nearly twenty years, together with a few hitherto unpublished and inspired by West Indian and Caribbean scenery, and odors and sounds also, for they have not only the light but the air of the tropics in them.
LEXINGTON, Oct. 15. -- The meeting of the Kentucky Trotting Horse Breeders' Association closed to-day. Following is a summary of to-day's races:

In to-day's TIMES -- Saturday Review of Books and Art -- a most charming and valuable additional publication by the way -- there is a little note entitled "TWO Heroes of Balaklava." in which one "J.P." inquires about the death of a survivor of the famous charge.

Mr. Fields used to tell of a merchant who rose from the perusal of Shakespeare with the feeling that "not six men in Boston could have written those plays," and this merchant, it seems to us, fairly represents the average of the class of readers to whom Mr. Bates addresses himself, a fact that should in fairness influence our criticism of the result.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15. -- Revolt seems imminent in the ranks of the Chicago and Milwaukee Brewers' Association, the organization that has stood for two years before the public in the light of a trust. Six of its most prominent members -- the Pabst, Schlitz, Schoenhafen, Fortune Brothers, Tossetti, and Standard Companies -- besides the Anheuser-Busch Company of St. Louis, have come to an agreement to form a new association.

The resignation of Col. J. THOMAS SCHARF from the office of Chinese Inspector for the Southern District of New York is accompanied by a statement of which Secretary GAGE can hardly fail to take notice. He resigns upon the express ground that his efforts to secure the enforcement of the laws restricting Chinese immigration have not been supported by the Treasury Department and have in fact been thwarted and baffled by influences within that department.

The one important sale at Bangs's last week was that of Wednesday, Oct. 6, when a portion of the library of the late Rudolph August Witthaus, M.D., was disposed of. As might have been expected, a good part of the books were medical in character, but there were also a number of interesting works on alchemy and astrology, and no less than nineteen early printed books, some of which brought very fair prices.

-- Somebody has played an elaborate and cruel joke on the American Humane Society, for it is impossible to believe that the members of that organization, unless led astray by false information supplied to them by some malicious humorist, would have rendered themselves and their cause ridiculous.

Many persons will be glad to read of the punishment of a soldier of the National Guard of this State who engaged in riotous conduct on Labor Day while returning from rifle practice at Creedmoor. No persons will be better pleased than the great body of National Guardsmen who regard the upholding of the civil law as a most important part of their duty.

BUFFALO, Oct. 15. -- This morning President Houghtaling delivered his opening address before the International Convention of the Brotherhood of St. Andrew. He had a good deal to say in the address about personal purity. Referring to temperance, Mr. Houghtaling said: "I hate to meet a brotherhood man with the smell of liquor on his breath.

The report of W.D. Cornish, who was appointed special master to take testimony in the suit of J. Pierpont Morgan and others, as trustees, against the Union Pacific Railway Company, Frederic R. Coudert, and others, as receivers, was confirmed yesterday by Judge Lacombe of the United States Circuit Court.

SPEONK, L.I., Oct. 15. -- From the present indications the conservative element and the ancient name of Speonk are to win a decisive victory over the Remsenburg partisans after a long, patient, and apparently hopeless fight.

Among the company who will assemble this afternoon on Morningside Heights, when the Sons of the Revolution present to Columbia University a tablet commemorating the battle which took place 121 years ago to-day, in part upon the ground where the university buildings stand, there are probably but few to whom that battle and its results are more than a reader's vague memory.

BATTLE CREEK, Mich., Oct. 15. -- "Philanthropy" was the special subject considered at the Civic-Philanthropic Conference to-day. The attendance was so large that the principal meetings hereafter will be held in the Seventh Day Adventist Tabernacle, the largest auditorium in the city.
WADING RIVER, L.I., Oct. 15. -- John Mumby, a deaf-mute, who lives here, has begun war on bicyclists who ride on the sidewalks of this town.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 15. -- United States Senator Arthur Pue Gorman to-day issued an open letter to Edwin F. Abell, publisher of The Baltimore Sun, in which he offers to relinquish the leadership of the Democracy in Maryland, provided Mr. Abell will accept it, and support the Democratic ticket in the coming State and legislative campaign.

KINGSTON, Oct. 15. -- Early this morning Katie Clum, the seventeen-year-old daughter of Henry Clum, a well-to-do farmer of Prattsville, Greene County, was abducted from her home by three negroes named Henry, Frank, and Mary Darr and spirited away.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 15. -- The links of the Morris County Golf Club were practically owned by the women golfers of the club to-day, and their bright costumes, flitting here and there over the broad greensward, gave the links an additional and very attractive element of picturesqueness.
Why should not the Citizens' Union nominate candidates for the Assembly?

Arrangements have been made for the celebration in this city of the two hundred and fiftieth anniversary of the adoption of the Westminster Standards, beginning Monday, Nov. 8, at 3 P.M., in the "Old First" Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Eleventh Street, under the auspices of the Historical Committee of the New York Presbytery.

CAMDEN, Oct. 15. -- Eli Shaw was arrested this afternoon on the charge of having murdered his mother and grandmother early on Tuesday morning. Ever since the murders were committed the young man had been under surveillance, although yesterday Chief Dodd declared that there was no suspicion attaching to him.

MOHONK LAKE, N.Y., Oct. 15. -- The Indian conference closed to-day. The success or failure of the allotment system was the main theme of discussion to-day. Gen. Whittlesey in presenting some statistical information said he believed there was now enough light to justify the conclusion that the allotment had been a wise and beneficent policy.

PRINCETON, Oct. 15. -- The coaches of the Princeton football team are anxious on the eve of the game with the Carlisle Indans, and the whole university believes that it will be the hardest fought game of the year. The work of the Tigers has not changed for the better, and the seriousness of the situation has brought twelve coaches to town.

RUTLAND, Vt., Oct. 15. -- In the October Term of the United States Circuit Court just closed in this city, Judge Hoyt H. Wheeler handed down a decision in the case of Arthur S. Weeks, United States Internal Revenue Collector for Vermont, who was charged with contempt by a State court.

The public opening of the new Astoria Hotel, at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, will take place in November, and its social christening will be on Nov. 1, on which date a charity entertainment will be given.

READING, Penn., Oct. 15. -Suffering under the shame of imprisonment for an alleged trivial offense, Mrs. Matilda Malto, widow of Francisca Louza Malto, a Brazilian of eminence, died late last night at St. Joseph's Hospital, in this city, from the effects of a dose of morphine taken with suicidal intent.

By what right the street railways of New York carry mails has been a question which followed the decision of Corporation Counsel Thornton of Chicago, who affirmed on Wednesday that the street railways of that city had no right to transport mail.

Seth Low addressed the first of the three meetings which he attended last night, at Majestic Hall, 119 East One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street. The hall has a seating capacity of about 500, and it was packed with people who proved responsive to everything that the Citizens' Union speakers said.

From a high ofilelal source comes the intimation that there is a strong probability of another 1 per cent. dividend on Southern Railway preferred tn the near future. There was talk of this when the stock was selling up close to 40 a few weeks ago. and at that time many insiders were outspoken in declaring that such a dividend would soon be made.
The Police Board listened yesterday afternoon to several protests filed against the certificates of nomination of several candidates for minor offices by independent political bodies.

There was trouble yesterday among the workmen employed in laying the trolley on the Second Avenue line of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company. About 200 discharged men and strikers went in the morning to the up-town office of Contractor D.D. McBean, at 2,136 Second Avenue, and asked for their pay.

At the fourth session of the Fall conventions of the New York Board of Trade and Transportation yesterday afternoon the subject of "an American International Bank" was discussed. There was a larger attendance than on the day before.

ERIE, Penn., Oct. 16. -- The biennial report of the Board of English Home Missions submitted to the conference of Evangelical Lutherans to-day shows that the financial condition though distressing, is far from being discouraging. The deficit for the biennium just closed was $3,767. The statement of the Treasurer shows receipts of $27,431 and expenditures of $27,420, leaving a balance of $11.

LONDON, Oct. 16. -- The Honor Oak Golf Club, which has owned One Tree Hill for three years, finding the property was being wantonly destroyed or stolen, caused the ground to be fenced in, thus shutting out the general public, to the great delight of the neighboring residents, whose life had been made hideous because of the congregating there of drunken, dog-fighting ruffians from the slums of Deptford.

THE supremacy of American art metal work has received a notably conspicuous recognition again in an order just executed by Tiffany Co. for shipment abroad. This most recent example of American metal work to go abroad derives special interest from the fact that it is to be presented as a testimonial to the manager of the "Metallgesellschaft" of Germany, one of the leading spirits of the metal trade on the Continent of Europe.

During the past year the air has been laden with prophecies more or less sinister. We were told that the European Cabinet was a sham -- a bubble to be pricked by the point of a cambric needle; that selfish greed, and a piratical passion to seize the property of a dying man would dissolve the concert of the Princes; that a general European war was imminent, and that Armageddon would come.

Nearly 300 members of the National Guard appeared on the Creedmoor shooting ranges yesterday, to qualify as marksmen and sharpshooters. By far the largest number of entries were made for the latter class of qualification, as yesterday was the last day of this year on which practice at the 500 and 600 yard ranges will be allowed.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- It is generally expected in Washington that James Knox Taylor will be appointed Architect of the Treasury, as a result of the competitive examination which has just closed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- Administration Republicans are palpably exercised about three political contests now waging. They are manifesting an engrossing interest in New York, where they hope to see Gen. Tracy win; they are deeply concerned about Ohio, where they hope to carry the Legislature for Senator Hanna, and they are alarmed about Maryland, which they have hoped to carry and insure the election of a Republican Senator to succeed Gorman.

Another mishap has occurred to the monitor Terror, the repairs to which will keep her in the navy yard in Brooklyn for some time. The trouble was found to be with the condensers and the out-board delivery pipes.

PORTLAND, Me., Oct. 16. -- Robert Damren of Oakland has within a few days found his daughter, from whom he was separated in 1876, and Miss Alice Maude Wormell, as she has been known, a young lady of unusually prepossessing appearance, residing in this city, is happy in the discovery of her father.

It is known that with the exception of a stature, the camel is absolutely a llama; Its blood globules being elliptical, its teeth reptilian in form, its rudimentary third and fifth toes permanent. It possesses, further, that mysterious pouch of the stomach for the storage of fluids, the same kind of callosity on breastbone and knees, acquired by the camel through kneeling to receive loads.

Evangeline Cossio y Cisneros, the young Cuban girl whose escape from a prison in Havana was attended with so much daring, was formally welcomed to freedom last night at Delmonico's, and afterward in Madison Square.

IF any one is laboring under the delusion that because there will be no Franco-Prussian opera under the management of M. Maurice Grau at the Metropolitan Opera House this season, the borough of Manhattan, Greater New York, will go hungry for good music, this is the hour when his delusion is to be scattered to the four winds.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- Guarded intimations from the friends of the Administration concerning the inclinations and intentions of the President make it appear that, while the annual message of the President will recommend currency reform, there will not be any sanguine expectation that currency reform will be accomplished or much more than begun.

The two-day athletic carnival under the auspices of the Now Jersey Athletic Club, at the Madison Square Garden, Friday and Saturday evenings, Dec. 17 and 18, promises much. Last year the New Jersey Athletic Club held a one-night meeting at Madison Square Garden, and, through the work of James E. Sullivan and other members of the Athletic Committee, the meeting was a success, financially and from an athletic point of view.

Many city officials attended the reception and dinner at the Waldorf given for Dr. Thomas Hunter, Principal of the Normal College, last night. The dinner was given by the pupils who were graduated from Grammer School 35 between the years 1855 and 1870. Dr. Hunter was then Principal of that school.

STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 16. -- Lizzie Fleming, a servant in the employ of Alanson C. Dixon, a Stamford grocer, was seized with homicidal mania shortly after midnight last night, and, arming herself with an axe, entered her mistress's sleeping room, attacked Mrs. Dixon, inflicting probably fatal injuries, badly wounded Mr. Dixon, and hurt his daughter. She then fled and was found this morning, unconscious, under the front porch of the house.

EASTON, Penn., Oct. 16. -- The Lafayette-Cornell game this afternoon resulted in a tie, each eleven scoring 4 points. Lafayette's three backs -- Worthington, Walbridge, and Bray -- were on the sick list, and in no condition to go on the field, and before the end of the game they were compelled to give up playing. Worthington was disqualified for slugging, but the two others became exhausted in the second half.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 16. -- That the revival of support on the part of the undergraduate body in general in all athletic matters was not spasmodic is manifest to any one who goes out to the field almost any afternoon in the week.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16. -- Chicago's new library was thrown open to the public this week, after its dedication on the evening of Oct. 9 -- Chicago Day. There are several points in connection with this new structure which are worthy of note. In the first place, there has been no suspicion of jobbery; then, it was finished within the limits of the original estimate, which was $2,000,000.

The Harlem friends of Henry George opened their campaign last evening with one outdoor meeting at One Hundred and Twenty-first Street and Park Avenue, where the Henry George Club of the Thirty-fourth Assembly District had an illuminated stand, and another mass meeting at Majestic Hall, in One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, under the auspices of the Sixteen to One Club.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 16. -- Capt. Goodrich of the Harvard 'Varsity crew was seen this afternoon in regard to the report that H. Willis, who has rowed third on the Leander crew for the past few years, and is a pupil of Mr. Lehmann, is coming over this Fall to help the training of next year's crew.

That was a suggestive remark in the latest manifesto of JACOB WORTH that when the people were once aroused they would have no trouble in smashing a political machine and that it was as easy for them to smash two machines as one.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16. -- Bishop McLaren repudiates the proposition to put the Episcopal Church of America under the hierarchy of the Church of England. He rebukes what he calls the sycophancy of certain American Bishops who fell in with the scheme. The Bishop is a sturdy American, and demands freedom for his Church.

PARIS, Oct. 5. -- M. Hanotaux's curt dismissal of M. Loze, the French Ambassador in Vienna, is the diplomatic topic of the day. The incident is without parallel in modern French history. M. Loze was not exactly a model Ambassador, but his tenure of office in the Austrian capital had been marked by no startling or unpardonable political blunder.

Eight carefully prepared models for the Soldiers and Sailors' Monument were placed on exhibition at the arsenal, in Central Park, yesterday. The designs shown include widely varying plans for the monument, from those in which the plain circular shaft predominates to the triumphal arch design.

KUMPEI MATSUMOTO is the youngest native editor in Japan. He is the proprietor of a monthly magazine called The Greater Japan, the organ of the Liberal party in Japan, and he has recently started an international journal named Japan and America.

Mr. Goodwin has been absent from New York a long while, and he returns to us at the Knickerbocker Theatre to-morrow night with a new play, "An American Citizen," by Madeline Lucette Ryley, which has been warmly received in other cities. The smart author of "Christopher, Jr.," "A Coat of Many Colors," and "The Mysterious Mr. Bugle," seems to have chosen a promising subject for this play, and to have treated it skillfully.
The Attempt to Show that the Notaries' Certificates Are Improperly Worded Made Light of by the Citizens' Union Lawyers.

LONDON, Oct. 16. -- The British Cabinet this morning held its first Autumn meeting at the Foreign Office. The Premier, Lord Salisbury, presided, and all the Ministers, with the exception of Lord James, the Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster; Viscount Cross, Lord Privy Seal, and Walter Long, the President of the Board of Agriculture, were in attendance. The meeting lasted two hours.

A BRISK man of business, nervous in temperament and brusque in action, but socially as genial as mellow sunshine, holds the office of Assistant United States Treasurer in this city. His name is Conrad N. Jordan, and his experiences in the financial world have been as varied as they have been distinguished.
The Democratic Union, which its President described as "composed of Democrats of all shades and stripes," held its ratification meeting in Carnegie Hall last night.

The stormiest meeting of the campaign in Brooklyn was that of the Young Republican Club last night. This is the powerful organization which has given Brooklyn two Mayors, Low and Schieren. It declared for Low last night, after a tempestuous session in which the lie was passed, members shook their fists in each other's faces, and for long periods of time it was impossible to hear anything but an uproar of shouts and howls.
Brooklyn is not only to have lower rates for electric lights, but within the next week the largest and most powerful electric generator ever constructed will be in operation there.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Oct. 16. -- Kate Clum, the seventeen-year-old daughter of Henry Clum of Prattsville, Greene County, who was, her father claims, abducted by Henry, Frank, and Mary Mendore, negroes, early on Friday morning, is safe in her mother's arms to-night.

Abram S. Hewitt arrived home from Europe yesterday morning on the Cunard steamship Umbria. Mr. Hewitt went abroad for medical treatment and spent most of the time in Paris. He was under treatment there for twenty-one days.

NEWTON, Mass., Oct. 16. -- Yale defeated the Newton Athletic Association this afternoon -- 10 to nothing -- before a crowd of 3,000 spectators. It was a hot day, and the frequent delays from minor injuries spread out the time of the two short halves over a long period and detracted from the interest of the contest.

Is the President aware that his Secretary of the Interior is committing him to the support of the worst element of his party in the Mayoralty campaign in this city? If he is aware of this, the day will come when he will deeply regret that he did not "call him down."

LONDON, Oct. 16. -- While most of London society is concentrating its attention upon the shooting estates and the golf links of the country, so much of society as may be in London will assemble at Covent Garden on the night of Oct. 19 to listen to the first rendition of "Diarmid," the new opera, the work of the Marquis of Lorne and Hamish McCunn, the former the librettist, the latter the composer.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16. -- The Pennsylvania football eleven to-day defeated Dartmouth by the score of 34 to 0, 16 in the first and 18 in the second half, 20 points more than Harvard scored against the same team last Saturday. Pennsylvania was weakened by the absence of Capt. Minds at full back and Garnett at left tackle. At no time during the game did the visitors menace the red and blue's goal.

People along First Avenue between Ninety-fifth and Ninety-sixth Streets were pleased last night by the knowledge that while they may not live quite so fashionably as those on Madison Avenue, they indulged yesterday afternoon in an aquatic demonstration rivaling that which startled the more pretentious thoroughfare last Sunday morning.

A story of a man with his entire left side paralyzed, his skull fractured, and his body covered with bruises, sitting in a cell in the Leonard Street Station for twenty hours without medical attendance was told yesterday morning at Police Headquarters.

ANACONDA, Mon., Oct. 16. -- Operations in coal-producing regions in Montana were never so active as at present. All coal and coke properties are running to full capacity, but cannot supply the demand. At How the Montana Coal and Coke Company has over 400 coke ovens in full blast, 500 men employed, and is now at work building an additional forty ovens, which will necessitate hiring more men.

We have the testimony of The Daily News, the only direct supporter of Tammany in the daily press of the city, that the Tammany managers are "happy" over the prospect of "a heavy Republican vote for the Democratic city ticket."

Fire Marshal Brymer of Brooklyn is investigating an incendiary fire which Mrs. Meyer Klauber discovered early yesterday morning in the brick workshop of her husband's dyeing and cleaning establishment in the rear of 295 Bedford Avenue, Williamsburg. The crying of Mrs. Klauber's baby led to the discovery of the blaze. Klauber's store is in front of the premises, and all around are thickly populated dwellings.

Mrs. Murphy will figure no more on the books of the Dock Department, and her shanty will figure no more as a landmark of the upper west side. No one in the Dock Department knows how long Mrs. Murphy has held squatter sovereignty over the neighborhood of Seventy-ninth Street and what would be Twelfth Avenue if the avenue were cut through.

LONDON, Oct. 16. -- The Newmarket race-course has been the centre of the social world of Great Britain during the week. There were large house parties at all the swell residences in the vicinity, and the Prince of Wales, who has been shooting with the Duke of Cambridge on the Six-Mile Bottom, attended the races daily, generally wearing a dark brown golfing cape.

There was jubilation at the Citizens' Union headquarters in East Twenty-third Street yesterday because of a number of things that have happened and which Chairman Reynolds and Secretary Clark and others in authority think are good auguries in the campaign.

" I have been trying to find out what the people around me are most interested in these days," said the Philosopher the other evening at the club, in the tone of a man who was making a strictly confidential communication.

The League for Political Education began its series of Saturday morning lectures yesterday at 11 A.M. in its headquarters, 509 Fifth Avenue. Mr. C.R. Lowell and Mrs. Silas Betts spoke on "The Municipal Situation.'' There was a good attendance.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 16. -- Harvard met the cadets this afternoon and the game resulted in a score of 10 to 0 in favor of the Crimsons. Under the circumstances, the result was remarkable, as at times Harvard was clearly outplayed, and only succeeded in gaining her distance through good work by Dibblee and remarkable running and good defensive work on her territory.

MATTEAWAN, N.Y., Oct. 16. -- Through the accidental discharge of a gun at the target practice of the Fishkill Hunt Club yesterday George Freeman, a negro, lies in the General Hospital at Fishkill Landing to-night in a precarious condition, suffering from the effects of the entire charge of the gun, which he received in his body.

A letter of interest to voters from Archbishop Corrigan will be read this morning to the congregations of the Roman Catholic churches in the Archdiocese of New York. Primarily, the letter designates the last Sunday of the present month as the date for the annual collection of Peter's Pence.

Solomon declared that there was nothing new under the sun, and this dictum has always been a damper on the genius of every writer. Try as he may, he feels that he is only saying things that have been said hundreds of times before, and he drops his pen and sighs over the ancient ideas that he is trying to freshen up by putting them into a new arrangement of old words.

Ex-Postmaster General Thomas L. James, President of the Lincoln National Bank, returned recently from a European trip, during which he had many opportunities of observing at close range the attitude of the foreign investor toward American securities and learning the views of prominent European financiers regarding the American outlook.

LONDON, Oct. 16. -- Although, as was said last week, people of the highest authority are confident that the Anglo-French dispute in the matter of the West African boundaries will be amicably settled, the discussion of the various phases of the subject occupies so much journalistic attention, both in London and Paris, and is engendering so much heat, that it is impossible not to treat it as a matter of importance.

LONDON, Oct. 16. -- The Army and Navy Gazette voices the opinion of British military men in congratulating the country upon the fact that the Government has at last determined to increase the effectiveness of the army. The Gazette says it is useless to deny that there is reason for alarm, adding that the army is unequal even to ordinary demands, the home batteries and battalions being little better than so many "military nurseries."

Many inferences might be drawn from the formidable list of musical announcements published in to-day's issue of our Illustrated Weekly Magazine. The most obvious inference is that the opera is not only not a necessity to the true musical life of this metropolis, but actually cramps it.

The interscholastic football season in this vicinity is now well under way. The championship season of the local association will begin next week. The championship season of the Long Island Interscholastic Athletic League opened yesterday, and from now until Thanksgiving Day, when the championship fight will end, some good football is expected.

What kind of a dinner can be given for a party of six people at one of New York's best restaurants for $20? At the best and highest priced restaurants a dinner worthy of the name "dinner" could not be given at all, many people would say.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 16. -- The return match between the Tuxedo and West Point golf teams was played here to-day and West Point was victorious by four holes. The team representing West Point was the best yet put in the field, and Tuxedo was short two of its good men. The course was in good shape, except on two of the putting greens.

MADRID, Oct. 16. -- The Government has received information from Manila that the insurgents of the Philippine Islands have replied to the overtures of Capt. Gen. Primo de Rivera, who has been trying to induce them to submit, demanding extensive amnesty to begin with and a full pardon eventually.

BATTLE CREEK, Mich. Oct. 16. -- The programme of the Civic-philanthropic Conference to-day was an interesting one. There would have been a lively discussion at the morning session had things turned out as anticipated. The Rev. A.E. Craig, Ph.D., of Albion, in his address on "Ethics of Socialism" denounced modern socialistic ideas most vigorously.

We have no sympathy with any class of voters that are guided in polities by their own interests exclusive of and opposed to the general welfare. It is charged by one of the narrower Republican organs that this is true of the Wheelmen in the present campaign in seeking the election of Mr. Low.

It is plain that Mr. WOLCOTT, with his commission, would do well to come home, submit a blank sheet of paper as a full report of all that has been accomplished, and leave Mr. McKINLEY free to try to secure the absolute maintenance of the gold standard to which he is pledged.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 16. -- Mrs. Emma Zane and her daughter, Mrs. Sarah Shaw, who were murdered at their home in this city early on Tuesday morning, were buried this afternoon. Eli Shaw, son of Mrs. Shaw, and grandson of Mrs. Zane, who is under arrest on suspicion of having murdered them, was allowed to be present at the funeral services at the house this afternoon.

BERLIN, Oct. 16. -- Soon after the new United States tariff went into effect the officials of the American Embassy informed the German Government that the United States was willing to begin negotiations for a reciprocity treaty under Clauses 3 and 4. No answer of any kind has thus far been made, but preparations are actually making to open negotiations.

IT may not be known to many readers -- and especially to those to whom the inner life of a girls' boarding school is a sealed book -- that at the present moment there are hundreds, and indeed thousands, of cases of two girls who genuinely "love" one another, or at any rate act as if they do, and believe they do.

Marriages are not of such frequent occurrence in most families that it is absolutely necessary to be posted upon the intricacies of that important factor in wedding etiquette stationery, but when such occasions do arrive a few hints are helpful. These are given in a beautiful little book compiled by Charles Young, and published by the stationery department of the Bailey, Banks Company of Philadelphia.

Princess Kaiulani, otherwise Miss Victoria Cleghorn of Hawaii, and her father, A.S. Cleghorn, arrived yesterday from Southampton on the American Line steamship Paris. The Princess, accompanied by a Hawaiian maid, followed her father down the gangway, and they went at once to a carriage which awaited them on the main floor of the pier.

She was a "plump lady." That was what the children who stood outside the church door to see the wedding guests go in said of her. They were right; she was a plump lady, though she was attired in a black gown, "which is the gown of all others all unduly plump ladies should wear, as the fashion books say.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Oct. 16. -- Application was made to Justice Barnard, at Special Term to-day, for a hearing in certicrari proceedings instituted by Whitelaw Reid's wife, Elizabeth M. Reid, against the assessors of the town of Harrison, Westchester County, to review the assessment made against Ophir Farm, the Reid country seat.

LONDON, Oct. 16. -- At the Chapel Royal, St. James's Palace, to-day, the Sub-Dean the Rev. Edgar Sheppard, baptized the infant son and heir of the Duke and Duchess of Marlborough. The Prince of Wales, who was a sponsor at the Duke of Marlborough's christening, acted again to-day in that capacity for the latter's son.

Congressman Quigg, President of the Republican City Committee, gave out the following statement last night concerning the nominating petition of the Citizens' Union placing Seth Low in nomination for Mayor. The law requires that this petition shall be signed by 2,000 voters of the municipality.

LONDON, Oct. 16. -- Edward Langtry, the husband of Lily Langtry, the actress, died last night in the Asylum for the Insane at Chester, to which he was recently committed by a Magistrate after having been found wandering in a helpless condition in that vicinity. It is supposed that Mr. Langtry was suffering from concussion of the brain, due to falling down the gangway of the steamer on which he traveled from Dublin to Holyhead.

READING, Penn., Oct. 16. -- The artist in quest of studies in "picturesque decay" will be well repaid the time and trouble spent in a pedestrian trip along the towpath of the Schuylkill Canal, between Port Clinton and Schuylkill Haven, Penn.

CAMBRIDGE, Oct. 16. -- The football outlook at Harvard is much more encouraging than it was a week ago. This is due, beyond doubt, to hard work and good, steady coaching. The team work is much better, and there is more vim and dash in the play than there has been hitherto manifested.

The laying of the cornerstone for Fisk Hall, which is to be a part of Barnard College, yesterday afternoon, gave Joseph H. Choate, the lawyer, an opportunity to give his opinion of Messrs, Croker and Platt and to declare his admiration for Seth Low and his belief that New York City needs him greatly.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16. -- Officials of the Treasury Department no longer have the slightest doubt about the adequacy of the new tariff law. They are fully convinced that it will produce sufficient revenue to run the Government and provide a surplus for such use as Congress may designate. During the first three months and fifteen days of the current fiscal year, beginning July 1, the deficit amounts to $34,380,000.

A short statement made by Consul General LEE in Washington regarding the recent liberation of a young woman from a Spanish prison in Havana seems to have escaped the attention of newspaper readers. It is interesting as an explanation of some of the difficulties that would have been encountered if the Spaniards were really determined that Miss CISNEROS should not escape.

When the booths closed at 10 o'clock last night 567,608 citizens had qualified to vote at the election of the first Mayor of the Greater New York. The heavy registration is proof of the general interest felt in the result to be determined Nov. 2.

Proprietors of swindling games who frequent county fairs and fleece the farmers are the latest attestants to the fact that the era of prosperity has set in. It has been a year of exceptional profit to them. The greater the swindle and the more transparent, the more satisfactory it has been as a means of parting the countryman from his dollars.

HAVANA, Oct. 16. -- The coasting steamer Triton, from Havana to Bahia Honda, Province of Pinar del Rio, has been wrecked between Dominica and Mariel, on the north coast of that province. The steamer went ashore this morning during heavy weather, grounding about eight miles from the coast.

GLASGOW, Oct. 8. -- Watson's new 80-rater Bona has been so successful during the past Summer that Fife is to be commissioned to design and build a Bona for Mr. Peter Donaldson, owner of Fife's 66-rater Isolde.

" The Revival of Alchemy" was the subject of an address delivered by Dr. H. Carrington Bolton at a recent meeting of the New York section of the American Chemical Society, held in the lecture room of the College of the City of New York.

PEORIA, Ill., Oct. 16. -- The proposed plan of federation ratified by the conference of Grand Chiefs and representatives of the railway brotherhoods, held here during the week, was made public to-day. Although the convention of the firemen, trainmen, telegraphers, and conductors had indorsed the proposed plan, it has been referred to the lodges for ratification.

WHENEVER "The Lady of Lyons" is performed nowadays one may read in the newspapers how bombastic and false to nature it is, how meretricious its glitter, and how vulgar its appeals to the prejudices of the commonest kind of humanity, as, for example, in its set speeches about heroism, military glory, the equality of man, and the steadfast affection of good mothers for their sons.

Local cycle organizations were busy last week holding meetings and considering what could be accomplished to better cycling, both in a general way and in specific instances. The Associated Cycling Clubs of New York last Monday held a meeting, at which much of interest and something of importance was done. The Streets and Highways Committee of the League of American Wheelmen City Consulate also met, and the Consuls as well decided a number of questions.

MACON, Ga., Oct. 16. -- Constable William Limba, son of a Justice of the Peace of Powersville, in Houston County, and Barker Amos, colored, fought yesterday afternoon at the home of Amos, about two miles from Powersville.

PEORIA, Ill., Oct. 16. -- The proposed plan of federation ratified by the conference of Grand Chiefs and representatives of the railway brotherhoods, held here during the week, was made public to-day. Although the convention of the firemen, trainmen, telegraphers, and conductors had indorsed the proposed plan, it has been referred to the lodges for ratification.

WHENEVER "The Lady of Lyons" is performed nowadays one may read in the newspapers how bombastic and false to nature it is, how meretricious its glitter, and how vulgar its appeals to the prejudices of the commonest kind of humanity, as, for example, in its set speeches about heroism, military glory, the equality of man, and the steadfast affection of good mothers for their sons.

The Citizens' Union has done good service by its method of stultifying such prominent opponents as Platt and Croker. It has compelled them to resort to a Job lot of nominations, which have a tinge of comical confusion; and it has also wounded the feelings most terribly of the Siamese dictators whose raids upon every movement not partisan are matters of local history.

Philip Shields, twenty-four years old, and Joseph Beach, twenty-four years old, both living at 28 Second Avenue, were badly burned early yesterday morning while attempting to extinguish a fire which broke out in the apartments of Frederick Shields, on the third floor of the building. Both of the injured men were removed to Bellevue Hospital.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 17. -- The Slocum memorial window presented to the First Presbyterian Church of this city by Mrs. Russell Sage and her brother, Joseph Jermain Slocum, was unveiled to-day. The ceremonies concluded the centennial celebration of the church, which has extended throughout the week and in which Mrs. Sage has taken a prominent part.
NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 17. -- Harry Edwards, who was thrown from his bicycle on Wednesday night, died this evening at his home in Arlington.

The Rev. Reese L. Alsop, rector of St. Ann's Protestant Episcopal Church, Brooklyn, preached yesterday morning on the issues of the greater city campaign. His text was taken from Revelation, xxi., 16: "And the city lieth four square." He said, in part:

Justice Gaynor of the Supreme Court, in a decision which will be handed down by him this morning, upholds the Citizens' Union petition nominating Seth Low, and declares that the decision of the Police Commissioners of this city in respect to these petitions is valid.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17. -- The feat of replacing an iron bridge span 242 feet long, 25 feet wide, and 30 feet deep with one of the same dimensions of steel was accomplished in this city to-day in two minutes and thirty-two seconds.

Henry George has in an open letter replied to certain statements in regard to himself attributed in published interviews to ex-Mayor Abram S. Hewitt. He contradicts Mr. Hewitt in some instances categorically. The letter is as follows:

The returns of exports and imports for September, just published by the Bureau of Statistics, make a remarkable showing. For every dollar's worth imported there was nearly two and a half dollars' worth exported. The following table gives the classified figures:

The members of the Seventh Regiment are making preparations for the Winter season. The Athletic Committee has selected Saturday, Dec. 4, for the annual games, and already some of the athletes are in training. The shooting usually begins in October, but this year the opening had to be postponed because the ranges are not ready.
LONDON, Oct. 17. -- The Sunday Times, in a review of the bimetallic negotiations, says:

PORT TOWNSEND, Washington, Oct. 17. -F.W. Vaille, Assistant Superintendent of the Pacific Coast Mail Division, who went North three weeks ago to look into the feasibility of establishing a new mail route in connection with the Canadian Government to the interior of Alaska, returned on the Alki yesterday.

Consciousness of the importance of good statuary is attested by the obstacles we place in the way of too prompt an acceptance of monuments that lack the approval of the best critics who can be designated off-hand and fail to meet the ideas of the chief officials more directly interested than others in the appearance of squares and parks.

" Christ and Socialism" was the title of the sermon delivered yesterday morning at the Madison Square Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Dr. Melancthon Woolsey Stryker, President of Hamilton College. Dr. Stryker took his text from the Book of John, 5th chapter, 27th verse.

When Bernard C. Hinrichs, fifty-eight years old, of 3 Ash Street, Jersey City, went home Saturday night he was under the influence of liquor and seemed to be on the verge of delirium tremens. He exhibited a revolver, saying he had bought it for the purpose of killing his wife, his son, his daughter and himself. His wife and children succeeded in quieting him, however, and persuaded him to lie down.

VICTORIA, B.C., Oct. 17. -- The steamer Danube has arrived here from St. Michael, whence she sailed ten days ago. She brought eight-two passengers, most of whom failed to reach the mines by the all-water route. Some got as far as Fort Yukon and had to turn back. There are twelve miners from Circle City, who bring about $72,000 in gold dust.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Oct. 17. -- It is the general opinion here at present that there is too much politics in the school-system of the State. This feeling has been brought about by the methods said to have been adopted by State Superintendent of Public Instruction Charles S. Skinner, in the appointment of enumerators for the census soon to be taken under the provisions of the biennial school census law, passed two years ago.

LONDON, Oct. 18. -- The Daily Chronicle announces this morning that, in view of Lord Salisbury's desire to resign the Premiership, an early reconstruction of the Cabinet is probable. According to The Daily Chronicle, no serious difference of opinion exists among the Ministers on matters of policy, but Lord Salisbury finds his health unequal to the strain and burden of his two offices of Premier and Foreign Minister.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- President Nick Young of the National League to-day made public the batting record of players who took part in fifteen or more championship games last season. The record is as follows:

One of the most exciting runaways seen on Seventh Avenue in many years occurred sortly after 4:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon. But for the presence of mind of Mounted Policeman John McGee several fatalities might have been recorded. As it was, two men and a light wagon and a wheelwoman were dangerously injured.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Oct. 14. -- Jacob Tomlinson, the hermit of Mission Valley, is hunting for a wife. He is seventy-eight years of age and fully realizes that he has only a few more years to live. He wants a good-looking young woman to cheer his declining days and to inherit his comfortable fortune when death summons him to the other shore.

Prof. Felix Adler delivered the first lecture of the season yesterday before the Society for Ethical Culture at Carnegie Music Hall in the presence of a large audience of members and guests. His subject was, "The Need of a Working Philosophy of Life."

The paper read at the Battle Creek conference by Dr. HOLMES of Chicago on the tramp question is not one of the most valuable results of that meeting. The tramp does undoubtedly present a question which is interesting, and even important, though Dr. HOLMES seems considerably to exaggerate its importance.

STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 17. -- At the hospital to-day the condition of Mr. and Mrs. Alanson C. Dixon of this place, who were assaulted with an axe by Lizzie Fleming, their servant, while seized with a homicidal mania early Saturday morning, was said to be slightly improved, but they are both in a critical condition.
NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 17. -- There were five deaths to-day from yellow fever and fifteen new cases.
HAVANA, Oct. 17. -- La Lucha, in its leading editorial yesterday, attacked the Sagasta Cabinet, and said: "We are returning to the policy of cheat and inconsistency."

When the work of Columbia University has been adjusted to its new environment on Morningside Park plans that contemplate an extension of the opportunities for public school teachers to study their profession will be put into execution.

The meeting of the Tammany wing of the Progressive Democratic League yesterday at Flannery's Hall, at Hudson and Leroy Streets, was not half as large as the one held on the previous Sunday, and the apparent success of the Henry George movement seemed to have disconcerted the delegates.

Laden with munitions of war for the fighting patriots of Cuba, the little two-masted schooner Silver Heels crept out of this port by way of Hell Gate early yesterday morning, and while the Deputy Marshals were scouring the East River and the Upper Bay in vain search, she was flying down the Sound before the impetus of a howling wind from out the west.

Fire in the seven-story brick factory and warehouse at the northeast corner of Spring and Hudson Streets yesterday afternoon got completely beyond the control of the firemen and almost entirely destroyed the building. For several hours the flames, fanned by a stiff westerly wind, threatened the buildings along the entire block on the south side of Spring Street from Hudson to Varick Street.
Why should Republicans in Greater New Work vote for Gen. TRACY?

No journalist in this city, none, indeed, in the country, could be so peculiarly missed as will be Mr. DANA. It is just half a century since he began newspaper work on The Tribune, under the guidance and inspiration of HORACE GREELEY. It is nearly thirty years since he took control of The New York Sun.

ALBANY, Oct. 17. -- The motion calendar in the Court of Appeals for to-morrow contains an interesting case brought from the Syracuse-Buffalo department. It is to determine whether or not a lunatic properly may be made a party to an action at law.

The Rev. W.H. Brooks preached yesterday in St. Mark's Methodist Episcopal Church, (colored,) in Fifty-third Street, near Broadway, on "Principle Above Party." His text was from Isaiah lxii., 1. Mr. Brooks grew especially emphatic in the course of his address when he hinted at the prejudice against the colored race which is thought by many members of it to exist in the local councils of the Republican Party.

Charles A. Dana died at 1:20 o'clock yesterday afternon at his home, at West Island, Dosoris, near Glen Cove, L.I. He was ill a little more than five months, but it was not until about three weeks ago that it was known that his illness was mortal. On June 9 he was at the office of The Sun, apparently strong and hearty.

A thoroughbred bull dog and a cab horse struggling fiercely for the mastery was an interesting sight at Broadway and Twenty-seventh Street yesterday afternoon. The fight lasted probably eight or ten minutes before it was possible to tear the dog away. It took the combined strength of four men to hold the dog down while the cab horse, shaking with fear and pain, was led away out of further danger.

In an interview with Murat Halstead, and given out by him last night, ex-President Benjamin Harrison formally declares himself on the Mayoralty situation. Gen. Harrison strongly favors Gen. Tracy's candidacy, and speaks disapprovingly of Seth Low and the Citizens' Union.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17. -- An abstract of the annual report of the General Superintendent of the Railway Mail Service shows that at the close of the year there were 1,164 railway Post Office lines, manned by 6,854 clerks; 33 electric and cable lines, with 102 clerks; 42 steamboat lines, with 57 clerks, making a total of 1,239 lines and 7,013 clerks.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Oct. 17. -- C.C. Pinckney, Jr., manager and the holder of controlling interests in the Farmer's Mining Company, the Wappoo Mills, the Horseshoe Mills, and Magnolia Mining Company, suspended payments Saturday. According to best information obtainable, the liabilities are in the neighborhood of $200,000.

LONDON, Oct. 17. -- The Sunday Times says that the reports that an English syndicate was to buy the Union Pacific Railway were based upon the efforts of meddling promoters to blackmail the reorganization committee into giving them a share of the profits.

The Republican leaders take the heavy registration to mean the election of Gen. Tracy. "I have not analyzed the figures yet," said Senator Platt last night, "but the large registration in the up-town districts favors the Republican ticket. We appear to have held our own down town. A heavy registration always means a large Republican vote."

Wall Street starts in upon the coming week with greater confidence than it has had at any time for a month past. Among the traders bearishness is still rampant. But with the rank and file of Wall Street, with the larger interests as well as with the smallest commission house customer, there is a general feeling that the reaction, which has already gone further and lasted longer than was expected or warranted, is over with.

WINDSOR, N.S., Oct. 17. -- Historic Windsor, one of the most beautiful towns in the provinces, was devastated by fire this morning. The fire raged for six hours, beginning a little before 3 o'clock, the flames all the while being fanned by a violent northwest gale.

Miss Miriam Azar, recently of Jaffa, and Touma Elia, formerly of Lebanon, were married last evening in the Syrian Orthodox Church, 17 Washington Street, according to the rites of the Greek Church by the Venerable Rev. Archmandriet Raphael Hawawiny.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17. -- Representatives of the Cook County Democracy will go as an escort to Mayor Harrison when he visits New York, Nov. 1. This was decided on at the meeting of the Democratic Club this afternoon.

This is the first opportunity the public has ever had, or probably ever will have, of testing a remedy for Catarrh, Bronchitis and Asthma absolutely free. Thousands of bottles of medicines for other ailments have been given away during the past, but never before in the history of medicine has a cure for these dangerous diseases been offered to the people without price.
CHICAGO, Oct. 17. -- The Rev. Robert Collyer of New York, who is visiting Chicago, said to-day:
LONDON, Oct. 18. -- The Daily News, in an editorial headed "The Bimetallist Conspiracy,'' says this morning:

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Oct. 17. -- The schooner Alfred A., Capt. Albert Pittee, owned by the Rockport (Mass.) Granite Company, sank shortly after midnight near the Outer Pig Rocks of this port while on her way from Rockport to Boston laden with paving stones. The crew consisted of the Captain and three hands, all hailing from Rockport.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18. -- The jury before which Adolph L. Luetgert has been on trial on the charge of wife murder, is engaged in an effort to agree on a verdict. It took the case a little before 5 o'clock this afternoon.

A letter was sent yesterday to Miss Julia Arthur and Arthur Lewis, her manager, by the members of Miss Julia Arthur's company, expressing their regret and sympathy at the loss sustained by her through the burning of the theatre in Detroit, with all the scenery and costumes of "A Lady of Quality."
The registration of over 567,000 votes in Greater New York means a vote between 525,000 and 530,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18. -- The Executive Committee of the National Municipal League has issued an address to "the friends of good government throughout the United States," the burden of which is a denunciation of Tammany Hall and a plea for the election of Seth Low as Mayor of Greater New York.

Tennessee Coal and Iron's September statement made a remarkable showing. Net earnings for the month were $62,000, against $28,000 in September, 1896, an increase of $34,000, or over 120 per cent. This represents a deficit of $19,873 in September of last year changed into a surplus last month of more than $14,000.

A committee of thoroughly competent, earnest, and volunteer citizens, of different parties, is engaged in Washington in framing measures of currency reform to be submitted to the next session of the Congress. Its work is progressing favorably, under the Presidency of ex-Senator EDMUNDS.

The American Association of Allied Arts met at the Nevada, Boulevard and West Seventieth Street, yesterday, Mrs. L.W. Holcomb, the Vice President, acting as Chairman, in the absence of Mrs. E. Launitz-Raymond, the President, Mrs. Cory, Principal of the School of Industrial Art, read a paper on "Advantages of a Practical and Industrial Education for Women," in which she pointed out the opportunities for good designers offered in certain American industries.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- The Director of the Mint has submitted to the Secretary of the Treasury his report for the fiscal year 1897, covering the operations of the mints and assay offices, together with the statistics of foreign countries relative to production, coinage, and the monetary condition of each.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- In September the Secretary of the Treasury received a report from New York that the services at that port of Chinese Inspector J. Thomas Scharf could be dispensed with without detriment to the service. On Oct. 1 Inspector Scharf was informed that his services would not be required after Oct. 15.

The trial of Minnie Seligman Cutting's suit against Henry Clay Miner for $5,000 damages for alleged breach of contract was continued yesterday morning in the Supreme Court before Justice Bischoff. The former actress, stylishly garbed, sat with her counsel, and several of her friends were in the room.

SEATTLE, Washington, Oct. 18. -- Capt. P.H. Ray of the Eighth United States Infantry, who was sent with Lieut. Richardson to explore the Yukon Basin and make a full report to the War Department concerning supplies and the need for troops, is now at Fort Yukon, 1,300 miles from St. Michael.

BUFFALO, Oct. 18. -- The Rev. Dr. Charles Gore, Canon of Westminster Abbey, who came to Buffalo to attend the convention of the Brotherhood of St. Andrew, has been quite ill since Friday evening, when he gave his address in Music Hall on "Individual and Corporate Work: Their Mutual Dependency." To-day he was reported somewhat improved, although still weak and unable to leave his bed.

LONDON, Oct. 18. -- The afternoon newspapers to-day echo the opinions of the morning newspapers in congratulating the Government upon "finally disposing of the bimetallic scare" and expressing regret that it should "ever even have seemed to receive support in high quarters."

Seth Low spoke at four meetings in Brooklyn last night -- in the Fourteenth, Sixteenth, Nineteenth, and Seventh Wards. In each he was received by large audiences, and in three of them by audiences that were distinctly enthusiastic.

The rich fund of personal humor of Mr. Nat Goodwin and his power to touch the sympathies of his fellow men and women are amply illustrated in the performance of "An American Citizen," the new comedy by Madeline Lucette Ryley, with which he began a long engagement at the Knickerbocker Theatre, in presence of an uncommonly fine and highly appreciative audience last evening.

CAMDEN, Oct. 18. -- There was an exciting scene in Mayor Westcott's office this morning, which culminated in Assemblyman Harry S. Scovel, attorney for Eli Shaw, who is accused of the murder of his mother and grandmother, being ejected from the office by two policemen. Subpoenas had been issued for the appearance of some forty to fifty persons this morning at the Mayor's office for examination relative to their knowledge of the case.

One of the quietest portions of Jersey City was thrown into an uproar early yesterday morning, and the opinion is that the incident was caused by an officious burglar alarm in the home of Charles Shaw, at 22 Duncan Avenue.

Edward Bell of Bell Co. offered on the Stock Exchange yesterday to bet $3,000 to $1,000 against Low, $5,000 to $1,000 against Tracy, and $600 to $5,00 against George on the condition that all candidates go to the polls. The wagers were on commission. No acceptances were reported.

ALBANY, Oct. 18. -- Attorney General Hancock has just received notice of a decision by the United States Supreme Court that virtually settles the right of the State to seize lands within the forest preserve of the Adirondacks upon which there are arrearages in taxes and to compel persons who have cut timber from the lands after the arrearanges began to pay the State for such timber cut.

An enthusiastic crowd of about 6,000 Republicans assembled in the Clermont Avenue Rink, Brooklyn, last night, to hear Gen. Tracy's second speech in that city in the present campaign. Benjamin Butterworth of Ohio, Senator John M. Thurston of Nebraska, and Henry A. Powell, the candidate for District Attorney of Kings County, were the other speakers, and Silas B. Dutcher presided.

The regular weekly meeting of the colored clergymen of Greater New York, held in St. Mark's Church, Fifty-third Street, yesterday afternoon, was devoted almost entirely to politics. Of the fourteen clergymen present, representing Methodist, Baptist, and Presbyterian churches, all were for Seth Low for Mayor, and nearly all have been speaking in his behalf from their pulpits, and will continue so to speak.

The Congregational Club held its first meeting of the season at the St. Denis Hotel last evening. The meeting was very largely attended, probably because of the topic announced for presentation, which was "The Mayoralty Campaign in Greater New York." Among those present were the Rev. Drs. A.H. Bradford, William Hayes Ward; S.H. Virgin, Albert Shaw, J.L. Halsey, George Taylor, and the Rev. Drs. A.H. Clapp and C. Irving Fisher.
Charles W. Dayton received a magnificent welcome at Terrace Garden last night at the hands of 2,500 people.

Eleven policemen were detailed yesterday to take children to school. They reported at some of the east side schools at 8:30 o'clock, and took the children to the schools to which they had been assigned, and at 3 o'clock in the afternoon escorted them back again.

The Supreme Court Special Commission on Rapid Transit, composed of Arthur D. Williams, John Sabine Smith, and George W. Young, held yesterday afternoon its last meeting for the purpose of hearing testimony.
Allow me to dissent from what you say in yesterday's TIMES, in reply to T.G.B., respecting the incorrectness of Kipling's lines:

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18. -- The resolution recently passed by the Select Council to submit the question of leasing the city gas works to a private corporation was defeated to-day in Common Council. The vote was 54 for the resolution and 64 against. There were but few absentees.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- The annual report of Third Assistant Postmaster General John A. Merritt was made public to-night. It shows that the postal revenue for the year and the total actual expenditures were as follows: Ordinary postal revenues, $81,698,281; receipts from ordinary money-order business, $967,181; revenue from all sources, $82,665,462.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. -- The State Department has refused the request of the Mexican Government for the surrender to it, under extradition treaty, of Jesus Guerra, who was one of Garza's lieutenants in the celebrated Garza raid into Mexico in December, 1892.

It is plain that there is a good deal more of politics than finance in the treatment of the Wolcott commission by the Salisbury Government. Had finance alone controlled, the negative decision would have been prompt and final. As it is, the decision seems to have been negative, but more or less ambiguous.

There is one theory of the intrusion of ex-President HARRISON with an interview into our municipal campaign which presents the ex-President in an amiable light.
