That is to say, that he has a desire to give a boost to his old friend and Secretary of the Navy, and that he does not much mind what he says for that purpose.

Daniel Birdsall Co. have sold for the estate of William Rogers to the Edison Electric Illuminating Company the triangular plot which will be at the northwest corner of Elm and Pearl Streets after the former thoroughfare has been widened. It has a frontage of 59 feet on Elm Street. a westerly line of feet, and southerly line of 16 feet.

ALBANY, Oct. 18. -- Attorney-General Hancock has written an opinion to the effect that a person who is born in this country, removes to a foreign country at an early age, and returns to this country some years after, is entitled to the right of suffrage without taking out naturalization papers, provided he complies with the election law relative to registration.

There are increasing signs that the people of New York are coming to understand how unprecedented is the opportunity which is offered to them by the Citizens' Union. That men should be nominated for the elective offices of the new municipality for no other reason than their apparent fitness for the duties of the office for which they are respectively named is of itself a refreshing novelty.
MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 19. -- The fifty-first annual meeting of the American Missionary Association began its sessions here this afternoon, President Merrill E. Gates of Amherst, Mass., in the chair.

An application was granted yesterday by Justice Truax, in the Supreme Court, ordering the Metropolitan Street Railway Company and the Ninth Avenue Railroad Company to show cause before Special Term, Part I., of the Supreme Court next Monday why they should not be enjoined from proceeding with the construction of their tracks on Amsterdam Avenue.
Mrs. E.M. Pelgram has sold, for about $60,000, the four-story brownstone front dwelling 91 Riverside Drive, 20 by 102.

Judge Robert A. Van Wyck's letter formally accepting the Democratic nomination for Mayor of the Greater New York was made public last evening, and is as follows: The Hon. Almet F. Jenks, Chairman; John C. Sheehan, Bernard J. York, Dr. Feeney, James McCartney, and John H. Sutphin, Committee.
Ex-Mayor Grace yesterday announced his adhesion to the Democratic city and county ticket in the following statement:

SEATTLE, Washington, Oct. 19. -- The steamer Bertha has arrived here from St. Michael, Alaska, whence she sailed Oct. 5. The Bertha brings no later news than was brought down by the Danube, which left St. Michael one day before the Bertha. Fourteen passengers came down on the Bertha, with about $30,000 in gold, most of it being in the possession of Arthur M. Pope and Harry Wright.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 19. -- Theodore Roosevelt, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, was a guest of the Cleveland Chamber of Commerce to-night. He delivered an address on "The Public Service." that was listened to by the business men of the city. In his address Secretary Roosevelt said:

With each day the enthusiasm and activity at Citizens' Union headquarters increases. Daily, too, new support is coming to the ticket headed by Seth Low. Another delegation of colored voters called on Mr. Low yesterday afternoon and assured him of their support. They were led by James E. Carr, who was a candidate for appointment as Assistant District Attorney under W.M.K. Olcott.

Since the ruling by the Treasury Department that imported calfskins must be classified as hides and assessed 15 per cant. duty protests from importers have been accumulating in the Custom House in the United States General Appraisers' Department. A hearing on several of these protests was held by Board No. 1 of the General Appraisers yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19. -- George M. Pullman died suddenly of heart disease at 5 o'clock this morning. His death occurred in his magnificent brownstone residence at the corner of Prairie Avenue and Eighteenth Street, where he had resided for many years.

Minnie Seligman Cutting smiled gratefully upon the jury in the Supreme Court, before Justice Bischoff, yesterday, when the foreman announced a verdict in her favor in her suit against Henry Clay Miner for damages for breach of contract. Mrs. Cutting sued for $5,000, and the jury awarded her $3,445, with interest from May 12, 1894.

In Lenox Lyceum, Madison Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, to-night, the Republicans will hold what they hope to make their banner mass meeting. Secretary of the Interior Cornelius N. Bliss will act as Chairman, and Gen. Tracy and Gov. Frank S. Black will speak. Conterno's Ninth Regiment Band will furnish the music.

Last Summer I read with much amusement and some satisfaction your rather skeptical mention of the yacht which The Sun reported as being off Long Beach one stormy Sunday, with all her sails set, including the spinnaker, which she "carried." I am a sailor, and was much interested in The Sun's article, because I happened to be off Long Beach that day looking for "blues."

A disastrous collision between Engine Company No. 21 and Hook and Ladder Company No. 2 was narrowly averted last night at Second Avenue and Forty-seventh Street. As it was, a horse attached to the engine was instantly killed by contact with an elevated railroad pillar and the engine was so wrecked as to be unserviceable at the fire to which it was going.

Gen. TRACY is making his fight on the issue of Bryanism. The foes of currency debasement, the defenders of the National honor, rallied to the Republican Party last year and beat back the forces of disorder and repudiation. TRACY, BLISS, and The Sun loudly warn the community that Bryanism is organized and militant in the municipal contest.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 19. -- The trial of Peter James, alias Eddie Jacques, for murder in the first degree, in having caused the death of Walker B. Adams on the night of Aug. 19, 1896, was continued to-day in the Supreme Court.

SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 19. -- At a meeting yesterday of the Union Pacific, Oregon Short Line, and Oregon Railway and Navigator Companies an agreement was made which provides for the resumption of the traffic relations between the roads which were in existence prior to Sept. 23 last, when the cancellation of the Oregon Railway and Navigation Company tariff by the Union Pacific took place.

Frederick Raymond, a driver in the employ of the Warwick Valley Milk Association, the offices of which are at 1,279 Broadway, according to his own story had a peculiar experience early yesterday morning.

There is no mistaking the significance of GEORGE M. PULLMAN'S career, and no disputing that it is of the old-fashioned American kind. It is a career much easier to run in this than in any other country, though less easy to run in this country, as we are often assured and apt to be persuaded, than it formerly was.

What a contemptible, underhanded, tricky, and shysterlike campaign PLATT is carrying on. The attack on the validity of the Citizens' Union certificates of nomination was about the lowest politics New York has ever seen. FERNANDO WOOD was not at all a squeamish man, but we think he would have blushed to be caught in such a business.
We suggest to the managers of Mr. Low's canvass the immediate organization of a series of noon meetings for business men, such as were so effective for the cause of sound money last year.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 19. -- The steamer Belgic, which has arrived here from Yokohama, brings news that it is rumored in Court circles that Kemura Jutare, Vice Minister of the Japanese Foreign Office, will succeed Mr. Hoshi as Minister to the United States upon the latter's return, and that Kalo Takakiro, now at the Court of St. James, will be recalled.

Mr. W.M. IVINS has come ostensibly to the rescue of Gen. TRACY with an open letter addressed to Mr. Low. What the real object of this singular appeal may be is left as much in the dark at the end as at the beginning of Mr. IVINS'S two columns of perverse and irrelevant exposition.

Since the opening of the present exciting campaign the accuracy and fairness of the reports of THE TIMES have been recognized by all parties. We have received unsolicited expressions of appreciation of these qualities from managers of the Republican, the Tammany, and the Henry George organizations, and numberless like expressions from our readers.

In a question of veracity between Henry George and William M. Ivins, there is no room for doubt, but it will be satisfactory for some of your readers to know that Mr. George detailed his interview with Mr. Ivins before the election of 1886 to me and others of his friends exactly as he gives it now to the public, with the single exception that he did not then name Tammany's emissary.

The Directors of the Peoria, Decatur and Evansville Railway Company, organized on Monday, electing Robert S. Anderson President and John H. Prall Vice President. The Executive Committee consists of Robert S. Anderson, Henry I. Clark, and E. Chamberlain.

The special commission appointed by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court to review the plans and estimates of the Rapid Transit Railroad Commission as approved by Mayor Strong and the Board of Aldermen continued the hearing yesterday of objections thereto. All the Commissioners were present.

Though less than 300,000 shares were traded in on the Stock Exchange yesterday, prices advanced throughout the whole list, and in many conspicuous quarters the changes for the better extended beyond two and three points. Again commission house buying was a prominent feature of the day's business.

Avon Saxon, the American concert, operatic, and oratorio baritone, who, before his departure three years ago for England, was identified with Boston Ideal Opera Company, is about to return to this country. Since Mr. Saxon left America he has toured in concert and opera throughout England, Ireland, Scotland, Germany, France, Australia, and the South African provinces.

READING, Penn., Oct. 19. -- The sight of a woman dressed in pretty hunting costume, gun on shoulder, and two wildcats by her side, greeted a party of chestnut hunters on Neversink Mountain, near this city, yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19. -- The meetings of the Catholic Archbishops to consider questions of policy and administration of the Church in America, and of the Directors of the Catholic University, to pass upon the affairs of that institution, have brought to this city a notable assemblage of Catholic dignitaries.

The United Democracy has issued a statement over the signature of Henry Nichols, Chairman of its Campaign Committee, which, besides the assertion that its ticket is in the field to stay, conveys an impression of melancholy. The withdrawal of Henry George, the statement says, will not affect the United Democracy's determination to stay in the fight. The statement says further:

A dispatch to The World from London reports that Mr. MCKINLEY'S silver Commissioners "believe their failure here means that no further effort in behalf of bimetallism will be made for many years." They have received no official notice of the decision of the British Cabinet, but they know what it will be, and "when the expected reply is received the Commissioners will return to the United States."

Nature wore her prettiest Autumn gown in Westchester County yesterday afternoon, and everybody within the Morris Park inclosure seemed to be in accord with her. The weather was delightful for such exciting outdoor sport as racing. A feature of the programme was the fact that all of the six events were on the circular track, where every portion of a race is visible from the grand stand.

Col. George E. Waring, Jr., Commissioner of Street Cleaning, last night gave his views on "The Twentieth Century City, what it may be if managed on business principles, calling to its aid the highest scientific, artistic, and philanthropic talent." This was the subject of discussion at the sixty-first regular meeting of the Quill Club, held in the banquet room of the Windsor Hotel.

BELGRADE, Oct. 19. -- King Alexander of Servia, accompanied by his father, ex-King Milan, has arrived here. This is the first visit of ex-King Milan to the Servian capital since his abdication in 1889.
An action brought by Eunice Milligan to recover $25,000 from Robert F. Nathan and his wife for false imprisonment and malicious prosecution was on trial in the Supreme Court yesterday.

The big North German Lloyd flier, Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse, arrived in port yesterday morning on her second westward trip. She did not equal in time her maiden trip, but despite severely rough weather she made a run that would have been a record breaker but for her own wonderful previous performance.

I have been ill for a few days, and as I recover it appears that the Soldiers' Monument has come to the fore again and that the Mayor and certain members of the committee of that uncertain structure have been down to Gettysburg for aesthetic inspiration and come back confounded with the wonders they saw.

TRENTON, Oct. 19. -- The State Board of Canvassers this afternoon canvassed the returns of the recent constitutional amendment election and found that the anti-gambling amendment had been carried by 802, and the amendment restricting the power of the Governor by 7,426, and that the Woman's Suffrage amendment was defeated by 10,059. The returns also showed 961 rejected ballots.

TRENTON, Oct. 19. -- The State Board of Canvassers this afternoon canvassed the returns of the recent constitutional amendment election and found that the anti-gambling amendment had been carried by 802, and the amendment restricting the power of the Governor by 7,426, and that the Woman's Suffrage amendment was defeated by 10,059. The returns also showed 961 rejected ballots.

The second week of the Fall conventions of the Board of Trade and Transportation began yesterday afternoon in the hall of the board, at 203 Broadway. President Darwin R. James presided. Attendance at the meeting was small.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 20. -- The annual meeting of the stockholders of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company was held here this afternoon. There were about seventy stockholders present, representing 273,361 shares.
WATERTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 20. -- Benjamin F. Hunt, eighty-seven years old, of Bridgeport, Conn., married Mrs. Julia Ann Sherman, ninety years old, of this city, this afternoon.

It is announced from Washington that the Cabinet has agreed that each head of department shall issue regulations carrying out the President's rule regarding dismissal from office, and that these shall conform in their general character to those already adopted by Secretary GAGE in the Treasury.

At yesterday's session of the Fall convention of the New York Board of Trade and Transportation, held in the afternoon at 203 Broadway, Jay L. Torrey submitted a paper on "The Bankruptcy Bills." The attendance at the session was not large. Darwin R. James, President of the Board of Trade, was in the chair. Mr. Torrey's

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20. -- William Wharton, one of the largest stockholders of the Bethlehem Iron Company, to-day confirmed the report that the company had made an offer to sell its plant to the Government. It had simply shaped itself in the nature of a verbal suggestion to the effect that if the Government intended to erect an armor plant, it could buy out the Bethlehem Company at a low price.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 20. -- A stranger is supposed to have dropped a big lump of plaster of paris on the beach this afternoon, and then picked it up. After picking it up he gave it to Policeman Kipp. It was made up to resemble the supposed appearance of the plaster containing Guldensuppe's head.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20. -- At 8:30 o'clock tonight it was announced from the office of State's Attorney Deneen that there would be no announcement of a verdict in the Luetgert case before the opening of court to-morrow.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Oct. 20. -- Ferdinand Carriere of Rimouski, Quebec, who was arrested yesterday for firing a revolver, and saying he wanted Premier Laurier's blood because the Premier would not give him a job, was before Police Magistrate O'Gara this morning, sufficiently sober to realize he was in a rather serious perdicament.
Ex-Mayor WILLIAM R. GRACE makes the charge that the Citizens' Union has formed an alliance with the Socialists. In his apology for supporting the candidates of Tammany he makes this statement:
PRINCETON, Oct. 20. -- The exercises of Commemoration Day will be held Friday, Oct. 22, at 11 o'clock. The guest of the occasion will be the Earl of Aberdeen, Governor-General of Canada.

One of the fiercest and most costly fires that have visited lower New York for some time gutted the four-story and basement warehouse at 3 Platt Street shortly before noon yesterday and spread to the buildings on either side. The building at 3 Platt Street was occupied by James B. Horner, importer and exporter of essential oils and manufacturer of cubeb cigarettes.

JOLIET, Ill., Oct. 20. -- Without any preparation for such a trial, Joe Patchen, the black pacing stallion, this afternoon reduced the world's record by nearly four seconds. Oscar Ames was in the sulky in place of Atkinson. After scoring once, Ames signaled for the word and away the big black went with the running mate trailing a length or two away.

The Brower estate has sold the block front on the west side of the Boulevard, between One Hundred and Eighth and One Hundred and Ninth Streets, 200.51/2 by 100. This property has been held at $150,000, and the present selling price is doubtless somewhere in that neighborhood.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20. -- A number of private dispatches have been received here from different parts of the country saying that the Presidency of the Pullman Palace Car Company would be offered to Robert T. Lincoln.

An immense mass meeting of workingmen, the first of the campaign, in support of Seth Low and the ticket of the Citizens' Union, was held last night in Cooper Union. The meeting was gotten up for residents of the First Council District, which, roughly speaking, comprises the east side, from Fourteenth Street, and the west side, from Canal Street, down to the Battery.
HAVANA, Oct. 20. -- La Lucha, in an energetic leading editorial entitled "War is Convenient for Spain," says:
The meeting of the Police Board yesterday morning ended with a personal altercation between Commissioners Parker and Moss.
The President has been grossly misrepresented by the Platt managers, from most dishonorable motives and in a manner of which those still capable of shame should be heartily ashamed.

The Executive Committee of the Manhattan Democracy, better known as the Stecklerites, met last night at the Metropolitan Hotel, Twenty-eighth Street and Broadway. Alexander Bremer presided, and it was decided to indorse the candidacy of Seth Low for Mayor. A Campaign Committee will be appointed and work begun in every election district.

TRENTON, Oct. 20. -- The Democratic State Committee through a special committee consisting of State Senator William D. Daly, of Hudson County, Chairman; E.L. Price, of Essex County; James W. Lanning, of Mercer County; William D. Wolfskeil, of Union County, and Charles L. Rogers, of Ocean County, to-night issued the following address to the voters of New Jersey:

In the quaint little cemetery of St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Church, in Glen Cove, L.I., a distinguished assemblage witnessed the burial of Charles A. Dana, at noon yesterday. The grave had been dug just beneath the branches of a locust tree on the crest of a hill back of the church. After the brief service in the church the funeral party emerged from the side door and slowly ascended this hill.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 20. -- The name of the author of "A Soldier of France," Miss Fanny Davenport's new play, is still shrouded in mystery, and probably will be for a few days yet. All that is known definitely is that the writer is an American. It is in the performance a succession of beautiful stage pictures and gorgeous accessories, and the supporting actors are all competent.
ERIE, Penn., Oct. 20. -- The General Council of the Evangelical Lutheran Church, which has just closed its twenty-sixth convention, transacted considerable important business.

As the campaign goes on the competition for the fourth place between Gen. TRACY and his competitors becomes daily keener. The situation, however, is gradually clearing so as to show that Gen. TRACY'S chances are improving, and there is now little doubt that he will succeed in defeating all of his three competitors.

LONDON, Oct. 20. -- Lord Salisbury sent this evening to Ambassador Hay the reply of the British Government to the proposals of the American Bimetallic Special Commission, headed by Senator Wolcott. It is a diplomatically worded note.

SIMLA, Oct. 20. -- Official advices from Fort Lockhart say that after the fighting on Monday last between the British troops under Gen. Sir Yeatman Biggs and the insurgent tribesmen from Chagru, on the Samana Range, the British force returned to Shinwari and the tribesmen, greatly reinforced, reoccupied Dargai Ridge, which commands Chagru.

Probably the most enthusiastic political mass meeting the residents of Flushing, L.I. have ever witnessed was held last night at Stone Hall, where Seth Low and ex-Secretary of the Treasury Charles S. Fairchild addressed an audience of over 700 persons on the issues of this campaign.

Wall Street brokers who bet -- and who when they bet like to see the money put up -- were in anxious mood yesterday. It was all on account of the amiable Col. Swords, whose province it is whenever an election is pending to drop down on New York and offer to bet large bundles of money on whoever his party's candidate may be.

I notice in a morning paper that President Orr of the Rapid Transit Commission demands of the Park Board that the latter's permission for the occupancy of the Battery Park should be unconditional. This means practically the despoilment of a considerable portion of that beautiful but limited space.

The stock market has drifted from buoyancy and strength -- from a general rush to buy anything where activity was discernible to depression and weakness, and a selling movement wherever there were signs of animation.

Henry George and Charles W. Dayton spoke at two mass meetings in Brooklyn last night -- one at the Academy of Music and the other at the Clermont Avenue Rink. The Rink was engaged at the last moment, and the fact that there was to be a meeting there was not advertised, except by scattering circulars at the bridge and ferry exits.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 20. -- Before the American Missionary Association to-day, the second day of its annual meeting, the Rev. Dr. A.F. Beard of New York, Secretary of the association, read a paper entitled "The Problem of the Residuum." In the course of his address he said:

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 20. -- Golf was pursued with more than usual animation and vigor to-day on the fine links of the Morris County Golf Club. The weather conditions were not exactly of the character which the club would have chosen, but in all other respects where the club and its committees could exercise their power and judgment, the conditions were admirable.

If many more sales of such high-class show horses as were offered at auction by F.D. Grand yesterday are held in the American Horse Exchange, the big building will bid fair to rival Madison Square Garden during Horse Show week.
Judge Van Wyck's letter of acceptance was the principal topic of conversation about Tammany Hall yesterday. Mr. Sheehan had the following to say about it:

A Citizens' Union meeting was held last night at Brooks's Assembly Rooms, Broome Street, near the Bowery, in the Sixth Assembly District, a Tammany stronghold. It fell short of complete success in attendance, but was remarkable for enthusiasm.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20. -- The Universal and Mutual gas plants and franchises are now the property of the People's Gas Light and Coke Company. The deal by which the properties were transferred was closed to-day. The price is between $5,400,000 and $5,700,000.

Tammany Hall has come out flatfooted in support of Thomas F. Grady in his attack on Col. Waring and the Department of Street Cleaning. A long statement, containing all sorts of allegations, was circulated by the managers of Tammany Hall yesterday, and this is to be reproduced in pamphlet form and circulated as a campaign document.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 20. -- The football game to-day between Yale and Brown opened the eyes of the Yale men. Brown's eleven broke through the Yale line almost at will and made 14 points, scoring three touchdowns against the home team, the largest score ever made on the Yale field against a Yale eleven.

There has probably never been in a civilized community any parallel to the apathy with which Judge VAN WYCK'S letter of acceptance has been received. The physical, intellectual, and moral welfare of three millions of people will be very considerably affected by the result of the coming election.

Why do the managers of Gen. TRACY'S canvass employ so much imported talent? Where are the eminent Republicans of New York City whose voices are familiar to their fellow-citizens, who enjoy the respect and confidence of men of all parties, and who have a home acquaintance with the affairs and interests of the city?

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- Gen. Wilson, Chief of Engineers of the Army, has made his annual report to the Secretary of War. It is devoted to the fortifications and river and harbor improvements of the country. The estimates for coast defenses for the year 1898-9, are as follows:

Tammany Hall kept up its attack on Commissioner Waring yesterday in spite of the fact that many members of the organization are outspoken in their statements that the proposed pamphlet, parts of which were published yesterday, was not justified. It was said that the attack would take more votes from Tammany than it could possibly make for it, and it is known that those holding such views will vigorously oppose the circulation of the pamphlet.

LONDON, Oct. 21. -- The stanch resistance of the insurgent tribesmen when the British forces stormed and eventually carried the Dargai Ridge of the Samana Range, yesterday afternoon, as detailed last night in dispatches from Fort Lockhart, via Simla. and the apparently heavy losses of the British, are facts which are viewed with serious misgiving in London to-day.
NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 21. -- There were 30 new cases of yellow fever here to-day and 2 deaths. Among the dead is Sister Sylvester of St. Joseph's Orphan Asylum.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 21. -- Plenty of excitement and interesting golf characterized the play in the second day's contests of the open tournament at the Morris County Golf Club. The events for the chief trophy, the handsome Morris County Cup, and the consolation prize were narrowed down to the semi-final rounds, which will be played to-morrow morning, and in the afternoon the fortunate victors will be known.

Last night the Governor said in substance that there could be no action in public affairs which was not partisan. His proposition, boldly put, was that a partisan is a patriot, and a non-partisan a fool or a fraud. This held the audience for several seconds, because it was composed of men who think the same way, many of whom make their living by politics, and more of whom would like to do so.

LONDON, Oct. 21. -- The Marquis of Salisbury, in his note to the United States Ambassador and to the French Ambassador, Baron de Courcel, says that by far the most important proposal submitted by the two governments respecting bimetallism is that concerning the reopening of the Indian mints, adding:
LOUISVILLE, Oct. 21. -- Following is a summary of to-day's races:

THOMAS C. PLATT and GOV. BLACK might have the hardihood to attempt the defeat of Judge PARKER and President Low by an illicit use of the Secretary of State's power of control over the form of the official ballot, but the time has gone by when a Judge on the bench can be found to abet such crimes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- Secretary Long has become deeply concerned at what he regards as the very large expenditures made by the Navy Department on account of repairs to ships. He thinks it strange that within a few weeks after the commissioning of a new ship she should be tied up in a navy yard for extensive alterations under the guise of repairs.

Carnegie Hall was the scene last night of a monster demonstration by Republicans -- non-partisans in municipal affairs -- who favor the election of Seth Low as Mayor of the Greater New York. It was officially termed a grand ratification meeting of the Republican organization of the City of New York to indorse the nomination of Mr. Low.

It appears that the escape from this port of a schooner suspected of being a filibuster, which contrived to evade the officials detailed to prevent her departure, has provoked much excitement and indignation in Madrid, and still more in Havana. The Imparcial of Madrid, a respectable and responsible journal, is reported to have published a "violent article" calling upon the Spanish Government to demand explanations.

Mr. Oscar Hammerstein reopened last night the theatre part of his Olympia, now christened The Lyric. He selected for the first attraction a Parisian operetta entitled "La Poupee," which is in plain English "The Puppet." The French libretto is by Maurice Ordonneau, and the music by Edward Audran. The English version was made by Mr. Arthur Sturges, who has hitherto been unknown to fame and apparently is not eager to make its acquaintance.
Frederick Zittel has sold, for Max Schoenfeld, to Mrs. Ann Duffy, for about $45,000, the four-story dwelling, with extension, 12 West Seventieth Street, 22 by 60 by 100.5

According to an estimate made by the Campaign Committee of the Citizens' Union yesterday Seth Low will receive at least 137,689 votes in the boroughs of Manhattan and the Bronx. In an unofficial statement made on Wednesday it was estimated that Mr. Low would receive 77,000 votes in Manhattan and the Bronx and 75,000 in Brooklyn, such estimate being based on the enrollment of 102,000, less 25 per cent., in allowance for signatures not genuine.
The session of the Board of Trade and Transportation's Fall convention, held yesterday afternoon at 203 Broadway, was devoted to the discussion of "The Monetary Commission." Darwin R. James presided.

GOV. BLACK, coming down from Troy to tell the citizens of New York what they ought to do in a city election, feels the need of some explanation for his intervention. The only one he has to offer is that be is a Republican and advocates in this election the triumph of Republican principles.

ALBANY, Oct. 21. -- Superintendent of Insurance Louis F. Payn has granted a charter to the Northern Insurance Company of New York, permitting it to do a fire insurance business in this State. The company is incorporated with a capital stock of $200,000, and has a surplus of $50,000. Its principal office will be located in New York City.
