The Sixteenth Assembly District, which in former years was the banner district of Tammany Hall, held one of the largest meetings of the campaign last night in and around the house of the Jefferson Club, at 247 Seventh Street, to ratify the nominations on the Tammany ticket.

BOSTON. Oct. 21. -- Boston celebrated the one hundredth anniversary of the launching of the famous frigate Constitution with a general holiday to-day. Literary exercises were held in the Old South Church, the marines and sailors from the United States warships in the harbor paraded with several local organizations in the afternoon.

A syndicate of English and New York capitalists has been formed to build an eighteen-story hotel on the lines of the Astoria, to be erected on Riverside Drive, overlooking the Palisades. The hotel will be known as the Hendrik Hudson, and the ground and building will cost $4,000,000.
How can anybody, politician, statistician, or guesswork wayfaring man any longer delude himself about the result of this election?
Several hundred women honored their Alma Mater at the seventh annual banquet of the Emma Willard Association at the Windsor Hotel, yesterday.

The fact that not a newspaper in New York will directly advocate the cause of Tammany is significant and hopeful and ought to be decisive. The furthest that even the most cynical newspaper can be got to go in that direction is the indirect advocacy of "whooping it up for TRACY," in the hope of withholding enough votes from SETH LOW to secure a Tammany victory.

WASHIGNTON, Oct. 21. -- General Superintendent Kimball of the Life-Saving Service reports that the number of disasters within the scope of the service during the year was 699, being considerably greater than for any preceding year. The number of vessels totally lost, however, was only 53, against 67 in 1896 and 73 in 1895.

There is a suggestion of polite sarcasm in the note of Lord SALISBURY to the Ambassadors of the United States and France on the silver business. Great Britain will do nothing she is asked to do. She will not open the Indian mints. A conference under the circumstances would be of no use, and will not be seriously considered.
In a statement issued yesterday by the Republican campaign managers from County Committee headquarters the charge is made that the Democrats are colonizing Queens County.

It is to the writer a matter of marvel that any one acquainted with standard grammarians, or, better still, with English literature, should either question the correctness or fail to perceive the beauty of Mr. Kipling's use of the singular verb after the two nouns in the first line of the second stanza of his noble recessional.

LONG BRANCH, Oct. 21. -- The vessel which went ashore here last night proved to be the two-masted schooner Richmond, Capt. Eugene Stanton, of Rockland, Me. The life savers rescued the crew early this morning, after the schooner had worked across the outer bar and drifted within easy reaching distance.

The Rapid Transit Special Commission resumed its session yesterday, and heard the conclusion of the argument of Lawyer George Zabriskie, representing property owners who object to the construction of the proposed underground road and to the plans submitted by Chief Engineer Parsons and approved by the Mayor and Board of Aldermen.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- The Board of Directors of the Catholic University reached a decision to-day in the case of Mgr. Schroeder. The following official statement was given out by Mgr. Conaty, rector of the university and Secretary of the board;

ALBANY, Oct. 21. -- Application has been made to the State Board of Railroad Commissioners by the Metropolitan Street Railway Company for permission to change Its motive Dower on seversLl streets in New York City' to the underground system of electricity. The boarrl will give hearings on the applications in New York City Oct. 26.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- Secretary Alger has sent to Lieut. Col. Randall, commander of the United States troops at St. Michael, Alaska, an order directing him to make use of the reindeer in Alaska for the transportation of supplies and the relief of sufferers who may be endeavoring to make their way down the Yukon.

" Postal Telegraphs" was the subject for discussion at the session of the Board of Trade and Transportation at 203 Broadway yesterday. 'The attendance was small. A paper prepared by F.B. Thurber was presented.

Members of the Horsemen's Protective Association may congratulate themselves on the fact that the programme for the extra day's racing at Morris Park yesterday, arranged by a committee of the association, was productive of a splendid day's sport. It did not bring out the best horses in training, but it brought together large fields in which the finishes were exciting and victory in doubt until the wire had been crossed.

WARSAW, N.Y., Oct. 22. -- The pink tinted "sample ballot" to show the voters of Wyoming County what will be given them Nov. 2 is out. It is 10 1/2 inches long and 14 1/2 inches wide. It has columns for the Republican eagle, Democratic star, National Democratic ship, Socialist Labor arm, and Prohibition fountain, which are headed respectively by Wallace, Parker, Parker, Cuno, Baldwin, while one column is left blank.

Felix, Festus, and Agrippa, historically are very closely related. They stand side by side. Spiritually they are also closely related, but they do not stand side by side. There is a great distance between them. They stand, however, on a large circle, and although far apart on that circle, each one is the same distance from the great truth which is its centre.

Looking in a volume of forgotten photographs. I found one of the lovely Queen of Italy when she was seventeen, with her young autograph, and that of Garibaldi. near her. "given to her friend Avezzano." This carried me back to my first visit to Florence, in 1859, when the young royal cousins had been first married -- Umberto and Margharita.

The second batch of brood mares from the Brookdale Stud, which were sold at auction at Morris Park yesterday, brought much better prices than the lot sold on Thursday. The star of yesterday's sale was Retribution, the dam of Requital, who holds the double honor of winning the Futurity and Realization; there were also Arab, Nick, Contribution, and several other high-class horses.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22. -- Judge Tuthill, State's Attorney Deneen, Assistant State's Attornew McEwen, ex-Judge Vincent, and Attorney Phalen had an informal conference lasting over one hour in the Judge's private chamber to-day. Luetgert was brought into court, and the report went abroad that a formal motion to admit him to bail would immediately follow the conference. When the conference was over Luetgert was taken back to jail.

German-speaking Americans from all sections of Brooklyn congregated at the Clermont Avenue Rink, in Brooklyn, last night and heard Carl Schurz, ex-Mayor Schieren, Carl Hauser, John H. Schumann, and other members of the United German Societies and the German-American Reform Union tell them, in the language of the Fatherland why they should support Seth Low for Mayor of the Greater New York.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 22. -- A.M. Robbins won his first big match in a golf tournament to-day when he beat the champion and pride of the Morris County Golf Club in the final round for the principal trophy of the contest, the Morris County Cup. The last round was played in the rain, but this did not deter about fifty spectators, including half a dozen zealous ladies, from following the contestants over the links.

Henry George carried his campaign into the heart of the east side last night. He was greeted everywhere by the most enthusiastic crowds, and each of the four halls where he spoke was crowded almost to suffocation. With the candidate were Charles W. Dayton, Jeremiah O'Neil and E. Lawson Purdy. Mrs. George also accompanied him.

MADRID, Oct. 22. -- Senor Sagasta, the Premier, presided at the Cabinet council to-day. The draft of the proposed reply to the note of the United States, presented through Gen. Stewart L. Woodford, the American Minister, shortly after his arrival here, was under consideration, and was unanimously approved.

The flat house at 970 Boston Avenue was surrounded yesterday afternoon by a crowd of curious people listening to the wild screams of a distracted woman who had killed her two-year-old boy with a revolver that she didn't think was loaded.

In most emphatic terms President Isaac B. Potter said yesterday that the League of American Wheelmen could not afford to tolerate Sunday cycle racing. As it had been rumored that Mr. Potter would favor those who have called for Sunday cycle competitions with a view of assisting his campaign for re-election to the League of American Wheelmen Presidency, the statement will do much to clear the league political atmosphere.

The great Republican meeting at Carnegie Hall was a revelation. As an exhibition of Mr. Low's strength in that party it exceeded the hopes of his most sanguine supporters. It dumfounded the Platt Republicans by giving public evidence of their slight hold upon the voting force and moral weight of the party.

Was it Lord Tennyson or Lady Franklin who composed the epitaph on Sir John Franklin's monument in Westminster Abbey? I have seen it stated that Lady Franklin wrote it, and yet the lines are so good that they seem possible only to a writer of genius.

There is an unusual amount of new church construction now under way and in prospect in this immediate vicinity. Besides the large new church edifices going up in this city of which descriptions have been printed, there are several projects in which congregations of lesser note are interested.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- The President had a public reception this afternoon. Among the callers was Miss Cisneros, the escaped Cuban girl. She was accompanied by Mr. and Mrs. Karl Decker and Mrs. John A. Logan. The President shook hands with Miss Cisneros, but had no conversation with her.

LONDON, Oct. 22. -- The correspondence in regard to the bimetallic proposals of the United States Monetary Commission was issued by the British Foreign Office this evening, and the following account of the negotiations was taken from it:

County Chairman Quigg and the Republican leaders say that Tracy will be elected by a plurality of 17,000 over Van Wyck. The following official estimate was given out at Republican headquarters yesterday:
I was surprised and amused by the criticisms of the Macdougal Street sailor in your columns upon the picture of the yacht Henrietta in Truth.

Seth Low, no doubt spoke from his heart when he said yesterday, in the presence of three thousand women, who had enthusiastically welcomed and lauded him in Association Hall, Brooklyn, that the memory of the occasion would be with him as long as he lived. Such a reception as was given him by influential women, was probably never before accorded to any candidate for popular favor.
It is time for this community to be rid of its delusions about BENJAMIN F. TRACY.

The non-Catholic public has not kept itself accurately informed of the difficulties and divisions in the "Catholic University of America" which have resulted in a request for the resignation of Mgr. SCHROEDER from a professorship in that institution. But it does not need more specific information when it is informed that that professor represents in the university the German Catholics.

John Watts Kearny, Jr., son of John Watts Kearny, who for many years was nspector General of New Jersey, and a grandson of Gen. "Phil" Kearny, was yesterday adjudged a habitual drunkard on the salt of his father.

ALBANY, Oct. 22. -- At 12:30 o'clock to-day L.B. Gleason, counsel for the United Democracy, appeared before the Extraordinary Term of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, Third Department, called by Gov. Black to argue upon an order to show cause, granted by Judge Landon, why argument should not be heard upon the order granted by Justice Herrick restraining the Secretary of State from putting on the ballot the name of the United Democracy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- The official correspondence relating to the case of Mgr. Schroeder of the Catholic University was made public to-day. The letter of Mgr. Schroeder, submitted to the Board of Directors of the University, is addressed to Bishop Horstmann of Cleveland, who acted as attorney for the Monsignor before the board.

One of the features of the day at Tammany Hall yesterday was a very large meeting of "spellbinders," which was held behind closed doors in the Organization Committee's room. Maurice B. Blumenthal presided. The meeting was illustrative of the campaign system inaugurated by Tammany, and there was a lot of plain talk to the orators regarding the subjects they were to speak and dwell on.

W.G. Hitchcock Co., one of the oldest and best-known mercantile houses in this city, made an assignment yesterday with preferences to William J. Curtis of the law firm of Sullivan Cromwell, 45 Wall Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22. -- Gen. Miles, Major General commanding the army, in his report to the Secretary of War, says the army, although inadequate in point of numbers, was never in a higher state of efficiency, both as to the character and qualifications of its officers and intelligence and loyalty of its soldiers.
ASHEVILLE, N.C., Oct. 22. -- The National Bank of Asheville has closed its doors. No statement has yet been made. This leaves but one bank here.
LONDON, Oct. 22. -- The reply of the Government of India, upon which Lord Salisbury based his decision, gives an emphatic negative to the proposal to reopen the India mints It says:

PRINCETON, Oct 22. -- The one hundred and fifty-first birthday of Princeton University was celebrated to-day. Great interest was manifested in this year's commemoration on account of the presence of ex-President Grover Cleveland and the Earl of Aberdeen, Governor General of Canada. The academic procession of Princeton Trustees, Faculty, Alumni, and undergraduates formed at Marquand Chapel at 11 o'clock and marched to Alexander Hall.

The author of "The Honorable Peter sterling'' has set himself a standard from which his public will not let him off. He has established his claim to be taken seriously as a writer of fiction, and nothing less true, less rounded, less ripe, than his first novel will be accepted as worthy of his excellent talent.

On the application of Victor J. Dowling, representing William J. O'Brien of the Granite Cutters' Union and the Board of Walking Delegates. Justice Pryor of the Supreme Court yesterday granted an alternative writ of mandamus requiring Mayor Strong and the Commissioners of the new East River Bridge to show cause why the contract with P.H. Flynn for the erection of the foundation piers for the bridge should not be annulled.

De Lancey Nicoli, as attorney for Mrs. Annie Douglass, yesterday made a motion before Surrogate Fitzgerald to vacate and set aside the decree of May 18, 1891, admitting the probate of the will of Gen. Francis B. Spinola. The General, who was a brother of Mrs. Douglass, left his estate, valued at over $1,000,000, to his wife and a nephew, Ferdinand McKee

CHICAGO, Oct. 22. -- Private Charles Hammond, United States Army, showing plainly the effects of his fourteen days' confinement on a bread-and-water diet in the guardhouse at Fort Sheridan, appeared before the court of inquiry to-day and told of the circumstances of his disobedience of the orders of Capt. Levering and of the subsequent measures taken by that officer to enforce his commands. Under oath he testified as follows:
SOUTH NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 22. -- Jennie Kinsella was frightfully burned by vitriol thrown last night, and to-day is in an extremely critical condition.

It is quite possible that the press dispatch is correct which declares that the Spanish reply to the note of the United States delivered by Mr. WOODFORD "will contain a formal protest against filibustering." Such a protest would be "brutum fulmen" in the absence of any proof that the Government of the United States had encouraged filibustering or had failed to use due diligence to prevent the departure of filibusters.
" I can't help it! I am too weak and tired to do any work to-day!"

There was a half hour of wild excitement in Exchange Place, Jersey City, yesterday. It was occasioned by a black pig, which escaped from a crate. A chase was organized in which a score of men and boys joined. The pig, being badly frightened, took to the sidewalk and knocked down Kitty Gobel, sixteen years old, who was on her way to the Pennsylvania ferry.

Before the commencement of the proceedings of the Special. Commission appointed by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court to hear testimony as to the feasibility of the proposed underground railway, which met again at 256 Broadway yesterday, Edward M. Shepard, senior counsel to the Board of Rapid Transit Commissioners, was presented .to the members of the commission individually.

The Tammany men who resent CROKER'S brutal arrogance will deserve no better fate than perpetual servitude if they do not finish him this time. Forecastle grumbling will do them no good. He will punish them for that, on some talebearer's report. His utter destruction is their only relief.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Oct. 22. -- Mrs. Archibald Otens, aged thirty-five, is in jail here to await the action of the Grand Jury on a charge of maiming Wilson R. Denman at Ellenville last night. Although both are married, jealousy is at the bottom of the trouble. Up to a year ago Denman and Mrs. Otens were often in each other's company.

The Republican Party in New York City, like the Democratic Party, has suffered its affairs to be managed and its candidates to be named by a small group of rum sellers, shysters, loafers, and office holders calling itself the County Committee and controlled by a buccaneer in chief or boss who is invariably out for pelf.
Another part of Barnum Bailey's circus will sail to-day for England, on the steamer Mississippi. They are the billposters.

The Messrs. Harper Brothers have published this week the following books: "The Personal Equation," by Harry Thurston Peck; "Ars Recte Vivendi," by George William Curtis; "Alan Ransford," by Ellen Douglas Deland; "Outlines in Local Color," by Brander Matthews; "Stuart and Bamboo," by Mrs. S.P. McLean Greene; "John Leighton, Jr.," by Katrina Trask; "Celebrated Trials," by Henry Lauren Clinton, and "Paste Jewels," by John Kendrick Bangs.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 22. -- Justin Winsor, LL.D., Librarian of Harvard University, and the first President of the American Library Association, died this morning. Dr. Winsor's illness began with a cold a few days ago, and so aggravated an old trouble that an operation became necessary, the shock of which proved too severe for his constitution.

ALBANY, Oct. 22. -- During the present year the Bureau of Labor Statistics has been collecting statistics as to the number of organized workingmen, duration of employment, rates of wages, hours of labor, and the number of men unemployed in the State, by means of regular quarterly reports from trades unions.

News corers from London of a Landor find, and great must be the joy of those who still share with Landor's contemporaries love for "The Old Lion " -- him of whose voice Swinbourne wrote the fine lines:

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 22. -- The one hundred and twentieth anniversary of the battle of Red Bank was celebrated to-day. Short addresses were made on the historic field, which is a short distance down the Delaware River, by the Rev. Russell H. Conwell of Philadelphia, Gen. James F. Rusling of Trenton, and John Whitehead of Morristown, President of the New Jersey Society of the Sons of the American Revolution, which had charge of the celebration.
The New York Investment and Improvement Company has sold, for $90,000, the plot, southeast corner of the Boulevard and Cathedral Parkway, 100 by 100 and irregular at the rear.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 22. -- Atlanta's magnificent water works system is threatened with destruction through the corroding effect of heavy underground electric currents on the water mains. For the past few months many complaints have been lodged at the water works on account of unjust bills, the overplus evidently occurring from leakage.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23. -- The most interesting event at the White House to-day was the visit of Senator Thomas C. Platt of New York. The hot campaign over the city election in New York, in which the Senator has taken a prominent part, made the visit significant. Senator Platt wanted to secure some appointments, and was desirous that they should be made before the election.

Ninety marksmen's and thirty-four experts' qualifications was the record of yesterday's supplementary practice at the Creedmoor shooting ranges. It was the last day but one on which the members of the National Guard, who have not qualified in either of the two classes this year, could have an opportunity to make up for their delinquency.

In the era which immediately preceded the era of the Crusades the goal of the pilgrim was usually Jerusalem, and that for obvious reasons. Jerusalem, according to the confused geography of that age, was not only the centre of the world, not only a city that was the joy of the whole earth and at unity in itself, but the city where the Lord was slain, and the joy of the whole earth.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23. -- The steel steamship Miami, built by the William Cramp Ship and Engine Building Company, was launched successfully at the company's yard to-day. Not only was the launching a success, but the shipbuilders covered themselves with honor, as the record for building a modern vessel has been broken.

CHICAGO, Ill., Oct. 23. -- The funeral of George M. Pullman was held at the family residence, in Prairie Avenue, to-day. The officiating clergymen were the Rev. Drs. N.D. Hillis and C.H. Eaton of New York, the latter a visitor at the Pullman home on the night of the great financier's death. Each minister spoke briefly, the Imperial Quartet sang a selection, and the coffin was closed.

In a dispatch from Saratoga published by the morning papers recently, it was said that the Sacandaga Gold Mining and Milling Company, in which ex-Sheriff William W. Worden of the Worden House, at Saratoga Springs, is the principal stockholder, had developed from sand gold that has assayed from $34 to $100 per ton.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 23. -- The Monmouth County Grand Jury, before adjournment last evening, made a presentment in regard to the filthy condition of Wesley Lake, near Main Street, this city, against the joint owners, James A. Bradley and the Ocean Grove Association, criticising them for allowing the lake to become a menace to health, and asking the court to take some action for its relief.

The growing boldness of Dr. BARTH'S discussions of the Kaiser's tendency to absolutism must presently have its effect either upon him or upon Germany. If his is but a voice crying in the wilderness it will be a simple matter to still it by suppressing his paper and clapping its editor in jail for majestats-beleidigung.

Josef Hofmann, the young pianist, who was heard here ten years ago at the age of ten, has been engaged for thirty concerts by Theodore Thomas, and will be heard here with the Chicago Orchestra in the Spring. Those who have heard him recently speak with great enthusiasm of his playing and his compositions.

READING, Penn., Oct. 23. -- There are four old men in this city who assemble together almost every day, recall old times, and discuss the probabilities of the future, who constitute, in all likelihood, the most remarkable quartet in Eastern Pennsylvania.

LONDON, Oct 23. -- Second Mate Olssen of the Norwegian bark Seladon, Capt. Jaeger, from Newcastle, N.S.W., July 13, 1896, for Honolulu, which was wrecked in the South Seas in August, 1896, has arrived in London with a dozen of the survivors, who tell a terrible story of their experience.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 23. -- Several hundred spectators saw the Princeton annual Fall handicap games here this afternoon, and one or two remarkable performances were made in the running events, considering that the track was heavy and slow. Cregan, the New, York Athletic Club crack miler, won the 1,000-yard run handily in 2:22 2-5.

BERLIN, Oct. 23. -- In order to strengthen in the most particular manner the Anti-Prussian tendencies of Bavaria, three letters written by the late King Ludwig II. of Bavaria have been disclosed, and their publication has been much criticised here. The first, written in July, 1871, to an official in the King's confidence, says:

" I've got a job hauling lumber," he said, "and I haven't got quite team enough. Only," he added, "don't give me anything that isn't true." (that is, technically, good to pull,) "because I can get along with what I've got, but if I can get a horse to mate this big one of mine I can do a good deal better."
Next week's meeting of the American Public Health Association in Philadelphia, which begins on Tuesday and continues to Friday, will be the society's silver anniversary.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 23. -- There is a great deal of interest in the South in the negro agricultural college to be opened formally and dedicated Nov. 17 at Tuskeegee, Ala. Secretary of Agriculture Wilson will make the principal address, and prominent educators of both races from several States will be present.
The following paragraph is from a Southern newspaper:

Do any of your readers remember the Presidential campaign of 1884? Grover Cleveland's election was due to the solid vote of stanch Republicans, who were courageous enough to lay aside party affiliations for the sake of honor. Mill owners and men who had fortunes to make from a protectionist tariff at such a time preferred the sacrifice of private interest to that of National self-respect.

READING, Penn., Oct. 22. -- A contract was signed yesterday in Washington by Secretary Long that will keep the large Carpenter steel plant in this city busy for sometime. The contract is for $160,000 worth of armor-piercing projectiles, to be held in reserve for the use of the navy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23. -- The commission appointed last January to arbitrate the claim of the Cauca Railway and Land Company of New York for $962,909.14, against the United States of Columbia, filed an award to-day at the State Department, fixing the amount of the claim at $452,048.93, payable to the Cauca Company in gold coin of the United States with 5 per cent. interest added after Jan. 26, 1898.

Dr. Fridtjof Nansen, the Norwegian explorer, arrived in New York yesterday on the steamship Lucania, which was sighted off Fire Island at 1:40 P.M. At 4:30 P.M. the steamer Favorite, with the Nansen committee, composed of Scandinavians living in New York, went alongside and, amid cheers for the distinguished explorer, took him off and started with him back to the city.

NEWPORT, Oct 23. -- The improvement now being made on and about Spouting Rock Beach by Summer residents who own that place represent a large outlay. A committee of the owners, of whom I. Townsend Burden is the executive, has full charge, and is not limited at all as to expenditure.

At the Greenwood Athletic Club, Twenty- fifth Street, near Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn, last night Thomas Hawkins, a pugilist, of 66 Columbia Place, Brooklyn, received injuries at the hands of Frederick Witman of 747 Myrtle Avenue, also a pugilist, which will probably result in his death.

FREEPORT, L.I., Oct. 23. -- The women of the Sewing Society of the Methodist Church of this town had an "experience meeting" last Wednesday night and told how they had earned the dollar apiece which they had undertaken to obtain by extra exertions during the week, the money being pledged in advance to religious purposes.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Oct. 23. -- The most remarkable car robbery trials on record in the South came to an end in the Superior Court, at Dalton, Ga., to-day.

COLOGNE, Sept. 4. -- The artists and photographers have done their work well with this place, and made the world familiar with it. If a stranger were to open his window here, without knowing where the train had set him down, he would say at once, "This is Cologne. There is the great cathedral with its twin spires. That ribbon of silver beyond is the Rhine by moonlight."

For the benefit of those chroniclers of drama and music who are laboring under the misapprehension that Mlle. Yvette Gullbert is attacking grand opera at La Scala, it may be stated that Yvette is not in Milan. She is still doing her old turns at La Scala, Paris, and that is an altogether different place.

" Lord Chumley," the four act comedy by Belasco and De Mille originally produced by Daniel Frohman with E.H. Sothern in the title role in the Fall of 1880, will be revived this week at the Lyceum Theatre. The cast will include Miss Harned and the other members of Mr. Sothern's company, including Etta Hawkins, who will take her original part of Meg, the lodging house girl.

George Dougherty yesterday appeared in the Adams Street Police Court, Brooklyn, charged by the Health Department with keeping about 500 loads of manure on Malbone Street. His counsel, E. L. McCrossin, asked for an adjournment, and said that his client was removing the manure as fast as he could.

Prof. Albert S. Bickmore delivered yesterday, at 10:30 A.M., at the American Museum of Natural History, the second lecture of his present series on Greece and Italy. All of these lectures are under the auspices of the State Department of Public Instruction, and are intended for the teachers of the State.
NEW YORK, March 22. -- My greatest surprise is to be surprised so little; and in the mild atmosphere, under a brilliant sun, it does not seem to me that I have changed climates.

The Metropolitan Bicycle Academy, Sixtieth Street and the Boulevard, was the scene of an enthusiastic Republican ratification meeting last night that varied from an audience of many hundreds to an audience that only half filled the seats, with the falling and rising attractions of the Van Wyck wheelmen's parade outside the doors, and the varying hopes of Gen. Tracy's appearance as a speaker.

LONDON, Oct. 23. -- The American Line steamer St. Louis, which sailed for New York from Southampton to-day, had on board Mr. Pierre Lorillard, the well-known American horseman. After spending two years in Europe, he declares he will pass most of his time in future on this side of the Atlantic.

Many arguments have already been advanced to deter old-time Republicans from voting for Gen. Tracy, who (however honorable in himself) has undoubtedly been selected by Platt with the expectation that he would prove a faithful lieutenant and henchman in administering the affairs of the largest and most important city of the Union.

The recent death of Charles A. Dana will render his "Reminiscences of Men and Events of the Civil War," the first part of which appears in the present November number of McClure's Magazine, of great interest. The paper is illustrated with portraits from the War Department and a collection of civil war photographs. At once, without phrasing, Mr. Dana opens his subject, and his peculiar straightforward and trenchant English is conspicuous.

Edward M. Shepard of Brooklyn, who returned from Europe last Thursday, has issued a statement giving his unqualified support to Seth Low for Mayor. On the day of his return he declined to take a definite stand until he had become familiar with the situation. It took but two days for Mr. Shepard to decide in favor of Mr. Low. Following is his statement, issued yesterday:

I beg to submit that New York has never before experienced such a mixed condition as we find in the political arena to-day. It is reassuring to note the increasing independence of the citizen, and that he actually stands up for his rights and proposes to make himself heard in the choice and election of public officers.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Oct. 23. -- A new candidate for United States Senator was sprung to-day on the Democratic side as a result of the pronounced opposition in certain quarters to John R. McLean. He is Col. James Kilbourne, the wealthy Columbus manufacturer. One of his chief supporters is John H. Thomas of this city, who was a candidate against Brice six years ago.

READING, Penn., Oct. 23. -- A trio of swindlers has been operating in Eastern Pennsylvania for a few weeks, and Pinkerton men have been on the lookout for them. Two were arrested at the American Hotel, Allentown, Thursday, and one at Stroudsburg, Penn. The operations of the trio consisted in drawing fraudulent drafts and forging names to checks.

RADICAL departures in articles of table service are not favored by households of refinement, and novelties in this line are almost invariably confined to the introduction of new effects in color, sometimes very subtle, or the minor features of design, a graceful curve, or a beautiful line.
According to a recent report from Julius G. Tucker, the United States Consul at Martinique, there is likely to be a strong demand for American butter on that island.

LONDON, Oct. 23. -- The Gordon Highlanders praises are in everybody's mouth, and the Sikhs and the Ghurkas, who shared with them in the magnificent exploit of the Chagru-Kotal, share the laudation here as well. The sinister dimensions of the death roll take the English, however, by surprise.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Oct. 23. -- After a profitable season at nearly all the resorts along the New Jersey coast between Sea-bright and Point Pleasant, one of the heaviest booms experienced in the building trade in several years is being witnessed at the several resorts, and by the opening of next Summer season it is estimated that about one million dollars will be expended on the erection of new buildings and other improvements.

The Judge is very severe on the newspapers these days for reasons not disconnected with their unanimous refusal to have a good word to say for the ticket for municipal officers placed in nomination by Tammany Hall.

LONDON, Oct. 23. -- The Bimetallic League has tardily presented to Sir Michael Hicks-Beach, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, a detailed reply, signed "Aldenham," to the protest by the commercial interests against bimetallism. The reply says the League has often pointed out that the changes taking place in the British standard are due to the action of foreign nations without the consent of the British Government.

Miss Maude Gonne, the young woman who has devoted her fortune and talents to the cause of Ireland, arrived yesterday from Liverpool on the Cunard line Lucania. She is the proprietress and editor of L'Irelande Libre, an Irish patriotic paper published in Paris, and she has already done so much in the interest of her native land that she is referred to by her sympathizers as "The Irish Joan of Arc."

The Lotos Club added another name last night to the roll of distinguished guests it has entertained. Anthony Hope sat in the seat of honor, a seat that has been occupied by most of the famous men who have visited this country during the life of the club.
POINT ARENA, Cal., Oct. 23. -- Thirteen seamen, comprising almost the entire crew of the steam schooner Casper, were drowned early this morning by the wreck of the vessel.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23. -- When the trains of the "Alley L" began running around the "loop" this week Chicago witnessed the opening of the most unique system of street railway transportation in the country. The three separate cities of which Chicago is practically composed, are now in direct railway connection with each other for the first time.
Henry George addressed an enthusiastic meeting in Sehring's Washington Hall, Unionport, last night. Citizens of Westchester, West Farms, and the surrounding districts crowded the hall.

RUTLAND, Vt., Oct. 20. -- James Barrett of this city, an ex-Judge of the Supreme Court of Vermont, now nearly ninety years old, a former instructor and associate of Mr. Dana, gives some of his recollections of the editor in his earlier years. Judge Barrett said:

The annual Fall ladies' day and handicap tournament for women golfers were held yesterday by the Dyker Meadow Golf Club of South Brooklyn. Over thirty women played in the eighteen-hole contest, and the clubhouse was crowded with guests all day long. Daniel Chauncey, Captain of the club, presented the first and second prizes, and the club gave a third trophy.

It is too early for judgment to be passed on Dr. Miquel's work as Minister; even his admirers admit that his schemes -- and they are many -- are not all perfect, while that some of them have considerable merit his bitterest foes allow. Prussian finances were in a deplorable condition when he accepted office; expenditure was increasing by leaps and bounds, and without any corresponding increase of income.

Columbia Oval's green turf at William's Bridge was trodden by an enthusiastic lot of young collegians yesterday afternoon, when the annual Fall games of Columbia University were held. The entry list was larger than ever before, and the brawny young athletes showed unusual spirit in their strife.

One of the guardians of Prospect Park, Brooklyn, is a believer in matrimony. This is Barney, who devotes his time to spearing stray leaves which desecrate the park's clean lawns. Barney is a picturesque figure, and visitors to the park who are conversationally inclined never fail to ask him questions, most of which are of a personal nature.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Oct. 13. -- Yellow fever is raging within a few hours' sail of Kingston, and several "suspected" cases have occurred here recently. It is admitted that the sanitary condition of Kingston is defective and that malignant fever of a serious type is prevalent throughout the island, but the authorities are endeavoring to conceal the existence of yellow fever.

BERLIN, Oct. 23. -- An article in the Nuova Antologia, an influential Italian magazine, published by ex-Minister Ferraris, has caused a profound sensation in Germany. The article is a summary of a forthcoming book by Signor Chiala, the Italian Senator and historian. He advocates the formal withdrawal of Italy from the Dreibund at the expiration of the present term of that compact, and the forming of a new Zweibund between Italy and Great Britain.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 23. -- Joseph and Martha Stamper of Carter County have been tried in the United States Court here on the charge of conspiracy, and the testimony in the case reveals a widespread plot to rob the Government of mileage and witness fees by the preferring of bogus charges of violations of the revenue laws.
The bronze bust of Mozart which was won by the United Singers of Brooklyn at the recent National Saengerfest in Philadelphia was presented to the City of Brooklyn yesterday.

Paul Bert discovered that the blood of animals living in high altitudes absorbed more oxygen than that of similar animals at ordinary elevations and in this observation he was soon confirmed by Muntz, who removed rabbits from Tarbes to the Pic du Midi de Bigorre in the Pyrenees, (2,377 meters,) where they remained close to the observatory on the summit of the mountain, and bred naturally.
The very frank story given by the British Government of the negotiations with the Wolcott commission and the French Ambassador must make sorry reading for Mr. McKINLEY. Take this passage:
Henry E. Dixey will make his debut as a magician at the Garden Theatre for a limited engagement, beginning on Monday, Nov. 15. Active rehearsals will begin on Monday.

PARIS, Oct. 12. -- M. Meline, the Prime Minister, has now completed, in the speech that he has just delivered, the indications already supplied by his colleague, M. Barthou, of what the Ministerial programme will be next session. He expressed, as he had some right to do, considerable satisfaction that the Cabinet had lasted so long, and he is confident of its enduring until the next elections.

Two men met their death early yesterday morning in a fire which destroyed the three-story and attie brick building at 773 Broadway, used by Gardner Vail in the manufacture of collars and cuffs. The victims were Patrick Colloppy, the engineer, forty years of age, and Henry Haight, the foreman, fifty years of age, both of whom were accustomed to sleep in the building.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 23. -- West Point defeated Tufts this afternoon by a score of 30 to 0. In the first half West Point's playing was rather listless, due to the fact that but six of the regular men were playing, and neither side scored. In the second half, however, Scales and E. Humphrey were substituted, with the result that the cadets scored five touch-downs and kicked five goals.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 23. -- Harvard defeated Brown 18 to 0 to-day in one of the best games of football ever seen on Soldiers Field. Spectators and players alike went to the game with a view to making a comparison with Yale's recent showing against Brown, and Harvard men are jubilant over the result.
The New York Household Economic Association, organized last March, began its regular work, the first of a course of meetings, at the Carnegie Building Friday afternoon.

Archbishop Xeane, formerly rector of the Catholic University at Washington anw now Secretary 0.f the Congregation of Cardinals at Rome, sailed on the French liner La Gaseogne for Havre yesterday. Archbishop Chapel!e of Santa F, the Rev. Sylvester iV/alone of Brooklyn, and others bade him good-bye on board the steamer.

That was a vigorous and timely allocution which ex-President CLEVELAND made at Princeton on Friday. It was in the line of his former address at the same university, and, like that, it derives additional point and force from the fact that the orator does not happen to be himself a college-bred man.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23. -- Mayor Harrison refused to take seriously the stories telegraphed from New York regarding the result of his trip to the Eastern city in the interest of the Tammany candidates. Supporters of Henry George were quoted in these dispatches with charging Mayor Harrison with a disruption of the Western Democracy by his action in accepting Mr. Croker's invitation to speak in behalf of Judge Van Wyck and the Tammany Hall nominees.

TORONTO, Ontario, Oct. 23. -- The biennial convention of the World's Women's Christian Temperance Union was formally opened this morning in the pavilion at the Horticultural Gardens by Miss Frances E. Willard. The building was packed to overflowing, and many were clamoring for admission.

CHICAGO, Ill., Oct. 23. -- It is said here that W.A. Vincent and A.A. Goodrich, Luetgert's attorneys, called on Mayor Harrison to-day and made a formal demand that Police Inspector Schaack be removed. Judge Goodrich called the Mayor's attention to a published interview, in which Inspector Schaack is quoted as giving intimation that Juror Harley was influenced by Goodrich in holding out for a disagreement in the Luetgert case.

Draw an up-curving line from Friday a week ago to Thursday morning last, and then curve the line downward, and you have the course of the market. Most stocks were lowest on the Friday mentioned; then they began to rise and the rise continued till Thursday last, when prices had advanced about three or four points.

MADRID, Oct. 23. -- After the Cabinet meeting here yesterday, at which the reply of Spain to the note of the United States, presented by the United States Minister, Gen. Stewart L. Woodford, soon after his arrival in this country, was unanimously approved, Gen. Woodford, it is said, cabled 2,000 words in cipher to Washington, and it is supposed this was the text of the Spanish reply to the United States.

" ARNOLD is a traitor and has fled to the British. Whom can we trust now?" These were the words in which WASHINGTON announced to LAFAYETTE and KNOX the appalling crime of BENEDICT ARNOLD. "Whom can we trust now?" Up to that very moment ARNOLD had possessed the unabated confidence and esteem of his commander.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 23. -- At Latonia today a serious accident occurred in the last race, two jockeys being hurt. At the stretch turn Madreliene, with Jockey Joe Hill up, collided with El Toro, ridden by Jesse Conley, the colored lightweight. Both horses went down with their riders, and Hill was badly injured about the chest. Conley escaped with a few slight bruises.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 23. -- To-day's fever record was much worse than anticipated. There were about forty new cases at 7 o'clock, and at that time the day's record included seven deaths. There is no abatement of the fever, and at the same time there is no apparent disposition on the part of the plague to grow any worse.

A great deal of nonsense has appeared in misinformed quarters concerning the recent relieving from duty with the Tenth Battalion of Albany of Surgeon Louis H. Balch. It has been stated that the Surgeon was relieved from duty because he wrote an article on Oct. 10 criticising the National Guard over his own signature; but this, it may be said, is not true.
BOISE, Idaho, Oct. 23. -- For ten days a woman has been Governor of Idaho, not as the result of election, but Governor, nevertheless, empowered with executive authority, and exercising it.

The purposes for which water power is being utilized are exceedingly varied. It is used directly as electrical energy for lighting purposes, and for chemical and metallurgical operations. Transformed again into mechanical energy by means of the electric motor, it is used for working tramway systems, for producing wood pulp for papermaking, and for driving machinery of all kinds at the mines or in engineering and other workshops.

BERLIN, Oct. 23. -- Just now there are over 100 cases of young men being drafted as recruits into the army, in which the United States Embassy is interested. They are the sons of American citizens born here after their fathers resettled in Germany. The young men claim American rights, and declare their intention of emigrating to the United States; but, nevertheless, they are held for military service.

The Athenaeum Association of Jamaica, L.I., is one of the most progressive women's organizations in the Greater New York. Its great aim is to put up a building, an athenaeum, where can be centralized the organized literary and philanthropic work of women.

May not Americans find in this a criticism that may apply to advertising at home as well as abroad? What is effective, and what is good manners as well as good policy, is equally applicable here as in foreign countries.

Albert B. Boardman yesterday closed him argument before the Rapid Transit Special Commission in favor of the proposed underground road. All of the testimony and the arguments for and against the scheme have now been heard by the commission, and the gentlemen comprising that body, namely, Arthur D. Williams, John Sabine Smith, and George W. Young, have until Nov. 8 in which to formulate their report for the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court.

LONDON, Oct. 23. -- The Greater New York election amenities are followed here with considerable interest, especially the presentation of Mr. Richard Croker as a crony of the Prince of Wales. The London Figaro on this subject says:
The Word of yesterday, after referring to the general belief that Mr. McKINLEY had interfered in the city election in New York and the severe criticism visited upon him by Republicans, says:

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 23. -- The State Federation of Woman's Clubs will invade South Jersey on Thursday and Friday of next week. There is considerable diplomacy about the selection of Camden for their meeting place, because the Woman's Club movement is not generally understood in West Jersey, and has not flourished so well as it has in Eastern New Jersey, particularly in Union and Essex Counties. There are only seven clubs south of Trenton.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 23. -- The Cercle Francais de l'Universite Harvard has decided that "Le Medecin Malgre Lui" of Moliere should be the play given this year. The time arranged for its production is shortly after the midyear examinations.

Prince Peter Krapotkin, the Russian Socialist and Anarchist, arrived last evening from Washington by the 6:30 train over the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, and went uptown to stay with some friends. He is a well-preserved old gentleman of about fifty-five years, ruddy, of medium build, bright eyes, hair gray mixed, and wears a full, shaggy beard.

Two important meetings of yachtsmen will be held this week. On Thursday there will he a meeting of the New York Yacht Club, when various reports will be submitted and discussed, and a Nominating Committee will be elected to select officers and committee for next year. It is possible that the friends of the National Organization will try to have a resolution adopted favorable to the new scheme.
THE correspondent of La Illustration Espanola y Americana gives the following details of the monument to Raphael unveiled in his native city of Urbino the 22d day of August last:

Charles E. Hardick, a printer, was run over and killed by a fire engine in Brooklyn yesterday. A short time afterward his wife went to the Adams Street Police Court to press a charge of assault against him, and learned there for the first time that he was dead.

THERE are two special occasions when the members of the Larchmont Yacht Club think themselves in duty bound to be at the clubhouse. These are the opening and closing days of the yachting season. The opening day is in May, usually the last Saturday, and the closing day is in October.
Commissioner of Street Cleaning Waring yesterday got out the following statement headed "Concerning Asa Bird Gardiner":

PARIS, Oct. 23. -- In the Chamber of Deputies to-day M. Gerault Richard, Socialist, raised a discussion on the price of bread. He said the increase of price was due to "shameless speculators," and that only the big agriculturist profited by it. Continuing, the Deputy charged the Government with being a "famine Ministry." This caused violent protests from the supporters of the Government.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 23. -- George Braun to-day pleaded guilty to a charge of bigamy. He was charged in an indictment found by the Grand Jury now in session with having married Pauline Caufman of Rochester, while he knowingly had a wife, Mathilda Braun, living at Syracuse.

The last day of the Fall meeting of the New York Driving Club attracted a large crowd to Fleetwood Park yesterday afternoon. The features of the day were a free-for-all pace and a match race between Russell T. and Grateful for $500, which resulted in Russell T. winning three straight heats easily.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 23. -- The football elevens of Cornell and Princeton met this afternoon on Percy Field. The Princeton men came with lots of money to bet, and they willingly offered odds that Princeton would win, but were somewhat cautious on the point that Cornell would not score.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 23. -- In an attempt to save Edward G. Haynes, alias George Allen, accused of the murder of Mary Daly and Mary Crouch, at Sacket's Harbor on April 16 last, from death in the electric chair, the defense resorted to a surgical operation this afternoon to prove to the jury what they maintained was shown in the X-Ray photographs of Alien's neck which they offered in evidence.

There was a notable struggle which enlisted all the elements of physical power and many of the qualities of the scientific and successful warrior when the football teams of Yale University and the Carlisle Indian School met yesterday on the Polo Grounds and strove with each other for mastery and honors.

THE musical season of 1897-8 opened with a glad surprise. It is not at all likely that any one expected performances worthy of serious consideration from a military band, but Maestro Eugenio Sorrentino and his admirable Banda Rossa have given local musicians food for thought.

To the general riding public the introduction of the chainless bicycle of the model which experts almost universally unite in asserting will be the standard for future cycle construction has been hailed as the cycling event of the year, apart from matters pertaining to the race track. That it is practicable few doubt.

CROTON LANDING, Oct. 23. -- A strike of large proportions is in progress at the new Cornell dam, about two and a half miles from this village, where about 800 Italians, Slavs, and Poles have gone out against alleged arbitrary orders, said to have been given by Charles Brenchard, one of the sub-contractors.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23. -- In the next bulletin issued by the Commissioner of Labor, Carroll D. Wright, official notice will be taken of spurious statistics which have been sent broadcast through the press of the country purporting to come from the Commissioner of Labor.

If the name began with De, which is the particle indicative of nobility, it was an easy matter, the only thing necessary being the separation of the initial syllable from the rest of the name. For instance, Monsieur Delamare became Monsieur de Lamare; Monsieur Delestrade was transformed into Monsieur de Lestrade, and Monsieur Dervilley signed "D'Ervilley."
TOPEKA, Kan., Oct. 23. -- A happy condition prevails in Kansas. All her people -- men of all political faiths -- are singing her praises, for the State is enjoying an era of great prosperity.

The Sixth Regiment of Infantry, stationed at Fort Thomas, Kentucky, opposite Cincinnati, and commanded by Col. M.A. Cochran, has recently completed one of the longest, if not the longest, of the practice marches made by the troops of the regular army in recent years for the purpose of teaching the "young 'uns" how it is done in time of actual field service, and to keep the hands of the "old uns" in training.

It is interesting to observe that Tammany continues to placard the fences and dead walls with its ticket under the heading of "Regular Democratic Nominations." Undoubtedly, that is the heading which is calculated to attract the "brute vote" upon which Tammany relies. But this year, for the first time, the regularity of Tammany is in question.

GARRISON'S, Oct. 25. -- At 1 o'clock this morning three bodies, supposed to be the last in the wreck, were recovered. They are thought to be those of the missing men, but identification has not been positive.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 24. -- The Rev. Archibald A. Murphy, pastor of the Second Presbyterian Church, in his sermon this evening discussed the criticisms made against Princeton University in relation to the licensing of Princeton Inn. In the course of his sermon he said:

There was an excise battle early Sunday morning in the saloon of Patrick McCarthy, at 1,111 First Avenue, between the proprietor and five men on the inside and a roundsman and five policemen, on the outside, which resulted in the capture of the leader of the inside forces and his chief aide, James Farley, a bartender.

The Rev. Dr. Lindsay Parker, rector of St. Peter's Protestant Episcopal Church, State Street, Brooklyn, preached a sermon yesterday morning on "Civic Liberty." Dr. Parker, without mentioning Seth Low by name, made a pointed reference to his candidacy, and said he was going to vote for him. In the course of his sermon, Dr. Parker said:

The Rev. Maurice H. Harris of Temple Israel. One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street and Fifth Avenue, delivered the first of his course of Winter lectures to a large audience in the Temple Friday evening. His subject was "Our Enlarged Municipal Responsibilities.'' He said in part:
MADRID, Oct. 24. -- A Government note protesting against filibustering will be handed to United States Minister Woodford to-morrow.
CHICAGO, Oct. 24. -- The will of George M. Pullman was opened last night and read to the members of the family at the Pullman residence, 1,729 Prairie Avenue.

The desire of every honest, intelligent, and public-spirited member of this community is that an era of good government shall be inaugurated by this first election of municipal officers for the Greater New York. For the attainment of this desire, the best citizens have gathered together in greater numbers, with more enthusiasm and greater independence than ever before, and formed a municipal party known as the Citizens' Union.

DENVER, Col., Oct. 24. -- The Tabor Grand Opera House was crowded to the doors this evening with people to listen to the Rev. T.H. Malone's much-discussed lecture on "Socialistic Fallacies." So great was the demand for admission that hundreds were turned away, and for the benefit of those who were unable to hear Father Malone tonight he has consented to deliver the lecture again next Sunday night.

A meeting to "ratify the Tammany Hall city and county ticket" was held last night in the Windsor Theatre. Bowery, near Canal Street, under the auspices of the East Side Business Men's Association. Ferdinand Levy was the chairman.

BABYLON, L.I., Oct. 24. -- Miss Ella Hart, Principal of Babylon School, District No. 2, does not look as well as she did Friday morning, but she has vindicated her position as the ruling authority in her institution and subjugated the Coleman family.

-- Most people will merely smile over the news that one of the Cuban leaders, now on board an ocean-going tug loaded with ammunition and filibusters, announces the intention, when opportunity offers, to seize a Spanish war ship, and with it to give the rebels possession of the port which they have so long needed.

Richard Croker attended a meeting of the Tammany Hall Committee of the Twentieth Assembly District, held in the clubhouse, 207 East Thirty-second Street, yesterday afternoon. The Twentieth is Mr. Croker's old district, of which he was leader for many years. When he arrived at the hall he was received with great applause.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21. -- Secretary of State Sherman puts his foot down prompt upon disquieting reports about imminent sensational developments growing out of the negotiations with Spain. All day Saturday there was newspaper anxiety to obtain from the Department of State the whole or the substance of a dispatch of 2,000 words said to have been sent from Madrid to Washington.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- From some remarks made to-day by Secretary Sherman, it may be gathered that the commission headed by Senator Wolcott and having Vice President Stevenson and Mr. Paine as members, had not derived authority from the Administration to make the propositions enumerated by the Governor of the Bank of England and those recently mentioned in the report of the negotiations made by Lord Salisbury.

MOBILE, Oct. 24. -- There was a much larger report of new cases to-day than usual. The best known among the sick is Mrs. Groom, sister of Mrs. Bellamy, the writer. Total cases to date, 209; deaths, 28; recoveries, 146; under treatment, 35.

So profound was the sensation created by the lecture delivered by Prof. Felix Adler yesterday before the Society for Ethical Culture at Carnegie Music Hall, that at its conclusion there was a spontaneous burst of applause on the part of a large portion of the audience, which seemed forgetful of the fact that the exercises were of a semi-religious nature.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., Oct. 24. -- A thousand laborers in the employ of the New York and Philadelphia Traction Company to-day laid two and a half miles of track through Eastern Turnpike, in Bridgewater Township, between this place and the Borough of Bound Brook The work was done in defiance of the Sheriff and other peace officers, and against the protests of property owners.

The armored cruisers New York and Brooklyn and the battleships Iowa, Massachusetts, and Texas, under the command of Rear Admiral Montgomery Sicard, commander of the North Atlantic station, arrived at the anchorage off Tompkinsville early yesterday morning.

LONDON, Oct. 24. -- Capt. John Frederick Lugard, British officer in command in the Kalahari Desert, South Central Africa, who was for some time in command in British East Africa, and later was connected with the Royal Niger Company, has just returned to London from Central Africa. William R. Foster, Jr., who, in 1888, stole $193,000 from the Gratuity Fund of the New York Produce Exchange, and fled to Europe, has been arrested in Paris, France, and will be brought back to this country for trial on the charge of forgery.

The little three-story frame dwelling 235 Sixth Street served as the theatre for a scene in which a night marauder and a physician were the chief actors, and which had a ludicrous as well as a dangerous side, early yesterday morning. It resulted in victory for the pluck and dexterity of Dr. Leo H.R. Hibbe, after a hand-to-hand encounter with a burglar.

Judge Advocate General LEMLY, in his annual report to the Secretary of the Navy, discusses a number of topics with interest and animation. His recommendations in behalf of technical deserters and of veteran seamen who do not enjoy the privilege, which they ought to enjoy, of retirement for services after thirty years in uniform, and some minor suggestions, invite approval.
The Citizens' Union leaders are much encouraged at the reports received with regard to the situation in every part of Greater New York, but more especially with reference to the east side.

GARRISON'S, Oct. 24. -- After the moment of crash and splash, during which woodwork was torn, splintered, and ground into bits, and iron and steel were rent, twisted and broken, the waters closed silently and swiftly over the engine, the express car, and the combination car, while the first three sleeping cars, half submerged, were slowly sinking.

Boatman "Billy" Quigley of Quigley's Basin, at the Battery, is one of the most industrious and sober-going men on the water front. He is held in respect equally by tugboatmen, steamship Captains, managing owners, and fellow-boatmen. He knows the whereabouts of a greyhound, a tramp, or a wind jammer, whatever part of the world she may be, once she has visited this port.

OIL CITY, Penn., Oct. 24. -- Three persons were burned to death and seven others severely injured in a fire that destroyed the Hotel Brooklyn, at Kelletville, twenty-five miles southeast of Oil City, early this morning. The building was a three-story one, roughly built of boards, and it burned like tinder.

SEATTLE, Washington, Oct. 24. -- The steamer Humboldt arrived here last night with five men from Dawson, leaving there Sept. 3, and three men from Minonk and other points on the Yukon. They say no gold will come out this Fall, as this steamer brought the last of those who have come down the Yukon. The river is already frozen hard, and all boats are laid up for the Winter.

CHOATE, ERHARDT, ROOT, SWAYNE, STRONG, and others are daily described as "traitors to the Republican Party" in articles which explain that the Republican Party is the same as "the Republican organization of the State of New York." In order to gratify a pardonable curiosity to what it is they are "traitors," we give from authentic sources a compendious history of "the Republican organization of the State of New York."

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 24. -- K.B. Speedy, a high diver, jumped from the top of the channel span of the Louisville and Jeffersonville Bridge, a height of 160 feet, this afternoon in the presence of 1,000 people, who crowded the streets of Louisville and Jeffersonville fronting near the scene, two excursion steamers, and the bridge pathway.

LONDON, Oct. 24. -- The Bank of England's recent borrowings have reduced materially the floating supply of money. Last week's return showed a reduction of four millions sterling on the total deposit, caused by the hardening of rates, and the discount houses advanced the deposit rate from 1 1/4 per cent. to 1 1/2 per cent. for money on call, and from 1 1/2 per cent. to 1 3/4 per cent. for money at notice.

OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 24. -- Gen. John C. Cowin, special counsel for the United States in the Union Pacific foreclosure suit, last evening admitted that there was more than a probability that the sale would be postponed, but he would not make a positive statement to that effect. He started for St. Paul to-day to confer with Judge Sanborn and Special Master Cornish on Monday.

A hurricane is raging off the Atlantic coast, and mariners were warned yesterday not to go to sea. Chief Moore of the Weather Bureau at Washington sent out orders for the display of hurricane signals at the Delaware Breakwater, Beazly Island, Cape May, Sandy Hook, New York, Montauk Point, Newport, Narragansett, Woodhull, and Cape Cod.

The Japanese Minister at Washington, Mr. TORU HOSHI, makes a valuable contribution to the good understanding which should exist between his nation and our own in an article on "The New Japan," in Harper's Monthly for November.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24. -- The casket containing the body of George M. Pullman was laid on the concrete flooring of a pit 13 feet long, 9 feet wide, and 8 feet deep, in Graceland Cemetery. This concrete was 18 inches thick. The body itself had been placed in a lead-lined box wrapped in tar paper. Under and around the box was an inch of asphaltum.

Six hundred persons assembled at the Metropolitan Temple, Seventh Avenue and Fourteenth Street, last night to hear a sermon from the Rev. S. Parkes Cadman upon '"The Best Interests of Journalism." Mr. Cadman took his text from Chronicles xxvii., 32:

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 24. -- While crowds of people were on their way to the churches in the neighborhood to-day, two men entered the cigar store of John Mather, at Fifth and Market Streets. Both men were white. They commanded Mather to give them all the money he had. He refused to comply and grappled with one of them.

As some of your readers may be uncertain as to whether Seth Low or Henry George ought to have their votes, I would like the privilege of saying a few words in your columns that may help to clear up that uncertainty.
