GARRISONS, Oct. 24. -- The first body found was that of Mr. Williams. It was against the bank, about twenty feet from the half-submerged cars. There was just breath in it, but death came with rescue. Mr. Williams had in some way crawled through a window and made his way ashore, where he stopped on the shelving remains of what had been wall and embankment under the perpendicular eight-foot bluff that remained.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- In his annual report to the Secretary of the Navy, Philip Hichborn, Chief Constructor of the Navy, says the strength of the navy Oct. 1 was 141 vessels all told, including the ships of both the old and new navies.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- President Nick Young of the National Baseball League today made public the fielding record of players who took part in fifteen or more championship games during the season of 1897. The following shows the record of the ten leading men in each position:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- In his last weekly report to Surgeon General Wyman, Sanitary Inspector Brunner of the Marine Hospital service reports seven deaths from starvation in Havana for the week ended Oct. 7, and twenty-one for the week ended Oct. 14. He also reports a rapid increase in intestinal diseases due to the contracted food supply, estimating that two-fifths of the total deaths of the city are due to this cause.

The trial of George W. Holt, an insurance adjuster of Brooklyn, who is charged with aiding in the escape of Samuel Milch, another adjuster, indicted as an accomplice in a fire at 121 Walker Street in 1894, was begun yesterday morning in the Court of General Sessions.
LONDON, Oct. 26. -- The Times, after remarking editorially this morning that "the real danger is that America will take some step to precipitate a crisis," says:

The Presbytery of New York held a special meeting yesterday afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church, to hear the judgment of the judicial commission appointed on Oct. 4 to decide the appeal of Herman Warszawiak from the judgment of the session of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, suspending him from the communion of the church.

If you, reader, have periodical headaches, uncertain pains, an occasional feeling of nausea, a dry mouth or coated tongue, a parched skin, intermittent feverishness, lines under the eyes or dull pains, especially in the lower part of the body, you have kidney trouble in some one of its many acute forms, and should act at once if you wish to avoid disaster.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- Over $90,000 of alleged fraudulent warrants on the United States Treasury on the account of the Creek Indian Nation, in Indian Territory, have been discovered by Government authorities. The alleged fraud was perpetrated in connection with the payment of the Creek Indian Nation debts, and only the barest details have reached here.

READING, Penn., Oct. 25. -- Millions of tons of coal which have been lying for years beneath the numerous culm banks in Schuylkill County, Penn., are now being reclaimed, owing to cheaper rates in transportation.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- The International Seal Conference met again at the State Department to-day with all the members present.

A special hearing was given by Board A of the United States General Appraisers yesterday, to importers who have filed protests against the Treasury Department's construction of Section 33 of the new tariff act. There are several hundred of these protests, and the question involved is, What actually constitutes a legal entry? Importers in New York, Chicago, Philadelphia, Louisville, St. Louis and other ports were represented at yesterday's hearing.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 25. -- The claim of Dr. Joseph O. Hirschfelder of this city that he has discovered a cure for consumption, announced last April, has been investigated by the Faculty of the Cooper Medical College.

One of the largest and most enthusiastic meetings of the campaign was addressed by Seth Low and Mayor Strong at Urback's Hall, One Hundred and Sixty-ninth Street and Third Avenue, last night. The hall was crowded until standing room was at a premium.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- Up to the close of office hours to-day Spain's reply on the Cuban question had not reached the President or State Department.

The force of Mr. Low's candidacy is not only unifying but victorious. It is impossible now for any reasonable and observant man to doubt his election. The signs are too numerous and convincing. Every test of popular feeling, every attract to find out the intention of the voters, reveals a depth and volume of Low sentiment that portends a certain triumph.

The trial of Frederico Mora, Ricardo de Requesens, and their alleged confederates, charged with making and issuing counterfeit notes of the Government of Costa Rica to the amount of $1,000,000, was begun in the criminal branch of the United States Circuit Court, before Judge Tenney, yesterday morning. There was a large number of witnesses present, including those who arrived here from Costa Rica on Tuesday last.

LONDON, Oct. 25. -- The Lorillard-Beresford Stable's three-year-old chestnut colt Quibble II., by Sensation out of Quandary, won the Newmarket Maiden Plate to-day. There were six starters; Coolgardie finished second, and Bonfire was third. Quibble II. was ridden by "Tod" Sloane, the American jockey.

ALBANY, Oct. 25. -- The Court of Appeals to-day declared the Police Commissioners of New York City properly granted a certificate of an independent nomination to the Citizens' Union, which placed Seth Low in nomination for Mayor of Greater New York.

Henry George again invaded Brooklyn last night, and, in spite of the bad weather, received a warm reception. He was scheduled to speak at an open-air meeting at the corner of Hamilton Avenue and Carroll Street, and afterward at the Athenaeum, Clinton Street and Atlantic Avenue. A crowd of over 1,000 persons gathered in the rain in the open air and listened to him and a number of other speakers, cheering enthusiastically.

One or both of them may die, but unless all present signs are false and unless the convictions of all sane observers are delusions, the race is between Seth Low and R.A. Van Wyek, and one or the other of them will be the first Mayor of Greater New York. The growth of the Low movement has been the surprise and the sensation of the canvass which now enters on its last week.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Oct. 11. -- John Augustine, an American citizen, was arrested at San Carlos, at the mouth of the San Juan River, on Sept. 24, by order of President Zelaya, and was brought here at once, without any pretense of a trial, and was imprisoned in the penitentiary.

At the Broadway Theatre last night a new operetta, entitled "The Idol's Eye," was brought forward. This new piece is the work of Harry B. Smith, who supplied the book, and Victor Herbert, who composed the music.

OMAHA, Neb., Oct. 25. -- Judge W.D. Cornish, Special Master Commissioner for the sale of the Union Pacific, and Judge W.R. Kelley, General Solicitor for the receivers, had their first news of the postponement of the sale from The Associated Press this morning. They were both very much astonished, and declined to say anything further than that the news was a great surprise and completely upset them.

TORONTO, Oct. 25. -- The second day's session of the World's W.C.T.U. Convention was opened with the Pavilion crowded to the doors. Mrs. Sanderson read her report as Treasurer of the World's W.C.T.U. The financial statement covered the period from June 1, 1896, to May 31, 1897. The total receipts from all sources were $2,081.26; disbursements, $2,032.26.

BERLIN, Oct. 25. -- The refusal of the Czar and Czarina to receive the Grand Duke and Grand Duchess of Baden at Darmstadt, after the latter had intimated to their Russian Majesties a desire to visit them, is vogorously criticised by the German press.

Clifford, one of the most brilliant performers the American turf has ever known, was the star of the sale of thoroughbreds at Morris Park yesterday. He was purchased by John Sanford, the Master of the famous Hurricana Stud, for $7,000, and, although he is only seven years old, and apparently in condition for another year of campaigning, he will be retired to stud service.

An enthusiastic meeting in support of Seth Low's candidacy was held in the Christian Science Chapel, at Eighty-second Street and the Boulevard, last night. There were nearly 1,000 people in the hall -- all that it would hold -- and every mention of Mr. Low or statement of the principles for which he stands was cheered to the echo.

GARRISON'S, N.Y., Oct. 25. -- No additions to the total of nineteen lives lost in the disaster to the State Express near here yesterday morning has been made, after a thorough search of the wrecked cars and an investigation of the reports of the train and Wagner car conductors. The officers of the road say all their passengers and trainmen are now accounted for, and that no further addition to the list is possible.

Seth Low got a rousing reception from the Campaign Committee of the German-American Reform Union at its headquarters in the Grand Central Palace, at Lexington Avenue and Forty-third Street, yesterday afternoon.

Chickering Hall was crowded last night, galleries, platform, and parquet, with a wildly enthusiastic audience that had assembled to hear Bourke Cockran, Elihu Root, and other speakers pay a last tribute to the memory of Charles Anderson Dana. The exercises, which were held under the auspices of the Cuban Revolutionary Party, were notable for the response that every reference to the struggle of Cuba for freedom evoked.

BOSTON, Oct. 25. -- The minority report of George E. McNeil of the Special Commission on Taxation was submitted to the Governor this afternoon. The report is a lengthy one, and in beginning the discussion of the question of taxation from his standpoint he says that it is proper to inquire how much the non-taxpaying millionaire is worth to the State.

In the work the New York City Consuls of the League of American Wheelmen have planned for this Winter the improvement of roads occupies an important place, and the first move in this crusade has been arranged for next Sunday, when the Streets and Highways Committee will travel over city thoroughfares frequented by wheelmen.
The Union Pacific Railway Reorganization Committee issued this statement yesterday:

We do not yet authentically know what the dispatch conveyed by Gen. WOODFORD is to which Spain has now replied. We do not even know so much about it as we know about the reply, the substance of which the Madrid Government seems to have allowed to transpire in advance of its formal publication, if not of its actual delivery.
The sentiment in favor of Seth Low for Mayor was known to be strong at the Produce Exchange, but until yesterday morning the definite strength was not known.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- Fourth Assistant Postmaster General Joseph L. Bristow, in his report for the fiscal year, says:

L.J. Phillips Co. have sold for George F. Johnson, for about $60,000, the four-story brownstone-front dwelling West Sixty-ninth Street, 23 by 78 by 98.9. This completes the sale of a row of similar dwellings purchased by Mr. Johnson from Henry F. Cook.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25. -- Double tracks for lake boats are proposed by lake men. The plan is to have a course for up-bound boats and another for down-bound boats along the west shore of Lake Huron from Port Huron to Presque Isle, just above Alpena. All this commerce is converged where the course from Lake Michigan joins that from Lake Superior.

There are differences of opinion between Henry George and ex-Postmaster Dayton on more subjects than the attack on Richard Croker. Mr. Dayton said several days ago that he did not believe in personal attacks on Croker, but opposed "Crokerism," which, he said, was opposed to Democracy and stood for political slavery.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- An opinion was handed down by Justice Brewer in the United States Supreme Court to-day in the case of the United States versus Goldenberg Brothers Co., of New York, involving the construction of Section 14 of the Tariff Administrative act of 1890. The question which came to the Supreme Court on a certificate from the Circuit Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, was as follows:

A complaint was filed in the office of the County Clerk yesterday by Charles Austin Bates, who has an office in the Vanderbilt Building, in which he alleged that he is entitled to 20,000 shares of stock of the General Electric Railway Company of Chicago, the par value of which was $2,000,000. He has brought suit to recover this stock, which, he alleges, is at present held by J. Pierpont Morgan Co.

The rainy weather did not interfere greatly with the golf matches of the Ardsley Club, near Dobbs Ferry. The preliminary round for the Bacon Cup was played, the lowest sixteen scores of the Class A players qualifying for the hole-play rounds, commencing to-day, and the best sixteen of the Class B golfers qualifying for the consolation trophy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- The War Department has just received a report from Capt. Ray of the condition of affairs in the gold region as he has found them from St. Michael to Fort Yukon, supplemented by the accounts of the most reliable persons he could communicate with as to the state of affairs on the Klondike and its neighborhood.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 25. -- Prof. Charles W. Shields of Princeton University authorizes the statement that, in consequence of the "unjust, unconstitutional, and defamatory action" of certain Presbyteries and Synods, involving his good name, he has decided, for his own personal protection, to separate himself from the Presbyterian Church in a constitutional manner with the least possible delay.

A politician of average effrontery, of just the ordinary degree of meanness, would blush to be caught in such dirty business as the attack upon the validity of Low's nomination. PLATT, we should say, is too old a bird to commit such a blunder. Probably QUIGG put up the job. He is inexperienced and without knowledge how such things react.

John T. Williams, the proprietor of a feed store at 1,414 Avenue A, was arraigned in Yorkville Court yesterday morning, accused of having murdered his wife Kate. He denied the charge, and was committed without bail for examination today. Frank Porter of 402 East Seventy-seventh Street, John Barry of 1,523 Second Avenue, and Thomas Conroy of 344 East Seventy-seventh Street were detained as witnesses.

It is known that Senator PLATT changed the church he was in the habit of attending when sojourning in the city, on account of the want of consideration his former pastor showed for his feelings. The former pastor, Dr. PARKHURST, is an impetuous and impulsive preacher, and it was quite natural that in inculcating elementary morality he should have forgotten the presence of his distinguished parishioner.
With what fear and misgiving the friends of good government in this city would look forward to the contest at the polls if PLATT and CROKER had control of the election machinery and of the count!

The leaders of the Citizens' Union do not regard Senator Platt's latest statement as a document which will in the least weaken their movement. They believe that the election of Seth Low is as certain as anything political may be. "The statement is absurd," said Executive Chairman James B. Reynolds yesterday.
The Republicans will end their campaign with two big meetings, at one of which Bourke Cockran will be the star speaker. The other will be addressed by Benjamin F. Tracy and Chauncey M. Depew.

The programme at Morris Park yesterday was perhaps the poorest in class the meeting has known, but there was much in its make-up to compensate for the lack of quality. The fact that all of the six events were decided over the Withers track, where every portion of a race from the start to the finish is visible without the use of field glasses, was cause for rejoicing among the spectators.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- A feeling of alarm has seized upon everybody in the Administration circle over the Ohio situation. For a week or more the heads of departments have been bombarded with emergency calls for appointments of Ohio men, the cause invariably assigned being that Senator Hanna's re-election is endangered.

MADRID, Oct. 26. -- The Spanish Government refuses to furnish for publication the text of the note of Spain, which has been handed to the United States Minister here, Gen. Stewart L. Woodford, as an answer to the communication which the General placed in the hands of the Duke of Tetuan early in September last, when the latter was Minister for Foreign Affairs, on the subject of the insurrection in the Island of Cuba.

Contracts were signed yesterday for the sale of the five-story business building at 388 Broadway, extending through to Cortlandt Alley, 28 by 175. The buyer is a client of Parsons, Shepard Ogden, and the price was about $157,000.

The death of the Professor of Poetry at Oxford would not ordinarily be an event of much moment. The only fruits of the professorship that ordinary readers of English will be apt to recall are the "Lectures on Translating Homer," which MATTHEW ARNOLD prepared as part, or possibly as the whole, of his professorial duties.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- The Japanese Legation has received no recent information relative to the status of Japanese-Hawaiian affairs. A letter came yesterday from Mr. Shimamura, the Japanese representative at Honolulu, but it made no mention of the reported agreement to arbitrate all differences on the immigration question. It is the general understanding, however, that an amicable solution will be reached, if, indeed, it has not been already concluded.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- The status of the Indians in Alaska and their right to take up or hold a mining claim, according to the United States mining laws or pursuant to any treaty with Russia at the time of the Alaskan purchase, is discussed in a decision made to-day by Commissioner Hermann of the General Land Office.

Nothing is more remarkable and nothing more cheering in this canvass than the eager interest that is taken in it by those who are commonly regarded and regard themselves as "out of politics." Most women regard themselves as out of politics by reason of their sex. But women who have no opinions upon the tariff and the currency have very strong opinions about the municipal government.

DENVER, Oct. 26. -- A severe snowstorm, accompanied by a high wind from the north, began here last night, and is not yet over. Electric cars are unable to run. The storm is general in this section. Wires to the west and south are down, and railroad trains are much delayed.

When the first season of the Metropolitan Opera House, the season of 1883-4, came to an end, Mr. Henry E. Abbey, the manager, indulged in the luxury of a benefit. Mme. Marcella Sembrich, the colorature soprano of the company, who had shared the honors of the season with Christine Nilsson, was down on the programme for a violin solo, the eighth concerto of De Beriot.
The National Democrats, for the first time in the campaign, held a great mass meeting last night. It was the night of Seth Low's final tour of Brooklyn, and the Clermont Avenue Rink was crowded.

The work of the Monetary Commission is proceeding with great energy. It is much further advanced than could have been hoped, considering that all its members are busy men, devoting valuable time to purely public service with no incentive but their desire that their service may be the best that they can give.
To say "I told you so" is not a very eminently satisfactory remark to him who makes it or to his hearer, yet there are times when it seems the only thing to say.

Several thousand German Democratic citizens met in Cooper Union last night and ratified the Tammany municipal, county, and Assembly ticket. William Sohmer presided. The hall was by no means full, and at the conclusion of each speech the audience grew slenderer.

The second day of the trial of Frederico Mora, Ricardo de Requesens, and Louis Houseman, who are charged with counterfeiting notes of the Bank of Costa Rica in the amount of $1,000,000, was finished in the criminal branch of the United States Circuit Court yesterday.

The Rev. Dr. Julius A. Ward, ex-pastor of the Fowler Methodist Episcopal Church in Minneapolis, Minn., is in the city for the purpose of founding an interdenominational church in one of the slum sections of the city.
Seth Low made his last campaign speeches in Brooklyn at five different meetings last evening. At each meeting he was greeted by large audiences and with great applause.
Controller Fitch gave out the following statement yesterday afternoon:

Patrolman Frederick Smith of the East Fifth Street Police Station, was shot and killed this morning, in the Church of the Holv Redeemer, Third Street, between Avenues A and B, by a burglar who was robbing the poorbox. He was caught, and gave the name of Fritz Meyer, forty-five years old, no home.

-- Probably the Government weather forecasters would not admit that the lugubrious warnings sent forth by them Monday evening were not fulfilled by yesterday's meteorological conditions. The passengers on incoming steamers are quite convinced that there was a cyclone which more than bore out the official prophecies, so it would be more or less unjust to score another complete and notable failure against the Weather Bureau.

A new trust company is being organized in this city the title of which is to be the Fifth Avenue Trust Company. It will be situated at Fifth Avenue and Forty-third Street. The company's capital is fixed at $500,000, and it will begin business early next year with a paid in reserve of $500,000. All of the capital has been subscribed.

SIMLA, Oct. 26. -- It is estimated that the tribesmen have massed 20,000 men at Sempagha Pass, where they are busy making rifle pits in the sangars and strengthening their defenses. It is generally believed, however, that it will be possible to turn the position by either flank, and, though hard fighting is possibly in store, it is hoped that the pass will be carried without great effort.

George R. Blanchard, Commissioner of the Joint Traffic Association, and Simon Sterne, who took a leading part with Judge Reagan of Texas in drafting the original Inter-State Commerce bill, discussed "Railway Pooling'' before the Board of Trade and Transportation yesterday. The Assembly Hall at 203 Broadway was filled with visiting merchants and business men.

BERLIN, Oct. 26. -- The Tageblatt explains to-day that the refusal of the Czar to receive the Grand Duke and Grand Duchess of Baden at Darmstadt on Saturday last was due to the sarcastic comments made by the Grand Duke of Baden upon the conversion of the Czarina, formerly Princess Alix of Hesse, sister of the Grand Duke of Hesse, to the Greek Church, previous to her marriage to the Czar in November, 1894.

DELAWARE BREAKWATER, Oct. 26. -- The storm on the coast hereabout continued with but little abatement to-day. The schooner Elizabeth S. Lee, which was driven ashore yesterday on the point of Cape Henlopen, went to pieces this morning, and her cargo of coal is a total loss. The schooner Sarah J. Vaughn, bound from Philadelphia for Norfolk, with 350 tons of coal, which rail ashore on the beach at the breakwater, broke amidship this morning.

ALBANY, Oct. 26. -- The Court of Appeals to-day handed down a decision reversing for a second time the judgment of conviction of murder in the first degree rendered against Martin Strait of Elmira in May, 1895. Soon after this conviction an appeal was taken to the Court of Appeals, and the judgment of conviction was reversed and a new trial was ordered.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Oct. 26. -- A letter bearing on political conditions generally from Senator Henry M. Teller of Colorado has been received by William Wilhelm, representative of the Republican Silver Party in this county. Among other things Senator Teller says:

CHICAGO, Oct. 26. -- Chief of Police Kipley to-day issued an order discharging from the force 434 policemen and appointing in their place a like number of members of the "Star League" of Democratic ex-policemen who had been discharged under the previous administration. It is the biggest general order issued since ex-Chief Badenoch (Republican) issued his order in May. 1895, discharging 587 men.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- Commissioner of the General Land Office Binger Hermann has submitted his annual report to the Secretary of the Interior. Compared with the previous year, it shows a decrease of 3,298 original homestead entries, aggregating 378,625 acres. In the entire disposals of public lands there was a falling off of 5,370,406 acres.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26. -- "Within the last twenty-four hours we have received information that may make another trial of Luetgert unnecessary," said Attorney Albert Phalen to-day. "I will not reveal the name of my informant or the location of the city in which he lives, but it is within 200 miles of Chicago, and the man is an ex-official of the place.

Ex-Mayor Gilroy issued from Tammany Hall yesterday a statement making comparisons between the financial situation existing during the six years preceding the present administration and that during Mayor Strong's term. He said:

Twenty-eight of the thirty-five members of the Executive Committee of the Business Men's Republican and Sound Money Association, which was formed last year to assist in the election of McKinley and Hobart, and who represent twenty-eight of the thirty-five business organizations which participated in the great sound money parade, met last night at Citizens' Union Headquarters, 39 East Twenty-third Street, and Indorsed the candidacy of Seth Low.

A petition has been submitted to the Park Board asking that one of the small parks now in the course of construction shall be named "Stiles Park" in memory of the late WILLIAM A. STILES. The park selected would probably be one on Heater or on Houston Street, for which there is no special local name appropriate.
DENVER, Oct. 26. -- Gov. Adams has received the following message from Deputy Sheriff Frank E. Watson:
" The greatest danger at this season on the year comes from shutting up the pores of the skin."

The most deluded persons in this campaign are the young and ambitious Republicans who support TRACY because of their superstitious fear that if they become irregular this Fall they can never get a nomination from the Platt machine, so that a political career would be shut to them.

LONDON, Oct. 26. - -The first attempt to organize a syndicate in London for the purchase of the Union Pacific Railway having the appearance of substantiality is being made by Coates Son Co., stock and share brokers. A swarm of cheap American and European promoters has infested the city since it became known that the property would be put up at auction, but their efforts could not be considered seriously.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- The gradual replacement on war vessels of the cylindrical boiler by various forms of the water tube boiler constitutes the most important fact in marine engineering at this time, according to Engineer in Chief George W. Melville, who has just published his annual report to the Secretary of the Navy.

TORONTO, Oct. 26. -- The World's Woman's Christian Temperance Union Convention came to a close this afternoon. The following officers for the ensuing year were elected this morning: Honorary President -- Mrs. M.C. Leavitt, Boston; President -- Miss Frances E. Willard, Evanston, Ill.; Vice President at Large -- Lady Henry Somerset, England; Secretary -- Miss Agnes E. Slack, England; Assistant Secretary -- Miss Anna Gordon, Evanston, Ill; Treasurer -- Mrs. Mary M. Sanderson, Danville, Quebec.

SKAGUAY, Alaska, Oct. 20. -- Clifford Sifton, Canadian Minister of the Interior, and party returned yesterday from a trip over the Chilkoot and Skaguay trails, going as far as Lake Tagish. Mr. Sifton says that from information he received while in the interior there will be no shortage of food at Dawson City this Winter, and that the reports of ravages by typhoid fever have been exaggerated.

LONDON, Oct. 27. -- A dispatch to The Daily Mail from Odessa says that reports have been received there of a terrible epidemic of malarial fever and leprosy at Tiflis, capital of Russian Transcaucasia, on the Koor, and at Batoum, a seaport town of Asiatic Russia, on the east shore of the Black Sea.

Forty-two members of the Republican organization of the Twenty-seventh Assembly District and the Twenty-seventh Assembly District Republican Club have issued a circular, giving details of methods by which they say the last convention of their district was packed and the reasons why they support Francis E. Laimbeer for Assemblyman and Joseph Oatman for Alderman, nominees of the independent Republicans and the Citizens' Union.
The election of a Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals should be decided by the merit of the candidates. Politics and partisanship may be put quite out of the voter's mind.
CHICAGO, Oct. 26. -- Ex-Gov. Altgeld said to-day, regarding Mayor Harrison's proposed visit to New York, and the report that it would split the Democracy: "That idea is too absurd to be discussed."

LITTLE PERRY, N.J., Oct. 26. -- John Kaufman, Jr., Postmaster of this place, has not been in town since Saturday. His father, a wealthy grocer, and Mrs. James L. Pickens, who were on the young man's bond, have taken charge of the Post Office. They refuse to say anything or to confirm rumors of a defalcation of Government funds which has been circulated.

HAVANA, Oct. 26. -- It is announced from Spanish headquarters here that details have been received of the death recently, near the Felicitas Farm, in the Managua district of this province, of Gen. Adolfo Castillo, the well-known insurgent leader, who was reported killed some time ago, which news was apparently confirmed by official advices yesterday.
The following is not a forecast, but will show how many votes might be required to elect, say, Mr. Van Wyck or Mr. Low.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26. -- The Western roads and the Southern Pacific have finally decided to submit their differences regarding immigrant business to arbitration. This matter has been hanging fire for three years and has been the source of nearly all of the demoralization that has existed in immigrant rates.

GARRISON'S, N.Y., Oct 26. -- Despite the statement of the officers of the New York Central Railroad that the crew and all the passengers of the train that plunged into the Hudson River near Garrison's Sunday were accounted for, and the list of nineteen dead was a complete one, another body was found this afternoon when the day coach, which already had yielded six bodies, was raised from the water and searched.

A suit is pending in the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court of the Second Judicial Department involving 100 shares of stock of the Rogers Locomotive and Machine Works and a point of law in which lawyers are deeply interested because it is new and important. The suit is known as "the estate of Jason Rogers, deceased."

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 26. -- Gen. Harrison and family arrived at noon to-day from New York. In an interview relative to the campaign in New York, he said he knew nothing about the prospects of the campaign with so many parties in the field.
Cats, boys, and men are doing no end of mischief to the birds and squirrels in the Park.

Martin A. Knapp, Chairman of the Inter-State Commerce Commission, was the author of a paper on the extension of the powers of the commission, presented before the Board of Trade and Transportation at 203 Broadway yesterday.

The trial of the suit for $50,000 damages for breach of promise of marriage, brought by Anna Berliner against Jacob Scharlin, both deaf-mutes, was continued before Judge MacLean in the Supreme Court yesterday. Jacob, the defendant, tall, intelligent, his small black eyes glittering with shrewdness as they followed the twinklings of the interpreter's fingers, showed on his own briskly snapping fingers what he considered the proper form of proposal of marriage.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 27. -- The Rev. Dr. Chauncey Brewster of Brooklyn will be raised to the position of Coadjutor to Bishop Williams of Connecticut in Trinity Church to-morrow. The Bishops of New York, Massachusetts, Philadelphia, and other cities are present for the occasion, with many of the clergy and laymen of Connecticut, and the services promise to be impressive and memorable.
John M. Golding has sold for Mrs. Mary Agnes Barlow to a Dr. Gibb, for about $37,000, the five-story English basement dwelling, 55 West Thirty-eighth Street, 17 by 98.9.

One of the largest and most enthusiastic mass meetings held in the interests of the Citizens' Union campaign since the nomination of Seth Low for Mayor assembled yesterday afternoon in Cooper Union and overflowed into the streets adjacent.

Seth Low faced a real Bowery audience last night. Two thousand people had gathered in the Thalia Theatre for the sole purpose of hearing him, as they made very evident when speaker after speaker got up and talked and there were no signs of Mr. Low. Cries for "Low, Low" interrupted every speaker, and the people stirred uneasily in their seats until the candidate for Mayor appeared on the stage.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- Gen. Otis, commanding the Department of Colorado, has telegraphed Adjt. Gen. Breck as follows, touching the Indian outbreak in Colorado:

HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Oct. 27. -- The third day's trials of the National Beagle Club were run off three miles south of Hempstead to-day. Class A, for dogs and bitches fifteen inches and under, was continued from yesterday, when two heats were started. The first pair down to-day was D.F. Summer's Sailor and Joshin's Trick. They soon started a rabbit, and trailed it for over two hours, Trick doing the better work.

ATLANTA, Oct. 27. -- Gov. W.Y. Atkinson, in his annual message to the General Assembly, read in both branches of that body to-day, calls attention to a startling increase of crime, as shown by the State's prison records, and makes a series of recommendations for the suppression of lynching and the disposition of the convicts.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27. -- Mayor Harrison, accompanied by his Cabinet, a brass band, and nearly 300 broad-shouldered members of the Cook County Democracy, all wearing silk hats, left here at 10 o'clock to-day for a three days' stumping tour of Greater New York.

TOLEDO, Oct. 27. -- William J. Bryan came into Ohio to-day to give a finishing touch to the campaign for the Democratic ticket. He is traveling in a private car. He began work at the little town of Montpelier. He had a good-sized audience and devoted his speech to the free-silver issue and an attack on Senator Hanna.

The Rev. Dr. Edward McGlynn, whose advocacy of the principles of Henry George eleven years ago led to some extent to his breach with the Roman Catholic Church, was one of the principal visitors to Mr. George's headquarters in the Union Square Hotel yesterday. Dr. McGlynn said he was still a supporter of Mr. George, but would not appear on the platform in this campaign.

COLD SPRING, N.Y., Oct. 27. -- Coroner W.T. Wood and a jury of twelve, with John P. Donohue as Foreman, began an inquest this evening on the dead killed in the Wreck of State Express No. 46 near Garrison's on Sunday.

If the "poor" owners of horses on the Metropolitan circuit, who petitioned the Westchester Racing Association for extra days, in order that they might have a better opportunity of earning Winter oats for their horses, went to Morris Park yesterday with this same object in view, they left last night sorely disappointed.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27. -- The American Public Health Association, in its convention to-day, adopted a resolution directing the appointment, in accordance with the recommendations of President Horlbeck, in his annual address, of a committee of five to investigate the origin of yellow fever.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- The Spanish Minister, Senor Dupuy de Lome, consented, for the first time, to-day to speak concerning the policy of autonomy which the Spanish Government proposes to apply to Cuba. This has been referred to in general terms since the advent of the Sagasta Ministry, but there has been a lack of authentic details.

LONDON, Oct. 27. -- The race for the Cambridgeshire Stakes, at the Newmarket Houghton meeting to-day, was won by Sir W. Ingram's Comfrey. James R. Keene's St. Cloud II. was second and the Lorillard-Beresford Stable's Sandia was third.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 27. -- G.L. Cadwalader, the Yale left guard who was injured in Monday's regular practice, and whose injury has puzzled the medical authorities of this city since then, had a careful examination this morning, and the surgeons agreed that he had sustained a fracture of the right collar bone near its juncture with the breast.

The Herald yesterday published a very important dispatch from Madrid, being the report of an interview with Senor MORET Y PRENDERGAST, the Minister for the Colonies. It was an explanation, much more detailed than has hitherto been vouchsafed of the plan of autonomy prepared by the Spanish Cabinet.
The battle for honest self-government in Greater New York is one of the most inspiring this generation has known. In some respects it is distinctly the most noble.

PRINCETON, Oct. 27. -- The Princeton Golf Club played the qualifying round, medal play, this afternoon on the club links over the new nine-hole course. The links lately have been much improved, new bunkers having been made and holes and bushes which obstructed the course removed. A good deal of attention has been paid to the putting greens also. The course now is in good shape.

Mr. William C. Herron, Western representative of the iron firm of Rogers, Brown Co., is at present in this city. In his opinion iron trade conditions are exceedingly favorable, and he looks for a prosperous year in that branch of industry. To a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES Mr. Herron said yesterday:

The report that Senator Platt and Richard Croker have made a deal, the terms of which are alleged to be that Judge Van Wyck is to receive sufficient Republican support to elect him Mayor against Seth Low in return for Democratic support of Republican Assembly candidates, is generally credited by independent voters.
In one inadvertent expression The Sun has told the truth and given away the nature of the operation in which it has been induced to assist.

Although enriched many times before by the same generous benefactor, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has once more profited by a princely gift from the hands of Henry G. Marquand. It is a number of antique bronzes, the value of which can only be roughly estimated, although Gen. Di Cesnola, the Director of the museum, has been offered 28,000 for one piece.

ALBANY, Oct. 27. -- Papers of incorporation of the Fine Arts Federation of New York were filed with the Secretary of State to-day. The principal office will be in New York City. The federation proposes to insure united action by the art societies of New York in all matters affecting their common interests.

Tammany Hall is straining every muscle to make the ratification meeting to-night a success. It was said around the Wigwam yesterday that much depended on this meeting and the showing made there. Tammany has put forth its most famous orators, and drafts have been made on other sections of the country for speakers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- Attorney General McKenna to-day fully confirmed the statements heretofore made as to the recent offer of the Reorganization Committee and its acceptance by the Government, by which the payment of the full amount of the Government's claim against the main line of the Union Pacific Railroad, principal and interest, is guaranteed.

ALBANY. Oct. 27. -- The Judge Advocate General has recommended, and the recommendation has been approved that no courts martial he ordered on the charges brought by Second Lieut. George C. Butcher, Company F. Forty-seventh Regiment, against Capt. M.J. Colligan and Private H.A. Wellington of the same company.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27. -- The sixty-third semi-annual convention of the New England Cotton Manufacturers' Association began this morning in the Philadelphia Textile School. The sessions will continue for two days, and will be largely devoted to a discussion of technical papers and an inspection of textile plants and other industries.

The Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott of Plymouth Church made his first appearance on the stump last night at a Low mass meeting in the Brooklyn Atheneum, on Atlantic Avenue, near Clinton Street. The Atheneum was crowded, but a number of George sympathizers and a few Tammany men were in the hall.

An authoritative declaration of the meaning of the law and an instruction to the Inspectors of Election throughout the city are needed to insure a uniform interpretation of two conflicting provisions of the election law.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- The event of the day at the State Department was the receipt of the long-expected cablegram from United States Minister Woodford, at Madrid, transmitting the answer of the Spanish Government to his representations in the interest of peace in Cuba. This message began to come in installments at 2 o'clock last night, and it was nearly noon to-day before it was all in hand at the State Department.
SETH LOW is speaking four or five times a night, not only in big meetings, but in small, among the homes of the poor, in every part of Greater New York. HENRY GEORCE is doing likewise.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- J.E. Jones was appointed to-day Postmaster at Holland Patent, N.Y., a fourth-class office.

RICHMOND, England, Oct. 27. -- The Duchess of Teck, cousin of Queen Victoria, sister of the Duke of Cambridge and mother-in-law of the Duke of York, died at the White Lodge here at 3 o'clock this morning.

BLOOMSBURG, Penn., Oct. 27. -- The Wintersteen dynamite conspiracy case came to a sudden termination to-day, when it was announced that the trial had been continued indefinitely, and the jury discharged. The general opinion is that the case will never be recalled. It is stated that the continuance was brought about by an agreement of counsel.

ST. PAUL, Oct. 27. -- A special from the Lerov Lake Reservation, in Northern Minnesota, says: Information by special messenger has just reached the reservation that a fight occurred yesterday between two Indians and a Game Warden, in which all three were killed, also one Indian woman.
Frank Dietz has been engaged as advance representative for Mme. Nordica whose tour will begin in Milwaukee Nov. 9.

There is one aspect of the political situation that appears to have been generally overlooked. In former contests the respectable voters of our city have always had presented to them a choice of evils. They could only deal a blow to one of the machines by giving aid and support to the other.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27. -- There was a large audience of Congregational ministers and laymen present, at the second day's session of the inquiry into the charges against the Rev. Dr. C.O. Brown, made by the Bay District Conference. Dr. Brown, accompanied by his wife and son, came early to the church.

The remarkable statement was made yesterday at Citizens' Union headquarters that no further financial help was needed; that the managers of Mr. Low's campaign had all the money necessary to meet the legitimate expenses of the campaign. The Union leaders regard this situation as significant of the sentiment for Mr. Low and nonpartisanship.

A remarkable series of coincidences connects Fritz Meyer, who shot and killed Policeman Smith in the Church of the Most Holy Redeemer, in this city, yesterday morning, with the murder of George Stelz, the old assistant sexton of the Church of the Most Holy Trinity, in the church building, Montrose Avenue, Brooklyn, on the night of Aug. 29.

JAMAICA, L.I., Oct. 27. -- The charges made by Controller Fitch of New York that his experts found many irregularities in the accounts of the town of Jamaica, while examining them, were to-day denied by the officials of Jamaica. They say that the Controller made the charges for political effect.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Oct. 27. -- The matter of the final accounting of the late Austin Corbin, President of the Long Island Railroad Company, occupied the attention of Surrogate Petty here this afternoon. There were a number of objections to the report of the executors, and it is probable that there will be a bitter fight in the courts before the matter is settled.
The trial of Gen. Mora, de Requesens, and Houseman, charged with counterfeiting notes of the Bank of Costa Rica, was continued yesterday.

Expressions of confidence in early improvement of security market values come from representative and conservative financiers of every section of the country. Men standing at the head of large financial institutions, and by reason of their positions closely in touch with financial conditions, are generally assured of continued improvement, not only in the business of the country, but in investment security values.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 28. -- Judge Judson Harmon, who was Attorney General under the last Administration, to-day gave out the following statement regarding the proposed sale of the Union Pacific Railway:

HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Oct. 28. -- The trials of the National Beagle Club were continued to-day on the Longman and Heilman farms, three miles south of Hempstead. The finish of Class A, which has been three days in running off, was accomplished. H.S. Joslin's Trick and D.F. Summers's Belie S. were again put down for a final heat to decide for first prize.

The New Jersey State Board of Riparian Commissioners met in the Fuller Building, Jersey City, yesterday, to hear all persons who might wish to file objections to the proposed extension of the pier line of Jersey City, Hoboken, Weehawken, Bull's Ferry, and Shady Side, according to the plan prepared by the New York Harbor Line Board and approved by Secretary of War Alger.

From all sections of the Greater New York assurances have reached the headquarters of the Citizens' Union that the sentiment for Seth Low is growing hourly. The leaders are no longer considering the chances of his election, but are figuring out what will be his plurality over the lealer of the two organization candidates.

Mayor Strong and the Commissioners of Charities formally opened eight new buildings connected with the Almshouse on Blackwell's Island yesterday afternoon. The ceremonies were conducted in the new central dining room. A large number of persons were present.

The announcement that the Rev. Father Thomas J. Ducey would deliver an address on "Greater New York and Bosses" in the interest of Henry George drew between four and five thousand persons to Cooper Union last night. The doors were thrown open to the public at 7:30 o'clock, and by 8 o'clock there was not an empty seat in the hall.

VIENNA, Oct. 29. -- 1 A.M. -- The Reichsrath has had another stormy night session. The leaders of the German parties protested against the policy, adopted on the suggestion of Dr. Kramarez, the Acting President, of discussing motions for the impeachment of the Ministry at the morning sittings and of devoting the evenings to the bill for the extension of the compromise with Hungary for a year.

Such a week in politics as the week now closing has never been seen before in New York. The oldest politicians cannot recall such a rush of voters toward one candidate, such a general and precipitate movement to get over to the winning side.

In the year following the disbandment of the San Francisco Vigilance Committee of 1856 there was organized a "People's Party" to nominate and elect a Mayor and other officials for the government of the city, independent of State or National politics.

NEWPORT, Oct. 28. -- Robert Goelet's new steam yacht Nahma, Capt. W.E. Churchill, arrived here at 4 o'clock this afternoon from Scotland on her maiden trip. The yacht left Gourock on Monday, Oct. 18. Capt. Churchill says he encountered nasty weather and head seas, but the vessel behaved splendidly and stood the shaking up well.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 28. -- Golfers from fifteen clubs assembled on the links of the Essex County Country Club to-day to play for the half-dozen or so silver prizes offered by the club for the victors in its first open tournament. The golf course is a very sporty one, the turf very good, and the greens the same.

GARRISON'S, N.Y., Oct. 28. -- The theory advanced by some of the railroad people that the embankment of the New York Central Railroad, at the point where the State Express was thrown into the river on Sunday, was blown out with dynamite by train wreckers is given little or no credence by the people of the surrounding country.

The last session of the Fall conventions called by the New York Board of Trade and Transportation was held yesterday at the offices of the board, 203 Broadway. It was expected that another session would be held to-day to discuss "A Ship Canal from the Lakes to the Sea," but James J. Hill, President of the Great Northern Railway, who was to read a paper, telegraphed yesterday he would not have time to do so.

As the close of the campaign draws near in Ohio both parties are making the most desperate exertions. It is generally conceded by the Democrats that the Republicans will carry their candidate for Governor, but the Legislature, which decides the Senatorship, is in some doubt and claimed by both parties.

As Mayor Harrison (supporter of Bryan in the last election) and a large delegation from Chicago purpose to take a hand in the election of a Mayor in New York and to put Van Wyck and Tammany in power if possible, an extract from Jefferson on local government would seem to be timely, as follows:

According to witnesses of the event Charles T. Earl, an amateur member of the Kings County Wheelmen, yesterday rode a straightaway mile in 1:22 1-5, the fastest time ever recorded for the distance in this country or in Europe. William Martin, an American, now racing in Australia, is said recently to have made the straightaway in 1:19 3-5, but this record has not been authenticated.

LONDON, Oct. 29. -- Long cable messages have been sent to United States Attorney General McKenna in the matter of the Union Pacific Railway sale on behalf of the Coates syndicate, making offers meeting objections raised against previous offers made by the syndicate.

Two hundred and forty-four members of the Cook County Democracy and Democratic Marching Club, headed by Mayor Carter Harrison and a band eighty strong in Hussar uniform and accompanied by eleven Chicago journalists, came here yesterday afternoon to help capture this town for Tammany Hall, and got lost in the Grand Central Station, in Forty-second Street.

HAVANA, Oct. 28. -- Gen. Weyler will leave Havana to-morrow on the Montserrat. He will be accompanied only by his general staff officers and aides-de-camp. There will be no other passengers on the steamer.
Dr. Rainsford's story at yesterday's meeting has been incompletely reported:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- From a reliable source it is learned that the conference between Russia, Japan, and the United States, now proceeding here, in reference to sealing in the Bering Sea and the North Pacific, has advanced to an important stage, and that a proposition has been reduced to writing which, if accepted, will bring about a complete change in the sealing question.

The statement has been made publicly, and not as yet denied, that the Chairman of the Republican City Campaign Committee has promised to promote the passage of bills providing increase of salary or establishing pension funds for letter carriers, firemen, and policemen, in return for the support these public employes may give the Republican candidate for the Mayoralty.

There was a meeting last evening in the interest of good government and of the candidates of the Citizens' Union at the hall of the Young Women's Christian Association, 7 East Fifteenth Street. The hall seats about 650, but only half the seats were occupied by young women and their husbands, fathers, or brothers.

The persistent but unsuccessful efforts of ex-Bridge Commissioner Abraham Schwab to swing a Van Wyck banner in Leonard Street at some point between West Broadway and Broadway has been the subject of comment in that neighborhood this week. Mr. Schwab has made three different attempts to publish his sentiments in that way, but somehow or other he has met with defeat.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- Adjt. Gen. Breck has received the following report from Gen. Otis, commanding the Department of Colorado, as to the Indian troubles there:

The Ulster County bar some time ago set a wholesome example by adopting resolutions of compliment and congratulation upon the nomination of Judge ALTON B. PARKER for the Chief Judgeship of the Court of Appeals. Judge PARKER began the practice of the law in Kingston in 1873.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28. -- Dr. Jose Congosto, who for a number of years has been Spanish Consul in Philadelphia, and who was recently appointed Secretary General of Cuba, will sail for Havana on the steamer Mexico, which leaves New York on Saturday. Dr. Congosto states that the plan of autonomy proposed by Spain for Cuba will result in the termination of the war in a short time.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- Secretary of State John Sherman has written a letter to the editor of The Cincinnati Volksblatt giving his views on the political campaign in Ohio. He says that it is a retrial of the issues of 1896, and argues at length in favor of a protective tariff and against the free coinage of silver.

Two small failures were reported down town yesterday, those of Read, Parsons Co., a Stock Exchange firm, with offices in the Edison Building, and J.R. McKee, Jr., of the Consolidated Stock and Petroleum Exchange, doing business as McKee Cloud, at 60 Broadway. Read, Parsons Co. have not been active in business since Aug. 9, when Mr. Read committed suicide.
Frederick Zittel has sold for Michael Brennan to E.A. Solomon, for $42,000, the four-story brick and stone dwelling, 9 West Seventieth Street, 20 by 60 by 100.

Gen. Tracy closed his campaigning in Brooklyn last evening by addressing three meetings in the Eastern District and winding up at the Clermont Avenue Rink, where a crowd of some 4,000 or more people awaited his coming.

The crowd that Tammany Hall got together last night to greet Mayor Carter H. Harrison and his "244 stalwart organization Democrats" of Chicago was the largest political gathering yet seen in the municipal campaign. Its first wave, as it flooded into East Fourteenth Street, filled the space from curb to curb, between Union Square and Third Avenue.

PRINCETON, Oct. 28. -- Mrs. Grover Cleveland, wife of the ex-President, gave birth to a boy weighing twelve pounds to-day. Both mother and son are reported doing well. Mr. Cleveland was overjoyed. He had desired a boy, and his first three children were girls.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 28. -- John Burns of 107 Condit Street was the innocent victim of an assault by the irate parents of a seventeen-year-old girl to-day on Broad Street, in front of the Prudential Building. Burns, who is nineteen years old, was loitering at the door of the building, when the girl asked him to direct her to United States Commissioner Whitehead's office.

That is, upon the whole, a wise will which the late GEORGE M. PULLMAN made. His twin sons had disappointed him. They had not, it seems, addicted themselves to business or learning or any respectable form of human activity, but solely to such pleasures as Chicago affords.

TOLEDO, Oct. 28. -- The long list of forgeries committed by Prof. Martin Fried-berg, the suicide, is growing at a rapid rate. It already has been learned that the professor forged the names of nearly 100 persons, and almost every hour develops more of the man's duplicity.
The Treasurer of the Citizens' Union makes the noteworthy announcement that he has money enough.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28. -- In the Probate Court to-day, at a hearing in the contest over the estate of the late Allen Gregory, Mrs. Lillie D. Gregory, a niece by marriage of the dead cattle dealer, testified that she was the person who performed the marriage ceremony which, it is alleged, made Allen Gregory and Martha Clybourn man and wife.

From the beginning THE TIMES has insisted that the Citizens' Union movement was directed as much against PLATT as against Tammany. To succeed it must smash both machines. It could not accept one as an ally against the other.

John Brooks Leavitt charged openly last night, in a speech before nearly 2,000 persons, at Long Acre Square, on Broadway, that Senator Thomas C. Platt had laid himself liable to an indictment under the Penal Code for having demanded of the New York Life Insurance Company the sum of $30,000, part of which the company is said to have paid in order to prevent hostile legislation against itself.

What precisely is the mission of the Mayor of Chicago and his praetorian guard in New York remains to be fully disclosed. On the surface it appears to be an "interchange of civilities." Many Tammany delegations at many National Conventions have burst upon Chicago and tramped the slime of her streets, to the blare of a brass band, on their way to the hotel where their headquarters were established.
Few stocks changed yesterday more than fractionally, transactions being practically confined to professional trading. The outside public showed no apparent interest in the course of business.

OLYMPIA, Washington, Oct. 28. -- Gov. Rogers to-day sent President McKinley a copy of an editorialy article entitled, "Bayonets Behind Monopoly," on the operations of P.B. Weare, in the proposed establishment of a military reservation at St. Michael, Alaska, which would have the effect of barring out citizens of this State who might wish to engage in business there.

Fritz Meyer, who shot and killed Policeman Frederick Smith of the Fifth Street Station, in the Roman Catholic Church of the Most Holy Redeemer, on East Third Street, early on Wednesday morning, was indicted yesterday for murder in the first degree, and will be placed on trial before Justice Fursman, in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court, next Monday.

LANCASTER, Penn., Oct. 28. -- The mangled body of Miss Annie Spence, a pretty young woman of this city, which was found beside the tracks of the Pennsylvania Railroad, have been identified fully. Miss Spence left this city on Oct. 2 to visit her home at York. From there she went to Baltimore. Most of her travel was made by freight trains.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28. -- The American Public Health Association Convention to-day adopted a resolution indorsing the action of churches in adopting the use of individual cups or chalices in administering the communion wine, and the association recommended the use of individual cups wherever communion cups are now in use.

Will you grant the prayer of one who has read your valuable paper got many years? What is the legend running with the feeding of the pigeons on St. Mark's plaza, Venice, at a certain hour of the day? I ask in behalf of my daughter.

In this and following pages THE REVIEW OF BOOKS AND ART presents to-day a series of interviews with the prominent book and art dealers of the country, setting forth their views of the revival of business in their lines. An effort has been made to secure not only a representative, but an exhaustive, list, in order that a wide survey might be secured and at the same time opinions independent of each other.

The Rev. Dr. Charles A. Berry, pastor of the Queen Street Congregational Church, Wolverhampton, England, is coming to this country for a much larger purpose than the preaching of the two Beecher memorial sermons in Plymouth Church on Nov. 7. He is Chairman of the Congregational Union of England, the greatest ecclesiastical honor among Non-conformists, and head champion of the unity movement which has accomplished so much of late.

Justice Gaynor of Brooklyn, who is a Summer resident of Great Barrington, discovered a few weeks ago that the local library had no copy of the Bible. Accordingly, he presented a copy, with this inscription: "I have visited many libraries which lacked many books, hut only one library which lacked The Book, and to that one I send this."

The sixty-one sections of the city government of Chicago and their 193 friends and allies, who have come here to help New York elect the Tammany ticket, distributed themselves variously after the ratification meeting at Tammany Hall on Thursday night.

It was charged on Thursday by Charles Stewart Smith, Vice President of the Citizens' Union, that Senator Platt and Richard Croker had made a deal whereby the Republicans were to support the Democratic Mayoralty ticket in return for support of the Platt State ticket. Such reports were also current gossip in centres where politicians congregate.

In the article entitled "Two Brothers Estranged" (Cardinal Newman and Francis W. Newman) in last Saturday's Review of Books and Art a reference is made in the last paragraph but one to "one of the most touching and brilliant passages in our language by a great English novelist, which was inspired by the story of the Newmans."

A recent English writer on language notes that in his own country "awful jolly" has replaced the "vastly fine" of the last century, but had he been an American he would long ago have lamented that "fine," coming by way of the prize-ring, had returned to favor in the United States and with "perfectly" prefixed had driven "splendid," "elegant," "lovely" and "real nice" into the background.

Richard Watson Gilder made his appearance as an outdoor speaker on the east side last night. He spoke at Mulberry Bend Park and Corlears Hook, and at each place vigorously denounced Van Wyck as "a mask, not a man," and paid a high personal tribute to Henry George.

At a London auction house were recently sold over 20,000 pantomime and burlesque dresses and other theatrical properties which have been in use up to a recent period at Drury Lane Theatre. The properties were selected by the late Sir Augustus Harris, and consisted of principals' and other dresses for various well-known operas, pantomimes, and dramas.

LONDON, Oct. 29. -- The newspapers today are devoting much attention to the death of Henry George, the candidate of the Jeffersonian Democracy for the office of Mayor of Greater New York, publishing long sketches of his career and philosophical and economical theories.

In their public utterances yesterday the Republican leaders expressed the opinion that the death of Henry George would not impair the chances of Gen. Tracy's success. Privately, however, it was the expressed belief of not a few that Seth Low and Judge Van Wyck would be the beneficiaries of the lapse of the George movement should that be the result of the death of the leader of the Jeffersonian Democracy.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 29. -- James A. Tyng continued his winning golf to-day on the links of the Essex County Country Club. He defeated two able men, and so won the right to be one of two competitors in the final round for the big trophy of the tournament, the silver cup offered by the Essex County Club. His opponent in the closing match to-morrow morning will be F.A. Dallett of the home club.

Is BOURKE COCKRAN more respectably employed tramping the tribune for PLATT'S sham candidate than when in the Chicago Convention of 1892 he postponed for one hour the inevitable nomination of GROVER CLEVELAND by his futile Tammany oratory?
The duty of the hour must at this late period of the campaign appear plainly before JACOB WORTH.

Seven Wagner coaches of unusual beauty of design and richness of finish were inspected by a large number of persons in the annex of the Grand Central Station yesterday. These cars constitute a portion of the equipment of the Lake Shore limited, which will run daily between New York and Chicago on a twenty-four-Hour schedule.
LITTLE ROCK, Oct. 29. -- Ex-Attorney General A.H. Garland, who for several weeks has been under a physician's care in this city, has been removed to Washington for treatment in a hospital there.

" Aaron in the Wild Woods" should be read to little ones, and if you have an imaginative child you should watch its influence on him or her for there might be some who would cry and sob over the story, so plaintive is it. Little Crochet, Addison Abercrombie's son, is paralyzed from the waist down and only moves on crutches.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 29. -- There was a meeting last night of the stockholders of the Elmwood Cotton Mill, the first negro cotton mill in the country, for the purpose of electing Directors. There was one white man present, W.S. Monteith, the originator of the scheme.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29. -- The action of the Bay Conference of San Francisco suspending the Rev. Dr. C.O. Brown for unministerial conduct, was sustained to-day by the Mutual Council of the Congregational Church, which reviewed the case. The finding, however, vindicates Dr. Brown in respect to the original serious charge brought against him.

GARRISON'S, N.Y., Oct. 29. -- In spite of public opinion to the contrary, the officials of the New York Central Railroad are as positive as ever in their theory that train wreckers were responsible for the fatal accident near Garrison's last Sunday. Chief Detective Humphrey said to-night that the more the case is investigated the stronger become the indications that the train was wrecked.

At a sale last week in Boston of books from the libraries of George B. Chase and the late John P. Dale, bookbinder, of Boston, by C.F. Libbie Co., were rare Americana, town histories, and genealogies, extra illustrated books, and large paper copies. Some of the books and prices were these:

TUXEDO, Oct. 29. -- The annual Autumn dance, which is looked upon as the closing event of the season at this resort, took place to-night. Every room in the clubhouse and annexes had been engaged several days in advance, and every one of the many houses in the park entertained a number of guests. The afternoon trains from New York brought a large accession to the hundreds already assembled here.

Henry George came of old Pennsylvania stock and was born in Philadelphia on Sept. 2, 1839. His father, R.S.H. George, was a publisher of Protestant Episcopal Church books, and Henry's early associations were with clergymen and members of that particular denomination. He was the oldest of eight children, and when but little more than an infant he began his studies in a private school.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Oct 29. -- Mr. and Mrs. O.H.P. Robinson of Bellport celebrated the sixty-fourth anniversary of their wedding last night at the old homestead. Mr. Robinson is eighty-six years of age. His wife is three years younger. Mr. Robinson is the inventor of the ball-bearing principle now so extensively used and made familiar by its application to bicycle bearings.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- President McKinley to-day issued his first Thanksgiving Day proclamation, as follows:

Rightly seen, the women of our National youth were extremely interesting spectacles. Interesting because they are so distinctively our own, of course, and also because their surroundings and the circumstances of their lives called into play all the individuality that was in them.

TACOMA, Washington, Oct. 29. -- New York men have organized a company which is intended to rival the Alaska Commercial and North American Transportation and Trading Companies in their operations in the Alaskan gold fields, according to letters received from A.C. Sickels, now in New York.

Sir Charles Gavan Duffy in The Contemporary Review writes most pleasantly of his reminiscences and tells of a visit paid to Disraeli some time in 1855. The object of Sir Charles's visit was a political one. It was to sound Disraeli as to the return of Smith O'Brien, and some diplomacy was necessary.

At the Citizens' Union meeting in Webster Hall, on East Eleventh Street, last night, Seth Low, Charles S. Fairchild, and Joseph H. Choate referred in their speeches to the death of Henry George, all of them expressing for him admiration and respect, and Mr. Choate called upon the followers of the dead leader to continue their fight against bossism under Low's banner.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29. -- Efforts were being made to-day by the friends of the late Henry George in Chicago to get his son, over his signature, to issue an address, urging all the supporters of his father in the New York Mayoralty campaign to use their votes and influence in behalf of Seth Low, the Citizens' Union candidate.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- Secretary Wilson to-day presented his report to the President, reviewing the operations of the Department of Agriculture for the past year. The most important recommendation made by him is one that agents for the department should be stationed at each of our important American embassies for the collection of information of interest to our American farmers.

Landslides, like the law, take small account of minor matters, but they have a way of producing incidental results that surprise everybody. If the Low landslide in the great city affects also the interior counties, there may be an overturn in the Assembly.

BUFFALO, Oct. 29. -- Miss Frances E. Willard, President of the National Woman's Christian Temperance Union, called the twenty-fourth annual convention of the organization to order in Music Hall this morning. Miss Willard said that the "Crusade Bible," which was used last week at the World's Woman's Christian Temperance Union Convention at Toronto, was held by the customs officials, and for the first time she was unable to read the crusade psalm from it.

William A. White Sons have sold for Jean J. and Henrietta T. Renbell of Paris, to the estate of William C. Rhinelander, the four-story building, with stores and lofts, 479 Broadway, extending through to 52 Mercer Street, 26 by 200. The buyers already own 477, similar and adjoining, and it is understood that upon the expiration of existing leases the entire plot will be improved by the erection of a modern mercantile building.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 29. -- The Rev. Dr. George Edward Martin, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church in this city, has received a call to the pastorate of the North Minster Church of Philadelphia.

A literary and art periodical which should devote itself to the news of literature and art -- which should review books and exhibitions promptly, and print other news of books and art with completeness and alertness -- has long been needed. THE NEW YORK TIMES, in its REVIEW OF BOOKS AND ART, has aimed during the past year to supply this need, and is amply convinced that its venture has found its field.

VIENNA, Oct. 29. -- Herr Lecker, at 6:30 o'clock this morning, was still delivering the speech which, after a battle of words with Herr Wolff, the German Liberal leader, and uproarious scenes in the Reichsrath, he was able to resume at 10:50 o'clock last night.

Of delightful quality is "My Studio Neighbors,'' by the late William Hamilton Gibson, who to the most acute eye of the naturalist added both artistic and literary talents. The neighbors are birds, insects, and flowers. There are moths, mice, bees, wasps who come to see him, and they all are made welcome.

Jacob Worth has come out for Seth Low. The public announcement of his action was made at a number of Citizens' Union meetings held in Brooklyn last evening, and was everywhere received with tumultuous applause and cheering. The greatest demonstration was made at a Low meeting under the auspices of the Brooklyn Young Republican Club, in the Criterion Theatre.
The name of Sir John Gilbert is intimately associated with modern book illustration, and his death this month recalls many memories.

Frederick and Charles, which seems not to be half so well known as it deserves to be. Though over-shadowed by the fame of Alfred Tennyson, the poems of the others have been known and loved for a generation or more.

Henry George, the candidate of the Democracy of Thomas Jefferson for Mayor of the Greater New York, writer and philosopher, deal yesterday morning at 4:50 o'clock of apoplexy in the Union Square Hotel.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 29. -- The Alaska Commercial Company's steamer Excelsior, Capt. Higgins, has arrived here, fourteen days from St. Michael and eight and one-half days from Unalaska, the only intermediate port at which she stopped. She brought 8,000 ounces of gold, all belonging to the Alaska Commercial Company. No miners came down on her.

HAVANA, Oct. 29. -- Lieut. Gen. Weyler embarked on the steamer Montserrat shortly after 4 o'clock this afternoon, but, under instructions from Madrid, the vessel will not sail until after the arrival of Marshal Blanco, the new Governor General of Cuba.

A decision of peculiar interest and significance was handed down, with several other decisions, by the Board of United States General Appraisers yesterday relative to the admission into this country of replicas of noted works of art free of duty. This subject has received considerable attention from the Treasury Department.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 30. -- The University of Virginia and the University of Georgia football teams met at Brisbine Park this afternoon, in the hardest-fought game ever seen on a Southern field. The game was "rough and tumble" from the very beginning, and to-night Von Gammon of Rome, Ga., the crack fullback of the Georgia team, lies on a cot in the Grady Hospital at the point of death.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- Gen. Miles, in his capacity of Acting Secretary of War, has received from Gen. Brooke, commanding the Department of Missouri, the report of the court of inquiry which he appointed. by direction of Secretary Alger, to investigate the charges made against Capt. Lovering of the Fourth Infantry of ill treating Private Hammond.

MR. BROOKS'S volume should be accepted as a sign of the times in America. Few topics in late years have risen more rapidly in public attention than early American history. Interest in the patriotic societies and devotion to study of family history have created an awakening in this direction such as neither the schools nor Fourth of July celebrations ever could have done.

Justice Truax of the Supreme Court yesterday granted a writ of prohibition, returnable Nov. 5, restraining the Police Commissioners from placing Patrolman Francis T. Walters of the East Thirty-fifth Street Station on trial next Monday on the charge of misconduct in connection with Capt. Sheehan at the Forty-seventh Street Station, in attempting to obtain evidence against policy dealers.

Elaborate tables of vital statistics of Massachusetts from the twenty-eighth annual report of the State Board of Health give a number of interesting facts bearing on the Intermittent discussion regarding the possible extinction of the New England stock because of the predonderance of females and the failure of births to compensate for deaths.

November is sole owner of the meteors that bear its name, and holds the honor of being the month when the earth makes her way through the meteor zone, sets on fire the cosmic atoms that impinge against her atmosphere, and transforms them into stars with shining trains that glow and disappear in the November sky.

TOM L. JOHNSON, a chief executive of the Henry George campaign, is perhaps the most interesting figure in our politics to-day. An acquaintance the other day characterized him as "The Great American Paradox." "Do as I say, not as I do," appears to sum up the man's whole life.

Representative labor men say that Seth Low's record as an arbitrator in labor difficulties has always been regarded by men of their class as perfectly clean. As arbitrators in labor difficulties, Mr. Low and Bishop Potter are equally honored by workingmen of all creeds. Those decisions were made at a time when Mr. Low had no expectation of running for any political office whatever.

One of the greatest of the services which the canvass of HENRY GEORGE has rendered to this community has been the detachment by it from the "brute vote" of Tammany Hall of thousands of voters who could not have been detached by any other agency. How rooted and inveterate is party spirit the present canvass has given us some astonishing proofs, even among educated men.

The "grand Tracy mass meeting" announced for last evening, and held in Carnegie Music Hall, was distinctly a Republican demonstration. The meeting was imposing in point of numbers, and its enthusiasm knew no bounds. The main floor had no empty seat, and many stood; the boxes all seemed to be occupied, and the galleries were filled, if not actually crowded.

Conductors and ticket choppers are creatures of patient and long-suffering endurance. They are paid for possessing these virtues; they can wait.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30. -- Attorney General McKenna said to-day that he had no official information as to the truth of the report that the Sage syndicate would seek to secure an order restraining the sale of the Union Pacific Railroad. He admitted that he had heard the rumor, but added that if founded upon fact the department would not necessarily be informed concerning it.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 30. -- One of the most bitter and at the same time significant political contests ever fought in Kentucky will be decided next Tuesday. The contest is not of importance so far as the offices axe concerned, but on its result will depend in great measure the future political alignments in the State, and on it may depend the existence of one or more parties.

No citizen of New York is more worthy of the respect of New Yorkers than Mr. Henry George. He has adopted some ideas about taxation and other questions which many people do not believe in; but as a man and as a citizen he is sans peur et sans reproche. As a man his integrity is incorruptible; an a citizen he is absolutely devoted to the public welfare.

No strong interest has anywhere appeared to be even casually attentive to the course of quotations.

THE Astoria Hotel, when completed, will have the largest isolated electric-light plant in existence. BERLIN, Oct. 30. -- Emperor William will hold his great annual St. Hubertus chase next Wednesday in the Grunewald, near Berlin. The guests will be more brilliant and numerous than usual.

Walter Webb of the New York Central Railroad last Friday as the sequel of a temporary dynamite scare near Little Falls, on the main line of the road.
LONDON, Oct. 30. -- A special dispatch from Madrid announces that Gen. Bon, a prominent Carlist, has been arrested at Barcelona, on arriving there from France.
