Sheehan declared yesterday afternoon, after a meeting of the Tammany Hall Committee on Organization, at which the district leaders from the thirty-five Assembly districts and the annexed district gave their figures, that Van Wyck's plurality in the Boroughs of Manhattan and the Bronx would be at least 65,000.

I rejoice to say that I have the opportunity afforded me to read every day a clean, newsy, and absolutely accurate paper in THE NEW YORK TIMES. I have read it for many years, and have always admired it, but under its present management it far surpasses every paper published in the city.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30. -- After a running battle through alleys and back yards for over a mile, Sergt. Thomas Howard of the Desplaines Street Station to-night fatally wounded and captured William, alias "Skippy," Rowan, one of the most noted criminals in the country, wanted now in St. Louis for robbery anud murder.

LENOX, Mass., Oct 30. -- The twelfth annual dinner of the Lenox Club took place to-day. Twenty-six persons sat at the table, which was decorated handsomely. The repast was followed by bright speeches, with John S. Barnes as toastmaster.

Durland's Riding Academy, at Sixtieth Street and Eighth Avenue, was crowded to the doors last night in response to the invitation of the Citizen's Union Committee of the Nineteenth Assembly District. Seats had been placed as closely as possible -- far too closely for comfort -- on the tan-covered floor.

November's advent brings the Winter season near, although the members of New York society are still scattered through the various suburbs, and are lingering in quite respectable contingents at Lenox and Newport. The first events and incidents on the Winter's programme of city gayeties are scheduled, however, for the week which opens to-day, and the return of the fashionable element to town will not, from all indications, be much longer delayed.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 30. -- Harvard easily defeated Cornell on Soldiers' Field to-day, but was scored on for the first time this season. Harvard made four touchdowns and forced Cornell to make a safety, while in the first half, after gaining the ball on a mused kick. Young kicked a pretty goal from the field for Cornell.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 30. -- President McKinley and party arrived here on time at 10:45 o'clock this morning, debarking at Torrence Road, a station two miles from the terminal depot.

BERLIN, Oct. 30. -- The new German Ambassador to the United States, Dr. von Holleben, recently Prussian Minister to Wurtemberg, and formerly, from 1892 to 1893, German Minister to the United States, left Berlin on Wednesday last to spend a fortnight on his family estate previous to his departure for America on the North German Lloyd steamer Wilhelm der Grosse Nov. 9.

Elbridge S. Brooks, in his new volume, "The Century Book of the American Revolution," takes his party of boys to the scenes of the two Revolutionary battlefields that are embraced within the limits of Greater New York -- Long Island and the Harlem Heights.

PARIS, Oct. 19. -- The agitation that has recently begun again in connection with the ex-Captain, Dreyfus, condemned to perpetual detention on the charge of acting as a traitor, reveals the fact that a great number of people still believe in the ex-Captain's innocence. His wife continues her heroic efforts to make this innocence clear, and to procure her husband's release.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30. -- Jeffreys R. Brandon was before Justice Martin this morning charged with wife abandonment. Brandon was formerly President of the Parnassus Gold Mining and Milling Company, and is known as one of the ablest mechanical engineers in the city. His wife resides in Detroit, where she is said to be quite prominent.

Prof. J.W. Jenks of Cornell University lectured before the League for Political Education yesterday morning at its headquarters, 509 Fifth Avenue. His subject was "Civic Virtue," but he devoted his time to a discussion of "drift" in political life and the duty of citizens in the present local campaign.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30. -- The members of the Chicago Branch of the Single Tax League met at their rooms in the Schiller Building and passed resolutions concerning the death of Henry George. A telegram was sent to the bereaved family, and John Z. White, who is now in New York, was wired to remain there and represent the club at the funeral.

The card at Morris Park yesterday was excellent for, although there was only one fixture -- the Fordham Highweight Handicap -- there were three races for horses of all ages, and all of them handicaps. For some reason or other, the card was hacked to pieces, for in all but the two-year-old handicap and the steeplechase the fields were considerably reduced.

The National Society of New England Women has not been so busy since it was organized as it has been for the last week, and will continue to be until Nov. 30, when its dramatic historical entertainment is to be given at the Metropolitan Opera House.

LONDON, Oct. 30. -- Since that memorable if somewhat mythological episode of Count Benedetti's cup of coffee at Ems in July, 1870, there has been no international personal incident so well calculated to set two big nations by the ears as the affair between the Czar and the Grand Duke of Baden.

WEST POINT, Oct. 30. -- The cadets were a match for Yale to-day, and had it not been for a run by one of Yale's speedy backs the score would have been 6 to 0 in favor of West Point, instead of a tie. West Point played superb football, and, according to Walter Camp, "Yale's defense is a thing of the past."

Maurine Grau of the Metropolitan Opera House, New York, and Covent Garden, London, arrived from Europe on the steamer La Touraine early yesterday. Only a few friends knew of his possible arrival. Mr. Grau called a carriage and drove directly to the Glisey House, where he eluded all interviewers.

BOSTON, Oct. 30. -- Arthur D. Williams, President of the Board of Commissioners appointed by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court of New York to pass on rapid transit plans, is here to-day in an official capacity to inspect the Boston subway. Commissioner John Sabine Smith has already made his examination of the subway, and the third Commissioner, G.W. Young, is to be here this evening.

On learning of Mr. George's death he telegraphed the committee that he would not come, but advised members of the Alliance to vote the ticket without change.

From General Headquarters it is announced that the orders prescribing and authorizing the award of State decorations for long and faithful service are amended so that field musicians, including Drum Majors and principal musicians, who receive from the organizations pay for the service they render, shall, after the 1st day of October, 1897, not be entitled to claim, or eligible to receive, the State decoration referred to.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 30. -- An unusually large field of golfers turned out to-day on the links of the Essex County Country Club, to compete in the open handicap event for the handsome silver vase given by Dr Leslie D. Ward. Over seventy men started and sixty-three finished, one of the largest number that has played in any competition this season.

LONDON, Oct. 30. -- Lord Chancellor Halsbury evidently believes in the policy of the spoils belonging to the victors and that it should be the predominating influence in making appointments, for a worse piece of jobbery than the appointment of Charles John Darling, Q.C., Conservative, member of Parliament for Deptford, to the judicial bench would be hard to find.

Mme. Marcella Sembrich gave her second concert at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon. The auditorium was almost filled by an audience which was always generous with its applause, and at times enthusiastic. Mme. Sembrich's programme numbers were: "Ah, fors e lui," from Verdi's "Traviata" three lieder -- Schubert's Neugierige," Mozart's "Veilchen," and Forsters "Ich Liebe Dich" -- and a waltz song, "Voce di Primavera," written for her by Johann Strauss.

COLUMBUS, Ohio., Oct. 30. -- Ohio will elect next Tuesday a Governor, Lieutenant Governor, one Judge of the Supreme Court, Attorney General, Treasurer, Commissioner of Common Schools, one member of the State Board of Public Works, 36 Senators and 109 Representatives, and county tickets in each of the 88 counties of the State.

There is every indication that the funeral of Henry George, the ceremonies attending which will begin at 7 o'clock this morning, will be the largest civic demonstration of the kind that has been seen in this city since Abraham Lincoln's body was borne in state to the City Hall.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment at its meeting yesterday authorized an issue of $3,000 in bonds for the improvement of Paradise Park. The square is to be asphalted anew, and the horse fountain and music stand are to be repaired. Thirty-five hundred dollars was appropriated for the improvement of Hancock Park.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30. -- There is mutiny in the ranks of the University Glee and Mandolin Clubs. Last night an order was issued by the manager requiring all freshmen members to wear soft hats, while upper classmen were permitted to wear silk ones on the holiday trip. Mustaches and beards must be removed by all before Nov. 15.

Clorinda Wildairs the heroine of fiction Julia Arthur will portray at Wallack's Theatre to-morrow night, is the daughter of a hard-drinking country squire in England in the early years of the eighteenth century. Clorinda is brought up rudely, among men, and in her girlhood affects masculine attire.

Contrary to general expectation, however, only a small crowd attended the ranges, the application for cards not exceeding 200. Of these 143, aided by the favorable weather, qualified as marksmen and experts.

Seth Low addressed a meeting of the Home Rule Democracy last night at its headquarters. Lyric Hall, on Sixth Avenue, near Forty-second Street. The Home Rule Democrats, with County Clerk Henry D. Purroy at their head, seven hundred strong, extended to Mr. Low a welcome of great cordiality and followed his every sentence with cheers and cries of approval.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- To-day's yellow fever reports to Surgeon General Wyman show that the situation is better and the outlook more encouraging than for several days past. The officials of the service now believe that the worst of the epidemic has passed, and that from now on, as frost gradually makes its appearance in the affected districts, the daily number of cases will diminish.

SIMLA, Oct. 31. -- According to a dispatch from Karappa, the expected advance to Arhanga Pass was made this morning. Gen. Westmacott seized the villages covering the line of advance, and the artillery, brought into action at 8:30 o'clock, soon expelled the tribesmen from the sangars. Only slight opposition was encountered.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31. -- Metropolitan Temple was crowded at noon to-day at the memorial services for Henry George, held under the direction of the Single Tax Society. Miss McCloskey, a cousin of Henry George, sang "Flee as a Bird," which was one of Mr. George's favorite compositions. She was overcome with grief while singing and most of the audience was affected similarly.

John A. Nichols, the Brooklyn ex-Commissioner of Quarantine, a life-long Republican, and a former leader in Republican political circles, returned on Saturday from his country home. It was rumored yesterday that he had decided to abandon the organization candidate for Mayor, Gen. Tracy, and to adopt the one nominated by popular petition, the choice of the Citizens' Union.
LOWVILLE, N.J., Oct. 31. -- Jesse Irons, a resident of Lyons Falls, last night by mistake drank a quantity of coloring extract in place of cough medicine, and died two hours later.

The Brooklyn Navy Yard was crowded with visitors yesterday. More than 10,000 persons went there to see the cruiser Brooklyn and the first-class battleship Iowa. It is the first time since the Brooklyn was presented with the silver service that she has been at the yard, and the first time the Iowa has been there since she was put in commission.

The funeral procession of Henry George was started from the Grand Central Palace at a few minutes after 7 o'clock. The casket was borne out through the front door of the Palace at 7 o'clock precisely, the ushers, honorary pall bearers, and others being massed from the door to the catafalque and dividing so as to make a narrow lane.

The season for shooting deer on Long Island will open next Wednesday, and sportsmen are looking forward to that day with a great deal of pleasure. There are four days in the year when deer can be shot on Long Island, the four Wednesdays in November, and every one who can takes advantage of this to get a little sport near home.

LONDON, Oct. 31. -- Money is temporarily plentiful, and as a result the rates show a downward tendency. The sales of American securities have ceased, and it is expected London will have to settle the adverse trade balance in bullion, though large gold withdrawals are not expected.

The Republican district leaders reported yesterday at county headquarters, 1 Madison Avenue, that their respective organizations were ready for Tuesday. Chairman Quigg passed Sunday in consultation with his lieutenants and gave his final instructions with regard to the work of to-day, which will be mainly directed toward preparation for getting out the full Tracy vote.

At 10:15 o'clock last night an ambulance call was sent to the Manhattan Hospital from a drug store at Eighth Avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-third Street. On the sidewalk in front of the store was James Keane, sixty-five years old, who lives alone at the Hotel Minot, at Eighth Avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street, and who had been taken suddenly ill.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct. 31. -- The Stove sisters, three in numbers, have lived near Fostoria, and have successfully conducted a farm for twenty-five years without molestation.

Two of the new electric cars built for the Metropolitan Street Railway Company for use on the rebuilt Fourth Avenue line were tested yesterday morning. The cars were run over the road from Forty-second Street to Astor Place. A number of prominent railroad men were on the trip, which was voted a success.

HAVANA, Oct. 31. -- The Spanish cruiser Alfonso XIII., with Marshal Blanco, the new Governor General of Cuba, on board, was sighted off Havana this morning at 5:30 o'clock. At 7 o'clock the Alfonso XIII. entered the harbor, and Lieut. Gen. Weyler, the Marquis Ahumada, Admiral Navarro, and other high military and naval officers went in a special steamer to meet Capt. Gen. Blanco.

We hope the method of voting the official ballot has been explained sufficiently to bring it within the comprehension of even the most acute and gifted minds. The illiterate voter handles it well enough. It is only ex-Governors, railroad Presidents, and millionaires who get into trouble.
CHELSEA, Indian Territory, Oct. 31. -- To-day John S. Watka, the Creek Indian who shot Jonas Deer, a member of his tribe, was executed for the crime.

" The Ideal New York" was the subject of the Rev. Minot J. Savage's sermon yesterday morning in the Church of the Messiah, Park Avenue and East Thirty-fourth Street. He took as his text the third verse of the eighty-seventh Psalm: "Glorious things are spoken of thee, O city of God."
Is the editor of The Sun crazy? Really, to a person of an ordinary turn of mind, it would seem as if the editorial page of this morning's Sun had been printed in a lunatic asylum.

Very little activity is expected in Wall Street to-day. To-morrow's elections in New York and throughout the country are absorbing all attention and keeping speculators from market ventures. The London markets will be closed on account of the holiday there.

WICHITA, Kan., Oct. 31. -- Chief Charles Bluejacket of the Shawnees died last night at the town named in his honor in Indian Territory. He is mourned as the last of a notable line of chiefs and will have no successor, as the tribe will be ruled by an Executive Council. He was born in Michigan in 1816, and was a friend of Tecumseh and his brother, the Prophet, both noted among Shawnee warriors.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 31 -- Thirty-five cases of yellow fever were reported to-day, and five deaths. These figures encourage those who are fighting the fever, but it is feared the heavy rain which has fallen will have a bad effect on the patients, and will cause many new cases to be developed to-morrow. Cold weather is expected to succeed the rain.
CHICAGO, Nov. 1. -- The effects and scenery of the "Paris Doll," belonging to Vernona Jarbeau's company, are again in the hands of the Sheriff, this time on a replevin writ.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Nov. 1. -- Early last Spring an article entitled "The Waste Water Power of Ulster County" was published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Soon after the publication of that article, capitalists from Fitchburg, Mass., came to Ulster County, and after inspecting a number of its unused sources of great water power, picked out Honk's Falls on the Rondout as the site of a great dam which they determined to build.

The final competition arranged by the Trustees of the New York Public Library to secure an acceptable design for the proposed building closed at 6 o'clock last evening, when the drawings of the twelve chosen competitors were submitted to George L. Rives, Secretary of the Trustees' Committee, at 32 Nassau Street.

Golfing in the rain was apparently enjoyed yesterday at the Knollwood Country Club, near White Plains. The open tournament of the club, which is to continue three days, was begun. Thirty-one contestants started and finished the thirty-six-hole medal-play round. The best sixteen became eligible for the hole-play rounds beginning this morning, for a handsomely ornamented silver cup given by John D. Archbold, President of the club.

ALBANY, Nov. 1. -- The finishing touches are being made to the grand western staircase in the Capitol, and when the Legislature reassembles the beautiful and costly conception of Richardson and Perry will be completed, with the exception of the electroliers. At present the carvers are at work on the last bas-reliefs of former Governors of the State of New York, which adorn the walls of the well, close under the skylight.

Three prominent speakers addressed an east side Seth Low mass meeting last evening at Apollo Hall, on Clinton Street, near Broome Street -- Felix Adler, the Rev. Dr. W.S. Rainsford, and Richard Watson Glider. The hall was packed, principally by Hebrews, who cheered enthusiastically for Mr. Low. There were a few Henry George and Tammany men present.

The Campaign Committee of the Citizens Union is confident of Mr. Low's election today. Its members spent several hours yesterday in investigating the returns made by canvassers who had carefully estimated the vote in 663 of the 883 election districts in this city, and the estimates made by well-informed men of the vote in Brooklyn, and in Queens and Richmond Counties.
Tammany Hall issued its final statement of the campaign yesterday, in which it predicts success for its ticket.

MANCHESTER, England, Nov. 1. -- Lord Rosebery addressed a large meeting here this evening in connection with the centenary celebration of the Chamber of Commerce. He reviewed the history of free trade, elaborately eulogizing what he described as its "advantages to England."

The trial of Fritz Meyer, or Constantine Steiger, as he is now believed to be, for the murder of Policeman Frederick Smith of the Fifth Street Station last Thursday night in the Church of the Most Holy Redeemer was begun yesterday morning in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court. Justice Fursman of Troy presided.

We judge by the exhibitions of alarm and job type in the columns of our Croker neighbor, The Journal and our Platt neighbor, The Sun, that both Tammany and the Republicans apprehend a large transfer of Henry George votes to Mr. Low.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Oct. 20. -- The text of the report of the Royal Commission on the Sugar Industry in the West Indies has just come to hand. The conclusions at which the Commissioners have arrived are viewed with alarm and despair by the sugar planters. The Commissioners admit that the estates must be inevitably thrown up if relief in some shape or form be not forthcoming.

-- If Indian criminals have such a respect for the law and their own word of honor that, after conviction of murder, they can be trusted to go about unguarded for weeks and will report promptly at the place of execution at the appointed day and hour, why is it that the task of elevating and civilizing the tribes has proved so hard?

In the cause of charity the completed portions of the sumptuous Astoria were thrown open to the public yesterday afternoon and evening. Wealth and fashion, in radiant garb, did their part toward making the occasion one of social enjoyment as well as of substantial benefit to the charities concerned.

What should be the status in the eyes of the L.A.W. Racing Board of wheelmen engaging in century runs with women has been a question over which many have puzzled of late. An open century run in which prizes are offered for those finishing in the least time is about as plain a competition as racing around a cement cycle track.

In the absence of Commissioner Parker, the Police Board at yesterday's meeting filled the fourteen vacancies in the list of Sergeants. One of the officers promoted was Roundsman John Tracy, who was on duty in the office of Commissioner Andrews. His advancement had been opposed for a long time by Commissioner Parker, and finally the old eligible list was discarded and a new one prepared as the result of a competitive examination.

Senator WOLCOTT and Gen. PAYNE of the so-called Bimetallic Commission sailed on the Campania from Liverpool on Saturday. At the last moment Mr. WOLCOTT slipped across the Channel and spent a few hours at Paris, but the results of his visit are more likely to interest the baggage inspectors at the Cunard dock than the silver men of the United States or elsewhere.

The Democratic Party will profit in political health and morals by the defeat of Tammany to-day. During the Hill-Morton campaign for the Governorship in 1894 a Democrat very wisely remarked that a party advances by victory, not by defeat. That remark would apply to the situation in New York City if Tammany were a party instead of a faction readily detachable and in fact often detached from the Democratic Party.

It is not to be supposed that there is a single voter within the boundary of Greater New York who does not understand that the election to-day is between VAN WYCK and Low. Whoever votes for TRACY must be assumed deliberately to throw away his vote, so far as the purposes of this election are concerned.

CANTON, Ohio, Nov. 1. -- The people of Canton turned out in large numbers to welcome President McKinley upon his arrival at home this evening. He was escorted to his residence by the Canton Troop, and no sooner had he reached there than he was waited upon by the Commercial Travelers' Association and a large delegation of workingmen from Dueber Heights, most of whom are employed at the Dueber Watch Works.

On the rolling brow of Ocean Hill, that is tipped with the first beams of the morning sun and lightened by the gleam of the ocean in the distance, the body of Henry George was laid at rest in Greenwood Cemetery at noon yesterday. Simple as had been the life of him who had been regarded as the people's champion were the ceremonies at the home and at the grave.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 1. -- The most distressing effect of the yellow fever epidemic in Louisiana and adjacent States has been the paralysis of business as a result of the quarantine regulations. Only a comparatively small number of people have contracted the disease, and the death rate has not been high, but the entire population has suffered from the business and industrial depression.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 1. -- John Bell Hatcher, Ph.B., Curator of Vertebrate Paleontology of Princeton University, will sail on Nov. 6 for South America to continue his investigations into the paleontology and geology of Southern Patagonia, commenced two years ago. Mr. Hatcher will land at Punta Arenas, in the Straits of Magellan, and will work from that place northward along the eastern base of the Andes as far as the Argentine territory of Chubut.

It is seldom that the naval officers assigned to court-martial duty are disturbed by the sight of a medal of honor. While there are many brave men in the service and many heroic deeds have been performed by them, only a few have received any recognition from the Government, and fewer still a medal of honor.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- The monthly statement of the public debt shows that at the close of business on Oct. 30, the debt, less cash in the Treasury, amounted to $1,020,563,901, an increase for the month of $8,441,188. This increase is principally accounted for by a decrease in the amount of cash on hand.

Adolph Meyer, a bartender, formerly employed at Third Avenue and Seventy-first Street, last night shot and killed Kate Mergert, cook for the family of Ernest Ayrlax, at 219 East Seventy-first Street, and afterward committed suicide in his room, at 304 East Seventy-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- It is expected that a treaty or convention between the United States, Russia, and Japan will be formally signed and executed at the State Department during the present week, carrying out the proposition before the Bering Sea Conference for a suspension of pelagic sealing.

Cooper Union was crowded last night at a mass meeting held under the auspices of the German-American Democracy of Thomas Jefferson, with an audience brimful of enthusiasm. It sat for three hours listening to speakers in English, German, and German-American, and applauding vehemently at every opportunity.

BUFFALO, Nov. 1. -- The National Convention of the Women's Christian Temperance Union to-day discussed and adopted the report of Mrs. Mathilda B. Carse on the management of the Woman's Temple, in Chicago. Mrs. Carse attributed the crisis in its affairs to the financial condition of the country.

The campaign in the dry goods district was closed for the Citizens' Union yesterday by a whirlwind meeting at 196 Church Street at the noon hour. Tracy men have heretofore endeavored unsuccessfully to stamped the meetings there, and this fact brought out an enthusiastic crowd of Low men, determined to defeat any such attempt.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Oct. 14. -- It is understood that the Diet of the Greater Republic of Central America, now in session here, has refused to agree with the arguments put forward by Secretary Sherman in support of the appointment of Capt. William L. Merry of San Francisco as Minister of the United States to Nicaragua, Costa Rice, and Salvador, while partly recognizing the Diet.

In the October Review of Reviews the chief feature is a so-called "Character Sketch" of Mr. Richard Croker, the chief Tammany "boss," founded on a series of conversations which took place on an Atlantic liner that was conveying Mr. Croker home to the city over which he ruled so long. The conversations are of an extraordinary character on account of the attitude of conscious virtue assumed by Mr. Croker.

To no one did Monday's skies look more cheerless than to Antone, the aged organ grinder, long a familiar figure in the neighborhood lying between Broadway and Sixth Avenue, from Twentieth to Thirtieth Street. Where he comes from, this bent and wrinkled Antone with his toothless smile, no one knows any more than his name is known.

A business men's meeting of the Democracy of Thomas Jefferson was held at noon yesterday at 47 Liberty Street. Charles W. Dayton was announced as one of the speakers, but he sent word that he was detained. Several hundred followers of Henry George assembled in expectation of hearing Mr. Dayton, and remained to cheer the oratory of other speakers.

The question whether a man can be compelled to support his stepchildren was raised in the Chancery Court in Jersey City yesterday. The suit was brought by Ellen Gillespie against James Gillespie of West Hoboken.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- The report of the Commissioner of Internal Revenue for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1897, shows the total receipts from all sources to have been $146,619,593, a decrease, as compared with the receipts of the fiscal year 1896, of $211,022.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1. -- Special Agent Zeverly of the Interior Department, whose discovery of $90,000 worth of fraudulent Creek Indian warrants was announced last week, reached here to-day. He had a conference with Acting Secretary of the Interior Ryan and made a verbal report of his investigation.

C.R. Gregor Son have sold for David E. Oppenheimer and Joseph Hammershlag to S.W.B. Smith the plot on the north side of Seventy-ninth Street, 117.9 feet west of Columbus Avenue, 57.3 by 102.2 by 54.1 by 102.9. The property will be improved immediately by the erection of a seven-story apartment house.

An English essayist a few years ago attracted attention by a series of amusing paradoxes under this title. He affected to deplore what he pretended to establish. But, in fact, this present canvass has borne testimony to the fact that political controversy is a great deal freer from mendacity than it used to be.

DENVER, Nov. 1. -- At midnight the Colorado Midland Railway became an independent system, freed from the receivership and the control of the Federal court. The change was effected without the slightest ripple in the current of business, practically the same officers as before having control.

The Builders' League of this city has a very hitter feeling against Corporation Counsel Francis M. Scott, owing to a case in which the league claims Mr. Scott opposed its efforts to prevent the payment by the city of the salary of Michael Tully, a Building Inspector. The league claimed that Tully's salary should be withheld on the ground that he was illegally appointed.

The scenes at the George headquarters, in the Union Square Hotel, yesterday, were in marked contrast to the activity that had been seen there up to the time of Henry George's death. The leaders have not recovered from that tragic blow, and, while they still make claims of success, they have not the confident tone of a few days ago.

OMAHA, Nov. 1 -- The Union Pacific Railroad, including the buildings and the property used in the operation of the system, was sold this morning to the Reorganization Committee for the sum of $53,528,532.76. This amount does not include the Sinking Fund, in the hands of the Government, and, taking this to be $4,036,400, the amount stated in the decree for the sale of the road, the total paid for the property was $57,564,932.76.

Sorosis talked of science yesterday, and incidentally two important discoveries were made -- one that Mrs. Helmuth, Sorosis's ex-President, does not believe in ice cream soda, and the other that Sorosis is familiar with the slang of the day.

The laying of the cornerstone of the new Church of the Holy Trinity, constituting the centrepiece of the magnificent benefaction of Miss Serene Rhinelander in memory of William Rhinelander and William O. Rhinelander, took place on East Eighty-eighth Street, between First and Second Avenues, at 4 P.M. yesterday.

The regular Autumn reception and the thirty-third semi-annual exhibition of the Metropolitan Museum of Art was held last night. Owing to the inclement weather the attendance was not so large as on some former occasions, but the gathering of art lovers was representative and enthusiastic. The museum has been enriched this year by some almost invaluable treasures, which were exposed to view last night for the first time.
The death of Henry George and the consequent cancellation of bets on the Mayoralty contest resulted in a new series of odds among sporting men yesterday.
Mr. Harry Brooks, a well-known and valuable citizen of New York City, has passed through an experience which, while it may not be unusual, is none the less valuable, and is therefore given herewith.
Presenting a list of new enterprises started in various Southern States during the week just ended, The Tradesman (Chattanooga) says:

LONDON, Oct. 20. -- Yesterday, at the Imperial Institute, South Kensington, an exhibition of the Queen's Diamond Jubilee presents was opened to the public at an admission fee of 1 shilling per head, the income from the exhibition -- which will last several month -- to be devoted to the Prince of Wales's Free Hospital Fund.

In a street row over the possession of stuff to be used in rival bonfires William Shaefer, twenty-two years of age, was stabbed, probably fatally, by Harry Burger, seventeen years of age, of 403 East Nineteenth Street, last night.

The Police Commissioners and Chief Rodenbough of the Bureau of Elections were greatly exercised and vexed yesterday by a printer's error, by which in nine election districts of the Thirty-fifth Assembly District ballots were furnished on which no name for Justices of the Supreme Court was the right one, and by complaints regarding Henry George pasters.

LONDON, Nov. 2. -- In well-informed circles here it is not believed Spain has signed the contracts referred to by The Daily Chronicle to-day as having been concluded last week with an important firm of British shipbuilders, by which that country acquires some cruisers, armed with quick-firing guns, which the firm had nearly completed for another Government.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- One of the recommendations which Secretary Alger will make in his annual report will be in relation to the reorganization of military bands.
The atmosphere at the headquarters of the Jeffersonian Democracy, in the Union Square Hotel, was quiet and subdued soon after the returns began coming in last evening.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 2. -- The body of the man washed up on Sullivan's Island beach yesterday was identified to-day by Purser Martin of the steamer Iroquois as a man who, under the name of H. Johnson, sailed from New York on the Iroquois last week. He was a thirty-third-degree Mason, and his clothing and jewelry indicated that he was a person of wealth.

Mr. H. Cavendish, cousin of the Duke of Devonshire, has just returned from West Africa, where it was falsely reported recently he had been killed while on a sporting expedition. He has been seen by a Reuter's representative, to whom he told an interesting story of adventure in Somaliland and British East Africa.
LONDON, Nov. 3. -- The Times, commenting editorially on the election of Judge Robert A. Van Wyck as the first Mayor of Greater New York, says:
FRANKFORT, Ky., Nov. 2. -- One of the bloodiest election riots which ever took place in Kentucky was witnessed on the streets of this quiet little capital town between 12 and 2 o'clock this mornng.

Mr. C.Y. Turner has about completed the ceiling for the entrance hallway of the Bank of Commerce Building, at Nassau and Liberty Streets, upon which he has been at work since the completion of his remarkably successful and effective series of paintings for the broken frieze of the Fifth Avenue restaurant of the New Astoria Hotel.

Judge VAN WYCK has been elected Mayor of New York, after a perfectly fair and honorable cavass, by a decisive majority. The preference of the voters for him and his party was unmistakably expressed. The campaign was one of extraordinary earnestness and vigor.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 2. -- The Plaindealer, Democratic, makes the following statement at 10:30 o'clock to-night:

Apropos of the question of cruelty to animals, a correspondent sends this story: Two men were walking along a shady path in the woods of Northern New Hampshire recently. One of the men owned a beautiful dog, and the animal was bounding along in advance of them, sniffing here and there, and looking frequently up into the branches of the tall oaks which lined the way.

HAVANA, Nov. 2. -- Another list of appointments by Marshal Blanco, the new Captain General of Cuba, was issued from the palace to-day. Brig. Gen. Luis Valderrana has been ordered to assume command of the central district of the Province of Havana; Brig. Gen. Diaz Decevalla will assume command of the Eastern District of this province, and Brig. Gen. Andres Garoto will in future command the Western District of Havana Province.

Alfred Schlegel, who lives at Hancock Street and Thompson Avenue, Woodside, L.I., was shot and seriously wounded in his home Monday night by Robert Arndt of New York City. Arndt has been arrested, and Schlegel is at St. John's Hospital, in Long Island City.

The incorporation at Albany on Monday of the New Amsterdam Gas Company of New York City, with a capital stock of $23,000,000, of which $10,000,000 is to be preferred, is a not unnatural sequel to the recent consolidation of the Equitable and New York and East River Gas Companies. Its creation is accepted as an indication that within six months all the gas companies of Greater New York will be united.

KEYPORT, N.J., Nov. 2. -- Ex-Judge Alfred Walling, Jr., for many years prominent in the politics of Monmouth County, shot himself in he head at his home, on Broad Street, in this city, at 10:30 o'clock this morning. He died instantly. He cast his ballot at 9 o'clock and went home. After writing a note which showed that he carefully had planned his suicide he fired the fatal shot.

The Rev. Charles L. Dodgson of Christchurch, is a sort of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde. In his above capacity he is a mathematician not unknown to fame. As Lewis Carroll, he is one of the best-known storytellers. The two existences overlap in that attractive work, "The Tangled Tale," which is a series of arithmetical puzzles conveyed in the form of amusing narrative.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- Important preparations are being made for the signing of the new treaty between the United States, Russia, and Japan, for the suspension of pelagic sealing in Bering Sea and the North Pacific. It can now be stated that the formal ceremony of signing is expected to occur at the State Department next Friday.
United States Consul Morris writes from Ghent:

OMAHA, Nov. 2. -- The Reorganization Committee of the Union Pacific, which yesterday bought the Government lien, the second mortgage on the property of the Union Pacific, to-day purchased the first mortgage by which the construction bonds were secured. The price paid was the amount named as the minimum bid to be accepted, $50,637,475.

The Assembly, which is made up of 150 members, had last year 102 Republicans, 1 Independent Republican, and 47 Democrats, the straight Republican majority being 54. This year's Assembly will consist of 79 Republicans, 67 Democrats, and 4 Citizens' Union nominees, the composition of the body being as follows:

KINGSTON, N.Y., Nov. 2. -- A long-fought and interesting case will be argued at the coming term of the Court of Appeals arising out of legal complications of trout fishermen with Clarence M. Roof, a liquor dealer who resides in New York City and who owns a private preserve on the bank of the Neversink, in the town of Denning, Ulster County.
A remarkable feature of the voting yesterday was its rapidity during the morning hours.

DENVER, Col., Nov. 2. -- The election in this city passed off in the quietest manner imaginable. The vote was but little over half that cast last year. Returns received from the city up to 11 o'clock indicate the election of most if not all of the candidates of the silver Republicans by pluralities ranging from a few hundred up to two or three thousand.

Rainy weather had no material effect upon golf yesterday at the Knollwood Country Club, near White Plains, unless unusual excitement and very close games can be credited to the unfavorable weather conditions. Although a few men failed to appear when their matches were called, those who were present set a hot pace and gave the Knollwood Club another record-breaking day.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 2. -- Returns so far show that the Democrats have carried Howard, Talbot, Carroll, Cecil, and Baltimore Counties. Malster, Republican, has a majority of 2,500 over Williams, Democrat, for Mayor of Baltimore City. It is probable that the Republicans have carried the three legislative districts of Baltimore City, but indications at this hour, 12:30, point to a Democratic Legislature in the State.

At noon yesterday Election Commisioner Charles J. Edwards of Brooklyn finished a canvass of that city, and declared that two-thirds of the vote had been cast. The rush of Brooklyn voters to the polls was something almost without parallel in the history of the city. The voting was quiet and orderly, and few disturbances were reported.

FORT DUCHESNE, Utah, Nov. 2. -- Reports were received here which, if true, and from their source there can be no doubts as to their reliability, confirm the belief expressed here that there was not much, if any, foundation for the wild reports in circulation regarding killing and burning by the Indians.

John Holmes, the brother of the "Autocrat," the late Dr. Oliver Wendell Holmes, is hopelessly ill. Never a strong man, he has failed perceptibly the past year, and for some time he has had a heart trouble. Within a week this has taken a form which leaves no chance for recovery. Three years younger than his distinguished brother, at eighty-six he has shown wonderful vitality.
William A. White Sons have sold for Isaac Walker, at a reported price of $200,000, the two four-story buildings 7 and 9 West Thirtieth Street, 50 by 98.9.

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 2. -- Edward Hamilton, for twenty-five years an employe of the Worcester County Institution for Savings, this morning shot and killed his wife and one child and fatally wounded another child. He then shot himself, and died this evening of his wound.

BOSTON, Nov. 2. -- At the annual State election to-day the Republicans, as usual, swept the State by a substantial majority, electing their entire ticket as well as three-quarters of the members of both branches of the Legislature. The head of the State ticket elected was as follows:

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 2. -- The finals in the handicap contests of the New Brunswick Golf Club and for the consolation prizes took place on the Ross Hall links this afternoon. In the morning the qualifying games were played, and the following were the scores:

CINCINNATI, Nov. 3. -- At 12:15 A.M. the telegraph editor of The Enquirer sent this out: "Cincinnati, Ohio, Nov. 2. -- The Legislature is Democratic. Chapman is elected. Every effort is being made to count them out, but it will not succeed."

For no apparent reason, Miss Jessie K. Parsons, a wealthy and pretty young woman, whose home is at 120 Locust Hill, Yonkers, ended her life in a room at the Manhattan Hotel, Forty-second Street and Madison Avenue, some time between 9 o'clock Monday night and 10:30 o'clock yesterday morning.

ALBANY, Nov. 2. -- The recent wreck on the New York Central called the attention of the Railroad Commissioners to the obvious fact that in railroad collisions and wrecks the ends of cars are most damaged, and that emergency tool boxes, which usually are placed in the inside ends of cars, are of little or no use when they are needed most.

ORANGE, Nov. 2. -- The annual football game between the Orange and Elizabeth Athletic Clubs was played at Orange Oval to-day, and, after a hard fight, the battle ended as it did last year -- a tie, the score being Orange, 6; Elizabeth, 6.

The Coroners of the various boroughs will all be Democrats. In the Borough of Manhattan four Coroners were elected, all of them being Democratic candidates. The two Coroners in the Borough of the Bronx, the two in Brooklyn, the three in Queens, and the two in Richmond will be Democrats, all elected by handsome pluralities. The following are the successful candidates.

MADRID, Nov. 2. -- Marshal Blanco, the new Captain General of Cuba, has sent a cable message to the Spanish Government saying he has formed a favorable opinion regarding the prospects for the pacification of Cuba.
Elections were held yesterday in ten States outside of New York -- Ohio, Iowa, Nebraska, Colorado, Massachusetts, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Maryland, Virginia, and Kentucky.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 2. -- The Democrats have swept Virginia by not less than 50,000, and possibly by 60,000, votes for Tyler for Governor and their other candidates on the general ticket. They carried both branches of the Legislature by fully two-thirds majority, and will re-elect John W. Daniel to the Senate.

The result of the election yesterday was a complete victory for the Tammany city, borough, and county tickets. Robert A. Van Wyck, the head of the city ticket, was elected Mayor of the Greater New York by a plurality of about 86,000. Each of the five boroughs contributed to the total.

The people have voted for Democracy, but not for Crokerism. They have voted against sham reform, but not against true reform. They are as anxious for good government, with all that implies, as the most superior member of the Citizens' Union. They want clean streets and the honest expenditure of public money and they expect to get these things from the Democracy.

A writer in The Toronto Printer and Publisher, commenting on the tendency of some of our United States cousins to indulge in "tall talk," recalls an incident that occurred in Montreal at the time that the press of the United States was threatening that the $5,500,000 awarded to Canada by the Halifax arbitration would not be paid.
Republican headquarters, at 1 Madison Avenue, were deserted during the greater part of the day. County Chairman Quigg arrived there at 2 o'clock, and gave out this statement:

Tammany Hall was the centre of interest last night, and, as usual, it kept open house. It was also in a very jovial mood, which increased as return after return showed that its chief candidate was piling up a plurality the extraordinary size of which was beyond question.

Perry Belmont expressed much joy at Tammany's victory last night. He said: "Democrats of Greater New York are to be congratulated. Their victory wants no element of completeness. It is a triumph for the American rule of 'government by party,' this time by the Democratic Party. It speaks for government by the plain people and for them.

Mr. HANNIS TAYLOR, lately our Minister at Madrid, in his magazine article on the Cuban question, has set forth that the Spaniards do not know what autonomy means, and that it is quite impossible that any genuine project of home rule for Cuba can emanate from the Spanish Ministry. It appears that freedom of speech is as little understood at Madrid as autonomy.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 2. -- Heavy rains throughout this State to-day have delayed returns, on account of bad roads, and many precincts will not be heard from for some time.

The part played by insects in the distribution of minute vegetable organisms has been made the subject of an interesting investigation by Dr. Amedeo Berlese at the Portici Laboratory for Agricultural Chemistry. That they do perform this task, often a very mischievous one, has long been known, but the professor, as is shown in the current number of Nature, has proved that, for good or evil, they are more active than had been hitherto ascertained.

At the present writing it is plain that there has been a very general and widespread reaction from the Republican Party throughout important sections of the Union. As is usual after periods of intense feeling, the change is to be traced rather to discontent with the party in power than to any gain in strength for the ideas of the opposition -- the opposition, indeed, this year having curiously vague and confused ideas.
BUFFALO, Nov. 2. -- The National Convention of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union re-elected the present officers to-day, headed by Miss Frances E. Willard.

DES MOINES, Nov. 2. -- The large falling off in the vote in this State was less damaging to the Democrats than to the Republicans. The State has gone Republican, but with a reduced plurality for Leslie M. Shaw for Governor. The reduction in the vote was much greater than any one had expected, and brought the Republican Party very near defeat.

Is it true that the officials at the Admiralty set their faces against any new invention of an unknown man, and decline to investigate into its merits unless it is brought to their notice by some one connected with the department? Mr. S.H. James, the inventor of the submarine sentry and sounding machine, asserts that it is, and that the effect is to force the inventor to take his production abroad.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- The election results of to-day do not promise to change the division by parties in Congress. The House is not affected by the elections, and the Senate will be changed by it only in two places if Maryland shall be lost to the Democrats and Ohio to the Republicans.

Strenuous efforts are being made to create the impression that, after all, we are on the verge of great foreign crops, news from Argentina being especially cheerful in its tone. This is not strange, whatever the facts may be, for Europe, obliged to buy American breadstuffs, has quite enough genius to make its bluffing artistic.
The headquarters of the Citizens' Union presented a lively scene yesterday.

ORANGE, Nov. 2. -- On the golf greens of the Essex County Country Club to-day there was a large turnout of players who competed for the Governors' Cup, for which there is playing on Memomrial Day, Fourth of July, Labor Day, and election day. There also was playing for the November Cup. The scores made for the Governors' Cup were:
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2. -- The people of Pennsylvania elected their State Treasurer and Auditor General to-day. The vote polled throughout the State was very light.

Most of the candidates, both the defeated and the victorious, were very reticent about the result of yesterday's election. There was little exultation on the one hand, and little complaining or explaining on the other.

The returns from the greatest city election ever held in the world were all received and distributed last evening in a room 25 feet long by 18 feet wide in the basement of Police Headquarters, at 300 Mulberry Street.

When Conterno's band played "Auld Lang Syne" at Morris Park yesterday afternoon the curtain was rung down on the racing drama of 1897 in this State, and the followers of the sport who keep up with the circuit began at once to figure on their trip to Washington, where racing will start on Saturday.

The Citizens' Union movement has been vindicated by the result of the election. The organizers of that movement undertook to ascertain whom a majority of the anti-Tammany voters, presumably capable of being united in support of a single candidate, wanted to have nominated. To that object they devoted all their efforts for months, not always with the highest sagacity, but with ultimate success.

Two events of high import in the fashionable world followed one upon the heels of the other to-day. One was a christening and the other a wedding. By an inversion of natural chronological sequence the christening took place before the wedding. The Duke of Marlborough's heir received his name with honors such as are due to Princes.

On Dec. 1 ten Canadian banks will pay out $1,406,758 in half-yearly dividends. The Bank of Montreal pays out more in dividends than any two banks in Canada put together, the sum for the year being $1,200,000, or 10 per cent. on the paid up capital of $12,000,000. The Bank of Montreal's rest is $6,000,000, and the nearest approach to that is the Merchants' Bank of Canada, which is just half the amount.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 3. -- A careful estimate at 1 o'clock this morning gives the Legislature to the Republicans by a majority of ten on joint ballot, though the usual Republican counties of Jefferson, Erie, Ashtabula, Champaign and others are to hear from.
The Citizens' movement, though it has failed in the election of a Mayor, has vindicated its right to exist and laid firm and sound the foundation of great usefulness.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 2. -- Nebraska to-day renewed her allegiance to fusion by electing the three candidates on that ticket by pluralities ranging from 10,000 to 25,000. Nothing like complete returns have been received or will be received to-night, but enough are in to measure the result, and indicate a greater fusion victory than in the Presidential year.

Senator PLATT has won his disgraceful fight against the people of Greater New York. He has contrived to divert, from the party of good citizenship, votes enough to throw the municipal government into the hands of Tammany.
It is a Democratic year. That explains everything.
The Democratic victory in New York State seems to be complete.

The Spanish talk about war with the United States is so pathetic in the actual condition of Spain that it, ought not to excite any resentment in this country. Every allowance is to be made for a poor and proud nation engaged in a struggle which is predestined to failure and naturally disposed to throw the blame of failure on somebody else.

DENVER, Nov. 3. -- The Union Pacific, Denver and Gulf, in addition to paying for fifty miles of road out of the earnings has $100,00 cash on hand. Receiver Trumbull has made his report and there is satisfaction among the Eastern stockholders. Everything is pointing to the reorganization of the road.

BOSTON, Nov. 3. -- Roger Wolcott, (Rep.,) has been re-elected Governor of Massachusetts by a plurality of nearly 87,000. There are still a few remote precincts to be heard from, which will not change the figures materially. Revised and corrected returns from all but a few precincts show a total vote of 165,370 for Wolcott, 79,414 for George Fred Williams, the regular Democratic candidate, and 14,134 for William Everett, the nominee of the National Democrats.

The majority of the men who were actively engaged in the municipal campaign took a day off yesterday to recuperate from the wear and tear of their arduous work. The headquarters of the various political parties were deserted, except for a few clerks who were arranging their papers and directing the workmen engaged in packing up the campaign paraphernalia and removing the furniture.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 3. -- Chairman James K. Jones of the Democratic National Committee said: "I regard the result of the elections as particularly favorable to the Democratic Party, and very gratifying to Democrats everywhere. It is all they could ask, and more than many of us asked."

-- Etymologists, as well as almost everybody else, except a few Spanish officers, have reason to lament the present situation in Cuba. Unless the rebellion there ends very soon in either success or failure, an ancient and honorable word is likely to get twisted all out of meaning and to become a self-confessed prevaricator.

Nothing has yet come to light to show that Jessie K. Parsons, who killed herself in the Manhattan Hotel, had any special reason for the act other than that, being of a pessimistic turn of mind, life had lost its charm for her. Her relatives say that is the only explanation of the deed that they can give.

The place of Lord Rector of a Scotch university is one of brief but considerable distinction. His sole function is the de livery of an address, but among these addresses have been some of the most notable and a few of the noblest passages of modern literature. Naturally, the standard set in the vividly characteristic effort of CARLYLE and the equally original but more subtle address of Mr. BALFOUR cannot be maintained every year.

There may be a few among the enrolled members of the Citizens' Union, or among those who voted and worked for its candidates, who in their disappointment may be tempted to think that there was no use in forming the Union, or that whatever usefulness it had is now departed. It would be a great mistake to accept either of those propositions.

LONDON, Nov. 3. -- The elections in the United States continue to overshadow all the other news in the English newspapers, and the results are discussed generally at the hotels, clubs, and other such places, as well as on the trains, horse cars, and omnibuses.

LOUISVILLE, Nov. 3. -- Kentucky wheels into the Democratic column again by a majority of over 18,000. Reports from all over the State show that Samuel J. Shackelford, the Silver Democratic nominee for Appellate Court Clerk, will have fully that majority, and that the silver Democrats will have a majority of over twenty in the two houses of the General Assembly.
ANDERSON, Ind., Nov. 3. -- Marion Chapman, Ole Weidner, and William Huntsinger and wife, all country people, have entered upon litigation proceedings over a duck.

We repeatedly admonished PLATT and The Sun that they were running a grave risk in making free silver the main issue of the Mayoralty campaign. We told them that it looked as though they were going to be beaten -- a reckless prophecy at the time, now come to superlative fulfillment. It seemed to us that the stake was too big for a losing game.

The indoor riding, season was formally opened last night at Durland's Riding Academy, Fifty-ninthStreet and Grand Circle, with an interesting music ride, followed by an exhibition which was a sort of advance pocket edition of the coming Horse Show. There was a musical programme, as well as numerous feats of horsemanship, and the latter feature proved such a drawing card that scarcely standing room was to be had in the building.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., Nov. 3. -- If the Boston-bound schooner Fortuna survived the collision which took place early this morning twenty miles south of Montauk Point with the schooner Edward E. Briery the three men of her crew of eight which were not taken off by the latter schooner are probably alive and drifting about the ocean south of Long Island on their nearly unmanageable vessel.

Arthur H. Fenn, the Palmetto Golf Club champion, repeated yesterday at the Knollwood Country Club, near White Plains, his performance of last Spring, when he won the principal trophy in the club's open tournament. At that time he established a new record for the eighteen-hole course, 77 strokes. In this respect he also repeated his work of six months ago, making the new record this time of 76 strokes, as previously told.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 3. -- Both parties conclude to-night that the Senate will stand 18 to 13, giving the Lieutenant Governor, who presides, the deciding vote. The Republicans claim to have elected 74 of the 145 members of the General Assembly sure. Chairman McConville of the Democratic Committee concedes the election of Bushnell by 5,000 and says that the Legislature will be close.

The details of a deal in suburban real estate involving over $1,000,000 were made public yesterday. The West Brooklyn Land and Improvement Company has sold all of its tract, extending from Fortieth to Sixty-fourth Street, and from Fort Hamilton to Eighteenth Avenue, Brooklyn, to a syndicate, in which former State Senator William H. Reynolds, the well-known Brooklyn builder, is the principal stockholder.

PORT TOWNSEND, Washington, Nov. 3. -- The steamer Al-Ki arrived at midnight from Alaskan points with ninety passengers, three-fourths of whom were from Skaguay. Among the passengers were two surveying parties, which operated along the Stickeen River for about ten weeks. One party worked in the interests of the Canadian Pacific Railroad Company, the other in, the interests of the Dominion Government.

WINDSOR, England, Nov. 3. -- The funeral services over the body of the Duchess of Teck, cousin of Queen Victoria, mather-in-law of the Duke of York, and sister of the Duke of Cambridge, who died at the White Lodge, Richmond, on Oct. 27, took place to-day in St. George's Chapel, Windsor Castle.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 3. -- President McKinley was the guest of honor to-day at the exercises incident to the celebration of Founders' Day at the Carnegie Library and Art Building. He arrived in this city at 11:15 o'clock on a special train from Canton, and was received with a salute of forty-five guns.

TRENTON, Nov. 3. -- New Jersey yesterday elected six State Senators and a complete Assembly of 60 members. Of the 15 members of the Senate holding over, 13 are Republicans and 2 Democrats, and the 6 elected yesterday include 1 Republican and 5 Democrats, making the complexion of the Senate for the next session Republicans 14, Democrats, 7.

Tom Eck, the trainer and manager of Kiser and Mertens, arrived from the Southern circuit yesterday. He offered to race Mertens against any rider in the world for a mile race, unpaced, but Gogoultz, the mile handicap champion of France, preferred. He would like to match Kiser against another Frenchman, Lamberjack.

LONDON, Nov. 3. -- At the first day's racing of the Northampton and Pytchley Hunt November meeting to-day Mr. H. Elsey's two-year-old bay colt Bambrini, ridden by "Tod" Sloane, won the St. Crispin Nursery Handicap.

A picturesque house of worship has been provided for the Briarcliff Congregational Church at Briarcliff Manor, in Westchester County, through the generosity of Walter W. Law of this city. The church building is built of roughly hewn blocks of stone taken from a neighboring quarry, and standing on a slight elevation at the junction of two country roads it presents an invitingly snug appearance.

Wet feet was the subject upon which Charles F. Wingate discoursed to a goodly number of women, assembled at the Murray Hill Hotel yesterday. It was rather appropriate that the women should have been members of the Rainy Day Club, though the wet feet of Mr. Wingate's discourse were not the feet of women but of houses.

BELMONT, N.Y., Nov. 3. -- Allegany County complete gives Wallace, (Rep.,) a majority of 1,911, and Litchard, (Rep.,) for Assemblyman, 214 majority over Breckenridge, (Dem.) This is a Republican loss of over 2,000. The failing off in the total vote is 4,000.

There have been few things in our life as an urban community and nothing at all in our political life to justify the belief that 75,000 votes in New York, 64,000 in Brooklyn, and 148,000 in the entire greater city could be secured after a four months' canvass for a Mayoralty candidate put in the field without the support or co-operation of a political party.

SEATTLE, Nov. 3. -- A new Klondike has been discovered in Alaska. This time the diggings are located on the American side, but the location is a profound secret that is locked up with three men. Lester Turner, Cashier of the First National Bank of Seattle; George Renneck, and George Stinson, both old Alaska miners.
Fire in a five-story tenement at 52 Manhattan Street early yesterday morning caused the death of James C. Duigard, who lived in the house. He lost his life while trying to save his insurance papers.

MADRID, Nov. 3. -- Senator Salvani has written a letter to the newspapers here in reply to the article on the Cuban question published in an American magazine, of which Hannis Taylor, the former United States Minister to Spain, is the author. The Senator says:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3. -- Comments upon the elections of yesterday have been guarded here to-day, whether made by Republicans or Democrats. While Maryland and Ohio continue to be described as doubtful this prudence in giving opinions is likely to continue.

CANTON, Ohio, Nov. 3. -- "I am well pleased with the result of the election, as it indicates that fealty to the Republican Party and the principles it represents are as strong as ever," said President McKinley this morning. The interview was in the private car Mayflower, in which the President was spending the night, previous to his return to Washington.

The most worthless of all the spilt milk of the campaign is the much-lamented failure of the Citizens' Union and the Republicans to unite against Tammany. The evidence of the returns is incontrovertible that even with such a union Low would have been defeated.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 3. -- The whaling steamer Alexander arrived here to-day from Point Barrow, and reports that she left at Herschell Island, on Aug. 25 last, the whalers, Grampus, Fearless, Orca, Newport, Jennie, Belvidere, and Wanderer hemmed in by the ice with little or no chance of escape, although none of them had sufficient provisions to carry them through the Winter.

The results of the elections in the various States as reported in the latest edition of THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday morning were not altered materially by later returns. The most doubtful contests were those in Ohio and Maryland, and in respect to both of these States there is still no absolute certainty of the result.
Mr. MCKINLEY will do well to study the returns of Tuesday's elections. He will find them, in the ancient phrase, useful for "instruction, admonition," and even for "reproof."

The Democratic victory of Tuesday in Greater New York was decisive. The Tammany forces elected every candidate on the city, county, and borough ticket, with the exception of two Councilmen in Brooklyn and thirteen out of the sixty Aldermen in the greater city.

CAMBRIDGE, Nov. 3. -- Harvard made easy work of Wesleyan on Soldiers' Field to-day, scoring five touch-downs in the first half, of twenty minutes, and two more in the second half, of eight minutes, which, with three goals kicked, made the final score 34 to 0.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 3. -- Marcus A. Hanna probably has won by a scratch. For twenty-four hours his political scalp has been in great danger, but things are looking better for him this evening. The Democrats do not concede a Republican majority in the Legislature, but there seems to be no doubt that the Hanna people will control that body.

The cotton textile trade of the Southern States is one of the most interesting in the history of the country's industrial development. It began during the last ten years of the first half of the century. In 1850 the mills were of some account, in those days, commercially speaking. A few of these -- they were small, even for that time -- were operated with slave labor, and results were satisfactory.

Judge Robert A. Van Wyck spent a busy day yesterday. He slept little the night before, not retiring until about 6 A.M., and left his home, 135 East Forty-sixth Street, before 11:30. After this he hurried from place to place, just missing at each a group of political and personal friends who were following in his rapid footsteps to congratulate him on his great victory.
ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 3. -- Fritz Meyer, alias Steiger, the murderer of Patrolman Frederick Smith of New York City, is a criminal with quite a record.
BERLIN, Nov. 3. -- The Tageblatt, referring to the New York election, deplores the victory of Tammany, adding "as it places the undesirable elements of the Irish on top," and concludes:

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 3. -- John C. Rockwell, Superintendent of Public Schools of this village, was an intimate friend of Miss Jessie K. Parsons. Their parents were close neighbors at Pound Ridge, and they had known each other for many years. Miss Parsons was in the habit of consulting Mr. Rockwell in all important matters, particularly since Mr. Parsons's death.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 3. -- The pilotboat Thomas S. Negus, having on board Capt. Joseph McClure and his company of eight men, bound for the Klondike to prospect for gold, sailed from Belle Dock to-day on her long voyage to the other side of the continent.

Two score or more sample bales of leaf tobacco, scattered about on one of the upper floors of the United States Appraiser's Department Annex, at Laight and West Streets, engaged the attention yesterday of a large number of Government Appraisers and Tobacco Examiners. There was also a considerable quantity of loose leaf tobacco from El Paso, spread over two or three tables.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 4. -- An official count of the ballots cast on Tuesday last, made in most of the counties to-day, leaves no further room for doubt that the Republicans have control of both branches of the Legislature and that a Republican will succeed Arthur Pue Gorman in the United States Senate.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 4. -- As the official canvass of the vote in Ohio proceeded to-day, the Republican plurality on the State ticket increased, but on the legislative ticket the result is close. The Republican plurality on the State ticket exceeds 28,000.

MADRID, Nov. 4. -- At the meeting of the Spanish Cabinet yesterday it was decided to demand an explanation from Gen. Weyler of the remarks he made in his farewell address on leaving Havana, on Sunday last.

P.M. Stewart, the Citizens' Union candidate for the Assembly in the Nineteenth District, and Howard P. Okie, Citizens' Union candidate for Alderman, declare they have evidence of fraud perpetrated by the Election Inspectors of the Eighth Election District of the Nineteenth Assembly District, and say that a willful miscount of the ballots was made.

The trial of the contest of the will of Joseph Richardson began yesterday before Surrogate Fitzgerald, whose court room was crowded with persons interested in three wills made by this testator, and their friends. The various beneficiaries were represented by a formidable array of counsel.

The failure of the Myers ballot machine to register the vote cast for him Tuesday in Yonkers cost Gustave Desgrey, Jr., the office of Justice of the Peace and elected his Democratic opponent, Joseph Hover. As a consequence the City of Yonkers is in a turmoil of excitement, and there is considerable talk of appealing to the courts to declare the entire election invalid and to order a special election.

A well-dressed woman who registered as Laura Haddox, New York, engaged a room for the night on Wednesday afternoon at the Belvedere Hotel, at Fourth Avenue and Eighteenth Street. Yesterday morning she was found lying dead on the bed. It was a plain case of suicide. She had turned on the gas after placing in her mouth the end of a tube that connected with the jet.

Inspired doubtless by the renewed public interest in the life and works of the poet Tennyson, due to the recent appearance of the admirable and exhaustive biography of the dead laureate by his son, the present Lord Tennyson, the Grolier Club has prepared for its first exhibition of the season a collection of sixty editions of Tennyson's poems, chronologically arranged, together with some interesting items of Tennysoniana and a series of portraits of the poet.

Bidding at an auction sale is ordinarily not to the taste of the members of New York's inner circle of society, but when the sale is of boxes for the Horse Show, as was the case yesterday afternoon in the Madison Square Garden Concert Hall, prejudice is thrown to the winds, and society turns out in force to become bidders.

The secure control of the Legislature in Maryland by the opponents of Senator GORMAN is now generally conceded even by his friends. He will be succeeded in the Senate in 1899 by a Republican. If his opponents have sense and virtue enough, Mr. GORMAN'S successor will be a clear-cut and outspoken advocate of a sound currency.

The difference between the scientific banking of England and the happy-go-lucky system of the United States is forcibly apparent just now. As a result of our heavy exports and light imports, Europe is indebted to this country on current account a sum estimated at about $100,000,000.

LONDON, Nov. 4. -- There was an extraordinary case heard before the Lord Mayor's Court to-day, when a man named Hinde sued the Prince of Wales to recover 60,000 ($300,000,) alleged to have been wrongfully paid him by the late Under Sheriff Croll, who was the liquidator of the United Kingdom Electric Telegraph Company.
Every leader of the Bryanite party of last year from the candidate down takes courage for 1900 from the reaction against the Republicans on Tuesday.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Nov. 4. -- The Chesapeake and Ohio vestibuled express known as the "F.F.V.," from Cincinnati for Washington, was wrecked near Old Shadwell, five miles east of this place, this afternoon. Four persons were killed and seventeen injured.

Many of the racers who followed the National circuit during the last season have announced their intention of abandoning short-distance contests in favor of the middle-distance match races. So many recognized leaders on the cycle track have expressed such an intention that managers and race-meet promoters believe a circuit of middle-distance races wilt be the feature of next year's racing, and that possibly the circuit of the short-distance riders will be abandoned.

How are the faithful to be rewarded? Judge Van Wyck's assertion that only Democrats are to be on guard is a source of great comfort to the Tammany braves who would not mind being struck by the appointive lightning.

Senator Platt's control of the Assembly, it is declared, depends entirely upon the course adopted by the six Republicans elected from Kings County. It is said by anti-organization leaders that four at least of the Brooklyn Assemblymen are anti-Platt men, who will not vote with the organization Assemblymen on any distinctively Platt proposition.

Oscar Hammerstein, the owner and manager of the Olympia, yesterday made an assignment for the benefit of his creditors through his attorneys, Root, Howard, Winthrop Stimson, 32 Nassau Street, to Lewis J. Phillips of 15S Broadway. The liabilities, with the exception of the nine-hundred-thousand-dollar mortgage held on the building by the New York Life Insurance Company, are said to be about $50,000.

William T. Harris, National Commissioner of Education at Washington, last night delivered at the Teachers' College, Morning-side Heights, the fifth and last of a series of lectures on "The Philosophy of Education." About 250 teachers and students of the college were present and took copious notes of the discourse.

While Fritz Meyer, or Constantine Steiger, as his name is now known to be, is on trial for his life for the murder of Patrolman Frederick Smith, at the Church of the Most Holy Redeemer, the police are working on clues that they intimate may connect the man with many other crimes, from murder down to petty larceny.

NEWARK, Nov. 4. -- Mr. and Mrs. Henry C. West of Brooklyn visited the county jail here to-day, and Mr. West without hesitation picked out of a large group of prisoners Thomas Hanley, one of three men arrested by the police for robbing freight cars, as the man who fired two shots at him and two at Mrs. West on the morning of March 3 last at Cranford.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- Secretary Bliss has returned from New York. Regarding the elections he made the following statement to-day:

BOSTON, Nov. 4. -- Joseph A. Iasigi, formerly Turkish Consul General in this city, who has been on trial for the last few days in the Superior Court, charged with embezzling about $200,000 from Pierre Charles Derieux and Charles Antoine Berger de la Villardiere of France, of whose estates he was trustee, was to-day found guilty on 21 of the 78 counts in the indictment against him.
The editor of The American Agriculturist of Oct. 16 last says:

VIENNA, Nov. 4. -- Emperor Francis Joseph to-day received in audience Herren Abrahamovicz and Kramarz, the Vice-Presidents of the lower house of the Reichsrath, and expressed to them his satisfactionat the perseverance, calmness, and firmness with which they had conducted the recent difficult debates in the house.
CHICAGO, Nov. 4. -- If there is a bull clique in wheat, as is generally believed, the market got away from it to-day for a few moments.

Mrs. Martha Durrs, while in charge of her husband's grocery store, at 366 East One Hundred and Sixth Street, had an exciting encounter with a robber shortly before noon yesterday. She was stabbed three times, and became unconscious from fright and loss of blood.

Joseph Walsh, eighty-five years old, an eccentric character, living in extreme poverty, and yet believed to be possessed of thousands of dollars, was found dead yesterday in the hall of the building at 167 East Ninety-ninth Street, where for the last eleven years he and his daughter Mary, thirty-six years old, have occupied three small rooms.

Several yachtsmen agreed last night to build 25-foot knockabouts for racing on the Sound next season. They met at the Grand Union Hotel, and the meeting was presided over by Commodore C.A. Gould of the American Yacht Club.
Maclay Davies have sold for John R. Simmons the four-story stone-front dwelling, 9 East Eighty-fourth Street, 25 by 102.2.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Nov. 4. -- A dapper-looking man, with black hair and mustache and snapping black eyes, walked into the police station this afternoon and asked Acting Chief Welton if he knew a man named W.J. Reardon.

The fact that a large number of machine Republicans cast their votes for the Tammany candidate on Tuesday in order to "save the organization" was plain on the face of the returns. It is now officially confirmed by The New York Sun, the relations of which with the Platt machine are far more intimate than those of any other paper.

DENVER, Nov. 4. -- The future of the new Colorado Midland Railway Company, of which the Reorganization Committee has just assumed the management, is demanding the attention of every Western railroad manager.

Henry O. Havemeyer, President of the American Sugar Refining Company, and brother of Theodore A. Havemeyer, who died last April, awaits at his country home at Palmer's Hill, near Stamford, Conn., the result of a heroical surgical operation.

The latest returns from Ohio show the election of the Republican State ticket by a plurality exceeding 28,000, but make little change in the situation regarding the Legislature. The Republicans still claim to control the Legislature by a majority of five on joint ballot, but the Democrats dispute the claim, and both parties charge fraud in several counties.

Seth Low and the Citizens' Union deserve praise for their gallant, unselfish, patriotic fight. Although they fought against heavy odds -- two strong party organizations, the odium of Republican Raines Reform (the ominous R.R.R.) and of Dingley, Black, and Platt legislative genius -- they polled almost one-third of the entire vote, came out second place in the race, and "downed" one boss in their attempt to overthrow two.

The New York Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor has issued a prospectus on beginning its fifty-fifth year of service, setting forth the aims and methods of the organization and some account of what it has done. The association is nonsectarian, and occupies a field uninvaded by any other charity -- that of giving "general relief" in this city.

After Prof. ROENTGEN'S rays and the kinetoscope and the phonograph, we of the latter edge of the nineteenth century have become supercilious with rgard to novelties in science; yet our languor may be stirred at the prospect of telegraphing through air and wood and stone without so much as a copper wire to carry the message.

A very skillful penman, who signed himself W. Tompkins, made an attempt yesterday to collect $260 with a check on which the name of Mayor Strong was forged. The cheek was drawn on the State Bank, 378 Grand Street, by Tompkins in his own favor, and beneath his endorsement was written the name W.L. Strong.

William H. Sands, who jumped up prominently again in the first rank of golfers by winning the John Reid gold medal and championship of St. Andrew's, added new honors to his fame yesterday on the links of the Westchester Golf Club, near West Farms, by making a new amateur record for the links.
