WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- Dr. W.H. Evans and Benton Killin, Comissioners appointed to investigate the agricultural possibilities of Alaska, have submitted their reports to Secretary of Agriculture Wilson. The reports agree that, while comparatively little agriculture exists there, it is possible that enough of certain crops and animals may be grown to sustain a considerable population, provided proper methods are pursued.

The British Government will doubtless move promptly for the negotiation of reciprocity agreements as to the trade of the West Indies, and will probably be met in an entirely friendly spirit by the Administration. But the grounds of agreement are very limited. The sugar exports from the colonies to this country are important, but in the present condition of our revenue it is not likely that concessions will be made in this direction.

SEATTLE, Nov. 4. -- A persistent rumor circulated in railroad offices in Seattle is to the effect that J.J. Hill, President of the Great Northern, is engaged in an attempt to get control of the Oregon Improvement Company by large purchases of stock or by appearing as a bidder at the receiver's sale which will probably take place soon after Jan. 1.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 4. -- Prof. Claude Crittenden, who died suddenly in a cab in New York last night, left here Oct. 19, to resume his classes at the Masters' School, at Dobbs Ferry, where he was instructor in advanced piano playing. He was a student of Liszt, Kullaka, and other eminent German instructors, and was a teacher of rare ability.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4. -- In the course of the trial of Harry Stewart for burglary, his nineteen-year-old wife, whom he married six months ago, fainted when she learned, she was married to a man with a criminal record of several years.
SPRINGFIELD, L.I., Nov. 4. -- The appearance of the New York bicycle police to collect the election returns from this neighborhaad caused wrath and much demoralization among both parties.

LONDON, Nov. 4. -- William R. Cremer, the former Member of Parliament for the Haggerston Division of Shereditch, editor of The Arbitrator, and First Secretary of the International Workingmen's Association and Secretary of the International Arbitration League, will sail for New York from Southampton Saturday next on board the American Line steamer St. Paul.

Bad weather united with the forces of bad government in bringing about the defeat of Judge WALLACE on Tuesday. In nearly all the rural districts of this State there was a marked falling off in the vote, and this is invariably against the Republican Party. -- The Commercial Advertiser.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 4. -- The weather and links were ideal to-day when the first round of the open tournament of the Ocean County Hunt and Country Club was started. The programme was changed so that the first eight in the qualifying round played for the Laurel House Cup, and all others entered the Consolation Cup contest.

ALBANY, Nov. 4. -- The closeness of the vote on members of Assembly has proved an interesting topic about the Capitol to-day, and the organization of that body has been talked about by leading politicians. The completed returns demonstrated by noontime that the body was safely Republican by 8 majority, at least, even conceding ten yet doubtful districts to the Democrats.

LONDON, Nov. 4. -- There has been a flood of political speeches this evening. Arthur J. Balfour, the First Lord of the Treasury, spoke at Norwich. Sir Michael Hicks-Beach, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, spoke at Sheffield, and Joseph Chamberlain, Secretary of State for the Colonies, at Glasgow.

" PLATT must know that his days as a boss are numbered," says Mayor STRONG. PLATT cannot survive this crushing defeat, say all the unreflecting Poll Parrots; it will put an end to his control of the party.

HAVANA, Nov. 4. -- Dr. Jose Congosto, the former Consul of Spain at Philadelphia, who was recently appointed Secretary General of Cuba, arrived here to-day. Dr. Congosto was received on his arrival by delegations from the local political parties.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 4. -- The sale of the Kansas Pacific branch of the Union Pacific Railway under the Government foreclosure, set for to-day in this city, was postponed till Thursday, Dec. 16. W.D. Cornish of St. Paul, Special Master, was present, and at 11 o'clock appeared at the station of the Union Pacific.

CAPE TOWN, Nov. 4. -- A dispatch from Bulawayo says that the newly constructed Bulawayo railway was formally opened today in the presence of Sir Alfred Milner, Governor of Cape Colony and High Commissioner of South Africa, and a large assemblage of South African officials, railway magnates, and capitalists.
SAN DIEGO, Cal., Nov. 4. -- The junk Acme arrived to-day from the lower California coast, and brought with her Capt. William Hall. Capt. Hall said:

At the regular monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce yesterday, at which President Alexander E. Orr presided, A. Foster Higgins, Chairman of the Committee on Harbor and Shipping, presented a report on harbor defense, and said:
LONDON, Nov. 6. -- A dispatch to the Times from Rio Janeiro says:

LAKEWOOD, Nov. 5. -- The golf tournament of the Ocean County Hunt and Country Club was continued to-day. The semifinals and finals of the Laurel House Cup contest were the features. In the semifinals in the morning M.R. Wright beat H.S. Curtiss, four up and three to play, and James Converse beat A.B. Claflin, four up and three to play.
LONDON, Nov. 5. -- "The First Born," having proved a failure, will be withdrawn from the Globe Theatre to-morrow, and the whole company, after six performances, will return to America.
A daring attempt at highway robbery was made last night on the Western Boulevard, near One Hundred and Forty-third Street.

No careful reader of the memoir of Lord Tennyson can have failed to conclude that his son studiously aimed to respect his father's wishes in every part of the book. The book is pervaded by restraint from beginning to end. If one false step was taken it was in publishing two or three lines in the letters to and from the Queen.

Anti-Platt Republicans assert that men representative of the party as a whole and not of Senator T.C. Platt individually will organize the Assembly. They likewise assert that a radical change in methods of party organization management is absolutely necessary to the future success of the party.

PARIS, Oct. 25. -- One of the special attractions of the forthcoming exhibition will be an immense Javanese kapong. It may be remembered that in 1889 a number of Javanese dancers were brought over to Paris by a Dutchman, a Mr. Bernhardt; lithe young girls, whose appearance was universally thought to be highly attractive in spite of their bronzed skins.

The Red Star Line steamship Southwark, which sailed on Wednesday for Antwerp, returned to port yesterday with fire in her forehold. She was sighted by the marine observer at Fire Island at 10 A.M. signaling that there was a fire, and word was at once sent to the city.

Out of forty-three talesmen examined yesterday in the trial of Fritz Meyer, or Constantine Steiger, for the murder of Policeman Frederick Smith, only one proved acceptable as a juror and was sworn in. His name is Carl F. Doerr, an agent, of 129 Crosby Street, who lives at 665 East One Hundred and Thirty-seventh Street.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 5. -- The Ohio Legislature stands seventy-four Republicans, seventy Democrats, and one doubtful, according to the official returns received up to to-night. With a dozen or more of the eighty-eight counties very close, there have been no material changes except in Wood County, which will be claimed by both parties until the courts pass on the action of the Supervisors.

Nearly 1,000 men and women teachers in New York public schools were participants in a mass meeting yesterday afternoon and evening, in the Chapel of the Normal College, Park Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street, which was remarkable among all the gatherings of the kind that have taken place this Fall.
First Meetings at the General Offices Next Monday -- Short Fall Docket for the Classification Division Is Now in Preparation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- The monetary commission named by the Indianapolis Conference is quietly going on with its work here. While it is not yet possible to make an accurate forecast of what it will recommend, it is learned that it will propose certain concessions by National banks as an acknowledgment of advantages to be gained by currency law revision.

The munificent gift of the Due d'Aumale to the Institute of France will pass formally into the possession of the institute next Spring. A report just made to the institute fixes the value of the gift and specifies certain items in an interesting way. The value of the collection is set down at 15,000,000f., of which sum 1,500,000f. represents additions made by the Duke after he executed the deed of gift.

PARKERSBURG, West Va., Nov. 5. -Near Ripley, Jackson County, this State, early Wednesday morning an aged widow, Mrs. Edward Green, and her son and daughter were murdered in cold blood and another daughter was wounded by John Morgan, a white man, twenty-four years old, for $58.

SING SING, N.Y., Nov. 5. -- A house on wheels, which in March, 1894, started from Port Angeles, Washington, for New York, reached this village last night, after having traveled 6,630 miles. The proprietor is M.E.A. Lasley, who describes himself as a tourist, traveler, miner, and Western pioneer, and he looks it.

The celebration of the two hundred and fiftieth anniversary of the adoption of the Westminster Standards, to be observed in this city Monday and Tuesday, is under the auspices of the Historical Committee of the New York Presbytery. The opening meeting of the celebration will be held in the First Church, Fifth Avenue and Twelfth Street, Monday afternoon at 2:30.

Application was made yesterday by the widow of Andrew J. Garvey, before Surrogate Arnold, for the payment of $5,000 a year to her by the Union Trust Company out of the estate of her husband. Garvey was notorious twenty-five years ago, when he gave testimony against "Boss" Tweed. He died in Southampton, England, April 5, 1897, and left an estate estimated at $600,000.

BOSTON, Nov. 5. -- The Lancaster arrived at Fort Monroe last night with six of the crew of the American bark Olive Pecker, who were taken on at Bahia, Brazil, where they had been held on charges of mutiny and murder of the Captain of the Pecker. The Navy Department notified the Attorney General that the prisoners were at his disposal, and he requested that they be delivered at Boston.

Mr. H.O. Havemeyer's illness was meat for the rumor mongers yesterday. Again they reported him dead, industriously spreading that story as an accompaniment to the traders' smashing raids on Sugar Trust stock. The houses who were heavy sellers of the stock on Wednesday were used in the same way yesterday for the purpose of giving color to the reports regarding Mr. Havemeyer, these houses being understood to have information from Stamford.

The pretty and pleasant village of Randolph, something less than a score of miles from Boston, contains the home of Miss Mary E. Wilkins, the most delicate and appreciative delienator of rural New England characters who has written within a generation. In the placidity of the little town she weaves her stories, and from the clear air and sightly outlook over a part of picturesque Norfolk County she draws inspiration and the strength to work.

BUFFALO, Nov. 5. -- William Moran, forty years old, and John Moran, his nephew, aged sixteen, were sentenced yesterday to the Erie County Penitentiary, from Westfield, N.Y., for car burglary. Constable Driggs was detailed to bring the prisoners to Buffalo.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- A lot of ridicule has been poked at Gen. Miles since he said that the Chicago Sub-Treasury ought to be fortified with Gatling guns, but the General has lost none of his belief in the wisdom of the plan. The Chicago Sub-Treasury, with its millions of dollars in gold, is believed by Gen. Miles to be in danger of looting at the hands of organized conspirators or a lawless mob.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- A new phase of the Bering Sea negotiations developed to-day, when the State Department was advised that Sir Wilfrid Laurier, Premier of Canada, and Sir Louis Davies, Minister of Marine and Fisheries in the Laurier Cabinet, would come here early next week to take part in the negotiations.

A Paris house that has long had peculiar interest for Englishmen is about to be sold -- the place called Bagatelle, where lived the late Sir Richard Wallace. The vast collection of art objects possessed by Sir Richard and left to his widow, (whose public bequest of them was about the most interesting feature of art news early this year.) must forever be associated with this place.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Nov. 5. -- Edward Martin, who gave his niece, Miss Serena M. Martin, a fortune, which has just come into her possession through the decision of the Illinois Supreme Court, died in Red Hook, Dutchess County, in December, 1893, aged eighty-two years. He was a pioneer in railroad building and the development of the West.

What is the result of the late election? The immediate and necessary result is, of course, that the occupant of the Mayor's chair for the next four years will be Van Wyck, and not Low; that the various subordinate offices of the City Government will be filled by men chosen by Mr. Croker, and not by men chosen by the Citizens' Union.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 5. -- The members of the State Committee of the National Democratic Party have determined to maintain their organization in Missouri and continue the fight along educational lines. To this end permanent headquarters will be established here, with Secretary L.R. Wilfley in charge.
LONDON, Nov. 6. -- The Madrid correspondent of The Daily Mail, commenting on the difficulties that confront the Spanish Government, says:

BOSTON, Nov. 4. -- Mr. Frederick Burk's Atlantic Monthly paper on "The Supply and Training of Teachers" has caused no little commotion in the Normal Schools, for the pupils read the magazine, and, being no more and no less reverent than other American girls, they have since shown a marked tendency to regard their teachers with an "I-don't-think-you-know-everything" air decidedly unpleasant to encounter.

HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., Nov. 5. -- The body of Algernon W. McKay, who lost his life in the New York Central Railroad disaster at Garrison's, was found floating in the middle of the river, off Iona Island, four miles below the scene of the wreck, at 9:30. o'clock this morning, by a boatman named Benjamin Lent, who was gathering driftwood.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- The first annual report of Commissioner of Pensions H. Clay Evans to the Secretary of the Interior was made public to-day. He says: "There were added to the rolls during the year the names of 50,101 new pensioners, and there were restored to the rolls 3,971 pensioners, who had been previously dropped, a total of 54,072.

Rodman Cornell, the nine-year-old son of Charles R. Cornell, an employe of the Chemical National Bank, had a narrow escape from death in a bicycling accident yesterday. The boy, who lives with his parents at 602 West One Hundred and Forty-seventh Street, was in the habit of attempting dangerous feats of coasting.

MADRID, Nov. 5. -- The Government received a cable message from Marshal Blanco to-day saying that "the Autonomist Party in Cuba is reorganizing," and that "several families who had emigrated are returning to the island."

Representatives of several foreign Governments gathered in the Twenty-third Regiment Armory, in Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon to witness tests of W. Lennard Foote's recent invention of auto-dynamic bullet-proof armor. Mr. Foote is a Brooklyn man. He has been at work on his armor for many years, but has brought it to a satisfactory state of efficiency only within the last few months.

SOUTHAMPTON, Nov. 5. -- The American Line steamer St. Paul, which will sail from this port for New York to-morrow will take among her passengers, in addition to William R. Cremer, the Secretary of the International Arbitration League, Mr. and Mrs. Augustin Daly, Ada Rehan, and Julie Opp.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 5. -- A mob is reported to be en route to Pickens County Jail, at Carrollton, Ala., where Bud Beard, colored, is in jail on a charge of assaulting the seven-year-old daughter of Ben Crockett, a farmer residing at Reform. He was captured by the Sheriff yesterday afternoon.

ALBANY, Nov. 5. -- The elevation of Justice Alton B. Parker from the Supreme Court bench to that of the Court of Appeals creates a vacancy in the office of Justice of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial District, which must be filled by the Governor on Jan. 1 next, the appointee to serve until a successor to Justice Parker can be elected at the next general election.

The counting of the ballots of the annual election of the New York State Division of the League of American Wheelmen was completed yesterday. All the regular nominees were elected, with one exception. This was Huyler Ellison, independent, in the Second District. He obtained a total of 840 votes, displacing Edward H. Walker of Brooklyn, the regular candidate.

The announcement that WEYLER is likely to be called to a sharp account on his arrival in Spain is, of course, gratifying, as a matter of general justice and decency. It is gratifying also to be told that among the charges will be those of the corrupt conduct by which he is believed to have enriched himself at the expense both of exhausted Spain and of devastated Cuba.
The Campania of the Cunard Line arrived at her dock at a little after 7:30 o'clock last evening.

I saw in The World of Oct. 30 an account of the Seth Low meeting in Cooper Union of the preceding evening, in which Mr. Low is quoted as using the following language in speaking of the death of Henry George:

Undoubtedly it is the ambition of Mr. McKINLEY to be re-elected President. It is a natural, almost an inevitable, ambition, and if served worthily an honorable one. At the present moment Mr. McKINLEY must feel that the attainment of his object is seriously imperiled. The fact is none the less bitter because, in sober truth, he has no one but himself to blame.

COLUMBUS, O., Nov. 5. -- The Ohio Department of Agriculture has made its official report on the acreage and conditions of crops Nov. 1. The information is gathered from 1,600 correspondents residing in every township in the State. The report is made without comment on the conditions found in all the localities.

The divers political organizations of the Nineteenth Assembly District are much excited over the prospective recount of the ballots cast for P.M. Stewart, Citizens' Union candidate for the Assembly, and also those cast for the Citizens' Union candidate for Alderman, Mr. Okie. The official returns, as seen at Police Headquarters yesterday, record the vote for Assemblyman in the Nineteenth as follows: Weil, (Dem.,) 3,665; Stewart, (Citizens' Union,)' 3,583; Mazet, (Rep.,) 3,147.

-- English comment on the result of New York's recent election proves little, perhaps, except a cousinly inclination to believe the worst about us and to take a view of our prospects as gloomy as that worst will warrant. None the less is it a most terrible thing to give even an excuse for such remarks as the European press is now making about us in unanimous chorus.

Dr. Mary E. Green, President of the National Household Economic Association, talked to the New York Branch about the value of a knowledge of household economics yesterday. A goodly number of women were gathered in Room 701 of the Carnegie Building to hear her.

Young Men's Christian Associations of New York have planned an eventful November. The great event of the month at all of the branches is the Week of Prayer for the spread of Christ's kingdom through Y.M.C.A agencies throughout the world. At the Twenty-third Street Branch there is to be a series of addresses, delivered at 9:15 every night, by the Rev. J. Manton Smith, the singing evangelist from Spurgeon's Tabernacle, London.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 5. -- Detectives and police are scouring Cincinnati for H.D. Halbert, charged with murdering Capt. Thomas Hoobler at Vanceburg, Ky., last Tuesday night. Halbert is a civil engineer and contractor, and an expert in the use of chemicals. He was formerly a partner of Hoobler, but they disagreed and dissolved partnership.

Most of the arguments used recently to depress the market are regarded by the veterans of Wall Street as of a sentimental character, and not entitled to serious attention from investors. It continues to be shown that business returns from the railroads and the industries afford encouragement, and that all indications point to greater improvement, general and permanent.

Mr. HANNIS TAYLOR, being a private citizen, is quite "immune" from official discipline or even official criticism for what he may choose to say or write about Spain and Cuba. But an appeal may lie to his own sense of propriety. Everything he knows that makes people willing to hear him on these subjects he learned during an official residence in Spain as the representative of his own Government.

BOUND BROOK, N.J., Nov. 5. -- An accident to a coal train on the Lehigh Valley Railroad last night resulted in the wrecking of another train and the death of the engineer of the second train. A pair of wheels from a west-bound freight broke loose near the station here and landed on the eastbound rails.
Hall J. How Co. have sold for Daniel R. Kendall, executor, to Charles Riley, the plot on the north side of One Hundred and Seventeenth Street, 385 feet east of Lenox Avenue, 100 by 100.11.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- A rumor is in circulation to the effect that Collis P. Huntington will default the interest on the first mortgage Central Pacific bonds in January, for the purpose of precipitating the settlement of the debt of that property and bringing uncertainties to an end. He is said still to be convinced that he can induce Congress to pass a Central Pacific refunding bill, but in this view he is practically alone.

DOVER, N.H., Nov. 5. -- The trial of Joseph E. Kelley, the young Somersworth murderer and bank robber, will begin here next Monday. Nearly 150 witnesses have been summoned, and it is thought that the case will occupy the attention of the court for about two weeks. Chief Justice Carpenter will try the case, assisted by Judge Clarke of Concord.

There was general selling of securities at the Stock Exchange and the Consolidated Stock and Petroleum Exchange yesterday, but at no time war there any evidence in the trading or the actions of the brokers of a panicky situation.

A member of the Republican County Committee was urged, previous to the election, by a Republican friend (a lawyer of this city, who gave me the fact) to exert his influence for the indorsement of the Citizens' Union candidate, as a matter of good politics, for the credit and prestige of the Republican Party.

PARIS, Nov. 5. -- At the request of the Colonial group in the Chamber of Deputies, the Government has consented to hold a big colonial exhibition at St. Cloud, one of the mot frequented environs of the city on the west, in connection with the great exposition of 1960.

There may be a few austere patriots in this community who believe it to be a matter of pious obligation to get down on their marrow-bones morning, noon, and night and pray that Mayor VAN WYCK'S appointments may be uniformly disreputable and shocking, that Tammany may loot the public chest, and that the city may groan under a veritable plague of bad administration for the next four years.

A novelty was introduced into the second day's play of the Westchester Golf Club's open tournment yesterday, which attracted a large number of ladies to the links. This feature was a mixed foursome contest, in which men and women play as partners, taking alternate strokes at the same ball.

Members of Company H, Ninth Regiment, have prepared a petition to Col. Seward, asking him to appoint a date for an election in the company. The object of the members interested in the petition is to reinstate Sergt. T.W. Lyon and make him a Lieutenant.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 5. -- The Municipal League has issued an address to the voters of the city, based on the results of the New York election.
The leaders of the moribund silver party are in worse case than we thought them. They are even trying to pluck up courage and find support for their drooping cause in the New York election.

In looking forward to the time when wheeling across the Brooklyn Bridge will be difficult, if not dangerous, because of the trolley lines now being laid upon the two driveways, it is gratifying to know that President Berri and Chief Engineer and Superintendent Martin are contemplating the erection of a cycle path for the exclusive use of wheelmen and wheelwomen.

The anniversary of the Freedman's Aid and Southern Education Society will be held in the Hanson Place Methodist Church, Brooklyn, to-morrow and Tuesday. The occasion will bring together many Bishops and ministers of the Methodist Church, quite a number of whom are already in the city. The programme of the session will consist in part of addresses on the work of the society in the South.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- The Board of Inquiry in the case of Capt. O.M. Carter, Corps of Engineers, who was charged with irregularities in the management of the River and Harbor Works in Savannah Harbor, has come to an end, and it is expected that the report of the findings of the board will reach Gen. Wilson, Chief of Engineers, for his indorsement in the course of a day or two.

Probably the most striking picture Of arahiteetura! beauty which will first presen itself to the eye of the visitor to Columbia University is the library, and the approach to it, which Is novel In both design and trealmaent. The great library, which graces the centre 6f the site. and faces !he city to the south, is the central figure about which all of the buildings axe grouped.

LONDON, Nov. 6. -- " The Little Minister," with Mr. Cyril Maude as the minister and Miss Winifred Emery as the Lady Babbie, was introduced to a most enthusiastic audience at the Haymarket this evening. The piece was excellently mounted, and Brandon Thomas and Sydney Valentine as the Elders, and W.G. Elliot as the Earl of Rintoul did praiseworthy work.

VIENNA, Nov. 6. -- At the meeting of the Budget Committee to-day the Minister of Finance pronounced a grave warning of the danger involved in a suspension of the Constitution unless the provisional compromise bill were adopted.
In discussing the banking functions of the United States Treasury and the inadequate powers given it properly to discharge them, THE TIMES remarked on Friday:

A second letter from Mr. Hallbeck on the subject of gymnastics in the schools was noted in your issue of yesterday, and was read with considerable interest and amusement. Alexander Pope, in his "Essay on Criticism," not only points out the qualities that make good verse, but does so in language that, in itself, illustrates each point.

Plymouth Church is about to celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of the arrival of Henry Ward Beecher in Brooklyn. It was in May, 1847, that Mr. Beecher preached for the first time in the city in which he was to gain fame. During the following November he was formally called by Plymouth congregation, and immediately accepted and began his work.
Chamberlain (S.D.) Letter to The Chicago Record.

WOODBRIDGE, N.J., Nov. 6. -- Mrs. Thomas Johnson of St. George Avenue is suffering from shock at her home, as the result of an encounter with highwaymen. Mrs. Johnson, while driving to Perth Amboy last evening, was waylaid by two men. They had been hiding behind a tree, and as Mrs. Johnson's horse came alongside, one seized the reins, while the other tried to climb into the vehicle.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6. -- The announcement that a company has been organized with Charles H. Cramp as President to carry passengers from the Pacific coast to the Alaskan gold fields has received an interesting supplement in the statement that four of the boats to be used are the steamships Pennsylvania, Ohio, Indiana, and Illinois of the American Line, which have been sold to the new company.

The accomplice of Fritz Meyer, otherwise Constantine Steiger, in the attempt to rob the brewer Ernest F. Ochs of Williamsburg on July 28 has been discovered and identified. He is George Werner, now undergoing a term of imprisonment of one year on Blackwell's Island for carrying on his person a set of burglar's tools.

NEWPORT, Nov. 6. -- Among the week's departures were Mr. and Mrs. Potter Palmer. They had allof their furniture packed for shipment to the West. They say they will not return here another season. Mrs. Palmer made offers for several of the larger Newport villas, including the famous Marble House.

The North Hudson County Electric Railway Company is extending its line from Hoboken to Jersey City. Poles are being strung along Newark Street, Hoboken, and the company encountered no opposition until its employes dug up the ground in front of the residence of Mrs. Christiana Parrott, at No. 422.

Hockey will be much more popular this season than it was last. Arrangements are now being made for tournaments, which are to be held during the Winter, and teams are being made up. The St. Nicholas Rink at Sixty-sixth Street and Columbus Avenue will be opened on Nov. 20, and after a few days for practice the first tournament will begin.

Two sensible recommendations are made by Commissioner of Pensions H. CLAY EVANS in his first annual report to the Secretary of the Interior. The first is that a law be passed that no pension be granted to a soldier's widow who shall remarry. The second is that provision be made for the publication of a complete list of pensioners.

The Indian country bordering on Western Arkansas has produced many individuals who have become conspicuous for their daring, both as the conservators of the peace and civil government and as defiers of the...

SEATTLE, Washington, Nov. 6. -- The real estate, railroads, franchise, bonds, stocks, and steamer lines of the Oregon Improvement Company were sold under a decree of the Circuit Court by Special Master Eben Smith, for $1,000,000, at noon to-day. The purchasers were J.I. Waterbury and T. Jefferson Coolidge, Jr., of New York, in behalf of the Reorganization Committee.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- H.H. Hanna, Chairman of the Executive Committee of the Indianapolis Sound-Money Convention, was asked to-day when the Monetary Commission would be able to make a report and formulate its plans. He said he did not see how the commission could complete its work and have its plans ready before the 1st of December.

" For more than fifty years I have made my living under the waters of the rivers and harbors of this section of the country. That is, I have worked as a diver during that time, and while I am now getting to be an old man, I still follow that profession. I have had many and varied experiences."

WATERBURY, Conn., Nov. 6. -- Bee-hunting in New England has almost become one of the lost sports, though it still has many followers both for pleasure and profit in the three northern-most States. The destruction of the forests before the advance of population, thus destroying bee trees, and the facts that the sport needs a lot of special training, and is generally accompanied by a lot of discomfort, have deterred people generally from its enjoyment.

LONDON, Nov. 6. -- An echo of the famous Ardlamont tragedy was heard at Leeds on Wednesday, when Alfred J. Monson, who in 1893 was tried on the charge of murdering his pupil, Lieut. Dudley Cecil Hambrough, the jury bringing the Scotch verdict of "not proven," was summoned for deserting his wife.

The first step toward arranging a football game for the Greater New York interscholastic championship was taken at a meeting of the Long Island Interscholastic League Friday afternoon, when a committee was appointed to confer with the Interscholastic Association of New York. The last two years the associations have held dual athletic meetings, and in 1895 a game was played for the intercity baseball championship.

Each day the Law Committee of the Citizens' Union is receiving additional complaints from some of the watchers in the various election districts throughout the city to the effect that fraud was perpetrated on Election Day, and careful investigation has developed the fact that there was at least gross inefficiency among the election officers in a large number of districts.

Gen. C.H.T. Collis, Commissioner of Public Works, has begun suit in the Supreme Court against the Press Publishing Company, which publishes The New York World, for $250,000 damages for libel. The action is based on an article published in The World on Oct. 6, in which the plaintiff was accused of using his official powers to make contractors for city work accept the Fidelity and Deposit Company of Maryland as surety on their bonds.

It is generally taken for granted that the recent election settled all administrative policies and probabilities, so far as this city is concerned, for four years from Jan. 1, 1898. This is not true, however, as a great many changes, even in the political complexion of the city administration, may take place during Mayor Van Wyck's term of office.

Richard Croker betook himself southward yesterday "for health and pleasure," as he himself expressed it. He left at 4:25 P.M. on the Pennsylvania Railroad. Asa Bird Gardiner, Mr. and Mrs. Randolph Guggenheimer, and Mr. and Mrs. Miles O'Brien accompanied him. Judge Van Wyck was not of the party.

Before an audience of nearly 2,000 persons the first of the free lectures given under the auspices of the Board of Education at Cooper Union was delivered last night by W.W. Ellsworth on "From Lexington to Yorktown," a story of the American Revolution in condensed and chronological form. Illustrated with about 170 stereopticon views of the famous battle grounds as they are to-day, and of reproductions of old prints of battles and other historical memoranda.
LONDON, Nov. 6. -- The Spectator, to-day, repeats its arguments of last week on the subject of Cuba and comes to the conclusion that when President McKinley gives his decision it will be for war.

MR. PAUL WAYLAND BARTLETT has been at work in Paris on a commission for the bronze portal to a tomb in Woodlawn. The illustration shows the young sculptor putting the finishing touches on the clay in his studio.

Prof. Albert S. Bickmore lectured yesterday morning at the American Museum of Natural History before a large audience on "Southern Italy -- Naples and Pompeii.'' The lecture, which will be repeated next Saturday at 10:30 A.M. was one of the series given under the auspices of the State Department of Public Instruction, prepared for the teachers of this city and State.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- The report of the Government Directors of the Union Pacific Railway Company for the fiscal year just ended has been submitted to Secretary Bliss. A summary follows:

LONDON, Nov. 6. -- Neither "The Cat and the Cherub" at the Lyric Theatre nor "The First Born" at the Globe Theatre is successful, and, as cabled yesterday, "The First Born" was withdrawn from the Globe to-day and the whole company, after six performances, will return to America. The comparisons which the critics have drawn are decidedly in favor of the Lyric's version of the Chinese play.

The recent death of the Duchess of Teck recalls vividly to my mind her charming presence at Homburg a year ago this Summer. She was always the most popular of the royal family, and it is said that the Queen was so jealous of her when she was a girl that she prevented several good matches that she might have made.

Capt. Gould of the American ship Challenger, which arrived yesterday, 121 days out from San Francisco, is something of a humorist, and his literary aspirations are said to have been inspired by the success of Capt. Peabody, formerly of the Tam O'Shanter, and now of the ship New York.

Oscar Hammerstein in the last two days has received many letters and cablegrams in which the senders say they hope he will soon be able to straighten out his financial difficulties. Many offers from prominent managers have been received for the lease of the building, including bids to take the music hall and Lyric Theatre separately.

RAPID CITY, S.D., Nov. 5. -- If the prosperity the Black Hills is now enjoying is continued a few years longer it will have the effect of changing the whole aspect of the country round about this city. An examination of the books in the Register of Deeds office shows that in the past few months there have been thousands of dollars invested in transfers as against insignificant sums for the past few years.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 6. -- Applications closed this noon for tickets to the Yale-Princeton game here, Nov. 20. There was a perfect rush to deposit blanks containing money for the seals in the big box at the Osborne Hall Pharmacy, and it is now practically certain that all the two-dollar seats will be covered by the applications.

It seems curious enough that the most definite explanation that is to be had of the flurry in Wall Street on Friday should be to refer it to the passage by the Chamber of Commerce of a resolution calling for the enlistment of some 4,000 additional artillerymen. As a matter of fact, the addition of that number of trained soldiers is necessary to make effective the fortifications already authorized.

LONDON, Nov. 6. -- The sporting newspapers have devoted much attention to "Tod" Sloane, the American jockey, since he has begun winning races on the English turf. Sloane's style of living astonishes the English sportsmen. He has apartments at the Hotel Cecil, with his valet, and, goes back and forth by train to the various race meetings.

A thirteen-year-old would-be train wrecker named Michael Butler was arraigned yesterday before Police Justice Worth in the Myrtle Avenue Court, Brooklyn. He lives at 233 Concord Street. At about 1 P.M. last Sunday Butler was playing on Hudson Avenue, under the tracks of the Brooklyn Elevated Railroad, with three boys of about his own age -- Robert Matthews of 171 Tillary Street and John and Richard Trotter of 193 Bridge Street.

CHICAGO, Nov 6. -- It has developed that the man known as Fritz Meyer, who was arrested in New York Oct. 28, charged with the murder of Policeman Fred Smith in the Church of the Holy Redeemer in that city, has established a record of crime in Chicago, and that, were it not for the intervention of a trifling circumstance, Capt. Colleran, Chief of Detectives, might have experienced the fate of the New York policeman.

The third annual convention of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs and Societies is to be held at the Women's Educational and Industrial Union in Syracuse. It is expected that a large number of the club members will be present during its sessions, Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday, the 10th, 11th, and 12th of this month. The programme of the convention in neat pamphlet form is already out.
Mrs. Humphry Ward gave a free Sunday evening lecture in the hall of the Passmore Edwards Settlement, Tavistock Place, London, two weeks ago. Mrs. Ward took for her subject "Social Ideals."

Dr. Mary Putnam Jacobi made an address to the League for Political Education at 11 A.M. yesterday at the league's headquarters, 509 Fifth Avenue, on "A Country Constituency." She talked of what women may do in political matters, and what direct and indirect influence they may bring to bear in the effort to procure good municipal government.

BERLIN, Nov. 6. -- Baron von Thielmann, Secretary of the Imperial Treasury, has returned here after a trip driving which he visited the various Courts of South Germany and Saxony. In conversation he said there were no important new financial plans under consideration, and expressed confidence that the pending tariff questions with the United States will be satisfactorily solved.

" Scientific courtship" as recommended by the Rev. Dr. Chamberlain of New Jersey is suggestive of various and novel emotions hitherto unknown to that period of felicity. We think there are some decided advantages in the system.

George E. Armstrong yesterday won the amateur championship of the Richmond County Country Club, at Staten Island, and the George Hunter gold medal, which is the championship emblem. This he will hold for one year. The furious wind made playing extremely difficult, as can be well seen from the fact that no scores below 100 were turned in.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- Word has been received here that the delegation of native Hawaiians who will come here to oppose annexation is made up of Prince David Kawananakoa, James K. Kaulia, David Kalauokalani, and J.M. Kaneakua. The Prince will pay his own expenses, but those of the remaining delegates will be met by a subscription among the natives, the amount to be raised being $4,500.

Police Officer O'Sullivan of the Elizabeth Street Station is a new and enthusiastic policeman, and has not been on the force long enough to acquire the wholesome awe of the Fire Department which all his experienced comrades have.

" I have always hated 'woman's magazines,' 'woman's columns,' and 'woman's pages,'" said a bright woman the other day. "We might just as well have 'woman's food' and ' woman's drink.' A magazine or a column or a page that isn't fit for women and men isn't fit for either women or men."

Raids, energetic and adroit, upset security market values during the past week. Current quotations were kept under continual pressure, and this bear aggressiveness resulted in putting a great majority of the week's net changes on the side of declines. Some of the recessions were substantial; more than fractional shrinkages were forced.

BERLIN, Oct. 23. -- To insult a person of quality, even indirectly, is a dangerous practice in Germany. A very large percentage of American and British editors would, if they lived and wrote in this country, find themselves behind the bars if they attempted to express themselves so freely as they do now.

When the Queen came to the throne omnibuses were a new but already popular institution. They were longer, narrower, and lower than the present ones, and had no seats on the roof. The passengers were carefully shut in by a door at the end, as if to make quite sure of them, once they were captured, till they had paid their fares.

There is no doubt that too much meat is eaten in this country. Americans are a nervous people, and they do not need the constant stimulus of meat. The vegetarians of New York might do a good work for the general good of humanity if they would open a really first-class vegetarian restaurant.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- The President is much concerned over the representations that many persons are in a starving condition in Alaska, and it is probable the matter will be fully discussed at the next Cabinet meeting.

BUFFALO, Nov. 6. -- The Western Transit Company's steamer Idaho, which left Buffalo yesterday afternoon for Chicago laden with package freight, foundered off Long Point on Lake Erie during a furious gale at 4 o'clock this morning.

The trial of LUETGERT, the Chicago sausage maker, for the crime of boiling his wife was considered a public calamity at points as remote from the courtroom as New York on account of the hideous pictures which it projected upon the pages of some of our illustrated contemporaries.

Dickens was a master of character delineation, and possessed a marvelous knowledge of the varied phases of human nature, but his acquaintance with the symptomatology of disease must have been limited, for it would be impossible to accurately classify the causes of the many deaths which occur in his writings.

Prof. Edward R. Shaw, Ph.D., Dean of the School of Pedagogy of the University of New York, delivered a lecture last Wednesday afternoon in the Art Building, 174 Montague Street, Brooklyn, on "The Logic of Children." The lecture, which was under the auspices of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences in the departments of pedagogy and psychology, was the third in Prof. Shaw's course in "Pedagogy."

A young woman who falls into a hypnotic trance if her eyes encounter the fixed gaze of another, who has lost the sense of touch, is insensible to pain and cannot tell the difference between heat and cold, is now the subject of scientific study on the part of some of the foremost experts in nervous diseases in this city.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 6. - A terrific battle was waged in the United States Circuit Court to-day for the possession of the Georgia Railroad through the lease. The Southern Railway, through Thomas Ryan, and the Louisville and Nashville Railway are the contestants. The sensational feature of the trial was the argument of Lawyer Henry Crawford of New York and his attack on the Louisville and Nashville.

Whatever in their own hearts and lives men may do with the Bible, they cannot avoid accepting it as a fact. Make out of it what they will, here it is, here it has been, here it will be, till time shall be no more. A fact is something done, as the word means an effect produced, an end reached.

Mr. Robert Goelet's steam yacht Nahma, which is now in these waters, is one of the handsomest yachts afloat, and in construction and interior decorations is very much like the Mayflower, which was built for the late Ogden Goelet. She was built by the Clydebank Shipbuilding and Engineering Company from designs by G.L. Watson.

In the fifteenth annual report of the Central Council of the Charity Organization Society of this city, soon to be issued, a comprehensive idea is given of the amount of destitution in New York and the methods of relief followed. The following facts are taken from advance sheets of this report: Important progress has been made recently in securing an interchange of information among the principal charitable agencies.

PARIS, Oct. 26. -- A strange rumor reaches me to-day that the Dreyfus case is soon to be reopened in a most sensational manner. The intention is attributed to Senator Scheurer-Kestner to interpellate the Government on the subject within a few days. Senator Scheurer-Kestner occupies a very important position in the upper house, of which he is one of the Vice Presidents.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 6. -- "Bob" Cook, Yale's veteran coach, said last night that this year he intends to give the candidates for the Yale crew a more thorough training than that of previous years. Every afternoon the candidates, most of whom are sophomores, will receive personal instruction in pair oars under Cook's direction.

Little things show the way the wind blows. This time it's stockings. They mark the difference between the deep-seated sentiment of the young woman and the practical outward and visible sign of feeling in the young man. Just now the shop windows are filled with a gorgeous medley of orange and black, united with, yet separated from, a mass of brilliant blue.

NOW let us consider fairly "A Lady of Quality" as a play and the portrayal of its central personage, and only one of importance, Clorinda Wildairs, by Julia Arthur. When I read the book by Mrs. Burnett I fancied I saw a play in it, and said so in a printed review; but I am quite sure the play now at Wallack's is not the play I saw in the book.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- A convention between the United States, Russia, and Japan, looking to the joint protection of the seal, was signed at the State Department to-day at 12:15 P.M. It will require the ratification of the Senate to become effective.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 6. -- Lafayette went down to an overwhelming defeat this afternoon, and the invincible Tigers added another victory to their already long list by rolling up 57 points to 0 for the visitors. Seven thousand spectators witnessed the one-sided contest, which, notwithstanding the size of the score, was intensely interesting and exciting.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- From an Ohio Republican, whose interest in the President and whose friendship for Senator Hanna cannot be doubted, it is learned to-day that there is not the remotest expectation among Mr. Hanna's closest friends that he can be elected to the Senate for the remainder of the term for which he was appointed or for the long term to begin in March, 1899.
Twenty-five of the counties of Georgia were named for men who had been Governors of the State, all of ante-rebellion times.

It has been suggested that the interference of the United States with Spanish rights in Cuba would cause great irritation to certain European powers, and that conceivably Spain might hope for assistance from some one or other of these in the struggle. We believe that to be the idlest of dreams.

Mayor-elect Van Wyck filed a sworn statement with the County Clerk yesterday, in which he sets out that the expenses of his campaign to him were but $158.75. The greater portion of this went to J.P. Potts, a stenographer, and the balance was expended for photographs and newspaper clippings.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6. -- Eugene Lindsay, a clerk in the office of the Prothonotary of the Common Pleas Court; John A. Merrick, Assistant Clerk of the United States Circuit Court, and his father, Richard W. Merrick, also a Clerk in the United States Circuit Court, were arrested to-day charged with issuing fraudulent naturalization papers.

The favorable statistical position of this country as a feeder of Europe, the southern hemisphere, and, incidentally, the East Indies, has not changed, because change is impossible. The law of demand and supply is to govern our grain transactions up to the time when the 1898 crops may come into the markets of the world.

Although that noted Kentucky institution, the barbecue, is not by any means confined to the Bluegrass, yet it is only there that it reaches its happiest development. And just as the Bluegrass is "the garden spot of the world and Woodford County the asparagus bed," so Woodford is pre-eminently the favored spot for holding barbecues.

THE musical season of 1897-8 is now fairly under way. The incidents of the week which has just come to a close were the opening of the Astoria Hotel series of concerts and the beginning of the Symphony Society's season.

There exists at present some slight coolness concerning a matter of patriotism between the Irish National Alliance and the '98 Centennial Association, and from present indications it looks to many Irishmen as if there will be two excursions from New York to Ireland next year to celebrate the "Rising of '98."

William T. Hornaday, Director of the New York Zoological Society, is authority for the statement that the first genuine gorilla seen alive in this country reached Boston on the 2d of last May, and died five days afterward from the effects of a cold caught on the voyage across the Atlantic.

RAPIDLY, yet with master skill, the finishing touches are being laid on Columbia's Library -- the great Greek cross of white stone with its dome only second in New York to that of Grant's Tomb -- dedicated to the memory of Abiel Abbot Low, merchant, by his son Seth.

Three persons were arrested last evening, one of them being a woman, on the charge of stealing or being implicated in the theft of cement. It is stated that over twenty more persons will be arrested shortly on the same charge. It is estimated that from 500 to 1,000 barrels of cement, valued at $3 a barrel, have been stolen, and possibly more than that.

Marlowe's Mephistopheles is the fiend of the English Renaissance; Milton's Satan and Bunyan's Apollyon are the solemn figures, conjured up by Puritan faith and art in the time of England's greatest religious ferment; lastly, Goethe's Mephistopheles typifies, in its cold cynicism and materialism, a spirit developed by that period in German history known as "Sturm und Drang."

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 6. -- According to the news from the Arctic brought by returning whalers, eight vessels are now held fast in the ice. The steam whalers Belvidere, Orca, Jessie H. Freeman, and the schooner Rosario are near Point Barrow, and the Newport, Fearless, Jeannie, and bark Wanderer are off the Turn Reef.

At the recent meeting of the American Public Health Association in Philadelphia the platform during one session held what looked to be a miniature telephone cage, but which proved to be a "humidifier," referred to in a paper read by Dr. Henry J. Barnes of Boston upon the "Lack of Proper Humidity of Indoor Atmosphere."

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 6. -- Daniel S. Lamont, Vice President of the Northern Pacific Railway, has arrived here on a tour of inspection of his road. He refused positively to speak of the recent elections, declaring that he has abandoned politics.

Ex-Mayor Abram S. Hewitt regards Sir Henry Bessemer as one of the greatest of the world's benefactors. In speaking of a rich man's relation to the general community, at the recent informal opening exercises at D.O. Mills's model hotel for poor men, Mr. Hewitt alluded to Mr. Bessemer as an instance of a man who might enrich himself and yet receive only an infinitesimal part of the wealth derived from his own genius and work.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- Senator Gorman's loss of the Legislature of Maryland, in Tuesday's election, assuring the election of a Republican to succeed him on March 4, 1899, is one of the most keenly realized results of the recent contests so far as the capital is concerned. For Mr. Gorman, while nominally a Marylander, has been a District man all his life.

The bicycle has entered the navy, and from present appearances has found a permanent place. Every ship in the service has its quota of wheelmen, who spend their leisure time when the vessels are in the harbor on their silent steeds. When the ships are at sea the wheels are safely stowed away, either below decks or in the quarters of the officers and men.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Nov. 6. -- The beautiful exhibition of the Dutchess County Horticultural Society has just closed in the State armory in this city. It has been the delight of thousands of people, and was participated in by the gardeners of nearly all the wealthy owners of country homes in the middle Hudson.

A REPRESENTATIVE canvas by the late Homer D. Martin, illustrated herewith, is a feature of the Autumn and Winter exhibition of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, which was opened to the public last Monday. This canvas was painted by Mr. Martin in St. Paul in 1895 from sketches made on a previous tour through the Valley of the Seine.

PORT JEFFERSON, N.Y., Nov. 6. -- The schooner yacht Social, which is reported to have been sunk in a gale on the rocks off St. Croix, one of the Bermudas, on Oct. 23, had been lying in this port for several years. She was the property of Oscar B. Smith of Morristown, N.J., and a broker in New York, but he sold her, after she had been condemned, to Capt. J.C. Lord, for $100.
Michael Banner, the violin virtuoso, will make his debut in Berlin, next Wednesday, Nov. 10, at Saal Bechstein, under the management of Herrmann Wolf.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Nov. 6. -- The net results of the first day of the deer season are not yet known. By State law deer may be hunted during the four Wednesdays of November. Deer have been so abundant in the Long Island woods this season that they have done much damage to crops, and formers have been looking eagerly for the annual hunt.

Major Moses P. Handy, Special Commissioner of the United States to the Paris Exposition of 1900, returned here yesterday on the steamship Paris. With Mrs. Handy, he went to the Waldorf, where he will remain till to-morrow, when he will go to Chicago. He has been ill for two weeks, and his return was consequently delayed.

Golfers had a furiously high wind to oppose their progress yesterday over the links of the Westchester Golf Club, in addition to the numerous stone walls, and it was little wonder then that when both these forces joined to make the golfer's path one of aggravating trouble few low scores were turned in.

DE QUEEN, Ark., Nov. 6. -- Advices from Indian Territory have just been received here that Walla Tonka, the famous Indian ball player, who was convicted of murder and was to have been shot at Alikohi, Wolfe County, Thursday, still lives. Hundreds of whites and Indians had gathered to witness the execution, which was to have been a double one, as Wallace Crosby, another Choetaw, was to have shared Walla Tonka's fate.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6. -- Gen. James N. Tyner, Assistant Attorney General for the Post Office Department, in his annual report to Postmaster General Gary says that during the fiscal year 244 fraud orders, under the amended lottery laws, were issued. Sixty-four were subsequently revoked, most of the persons having abandoned the business.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6. -- The University of Pennsylvania football eleven this afternoon defeated the Carlisle Indians on Franklin Field by the score of 20 to 10. The red men kicked two goals from the field in the first half, while the red and blue scored two touch-downs, from which no goals resulted.

The Irving Club's football team won a close game from the Yale consolidated eleven by a score of 6 to 4 at Eastern Park yesterday afternoon. The consolidated team included a number of the best freshman players at Yale. In the first half the collegians outplayed their Brooklyn opponents and scored a touch-down five minutes before time was called.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 6. -- The contest for control of the Ohio Legislature is considered ended to-day. The official counting in some counties will continue next week, but there has been such close watching that no material changes are expected. The indications are that the Senate will stand 19 Democrats and 17 Republicans and the House 51 Democrats and 58 Republicans, with a majority of five Republicans on joint ballot.

AS a fitting tribute to the memory of the late Lewis May, who died July 22 last, the memorial service to be held to-day at Temple Emanu-El will be a notable event. Nothing less than an unusually high regard for Mr. May could have evoked the general desire which has been shown to do him honor, and this alone will make the occasion really significant.

In view of the proposed annexation of Hawaii by the United States, the returns of the census of 1896, just issued by the Department of Public Instruction at Hololulu, constitute a very opportune publication, for they contain ample evidence of the ever-increasing preponderancy of the foreign over the native elements in the islands.

Cable dispatches from Simla, India, have recently had a good deal to say about the Gordon Highlanders, whose First Battalion, with the regiment of Ghurkas, bore the brunt of the fight when the British forces stormed Dargai Ridge and captured the almost impregnable positions of the tribesmen, a few weeks ago.

It is strange how much more inconsistent a man is than a woman. There is a man in this town who is an ardent politician, that is, if a mall who understands municipal affairs and has a strong desire to see that they are well directed can be called a politician. Anyway, he is so much interested in politics that the interest is communicated to the small boy of the family.
COBLENTZ, Sept. 15. -- A great amount of American brain power has been wasted in this Rhine Valley in making comparisons between the Rhine and the Hudson.

The departure yesterday of Gen. McLeer of the Second Brigade of Brooklyn for Gettysburg and other scenes of battle in the South, accompanied by several members of his staff, recalls the story of the loss of the old General's arm and the wounds he received upon one of the fields he is now on his way to visit.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 6. -- In the last exhibition game of the season of 1897 the Yale 'Varsity football eleven this afternoon defeated the team representing the Chicago Athletic Club by the score of 16 to 6. Good kicking was a difficult art because of a spanking northwest wind. The game was marked by the remarkable playing of Draper of Chicago, the famous former Williams half back, and the wonderful improvement in the Yale team.

If there is one human passion more inexplicable than another, it must be fear for which no excuse can be given or explanation made. It is not always the presence of real danger, but the dread of the unknown or unknowable, the feeling that some horrid thing is about to happen against which no defense can be made.

Wanted: Information which shall establish the identity of Mr. Wo Chang, author of "England Through Chinese Spectacles." (The Cotton Press.) Mr. Chang tells us himself that he had the advantage of an extended training in the English language and literature under a very learned and wise English tutor residing at one of the treaty ports.

Southern merchants and business men now in this city make generally encouraging reports of the prospects for business in that section, in spite of the retarding effect of the yellow fever outbreak and the resulting rigid quarantine regulations. They agree that while the fever has injured trade temporarily, it is likely to be followed by a season of remarkable activity, which will almost, if not quite, balance the account.

SENTIMENT has but little consideration when a city's thoroughfares are to be improved. Concrete practical problems present themselves for clear-headed solution then, and in the study of them legend, tradition, or all the guardians of the past have no place.
The propositions which Senator WOLCOTT'S silver commission laid before the Governments of Great Britain and France must have done very great harm to the credit of this country and its industries.

MILLVILLE, N.J., Nov. 7. -- Last night the grave of Mrs. Phoebe Tilton, in Mount Pleasant Cemetery, was opened and the body taken cut. Then the grave robbers stripped and mutilated the corpse. The citizens are excited over the occurrence, and if the robbers were caught it is doubtful if there are officers enough in the county to save their lives.
Concerts during the afternoon and evening by Lander's Band will, as usual, be a feature of this year's Horse Show, which will be inaugurated at Madison Square Garden next Monday.

LOUISIVLLE, Nov. 7. -- Fenton Mundweiler, Abbot of St. Meinrad's Abbey, in Spencer County, Ind., filed a petition in the Federal court yesterday praying for an order of removal of the Preston will case, in which he is the defendant, from the Trimble Circuit Court to the United States District Court.

HELENA, Mon., Nov. 7. -- The Chicago capitalists who invested money in the plants for the extraction of gold from the bed of Grasshopper Creek are now receiving their reward. Three dredges have been in operation all Summer, and the returns have been so satisfactory that London company has been formed to prosecute the same line of work, and is now placing the necessary machinery.

ORANGE, Nov. 7. -- A horse, which had created considerable excitement in Millburn for a number of months owing to its affliction with hydrophobia, was shot last night by Col. Edward S. Edwards, Superintendent of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

" The Name of God" was the subject of Prof. Felix Adler's discourse at Carnegie Music Hall yesterday, before the members of the Society for Ethical Culture and an unusually large number of guests. It was the first of a series of addresses on religious subjects which will continue throughout the season.
The British Iron and Coal Trade Review writes as follows respecting manufactured iron and steel:

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 7. -- Oscar Hammerstein had a prolonged conference to-day with Francis Wilson, the comedian, at the latter's home, in Residence Park Mr. Wilson subsequent]y announced that Mr. Hammerstein had offered him the opera La Poupee, but that no definite conclusion had been arrived at.

the celebration of the quarter millennial anniversary of the adoption of the West-minister standards, which is to be held under the auspices of the Presbyterian Union and the Historical Committee of the New York Presbytery, will commence to-day at 2:30 P.M. in the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Twelfth Street.

An informal reception was held yesterday afternoon aboard the steamship City of Columbia at the foot of East Ninth Street. The ship will take a large party of adventurers to the Alaskan gold fields, and the reception was for the purpose of giving the 300 passengers, already booked, a chance to become friends and inspect their quarters.

-- New York cabmen and truck drivers have taken pains in the last few days to give frequent and effective demonstration of their dislike for bicyclists. They have killed nobody outright, indeed, but they have put something like a dozen wheels beyond the possibility of repair, and have fractured and confused the riders thereof seriously enough to keep them off the streets for some time.

An unannounced meeting of Republicans who were elected to the Assembly from New York and Brooklyn was held on Saturday night in the home of State Senator George W. Brush, 2 Spencer Place, Brooklyn, to consider the most feasible plan for wresting the control of the Assembly from Senator Platt.

HARTFORD, Nov. 7. -- Commissioner of Insurance Frederick A. Betts will make public to-morrow the report of his investigations of the National Life Association of this city, the outcome of which was the requested resignation of President Fletcher and Director Wilbur, the voluntary resignation of H T. Braman, the Secretary, and the reorganization of the company.
Mr. McKINLEY will make a very bad matter much worse if he listens to the advisers who tell him that his recent reverses were due to listening to the independent element in the Republican Party.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 7. -- The physicians in attendance upon Major Benjamin Butterworth, Commissioner of Patents, who is ill with pneumonia at the Hollenden Hotel, have little hope of his recovery.

The eighth annual exhibition of the New York Water Color Club was opened to the public at 10 o'clock yesterday morning at the galleries of the American Fine Arts Society, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street. There were but few visitors during the day, but owing to the unusually fine collection of pictures that have been gathered together the exhibition is expected to be as successful as any that the club has given.

The Economiste Francais has an interesting article by M. Paul Leroy-Beaulieu, in which that eminent political economist states that the constantly increasing production of sugar and the fal lin price resulting therefrom must inevitably bring about the ruin of an industry upheld solely by a dangerous system of protection.

LONDON, Nov. 7. -- The money market is easier, but not to a great extent. It is expected that only a portion of the loans due at the Bank of England will be repaid, and on the outside supplies are unusually small. Discount rates cannot fall while money continues scarce.
MADRID, Nov. 7. -- The Cabinet Council has approved the proposal of political amnesty for Cuba and the Philippines.

A simple and austere beauty marked the memorial service held in the Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Forty-third Street, yesterday afternoon, in honor of Lewis May, who was President of the congregation and whose death took place in last July.

SIMLA, Nov. 7. -- Official dispatches from Maidan, in the Maidan Valley, where the British column under Sir William Lockhart is encamped, say that a large deputation of the Orakzais has entered the camp to treat for peace, but that as yet the Afridis give no sign of yielding.

An interesting summary is given in Nature of a French book by Dr. Paul Regnard on the "Effect of Altitude on Man." Many of us have ascertained by experience that, when we feel "used up" after a long period of hard work, we recover tone most quickly by seeking some quiet mountain resort, at a few thousand feet above sea level.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7. -- The Monetary Commission has received from John C. Bullitt of Philadelphia a suggestion for the reform of the banking and currency systems of the country. The commission has given careful attention to Mr. Bullitt's plan partly because it has been indorsed by financiers whose judgments are entitled to weight.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7. -- Controller Eckels wires a two-column dispatch to a Chicago newspaper in which he says the failure of the Wolcott commission should convince Congress that currency reformation by such means is impossible, and that there must be affirmative legislation before the Nation can occupy that place which is its due.

SANTA FE, N.M., Nov. 7. -- Atlantic and Pacific Passenger Train No. 2, on the Santa Fe Road, from the West, was stopped by four men near Grant's Station, ninety-five miles west of Albuquerque, at 7:30 o'clock last night. After blowing open the express company's safe, the robbers wrecked the train, which caught fire, several cars being destroyed.

BUFFALO, Nov. 7. -- The following are the names of sixteen out of the nineteen men who lost their lives on the Western Transit Company's steamer Idaho, which sank in the gale Saturday morning above Long Point on Lake Erie:

HARRISBURG, Nov. 7. -- Capt. Alexis R. Paxton, Fifteenth Infantry, U.S.A., has forwarded to the Secretary of War a report of the operations of the Third Brigade and Philadelphia City Troop in the Hazleton region, following the killing of strikers at Lattimer by Sheriff Martin and his deputies.

The imprecatory, or cursing, Psalms have given trouble to the theologians and great comfort to Col. Ingersoll. Common saints have skipped them and kept silent. The writer has questioned their inspiration, but the election has cleared away all mists of doubt and vindicated their inspiration. They were written for Thomas C. Platt.

Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, was crowded to the doors yesterday morning, and the Rev. Dr. Charles A. Berry of Wolverhampton, England, who was to preach, looked upon a congregation as large as those which greeted Henry Ward Beecher. The church was celebrating its golden jubilee, and though tickets of admission were required up to 10:20 o'clock, and no one was admitted who did not have one, the building was crowded long before that hour.

Down in Maine the owls may be heard talking in that way all night long. Mr. DINGLEY has acquired their sublimated wisdom. Could anything be more owlish than the contention that the Republican loss of 338,000 from last year's vote was occasioned by the aloofness of PLATT'S Republicans and the Citizens' Union?

The return of Mr. WILLIAM R. CREMER to the United States as the advocate of a reciprocity treaty with Great Britain may have a decided influence. Mr. CREMER'S especial mission on this occasion is as the representative of the working people of the United Kingdom. He is the bearer of a petition from 7,000 trades union officers, who, he reports, represent 2,750,000 workingmen.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 7. -- John R. McLean and party left to-night for Washington. Mr. McLean has been considered the Democratic candidate for Senator, and his departure is regarded as an indication that he concedes the Legislature to the Republicans, notwithstanding the numerous notices of contest.

Who will the first Chief of Police of Greater New York, and who will be the Police Commissioners appointed by the Tammany Mayor in January next are the questions that the politicians in and out of the Police Department are asking each other.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Nov. 7. -- The Hotel San Marco, one of the finest and most commodious hotel properties in this city, was burned to the ground this morning. The loss is about $250,000, with less than $50,000 insurance.

The official visit of the Premier of Canada to Washington, which is announced as imminent, is, we believe, quite unprecedented. It is, of course, common enough for Great Britain to name some representative colonist as her representative in a negotiation in which the colony is more directly interested than the mother country.

The professional traders of the Stock Exchange, who now, after the 15-point decline in the stock market, are most persistent bears, and who last week succeeded in bringing about substantial declines in prices by frightening Wall Street with all sorts of silly rumors, are promising further bearish developments in the week to come.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Nov. 8. -- Toledo is to have another Chicago line. It is to be a round-about route, but a still shorter line than the Lake Shore. It is to be built by the Wabash. The authority for the statement that the Wabash is going to build it is Col. S.C. Reynolds, a Director of the company.

The capacity of the cigarette for mischief was illustrated in a startling manner yesterday afternoon, at Nineteenth Street and First Avenue, where one of those destructive luxuries provoked an explosion which tore up a large section of the avenue, injured several people, and may cause a man's death.

Argument on the application for an injunction to restrain the city from paying and John McCullagh from receiving pay as Chief of Police was heard yesterday by Justice Beach in the Special Term of the Supreme Court. The case was presented in the form of a taxpayer's action, Joseph Murphy of the Memorial Committee of the Grand Army of the Republic appearing as the applicant.
Douglas Robinson Co. have sold, for Charles W. Sloane, the four-story brownstone-front dwelling 60 Park Avenue, 17 by 80.

DENVER, Nov. 8. -- W.D. Cornish, Master in Chancery, appeared at the Court House to-day at the hour originally set for the sale of the Denver Pacific Road and publicly announced the postponement of the sale until Dec. 20.

" It is hard to tell," said Mrs. Etta Morse Hudders, in her lecture upon ventilation yesterday in the Domestic Science Department of the Brooklyn Institute, "which is the worst -- the draughty houses such as our grandparents had or the hot-air boxes into which we have made our houses to-day.

After opening with a show of much firmness, and with a considerable volume of transactions at prices better than the final quotations of last week, the stock market yesterday of a sudden became feverish, and throughout most of the day was weak. Many substantial declines were scored. Only in two or three exceptional instances were there any material advances, and almost entirely such advances were in stocks outside the standard list.

The little schooner Silver Heels, which in the early morning of Sunday, Oct. 17, evaded the revenue cutter Chandler and put to sea with a cargo of arms and ammunition for the Cuban insurgents, encountered other dangers, it appears, in her now famous expedition, and she had the company in her tribulations of the tug P.H. Wise.

SEATTLE, Washington, Nov. 8. -- Contracts for the construction of twelve river steamers, twenty-four freight barges, and two towboats, were let to-day by the Yukon Company to the shipbuilding firm of Moran Brothers of this city. The amount to be paid is approximately $100,000, in installments of $10,000.

HAVANA, via Key West, Fla., Nov. 8. --There is a great deal of excitement here at present in all political circles, due to increasing lack of confidence in the ability of Spain to establish an autonomous form of government in Cuba and to the apprehension that the Spanish troops will not be able to suppress the insurrection by force of arms.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 8. -- It was reported in local political circles yesterday that Charles L. Kurtz, ex-Chairman of the Republican State Committee, slipped quietly into the city during the afternoon and was in close conference with Senator Foraker, his chief, on the Senatorial question. The reports had it that the Senator and Kurtz had surveyed the situation carefully, and had reached an understanding unfavorable to Mr. Hanna.

The National conference of citizens from all parts of the country for the organization of a movement to revolutionize the election laws of each State, and to place the primaries under the jurisdiction of the law, equally with the elections, will be held in this city in the first and second weeks of next month.

One of our esteemed freak contemporaries has startled its readers, if its habitual readers are still capable of being startled, by diverting its yellow searchlight from the slums of New York into the library of the Vatican. There they have illuminated a manuscript which has escaped the notice of some sixty generations of searchers, being nothing less than the official report by PONTIUS PILATE of his interview with JESUS of Nazareth.

The new comedy presented in an adroit and graceful manner at the Empire Theatre last evening, with an exquisite Louis Quinze background, is, to be sure, a very old comedy, for the elder Dumas, in emulation of Marivaux, wrote "Un Mariage sous Louis XV." when our grandfathers and grandmothers (who, bless their dear hearts, knew mighty little about French plays) were young folks.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- In the list of candidates for the United States Senate to succeed Mr. Gorman is a man who, some knowing persons think, will carry off the honor, though he scarcely is mentioned for the place. He is Charles Jerome Bonaparte, the well-known Baltimore lawyer and grand nephew of Napoleon Bonaparte.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- Not until the present administration of the Treasury Department has there been a time when the figures concerning the commerce of the United States with other countries were not accessible, in almost all stages of their arrangement, to such representatives of the press as chose to gather them. This privilege was not exercised by many newspaper men.

The very able and convincing report of the three Commissioners appointed by the Appellate Division gives new life to the project of rapid transit and new hope to a community long ago grown weary almost to despair of the defeats and delays to which an enterprise urgently demanded by them and having their express sanction at the polls was subjected by interested opposition and the abuse of law.

Much to the surprise of all concerned, the selection of the jury for the trial of Martin Thorn, accused of having, with the assistance of Mrs. Augusta Nack, murdered William Guldensuppe in a cottage at Woodside, L.I., on June 25, was completed yesterday. The first of the twelve was accepted one hour after the calling of the panel had begun; the last stepped into the box at 3 o'clock, the hour fixed for adjournment.

The police of both this city and Brooklyn have, they think, found evidence which connects beyond a doubt Constantine Steiger, or Fritz Meyer, as he called himself, with the murder of Bellringer George Stelz at the Church of the Holy Trinity, in Williamsburg, last August. They have found the watch of Stelz, which was traced through Steiger's hands, and arrested Frederick Aring, his supposed accomplice on this and other occasions.

When the indoor season at the Central Park Riding Academy closed last Spring, the proprietors, Heinemann Brothers, began to make extensive preparations. More space for spectators was made without encroaching upon any of the ring space, and new decorations were added. The bed of the big riding ring has been replaced with a newer and a firmer one, and a new coat of top dressing of tanbark has been laid.

BUTTE, Mon., Nov. 8. -- A great gold strike has been made on Upper Sag Creek. A ledge of quartz extending for many miles and running $100 to the ton has been discovered and the people in that part of the State are wild with excitement.
