The little town of Utica has been almost deserted by the male inhabitants who have staked out the whole surrounding country.

A meeting of the National Sound Money League will be held in the rooms of that organization in the Bowling Green Building, this city, to-day, beginning at 11 A.M. Several members from out of town have signified their intention of attending. E.V. Smalley, the General Secretary, has received letters from Vice Presidents in different States, which will be read.

Jacob Worth yesterday gave out a statement in the form of an interview on the results of the election, in which he declared that a movement was under way for the formation of a citizens' organization throughout the State. It would, he said, be formed in every one of the large cities, and in New York and Brooklyn would represent more than one half of the Republican voters.
How will the new City Government clean the streets? As BRENNAN and ANDREWS did or as WARING does?

A ruling on an issue of as great moment as has been raised for many years will be officially demanded of the National League of American Wheelmen Racing Board in connection with the so-called century run under the auspices of the Long Island City Wheelmen, which was held on Sunday from Long Island City to Oakdale and return.

LONDON, Nov. 8. -- The new Lord Mayor of London, Mr. Horatio David Davies, Member of Parliament for Chatham, was formally installed in office at the Guildhall to-day, with the usual ceremonial, succeeding Sir George Faudel Philips. The ancient custom of presenting the elected Chief Magistrate of London to the representatives of the Sovereign and to the people, known as Lord Mayor's Day, will be observed to-morrow with great ceremony.

The New York Presbytery met yesterday afternoon in the "Old First" Presbyterian Church, in Fifth Avenue, between Eleventh and Twelfth Streets, and almost immediately resolved itself into a general meeting to celebrate the 250th anniversary of the adoption of the Westminster Standards. The Presbytery itself will meet again Monday, Nov. 15, at 3 P.M., in the same church.

The bosses have not come very well out of the elections. In this State the Democrats, who have for a year and more been deprived of the fostering care of a State boss, have effected a change of about 150,000 votes from the "normal year " of 1895 in their favor. This is at the expense of the Republicans, whose "honored leader" has never been in more complete control, nor more openly directed the organization.

The trial of the contest of the will of Joseph Richardson was resumed yesterday before Surrogate Fitzgerald, and it had not been in progress long before the attitude of W.R. Spooner, who represents the Trustees of the Central Park Baptist Church, a beneficiary under the contested will, created great surprise and called forth a vigorous protest from counsel for Mrs. Richardson and the Rev. Dr. Harry M. Warren.

ATLANTA, Nov. 8. -- Without one word of discussion the House of Representatives, by a vote of 91 to 3, to-day passed the anti-football bill, and it is now on its way to the Senate. This result was anticipated, notwithstanding the warm opposition of the State University, which, recovering from the shock of Student Von Gamon's death, tried to stem the tide of opposition in order to save the game.

The religious "revival" which is said to be in progress in a prominant woman's college in Massachusetts appears to have reached a stage that calls for the interference of the Faculty and of parents. The drift of things is pretty plainly indicated in a dispatch to our neighbor The Sun from which we quote:
" The great American trouble is dyspepsia."

ALBANY, Nov. 8. -- Justice Alton B. Parker certified to the Secretary of State to-day that his personal expenses as a candidate for Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals amounted to $530, of which $500 went to the Democratic State Committee, and $30 for postage.

ALBANY, Nov. 8. -- Formal application has been made to Gov. Black for the pardon of Amer Ben Ali, better known as "Frenchy," who was convicted in New York in 1891 of manslaughter in the first degree for the killing of an old and dissolute woman known as "Old Shakespeare." The petition praying for Executive clemency is signed by many men of national and international repute.
LONDON, Nov. 8. -- At the first day's racing of the Lingfield Park November meeting to-day Richard Croker's three-year-old bay filly Georgiana won the Chellows Plate.

HAVANA, Nov. 8. -- At the solicitation of Senora Emilia Quesada, widow of Senor Arteaga Quesada, Capt. Gen. Blanco has pardoned her son, Julio Quesada, a nephew of Senor Gonzalo Quesada of the Cuban Junta at New York. The young man was under sentence of death.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- Two weeks ago Secretary Sherman told a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES that there was no information from Minister Woodford, at Madrid, to justify the sensational reports current at that time about an imminent breach of friendly relations between Spain and the United States.

GARFIELD, N.J., Nov. 8. -- In an altercation over a missing bicycle in McCabe's Hotel, near the county bridge here, last night, William Nixon, a respectable citizen of Passaic, was killed by a blow with a club wielded by an iron worker, whose name is unknown to the authorities.

Mr. HANNIS TAYLOR is scarcely candid in the explanation which he has felt to be required of his appearance in print as an expert upon the Cuban question. It is scarcely accurate to say that his recent writings upon the subject were "based upon facts accessible to everybody."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- The United States Supreme Court to-day affirmed the decision of the lower court in the case of the Inter-State Commerce Commission against the Alabama Midland and the Georgia Central Railroad Company and others. The case arose out of charges by citizens of Troy, Ala., that the companies were disregarding the long and short haul clause of the inter-State commerce law.

-- There is something of pathos in the almost constant failure of the Carlisle football players to win from their white antagonists honors more substantial and satisfactory than those incidental to a victor's respect. That sort of glory is, of course, by no means insignificant or worthless, and not a few successes give rewards far less precious, but nevertheless human nature is not content, much less happy, because of it.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Nov. 8. -- The State Railroad Commissioners, with the aid of experts in railroad building and engineering, to-day made a thorough technical examination of the section of the New York Central Railroad near Garrison's where the State express was wrecked and twenty-one persons were killed on Sunday morning, Oct. 24.

" The Louisville Journal has been compelled by the loss of readers to abandon its hostility to silver, and announces that it will hereafter support the Democratic platform without reserve." -- "Matthew Marshall" in The Sun.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Nov. 8. -- At 2:30 o'clock this morning Howard Shafer, son of the late Ira Shafer, who lives with his wife, mother, and sisters in the Shafer homestead, a beautiful country place on the banks of the Hudson at Oaks, opposite this city, was aroused by a noise in the hall down stairs.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 8. -- Attorney General Monnett, W.L. Flagg of New York, and Edgar B. Kincade of this city, acting upon information furnished by George Rice, a Marietta oil dealer, presented to the Supreme Court in Chambers to-day an application for a rule in contempt against the Standard Oil Company.
The Small Parks Advisory Committee met in the Mayor's private office yesterday and submitted to the Mayor a report recommending where small parks and playgrounds should be laid out in the city.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- United States Fish Commissioner John J. Brice has submitted to the President a summary of the work accomplished by the Fish Commission since Dec. 1, 1896.

DULUTH, Nov. 8. -- A big real estate swindle has been unearthed here in which New York and other Eastern investors, together with Chicago, St. Louis, Minneapolis, and Cleveland men, have been defrauded out of about $200,000. The men who worked the scheme are thought to be the same who victimized a number of Eastern people on the same property several years ago.

Arthur D. Williams, John Sabine Smith, and G.W. Young, the Commissioners appointed by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court to pass upon the practicability, desirability, and advisability of construction and operation of the railroad approved by the Rapid Transit Commissoners, yesterday presented to the court a report which is the outcome of their investigation into the merits of the questions referred to them and in which they favor the building of the road.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9. -- Charles Goorbach, a cigar manufacturer, on Norris Street, near Fourth, to-day attempted to kill his father-in-law, Frederick Fritz, and the latter's son, Joseph, of 2,020 North Fourth Street, by shooting them. He then sent a bullet through his own brain, and died soon after being admitted to the Episcopal Hospital.

The Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York yesterday announced that the company has adopted with other prominent life insurance concerns new and uniform tables of premium rates, based on the American table of mortality, at 3 1/2 per cent. interest, which will go into effect on Jan. 1, 1898, and that it is intended that reserves on policies issued at the new rates shall be computed upon the same basis.

Illinois Central gross earnings for September increased $436,148 and net $94,752. For the month of October gross earnings increased $109,388. Kansas City, Memphis and Birmingham's earnings for the fourth week in October decreased $18,335 and for the month $35,184. Northern Pacific showed a decrease for the fourth week in October of $36,285 and an increase for the month of $196,396.

William Cauldwell, former proprietor of The Sunday Mercury and until recently owner of the Hotel Empire, was arrested yesterday on Broadway by Deputy Sheriff Walgering, in a suit brought to have him removed as one of the trustees of the estate of the late Jason Rogers, the millionaire locomotive builder, and charging him with having converted to his own use over $200,000 of the trust funds of the estate.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 9. -- The Supreme Court decided yesterday the case of the Erie Railroad against the City of Newark on appeal. The case is decided in favor of the railroad company. The City of Newark opened a street across the tracks of the company. The company was awarded in the lower courts the sum of $250 for the expense of planking and similar work.

WOODBRIDGE, N.J., Nov. 9. -- Samuel Coddington, Postmaster of this place, received a letter this morning from John R. Ames of Barre Centre, N.Y., saying that his son, Harry Ames, twenty-eight years of age, had escaped from the Willard Asylum on Aug. 30, and had not been heard from.

The Richmond Board of Canvassers met at the Court House in Richmond yesterday for the purpose of canvassing the vote cast at the election. Owing to legal complications which poured in upon the board an adjournment was taken to this morning to give the members of the board a chance to find out where they stood.

BOSTON, Nov. 9. -- The first persons to get into line for the sale of Harvard-Yale football tickets that opened this morning gathered in front of Wright Ditson's store last evening at 6 o'clock. They were five boys, and they appeared at the same time. When the sale opened, the line extended along Washington Street, round the corner of Franklin Street, and quite a distance down that street.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9. -- The Select Council to-day at a special meeting approved the ordinance leasing the Philadelphia gas works to the United Gas Improvement Company for a period of thirty years. The ordinance passed by a vote of 25 to 13, after a session lasting from 10 o'clock this morning until after 6 o'clock to-night.

PARKERSBURG, West Va., Nov. 9. -- A battle to the death between a United States Deputy Marshal's posse and a gang of desperadoes, occurred Sunday at the hamlet of Mudd Lety, in the mountain fastnesses of Nicholas County.

The Republican County Committee in Kings County met last night for the first time since election day, and, though there was a great deal of talk about harmony, the harmony all disappeared when a motion in the interest of the Platt faction was introduced. The Platt people made a considerable stride in the direction of attaining their project for making the County Committee smaller, and therefore more easily mnanageable.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9. -- Clarence New, until within a week Corporal of Company G, Fourth Infantry, United States Army, stationed at Fort Sheridan, has been "busted." His comrades are told this in the post bulletin.

Charles Schlegel, sixty years old, a grocer living at 251 East Seventy-seventh Street, early yesterday morning, it is alleged, murdered his wife Caroline, twenty years his junior, by shooting her behind the ear with a pistol. He then attempted suicide by cutting his wrists with a shoemaker's knife.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 9. -- The convention which meets here to-morrow of the United Daughters of the Confederacy has attracted the most prominent women of the South and several from New York. Mrs. Fitzhugh Lee, President of the society, has arrived, as have most of the other officers and delegates.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Nov. 9. -- A remonstrance against allowing Chinese coal miners to be imported into the State for the purpose of mining coal at Wilmington and other towns in place of the striking miners was placed before Gov. Tanner to-day in the name of the United Mine Workers of Illinois. The Governor was asked to cooperate with the State Secretary of the Miners' Federation in keeping out the coolie labor.

MILLEDGEVILLE, Ga., Nov. 9. -- The negro section of the Georgia Insane Asylum burned to-day. There were within the walls at the time the fire broke out inmates and all over 700 persons, but the efficiency of administration was such that no lives were lost.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9. -- Illinois Central earnings for the quarter ended Sept. 30 were: Gross earnings, $6,505,958, against $6,199,541 for the corresponding period last year; increase, $306,417. Operating expenses, $4,779,739, against $3,385,835 last year; increase, $910,904. Net earnings, $1,726,219, against $1,330,706; increase, $395,513.
After an attempt to murder his wife in their apartments last night, John Falihee, twenty-one years old, of 240 West Forty-sixth Street, shot himself in the temple and died almost instantly.
TUCKAHOE, N.Y., Nov. 9. -- A combination of bees and boys caused some unusual exercises in the Methodist Episcopal church here Sunday.

LONDON, Nov. 9. -- In spite of a thick drizzle and heavy fog Horatio David Davies, the newly elected Chief Magistrate of London, was presented to the representatives of the Sovereign and to the people to-day with success. The usual throngs of people lined the route, and the decorations were more ambitious than usual.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- The Cabinet today gave consideration to the ice-bound Bering Sea whaling fleet. Two plans have been decided upon -- one to send the Bear from Seattle, which cannot be made ready for two weeks, and another to send the Thrasher, a whaling vessel now at San Francisco.

Joseph H. Franklin, General Manager of the Harlem Branch of the New York Central Railroad, was the first witness in the trial of the contest of the will of Joseph Richardson before Surrogate Fitzgerald yesterday. Mr. Franklin said that he knew Mr. Richardson quite well, and had called on him several times during his last illness.

Two sessions of the Executive Committee of the National Sound Money League were held in the headquarters of the organization on the sixth floor of the Bowling Green Building yesterday. Some significant statements were made, on very high authority, regarding the attitude of the Administration at Washington on financial questions.

Twenty-seventh Street, between Fourth and Madison Avenues, was a busy spot yesterday, for from sunrise until sunset carpenters, roofers and laborers were busily engaged in building the wooden annex where a number of horses entered in the coming Horse Show, which opens next Monday, will be stabled during the week of the show.

The first of the certificates of election to be filed in the County Clerk's office yesterday was that of Asa Bird Gardiner, District Attorney-elect, who spent $2,663.52 for printing, banners, and flags, and newspaper advertisements.

CARSON, Nov. 9. -- In revenge for an alleged wrong to his sister, Julian Guinan, aged sixteen years, shot and fatally wounded Charles Jones, United States District Attorney, late this afternoon. Jones died soon after the shooting. An hour or two after Jones's death Guinan surrendered at the Sheriff's office.

READING, Penn., Nov. 9. -- Alfred Blatt of Shartlesville was arrested to-day on a peculiar charge. Mrs. Mary Helm, the prosecutrix and a neighbor of Blatt, is the mother of a seven-year-old boy who, up to yesterday, possessed a wealth of hair which hung down his back in golden curls.

State Senator Frank D. Pavey was asked yesterday as to what plan he had formed in regard to the attempt to deprive Senator Platt of his control of the Assembly. He was at first disinclined to talk about the matter, saying that as he had just returned from Europe he was hardly in a position to comment on the political situation in this State.

Instead of its regular monthly meeting the National Sculpture Society met last night to dine with the Architectural League. The joint dinner took place in the quarters of the league on the second floor of the Fine Arts, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street. The Presidents, other officers, and many of the members of the Sculpture Society and Architectural League sat down to a modest dinner about 7 o'clock.

It seems rather a pity that Mayor STRONG'S administration should not be able to spend all the money available for small parks and playgrounds under the act of 1887. Although the act has been in force for nearly ten years, the most valuable work that has been done under it has been done within the last three.
Oppenheimer Hammerschlag have sold to a Dr. Sanderson, for $39,000, the five-story American basement brick dwelling, 144 West Seventy-seventh Street, 19 by 60 by 100

WICHITA, Kan., Nov. 9. -- "Dynamite Dick," a noted Indian Territory outlaw, whose real name is Charlie Clifton, was killed by officers near Checotah, Indian Territory, in the wildest part of the Cherokee Nation, yesterday.
An accident which seriously injured two valuable horses belonging to Dr. George H. Smith of 921 Greene Avenue, Brooklyn, occurred yesterday afternoon.

An examination of the original tally sheets filed with the County Clerk, which was made yesterday by Horace E. Deming and Howard P. Okie, shows that both the Citizens' Union candidates in the Nineteenth Assembly District were elected on Tuesday, Nov. 2. The error in the returns was discovered yesterday, and will be corrected at once by the Board of County Canvassers.
NEW HAVEN, Nov. 9. -- The Fall meeting of the Yale Corporation was held this noon in the Treasury Building.

Unquestionably the regulation of primaries by statute law can be of some use, and existing abuses are so intolerable that the combined movement to promote such regulation is natural. But it would be very easy to seek to much from the law, and to neglect means outside of the law which are indispensable.

LONDON, Nov. 9. -- The brilliancy of the gathering at the Lord Mayor's banquet at the Guildhall this evening was somewhat marred by the tokens of mourning for her Royal Highness the late Duchess of Teck. A majority of the ladies present wore gowns of black or dark gray.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9. -- The National Baseball League began its annual meeting here to-day.

It is reported that Mr. McKINLEY is very wroth with Mr. PLATT and Mr. BLISS over the way in which New York was turned over to the Democratic Party this year, and that he has given rude expression to his feelings. As to the expression, the report may be an error; of the President's resentment there can be no doubt.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9. -- John A. Merrick, a clerk in United States Commissioner Bell's office; Richard M. Merrick, his father, also a clerk in the same office, and Eugene Lindsay, a clerk in the City Prothonotary's office, had a hearing to-day before United States Commissioner Edmunds, charged with issuing fraudulent naturalization papers, and at the conclusion of the hearing they were each held in $5,000 bail for court.

The Presidents and Faculties of the leading colleges do not appear to regard football as a brutal and dangerous sport. They have sometimes complained that excessive interest in the game diverted the attention of students from their class work and have found it necessary to impose restrictions upon training and playing. But recent inquiries reveal no disposition to prohibit the game as being too dangerous.

-- All the ambitious persons who strove for office at the recent election, including those who won and those who didn't, are now obeying the remarkable law in relation to campaign expenses. Some of the candidates do what that law nominally forces them to do -- that is, they tell exactly the purposes for which their money was spent.

The fourth panel of talesmen in the trial of Constantine Steiger, or Fritz Meyer, for the murder of Policeman Frederick Smith, was exhausted at noon yesterday with only eleven jurors secured, and a recess was taken until to-day, when it is expected the selection will be completed.

A divorce case now pending in Massachusetts is interesting to our yellow contemporaries on what may be called yellow grounds. The parties are conspicuous, and the case seems to turn upon the question whether the wife, who sues for a divorce upon the ground of her husband's infidelity, had forfeited her rights by desertion.

Justice George F. Roesch of the Fourth District Court, in a decision yesterday places the Rev. Daniel C, Potter in possession of his study in the Church House, 162 Second Avenue, from which he was forcibly ejected on March 3 last, and also decides that Miss Julia Ross shall be restored to possession of the third, fourth, and fifth floors in the same building, from which she was ousted about the same time.

Mrs. A. De Witt Cochrane showed yesterday that she is an able as well as a plucky golfer by going the rounds of the Ardsley Club links, saturated as they were by moisture, and with intermittent showers falling during the game. The contest was the semi-annual tournament for the women's championship of the club, and Mrs. Cochrane's efforts were rewarded with victory.

SPRING VALLEY, Ill., Nov. 9. -- The news that Chinamen are to be imported into the mines at Carbon Hill is not considered very seriously at this place. Men stood around the corners to-day in knots discussing this latest phase of the strike situation in Northern Illinois. But the coolies did not interest them as much as the reported settlement at Braceville, where it is said the miners have accepted the operators' offer.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 9. -- Lieut. Michael J. O'Brien of the Fifth United States Infantry, who was the prosecutor in the recent sensational trial by court-martial of Capt. Henry Romeyn, has tendered his resignation to Col. Henry Cook, the commander at Fort McPherson.

Emanuel M. Friend, counsel for Mrs. Augusta Nack, made a statement last night to the effect that Mrs. Nack had turned State's evidence against Martin Thorn, with whom she is jointly indicted for the murder of William Guldensuppe, the bath rubber, in June last.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- Trading stamps, which have been used extensively by Washington merchants, were declared to be factors in gift enterprises in a decision rendered by Judge Scott of the Police Court to-day. The trading stamp scheme has caused considerable agitation among tradesmen in this city. An appeal will be taken.
Stock market improved.

Only eight of the one hundred and eight churches invited were represented at the Council called for yesterday to consider the matters at issue between the Tabernacle Baptist Church, of which Dr. D.C. Potter is pastor, and the New York City Baptist Mission Society. The meeting was in the Welsh Baptist Church in East Eleventh Street.

An excellent array of golfers turned out yesterday on the links of the Westchester Country Club, at the beginning of the club's annual open tournament. The course is practically the same as last year, with the exception of the first and ninth holes, which have been lengthened, making the circuit of the nine holes 2,516 yards.

What is the meaning of the item "newspaper sketches" which appears in so many of the certificates of campaign expenses filed by candidates? It appears to be something different from "newspaper advertising," which is also a frequent item. Does it mean that newspa pers published in their news columns sketches of the lives of candidates and took pay for the publication?

John N. Golding has sold for Sidney Dillon Ripley and the Knickerbocker Trust Company, trustees, the lot northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Seventy-sixth Street, 27.2 by 120. It is the intention of the purchaser to erect on the lot a fine residence for his own occupancy.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10. -- Every trace of the weakness which has prevailed in the wheat market lately disappeared to-day. Strong cables and reports of serious damage by frost in Argentine caused a very substantial opening advance, which was added to later by the large export engagements, May closing at two-cent advance.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Nov. 10. -- On the arrival of the New York steamer Puritan at the dock in this city it was said that a man who registered as H.H. Brown, a railroad contractor, on his way from New York to Boston, died aboard the steamer in the Sound about 7 o'clock last night. The Medical Examiner in this city said death was due to heart disease.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- The board on naval reorganization, which has been in session in the room of the Chairman, Assistant Secretary Roosevelt, has adjourned for ten days, at the end of which time it is expected that each of the four committees appointed' will have embodied in form to be recommended as the basis of legislation the views agreed upon in the meetings already held.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10. -- The Yukon Company of Seattle, Wash., to-day executed a contract with the Roach Shipbuilding Company at Chester, Penn., for two 5,000-ton steamships to ply between Seattle, Wash., and St. Michael, Alaska, to connect at the latter point with the fleet of twelve Yukon River steamers now being built by Moran Brothers at Seattle.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Senor Dupuy de Lome, the Spanish Minister, has received the following cable message from Gen. Blanco, Governor General of Cuba:

The old dishonest outcry against an underground rapid transit railway as a place of foul air, smoke, gloom, and asphyxiation, is disposed of by the report of the Commissioners to the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court:

WICHITA, Kan., Nov. 10. -- The jury of Cherokee Indians that tried M.M. Rowe, a half-blood Cherokee, at the Saline District Court House in Pryor Creek, Indian Territory, yesterday, for the murder of Howling Wolf, held a secret meeting in the woods previous to the trial and decided to find the prisoner guilty regardless of the evidence.

Permit me as a subscriber and constant reader of THE TIMES to express my surprise that your dignified and usually accurate journal has been taken in by one of The Sun's acrobatic feats in reporting. I refer, of course, to the dispatch forming the basis of your leader on "College Revivals" in Tuesday's issue.

In The Beacon, (New York,) June 21, 1845, I find the following paragraph by the editor, Gilbert Vale, concerning George Washington Matsell, a famous Tammany man, who was the first to fill the then new office of Chief of Police. It seems worth reading at a time when another Tammany leader is chosen to be the first Mayor of Greater New York.

The regular monthly meeting of the Trustees of the New York Public Library was held at the Astor Library Building yesterday afternoon. John Bigelow presided, and all the Trustees except Bishop Potter and Alexander Maitland were present.

The position which you have taken and defended so ably throughout the recent campaign deserves the heartiest commendation from all good citizens, and the public spirit displayed by your present attitude and by your promise of giving to the new administration all possible support in securing good government for our city is just as admirable.

Up-country Republicans take a gloomy view of the future of the State organization. While dyed-in-the-wool partisans profess to find satisfaction in the fact that Seth Low was not elected, yet that does not, they say, compensate them for the defeat of Judge Wallace and Gen. Tracy.

BERLIN, Nov. 10. -- The result of the municipal bye-election at West Preignitz, Prussia, Province of Brandenburg, where Herr Schulz, the Radical candidate, has been elected by a vote of 7,481, as against 5,999 cast for Herr Saldern, the Conservative candidate, is highly significant of what is likely to happen at the next general Reichstag elections.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Senor Jose Canalejas of Madrid arrived in Washington to-day, accompanied by Capt. Vega and Saint Aubin of Madrid. Senor Canalejas speaks good English, but with a marked Spanish accent. Discussing the feeling in Madrid on the Cuban question, he said:...

There were two little rows to enliven the routine business of the Police Commissioners at their meeting yesterday. A vote had just been taken adopting a resolution of Chief McCullagh's remanding ten Detective Sergeants to patrol duty, when Commissioner Parker said that under no Circumstances would he oppose any recommendation of the Chief.

PARIS, Nov. 10. -- Wagner's opera, "Die Meistersinger," was performed this evening at the Grand Opera House for the first time in Paris. It was presented under the title "Les Maitres Chanteurs," splendidly staged, and performed by French artists with immense success.

TORONTO, Ontario, Nov. 10. -- A correspondent telegraphs an extended Interview with William Ogilvie, Surveyor of the Department of the Interior, who left Ottawa for the Yukon country June 19, 1895, and is now on his return.

Perez M. Stewart, Citizens' Union candidate for the Assembly in the Nineteenth Assembly District, who, it is thought, was elected, instead of Solomon C. Weill, the Tammany candidate, was so confident of going to Albany yesterday that he gave out a statement to the effect that he would support Mr. Laimbeer for the Speakership of the Assembly.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 10. -- The New York State Federation of Women's Clubs met in annual session in this city this morning, and will continue to-morrow and Friday. There are two hundred clubs in the federation, and each club sends two delegates to this, the third, annual convention.

Although Superintendent and Chief Engineer C.C. Martin of the New York and Brooklyn Bridge has declared that the bridge authorities cannot provide a path for cyclists, the city Consuls of the League of American Wheelmen are preparing to settle on a feasible plan and to urge its adoption at the earliest moment.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Experts representing the United States, England, and Canada assembled at the State Department about 2:30 o'clock this afternoon and began a conference in respect to the Bering Sea sealing question. There were present Messrs. Jordan, Thompson, and Magoun. In addition, Gen Foster and Mr. Hamlin were in attendance for the United States, and Sir Louis Davies for Canada.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- The November report of the Statistician of the Department of Agriculture, issued to-day, gives 23.7 bushels as the average yield per acre of corn throughout the country, according to the preliminary returns of the department's correspondents. The corresponding preliminary estimate last year was 27.3 bushels, and that of 1895, 26.2 bushels.
TUSKEGEE, Ala., Nov. 10. -- Owing to the yellow fever the dedication of the Mary Stearns Agricultural Hall and addition to the Normal Institute has been postponed until Nov. 30.

BOSTON, Nov. 10. -- The annual dinner of the Home Market Club was held at Mechanics' Hall in this city to-night. The most distinguished guests were Congressman Nelson A. Dingley of Maine, Congressman Charles A. Russell of Connecticut, Congressman Jonathan P. Dolliver of Iowa, and Senator Henry Cabot Lodge, all of whom made speeches.

PARKERSBURG, West Va., Nov. 10. -- Fuller details of the desperate battle between United States Deputy Marshals and outlaws in the little Methodist Church at Muddlety, Nicholas County, Sunday morning, were received here to-day.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Supervising Special Agent Chance has submitted his annual report to Secretary Gage.

In your issue of this date a correspondent who signs himself "Taxpayer" attacks a proposed ordinance having for its object the introduction of a system for a thorough and, as far as possible, uniform numbering of buildings in this city. Among other extraordinary statements, "Taxpayer" informs us that "the present system of house numbering is good enough for all purposes," and he furthermore promptly suspects a "deal."

SEATTLE, Nov. 10. -- Cameroc C. Burns, a young college boy of Kalamazoo, Mich., arrived this afternoon from Dawson City on the steamer Homer. He left Dawson Sept. 23, and, poling up the Yukon to the head of Lake Linderman, crossed the Chilkoot Pass to Dyea.

TACOMA, Washington, Nov. 10. -- Missionaries, supposedly belonging to the Christian Missionary Alliance, having headquarters in New York, were attacked six weeks ago by an angry mob of 5,000 Chinese in Hunan Province, Central China. Only a brief account has been received, which does not say whether any missionaries were killed.

Mrs. Augusta Nack confessed yesterday in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court of Queens County that she helped Martin Thorn, the barber and one of her lovers, to murder and butcher William Guldensuppe at Woodside, L.I., on June 25, and to drop fragments of his body in water and on land along Manhattan Island.

One of the most interesting lectures ever given in this city was delivered last night at the American Museum of Natural History under the auspices of the American Ornithologists' Union before an audience of nearly 1,000 persons by Dr. Daniel Girard Elliot, Fellow of the Royal Society of England, on "A Naturalist's Expedition to East Africa."

LONDON, Nov. 10. -- Lord George Hamilton, Secretary of State for India, in a speech at Acton this evening, defended the "forward policy" pursued in India during recent years against attacks lately made upon it by Mr. John Morley, Mr. Herbert Asquith, (Home Secretary in the last Liberal Government,) and other Liberal leaders.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Representative Lemuel Ely Quigg made his appearance in Washington to-day, called upon the President, and freely communicated his views on several topics to a reporter, who wrote them out very fully.

SAN DIEGO, Cal., Nov. 10. -- The steamer Albion, which has arrived here from Mexcan ports, had as a passenger from San Benito to Santa Cruz, Prospero Moraes, the leader of the recent revolt in Guatemala. Moraes talked very freely among the other passengers about events in Guatemala. He was very bitter against Fuentes.

Mme. Eloise Kutcherra, who, it will be remembered, appeared in New York three years ago in grand opera with the Abbey Grau forces and afterward with Walter Damrosch, denies that she intends to abandon the operatic stage. She has been engaged to sing at the Colonne concerts in Paris this Winter, and will also sing in Bordeaux, Berlin, Frankfort, and Brussels.

One KELLEY, who is on trial in New Hampshire for murder, seems to admit that he did the murder in question, but to maintain that he would prefer not to be punished for it. There is nothing surprising about his position so far. What makes it rather unusual is the explanation he gives of his preference.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Nov. 10. -- It has been long known that the Grand Trunk Railway was desirous of tapping the Ohio coal fields. To-day it is authoritatively announced that it will, within six months, be running trains into Toledo.

SIMLA, Nov. 10. -- Official dispatches received here to-day from the British camp in the Maidan Valley tell of a "reconnaissance" in force by the British which turned out to be quite a boomerang engagement.

Section 122 of the Dingley law, "An act to provide revenue for the Government and to encourage the industries of the United States," provides that "there shall be levied, collected, and paid upon iron in pigs imported from foreign countries a duty of $4 per ton."

ALBANY, Nov. 10. -- H.E. Jacobi, a stonecutter employed on the Capitol, was arrested on Monday by detectives from Vermont on the ground that he had violated the excise law of that State. He was taken from the State without requisition, and complications may follow.

The New York Board of Trade and Transportation, at its monthly meeting yesterday afternoon, adopted a resolution for the appointment of a committee of five to prepare a measure for the purpose of limiting the height of buildings which may be here-after erected in the city, and to secure its passage by the new Municipal Assembly.

The news leaked out yesterday that arrangements had been made by Juan M. Ceballos, the well-known banker and President of the Produce Exchange, to give a dinner to Don Jose Canalejas y Mendez, Spain's special representative to this country, who was sent here, it has been alleged, for the purpose of bribing members of the Cuban Junta.
Further statements of expenses incurred in the recent election campaign were filed by candidates in the County Clerk's office yesterday as follows:

All the repairs and alterations to the battleship Iowa have been completed. The final work on the steam-steering gear of the vessel, which was damaged while the ship was on her way to this port from Boston, was finished at the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday.

The public hearing given by the Board of Street Openings and Improvements yesterday developed vigorous and righteous opposition to the plans of the Department of Public Works for the extension of Riverside Drive across the Manhattan Valley. The plan is just the sort of scheme the public would expect from the official who proposed to convert the lower end of Central Park into a desert of asphalt.

BETHLEHEM, Penn., Nov. 10. -- The Right Rev. Ethelbert Talbot, D.D., LL.D., was this evening elected Bishop of the Episcopal diocese of Pennsylvania. Dr. Talbot is at present Missionary Bishop of Wyoming and Idaho.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 10. -- It is expected that Yale's line-up when it meets Harvard at Cambridge Saturday will be as follows: Hazen, left end; Rodgers, (Captain,) left tackle; Marshall, left guard; Cadwalader, centre; Brown, right guard; Chamberlin, right tackle; Hall, right end; Desaulles, quarter back; Benjamin, half back; Dudley, half back; McBride, full back.

PRESCOTT, Arizona, Nov. 10. -- A deed of trust from the Santa Fe Pacific Railroad to the Union Trust Company of New York, was filed for record here to-day. The amount involved is $16,000,000, and includes the railroad and telegraph line belonging to the railroad company beginning at Albuquerque and extending to Needles, together with all rolling stock and improvements.

TACOMA, Nov. 10. -- The rebellion in Formosa continues, and it seems impossible for the Japanese Government to suppress it. Six officials of the Formosan Government were attacked by natives early in October while making a tour of investigation. Five were killed and one escaped. Over 200 rebels attacked the Bitokaku lighthouse, intending to destroy it and thereby wreck Japanese vessels due that night.

RUTLAND, Vt., Nov. 10. -- The appearances to-day are that the great controversy for the control of the Central Vermont Railroad system, which was .apparently settled at the recent bondholders' meeting in favor of the Grand Trunk Railway, may be reopened.

NEWBURYPORT, Mass., Nov. 10. -- The Electrolytic Marine Salt Company has been incorporated at Portland, Me., with a capital stock of $10,000,000. The purpose of the company is to wrest from the sea the gold that is held in solution, according to the promoters belief, by a jealously guarded secret process.

Section 33 of the Tariff act was construed by the Board of United States General Appraisers yesterday in a manner that will disappoint a hundred or more importers whose protests are overruled. This section relates to the assessment of duties on goods consigned to interior points, and deals particularly with cases which arose under the Treasury Department's interpretation of the exact time that the new Tariff act went into effect.

LONG ISLAND CITY, Nov. 10. -- The Rev. R.H.P. Miles, pastor of the First Presby terian Church of Ravenswood, to whom it is declared Mrs. Nack made her first confession, said to-night that he had not attempted to work on the Nack woman's feelings.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- The indications are that the Inter-State Commerce Commission will issue an order in compliance with the petition of the American Warehousemen's Association against the railroads of the country, requiring the railroad companies to publish on their tariff sheets and otherwise a uniform time for completing the delivery of freight of all classes.

ALBANY, Nov. 10. -- The Appellate Division of the Third Department has agreed with Justice Chester in vacating the order compelling the Coal Trust Presidents to appear before a referee. The court does not decide the question of constitutionality of the law, except through Justice Landon, who dissents.
Judge CHESTER'S decision in the case of the coal roads under the so-called anti-trust law has been sustained by the Appellate Division of the Third Department by a vote of 4 to 1.

The Milbank Memorial, which is the western wing of Teachers College, on Morningside Heights and One Hundred and Twentieth Street, was dedicated with impressive ceremonies yesterday afternoon. The exercises were held in the Memorial Chapel, an exquisite piece of architecture and mural decoration that occupies part of the west wing.

CORONADO BEACH, Cal., Oct. 30. -- The end of my hurried trip through this great Republic is drawing nigh. I left Louisville, Ky., over the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, and after waiting for an hour or so at North Vernon, proceeded on my way to St. Louis. At a station about sixty miles east of St. Louis three gentlemen entered the parlor car.

The trial of Martin Thorn for the murder of William Guldensuppe will be begun again to-day. The jury that was impaneled to try the case will be discharged this morning, and the work of drawing a new extra panel of 200 men will be started.

RUTLAND, Nt., Nov. ll. -- The ennington and. tuth%nd Railway Conxpany has just refurrded its bonded indebtedness by paying off !t.s. 0]d ? per cL-nt, bolds and replacing' them by 4Y._, per cents. The old debt was created-in 1877 and was $475.(K). The new mortgage is to secure bonds for $500, tX)0, the principal of tile bonds being payable Nov. 1, 1927.

BOSTON, Nov. 11 -- While death was near her, Miss Lizzie Anna Larrabee of Wilmington on Tuesday was married to Charles E. Clark, a Harvard Law School student, to whom for some time she had been engaged. The young people were acquainted in Maine before they made their home in Wilmington, and had planned to marry after Mr. Clark should complete his college course.

The truth of the rumor that gained currency yesterday to the effect that the Metropolitan Street Railway Company and the Third Avenue Railroad Company had come to an agreement whereby both were to use the same set of tracks on Amsterdam Avenue, was positively denied last night by Edward Lauterbach and William H. Page, Jr., of counsel for the Third Avenue Company.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- The President has detailed Passed Assistant Surgeon Eugene Wasdin and Passed Assistant Surgeon H.D. Geddings, United States Marine Hospital Service, for special duty at Havana, Cuba, for the purpose of making bacteriological investigations into the cause and nature of yellow fever.

From the three designs submitted in the final competition for a building for the New York Public Library -- Astor, Lenox and Tilden foundations -- on the old Bryant Park reservoir site, the trustees have selected that prepared by Carrere Hastings of 44 Broadway. This plan, according to the terms of the competition, is subject to such alterations and changes as may be deemed necessary or advisable by the trustees.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 11. -- The death of young Gannon at Atlanta and other sad results of football have caused the women of this city to begin a crusade against the game. At a meeting of the King's Daughters, composed of some of the most prominent women here, a unanimous vote was recorded against football.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- Secretary Sherman, Minister Romero of Mexico,, and Minister Meron of Argentina, members of the Executive Committee of the Bureau of American Republics, were at the White House to-day and presented the first volume of the Commercial Directory of American Republics to President McKinley. There was considerable formality about the matter, the presentation being made in the Blue Parlor. Secretary Sherman presented the volume, saying:

LONDON, Nov. 11. -- At the second day's racing of the Liverpool Autumn meeting today, D. Seymour's five-year-old bay mare Sapling, ridden by "Tod" Sloane, the American jockey, won the Liverpool Stewards' Plate.

-- That Kentucky decision reported yesterday, by which building and loan associations are forbidden to charge their members more than 6 per cent. for the use of money, is surprising in that it seems to place this sort of borrowing on the same footing with ordinary loans. It has generally been held that they are quite different in principle.

At Lexington Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street last night at 10:30, John McGovern, twenty-one years old, of 600 West Forty-fifth Street, made a bid for public sympathy and an effort to promote excitement by suddenly falling and giving really creditable imitation of man who has been run over by a cable car.

William Murphy, twenty-two years old, of 77 Coles Street, Jersey City, was arraigned before Police Justice Nevin yesterday, charged with assaulting Peter Leonard, fourteen years old, of 325 1/2 Eighth Street. It developed from the evidence that the charge should have been assault with intent to kill, as Murphy had knocked young Leonard down and kicked him almost to insensibility, and then tried to throw him in front of a railroad train.

ALBANY, Nov. 11. -- Justice Merwin wrote the prevailing opinion of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, Third Department, whose decision was handed down yesterday sustaining Justice Chester in vacating the order compelling the Presidents of certain coal carrying railroads to appear before a referee in proceedings under the anti-trust law.
The temporary advantage gained on Wednesday by counsel for Fritz Meyer, now on trial for the murder of Policeman Smith on Oct. 26, was lost yesterday.

Civil Justice William F. Moore of the Third District Court was attacked by a middle-aged woman at Sixth Avenue and Eleventh Street at 10 o'clock yesterday morning. The woman, who is the wife of Abraham Levon, a plumber and contractor of 293 East Fifty-second Street, was arrested by Patrolman White of the Mercer Street Station.

Mrs. Annie Haber of 139 Walton Street, Williamsburg, yesterday at the point of a revolver drove two City Marshals who wanted to dispossess her out of her rooms. The woman has a fourteen-year-old son, Louis. She was several weeks in arrears on rent, and the landlord brought dispossess proceedings against her in the Second District Civil Court.

The Mecklenburg County (N.C.) Commissioners have given a plot of land thirty feet square in front of the new Court House in Charlotte for the erection of the monument to the signers of the Mecklenburg Declaration of Independence. Four thousand dollars of the $6,000 desired for its erection has been subscribed.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. ll. -- A special meeting of the Board (f Directors of the Oregon Improvement Company was held here yesterday for the purpose of authorizing the transfer of the company's property recently sold in Seattle to the Reorganization Committee for $1,000,000. k motion authorizing the transfer of the property to the committee was passed, but the date Was not setrled.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- The President to-day appointed Sardis Summerfield United States Attorney for the District of Nevada.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 11. -- The special committee of fifteen appointed by the last General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church of the United States of America, met in its first session at the Denison Hotel this morning. Dr. John L. Withrow of Chicago is Chairman. The committee is to endeavor to solve the home mission problem of the Church, to report its solution to the next General Assembly.

Readers of The Sun may remember that that ingenious journal invented during the municipal campaign one Prynne Coxe, member of Good Government Club C, to whom it imputed absurd sentiments which it produced as characteristics of the spirit of reform and nonpartisanship. It seems that a newspaper
Douglas, R'0binson Co. have sold for the estate of Theodore T. {oran the dwelling, 4 West Fifty-third Street, -5 by 98.9.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- At to-day's session of the Bering Sea conference the report of Prof. Lucas upon the habits of the seal was read, as were also the reports of Messrs. Jordan, Thompson, and Macoun. The reports of Profs. Jordan and Thompson had not been exchanged heretofore. The papers led to considerable discussion, which was, generally speaking, of an amicable character, although some marked differences of opinion were expressed.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 11. -- The sophomore-freshman cane spree was held in front of Pod Hall last night. The cane spree is an ancient custom, and has been held annually in Princeton. In the seventies it was not recognized by the Faculty, so it was held on Nassau Street in front of the Post Office.

" Our objects are strictly business," Lord SALISBURY said at the Lord Mayor's banquet, in expounding the colonial expansion of England. In general that is quite true. The man-of-war follows the trader, as BISMARCK said it should also do in the expansion of Germany. By adhering strictly to business, Great Britain has succeeded in acquiring an enormous amount of business.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 11. -- Harvard's line-up Saturday in the football contest with Yale probably will be: Cabot, left end Swain, left tackle; Bouve, left guard; Doucette, centre; Shaw or Haskell, right guard; Donald, right tackle; Moulton, right end; Garrison, quarter back; Dibblee, left half back; Swain or Warren, right half back; Warren or Houghton, full back.

EN ROUTE TO KLONDIKE, FOOT OF MILES CANON, Oct. 9. -- We have succeeded in reaching this point in safety with but few mishaps and none serious, though some just missed being so. We have just shot the rapids at this point in safety, and will go on at once, as we wish to get over the White Horse Rapids to-night if possible.

HAVANA, Nov. 11. -- At a meeting of the Central Committee of the Union Constitutional Party to-day, held under the Chairmanship of the Marquis of Pinar del Rio, it was resolved to send a cable message to the Queen Regent protesting against the establishment of autonomy and requesting her not to sign or sanction any decree establishing an autonomous regime in Cuba.

The third and final day's session of the American Ornithologists' Fifteenth Congress was held yesterday in the library of the American Museum of Natural History, in Central Park, at Seventy-seventh Street. The most interesting paper read was undoubtedly that presented by William Dutcher, Chairman of the Committee on the Protection of Native Wild Birds.

The anti-Platt leaders asserted yesterday that they would not take part in the execution of any plan looking to the reorganization of the Republican Party that did not include the retirement of Congressman Lemuel E. Quigg as Chairman of the County Committee.

BRINDISI, Italy, Nov. 11. -- Letters received here to-day from Athens say that the torpedo scandal continues to be the sensation of the Greek capital. As cabled on October 28, it had then just been ascertained that all the cartridges fitted to the torpedoes during the war between Greece and Turkey were not provided with percussion caps and fulminating mercury.

At daybreak yesterday the big pier of the Atlantic Transport Company, at Houston Street and the North River, was freighted with a curious burden. Solemn elephants stalked about, hundreds of horses and ponies cavorted, neighing, and from a vast collection of red and gold cages issued the roaring of lions, the yells of hyenas, and the barking of bristly faced seals.
ALBANY, Nov. 11. -- Gov. Black issued his first Thanksgiving proclamation to-day. It is as follows:

The jury appointed by the Academy of Design to select and decide upon plans for the new home of the Academy, to be erected on the site purchased at One Hundred and Tenth Street and Amsterdam Avenue, on Morningside Heights, opposite the proposed Cathedral of St. John the Divine, met yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 11. -- It is now certain that a change must be made in Yale's football eleven at the last moment. Charles Dudley, left half back, received news tonight that his mother died at Washington this afternoon. He was summoned home, and will be gone for several days. It is thought, however, that he will return in time to line up against Princeton next week Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11. -- Secretary Sherman and Sir Wilfrid Laurier, the Premier of Canada, this afternoon began the first of a formal series of conferences for the purpose of bringing about an agreement by which as many as possible of the questions now causing friction between the United States and the Dominion of Canada may be adjusted amicably by treaty or otherwise.

The annual report of the business of the Manhattan Railway Company has a bearing upon the plans of the Rapid Transit Commission which it will repay the people of New York City to study attentively. We subjoin the financial statement of the report for the year ended Sept. 30, in which the results of the twelve months' operations are compared with those of the previous year:

The work of the Citizens' Union for the next four years, whatever else it may be, must be one of education of the voters. We do not for a moment entertain the idea that the Union will dissolve, or that it will abandon so noble an enterprise in which they have accomplished so much.

VIENNA, Nov. 11. -- When the Reichsrath reassembled to-day, the President rejected a series of motions upon the part of remembers of the Left for a roll call of votes, declaring it was the duty of the President to maintain Parliament in a condition to perform its functions, and not to treat the rules of procedure as though they were established for purposes of obstruction.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 11. -- Frederick Fishel, alias "Pinkey," who absconded with $19,000 belonging to Alexander Ullman, a layer of odds at the Morris Park race course, on Oct. 30, was arrested here today at the Imperial Hotel. He made a full confession, and said he had lost all the money on the races since leaving New York.

" The Results of Ten Years of Municipal Progress" was the subject discussed before the Nineteenth Century Club at its first meeting of the season last night at Sherry's. The speakers were Gov. Hazen S. Pingree of Michigan and Herbert Welsh of Philadelphia, one of the leaders of the National Municipal League.

PRINCETON, Nov. 11. -- The Presbytery of New Brunswick met in the First Presbyterian Church here to-day to pass upon the case of the Rev. Dr. Charles Woodruff Shields, Professor of Revealed Religion at Princeton University, who tendered his resignation as a member of the Presbytery because of the criticism aroused by his action in signing the application for a liquor license for the Princeton Inn.

The Executive Committee of the Citizens' Union met last night at 39 East Twenty-third Street to take preliminary steps in effecting a permanent organization to conduct for the next four years a campaign on the issues in behalf of which the battle for Seth Low and non-partisanship in municipal affairs was fought.

Senators O.H. Platter of Connecticut, Nelson W. Aldrich of Rhode Island, and James K. Jones of Arkansas and Representatives Walter Evans of Kentucky, Charles A. Russell of Connecticut, and Benton McMillin of Tennessee, members of the joint Congressional committee appointed to propose a plan for the repeal of the tax on alcohol used in the arts, began a three days' hearing at the Murray Hill Hotel yesterday.

The McKinnon life-saving davit, for use on naval and merchant vessels, was tested at the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday. A number of naval officers and men interested in shipping affairs were present to see the new device operated and inspect its mechanism and construction.

CHARLESTON, Ill., Nov. 11. -- The case of Attorney Alfred C. Ficklin was brought to a close this afternoon by his being sent to the insane asylum. Fecklin is the son of the late Orlando B. Ficklin, who married a sister of Alfred H. Colquitt, formerly Governor of Georgia. Ficklin the elder was well known all over the West.

HARTFORD, Nov. 11. -- "His Little Dodge," Justin Huntley McCarthy's comedy, so successfully produced at the Royalty Theatre, London, last season was given at the Parsons Theatre to-night. The company included M.A. Kennedy, Mabel Amber, Henry Bergman, Harold Russell, Sallie Berg, and Charles Sturges.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. ll. -- The Spartan father has a counterpart he'e. His devotion to duty has resulted in the conviction and imprisonment of his son, Dr. Horace E. James, %who was a candidate last year on the Democratic ticket against Gen. H. H. Bingham. The case was kept very quiet until yesterday, when the action of the Judge who presided at the trial, two weeks ago, in reducing the sentence brought it to light.

CANTON, N.Y., Nov. 11. -- Asa Briggs, the eighty-three-year-old farmer of Hannawa Falls, nine miles from here, who was shot by a masked man last night, is still alive, but has no chance of recovery. His daughter, who was shot in attempting to protect her father, is doing well and is in no danger of death.

Traditional sentiment regarding the hesitancy of young ladies to engage in sports or open-air exercise in rainy weather was badly shattered yesterday on the links of the Ardsley Club, when six teams of women golfers appeared bright and early to compete in the first open match of this kind ever held.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 11. -- At the second day's session of the annual convention of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs and Societies the routine business was lost sight of to a considerable degree in the contest for the office of President of the organization between Mrs. William Ted Helmuth of Sorosis, New York, and Mrs. L.V.L. Lnych of this city.

The anti-machine Republicans in this city were made happy last night by John E. Milholland's report that President McKinley had taken a stand against Senator Platt and the machine forces in this State. Mr. Milholland went to Washington on Tuesday and on Wednesday was closeted with the President for more than an hour discussing the situation of the Republican Party in New York.

The proposal to give a public dinner to Mr. LEMUEL ELY QUIGG at once excites curiosity upon what ground the banquet is to be "tendered." Public dinners are commonly offered in recognition of some public service or of some signal personal success. Unsympathetic mankind does not invite a new-made bankrupt to a banquet in order to celebrate his bankruptcy, and yet something like that would be the significance of a public dinner to QUIGG.

William Berri, President of the New York and Brooklyn Bridge Trustees, said yesterday that there was no cause for alarm on the part of the public over the running of trolley cars on the bridge or in the four loops at the New York end.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 12. -- An ordinance prohibiting Rugby football was introduced in the House of Delegates by ex-Speaker Hirman G. Lloyd, at the meeting of the body to-night. The increase in the number of accidents and fatalities is responsible for the bill. Mr. Lloyd says the game as played now is worse than prize fighting.

The last session of the fifth annual meeting of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers ended last night with a dinner at Delmonico's. About 150 members and guests were present, and Assistant Secretary of the Navy Roosevelt came from Washington to address them.

Flowers in great profusion filled the ballroom of the Hotel Astoria yesterday, when the floral exhibition of the New York Gardeners' Society was opened. Every available space, including the conservatory and foyer was dense with foliage and blossoms. The exhibition is for the benefit of the Loomis Sanitarium for Consumptives at Liberty, N.Y.
LONDON, Nov. 12. -- At the third day's racing of the Liverpool Autumn meeting to-day, Lord Stanley's four-year-old bay colt Chiselhampton won the Liverpool Cup.

BOSTON, Nov. 12. -- Yale and Harvard, after an intermission of three years, will meet again on the gridiron at Soldiers' Field in Cambridge to-morrow. No contest between the two universities ever aroused greater interest than the one to be decided to-morrow, and the enthusiasm of the alumni and undergraduates of both institutions is at the boiling point.
Some 300 leading Republicans of the Twenty-fifth Assembly District gathered in the hall at the "Chimney Corner," Twenty-fifth Street and Sixth Avenue, last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- Definite arrangements have been made for taking up the subject of a reciprocity treaty between the United States and Canada, and to this end meetings have been fixed between John A. Kasson, who is delegated by President McKinley to conduct reciprocity negotiations, and Sir Wilfrid Laurier, the Canadian Premier, and Sir Louis Davies, Minister of Marine.

-- None of the reports coming from Alaska prove, or even indicate that he who goes to the Yukon country must of necessity experience hardship and danger. It seems to be merely a matter of foresight and preparation, and he who has the one and makes the other can probably live and work there the year round about as comfortably as on a New England farm.

Superintendent Elliott of the State asylum in Flatbush has again refused to accept Catherine Meyer, the old woman who has been the subject of a long controversy between the State and city authorities in Brooklyn. She is mentally unbalanced, but Dr. Elliot declares that she is merely childish from old age, and not, therefore, insane within the meaning of the law.

Elizabeth Stuart Phelps, (Mrs. Ward,) whose "The Gates Ajar" and "The Madonna of the Tubs" have given her such fame as falls to the lot of few American women authors, in "The Story of Jesus Christ" is thoroughly conscious of the enormous difficulties such a subject presents. In the preface she states that the book "is not theology or criticism, nor is it a biography."

LONDON, Nov. 12. -- Striking evidence of Spain's financial straits is furnished in the dispatch of the Madrid correspondent of The Daily Mail, cabled, saying the Spanish Government, finding it impossible to raise the sum of 3,000,000. ($15,000,000,) by loan or taxation, to carry out its original naval plans, has decided to build two new cruisers only of 2,000 tons each.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12. -- The National Baseball League magnates were in session here this afternoon from 1:30 to 5 o'clock, and adjournment was then taken until to-morrow morning. It is expected that the meeting will be concluded to-morrow. One of the important results of to-day's meeting was the abolishment of the Temple Cup series of post-season games, which have been played between the clubs ending first and second the last four seasons.

RALEIGH, N.C., Nov. 12. -- The stockholders of the Raleigh and Gaston Railroad met here yesterday. Mr. Ryan of New York was represented by Attorney J.W. Hutchinson, Jr., of New York. President Hoffman's report was objected to by Hutchinson and John Windor, but the present management was indorsed by a vote of 11,870 to 21 shares. President Hoffman and all the old Directors were re-elected by the same vote. E.W. Fuller was elected a Director.

While the decision of the Appellate Division of the Third Department on the coal roads case does not go to the constitutionality of the Lexow law, the ground on which it is based is singularly significant of the character of the law.

Nat C. Goodwin, the comedian, was a witness in the City Court yesterday in supplementary proceedings instituted by the Gillin Printing Company, which is trying to collect the amount of a judgment against Manager G.B. McLellan of the Casino for printing done for McLellan when he was touring the country with the opera company headed by his wife, Pauline Hall.

A report reaches this city from Washington that the name of Joseph H. Choate has been suggested to President McKinley for the prospective vacancy in the office of Attorney General, and that his appointment is being urged by the independent Republicans of New York as an appropriate recognition of their element of the party in this State.

The New York Local Assembly of the Brotherhood of St. Andrew met yesterday afternoon in he vestry building of St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Church, 29 Vesey Street. Two hundred business and professional men were present.

ProL Rodolfo Lanciai's volume is Intended as a companion book for students and travelers who visit the existing remains ad study the latest e.ca,'ations of ancient ROme, and to his previous admirable works, -Ancient Rome in the Light of 11eeent Discoveries" and "Pagan and Christian Rome," .which have.brought him such deserved fame and reputation as an archaeologist, historian, and explorer.

William H. Sands, who recently won the St. Andrew's championship for the third successive year, won the Country Club Cup yesterday in the final round for the principal trophy in the Westchester Country Club's open golf tournament. His opponent was M.R. Wright of the Philadelphia Country Club, and the contest was a close and interesting one.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 12. -- Martin Ensley of Memphis, was placed on trial to-day before Judge Hirzel at Clayton, the county seat of St. Louis County, on the charge of assault with intent to kill Charles D. Collins, at Meramec Highlands, one night last June. He is also charged with stealing $6,000 from Collins.

MOUNT PLEASANT, Iowa, Nov. 12. -- Warren Wallace Beckwith, who eloped with Miss Jessie Lincoln, the daughter of Robert T. Lincoln, returned to this city last night, alone but not disconsolate. He is a true athlete, and when he gave his word to the Captain of the Iowa Wesleyan football team that he would be here Friday to practice for Monday's hard game with Monmouth, his Captain knew that nothing would detain him.
Will you kindly give in the highly esteemed NEW YORK TIMES (daily or SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS AND ART) some account of St. Ronan, also of St. Ronan's Well, its location, and the reason for its name?
Slawson Hobbs have sold to Frank H. Presby, representing Mrs. Elizabeth S. Clark of Cooperstown, N.Y., (the Clark estate,) the following vacant lots and plots:

In the Summer of 1887 I had a great bit of good fortune in seeing in his retirement at Annecy the author of those splendid compilations and critical essays on the English dramatists, Henri Taine, the most accomplished writer of his day on literature.

VIENNA, Nov. 12. -- The Unterhaus discussed to-day the proposal to impeach the Ministers for an alleged violation of their Ministerial powers by the issuance of a decree authorizing the official use of the Czech language in Bohemia. The members of the Left retired from the chamber at the beginning of the sitting, after a declaration that they would readily co-operate in a constitutional settlement of the question, if necessary, by peaceful compromise.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12. -- John A. Logan today forwarded the cash book of the Horse Show to the Board of Agriculture, thus completing his report on the recent display of blooded horses and Fall toilets at the Coliseum. It is said Mr. Logan disposed of the funds of the show in making the management of the exhibition popular with a lavish hand.

News of the death of Francis Turner Palgrave was cabled from England a fortnight ago, and the event was duly commented on in this newspaper. But Palgrave was a man who ought not to be dismissed in a single article. His was the unique distinction of having acquired, merely by compiling an anthology, a degree of literary reputation such as comes only to authors who write very successful books.

The opponents of the underground rapid transit railroad are hard pushed for arguments. Their main reliance now is the constitutional debt limit. If we issue bonds for $35,000,000 for this road, they argue, we shall incur all the indebtedness the Constitution permits, and thereafter, no matter how urgent the need, we can borrow no more money.

In your Review of Books and Art of to-day an article upon "surface impressions of New York after an absence," impels me to offer a suggestion which was many times imparted to me by the late Homer Martin in expeditions which took us in various ways across the bay and rivers of our city.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- It is the intention of Chairman Cannon of the Appropriations Committee of the House to begin the preparation of the appropriation bills at the earliest possible date. He has announced the appointment of the sub-committees, and those on the Pension and the Legislative, Executive and Judicial bills have been called to meet Nov. 27, a week in advance of the assembling of Congress.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- Secretary Alger has issued regulations governing the use and occupation of lands within the limits of the military reservation of St. Michael, Alaska. The regulations are substantially as follows:

VICTORIA, B.C., Nov. 12. -- The steamer Farrallon arrived from Skaguay and Dyea yesterday with sixty returning prospectors and several officers of the customs and police returning from Lake Tagish. She brings the news that a horse tramway is being built at Skaguay and that works are being established and an undenominational church erected.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12. -- Bishop Charles C. McCabe caused considerable surprise among the members of the General Missionary Committee of the Methodist Church to-day when he announced that he had established an Alaskan mission. He said he had borrowed $400 and sent a missionary into Alaska, and that the latter was now ministering to the spiritual wants of the gold diggers.

In an editorial contained in your issue of the 9th inst. you have fallen into a strange confusion that does me great injustice. My article in The North American Review upon the Cuban question was "based upon facts accessible to everybody." After the same investigation you could have written the article just as well as myself, as every matter specially derived from my official station was carefully avoided.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- Senator Thomas C. Platt appeared at the White House this morning carrying a bundle of papers. It was assumed by those who saw him that they related to appointments which he wishes to have made as soon as possible. He was with the President a long time, but he had nothing to tell as to the nature of their conversation.

On the date of Sept. 28, 1897, I wrote an article in regard to the so-called industrial stocks, which you kindly published. I called particular attention to Sugar stock, which I said and emphasized most emphatically as being a menace to the general market on account of its gymnastic gyrations -- the company whose balance sheets no one has been able to even get a glimpse of.

COLD SPRING, N.Y., Nov. 12. -- Interest is waning in the Coroner's investigation of the Garrison disaster, and the Town Hall in this village held not more than half its usual crowd of curious people when the third session was held to-night. Coroner William T. Wood presided, with District Attorney Southard as examining attorney. Railroad Commissioners Ashley W. Cole and Frank M. Baker were present.

NEW BRUNSWICK, Nov. 12. -- Dr. Charles W. Smith of Rahway was called upon to plead at the Court House here this morning to the charge of polluting the city's supply of drinking water by bathing his patients in Lawrence Brook, from which the supply is derived. Dr. Smith is the head of the American Medical Co-operative Association of Rahway and has a sanitarium near Lawrence Brook.

PENN YAN, N.Y., Nov. 12. -- Judgments have been filed in the Yates County Clerk's office against Stephen W. Van Deventer and Albert R. Van Deventer, his son, amounting to $21,178.28, in favor of Susie M. Van Deventer. This is the outcome of a legal action brought to compel the fulfillment of an ante-nuptial contract.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12. -- O.W. Potter, S.W. Rawson, and H.A. Ware will retire from the Directory of the Commercial National Bank at the end of the present year. These Directors opposed the election of Controller James H. Eckels to the Presidency of the bank, and their resignations are taken as a protest against the changes in the personnel of the bank's officials and also against anticipated changes in the policy of the institution.

The authoritative forecast of Mr. LAURIER'S mission to Washington promises an entire Winter's entertainment. The errand last upon his list, but quite the first in interest, is to arrange an entering wedge for the growth of reciprocal commerce. None will wish him success more than we, nor will any one be more curious to see how he will work it.

Mr. Christie Murray in his "My Contemporaries in Fiction" says pleasant things and sometimes does not. As to the modern men, Mr. Christie Murray writes: "You may draw a triangle, and at one of the extremes you may place Meredith, at another Stevenson, and at another Hall Caine." And the critic talks of Meredith's "cataclysmic eloquence."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- The President to-day issued the following proclamation:

That good music is rowing in the esteem of New Yorkers received a new demonstration yesterday at the first public rehearsal of the Philharmonic Society in Carnegie Hall. The auditorium was packed, as it has not been since the days when all the women transformed themselves into Queens of Sheba and went up to learn wisdom from the Solomon of the piano.

The Pleasure Palace has procured Auguste Van Biene for a dramatic sketch, and also Edward J. Henley, who will appear Nov. 29. Robert J. Downing, the tragedian, is under contract to appear Dec. 13, in the arena scene from "The Gladiator."
OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 12. -- The physicians of Omaha are puzzled in regard to the nature of an ailment that has become epidemic in the city.
TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 12. -- Gov. Leedy, in his Thanksgiving Day proclamation, hits at defamers of Kansas. He says:

Pilate's question, "What is truth?" is a very important question. It is well for every man to carefully consider it, because what he esteems as essential truth makes him what he is. Not what he merely considers true, but what is vitally so -- the truth itself; so true that he believes in it, hopes to attain it, and clings to it with his heart's best affections.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Nov. 12. -- A strong combination of steel tubing manufacturers has been perfected, and the new corporation will represent 90 per cent. of the tubing output of the United States. The combination is made up of the Brewer Seamless Tube Company, the American Weldless Tube Company of this city, the Shelby Tube Company of Shelby, Ohio; the Ellwood Tube Company of Ellwood, Penn., and the Greenville Tube Company of Greenville, Penn.

Seen at sunset from the roof of the gigantic hotel at Fifth Avenue and Thirtyfourth Street, the city appears stretched out at the foot of a mountain that rises like a Pike's Peak from the plain of roofs. We are slow in putting up cathedrals, but with what alacrity do we not construct temples reaching to the skies, wherein to worship the modern gods of comfort and luxury!

Bertram, fourth Earl of Asburnham, had a brother, who, like himself, was a devoted collector of books -- the Hon. Percy Ashburnham. The sons of peers seldom collect books. Other pleasures less intellectual, less innocent, more commonly claim their devotion. Rarely, indeed, has a peer reared two sons who both took to this pure and ennobling hobby.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 12. -- James R. Sovereign, who has been General Master Workman of the Knights of Labor for the past four years or more, was this afternoon relieved of his office by the General Assembly, which has been in session in this city since Monday last. Under ordinary conditions, Mr. Sovereign's term of office would not expire until the next meeting.
In their weekly review of trade, Messrs. R.G. Dun Co. to-day will say:

A golden jubilee celebration in commemoration of the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of he North Presbyterian Church, at Ninth Avenue and Thirty-first Street, will begin to-morrow at 10:30 A.M., when the "Trumpet of Jubilee" will sound from the choir gallery. The Rev. S.B. Rossiter, D.D., pastor, will conduct the exercises, which will be of a varied and interesting character.

I am one of those who greatly appreciate THE SATURDAY REVIEW OP BOOKS AND ART of my TIMES, and who rejoice in its success --an evidence of the intelligence and taste of the Greater New York public very comforting after the mournful exhibition of the opposite qualities last Tuesday.

M.H. Tichenor Co. of Chicago brought a number of prize winners at the recent Horse Show in Chicago to this city and sold them at auction yesterday, at the American Horse Exchange. The sale was one of the best of the year and the prices and attendance were almost as good as those produced by the sale of Oliver H.P. Belmont's shown Horses a few weeks ago.

The eleven remaining members of the jury impaneled to try Martin Thorn for the murder of William Guldensuppe were formally discharged yesterday morning, and the hearing of the case was postponed until next Monday week, Nov. 22. This decision was reached after protracted consultation and after Mr. Howe, for the defense, had submitted propositions for continuing with the eleven jurors as a basis, and one new man to fill the panel.

Undoubtedly the popular notion of the Klondike region has become that it is a "placer" which will be exhausted of its surface gold within one or two Summer seasons, and will then revert forever to its primitive solitude and savagery. That has been the case with regions much more favored by nature in respect of climate than the region within the Arctic Circle, where cold and darkness reign much more than half the year.

There will be a recognition service and pastoral installation at the Bethesda Congregational Church, at Ralph Avenue and Chauncey Street, Brooklyn, at 4 o'clock on Tuesday afternoon. An ecclesiastical council will meet on that occasion for the purpose of making the necessary inquiry and extending to the new church the fellowship of the Congregational churches.
