The Brooklyn and Jamaica Bay Turnpike Company filed its certificate of incorporation at Albany yesterday. It is said to be the first organization of the kind formed under the State laws for twenty-five years. The termini of the road are to be at Rockaway Beach, in Hempstead, and Old Mill Creek, in Jamaica.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Nov. 12. -- Three men classed first as tramps, but who now are supposed to be of a more desperate class of criminals, entered the saloon of J.Q. Doyle, on West Bridge Street, about 7:45 P.M., and with drawn revolvers ordered those present to throw up their hands. At the time there were in the saloon Mr. Doyle, his barkeeper, James Ash, R.W. Snyder, Doyle's brother-in-law, and Thomas Baggs.

The past week has not been an over lively one in art circles. One or two minor exhibitions, the eighth annual display of the New York Water Color Club in the Fine Arts Galleries, and an interesting little showing of drawings and etchings by Charles Keene of Punch at the Keppel Gallery have, however, given pleasure to art students and lovers.

Hallam, Lord Tennyson, in the biography of his father, asserts that Mr. Gladstone hesitated to offer the poet a coronet on the curious ground that he wore a wide-awake hat instead of a tall silk one. Hallam, Lord Tennyson prints the journal kept by himself while on a yachting trip with Gladstone and his father, during which the offer was made.

Yesterday was the last day allowed for the filing by candidates of their certificates of election expenses, and those who failed to comply with the law -- and there are many, although the exact number was not ascertained -- will have to explain their negligence before the Grand Jury or be fined and imprisoned.

An interview with Mr. W.D. Howells, published in a newspaper in Paris, where Mr. Howells has been staying, contains views of American literature, the tone of which an English critic describes as "specious complacency." He is represented as entirely satisfied with our realistic school, including Miss Wilkins, Miss Jewett, Brander Matthews, and Hamlin Garland, "who are doing excellent work of the Jane Austen sort."

My attention has been called to the remarkable statements of your Boston correspondent, under date of Nov. 4, in your Review of Books and Art of last Saturday. It would be hard to find a more vivid imagination than that of your correspondent, and if you place his future communications concerning school matters under the title of "Interesting Fiction," I think they will be appreciated at their true value.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- William J. Coombs of New York, who acted in an advisory capacity to the Government in connection with the sale of the Union Pacific Railroad, is in the city for the purpose of conferring with the Attorney General respecting the affairs of the Central Pacific. The conference is to take place to-morrow.

Lawson N. Fuller is indignant and tired. His indignation found vent last Tuesday in the filing of a suit for $68,333 against the Manhattan Railway Company, and his weariness is due to that corporation's lack of appreciation of his many years of incessant toll and public speaking in its behalf, as well as in the interest of rapid transit.

The Board of Commissioners for the Soldiers' and Sailors' Memorial adopted yesterday afternoon the design, "No. 6," of Arthur A. and Charles W. Stoughton for the monument to be erected on the Plaza of fifty-ninth Street, Fifth Avenue, and Central Park. The choice was made upon the recommendation of a special committee, appointed by the Commissioners. Eight designs were submitted.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- Cabled reports from Valparaiso of the existence of a plan for a dreibund of Chile, Peru, and Argentine with the purpose of seizing and dividing Bolivia attracted considerable attention in diplomatic circles here to-day, but hose who are well informed concerning South American affairs are inclined to question them.

BERLIN, Nov. 13. -- The visit of Count Goluchowski, the Austro-Hungarian Minister for Foreign Affairs, to King Humbert at Monza, and its attendant circumstances, are regarded in German political circles as being of the highest importance. The Conservative and Agrarian newspapers interpret the visit as meaning a closer understanding between Austria-Hungary and Italy and as a leaning of those two powers toward Great Britain.

Are we to take literally the Earl of Rothes's saying, "that if a man were permitted to make all the ballads, he need not care who should make the laws of a nation''? If this dictum have some small proportion of truth in it, there is much more of what is positive in the effects of the early school book on a people.

The close of another week's dealings finds the Boulevard lot still occupying the position of supremacy. One vacant corner on Fifth Avenue and two on Park Avenue have diverted attention momentarily, but the Morningside district has shown that it is the chosen field both of the speculator and the investor.

! LONDON, Nov. 13. -- In the three-quartermile charapionship footrace at the Calford Grounds to-day. F. E. Bacon beat E. C. Brodin by four yards 1n.3:21N. Each man led alternately, but Bacon went to the front on entering the stretch. The wind interfered with the time.

The long predicted has come. There is stress and storm in American cotton mills. Too much machinery has been installed. Too many mills have been built. Massachusetts has led the way on reducing hours of labor and suffers from her liberality.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Nov 13. -- The Arbuckles have repudiated their contract with the Ohio Wholesale Grocers' Association. The following is a copy of a confidential circular issued by the Woolson Company, and the Arbuckles have issued a similar one, except as to fixing selling price:
DENVER, Nov. 13. -- The football game between the teams of the East Denver and West Denver High School students ended in a riot, in which all the players and a Couple of hundred spectators took part.

The annual meeting of the State Association for the Protection of Fish and Game will be held in the Yates Hotel, Syracuse, at 10 A.M., Thursday, Dec. 9. The meeting is called at this time in order to give the Law and Legislative Committee time to prepare the proposed amendments to the fisheries, game, and forest law and to be able to present them to the Legislature at an early date.

BINGHAMTON, Nov. 13. -- Scientists in this city are puzzling over an aerial visitor that dropped in this vicinity early this morning. Prof. Jeremiah McDonald, who resides on Park Avenue, was returning home at an early hour this morning when there was a blinding flash of light and an object buried itself in the ground a short distance from his premises.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 13. -- Harvard and Yale played each other to a standstill this afternoon on Soldiers' Field. For two thrilling hours the two sturdy elevens struggled over the white-lined gridiron, desperately disputing every inch of territory and vainly essaying to cross the coveted goal line.

LONDON, Nov. 13. -- The prophets who last week were so busy with predictions of the great political light and leading to be gathered from Lord Salisbury's Guildhall speech, were. as I foresaw, doomed to disappointment. Never has Lord Salisbury said so little or said it so feebly. The whole thing was, at its best, but the brief blither of a tired old man cowed by a younger and fiercer personality.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 3. -- Modern Belgium bids fair to rival ancient Flanders as the great centre of European art, particularly in the domain of public art. In 1894 there was founded in Brussels the "National Belgium Society for the Development of Art in Its Application to Street Decorations, and to All Objects of Public Usefulness."

A paragraph appeared in this column last week stating that, although a person may dream of falling from the top of a building, the man does not live who dreamed that he struck the pavement. It has been asked, why is it that, although we may dream of the most attractive food and drink placed before us, we never dream of devouring the repast?

The movement which was begun last Spring to introduce and domesticate in the Southern States the lecture platform system, which has flourished so long in the New England States and has played so important a part in advancing the ideas and methods of that robust section of the Union, has passed the experimental stage and reached a point where its complete success is no longer a matter of doubt.

Bicycle racing men discussed little else yesterday than the feat of Charles Murphy of the Kings County Wheelmen, who is credited with riding a genuine mile Friday afternoon in 1:00 4-5, on Twenty-second Avenue, from Eightieth to Sixtieth Street, Brooklyn. Added information on the ride, which is the fastest ever ridden for the distance, so far as is known, leaves little doubt of its genuineness.

May Irwin's return to the metropolis needs no trumpeting. She will appear at the Bijou Theatre to-morrow night in a new farce by H.A. du Souchet, author of "My Friend from India," called "The Swell Miss Fitzwell." The story of the piece is told as follows: A young Frenchman of title, Count de Cagiac, marries a poor American girl.
We arrived at Milan one moonlight night, and, having engaged our rooms at the Venezia and left in them our impedimenta, we went at once to see the cathedral.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 13. -- The new General Master Workman of the Knights of Labor, Henry A. Hicks, occupied the chair this morning when the General Assembly convened, and Past General Master Workman Sovereign occupied a seat in the rear of the room, among the delegates. Mr. Sovereign is the only Past General Master Workman in the order, all the others who have occupied this position having been expelled or died.

The gale was at its height Friday night and boisterous seas were lashing themselves into frenzy along the coast when two sailormen of the Sandy Hook pilot service lost their lives in the performance of their duty.

Indoor golf is to be one of the features of the athletic work of many young society girls this Winter. They are the younger girls, hardly risen to the dignity of society "buds," but they have already been exposed to the contagion of golf, and they will prepare this Winter to be genuine fanatics by the time their school duties are over, and the links are in good condition next year.

It was a clear case of doing evil that good might come. "Such a nice, easy way of earning money for the church," the young people said. "It is a great deal worse when you make such use of the money," said the mamma of the family indignantly. It was nothing more or less than gambling. The young people did not call it that, though.

BOSTON, Nov. 13. -- At the Hotel Vendome to-night, where the Yale eleven is quartered, there is to be found no trace of melancholy and discouragement. On the contrary, a feeling of greatest satisfaction permeated the whole Yale contingent because of the fact that a team, made up of men whom they chose to call green at football, made such a showing against Harvard's magnificent eleven.

The duplicate and class matches were decided at the Seventh Regiment ranges last night. The former is for teams of two men, not necessarily of the same company, the team having the greatest number of comparisons, shot for shot, to be declared the winner of the first prize. There were three prizes, each divided into two equal parts.

" How to Teach English in the Elementary Schools" was the subject of discussion before the Schoolmasters' Association of New York and vicinity, which held its regular monthly meeting yesterday in the Law School of the New York University. Superintendent William H. Maxwell of the Brooklyn public schools led the discussion, and his remarks were listened to with marked attention by a large number of members and guests.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 13. -- An opinion handed down in the United States Circuit Court of Appeals holds that the boycott is not a legal weapon. The decision will be of interest to the labor organizations all over the country, inasmuch as it upholds the right of corporations to introduce their saving devices into their establishments.
Every one has his own idea as to what will constitute a happy marriage, but there is one point on which nearly all agree -- the wife must not be older than the husband.

Chicago, ever in the van of progress, has just started a "Human Nature Club." The announcement, it is true, may have a momentarily startling effect, for, by all accounts, there is a good deal of human nature in Chicago, and much of it is apt to manifest itself in a manner which gives anxiety and even sometimes affords employment to the police.

The season of grand opera in French, German, and Italian to be given at the Metropolitan Opera House under the direction of Walter Damrosch and C.A. Ellis will open on Monday evening, Jan. 17. It will continue for five weeks, during which period twenty performances (fifteen evening and five matinee) will be given on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday evenings and Saturday afternoons.
VINTON, Iowa, Nov. 13. -- The first week of the Novak murder trial closed with one of the most interesting climaxes that ever characterized any trial in the history of the State.

I found her up in New York State near the border, and a delightful find she was -- such a kindly, hospitable old soul, always ready for a chat with the Summer boarder. She had lots of common sense and good judgment, but her proverbs and ancient saws and her constant Malapropisms were a source of continual amusement to her hearers.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13. -- No mere average citizen of Chicago can hope to keep track of the crookedness which distinguishes everything connected with the business of the city. What the special character of the rascality may be is not very evident on its face, but that there is plenty of chicanery at the bottom of the recently collapsed garbage contract there are plenty of symptoms to indicate.

Let no one make the mistake of supposing that the Manhattan Railway Company is hostile to underground construction. Its opposition to the plans of the Rapid Transit Commissioners is limited to their particular hole in the ground. Meanwhile its own subterranean operations, dating from a period long anterior to the organization of the present commission, have been extensive, far-reaching, and peculiar.

PHILADELPIA, Penn., Nov. 13. -- What was intended to have been a four-round bout between Joe Butler, the colored pugilist, of Philadelphia, and Jack Bonner of Summit Hill, Penn., at the Arena to-night was stopped in the second round, and Butler was placed under arrest for an attempt to assault the referee.

LONDON, Nov. 13. -- The speech of the Marquis of Salisbury at the Guildhall on Tuesday last, Lord Mayor's Day, again proved him to be past master of saying nothing in many soothing words. It was essentially a peace speech, and did not contain a single indication of how far the Government is prepared to go in Indian, Egyptian, Soudan, or Niger affairs, beyond a general "what can be done will be done."

The verdict of $30,000 damages against the New York, New Haven and Hartford Company for the death of Dr. MIXSELL is the most conspicuous result thus far of an amendment to the Constitution which went into effect two years ago. This was the amendment providing that the right of action to recover damages for injuries resulting in death should never be abrogated, and that the amount recoverable should not be subject to any statutory limitation.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13. -- The annual Fall meeting of the National Baseball League was brought to a close this evening. The double umpire system was adopted. It was announced that a regular schedule for umpires would be prepared. Provision was made for the suppression of rowdyism on the ball field, and it was decided to have four trips between the sections instead of two, as heretofore.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 13. -- The work on the mortar battery at Fort Adams and at Dutch Island, where two twelve-inch breech-loading rifles are to be placed, has been so well advanced that by next Spring twelve ten-inch mortars and two twelve-inch breech-loading rifles will be in readiness to protect Narragansett Bay.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13. -- The statement was made to-day that the visit of Sir Wilfred Laurier, the Canadian Premier, and Sir Louis Davies was arranged at London during the Queen's Jubilee, when conferences were held between Lord Salisbury, Mr. Chamberlain, Secretary of State for the Colonies, and the Canadian officials.

THAT the horse will have more to do with the annual Horse Show in future years is a certainty. The recent sale of boxes for this year's exhibition proves that conclusively. The affair has palled on the butterflies. Musicales, dinners, dances, and vaudevilles at the Astoria seem destined to be the fad.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Nov. 13. -- A prominent bicycle manufacturer of this city to-day announced that a pool has been formed of ten or twelve of the leading manufacturers of medium-grade bicycles, and that they will fix a scale of prices and practically control the output. The same information was substantiated by another manufacturer later in the day, although details are somewhat meagre.

Many a golfer who played in the big interclub team contest yesterday on the links of the Westchester Country Club declared he had never before played his favorite sport in such blustering weather. The wind fairly howled around the clubhouse, and the rolling whitecaps in Pelham Bay were another potent reminder of the gale that was blowing.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 13. -- The dead bodies of Henry Turner and those of his wife and sister were found in a potato patch in Campbell County to-day. They had been shot to death and brained. Bloodhounds have been called for.

The lack of speculative interest on the part of the public, so apparent just at the present time, and the probability of continued apprehension of Congressional possibilities, has made many of Wall Street's most conservative financiers doubtful of any marked improvement in the security markets for some little time to come.

Thanksgiving week will be as lively as usual in New York this year, and the managers who find that period their harvest time have arranged for good bills. Only Mr. Daly will be out of the field, "The Geisha" occupying his stage, while Miss Rehan and the regular company, having returned hither from their English trip, will give their time to other cities.

THE fame of the elder Dumas rests, first of all, upon his rich and wonderful romances. When his name is mentioned dear memories arise of intrepid d'Artagnan and "Les Trois Mousquetaires," of Edmond Dantes escaping from the dungeons of the Chateau d'If to find that the world was his, of Josef Balsamo and an idealized Marie Antoinette and the faithful Chevalier de la Maison Rouge.

The West Africa question, about which the cable dispatches have so much to say, with meagre actual information, is likely to assume an aspect of vast and serious importance in European diplomacy before the Anglo-French Commission, now sitting in Paris, comes to a definite plan of settlement. The agreement of the commission will place under French or British control extensive areas of the most populous and wealthiest territory on the Dark Continent.

Some time ago, while looking over a wheelbarrow-load of rubbish written to prove that such plays as "King Lear" and "The Merry Wives of Windsor" emanated from one of the least poetical and least humorous minds of modern times, I was reminded of a story which I heard when a boy.

BINGEN, Sept. 25. -- One of the most difficult things in European travel is keeping away from the shopworn tourist routes. Everything tends to sweep the stranger toward them. A definite number of Americans and English are expected in this great world's park every Summer, and they are expected to go to certain places in certain ways.

PRINCETON and Yale will meet on the gridiron at New Haven next Saturday afternoon. It is the most important game of the football season and the one which all college graduates and undergraduates look forward to from the time the two teams begin to practice.

JAMAICA, I.I. Nov. 13. -- The election Inspectors who served in Long Island City and other towns in the county at the recent election were subpoenaed to-day to appear before the Queens County Board of Canvassers, in this village, Monday, and go over their returns. When the board met to-day to canvass the votes, so many mistakes were found that it was decided to summon the Inspectors and have them make corrections.

SIOUX FALLS, S.D., Nov. 9. -- "Indian logic has always been difficult to overcome by the whites who have to deal with the Government wards, but the most embarrassing position I was ever in," said Dr. McGillicuddy, a former Agent at the Pine Ridge Agency, "was when we representatives of the Government sought to treat with the Indians in their religious uprising at Pine Ridge in 1890.

Few important developments have marked the course of business during the week just ended. Of the substantial things that have come to pass, not one has been discouraging. Wall Street has been dull; changes that have taken place in stock market quotations signify virtually nothing of consequence.

DECATUR, Ala., Nov. 13. -- The negro's capability of self-government is being put to an actual test on the ground where he at one time worked as a slave. This is the result of a colony scheme recently inaugurated by Mrs. Lillie K. Ray, who is well known in financial and literary circles. "Cedar Lake Colony" is situated three and a half miles south of this city.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 13. -- Judges Pardee and Newman of the United States Court handed down a decision in the famous dispensary case this morning enjoining the Southern Railroad from refusing to haul liquor into South Carolina in future.
MUNICH, Bavaria, Nov. 1. -- In the year 1575 there was published in Munich, the capital of Bavaria, a ponderous work in five volumes, with a title of which the following is a close translation:

FAR ROCKAWAY, L.I., Nov. 13. -- Postmaster George A. Koch of Woodsburg reported to the authorities this forenoon that the Post Office, which is in his drug store, was broken into this morning by two burglars.

When the trial of Martin Thorn for the murder of William Guldensuppe, the bath rubber, whose dismembered body is supposed to have been found in fragments along the East River and the upper end of Manhattan Island, is begun again at Long Island City, on Nov. 22 , it is certain that there will be one of the strangest and most dramatic episodes in criminal history.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 13. -- It was grand football weather, and a tremendous crowd saw the stubborn but vain struggle.

The Queens County Grand Jury yesterday indicted Mayor Patrick Jerome Gleason of Long Island City on two complaints for misdemeanor, and with him the entire Water Board, of which the Mayor is a member ex officio. The other members are John W. Moore, Commissioner of Public Works; William Smith, President of the Common Council; Water Commissioner Levee, and Frederick Green, formerly Water Commissioner, who resigned recently.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 10. -- The citizens of the little town of Allen, in Lyon County, Kan., will not be surprised any day to see the two rival milliners, Mrs. White and Mrs. Keith, settle their troubles on the public thoroughfare in genuine frontier fashion.

Lord SALISBURY'S speech at the Lord Mayor's banquet, with all its geniality, sounded a distinct note of warning. France was told that England had made concessions in Africa for the sake of peace, but that there was a limit to those concessions. The admonition referred, of course, to the rivalry between France and England in the Valley of the Niger.

The Republican Party was placed in power as a barrier to free-silverism. In so far as it has rendered impossible the passage of a free-silver bill it has fulfilled its trust. But it pledged itself to more than this. It promised to maintain the gold standard until a double standard could be secured through international co-operation.

In a quarrel at 12:10 o'clock this morning in the Gerard House, 123 West Forty-fourth Street, Richard Mandelbaum, thirty years old, a guest of the house, was shot in the groin by James W. Kirk, thirty-one years old, also a guest.

Lewis L. Delafield was asked yesterday what he thought of the attitude of hostility assumed by The Brooklyn Eagle and certain Brooklyn men to the issuing of bonds for building an underground rapid transit railroad in this City. In reply Mr. Delafield made the following statement.

Whatever may be the intent of the party assuming control of the City Government on Jan. 1, it is certain that few, if any, of the reforms inaugurated under the administration of Mayor Strong can be abandoned. Many of them were made possible only by acts of the Legislature, which no future Legislature would care to repeal, while others begun because of urgent need are so far advanced toward completion that retrogression is impossible.

LONDON, Nov. 13. -- The struggle for the control of London's School Board is raging fiercely, and is growing more intense as the time for the elections approaches. The issues are somewhat involved; but, broadly, the contending parties are the Progressives and the Moderates, and the bone of contention is religious teaching in the board schools.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 13. -- The football game between the Orange Athletic Club and Chicago Athletic Club teams at the Orange Oval this afternoon was a very lively contest from start to finish. The weather was just right for good, active work on the gridiron and cold enough to tint with crimson the beautiful faces of the many belles and buds of Orange society, who were out in full force.

HAVANA, via Key West, Nov. 13. -- Dispatches from Madrid say that the officially inspired papers El Correo and La Correspondencia point to the possibility of a division of the Autonomist Party into Radical and Conservative wings. According to these papers the Reformist Party would be dissolved and its elements would form the Radical wing of the Autonomist Party, headed by Senors Jose, Bruzon, Giberga, and Fernando Gonzales.

Among the passengers on the American Line steamer St. Paul, which arrived from Southampton yesterday, were Augustine Daly, Miss Rehan, and many members of the Daly Stock Company. They were all pleased to get back, and several of them who have crossed the sea time and again say that the trip was the roughest they ever experienced.

An interesting fact connected with the ancestry of Mayor-elect Van Wyck which has been overlooked by his biographers is his connection with the famous Maverick family, which gave a new word to the English language in the term "maverick," applied, on the great cattle ranges of the West, to an animal found without the owner's brand.

An account of the quantity and value of the minerals obtained from mines, quarries, brine works, , in the United Kingdom during the year 1896 is given in a Blue Book just issued by the Home Office. Many facts of interest are contained in the report, in addition to the statistical information, but the limitations of space will only permit us to refer to a few of them.

TRENTON, Nov. 13. -- The Democrats are looking for a unifying force, believing that, if they can find it, they can within a short time recover the State of New Jersey. The success of the party in the recent election has had a stimulating effect, and in ever part of the State there is unusual activity just now.

IN presenting a recent and strikingly good portrait of Rudyard Kipling it would be surplus-age to accompany it with anything like a criticism of the English writer who has been within the last few years the most extensively criticised of any. But he has not been so widely criticised as he has been widely read.
THE second annual exhibition in the art galleries of the Carnegie Institute opened in Pittsburg on the 4th, and was honored by the company of the President of the United States.

Only a few more nails remain to be driven, and a few more boards to be laid in the stalls, and the preparations for the annual display of the National Horse Show Association, which is to open at Madison Square Garden to-morrow, will be complete.

The American Line steamship St. Paul got in yesterday, nearly twenty-four hours late, the time of her passage being 7 days 6 hours and 21 minutes. From the time of passing the Lizard, last Saturday, till she reached port she encountered a succession of westerly gales and high head seas, causing delay but no damage.

THE conservative old town of Flushing, now part of our municipality, has put on gala attire, and its people of all faiths have united in honoring a kind-hearted, fatherly old man, who has been a conspicuous figure in their midst for half a century. Dr. Smith has lived out his fourscore years, and is still in vigorous health.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 13. -- The Durrant case has been the topic of the week. Extensive preparations to report the hanging had been made by the local papers before the Supreme Court's decision defeated the sentence.

About 100 women, most of whom were school teachers, assembled last Wednesday afternoon in the larger lecture room of the Young Men's Christian Association Building, 502 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, to listen to addresses on "How Children Reason." The conference was under the auspices of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences, Department of Pedagogy.

There was a unique deposit in the cornerstone of the new building of the Bellevue Hospital Medical College, which was laid yesterday afternoon. It was a sealed glass tube containing living specimens of the bacillus aerogenes capsulatus. These are the oldest identified spores of this species of bacterium, which comes from a certain form of gangrene.

In 1830, on a path in a wood at Somersby, Tennyson came unexpectedly upon a slender, beautiful girl of seventeen, and impulsively said to her, "Are you a dryad or an oread wandering here?" Six years later he met Emily Sellwood again, on the occasion of the marriage of his brother Charles to her youngest sister.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 13. -- Every State in the South is looking to the Georgia Legislature to take the initiative in legislation to prevent the execution of lynch law, the prevalence of which in Georgia and other Southern States during the past few months has aroused feeling in all parts of the Union.

WHEELING, West Va., Nov. 13. -- Private dispatches received here from Internal Revenue Collector White of this district, who is now in Washington in consultation with the United States Attorney General, announce that an appeal will be taken speedily from Judge Jackson's recent decisions construing the tenure of office features of the civil service rules and law.

The fact that 80 per cent. of the actions for divorce are brought by women would appear to tell heavily against the men of the country, but, as a matter of fact, a large percentage of these divorces go by default, which implies either collusion or indifference on the part of the delinquent. Many men, it is estimated, permit the offending wife to bring the suit rather than to disgrace her and her children.

THE fact that Felix Mendelssohn died on Nov. 4, 1847, has called to the minds of some of our local providers of music the existence of a considerable quantity of pleasing music written by him. Englishmen, who have never recovered from the excitement caused by the production of "Elijah,'' an original oratorio, in their country, would doubtless regard with horror the habitual neglect of Mendelssohn's symphonies and chamber music in this country.

Birds driven before the wind are tossed about relentlessly, and they rarely recover their balance after once being caught by the gale. Shore birds are either dashed upon the waves and made to swim for their lives, or they are hurled violently against trees or other objects and killed. Shore birds, when facing a gale, will take every advantage of trees, houses, and hills as defenses against the wind.

Superintendent Jasper of the public schools of this city issued a statement yesterday about the promotion of teachers and increases in salaries. This is the explanation which he promised at the meeting of the Primary School Teachers' Association in the Normal College on Nov. 5. Here is the statement:

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 13. -- The Rev. Dr. Carson of the African Methodist Episcopal Church, now holding its regular annual conference in this city, created a disturbance yesterday shortly after the conference was called to order by Bishop William Benjamin Derrick of New York.

The statements presented to the Congressional Committee of the advantages of untaxed alcohol for use in the arts are entirely conclusive. There is no more reason why domestic alcohol used in manufactures should be burdened with taxation than there is why the corn from which it is made should be taxed. It should, if possible, be made as free as cotton or wool or iron, or any other material of industry.

Assemblyman-elect Francis E. Laimbeer, Alfred R. Conkling, and James B. Reynolds, Chairman of the Citizens' Union Executive Committee, made addresses yesterday morning before the League for Political Education at 509 Fifth Avenue, on the "Lessons of the Campaign." Mr. Laimbeer was the only speaker on the programme for the day, but as Mr. Conkling and Mr. Reynolds were present they were called on.

A runaway horse drawing a buggy containing two men started in Central Park last night at 6:30 o'clock on the West Drive, about a half mile from Fifty-ninth Street, ran out of the Park at the Eighth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street entrance, dashed around the statue in the Circle, and continued madly up the crowded Boulevard.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 13. -- The trolley line of the South Orange and Maplewood Street Railway Company has been completed, and cars are now running from the terminus of the Watchung branch of the Erie Railroad, in this city, to Maplewood, a distance of eight miles.

When a woman went to the East Thirty-fifth Street Police Station last night and asked that a policeman be sent to her home, 236 East Thirty-fourth Street, where a woman acted in such a peculiar manner as to attract general attention, Patrolman McCormick was sent. At the number mentioned, the policeman was taken to the second floor, which he found handsomely furnished.

MADRID, Nov. 14. -- The Bishop of the Diocese of Majorca, Balearic Isles, who last September excommunicated Senor J. Navarro Reverter, Minister of Finance in the Cabinet of Gen. Marcelo de Azcarraga, for an alleged conversion of Church property to governmental uses, is dead.

The Tammany wing of the Progressive Democratic League held a special meeting yesterday afternoon at Flannery's Hall, Hudson and Leroy Streets. Assemblyman-elect James Oliver, who had a walk-over in the Second Assembly District, looked extremely happy. Several of the other delegates who had fought for Tammany also looked pleased in expectation of comfortable jobs when the tiger shall again fasten his claws upon the metropolis.

TACOMA, Washington, Nov. 14. -- Vice President Daniel S. Lamont of the Northern Pacific Railway is here negotiating with Manager Anderson and Director Foulkes of Philadelphia for the purchase by the Northern Pacific of a controlling interest in the Tacoma Land Company. The railroad originally held 51 per cent. of the land company's stock, but several years ago a new stock issue was made, and the railroad did not purchase the shares allotted it.

It seems a little odd that in these closing years of the nineteenth century a Circuit Court of the United States should find it necessary to decide that a conspiracy among workmen to prevent the introduction of a labor-saving machine is illegal. It seems still more strange that of the three members of the court one should be unable to concur in this decision.

The Metropolitan Opera House was packed to the doors last night when the second of the series of Sunday concerts was given. The solo performers were Mme. Marcella Sembrich, the famous soprano; Signor Giuseppe Campanari, baritone of the Grau Opera Company, and Richard Burmeister, pianist.

The meeting of The Jockey Club, which is called for 4 P.M. to-day, promises to be a lively one, and before the session ends some of the trainers and owners who have been loudest in proclaiming themselves members of the Horsemen's Protective Association may be equally loud in declaring that henceforth they are done with the organization.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- Horace White has submitted answers to the interrogatories of the Monetary Commission regarding improvements in the currency system of the United States. Mr. White advocates the retirement of the greenbacks and the adoption of an elastic banking currency based upon business assets.

RAWLINS, Wyoming, Nov. 14. -- Sixty miles to the south of this city, which is the nearest railroad point, and separated from civilization by mountain barriers for a hundred miles to the east, west, and south, in the very heart of the Sierra Madre range of the great continental divide, there is said to have been discovered the greatest gold fields in the whole world.

A little incident in the world's complex trade is related in The London Times. It is the export of a large quantity of Queensland beef and River Plate mutton from London to Cape Town. All the meat was, of course, frozen and had been transported some 6,000 miles before resuming its journey for another 6,000 to its final market.

Frederick Meitzel, mate, and Julius Kaars, able seaman, of the Norwegian brigantine Iona tell a tale of woe, in which they accuse the skipper, Capt. Mosher, of cruelty. The Protestant Episcopal Church Mission Society for Seamen has taken up the case and put it into the hands of lawyers, who will seek to libel the vessel before she clears from Montville, Conn., where she is now lying.
The Central Labor Union had a lively time yesterday afternoon after a committee had reported on charges against George Blair, a labor agitator, and now a box manufacturer.

ASPEN, Col., Nov. 14. -- A fire that may cause the closing down of every big mine in the camp is raging in the eighth level of the Smuggler Mine. The cause of the fire is supposed to be spontaneous combustion, although there are a few who are inclined to the theory that a careless miner started the fire with a candle.

The notion that the Republican Party in New York can be "reorganized" successfully by a struggle in the County Committee over Mr. QUIGG'S Chairmanship while Mr. PLATT remains "neutral" does not rise to the dignity of a delusion; it is sheer humbug. No reorganization will amount to anything unless made by the Republican voters, free to vote at every stage of the process and sure of an honest count and a clean enrollment.

Apropos of the great strike of English engineers, which shows no sign of an early termination, notwithstanding that it has been going on for several months, the latest issue of The Iron Age gives much space to a presentation of opinions of American manufacturers as to the effect of the strike on trade in American machinery and tools.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14. -- With more than $1,000 sewed in his clothing, Samuel Kaufman, a broommaker, who had been in hiding in Chicago for a month, was arrested tonight in a synagogue at 373 Clark Street, by Detective Davidson of the Central Station.

A paper has been announced to appear weekly in the National capital the main purpose of which will be to advocate the repeal of the civil service law, and incidentally to promote the election as President and Vice President of Congressman GROSVENOR and Senator GALLINGER, the special champions of the repeal.
Senator Platt explains the result of the Mayoralty election from a Republican organization point of view in the following statement given out last night:

LEAVENWORTH, Ind., Nov. 14. -- The failure of the banks in Marengo, English, and this city, which was announced yesterday, caused great consternation among business men, many of whom had their entire available capital on deposit in one or another of the institutions. The crash was unexpected, and all of the banks continued to receive deposits up to the hour of closing on Friday.

The curious delusion still prevails that in the late municipal campaign the forces of good government were divided. In his talk to the League for Political Education on Saturday, Assemblyman-elect LAIMBEER performed the autopsy upon the lost cause:

It is the belief of the bull party in Wall Street that in the week just past the bear movement in stocks culminated. Beyond any doubt the bears met defeat during the week. They were aggressive; they made organized and well-planned raids upon the market. In spite of this, however, prices did not go down. On the contrary, quotations advanced.

The cornerstone of the new building of the Universalist Church of the Divine Paternity was laid yesterday afternoon at Central Park West and Seventy-sixth Street. There was a large attendance, but the service in the inclosure made by the half-finished walls had to be cut short because of the cold weather.

LONDON, Nov. 14. -- The correspondent of The Times at Valparaiso, Chile, says that the harvest of cereals will be a third greatest than it was last year, while crops of all kinds promise above the average.

SEATTLE, Nov. 14. -- James H. Hill, President of the Great Northern, has made a good stroke in the cotton exporting traffic. Backed by the Japan Steamship Company's Seattle-Yokohama line, he has been able to make rates from Texas and Louisiana to Osaka and Kobe, Japan, by which he has captured fully half the probable business of the season of 1897-8.

Wholesale and manufacturing druggists report a specially large distribution of staple goods, the week witnessing an activity such as gladdened the hearts of the trade in 1892 and former prosperous years. All branches of the distributive trade are in first-class financial trim, carrying large and well-assorted stocks, making prompt settlements for the same, and reaping satisfactory profits.

A short, stout man with a grizzly mustache and wearing a huge overcoat of sea-otter fur was a conspicuous figure in the lobby of the Hoffman House last night. He registered as "A. Buckley, Dawson City, Klondike," and the fact that he hailed from the land of gold caused him to be besieged with questions from those whose attention was attracted by his unusual costume.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- The first annual report of Postmaster General James A. Gary to the President was made public to-night. Its feature is the strong advocacy of postal savings depositories. Mr. Gary says the time is ripe for the establishment of postal banks, and that the addition of a well-organized system would confer a great boon upon a large number of persons and ultimately be of inestimable benefit to the whole country.
Improvement has come in a natural way.

BISMARCK, N.D., Nov. 14. -- Alexander Coudot, an Indian half-breed, and Paul Holytrack and Philip Ireland, full-blooded Indians, the first of whom was sentenced to death for the murder of six members of the Spicer family, last February, and had just obtained a new trial from the Supreme Court, and the latter two self-confessed accessories in the murders, were taken from the County Jail in Emmons County last night and lynched by a mob.

WESTWOOD, N.J., Nov. 14. -- Last Monday evening the local cornet band practiced in the house of the Continental Hook and Ladder Company. They left about midnight. The house was not opened again until last night, when Aaron Tuers went to the house to open it for a meeting. He found there a bull dog belonging to A.C. Brackett. The dog was almost dead from lack of food.

When there is a plenteous board, with a goodly amount of liquid refreshment on the side, no more jolly party than a crowd of horsemen can be found. All of these conditions were grouped at the annual Horse Show luncheon in the Madison Square Garden restaurant, where yesterday afternoon about 150 gentlemen interested in the big exhibition which will open to-day gathered at the invitation of the Directors of the National Horse Show Association.

The Rev. R. Heber Newton, pastor of All Souls' Church, at Sixty-sixth Street and Madison Avenue, preached yesterday concerning the two hundred and fiftieth anniversary of the Westminster Assembly. He selected his text from Hebrews, Chapter 12, a portion of the twenty-sixth and twenty-seventh verses, which read:

PRINCETON, Nov. 14. -- Princeton now realizes that the game with Yale next Saturday will not be the "snap" that was anticipated before the Yale-Harvard game yesterday. The wonderful defense of Yale has caused much shaking of wise heads among the football coaches and visions of twenty or more points have been rudely dispelled.

Spain has herself to blame for the instant rejection by the Cubans of her scheme of autonomy. Her revolted subjects do not trust her. They do not believe in her good faith. They think she intends to cheat them as she did twenty years ago.
Mrs. Augusta Nack was taken from the Queens County Jail yesterday to point out the place where she said the saw which was used to dismember the body of Guldensuppe was buried.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 14. -- S.H.H. Clark, one of the receivers of the Union Pacific Road, started for New York last night. While on this trip Mr. Clark will meet the other receivers and the Reorganization Committee of the Union Pacific. It is the general opinion that he will return as President of the reorganized railroad.

" What Has Religion Done for Civilization?" was the subject of Prof. Felix Adler's address before the Society for Ethical Culture yesterday at Carnegie Music Hall. A large audience was present, and the remarks of the speaker were listened to with close attention.

DENVER, Col., Nov. 14. -- The gold resources of Colorado have been developed in a manner but little appreciated by those beyond the borders of the State during the past four years. In 1893 the value of the yellow metal mined was but $8,000,000; for the year just closing it will not be far from $22,000,000, an increase of nearly 300 per cent.
The Star Furnace of the Star Furnace Company at Jackson, Ohio, has been put in blast.

The annual meeting of the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States was held at the Astor House yesterday. It was one of the best attended meetings in the history of the union. The meeting began at 10 A.M. and lasted until early this morning.

A discussion was begun yesterday in theatrical circles over the originality of Martha Morton's comedy, "A Bachelor's Romance,'' which has been running at the Garden Theatre with Sol Smith Russell in the leading role.

A good many Americans must have wondered, from time to time, at the evidences of Spanish hostility and bitterness which have been brought to light. The clearer it becomes that Spain has no grievance against us the more active the speculation upon the nature of the grievance which she supposes herself to have.

" It is a wonder people live as long as they do," said a leading physician while conversing with some newspaper friends recently. "Every breath that is taken contains poison. Millions of germs, so small they cannot be seen by the naked eye, are drawn into the lungs, the throat, the stomach, and while many of them die, thousands of them live and feed upon the body and cause what is called disease.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 15. -- Ex-Senator William D. Edwards of Hudson County late this afternoon made application to Justices Van Syckel, Dixon, and Collins of the Supreme Court for a recount of the ballots cast for and against the anti-gambling amendment to the Constitution at the special election on Sept. 28.

LONDON, Nov. 15. -- The newspapers of this city have just received graphic details by mail of the recapture of Dargai Ridge by the Gordon Highlanders on Oct. 20, during which that regiment exhibited remarkable dash and courage.

There was a good deal of mystery connected with three guests at the Gilsey House yesterday. One of them was a fine-looking, gray-haired man, who registered as John Meigs, Pottstown, Penn. Later he turned out to be the Principal of the Hill School, a fashionable academy for boys in that town.
Slawson Hobbs have sold for Dr. Philip B. La Roche, to Oppenheimer Hamershlag, the lot on the north side of One Hundred and Thirteenth Street, 200 feet east of Amsterdam Avenue, 25 by 100,11.

Richard Croker returned yesterday from his journey into the South in search of rest and recreation. He was accompanied by Mrs. Croker, and on the same train were District Attorney-elect Gardiner and Thomas F. Grady. The party left Hot Springs, Va., Sunday night and arrived at the Jersey City Station of the Pennsylvania Railroad a few minutes before 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 15, -- The thirteen members of the National Circuit of Bicyclists have sued the Central Railroad for $26,000 damages for holding their baggage on account of their failure to pay $1.32 claimed for the transportation of Little Pete, the midget mascot from Macon, over the railroad.

It seems to have been agreed beforehand that the Horse Show, as a "social event," is not to be so successful this year as it has been heretofore. This consensus has been reached by a contemplation of the bids this year for the boxes as compared with previous years, and also from a comparison of the names of the bidders.

The French Line steamer La Gascogne, which reached port yesterday morning twenty-four hours overdue, had an encounter with the November seas of the North Atlantic which her passengers will long remember. All incoming vessels have brought reports of the fury of the westerly gales prevailing, but the roughest weather yet reported was met by La Gascogne, and she came in with a damaged bridge, deck fittings awry, and one of her ventilators gone.

NEWPORT, Nov. 15. -- The Summer residents of Newport are not pleased at the prospect of success of the efforts to connect the mill town of Fall River with this resort by a line of trolley cars. The consummation of the project is assured if favorable action can be obtained in petitions which will be presented to the Councils of Portsmouth and Middletown at the next regular meetings of those bodies.

Although the Mayors of New York and Brooklyn did not attend, as they were invited to do, the meeting of cycle association delegates held at the League of American Wheelmen's New York State Division headquarters, Vanderbilt Building, to take action on the question of a cycle path over Brooklyn Bridge, the session was important.

" There are, however, reasons why this session might be short and busy if brevity and business were the consistent aim of the men in charge. The tariff is out of the way, except for a few amendments with a view to increasing the revenue." -The Waterbury American.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Nov. 8. -- The threatened rupture between Germany and Haiti has, so far, been amicably settled, thanks to the mediation of the United States Minister, Mr. W.F. Powell, though it is still understood that Germany intends to make a naval demonstration in Haitian waters. The German version of the trouble has already been published. The following is the Haitian side of the dispute:

Homer W. Nichols of R.H. Bissell Co., stock brokers, was on the witness stand in Surrogate Fitzgerald's court yesterday morning and part of the afternoon, testifying in the Richardson will case. He produced a bundle of papers which he said were all the checks, vouchers, letters, and other papers that came into his possession last April and May, either directly or indirectly, from Joseph Richardson and relating to Richardson's affairs.

LONDON, Nov. 15. -- A Parliamentary bye-election was held to-day in the Borough of Deptford, London, to fill the vacancy caused by the elevation of the late member, Charles John Darling, Q.C., to the Queen's Bench Division of the High Court of Justice, in succession to the Hon. Sir Richard Henn Collins.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 15. -- Katherine Steadman, who committed suicide in New York last night, was the daughter of Peter Kelsen and the wife of William J. Steadman, a driver in the employ of the American Express Company. She was married to Steadman, who was then janitor of the Wieting Opera House, nine years ago.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Nov. 15. -- Lawyer John B. Quinlan of New York, representing relatives of Thomas E. Bradway, who died in Islip on Sept. 5 last, leaving his entire estate to his step-granddaughter, Miss Fannie E. L'Hommedieu, filed notice with Surrogate Petty of a contest of the will. Mr. Bradway lived in Islip for a few years before his death, and came from New York City.

Paul Baur, alias George W. Duval, the young man accused of robbing women, was arraigned before Magistrate Wentworth, in Jefferson Market Court, yesterday afternoon. He was held in $1,500 bail each on the two charges of carrying knock-out drops and robbing Sadie Miller on Oct. 8 at 171 East Thirty-third Street of $600 worth of diamonds and $35 in money.

NEW BRUNSWIK, N.J., Nov. 15. -- The Carlisle College football team spent several hours here this morning. The team, with its managers and rooters, chartered a special car to take them back to the college after the game with Brown at New York, and last night the car was attached to the owl train in Jersey City.
Arthur E. Valois of 22 Broad Street, who for years had been Dr. Evans's attorney, said yesterday: ...

Mayor Hoos yesterday vetoed the plans for Jersey City's new water supply, film his objections with the Street and Water Board. He says that of the three plans proposed, marked "A," "B," and "C," only the first is available. That provides for a daily supply of 50,000,000 gallons, maximum, but the specifications are faulty.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- The Secretary of Agriculture, in his report for the fiscal year ending June 30 last, draws attention to the purpose of the department to give wide circulation to everything in the way of experience, discovery, or invention that can interest American farmers. "The department will in future," he says, "help producers to find markets for surplus productions, by getting and spreading information concerning them and concerning what foreign markets require."

CHICAGO, Nov. 15. -- Rather than purchase safety for herself at the price of dropping to probable death the pet dog she held in her arms, Mrs. Margaret Burns of 53 North State Street allowed herself to be struck by an electric car at North State and Illinois Streets this afternoon. She was thrown ten feet and landed upon the paving stones, breaking her collar bone and terribly bruising her head and shoulders.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Nov. 15. -- Two attempts were made last night to wreck Erie trains near Sloatsburg. A west-bound passenger express had a narrow escape from being derailed by running into a pile of fish-plates on the tracks. The wheels staid on the rails, and the obstruction was cleared. Soon afterward an east-bound freight train ran into a pile of heavy ties placed across the track near the spot where the fishplates had been found.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Nov. 15. -- Capt. Mosher of the brigantine Iona, whose crew of six men deserted him at Montville in the Thames River at the end of a voyage from Port au Prince, indignantly denies that he treated the men cruelly, as they have asserted. Capt. Mosher said to-night:

SNOW HILL, Md., Nov. 15. -- William Sidney Wilson committed suicide by shooting at his home, in Snow Hill yesterday afternoon. For some time he had been in bad health, and he is supposed to have taken his life while suffering from temporary insanity. He died instantly after firing the shot.

A seven-year-old girl, artless and pretty, sat upon the floor in the Court of General Sessions yesterday, while Recorder Goff, the jury, lawyers, and a pale-faced man watched her illustrate how she and her brothers and sisters played with lanterns one morning in her father's store. So well did she do this that when she finished there were murmurs of admiration from the jury box and the bystanders.

LONDON, Nov. 16. -- A special dispatch from Berlin says that the court-martial has confirmed the sentence of the lower court upon Dr. Carl Peters, former German High Commissioner in Africa, ex-Chairman of the German Colonial Society, and the well-known African explorer, charged with extreme cruelty, and even worse offenses, to natives while he was Commissioner in Africa in 1891.

The thirteenth annual Horse Show was opened yesterday in Madison Square Garden, and it suffered severely from the bad weather. The dreary drizzle and the influence of fashion's decree formulated three seasons ago, that the first day of the show shall not be marked by a distinctively fashionable attendance, combined to make the society side of the affair in the afternoon and evening its less important one.

QUEENSTOWN, Nov. 15. -- Particulars have just been received of the wreck of the British steamer Rutherglen, Capt. English, from New York on Oct. 26 for Plymouth, which, as cabled on Saturday afternoon last, foundered when 330 miles west of the Fastnet Light. Her crew was picked up by the Norwegian bark Hermanos, and reached Crookhaven, twenty-one miles from Skibbereen, on Saturday.

The Board of Aldermen, convened as a Board of County Canvassers, began the count of the Nineteenth Assembly District yesterday morning. In this district Perez M. Steward and Howard P. Okie, the Citizens' Union candidates for the Assembly and for Alderman, claim the election, although the police returns counted both out.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- The British, Canadian, and American delegates to the Bering Sea meeting had expected to bring their labors to a close to-day, but, after two arduous sessions, lasting until 5:30 this evening the experts had not been able to reconcile all their differences. It was determined, therefore, to continue the meeting to-morrow.

ORANGE, Nov. 15. -- Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Hoag and their daughter Constance will sail for the Klondike gold fields in a few days on the brigantine Harriet G. On their arrival in Alaska Mr. Hoag will open a general supply store.

At the annual meeting at Baltimore yesterday of the stockholders of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company these Directors were re-elected: William F. Frick, James L. McLane, George C. Jenkins, Alexander Shaw, George A. Von Lingen, Maurice Gregg, William H. Blackford, Louis Fitzgerald, Eugene Delano; Edward R. Bacon, William A. Read, and Howland Davis.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15. -- Mrs. Mabel Estelle Wallace, at whose home on Indiana Avenue John B. Ketcham died on Saturday, asserts that she is the widow of the dead clubman. According to Mrs. Wallace, the ceremony by which she became the third Mrs. Ketcham was performed in Milwaukee on, Sept. 24 by a Methodist minister.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- Commissioner General Powderly of the Immigration Bureau to-day received a telegram from Special Inspector Baldwin at Memphis, Tenn., that he had arrested twenty-eight alien stave cutters, illegally brought into this country under contract, and would go to Mississippi to-night to arrest the remaining twenty-two.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- The inquiry is heard here as to what will happen if the attempt to settle the Bering Sea dispute falls through. The answer of some men who have disapproved of the notion of negotiating with Canada is that there will be no further negotiations on any of the subjects deferred for consideration until the sealing dispute is settled.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15. -- Postmaster Van Cott of New York arrived here last night and returned to-day after a conference with Postmaster General Gary and Assistant Postmasters General Heath and Shallenberger. He secured an increase of salaries for the clerks of the $600 and $700 classes in the New York office, the increases aggregating $12,000 for the remaining six months of the fiscal year.

Yesterday's stock market was excessively dull and uninteresting. Stocks were irregular and without any decided tendency. Transactions on the Stock Exchange aggregated less than 190,000 shares. But few of the day's net changes were more than fractional, and these for the most part were declines.

Sheriff Buttling and a jury yesterday assessed damages in the suit of Florence Van Schaack against Peter Van Schaack, in Brooklyn. Mrs. Van Schaack sued the defendant, who is her father-in-law, for $65,000 for alienating the affections of her husband, John C. Van Schaack. The defendant is a merchant in Chicago.

BISMARCK, N.D., Nov. 15. -- An interesting legal question is presented by yesterday's lynching of three of the Spicer murderers. Two of the men, Holytrack and Ireland, were the State's witnesses, and without their testimony the State has no case against two surviving suspects, Black Hawk and Defender.

Discussion of the Warszawiak case, or, rather, an attempt to discuss it, after the Moderator, Dr. W.D. Buchanan, had ruled discussion out of order, upset yesterday's session of the New York Presbytery, and for a time gave to the meeting in the First Church, Eleventh Street and Fifth Avenue, more the appearance of a heated political debate than of a business assemblage of grave and reverend pastors.

HAVANA, via Key West, Nov. 15. -- Considerable anxiety is expressed in official circles here as to what will happen after the arrival of Gen. Weyler in Spain. There are people who believe that trouble will follow any determined effort of the Spanish Government to discipline the former Governor General of Cuba, and, in any case, many well-informed persons believe that serious events will occur in January or February next.

VICTORIA, B. C., Nov. 15. -- The German warship Falka, which was dispatched from Australia on receipt of the news there of the murder of the trader Von Hagen, returned recently from German New Guinea, having avenged the savagery of the natives.

The new Delmonico's, at Forty-fourth Street and Fifth Avenue, was opened last night informally. Nearly 1,000 guests visited the building and wandered through the handsome rooms. The building was designed by James Brown Lord.

-- Philadelphia is excited over a succession of phenomenally low tides. New York, too, has recently learned something about low tides. No longer ago than the night of Nov. 2 we had one that caused much inconvenience and humiliation to many good people, but depression here was political and moral, while at Philadelphia it has been literal and aqueous.

MONTREAL, Nov. 15. -- C.M. Hays, General Manager of the Grand Trunk Railroad, left this evening for New York. It is said that his mission there is to complete negotiations for a new freight route in conjunction with the Wabash over the line of the Grand Trunk Company from Detroit to Suspension Bridge, and over the New York, Ontario and Western to New York.

The title "comic opera" has been pretty thoroughly stretched in the last few years. It originally belonged to such works as Mozart's "Marriage of Figaro" and Rossini's "Barber of Seville." These are operas and they are comic; therefore they have a right to the title. Gilbert and Sullivan applied the name to their "Pinafore" and to their other works in the same class.
LOUISVILLE, Nov. 15. -- A morning paper, under the caption "Sovereign's Vaulting Ambition," says:

Breese Cummings -- Railways continue to show earnings equal to and in many instances in excess of the expectations of last Summer, and are thereby insuring to holders of better class of stocks dividends for some time to come. The apathy of the public to stocks is attributable to the fear, now less, but not wholly removed, of complications with Spain, or at least an airing in Congress of the jingo spirit.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Nov. 16. -- Alexander Brothers' grocery store, at Campbell Hall, had been robbed three times within a year, and the proprietors attached a burglar alarm to the front door and connected the alarm with George Alexander's residence. He was awakened yesterday, before dawn, by the alarm and aroused several neighbors.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- Postmaster General Gary will appoint very shortly a commission to make a thorough investigation of the Greater New York scheme as affecting the postal service, and on the basis of its report a special message will be sent to Congress asking for authority to abolish the county seats to be embraced, and calling for a special appropriation to cover the expense of the Greater New York service.
In the daily papers of the 15th inst. there appears a remarkable letter from Senator T.C. Platt.

NEWARK, Nov. 16. -- Word was received here to-day that the Court of Errors and Appeals, in Trenton, had affirmed the conviction of Joseph A. Rohr for forgery, and Rohr will now have to serve the sentence of six months which was imposed on him in the Essex County Court in February, 1894.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16. -- The rates between Chicago and St. Paul are demoralized. The business is being carried on practically a basis of $3 for one way, and the passengers fix their fares just about as often as the railroad men from whom they purchase tickets. The competition is so keen that inducements are offered to purchasers of tickets even at the low rates that are being made.

GREENPORT, L.I., Nov. 16. -- The Long Island sea serpent is not dead yet. He has been seen many times in the last few years, and even when run down by sailing vessels or hit by expert marksmen seems to bob up, serene and undisturbed.

Again yesterday the market for stocks was dull. Less than 200,000 shares changed hands. But unlike the market of Monday yesterday's showed strength throughout. Nearly all stocks advanced, although most of the advances were but fractional, being scaled down by a reaction which came before the close.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 16. -- The State Board of Taxation to-day submitted to the Governor its annual report. The report shows the taxable property in New Jersey to be as follows: Real estate and personal property, $812,616,240; railroad and canal property, $220,869,240; amount of property exempt from taxation under different laws, $88,302,689.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 16. -- Arthur B. Moody, son of L.W. Moody, an insurance agent of this city, was arrested late this afternoon as an alleged fugitive from justice, and his case will come up before the City Court to-morrow. Bonds to the amount of $2,500 were furnished and the mean was released pending the hearing.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16. -- The Western lines are having difficulty in the settlement of their immigration traffic troubles. The Union Pacific has refused to go into the latest deal with the steamship companies by virtue of which the emigrant clearing house of the Western roads is to have the routeing of all the emigrant business.

LONDON, Nov. 16. -- A great mass meeting under the auspices of the National Union of Conservative Associations was held this evening in the Albert Hall under the Presidency of Earl Cadogan, the Lord Lieutenant of Ireland, at which the principal speaker was the Premier, the Marquis of Salisbury.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Nov. 16. -- Attorney General Cameron of the Manitoba Government, when asked to-day for his opinion on the reported pronouncement by his Holiness the Pope on the Manitoba school question, in which it is decreed that the children of Catholic parents should attend none but Catholic schools in Manitoba, said:

Your editorial in THE TIMES of the 15th, stating that "there has been too much talk about the forces of good government being divided in the late campaign," was read by me as are most of the editorials in your paper. It will not do for the Citizens' Union to assume that the recent vote represents its strength in the cities, for not one-third of that vote can be depended upon.
Ranald. H. Macdonald has sold for Mrs. Lillian L. Aymar, for $36,000, the four-story brick English basement dwelling 37 West Thirty-fifth Street, 19 by 70 by 98.9.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- An immense claim, embracing 7,000,000 acres of land in the Northwest, and including the cities of Minneapolis and St. Paul was brought before Commissioner Hermann of the General Land Office to-day, and the assistance of the Government in securing official data was asked for.

Quarrels between marines attached to the navy yard and saloon rounders in the neighborhood have been of frequent occurrence. One of these quarrels early yesterday morning resulted in the shooting of one of the rounders. Alexander McMillan, who did the shooting, is a marine. He and Corp. Lover left the yard on Monday night and went out for a walk.

The Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse came into port yesterday 6 days and 58 minutes from Southampton. This is not up to her record, but in view of the rough weather now prevalent on the North Atlantic, the significance of the run is understood when it is said that it falls only 27 minutes short of the St. Paul's record trip, made under favorable conditions of weather.

Fritz Meyer, or Constantine Steiger, was found guilty of murder in the first degree yesterday for shooting Policeman Frederick Smith on the night of Oct. 26 in the Church of the Most Holy Redeemer. Justice Fursman finished his brief charge at 3:55 o'clock and one-half hour later the jury returned with its verdict.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 16. -- Atlanta has two Assistant Postmasters. One is Major Couper, the incumbent under the Democratic office holder, and the other E.F. Blodgett, who was appointed by Major W.H. Smyth, the Republican who took charge of the office Monday night. Smyth demanded Couper's resignation, and the latter refused it, securing an injunction from the Federal Court until to-morrow morning, when the contest will be decided.

A committee of sanitarians and bacteriologists appeared before President McKinley on Monday to urge an appropriation for the investigation as to the causes of yellow fever, and Dr. A.H. Doty, one of its members, returned to this city yesterday, confident that the President's co-operation was assured.

ALBANY, Nov. 16. -- When, a few months ago, Erastus Coming died here, a reputed millionaire, and connected with many large institutions, many newspaper articles appeared claiming that his money had been extravagantly squandered, and that $12,000,000 left him by his father had disappeared. From the pulpit of All Saints' Cathedral to-day Bishop Doane, while mentioning Mr. Corning's many gifts to the Church, denied these stories and put the matter in a new light.

Marcus C. Hawley, a hardware merchant of this city, who had a long acquaintance and intimate business relations with Joseph Richardson, yesterday continued and concluded his testimony before Surrogate Fitzgerald, who is hearing the contest of Mr. Richardson's wills. On Monday Mr. Hawley said he saw the testator nearly every day during his last illness, and that he believed him to have been irrational then.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- Capt. Shoemaker, Chief of the Revenue Cutter Service, under the direction of the Secretary of the Treasury, has prepared a letter of instructions to Capt. Tuttle, who is to be in command of the steamer Bear on her cruise north for the relief of the eight whaling vessels ice-bound in the Arctic Ocean.

RACINE, Wis., Nov. 16. -- The body of Samuel H. Skewes, a pioneer and one of the best known men in Racine County, was found in his bedroom in the Thompson House at Union Grove, sixteen miles west of here, this morning. The body was found in a kneeling position against the bed, with the hands clasped as if in prayer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- The final act on the part of this Government in the ratification of the treaty adopted by the recent Universal Postal Congress was taken today when President McKinley signed the formal convention or treaty and Secretary of State Sherman had the Government seal affixed. Postmaster General Gary had already signed.

STONEHAM, Mass., Nov. 16. -- "Eddie" Buckman, one of the brightest boys in the town, died last week at the Massachusetts Homeopathic Hospital. His death was due directly to a football game, and as a result there will be strong efforts made to have a law passed in the State prohibiting the game.

Despite the better weather of the daylight hours, the attendance at the Horse Show in Madison Square Garden yesterday during the morning and afternoon sessions was not as large as on Monday, and the society element was not well represented. The ticket speculators were offering choice seats and boxes at ridiculously low prices.

It is curious how the belief has been making its way under the surface in France, as well as in other countries, that a French court-martial had condemned an innocent man to a living death. There was not very much direct evidence accessible to the public on either side.

TRENTON, Nov. 16. -- The argument for a recount of the rejected ballots of the special election held in September for amendments to the Constitution was concluded to-day before Justices Van Syckel, Dixon, and Collins.

Your excellent and logically reasoned leader in this morning's issue concludes with the pertinent query, "The only question worth pressing for an answer now is, why did so many Democrats vote for Van Wyck?"

Albert Mott, Chairman of the League of American Wheelmen National Racing Board, while in New York, said he had received word from George H. Orr, President of the Canadian Wheelmen's Association, repudiating the statement ascribed to him to the effect that he believed the Pacific coast outlaws were in control of racing throughout the extreme West, and that he would recommend that the Canadian association recognize them as against the League of American Wheelmen.

PARIS, Nov. 16. -- Comte Esterhazy, who, it is said, answers the description "of a rich and titled officer, well known in Paris society," who had been requested to resign his commission in the army in consequence of the continued leaking of military secrets since Capt. Dreyfus was deported, has written a letter to Gen. Billot, the Minister for War, with regard to the alleged "infamous accusation."

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 16. -- Minnie Walkup, the woman known in Chicago as Mrs. Mabel Estelle Wallace, and John B. Ketcham were married at the residence of the Rev. W.A. Hunsberger, in this city, by the Rev. I.P. Roberts on Sept. 24. The groom gave the name of his parents as Valentine and Rachel Ketcham, and the parents of the bride are recorded as James and Elizabeth Wallace.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 16. -- This morning a man was found unconscious in the basement of the Grand Opera House by a policeman, and was identified as Herbert Wiswall, a wealthy capitalist of Boston and Treasurer of a large bleachery at West Point, Ga. He was at once taken to the Grady Hospital, where his head was found to be badly injured and his eyes discolored and badly bruised.

According to the belief of District Attorney Youngs of Queens County and others who are connected with the trial of Martin Thorn for the murder of William Guldensuppe, the saw with which the body was dismembered has been found and is now in the safe of the prosecuting attorney. The saw was found in the Flushing meadows yesterday by an Italian named Anton Pustonski, who lives in Flushing.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 16. -- The National Fox Hunters' Association will begin its fourth annual meet, at Cynthiana, to-morrow. The recent rains have put the ground in good condition for trailing, and as Harrison County is overrun with foxes the indications for a successful meet are very promising.

The Bulletin of the Bureau of Statistics on Domestic Exports for October and the ten months ending with October (corrected to Nov. 9) is just at hand. It affords an opportunity for comparing the progress of the Port of New York in the export trade with that of the other ports of the North Atlantic. The comparison is far from cheerful.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16. -- The closing portion of the voyage of the steamship Belgenland, which arrived to-day from Liverpool, was eventful. To the watchful eye of the lookout can be credited the saving of a number of lives.

UTICA, Nov. 16. -- The Root Hall of Science and the Benedict Hall of Languages were formally presented to Hamilton College, at Clinton, and dedicated to-day. At the same time the renovated chapel was reopened and the addition to the campus was presented.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- Consul Monaghan, at Chemnitz, in a report to the State Department on Germany's exports to the United States, says: ...

SIMLA, Nov. 16. -- Official dispatches which eached here to-day from the British camp in the Maidan Valley announce that Gen. Kempster's brigade while coming in yesterday evening was attacked by the enemy in force. The tribesmen were driven off with the assistance of star shells, which illuminated the scene of the encounter sufficiently to enable the tribesmen to be seen.

It will be matter for regret if the conferences at Washington between Sir WILFRID LAURIER and his associate and the Commissioners on the part of the United States should not result in an agreement. Many intimations, however, have been thrown out at Washington to prepare the way for the announcement that an agreement is impossible.

It is much to be hoped that the Board of Street Openings at its meeting to-day will adopt the view expressed by the Controller at the last meeting and allow the project for the extension northward of Riverside Park to lapse by its own limitation. Such a disposition of it, there is every reason to believe, would be an "innocuous desuetude"

NYACK, N.Y., Nov. 16. -- The "Seventy-six" stone house at Tappan, where Major Andre was imprisoned during the Revolution, and which was partly blown down by a storm two weeks ago, was bought to-day by Charles A. Pike, a wealthy resident of Tappan.

One man was burned to death and five women slightly injured in a fire which consumed the storeroom of C.A. Woolsey's Paint and Color Works, at Grand Street and Pacific Avenue, Jersey City, shortly after 9 o'clock yesterday morning. The building, erected on piles over swampy ground, first collapsed and then took fire from an overturned stove.

The first concert of the sixth season in this city of the Kneisel Quartet of Boston was given last night in the handsome hall of the Mendelssohn Glee Club, in West Fortieth Street. The size of the audience, which quite filled the hall, was sufficient to attest the interest of music lovers in the playing of this admired organization. For four years its concerts here trembled in the balance of approval.

People in the outlying boroughs which after the 1st of January will be parts of Greater New York re becoming anxious to know what ordinances and rules they will be living under. There is evidently much confusion and uncertainty on this point.

The effort to stop the construction of the trolley loop at the New York end of the Brooklyn Bridge was resumed before Justice Andrews in the Supreme Court yesterday, when argument was heard upon the motion to continue the preliminary injunction against the Bridge Trustees.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16. -- The oft-agitated project of establishing in the City of Washington a great National university on the lines suggested by President Washington may come to something in a short time. Several women of prominence have taken hold of the project with a determination to push it to a successful conclusion if possible.

Meetings of the Republican Ward Committees of Brooklyn were held last night, and the leaders gathered for the first time since Nov. 2 to discuss party reorganization.
