Immediately after election there was much talk on the part of the Platt partisans of disciplining the 50,000 Kings County Republicans who voted for Seth Low for Mayor.

ALBANY, Nov. 16. -- Bishop William Croswell Doane in his annual address to the clergy of the Diocese of Albany to-day, speaking of the relation of America to England in the Lambeth Conference, was very intense in his condemnation of what is called "jingoism." Relating to the report upon the subject of international arbitration, he said:

The new Academy of Design, the plans for which have been accepted, and which were designed by Carrere Hastings, will occupy the entire block on the east side of Amsterdam Avenue, between One Hundred and Ninth and One Hundred and Tenth Streets, and will face the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, at present in process of construction.

" Modern Heroes" was the topic of the evening at the sixty-second meeting of the Quill Club, at the Windsor Hotel last night. The speakers were Frank Moss, President of the Board of Police Commissioners; Commissioner James R. Sheffield of the New York City Fire Department, and Major Horace L. Piper of the United States Life Savings Department.

LONDON, Nov. 17. -- It now appears that the statement made yesterday in a special dispatch from Vienna that the Turkish Government, in reply to the demands of Baron de Calice, the Austro-Hungarian Ambassador to the Porte, had agreed to salute the Austrian flag after dismising the Vali of Adana and the Mutossaril of Mersina, for indignities offered to the Austrian merchant Brazzafolli, was premature.

It took the jury in the case of Bernard Blumenthal, accused of arson, in General Sessions, just ten minutes to decide that the man is not guilty of the crime charged against him. They retired to deliberate at 12:10 o'clock, and at 12:20 o'clock were ready to return to court.

HAVANA, Nov. 17. -- Gen. Pando, who is in charge of the military operations in the field, received to-day at the palace the chiefs of the volunteers, whom he asked to send as many contingents as were disposed to undertake the work as garrisons for the principal plantations and as guards for the railway lines, bridges, and stations. The chiefs will give their answer to-morrow.

LONDON, Nov. 17. -- In the race for the Oadby Plate at the last day's racing of the Leicester November meeting to-day, "Tod" Sloane rode Mr. Murray Griffith's three-year-old bay colt Orestes, but the latter was unplaced.

ALBANY, Nov. 17. -- The Board of Railroad Commissioners has granted permission to the Metropolitan Street Railroad Company to change its motive power from horses to underground electricity on Eighty-sixth Street, One Hundred and Sixth Street, and One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Streets.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 17. -- Prof. Wiggins believes the aerolite that fell near Binghamton a few nights ago, and is alleged to have contained a piece of iron with hieroglyphics, was really a message from Mars. "My opinion is that stones have for many thousands of years fallen from space upon the earth which actually contained written characters.

The case of DURRANT, under sentence of death in California, is one of those which tend to explain lynching. When a crime is committed that horrifies and angers a community, the general demand for the execution of justice upon the criminal is a righteous demand. In a civilized community no lawless action is taken, because people are convinced that justice will be promptly and accurately done according to law.

CHICAGO Nov. 17. -- Relatives of the late John B. Ketcham will contest his will, if such an instrument is in existence, on the ground that he was not only of unsound mind at the time he may have signed it, but for ten months previous. Ketcham's two brothers and two sisters will also deny that their brother was legally married to Minnie Wallace Walkup.
VIENNA, Nov. 17. -- Emperor Francis Joseph, in receiving the Hungarian delegation to-day made a speech in which he said:

President Rossiter of the Brooklyn Heights Railroad said yesterday that there was no reason to worry over the recent decision of the Court of Appeals in the Kingston case, which had been misinterpreted in such a way as to give the impression that the trolley and elevated companies in Brooklyn could not cross the Brooklyn Bridge. He said it was his opinion that the cars would cross the bridge in accordance with the present plans.

The Rev. Dr. George H. Houghton, for nearly fifty years rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration, better known as "The Little Church Around the Corner," died last evening at 5:30 o'clock at the rectory, 1 East Twenty-ninth Street, after an illness of only one and a half hours from congestion of the lungs.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 17. -- Following the recent action of the State Legislature in repudiating the Bullock bonds, issued during the war, upon which the Finance Committee has on several occasions made a favorable report, the following letter from E.P. Scott of New York, made public today, creates a great deal of discussion and may lead to some other formal action by the General Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- The officers of the State Department were very much surprised at the reports of the total failure of the negotiations between the United States and Canada for the settlement of pending questions, which appeared in several newspapers this morning. The negotiations are still in progress.

CYTHIANA, Ky., Nov. 17. -- The annual hound trials of the National Fox Hunters' Association are in full swing, though this, the first day, was barren of results. Breakfast at 5 o'clock this morning was followed by an early start from town, and about three miles west the pack of nineteen competitors in the National Fox Hound Derby was thrown into covert.

The contest between skilled and unskilled labor furnishes an amusing episode in the attack upon the Musical Mutual Protective Union by the "American Federation of Labor." A trades union which comprises all that is available of skilled labor in its own branch is in a position to take full advantage of whatever demand there may be in the community for that particular variety of skilled labor.

One thing is quite effectually secured by the recent disclosures in Paris, and that is that the Dreyfus case is to be tried over again and tried in public. In other words, the elaborate mystification which the War Office has kept up over the case can be no longer maintained in the presence of an aroused public sentiment.

Before the Senate of the United States takes up the treaty offered by the Dole Government of Hawaii for the annexation of the Sandwich Islands to the United States, two bodies of delegates from Hawaii will ask to be heard by the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations. One of these delegations will include the Hawaiian Minister and Commissioners appointed by the Government of the islands.

OSHKOSH, Wis., Nov. 17. -- Henry Sherry, the great lumber operator and manufacturer, who had interests in nearly every northern county, to-day gave up the fight against business misfortunes and the shrinkage of assets and credit, due to hard times, and assigned all his vast properties for the benefit of his creditors.

LONDON, Nov. 18. -- A special dispatch from Shanghai says that the commander of the German cruiser division, Admiral von Diederich, landed troops at Kaio-chau on Monday morning, Nov. 15. The three forts were held by 1,500 Chinese, and their guns commanded the fleet. Admiral von Diederich placed his four cruisers immediately opposite, ready to fire, and sent an ultimatum ordering an evacuation of the forts within three hours.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- Prof. Milton Whitney, who is in charge of the Division of Soils of the Agricultural Department, is engaged in the investigation of the climatic conditions of moisture and temperature in their relation to the local distribution of crops. The work will eventually embrace all the soils and staple crops in the country.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 17. -- The Harvard team lined up this afternoon for the last hard practice of the year. To-morrow afternoon there will be some short signal work on Soldiers' Field, and at 4:45 P.M. the team will leave Boston for Philadelphia by the Fall River Line. During its stay in Philadelphia the Harvard team will be quartered at the Hotel Aldine.

The Secretary of Agriculture forgets that he is a part of the Administration of WILLIAM McKINLEY. In his annual report he talks for all the world like a sensible and patriotic American, anxious to use the powers of his office to increase the prosperity and promote the happiness of his country.

So successful was the first tour of the League of American Wheelmen City Consuls, on which some thirty miles of New York streets were inspected, that a similar ride has been arranged for next Sunday. On the first day the consuls confined their attention to the Island of Manhattan, but Sunday's trip will be in the district above the Harlem. All the consulate will be invited, and a number of city officials.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 17. -- Justices Van Syckel, Dixon, and Collins of the Supreme Court to-day denied the application for a recount of the votes on the anti-gambling amendment to the State Constitution. The opinion was written by Justice Van Syckel, and represents the unanimous sentiment of the court.

When Mrs. Michael Ford, who is the wife of the janitor of the Windsor Apartment house, at 1,700 Broadway, awoke at 11:15 o'clock last night, she found the house afire. Ford, his wife, and their three children live in the basement. Mrs. Ford screamed, and her husband, who was working in another part of the basement, rushed in.

After a two days' trip at sea, the battleship Iowa, the first of the new 'sea-going battleships' to be built for the navy, dropped anchor off Tompkinsville yesterday, and later steamed up to the navy yard at Brooklyn, where she was moored to the cob dock. The vessel had just returned from a foutry- eight hours' cruise at sea, on her final acceptance trial trip.

EAST ORANGE, Nov. 17. -- Preparations are about completed for the annual fair for the benefit of the Memorial Hospital, which will be opened in Berkeley Hall this afternoon and continue to-morrow, evening and Friday afternoon and evening. It is the great charitable and society event of the year here.
The Immigration Bureau at the Barge Office was upset for several hours yesterday, all on account of a baby. The baby is only five months old, and arrived yesterday on the White Star steamer Majestic.

The Richmond County Board of Canvass resumed work yesterday, and continued the canvass of the districts as returned according to the order of Supreme Court Justice Smith. When the Twelfth District of Castleton was reached, Mr. Davenport wanted it laid aside until his associate counsel, W.A. Shortt, was present, but the board would not listen to this and went on.

COLD SPRINGS, N.Y., Nov. 17. -- The fourth session of the Coroner's inquest into the cause of the accident on the New York Central Railroad near Garrison's on Oct. 24 was held in the Town Hall in this place tonight. It was expected the investigation would be completed at to-night's session, but Coroner Woods announced that at least two more sessions would be necessary.

In THE TIMES of the 15th is a contribution headed "A Plea for the Birds," and signed "A.A.C." For some years I have been inclined to start an Anti-Audubon Society, and the contribution referred to is one of several recent new incentives to carry out my intent.

The Organization Committee of the Citizens' Union, at a meeting at the headquarters, in East Twenty-third Street, last night, resolved to continue and to extend the Union "for the furtherance of its declared principles and objects."
We trust that Vice President HOBART is as good a prophet as he is a sensible and practical business man.
Jessie M. Converse has sold to J.S. Bache, for about $100,000, the four-story and basement brownstone front dwelling, with extension, 8 East Sixty-seventh Street, 25 by 100.
The trial of William Woodward, alias "Big" Hawley, for trying to blackmail Samuel Willard Bridgham was begun in the criminal branch of the Supreme Court, before Justice Fursman and a jury yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 17. -- Arthur Blair Moody of this city, who was arrested at his home on Fair Haven Heights yesterday at the instance of Detective Sergeant Evanhoe of New York as an alleged fugitive from justice, did not appear in court to-day, but remained in the office of his counsel, and the court proceedings were arranged so that the case was continued for one week from next Friday.

The Board of Education at its meeting yesterday postponed final action on the promotion of teachers schedule, in deference to a protest signed by the different teachers' associations. The postponement is only until the next meeting, and Commissioner Prentiss said it was very improbable that any change would be made in the scheme as laid out.

SIMLA, Nov. 17. -- The official dispatches received to-day from the British headquarters in the Maidan Valley say that on Gen. Kempster's returning to camp with his baggage on Monday last, the Sikhs of the British force were split up into companies and held the spurs of the Kotal. The enemy appeared in force, and, rushing forward with great perseverance, some hard hand-to-hand fighting followed.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17. -- "Is Baptism a Prerequisite to the Lord's Supper?" was the topic discussed last night at the fourteenth annual meeting of the Baptist Congress in Immanuel Church, Michigan Avenue and Twenty-third Street.

NEWARK, Nov. 17. -- The joint Water Ways Committee appointed by the Chamber of Commerce of Staten Island and the Boards of Trade of Newark, Elizabeth, and Perth Amboy met in this city this evening to hear the report of the sub-committee to which the work of gathering statistics and considering the project from all its bearings had been intrusted.

But for the interference of mutual friends there would have been a genuine stand-up and knock-down fight a yesterday's public hearing before the Board of Street Openings and Improvement on the proposed extension of Riverside Drive between A. Judson Fullam of West One Hundred and Fifty-second Street and Martin Newall, a property owner in the same neighborhood.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 17. -- It is believed that the top notch was reached in the speculation for tickets to the Yale-Princeton game this morning. A few seats were sold for $12 each. The prevailing price is $10 for two-dollar seats and $6 for one-dollar-and-a-half positions.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- At the preliminary meeting of the representatives of the striking engineers and their employers, just held, it was agreed to hold a formal conference on Wednesday next, Nov. 24. Each side will have fourteen representatives.

The brief quarrel between Austria and Turkey was not related to the general quarrel of Europe with the Turk. Nevertheless it indicates a useful formula for his treatment. An Austrian had been subjected to various injuries and indignities at the hands of Turkish officials, and the Austrian Government labored to obtain redress for him through peaceable and diplomatic methods, and entirely in vain.

R.H. Bissell, the stock broker, through whose firm Joseph Richardson's business was transacted, was the first witness called yesterday to testify in the contest of Mr. Richardson's wills before Surrogate Fitzgerald. Mr. Bissell identified Mr. Richardson's signature to a paper which Mr. Peckham handed him, and which was afterward offered and admitted in evidence.
At the November meeting of the Medico-Legal Society, held last evening in the Hotel Marlborough, the following persons were placed in nomination for office for the ensuing year:

LONDON, Nov. 17. -- A special dispatch from Vienna says that a telegram has been received there from Baron de Calice, the Austrian Ambassador at Constantinople, saying the Sultan has declared his willingness to give Austria full satisfaction for the Mersina incidents and in regard to the disputes in connection with the Oriental Railroad growing out of the transportation of Turkish troops during the recent war between Turkey and Greece.

-- "Spanish pride will never consent to any diminution of Spanish territory." This statement has been made so often since the present Cuban rebellion assumed threatening proportions that it has gained no little credence among those who do not take pains to remember what a vast amount of practice "Spanish pride" has had in consenting of this very same sort.

HAVANA, via Key West, Nov. 17. -- It is reported late this evening that Marshal Blanco has received cabled instructions from Madrid to release the prisoners captured on board the American schooner Competitor in April, 1896, by the Spanish gunboat Mesagera, and that they will sail to-morrow, Thursday, for the United States.

The police at the Central Office arrested last night Peter Geistel, alias "Dutch Pete," twenty-six years old, a butcher, living at 304 East Eightieth Street, who was the alleged accomplice of Steiger, or Fritz Meyer, the murderer of Policeman Smith, and also of Stelz, the sexton of the Church of the Holy Trinity, in Williamsburg, last August.

A correspondent sends a story about a conversion by marriage. A colored woman came to his office to solicit 5 and 10 cent subscriptions for a new carpet and organ for her church. A young lady in the office gave the woman 10 cents, whereupon the correspondent suggested that "both she and the colored lady were probably good Baptists."

A striking refutation of the common assumption of many well-meaning but very mischievous philanthropists that the poor must be helped at every stage of their existence at the expense of the taxpayers, is to be found in the success of the classes in sewing and cooking recently established by the Mechanics' Institute.
In its review of trade conditions The Iron Age, foremost authority on the iron trade, will to-day say:

Three wealthy women, two of them members of old New York families and one a well-known English amateur artist, are said to be the victims of Arthur Blair Moody, who was arrested near New Haven Tuesday on a charge of being a fugitive from justice. Moody has been indicted in this city for grand larceny.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- Judge Emory F. Best of Georgia resigned to-day the post of Assistant Commissioner of the General Land Office and was appointed Assistant Attorney in the Interior Department. He made way for ex-Congressman Frank W. Mondell of Wyoming, who was at once appointed to the place.

The cool wave brought no frost to the Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night, for there was a large crowd, in noticeable contrast to the sparse attendance on Monday and Tuesday evenings. The horses themselves responded to the improved weather conditions, and when brought out in the ring for their morning exercise seemed like new animals.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 18. -- Leonard Hein, a native of Bavaria, once a Colonel in the German Army and a member of a wealthy family, died yesterday in abject poverty at the St. Louis City Hospital, aged fifty-five years. He was of royal parentage, his father having been a relative of Emperor William I., grandfather of the present Emperor.
CHICAGO, Nov. 18. -- Fred R. Ketcham today got a verdict of $21,666.33 in his suit against the Northwestern Railroad for $25,000 damages for blacklisting.

May Kellard began another episode in her varied life when she appeared in General Sessions yesterday to defend herself against the charge of forgery. She was indicted last June upon complaint of Mrs. Mary D. Spencer, a florist of 304 Columbus Avenue, who alleges that Miss Kellard had obtained from her $750 upon a note for $1,000 upon which the name of Mrs. Virginia Wood was forged as maker.
From The Hartford (Conn.) Times, Nov. 17. A Washington dispatch to THE NEW YORK TIMES says:

-- "Catfish and waffles," says The Philadelphia Record, "are now interesting the bon vivants." The French in this statement might be criticised on more than one ground, perhaps, but the general meaning is clear enough, and the revelation it makes in regard to Philadelphia habits and standards is eminently precious.

The County Clerk has submitted to the District Attorney the list of candidates for offices in the last campaign who have failed to file their statements of expenses as provided by law. The list includes:

If the story told by Ernest Neithardt of Rochelle Park, N.J., to the police of the East Fifth Street Police Station is true, he was the subject yesterday morning of one of the most remarkable crimes and the victim of one of the strangest calamities recorded in police annals.

ALBANY, Nov. 18. -- Gen. Austin Lathrop, Superintendent of State Prisons, says that the present system of convict labor is a success. He will report to the Legislature that it not only furnishes employment for all the convicts in the State prisons who are able to work, but also makes those institutions self-supporting.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 18. -- Ex-Congressman Baldwin of Duluth will leave this city next Monday for Juneau to operate in the mineral regions in that section. He has a scheme mapped out, and has organized a stock company and engaged eight experienced prospectors to go with him. They are all men who explored the Mesaba Range when it was in its infancy, and have worked in the Rainy Lake gold region.

The public memory is so short that, in order to appreciate the significance of the findings of the seal experts, it is well to recall what our English and Canadian friends said when the United States first affirmed what is now declared to be true. Said Minister DAVIES in London last July: "The Canadians have never believed that the seals were in any real danger of extinction.

The application of J.C. Clifford, President of the Waldorf Athletic Club, for a peremptory mandamus to compel Mayor Strong to issue a license permitting the club to give boxing exhibitions was denied yesterday by Justice Andrews of the Supreme Court. The reasons given by the Court for refusing the writ are:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- Senator Morgan of Alabama, member of the Committee on Foreign Relations, has reached here on his return from Honolulu, where he went to post himself on the annexation question. For the first time he submitted to-day to an interview on the results of his trip, and said:

PARIS, Nov. 18. -- The alleged false imprisonment of Alfred Dreyfus, the former Captain of French Artillery, who is undergoing a sentence of imprisonment for life after having been convicted by a court-martial of selling French military plans to the agents of a foreign Government, continues to be very widely discussed in Paris and throughout France.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- The Inter-State Commerce Commission desires to correct the recently published statement that only the New York Central and Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroads are fully equipped with safety appliances. Out of 436 roads that have reported to the commission in the matter of safety appliances, 75 roads, or 17.20 per cent., will be equipped with automatic couplers by Jan. 1, 1898.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 18. -- There is a rumor current here to-night that a large number of counterfeit tickets for the Yale-Princeton football game are being offered for sale by speculators. It is said the tickets were printed in New York and arrive here last night.

CORUNNA, Spain, Nov. 18. -- The Spanish steamer Montserrat, which left Havana on Sunday, Oct. 31, with Gen. Weyler, the former Captain General of Cuba, on board, and which subsequently touched at Gibara and at Puerto Rico, arrived here unexpectedly to-day. She was not due to arrive here, according to the announcements, until Friday evening.

The second of the subscription series of concerts at the Astoria Hotel, was given in the ballroom last night. The programme consisted of Berlioz's overture to "Benvenuto Cellini," the violin concerto in B minor of Saint-Saens, the slow waltz from Volkmann's serenade for strings, "Anitra's Dance" from Grieg's "Peer Gynt" suite for strings, the Schubert-Liszt "Wanderer Fantasia" for piano and orchestra, and the pilgrim's march from Belioz's "Harold in Italy" symphony.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- Commodore George Dewey, President of the Naval Board of Inspection and Survey, in charge of the sea trial of the battleship Iowa, returned to his office in the department delighted with the showing made by the new vessel.

Just now many papers have much to say about Canada and the Canadians, and the question is often asked, Why are Canadians so loyal? Why do they not become annexed to the United States? As every person can better attest for his own individual case, I will give my experience with the Government of Canada and contrast it with the treatment one need expect from the United States Government in a like case.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 18. -- The Harvard football team left this afternoon for Philadelphia, where it will play Saturday against the Pennsylvania University's team.

The Trustees of Sailor's Snug Harbor yesterday continued their investigation into the charges of cruelty and mismanagement made against President Trask and other officials of the institution by the inmates. There were present at the board meeting in the Bank of Commerce Building Mayor Strong, the Rev. Dr. Morgan Dix, the Rev. Dr. Howard Duffield, Alexander E. Orr, Recorder Goff, Capt. George L. Norton, and Capt. Jayne.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18. -- Statements made by Tom Riley, the Milwaukee hackman who drove Mrs. Mabel Wallace Walkup to the residence of the Rev. J.P. Roberts to be married on the morning of Sept. 24 last, tend to strengthen the claim of John B. Ketcham's relatives that he was not the groom on that occasion.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- Senor Dupuy de Lome, the Spanish Minister, had a long conference with Assistant Secretary Day this morning, and it is believed that the Spanish Government is voluntarily about to remove another troublesome factor from the field of negotiations in revoking the decree made by Weyler prohibiting the exportation of tobacco from Cuba.

During the trial of the case of Audio de la Piechardiere against Charles H. Ropes, a wealthy broker, whom he is suing for $5,000 damages for an alleged assault, before Justice Bookstaver and a jury in the Supreme Court, both Judge and jury became indignant at the attempt on the part of A.H. Clapp; attorney for the defendant, to reflect upon the character of a woman witness for the plaintiff.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Nov. 18. -- Five new buildings were dedicated at Mount Holyoke College to-day, replacing those destroyed by fire one year ago. At the same time the sixtieth anniversary of the founding of the college was celebrated.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Nov. 18. -- A conference of silver Democratic leaders will be held in Louisville to-morrow night. William Jennings Bryan and Senator James K. Jones of the Democratic National Committee will be present to meet about fifty leading politicians of this State.

THE TIMES of last Sunday told us how the Dean of Rochester, speaking at a school fair of the necessity for the religious education of children, referred to the last sad example of American depravity to point his moral. According to the Dean, New York does very well for secular education, "but it has too little regard for the immortal souls of the children."

CINCINNATI, Nov. 18. -- The annual meeting of the Baltimore and Ohio Southwestern stockholders was held here to-day. The old Board of Directors was re-elected, and the Directors re-elected the old officials: President -- E.R. Bacon; Vice President and General Manager -- W.W. Peabody; Secretary -- Edward Bruce; Assistant Secretary -- F.E. Tracy; Treasurer -- W.E. Jones.

Two weeks ago the Board of Governors of the Commercial Club gave a dinner at the club rooms, on Chambers Street and West Broadway, to the members. Last night the members gave a dinner to the Governors. More than 200 of the 400 members were present, and applauded the utterances of the long list of speakers.
" The Democrats who considered themselves better than their party voted for Low because they regarded him as the embodiment of their ideas and notions of personal politics.

CITY OF MEXICO, Nov. 18. -- A profound sensation was made in the course of the trial of the police officials charged with the murder of Arroyo, the would-be murderer of President Diaz, by the production of the confession of the late Inspector General of Police Velasquez. Velasquez said in part: "I entertain the most enthusiastic admiration for Gen. Diaz.

The result of the meeting of the Committee on Organization of the Citizens' Union was really a foregone conclusion. The first fair contest that has ever been made in New York for the principle of non-partisanship in municipal affairs has enlisted 148,000 voters. Such an outcome of an organization improvised for the occasion and resolutely ignoring all other issues than that of municipal good government is of itself a great success.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- The Secret Service Bureau announces the discovery of a new counterfeit ten-dollar silver certificate, and a counterfeit National bank note.

In the South Reformed Church, Thirty-eighth Street and Madison Avenue, shortly after 4 P.M. yesterday, Miss Aline Marguerite Van Orden, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Van Orden of this city, was married to Charles Gallaudet Trumbull, son of the Rev. Dr. H. Clay Trumbull of Philadelphia. The officiating clergymen were the bridegroom's father and the Rev. Dr. Henry Van Dyke, pastor of the Brick Presbyterian Church, at Thirty-seventh Street and Fifth Avenue.
An attempt to defraud the Government was prevented by the United States Appraiser yesterday when an importation involving 200 and 300 carats of small diamonds was invoiced at about $24 per carat.

Justice Maddox of the Supreme Court decided yesterday in Long Island City that the present Grand Jury of Queens County was illegally constituted, and he therefore discharged it from further consideration of any cases before it. Queens County is thus without a Grand Jury, though the court is in session, and the indictments that have been found this term will no doubt be thrown out as worthless.

Peter Geistel, alias "Dutch Pete," now under arrest in Brooklyn as the accomplice of Constantine Steiger in the murder of Bellringer George Stelz, at the Church of the Holy Trinity, Williamsburg, last August, by the statement of a friend last night was also an accomplice of Steiger at the robbery of the Church of the Most Holy Redeemer, this city, when Policeman Smith was killed.

The Controller very properly characterized as an outrage the scheme by which certain property owners north of One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street coerced the Board of Street Openings. This they did by getting a law passed at Albany making mandatory upon the board an expenditure of millions upon a scheme for bringing their property into the market without regard to the mischief the scheme might work or to any other consideration.

Edouard Taylore, who is called the "Jimmy" Michael of France, is expected to arrive in New York on the American Liner St. Louis late to-night or to-morrow morning. Men interested in cycle racing abroad say that in Taylore "Jimmy" Michael has one of his most powerful rivals, and that it would not be surprising to see Taylore blossom out as winner over all comers.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Nov. l8. -- John P. De Camp, an account of whose alleged death was published in a New York paper on Tuesday, returned here to-day. He says he does not know who caused the publication, nor what the motive of it was.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18. -- Senator William E. Chandler of New Hampshire, in an interview to-day regarding legislation at the coming session of Congress, said:

CYNTHIANA, Ky., Nov. 18. -- The second day of the National Fox Hound trials was productive of some good sport. The Directors of the hunt decided last night to meet at Robinson Station. This meant a ride of ten miles before the hunt began. But better luck than yesterday was in store for the pack, for they had no sooner been thrown into cover than they gave tongue and jumped for a fox.

The funeral of the Rev. Dr. George H. Houghton, late rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration, in East Twenty-ninth Street, known to the greater part of the public and to the theatrical world as "The Little Church Around the Corner," who died on Wednesday, will be held in the church of which he has had charge for nearly fifty years, at 10 o'clock to-morrow morning.

Application of the principle of the famous Mannlicher rifle has but recently been made in the manufacture of a special rapid-fire magazine pistol, and an agent commissioned to lay the merits of a weapon of that description before the United States Government is already in this country, and will in a few days present himself with proper credentials at the War Department in Washington.

Notwithstanding Richard Croker's protestations that he has not talked with Mayor-elect Van Wyck concerning appointments, men who want positions under the next administration continue to seek audience with him. Mr. Croker was at his office at 111 Broadway for several hours yesterday.

This year's Horse Show is the thirteenth. The superstitious among the horsemen might have had some forebodings of ill when thinking of the success of the show, but the officers evidently have no fear of the number 13 because the Board of Directors of the association is composed of thirteen members, and the majority of these have been on the board since the first Horse Show was given in the old Madison Square Garden.

That the recent reaction in the stock market and its present dullness must be succeeded by better values and a greater activity is the opinion of many close observers of the financial situation. Depressing factors are disappearing one by one and making it hard work for the bearish contingent to furnish "news" that has not already been discounted by the Street.

NEW BRUNSWICK, Nov. 18. -- United States Senator Platt of New York yesterday became the owner of 210.21 acres of land in Middlesex County. The property is farm land, lying in Monroe Township. Thomas Canary, formerly in partnership with George W. Lederer in the management of the Casino, New York; Mary Canary, and Thomas Auld were the owners.

At the Seventy-first Regiment Armory yesterday afternoon W. Lennard Foote, the inventor of Lennard's Bulletproof Auto-Dynamic Armor, repeated the test he made at the Twenty-third Regiment Armory, in Brooklyn, about two weeks ago, and gave an exhibition of the invulnerability of his invention before representatives of a number of foreign Governments and State militia officers.
Here is a graphic narrative from real life showing how many of our friends whom we love may be on the verge of a great tragedy.

Senator Platt will have his way, and Congressman Quigg will be re-elected Chairman of the Republican County Committee. At the regular monthly meeting of the committee, held last night in Murray Hill Lyceum, Third Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, a resolution of confidence in the County Chairman was adopted without a dissenting voice.

ALBANY, Nov. 18. -- Owing to the great number of litigations over title to lands from the result of tax sales which have been brought against the State recently, Attorney General Hancock has decided to create a new position in his office, to be known as tax clerk. The salary of the position will be $1,800 per annum.

LONDON, Nov. 19. -- According to a special dispatch from Shanghai Admiral von Diederich, Commander of the German cruiser division, before landing marines at Kiao-Chau on Monday morning notified the British, French, and Russian Admirals of his intention, and it is said that the Russian Admiral expressed approval.

MONTEVIDEO, Nov. 19. -- The city is in a panic over the incident at to-day's session of the Chamber of Deputies and the report that Dr. Miguel Herrera y Obes, Minister of the Interior and of Justice in the Borda Cabinet, has been shot with a revolver.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 19. -- The Canadian Commissioners appointed by the Dominion Government to confer with Commissioners appointed by the United States in regard to deep waterways have prepared their report to the Canadian Government. The Commissioners of both countries have been at work for about two years.

ITHACA, Nov. 19. -- Hannis Taylor, ex-Minister of the United States to Spain, delivered an address on Cuba before 2,000 persons in Library Hall here to-night. The audience was in sympathy with the Cubans and applauded every reference made by the speaker to their struggle for liberty, and particularly his declaration that the time had arrived for the United States to recognize the independence of the island.

James Masterli, who killed Michael Fitzsimmons of New York in Jersey City on Aug. 21, was yesterday convicted of manslaughter in the Court of General Sessions before Judge Hudspeth. Masterli and his father were employed as watchmen at the ruins of the Jersey City Chemical Works, which had been destroyed by fire.

Should collectors bequeath their treasures to libraries, or should they leave behind them the request that they should be dispersed at public auction? Edmond de Goncourt, the novelist, was of the latter opinion, and at Bangs Co.'s may be seen a framed extract from his will in which his desire is expressed.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 19. -- Fred W. Pugsley, whilom Sunday school Superintendent, politician, and society man, who left this city some time ago under a cloud, was completely disgraced to-day when it became known that the Grand Jury had indicted him on fifteen counts for felony. Pugsley has been living in New Jersey. It is reported that he started for Europe recently and is now in Italy.

The Western National Bank, of which John E. Searles, Treasurer of the American Sugar Refining Company, is President, has bought out and paid for nine-tenths of the stock of the United States National Bank, of which Dr. James H. Parker is President. The United States will retire from business by liquidation in absolute financial prosperity.

Dr. Robertson Nicoll says that Mr. Kipling would not take payment from The Times for his "Recessional" or for "Our Lady of the Snows." Mr. Kipling's reason was that he did not desire payment for poems that were purely patriotic. Probably this is the first case on record where a poet of eminence has refused a check for his productions.

Reports from the different State Divisions of the League of American Wheelmen indicate that the regular nominees were generally elected. Out of 360 delegates, an estimate gives Isaac B. Potter, the present President, 190 votes for re-election. While at present the returns are not conclusive, there is reason to believe Mr. Potter will retain a plurality, if not a majority.

The movement to destroy the Platt organization has begun to take definite shape, it is reported, and already conferences of prominent anti-organization men have been held, at which a plan of procedure was discussed. It is the intention of the leaders of the movement to perfect a State organization in time to send a full delegation to the next State Convention.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- Californians are confident that the position of Attorney General, soon to be made vacant by the transfer of Judge McKenna to the Supreme Court bench, will be filled by the appointment of Judge Waymire. This will enable California to hold honors in both the Supreme Court and the Cabinet.

The Christian life is described in the Bible under various names. Sometimes it is spoken of as "a husbandry"; sometimes as "a building"; sometimes as "a race," and sometimes as "a warfare." But whatever term may be used, there is always involved in it the idea of a struggle and conflict, demanding most careful watching and most earnest effort.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19. -- The inquest upon the body of John B. Ketcham has been continued until Tuesday. This has been done in order to allow the Coroner and police to go to each of the drug stores at which medicine was procured for Ketcham, to compare the prescriptions on file with those now in the possession of the physician who issued them.

William H. Chandler, who was the fifth juror secured to try May Kellard for forgery in the General Sessions, was yesterday challenged peremptorily by Assistant District Attorney D. Frank Lloyd, after twelve talesmen had been accepted. The reason given by Mr. Lloyd was that he had seen Mr. Chandler exchanging smiles with the defendant. Mr. Chandler denies this.

Tammany Hall yesterday celebrated its victory in the recent municipal election by giving away $40,000 of unexpended campaign funds, $20,000 to the Cuban insurgents and $20,000 to the poor of this city. Nathan Straus supplemented this with a gift of 1,000 tons of coal, also for the poor of New York.

This terrestrial globe will be scarcely large enough for a football if it keeps on shrinking at its recent rate. A fortnight ago STANLEY AFRICANUS rode in a palace car to Buluwayo, and the rails will soon penetrate the remotest regions where only a little while ago he fought and cut his way through forests and savages.
BOSTON, Nov. 20. -- The Journal this morning says:...
LONDON, Nov. 19. -- The race for the Derby Cup was won by Mr. Fairie's three-year-old bay colt Eager, at the second day's racing of the Derby November Meeting, to-day.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Nov. 9. -- The black soldiers of the First Battalion West India Regiment broke barracks on Thursday night last, (Nov. 4,) and, proceeding to this city, began to assault and belabor every citizen and policeman with whom they came in contact, the police in particular suffering severely. About 150 of these men gathered in the Parade Gardens, belonging to the Government, and played havoc with the trees.

PARIS, Nov. 1. -- "The Jasper Cane" ("La Canne de Jaspe") is a volume of singularly fascinating stories by M. Henri de Regnier, the symbolist poet, whose personality is not altogether unknown to the readers of THE NEW YORK TIMES, for his recent duel with Comte Robert de Montesquiou caused an endless amount of talk at the time.

In an editorial published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 6 under the caption "San Diego and San Pedro Bays," it was said: "The People of San Diego, Southern California, are much exercised over the proposal to appropriate $2,900,000 of the National funds for the construction of a deep-water harbor at San Pedro.

PARIS, Nov. 19. -- The Jour says Count Ferdinand Walsin Esterhazy, the retired Major of the French Army, who is accused of being implicated in the leaking of military secrets since Dreyfus was deported, and who is said to have been the author of the unsigned letter which led to the trial and condemnation of Dreyfus, has upon more than one occasion confided to it (the paper mentioned) information contrary to the military regulations, adding:

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 19. -- The Solomon Islanders on the Island of Guadalcana, emboldened by their success in overcoming the Austrian expedition under Baron von Norbeck, recently raided the English settlements and robbed and pillaged the inhabitants. Three murders were perpetrated, the victims being Jean Porritt, a trader, and his two assistants.
Hall J. How Co. have sold for the Cheeseman estate to a client, the lot northeast corner of Lenox Avenue and One Hundred and Eighteenth Street, 25 by 100.

Some interesting manuscripts of Gilbert White of Selborne are about to come into the auction room in London. About two and a half years ago the original autograph manuscript of White's famous book was sold for 294, and now purchasers are to have an opportunity to acquire the original letters which White sent to Thomas Pennant.

The sale of the second part of the late Lord Ashburnham's library will take place in London during the second week of December. The sale of the first part took place in June during the jubilee festivities. The men who conduct these sales take care that they shall be held while the buying public are in London.

A burglar with a stout pole and a sharp hook did some seal fishing early yesterday morning in West Thirty-fourth Street in the vicinity of the new Astoria Hotel. With a cloth-covered weight the lone burglar punched a hole in the plate glass front of Siede's fashionable fur establishment at No. 34.

It seems strange that in the heart not alone of the "nation of London," but of the city of that name, a fire should be permitted to rage for hours practically unresisted. For it seems that the efforts of the firemen were from the first directed not to putting out the fire but only to prevent it from spreading.

The Schedule Committee of the Long Island Interscholastic Athletic League held a meeting at Adelphi Academy yesterday afternoon and perfected arrangements for the annual handball and basket ball tournaments. The following schedules were arranged:
In their weekly review of trade Messrs. R.G. Dun Co. will say:

The Horse Show begins its last day this morning. Yesterday was marked again by a good attendance, and the evening session was the gayest, socially, of the week. The seats and boxes were filled with handsomely, and often strikingly, gowned women and men in evening dress, while the spaces back of the seat rows were filled with people, standing and craning their necks to obtain a glimpse of the performances in the ring.

Many curious details having to do with early Georgia and Savannah may be found in The American Colonial Tracts for September, a monthly published by George P. Humphrey of Rochester. Where were inducements offered such as might suit a man could he be prevailed upon to lay out a county and build a new town in Georgia 162 years ago.

New officers of the New York City Christian Endeavor Local Union were chosen at the annual meeting held on Thursday evening in the Lexington Avenue Baptist Church. They are: President -- H.A. Kinports; Vice President -- Dr. W.B. McCracken; Secretary -- William J. Yates; Assistant Secretary -- David Lindsay; Treasurer -- William A. Sinclair.

LONDON, Nov. 19. -- Fire this afternoon burned over four acres occupied by large six-story business houses lying eastward of Aldersgate and between that thoroughfare and Red Cross Street, and destroyed property valued at nearly 5,000,000, ($25,000,000.)

In the communication entitled "The Teachers of Massachusetts," published in your last Saturday's REVIEW OF BOOKS AND ART, George E. Gay takes issue with a correspondent on Mr. Frederic Burk's criticism of normal schools.

In "His Grace of Osmonde" and "A Lady of Quality," Mrs. Burnett has tried the interesting experiment of making one plot do for two fables. Most novel readers and theatregoers by this time know the story of Clorinda Wildairs, her blustering, brilliant youth, her curious development, her tragic secret, and her peaceful and beautiful wedded life.

There was a revival yesterday of the report of a truce in the Amsterdam Avenue fight between the Metropolitan Street Railway Company and the Third Avenue Railroad Company. It was said that the companies were driven by fear of the Kingston decision to an attempt to reach an amicable agreement.

Mr. EDMUNDS, the veteran statesman and President of the Arbitration Conference, is reported to be confident of the renewal of the negotiations and the ratification of a treaty this Winter. This hope is based largely on the cordial interest shown by President McKINLEY.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 19. -- Edward Rosenfeld, who arrived from New York recently, was yesterday arrested on several charges of forgery.

" Jim of Thirty-three" is almost as well known to Fire Department members as Chief Bonner. His picture and biography are in the official history of the organization. Few men have served much longer then he has, and none more faithfully or bravely.

The bark Agate, 600 tons register, is lying at the foot of Court Street, Brooklyn, and is being made ready for a trip to the Alaskan gold fields. The promoters of the expedition intend to set sail by Dec. 10 at the latest. They are members of the Copper River Mining and Development Company, which has offices in the Arbuckle Building.

As one who did a little something toward the making of literature in this country, I am greatly gratified to see your splendid eight-page paper THE SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS AND ART. This, indeed, is a venture greatly needed, and I feel convinced it will be thoroughly appreciated by many more than "bookworms" whenever the English language is spoken, and its literature produced.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 19. -- This city became football wild to-day, and every hour adds to the enthusiasm and the crowds. For some days the larger store windows have been scantily decorated with the blue of Yale and the orange and black of Princeton, but this morning the window decorators began the preparation of the most elaborate decorations ever seen in this city in connection with a Yale athletic event.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- Wu-Ting-Fang, the Chinese Minister, has received the following official statement from Pekin, relative to the seizure of Kaio-chau Island:

ST. PETERSBURG, Nov. 19. -- The appointment of Prof. F. de Martens of the Ministry for Foreign Affairs and Professor of International Law in the University of St. Petersburg, as arbitrator in the Anglo-Venezuelan boundary dispute, has been formally approved by the Czar.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 19. -- The new recitation hall which John D. Rockefeller built for Vassar College at a cost of $100,000, was dedicated this afternoon. The building occupies a commanding site near the entrance to the college grounds, and is altogether the finest of the college buildings. It is a three-story structure of brick, with limestone trimmings.

Judge Duffy, in the Long Island City Police Court, yesterday committed "Corkey" Lee, the official poundmaster of Long Island City, to one day in jail, and at the examination testimony showing the unbusinesslike method with which "Corkey" does business came out.

A Malden (Mass.) correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES asserts that Frederick Burk's article has made no commotion in the Normal Schools of the State; and that "if it is (sic) true that the teachers in our Normal Schools believe that some general truths pertaining to the instruction of youth have been established by suitable evidence during the last 2,000 years, the people of Massachusetts will forgive them and continue to patronize the schools."

The Appellate Division yesterday affirmed the decision of the Special Term, adjudging Commissioner of Correction Robert J. Wright to be in contempt for disobeying the order requiring him to reinstate John Fallon in his position of Warden of the City Prison. In January, 1896, Fallon was suspended, and after a trial was found guilty upon charges and removed from his position.

I was surprised to see in THE TIMES of to-day an article by a woman in favor of an "Anti-Audubon Society." I saw the plea for the birds by "A.A.C." which has roused the ire of "A.B.C." I, myself, thought it very good, not by any means weakly sentimental, but a just deprecation of wanton cruelty.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Nov. 9. -- Alleged details have just been received here from Santo Domingo, the Spanish Republic of the West Indies, of the arrest of Arthur Tweedy, late British Vice Consul at Port-au-Prince, the capital of Haiti, and now British Consul at Santo Domingo.

A violin valued at $5,000 is the feature of an exhibition of old instruments now on view at the Everett House, in this city. It is one of the few high-priced violins in this country, and comes from Lyon Healy. J.C. Freeman is in charge of the exhibition, which is open to the public from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M.

Marie Corelli has had her portrait made, the artist being a Miss Donald-Smith. One might expect that Marie Corelli would appear as a flashing dream, dressed in black, with gores of crimson, but she does not. The artist has given Marie Corelli the guise of a golden-haired young person, clad in virginal white, walking down a staircase.

Senator CHANDLER of New Hampshire says of the next session of Congress: "As to financial legislation, especially as to a revision of the banking laws, I do not see how any such legislation can be passed." Considering how unsound Mr. CHANDLER'S view's on finance have been and how strong is his desire for mischievous legislation, this opinion is not discouraging to the friends of currency reform.

The Wayside Inn of Longfellow has today a more real existence than in the lifetime of the poet. At least when he wrote his famous tales the old tavern at Sudbury was no longer a public house, and it was merely the poet's imagination which brought mine host to life and endowed him and his guests with those fascinating story-telling powers.

One of the moat popular books of a few years ago was "How to be Happy Though Married." It was a noteworthy example of success, due in large part to a title. The author of it has since published "The Five Talents of Women," which secured a more modest success. He has now just issued through the Frederick A. Stokes Company a volume devoted to "The Love Affairs of Some Famous Men."

The Public Education Association held its annual meeting yesterday afternoon in the American Art Galleries, 6 East Twenty-third Street. The President, Mrs. Schuyler Van Rensselaer, presided, and the meeting was addressed by James C. Carter and President Hubbell of the Board of Education. There was a very large attendance.

The case of FRED R. KETCHAM of Chicago against the Northwestern Railroad Company is a very interesting one. He has just secured a verdict of $21,666.33 for damages caused by what is known as "blacklisting." He was a freight conductor in the employ of the defendant company at the time of the famous Pullman strike, gave up his train, and was discharged.

PRINCETON, Nov. 19. -- Versemakers at Princeton have ground out some new songs to be sung at the Yale game to-morrow. Among the ditties which Princeton rooters will sing is the following, to the air of the "Couchee-Couchee":

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- Paul W. Bartlett, the American sculptor, residing in Paris, who provided the statue of Law now in place in the Congressional Library rotunda, and who also designed the statue of Columbus, arrived here to-day to see his figure of Columbus placed on its pedestal in the rotunda gallery.
The Tribune states very fairly, without indorsing, the objections of some Republicans to undertaking currency reform at the next session of Congress, in the spirit of Secretary GAGE'S proposition:

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 20. -- A pigeon shooting match between George J. Gould and Dwight M. Harris was an event of interest at the Ocean County Hunt and Country Club traps this morning. Four rounds of ten birds each were released from the cages, lfr. Gould winning two rounds at 27 yards and Ir. Harris one at 28 yards and one at 29.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 20. -- The Lakewood season is on fully a month earlier this year than ever before. All the hotels are open. The Laurel House was, as usual, the first to receive guests, and has been entertaining a goodly number of people for seven weeks. For a month the Palmer House has been open, and on Thursday the Lakewood Hotel and the Laurel-in-the-Pines both opened for the season of 1897-8.

" Americans will not pay for the finest flavored teas," said Mr. Blechynden, a man who has spent twenty years in India, speaking to the New York Association of the Teachers of Cookery at the Teachers College recently. "Good teas do not come to this country. If you want good tea, go to the poor people in the North of Ireland.

Justice Abraham Lawrence, in the Supreme Court, yesterday granted a temporary injunction restraining the Rev. John W. Kjelgaard, pastor of the First Free-Will Baptist Church of this city, and John H. Russell and Peter Hessey, President and Secretary of the Board of Trustees of the church, respectively, from interfering with the church property pending the application for a permanent injunction and the appointment of a receiver for the property.

At the last meeting of the Mothers' Congress of the City of New York. Dr. Mary Putnam Jacobi delivered an address on "The Care of the Adolescent Girl" of uncommon interest to all who are concerned in the training of children of the gentler sex. Dr. Jacobi laid special emphasis upon the necessity for a purpose to animate all women's lives.

In 1872 Mr. W. Bancroft Espeut imported four pairs of the Indian mongoose from Calcutta into Jamaica for the purpose of destroying the "cane-piece rat." Ten years later it was estimated that the saving to the colony through the work of this animal amounted to 100,000 annually. Then came a sudden change in the aspect of affairs.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 20. -- Emma Goldman, the Anarchist leader, lectured last night in the People's Tabernacle (Congregational) and boldly proclaimed her infidelity, her disbelief in laws, and her opposition to the customs of matrimony,

At the meeting of the "Section of Neurology and Psychiatry" of the Academy of Medicine, Friday evening, two papers were read that are of general interest and provoked considerable discussion. The first was by Dr. William P. Wilkin, and was entitled "A Consideration of the Place and Value of Hypnotism in the Treatment of Disease."

The Mannlicher pistol, made in Berlin, described in THE NEW YORK TIMES recently, is not the only small arm brought to this country from Europe in which the smokeless powder is used. The Borchardt automatic repeating pistol was tested in target firing at Creedmoor on Sept. 11 by Col. McCoskry Butt of the Twelfth Regiment and Major N.B. Thurston, at 25, 100, and 200 yards.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- A few members of the Senate and the House of Representatives have appeared in Washington this week, mostly men like Senator Morgan, who live here nearly all the time, but it is safe to say that not until after Thanksgiving Day will there be a quorum of either body in this city.
Two reasons, among many others, why we cannot decently annex Hawaii must impress every reasonable and disinterested mind:

The Executive Committee of Tammany Hall is not legally responsible for the disposition of the money subscribed to its campaign fund, except to the subscribers. As it may be supposed that they consider that they have received value for their contributions, they are not likely to make any objection.

BERLIN, Nov. 20. -- The Economic Council, which began its sessions this week and whose most important meetings will be attended by the Emperor, is a body specially called together by the Government to devise the best measures needed in regard to international tariff relations, with special reference to the United States and Great Britain and her colonies.

LONDON, Nov. 20. -- Rosa Obitzka, who has sung in the Metropolitan Opera House, New York, had an enthusiastic reception at Thursday's Philharmonic concert in London. She has been engaged to sing with the de Reszkes in German opera at St. Petersburg in April.

George R. Ernst, Consul at Reichenberg, Austria, in a report to the Department of Agriculture, has furnished some interesting facts relative to wheat shortage in Austria-Hungary and the consequent importation of American grain. Mr. Ernst says:

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 20. -- There is ground far the belief that the action of the Government in dispatching the revenue cutter Bear to the relief of the ice-bound whalers in the Arctic Ocean was taken with a view to covering up the glaring abandonment of the wrecked whaler Navarch. It will bring out the heroic devotion to duty of the revenue marine officers.

Christian English, the mechanical engineer of The New York Sun, is an angry man. He says he has been bunkoed out of a $10,000 interest that he had in a house at 1,014 Avenue A. He wants his money back and $5,000 damages besides, and to secure this he has employed a lawyer.

-- Those who are seeking for signs of prosperity in these days would do well to drop in at the important musical entertainments. This first public rehearsal of the Philharmonic Society, an afternoon performance, drew an audience which packed Carnegie Hall so that even the heads of the aisles were crowded.

An unknown woman held up a seven-year-old girl in the most crowded portion of One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street last night and robbed the little girl of $2. The act was deliberate, and the woman fled, leaving the little girl standing on the curb crying bitterly.

LONDON, Nov. 20. -- A number of fire engines to-night are still playing upon the smouldering ruins marking the scene of the great conflagration, near the General Post Office, yesterday, by which a very large amount of property was destroyed. Tottering walls have been falling every now and then.

At the meeting of the Medico-Legal Society on Wednesday night, a paper by Dr. Carleton Simon of this city was announced, but was not read, for the reason that it was not yet quite complete. It will appear in a future publication of the society. The subject appeals promptly to the curiosity as well as to a much deeper interest, that which mankind always feels in a study of itself.

The apprehensions that were expressed at the beginning of the week that the Horse Show might become a mere horse show have been realized. It is true that everybody in New York who cares about horses has gone to the show. But the great majority of them have gone to see the horses. The occupants of the boxes have for the most part given over the endeavor to "outstyle" the occupants of the ring.

" The movement is simmering," said William Brookfield yesterday, speaking of the anti-Platt agitation, started by the protest of James Yereance at the meeting of the Republican County Committee Thursday night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- Secretary Gage scans the daily report of the receipts and expenditures of the Government with hope that is deferred. Four months of the fiscal year only have passed and the deficit is more than forty millions of dollars. During three of those months the Dingley law has been in operation.

ALBANY, Nov. 20. -- Superintendent Verplanck Colvin of the State Land Survey has just returned from an official visit to the central western portion of the Adirondacks, where he has been directing the work of survey of the boundary line between the counties of Hamilton and Herkimer.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 20. -- The little hamlet of Barrett, in Marshall County, this State, is the home of one of the most eccentric as well as one of the wealthiest men in the West. His name is Horace L. Sage, and he is a cousin of Russell Sage, the Wall Street financier. He is a bachelor, an octogenarian, and is worth in Kansas lands and Government securities $1,500,000.

What a difference there is in the faces of women, and for that matter, of men also, and how strange the effect is. There are faces that attract men and fascinate women, while there are others that seem to repel just as strongly.

MOUNT VERNON, Nov. 20. -- Many people in this city are suffering from headaches to-day as the result of being made sick by odors from gas last night. When the lights were turned on early last evening people all over the city noticed a peculiar, nauseating odor about their apartments.

Gen. AUSTIN LATHROP, Superintendent of State Prisons, makes a striking statement of the working of the present law for the employment of convict labor. During the eleven months for which the law has been in force requisitions, or orders, have been received for supplies worth $750,000, selling price.

AFTER a most honorable service of more than thirty-two years in the Fire Department of this city, Battalion Chief Benjamin A. Gicquel was recently promoted to the position of Deputy Chief. His promotion is regarded throughout the department as a well-deserved reward for a long and faithful career as a "fire fighter."

In the presence of a score or more of the Protestant Episcopal Sisters of St. Mary and Sisters of St. John the Baptist, together will about 200 of the older parishioners of the Church of the Transfiguration, in East Twenty-ninth Street, a requiem mass was said over the body of the rector, the Rev. George Hendrick Houghton at 7 A.M. yesterday.
Any one in need of a complete outfit of baby clothes will do well to apply to the Secretary and Treasurer of the Aid-a-Bit League, which has one to dispose of cheap. The reason why is here set forth:

" Ancient and Modern Rome" was the subject of Prof. Albert S. Bickmore's address yesterday morning, at the American Museum of Natural History, in the series of lectures he is giving to the teachers of the State under the auspices of the Department of Public Instruction. These lectures have so grown in popularity that the audience now overflows the hall, and applications for tickets are still flowing in daily.

Within the last fortnight two bicyclists arrested for "scorching" after a long chase have been fined $3 each and allowed to go. Only a short time since a drunken driver who had put many lives in peril and had fought desperately with the policeman who arrested him was released on the payment of $10.

Patrolmen Logan and Rothschild of the East Eighty-eighth Street Station took to Bellevue Hospital last night a pair of extremely pretty girl babies, twins, which Mrs. Eliza Fritchie of 108 East Eighty-fourth Street had found shortly before, in the vestibule of her home, on returning from a shopping tour, and now the hospital authorities are looking resignedly forward to a positive invasion of foundlings in the near future.

WILMINGTON, N.C., Nov. 20. -- The pleasure yacht Republic, Capt. Randelette, bound from Mobile to New London, and owned by George Matthews of New York, was towed up to the city to-day in a dismantled condition.

" Miserable night, isn't it?" The speaker was a fine-looking man of middle age and with nothing more remarkable about him than a pair of keen gray eyes which had in their depths a peculiar twinkle. He had just entered an elevated train at Park Place and had taken a seat next to the person to whom he had made the remark about the weather, which was in every way fitting.

TO visitors to the Chamber of the United States Senate there is no more impressive figure in that body than that of the senior Senator from Vermont, the venerable but still capable, attentive, and alert Justin S. Morrill.

Figures illustrative of the growth of the trade in exports of numerous articles of home-made manufacture have on several occasions recently been presented in these columns. This business is becoming of considerable importance, and the significant fact is being gradually recognized by consumers abroad that American inventive genius is without a peer, and that the progressive manufacturer must avail himself of American appliances if he means to produce the best results.

Augustan Daly has decided to make next week the last of "The Geisha," and on Monday evening, Nov. 29, Miss Rehan will make her first appearance since her return from England at Daly's Theatre as Katherine, in "The Taming of the Shrew." Charles Richman, George Clarke, John Craig, Edwin Varrey, William Owen, Tyrone Power, Joseph Herbert, Wilfred Clarke, Sidney Herbert, Marie St. John, Ethel Hornick, and Mrs. G.H. Gilbert will also appear in this production.

James T. Hyde, the Assistant Secretary of the Horse Show Association, and a prime mover in shows held all over the country, has one or two gray hairs now. They appeared last week, and were not caused by any worry or hard work connected with the recent show, but by the fun several of his friends have had with him.
LONDON, Nov. 20. -- Prof. Henry Calderwood is dead.

The interest of railroad men, financiers and the business public in general, is already largely centred upon the approaching argument before the Supreme Court of the United States of the Appeal of the Government in the case against the Joint Traffic Association from the judgment of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals, favorable to the defendant body.

Among the cycle club and good road association delegates who attended the meeting last Monday to consider a feasible plan for a pathway for cyclers over the Brooklyn Bridge, it seemed to be the sentiment that the gathering was a forerunner of many, when all the cycle and good road bodies would join hands to secure the accomplishment of their aims.

The Comparative Literature Society held its semi-annual meeting yesterday in the Carnegie Lyceum, Fifty-seventh Street and Seventh Avenue. Charles Sprague Smith, the Director, presided, and about 250 members were present. The topic presented for the consideration of the meeting was "The Need of a Literary Institute," Charles Dudley Warner, Advisory Councilor of the society, delivering the address on that subject.

On the editorial page in to-day's issue of THE TIMES, under the head of "Personal," is a paragraph on the use of birds for millinery purposes -- a remarkable combination of sense and nonsense -- the gist of which is expressed in the sentence: "Killing is the law of nature, and the pretty little birds are not exempt from it." The writer says:

BALTIMORE, Nov. 20. -- This city is now passing through what might be appropriately called the third stage of the evolution of rapid transit. The first was the transition from horse cars to the trolley and cable motors, the second was the extension of city lines into the suburbs, and now comes the consolidation of systems with a view to monopoly in street railway operation.

PARIS, Nov. 20. -- William Riley Foster, Jr., who was arrested at Neuilly, near Paris, on Oct. 23, charged with having embezzled $193,000 belonging to the Gratuity Fund of the New York Produce Exchange while special attorney of the fund in 1888, is making a hard fight against extradition to the United States, an application for which was made to the French authorities by the American Embassy.
Mrs. Frederick Nathan made an address yesterday morning before the League for Political Education, at its headquarters, 509 Fifth Avenue, on "The Consumers' League," of which she is President.

The Board of County Canvassers yesterday officially announced the number of the votes cast for candidates in the County of New York, which includes the Boroughs of Manhattan and the Bronx, at the last election. The vote polled by every candidate was declared, except two only -- the vote for Alderman and Assemblyman in the Nineteenth District, where it is withheld pending a contest in the courts.

The long-time-expected and much-feared advance of Russian influence in Persia has come. It is not a showy one at the outset, but it bodes no good for our Protestant in situations. Russian priests have come to Oroomiah to open schools. The Christian population, groaning under Mohammedan oppression, and seeing in their coming the promise of political deliverance, have welcomed it with wild enthusiasm.
In THE TIMES of Sunday last I read with interest an article entitled "Not a Question of Years. Happy Marriages Possible Even When a Wife Is Older Than Her Husband."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 20. -- Yale, 6; Princeton, 0. The score tells briefly the story of the greatest athletic football game Yale Field ever saw. It tells of a victory for the Blue as fair as it was complete and as brilliant as it was surprising.

" Uncle 'Lisha's Outing" will be to many readers like an echo from their own past, a rustic past peopled with "folks" at once keen and simple, with wits so apt and ways so plain that in their presence the elaborations and devious follies of urban life seem suddenly ridiculous.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20. -- The Chicago-St. Paul roads met to-day with the members of the Executive Committee of the Western Passenger Association, for the purpose of considering the reduction made yesterday by the Wisconsin Central in the rates between St. Paul and Minneapolis and Chicago.

The methods adopted by the German Emperor of at once promoting the expansion of Germany and demonstrating the need of a large navy are not marked by suavity. In Haiti the German Minister intervened to prevent the punishment of a German subject who seems to have been quite justly condemned for disorderly conduct.

A recently tested telescripteur perfected in Berlin is intended to receive and record telephone messages during the absence of the party called. By its use a skillful operator can transmit 120 letters a minute. It consists of a keyboard, which makes contact when the key is pressed, and sends momentary currents into the line.

PARIS, Nov. 20. -- During the debate in the Chamber of Deputies to-day on the subject of the agricultural crisis the Premier, M. Meline, declared the cause of the crisis was the progressive fall during the past twenty years in the price of all agricultural products, combined with the depreciation in the price of silver.

WILMINGTON, N.C., Nov. 20. -- The schooner Charles H. Sprague, Capt. Harper, from Georgetown for New York, with a cargo of lumber, is in the harbor at Southport, with her port rigging torn away, as a result of a collision at sea on Wednesday afternoon.

PERHAPS some persons who attended the recent Boston Symphony Orchestra concert and insisted on a repetition of the last movement of Grieg's "Peer Gynt" suite thought themselves sadly abused when they read THE NEW YORK TIMES and its esteemed contemporary The Tribune on the following morning.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 20. - "So this is a free country," said an English resident of San Francisco, sententiously, to an American visitor who had been dilating upon the beauties of the American idea. "But let me tell you the history of one woman in free America. You may doubt it, but I can substantiate it.

Two important matches were decided at the Seventh Regiment ranges last night. In the handicap match, the conditions of which were seven shots standing and seven shots prone, there were five prizes for as many classes. Private H.W. Wilson, Company D, a new member of the club, carried off first prize. The team-of-two match, seven shots standing and seven shots prone, had numerous entries.

Sir John Fastolf had by his will devised his castle, called Caister, to John Paston. As a fortification, it was an excellent defense against foreign invaders, and as a residence it was worthy of royalty itself. In fact, the Duke of Gloster, afterward Richard III., at one time contemplated making it his abode.

Every woman who sees "A Lady of Quality" meditates enviously upon the good old days of Queen Anne and the pretty gowns and fine manners. We do not have either now. That is, comparatively. We have pretty gowns, rich gowns, lovely gowns, but they none of them have that charming and always becoming style which makes Queen Anne gowns so altogether delightful.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- Probably for the first time in a full half century the Navy Department to-day opened proposals for building a full-rigged sailing ship without steam power This craft is wanted for the instruction of the cadets at Annapolis in seamanship and navigation according to the old fashion.

The Waldorf-Astoria was the scene early yesterday morning of an accident that came within an ace of costing H.A. Seagrist of Chicago, a guest of the hotel, his life, and which gave rise to all sorts of reports and rumors. Wall Street has had a week devoid of interesting incident. Quotations have fluctuated in uninteresting ways. Nothing of consequence has come to pass. Here and there bear speculators have tried to force reactions through grewsome recitations of what might happen; but expectations so arranged have disappointed traders counting on depression.
Raoul Pugno, the pianist, will give a recital at Carnegie Hall on Thursday afternoon, Dec. 2, at 3 o'clock. His programme will consist wholly of works of the new French School.

MAINE has been succeeded as a shipbuilding State by Pennsylvania, and with the change of place the type of vessel now constructed is vastly different. The old American clipper ships, with their fine lines and lofty spars, have been followed by the ponderous steel ships propelled by powerful steam engines.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Nov. 20. -- A westbound freight train on the Erie Railroad was derailed by train wreckers at Sloatsburg early this morning. This is where attempts were made last Sunday to wreck an express and a freight train. The wreck today is thought to be due to the same miscreants, who were unsuccessful on the previous occasion.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20. -- Before the largest crowd that ever witnessed a football game in this city the University of Pennsylvania football eleven this afternoon on Franklin Field defeated the Harvard team by the score of 15 to 6. It was not a "sensational" game. There were but few good runs, the fifty-five-yard dash of Parker and Jackson's twenty-five-yard run being the only ones of moment.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 20. -- The arrangements for the Merrill-Dresser wedding, which will take place Dec. 1, were completed yesterday. The bride, Miss Pauline Georgine Warren Dresser of Newport, is the sister of Mrs. J. Nicholas Brown. The bridegroom is the Rev. George Grenville of Merrill of Tuxedo, N.Y.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Nov. 20. -- In March, 1894, Miss Alice P. Decker, one of the prettiest girls in Tivoli, made a runaway match with John T. Hoffman, son of Theodore A. Hoffman, a prominent resident in Northern Dutchess County, and the County Clerk who was removed by Gov. Hill for his stand in the Osborne Senatorial contest, and is at present filling his third term in the office from which he was removed.

Once I spoke, in a certain article, of two illustrious friends of mine, one in France, the other in Spain, whose ascendency over their fellow-countrymen was almost supreme: Gambetta and Canovas, endowed by heaven with all the qualities vouchsafed to the favored ones of earth, but both afflicted with a certain grave weakness -- that of not being able to endure contradiction.

PARIS, Nov. 10. -- The Dreyfus question continues to agitate the public mind, and there can be no doubt that the feeling of uncertainty as to whether the ex-Captain was guilty or not is becoming widespread. M. Bernard Lazare, who is the representative of the Dreyfus family, has not yet published his new brochure on the subject of the prisoner's condemnation, and the book is not expected to appear for another weak

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 20. -- The contested election of the President of the Borough of Richmond, S.I., came before Justice Dykman, holding a special term of the Supreme Court to-day, in the shape of an alternative writ of mandamus issued by Justice Keogh, to show cause why certain ballots claimed as void and defective should not be counted.

STREATOR, Ill., Nov. 20. -- The convention of striking coal miners of the Northern Illinois coal fields at a late hour last night reached a secret agreement which will be made known next Monday to the various organizations interested. It is believed it has taken steps looking to the securing of a compromise.

Preparations for the grand historical entertainment, to be given by the National Society of New England Women at the Metropolitan Opera House on Nov. 30, have about been completed. More than a thousand persons are expected to take part in the tableaus, and, as far as possible, the characters they will represent will be those of their own ancestors.

It is bewildering to contemplate the effects of the introduction of this great invention into general use. Some of the things already possible, and which have been tried by its merits, are as follows:
