LONDON, Nov. 20. -- "Satan's Invisible World Displayed or Despairing Democracy," is the striking title of a book dealing with the Greater New York, which W. T. Stead, the editor of The Review of Reviews, will give to the public of England and America next month as the fruits of his recent trip "across the water."

Chestnut Street, Philadelphia, used to be known as the scene of the most outrageous commercial architecture in the United States. Indeed, it was and is extremely bad, and it is rendered the more irritating by the fact that the worst buildings seem to be the most admired. Tile promiscuous Philadelphian will point you with pride to the municipal disgraces.

HABITUALLY foreboding persons are justified somewhat in their apprehension that the public may soon get surfeited with the new kind of pseudo-darky songs and that still another rickety prop may thus be shoved from under the insubstantial structure of American Drama.

The addition to St. Bartholomew's Parish House, in East Forty-second Street, which has cost $200,000, and which was made possible by Vanderbilt generosity, is being completed room by room. Several rooms have been made ready during this week, and their occupants have moved into them. This plan is to be followed until the entire addition is occupied.

IN Wednesday next and until Saturday night at 10 o'clock the old Thirteenth Regiment Armory in Brooklyn will be given over to the second annual dog show of the Metropolitan Kennel Club. Last year's venture was such a signal success that the club will hereafter hold an annual show in Brooklyn during Thanksgiving week.

LONDON, Nov. 20. -- The spectacle of the Sultan being taken up by the Austrian Ambassador and shaken like a rat till he squealed submission, has greatly exhilarated the general European public. Those whose business it is, however, to comprehend what is beneath the surface are not a little mystified by the incident, or rather by the extraneous issues, which, apparently, as an afterthought, were engrafted on it.

THE United States battleship Iowa, the first of her type which, according to the Naval Register, is rated as a steel seagoing battleship, is to be added to the active list of the navy, a few days ago completed her final acceptance trial trip.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20. -- Assistant Secretary Davis of the Interior Department made an important decision to-day, reversing the decision of the Commissioner of Pensions on the claim of Charles A. Fry and Sarah E. Fry, minor children of John Fry of Company E, Twentieth Kentucky Infantry.

LIMA, Peru, via. Galveston, Texas, Nov. 20. -- The newspaper press of the country have requested the Government to oblige the Peruvian Corporation to dismiss from its service Victor H. MacCord, an American citizen, because Mr. MacCord is pushing a claim for damages for false arrest and imprisonment against Peru.

LONDON, Nov. 20. -- The spectacle of the Sultan being taken up by the Austrian Ambassador and shaken like a rat till he squealed submission, has greatly exhilarated the general European public. Those whose business it is, however, to comprehend what is beneath the surface are not a little mystified by the incident, or rather by the extraneous issues, which, apparently, as an afterthought, were engrafted on it.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 20. -- The fourth match of the President's Cup series on the links of the Golf Club of Lakewood, attracted the largest field of players thus far seen this season, the unusual attendance being in part because of perfect weather, and also an indication that interest in the series is on the increase and that golfers are here in greater numbers since the conclusion of notable events elsewhere.

It was reported yesterday that the hostlers, drivers, and sweepers of the Street Cleaning Department, and who belong to the Empire and Alpine Labor Clubs of the Knights of Labor, have directed Patrick McNulty, their business agent, to bring three separate suits against the city for the recovery of claims for back pay, Sunday pay, and fines, which they say amounts in all to some $150,000.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 20. -- Through the efforts of Mrs. E.R. Wharton and Mrs. Victor Sorchan the Association for Decorating the Newport Schools was instituted, and as a result of the persistent work on the part of these cottagers many of the schoolrooms are tastefully decorated with objects of art, instead of showing bare walls.

The Horse Show ended last night, and now all the horses and all the members of society who have been on exhibition for a week can take a rest. The horses will go to their comfortable stables, and some of them looked as though they would be glad to do so. The members of fashionable society will take part in more festivities, and will soon forget the Horse Show.

OCONOMOWOC, Wis., Nov. 20. -- A mysterious tragedy was committed at this place some time last night at the residence of Ernest Cornell. Two little children, Willie Cornell, aged six years, and Lillie, aged four years, were found dead, lying on their bed with their throats cut, and Ernest Cornell, their father, was lying on the floor with a gash across his throat which extended from ear to ear.
RAHWAY, Nov 20. -- E.J. Laing, one of Rahway's oldest residents, is somewhat eccentric. He owns a livery stable fronting on Campbell Street, one of the main thoroughfares of the city.

The hearing by the Appellate Division on the motion to confirm the report of its commission in the matter of the rapid transit road has been set down for to-day. There has been in certain quarters so determined and extreme an effort to influence public opinion on this matter adversely, to the report of the commission appointed by the court that it is well to recall the essential facts in the case.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 21. -- The Methodist Episcopal Church Congress began a six days's session at Christ Church this morning. The call for the congress, which was signed by Bishops Vincent, Ninde, and Fitzgerald, and many prominent Methodist educators, says:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- Many suggestions and recommendations of importance are contained in the first annual report of Gen. Russell A. Alger, Secretary of War, just submitted to the President. The Secretary quotes with approval a terse official statement of the condition said needs of the army prepared by Major Gen. Nelson A. Miles.

The first of a series of thirteen sermons on "Our Unitarian Gospel," by the Rev. Dr. Minot J. Savage, was delivered yesterday morning at the Church of the Messiah, Thirty-fourth Street and Park Avenue. The specific subject of the sermon was "Unitarianism." The text of the sermon was found in Ephesians, iv., 6: "One God and Father of all, who is above all, and through all, and in you all."

DULUTH, Nov. 21. -- Capt. Walt Thurman of the schooner Medusa, which has just reached this port, reports the suicide of Mate John T. Miller last Thursday night. Miller is a New York man, and from papers left it is learned that he has a family living on Mangin Street, New York, or in Long Island City.

Has London ceased to be the capital of the British Empire? Or has the agreement of the seal experts really closed the mouths of those London editors whose able leaders these so flatly contradict? Whatever the explanation may be, it is singular, that we hear nothing from the English metropolis about, Sir WILFRED'S mission.

The Marquis de Apeztequia, leader of the Conservative Party (or Assimilists, as they are called,) in Cuba, who is said to have brought about the recall of Weyler by the Spanish Government, arrived in this city yesterday on the French Line steamship La Champagne. He came from Madrid, and is on his way back to Cuba.

VIENNA, Nov. 21. -- Count Goluchowski, the Austro-Hungarian Minister of Foreign Affairs, when making an appeal to all Europe in his annual address yesterday before the Austrian and Hungarian delegations to take advantage of the present era of peace and to join closely for the vigorous defense of conditions common to European countries, as against the "crushing competition of transatlantic nations," said:
A case of petty larceny which was brought up in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday morning had about it pronounced indications of systematic shoplifting and theft, possibly by an organized gang.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- There is no immediate prospect of the conclusion of the reciprocity negotiations between the United States and France. Both Governments have presented elaborate statistics to show their respective positions in any reciprocity arrangements, but the matter has not progressed to the point where an agreement can be foreseen.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Nov. 21. -- A transaction has just been closed in Cleveland, by which Eastern capitalists, including ex-Gov. Flower, J.W. Hinkley, Anthony N. Brady, and Mr. Belmont of New York have acquired the entire property of the Walker Company, including all the stock and bonds. The Walker Company has extensive factories and foundries in Cleveland, covering twenty acres.

Gen. Albert Ordway of the United States Army died at the Hoffman House at 7:15 o'clock last evening, from jaundice and pleurisy, after a lingering illness, which had lasted for two years. There were present at his bedside Mrs. Ordway, his sister, Miss Emma Ordway, Lieut. E.W. Very, his old friend and business associate, and his physician, Dr. D.P. Pease. The body will be taken to Washington to-day.

Mr. HENRY M WILLIAMS and Mr. F.O. HOUGHTON of Cambridge issue a statement that $19,000 has been raised toward creating a park in memory of JAMES RUSSELL LOWELL out of a portion of the grounds about his birthplace and residence in that town. This is their way of saying that the balance necessary to complete the sum of $35,000 would be very welcome.

HAVANA, Nov. 21. -- Senor Jose Canalejas y Mendez, the editor of El Heraldo of Madrid, one of the leaders of the Spanish Liberals and former Cabinet Minister, immediately after his arrival here to study the conditions of the Island, visited the authorities, later was entertained at a banquet, and has already had many conferences with leading representatives of the various parties.

Jewish wedding ceremony which was being held last evening in the big tenement house at 123 Henry Street, was interrupted by a row, in which one man was shot and fatally injured, and the entire neighborhood was panic stricken.

The twenty-fifth anniversary of the establishment of the Jerry McAuley Water Street Rescue Mission was celebrated yesterday with two meetings in Carnegie Hall. The mission was established by Jerry McAuley, ex-convict, river pirate, and desperado, for religious work especially among the lowest class of outcast men and women of the city.

The Republican Party in New York is now the subject of two attempts at reorganization, both futile. The cry of the Platt faction is "get together." It is the old, familiar exhortation, always heard after a campaign of division and disaster, and, as usual, it is heard first and loudest from that element of the party that was most unharmonious and quarrelsome before the election.

William F. Burden, the well-known iron manufacturer of Troy and society leader and clubman of Newport, died suddenly from heart disease at 8:30 o'clock last night in his apartments at the Waldorf-Astoria. He and his wife had arrived two weeks ago from their Newport home to attend the Horse Show and had occupied a suite of rooms at the hotel.

MEMPHIS, Nov. 2L-The exercises in commemoration of the life and services of the late United States Senator Isham G. Ha.rris, twice postponed on account of yellow fever, were held to-night at the Auditorium. Addresses were made by Senator Bate of Tennessee, Senator Turpie of Indiana, Congressman "Williams of Mississippi, Gov. R. L. Taylor, and Gen. George "Ww Gordon of Memphis.
The following sales at auction are down for to-day at 111 Broadway:

There was not a large attendance at the Sunday service yesterday in the Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Forty-third Street, owing to the fact that it was not generally known that Sunday services were being held. Yesterday was the second Sunday on which services have been held in the Temple this Fall.

ALBANY, Nov. 21. -- The first experiments in the cultivation of sugar beets and the manufacture of sugar there from in New York State have been successful beyond the expectations of those who were directly interested in the project. In the act of last Winter an appropriation of $25,000 was made to carry on the experiments.
ZANZIBAR, Nov. 21. -- Particulars have reached here of a revolt among the Soudanese troops in Major MacDonald's expedition in the lake country south of the equatorial provinces.

The doors of the Centre Street Court had been closed for some moments yesterday morning and nearly all of the business of the day had been completed, when a loud knock was heard. It was repeated several times before the door was opened, and then a young man was allowed to enter only after having pleaded strenuously with the officer who was guarding the door to be allowed to see the Magistrate.
LONDON, Nov. 22. -- A dispatch from Montevideo to The Times says:

KANSAS CITY. Mo., Nov. 21. -- The new fast mail service on the Santa Fe Railroad began this morning. The train is to run from Kansas City at 9:30 in the morning. It will deliver local and Eastern mails in Western Kansas towns nearly twelve hours earlier than heretofore, and improve greatly, in connections for the far West.

" What Is Religion?" was the subject of Prof. Felix Adler's discourse before the Society for Ethical Culture yesterday at Carnegie Music Hall. A large audience was present. Prof. Adler first dwelt upon the conditions which a definition of religion must satisfy, and then, speaking of definitions that had already been attempted, said:

The 11S blue ribbons, the cash and other ribbon prizes offered by the National Horse Show Association at the thirteenth annual show having been awarded, experts, in summing up the results, agree that as a means of bringing together the best strains of equine blood the broad continent of America could furnish, as well as a number of foreign-bred horses of undisputed high quality, the function was a success far beyond its predecessors.

The effect on Southern business of the raising of quarantine restrictions is shown by the activity of the railroads. One day last week the Louisville and Nashville Railroad handled through here 2,800 freight cars. From various domestic sources orders have suddenly sprung up for coal, creating a great demand for cars and taxing the ability of the roads to supply.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- Col. William L. Trenholm, who was Controller of the Currency in President Cleveland's first Administration, has submitted his views of currency reform to the Monetary Commission. They embrace a number of features entirely different from those of other experts.

LONDON, Nov. 21. -- In the early part of last week, with currency returning from the provinces, the floating supply of money seemed increasing and rates correspondingly weakened. The repayment of loans to the Bank of England and further borrowing by the bank stiffened the market. The forthcoming settlement on the Exchanges is tending to produce the same effect.

-- Now that the State Superintendent of Prisons has reported that the institutions under his charge have become self supporting and a little more, we may expect soon to hear complaints about the competition of convict with honest labor. It cannot be denied that such competition exists under the Present system, of turning the prisons into shops for the manufacture of supplies for the different State Departments.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 21. -- News has just been received here of a tragedy at Bayou La Combe, in the interior of the State. Four men, Arthur and Edwin Jolie and Lawrence and Edwin Cousin, had a street fight with shotguns and revolvers. All four are dead.

BOSTON, Nov. 21. -- Manuel Genoaria, a sailor on the fishing schooner Two Forty of Gloucester, lying at T Wharf, went crazy last night and ran amuck with a sharp knife, attacking his four shipmates while they were lying in their bunks. Genoario was afterward found dead upon the floor of the cabin, with his throat cut and his blood-covered knife in his hand.
MADRID, Nov. 21. -- The royal decrees for the establishment of autonomy in Cuba will be submitted to a Cabinet council to-morrow.

The Central Labor Union, at its meeting yesterday, adopted resolutions favoring the proposed underground rapid transit road, and urging that work upon it be started at once. The meeting also positively refused to recognize any more unions in the building trades than there are at present, notwithstanding the subdivision of the branches in this industry that is made from time to time by the men.

MUSCATINE, Iowa, Nov. 21. -- The twelve large pearl button factories in Muscatine make this city the recognized centre of the pearl button industry in the United States. Ever since the first factory was established, the business has grown steadily, and now that the tariff laws give the American manufacturer a great advantage over foreign competitors, it is very profitable.

Through the operation of the Chinese exclusion law, two Chinamen on the American ship Benjamin Sewall are placed in a curious position. They shipped as cook and steward at Shanghai, but on the vessel's arrival here about a month ago, the Chinese Inspectors forbade their leaving the ship.

NEWPORT, R.I., Nov. 21. -- William F. Burden owned the handsome villa here known as "Beach Bound," on the hills at Brenton's Cove and Harrison Avenues. He was a prominent Summer resident, coming early in the Spring and remaining late each Fall. Last Thursday, with Mrs. Burden, he went to New York to attend the Horse Show, closing his villa before departing.
MANCHESTER, Nov. 21. -- The market for both yarns and goods was more active last week. Yarns were steady, though users were less eager buyers because the danger of a strike was considered removed.

Feather importers of this city believe that the cabled reports that the destruction in the big fire in London on Friday of ostrich feathers worth $75,000 would cause a general advance in price refer only to the English and European markets. They say they have not advanced the prices here, and that, although they expect an advance, it will be caused by the increased demand of fashion and generally low stocks.

A New Yorker whose business makes him an authority on the subject said the other day that there was and had been for a year and more more first-class commercial building going on on Manhattan Island than in all the rest of the United States put together. Surprising as the statement may at first be, the observation every New Yorker tends to confirm it.

NEWARK, Nov. 21. -- William Bamba, a full-blooded Oklahoma Indian, who has been performing at a museum with the "Running Elk" combination, was arrested today by Detective Koerber and Policemen Moore and Cookley after a chase of nearly three miles. Koerber went to Bamba's lodging at 240 Springfield Avenue to arrest him for having stolen two silver watches from Jacob Tanner, with whom he had been drinking last night.
TACOMA, Nov. 21. -- Superintendent Foster of the Everett and Monte Cristo Railroad, who went to Monte Cristo on Wednesday's train, walked in from Robe, arriving at Everett last night.

It strikes me that J.A. Allen, who, in your issue of to-day, contributes an article on the "Audubon Society" discussion headed, "Birds and Millinery," would be a wise selection for a first President of an "Anti-Audubon Society." For his whole statement of what a society should be for the prevention of wanton destruction of birds is precisely what we reasonable women are standing out for, in opposition to the Audubon Society extremes.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21. -- Mrs. Margaret Keegan, living at 512 West Fifteenth Street, had a strong belief that banks were instituted for the sole purpose of swindling people out of their money, and desiring to retain all of her funds in a safe place, she selected a barrel and placed the barrel in a closet in her home.

HASTINGS, N.Y., Nov. 22. -- A daring gang of sneak thieves visited this village during the past two nights and succeeded in carrying away booty worth about $800. The solitary policeman knew nothing about the theftes.

HAVANA, Nov. 22. -- Official dispatches from Matanzas announce the release of Senora de Roca, mother of the insurgent leader Jose de Roca, and several other prominent people who have been imprisoned there for some time past.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 22. -- In the United States Circuit Court to-day Webb McNall, State Insurance Commissioner, won a victory in the decision of Judge Foster, refusing to issue an injunction asked for by the Travelers' Insurance Company of Hartford, Conn., to restrain the Commissioner from examining the company's books.

The new beginning of the trial of Martin Thorn for the murder of William Guldensuppe was opened yesterday in the Queens County Court House, Long Island City. Justice Smith, who presided at the last trial, retired because of an attack of malaria, and was replaced by Justice Samuel T. Maddox of Brooklyn.

The business of organizing the Republican Party in opposition to PLATT goes merrily on at nightly conferences and wherever two or three Republicans full of probity and resentment are met together. There are so many anti-Platt conferences that we suspect PLATT is organizing some of them himself.

Tile Denver Republican calls upon the miners of Colorado to make the State's product of gold this year at least $22,000,000, and it tells them they can do it if every camp in the State pushes developmeat to the utmost figure.

The committee of Tammany Hall leaders appointed to distribute the $20,000 of surplus campaign contributions appropriated by the organization for the benefit of the poor of the city met at the Wigwam at 4:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon. There was a full attendance of the membership, which includes one representative from each Assembly district, with John H.G. Vehslage as Chairman.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- Fourth-class Postmasters were appointed to-day as follows:

HAVANA, Nov. 22. -- Gen. Pando has arrived at Matanzas, has visited the hospitals there, and has ordered the distribution of 1,000 rations of food daily to the "reconcentrated" people. Gen. Pando started by train from this city on Saturday in order to take charge of the campaign against the insurgents.

The most elaborate funeral in the history of Staten Island was held yesterday at Rosebank. The dead person was Mrs. Marie Pecaroro, wife of Giuseppe Pecaroro, a wealthy Italian barber of Ormonde Place, Rosebank.

Mrs. Ballington Booth was ordained an evangelical minister last night in the presence of a large crowd at Carnegie Hall. The Volunteers of America. of which Mrs. Booth and her husband are the leaders, was represented by uniformed soul savers in rank from a brigadier to a private and of both sexes. Chauncey M. Depew made a speech.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 22. -- Police Lieutenant James Lallus, who was injured in a football game at Exposition Park Nov. 2, is not expected to live. Lallus was left guard of the Pittsburg Athletic Club's eleven. He was kicked in the head, and had an ankle dislocated. The wound in the head caused erysipelas.

For the first time in years, so many Republican politicians say, the opposition to the leadership of Senator Platt and the domination of the organization has become so formidable that a change in the present policy and management of the party is regarded as inevitable if success is to be achieved next year and in 1900.

There is a fine consistency in Magistrate DEtrEL'S Judicial determinations; also much wisdom of the kind that, in one admlnlstr'ition, prepares for the next.. He might, however, have gone even further than he did yesterday when announcing the policy he intends to follov in regard to persons charged with violating the lqaines law.

It is to be hoped that members of Congress may consider the extraordinary speech of the Austro-Hungarian Minister of Foreign Affairs upon the necessity of a European league against the "destructive competition of America" in agricultural products. Count GULOCHOWSKI is by no means a Morgan or a Lodge.

WICHITA, Kan., Nov. 22. -- The plan of forming an Indian State from the five civilized tribes of the Indian Territory, which was advanced by Chief Ispaharcher, head of the Creek Nation, in his recent message, is being favorably considered by the allied tribes, and a general convention will be called at which formal action will be taken.

JAMAICA, L.I., Nov. 22. -- Charles Bauer, an employe of Supervisor Frederick Dunton, at his home in Hollis, was seriously injured in an encounter with a deer owned by Mr. Dunton on Saturday evening. Misses Lois and Emma Dunton, the two daughters of the Supervisor, went into the inclosure where the deer was kept to secure some pieces of wood, which they intended using in decorating a stage where an entertainment was to be held.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22. -- The new form of interchangeable mileage ticket issued by the western roads is proving very popular. The Sebastian ticket was placed on sale Nov. 15, and 25,000 tickets were ordered printed. It was thought 25,000 would be sufficient for the demands that would be made. This number is exhausted, however, and another 25,000 has been ordered.

The love of money is the root of all evil, wrote the Apostle. That is not altogether true, for many kinds of evils spring from other lusts than the lust for gold. But it is a good, workable proverb, solidly based upon the observed behavior of men and money. It is so true that in some cases it may be turned about, making the love of money the cure of evil.

Arguments for and against the scheme of rapid transit, as laid out by the Rapid Transit Commissioners and approved by the Special Commission, Arthur D. Williams, John Sabine Smith, and George W. Young, were presented yesterday to the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, First Department.

MADRID, Nov. 22. -- The new Cuban tariff is the subject of considerable heated discussion here at present. The Cuban Reformists have published a manifesto, claiming for the Cubans the right to establish their own tariff, on the ground that the tobacco monopoly prevents commercial reciprocity between Spain and Cuba.
"' revery man at 40 is either a fool or a physician."

LANCASTER, Penn., Nov. 22. -- Miss Emma Eshleman of Rothsville, this county, was the victim of an assault at the hands of Christian Curly to-day. Miss Eshleman, who is the daughter of a prominent farmer, had been visiting a neighbor in company with her sister, Ada. They were walking home on the turnpike when they encountered Curly, who had secreted himself behind a clump of bushes.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- "The Royal Box," Charles Coghlan's play, "adapted, remodeled, and rewritten" from a drama by Alexandre Dumas, was produced at the Columbia Theatre to-night.

A remarkable surgical operation, which has been performed once or twice in Germany, but never before in these countries, was carried out yesterday in one of the principal factories of Dublin. The operation was the cutting from a pig, as the blood was pouring from its throat and life still remained, of an eyelid, and attaching it by stitches to a human patient.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 22. -- Treasurer W.F. Burdell of the Republican State Executive Committee filed with the Secretary of State to-day, in compliance with the Garfield Corrupt Practices act, a statement of the moneys expended to secure the re-election of Gov. Bushnell and the election of a Republican Legislature.

The editorial headed "The Right to Safety" in your issue of yesterday is a very timely one. Since the appointment of the so-called City Magistrates, now some three years since, we have heard much of their great superiority over the old "Police Justices" in character, energy, proper administration of the laws,

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- One of the most important features of the Bering Sea negotiations not heretofore disclosed is that in the event Great Britain and Canada consent to a suspension of pelagic sealing for one year, the United States at the same time will agree to a suspension of all killing of seals for one year on the Pribilof Islands, constituting the American seal possessions in Bering Sea.

GOUVERNEUR, N.Y., Nov. 22. -- The United States Grand Jury at Auburn on Saturday handed in a sealed indictment against Luke Usher of Potsdam, President of the National Bank of that place, which failed on Jan. 25 last. There are eleven counts in the indictment, which charges Usher wies misappropriating several hundred thousand dollars.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22. -- Capt. Leonard A. Lovering of the Fourth Infantry, stationed at Fort Sheridan, appeared before a court-martial at that post to-day to stand trial on the charge of "conduct prejudicial to good order and military discipline." The specific charge is causing Private Hammond to be dragged over the ground by the heels from the guardhouse to the office of the regimental Adjutant after Hammond had refused to walk.

Some bookkeeping entries and business formalities yesterday placed $13,645,250.89 to the account of the Government for the Union Pacific Sinking Fund bonds, and the Reorganization Committee received $4,500,000 of the bonds here and $9,145,250.89 at Washington.

Horses and most of the cattle, large and smaL, have, as a rule, a limited range of diet. as have wild vegetable-eating animals, such as deer and others. The carnivorous animals confine themselves mostly to meat. Som mammals and birds axe omnivorous, being apparently intended by nature as scavengers.
Messrs. Norton and TunstaU of the Stock Exchange thus sum up their opinions of the stock market outlook:

At the meeting of the Park Board yesterday afternoor bids were opened for the erection of the new east wing of the Museum of Art. There were more than a dozen bids. What appeared to be the lowest were those submitted by Grace Hyde, contractors, and Thomas Dwyer. The former's bids were as follows: For bnfidlng the wing, using limestone for front, $721,000; u.slng marble for front, $743,900.

The scene that will carry the new English melodrama, "The White Heather," which was produced in an elaborate and expensive manner at the Academy last evening, is of a pictorial rather than a strictly dramatic character, but it is perfectly intelligible, is clearly led up to, and produces a thrilling effect.

William Carroll Woodward was found guilty by a jury in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court yesterday of attempting to blackmail Samuel W. Bridgham, the son-in-law of William C. Schermerhorn. The defendant heard the verdict without a change of color. He even anticipated it, for he said audibly to his counsel, as the jury filed in: "It's a hundred to one they've decided against me."

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 22. -- When the State Canvassing Board met to-day it was served with a protest, signed by E.R. Sizer. Secretary of the Republican State Central Committee, and other citizens, against a canvass of the State returns on the ground that the law had been violated by Secretary of State Porter, whom it charged with opening and tampering with county returns.
John Lottogran, an Italian newsboy of 237 East Forty-fourth Street, was killed in front of the Grand Central Station last night in a rather peculiar way.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- It is learned from an authoritative source that no recent negotiations have occurred between Secretary Sherman and Sir Julian Pauncefote, the British Ambassador, concerning a new arbitration treaty between the United States and Great Britain, that no exchange of notes has occurred between Mr. Sherman and Lord Salisbury on this subject, and that Sir Julian has not spoken of the matter since he returned to Washington from London some weeks ago.

The Brooklyn Board of Aldermen have completed the canvass of the vote cast in the recent election, except in the fight for Mayor, Coroners, and Councilmen. For Chief of the Court of Appeals the vote was 156,412, divided mainly as follows: Alton B. Parker, (Dem.,) 96,124; William J. Wallace, (Rep.,) 55,563; Theodore F. Cuneo, (Soc.,) 3,964; Francis E. Baldwin, (Proh.,) 1,752, Thomas C. Platt, 1.

Hereafter it will be possible to visit Boston in safety and comparative comfort. A "guide and courier service" has been established there, and the arriving stranger is to be saved from all the anxiety, as well as from all the danger, hitherto experienced by those who, with only the knowledge that is obtainable beyond the limits of Boston, have ventured into that admirable but peculiar city.

A London newspaper warns the Spanish Government that Gen. WEYLER may become a very dangerous person. A soldier, it says, who attracts such diverse elements as Conservatives, Republicans, Carlists, and workingmen is a formidable factor in Spanish politics. That seems to be the opinion of the Spanish Government, if it has caused Gen. WEYLER to be admonished not to land at Barcelona, upon the ground that his doing so might endanger public order.

Christian Entes, seventeen years old, was held for trial in default of $1,000 bail in Essex Market Court yesterday, on a charge of burglary. The lad has passed two years in the House of Refuge, four in the Juvenile Asylum, and one in the penitentiary, whither he was sentenced for setting the Asylum on fire. He was set free three weeks ago.

The latest phase of the Dreyfus case is the most exciting of all its phases. It has all along been plain that the French Government had much to conceal about the matter. The proceedings of the court-martial were secret and the Government has ever since refused to publish the evidence on which Capt. DREYFUS was convicted.
DENVER, Nov. 22. -- Dr. O.E. Miller has organized a mission called the Co-operative Bible Union in this city, and is conducting daily religious services.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- The Smithsonian Institution has come into possession of the Hallett Phillips collection of Indian implements and antiquities from the Potomac Valley. It is reputed the largest collection of its class in the world, and its value is enhanced greatly by the careful arrangement and record of individual specimens.

DALLAS, Texas, Nov. 22. -- Dan A. Stuart, the well-known promoter of pugilism, has said farewell to Dallas. He has sold every interest with which he was identified in this city, including real estate, and will hereafter make New York City his home. Mr. Stuart has been a resident of Dallas for twenty-two years and has occupied the same suite of private rooms for seventeen years.

Another of the bevel-gear models which is expected to form one of the 1898 standards in chainless wheels, was placed on the market yesterday. It is the "Spalding Chainless," put out by A.G. Spalding Brothers. The mechanism consists of a series of four bevel gears, used in conjunction with a tubular gear shaft.

The ground plan of the Zoological Park was approved yesterday by the Park Board. It was, for the most part, the plan originally prepared last year by the director, William T. Hornady, and approved by the Zoological Society.

Pale and emaciated from long confinement in the Cabanas Prison at Havana, the five members of the crew of the famous filibuster schooner Competitor arrived here yesterday on the Ward Line steamship Saratoga. For months they had lived in dread of the execution of the sentence that they be shot.

LONDON, Nov. 22. -- A well-informed correspondent at Kabul, capital of Afghanistan, writing from that city under date of Sept. 20 last, gives an account of an interview which he had with the Ameer of Afghanistan in a durbar, in which the Ameer, referring to the rising of the tribes on the frontier of British India, said:

Thomas A. Fulton of the Amsterdam Avenue Protective Association and President Miller of the Association for the Public Ownership of Franchises appeared before the Railroad Committee of the Board of Aldermen yesterday to protest against the laying of four tracks on Amsterdam Avenue. Aldermen Parker, Goodman, Marshall, Hall, Robinson, Brown, and Murphy were present.

A mistake was made by the ring officials at the Horse Show last week, and the wrong names were given as winners of the ribbons in the class for the Park police. A correction has been made, and the winners were: First prize, James Cottier's horse; second prize, John Hoey's Sunshine; third prize, John Murphy's Zoldo, and the highly commended ribbon to the horse ridden by Andrew J. McNulty.

BOSTON, Nov. 23. -- Republican caucuses were held to-night in all the wards and ex-Mayor Curtis carried every one with the exception of Ward Twenty, where the contest with his opponent, ex-Alderman Sanford, is still in doubt.

TACOMA, Washington, Nov. 23. -- A fight took place last month near Canton, China, between armed merchants and villagers and a large band of robbers which had been plundering the suburbs of Canton. Nine of the robbers were killed and forty injured. The bandits retreated, but have sent word that they will get reinforcements and rob the richest stores in Canton.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23. -- Grief over the disgrace of his father, Charles M. Charnley, is supposed to have caused the suicide of James Charnley, Jr., who was found in his room in the Hotel Pfister, at Milwaukee, on Sunday, with a bullethole in his heart. Charles M. Charnley, formerly President of the Presbyterian Board of Aid for Colleges and Academies, disappeared last Summer, short some $60,000 of the funds intrusted to him.

BOSTON, Nov. 23. -- The State Board of Railroad Commissions to-day refused to ratify the lease of the West End Railroad Company to the Boston Elevated Railroad Company, on the ground that the transaction would be detrimental to the public welfare. In rejecting the lease the Commissioners say: "Upon the facts and considerations that have been presented, the proposed rental charge is, in our judgment, unwarranted, and involves an unreasonable and excessive public burden.

S. Van Rensselaer Cruger Co. have sold, for Johanna D. Favorat, to Max Marx, for $22,000, the four-story brownstone front flat 126 East One Hundred and Fourteenth Street, 26 by 100. In part payment, $17,500, the buyer gives the three-story brownstone front dwelling 541 West One Hundred and Forty-seventh Street, 17.6 by 100.
LONDON, Nov. 23. -- The Countess of Lathom, while returning from a shooting party to-day, was thrown out of a trap and killed, near Wigan, Lancaster.

Mr. ZABRISKIE is much too airy and flippant about the vote of the people in 1894 for municipal construction of a rapid-transit railway. The plans now proposed, he assured the Appellate Division, are not those voted on three years ago, and that vote has no relevancy to the question now before the court.
A sad case of poverty, distress, and man's inhumanity came to light yesterday, following the arrest of Mrs. Mary Kammerman, a young woman of 67 Avenue C.

Shortly before 5 o'clock yesterday morning a kerosene lamp exploded in the apartments of William Schopp, on the second floor of a frame house at 22 Ocean Place, Brooklyn. The flames extended to the furniture, and the Schopps, failing to extinguish the fire, rushed out and warned the other tenants. James Daly, who lived on the third floor, ran down to see what was the matter.

Letters received from the country counties indicate a deep interest on the part of up-State independent Republican leaders in the anti-Platt-Quigg movement. Communications have come from Erie, Chautauqua, Niagara, Monroe, Onondaga, Madison, Oneida, Herkimer, St. Lawrence, Albany, and other counties from anti-Platt partisans, urging the Greater New York leaders to continue the agitation for reform in party management.

The annual meeting of the Children's Aid Society was held at 45 Wall Street yesterday afternoon. The following officers were re-elected: William Church Osborn, Charles E. Whitehead, J. Kennedy Tod, James R. Roosevelt, and Arthur C. James, Trustees; D. Willis James, President; A.B. Hepburn, Treasurer, and C. Loring Brace, Secretary.

George W. Schiffer, an American citizen, resident of Buffalo, arrived here yesterday on the Atlas Line steamship Alleghany, with a story of indignities to which he was subjected in Colombia, and for which he has lodged with the United States Minister at Bogota a claim for $25,000 damages against the Colombian Government.

One of the most fashionable weddings of the season was celebrated shortly after 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon in St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church on Stuyvesant Square. The bride was Miss Louisa Shaw Barlow, daughter of the late Gen. Francis C. Barlow, and the bridegroom was Pierre Jay, President of the Second Avenue and Central Crosstown Railroad Companies, and a great grandson of John Jay, first Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States.

DETROIT, Nov. 23. -- Gov. Pingree, in an interview to-night, denied all knowledge of the formation of a big stock company, of which he was to be at the head, for the purpose of developing the asphalt fields of Venezuela.

We have no doubt that the report is correct that the President means to apply his order as to "removals" in the Federal service to reductions of rank and pay. A man who is taken out of a three-thousand-dollar place and put into a fifteen-hundred-dollar place to make room for a new man is just as clearly "removed" from his former place as if he were dismissed from the service altogether.

James F. Brandt, a painter, fell from the south dome of the General Post Office Building to the portico in front of Postmaster Van Cott's office yesterday morning. The distance is about 80 feet. Brandt's head was crushed, and it is supposed that death was instantaneous.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23. -- Private Charles Hammond was the principal witness in the Lovering court-martial to-day, and proved himself entirely capable of holding his own with the attorneys who are acting for Capt. Lovering, who is charged with treating Hammond cruetly. Hammond gave damaging evidence against Lovering.

BUFFALO, Nov. 23. -- St. Clair McKelway of Brooklyn delivered an address before the Liberal Club this evening on "Municipal Methods and Morals." He received an enthusiastic welcome. In the course of his remarks he said:

Constantine Steiger, alias Fritz Meyer, heard without a tremor the death sentence passed upon him in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court yesterday, for the murder of Policeman Smith. In marked contrast to the prisoner's demeanor was that of Justice Fursman, who sentenced him.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- The special naval board appointed to examine into the cost of armor making has designed a plant, the details of which it will present to Congress. It will cost more than $3,000,000 and will have a capacity of 6,000 tons of armor per annum, which is about the combined capacity of the two armor plants now supplying the navy.

The jury to try Martin Thorn for the murder of William Guldensuppe was completed yesterday in the Queens County Court, and District Attorney Youngs opened the case for the people and examined several witnesses. He brought out testimony regarding the discoveries of the different parts of the body supposed to be Guldensuppe's, and the removals of them to the Morgue.

NEWARK, Nov. 23. -- The wedding of Edwin W. Pierson and Miss Bertie L. Mills of this city, which took place privately in New York on Sept. 24, has just been announced. They were commuters on the same train to New York every morning for months before they spoke.

The freshmen at Columbia College won their right to carry canes and smoke pipes after stubborn struggles with the sophomores in a "cane spree" and a tug of war match yesterday on the grounds south of the library.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 23. -- The Fall series of thoroughbred sales was opened here to-day by William Easton, the New York auctioneer. Among the important consignments disposed of was the entire string from the famous Dixiana stud, the property of Major B.G. Thomas of this city, the oldest thoroughbred breeder in America.

ALBANY, Nov. 23. -- The Court of Appeals has decided the Edson will cases. By the will of Margaret B. Edson she gave a third of her estate to her brother, Marmont B. Edson, made specific bequests of $206,000 to a number of institutions, and left the residue to her executors. John E. Parsons, Charles S. Fairchild, and John A. Bartow. But a codicil made absolute the bequests to the three executors as trustees.
ALBANY, Nov. 23. -- The Court of Appeals has affirmed the judgment of conviction and death in the case of Hadley A. Sutherland, a negro who killed Sarah Wrenn in Brooklyn March 22, 1897.

" The currency issued by the National banks should be retired at fast as possible consistent with the vested rights of the banks, and its place supplied with Government notes. With bank currency out of the way, that of the Government would have the field to itself, and might be augmented without risk to meet every requirement of business." -- The Sun.

The recent discussion in your columns of this question prompts me to ask you to publish a Jerseyman's views on the subject, one of the many thousands who do business in your city every day. It is a matter of profoundest mystery to me why the several elevated roads possess no cross-town facilities to speak of, or any arrangement of "loops" making them accessible to the several principal ferries and railroad stations.

BARCELONA, Nov. 23. -- Gen. Weyler, the former Captain General of Cuba, arrived here this morning on board the Spanish steamer Montserrat, from Havana via Gibara, Puerto Rico and Corunna. The General landed beneath the Columbus Monument at 10 A.M., accompanied by Gen. Montaner, and was acclaimed by about 20,000 people.

VINTON, Ia., Nov. 23. -- The jury in the case of Frank Novak, charged with killing his room-mate Murray, and afterward setting fire to the house in which they lived, to-night returned a verdict of murder in the second degree.

The anti-Platt resolutions of the Brookfield Republicans are admirable. Their recital of grievances is temperate, their declaration of hostilities manly and courageous. But will these gentlemen fight? They have drawn the sword. Will they throw away the scabbard?

The Evening Post has some remarks upon Count GOLUCHOWSKI'S proposal of a European league to resist American competition, under the title of "A War of Tariffs." But, in fact, there can be no further war of tariffs, so far as we are concerned. We have gone to the last extreme already. The Dingley bill proclaims non-intercourse with foreign countries so far as buying what they have to sell is concerned.
W.D. Bynum, Chairman of the National Democratic Committee, yesterday issued the following address to the National Democracy:

The second day's session of the champion trotters and pacers' sale at Madison Square Garden yesterday was even larger than that of Monday, for some of the best of the lot of 700 to be disposed of, the consignment from C.J. and Harry Hamlin, were offered.

The wrangle over arbitration is marked by a bitterness almost worthy of the earlier stages of the preliminaries of war. Such extreme touchiness upon fanciful points of honor is not characteristic of circles where every individual's honor is above reproach, but rather partakes of the farcical character of pugilists' antebellum negotiations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- Senator Lindsay of Kentucky, who is one of the three gold Democrats in the Senate, was asked to-day what policy he and those Democratic Senators who agree with him on financial questions would pursue in case an effort should be made to secure currency legislation at the approaching session of Congress. He replied:

There's a new leader in town, according to Richard Croker, and his name is Edward Murphy, Jr. The Senator came down from Troy yesterday morning. He and Mr. Croker saw each other during the day, and afterward the leader of the Democratic Party in the city took occasion to say that he recognizes Senator Murphy, and not Senator Hill, as the leader of the Democracy of the State.

As we have said before, the best evidence that the offer of autonomy to Cuba is made by the Spanish Ministry in good faith is the amount of opposition it arouses in Spain itself. The offer is in fact unexpectedly and surprisingly liberal. It may very well have been made so because the situation of Spain is desperate, but that does not alter the fact.

LONDON, Nov. 23. -- The Right Hon. Charles T. Ritchie, President of the Board of Trade, made an important speech before the Chamber of Commerce of Croydon to-day, taking as his theme the decline of British exports during the last ten months, upon which he hung a grave warning against American competition, now "ousting British trade."
Following are topics which yesterday received Wall Street attention:

MONTREAL, Nov. 23. -- The Harbor Commissioners delivered their finding in the Yantic-Canadienne collision case to-day. Their decision was that if the Yantic had not ported she would have cleared the Canadienne. Peron, the pilot on board the Yantic, was severely censured and his license suspended until July 1, 1898.

Pezon, the lion tamer, died at the age of seventy-three. He was a highly popular character here, and for more than forty years the fairs near the Bastile -- those of Clichy, Montmartre, Neuilly, Les Loges, and endless others in the provinces -- were the theatres of his exploits. He was so popular that he felt he could put forward his second son, also a lion tamer, at the next Legislative elections.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 24. -- The National Organization Committee, representing the Middle-of-the-Road faction of the Populist Party, this afternoon gave out the following address as having been unanimously adopted by the committee:

MADRID, Nov. 24. -- A review of the newspaper situation here shows that ten newspapers are hostile to Gen. Weyler, while five papers are in his favor. Of the military organs, two periodicals support the former Governor General of Cuba and one opposes him.

Justice Andrews, in the Supreme Court, yesterday handed down a decision in which he continues the temporary injunction restraining the Trustees of the Brooklyn Bridge and the Mayors of New York and Brooklyn from continuing the work of laying tracks and loops at the New York terminus of the bridge.

Cable dispatches from Paris announce another and successful test of the Heilmann locomotive, which, it will be remembered, is a generating plant on wheels delivering its current to the motors that drive on the axles of the whole combination. The statement also comes that the Directors of the Western Road are going to adopt it.

INDEPENDENCE, Kan., Nov. 24. -- In the District Court here to-day a divorce was granted to the Rev. Willis Jordan, pastor of the Christian Church at Candy, from his wife, Ada Jordan. The case appears on the docket under the peculiar title of Willis Jordan vs. Ada Miller, called Ada Jordan. The Rev. Mr. Jordan caused a sensation by publicly denouncing his wife from the pulpit on Sunday.

The election of a Captain for Company D of the Sixty-ninth Regiment, to fill the vacancy made by the resignation of Capt. Daniel Dowdney, has been indefinitely postponed. Mayor Strong's son, who is an Adjutant on Col. George Moore Smith's staff, was slated for the place, but at a caucus held Tuesday night it was found impossible to control the election.

VIENNA, Nov. 24. -- The members of the lower house of the Reichsrath to-day excelled themselves in producing the most disgraceful scene yet witnessed in that branch of Parliament. The turbulence resulted from a motion that only one of a number of similar petitions against the ordinance making the Czech language co-ordinate with the German in Bohemia should be read and printed.

HAVANA, via Key West, Fla., Nov. 24. -- After the order had been issued for the release of Gen Rius Rivera and Col. Bacallao, who were captured by Gen. Hernandez de Velasco last March, but before they were actually freed, both were conducted to the palace, entering by a side door from O'Reilly Street and going up a private stairway.

The charity fund of $20,000 set aside by Tammany Hall and the 1,000 tons of coal contributed by Nathan Straus will be divided equally among the Assembly districts of the city, beginning Dec. 11. This was decided upon at the meeting of the committee on distribution, held at the Fourteenth Street Wigwam at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon.
LONDON, Nov. 25. -- The correspondent of a London paper, describing the scene, says:

Police Capt. Kitzer of the Herbert Street Station, Williamsburg, is much puzzled over a strange story of assault and robbery told to him yesterday by Laurence Roth, a printer, of 14 Jackson Street. The incident preceded Roth's marriage on Tuesday night to Miss Josephine Demling of 562 Metropolitan Avenue. He is twenty-five years old. The time for the marriage was set for 7 o'clock on Tuesday night.

It is quite plain that Gen. WEYLER is aware of the political function of "a man on horseback" at critical periods, and that he believes that such a critical period is coming for Spain. He seems to be deliberately putting himself in view in order not to be overlooked when the crisis arrives.

BABYLON, L.I., Nov. 24. -- An armed posse of citizens, headed by Deputy Sheriff Towns, ex-Supervisor Robbins, and Overseer of the Poor Strong chased three tramps several miles through the country to-day, and finally caught them.

The full-rigged ship Port Patrick, Capt. Frank Hand, was almost totally destroyed by fire early yesterday morning at Pier 9 East River, where she was loading. Her cargo, valued at about $100,000, was also destroyed, and the commander and crew of the vessel narrowly escaped from the blazing ship with their lives.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24. -- The French Ambassador, M. Patenotre, has received a cablegram from his Government requesting him to start for Paris on Saturday next. Accordingly he will present his letters of recall to President McKinley on Friday, sailing the next day on the French Line steamship La Champagne.

Perhaps no man ever lived more economically in the City of New York, paying his way and earning the respect of those with whom he came in contact, than George H. Blanchard, who was found dead yesterday in the Raines law hotel, 352 West Forty-fourth Street, in the room he had occupied nearly a year and a half.
Hall J. How Co. have sold, for the Austin estate, to J. Allen Townsend, the plot northwest corner of the Boulevard and Ninety-eighth Street, 100 by 100.11.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24. -- At a dinner given to-night by Mr. P.A.B. Widener to about twenty intimate, personal, and business associates, all men of prominence in Philadelphia, the formal announcement was made by Dr. William Pepper, former Provost of the University of Pennsylvania, of Mr. Widener's intention to present to the Free Library of Philadelphia his magnificent residence.

There was little show of activity in yesterday's market, the Thanksgiving holiday being practically under way. Stocks especially conspicuous were for the most part inclined to weakness just at the close of business, though throughout the greater part of the day they were dull and strong.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 24. -- The British steamship Rossmore, which arrived here to-day, reports having sighted the schooner Elite, Capt. Hargrave, in midocean Nov. 18, with signals displayed that the crew was starving.

The Fire Board, at its meeting yesterday, received a communication from the Rev. James Le Barron Johnson, one of the clergy connected with Grace Protestant Episcopal Church, of which the Rev. Dr. W.R. Huntington is rector, formally announcing an endowment gift from the writer, which establishes a new annual medal for firemen.
TORONTO, Ontario, Nov. 24. -- Graham Brothers, owners of the stallion Royal Standard, which the Chicago Horse Show authorities declare is a ringer, telegraphed the following reply from Claremont:

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Nov. 24. -- A.R. Roberts, a passenger on the Santa Fe Overland, bound for San Francisco, became suddenly insane on Monday and labored under the hallucination that he was being pursued by enemies. Sympathizing passengers took charge of him, but he became worse, and yesterday morning, while the train was crossing the Mojave desert, jumped through a car window and escaped in the darkness.
Prices yesterday at the third day's session of the champion sale of trotters and pacers were steady throughout, averaging well, although only a few were above the $1,000 mark.

ALBANY, Nov. 24. -- The employes in the office of the Clerk of the Assembly have compiled the list of members elected for the session of 1898, and have arranged the voting strength of the various parties. The list shows 79 Republicans, 68 Democrats, 2 Independent Republicans, and 1 National Democrat.

A picturesque and enthusiastic party of eleven persons will set sail to-day on the little brig Harriet G., bound for the gold fields of the Klondike. They expect to sail comfortably around Cape Horn and reach St. Michael, Alaska, next July. Three of the passengers are women, and one is a girl of fourteen years.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24. -- The Cornell football team arrived here from Ithaca this evening in prime condition for the annual Thanksgiving Day game with the University of Pennsylvania. The Cornell party number thirty-five men, twenty-two of whom compose the 'Varsity team and substitutes, the remainder comprising the second team, which go to Annapolis on Saturday for a game with the Naval Cadets.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 24. -- Before the Methodist Episcopal Church Congress today Dr. H.D. Atchison, of Wilmette, Ill., spoke on Church Music, and in the course of his remarks said: ...

Armand D. Dreyfus d'O'Heguerty, for such was his full, though certainly very original, name, and it figures in the windows of his office, on the ground floor of 14 Rue Taltbout, was a commission agent for London financial and other houses, and for business firms in Brussels, Cologne, and Amsterdam.
CHICAGO, Nov. 24. -- The testimony to-day before the court-martial at Fort Sheridan, which is trying Capt. Lovering for alleged cruelty to Private Hammond strongly favored the accused officer.

The Sagasta Government is at least giving evidence of earnestness in its offer of autonomy to Cuba, whether that offer is intended to conciliate the Cubans or only to affect public opinion in this country. The aggrieved Spanish manufacturers have no notion of a colony but as a place which is maintained by the Government as a market for their goods -- at any price they may agree to charge.
Amid a running fire of objections, William G. Wood took the witness stand and gave testimony yesterday at the trial of May Kellard for forgery before Judge McMahon and a jury in General Sessions.

Samuel Proskauer, United States Consul at Puerto Cabello, has made a report to the State Department on the opportunities for Americans in Venezuela. He says: "So much attention having been recently given to Venezuela, her richness and resources dilated upon in print and private letters, it is but natural that every mail should bring many inquiries and requests for information.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 24. -- The French and Belgian glass workers at Arnold, Penn., near here, met last night and decided to go to Washington and join Debs's Social Democracy. On March 1, 1898, eighty-four men will leave and about a month later the entire colony of nearly 600 persons will follow.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 24 -- The special committee appointed by the State Grand Army of the Republic Department to investigate and report on the subject of American history as taught in the schools, has reported at great length in a decidedly analytical document with few suggestions. The only attempt at solution is made when the report says:

No speaker was more warmly applauded by the members of the Chamber of Commerce at its banquet than Gov. BLACK when he told them in measured but emphatic language that New York was losing its relative standing in the trade of the Republic because its business men allowed it to do so.

Thanksgiving Day will be generally celebrated all over the city to-day. In the churches there will be services in the morning, and the charitable institutions will give dinners in the afternoon and evening. Many entertainments will take place in the evening. Athletes will be active in many forms of sport, and altogether the day will be a busy one.

The assignments of Justices who are to serve in the various parts of the Supreme Court during the coming year which were made by the Appellate Division on Tuesday have caused as much dissatisfaction among the Justices as did the assignments for this year, and although the Justices will not talk out or be quoted their feelings are unmistakable.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24. -- The National Christian Citizenship League, in accordance with its annual custom, has asked some of the leaders of the Nation's thought to give expression to their opinions appropriate to the return of the National Thanksgiving anniversary. In a statement accompanying these expressions the league says: ...

The Republicans who are engineering the revolt against the Platt organization in this city report constant accessions to their ranks, many of them from unexpected quarters, and the leaders of the movement said yesterday that there was prospect for an early alliance of the anti-Platt forces.

BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 24. -- Messrs. Alexander Brown Sons, representing a syndicate of Baltimore, London, New York, Philadelphia, and Pittsburg capitalists, have consummated the purchase of all the stock of the United Traction Company of Pittsburg, amounting to $20,000,000, of which $3,000,000 is preferred stock and $17,000,000 common stock.

LONDON, Nov. 24. -- The yacht White Ladye, formerly the property of Mrs. Lily Langtry, the actress, has been sold at auction for 11,200, ($56,000.) The vessel cost to build for Lord Ashburton (Francis Edward Baring) 40,000, ($200,000,) and Mrs. Langtry spent 20,000 ($100,000) in decorating the yacht and her state boudoir suite.

American shares were generally higher in the London market. The principal changes were: Advanced -- St. Paul, 3/8, to 95 3/8; Erie first preferred, 3/8, to 36 1/4; New York Central, 1/4, to 109 1/4; Atchison, 1/8, to 13; Louisville and Nashville, 1/8, to 56 3/8, and Erie, 1/8; to 15. Declined -- Pennsylvania, 3/8, to 56 3/8; Illinois Central, 1/5, to 103 3/4, and Reading, 1/3, to 10 8/4.

We are not proud of the courtesy of our political campaigns, and yet our Cabinet Ministers do not vituperate their ex-colleagues over their signatures in the public prints. Surely, it was not from his American wife, or his American travels, that Mr. CHAMBERLAIN caught this trick. This is how Mr. CHAMBERLAIN, in a letter to the English press, describes Sir WILLIAM HARCOURT'S treatment of Mr. CHAMBERLAIN'S fine address at Glasgow:

Much new evidence was brought out yesterday, the third day of the trial, in Long Island City, of Martin Thorn for the murder of Guldensuppe. Mrs. Nack was again brought into court and was identified by several witnesses as the woman who had hired the Woodside cottage and was seen to go there with Thorn the day before the 25th of June, and with Guldensuppe the day of the murder.

In one of the most unpretentious looking banking offices in Wall Street there has been within the last few months a growth of business so extraordinary that it has aroused the liveliest interest on the part of the down-town bankers and of financiers generally. The National City Bank, which in May last absorbed the Third National Bank, now has about $80,000,000 of net deposits.

Prof. Thomas K. Cheyne of Oxford, England, delivered yesterday afternoon at the Union Theological Seminary, the last of his series of six lectures on "Jewish Religious Life After the Exile" The special topic of this lecture was "Judaism: Its Power of Attracting Foreigners; Its Higher Theology; Its Relation to Greece, Persia, and Babylon."

The speech of Secretary GAGE on Tuesday evening was frank, determined, and aggressive. It was in effect and in intent a declaration by the Administration that it will instantly take up the fight for currency reform and press it with might and main. He puts absolutely aside the "conservative" objection to agitation because, the conditions being what they are, "agitation is the highest conservatism."

The fact was made public Wednesday that Miss Alice Bache Gould, daughter of the late Benjamin Apthorp Gould, had intrusted to the National Academy of Sciences a fund of $20,000, but it was not possible at that time to state the precise conditions under which the gift was made. These are of interest, since they concern one of the largest funds in the country, the proceeds of which will be available for astronomical research.

Mr. MACOUN, the Canadian sealing expert, thinks the most important points settled by the agreement of the experts at Washington acquit Canada of all wrong. The experts agree, he says, that pelagic sealing is conducted according to the rules under the Paris award, and that so long as the haunts of the seals on land are protected, and the protected zone at sea is maintained, the seals are in no danger of actual extermination.

Eugene A. Pinkney, fifty years old, a manufacturer of rustic furniture, was held in $500 bail for trial yesterday on a charge of passing a worthless check for $50 on Charles G. Testera, the caterer in the Carnegie Music Hall. Pinkney was arrested a month ago on the same charge and was allowed to go on his own recognizance until the examination, but he did not appear at the time appointed.

DULUTH, Minn., Nov. 24. -- An Indian courier to-night from the Fond du Lac Indian Reservation brought news of a triple murder which occurred there last night. John Anamasin, a Chippewa half breed, whose reputation as a "bad Indian" has kept the reservation people in a state of terror for three or four years, went to Cloquet yesterday, and returned late last night crazed with liquor.

That is a fortunate discovery of the National Sculpture Society that the veto of its President suffices to prevent the erection of the Soldiers and Sailors' Memorial at the main entrance to Central Park. The use of this power will save the city from a grievous mistake.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 24. -- A number of prominent lobbyists in the rotunda of the Georgia capitol were on the anxious seat for a few hours this morning. Their worry was all because of a poker game that was played in the Kimball House in the room of one of the most prominent citizens of the State.

LONDON, Nov. 24. -- The inhabitants of this metropolis, as a result of the outcry which followed the great fire of Friday last, are much agitated in regard to the efficiency or inefficiency of the Fire Brigade, and the newspapers are filled with letters comparing London's system unfavorably with those in use in America and other countries.

The American Society of Civil Engineers formally threw open the doors of their new building at 220 West Fifty-seventh Street yesterday, with appropriate exercises. During the afternoon the spacious parlors and other rooms were thronged with invited guests, all of whom expressed delight at the splendid appointments.

The affairs of cattlemen in Nebraska have reached a condition which they regard with much apprehension. The situation is due to the fact that the ranges of the State have almost been drained of their supply of stock. This shortage applies to all kinds of cattle, even extending to calves and yearlings.

READING, Penn., Nov. 24. -- Ludwig Lushi of this city has proved conclusively that he is not easily daunted by little obstacles in the way of any feat he has determined to accomplish. Some time ago Ludwig, who is forty-one, rather handsome, and with features that indicate a determined character, concluded that he had remained in single blessedness long enough and he looked about for a wife.

The directors of the Western Railway of France have decided to employ M. Heilmann's improved electric locomotive. However, before putting it into daily use, they this morning commenced a series of experimental trips, to which they had invited not only the representatives of numerous French and foreign railway companies and the leading engineers of France, but also numerous members of Parliament and the representatives of the French and foreign press in Paris.
BOSTON, Nov. 24. -- What promises to be one of the bitterest fought and most sensational cases of the year came up in the Middlesex Probate Court before Judge McIntyre to-day.

VAN BUREN, Ark., Nov. 24. -- City Marshal Charles Wells of Mulberry, Ark., has arrested J.C. Dunham, alias James Buford, wanted in Santa Clara County, Cal., for the murder of Col. and Mrs. R.P. McGliney, Mrs. Hattie Dunham, Miss Minnie Schessler, J.K. Wells, and R.A. Briscoe, May 26, 1896.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 24. -- Jordan Hunter, colored, better known as "Mouse," and famed throughout the State as a barber, is dead at his home in Louisville as the result of a knife wound inflicted by Jennie Butler, who is under arrest.

RICHMOND, Nov. 25. -- Judge Hughes was here yesterday in consultation with M.F. Pleasants, Clerk of the United States Circuit Court, in regard to summoning a jury for the trial of John Anderson, now in jail at Norfolk, for the murder on the high seas of the Captain and mate of the schooner Olive Pecker.

Nobody appeared at the Morgue yesterday to claim the body of George H. Blanchard, the old recluse who died Wednesday at the "Raines law hotel," 352 West Forty-fourth Street, and the police made no progress in their efforts to discover some of his relatives. His effects are still at the West Forty-seventh Street Police Station, and will be held there until Coroner Fitzpatrick disposes of the case.

The twelfth of the season's course of free lectures at Public School No. 23, at Mulberry and Bayard Streets, was given last night by Raymond L. Ditmars of the American Museum of Natural History. The subject was "Snakes," and the lecturer illustrated his remarks with live reptiles.

Charles L. McNally, seventeen years old, was shot and seriously hurt yesterday morning by Policeman John J. Hannigan of the East One Hundred and Fourth Street Station, who was chasing him for being one of a crowd of boys who were creating a disturbance in East One Hundred and Seventh Street.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25. -- If there be any law under which they can take action, the Democratic leaders will attempt to prevent the Republican Legislature, in special session, from making a reapportionment of the State. Just how to proceed with anything like assurance of success is the question they are now endeavoring to solve.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 25. -- The Grand Jury of the St. Louis Criminal Court, under the law passed by the last Legislature, entitled "Frauds in Horse Races," has found indictments against C.S. Merbert, Fred Hagenfield, M.G. Winans, and O.A. Arthur, charged with being implicated in the Little-I-Am case of ringing at the St. Louis Fair Grounds last July.

The story of the wreck at sea of the yacht Cythera in the great blizzard that raged along the Atlantic Coast in March, 1888 was told for the first time last Sunday by one of the crew of the ill-fated vessel, Ilak Engleson. He is doubtless the only survivor of the craft, the fate of which had remained a mystery for nearly ten years.

It is possible that Count GULOCHOWSKI'S appeal to Europe to "unite against the destructive competition of America" may have had for part of its motive the production of an issue upon which the peoples of Austria-Hungary could unite. There is urgent need of such an issue. The question whether German shall be the sole official language of the empire has stirred up far more strife than any similar question in history.

In his eventful career on the cycle track little James Michael probably never finished such a wonderful performance as delighted thousands of spectators at the Madison Square Garden last night. The midget lad from Wales rode twenty-five miles in 50 minutes and 29 seconds on a nine-lap board track, banked so steeply on the turns that the riders leaned over at a seemingly perilous angle.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25. -- The football eleven of the University of Chicago, defeated the University of Michigan team this afternoon by the score of 21 to 12. The game was played in the Coliseum in the presence of 12,000 persons.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 25. -- After one of the fiercest contests waged on the football field in this vicinity, the Orange Athletic Club eleven defeated their old-time rivals, the Elizabeth Athletic Club, by a score of 6 to 4 this afternoon, on Orange Oval. Both teams were composed mainly of former college football celebrities, who were once known as champions of the sport.

ALBANY, Nov. 25. -- The College Council recently issued an invitation to the Faculties of what are known as the "literary" colleges to send representatives to a conference to be held at Vassar College tomorrow morning.

Ex-Congressman James J. Belden of Syracuse returned to New York yesterday. Last night at the Manhattan Hotel he denied that he intended to become the leader of the anti-Platt movement. "I am not the leader of any movement," he said, "and shall not become a leader. I have taken no personal interest in the matter and have not been consulted about it."

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25. -- The University of Pennsylvania football team defeated Cornell this afternoon on Franklin Field by the score of 4 to 0. It was by far the fastest game that has been played here this season, and developed unexpected strength in the Cornell team.

In 1885 I began to feel sick all the time. I really had no idea as to the nature of my ailments. "Why does your face look swollen so much every morning?" my wife would say to me. I told her I didn't know unless I had Bright's disease. Yet nothing was further from my idea of sickness.

George F. Stevens, the oldest telegraph operator at Police Headquarters, is missing. He has not been in his accustomed place in the Mulberry Street building since Saturday, and his friends, who have been fruitlessly searching for him, say that his body will be found in the river. If this is true, then the department has lost a trusted and tried servant, who always did his whole duty.
HAVANA, Nov. 25. -- Aear Admiral Vicente Manterola arrived to-day from Spain and took charge of the Admiralty Office. With him came also 300 soldiers, and 270 seamen.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 25. -- The General Assembly of Georgia refused to adjourn over Thanksgiving Day yesterday. Although the day had been so declared by the Governor, as well as the President, the members from the country declared that public business must go on, and pictured the hardships of the farmer who had to work every day in the year.

Driven nearly frantic with hunger, Frank Brower, thirty years old, a cooper, who came here from Albany, threw a big iron bolt through the large plate glass window in the store of Hamilton, Noyes Co., Sixth Avenue and Twenty-third Street, yesterday, and then in the hope that he would be provided with a good Thanksgiving dinner, asked to be arrested.

A thousand householders and several owners of factory property on the Park Slope, Brooklyn, have a joint plumbing bill which they intend to demand payment of from the city. This is how they say it all came about:

-- What is said to be the last of the many reports that have been made on the recent smallpox epidemic at Gloucester, England, has just been issued as a Parliamentary blue-book. It contains a summing up of all the information obtainable by careful and expert investigations, and deserves attentive study wherever interest is taken in public health, the prevention of disease, and the means of curing it.

ANNAPOLIS, Nov. 25. -- The football game here to-day between the cadets and young officers of the White Squadron, which the cadets won by a score of 8 to 0, was followed by a disgraceful incident, for which cadets of the lower classes were responsible.

John Daebler spent Thanksgiving Day in the workhouse, and gained a whole pound in weight. Though for the past twelve years a professional and confessed beggar, it was his first day in a prison in all the seventy-three years of his eventful life. Time was when Daebler was a sturdy, cheerful farm hand, with not a care in the world, a good appetite, and a fondness for hard work.

VIENNA, Nov. 25. -- The unparalleled scenes of violence in the lower house of the Reichsrath yesterday are almost the only subject of conversation throughout Austria to-day. The German Progressist Party has published a note, expressing regret at the outbreak and disclaiming any responsibility for it.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 25. -- Henry Green has brought suit against his sister, Annie Green, to clear his title to property on the Fountain Ferry Road, and to recover possession of the two front rooms, which he alleges she has occupied by sufferance.

For the first time in many years the anniversary of the evacuation of New York by the British troops occurred on Thanksgiving Day. The Old Guard always parades on Evacuation Day, and in order that the members of that organization might be permitted to eat their Thanksgiving dinners with their families, the parade yesterday was arranged for an earlier hour than usual.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- President McKinley attended Thanksgiving services at the Metropolitan Methodist Church to-day. He was accompanied to the church by his brother, Abner McKinley; Mrs. Smith, and Miss Barbor. Mrs. McKinley and Mrs. Abner McKinley were out driving for a short time, but Mrs. McKinley was not feeling well enough to attend church.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25. -- Bronco Baccaccio, a lion tamer, was attacked by a vicious lioness late Wednesday night, and though scratched by the claws of the infuriated beast, bitten in a half dozen places, and covered with blood from a score of wounds, he battled with the lioness with gun and club, and by the heroic efforts of Trainer Johnson, his assistant at the Zoo Gardens, escaped with his life.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 25. -- According to an afternoon newspaper, Dr. Nansen, the arctic explorer, who last night lectured to a crowded house at Music Hall on his travels in the far north, deliberately snubbed a committee of prominent officials of the municipality and Federal Government and gentlemen in private life who called on him at the Planters' Hotel to-day to extend certain courtesies.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Nov. 25. -- It is probable that a more earnest effort to form a combination to advance cotton will be made at the Cotton Growers' Convention to be held in Atlanta on Dec. 14 than has been attempted before. J.C. Wilborn, President of the South Carolina Alliance, has great hopes of effective results.
While smoking on the front platform of a horse car last night a reporter asked the driver how he had enjoyed his holiday.

The New England Society of Charleston seems determined to surpass even itself in the intellectual entertainment provided for its anniversary, December 22. Justice Brewer of the Supreme Court of the United States; Seth Low, the President of Columbia University, who made the great fight for the Mayoralty of Greater New York; United States Senator John L. McLaurin, and President Randolph, of the College of Charleston are to be among the speakers at the banquet.
