CHICAGO, Nov. 25. -- In spite of a drizzling rain, 2,000 people assembled at Bankers' Field this afternoon to see the football contest between the Knickerbocker Athletic Club of New York and the Bankers' Athletic Club of this city. The local team won by the score of 46 to 8. The line-up:
The following sales at auction are down for to-day at 111 Broadway:

TOLEDO, Nov. 25. -- D.C. Hansen of Chicago, who is the attorney of Mrs. Nettie Wallace Walkup-Ketcham, arrived here to-day for the purpose of making certain investigations in the interest of his client. In an interview Mr. Hansen said that Mrs. Ketcham vehemently denied any charge of duress or undue influence over John B. Ketcham, and maintained that her marriage was legal and Mr. Ketcham was mentally competent to make a will.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 25. -- The open tournament of the Lakewood Golf Club, which is to continue through the week, began to-day. The Laurel and Laurel-in-the-Pines Hotels are filled with golfers and their friends, and conversation in those houses is chiefly upon the absorbing topic of the week.

Down Pell Street toward the Bowery came ten or twenty, ragamuffins arrayed in all the fantastic garments that they usually put on to celebrate Thanksgiving Day, when with masks over their faces and tin horns in their mouths they blow lustily into the ears of the weary Italian fruit vendors and demand some apples or a handful of chestnuts.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 25. -- The members of the Meadow Brook Hunt Club and of society turned out in force to participate in the different events held yesterday on the grounds surrounding the clubhouse. On the programme were a jumping contest over hurdles, golf matches, and one of the stiffest cross-country runs that have been participated in by the club.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25. -- The decision of the court-martial at Fort Sheridan in the case of Capt. Lovering, who is charged with cruel treatment of Private Hammond, will not be announced here, but will be sent to Washington, as is usual in such cases. The general opinion at Fort Sheridan to-day was that the court would not hold Capt. Lovering blameless.

It has been the general belief that free coinage of silver by the United States would yield large profits to the mine owners. This view was accepted by the sound money advocates in the Presidential campaign last year. The following extract from an editorial comment on this subject, from the November number of The Bankers' Magazine, a leading journal of its class, conveys its views, and also the popular impression:

The regular holiday shoot of the Brooklyn Gun Club attracted several of the best marksmen in the club to the Liberty Avenue traps. Eight events were shot, the last one being unfinished on account of darkness. The principal winners throughout the day were Swan and Skidmore, The scores:

TORONTO, Nov. 25. -- The final football games for the Rugby championships of Canada were played to-day. At Montreal, Ottawa College defeated Hamilton for the senior championship by the score of 14 to 10 and in this city Toronto University won from the Britannias of Montreal by the score of 25 to 5 for the intermediate championship.

It was a "rope yarn Sunday" with "soft bread and shore food," and plenty of it on board all the vessels at the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday. The men from the various ships were set at liberty shortly after quarters in the morning, and they prepared to celebrate the day as only Uncle Sam's bluejackets can.

WASHINGTON, Nov, 25. -- The practice of the Bureau of American Republics in publishing advertisements in its official publications, against which considerable complaint has been made by the trade journals of the country, will be caned to the attention of Congress at its coming session. The trade journals complain of the practice as an unfair competition on the part of the Government.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 25. -- The first arrest under Tennessee's "Johnny" bill has just been made in this county. Lynn Chamberlain, the son of a prominent patent-medicine manufacturer, was placed in the custody of the police authorities for a violation of the law.

The annual competition for the Vice President's Cup was played yesterday on the St. Andrew's Golf Club links, at Mount Hope, Westchester County. All the winners of the Class A, B, and C handicaps during the past seven months were eligible, and the result was a large turnout. J.M. Thomas won the trophy with a net score of 173.

The Rev. Dr. R.S. MacArthur, pastor of Calvary Baptist Church, in West Fifty-seventh Street, devoted a considerable part of his Thanksgiving Day sermon to a discussion of civic evils. In addition to his regular congregation he had for hearers the boys from the Calvary Sunday school in uniform, and the cadets from the Olivet and Zion Colored Churches.
BERLIN, Nov. 25. -- Americans in Berlin met to-day at a Thanksgiving banquet at the Kaiserhof. The occasion was very enjoyable.

The Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott of Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, received a telegram yesterday from Tougaloo, Miss., informing him that the Girls' Hall of the Normal and Industrial School of that place had been destroyed by fire. The news was sent by Dr. Cyrus Hamlin, a brother-in-law of Dr. Abbott, who is the Dean of the school.

We feel that an expression of thanks is due to THE TIMES for its making more widely known the valuable extract from Popular Science News relating to the proved experiment of the Tunis naturalist, that heron farming can be carried on precisely as ostrich faming is done, to supply the market with the feathers.

Wonders will never cease. Hitherto Canada has insisted that the United States should pay damages to all Canadians who suffered by the suspension of pelagic sealing. But now we are told from Ottawa that the Dominion is willing itself to assume these damages, which, by the way, the decadence of the industry reduces to a nominal burden.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- "It is not new, at least to us, but I hope they have really accomplished all that the story sets forth," said Secretary of Agriculture Wilson after reading an account published in The London Daily Mail about a fortnight ago of what was described as a discovery of the highest importance, made on the experimental farm of the Earl of Winchelsea at Sleaford.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 25. -- Lee Pitts, a negro Pullman porter living in this city, is a prisoner at the Four Courts on the charge of attempted robbery. A.E. Hill, a broker of Providence, R.I., alleges that Pitts tried to steal from his pocket an envelope containing $39,000 in certified checks and $3,000 in cash.
Oscar Hammerstein has formally announced that the Olympia will be reopened under the management of a corporation, to be known as the Olympia Amusement Company.

There is trouble among the school teachers in the various districts on Staten Island because they have not been paid their salaries for more than three months, and it is not likely that they will be paid until after Jan. 1.

Before a crowd of 4,000 wildly enthusiastic school boys, the Brooklyn High School triumphed over the Polytechnic Institute eleven at Eastern Park yesterday afternoon by a score of 58 to 0. It was the seventh annual game between the two schools, and more than the usual amount of interest was manifested.

While the rest of the world was enjoying itself yesterday, a hundred or so of little birds were shivering and fluttering in their cages in a dreary little room up-town, in a vain attempt to add some brightness to the day, and to give pleasure to a score of casual visitors, who, for want of something better, dropped in to look at them.

" I have a theory about double rhymes for which I shall be attacked by the critics, but which I could justify perhaps on high authority, or, at least, analogy. These volumes of mine have more double rhymes than any two books of English poems that ever to my knowledge were printed; I mean of English poems, not comic.

VIENNA, Nov. 26. -- The day has been one of great excitement, owing to the riotous scenes in the Reichsrath, and tonight a crowd of 10,000 persons, including many students, threatened the Government with revolution and Premier Badeni with the guillotine.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26. -- The annual report of Secretary of the Navy John D. Long for 1897 has just been presented to President McKinley. The volume contains extracts from the reports of the chiefs of the several departments and bureaus and their recommendations respecting the appropriations needed to continue the work, and also a report of the work completed and under construction.

Hall Caine has lost one of his best friends -- a man almost if not quite, unknown this side the water, but whom Caine extois in choice and impassioned terms. The Rev. Tom Brown the Manx poet, is that friend. He died suddenly while Caine was in Paris suffering from a severe attack of influenza. Caine has since written of Brown as follows:

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 26. -- Andrew Satto, who said he was a car inspector of the Third Avenue street car line of New York, arrived here last Sunday. Monday he disappeared in circumstances that caused the police to believe that he had met with foul play.

SILVER CREEK, N. Y., Nov. 26. -- Augustus Kennedy, who lives on the Versailles Road, was shot in the shoulder and again in the back while sitting at a table in the front room of his house reading a paper last night.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26. -- The audience at the Great Northern Theatre to-night narrowly missed being entertained by a riot of stage hands, actors, and actresses, instead of "The Bohemian Girl," which was the opera billed for the occasion. The trouble was caused by a strike of stage hands and electricians.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 26. -- The Reorganization Committee of the Columbus, Sandusky and Hocking Railroad has arranged to take the road out of Receiver Fellows's hands by Jan. 1, and a new bond issue of $31,000,000 will be authorized. The present issue is $7,000,000. It is understood that George W. Sinks, President of the Deshler Bank of this city, will be President of the reorganized company.

Apparently conflicting provisions in Section 1570 of the Greater New York Charter have started discussion as to the legality of the election of the Coroners chosen for the Boroughs of Manhattan, the Bronx, Queens, and Richmond. Assistant Corporation Counsel Sterling said yesterday that there could be no doubt as to the legality of their election, although there might be some question as to their terms of office.

MADRID, Nov. 26. -- Marshal Blanco has cabled the Cabinet an assurance that he will be the arbiter in connection with the customs tariff, and that the interests of the Peninsula will not suffer thereby.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26. -- Wheat sold at $1 today for the December option, and closed at 99 1/2c, an advance of 3 8/8c. May showed a considerable amount of sympathy with the advance in December and closed 1 1/4c 1 3/8c higher. Efforts of shorts both here and from St. Louis caused the advance in December, and they were not supplied until $1 had been bid.

Not long ago a gentleman astonished the world, and tested the fortitude of his friends, by reciting from memory the whole of Dante's "Divine Comedy." The feat was accomplished in twenty-six hours, and was sufficiently novel and undesirable. But in eccentricity a reciter, who has recently performed before Miss Ellen Terry, goes further.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 26. -- The Tammany leaders arrived here on the Lakewood special this afternoon. They were immediately driven to the Lakewood Hotel, and were assigned to a large suite of rooms on the first floor. They dined in the public dining room and spent the evening in the hotel office, smoking and listening to the orchestra.

In Hazlitt's edition of "Luther's Table Talk" (1857) is given the history of that very remarkable book, and the story of it is worth recalling. The entire genuineness of "Luther's Table Talk" has been questioned, but the supposition is that the Great Reformer did write the major part of the book, or that it was, as a whole, revised by him.
Magistrate CRANE could hardly do less than hold Policeman HANNIGAN for the Grand Jury, and the Police Commissioners were certainly right in suspending him without pay and promptly ordering his trial.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26. -- A Chicago paper, professing to have its views from one who knows what he is talking about, says the court-martial at Fort Sheridan yesterday found Capt. Lovering guilty, as charged, of cruel and brutal treatment of Private Hammond. On the same authority the paper adds the statement that the court recommends that Capt. Lovering's punishment shall be a reprimand by the reviewing authority.

NEWARK, Nov. 26. -- The body of Marquis Muzio Azzi di Marchesi Vitellischi, formerly a Lieutenant in the Italian Navy, lies in a plain coffin in Mullin's undertaking establishment in this city awaiting the action of the county authorities. Some time on Wednesday night the Marquis, tired of the troubles of life and ill from brooding over the affairs of his family in Italy, fired a bullet into his brain.

The Rev. Dr. James A. Worden, Superintendent of the Sunday School Department of the Presbyterian Church in this country, has begun a movement to celebrate the opening of the Twentieth Century. His idea is to recruit the Sunday school army of his Church so that instead of 1,000,000 members, as at present, it will consist of a host of 1,500,000.

The subscription sale for the season of grand opera to be given at the Metropolitan Opera House, beginning Jan. 17, under the direction of Walter Damrosch and C.E Ellis, will open Monday, Nov. 29, at the box office. The season will be a comprehensive one, and will include examples of the modern French, German, and Italian schools.
" There is no way by which people exhaust themselves, kill themselves, so quickly as by exercising the affections."
BUFFALO, Nov. 26. -- President Jones of Hobart College, who witnessed the game yesterday between his college and the University of Buffalo, in an interview, said:

Not often does there appear a disclosure which at once dispels and deepens "the mystery of the sea" like that which appeared in THE TIMES yesterday morning. There are men, and especially there are women, in New York who waited for months after the descent of the memorable blizzard of March, 1888, with a heart-breaking anxiety for news of the Cythera.

The Academy complains of "the cunning way in which the American copyright law" is framed. It says we all know that if a book is to be copyrighted in the United States it must be printed here. "No plates or sheets sent from England will be protected from the pirate." Now, what is the result?

LONDON, Nov. 26. -- Special dispatches received here to-day from Shanghai say that Baron von Heyking, the German Minister to China, has presented to the Chinese Government the demands of Germany for the recent murder of German missionaries and the destruction of German mission property.

" The relation of great authors to the public," says Mr. Raleigh, "may be compared to the war of the sexes, a quiet, watchful antagonism between two parties mutually indispensable to each other, at one time veiling itself in endearments, at another breaking out into open defiance. * * * The public, like the delicate Greek Narcissus, is sleepily enamored of itself; and the name of its only other perfect lover is Echo.

Prof. Benjamin I. Wheeler, the advisory member of the Cornell Athletic Council, is in the city for a few days during the university's Thanksgiving recess. It was understood that Prof. Wheeler had come to New York to confer with Yale men relative to the challenge which it is said Yale has decided to send to Cornell for university boat races next season. Prof. Wheeler said yesterday:
John S. Kennedy yesterday obtained an injunction from Justice Lawrence in Part II. of the Supreme Court, restraining the New York Telephone Company from placing its lines over or upon his premises.

The last time I saw Dickens was in 1863, at the funeral of William Makepeace Thackeray, to which I accompanied my father. Although December, it was as bright and sunny as a Summer day. On getting out at the railway station we encountered George Cruikshank, with whom in early life Thackeray had studied etching, and whose illustrations were a feature of Dickens's earlier works.

LONDON, Nov. 26. -- "Tod" Sloane, riding D. Seymour's four-year-old bay mare Sapling, finished first in the race for the Ellesmere Welter Handicap, at the second day's racing of the Manchester November meeting to-day.

A careful reading of your correspondent "A.B.C.'s" letters leaves one in some obscurity as to the precise ground upon which she defends the continued wearing of bird plumes, after the fact has been abundantly established that the marketing of birds' feathers for millinery purposes is the agency which has reduced some species of birds in a detrimental degree and practically exterminated others.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 26. -- A dull day, with fitful showers of rain, muddy grounds, and heavy greens, were among the unfavorable conditions which faced the golfers this morning as they journeyed out to the Lakewood Club links to begin the first hole play rounds for the Lakewood Club Cup and the consolation trophies.

OTTAWA, Nov. 26. -- The reply of the Canadian Government to the proposition of John V. Foster, in respect to the means of arriving at a settlement of the different questions of dispute between the United States and Canada will be forwarded from here to-morrow. It is in substance as stated in the dispatch published in THE NEW YORK TIMES this morning.

The cable steamer Mackay-Bennett left the White Star Line pier, at Christopher street, at 9:30 A.M. yesterday, having on board a number of telegraph, telephone, steamship and newspaper men, the guests of the Postal Telegraph Company.

DETROIT, Nov. 26. -- President William L. Holmes of the new Detroit Telephone Company, who recently returned from New York; says that a party of capitalists who are about to organize an independent telephone company in Greater New York are negotiating for the use of the Detroit apparatus for the New York exchange.

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 26. -- Charles C. McCloud, Treasurer of the McCloud, Crane Minter Company, manufacturers of screws, lies at the City Hospital in a critical condition, as the result of self-inflicted wounds.

In a petition presented yesterday to Judge McMahon, in Part I. of the General Sessions Court, for permission to inspect the minutes of the Grand Jury, it is alleged that Police Sergeant William E. Petty, now attached to the King's Bridge Station, endeavored to persuade a policeman to swear falsely in a case before the Grand Jury.

On Monday next a hearing will be given by the Board of Aldermen on the application of the Brooklyn, New York and New Jersey Tunnel Company for permission to use land under the surface of the city for a rapid transit route passing under the East River, to Brooklyn, and connecting with the Long Island Railroad, extending to Jamaica and the island.

If the Attorney General of New Jersey fails in his action to restrain the contractors who are destroying the Palisades with dynamite for the stone there is in them, there is no great probability that any other form of procedure against the vandals will be successful or even attempted. The contractors have this advantage, that public sentiment, if not actually on their side, is not against them.

GLEN HAVEN, Mich., Nov. 26. -- This afternoon a yawl containing the mate and a portion of the crew of the steamer Gogebic arrived here. The men related the story of the stranding of their steamer on North Manitou Island last night during the snow storm and the mate sent messages to vessel owners and the underwriters asking for assistance.
Judge Schatz of the Court of Sessions in Mt. Vernon, yesterday morning saw a man acting in a suspicious manner on the street, and, going over to the fellow, told him that he was under arrest.

Conferences of anti-organization Republicans will be held to-night in the Fifth, Thirteenth, Nineteenth, Twenty-first, Twenty-fifth, Twenty-seventh, Twenty-ninth, and Thirty-first Assembly Districts. Plans of organization will be discussed, which will be presented for consideration at a meeting to be held at the Plaza Club, Sixth Avenue, near Fifty-eighth Street, on Monday night.

We speak of thirty-two years as the average life of a generation, meaning roughly that the sum of the lives of human beings born at the same time, divided by their number, will be about thirty-two years. The average expectation of life necessarily decreases with the advance of time, and more rapidly in the cases of those suffering from disease or hardship or injury.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 26. -- Gen. Vincent Marmaduke of Sweet Springs, Mo., who was recenty appointed by the ex-Confederate veterans of Missouri as Chairman of a committee to write an authentic history of the part Missouri and Missourians took in the civil war, to-day issued an address to the ex-Confederates of Missouri, in which he says:

PARIS, Nov. 9. -- A great sensation has been created in political circles by the appearance of M. Charles Baihaut's "Impressions Cellulaires" -- impressions of Mazas, of the conciergerie, and of Etampes -- the three prisons in which during four weary years the ex-Minister of Public Works in the "Panama" Cabinet was confined in consequence of having accepted a bribe of 300,000f. ($60,000) from the Panama promoters.

And yet it is doubtful if they ever saw much of each other. There are only a few instances given in the Scriptures when they were together, and on each of these occasions it was but for a very short time.

There has been recently described by The Milwaukee Sentinel a country library which has been carried on by a system so unique and ingenious and with a result so successful that it may well challenge attention from a far wider circle than its originators dreamed of being able to interest.

" Teddy" Hale, the Irish racer, is expected to arrive on the Etruria this morning. He has finished a season of riding on English, European, and Australian tracks, and will come to participate in the six days' race, beginning shortly after midnight one week from to-morrow. Hale is the winner of last year's race, and his good form leads many to expect in him the winner of this year's contest.

Glasgow is a town of readers, but the direction in which the industry of readers is there directed differs from those to be found in most cities. Opened to the public in November, the total number of issues since then at the public library has been 7,676,278. Of this total works of fiction are accountable for 722,801, or only 9.41 per cent., a modest proportion.

The home of Robert Grant, novelist, essayist in the lighter vein, and Judge of the Probate Court of Suffolk, is appropriately in the very heart of Boston's most cherished residential district, the Back Bay. Robert Grant himself is a Bostonian of the typical sort, cultivated, able, and intensely proud of the traditions of his native city, and as alert as any for the maintenance of her genius and institutions.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 26. -- The eleventh annual convention of the Association of Colleges and Preparatory Schools of the Middle States and Maryland opened at Vassar College this afternoon, being attended by about 400 delegates, among whom were many prominent educators from different colleges.

The sale at auction recently of the first English edition of fontaigne's "Essays," a book which is almost as rare as the original French edition, reminds one of the precious Montaigne once owned by the late Comte de Lignerolles, whose library was sold in Paris in 1804. This was a copy of the 1588 edition, which the author had given to Loisel. It brought 8,000f.

The prosecution in the case against Martin Thorn, accused of the murder of Guldensuppe, closed its case somewhat abruptly yesterday, evidently to the surprise of the defense. The chief witness of the day was John Gotha, who told of Thorn's confession of the murder to him.

The cornerstone of the Knox Memorial Chapel, Forty-first Street, near Ninth Avenue, will be laid to-morrow afternoon at 3:30 o'clock. The ceremonies will be quite elaborate and will be participated in by the following ministers: The Rev. Drs. David James Burrell, Edward B. Coe, and Ferdinant Schureman Schenck, and the Rev. Messrs. Hiram Evertson Cobb, John Gerardus Fagg, R.F. Junor, and William Vaughan.

WARSAW, N.Y., Nov. 26. -- The Rev. Gilbert Reid, the missionary to China who has received distinguished honors from Li Hung Chang and the Chinese Government, and who is now at his home in this place, is to be married to Miss Sallie Bell, at the home of the bride's sister, in Columbia, S.C., on Wednesday, Dec. 1.

This discussion concerning birds seems to have reached the point that so many discussions come to, and the fact is again brought out that in essentials the various disputants entirely agree, but each one is so engaged with the bearing of the conditions on his own particular subject that he overlooks the right of others to claim consideration for their favorites.

Prof. Cyrus Adler, Librarian of the Smithsonian Institution, presents in pamphlet form a clear synopsis of the proceedings of the conference held in London last year, the object being the production of an international catalogue of scientific literature. Prof. Adler's paper is a reprint from Science of Aug. 6 of this year.

Who was it that said, "To-day Russian and German journalists are divided into two classes -- those who are in jail and those who are not" ? Press offenses with incarceration are so common in Germany as to be deemed unworthy of comment. It is reported that the German Journalist is feeling himself terribly aggrieved, and that the "Association of German Authors and Journalists" has sent a petition to the Reichstag asking for justice.

It will doubtless surprise the general reader to know that according to the author of the book entitled "Marriage Customs in Many Lands," the Rev. H.N. Hutchinson, published by D. Appleton Co., there have been only two attempts previous to his own to make a thorough compilation of the varying marriage ceremonials and customs in all parts of the world.

After a long period of negotiation, one of the largest real estate transactions of recent months was closed yesterday. J.D. Trimble has sold for Harry Chaffee to C.W. Seaman, for about $450,000, the new six-story building, 43, 45, 47, and 49 Bleecker Street, just east of the new Elm Street, and extending through to Shinbone Alley, 85 by 100 by 63.6 by 80.

Three young men, giving their names as John Hennessy, twenty-two years old, of 7 Vandam Street; Thomas Murphy, twenty-two years old, of the Bowery, and James Phelan of 235 Mulberry Street, were arraigned in Centre Street Court yesterday afternoon. At the same time the police exhibited a lot of solid silverware which had been found in a bundle that one of them carried when arrested. The silverware is valued at several hundred dollars.

The Twenty-first Assembly District, which is just now the scene of three separate independent movements and boasts of a Citizens' Union enrollment of 3,500, led off last night in the movement to make a permanent municipal party out of the Citizens' Union organization.

The ancient Egyptians wore a profusion of false hair. With "an exaggerated idea of cleanliness," as Erman expresses it, they deemed natural hair unclean, and so shaved their pates and wore wigs. Egyptians of today follow in part the ways of their forefathers, and have bald heads, but allow their beards to grow.

The Presbytery of Brooklyn on Monday evening elected the Rev. Dr. Lorenzo Mason Clarke a member of the Presbytery, and the call of the First Presbyterian Church for his pastorship was formally approved. The new pastor will be installed on the evening of Dec. 8, with the following order of service, as approved by the Presbytery: The Moderator (the Rev. W.J. Hutchins) will preside and propound the constitutional questions.

ST. PAUL, Nov. 26. -- Cushman K. Davis, Chairman of the Senate Foreign Affairs Committee, said this evening that immediately upon the convening of Congress he would move the ratification of the Hawaiian annexation treaty. He said he was confident that it would be ratified, although he had made no canvass of the Senators to learn their sentiments.

Mrs. Beecher, the mother of John Beecher, one of Davenport's company of colonists, "was a good woman, and useful to the company," says Mrs. James T. Fields in the opening chapter of her "Life and Letters of Harriet Beecher Stowe," and the words describe every woman of the line down to the author of "Uncle Tom's Cabin," minister's daughter, minister's wife, and sister of six ministers, as she described herself to Frederick Douglass.

" The eventful first night arrived at last, and throughout my artistic career I have never experienced a more stormy evening. It was not the hostile party alone, but a whole series of mishaps which contributed to the great fiasco of my opera. The overture was completely drowned, a9 well as the first chorus, by the hissing and whistling of the public.

The New York Society of the Sons of the Revolution last night celebrated the one hundred and fourteenth anniversary of the evacuation of New York by the British in 1783, with a dinner at Delmonico's. Nearly 250 members and guests attended and listened to four set speeches and several informal ones.

A curious literary interest is the interest which men and women periodically take in proposals to establish in England and America an Academy modeled after the one of France. About once in ten years some one revives such a project as a suggestion in some newspaper and promptly gets up a list of members.

While business did not extend yesterday, the total of Stock Exchange transactions falling short of 200,000 shares, it was made plain that there is much more strength underlying the market than the professional traders of the Street have been estimating.

I could hardly have valued more a tress from a saint's head than I value one which may once have touched 'that godlike forehead,' seen so often in my youthful fancies, but never, alas! in the light of day.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27. -- Patrick Hartford, one of the policemen wounded in the Haymarket riot, and a pensioner of the Police Department, died at the County Hospital Friday night. It is believed that his wounds had something to do with his taking off.

The Prussian State railroads administration is constrained to apologize for a state of things which would fill our railroad managers with great satisfaction. It cannot possibly furnish all the cars that shippers are calling for, and to prove that it is not to blame it is shown that long since it ordered all the cars that all the German car-builders can turn out for months to come.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 27. -- A few months ago John J. Moore of Birmingham, Ala., while en route from Cincinnati to this city, started to get out of his berth on the Pullman car Hiawasse. His foot caught in a pillow, and he was thrown to the floor, injuring his leg.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27. -- The coal-mining strike in the Northern Illinois district ended yesterday. Twelve thousand men have gone back to work in the Coal City, Braidwood, Carbon Hill, Spring Valley, Lodi, Seatonville. La Salle, and Oglesby fields. One thousand men remain out at Streator, the only point where the miners and operators have not agreed.

The annual election of the New York Press Club to-morrow, which it had been thought would be unusually quiet, owing to recent developments, will now probably be the liveliest and most exciting in the history of the organization. The present incumbent of the office of President, Mr. Joseph Howard, Jr., was asked on Nov. 3 by a large and representative number of members to accept a renomination.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- A delegation representing the officers and Directors of the Pan-American Exposition Company called on the President yesterday in company with Representative D.S. Alexander of the Niagara district and laid before him the plan of the exposition, which is to be held at La Salle, on the Niagara River, in the Summer of 1899.

Great satisfaction is expressed at the reform in the procedure of what is called "l'instruction criminelle," or the preliminary examinations of prisoners by the magistrates described as Juges d'Instruction. Hitherto these gentlemen have had a large amount of latitude in dealing with accused persons, who were often subjected to long and terrible interrogations worthy of the Grand Inquisitors of old.

AUSTIN, Texas, Nov. 27. -- This afternoon John Rankin, a prominent citizen, was shot by Policeman "Jim" Grizzard. It is said that the cause of the trouble was a political difference over the coming municipal election in this city.
The trial of Martin Thorn for the murder of Guldensuppe has developed as many surprises as horrors, and the indications are that dramatic and remarkable incidents will mark its progress to the end.

In Manchuria and along the Mongolian borders of China there are thousands of farms on which nothing is raised but dogs, of a breed peculiar to this region. Each proprietor keeps several hundreds of them. They are of a large size, and when eight months old are killed, usually in midwinter, for the sake of their skins.

Wall Street has had a week free from interesting incident. Quotations have not yielded, though they have been under pressure; and they have not much advanced, though in some instances clever schemes to help them along have been supported. It has for the most part been a week without results of consequence.

From an ethical point of view it is plain that there is nothing to be said for the procedures of the Germans in China. The explanations given to the Chinese Government for the occupation of Chinese territory recall nothing so much as the explanations of the wolf to the lamb in the fable. The performance betrays with unusual cynicism the belief that morality has nothing to do with international relations.

WICHITA, Kan., Nov. 27. -- Alva Wilson, an inventor of this city, has just perfected a magazine gun, or rather an attachment for any rifle of standard make, whereby the rifle is transformed into a magazine gun whose possibilities for dealing leaden death in warfare are tremendous. The attachment is simple, effective, and easy of operation.

J.H. DOLPH paints cats. It is by no means depreciative of the richer gifts of this extremely talented painter to say that he paints cats, for he paints dogs also. More, he painted portraits with great success at one time, and scenes from American farm life -- the farmer plowing, sowing, and reaping.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 27. -- Many interesting and exciting features marked the close of the big open tournament of the Lakewood Golf Club to-day, and besides the close finishes on the links, which made the contests among the best that have been held here, extra interest was added to the day's sport by the appearance of New York's political leaders.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 27. -- The principal event of the coming week in intercollegiate circles will be the annual Yale-Harvard debate, which is to take place at New Haven on Friday evening. This event will have an unusual interest this year, owing to the live question to be discussed. The subject for debate is: "Resolved, That the United States should annex the Hawaiian Islands."

GLASGOW, Nov. 17. -- G.L. Watson of Glasgow has completed the design of a schooner yacht of about 280 tons, which is intended for a fast cruiser, or, more correctly, a racing schooner. This schooner is to be rigged with fore and aft canvas, with a fore and main mast, but with no square yards or square topsails on the foremast.

PARIS, Nov. 16. -- Not for many years has there been so great a sensation in Paris as that which has arisen to-day in the Chamber and among politicians generally, in connection with the Dreyfus case. The lobbies of the Chamber were particularly animated. I noticed McArthur Meyer, the editor of the Gaulois, who seemed to think that his co-religionist Dreyfus was guilty, but that a more public trial would have suited the Parisians better.

STIMULATED by the principle of the brotherhood of man, Mount Sinai Hospital has developed in an atmosphere of non-sectarianism. Planned and established with this principle paramount, it has, since its inception, received applicants without regard to creed, race, or religion.

Business men in Broadway, Williamsburg, in view of the approaching consolidation, are going to organize an association, the object of which is to secure needed improvement in that section of Brooklyn. The following circular was sent to fifty business men last week, of whom twenty-five attended a meeting on Friday afternoon:

BRUSSELS, Oct. 5. -- There are a score of ways of quitting Germany for the Western end of the Continent, but the traveler who has had some experience at making short cuts by the little local roads, in native fashion, is likely to look about for the fast trains, as I did rather than content himself with trains that run a small number of miles in a large number of hours.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 27. -- The Carlisle Indian football team was treated to a genuine surprise to-day by the eleven representing the Ohio Medical University. The game was played at the Western League bail park. Quarter Back Hudson and Centre Smith of the Indians were unable to be in the game on account of injuries received in Cincinnati.

OSHKOSH, Wis., Nov. 27. -- Richard Raddatz of this place, a young machinist and mechanical draughtsman, seems to have made a success in his attempts to solve the problem of submarine navigation. After five years of experiment he has built a craft which seems to demonstrate that it can be successfully propelled under water for hours at a time.

The new telephone company about to begin operations in this city is the Citizens' Telephone Company of New York and New Jersey. D.A. Reynolds, its Secretary, said yesterday that this was undoubtedly the concern to which William L. Holmes, President of the Detroit Telephone Company, referred indefinitely in a dispatch printed yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 27. -- Germany's Imperial Parliament will reassemble on Tuesday to begin its final session under a far greater strain of excitement than any Reichstag has ever known. One knows not whether the foreign or domestic politics of the empire is in the more unpleasant and dangerous state of confusion.

But far the best breeds belong to the East, and it is strange that the Crusaders never brought back some of the really first-class goats of Palestine and Syria to this country. The difference between the best breeds of sheep and goats of Palestine is far less than might be supposed from the wording of the New Testament.

ANOTHER bronze statue heroic in size has been cast for the Library of Congress by the Henry Bonnard Bronze Company. It has gone to Washington to take its place on the gallery of the rotunda with the Shakespeare, Wellington, Herodotus, and other effigies of men famous in literature, science, statecraft, and war. It is the Columbus, by Paul Wayland Bartlett, shown in the illustration.

There will be a number of important amendments to the Military Code considered by the Code Committee of the National Guard Association, which meets at the armory of the Second Battery next Friday. The Executive Committee of the association will also meet at the same time.

Perhaps one would hardly call a mouse dirt, but in the circumstances it was surely matter in the wrong place. There was something suggestive in the reply of the baker.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 27. -- On his farm, in the interior of Dutchess County, died, on Nov. 20, "Squire" George W. Ingraham, in his eighty-fifth year. "Squire" Ingraham was the originator in the State of New York of the law which gives a married woman the right to hold real and personal prope ty independent of her husband, which measure it took him eight years to get passed.

This is the strange adventure of Fadilla Mohamed, a very coy and very sweet little body, equally pretty whether attired in commonplace, everyday raiment or in pink silk tights. She lives with her mother at 2,081 Eighth Avenue, in a small but quiet and comfortable flat, where also lives, Grandme Mohamed. There are no others in the family.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- The State Department declined to say anything to-day respecting the answer of the Canadian Government on the seal question, details of which were telegraphed to the press from Ottawa last night, further than to state that no communication on the subject had been received from either the British Embassy or from Ottawa.

" I am quite sure that I shall not be retained by the incoming administration; I have positive information to that effect, but one thing I can assure you of -- that the standard of the Street Cleaning Department will not be lowered after Jan. 1 next, and that to the best of my knowledge its present efficiency will be maintained by the powers that will then assume control."

The spectacular fairy operetta of "Cinderella" will be produced at the Metropolitan Opera House during the week commencing Dec 27 by 3,000 boys, girls, young men, and young women. One thousand of these will occupy the stage at each performance. Those in charge of the entertainment say that, in point of size and the almost infinite variety of its scenes, nothing ever yet attempted in this city can be compared with it.

LONDON, Nov. 27. -- The question as to who may be accused of taking the greater liberties with Shakespeare is a mooted one between Augustin Daly and Beerbohm Tree, and has arisen as a result of the unpleasantness between the two distinguished managers over Mr. Tree's invitation to Ada Rehan to appear in his theatre.

The new Springfield rifle recently adopted by the National Guard was given a severe test at the Seventh Regiment Armory last night in two important team matches, in which every company was represented. Some good scores were made despite the fact that the members have used the new rifle only a short time.

Many millions of dollars are involved in the question of discriminating duties on goods brought into this country by way of Canada. Several hundred protests have been filed by American importers against the imposition of such duties, and the Board of United States General Appraisers yesterday fixed Wednesday, Dec. 15, for the hearing of testimony and arguments on these cases.

Daniel Frohman has arranged with Alexander Lambert as director of the New York College of Music, W.J. Henderson and the American Symphony Orchestra, and with Sam Franko as conductor, to present a lecture by Mr. Henderson on "The Orchestra," and its instruments at the Lyceum Theatre on Tuesday afternoon, Dec. 7, at 3 o'clock.

Brig. Gen. D.W. Flagler, Chief of Ordnance of the United States Army, says that the number of seacoast guns manufactured last year was about 50 per cent. more than in any preceding year. One of the most important events of the year was the successful completion of the first, or type 12-1nch, disappearing gun carriage.

It was reported on Staten Island yesterday that a movement is under way to consolidate the Staten Island Electric Railroad and Midland Electric Companies, and the deal may be consummated next week. The consolidation will be an important factor to Staten Islanders who are at present under a disadvantage caused by the bitter fights that have been in progress by the rival companies.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Nov. 27. -- There was much rejoicing here on Wednesday over the arrest of three tramps who invaded the premises of Mrs. Selah T. Clock and attempted to organize a premature Thanksgiving celebration of a destructive and disorderly character. They were captured by a posse, and it was generally felt that a triumph of detective skill and courage had been achieved.

NEW BRUNSWICK, Nov. 27. -- The latest phase of the Princeton Inn trouble is the reported intention of Prof. Rockwood, an Elder in the Second Presbyterian Church at Princeton, to resign from the Presbyterian Church. It is said that Prof. Rockwood may be disciplined for signing the application for a license for Princeton Inn.
BERLIN, Nov. 27. -- The police have confiscated this week's issue of the Kladderadatsch because it contained a cartoon ridiculing Emperor William's recent speech to the recruits.

Coming close on the statement of the Cuban Assembly that Cuba would treat with Spain only on the basis of absolute independence is an order issued by Gen. Calixto Garcia to the officers under his command, a copy of which was received yesterday by Gen. Tomas Estrada Palma. The letter is as follows:

The members of the American Society of Civil Engineers opened their new house, on West Fifty-seventh Street, near the Carnegie Music Hall, last Wednesday. The building is a beautiful example of French Renaissance in Indiana limestone, richly carved, and is a notable addition to the ever-increasing list of New York's handsome buildings.

The D.Y.N.T. Society's "Country Fair," at Sherry's, on the afternoons of Dec. 2 and 3 next, promises to be a quaint departure from ordinary fairs. The young ladies of the society, which is technically known as the Doe Ye the Nexte Thinge Society for Work Among the Poor, are the projectors of the fair, and have spared no pains to carry out the idea of an old-time country festival.

MUSKOGEE, I. T., Nov. 27. -- Chief Isparhecher has sent his message to the Creek Council, which is now in session at Okmulgee, I. T. He reminds them that they have not yet disposed of the question of the division of lands as proposed by the Dawes Commission, and adds: ...

Time, 10 A.M. The stage manager, sitting enthroned at a little table at the front and centre of the stage, with the manuscript before him and a movable bunch-light at his side, dominates the scene. The cavernous gloom of the empty theatre stretches beyond. On the stage the actors and actresses are huddled in little whispering groups.

ALBANY, Nov. 27. -- One of the questions that are uppermost in the minds of the Republican politicians of the State is whether Hamilton Fish will be one of the Gubernatorial candidates next Fall, or will wait and have a try for the United States Senatorship. The majority of the opinions expressed place the ex-Speaker in the list of possible nominees for the Governorship.

About 10,000 pounds of eiderdown are collected annually in Iceland, 7,000 being exported to foreign countries. Formerly the peasants used to receive over 21 shillings a pound, but the price has now fallen to half that Amount. The peasants seldom receive money, and are obliged to barter their down for merchandise furnished by the Danish merchants at the little settlements on the fjords.

The announcement was made recently that the last fragment of old Fort Crawford at Prairle du Chien, Wis., had crumbled into ruins. This marks the disappearance of the last relic of the ante-pioneer days and Uncle Sam's display of power as emphasized by the chain of forts which overawed the savage tribes in the first quarter of the century.
Poverty is a thing of infinite variety, and a human being's way of being poor is a very good index to his or her character.

Among the passengers on the Cunard Liner Etruria, which arrived yesterday, was Teddy Hale, the long-distance cycle champion of the world. He intends to take part in the six-day race which begins in Madison Square Garden at midnight, Dec. 5, and reported himself in the finest possible condition.

Mr. CHARLES DUDLEY WARNER delivered a most interesting address the other day to the Comparative Literature Society on the need in the United States of a "Literary Institute." The substance of it was that such a body could do much toward framing and getting generally accepted a standard of literature in this country.

The main source of the amber supply is the seacoast of the Baltic. It is fossil gum, originally the exudation of a species of conifer now extinct. This grew in luxuriant profusion hundreds of thousands of years ago on the marshy coasts of Northern Europe, when the climate was much warmer than it is to-day.

William C. Applegate, who during the Lexow investigation testified that he had paid Police Captain James K. Price for protection for "green-goods" men, was arraigned yesterday in the West Side Police Court and held in default of $3,000 bail to answer a charge of grand larceny. The complainant was Mrs. Charlice Walker, who accused him of entering her flat, 124 East Eighty-third Street, and stealing jewelry valued at $150.

Peter Latham of the Queen's Club, London, won the racquet championship of the world and a stake of $10,000 yesterday by defeating George Standing of New York at the Racquet and Tennis Club, in West Forty-third Street, by a score of 4 games to 3. The first, fourth, sixth, and seventh games were those in which the London player was winner.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 27. -- Vice President Warner of the Missouri Pacific said in regarl to a report that there was to be a general advance of wages and salaries, that would affect all employes of the Missouri Pacific system:

" The Irish National Alliance" is now circulating petitions for signatures, intended to secure the defeat by the Senate of any general arbitration treaty that may be proposed by the President of the United States. The petitions will be sent throughout the Union to the "councils" of the alliance, to the "Ancient Order of Hibernians," and to other Irish societies.

Dash and vigor and many brilliant feats of horsemanship were the features of the cross-country run held yesterday morning at Hempstead by the members of the Meadow Brook Hunt Club along the north shore of Long Island. The run was the longest of the season and was over a fourteen-mile course of some of the stiffest hunting country to be found on this side of the water.
PARIS, Nov. 17. -- The wintry season begins always for Parisian fashion with a return of the preceding Spring's latest creations, as well as the introduction of absolute nouveautes.

The hut consisted of a few feet of earth inclosed by a wall of stone, six feet thick, six feet high, and covered by a foot of earth laid upon boards. Inside a partition divided the space into two rooms, the one nearest the door for cows, dogs, and kettles, and the other, with the earth for a carpet, for cooking, eating, sleeping, and general living apartment.

NEWPORT, Nov. 27. -- It will be a source of disappointment to many of the cottagers when they return to their homes here next Summer and learn that the fire station in the southern part of the city is not erected, although it is nearly a year and a half since the taxpayers voted a certain amount for its construction.

In one of the most interesting and roughest football games ever played in this vicinity between scholastic teams, the Brooklyn High School team defeated the English High School eleven of Boston by a score of 10 to 6 at Eastern Park yesterday afternoon. Both schools had a clean record of victories for the season, and Brooklyn High School's victory gives them the right to the title of National champions.

In classic Greece the puppet show was a popular diversion. The peripatetic showman, known as a nevropaste, journeyed from town to town, carrying his wooden figures in a box under his arm, and with his booth strapped to his back, quite like his modern descendant who frequents English country fairs.

It has often been said that a movement which to some degree represents a man's life work is his most fitting tombstone. Seldom, however, has an attempt been made to carry out this idea with such realistic exactness as was done a few years ago in Oak Grove Cemetery, at Fall River, Mass., by one of the large mill owners of that city.

Mrs. P. of the east side is a dear old grandmother, who delights in a cup of coffee and a chat at the table of a neighbor. She spends her leisure time, of which she has an abundance, in going about and doing good. Some there are who look askance at this estimable old woman and speak unkindly of her, but these persons evidently do not understand her.

ROME, Nov. 7. -- Attention is periodically drawn to the Vatican by rumors of a new "creation" of Cardinals. The Consistory which was spoken of as likely to occur in this month of November is regarded as postponed till Christmas.

The report of the Board of Health for 1897 on the action of the Health Department in relation to pulmonary tuberculosis, and the scope and purpose of the measures recently adopted for its prevention, has just been published.

" Since the introduction into China of American flour it has continued to grow in popularity," says T.R. Jernigan, United States Consul General at Shanghai, in a report. "The quality and the color both commend it in the markets, and, comparatively, it is easily superior to any flour imported from other lands.

In a cavalry troop there generally grows up between each horse and his rider a strong bond of sympathy and friendship. Soldiers in the cavalry service are in most cases stationed at remote Western posts, where, far from home and friends, and as a rule unmarried, they are necessarily very limited in their social pleasures and amusements.
KOKOMO, Ind., Nov. 27. -- The Rev. John G. Brady of Alaska has written a letter from Sitka, under date of Nov. 7, to a friend in this city, in which he says:

Dr. Hale served the ministry in Washington for a year or two, and from 1846 to 1856 in Worcester, where he is affectionately remembered in many ways, and particularly as founder of its public library; and he was commissioned pastor of the South Congregation Church forty-one years ago, where he is marrying and baptizing the children and grandchildren of his early parishioners.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 27. -- Golf has held full sway in Lakewood this week. The first three days were full of preparation for the Fall tournament of the golf club, which on Thursday, Friday, and Saturday brought together the largest number of prominent golfers that have ever attended a tournament in this country.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- The officials here know nothing of any intention on the part of our Government to advise Hawaii to pay immediately to Japan without waiting for arbitration the sum of money claimed by Japan on account of the turning back from Honolulu of Japanese laborers last Spring.

HONOLULU, Nov. 20, via San Francisco, Nov. 27. -- Advices received to-day from Japan are that no progress has been made in the negotiations about the emigrant affair, owing to the fact that Hawaii sticks invariably to the policy of procrastination, in the hope, it is claimed, of transferring the responsibility of paying the compensation to the United States, but not affecting the proposed annexation.

LONDON, Nov. 27. -- It is claimed that the electric railroads at Cairo, Egypt, are beating those of Brooklyn in the record of numbers of people killed. The Egyptian roads have been running a little over a year, and 140 people were killed or injured by their cars during the first twelve months.

LONDON, Nov. 27. -- The warning of Count Goluchowski, the Austro-Hungarian Minister for Foreign Affairs, against "transatlantic competition" is much discussed, and is variously regarded as menacing to America and as indorsing Emperor William's view of the "yellow peril," or, as a warning against a British Zollverein.
MADRID, Nov. 27. -- The Official Gazette this morning publishes the royal decrees granting autonomy to Cuba and Puerto Rico.

Allerton, 2:09 1/4, who holds the fastest record of any living stallion driven to a high wheel, and who stands at the head of the list of all stallions, is a very fashionable sire in light-harness horse circles, and the fact that a number of his get were to be sold at the Fasig Co. combination sale of trotters and pacers at Madison Square Garden yesterday brought out a large crowd of well-known horsemen.

In the report of the Commissioner of Pensions one of the tables gives a complete list of the names of all the surviving widows and daughters of Revolutionary soldiers on the pension rolls June 30, 1897, with their ages and places of residence at that date, and the names of the soldiers with whom they were connected by marriage or birth.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 27. -- A delegation of native Hawaiians, headed by David Kalauskalani, a native lawyer, arrived here yesterday on their way to Washington, where they are going to protest against annexation. They are evidently little acquainted with the cost of lobbying, inasmuch as they are only provided with $1,000 to pay expenses.

The November Cup was the magnet that attracted nearly 100 devotees of the sport of trap shooting to the Bay Ridge trap-shooting grounds of the Crescent Athletic Club yesterday afternoon. There were but five shooters that faced the traps in this event. Notwithstanding the high wind that prevailed, the scores were exceptionally good.

There probably will be some important questions brought up and decided before the schedule of intercollegiate boat races for 1898 is completed. Now that there is a possibility that Yale may invite Cornell to row with her again there is a discussion going on as to what Cornell will do with the challenge. It will all depend upon the terms of the challenge.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 27. -- As the outcome of a quarrel between two Japanese employed on the revenue cutter Rush, Imai, a boy, was shot and killed this morning and the ship's steward, Charley Wishimura, is in jail at San Rafael, charged with murder. The encounter occurred while the cutter was lying in the bay near Sausalito.

TRENTON, Nov. 27. -- There is a possibility that Gov. Griggs may reconsider his decision in connection with the coming United States Senatorial contest and re-enter the fight. The Republican newspaper which generally speaks for the Governor says in a recent issue:

VIRTUOSOS and yet more virtuosos. Let us go forth to hear reeds shaken by the wind of a singer's breath, strings smitten into scintillant vibration by the blows of horsehair, and yet other strings jangled by the pounding of hammers operated by ivory keys.

HARTFORD, Nov. 27. -- Warden Woodbridge to-day received a telegram from the Italian Consulate in New York in relation to Fuda's confession. The Consul intimated that it is important that Impossino's counsel place Fuda's confession in legal shape for use before the Board of Pardons and for a new trial. He stated that he would write to the Board of Pardons, the Governor, and the District Attorney.
A contest for the billiard championship of the world will begin at the Madison Square Garden Concert Hall to-morrow night. Five players will enter.

The Rev. Alexander W. Bostwick, the new curate of Calvary Parish, the Rev. Dr. J. Lewis Parks, rector, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street, is only twenty-six years old. He was born in this city, but was educated in the public schools of Rochester. He received his university training at Hobart, from which he was graduated with honor in Anglo-Saxon, French, and English literature in 1892.

Two Cuban patriots, Dr. Frank Agramonte and Thomas J. Sainz, arrived in this city yesterday on the steamer Santiago. Both are young men, and American citizens. They have been imprisoned in the Spanish fortress at Santiago, Cuba, for more than two and a half years.

From the standpoint of practical common sense as well as of public spirit, citizens of the Greater New York are likely to take note of the fact that any substantial improvement in any particular section of the enlarged municipality will be of equal importance to all of the people who are interested in the development and prosperity of the American metropolis.

BARON THEODOR V0N HOLLEBEN, the new German Ambassador, has won for himself two distinct reputations, one as a diplomat and one as a duelist. The latter reputation, he says, is undeserved -- and he can show his scars to prove it.

The game of Mancala may be said to be the national game of Africa. It is most closely associated with that continent. It is found among all the tribes, and is an evidence of the essential unity that underlies all the African races. Among the abyssinians it is played by all classes, from the King to the peasant.

WICHITA, Kan., Nov. 27. -- The circumstances attending the death of O.E. Shoemaker at Coffeyville yesterday were both sad and romantic. Three hours before his death, when all hope of recovery had gone, he was married to Miss Eva Hawley, a Wichita belle.

For months previous to election the friendship existing between John Costello, tall and raw-boned, of 127 Allen Street, and John Steitz, short and fat, a saloon keeper, of 110 Bowery, was the wonder and admiration of the Bowery. But the campaign and election changed all that. For as Nov. 2 drew near, Costello threw all his Sligo ardor in the cause of Tammany, while Steitz, with Teutonic decision, declared unalterably for another side.

Dr. Harrison Allen, Emeritus Professor of Comparative Anatomy in the Medical Department of the University of Pennsylvania, died suddenly at his residence in Philadelphia a few days ago. His malady is supposed to have been heart failure, as he had been weak physically since he was operated on for appendicitis about a year ago.

Spain herself has demonstrated that she is powerless either to conciliate Cuba or to conquer it. Her sovereignty over it is, in my humble judgment, now extinct "for all purposes of its rightful existence," and the "hopeless struggle for its re-establishment has degenerated into a strife which means nothing more than the useless sacrifice of human life and the utter destruction of the very subject matter of the conflict itself."

The one hundred and fourteenth anniversary of the formal exacuation of New York by the British Army, as a relinquishment of territorial sovereignty, gives the occasion for the Daughters of the Revolution of the State of New York to enjoy a feast and honor their grandsires. The celebration festivities will be held at 1 o'clock on Friday next, at the Hotel Castleton, Brighton Heights.

IT is a little more than twenty-one years since Gen. Custer, full of hope and in the prime of life, marched from Fort Lincoln to the Rosebud River in search of the Sioux Indians, who were then on the warpath. Within a week the flower of his regiment -- the Seventh Cavalry -- lay with their commander dead along the bluffs overlooking the Little Big Horn Valley.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- Two predictions have been made here regarding the Congress that is to meet on Monday, December 6. The first, ventured by a member of the Senate, who has had much experience, is that the session will be long, that it will attempt many things, dawdle with all, and accomplish little.

In the estimation of coin collectors the most valuable of all the American coins today is the perfect silver dollar of 1804. That particular coin is worth whatever an enthusiastic collector is willing to pay for it. The highest auction price is $1,000, and there is a record of $1,200 having been paid for one at private sale. Only thirteen of them are known to exist and each has a record of ownership.

Alexandra Viarda, who will make her first appearance in this country at the Fifth Avenue Theatre to-morrow night, is spoken of as an actress of substantial fame on the German-speaking stage. She crossed the Atlantic Ocean, however, in advance of her foreign repute; but she will doubtless have a welcome not the less cordial for that reason.

From Monday, Dec. 6, to Saturday, Dec. 18, a Cuban fair will be held in the "Arcade," Tillary and Washington Streets, Brooklyn. The proceeds will be devoted to relieving the destitute in Cuba. Several Brooklyn cycle clubs will be in charge of booths, where interesting contests will be held. There will be a concert by noted solo performers during each afternoon and evening.

A team of horses attached to a heavy truck, belonging to Austin, Nichols Co., being left yesterday afternoon at the pier at the foot of Franklin Street, ran away, and at the corner of West and North Moore Streets, knocked down Martin Clary, a longeshoreman, forty years old, of 222 West Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- Surgeon General Wyman has received a dark report from Havana to show the conditions in that city during the week. There were 609 deaths in the city and in Regla, a suburb on the harbor.

Two French scientists, MM. Roux and Balthazard, have applied the X rays to a man after the ingestion of a certain quantity of bismuth. Experiments made successively on frogs and dogs have clearly shown the form of the stomach at the time of digestion. They have seen that the stomach of man, like that of the frog and dog, presents two distinct parts.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 27 -- The Rothschilds, through the San Francisco house of Liebes Co., are about to enter the Alaska trade.

H. Willard Griffiths, lessee of a row of flat houses in Forty-third Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, was summoned to appear before Police Magistrate Kudlich yesterday in the West Side Court, on a charge brought by Capt. Schmittberger's detectives that he had knowingly sublet apartments to disorderly and immoral persons.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 27. -- Milton H. Smith, President of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad, to-day gave out an interview, in which he vehemently opposes the pending railroad legislation before Congress. Before leaving the city he was seen and asked to give to the public a statement of his position in regard to the proposed measures.

Commissioner E. Ellery Anderson of the Board of Education has written a letter to Corporation Counsel Francis M. Scott, in reply to Mr. Scott's letter to him of Nov. 22, in which the former's request for certification of the justice of bills presented by Judge Allison to the board was denied. Among other things, in a communication filling seven typewritten pages, Mr. Anderson says:
LONDON, Nov. 27. -- "Tod" Sloane, the American jockey, finished first in four events at the Manchester November meeting to-day and was second in a fifth. There were six in which he took part.

ROCHESTER, Nov. 26. -- Since the recent investigations of the Deep Waterways Commission appointed by the Government to report on the best route for the proposed ship canal, much interest has been aroused in the subject throughout Western New York.

A Dresden paper, the Weldmann, statens that among the Hottentots (Hottentotent) the kangaroos (Beutelratte) are found the great numbers. Many of them wander over the country, free and unmolested; others less fortunate are taken by hunters and put into cages, (Kotter,) provided with covers (Lattengitter) to keep out the pain.

In view of the interruption occasioned by Thanksgiving, the realty market has certainly made a creditable showing during the last week. The number of sales and the amounts involved compare favorably with those of recent weeks, while the general character of the dealing shows, if anything, an improvement.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Nov. 27. -- The typhoon which swept over the Philippine Islands on Oct. 6 was the cause of one of the worst disasters reported from the Southern Ocean in many years. Thousands of lives were lost, among those who perished being many Europeans, and the damage to property was something appalling.

FREEPORT, L.I., Nov. 27. -- Justice Wilbur F. Tredwell has come out against football, and he says that if he has his way there will be no more games in Freeport. The Justice attended on Thanksgiving Day the game between the Monarch Club of this village and the Rockville Centre Football Club.
Following is Gov. Robert L. Taylor's speech at the Harris memorial exercises in Memphis last night:

In the sixth publication of the American Jewish Historical Society, just issued, David Sulzberger of Philadelphia has an article headed "Growth of the Jewish Population in the United States," in which he presents some interesting matter relating to that subject.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 28. -- The Detroit Chamber of Commerce Building will be sold next Wednesday under the hammer in default of payment of a first mortgage of $430,000 and interest held by the New York Life Insurance Company.

After being in a fight with a policeman James Kennedy, twenty-three years old, of 510 West Twenty-ninth Street, died last night in Roosevelt Hospital. The policeman, who admits that he used his club to defend himself, is Henry Woodley of the West Thirty-seventh Street Station.

A lecture under the auspices of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences was delivered at the assembly rooms on Montague Street, Brooklyn, recently, by Lieut. Commander Albion V. Wadham, United States Navy. It was illustrated with stereoptican views of warships and guns. The subject was "The Construction of Modern Men-of-War and Their Guns."

The world is still waiting to know whether the gallant Gordon piper of Dargai is named Milne or Findlater. Meanwhile, it has occurred to a Scottish correspondent to delve into military records in search of parallel instances of courage, and he has found several. One of these instances -- which occurred during the Peninsular wars -- was almost identical with that of the capture of the Dargai Ridge.

LONDON, Nov. 28. -- The close of the fiat racing season sees Mornington Cannon at the head of the winning jockeys, with 145 successes. Loates is second and Wood third. The papers comment at length upon the remarkable success of "Tod" Sloane, the American jockey, during the present month in England.

The course of the Twenty-ninth District members of the Republican County Committee in deciding to undertake a purging of the district rolls is by the anti-machine Republicans, especially in view of Chairman Quigg's announcement last night, as a straw which shows that the political wind is blowing their way.

WHITEHALL, N.Y., Nov. 28. -- Frank Lajoy, who killed William Jackson, a Deputy Sheriff, near Paradox Lake, Sept. 17, and was afterward indicted for murder in the first degree, escaped from the County Jail at Elizabethtown last night. Harry Harris, indicted for burglary and grand larceny, also escaped. Lajoy was one of three brothers whom Jackson was attempting to arrest for violation of the game laws when he lost his life.

The Rev. G.H. Denison delivered an object lesson sermon last evening to a large audience in the Church of the Sea and Land, on Henry Street, of which he is pastor. The subject of his sermon was "The Causes That Keep Men Down."
The Iron Age says of a tin-plate plant which is probably the largest in the country:

A rosy cheeked youth of fourteen years, in well-fitting knickerbockers and with a glib tongue, has for the past two weeks been working a clever swindling game on the unsuspecting residents of Harlem. Just how much money he has secured by his dishonest method is not known.
The only way to stop the greedy rush for pensions is to publish the pension lists.
TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 28. -- At the services in the First Baptist Church to-day, the Rev. Maurice Penfield Files appointed six of the handsomest girls in the congregation to act as ushers.

VIENNA, Nov. 28. -- The members of the Austrian Ministry to-day tendered their resignations to Emperor Francis Joseph, who accepted them and intrusted Baron Gautsch, who holds the portfolio of Public Instruction in the retiring Ministry, with the task of forming a new Cabinet.

Dr. Ernest Roach has lost a diamond ring which he values at $250, and on Saturday he accused Louisa Grant of having Stolen it. She was arrested on Saturday at midnight on the complaint of Dr. Roach. Patrolman T.A. Kelly was passing the residence of Dr. Roach at 407 Lexington Avenue when he saw the doctor and his wife quarreling with a stout, well-dressed woman wearing a heavy veil and much jewelry.

A train was hastening down from Harlem on the Sixth Avenue Elevated Railroad, and every car except the rear one was completely filled, mostly with women. It was in the middle of the forenoon, and the female passengers were classified by the loquacious trainman as "them shoppers." This same trainman confidentially remarked to several men who were standing on the platform of the rear car that he was tired.

I had a talk yesterday with an executive of one of the leading electrical manufacturing companies. He informed me that the affairs of his corporation are highly satisfactory, business good, the demand steadily increasing, and prices fair. He says that net earnings will show a material increase over last year. This is about the tenor of reports from the electrical manufacturing field.

Wearing a turban of yellow, signifying knowledge, and a robe of purple, portraying purity and activity, Virchand Gandhi of Bombay delivered a lecture on the religions of India before a small but deeply interested audience in the New Century Hall, 509 Fifth Avenue, yesterday morning.

Some of the retail druggists in this city say that the character of their business is changing rapidly and radically. They contend that the wholesale development of specific remedies has practically killed the prescription business, and that the competition of the large department stores in perfumeries, toilet articles, and proprietary specifics has cut down their margin for profit so closely that there is absolutely none left for breakage or waste.

We reviewed last week the various projects for increasing transit facilities from Manhattan Island across the East River, and showed that in the near future several improved avenues of communication will almost certainly be opened. When we turn to schemes for crossing the North or Hudson River, however, we find no existing means of communication save by boats, and no immediate prospect, to say the least, of the construction of either bridges or tunnels.
SEATTLE, Washington, Nov. 28. -- In an interview Gov. John G. Brady of Alaska said:

The Rev. Dr. Minot J. Savage filled the pulpit yesterday morning in the Church of the Messiah, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, and preached a sermon on "What Do You Give In Place of What You Take Away?" "This question," said the preacher, "Is proposed to Unitarians over and over again.

PROVIDENCE, Nov. 28. -- The barge J.S. Silliman, loaded with 470 tons of coal, for Fall River, was run into by the schooner Lottie. Capt. John Brown, from Thomaston to New York, with a cargo of 3,000 barrels of lime, just before midnight Saturday night, and both craft sank almost immediately.

MANCHESTER, Nov. 28. -- The public reports for last week were quieter, but probably business was really larger than before. Large Eastern cloth orders, for both yarns and goods, were placed, and also orders for some lines of shortings, at very low prices.

A wiser man than the ornithologist says "a word to the wise is sufficient." But the wise man of old did not have ornithologists and an Andubon Society to deal with. The writer signed "One of the Founders of the Original Audubon Society" in today's TIMES states as facts some very important points in this bird discussion.
If autonomy for Cubans means anything it is the power to rule themselves in matters of home concern. The Sagasta plan certainly does not secure this.

School Director Giles H. Gray addressed the classes in civil government at the Central Grammar School yesterday afternoon on civil government and the duties each citizen owed to the Government under which he lives.

Now, gentlemen, your are here no doubt not entirely or mainly to deal with foreign affairs, and I owe you some apology now for having dealt with them so much. [Cries of "No."] But there are other things to interest us besides them; and they are things which concern our own daily and hourly well-being. [Hear, hear.] We live in the largest city of the world.

It is the fate of reformers to be misused. Mr. Mark Twain is no exception. He set out to reform the German language, and he went to Vienna and announced his purpose in public. He announced it in German, too, and presented his own little speech as a sample of what the language would be when he had completed his self-imposed task.

The great activity in golf for the present season is over, but that does not mean that interest in the popular sport will diminish, for as long as the Winter remains open there will be club contests and handicap matches on near-by links, and talk regarding the coming annual meeting in February of the United States Golf Association will soon be heard in golfing circles.

The naive and pathetic query made in your issue of Nov. 27 by "One of the Founders of the Original Audubon Society" leaves no one in doubt as to the reply. "If," we are despairingly asked, "the women of the country will not respect and obey the laws of their own States, could we reasonably expect them to obey a National law?" we promptly argue that, reasonably or unreasonably the men could not.

In Ward No. 16 of Bellevue Hospital is a woman of sixty years, half blind and with one arm almost useless, who tells a story of a life astonishing in the contrasts it affords -- of a youth and middle age passed among persons of wealth and refinement in the ranks of the European nobility, and an old age of poverty and distress in a Bowery lodging house.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28. -- The Rev. Dr. John Brooks of Massachusetts, a brother of the late Bishop Phillips Brooks, preached at Holy Trinity Episcopal Church to-day.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 28. -- Louis Betuch of this place learned last night that his eighteen-year-old daughter Josephine had been the wife of Antonio Rose, a local barber, since Nov. 18, and says that he will punish his new son-in-law if it takes him lifetime.

La reine s'ennuie. It is said that all the younger royalties of Europe are learning or have already learned to bicycle, but there is one melancholy exception. This is the young Queen of Holland, who, during her last sojourn at Vienna, was seized with the longing called Velomania. An expensive and faultless machine was purchased, and she took it back with her to Holland.

Dr. Marion S. Miller, who said he represented the West Side Citizens' Association, called yesterday on the Central Labor Union, and urged it to co-operate with the association in its fight against a four-track trolley system in Amsterdam Avenue.

The Rev. Dr. W.H.P. Faunce, one of the Board of Ministers who preach to the students of Harvard University, and who returned last week after his Fall term of ministry at the institution, preached yesterday on the subject of "Religious Life at Harvard University," at the Fifth Avenue Baptist Church, in West Forty-sixth Street, of which he is the pastor.
CAMDEN, Nov. 28. -- A mob, bent on punishing a prisoner, had a battle this afternoon with two policemen on the edge of the South Camden swamp.

LONDON, Nov. 28. -- At the Church of St. Margaret, Westminster, yesterday Baron Mount Stephen was married to Miss Gian Tufnell, daughter of the late Commander R.G. Tufnell, R.N. The ceremony had been fixed for an earlier date, but was postponed on account of the death of the Duchess of Teck. Four children acted as bridesmaids.

We regret to learn that Sir Henry Doulton died on Wednesday evening at his house in Queen's-gate-gardens, after a few days' illness. He was born in Vauxhall in 1820, the second son of Mr. John Doulton, a Lambeth potter, whose business he joined on leaving University College School.
