WASHINGTON, Nov. 28. -- A startling story of the killing of two Washingtonians and the mutilation of their bodies by the natives of the Congo Free State has just been received here in a letter to Leo Harman of 1,723 Ninth Street, Northwest. The men were members of a party who during November and December, 1896, and January, 1895, went from this city to enlist in the Belgian army for service in the Congo State.

The Bureau of American Republics may not be chargeable with all the sins its accusers allege against it, but its "commercial directory" enterprise has too much the color of a private speculation carried on with the aid and authority of the Government of the United States.

PEQUAMING, Mich., Nov. 28. -- The steamer H.E. Runnelis has been ashore for two and a half days on the end of Point Abbaye, and to-day the first news reached this port, when the mate and one sailor arrived to get help for the steamer.

PARIS, Nov. 28. -- The Figaro has caused a sensation to-day in connection with the Dreyfus affair by publishing several letters purporting to be written by Count Ferdinand Walsin Esterhazy, who has been accused by M. Scheurer-Kestner, one of the Vice Presidents of the Senate, of being the author of the unsigned letter which led to the condemnation of Dreyfus.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28. -- Thirteen Chinamen, born on American soil, inserted advertisements in the newspapers two weeks ago calling a mass meeting to take steps to secure the franchise for Chinese. The meeting was held in Central Music Hall last evening. The hall was fairly well filled with men and women. Before the meeting came to a close it looked as if there was going to be trouble.

The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Eaton continued his series of lectures on "Morality in Fiction" last night in St. Stephen's Church, in West Forty-sixth Street, where the congregation of the Church of the Divine Paternity temporarily worships. Dr. Eaton's topic was "Peter Sterling; or The Saloon in Politics, and Government by the Average Man."

In an article entitled "For Bird Protection,'' in your issue of Nov. 26, signed "A.B.C.," attention is called again "to the proved experiment of the Tunis naturalist, that heron farming can be carried on precisely as ostrich farming is done, to supply the market with the feathers."

After holding several conferences with Senator Platt, the latest one at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon, County Chairman L. E. Quigg announced that the Republican organization was willing "to have the principle of majority rule tested under the present enrollment or under an entirely new enrollment.''

A decided sensation was caused in Plymouth Church last night when Dr. Lyman Abbott, during the second sermon in his course on the life and teachings of Paul, made a point which was taken as an allusion to the attacks upon him for alleged heresy. He said:

There is likely to be in Wall Street this week more guessing about what Congress will do than consideration given to any other subject. For more than a month past stock market values have been under pressure on account of troublesome things to develop as soon as Congress convenes; and on an average prices have been materially reduced.

ATLATA, Nov. 28. -- The Georgia Legislature, which has done several things during the past few weeks to make itself conspicuous, yesterday concluded nearly a whole week of debate on a question affecting the rights of veterans of the Federal army in Georgia.

Col. WARING announced on Saturday evening that he should not remain in charge of the Street Cleaning Department after Jan. 1. He also predicted that there would be no lowering of the standard he has established in the department. We trust that his prediction will be verified, though the only complete assurance on that point would be his retention.

In the absence of Prof. Felix Adler, who lectured in Philadelphia, M.M. Mangassarian, lecturer of the Society for Ethical Culture of Chicago, occupied the platform at Carnegie Music Hall yesterday, and spoke on "Theosophy, Spiritualism, and Christian Science" to a large audience.
One brief passage in the report on pulmonary tuberculosis presented to Mayor STRONG on Saturday gives evidence that the Board of Health has approached this grave problem in the proper spirit:

Charles F. Weineble, janitor of the Harlem Republican Club at 139 West One hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, found a metallic tube, three and a half or four inches long, on the sidewalk grating under the clubhouse stoop, about 1 o'clock on Saturday afternoon, and on examination it was found to resemble a dynamite bomb.

LONDON, Nov. 29. -- The latest reports from various points along the coast show that the gale which swept English waters yesterday and last night, and which had not abated its fury up to noon to-day, was one of the worst storms of recent years.

BOSTON, Nov. 29. -- The astronomers at Percival Lowell's observatory at Flagstaff, Arizona, have been very busy this year. Dr. J.J. See, who is largely responsible for the important discoveries made there, is in this city all with all his records, for the purpose of superintending their publication.

A peculiar accident occurred at the corner of Eighty-fifth Street and Madison Avenue yesterday morning, resulting in the killing of a car horse and causing intense excitement among street-car passengers and spectators.
Lalor Beringer have sold for Leopold' Rosenberg to John Downey $480,000 the ten-story business buildings 733 and 735 Broadway, opposite Astor Place, 54 by 100.

The Vienna correspondent of The London Times neglects to say who told him that Count GOLUCHOWSKI'S Pan-European League would be antagonized by a Pan-American League to do something for and with silver. It is therefore, we trust, not unparliamentary to say that the "exceptionally competent and well informed friend" knows too much that is not so.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Nov. 29. -- Lexington people are put out over the change in the selection of a young woman to christen the battleship Kentucky. A Lexington dispatch says that it has been understood ever since the plans for the ship were accepted that Miss Harriet B. Richardson, a society girl of that place, was to have the honor of christening the ship.

PENACOOK, N.H., Nov. 29. -- George A. Viehmann of New Brunswick, N.J., was married here this evening to Mrs. Mary Abbott Clarke, at the home of the bride. Prof. Louis A. Voorhees of New Brunswick acted as best man.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment met yesterday in the Mayor's office. Authority was given to Commissioner Waring to construct a new dump at Pier 43, East River, the present dump having been condemned as unsafe.

The cable dispatches which recently appeared in the daily papers indicating the great interest felt throughout Europe upon a subject of international interest have naturally awakened great attention, not to say excitement, in this city and throughout the land. It is a well-known fact that the demands of modern life have caused a strain which seems to shorten life and undermine health universally.

At the adjourned meeting held yesterday the Board of Education amended its original estimate of $6,852,390.73 needed for the maintenance of the public schools in 1898, reported Sept. 15, by adding $134,383, making a total of $6,986,773.73 for the Board of Estimate and Apportionment to consider at its meeting Dec. 2.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29. -- Prof. John Cohn of the German department of Northwestern University has completed the fund which makes it possible for the university to come into possession of the most valuable collection of German writings possessed by any of the colleges of the United States. On Saturday the last money was subscribed, and within a week the amount will be collected.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- Senor Dupuy de Lome, the Spanish Minister, had an interview with Assistant Secretary Day to-day. It is the plan of Capt. Gen. Blanco to take steps for the immediate execution of the reform schemes of the Madrid Government, and to do this legally a provisional arrangement will be made.
London, Nov. 29. -- The Rev. Prof. James Legge, D.D., LL. D., is dead.

A decision adverse to the present policy of the Treasury Department regarding importations of tobacco was handed down by the Board of United Sates General Appraisers yesterday. The opinion was written by ex-Judge Somerville, and it directly affects every tobacco importer in this country by determining that the commercial bale of leaf tobacco is the unit for dutiable purposes.

Policeman Henry M. Woodley, who used his club with fatal effect on James Kennedy of 510 West Twenty-ninth Street on Sunday, was arraigned before Magistrate Kudlich in the West Side Police Court yesterday on the charge of homicide preferred against him by Capt. Stephen M. Brown of the West Thirty-seventh Street Station.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- Justice Harlan handed down the opinion of the United States Supreme Court to-day in the case of J.J. Douglas, plaintiff in error, against the Commonwealth of Kentucky, holding the franchise of the Frankfort Lottery to be invalid. The case was brought to this court by Douglas on allegations of error in the decision of the Kentucky Court of Appeals, which was adverse to him.
LONDON, Nov. 29. -- The Lord Chief Justice is at present hearing an interesting case, which is attracting the attention of clubmen and members of the aristocracy here.

It is rarely that the spectators at horse sales in this city see a wealthy man who has horses to sell go into the sales ring to help sell them, but when the man is many times a millionaire and one of the best-known citizens o fhis community, and, furthermore, almost fourscore years old, there is an added interest in the spectacle.

PEKIN, Nov. 29. -- Inquiries made here in Chineses official circles confirm the statements contained in dispatches from Shanghai, giving the substance of the demands made by Baron von Heyking, the German Minister to China, as a result of the murder recently of German missionaries and the destruction of German mission property.
The trial of Martin Thorn in Long Island City continued to develop surprises yesterday. Thorn was on the stand several hours, and made a favorable impression on the spectators.

FINDLAY, Ohio, Nov. 29. -- A meeting was held this afternoon in the directors' room of the Findlay, Fort Wayne and Western Railroad for the purpose of ratifying the plans already determined upon for extending that road both east and west and forming one of the most important trunk lines in the country.

Mr. Charles Sonnenberg, formerly of this city, now a resident of Vryburg, in British Bechuanaland, South Africa, and a member of the Cape Parliament, is on a visit to this country for the first time in thirty-five years.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- While this Government has not been advised officially of the intention of the French Government to denounce the treaty of trade and commerce which has existed between the United States and Tunis for a century, some action in that direction is looked for, in view of the fact that the subject for a long time has been under negotiation between the State Department and the French Embassy.

BOSTON, Nov. 29. -- At a meeting of the Directors of the West End Street Railway Company this morning a committee of the Boston Elevated Railway Company appeared with a proposition for a new lease of the former corporation, under terms which, it is thought, will meet the objections made by the Railroad Commission to the former lease, which was disapproved by that body.

Republicans of the Twenty-first Assembly District to the number of 500 responded to a call issued by James S. Barcus for a mass meeting at Lion Park last night, "to discuss such changes in the Republican organization as will make possible the support of the entire Republican Party for Republican nominees."

Through E.J. Swords, General Eastern Agent of the Burlington route, it was announced yesterday that a reduction of $4.50 in the regular rate from St. Paul to Chicago would go into effect on Dec. 1. According to this statement the rate between those points would be $7 instead of $11.50.

Consolidation of the two Protestant Episcopal congregations of the Church of the Redeemer and the Church of the Holy Nativity has at last been effected, and appeal was made yesterday for Bishop Potter to decide which of the two rectors of the old parishes shall become rector of the consolidated one.

The statement made insistently by organization Republicans that Senator Platt has seventy-eight members of the next Assembly pledged to his support, thus assuring his control of that body, is still vigorously denied by the independent memberselect from this city.

The Holland-America Line steamship Veendam, from Rotterdam and Plymouth, which arrived yesterday, brought the passengers of her disabled sister ship Maasdam, which, when 500 miles out from Plymouth, bound for New York, was forced to return owing to the disablement of her forward cylinders.

Richard Croker, Judge Van Wyck, and all the other Tammany leaders who have been sojourning at Lakewood were expected to return to this city yesterday. The Mayor-elect came, accompanied by a number of lesser lights, but Mr. Croker was not with them, and the information they brought was that Mr. Croker would be at the New Jersey resort for a week or ten days longer.

A curious contribution to the statistics of sociology has been secured by the Committee on Statistics of the Charity Organization Society of this city. This committee has carefully followed and analyzed the records of 500 families which first applied for assistance in 1890, and gives the result in an elaborate report; showing the real causes of poverty, the alleged causes, the sizes of families, nationalities, personal characteristics, results of treatment, and other details.

The struggle in the Reichsrath has been partly pathetic and partly ridiculous, but wholly injurious to the empire which it has vexed. For it is not less injurious to a great nation to exhibit itself to mankind as an object of compassion than as an object of ridicule. The end of the riot which had become chronic was, unfortunately, the success of the rioters.

The old remark about what wonders good society and more water would work in Texas and in Hades might be easily modified to fit the present conditions on the Yukon. All Dawson City needs is better transportation facilities. There is no reasonable doubt that they will be provided during the coming season.

-- Sailors on English vessels are better protected by law than those who sail the seas under the Stars and Stripes, but for all that they are by no means safe from ill treatment on the part of owners and Captains who have more regard for economy than for the health and lives of their men.
SEATTLE, Washington, Nov. 29. -- Thomas Magee of San Francisco, who arrived in this city on the steamer City of Seattle from Dawson City, in giving an account of his trip over the Dalton trail, said:

At the conference between cycle organization delegates and the Executive Committee of the Board of Trustees of the New York and Brooklyn Bridge, held at the bridge offices, at Washington and Nassau Streets, Brooklyn, yesterday, relative to a plan for a wheelway over the bridge, the suggestion that met with the most favor was one to which hitherto little attention has been paid.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- Chief Justice Fuller handed down an opinion in the United States Supreme Court to-day dealing with the revolution in Venezuela in 1892, when the forces of Crespo were arrayed against those of Palacio. The case was that of George F. Underhill against Gen. Jose Manuel Hernandez, a follower of Crespo.

" Waldmeister" is the name of a flower sometimes called "woodruff" in English. It is the herb which the Germans use in making May wine, which as every one knows, is like the famous palm tree wine mentioned in Xenophon's "Anabasis" -"exceedingly headachy." But before it is headachy it is prone to stir up the satyr in man and the bacchante in woman, and after that there is more or less trouble.

ROME, Nov. 29. -- Archbishop Keane, former rector of the Catholic University at Washington, was received by the Pope to-day. His Holiness congratulated the Archbishop upon the abnegation with which, in a letter to the Pope, he had renounced his claim to be included in the list of candidates for appointment to the Archbishopric of New Orleans.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- Capt. Wright and Lieut. Cavenaugh, Ninth Cavalry, who commanded the troops in the recent Indian disturbance in Colorado, have recommended an investigation of the affair by the Interior Department. Capt. Wright secured a statement from the Indians, the substance of which is:
Was there ever a more candid man than L.E. QUIGG?

COLON, Colombia, Nov. 29. -- The seventy-sixth anniversary of the Isthmian Independence is being celebrated with great enthusiasm at Panama, here, and elsewhere. The festivities will last three days, and include military reviews, bull fights, masquerades, fire works, and theatricals.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Nov. 29. -- According to the statement of J.B. Mecklenberg and other prominent residents of Lagonda, where the large shops of Warder, Bushnell Glessner are located, there is much indignation among the residents of the place over a cut of wages, or a readjustment, as Manager Bauer terms it, which has been made since the election, in the big factory, of which Gov. Bushnell is the head.

Walter Bahan, a lawyer, had a motion to make in the General Sessions Court yesterday, and on coming into court placed his hat on the counsel table. Soon after he began to speak Court Officer Peter Seaman, noticing smoke curling out from under the hat, stole up behind Mr. Bahan, pulled his coat tail, and hoarsely whispered: "Your hat'll burn if you don't take that cigar from in under it."

The Brooklyn Board of Aldermen met yesterday and exercised the utmost generosity in the matter of granting franchises. About fifty miles of streets, extending from Queens County to Red Hook, were practically given away to an offshoot of the Nassau Electric Railroad, called the East River and Atlantic Ocean Railroad Company, and headed by Patrick H. Flynn.

PATERSON, Nov. 29. -- Through the arraignment of George Jossi, an Italian, who was before Recorder Senior here to-day, the story of how an Erie Railroad freight car had been used as a lodging house came out.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- Louis W. Pratt, Internal Revenue Collection for the Fourteenth Collection District of New York, with headquarters at Albany, has been removed peremptorily from office by order of the Secretary of the Treasury for misappropriation of funds belonging to taxpayers in his district.

The foreign dispatches indicate that the Kaiser will have trouble at the next meeting of the Reichstag. What are called in England the "bye-elections" are going against him in a manner which must be grievous to the good man. And apparently they are all going against him on the same ground -- that is to say, the ground of opposition to the military and naval "credits."

Heretofore, to our surprise, no public protest has been made against the threatened impost of a royalty sought to be imposed by the Canadian Government upon the product of the Yukon mines in Canadian territory.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29. -- A vigorous report has been made to the Interior Department by Agent Dow M. Wisdom, in charge of the Union Indian Agency, in Oklahoma, where the Five Civilized Tribes are located. In this report Mr. Wisdom says:

TRENTON, Nov. 29. -- The New Jersey Court of Errors and Appeals handed down a decision to-day affirming the conviction of Edward Clifford of murder in the first degree. Clifford is in the Hudson County Jail. He fatally shot William E. Wattson, Division Superintendent of the West Shore Railroad, in the station at Weehawken on March 5, 1896.

BERLIN, Nov. 29. -- The Berliner Tageblatt says it is reliably informed that the German Government only wants monetary reparation from Haiti for the recent arrest and imprisonment of Herr Emile Lueders by the Haitian tribunals, but that it will not brook any interference in the matter on the part of the United States.

Testimony in the suit of Edward V. Coogan against his brother, James J. Coogan, and his mother-in-law, Mrs. Sarah Lynch, whom he charges with conspiring to defraud him out of his legal and vested rights in property amounting to many thousands of dollars, was heard yesterday before Referee Ogden, at 111 Broadway.

Jim Key, the learned horse, was in New York yesterday and displayed his attainments to a number of friends of his master, Albert R. Rogers of 75 Maiden Lane, at a private exhibition in a stable at 156 East Twenty-fifth Street. Jim can do almost anything but use articulate speech, and his expressive eyes and the suggestive tosses of his finely formed head almost supply this deficiency.

Frank C. Ives, "the Napoleon of billiards," showed rare skill in last night's game in the world's championship tournament at the Madison Square Garden Concert Hall, beating Maurice Daly by nearly 250 points. A large crowd, including many women, was present.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 30. -- It is believed that by this time the $30,000,000 treasure of Cocos Island is safe on board the British cruiser Amphion. This is indicated by the news brought from Guatemala by the United States gunboat Alert. While she was in port the Amphion arrived from Esquimault and immediately sailed for Cocos Island.

We yesterday made some remarks upon the extreme improbability that reasonable Germans, in the Reichstag or elsewhere, would sustain the Kaiser's demand for an increase of the German Navy in the face of the evidence he has furnished of the reasons for which he wanted a big navy.

BOSTON, Nov. 30. -- Inquiry at the headquarters of the Humphrey Advertising Agency here disclosed the fact that the person under arrest in New York, claiming to be Irwin W. Humphreys, is not connected with the Boston firm. There is an Irving W. Humphrey, a brother of the manager, but he is now in Boston.

The anti-Platt Republicans have formally decided that under present conditions any alliance with the regular organization is out of the question. The only course left open to them, they assert, is to form a new organization and oppose the Platt-Quigg organization at the polls. This course, they say, they intend to pursue.
VIENNA, Nov. 30. -- The new Austrian Cabinet, of which Baron von Gautsch von Frankenthurn is President of the Council of Ministers, has been completed. The assignment of portfolios is as follows:

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Nov. 11. -- Thousands of Nicaraguan refugees in Costa Rica, as this letter is mailed, are reported to be arming themselves near the boundary of Nicaragua and to be threatening a revolution against President Zelaya's Government. The letter's army is concentrating near the frontier, under Gen. Hierra, a Colombian revolutionist, ready for a defensive or offensive movement against the revolutionists.

LONDON, Nov. 30. -- There is widespread interest here in what is known as the "promissory note case," now being heard before the Lord Chief Justice of England, Lord Russell of Killowen, in the Queen's Bench Division of the High Court of Justice.

BERLIN, Nov. 30. -- The last session of the present Reichstag was opened at noon today by Emperor William in person for the first time since 1894. The ceremony took place in the White Hall of the Royal Castle. His Majesty read the speech from the throne.

NEWPORT, Nov. 30. -- The members of the Town Councils of Middletown and Portsmouth, who have been petitioned to consent to the building of a trolley road between Fall River and Newport, went to Marlborough, Mass., to-day as the guests of the company which desires to build the road.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday continued the work of considering The provisional estimate of the city departments for 1898, and prepared a final estimate of the city budget as if the City of New York were going to continue as formerly.

ALBANY, Nov. 30. -- Adjt. Gen. C. Whitney Tillinghast issued an order to-day calling for a general court-martial for the trial of Corporal Charles W. Vickers of Company A, Thirteenth Regiment, and Private F.P. De Vigne, of Company D, Thirteenth Regiment and such other persons as may be ordered before it, to be held at the armory of the Seventy-first Regiment, in New York City, Dec. 8, at 8 o'clock in the evening.

LONDON, Nov. 30. -- Lady Millais, widow of Sir John Millais, the late President of the Royal Academy, is seriously ill. She is suffering from cancer of the throat, the same disease which caused the death of her husband.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- President McKinley has had his attention directed within a day or two to a very annoying state of things. From sources that he was bound to regard as trustworthy he has learned that the probable successor to Controller of the Currency Eckels has been indulging in something like dickering in patronage long before he is in possession of his office.

The third subscription concert at the Astoria Hotel last night was attended by an audience not quite so large as that at the second concert, but still large enough to make the handsome room appear to be comfortably filled, Nearly all the boxes were occupied, the Astor box being conspicuous by its emptiness.

JANESVILLE, Wis., Nov. 30. -- Miss Alice Starret, holder of the title of Countess by reason of inheritance under the laws of Denmark, and Robert C. Tetzlaff, a student in Valentine's Telegraph School, were secretly married here to-day and left on a wedding trip for Milwaukee. The bride was educated in the Convent at Le Mars, France, and came here recently.
According to Senator LODGE the first business of the Senate will be to secure the annexation of Hawaii, either by ratifying the treaty or by annexation.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 30. -- A man who registered at a local hotel as J. Barnes of New York was arrested to-day on a charge of horse stealing, but it since has been discovered that he is an extensive bogus check swindler, and papers found on him indicate he is Thomas Seymour Meyers of Bluefield, West Va.

MONTEVIDEO, Nov. 30. -- Senor Cuestas, the President, has issued a decree exiling Dr. Miguel Herrera y Obes, who was Minister of the Interior, and of Justice of the Cabinet of the late President Borda, Dr. Aguirrae and Gen. Tajes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- The Cabinet today considered the subject of sending relief to the miners in the Klondike region. President McKinley laid before his advisers a telegram from the Portland (Oregon) Chamber of Commerce, stating that there was danger of destitution and suffering in the Klondike and offering to supply the necessary food for relief if the Government would undertake its transportation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- The cruiser Marblehead has been detailed to visit Navassa to inquire into the condition of American laborers there. She will make her headquarters at Port au Prince, Haiti, and will be charged with the duty of protecting American interests in the event of aggressive action by Germany.

The big franchise grab of Monday in the Brooklyn Board of Aldermen created a storm in Brooklyn yesterday. On every hand the grab was denounced, and the Brooklyn papers were a unit in condemning it as a steal Some comments from The Eagle are given elsewhere.

The Board of Education of Whitestone, L.I., met last night and raised the salary of Principal Canant of the public school from $1,000 to $1,500. The board also raised the salaries of all the teachers in the school on a similar scale.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30. -- Not many members of Congress are here, although the regular session will open next Monday. Neither Speaker Reed nor Mr. Dingley, the floor leader of the majority, will reach Washington until Saturday or Sunday.

MAPLESVILLE, Ala., Nov. 30. -- Seven men are dead and seventeen more are not expected to live, as the result of drinking a mixture of wood alcohol and cheap whisky. The drink was bought in Selma, Ala., by "Bill" Anderson and another farmer, and brought here by them and retailed to farmers and laborers on the Mobile and Ohio extension, which is in process of construction through this place.

Whether the law authorizes a Police Magistrate to punish a person, who, having ridden in a hackney coach or cab, refuses to pay his fare, is a question that yesterday sprang into sudden prominence. Not that it had not been raised before, but this time a negative decision in a police court has alarmed many of the men whose honest earnings it appears in some measure to threaten.

Before a crowded audience at the Metropolitan Opera House last night were enacted dramatic scenes representative of various epochs of American history, which the National Society of New England Women had planned for weeks. The affair was one of unmistakable and brilliant success, and credit for its historic accuracy is due to Mrs. Charles Elliot Fitch, who wrote the text of the production and directed it in general.

One of the pleas -- you can hardly call it an argument -- used by our Brooklyn friends against provision for rapid transit in New York is that Brooklyn's share in the common assets will thus be wasted. The common assets available for any public enterprise are practically the assets of New York alone, since Brooklyn will contribute only a deficit, and such a plea smacks more of appetite than of justice.

Richard M. Montgomery Co. have sold for S.F. Jayne to Edwin R. Holden, Vice President of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad Company, for investment, the plot at the southeast corner of Riverside Drive and One Hundred and Fifth Street, 114 by 100.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30. -- The story of an unsuccessful attempt to swindle a prominent Philadelphian has just been brought to light, and investigation of the matter shows that this attempt was one of many such schemes to defraud, which have their origin in Europe and in which Americans are the intended victims.

Much solicitude has been felt during the last year or two as to the various results threatened by the erection of buildings of such excessive height as those recently constructed in the lower part of the city. We dwelt lately on the fact that every new building erected to tower above its neighbor robbed the latter and the streets to a great extent of most valuable light.

Many prominent Stock Exchange men have within a week past shown a disposition to abandon bearish attitudes and take more cheerful views of the stock market situation. Included in this list is Mr. Henry Allen, of Henry Allen Co., who since last Summer has been till now advising customers to leave the current market alone.

Castle Pinckney has long been an object of interest in the Harbor of Charleston. Its capture by a portion of Charleston's chivalry was one of the opening incidents of the storm of war that raged in the city's historic haven. It has long stood like a military memorial on the island of forty-seven acres upon which it is built.

The Board of Aldermen, at its regular meeting yesterday afternoon, granted, with only three dissenting votes, franchises to the Pelham Park Railway Company, which operates a horse car line from Bartow to City Island, to build two branches of its road, one to Westchester Village and the other in the direction of New Rochelle as far as the city line.

ALBANY, Nov. 30. -- The Right Rev. William Crosswell Doane, Bishop of the Episcopal diocese of Albany, made answer to-day through the newspapers to the Irish-American societies and individuals who had criticised his recent remarks on jingoism. In an interview to-day he says:

Nearly $30,000 was subscribed last night at the anniversary meeting of the Salvation Army, which was held at Carnegie Music Hall for the purpose of furthering Commander Booth-Tucker's colonization scheme, which he outlined in a lengthy address before a large audience, which seemed heartily in sympathy with the proposed plans.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 30. -- Richard Croker enjoyed to-day the rest which, he has all along insisted, is the sole object of his visit here. In company with John J. Scannell, William Sohmer, and Thomas J. Dunn, who are the only Tammany leaders left on the scene, he spent the day in undisturbed leisure.

Annie Drayton, alias May Murray, or "Big May," twenty-eight years old, and Flossie Maitland, twenty-six years old, were arrested by Detective Sergeants Aloncle and Car yeaterday on a charge of stealing sea skin garments valued at $600 from two fur houses.

Enthusiasm for Scotland and everything Scotch marked, as was natural, the one hundred and forty-first annual dinner of the St. Andrew's Society of the State of New York, held last night at Delmonico's. The decorations of heather were imported from Scotland for the occasion, the songs and toasts were Scotch, and an overwhelming majority of those present were Scotch or of Scottish descent.

The crusade you have begun against the pension abuse calls attention to the need of some agency interested in preventing the extravagant and harmful expenditure of the public money, and possessing sufficient authority to accomplish something in that direction. There undoubtedly exists a strong sentiment against this and kindred abuses, but it has been ineffective because diffused and lacking a channel through which to make itself felt.

It was a miserable-looking crew, that of the British half brig Elite, which was brought into his port yesterday on the steamship Exeter City, from Bristol and Swanson. The sailormen were taken off their dismasted and water-logged craft, 250 miles east of St. John's, N.F.
For an army to fight a battle and win it without a commanding General is a brilliant achievement, yet the annals of our wars furnish four instances of this brilliancy.

The annual general meeting of the Yacht Racing Union of Long Island Sound will be held at the Fifth Avenue Hotel on Tuesday evening next. The following business will be presented before the convention for action: Action on amendments to the general and racing rules, consideration of the report of the council, arrangement of dates for races for season of 1898, and election of the council for the ensuing year.

BOSTON, Dec. 1. -- Nellie Oliver, a notorious shoplifter, created a sensational scene in the streets down town to-day when two Headquarter detectives were accompanying her to a photographer's to have her picture taken for the Rogues' Gallery. It is seven years since she was last in the toils here, and a new photograph was desired.

MADRID, Dec. 1. -- At the Cabinet meeting yesterday, the Minister of Marine, Admiral Bermejo, presented the request of the Governor of the Island of Fernando Po, the Spanish penal settlement on the west coast of Africa, for more warships to guard that place.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 1. -- Mr. S.H.H. Clark, one of the receivers of the Union Pacific Railroad, to-day announced that the Presidency of that company had been offered to him by the Reorganization Committee, but that, owing to ill health, he had refused it.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- The Naval Board appointed by authority of Congress to ascertain the cost of an armor plant, the members of which are Commodore Howell, Capt. McCormick, Civil Engineer Endicott, Chief Engineer Perry, and Lieut. Fletcher, to-day made its report through Commodore Howell to Secretary Long.

A report was circulated yesterday that Amos F. Eno had purchased from the Gautier estate the four-story brick dwelling at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Tenth Street, on a plot 50.3 by 126, with an "L" at the rear 26 by 42.3. The brokers mentioned in connection with the sale would neither confirm nor deny the report.

One of the three big franchise grabs made on Monday by the Brooklyn Board of Aldermen was halted yesterday by Justice Gaynor of the Supreme Court, who granted injunctions in two suits brought by New York newspapers to prevent Mayor Wurster from approving it, and the Board of Aldermen from taking any further action.

HAVANA, Dec. 1. -- The Marquis de Apezteguia, leader of the Spanish Conservative Party, arrived here to-day. He was welcomed by the Central Conservative Committee and has had a long interview with Capt. Gen. Blanco. He says that the Conservative Party ought to stand by the Government in furthering the work of pacification; but he has not made any public declaration in favor of autonomy.

A suit for $50,000 damages has been brought against Howard and George J. Gould in the Supreme Court by Frank D. Mowbray for injuries received while employed as steward on George J. Gould's yacht Hildegarde, formerly owned by the Prince of Wales. Mr. Mowbray has placed his case in the hands of the law firm of Scott Clark, and on Tuesday afternoon Howard Gould was served with a summons at his office, 195 Broadway.

The fourth game in the world's championship billiard tournament in progress at the Madison Square Garden Concert Hall, played last night between George Slosson and Maurice Daly, resulted favorably for Slosson after a long drawn out contest. It was a close race almost to the finish, but finally Slosson proved his superiority.

" Beauty and the Beast; or, A Woman's Right to Be Ugly" was one of the subjects considered by the Rainy Day Club at its first meeting in its headquarters, the Grand Central Palace, yesterday afternoon.

There was a sudden revival of talk yesterday about the future leadership of Tammany. It took the form in most cases of some version of the story which began to circulate immediately after the election, to the effect that John C. Sheehan is to retire and that John F. Carroll is to take his place.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1. -- The A. P. Roberts Company, which owns and operates the Pencoyd Iron Works of this city, has received a cablegram from Utrecht stating that the company's bid of $474,000 is the lowest in the competition for the contract for the material and erection for the Government of Holland of an extensive iron bridge over the River Yssel, near Westervoort, Netherlands.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 1. -- Typhoid fever cases are on the increase, four more having been reported to-day -- one on Marshall Street, one on Matlock Street, one on Broadway, and one on Graham Avenue. Four cases outside the Paterson Orphan Asylum making a total of twenty-four during the were also reported yesterday afternoon, past month, exclusive of the orphans.
OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 1. -- Railroad men in Omaha believe that Horace G. Burt will be President of the reorganized Union Pacific.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 1. -- When ex-Secretary Herbert promised a Kentucky delegation that he would name one of the new battleships after this State, he told Miss Hettie Bainbridge Richardson of this city, who was present, that she should have the honor of christening the ship.

Half a century of activity in the cause of music in one city is a record that surely deserves to be honored. Fifty years ago Richard Hoffman, pianist, made his first appearance in New York. Yesterday afternoon he played in a concert given to commemorate that event in his career. He is still tall and erect of figure, gentle and sweet of countenance, and rich in enthusiasm for his art.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- The December statement of the public debt shows that at the close of business, Nov. 30, 1897, the public debt, less cash in the Treasury, amounted to $1,009,226,466, a decrease since Oct. 30 of $11,338,125. This decrease is accounted for by an increase in the cash due to the deposit of an installment of the proceeds of the sale of the Government's interest in the Union Pacific Railroad.

A pitiable case of destitution was brought to the notice of Magistrate Mott in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday by Gerry Agents Watson and Lynch, when Louis McDougal, thirty-seven years old, his wife, Sarah, and their three children, aged respectively thirteen, eleven, and nine years, were arraigned.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 1. -- At the sales of thoroughbreds to-day Bramble, the famous sire of Clifford, Ben Brush, and other good horses, was sold to Clay Woodford of Paris, Ky., for $3,700. The horse is twenty-two years old.

NORRISTOWN, Penn., Dec. 1. -- Charles O. Kaiser, the convicted murderer of his wife, Emma P. Kaiser, within a day or so, it is said, will make a full confession of his crime to District Attorney Strassburger.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1. -- The bill for an injunction to recover possession of $100,000 worth of stock of the American Cereal Company, claimed by the assignees of Ferdinand Schumacher, President of the Cereal Company, from the American Exchange National Bank, or its President, Robert Stuart, and Cashier J. Edward Maass, which was filed yesterday, was called up by Judge Grosscup to-day.

Good Government Club A held its annual meeting last night at its headquarters in the Tuxedo building, at Madison Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street. Trustees of the club and delegates to the Council of Confederated Good Government Clubs were elected, and there were short speeches by W. Harris Roome, ex-President, and by the victorious candidates of the Citizens' Union in the Twenty-seventh and Twenty-ninth Assembly Districts in the recent election.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1. -- Charles Warren Spalding, ex-President of the Globe Savings Bank, was to-day sentenced to an indeterminate term in the penitentiary. He was charged with embezzling $28,000 of Macoupin credit bonds, the property of the University of Illinois, of which he was Treasurer.

ALBANY, Dec. 1. -- Gov. Black to-day granted pardons to Thomas J. McCabe and Giuseppe Rosano of New York City, who have both been serving terms in the Elmira Reformatory, for convictions for grand larceny. Rosano has been incarcerated since September, 1895, and McCabe, with the exception of a few months, when he was out on parole, has been behind the bars since 1888.

The latest batch of reports as to Cabinet changes represent Mr. MCKENNA for the Supreme Court bench, the retirement of Secretary SHERMAN, if that can be brought about, and the appointment of Judge DAY to the State Department.

There was no new development yesterday in the Thorn-Nack murder case, except Thorn's positive denial that he made the confession that was printed in the morning as coming from him through Capt. Methven of the Long Island City police.

Considerable excitement and some damage was caused yesterday afternoon by a collision at the entrance to the East River, between the ferryboat Brooklyn of the South Ferry and the canal boat Warren. The Brooklyn left her slip at the foot of Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, at 5 o'clock. The canal boat, coal laden, was being towed up the river by the tugboat Veaux Powell. The tugboat was lashed alongside the afterpart of the Warren.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Dec. 1. -- The live-bird shoot to-day at the Driving Park proved something of a disappointment, owing to the fact that few of the experts who had promised to attend put in an appearance. There were only four contestants in the principal event of the day, a twenty-bird contest, for which an unusually fast lot of pigeons were trapped.

During the last few months Mr. Long had been the object of much criticism. If he had formed a scrap book of them, the letters he had received would, for style, calligraphy, elegant phraseology, and force of language, have proved an absolutely unique collection. But unfortunately for posterity, he had found another use for those letters.

ALBANY, Dec. 1. -- There was argued in the Court of Appeals to-day the appeal of Isaac Zucker, the cloak manufacturer, of New York City, who is serving a term of thirty-six years in Sing Sing Prison, having been convicted of arson in December, 1896. The appeal is from the decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, First Department, which affirmed the conviction.

It strikes us that President MCKINLEY might do a much worse thing than to change his mind about Mr. CHARLES G. DAWES of Illinois, to whom it is understood he offered, some months ago, the office of Controller of the Currency when Mr. JAMES H. ECKELS retires from that place.

Your editorial in this morning's issue entitled "Overloading the Soil by Buildings" is worthy of a more technical journal. The writer has maintained for some time that the problems met in designing foundations for our modern high buildings are more serious and far-reaching in their consequences than any other questions which arise in connection with this work.

BERLIN, Dec. 1. -- The Reichstag to-day re-elected Baron von Buol-Berenberg to the Presidency of the House and also re-elected the Vice Presidents, Herren R. Schmidt and P. Spahn. The next sitting of the Reichstag will take place on Friday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The exact nature of Germany's demands on Haiti became known to-day. The details came by way of the steamer from Port au Prince which arrived at New York yesterday. What Germany asks is this:

The Republicans of the Twenty-ninth Assembly District resumed last night their work of investigating the charges of fraud that had been raised with regard to the rolls. Alexander T. Mason, James Yereance, John V.B. Clarkson, Walter R. Benjamin, and N.A. Elsberg conducted the investigation.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 1. -- It has at last been discovered who the incorporators of the Atlantic and Pacific Aerial Navigation Company are. The company, which is officered by C.A. Smith, President, and M.A. Terry, Secretary, both of San Francisco, was organized to manufacture the air-ship of Hiram S. Maxim, inventor of the Maxim gun.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- The report of John Hyde, Statistician of the Department of Agriculture, offers several suggestions which demand the attention of business men and farmers in every part of the country. Millions of dollars of speculative and investment interests depend, at certain seasons, on the official bulletins issued by the department and prepared by the Statistical Division.
Hawaiian annexation will utterly wreck the Monroe Doctrine.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 1. -- The General Assembly of Virginia met to-day at noon and perfected an organization by the election of the officers nominated by the Democratic caucuses of the two houses last night. This Legislature elects a successor in the United States Senate to John W. Daniel.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 1. -- A bill was introduced in the House of Representatives here to-night to prevent the execution of Mrs. Elizabeth Nobles, now confined in the jail at Macon, Ga., under sentence of death for the murder of her husband. The bill was introduced by Representative Berry of Whitfield at the instance of Gov. Atkinson, who wished to evade the responsibility of passing on the old woman's case.

The Rev. Dr. Richard Gear Hobbs, the commissioner sent by The Christian Herald to distribute the money raised by that publication for the relief of the starving people in India, returned to New York yesterday morning after an absence abroad of nearly six months.

Commander BOOTH-TUCKER on Tuesday evening raised some $30,000 of the $100,000 he wishes for his scheme of relief for the crowded cities. The plan of the Salvation Army, he says, is "to transport the surplus crowds from the cities to the vast tracts of fertile but uncultivated lands which have been placed at its disposal, varying in extent from 1,000 to 400,000 acres, and including twenty-three different States in the West and South."

Part of the estate of William H. Osgood, yachtsman, clubman, and stock broker, who died Dec. 12, 1896, was a seat in the Stock Exchange. Adrian H. Muller Son were yesterday authorized to sell the membership at their auction sale of securities at the New York Real Estate Salesroom by John M. Bowers of Bowers Sands, executor of the estate.

-- "Lynching," said a man in an elevated train yesterday, "is the only thing that will convince Aldermen of the impropriety of acts like those just committed by the City Fathers of New York and Brooklyn." His companion demurred. "It might have a good effect," he said, "but what about the people who elect Aldermen of this sort -- Aldermen from whom they had no right to expect anything better?

LONDON, Dec. 1. -- It is reported here in well-informed circles that the views of the Russian Government have undergone a change as to the situation at Kiao-Chou Bay. Seeing the large force that Germany is assembling there, Russia is inclined, with France, to oppose German action.
The American Society of Mechanical Engineers held the second session of its semi-annual meeting yesterday. The following officers were elected:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- The Inter-State Commerce Commission to-day opened the hearing of the railroads which have petitioned for an extension of the time in which they may comply with the law of 1893 requiring them to equip their cars and engines with automatic car couplers, hand rails, and air brakes.

PRAGUE, Bohemia, Dec. 1. -- There was a renewal of the rioting here last evening. The windows of the German theatre, schools, restaurants, residences, and newspaper offices were broken. The troops eventually cleared the streets. Many people were injured and numerous arrests were made.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday voted unanimously to adopt the plans submitted for a public library by Carrere Hastings, the architects, and resolved to enter into an agreement with the New York Public Library, Astor, Lenox, and Tilden Foundations for the use of the building in Bryant Park to be erected in accordance with these plans by the Park Department at a cost not exceeding $2,500,000.

PARIS, Dec. 1. -- Owing to the defeat of the Government in the Senate yesterday, when the Senators by a vote of 133 to 113, rejected the motion of M. Darlan, the Minister of Justice, to shelve the discussion of the removal of a Magistrate, which had been denounced as illegal; M. Darlan to-day requested the Premier, M. Meline, to inform the President, M. Faure, that he had tendered his resignation.

City Magistrate KUDLICH has an interesting article in the current number of The Forum on "The Abuse of the Police Power." The article is in fact an exposition of the difficulties that encompass a Magistrate in his endeavors to use his office for the public good, and an appeal to the public to bear those difficulties in mind when it is tempted to judge him harshly.

DEER PARK, Mich., Dec. 1. -- Abandoned by her towing steamer and unable to work her way off a lee shore in the heavy northwest gale on Lake Superior, the schooner Joseph Paige went ashore to-day at Vermillion Point and became a total loss. The crew were rescued by the life-savers from the Vermillion station.

BOSTON, Dec. 1. -- The editor of The Missionary Herald of the American Board, the Rev. E.E. Strong, D.D., has compiled the statistics of Protestant missions in this and other lands for the past year as follows:

The Fulton, Wall Street and Cortlandt Street Ferries Railroad Company has been revived, and has filed an application with the Commissioner of Public Works for the necessary permission to open Wall, Pine, Liberty, Cortlandt, and William Streets for the purpose of laying tracks over which to operate a horse railroad.

The big trotting and pacing sale conducted by William B. Fasig Co., at Madison Square Garden for the past eight days ended last night. The sale in which about 700 head of horses were included, numbering among them many very fast ones, was the largest sale of trotters and pacers ever attempted in this country, and in all, the receipts amounted to about $200,000, the average being more than $300.

TACOMA, Washington, Dec. 1. -- Sailor Frank Wyckersham has just returned from an eight months' whaling trip in the Arctic Ocean on the steam bark William Baylies. His ship was in company at various times with the eight whalers now imprisoned in the ice east of Point Barrow. Wyckersham declares that the men aboard the ship are not suffering, as is generally supposed.

CARLYLE, Ills., Dec. 1. -- In August last the wife of Dr. G.H. Rice, a well known citizen of Sandoval, died. Her life was insured for $7,000, the amount being divided among several companies. All the companies were willing to pay the amount of the policies excepting the Metropolitan of New York.

WICHITA, Kan., Dec. 1. -- Capt. E.L. Hewes, the boomer who claims to have enrolled in Wichita 300 recruits for the "Sooner" army, with which he hopes to invade the Wichita Mountain country, within the Kiowa and Comanche Indian Reservation, in Oklahoma Territory, left here to-day for the Oklahoma Territory, where he will continue his recruiting.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1. -- With a broom lashed to the truck of her foremast; the private ensign of Henry M. Flagler, the owner, flying from the peak, and the flag of the Cramp Company at the masthead, the new steel twin-screw steamship Miami returned to the city this afternoon after a most successful trial trip.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Dec. 1. -- The Dutchess County Mutual Insurance Company was to-day made an issue in the war waged in Dutchess County between the Hunter and Vail wings of the Republican Party. At the last election an attempt was made to beat County Treasurer Haubenstel, a Hunter man, by attacking his credit, but the voters resented the trick by piling up a plurality of nearly 4,000 for Haubenstel.

The system of free lectures to the people, managed by the Board of Education, has had a surprising growth. Few people outside of those directly interested are aware of its extent and value as an educating influence. Statistics are dull reading, but the reader will pardon a short tabular presentation of the facts showing how very rapidly the attendance at the free lectures has grown.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1. -- Dr. von Holleben, the new German Ambassador, consented to-day to speak concerning some of the questions of mutual interest between the United States and Germany.

Meyer Schoenfeld, the leader of the coat tailors, received yesterday a letter from the United Hebrew Charities Organization, asking his co-operation in determining which of the persons in that trade who apply for assistance are worthy of it. The slack season in the cloak-making industry has already begun, and the tailoring industry is also less active than it was several weeks ago.

AUSTIN, Texas, Dec. 2. -- The National Prison Congress of the United States convened in this city to-night. The congress is to continue for four days. Gov. Culberson, on the part of the State, and Mayor Hancock, on the part of the city, welcomed the visitors, and President Roeloff Brinkerhoff of Mansfield, Ohio, delivered his annual address.

NASHVILLE, Ark., Dec. 2. -- Details of a street affray at Horatio, in which one man was killed outright and another fatally wounded, reached here to-day. The dead man is Dr. Smith, a prominent physician of that place, and the man fatally wounded is J.J. Smith, a business man of Horatio and a brother of the dead doctor.

During a quarrel in front of 221 West Twenty-seventh Street yesterday afternoon Rosa Woodson, twenty-eight years old, of 211 West Twenty-eighth Street, had her throat cut. The man who did the cutting is a negro. He succeeded in escaping, and the police have not even a description of him.

ALBANY, Dec. 2. -- The Forest Preserve Board at its meeting to-day contracted to spend some $29,000 for the purchase of land in the Adirondacks. The land purchased to-day comprises some four or five thousand acress of land in Townships 3 and 4 of Hamilton County at $4.75 an acre, and 1,200 acres in Township 5, same county, at $7 an acre.
LEWISTON, Me., Dec. 2. -- Congressman Nelson Dingley left for Washington to-day. In an interview just before his departure he said:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- The hearing given by the Inter-State Commerce Commission to the representatives of the railroads which have petitioned for an extension of time in which to comply with the car coupler law passed in 1893 was resumed to-day.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- Berkeley Balch, secretary of the Cuban League, appeared to-day before President McKinley and presented the following argument in behalf of the Cuban insurgents:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- The purposes of Rome concerning the case of Mgr. Schroeder of the Catholic University have been made known to the Catholic authorities in this country. The information has not come in an official form, but is said to be none the less definite, and is in the possession of Cardinal Gibbons, Chancellor of the Catholic University, and Mgr. Martinelli, the Papal Delegate.
The Ross estate has sold to a syndicate of operators the old three-story buildings southwest corner of Broadway and Walker Street, 50.10 1/4 by 127.7 3/4 by 100.8 by 24.4 by 100.3 1/2.

Two pretty and bright little girls, neatly dressed and not more than six years old, made the usually quiet West Thirtieth Street Police Station ring with their laughter and prattle for several hours last night.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 2. -- At a meeting of the Board of Directors of the Southern Pacific Railroad Company held here to-day Gen. Thomas H. Hubbard, Second Vice President, was elected to the First Vice Presidency, recently vacated by the death of Col. Charles F. Crocker, and George Crocker, brother of the deceased, was elected to fill the vacancy created by Gen. Hubbard's advancement.

The District Attorney of Queens County is reported to have said that he considered it his duty to accept from the woman NACK the "highest plea that he could get" instead of putting her on trial for murder in the first degree.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- The court-martial ordered to be convened at Savannah to try Capt. O.M. Carter, Corps of Engineers, is considered at the War Department to be a strong body of men.

The report is revived in Tammany Hall with renewed persistency that John C. Sheehan is booked for retirement as Chairman of the Finance Committee, and that if Richard Croker does not succeed him, some one who is in the full confidence of Mr. Croker will. It is also said that few, if any, of Mr. Sheehan's friends will receive recognition at the hands of Mr. Croker and the incoming administration.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Dec. 2. -- A special train of four private cars was run at an unprecedented rate of speed between Pittsburg and Chicago over the Pennsylvania Road for the purpose of ascertaining the possibility of reducing the time of the limited express to twenty hours between New York and Chicago.

ROME, Dec. 2. -- To-day the Chamber of Deputies appointed a commission of five to inquire into the charges against Signor Francesco Crispi, former Premier, in connection with the Bank of Naples scandals and the alleged illegal traffic in decorations.

LONDON, Dec. 2. -- Fierce storms again broke over the coasts of England during the past night, and the scenes recorded during the early part of the week are recurring. Heavy hail, snow, and rain storms accompanied the gales. The Dover and Calais Channel service is temporarily suspended, and several vessels are reported to have been wrecked on the Goodwin Sands.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- Owing to the illness of the civil engineer who was to take charge of the field parties with the Nicaraguan Canal Commission, it has been found necessary to secure the services of another engineer, and the departure of the commission has been delayed.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 2. -- By order of the Sheriff, an alleged pooh'oom was raided at 5'Iamaroneck last night. The Deputies captured bcoks, blackboards, instruments, and a lot of stuff. The rooms were in the upper part of a hotel. John ..ndrews and Charles iP. I2ropp, the alleged managers of the place, together with the fittings, were taken to the county jail.

President Alexander E. Orr was in the chair at the December meeting of the Chamber of Commerce yesterday. A feature of the session was the preamble and resolutions offered by Charles L. Seeger on the advertising and commercial directory schemes of the Director of the Bureau of American Republics, at Washington, and Mr. Seeger's tart comment thereon.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- The Government has fully decided to qualify as a bidder at the sale of the Kansas Pacific Railroad on Dec. 16 next, in case of the failure of the Reorganization Committee to guarantee the Government what is regarded as a fair and just figure for its interest. Whether the President and the Attorney General, however, will exact the full amount of the Government's claim of approximately $13,000,000 is not known.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- Secretary Sherman has closed the case of Emilio Clark, Consular agent at Piura, Peru, which attracted much attention some months ago, by calling for the resignation of Clark. On April 22 last was ousted from the quarters used below as the United States Consular office and above as a residence.

A decision was rendered by the Board of General Appraisers yesterday sustaining the action of the Collector of the Port of Boston in classifying various importations of broken "wool tops' as dutiable at 20 per cent. ad valorem. The firms of H. Hermes Co., T. Remick Co., and George F. Willett Co. of Boston claimed free entry on the ground that the merchandise was waste wool.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 2. -- After an exciting meeting last night the Board of Education refused to recognize the oral opinion of State Superintendent of Public Instruction Skinner that it is unlawful to employ Sisters of Charity as teachers in the public schools if they wear the garb of their order in the schoolroom.
PARIS, Dec. 2. -- Miss Sybil Sanderson, the opera singer, was married quietly here yesterday to Antoino Terry. Immediately after the ceremony they left for Italy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- Representative Dingley joins the almost unanimous Republican chorus that says that no currency legislation is possible with the Congress about to meet. His reasons, like those given by Senator Carter, Representative Walker, Senator Morrill, Representative Cannon, and others, is that the free silver majority of the Senate will render nugatory any action in favor of currency reform that the House may take.
WASHINGTON, N.J., Dec. 2. -- Ex-Mayor Henry Johnston, a prominent Prohibitionist, has been sued for $5,000 by William Barron, proprietor of the Keystone Saloon.
ITPI.CA, Dec. 2. -- The dJspatch from New Haven in regard to a Yale-Corncll boat race was shown to a representative of the Cornell navy, who said:

The Trustees of the New York Public Library are engaged in showing that they are men fit to be intrusted with the great civic responsibility that is imposed upon them. They have gone about to obtain the plans for a new library building with an intelligence and a thoroughness that have commanded and deserved admiration.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2. -- Annie Niggt, a young married woman, to-night murdered her two younger children by illuminating gas, and at the same time attempted suicide by the same means. The murdered children were Frank, aged two years, and Harvey, aged six months.
BOSTON, Dec. 2. -- Gov. Wolcott has removed Joseph C. Braman of 120 Broadway, New York, from the office of Commissioner of Deeds for Massachusetts in New York.

Alderman Parker at the opening of the special meeting of the Board of Aldermen yesterday introduced a resolution to request the Mayor to return to the board its resolution granting the franchise to the Pelham Park Railway Company passed on Tuesday. This was passed, and the board voted to reconsider the resolution in regard to the franchise.

The Rev. Thomas Thomas, colored, of 99 First Street, William's Bridge, referred to by the irreverent of his acquaintances as "Double Tom," had a tale of woe to pour into the ear of Magistrate Pool in the Morrisania Police Court yesterday.

The movement for a new Republican organization will be formally launched at a meeting to be held to-night in Lyric Hall, Sixth Avenue and Forty-second Street. The meeting was called by the anti-Platt organization of which William Brookfield and Gen. Wager Swayne are the leaders, and it will be attended by a delegation from the Republicans who were at the Plaza Club conference.

Andrew C. Zabriskie, President of the American Numismatic and Archaeological Society, read a paper before the society last evening in its rooms in the Academy of Music building on "United States History as Illustrated by Its Political Medals." Among his auditors were George Maccullogh Miller, Woodbury Langdon, Lambert Suydam, J. Sanford Saltus, George F. Kunz, Miss Hasbrook, and Mrs. Zabriskie.

Mr. and Mrs. George Henschel have returned to America, where there is always a warm welcome for them. Their first song recital in this city was given at Chickering Hall last night. The audience was one that filled the house with its numbers and its applause. It is not at all surprising that there was an abundance of applause.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 2. -- Miss Virginia MacTavish has set the epicures of Baltimore talking by her preparations to have Maryland terrapin and oysters sent to Rome for a luncheon that she will give on New Year's Day in honor of Queen Margaret of Italy. Miss MacTavish is a Maryland woman, and is a great-great-granddaughter of Charles Carroll of Carrollton.

Frank C. Ives clearly demonstrated his right to the title of billiard champion by breaking all previous records for the eighteen-inch balk line game, when he met George Sutton yesterday afternoon in the tournament at the Madison Square Garden Concert Hall. The young Napoleon was probably never in better form, and the ease with which he clicked off point after point was remarkable.

That is rather an Orphic announcement that is made from Washington, that the President will not take the extreme course of changing his church to mark his disapproval of the Thanksgiving Day sermon of his pastor. That was at first declared to be his cruel and unusual intention.

Does the Manhattan Elevated Railway wish to extend its lines and Increase its passenger facilities? We have no doubt that it can secure on just terms the city's permission for any reasonable extension of its present lines. It will take five years to complete the underground road, even if it is begun at once.
Put in tabular form, to make it more clear, the Treasury statement for the month just closed is as follows:
PRAGUE, Dec. 2. -- Martial law has been proclaimed here, as well as in the Judicial Districts of Karolenemthal, Ziskow, Weinberg, and Smichow, as a result of the rioting here and elsewhere.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- It is expected that the message of President McKinley will be devoted practically to the subjects of foreign relations and the currency problem. It will be unique in that it will ignore the great bulk of matters usually constituting the departmental portions of Presidential annual messages.

The State Board of Charities is deeply interested at present in the questions which have arisen over the incorporation of the Cooper Hospital of New York City. The hospital in question was incorporated at Albany some days ago, with a capital stock of $1,000. The State board asserts that the articles of incorporation should not have been filed until they had been approved by the board, under the Membership Corporation act.

William E. Mitchell, a broker, at 10 Wall Street, was arraigned in Centre Street Police Court yesterday morning on a charge of grand larceny. It is alleged that he obtained $3,500 under false pretenses from Oscar E.A. Weisner of 367 Seventh Avenue, Brooklyn. Mitchell is fifty years old, and lives at 558 Hancock Street, Brooklyn.

Martin Thorn will be sentenced to the electric chair by Justice Maddox in the Queens County Court House at 9:30 o'clock this morning. William F. Howe, counsel for Thorn, will at once give formal notice of appeal. Thorn will be taken to Sing Sing after he has seen his sister and her husband, and the Rev. Father Heindelmann, the Bohemian priest to whom he has taken a fancy.

CANTON, Ohio, Dec. 2. -- At an early hour this morning Mrs. Nancy Allison McKinley, the venerable mother of the President, was stricken with paralysis, and her death is believed to be only a question of a short time. That the attack would ultimately end in death was the first fear of the family, and the consultations of the attending physicians have tended to confirm this belief.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 2. -- The first interchange of correspondence between Yale and Cornell Universities looking toward a boat race for next Spring has taken place, and now, through the authorities of Yale, it is for the first time possible to state that Old Eli will measure blades with the champion Cornellians some time next June.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2. -- The President to-day appointed Blanche K. Bruce of Mississippi to be Register of the Treasury. Mr. Bruce represented Mississippi in the Senate in the reconstruction days, and is one of the best known negro Republicans in the country. The position to which he is appointed is one he held some years ago.
LONDON, Dec. 2. -- The firm of Morton, Rose Co., bankers, will be reorganized on Jan. 1., Mr. Rose retiring. The firm thereafter will be entitled Morton, Chaplin Co.

Franklin B. Parker, a well-dressed man, thirty-four years old, who says he is a horse dealer of 550 Lenox Avenue, and John Smith, a hostler, of 23 East One Hundred and First Street, were arraigned in the Essex Market Police Court yesterday, charged with having swindled Frederick Taylor of Fort Williams, Ont., out of $68. Taylor arrived in this city Tuesday and engaged passage on the White Star steamer Adriatic for England.

POTSDAM, N.Y., Dec.2. -- The preliminary examination of Howard W. Burt, who is charged with killing his father-in-law and attempting to kill his own wife, at Hannawa Fails, five miles from here, on the night of Nov. 10, will begin here to-morrow. The case promises to be interesting, both on account of the mystery attending the murder and the high standing of the defendant, who is related by marriage to prominent persons in the county.

ALBANY, Dec. 2. -- The announcement was made here to-night that a New York and Albany syndicate had purchased for $30,000 the old American Hotel property on State Street in this city, and will erect a theatre to be known as the Empire, and to be conducted as a first-class house. The plans are completed and the building is to be finished by Aug. 1, 1898.

A natural carbonic acid gas taken from springs at Oberlahnstein, near Ems, Germany, is imported into this country in liquid form, chiefly for use in charging American sparkling wines. This gas was the subject of a spirited hearing before the Board of Classification of the General Appraisers yesterday.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 2. -- The Diocesan Convention of the Episcopal Church of Arkansas has elected as Coadjutor Bishop, to assist Bishop Pierce, Archdeacon William Montgomery Brown of Cleveland. The election of Archdeacon Brown has resulted in great dissatisfaction, as indicated by expressions from lay delegates who supported the Rev. John Gass of this city.

VIENNA, Dec. 2. -- The Parliamentary dead-lock continues. Baron Gautsch, the new Premier, has made no progress toward a compromise satisfactory to the rival factions, and it begins to be feared that the present Reichsrath will never reassemble. Certain it is that if the Reichsrath meets with Dr. von Abrahamovics in the chair the same disorderly scenes will occur as before.

W.B. Cleary, a young lawyer, who was for nearly three years a clerk in the law offices of Hornblower, Byrne, Taylor Miller, in the Johnston Building, 30 Broad Street, is at present in Seattle, Washington, preparing to go into the Klondike regions with Henry Henderson, a brother of Robert Henderson, one of the earliest prospectors in the gold country.

Dr. Eliphalet Nott Potter, formerly President of Hobart College and now President of the Cosmopolitan University, was the speaker of the evening at the reception of the Drawing Room Club, held at the Waldorf-Astoria last night. His subject was "Washington as a Churchman and Communicant.''
OCONTO, Wis., Dec. 2. -- City attorney P.H. Lynch was disfigured and narrowly escaped being disabled for life by having a can of carbolic acid thrown in his face last night.

There are plenty of reasons for thinking that the world laughs less as it grows older. One obvious reason is that, as the world grows older, it understands better, its range of sympathy is extended. Children laugh at the village idiot or at the "funny faces" of papa in the agonies of toothache; when they are old enough to understand idiocy or toothache they no longer laugh.

Five representatives, or their proxies, from each Assembly district in the Boroughs of Manhattan and the Bronx met at Lyric Hall, Sixth Avenue and Forty-second Street, last night, in response to the call for a conference issued at the last meeting of the anti-Platt Republican organization of the City and County of New York.

MOBILE, Ala., Dee. 3. -- For four days past the newly appointed Republican Postmaster, P.D. Barker, has endeavored in vain to obtain possession of the office here from Postmaster Rapier, Democrat. The latter's attorneys have raised a point of law which Inspector Tate says has never been raised before in his experience, nor has he ever had to transfer an office situated precisely as this one is.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- In his annual report to the Secretary of the Treasury, Mr. Forman, the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, estimates that receipts from all sources for the current fiscal year will aggregate at least $155,000,000, an increase over the previous year of about $8,300,000.
I notice that The New York Observer of Nov. 11 was so unkind to itself a to speak of "John Leighton, Jr.," Mrs. Katrina Trask's novel recently published by Harper Brothers, in these words:

There is now no room for doubt that the great international language of the future will be English. That this magnificent destiny awaited it has been suspected by many; but, as long as the prophets were themselves of that nation, the statement attracted little attention. Within the last few years, however, foreign critics have come to the same conclusion.

Coroners Edward B. Coombs and George H. Nason of Brooklyn were indicted yesterday by the November Grand Jury of Kings County for presenting fraudulent bills and obtaining money on them. They were indicted on four separate charges. First they were charged jointly with presenting a false bill of $2,762.50 for 325 inquests, of which, it is alleged, 128 were fraudulent.

The doubt has often been expressed whether it is of any use to concern ourselves about happiness at all. The less we think about it, the less we consciously aim at it, the more probable it is, according to this view, that we shall attain enough of it for our needs. If this is really the case, happiness must be strangely different from all other objects of human desire.

One of the brightest traditions in the history of William and Mary College is that which tells of the wooing and wedding of Parson Camm, a gentleman famous once, whose fame deserves to be revived. John Camm was born in 1718 and educated at Trinity College, Cambridge. He was a man of good scholarship and sturdy character, an uncompromising Tory, one of the leaders in that "Parson Cause" which made Patrick Henry famous.

Would any one who ever heard Thackeray lecture, fancy for a monent that he ever suffered from stage fright? His pose before an audience was perfect. For a man over six feet in height, if not graceful, he was naturally imposing. Then his great massive head, the nose with the flattened bridge, offered a perfect piece de resistance.

In your SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS AND ART of Oct. 30 last, you say, in an article on "Other Tennysons Besides Alfred," , in referring to the Laureate's brother Frederic, that your knowledge of him is "mainly" derived * * * "through extracts from letters written to Mrs. Brotherton, during a correspondence of over forty years."

The capital of Norway is a comparative small place, where every one is more or less intimately acquainted with every one else. A personality as marked as Henrik Ibsen finds himself discussed with an unflagging zeal that may be flattering to him in the abstract, but cannot fail to be concretely annoying.

In the first half of the century girls of the richer classes were sent almost exclusively to boarding schools, or were taught by private governesses, whose educational merits could not be tested by any examinations. The school books were Mangnall's "Questions." Pinnock's "Catechisms." Mrs. Marcet's "Conversations," "Keith's "Use of the Globes," Mrs. Trimmer's "English History," and other elegant abridgements.

CANTON, Ohio, Dec. 3. -- Mrs. Nancy Allison McKinley, the mother of the President, manifested remarkable vitality to-day. Her death was expected hourly, but until a late hour to-night her condition showed but little change from that of last night. About 10 o'clock, however, a change was observed, and the attending physician expressed fear that she would not survive until morning.

After weeks in the forest of Fontainebleau it is difficult to realize its monotonous amplitude, its endless repetition of similar prospects. And yet as a forest it has no surpassing beauty. One may compare it with Dartmoor -- Dartmoor pared of its highest tors and set thickly with young trees, growing close as the moss on a boulder.

It has often been said, especially in Russia, that Tolstoi, while preaching simplicity and poverty, lives in luxury himself. This M. Tchertkoff (his Secretary, now in London) declares to be a mistake. Tolstoi handed over his property to his wife many years ago, and she manages the house in the ordinary style of Russians of their class, being a strict disbeliever in her husband's views.

Plans for the fiftieth aniversary of the organization of the New York East Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church have been somewhat interfered with in a rather unexpected manner. It was proposed to have the conference anniversary in the First Church in Middletown, Conn., in which city the first session of the conference was held.
