James Darmesteter has just told it, in her "Life of Renan," published by Houghton, Mifflin Co., will appeal to the hearts of all who read it. Below will be found a portion of this remarkable record of self-sacrifice, self-abnegation, and unfaltering love:

It appears from the report of the board of naval officers that if the Government goes into the business of making armor plate it must also set up a plant for making steel. An armor plate factory cannot be successfully and economically operated unless it has furnaces for producing its own steel ingots.

---- A Chicago paper, with what we almost suspect to be an intention to speak disparagingly about New York hotels, says that the young woman who is about to attempt a sixty-day fast in one of them "has picked out a first-class place for such a test." The insinuation, if insinuation there be, can be ignored because the Chicago man's statement is literally true.

BOSTON, Dec. 2. -- The new volume by the author of "Quo Vadis," Henryk Sienkiewicz, is a collection of ten stories, the longest of which, "Hania," gives the book its title, Prefixed to the stories is "The Old Servant," describing a type of man declared by the author to be disappearing from the face of the earth.
CHICAGO, Dec. 3. -- Estimated gross earnings of the Rock Island system for the month of November were $1,644,731, an increase over the estimated earnings of the same month last year of $443,095.

Heaven forefend that with rash hand I should rip open the chronic controversy as to the proper plural of spoonful, et hoc genus omne. At present, and for the present, that controversy is happily slumbering; and I would say, non molestar it can che dorme. It is very sure to wake up ere long and vex us.

Sentiment as well as sound argument has caused the non-Greek theory to pretty generally fail of acceptance. No one likes to believe that the Greek race has passed from the earth, and, believing what they like to believe, scholars have rejected the theory without any particular attempt to rebut its points.

In Paris it seems to be no longer the critic or even the public whose judgment is most courted for a book, painting, sculpture, or play, but the sword or pistol. And the Divine Being is supposed to set everything right with the same wisdom that once tempered His verdict in the trial by fire of the Dark Ages.

In Northern Pacific preferred, in Louisville and Nashville, and in Chicago Great Western there seemed yesterday to be substantial buying for foreign account.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- Fourth-class Postmasters were appointed to-day as follows:

A series of half-hour noon services for business men was begun in St. Paul's Church, at Broadway and Vesey Street, yesterday. The Rev. William Montague Geer, vicar of the parish, will deliver a short address at each service, the remainder of the time being chiefly devoted to the singing of hymns.

HAVANA, Dec. 3. -- Senor Canalejas, the Special Commissioner of the Spanish Government, has returned here from a visit to the Province of Pinar del Rio. He says there are 40,000 "concentradas" (peasants) gathered in from the country in the neighborhood of the towns in order to protect them from the insurgents or prevent them from joining the enemy, and that they are all in want.

PRAGUE, Dec. 3. -- The heavy snowstorm, which has been continuous since last night, has assisted in keeping the people quiet. The streets, cafes, and theatres are almost deserted. No advertisements appear in the newspapers; trade is at a standstill, and it is feared that there will be many failures owing to the losses from rioting.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 3. -- There was excitement in the little village of Cranbury, ten miles from here, yesterday, over the visit of ex-President Grover Cleveland, in search of the game the place afforded. Mr. Cleveland's visit came about by chance. Three weeks ago, Charles J. Cummings of Cranbury, overseer for James C. Robbins, planned a bicycle ride to Princeton.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- The hearing given by the Inter-State Commerce Commission on the question of extending the time within which the railroads of the country may comply with the provisions of the car-coupler and train-brake act was concluded at noon to-day. The commission intends to take some supplemental testimony under oath before coming to a decision.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3. -- Little Margaret Kelly of Goose Island saw a man robbing another this afternoon at the North Halsted Bridge. Instead of running away, the child approached the robber, and taking hold of his coat, remarked:

When old Tony Weller extended his paternal warning to his beloved and susceptible son, to put him on guard against the wiles of widows as a class, the venerable and sagacious whip could have had in mind only such accomplished widows as it had been the fortune of a man of somewhat limited travel to find in the part of Merry England across which he had directed his coach and team.

The art collection and the library of Chantilly will be thrown open to the public next May. The administrators of Chantilly, who are now arranging a general catalogue of the collections, for which the late Duc d'Aumale himself wrote the preface, have just undertaken at the same time a prodigious work.

RIPLEY, West Va., Dec. 3. -- John Morgan, who was to be hanged on Dec. 16, played a sharp trick on the jailer here last night whereby he walked out of jail and took to the woods, where bloodhounds are on his trail.

ALBANY, Dec. 3. -- There will be argued before the Court of Appeals next Monday the appeal of the heirs of Jay Gould from the decision of the New York Surrogate appraising the estate for the purpose of taxation at $78,000,000, and the appeal of the State and the City Controller from a decision exempting $5,000,000 of George J. Gould's share of the estate from taxation.

AUSTIN, Texas, Dec. 3. -- The opening business session of the National Prison Congress was held in this city to-day. Capt. Joseph Nicholson of Detroit, Mich., was detained at home by sickness and First Vice President Edward S. Wright of Michigan presided.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 3. -- Gov. John W. Griggs arrived here this evening from Washington. He was seen a short time after his arrival and was asked what there was in the story sent out from Washington that he was to be the next Attorney General. He would not say the office had been offered to him, neither would he deny that it had.

SCHENECTADY, Dec. 3. -- George R. Blodgett, counsel of the General Electric Company in patent cases and one of the best-known patent lawyers of the country, was shot, and it is thought mortally wounded, by a burglar early this morning. The shooting occurred at Mr. Blodgett's residence, at 11 Front Street, this city.

Commander Julien Viaud of the French Navy, better known by his literary pseudonym of "Pierre Loti," author of "Mon Frere Yves," "Fleurs d'Ennui," "Pecheur d'Island," "Madame Chrysantheme," and "Japoneries d'Automne," is about to retire from the service and devote his whole time to literature.
Here are a few results of Platt management above the Harlem River, where the majorities were all that Mr. PLATT desired:

Edward Boucher, a Belgian, and his French wife, Amelie Giot Boucher, who are accused of having stolen $5,000 worth of diamonds from Mrs. W.S. Hoyt of "The Wayside," Westchester, were held in $5,000 bail each yesterday in the Morrisania Court. Both maintained that they knew nothing whatever about the robbery.

At the school in London which bears his name a bust of Michael Faraday was unveiled a few weeks ago. It stands in Faraday Street, Walworth, and donor and place are commented on as alike appropriate. The bust is the gift of the Royal Institution, with which Faraday's name is inseparably linked; it is placed in a board school in the parish where he was born, in a district comparatively poor.

From some cause not yet explained, a large sugar caldron in the candy factory of D. Auerbach Sons, at 334 and 336 West Thirty-ninth Street, exploded yesterday morning, and six men were severely scalded, one of them receiving injuries which may prove fatal. Two others, although they will not die, will, in all probability, lose their eyesight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- Lieut. Commander John Pillsbury of the Vesuvius, which has been doing some hard work off the Florida Coast engaged in heading off filibustering expeditions, has been annoyed by the publication in the newspapers a few days ago of a story to the effect that he allowed the tug Dauntless to pass with a schooner in tow which carried supplies of war to the Cuban insurgents.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 3. -- Argument was heard before Justices Van Syckel, Dixon, and Collins, in the Supreme Court, to-day, on the application for a writ of certiorari to have the State Board of Canvassers reconvene and declare the anti-gambling amendment to the Constitution defeated. For the applicant, Charles Bott, there appeared ex-Senator Edwards, Allan McDermott, and former Attorney General John P. Stockton.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 3. -- The three-masted schooner Julia S. Bailey, Capt. W.A. Wyman, which left Hyannis Nov. 10, has been given up as lost. To-day it was given out that the schooner Harold L. Berry was in collision with an unknown schooner on the night of Nov. 13, somewhere north of Cape Cod.

Mrs. Johanna Wilkins, who had been married only two months, after seeing a dispossess warrant nailed to the door of her rooms and her unemployel husband discouraged with the battle of life, killed herself with carbolic acid at the Oriental Hotel, Broadway and Fifty-eighth Street, yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- The annual report of the Bureau of Navigation was transmitted to Secretary Gage to-day. Commissioner Chamberlain shows in the report that, as the result of administrative changes and legislation brought about by his bureau in the last four years, an annual continuing gain to the Government of $92,000 has been effected, and a saving in the burdens on shipowners of $81,000.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 3. -- It Is believed that the completion of the Trans-Siberian Railroad, with its terminus at V]adivostock, wilt Increase the trade of San Francisco. and there is talk ef establtshlng a line of steamers to that place, touching at Alaskan n,rts. A local subsidy of $3,000 a month ha already been subscribed for an .laskan line.

Dr. Garnett, Keeper of the Printed Books in the British Museum, has been asked for his opinion of the durability of books printed on paper made from wood pulp. He has observed no alarming signs of decay thus far, and he suggests that twenty years hence will be a better time to determine how well these books will survive.

Prince BISMARCK in his old age and retirement has fallen a victim to yellow journalism. Speaking of the Haitian incident, he declares that it is "a political necessity to oppose this American arrogance often and emphatically, and certainly when directed against Germany." We have not been arrogant or blustering.

Jacob Schaefer gave a fine exhibition of billiards last night in the tournament in the Madison Square Garden Concert Hall, and defeated, by a score of 500 to 401, Frank C. Ives, who only Thursday established a new world's record for the 18-inch balk-line game. The "Young Napoleon" had to contend with a great deal of hard luck, but he also played in miserable form at times.

WATERLOO, Iowa, Dec. 3. -- William Kern has made a confession implicating his sweetheart, Delilah Fales, in the murder of his father, Jerome Kern, and has confessed that he was her willing dupe and accomplice. He says he loved her. He had no particular enmity against his father, save that the latter objected to his attachment to Miss Fales.

Both the Dumas' hands are those of busy men, but the elder Dumas could go on for ever; he never stopped to punctuate. One of his literary canons was that a clear style punctuates itself. There is a good deal in this. The son never misses a comma, semicolon, colon, or full stop. He had not the father's facility, which resembled a tropical vegetation at the end of the rainy season.

The Yukon-Cariboo-British Columbia Gold Mining and Development Company, of which J. Edward Addicks is, or was, President, has changed its offices from the thirteenth floor of the Manhattan Life Building to 1,300 Market Street, Philadelphia.

A noteworthy entertainment in behalf of the Actors' Fund, arranged by Daniel Frohman, was given in the Knickerbocker Theatre yesterday afternoon. The house was crowded, and some of the dramatic performances of which the long bill was principally composed were of unusual merit and interest.

The good sense shown by Germany in reducing to $20,000 the indemnity it demands of Haiti in the Lueders case inclines us to doubt whether the demand that "the President of Haiti shall graciously receive the German Charge d'Affaires at Port au Prince" was authorized from Berlin.
BUFFALO, Dec. 3. -- The jury in the case of Warren Widrig, on trial for the murder of his wife at Springville, Aug. 6, 1897, this morning brought in a verdict of murder in the second degree.

PARIS, Dec. 3. -- According to the official returns, the last vintage amounts to 32,000,000 hectoliters. This is a falling off of 12,000,000 hectoliters from the vintage of 1898 and about 126,000 hectoliters under the average of the previous ten years.

A decision of importance to shoe manufacturers and to dealers in hides and skins was reached yesterday by the Board of Classification of the United States General Appraisers. This board, which comprises General Appraisers Somerville, Ham, and Tichenor, now reverses the ruling of the Collector of this port and declares that calf- skins are entitled to free entry.

VIENNA, Dec. 3. -- Herr Kramarsh, Vice President of the Reichsrath, declares that neither he nor Dr. von Abrahamovies, its President, will resign in the face of mob intimidation. He considers, however, that it will be impossible to carry the Ausgleich (Austro-Hungarian Compromise Bill) in the Reichsrath, and that the present arrangement with Hungary will have to be prolonged by Imperial decree without the assent of the Reichsrath.

The most profound impression which I received in this old, sad, learned town, Bologna, the slumber of whose colonnades is disturbed -- after all, not unsympathetically -- by the boisterous youth, eternally renewed, century after century, of students, was the impression which I received from the Museo Civico.

Something over 300,000 shares were traded in on the Stock Exchange yesterday. There was much manipulative work done. A fifth of the day's business was in Sugar Trust stock. An animated fight between bulls and bears on that stock was waged all day long. At the end of the day a small net advance had been scored.

Dear Sir: With all due respect for your eminent talents and your distinguished position, and with very kind feelings toward yourself, (my own mother being of the same honored name,) there are a few things I would like to say in reply to your sermon of last Sabbath, which seems to me calculated to do more harm than good.

New York contains a number of thousands of crooked people, and many more thousands of nice little girls. The crooked people are of all varieties, from the affable, handsomely dressed men and women who swindle their victims by wholesale to the slouching, murderous, besotted, burly thugs who are always under police supervision.

The art of conversation has suffered in England from the example of its most famous professor. Dr. Johnson understood it theoretically, but even so only to a limited extent. He was supposed to form his view of it in accordance with the rule of Bacon.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 3. -- The report that the Russian Government is buying large quantities of army supplies in the United States has been verified. Cable messages from Vladivostock asking that merchants bid on large lots are received frequently. Yesterday Dodge, Sweeny Co. of this city received a Vladivostock cable to figure on 1,200 tons of supplies.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 3. -- Yale oratory carried an intercollegiate audience by storm here this evening, the home speakers winning the tenth debating contest with Harvard. This is Yale's third victory in the ten years. The winning side to-night had the negative of the question, which was:

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 3. -- Mayor-elect Van Wyck of New York to-day joined the party of Tammany men attracted here by the presence of Richard Croker, and in his train came a long procession of lesser lights until the lobby of Nathan Straus's hotel assumed the appearance of a branch of the Fourteenth Street Wigwam.

At the Garden to-night the racing will be of a high order, judging from the numerous entries and the several special events. The regular schedule provides for the one-mile handicap and the half-mile open for amateurs and the one-third mile handicap and the one-mile open for professionals. In these events the prizes will be up to the League of American Wheelmen limit.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- Commissioner of Indian Affairs W.A. Jones, who is out in the West making a tour of inspection of agencies, has made an investigation that repudiates the reported project of men in Oklahoma, Kansas, and elsewhere to take possession of the Wichita Indian Reservation in Oklahoma and thus force upon Congress the early opening of those lands to white settlement.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 3. -- Dr. Harrison Wagner to-day lost his suit to recover nearly $2,000,000 from the County Commissioners of Frederick County. Judge Morris, in the United States court, before whom the case was tried without a jury, decided that there was no prima facie evidence of the validity of the 11,000 magistrate judgments against the County Commissioners upon which Dr. Wagner had based his claim. A verdict was accordingly rendered for the Commissioners.

The ancients ranked Bacchylides near Pindar, although not on a level with him, and the newly-discovered manuscript confirms this estimate. Though he lacks the strength and energy of Pindar, he is simpler both in language and in meter, and is distinguished for grace and elegance, ease and finish.

It is encouraging to learn from Mr. DINGLEY that the House Committee may report the Torrey Bankruptcy bill, as a substitute for the Nelson bill passed by the Senate, before the holidays. The House would undoubtedly pass the bill, as it has already done twice, and the matter would then go to a conference committee.

Whatever we may think of the project of Cuban autonomy prepared by the Sagasta Ministry, one thing must be conceded; that is, that it is an honest attempt to give to Cuba everything in the way of local self-government that, in the opinion of the most liberal Spaniards, Cuba can reasonably demand.
Mr. DINGLEY'S forecast of the work of Congress at the approaching session is remarkable for what he plainly thinks will not be done.

The crusade against the Bureau of American Republics at Washington for soliciting advertisements from manufacturers and using the franking privilege in canvassing for this business and circulating the publications containing such advertisements, received another impetus yesterday from a meeting of representatives of trade papers held in the rooms of the Merchants' Association.
Jesse C. Bennett Co. have sold for H. E. Woodward to W. K. Aston the three dwellings 520, 522, and 524 West One Hundred and Fortieth Street, 45 by 85 by 100.

Richard Le Gallienne's version of the Rubaiyat of Omar Khayyam is out in England. The critics have fallen foul of it. Recalling Tennyson's tribute to Fitz Gerald's version -- "I know no version done in English more divinely well; a planet equal to the sun, which cast it," The Daily News remarks, "How small and finicking it is compared with Fitz Gerald."

A fine of $350 was imposed on Frank Watlington by Presiding Justice Hayes, in Special Sessions, yesterday morning, for practicing dentistry without a license. The witnesses against Watlington were Gaetano Amato, an agent of the State Dental Society, and Peter Golden, a professional bicyclist.

Michael Hennessey, a young peddler, of 1,200 First Avenue, was at Police Headquarters yesterday, where he made serious charges against Policeman John B. Samson of the East Sixty-seventh Street Station, and told a story of brutality almost incredible.

BOSTON. Dec. 3. -- The famous Somerville case, which has occupied much of Judge McIntyle's time in the Middlesex Probate Court, came up to-day and was finished this afternoon. Decision was reserved. In this case Mrs. Edward H. Lowe brought suit against her husband for the custody of their two children. The couple lived on Rogers Avenue until last Spring, when they separated, selling the furniture and dividing the proceeds.

Mr. Henry Walters has recently presented to the Metropolitan Museum of Art a sliver medal of his father, the famous art collector of Baltimore. The medal was made for and under the direction of the son, by Louis Oscar Roty, a member of the Institute of France, who is recognized as the head of this branch of art.

The Power of Perseverance. -- Sir Henry Cavendish, the younger, with a slight frame and very moderate powers, by mere assiduity made himself the first sailor, skater, billiard player, fiddler, shorthand writer, and master of several other accomplishments of any man in Britain, by taking each in succession.

Martin Thorn, convicted of the murder of William Guldensuppe, was yesterday sentenced by Justice Maddox, in the Queens County Court House, Long Island City, to be killed by electricity in the penitentiary at Sing Sing in the week beginning Jan. 10, 1898. The sentence was generally understood to be only a formality, as its execution will be stayed by notice of appeal, and Thorn cannot be executed before May.

The New York Household Economic Association gave a housewarming yesterday afternoon at its new quarters in the New York Industrial Building. Lexington Avenue and Forty-third Street, and entertained a goodly number of its members and friends.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3. -- Secretary Alger received a telegram this morning in regard to the destitute miners in the Klondike country from M.S. Mason and H.R. Lewis, representing the Portland Chamber of Commerce and the Klondike Relief Committee of that chamber. It reads as follows:

The mind of Christ -- what subject! "Let this mind be in you" -- what a demand! These are the great thoughts brought before us in this lesson. Probably every careful, thoughtful teacher who seriously considers them will be inclined to lay the Book down with the deep consciousness that he cannot teach the lesson, because he never has, and never can, fully comprehend "the mind of Christ."

The ignorant, the needy, and the vicious are organized and consolidated into a political power by party bosses to control the municipal offices and revenue. These bosses are often men of wealth and social position. But they are patriots for revenue only. Like the boy in Eugene Field's jingle who said.
AUSTIN, Texas, Dec. 4. -- The National Prison Association has decided that it will hold its next annual meeting in Indianapolis.

LONDON, Dec. 4. -- The most important theatrical event of the coming week will be the first presentation on Monday at the Duke of York's Theatre of the comedy "The Happy Life," by Louis N. Parker, author of "A Vagabond King," which has had a London run this Fall. The new play will soon be produced at the Lyceum Theatre, New York, by Daniel Frohman.

The Cunard Line steamship Campania and the American Line steamship St. Paul came in Friday night too late to go to their docks, but so close as to excite the suspicion that they may have been in a brush.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4. -- Because she was jealous, without reason, she now says, Mrs. Roy Curry is at the County Hospital with a broken leg and several cuts on her head. She eloped with her husband to Milwaukee a year ago and they were married. Since then she has been very jealous of other women.

MALONE, N.Y., Dec. 4. -- The Saratoga and St. Lawrence Railroad, running north from Moira to Bombay, concerning which proceedings in foreclosure have been pending in the United States court for some time, was sold at public auction in Malone to-day by Congressman James S. Sherman of Utica, the trustee appointed by the court.

CANTON, Ohio, Dec. 4. -- President McKinley took leave of his dying mother this afternoon. The carriage was announced early to convey him to the special car at the Pennsylvania station awaiting the arrival of the regular east-bound train. But to the very last moment the President remained at the old homestead.

PORTLAND, Oregon, Dec. 4. -- The report of the Statistician of the State of Oregon for the current year will show it to have been the most prosperous in the history of the Commonwealth. With 96,000 square miles of territory, Oregon has at the present time less than 400,000 inhabitants. As thickly settled as England, it would give subsistence to over 30,000,000 people.

Though similarity in religious rites and ceremonies, relics of civilization, and numerous traditions would seem to indicate relationship with Asiatic peoples, still there are features in Indian physiognomy and physiological structure, as well as mental and moral characteristics, that essentially distinguish him from every other race.

TRENTON, Dec; 4. -- There is an underground movement among the lawyers of the State to secure the passage of a bill by the incoming Legislature which will prevent Judges of the Court of Errors and Appeals from practicing during the period of their terms. The "elevation" of the absurd lay branch of the Appellate Court has produced a novel complication which has aroused the wrath of many practitioners in different parts of the State.

Within the huge inclosure of Madison square Garden to-night the echoes of the neighboring church bells striking the hour of midnight will hardly have ceased before forty men will have started on what is probably the greatest feat of endurance tested in modern athletic contest. For six whole days, lacking two hours, these men will circle about a wooden track of nine laps to the mile.

A fortnight ago we referred to the exceeding largeness of our imports, especially from the United States, and to the relatively small purchases of our goods by that country. As the subject is of much importance we again refer to it. Were it not that the conditions affecting our trade at the present time are quite abnormal, some alarm would be felt lest our prosperity might not in the near future begin to wane.
There are several phases of the currency-reform problem which would make good food for Sunday reflection to men like Speaker REED, who declare that nothing should be done.

New York is not the same city it was a few years ago. When we stop to think of the number of mammoth buildings, palatial hotels, vast warehouses, and other improvements, the result is simply appalling! New York is growing at a tremendous rate, as the facts amply prove.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 4. -- On Sept. 3, 1896, William Mills Butler, alias Westerfield, was arrested for using the mails to defraud. He had some letterheads lithographed, ostensibly for the Orphans' Home at Rondout, N.Y., with the name of W.S. Bissell, the ex-Postmaster General, in the corner as President. Butler's name appeared as Secretary.

A Columbus Avenue cable car, in charge of Gripman T.E. Barnes of 785 Seventh Avenue, collided with a carriage at Columbus Avenue and Seventy-first Street last night. The two rear wheels of the carriage were torn from under it, and the frightened team ran along Seventy-first Street to Central Park West, where Policeman Higgins and Hans Gerstel of 229 Columbus Avenue stopped the horses.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- Less than half the members of the Senate and less than half the House membership had appeared at the Capitol to-day and left their addresses with the respective Postmasters. The members are postponing their arrival, as if there was no question so interesting as to need discussion by members before going into the two houses.

TRENTON, Dem 4. -- question that is attracting much attention at the present time in New Jersey is the proposition to substitute salaries for fees for Sheriff, County Clerks, and Surrogates. This change of absorbing all fees paid to county officers into the County Treasury will benefit at least one-half of the counties, and decrease the amount of money to be raised by taxation.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 4. -- The charity and interest in well-doing of Lakewood people has been shown this week in the annual meeting of the Lakewood Branch of the Needlework Guild, which was held on Wednesday at Edgemere, the home of Francis P. Freeman. The officers of the branch are as follows: President -- Mrs. E. L. Harding; Vice President -- Mrs. William B. Leeds; Secretary and Treasurer -- Miss Helen Marsh.

George Richards, well remembered as a quaint comedian in certain pieces by Charles H. Hoyt, including "A Hole in the Ground" and "A. Temperance Town," and Eugene Canfield, also associated with many of Hoyt's farces, as the bad boy, the demoniac imp, the clown, in short, who hampered the harlequin in his wooing, and gave dubious assistance to the Pantaloon, are now joint stars.

To the naturalist, and in some cases to the gastronomist, the wild fowl in the London shops are even more interesting than the game. The first rush of duck, teal, and widgeon finds its way to the market at about the end of the first week in October, and from that time till December these three "standard ducks" for the table form the main part of the supply.

The Directors of the Manhattan Elevated Railroad are considering plans for putting down a third track over the entire system of the road, and of building an extra road through West Street to Twenty-third Street, with a line through the latter thoroughfare connecting the east and west divisions, and the same plan is also under consideration by the Rapid Transit Commissioners, with whom the elevated road Directors have had frequent conferences.

A local Swarthmore Association was organized yesterday at a meeting of graduates and old pupils of Swarthmore College, held in the Friends' Meeting House in Rutherfurd Place. There are about 200 alumni of the college in New York and its vicinity, and 65 were at the meeting.

LONDON, Dec. 4. -- The revelations of the "promissory note case," heard before the Lord Chief Justice of England, Lord Russell of Killowen, in the Queen's Bench Division of the High Court of Justice this week, have created a painful impression, and much sympathy is expressed for the Marquis of Abergavenny, whose fourth son, Lord William Nevill, has been brought forward in so unenviable a manner, whereas his father is generally respected.

NO extended review of the theatrical incidents of last week is called for. That awful play entitled "Alexandra," with its dreary wastes of "aside" and soliloquy, its preposterous plot, its wretched setting and bad acting, one is only anxious to forget.

James Hansen went to Staten Island about two months ago with his wife to board at the house of Mrs. John Winmill on Brook Street, New Brighton. On Friday night Hansen's wife deserted him, taking with her $70 in cash, and Hansen says she also attempted to chloroform him, and but for the disturbance of Mrs. Winmill his wife's intentions would have been fulfilled.

Will you kindly help me out of a quandary? I am in receipt of a card advising me that certain ladies would be at home on certain days. Now, as I am not a society man, I would ask whether the ladies mean that they are at home in the afternoon or in the evening, nothing being mentioned on the card but just the day.

"It appears to me the market has a firmer basis for a steady upward movement than at any time since the culmination of the bull campaign in September last, at a moment when there seemed to be no top."

PARIS, Nov. 22. -- That colossal edifice, the Grand Opera House of Paris, which stares with a superior air down the long telescope of the Avenue de l'Opera at its dramatic rival the Theatre Francais, cost 86,000,000 francs, or $17,200,000, to build, and is uninsured! So its manager, M. Gailhard, informed me to-day with an air of importance which the figures justified.

The atmosphere of Chicago is without doubt favorable to large commercial ideas, Mr. CHARLES T. YERKES has inhaled the nutritious gas for many years. That he has found it alimentary and tonic to the imagination is sufficiently proved by his proposal to fill up or roof over the Chicago River and convert its surface into a "boulevard."

Jack Delaney established himself last night at the Polo Athletic Club as a plucky boxer. After having all the worst of a battle with Broderick of Yonkers for twelve rounds, he came backjn the thir4eenth and by his exhibition of gameness gained a draw decision.

NEWPORT, Dec. 4. -- Assurances have been received from Tiverton to the effect that the petitions of the Middletown and Portsmouth Street Railway Company, objected to by Newport cottagers, asking for a franchise to lay a track and operate a trolley road through that town, will be granted at the next meeting of the Town Council.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 4. -- It is reported at the Chamber of Commerce that the Peavey Elevator Companies have made a combine with the Pillsbury Companies and secured control of not only the wheat ill Minneapolis, but all the wheat that is stored in elevators throughout the Northwest.
LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 4. -- Mayor-elect Van Wyck has been the central figure in the great gathering of Democratic politicians here to-day, looming above Richard Croker himself for the time.

READING, Penn., Dec. 4. -- Reading business men believe in newspaper advertising. The general committee having in charge the preparations for the celebration of Reading's one hundred and fiftieth anniversary next June has decided to use the advertising, columns of the newspapers to herald the event.
PARIS, Dec. 4. -- The septuagenarian Marchioness d' Hicquelles committed suicide to-night in a garret in the Rue de Belloy by inhaling charcoal fumes.

BOSTON, Dec. 4. -- The Fall rowing season of the Harvard 'Varsity crew candidates was brought to a close to-day, and with an exciting race between two trial eights which have been practicing for the past month. The race was rowed on the Charles River basin, over the regular two-mile course.

NEWPORT, Dec. 4. -- Opposition to the proposed electric railway running through the island from Fall River has shown itself on the part of the Summer residents, some of whom have personally called upon the officials of the proposed road and explained their ideas of what would be the outcome of the railway and the result of bringing thousands of excursionists to this city during the Summer months.

COYTESVILLE, N.J., Dec. 4. -- If the members of the Congregational Church in this village fail to enjoy peace at their divine services to-morrow, it will be due to no fault of their pastor, the Rev. Solomon W.D. Brown, or of Samuel Kyles, their Senior Trustee, who is also special officer of the village.

Chloral is the most popular hypnotic, but is the one which most frequently gives rise to habit. Clergymen seem to be particularly addicted to the formation of this habit. When I opened the discussion on hypnotics at the British Medical Association last month I was taken to task for saying that chloral was a dangerous drug, yet it was admitted that it was the custom to give digitalis with the chloral.

Graphology is just now all the rage in Paris. Specimens of the handwriting of the unfortunate ex-Capt. Dreyfus have been compared with copies of the traitorous documents said to have been executed by his pen, and the whole city is in a fever of expectancy concerning new developments. In the meanwhile so-called experts in chirography are reaping a golden harvest.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- The Commissioner of Pensions has discovered a queer customer in Tennessee. The Pension Bureau recently received two papers purporting to be the declarations of widows executed before the Rev. Benjamin Parker, and bearing the impress of what appears to be a notary's seal, which reads: "The Rev. Ben. Parker, Notary Public, W.M.C., No. 1, Shelby County, Tenn."

"What do you think of the Greeks now?" is a question often asked me, and it is generally accompanied by a smile. For the Englishman in his heart always believes that might is right, and that a nation which has been defeated by a race nearly twenty times its size must have committed some enormous sin.
STOCKHOLM, Dec. 4. -- It is announced that gold has been discovered in the Mattillavaare Mountain, six miles north of Ofver-Tornea, at the northern end of the Gulf of Bothnia.

THE oft-quoted engraving in a sixteenth century publication of Adam aiming a musket at ducks in a pond in the Garden of Eden is scarcely more of an art solecism than are some of the acknowledged masterpieces of the great painters of the Renaissance.
At the St Nicholas Skating llnk last night the St. Nicholas Hockey Team defeated the Columbia University team by a score of 4 to 0. The iineJup was as follows:

BOSTON, Nov. 4th. -- A large and refined audience of ladies greeted Mrs. Kendall upon the occasion of her second appearance before a Boston assemblage this afternoon. In introducing her lecture the distinguished lady referred to the true position of woman in society, and how her physical condition affects her social and intellectual standing.
"What is the surest sign of high breeding?" was once asked a woman who was eminently qualified to answer such a question.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- Society, and particularly that part of society that includes the families of Cabinet officers, has not yet ceased to be agitated about the disturbance of old customs involved in following the programme for the Winter laid down by Secretary Porter and Col. T.A. Bingham, who are the masters of White House ceremonial affairs.

In a hundred places all over the city when Christmas comes, as many open-air fairs spring suddenly into life. A kind of Gentile Feast of the Tabernacles possesses the tenement districts especially. Green-embowered booths stand in rows at the curb, and the voice of the tin trumpet is heard in the land.
"Which is it, men or women, who are most given to singing?" queried the woman.

Another step toward the consolidation of the two anti-Platt movements among the Republicans of this city was taken last night, when the new Executive Committee appointed by the Brookfield-Swayne organization held its first meeting at 769 Sixth Avenue and created a sub-committee to collaborate with a similar committee already appointed by the Plaza Club protestants in the work of uniting the two movements.

The old guns that are mounted at Forts Hamilton and Wadsworth, at the entrance to New York Harbor, will belch forth no more welcomes to the dignitaries of our own or foreign countries. Their days of usefulness have passed, and they are rapidly being dismounted to make room for the more modern and powerful "peacemakers" adopted by the Government.

The marksmen from Princeton defeated those from Yale at Travers Island yesterday. The marksmen shot at thirty flying targets apiece, and the orange and black won by a margin of 17 birds. Considering the weather the shooting was considered remarkably good.

Prof. Albert S. Bickmore lectured yesterday morning at the American Museum of Natural History on "Northern Italy -- Florence and Venice." It was the last of the Autumn series of lectures that were given under the auspices of the State Department of Public Instruction for the benefit of teachers. it will be repeated next Saturday morning at 10:30.

On the eve of Congress -- and security markets not in a panic. This is not as has been popularly predicted. For weeks and weeks past Wall Street has been scared -- or has professed to be scared -- over direful things to happen as Congress should approach. So far not one of the scheduled evils has shown any sign of an appearance.

George Slosson defeated Frank C. Ives in the final game of the world's championship billiard tournament at the Madison Square Garden Concert Hill last night after one of' the closest games on record. The score was 500 to 498, the "Student" winning out in the forty-first inning with a remarkable run of 60.

THE appointment of John Mackellar as Superintedent of the Brooklyn Police Force puts an end to the talk of political deals which has been heard ever since Superintendent McKelvey's retirement left the office vacant. Mr. Mackellar, though a Republican, has never taken an active part in politics except to vote.
George McAneny, Secretary of the Civil Service Reform Association, made an address yesterday before the League for Political Education on "Present Aspects and Special Needs" of the Civil Service.

PROBABLY the planning of no great building to be erected in the City of New York has been awaited with so general an interest as that of the Public Library, to be placed on the site of the old reservoir on Forty-second Street, Fortieth Street, and Fifth Avenue.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 4. -- Gov. Bradley has given up the idea of appointing a sponsor for the new battleship Kentucky, to be christened next month. Miss Harriet Bainbridge Richardson, who claims that Secretary Herbert invited her to christen the ship, raised such a storm about the head of Kentucky's first Republican Governor that he is all at sea.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- Postmaster Rapier of Mobile, Ala., who refuses to vacate his office in favor of the man appointed to succeed him, will continue to hold office until legal opinion on his rights can be pronounced. Post Office Inspector Tate has been instructed to remain at Mobile to await the action of the department, which referred the matter to the law branch of the Government.

Our football rules, or those to which objection is specially made, are ingenious and cunning, but they lack common sense and intelligence. They tend more and more to eliminate individual effort, and to depend on combinations whose effect shall be irresistible. But what sport is there in being irresistible?

Among the passengers of the Campania, which arrived yesterday morning, was A.A. Chase, the fast English cycle racer, who has come to America to try conclusions with the speediest riders here. He was accompanied by his brother, Fred Chase, who is also a racer, and W.W. Walton, his manager and trainer.

THE two oldest graduates of Yale College now living are still practicing law in this city, although each is in the tenth decade of his life. The senior is Stillman K. Wightman, who was born in Scituate, R.I., Jan. 8, 1803, and is therefore in his ninety-fifth year.

ISHPEMING, Mich., Nov. 27. -- On Monday, Nov. 15, control of the Tilden mine passed from the Tilden Mining Company to the Oliver Mining Company, or from the Rockefeller to the Carnegie management. This transfer has aroused great interest among mining men and manufacturers, and there has been much speculation as to the terms on which the property changed hands.

A Wisconsin jury has awarded $5,000 damages to JULIA L. GREEN in an action brought by her against the Ashland Water Company, in which she charged that the defendant company had caused the death of her husband by furnishing through its pipes impure and unwholesome water containing the germs of typhoid fever.

If the common usage of slang were confined to a particular order of girls, it would, perhaps, serve as an indicator of character and pass unnoticed. It would, at least, not touch the sensibilities of gentlefolk. But it is not so confined. Slang is invading the very nicest of circles: it is beginning to influence the talk of our most carefully reared girls.

THAT this is a women's century seems in nothing to be so strongly emphasized as in the women's clubs. They show more clearly than anything else the wide diversity of women's interests, interests which it is felt need the help of organization to bring them to fruition. They cover too, a startlingly wide range.

The sub-committee of the '98 Centennial Association, under whose auspices the pilgrimage to Ireland next July will be made, met yesterday at the Hotel Netherland. Recorder John W. Goff presided, and others present were W. Bourke Cockran, Judge James A. O'Gorman, Gen. James R. O'Beirne, R.J. Kennedy, Edward O'Flaherty, John B. Kelly, and John Devoy.

When the sturdy athletes of the gallant Seventh Regiment meet on the polished floor of the armory to battle for athletic honors, and incidentally to strive to win the Nesbitt Trophy for their various companies, the big armory in the block bounded by Sixty-sixth and Sixty-seventh Streets and Lexington and Park Avenues is crowded to the limit.

The past week has not been a particularly lively one in the gay world, and, in fact, has served more as a preparation for the first week of the season proper, which opens to-day. There have been several coming-out receptions, two or three entertainments for charity, and several informal dinners and luncheons, but with these exceptions the week has been without particular incident.

Scott, in the journal of his cruise to the Northern Isles, mentions an Orkney clergyman who, when impeached before the General Assembly for drunkenness, admitted that he drank as other gentlemen did. Alvanley might have said the same about his gambling, though there, as in everything else, he drained the cup of dissipation to the dregs.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 4. -- The latest mail from Guatemala conveys the information that President Barrios is threatened with another uprising.

It is said the Californians are born on horseback; it may also be said they are married on horseback. The day the marriage contract is agreed on between the parties, the bridegroom's first care is to buy or borrow the best horse to be found in the vicinity. At the same time he has to get, by one of these means, a silver-mounted bridle and a saddle with embroidered housings.

Yesterday was marked in society by several "coming-out" receptions. Although a drizzling rain fell all day, it only heightened the brilliancy of the scenes within doors, and the attendance at all the receptions was large.

In America editors and reporters are called "newspaper men"; in Paris they are called "journalists." The pseudo-literati here bemoan the fate that we are not journalists. In Paris all sensational news is said to be a la Americaine. These are striking contrasts. Much has been said about American "yellow journalism"; some of the hard things uttered are true; some probably are not.

-- The stories of hardship and famine from Dawson City ought to strike terror to the hearts of all those persons, who, with no knowledge of the region of the Klondike, and with no experience whatever in mining, are ready to start out to face appalling dangers in the search of sudden wealth. But the stories will do nothing of the sort.

On Thursday night Mrs. Thomas Bannon, who lives in East Broadway, Flatbush, ran into the Grant Street Police Station pale and breathlessly reported that she had heard a burglar committing devastation in the basement of her home. Roundsman George W. Knox, Acting Detective Betts, and Patrolman Miller hurried to the house, where Knox took the lead descending the steps.

A small party, gathered in a cozy nook in one of the clubs of this city upon a recent rainy evening, had exhausted the topics of the day and drifted into reminiscent chat and story telling. One of them, with the prefatory remark that the incident he would relate might prove interesting as illustrative of the popular temper at the time and place, proceeded as follows:
The engineers' strike in England is further from settlement than ever, the employers having practically refused to accept any of the substantial claims of the workmen.

Three important cases, recently decided by the Board of Classification of the United States General Appraisers, are to be carried up for final adjudication in the United States courts. Each of the three decisions was against the Government as represented by the Treasury Department, and each case is regarded by the Federal authorities as being of sufficient importance to be settled once for all by the courts.

The object of the new tournament games of billiards that have been devised and introduced for the past decade and more has been to find some form of billiards that would be sufficiently attractive to the public and that would at the same time enable other players to compete upon an equal footing with SCHAEFER and SLOSSON, and during the last few years with IVES.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 4. -- M.H. De Young of The Chronicle has contributed $1,000 to the fund that is being raised to boom this city among intending travelers to Alaska during the coming season. The supine action of merchants in not contributing more than $6,000, after months of the work on the part of the promoters of the fund, is arousing attention.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Dec. 4. -- The State Board of Arbitration has prepared the following circular:

Mayor Wurster's long-repressed indignation over the condition of things in Brooklyn boiled over yesterday, and he gave P.H. Flynn a vigorous opinion on the subject of franchise grabs, appeared through the Corporation Counsel in the injunction suits, and roundly denounced the hold-up of salaries as a disgrace to the city.

One of the most attractive Santa Claus headquarters this year is at the Young Woman's Christian Association, 7 East Fifteenth Street. The salesroom there represents one of those useful institutions commonly known as a woman's exchange.

LONDON, Dec. 4. -- The fact that the engineers' conference has ended in a fiasco has occasioned no surprise, though it is much regretted. The extreme gravity of the situation cannot be overestimated. The address in which the delegates of the strikers submit the results to the members of the unions is most discouraging.

The Chinese are getting some practical illustrations of what the Christian civilization is which missionaries implore them to embrace. They will naturally judge the Christian religion rather by the results they see it to have achieved in those countries in which it has been established for nearly twenty centuries than by what the wandering preachers tell them about it.

DULUTH, Dec. 4. -- It developed here today that P.D. Armour and other Eastern exporters have been buying wheat in this market for immediate shipment, and that they are still in the market for as much as they can hope to get to Eastern ports before navigation closes. Armour is now loading one purchase of 500,000 bushels, which will be cleared out of here by Monday.

DETROIT, Dec. 4. -- Two suburban cars carrying some twenty passengers and both running at a speed of twenty-five miles an hour, collided on the Detroit and Oakland Electric Railroad at 1 o'clock this afternoon. The result was that three men were instantly killed and a score of persons injured, ten of them seriously.

A curious land claim of the Missouri, Kansas and Texas Railway is causing much trouble to the commission appointed by Congress to bestow the rights of citizenship upon the members of the "five civilized tribes" of Indians, and to bring about a fair allotment of tribal property among the individual Indians.

Allow me to take exception to your editorial in to-day's issue of your valuable paper, entitled "Mr. McKinley's Pastor." In it you seem to assume that it was perfectly just and proper, nay, perhaps praiseworthy, in the Rev. Mr. Johnson's attacking and vilifying Jesuitism and Jesuits. I would like to know why.

At the Orthodox Friends' Meeting House, in East Twentieth Street, there is to occur on the morning of Dec. 15, a ceremony such as has not occurred in New York in half a century, it is said. It will be a wedding, at which the ceremony will be that of the Society of Friends in the time of George Fox, Jonathan Evans, and Lucretia Mott.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- However meritorious the scheme for the reorganization of the naval personnel may be, and at the Navy Department it is the preponderant opinion that it is highly meritorious, the intimation of its scope and the expense that inevitably must be caused by it, in increasing the permanent salary list, will make it difficult to get it through the Congress this session.

PARIS, Nov. 15. -- Speaking of art, there is considerably more of it in this town than you find in the Louvre or the Luxembourg. You run across it in the most unexpected places. Sometimes to your joy and again to your sorrow. Cabby and the concierge and the garcon are all artists when it comes to wheedling tips -- the masons in cutting building stones, the glaziers in erecting glass canopies.
Ex-President Bartlett of Dartmouth College, at a public reception given him at Hanover, N.H., in honor of his eightieth birthday, thus responded to a call for remarks:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4. -- Assistant Secretary of the Interior Davis has made a decision in a dependent widow's case which, while in line with some former decisions on this subject, is of especial importance as emphasizing a policy affecting a large class of claimants. Many widows are applying for pensions who already have large property interests and consequently large incomes.

A number of students of the College of Dentistry and others assembled in the lecture room of the college yesterday afternoon to hear readings, recitations, and an address by Dr. Gardner Q. Colton. The doctor is more than eighty years old, and his first reading was on "How to Reach Eighty Years of Age."

Fifty alumnae and friends of Elmira College held a special business meeting yesterday at the home of Mrs. Charles C. Pope, 310 East Fifteenth Street, and appointed a committee of seventeen to procure the remainder of a $100,000 endowment fund which is being raised. The sum already raised amounts to $66,666.66, and the remainder is expected to be secured in this city.

There were several of the Wells-Fargo Express men at the Grunewald last night, including M.G.A. Taft of Houston, manager of the company for this district. Mr. Taft has been shut out by quarantine, and has not been here for some three months. He said that the restrictions had destroyed the business of the company out of Houston in all directions, and that they had lost many thousands of dollars.

PROVIDENCE, Dec. 4. -- Benjamin H. Child and Edward C. Huxley, were this morning appointed permanent receivers of the Kent Stanley Company, Limited, manufacturing jewelers of this city and New York, upon the petition to the Supreme Court of the Rhode Island National Bank, a creditor for $32,330. At the hearing to-day it was said that the company owed $1,800,000, and was hopelessly insolvent.

Adolph Neuendorf, for many years well known to the music-loving public of this city as a musical conductor and musician, died early yesterday morning at his home, 219 East Eighteenth Street, after a lingering and painful illness, of a complication of kidney and heart troubles aged fifty-four years.

SAN GABRIEL, Cal., Nov. 22. -- The first rain in six months has reached Southern California, and the byways, mesas, and hillsides are daily changing from the brown and gray tints which have mantled them during the Summer to the delicate green which is the sign of Winter in this climatic paradox.

His name was Gobbles, and it really was not his fault that he was taken for a baby. It was in the bridge car, and the man's hoary locks betokened that he had arrived at those years of wisdom when if he kept his seat in a crowded car no one would complain. But a woman with a baby! That is quite another matter.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 4. -- The fifty days' limit of the Georgia Legislature will soon be reached. There have been a number of sensations on the floors of the two houses, but the first real humorous incident of the session occurred yesterday, when a resolution was passed unanimously in the House thanking the only paper in Georgia which has spoken a word of praise for the lawmakers and the work they have accomplished.

LONDON, Dec. 4. -- All at once people have lost faith in the familiar "say so" of old. It has almost become an adage that the Austrian Empire would last as long as the present Emperor does. Only few months ago Franz Josef was busy and pleased with plans for the celebration of his jubilee next December.

It would be quite wrong to conclude that the crystal sphere is discredited among the faithful. Large numbers are sold every year -- few, by comparison, with the parchment talismans, of course, and for excellent reasons; in the first place, the parchment worn next the skin requires periodical renewal; in the next, the crystal ball will last forever, and is moreover, expensive.

The New York Press Club celebrated the twenty-fifth anniversary of its existence with a dinner in the grand banquet hall of the Waldorf-Astoria last night, and in honor of the occasion several prominent men occupied the elevated table reserved for guests of the club, while nearly 300 women filled the boxes and gallery above the banquet hall.

The severe sentences that have been imposed within the last fortnight on men convicted of election frauds are a most gratifying proof that there are some Judges who have a just sense of the enormity of this offense. There has been a far too great disposition to look upon these common election frauds as trifling matters not calling for much attention unless done on a large scale for a concerted purpose.

WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 4. -- Howard H. Morse, counsel for John D. and William Rockefeller, made application to-day to Justice J.O. Dykman, holding a Special Term of the Supreme Court, for a writ of certiorari to review in the Supreme Court the action of the Assessors of the town of Mount Pleasant, Westchester County, in regard to the valuation of the Rockefellers' property.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4. -- Well-informed officials of charity organizations state that they expect a decrease of about 50 per cent. in the demand for relief this Winter, as Compared with the last one. The revival of trade and the systematic work done by the organized charities are the causes. During the Summer every man who could show that he had a good chance of securing work elsewhere was given transportation for himself and family.

INTEREST in the subject of mycology is constantly on the increase. There are three sides to the study of mushrooms which may appeal to three widely different classes of people, though the true mycologist is fascinated by all. The first is the practical side, which attracts perhaps the greater number of people -- the mycophagists, the eaters of mushrooms; and the second and third are, respectively, the scientific and art sides.

The challenges sent by the track team of Columbia to Cornell, Princeton, and Brown have all been accepted. The meeting with Brown will take place in Providence during the first week in May; that with Cornell in New York during the second week in May, and that with Princeton in Princeton during the third week in May.
Miss Irwin was on her knees before the fire taking critical observations of the lighted gas log in the grate.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 5. -- That the State of Iowa is more prosperous than at any former period of its history is indicated by the consolidated report of the State and savings banks, which has just been issued by State Auditor McCarthy. It indicates that an increase of 10 per cent. was made in deposits in the three months and five days ending Oct. 5.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5. -- The leading physicians of Chicago are by no means agreed as to the utility of the measures recently adopted by the Board of Health of New York for stamping out pulmonary tuberculosis. Some regard the appropriation of $60,000 for this purpose as promising no success, while the majority speak of it as the beginning of the brightest era in medicine.
Dr. Maurice H. Harris, in the Temple Israel, of Harlem, on Saturday replied to Dr. Savage's sermon of the previous Sunday upon the "God of the Old Testament."

The trades unions in the large territory that will comprise the Greater New York next month have been worrying themselves to arrive at some understanding as to wages and hours of labor. In most trades the men in New York get the highest wages on account of the higher cost of living and of rents; and then next comes Brooklyn.

MANCHESTER, Dec. 5. -- There was a fairly good aggregate business last week, but it is considered smaller than the average week's output. The manufacturers did not share evenly in the orders, and some, who are still looking for business, accepted very low bids.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 5. -- The Tammany politicians gathered here made a new record as observers of the American Sunday to-day. Had they been delegates to a Methodist conference they could hardly have proved more faithful church-goers.

Bishop Peter T. Rowe of the Protestant Episcopal missionary district of Alaska has a territory under his jurisdiction covering an area of 570,000 square miles. In his second annual report, which he has just transmitted to the Board of Managers of the Domestic and Foreign Missionary Society of the Protestant Episcopal Church, Bishop Rowe says that he traveled 21,000 miles during the last year in attending to the duties connected with his work.

The name of David M. Koehler is to be presented to Mayor Van Wyck as the candidate of the Wholesale Liquor Dealers' Association for a place on the new Police Commission. Mr. Koehler has consented to allow his friends in the trade to push his claims upon the new administration, and they are confident that these claims will be recognized.

Harry Walsh, the two-year-old son of Mrs. Mary Walsh, was fatally burned by the explosion of a kerosene lamp in his mother's apartments on the third floor of 150 North Ninth Street, Williamsburg, last night. Mrs. Walsh was also severely burned, and at a late hour was in a critical condition at the Eastern District Hospital.

BERLIN, Dec. 5. -- When the German reinforcements, consisting of four companies of marines, numbering twenty-three officers and 1,200 men, and a company of naval artillery, numbering 200 men, arrived at Kiao-Chau Bay, for which point, as already cabled, they will soon set out, they will bring the total German force there up to 4,566 men, the largest body Germany has ever sent beyond European waters.

Some bright and fresh, and others dull and drowsy from being awakened from a sound sleep in their training tents, but all in as fine condition of muscle and nerve as days of hard preparation could make them, the squad of cycle racers who will endeavor to earn the big prizes offered began the six days' cycle race at Madison Square Garden shortly after midnight.

If the President's message is other than an encouraging document, Wall Street will be greatly surprised. Wall Street is persuaded that it has the very best authority for expecting inspiriting Presidential utterances.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- Surgeon General Wyman of the Marine Hospital Service has submitted his annual report to Secretary Gage. It shows that during the fiscal year ended June 30, 1897, the total number of patients treated at the hospitals and the dispensaries connected with the service was 54,477.

There were two Sunday night popular concerts last night, and the result was that people did not know to which one they preferred to go. So neither had a full house, but there were plenty of encores just the same. At Carnegie Hall Mme. Sembrich gave a concert and had three other soloists and an orchestra to help her. The soloists were David Bispham, the baritone; W.H. Lapin, tenor, and Jessie Shay, pianist.

Richard Croker made a sweeping denial yesterday of the several stories that he was interfering in various Assembly districts to have certain leaders turned down and others set up by the coming primaries.

Another buglary scare in Washington Park, Brooklyn, only three doors from the home of Mrs. Courtney, the daughter of Hugh McLaughlin, who was robbed of a case of valuable jewelry a short time ago, was caused last night. As a result there was great excitement in the neighborhood, a big crowd collected, and a large part of the Brooklyn police force was requisitioned.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 5. -- The proposed combination of wire, wire nail, and steel rod interests has advanced to the point where the concerns interested have decided to go in, and all that remains to be done is to reach an agreement on the value of the different mills. Daily conferences are being held in New York, and Cleveland manufacturers are in constant communication with the seat of activity.

The Federal Constitution confers on Congress the power to establish uniform laws on the subject of bankruptcies throughout the United States. The power has been exercised to so little purpose that the combined life of the three National bankruptcy statutes, passed since the adoption of the Constitution, has been but seventeen years.

The Saturday Review of London is making a furious but a very solid attack on the Indian policy of the Government. In its latest number, Nov. 27, it departs so far from its custom to review news and not to publish it as to reprint in full a most able speech of Sir HENRY FOWLER in criticism of the "Forward Policy."

A bold case of highway robbery, in which the robbers secured a booty of two strings of prayer beads and some candy from their dazed and trembling victims, took place shortly after 3 P.M. yesterday in Central Park. The leader of the robber gang, Benjamin Feinstein of 223 East Eighty-second Street, was captured by Park Policeman Sullivan after a hard and exciting chase through the wilds of the Park.

A young lady who lives in the wilds of New Jersey, who had had an attack of the grip and needed something cheering, received an invitation from a young lady of Cambridge to come and spend a couple of days with her; and as the Jersey young lady was coming to Boston anyway, she accepted the invitation with pleasure.

Burglars paid a visit to the Bennett mansion, at One Hundred and Fifty-fifth Street and Fort Washington Avenue, the city home of James Gordon Bennett, on Saturday night and plundered it of considerable property. Two men were arrested early yesterday morning on suspicion of being the burglars. They are William Ryan and Andrew Cunningham, who described themselves as homeless and of no occupation.

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Dec. 5. -- William Lawlor, an old-time resident of this place, was found dead in the woods near the Bloomingdale Asylum this morning. It is thought he was waylaid and murdered. Lawlor was a stonemason, and the shortest route from where he was working to his home lay through the Bloomingdale woods.

LONDON, Dec. 5. -- A new Sunday newspaper, the Sunday Special, this morning publishes a dispatch from Paris which gives what is alleged to be the story of the promotion of the defense of Dreyfus. According to this story, a Frenchman named Vignaud left Paris a year ago for Madrid, whither he went to endeavor to secure the influence of the Queen Regent in favor of Dreyfus.

MADRID, Dec. 5. -- El Liberal, the official organ, contends to-day that there is no ground to fear that the United States will recognize the insurgents as belligerents or otherwise interfere in the settlement of the Cuban difficulty, inasmuch as Spain has accorded her colonies in the Antilles the maximum of liberty that other powers accord their colonies.
CANTON, Ohio, Dec. 5. -- Mrs. Nancy Allison McKinley, the President's mother, is alive, but her condition is such that she may die any minute. She grows weaker every hour.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- The annual report of James H. Eckels, Controller of the Currency, for the year ended Oct. 31, 1897, opens with a brief review of the history of the legislation which constitutes the present National Bank act, and invites the attention of Congress to amendments to the law recommended in former reports without specifically repeating them.

I have read with great interest in THE TIMES of Friday the abstract of the lecture by the Rev. Dr. Potter on "Washington as a Churchman and a Communicant." The facts relating to this aspect of the life and character of the Father of His Country are so well established as to be beyond all question.

SING SING, Dec. 5. -- Martin Thorn is pleased with his quarters in the State prison here. He told the guards this morning that it was much pleasanter here than in the Queens County Jail and he thought the treatment was much better. He went to bed last night at 9 o'clock and slept without waking until 7 o'clock this morning.

ROME, Dec. 5. -- Gen. Pelloux, Minister of War, maintains the attitude he has taken up in consequence of the action of Parliament in amending the bill dealing with army promotions against his advice, and persists in his resignation.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5. -- Chicago's bank clearings for November reached the aggregate of $458,000,000, the highest in four years and a half. No month has had such an aggregate since May, 1893, when the clearings amounted to $461,000,000.

A mountain railway constructed on a novel plan is shortly to be opened on the Hochstauffen, near Bad Reichenhali, Bavaria. The chief feature of the new system is that the force of traction is directed vertically upward, being derived from a balloon. The latter has a diameter of 66 feet and a lifting power of 10,560 pounds.

" The Ethical Culture Society as the Meeting Ground of Jew and Gentile" was the subject of Prof. Felix Adler's address before the Society for Ethical Culture at Carnegie Music Hall yesterday. The audience was large and evinced great interest in the theme discussed by the speaker.

After a short absence the Rev. Dr. R. Heber Newton returned to his pulpit at All Souls' Protestant Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, yesterday morning, where a large congregation greeted him. He took his text from the Sermon on the Mount, "Ask and it shall be given you; seek, and ye shall find; knock, and it shall be opened unto you."

COYTESVILLE, N.J., Dec. 5. -- As was expected, the "disturbing element" in the Congregational Church in this place asserted itself in the most emphatic manner at the morning service to-day. As a result of the struggle which ensued between the two factions, the pastor, the Rev. Solomon W.D. Brown, and the Senior Trustee, Samuel Kyles, were arrested.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- There are many newly arrived members of both houses about town to-night, and there is much talk among them of the Congress that is to meet to-morrow. The uppermost topic is "a short session," and Republican Senators and Representatives appear to be agreed that all the work that should be done can be completed long before the usual date of the adjournment of the long session.

DR. MAX NORDAU dedicated his perfectly worthless work on "Degeneracy" to his "dear and honored master," CAESARE LOMBROSO. It is to LOMBROSO that the whole ruck of half-baked writers on "criminology" look up in reverence as the founder of that school of neo-charlatanry in which their credulous minds have been trained to formulate hop-skip-and-jump conclusions from snapshot observation of unauthenticated facts.
The Rev. Dr. Savage, in the Church of the Messiah, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, yesterday morning preached a sermon on "Are There Any Creeds Which It Is Wicked for Us to Question?"

Fire last night destroyed the five-story brownstone building 148 Duane Street, causing a loss of $100,000 to stock and $20,000 to the premises. The building was occupied on the ground floor by Julius Wile, Brother Co., liquor dealers, whose damage was mostly by water. Rice Bothers Tiffany, manufacturers of Young's perfumery, occupied the second floor.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 5. -- Toru Hoshi, Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary from Japan to the United States, was a passenger from the Orient on the steamer City of Peking. He left to-night for Washington, carrying with him important instructions in reference to the Hawaiian treaty of annexation, which will be considered by the United States Senate.

LONDON, Dec. 5. -- Money last week was scarce, and rates were firm, and the prospect is of further hardening. Business on the Stock Exchange was slack, but the tendency was better and there were indications of a revival, of the speculative spirit.

JAMAICA, L.I., Dec. 5. -- The decision given by Justice Garrettson yesterday quashing his own writ of mandamus is considered by lawyers to be of considerable importance. He took the step on the ground that the Court had no power under the law to order the Boards of Election to open the ballot boxes and recount the votes.

The gunboat Newport sailed yesterday from the Brooklyn Navy Yard on its way to Nicaragua with the Nicaraguan Commission, of which Rear Admiral J.G. Walker, retired, is the head. The members of the commission are Admiral Walker, Col. D.C. Hains, United States Engineer Corps, and Prof. Louis Haupt.

Although the interest of the people of New York has been sufficiently great to bring the project for carrying out a real scheme for rapid transit to the point where it now depends solely upon the decision of the court as to whether or not the city may lend its credit for the purpose, there is still the most dense ignorance on the part of thousands of our citizens concerning what the plan really is.

The buckle of Policeman Max Neumaier's belt probably saved his life last night, as a bullet fired at him while he was about to arrest an offender lodged in the buckle and staid there after passing through a door.

The Pastime Athletic Club's football eleven of this city defeated the Central Field Club of William's Bridge at Wallace's Ridgewood Park, L.I., yesterday by a score of 16 to 0. Next Sunday the Pastimes will line up against the Wadsworth Athletic Club team. The teams lined up as follows yesterday:

Magistrate Mott was amused yesterday in the Jefferson Market Police Court when he gazed on the complexion of two elderly prisoners who were arraigned before him charged with intoxication. The court officers also enjoyed a laugh at the expense of the aged Magistrate when the latter got mixed up and thought the second prisoner was the man upon whom he had but a few minutes before imposed a fine of $3.

I have read with interest the letters which from time to time have appeared in your columns in regard to the slaughter of birds for their feathers and the various suggestions for the prevention of the same.

The announcement that Messrs. Thomson and Campbell would sell at the Mart, Tokenhouseyard yesterday afternoon the well-known yacht White Ladye drew a large company, which, however, included but few intending buyers, and indeed the actual bidding was confined to three gentlemen -- Mr. Bailey of the firm of Messrs. Bailey Leeson, Mr. Nicholson of Messrs. Camper Nicholson, and Mr. J. Lawson Johnston of Kingswood, Sydenham Hill, who recently purchased the Britannia.

Central Office detectives yesterday arraigned in the Centre Street Police Court, before Magistrate Meade, two respectable-looking, well-dressed men, charging them with an attempt to blackmail Senor Dos Eugenio de Faria Teixeira, a rich Brazilian, who is living in a handsome house he has built at One Hundred and Fifth Street and West End Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- The long session of the Fifty-fifth Congress will open at noon to-morrow. On account of the extra session the opening of the regular session will be devoid of the excitement and interest which usually attaches to such an opening. On the eve of a regular session ordinarily, Washington thrills with excitement.

It was reported yesterday that the Tammany leaders who are resting at Lakewood have decided that the proposed rapid transit system will have to be abandoned. They determined, according to reports, that the present borrowing limit of New York is $50,000,000, and that when the indebtedness of Brooklyn and the other boroughs is added in January the new city will have a limit of only $16,000,000 within which to borrow and contract debts.
HAVANA, Dec. 6. -- La Lucha, in its leading editorial to-day, says:
Late, but frankly, a Republican President acknowledges that the Republican financial legislation of the last thirty-five years is unsound, unsafe, and ought to be reformed altogether.

TRENTON, Dec. 6. -- Until the official announcement came from Washington, the politicians here did not believe that Gov. Griggs had been selected to succeed Attorney General McKenna. When they found that it was a fact there was a flutter at the State House. There is expected to be a big gathering of Senators and Assemblymen here to-morrow.

BERLIN, Dec. 6. -- A dispatch to the Kolnische Zeitung from Prague says that during the riots there a battalion of infantry composed of Czechs enlisted from the locality refused to obey orders and received the rioting crowds with fierce national cries.

BUDAPEST, Dec. 6. -- In the lower house of the Hungarian Parliament to-day a bill was introduced by Baron Banffy, the Premier, prolonging for a year the Ausgleich, or compact between Hungary and Austria proper, without reference to any action on the same subject on the part of the Austrian Government.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 6. -- Burglars have held high carnival in Providence during the last thirty hours. The police say that the town has been overrun with criminals, suspects, and "hoboes" since the Boston police have been engaged in a vigorous campaign against them, giving them no quarter.

The Brooklyn Board of Aldermen met yesterday afternoon, and Mr. Hennessy promptly moved to adjourn. Alderman Wafer objected, saying that he desired to submit the offer of the Mutual Gas and Electric Light Company to pay the city $250,000 for a franchise. Alderman Leich moved to table the motion to adjourn.

VINELAND, N.J., Dec. 6. -- Justice Bray this evening caused the arrest of Walter Worden, the son of a prominent business man, and of John Campbell, also a well-known young man, charged with fighting in a ring on Sunday. The Justice announced that he would issue warrants for the arrest of all the witnesses of the alleged fight who do not appear and plead guilty.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 6. -- Editor Rousseau of The Osceola Times is a refugee from Mississippi County for fear of being killed by Sheriff Bowen. Rousseau editorially condemned the mob which recently lynched a negro in that county, and denounced the Sheriff in a most scathing manner, charging him with having been a party to the lynching.

The case of Sarah Ann Angell against the estate of Jay Gould was brought to an end yesterday when a jury in the Supreme Court declared a verdict against the plaintiff. From the nature of the testimony taken yesterday before Justice Freedman there is hardly any probability that the claim of Mrs. Angell will ever be heard of again.
PATERSON, Dec. 6. -- Gov. Griggs at his office to-day discussed his selection to be Attorney General in President McKinley's Cabinet. He said:

CANTON, Ohio, Dec. 6. -- At 10:30 o'clock to-night Mrs. McKinley is exceedingly low. She has just experienced a sinking spell, during which life seemed to be almost extinct. There were moments when she did not seem to breathe. If she rallies from this spell she will probably survive the night, but just now it seems doubtful that she will rally.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 6. -- The committee of the Naval Board of the Schuylkill Navy having in charge the candidacy of Gordon S.
