Carrigan, Commodore of the navy, for membership on the Executive Committee of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen, made its report to-night to the Naval Board, in which Secretary Fortmyer of the National association was charged with the responsibility of Mr. Carrigan's defeat.

With the whirring of chains and the rumble of the board track beneath them beating a ceaseless refrain relieved only by the monotonous "chugg, chugg" of the counters at the Fourth avenue turn, the riders in the six-day bicycle race have been building the greatest record ever noted in such a contest. The runs made by fast racing men in previous six-day contests were exceeded from the first hour on.

A gang of ruffians who infest the neighborhood of Orchard and Ludlow Streets yesterday made a raid upon the headquarters of the Brotherhood of Tailors, at 104 Orchard Street, a little before noon. Blows were struck, hair and whiskers were pulled, and chairs were broken. Several men were badly injured before the police could be informed, and when the bluecoats were on the way the ruffians vanished.
Permit me to say a few words in reference to your editorial of to-day entitled, "The Truth About Rapid Transit."

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment took up the final estimates again at a meeting in the Mayor's office yesterday morning. Col. Asa Bird Gardiner was present, while the District Attorney's office estimate was considered. A large number of men and women interested in the estimate for public libraries was also in attendance.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- Attorney General McKenna, in his annual report to Congress, publishes a report of ex-Gov. George Hoadly, special counsel of the United States in the Pacific railroad cases, in which is set forth a history of the foreclosure suits which resulted in the sale of the Union Pacific to the Reorganization Committee, and the postponement of the Kansas Pacific sale until Dec. 15.
Patrolman Herman Gerow of the Macdougal Street Police Station was arrested when he appeared for roll call at 6 o'clock last evening by Police Inspector Grant on a charge of perjury.

American shares were irregular in the London market. The principal changes were: Advanced -- St. Paul, 1/2, to 97; Reading, 1/4, to 11 1/4; Atchison, 1/8, to 13 1/4, and Louisville and Nashville, 1/8, to 56 3/4. Declined -- Illinois Central, 1/4, to 105 1/4, and Erie first preferred, 1/8, to 37 1/4. Canadian Pacific sold at 82 5/8, New York Central at 110 1/4, and Erie at 15.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- The establishment and regulation of a postal savings bank system is provided for in a bill introduced to-day by Representative Lorimer (Illinois.) Under his scheme, money-order offices selected by the Postmaster General are to be made branch postal savings banks, with an office in the department to be called the Central Bank.

The Society of Musical Arts gave its inaugural entertainment in the grand ballroom at the Astoria last evening under auspices as propitious as its most sanguine promoters could well desire. The audience was large, practically all the seats on the main floor being occupied, and none of the boxes remaining empty, and it was fashionable, in the representative sense of the word.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- A new counterfeit two-dollar Treasury note has been discovered. It is of the series of 1891, check letter B, Tillman, Register, and Morgan Treasurer. The note is printed by the photomechanical process, and is of fair workmanship and on good paper. In the portrait of McPherson the nostrils and lower end of nose are covered by an ink blur and the epaulettes are formed poorly.
CONGRATULATIONS ON HOME AND FOREIGN RELATIONS.

BOSTON, Dec. 6. -- United States District Attorney Jones has issued instructions that the papers in the case of Albert King, former messenger of the Boylston National Bank, who is under indictment on a charge of embezzlement, be filed upon his entering a plea of guilty and the payment of the costs.

PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti, Dec. 6. -- The trouble between Germany and Haiti, as a result of the alleged illegal arrest and imprisonment of Herr Lueders, a German subject, reached a crisis to-day. Two German cruisers entered this port during the morning and an ultimatum from the German Government was delivered to the Haitian Government, giving the latter eight hours in which to grant the demands of Germany for an indemnity to Herr Lueders.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- Secretary Gage to- day transmitted to Congress the estimates of appropriations required for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1899, as furnished by the several executive departments. The total amount called for is $462,647,885, which is about $32,000,000 in excess of the appropriations for 1898, including deficiencies and miscellaneous, and about $41,000,000 more than the estimates for 1898. The recapitulation by titles is as follows, cents omitted:
BERLIN, Dec. 6. -- The Reichstag to-day began the debate upon the first reading of the Government's Naval bill. The Imperial Chancellor, Prince Hohenlohe, made a statement on the subject, saying:
LONDON, Dec. 7. -- The Daily Telegraph, commenting editorially on President McKinley's message this morning, says:

If Mayor Strong's ideas are carried into execution, the passing out of existence of the old City of New York will be signalized by a solemn service in the Metropolitan Opera House on the last night of the year.

A knockabout farce, with songs,"My Boys", was brought in from the agricultural regions over Sunday, and was put on exhibition at tile Manhattan Theatre last night. George Richards appeared in it as pantaloon to the clown of Eugene Canfield.The dialogue hasd been written by William Gill.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- At noon to-day the first regular session of the Fifty-fifth Congress was begun. Simultaneously at both ends of the Capitol Speaker Reed in the House and Vice President Hobart in the Senate dropped their gavels and called to order the respective bodies over which they preside.

Nearly 400 members and guests attended the sixty-second annual dinner of the St. Nicholas Society, given last night at the new Delmonico's. All the traditional forms of the society were maintained. The banquet hall was decorated with streamers of orange bunting festooned from its four corners to the central chandelier, and the arms of the society supported by the Dutch and National flags hung from the wall behind the President's table.

Slawson Hobbs have sold, for Miss Sophia Furniss, Miss Clementine Furniss, and Mrs. Margaret Zimmerman, to David E. Oppenheimer and Joseph Hamershlag, the block bounded by the Boulevard, West End Avenue, One Hundred and Second and One Hundred and Third Streets, with the exception of the plot 100 by 100.11 at the southwest corner of West End Avenue and One Hundred and Third Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- The delegation of native Hawaiians who have come to this country to present a protest against the ratification of the annexation treaty reached Washington to-day. They are Col. John Richardson, James H. Kaulia, William Auld, and D. Kalaukalani.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Dec. 6. -- For some time past has been an open secret that as soon as the yellow fever and quarantine fights were over, there would be a united attack upon the Board of Health. The commercial community has blamed that body for letting the fever into New Orleans, for failing to stamp it out sooner, and for all the consequent ills.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- Secretary Alger to-day made public the reprimand administered to Capt. Lovering by sentence of court-martial as follows:

With a broken arm and severe scalp wounds John McKeown of 364 West Eighteenth Street lay lay beside the cable tracks at Lexington Avenue and Sixty-seventh Street yesterday afternoon holding tenderly in his right hand a canary bird. He had started to cross the tracks with his little feathered friend when he was struck by a car and hurled several feet.

Behind the ancient and what nowadays seems the rather childish blockade of arrangement, the Mercantile Library languishes. One is obliged to fool away so much time in trudging forth and tramping back for the exchange of a single book that 99 out of every 100 adult readers forego altogether the great privilege of using this magnificent collection of books.

Behind the ancient and what nowadays seems the rather childish blockade of arrangement, the Mercantile Library languishes. One is obliged to fool away so much time in trudging forth and tramping back for the exchange of a single book that 99 out of every 100 adult readers forego altogether the great privilege of using this magnificent collection of books.

LONDON, Dec. 6. -- A banquet was tendered Lieut. Peary, the Arctic explorer, this evening by the Geographical Club, Sir Clements R. Markham, President of the Royal Geographical Society, presiding. Afterward Mr. Peary lectured in the theatre of the University of London, under the auspices of the Royal Geographical Society. A large audience received him and Mrs. Peary with the heartiest applause.

CANTON, Ga., Dec. 6. -- A startling instance of prudence tempering religious enthusiasm is disclosed by the sale yesterday of the whisky distillery of J.W. Carmichael, whose product has been very popular hitherto throughout this section. Mr. Carmichael last September was a constant attendant at the revivals led by the Rev. Sam Jones.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 6. -- The first performance of Recina's "Athalie," under the auspices of the French Department of Harvard, was given in Sanders' Theatre this evening, before Gov. Wolcott, a large number of college presidents and professors, a number of Harvard faculty, and very many of the society people of Boston and Cambridge.

ALBANY, Dec. 6. -- Employes and officials of the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad at the investigation which was pursued by the Board of Railroad Commissioners to-day on the causes of the disastrous wreck on that road at Garrison's on Oct. 24, advanced an entirely new theory as to the cause of the wreck, which was to the effect that obstructions had been placed on the track to purposely wreck the train.

Wrapped in gloom and gunny sacks, the Oriental crew of the British tramp Wennington Hall, burrowed into the cinder heaps of the fireroom yesterday to keep warm. Everybody aboard the Wennington Hall was miserable. Matters were even worse than appeared from the report made on her arrival Sunday.

William H. Earl, thirty years old, of 2,794 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, shot himself through the head, yesterday, in Mrs. Minnie Lawrence's flat, at 1,265 Fulton Street. He is now dying, in St. Mary's Hospital The shooting marks the probable end of a life which for two years has been wayward and the cause of great grief to Earl's family and friends.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- Following are the comments of prominent members of Congress upon the President's message:

A daring burglary took place early yesterday morning in the delicatessen store of Albert Peiser, at 1,398 Third Avenue. A safe within two feet of the main door was blown open with dynamite, and although the intruders only got away with $15, there were negotiable unregistered United States bonds worth $3,000, $2,000 in checks and accounts and $496.44 in cash in the inner compartment, which they vainly tried to force.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- There was a large batch of bills introduced in the House to-day. They included the following:

August Spanuth, pianist; Ludwig Varum, violinist, and Anton Hegner, violoncellist, have constituted themselves a body of chamber music players under the title of New York Chamber Music Club. Three persons will naturally play trios, a form of chamber music which has been much neglected of late, so far as public performance is concerned.
PARIS, Dec. 7. -- The Republique Francaise to-day says the tone of President McKinley's message to Congress is "conciliatory, but not exempt from ambiguity."

Exports of general merchandise from the Port of New York for the week were valued at $10,357,740, against $3,985,380 in the preceding week, and $8,616,171 in the corresponding week of last year. Total since Jan. 1, $364,972,009, against $350,410,058 for the like period in 1896.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 7. -- Ingle Rush, former Treasurer of a Logan County township, came to the penitentiary last night unaccompanied by an officer. Rush had lived many years in the community without seeking political honors, and only a short time ago yielded to the persuasions of his friends.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 7. -- The contest over the distribution of Tammany patronage to the boroughs outside of Manhattan and the Bronx has for the time overshadowed the talk about places in New York proper.

BUDAPEST, Dec. 7. -- In the Lower House of the Hungarian Parliament to-day, Herr Francis Kossuth, the leader of the party advocating an independent Hungary, opened hostilities with a fierce speech on a motion which the House, just before closing yesterday, granted him permission to introduce to-day.

LONDON, Dec. 7. -- Walter Croot of Newcastle, England, who was defeated for the bantam weight championship of the world at the National Sporting Club last night by "Jimmy" Barry of Chicago, died this morning of the injuries which he received during the contest.

The next step in the formation of an independent Republican organization will be taken on Friday evening. At a meeting at the Windsor Hotel the Committee on Address of the Plaza Club conferrees will report an address and plan of action, which will then be made public. This course was decided upon last night at a meeting of the committee at the Republican Club of the Twenty-seventh Assembly District, 767 Sixth Avenue.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7. -- The local traction issues were the interesting features of the market to-day. Philadelphia, on buying credited to outside sources, scored an advance of over a point. Union Traction certificates were also in good demand, advancing sharply. Union Traction rose to 12 1/4 on buying, stimulated by increasing earnings and expectations that for the month they will show a handsome surplus over fixed charges.

It was an exceedingly pretty sight which met the view of the guests and members of Sorosis as they entered the beautiful ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday afternoon. Hundreds of ladies beautifully gowned in fabrics of many hues and colors sat facing the long, draped desk behind which sat half a dozen officers of this oldest and most famous of women's clubs.

Little Geneva Connors died yesterday of a broken heart. She believed in her worthless brother John when all his friends and relatives turned against him, and the discovery that he was unworthy of her love killed her.

The annual meeting of the Archdeaconry of the Protestant Episcopal Church of this city was held yesterday in the chantry of Grace Church, at Broadway and Tenth Street, being preceded by the Holy Communion service in the church itself, conducted by Bishop Potter, assisted by the Archdeacon, the Rev. Dr. Charles C. Tiffany. There was a large attendance of both clergy and laity.

Simon McDonnell, a policeman attached to the Elizabeth Street Station, was kicked to death by a horse at Seventy-second Street and the East Drive in Central Park yesterday while out driving and Park Policeman John J. Doolady, who was with him, had his arm broken.

PARIS, Dec. 7. -- The precincts of the Luxembourg Palace were crowded to-day, in anticipation of the opening of the debate in the Senate on the Dreyfus scandal. The police, however, were able to keep the people moving. There were many ladies and officers in the galleries, and the whole hall was crowded.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7. -- Five Chicago men are imprisoned in the snow hundreds of miles beyond the last point of civilization in the Northwest Territory. The condition of the men is precarious in the extreme. A relief expedition, provision for which was made in Chicago to-day, will undertake to rescue and bring them back to civilization.
MADRID, Dec. 7. -- The Cabinet to-day considered dispatches from Senor de Lome, the Spanish Minister at Washington, containing extracts from President McKinley's message to Congress.
CHICAGO, Dec. 7. -- Judge Dunne, of the Circuit Court to-day appointed James A. Russell receiver for the Illinois branches of the Supreme Council Catholic Knights and Ladies of America.

The annual meeting of the Yacht Racing Union of Long Island Sound was held in Parlor F of the Fifth Avenue Hotel last night. Quite formidable programme was laid out for action, but, owning to the length of time occupied in discussing the racing rules, part of it was reserved until a later meeting.

The Kaiser seems to have misjudged the temper of the Reichstag. In the days of his grandfather, BISMARCK used to come down to the Reichstag, whenever there was an increase in the army estimates, and bully the Legislature into granting the demands, invoking, when it seemed necessary, the authority of MOLTKE in addition to his own.

The identity of the vessel with which the Allan-State Line steamship Corean was in collision at two o'clock Sunday morning, fifty miles south of Sable Island, was established yesterday when the Atlantic Transport steamship Mobile, from London, arrived with five of her bow plates damaged.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- The invocation at the opening of the Senate to-day was delivered by the Rev. Dr. Charles A. Berry of Wolverhampton, England. He prayed that the Almighty might take into His care all the interests of the Nation, that from this Nation may emanate such feelings of brotherhood as would be a blessing to all mankind.
HAVANA, Dec. 7. -- To-day Capt. Gen. Blanco, the Governor General, signed a decree releasing forty-one persons who have been imprisoned on charges of complicity in the insurgent movement.

The President did not have the courage to confess that the Dingley bill is a failure. "To test its permanent value further time will be required," he says. The people, he thinks, "are in no mind to withhold from it a fair trial."
LONDON, Dec. 8. -- A special dispatch from Shanghai says:

FLUSHING, L.I., Dec. 7. -- The result of the special election held yesterday to decide whether $74,000 should be appropriated for the improvement of streets in the outlying district, and to expend $1,000 annually for the maintenance of the Flushing public library, resulted in victory and defeat. The proposition to expend the money on the streets was beaten by 35 votes, while the library proposition was carried by about a two-thirds majority.

The curse of the builders of Babel seems to have fallen upon Austria-Hungary. The wonder is not so much that it should have come at last as that it should have been delayed so long. That the crisis should have been staved off so long is a remarkable tribute to the statesmanship of the founders of the dual monarchy.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7. -- Gross earnings of the Illinois Central for the month of November were $2,534,427, an increase of $664,861 over the same month of last year. For the months from July 1 to Oct. 31 the net earnings were $2.604,963, an increase of $451,735 over the same period of last year.
HAVANA, Dec. 7. -- El Diario de la Marina, commenting upon President McKinley's message to Congress, says:

William B. Turnbull turned State's evidence against William Elford Gould, when the case of the alleged attempt to blackmail Senhor Teixeira, the Brazilian millionaire, was brought before Magistrate Meade, in the Centre Street Police Court, yesterday morning.
NEW HAVEN, Dec. 7. -- Burr C. Chamberlain, who has played tackle on Yale's football team for the last two years, will captain the team the coming year. His election as captain took place to-night.

NUTLEY, N.J., Dec. 7. -- A few weeks ago Clarence M. Noble appeared before the Township Committee and protested against the amount of his water bill. The bill showed that Mr. Noble had used $330 worth of water within three months.

PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti, Dec. 7. -- The trouble between Germany and Haiti appears to be settled. The Haitian Government has saluted the German flag, and the foreigners who had sought refuge on board ships in this harbor have returned to their homes.

The final speed trial of E. Burgess Warren's phenomenal little steam yacht Ellide was made yesterday afternoon, over the measured mile off Irvington-on-the-Hudson, and as a result the yachtsman will pay $6,000 as a bonus for speed in excess of that designated in the original contract.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 7. -- The first party of Indians from the five civilized tribes in the Indian Territory will start for Old Mexico by the 1st of January. A.B. Hullett of the Mexican Land Company, who came here yesterday from Muskogee, says the Choctaws and Chickasaws held a convention Friday, when they decided to go to the new colony and found an Indian State.

ALBANY, Dec. 7. -- A vigorous prosecution of the Coal Trust case has been planned by Attorney General Hancock, and if the Court of Appeals decides against him, the incoming Legislature will be asked to amend the laws. The Attorney General to-day filed and served notice of appeal in the anti-trust cases from the order of the Appellate Division.
The Secretary of the Treasury proposes:
BERLIN, Dec. 7. -- Herr Otto Finsch, the explorer, has been appointed Professor of Ornithology at Leyden University.

MOBILE, Ala., Dec. 7. -- The novel situation which the contest for Postmaster at Mobile has assumed is possibly due to haste on the part of Prelate D. Barker, President McKinley's appointee, to be installed before Congress should meet. Mr. Barker has been nervously anxious to forestall opposition that he apprehended would develop from members of his own party.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- Assistant Secretary Howell of the Treasury Department has written the following letter in answer to an inquiry concerning the receipts and expenditures of the Government:

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday took up the city budget for 1898, starting with the estimate for the District Attorney's office. District Attorney Olcott asked for $2,000 more than had been allowed in the provisional estimate of October on account of a deficiency in his contingency fund.

Promptly on the first day of the session a bankruptcy bill was introduced in the House. That shows the interest felt in the subject. Leaders on both sides agree that the matter will not be made partisan, that party lines will not be observed by either the friends or the opponents of any proposition.

Loyalty to Williams College and reverence for her traditions were the distinguishing characteristics of the forty-seventh annual dinner of the Williams College Alumni Association of New York, held last night at Delmonico's, Fifth Avenue and Forty-fourth Street. Nearly 150 members of the association were present, including four graduates of the class of '46 -- C.H. Gardner, A.V.W. Van Vechten, Thomas M. North, and A.K. Smith.

A meeting convened yesterday of the Audubon Society at the Natural History Museum. One main object for calling the meeting, Frank M. Chapman had stated in the notice in a daily journal, was "because of a threat made by a woman in THE TIMES and signed 'A.B.C.,' to start an 'anti-Audubon' society."

The Congress is being urged, from all parts of the country, not always with consistency, to be economical. With the expenditures continuing at the rate of $420,000,000 a year, the receipts are at the rate of $312,000,000 a year. Unless the receipts are increased or the expenditures greatly reduced, an increasing deficiency is assured.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 7. -- The House to-day killed the convict bill and undid the work upon which it has been engaged during the entire session. The measure, which had its birth in the House, and was declared to be the "expression of the views of the majority," was knocked on the head as ruthlessly as if it were aimed at the peace and happiness of every one who constituted this majority.

When the matter of the contested wills of Charles Coudert, the lawyer, and brother of Frederic R. Coudert, who died on July 13 last, was called in Surrogate Arnold's court yesterday John Townshend, counsel for the widow, Marie M. Coudert, asked that the hearing be adjourned until Jan. 3. Mr. Townshend announced that the contestants had decided to try and settle their differences out of court and that they had nearly reached an agreement.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- The following-named fourth-class Postmasters were appointed to-day:

The first new play of the season at Daly's Theatre is an exceedingly fragile three-act farce taken by F.C. Burnand of London Punch, from the German of Herren Blumenthal and Kadelburg, called "Number Nine; or, The Lady of Ostend." It was produced last night in presence of a large, fashionable, and demonstratively appreciative audience.

BERLIN, Dec. 7. -- In the Reichstag to-day Herr Richter, the Radical leader, during this the second day's debate upon the first reading of the Naval Bill, opposed that measure and dwelt upon the serious increase of expenditure. He contended that the great display of power made in China proved that the Government considered the navy equal to the task imposed upon it.
H.H. Cammann Co. have sold for J. and H. Stamme to H. and E. Hirsch two lots on the south side of One Hundred and Fourteenth Street, 100 feet west of Amsterdam Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- The essential parts of the annual report to Congress of Secretary of the Treasury Lyman J. Gage -- omitting such matters as have been covered by reports of subsidiary departments and previously published -- are as follows:

The criticism by "A." in to-day's TIMES of your editorial of Monday on "The Truth About Rapid Transit," meets my views from a technical and economic standpoint, but does not, in my opinion, go far enough into the general subject, and fails to suggest a remedy for the ills that are complained of in the present elevated roads.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- The President to-day submitted to Congress the report of Major Moses P. Handy of Chicago, Special Commissioner to the Paris International Exposition, giving the details of his mission. In his letter of transmittal the President says the report gives a clear and comprehensive presentation of the situation.

VIENNA, Dec. 7. -- Dr. Abrahamovics, the President of the lower house of the Austrian Parliament, has written a letter to the Neue Freie Presse, denying that he resigned the Presidency and his seat in the House, on the ground that he has been appointed a member of the upper house of the Reichsrath. He adds:
MOBILE, Ala., Dec. 7. -- Hannis Taylor, ex-Minister to Spain, to-night gave out a statement as to that part of the President's message which relates to the Cuban question. He says, in part:

The Rainy Day Club had its first party yesterday. It was given by the Woman's Literary Club of Arlington in the Arlington Clubhouse. Mrs. Kingsley, Mrs. Clara Laddey, and Mrs. R.G. Lambert were on the Reception Committee of the afternoon, and, with the President, Mrs. Jennie Suderly, and other club members, received and entertained the guests.

The tide of indignation in Brooklyn over the proceedings of the Board of Aldermen rose high yesterday. Denunciations poured in on all sides. The Manufacturers' Association of Kings and Queens Counties sent to Mayor Wurster an urgent request to veto the resolution giving forty miles of streets to P.H. Flynn's East River and Atlantic Ocean Railroad Company.

Some 500 or 600 people, many of them well known in society, crowded the Astor Gallery in the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday afternoon to attend the matinee musical given under the auspices of Victor Harris to benefit a fund started by charitable young women to endow in perpetuity a children's bed in the orthopedio ward of the Post-Graduate Hospital, at Twentieth Street and Second Avenue.

-- Who made the "many complaints" that have moved the elevated railway officials to inclose their stations with glassy? This question is interesting, or, rather, the answer to it will be, and for several reasons. As long experience has shown, complaint from members of the general public, no matter how frequent, and no matter whether it takes the form of tearful supplications or indignant threats, is heard with serene indifference by the Manhattan Directors.
WALTHAM, Dec. 7. -- In the municipal election to-day George L. Mayberry, the citizen non-partisan candidate for Mayor, carried the city overwhelmingly. The city voted no license.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8. -- The thirty-eighth annual meeting of the American Church Missionary Society was held here this afternoon. Gen. Wager Swayne, United States Army, the President of the society, presided. Bishop Peterson made the opening prayer.

The old and wealthy residents of Tottenville, S.I., are much agitated over a movement which has been started by new comers in that quaint little village to have the name changed to Bently. A petition largely signed by those in favor of the movement is being circulated, and will be forwarded to the Postal authorities at Washington.

When the second day's session of the semi-annual meeting of the Board of Review of the National Trotting Association opened yesterday morning at the Murray Hill Hotel there was a large crowd of horsemen in attendance, for numerous cases of "ringing" were on the docket, and interesting developments were looked for.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Dec. 8. -- The Fall River cotton manufacturers this afternoon voted to reduce the wages of the operatives. The cut will not be less than 10 per cent., and will affect about 25,000 employes. The cause of the reduction is the depressed condition of the cotton market. The action the operatives will take in regard to the cut is not known.
LONDON, Dec. 8. -- The Privy Council has affirmed the decision of the Appeal Court of Ontario relative to the power of the Lieutenant Governor to appoint Queen's Counsel.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- The Senate was in session less than an hour to-day.

TORONTO, Dec. 8. -- Lord Aberdeen, Governor General of Canada, was banqueted to-night at the National Club by a representative company. The speech of the evening was delivered by the Hon. Edward Blake, member of the British House of Commons, who will sail for England on Dec. 29.
THEODORE B. WILLIS, the Brooklyn City Works Commissioner, in recommending an issue of bonds to provide for the necessary immediate increase of the water supply, says:

An insurance policy for $1,000,000 has just been issued on the life of George W. Vanderbilt by the Mutual Life Insurance Company. Although it is generally known that this is a fact, the officers of the company would neither affirm nor deny the issuance of the policy when approached yesterday. The policy is the largest ever issued in the world, and has created a great deal of discussion among insurance men.

WAVERLY, Iowa, Dec. 8. -- Delilah Fales has confessed to the crime of killing Jerome Kern, who was found dead in a lonely wood Aug. 23, a bullet wound in his side and his clothes burned from his body.

The space you are giving to the subject of the Torrey Bankruptcy bill is timely and very important. One point in that connection is worth mention, and should be impressed upon all New York State Congressmen. Eight or nine years ago the Bankruptcy bill had passed the Senate and only required concurrence of the House and the President's signature to make it law.

Mr. ZABRISKIE, antagonizing rapid transit before the Appellate Division, totted up the multifarious liabilities New York has assumed, those she expects to assume, and those that will possibly be necessary of assumption some time in the future, affirming them all as present debts, and by that showing asserts that the city has already -- even leaving rapid transit out of the question -- exceeded its debt limit.
VANCOUVER, B.C., Dec. 8. -- The Aorangi brings the following Australian news:

The Democracy of Thomas Jefferson, represented by 200 delegates from the various Assembly districts of Greater New York, held a long and stormy conference at the Murray Hill Lyceum last night, as a result of which it was decided to form a permanent organization, and to carry the fight into the State. This will be done under the name of the "Henry George Democracy."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- Secretary Gage has submitted to the Department of State his report upon the action of the Treasury Department in suppressing filibustering expeditions to Cuba in violation of the neutrality laws, a synopsis of which was furnished by the department.

Christian Walterbogel, a conductor, who lived in Union Hill, N.J., died, and a committee of four was delegated by the Hudson County Railway Employes' Association to attend the funeral yesterday. The committee hired a coach and started for Walterbogel's house.

The fight against the President on the merit system was promptly opened in the House on the very first day of debate by Mr. McKINLEY'S fellow-citizen of Ohio and former colleague, the Hon. Mr. GROSVENOR.
TOLEDO, Dec. 8. -- More trouble is looked for by the coal operators in Ohio, and possibly in Pennsylvania and the entire soft-coal district.
LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 8. -- Richard Croker began his day's work this morning by attending early mass in St. Mary's Catholic Church. Thomas F. Grady and John B. Sexton went with him.
BOSTON, Dec. 8. -- Stockholders of the Boston Elevated Railroad at a meeting today ratified the proposed new lease of the West End Street Railway by the Boston Elevated Company.

ASHLAND, Wis., Dec. 8. -- The Government is about to try the experiment of making loggers out of its Indian wards on Indian reservation in Northern Minnesota. The plan, which is approved by Land Commissioner Herman, is that contracts for cutting dead and fallen timber on the White Earth and Winnibigoshish reservations will be let to the Indians themselves and no others.

The various injunctions obtained against the Brooklyn Board of Aldermen in regard to the recent franchise grabs were argued yesterday before Justice Van Wyck in the Supreme Court. There was no opposition to the injunctions restraining the granting of franchises to the Municipal Electric Light Company and the Flatbush Gas Company, and the papers were handed up.
Daniel S. McElroy has sold to an investor the five-story building 1,424 Broadway, 25.7 by 102.11 by 24.8 by 96, adjoining the Empire Theatre. The reported price is in the neighborhood of $175,000.
Your columns appear to be so open for a free discussion of the rapid transit question that I thought a few lines from an old subscriber might be accepted and published.

GALESBURG, Ill., Dec. 8. -- A verdict of $3,000 damages was awarded Lizzie Caine in her suit against William Andrews in court here to-day. In the Presidential campaign Mr. Andrews, in the heat of a street political argument, made a violent gesture with an open knife in his hand. The blade pierced the eye of Miss Caine, who was passing by.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 8. -- Philip Hill, colored, the murderer of George Lawrence, was respited from hanging to-day by Sheriff Harvey Lowry under the most peculiar circumstances.

Dr. Arnold Graff, twenty-seven years old, of 1,420 Fifth Avenue, was shot in the shoulder last night by his brother Richard, but was not seriously hurt. Dr. Graff lives on the third floor of an apartment house. Richard is thirty-two years old, an artist, with a studio at 42 East Fourth Street. When he appeared at the Fifth Avenue house last evening, Richard, it is said, had been drinking.

CHICAGO, Dec., 8. -- After spending twenty-one years in an insane asylum, Mrs. Mary Anderson, the wife of Hans Anderson, an East Chicago Avenue jeweler, returned home to-day, having been released, pending a further hearing upon an application for a writ of habeas corpus, and turned over to the custody of her husband.

ALBANY, Dec. 8. -- Capt. D. Marvin Goodrich of Harvard, Capt. Frederick D. Colson of Cornell, and Capt. Payne Whitney of Yale, representing the boating interests of their universities, held a conference here to-day. The greatest secrecy was observed. Orders were left at the hotel clerk's desk that the conferrees were not to be disturbed by anybody.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 8. -- James Murray, a prominent politician of Sebastian County, Ark., was robbed by footpads a short time ago, and he recognized Grant McBroom, a coal miner of Bonanza, a short distance from Jenny Lind, his home, as a member of the midnight gang that robbed him, so he got commission last Sunday as Deputy Constable for the purpose of apprehending McBroom.

Magistrate Brann, in the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday reversed the decision made by Magistrate Mott about a week ago to the effect that there was no law authorizing the arrest and punishment of a man who refuses to pay his cab fare.

The Attorney General could hardly fail to carry the Lexow anti-trust law for final interpretation to the Court of Appeals. Such professional reverses as he has suffered naturally require to be covered up by a decision that will throw the blame on the law, and as a matter of fact we very much doubt if the sharpest lawyer in the State could have made much of a case under the Lexow statute.
Your editorial on the bankruptcy laws, of the 6th inst., has caused me to trouble you with the following question:

William H. Anderson, the member of the Century Wheelmen of New York who started out to ride sixty-five centuries in as many consecutive days, has given up the attempt. He had finished forty-eight one-hundred-mile runs in forty-eight days, but at the end of the forty-eighth, one of his arms was almost paralyzed, and he has since been unable to use it for riding.

On the Teutonic from England yesterday afternoon came one of the most notorious criminals who have operated in this country in recent years. He is J.B. Ford, better known as Charles Fisher, who, a short time ago in London, made the statement that he would rather be hanged in America than live in England.

Mr. CARL SCHURZ discusses in the current number of Harper's Weekly, with his customary sound sense, the "Task of the Citizens' Union." He points out, what the leaders of the Union feel very strongly, that the work, to accomplish anything worth while, must be continuous, and what the objects of this continuous work may well be he summarizes as follows:

It is proverbial that men born in the woods are seldom scared by owls. So those to the Wall Street manner born do not tremble before the phantom terrors conjured up by the syndicate of liars. In stock market circles men know how to exhibit the symptoms of alarm when they feel it not, and to put on a brave outward seeming when sickening fear almost stops their heart-beats within.

MADRID, Dec. 8. -- The Premier, Senor Sagasta, in an interview regarding President McKinley's message to Congress, is quoted as saying he thinks the message satisfactory, "because the threat to intervene in Cuba was made merely to give satisfaction to a portion of American opinion, without the intention of executing it."

Several persons had narrow escapes in a fire which started early yesterday morning in the three-story brick building at 55 Avenue B, and neighbors played a prominent part in the rescues which were made before the firemen had an opportunity to do their share.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Dec. 8 -- Representatives of the two great syndicates which control the Cuban cattle trade, S.F. Bernds Co. and Centro de los Encomenderos, have just effected a consolidation and are now here arranging for the purchase of big herds of cattle in Texas and Northern Mexico. J.R. Stahle of Kansas City will have charge of this department and will make this market headquarters.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 8. -- The American Theatre Opera Company, capitalized at $10,000, was incorporated with the Secretary of State to-day. The company proposes to produce dramas and operas in the various cities of this country, and its Directors are: Elliot Zborowski, of London, Eng.; Henry D. Savage of Marshfield, Mass.; Arthur J. Clark of Philadelphia; David B. Ogden and Herbert Parsons of New York City.

William B. Turnbull made some unusually interesting statements when under examination in the Centre Street Police Court yesterday morning in the hearing of the case against him and William E. Gould, both charged with attempting to blackmail the millionaire Brazilian, Senhor Teixeira. z

It is the reported intention of the anti-Platt Republicans to hold an enrollment at the earliest practicable date, without reference to the plan of organization that may afterward be adopted. It is argued that, inasmuch as the election district will be the actual basis of enrollment, to hold an enrollment would not lead to any confusion if it should afterward be decided to form an organization on the enrollment district plan.

OMAHA, Dec. 8. -- Toru Hoshi, Japanese Minister to the United States, passed through Omaha this evening en route to Washington, accompanied by his private secretary. In a talk with a reporter Mr. Hoshi said:

The trouble between the Rev. Charles S. Robinson of the New York Presbyterian Church. One Hundred and Twenty-eighth Street and Seventh Avenue, and his congregation, was amicably settled last night, pastor and people agreeing to part with mutual good will and expressions of distinguished consideration.

The President declared in his message that we were constrained by every consideration of dignity and honor to ratify the Hawaiian annexation treaty. But the treaty appears to be dead. Its friends confess that they cannot get two-thirds of the Senators to vote for it. If the treaty fails the promoters of the job will have recourse to Senator MORGAN'S bill to annex the islands, which requires only a majority to pass it.

For nine years the members of the Musical Protective Union had not only played in harmony at their little concerts, but on the 8th of each December they had voted in harmony and unanimously re-elected Alexander Bremer to their Presidency. Yesterday, however, discord reigned, Mr. Bremer was defeated, and the ticket of an independent faction, with Sylvester A. Murphy at its head, was chosen.

ITHACA, Dec. 8. -- At a meeting of the Cornell Athletic Council, held in Boardman Hall to-night, communications from prominent Cornell alumni were read relative to the Cornell, Yale, and Harvard negotiations. The majority expressly advised that in case Cornell should enter a triangular race, at New London this Spring, it should be only on condition that she be received into the Yale-Harvard five-year agreement.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- The House Committee on Banking and Currency, which will have the shaping of a considerable portion of the financial legislation before the House, held its first meeting this morning and outlined its general plan of action.

We think not. The Emperor and his "boys" have compelled the Haitian Republic to apologize and pay smart-money, and they were pretty rough about it. There is nothing to be said about that. It is the custom in such matters.

John C. Sheehan, the nominal but no longer actual leader of the Tammany organization of this city, started yesterday for the Hot Springs of Virginia. He goes there to secure the rest and change of climate and scene which his physician has pronounced necessary to complete his recovery from the attack which recently confined him to his room for a week.

Miss Jessie Shay is a pretty young American, a mere girl, who learned all she knows about piano playing in New York City. She never studied abroad, but after completing her work here, under Alexander Lambert, she went abroad and gave concerts in Germany, where her playing was highly praised.

DETROIT, Dec. 8. -- Articles of incorporation were filed to-day for the Detroit and Cleveland Navigation Company with a capital stock of $1,000,000 divided into 20,000 shares. This is simply a reorganization of the Detroit and Cleveland Steam Navigation Company, whose corporate existence terminated to-day by statutory limitation.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- The bill introduced in the Senate to-day prohibiting pelagic sealing by the people of the United States provides as follows:

C.M. McClung of Knoville, Tenn., a successful merchant and representative Southern business man, is staying at the Plaza Hotel. When seen there yesterday he expressed himself as follows in regard to conditions prevailing in his part of the country:

The Mayor's office was crowded yesterday at the hearing given by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment to charitable institutions applying for city appropriations. Great interest was shown in the proceedings, as this year, for the first time under the Constitution, the giving of money to these institutions is discretionary.

YONKERS, N.Y., Dec. 8. -- The Rev. J.F. Jedlicka, pastor of the Holy Trinity Catholic Church, on Walnut Street, this place, heard a thief trying to force open a window in his house early this morning. The pastor made for the window, and was heard by the thief, who ran from the house. The priest raised the window and fired at the fleeing thief, but missed, owing to the darkness.

It is extremely unfortunate for any nation when there is a widespread popular suspicion that its courts fail to do justice "without fear or favor." There has for a long time been rather more than a suspicion against the criminal procedure of France. From the time when the police, in need, for its own reputation, of a victim, lays its hands upon a suspected person, every presumption is taken against him.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 8. -- The blind convict John Tyler, who was conditionally pardoned on Monday by the State Board of Pardons, yesterday made a desperate attack on Warden Woodbridge and three of his officers. He struck Deputy Baisden with a board from his cot, and wounded Officers Edgett and Knight with a small knife.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- There was no surprise to-day when it was learned that the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations had decided not to call up at once the treaty for the annexation of Hawaii.

Peter C. Kellogg, auctioneer, will hold his annual sale of trotting-bred horses next Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday, days and evenings, at Madison Square Garden. Consignments from the most prominent stock farms in the country will be offered for sale. John H. Shults, proprietor of the Parkville and Shultshurst Farms, will make the largest shipment, consisting of 100 head.

The invitation fair for the benefit of the New York Throat and Nose Hospital, at 244 East Fifty-ninth Street, of which Dr. Edward J. Bermingham is surgeon in chief, was held in the Astor Gallery and Myrtle Room of the Waldorf-Astoria, from 2 P.M. to midnight yesterday. It was the fifth annual fair of the Women's Auxiliary to the hospital, and was directed by Mrs. Bermingham, the President.

HAVANA, Dec. 8. -- The Spanish military officials here announced to-day that columns of troops belonging to the military district of Sancti Spiritus, Province of Santa Clara, acting in conjunction, have been engaged, at the Delicias Farm, with an insurgent force under Gen. Maximo Gomez.

When Richard E. Graf, the artist of 42 East Fourth Street, who shot his brother, Dr. Arnold Graf, at the apartment house at 1,420 Fifth Avenue, Wednesday night, was arraigned in the Harlem Police Court yesterday a statement was made by Dr. W. W. Taylor of 5 West One Hundred and Sixteenth Street that the prisoner had also shot his mother on the same evening.

The London Statist thinks the reason why England buys much from the United States and sells little is that our credit is bad and England is collecting her debts from us in produce. This is charmingly simple, and experienced thinkers are shy of simple solutions for complex questions.

As long as there are people who think Washington ought to have been a member of the Episcopal Church, it will be periodically announced that he was one. It matters little whether he was or not except in the interest of historical truth. It must not be forgotten that when Parson Weems and the Rev. Lee Massey wrote, invention of incident and exaggeration of fact were accounted legitimate biography.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9. -- A human foot, with a long steel nail driven through the great toe, was found upon a truck of the Pullman coach Miltiades, a through sleeper attached to the Denver express of the Alton Road, when it came into the Union Station this morning at 9 o'clock. The member was the right foot of a man. It was bare, and the blood upon it was fresh.
AVONDALE, Ohio, Dec. 9. -- Dr. John H. Dorn of New York city and Miss Sallie Echert, daughter of P. Echert, were married here last evening at the home of the bride's parents.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- In the Senate to-day Mr. Hoar (Rep.,Mass.,) secured unanimous consent, which, under the rules, was necessary, for the presentation of a petition signed by 21,269 native Hawaiians, protesting against the annexation of Hawaii.

DULUTH, Dec. 9. -- The Pioneer, the largest mine on the Vermillion iron range, closed down to-day, throwing nearly 500 men out of work. The reason given for the closing of the mine is the inability of the fee owners of the property and the stockholders of the mining company to agree on the question of royalties.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 9. -- The wedding of J. Fred Pierson, Jr., son of Gen. J.F. Pierson, of New York, and Miss Miles, daughter of Gen. William Porcher Miles, who was a member of the Confederate Congress, and is one of the leading sugar planters of the State, took place at Trinity Church this afternoon, Bishop Davis Sessums and the Rev. Dr. Beverly Warner officiating.

Three men were seriously injured and many other persons badly shaken up in a rear-end collision of two elevated railroad trains at the One Hundred and Second Street station of the Second Avenue road. The injured are Timothy Sullivan, a passenger, of 302 East One Hundred and Second Street; William H. Masterson, fireman of the rear train, 335 East Sixty-ninth Street, and Joseph O'Brien, a passenger, of 447 East One Hundred and Sixteenth Street.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9. -- The State Superintendent of Schools is about to begin a rigid investigation to discover how far the schools are obeying the law which provides a penalty where the nature and effects of alcoholic drinks are not taught.

The members of the Board of Review of the National Trotting Association are ordinarily inclined to show all possible leniency to accused horsemen, but at yesterday's executive session of the board at the Murray Hill Hotel there were many surprising decisions, which resulted in the expulsion of several persons from the trotting turf.

A number of the larger stockholders and officers of the steel rod and wire and nail manufacturing companies throughout the country met at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday for the purpose of pooling their interests and arranging the values of the properties that will be operated by the new organization.

BERLIN, Dec. 9. -- The Reichstag to-day resumed the debate on the first reading of the Government's Naval bill. Herr Hammacher, National Liberal, declared his party unanimously approved the principles of the measure and attached the greatest importance to the navy. In connection with the export trade, the speaker thought the commercial policy of the United States and Great Britain should be particularly considered.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- The following fourth-class postmasters were appointed to-day for New York offices: Carlyon, George E. Whittleton; Cuylervllle, William G. Wooster; Freehold, John H. Lacy; Hopewell Centre, John Sutton; Indian Falls, Charles W. Arnold; Solon, Daniel E. Morris.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- The Department of State is about to press to the end the issue that has been raised between it and the Government of Nicaragua, growing out of the refusal of Nicaragua to receive a United States Minister in the person of Capt. Merry of California.

Some jurors who have recently suffered because of the peculiarities and uncertainties of the jury law in this county are trying to organize a movement to induce the Legislature at its next session to make laws on that subject which can be understood and which will define the rights of citizens who are drawn for jury duty without possibility of error.

A decision just rendered by Justice STOVER is calculated to fill the minds of Raines law clubmen with conflicting emotions. The Excise Commissioner had applied for the revocation of the liquor tax certificates of three clubs. Two of these clubs purported to be actuated by ethical and intellectual motives of the highest order.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 9. -- The New York State Association for the Protection of Fish and Game is holding its annual meeting in this city. In the morning session a new name and constitution were adopted. The organization hereafter will be known as "The New York State Fish, Game, and Forest League."

Readers of THE NEW YORK TIMES who have watched the development of its SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS AND ART will take special pleasure in to-morrow's issue, when the size of that supplement will be three times the original size --

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- Representative Adams of Pennsylvania, who was to-day named as Chairman of the Sub-Committee on Foreign Affairs to deal with Cuban questions, when asked as to his views on the Spanish-Cuban status, said:

An Important meeting of Roman Catholic priests, who have charge of church schools, was held yesterday at St. Joseph's Rectory, in Sixth Avenue, to consider various matters connected with their schools and in particular to take action with regard to the school census now being taken up in this city by the State Superintendent of Public Instruction.

The troubles of Eugene V.N. Bissell, the son of the well-known auctioneer, because of the extravagant habits of his wife, Mary Valentine Yale Bissell, have received much public attention, and in the numerous suits brought against him in the City Court by dressmakers and others to recover the value of goods and dresses sold to Mrs. Bissell, her husband has always been defeated.

Senator Platt returned from Washington yesterday, and will remain in the city until President McKinley leaves Canton. Congressman L.E. Quigg came with the Republican organization leader, and, while they are in New York some course of action may be decided upon with regard to the anti-organization movement.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- With the exception of the offer of $2,500,000 received some time ago from the Union Pacific Reorganization Committee for the Government's interest in the Kansas Pacific Railroad, which was declined, the Government has received no intimation as to the purposes of the committee with respect to the sale set for Dec. 16.

Mayor Strong's suggestion that the passing of the present City of New York by consolidation be commemorated by a special meeting took concrete from last night in the appointment of a committee. The Mayor invited seventy-five heads of departments, Presidents of clubs and societies, and others to meet him at Delmonico's and discuss the project.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 9. -- To-day's proceedings in the trial of Charles A. Bonai, charged with the murder of George Marcus Nichols of Daniels Farms, produced another sensation, even more remarkable than that of yesterday, when David A. Weeks, Bonai's alleged accomplice, made a full confession. To-day Mrs. Charles A. Bonai, wife of the

The Spanish Consul General was again present at the continuation of the hearing of the case against William B. Turnbull and William E. Gould, charged with attempting to blackmail Senhor Teixeira, which was held before Magistrate Meade, in the Centre Street Police Court, yesterday. It was evidently the Interesting testimony that had been given concerning him which attracted him.

LOUISVILLE, Dec. 9. -- A decision involving directly nearly $500,000 and indirectly a similar amount for every succeeding year was handed down by Judge Miller in Chancery to-day. It was in the suit of the City of Louisville against the Louisville Gas Company, which resisted the payment of $70,000 additional franchise tax. Judge Miller holds that the Board of Assessors had a right to assess franchises for municipal purposes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- Secretary Long of the Navy Department to-day expressed the hope that the present civil service system will not be impaired. He said he had entire sympathy with the Congressmen who were brought directly in contact with applicants for official position, but he believed the President was right, and should be sustained.

The Allan State Line steamship State of Nebraska, which left her pier foot of West Twenty-first Street at 12:30 P.M., yesterday, with eleven second cabin passengers, and heavily laden with general cargo and cattle, put back to her pier early in the evening, owing to damage suffered in collision with a coal barge just inside Sandy Hook.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- The House of Representatives to-day got down to serious work. After some preliminary business the House went into Committee of the Whole, with Mr. Payne of New York in the chair, for the consideration of the Pension Appropriation bill, which was reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- The Haitian Minister, Mr. Leger, called at the State Department to-day to talk with the officials respecting the settlement of the difficulty between his country and Germany, and also to make some representations touching the case of the American engineer, Campbell, whose claim for an indemnity formed the subject of a resolution of inquiry, which has been presented in the United States Senate.

BOSTON, Dec. 9. -- Although Boston is the centre of cotton mill business of New England, the men prominently connected with the trade had little to say to-day for publication concerning the action of the Fall River manufacturers in voting to reduce wages, beginning Jan. 1.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9. -- Amid considerable excitement, December wheat sold to-day at $1.09, the highest price, with one exception, since the memorable "Old Hutch" corner in 1888. The market started very nervous, bids at the start ranging all the way from $1.01 1/2 to $1.05, and in a few minutes it sold up to $1.05.

There will be no lack of bills for the reform of the currency in the House of Representatives. Already Mr. WALKER, the energetic and versatile Chairman of the Banking and Currency Committee, has appointed a lot of sub-committees, each of which, it is significantly announced, will have charge of the measures introduced by its own members.

John N. Golding has sold for Paul Outerbridge to an investor the four-story brown-stone-front dwelling, 710 Madison Avenue, northwest corner of Sixty-third Street, 20.5 by 70. The buyer will alter the property for business purposes.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 9. -- An official announcement was made to-day of the settlement of the differences existing between the Seaboard Air Line and the Southern Railway in the following statement signed by R.C. Hoffman, President of the Seaboard, and Samuel Spencer, President of the Southern Railway:

The Committee on Streets of the Board of Aldermen announced a public hearing in the Aldermen's Chamber for yesterday afternoon upon the proposition to change the names or numberings of some of the city streets, and in spite of the fact that Clinton Place was proposed for a rechristening, no lover of the old in New York appeared before the committee.

The Boston gas properties recently purchased by the New England Coke and Gas Company were yesterday formally transferred to the acquiring company at the office of the Central Trust Company. The transaction was completed in the presence of the Directors of the Coke and Gas Company, including Richard B. Olney, ex-Secretary of State; William L. Elkins, Jr., Henry M. Whitney of Boston, and Almeric Hugh Paget.
LONDON, Dec. 10. -- The Madrid correspondent of The Daily Mail says:...

The new Art Committee of the Union League Club, and which is composed of Messrs. Thomas B. Clarke, Alfred E.M. Purdy, Joseph S. Stout, Henry R. McLane, Clarence Andrews, Howard C. Smith, and Joseph C. Willets, has secured for the first monthly club art exhibition of the season a small and carefully selected number of paintings by artists for the most part of the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries.
I am a daily reader and admirer of THE TIMES, under its present management, and sincerely regret to see it advocate so iniquitous a measure as the so-called Torrey Bankruptcy bill.

The Lakewood is Tammany Hall just now, and Richard Croker's friends are gathering there to attend a conference that is scheduled for Saturday and Sunday. Mayor-elect Van Wyck left the New Jersey resort yesterday and came to New York, but he will return to-day to remain over Sunday. The Mayor-elect declined to talk for publication.

The arrest yesterday afternoon by Central Office detectives of Charles Zaneli, alias Charles Braune, alias Charles Suhner, a barber who had a shop at 61 Warren Street, revealed a life insurance fraud and gave rise to suspicions of a series of murders for insurance money extending over a period of fourteen years. No evidence has been found, however, to make good this suspicion.

MADRID, Dec. 9. -- At a Cabinet council to-day, at which the Queen Regent presided, the Premier, Senor Sagasta, outlined the opinions of the European press regarding President McKinley's message to Congress, the majority of which, the Premier said, were favorable to Spain. He further declared that in the event of the United States wishing to intervene in Cuba it would find the Government prepared to defend the rights and honor of Spain.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 9. -- The Hale-Harvard-Cornell boating situation is unchanged, nothing having been settled in the meeting in Albany yesterday of Capts. Whitney, Goodrich, and Colson. The crews of the three universities are no nearer to or further from a race than before. Capt. Whitney of the Yale crew said to-day:

ZANESVILLE, O., Dec. 9. -- The Zanesville Street Railway and Electric Company went into the hands of William Christie, receiver, yesterday. The bonded indebtedness is $200,000, and the floating debt 75,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- Committee on Foreign Affairs of the House held its first meeting to-day and outlined its work on the several important foreign questions now pending. Chairman Hitt announced the following sub-committees:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- An investigation now being made jointly by the officials of the Congressional Library and the officials of the Post Office Department promises to throw a great deal of light on the recent widely discussed shortage of ex-Librarian Ainsworth R. Spofford. An examination by the Treasury Department about a year ago showed Librarian Spofford to be about $30,000 short in his accounts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- Although no formal action has been taken, a pretty general understanding has been reached by the leaders in the House of Representatives as to the course of legislation in the near future. This contemplates the disposal of appropriation bills as fast as they are ready for consideration.
INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 9. -- Chairman H.H. Hanna of the Monetary Commission has sent to bankers of the country 10,000 circular letters under date of Dec. 4, as follows:

CHICAGO, Dec. 9. -- Deputy Sheriff McNichols this afternoon attached a carload of scenery in the Chicago and Alton Railway yards, the property of the Corinne opera company. The writ was in favor of the Santa Fe Road, which had a claim of $1.160 for hauling the scenery from San Francisco to Kansas City.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 9. -- The residence of Dr. Isaac E. Emerson, of "Bromo Seltzer" fame, was robbed to-night of $10,000 worth of jewelry. The thief, who gave his name as J. Davis and is thought by the police to be a professional crook, was captured and taken to the police station, where the jewelry was found on his person.

" Why Is Systematic Charity Disliked?" was the subject of discussion at the meeting of the Nineteenth Century Club at Sherry's last night. Fully 500 members and guests were in attendance, and evinced a deep interest in the arguments for and against systematic charity. The speakers of the evening were Dr. John Graham Brooks of Cambridge, Miss Jane Addams, founder of the Hull House, Chicago, and Robert Treat Paine.

The death of Charles Mettam, at his home in Bayonne, N.J., on Sunday last removes one of New York's oldest architects, and one highly distinguished both as an architect and as a civil engineer. Mr. Mettam was born in Dublin, Ireland, in May, 1819. He was educated in his native city, and after practicing his profession there and in England, came to New York, with his wife and family in 1848.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- The work of preparation of the Indian Appropriation bill will be begun immediately in the House Committee on Indian Affairs, and the bill will be reported to the House early in January. There are many important matters before the committee, but everything will give way to the Appropriation bill.

There is no class of holiday books in which greater change for the better has occurred than in books for children. The progress made in educational methods is to be seen reflected in juvenile literature. More effectual means have been taken for reaching the young mind. The books are more wholesome, more truly instructive, more admirable in every way. This year's books in this class present an uncommonly attractive and useful array.

ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 10. -- Prof. Wheeler of Cornell answers all questions as to the Albany rowing conference by saying that he knows nothing more than he has already given to the press. Capt. Colson still maintains silence, giving as a reason his pledge made to the other parties to the conference. A gentleman influential in Cornell navy affairs said to-night.

The address of the Monetary Commission, which we published yesterday morning, ought to appeal to all business men as well as to the particular classes to whom it is addressed. There is a theory, of which The New York Sun is the ingenious and obstinate champion, that the mere prevention of free silver is all that was desired by the voters who brought the Republican Party back to power in 1896.

Good Government Club C had a dinner last evening at the St. Denis Hotel, and entertained nearly 100 members and guests. John Jay Chapman presided at the dinner and at the discussion which closed the festivities of the occasion.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 10. -- The financial report of the Pillsbury-Washburn Flour Mills Company for the year ended Aug. 30, 1897, was made public. It shows a profit of $450,000 for the year, which was nearly sufficient to pay all fixed charges of the concern, together with an 8 per cent. dividend on preference securities.

LYNN, Mass., Dec. 10. -- Four women shoplifters -- Mrs. Clara Phillips, Mrs. Ida M. Houston and Misses Lulu Cobb and Florence Manson -- were held in $500 bail each for their appearance in the Superior Court by Judge Berry in the local Police Court this morning.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court yesterday, in an opinion written by Justice Ingraham, reversed the order of Justice Lawrence, in Special Term, denying an application of Frederick C. Beach and Jennie Beach Gasper, children of Harriet E. Beach, for a commission to inquire into Mrs. Beach's apparent lunacy and incompetency, and ordered the motion to be granted.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 10. -- The big Albany and New York night boat Dean Richmond and the four-masted schooner William B. Palmer collided in the fog last night, opposite the Clinton Point stone crusher, six miles south of this city. No lives were lost and no one was seriously injured, but considerable damage was done to both vessels.
LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 10. -- The Mayor-elect of Greater New York returned here this afternoon after his flying visit to the city.

Miss Kinne, Director of the Domestic Science Department of the Teachers' College, addressed the Household Economic Association yesterday afternoon on the introduction of domestic science in the schools, and, alluding to the generally poor physical condition of children as she saw them, asked: "Aren't the mothers to blame for this?"

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10. -- Richard Mansfield, the actor, was to-day held in $600 bail to answer at court a charge of assault and battery preferred by John Metzger of Cleveland, who has been in the actor's employ as a dresser for the past seven years.

Fire in the building at 632 Broadway, which started in the basement at 5:55 o'clock last evening, did about $10,000 damage. Three alarms were sent in, and several streams of water were soon pouring in, extinguishing every spark..

Herr HAMMACHER is the victim of political delusions, more or less voluntarily induced. It is easy for him to believe in any hobgoblin that will help scare the Reichstag into voting the German Emperor's Navy bill, and among these "pan-Americanism" and a "British zollverein" are about equally fanciful.

The Board of Street Opening and Improvement yesterday decided to widen One Hundred and Tenth Street, from Fifth Avenue to Seventh Avenue, along the northern end of Central Park, by taking thirty feet from the blocks on the opposite side of the street.

Friedrich Wilhelm Nietzsche, the prose poet of the Oversoul, the author of "Thus Spake Zarathrustra," and alternately the deifier and denouncer of Richard Wagner, recalls in certain superficial ways the late Walt Whitman. Both are magnifiers of the Ego, not merely obtruding their personality upon the reader, as many writers have done, but shouting aloud their right to proclaim the greatness of themselves to an astonished world.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 10. -- The American Flint Bottle Manufacturers' Association completed a combination at Indianapolis, recently, and last week met and rearranged the whole price list with a slight advance. Headquarters have been established in Indianapolis, but up to the present the company has succeeded in keeping it quiet.
In its review of the coal and iron trades, The Engineering and Mining Journal to-day will say:

CANTON, Ohio, Dec. 10. -- This is the ninth day of the sickness of Mrs. Nancy A. McKinley. During these nine days she has taken but little nourishment and has been conscious only a few times. The aged patient has withstood the assaults of disease, and to-day she was in about the same state as on Thursday.

BOSTON, Dec. 10. -- "I stole to live" were the words attributed by a morning paper to Marie Wilkins, who was arrested at the store of the S.S. Pierce Company, on Huntington Avenue, at 9 o'clock last evening. Then followed a pathetic description of how she was homeless and clothed in tattered garments, but that withal she had an air of respectability bespeaking better days.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- The Attorney Genera to-day directed United States Attorney H.S. Foote at San Francisco to file a bill in equity against the Coal Dealers' Association of California for violation of the anti-trust law of July 2, 1890. It is stated that the association is composed of retail dealers of San Francisco, and has for its object the control of the retail trade.

Never was list of books prepared without "left overs" -- books that were not readily admitted under the familiar headings. There are essays, handbooks, educational books, technical books, calendars, elegant extracts, books of reference, collected works in prose and verse -- and what not else, a few volumes in each class, but not enough to make a group with a heading.

Charles Fleischmann, who died yesterday morning at Avondale, a suburb of Cincinnati, was almost as much a New Yorker as any resident of this city. Some of his largest business interests ad enterprises and several members of his family were here, and he was closely identified with the social life of New York and the Eastern turf.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- It was said in reliable quarters about the House of Representatives to-day that Secretary Gage, had made his purpose known not to embody his financial views in one comprehensive bill, but to cover special subjects in a number of special bills, some of which would go before the House Committee on Banking and Currency, and others before the Committee on Ways and Means.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- Chief Frederick Emory of the Bureau of Foreign Commerce of the State Department is about to undertake a considerable enlargement of the most useful feature of that bureau through a daily issue in print of the reports that come to the bureau from United States Consuls in every portion of the world.

There is a man in a cell at Police Headquarters who may turn out to be one of the most remarkable murderers of the age, or simply a person who has been peculiarly fortunate in making his insurance investments. His name is Charles Zanoli, and he is a German barber.

GAINESVILLE, Ga., Dec. 10. -- A revival of the whipping post has just occurred here, the unique feature being its sanction by the Mayor. Henry Brown, a young negro, has for some time been terrorizing the merchants by pilfering small articles of value and engaging in fights with the white boys. Gradually increasing in boldness, he attempted highway robbery yesterday.

Statistics show that next after fiction and history and biography, the books most largely published, are those which treat of religion. This statement refers only to the number published. As to readers, were it possible to obtain statistics, the showing might be different. But it remains true that a larger proportion of the reading public is interested in religious books than is commonly supposed.

According to the language and intent of the new city charter, consolidation will be no bar to the authorization and construction of a rapid-transit road, even if the work shall not actually have begun until after Jan. 1. Section 46 of the charter contains this provision:

It was a day of painful success for Charles W. Miller in the fifth day of the six days' cycling at the Garden yesterday. Hour after hour he pedaled stubbornly forward, breaking records with almost every turn of the track. Early in the evening Miller was nearly ninety miles beyond the nearest rider, and was 230 miles ahead of previously existing records.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- Ex-President Cleveland arrived in Washington this afternoon at 1:55 o'clock in a special car attached to the regular west-bound train on the Pennsylvania Railroad. He left Princeton this morning at 9:30 o'clock, and is en route to South Carolina on a hunting trip.

Slawson Hobbs have sold for William P. Dixon, of Miller, Peckham Dixon, to David E. Oppenheimer and Joseph Hamershlag, the plot on the south side of One Hundred and Second Street, 125 feet west of the Boulevard. This plot is directly opposite the twenty-two lots sold by the Furniss estate to the same purchasers early in the week.

Ever since the Board of Review of the National Trotting Association began its session at the Murray Hill Hotel, on Tuesday, the members of the board have thrown out cornered "ringers" and their owners whenever sufficient proof was forthcoming, but they waited until yesterday to burst out in all their wrath on some of the offending horsemen.

A friend writes to me: "I cannot read Howells, or Marion Crawford, or Merriman, or any of the others, except Barrie, and his tales are only stories, not really novels. Mrs. Humphry Ward is also an exception. Does this sound silly and a little snobbish? Yet I have a very real devotion to give to the older writers whom I love best -- Thackeray and Dickens and Hawthorne, George Eliot and George Meredith."

Verestchagin's pictures of the Russian campaign of Napoleon L, it may be remembered, when exhibited in Paris, did not please. It was not the art of the Russian painter which was not lauded. The subject jarred on the Frenchman's mind, especially as at the time of the exhibition every effort was being made for affiliation with Russia. So, after a brief showing of the collection, the paintings were removed.

I inclose a slip from THE TIMES REVIEW OF BOOKS AND ART of last Saturday, containing the article on the "Imp of the Press." The error in proofreading in the article itself is certainly as amusing as any quoted.

The report sent out from Paris a few days ago that Alphonse Daudet was to contend for the fauteuil of the Duc d'Aumale in the French Academy is evidently a mistake. Later advices not only fail to confirm it, but name his brother, Ernest Daudet, as the candidate.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- A singular Chinese case has come to the attention of the Treasury Department.

BATON ROUGE, La., Dec. 10. -- The work of the State Democratic Convention yesterday was devoted to settling upon a plan of nominating the thirty-six delegates at large to the Constitutional Convention. It was finally decided that the delegates from each of the six Congressional districts select six names to be presented to the convention, and a recess was taken to permit the districts to hold their separate meetings.

The actual distribution of Tammany's cash gift of $20,000 to "the deserving poor" and of Nathan Straus's 1,000 tons of coal, intended especially for needy widows, will begin to-day. The apportioning of the two benefactions to the various districts was completed yesterday afternoon, when the district leaders met at the Fourteenth Street Wigwam and received their checks and coal tickets.

It is a fine thing to demonstrate that a man astride two wheels can, in a six-day race, distance a hound, a horse, or a locomotive. It confirms the assumption, no longer much contested, that the human animal is superior to the other animals. But this undisputed thing is being said in too solemn aria painful a way at Madison Square Garden.

The art season, after a long period of inaction, opened with a rush on Monday last, and there have been several exhibitions of various kinds which have kept the members of the art world busy all during the week. Perhaps the most interesting displays have been those of portraits by Jean Boldini and Antonio de la Gandera, both noted Parisian portrait painters.

A history of the art development of New York as shown in the picture sales that have occurred here would present many interesting phases; in many respects there could be no better index to the growth of investments and the changes in fashions. THE REVIEW OF BOOKS AND ART is fortunate in being able to lay before its readers the following succinct account of this early art development.

Since the disposal of the Seney collection, in 1885, there have been many valuable collections sold at auction in New York. For this period there has been prepared for THE REVIEW OF BOOKS AND ART by Mr. Samuel P. Avery, Jr., a record of the important sales, omitting all where the totals have not exceeded $15, 000:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- The House Committee on Civil Service met to-day and outlined the work before it. Four sub-committees were appointed. Messrs. Brosius, Sprague, Alexander, Dockery, and Robertson will have charge of all matters relating to the amendment of the civil service law and rules. This is the most important part of the work, as there are many measures now pending looking to alterations in the law.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- The Agricultural Department to-day issued the following:

Miss Ruth Lawrence, daughter of Judge Abraham Lawrence and a member of a small club of New York society young women calling themselves "Little Daughters of the Quill," has written and published through Brentano's a little book of poems, entitled "Colonial Verses," which have for their subject the various rooms of Washington's home at Mount Vernon, the building itself, the garden, tomb, and outbuildings.
