Eighteen Assembly districts, two of them by proxy, were represented at a meeting in the Windsor Hotel last night, at which the special committees appointed by the Plaza Club conferrees submitted an address to the voters and a plan for a new Republican organization for the City and County of New York.

Forty thousand young men, members of the various social-religious organizations in the United States that are affiliated with the Roman Catholic Young Men's National Union of America, will celebrate the Feast of the Immaculate Conception of the Blessed Virgin, with appropriate religious services, in the various churches with which the societies are connected, to-morrow morning.

District Attorney Olcott said yesterday that, owing to circumstances which have controlled the postponing of the trial of the cases against Samuel Kreiser and others, charged with conspiracy in running fake auction sales, the trial might not be had during his administration, which merchants and others interested in the cases assert is equivalent to the fact that they will not be tried for a long time, if at all.

By the explosion of a vulcanizer Dr. Charles Lawrence, a dentist of 170 North Sixth Street, Williamsburg, was probably fatally burned late yesterday afternoon, and his brother-in-law, Dr. Henry Kregelow, was burned about the head and arms. The men are partners, and both belong to the Brooklyn Revolver Club, which was organized about two months ago.

Beginning to-morrow, three days will be devoted to the celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of the organization of the Evangelical Lutheran Church of St. Mark in New York by its members. This church is in thriving condition in Sixth Street, near Second Avenue, and although the constant changes of fifty years have scattered the original congregation widely, there are now between 650 and 700 communicants and more than 700 children in the Sunday school.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10. -- After considerable effort the bull clique in the wheat market succeeded to-day in closing the lid on the boiling December shorts and getting the price down to a point that does not so openly invite all the contract wheat in the country to Chicago. December closed at $1.03, a decline for the day of 4 cents, while May showed about 1 cent decline at the close.

Under the auspices of the City History Club, Prof. Woodrow Wilson of Princeton University delivered a lecture on "Patriotism Begins at Home" at Sherry's, Thirty-seventh Street and Fifth Avenue, last evening.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 10. -- Judge Ritchie today dismissed the petition for a mandamus brought by Robert W. Clark, Jr., (colored,) against the Maryland Institute to compel the institute to accept him as a pupil in its school of art and design. This is one of the most important and interesting cases that has arisen in the local courts for years.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 10. -- Justice of the Peace Connell of Belleville heard a report last night of the coolest burglar that the town has known for some time. John Hughes of John Street, Belleville, told him that Wednesday night, when the family retired, some one forgot to lock the back door of the kitchen.

That invaluable book, which, we trust, will ever be called after its originator, the late William F. Poole, "Poole's Index," is now presented in its third supplement, arranged and complied by Messrs. William L. Fletcher, Librarian of Amherst College, and Franklin O. Poole, assistant in the Boston Athenaeum Library.

Mr. Charles C. West of the Stock Exchange house of Charles Head Co. talked yesterday to a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES, giving his views of the stock-market outlook. Mr. West is a confident bull, believing in material improvement insecurity market values as the natural outcome of the vastly improved conditions throughout the country. Mr. West said:

WASHINGTON, Dec 10. -- Attorney General McKenna has taken steps looking to the postponement of the sale of the Kansas Pacific Road. As soon as he received a copy of yesterday's Senate resolution he telegraphed its substance to the Government's special counsel, ex-Gov. Hoadly, at New York, with a request that he prepare at once a motion asking for a postponement for sixty days, or until about Feb. 15.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10. -- Judge Dallas in the United States Circuit Court to-day heard argument on the motion of Thomas A. Baxter, of Boston, for permission to intervene in the application of Godfrey Morse, of Boston, and other bondholders, for the appointment of receivers for the Bay State Gas Company.

Under this heading are grouped that class of books which, after novels, are the most widely read of all books. They give us human history, and nothing so interests a human being as the history of other human beings. When those other persons have been famous, or have done great deeds, their lives are interesting to all sane and inquiring minds.

SEATTLE, Washington, Dec. 1. -- The steamer Rosalie arrived here yesterday from Skaguay and Dyea, Alaska, with thirty-five passengers. The Rosalie brings the news that James B. McAuley of Victoria is on his way out from Dawson City with a dog train, and is expected to arrive at Skaguay in a week or ten days.

The year 1887 was a very full and gay season at Aix, and memorable to me for many reasons. The Queen Marguerite was at Courmayeur, on the Italian side of the Alps. We often heard of her heroic ascents. We were ambitious to go on later to the royal wedding of Amadeo, which we did, and we threw in one bitter experience at Miolan.

The sophomore class of Columbia University, thinking that the freshmen were to have their first annual dinner last night, made plans to capture the class officers in order to keep them away from the dinner. The sophomores were divided into divisions, and each division, it was planned, was to capture some assigned man.

The work of getting a jury to try Edward J. Ratcliffe, the actor charged with assaulting his wife, the daughter of Peter Ds Lacy, the bookmaker, was begun before Judge Newburger in Part I. of the General Sessions Court yesterday afternoon. Ratcliffe was indicted June 25, 1897, on the charge of assault in the second degree. He was arrested in Chicago, and voluntarily came to New York to stand trial.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- At the opening of the session to-day it was agreed that when the House adjourn it be to meet on Monday. The House then resumed consideration of the Pension Appropriation bill under an agreement to close general debate on the measure at 3:15 P.M.

Yesterday's stock market was marked by frequent intervals of strength and weakness. All day the professional talent of the Stock Exchange were sellers of stocks, partly for the purpose of realizing and partly for effect upon the market. Those traders who for the week past have been operating on the bull side took profits yesterday, as is usual toward the end of the week.

County Chairman Quigg was at the Madison Avenue headquarters yesterday afternoon, engaged with Secretary George R. Manchester in making preparations for the primaries. With regard to the allegation that it is the desire of the anti-organization forces to conduct the proposed new organization along lines of non-partisanship in municipal affairs, Mr. Quigg said:

The second public rehearsal of the Philharmonic Society at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon drew an audience large enough to demonstrate very thoroughly that the majority does not go to the Philharmonic concerts simply to hear the soloists. The fame of M. Raoul Pugno, pianist, has not yet attained such dimensions that he can be credited with having attracted the audience.

Ten years ago the name of Rudyard Kipling was supposed, by anybody that knew it at all, to be the improbable pseudonym of some clever person who had begun to write dashing, ephemeral stories and stray verses about the English in India. To-day his name is recognized as the true one of the man who, if any, has attained by common consent the chief position in contemporary English literature.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 10. -- A case of a woman leading a double life came to light here when Henry M. Frustuck, a grocer of this city, had his wife, Mary, and Wiliam Wristland, arrested on a charge of bigamy. Frustuck married his wife in Los Angeles in 1888. He moved to this city in 1890 with his wife and little boy.

If the anointed Kaiser of Germany did not take himself with a seriousness that amounted to preternatural solemnity, it would have been quite impossible for him to make the murder of two missionaries the basis of the wonderful claims he has put forth upon China. The demand of a railway monopoly in Shan-Tung as the price of the missionaries' lives was sufficiently iudicrous.

The holiday book of ten years ago was distinctly an illustrated book -- usually large in cover size and thin in the back; but this type of book, which, after all, was an inconvenient, if not useless, thing, save for centre tables, has about passed away. More and more is the holiday book a book good for all the year round, and of proportions suitable for the ordinary bookcase.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 10. -- Michael Pursell, a boilermaker, was making some repairs inside the smokestack of the steamer Wellington at the Folsom Street wharf, when six fires were started below him.

The committee of seven who will have charge of the preliminaries for the demonstration in honor of old New York on the last day of the year will meet to-day at 1 o'clock in the Mayor's office. The committee was appointed at the meeting held at Delmonico's on Thursday evening, and consists of Mayor Strong, Dr. Depew, Justice J.F. Daly, Francis M. Scott, A.P. Fitch, W.F. King, and Salem H. Wales.

The representatives of the wire and steel rod manufacturers, who have been in this city for several weeks arranging the final terns of the agreement into which the individual factories will enter to constitute single company or trust, have about completed their work, and the success of the enterprise is certain.

ALTOONA, Penn., Dec. 11. -- Depositors in the defunct Gardner Morrow Bank of Hollidaysburg, 600 in number, held a mass meeting in the Opera House this afternoon to take steps looking toward the recovery of $750,000 deposited in the bank. The merchants of the town closed their business places, and the country people for miles around drove to town to attend the meeting.

IT is a good many years now since Margot first made her appearance in the world. How, when, or where that event took place no one who knew her could ever tell. Margot herself did not know. It was evidently an event of so little importance that it had never been thought worth while to make a record of it.

In the annual report of the Charity Organization Society of the City of New York, just issued, special attention is called to some of the most conspicuous charitable needs in this city. One of the greatest is additional homes for aged persons, similar to the Chapin Home, the Home for the Aged of the Little Sisters of the Poor, St. Johnland, the Methodist Episcopal Church Home, the Colored Home and Hospital, and the Presbyterian Home.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 11. -- At the last sitting of the Legislature of Tennessee a law was enacted which is known as the "Johnny law," and is so captioned in the code of laws of the State. It was made for the protection of a certain female school in Nashville, but applies to all parts of the State alike, and in Knoxville it was first to be tested.

PHOTOGRAPHY has become a widely practiced art during the past few years, and the reading public is constantly surprised by the appearance of photographic work of so much merit as to make it difficult to believe it is not always the product of skilled professionals.

The shortcoming of London, as a capital city, is that it is almost entirely devoid of the qualities of spaciousness and stateliness. It is not so much like a capital city as like a very large and overgrown provincial town. The few hours' run to Paris forces upon our attention the contrast between a mere town and a capital city in the true sense of the word.

WATERVILLE, Me., Dec. 11. -- A twelve-hundred-dollar shipment of cats has just been made to a Philadelphia merchant who proposes to place them on sale in a big department store there. The shipment included 100 kittens, and they are of all kinds and colors, the Angora variety predominating.

There was another school fight on Staten Island on Friday night. The meeting was held to select a site for a new school building in District No. 1 of the Castleton and Middletown School, and the session lasted more than four hours, not ending until 1:30 o'clock yesterday morning.
STANFORD UNIVERSITY, Cal., Dec. 11. -- Dr. Jordan, in an interview on pelagic sealing and the bill introduced in Congress to prevent Americans from engaging in it, said last evening:

HACKENSACK, N.J., Dec. 11. -- Johann F. Gerhardy of Dellemonte, who was arrested here on Wednesday while visiting a prisoner -- James Lewis Fourmier -- in the Bergen County Jail, committed suicide early to-day by hanging himself in a cell.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 11. -- " Billy" Lakeland, the trainer, this morning closed a deal for Hamburg, John E. Madden's great two-year-old, by Hanover, dam Lady Reel, the purchaser acting as agent for W.L. Powers of New York. When seen this morning Lakeland admitted having bought the colt, but declined to state the price paid.
Fully 8,000 people were in the Twenty-second Regiment Armory, Sixty-seventh Street and the Western Boulevard, last night to witness the nineteenth games of the athletic association of the regiment.

LONDON, Dec. 11. -- Four Cabinet councils in a week are calculated to arouse comment, but it must be admitted that the Marquis of Salisbury and his colleagues have a multiplicity of matters more or less urgently calling for a settlement.

BERLIN, Dec. 11. -- The Berlin butchers and meat dealers have passed a resolution requesting the Government to reopen the frontiers to meat import and to severely restrict the traffic in American meat. They say 28,000,000 marks' worth was imported in 1896 at prices which they cannot compete with.
LEWISTON, Me., Dec. 11. -- What is considered a remarkable case of answered prayer has happened in the family of Mr. Woods, who preaches at the Friends' Chapel, on College Street, this city.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Dec. 11. -- Danny Robb, whose former home was in Cumberland, Md., where he has relatives, was shot and instantly killed at the Palace Hotel this morning by the proprietor, William Downey.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11. -- Chicago may yet lose its popularity as a resort for highwaymen and other desperate characters if a movement inaugurated to-day by a number of West Side citizens proves successful.

REGRET at the removal from Van Cortlandt Park of the herd of buffaloes loaned to this city by the estate of Austin Corbin probably would be more widespread had there existed keener popular appreciation of the presence here of so fine a collection of these distinctively American game animals, which in the West are fast becoming extinct.

LONDON, Dec. 11. -- There is a controversy over the question of Oscar Wilde's reappearance as a dramatist. A prominent manager is preparing to produce his latest play under a thinly veiled pseudonym. There-upon the St. James's Gazette says:

In this morning's TIMES your correspondent L.D. Burdick appears quite angry because, "in the interests of historical truth," it is claimed that Washington was a churchman. If one goes on to read Mr. Burdick's letter expecting to find some reason for this indignation, he is met with some quotations which go to confirm "the historical truth" of the claim that Washington was a churchman.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 11. -- The committee appointed by the Grand Camp of Confederate Veterans to investigate the History Committee scandal, submitted its report this afternoon. This report was made to Col James N. Stubbs, who, as Grand Commander, appointed the committee, and who has figured prominently in the investigation.

I have two things still that I wish to tell you about concerning our trip to England. I have saved them up for the last, partly because, like the children, I like to have "the last the best of all the game," and partly because they really were the last events of our delightful visit.

Bottle makers throughout the country will be interested in a decision handed down by the Board of United States General Appraisers yesterday, in which a ruling by the Collector of this port is reversed. Witteman Brothers of this city protested against the classification as etched ware of a quantity of empty green glass bottles imported by them.

It is by all means to be hoped that some workable compromise or provisional expedient may be found by which the compact between Austria and Hungary can be kept in force until it can be duly and formally renewed. Of course the "dual monarchy" is a mere makeshift, though it has lasted thirty years.

A series of free musicals for working women are being given during this month at St. Bartholomew's Lyceum Hall, 207 East Forty-second Street. Instrumental music, singing, tales of travel, helpful suggestions, hot tea, and cakes make the hour pass pleasantly, and women of all creeds and nationalities are welcomed.

VIENNA, Nov. 27. -- The Delegations of the Parliaments of Austria and Hungary, which have the control of the army and foreign affairs of the dual monarchy, have this week met under the sign of a very peaceful situation in Europe. These Delegations are a queer body, or rather are queer bodies, but somehow they have managed the imperial business for thirty years.

YONKERS, Dec. 11. -- A fire which was attended with considerable excitement and some narrow escapes broke out shortly after 7 o'clock this evening in the two-story tenement at 9 John Street. The house was fully occupied, and so quickly did the flames spread that the inmates had considerable difficulty in getting out. They lost all their belongings, and several received bad burns.

If is a standing complaint of every American housewife that she finds it impossible to obtain good domestic servants. The question of obtaining good and efficient help as a thorn in the flesh of every housekeeper who is dependent on the help of others. The servant evil affects not only those who are in moderate circumstances, but equally as well the rich and affluent, who can well afford to pay liberal wages.

Among the pretty things which Santa Claus's chief lieutenants, the mothers and sisters and wives, are already beginning to gather together in large numbers for the Christmas holidays there is nothing more wonderful than the clever work of the Russian peasant women. There is one little corner filled with it in that emporium of pretty gifts and woman's work, the Woman's Exchange, just around the corner from Fifth Avenue in Thirtieth Street.

NEW HAVEN, Dec. 11. -- Yale University is devoting her attention earnestly to furnish a crew for 1898 that will redeem the defeat of Yale at Poughkeepsie last Summer. Yale sentiment is in favor of a race with Cornell, and "Bob" Cook is at work already to develop a crew that will represent the college creditably in the New London contest in June.

The New York Branch of the Guild of St. Barnabas for Nurses has just opened permanent headquarters at 144 Fifth Avenue. In doing so it leads other branches of the guild in Other cities. The guild is a National organization within the Protestant Episcopal Church. About 300 members belong to the New York Branch.

The Board of Review of the National Trotting Association, which has been in session at the Murray Hill Hotel since Tuesday, wound up its judgments of the cases on the docket and adjourned last night to meet again in Chicago next May.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Altogether the most interesting topic of War Department gossip for some weeks has been the case of Capt. O.M. Carter, Corps of Engineers, who is soon to be tried by court-martial at Savannah. To other than engineer officers the proceedings in the case have appeared to be very remarkable.

When Stephen Arnold Douglas was but a couple of years old he lost his father. He was born in Brandon, Vt., on April 23, 1813. He lived on a farm not far from his native town and picked apples and potatoes for every tenth bushel to help his mother make ends meet until he was fifteen.

A scheme to establish a National university as a memorial to George Washington, which has been under consideration for some time, is to be exhaustively discussed at a congress called for Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday in Washington.

THE word club as applied to a woman's organization was not one which would have been used to conjure with thirty years ago. One reason for this was, women say, in discussing the subject, that men's clubs did not mean then what they do now; they were organizations devoted more to high living than to thinking of any kind.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- A largely attended meeting of Republican Representatives in Congress was held to-night, at the River and Harbor Committee rooms, to devise means for securing a change in the present civil service law. About sixty members were present, representing most of the States having Republican delegations in Congress. It was noticeable, however, that Speaker Reed, Mr. Dingley, and other leaders of the House did not attend.

ClNCINN.a, TI, Dec. ll. -- It is stated on the best authority that the racing stable ofCharles Fleisehmann Son will. be run nxt year in the East and that 'the contract 'with Ted Sloan to ride for that stable-next season will hold good.

The three matches decided by the members of the Seventh Regiment Rifle Club at the armory last night were productive of some good scores. The Three Prize Match, the conditions of which were seven shots standing and seven shots prone, resulted in a tie between Lieut. A.G. Todd and Veteran A. Stein, Lieut. Todd received first prize because of the best score off shoulder.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 11. -- The election to choose a Board of Freeholders to present a new charter for the government of the city will be held on the 27th inst., and upon the result of the voting the future of San Francisco to a very great extent depends. Happily for the people the issue is squarely before them.

A children's "costume fete" was held yesterday in the ballroom of the Astoria in aid of St. Mary's Free Hospital for Children, in Thirty-fourth Street, near Tenth Avenue. Pretty children, dressed as flowers of all kinds, flitted around the room, selling the flower they represented, and the brilliant colors of the costumes made the display effective.

From the little mosque of the village arises the watchword of Islam, and with long-sustained musical notes the "mueddin" calls the faithful to prayer. In the gathering gloom one sees the Arabs congregating at the mosque, and a minute later the monotonous buzz of their prayers is heard.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11. -- A sequel to the troubles between Richard Mansfield, the actor, and John Metzger, who was for seven years Mansfield's dresser for the stage, developed to-day in a civil suit for damages brought by Metzger. Yesterday Mansfield was held by Magistrate Eisenbrown under $600 bail for a further hearing on a criminal charge of assault and battery upon Metzger.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11. -- Eight wards, seven of them on the South Side and the eighth the most remarkable First Ward ever heard of in Chicago, were formally and finally adopted by the City Council Redistricting Committee to-day. The new wards are the First, Fourth, Fifth, Thirty-second, Thirty-fourth, Twenty-ninth, Thirtieth, and Thirty-first.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- It is evident from the talk among the members of the House who are endeavoring to secure a combination to weaken and restrict the civil service law, that they will not all agree upon a measure of restriction. Very few of those who were induced to sign the call for a conference are confident that the President will contribute his aid to perfect any such proposition they may submit to him.

CENTRE MORICHES, L.I., Dec. 11. -- Editor Robbins of The Moriches Messenger ate his Christmas turkey yesterday, in consequence of the incautious character of the bird, the enterprise of a dog, a neighbor's lack of discrimination, and his own ability as a detective.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Carpenters have been at work for two or three days, fitting storm doors to the White House. They are contrived to keep out the wind, the snow, and the rain, and also some light that formerly made its way into the vestibule through stained glass windows introduced by President Arthur.

With the products of flour, such as bread, buns, cake, macaroni, vermicelli, , the adulteration, while more frequent, is likewise not very pronounced. Bread is said to be adulterated with alum, sulphate of copper, ammonia, flours other than wheat, and inferior grade of flour. It is questionable if these adulterations are practiced to any extent in the United States.

According to the committee's report, liquor may be obtained in Portland from ordinary bars under police protection, kitchen bars, pocket peddlers, hotel bars, apothecary shops, bottling establishments, express companies, clubs, and the city liquor agency. The ordinary bars have little on the outside to betray their nature, but access is easy.

The final match in the golf handicap series which has been in progress since Summer in the Staten Island Crick Club was played yesterday on the club links at Livingston, S.I. Only the winners of the previous contests were eligible to compete. It was a well-fought game, the finish being one of the closest ever seen on the links, three men tying for first place, with a net score of 90.

At Dibble we stopped at the head man's house. All our animals were fastened in the front yard. His daughter, an only child, was cooking in the yard, her dress tucked up and her arms and feet bare. She greeted us cordially, and then her father, "Hanna Mutter," a generous, hospitable host, gave us the best he had, in the best house in the town, and that is all one room.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11. -- Fire started shortly before 10 o'clock to-night in the basement of the six-story building at 809 and 811 Chestnut Street, occupied by the carpet manufacturing firm of John James Dobson as their wholesale and retail salesroom. The fire quickly shot up the elevator shafts.

Henry Allen: The stock market is strong because underlying conditions are uniformly favorable. Nothing can prevent such conditions as those we now have from affecting security market values. Bear manipulators may bring about temporary declines, but they can be only temporary and insignificant compared with the gains which securities are to make.

The great majority of the business men of the United States, acting through Chambers of Commerce. Boards of Trade, and associations, is urging upon Congress the passage of an impartial bankruptcy law. These commercial bodies have unanimously indorsed the Torrey Bankruptcy bill, which has been before Congress more than a dozen years, and has passed the House several times. They have with equal unanimity opposed the passage of the Nelson substitute bill.

As a cordial indorser of the many well-put home truths in Mrs. Obenchain's letter on "Extravagance and Economy" in THE TIMES of Nov. 28, may I be permitted to add a few lines from another woman's point of view, albeit of dissent on one or two points?

An ex-County Treasurer has been driving a cart in the Street Cleaning Department in this city for a year and a half, and for the last six months has been acting as a probationary assistant foreman in the same department. Notwithstanding the wide difference in the two positions, the incumbent would be satisfied to remain in the humbler of the two.

The first church Christmas tree for poor children in the City of New York was lighted in the parish of the Holy Communion in 1847, under Dr. Muhlenberg's direction, in the schoolroom of the high school for young ladies conducted by the Sisters, the schoolhouse proper, where in after years it was customary to have it, being not then completed.

The two Sarah A. Knights, whose respective claims to ownership of the same piece of property in this city furnishes the basis of a suit at law which was described in this newspaper yesterday, will meet each other for the first time in the Supreme Court room before Justice Cohen to-morrow forenoon.

Almost all of the war histories are written by officers and from their point of view. Here is a little one as to how a part of the Union forces got into the fight at Missionary Ridge written by a private, in which he tells what he saw and did.

To the sparsely settled moors of old Britain it would have been folly to furnish roads, but between first the larger towns and then the smaller villages were established the King's highways. And it was long after they were defined before, in general, they were worked or paved. The granting of franchises to stage and tramway lines followed later in the attempt to meet economically the growing wants of a denser population.

John Dickinson, a diamond importer, was found dead at 6:30 A.M. yesterday on Ninety-second Street, between First and Second Avenues, Brooklyn. It was only a short distance from his house, which is at Ninety-second Street and the Shore Road, Fort Hamilton.

Apropos of your editorial reference this morning to the refusal of the Turkish Government to make indemnity to American citizens for the destruction of their property to an amount of $100,000 or more, in November, 1895, a private letter just received from Constantinople attributes to Minister Angell, the opinion that nothing more can probably be accomplished by diplomacy.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 11. -- A semi-official declaration in support of Dr. Shields in his attitude toward the signing of the license application for Princeton Inn was made last night at the first annual dinner of the Union County Princeton Club by Chief Justice Magie, one of the members of the Board of Trustees of the university.

WHAT a pity it is that more people do not take the very small amount of trouble necessary to learn the difference between good and bad performance in music. It is a little more difficult to learn the difference between good and bad music, but even that can be done by any one of ordinary intelligence who will read three or four books and learn certain fundamental principles.

There was a general tendency to exultation yesterday on the part of the leaders of the movement for a new Republican organization in this city. They professed satisfaction with the reception given to the address issued by the Windsor Hotel conference, and pointed to Mr. Quigg's authorized interview, given out so as to appear simultaneously with that address, as an indication that the "regulars" were "rattled."

In eight years builders in Britain have constructed for foreign owners vessels aggregating nearly 1,750,000 tons -- an average of 200,000 tons per annum. This includes war ships; but, if we consider only merchantmen, we find that the average is now more than 150,000 tons, while ten years ago it was about 80,000 tons, and forty years ago only 25,000 tons.

Our protectionist neighbor The Tribune holds that it is unfair for Mugwump and free trade newspapers to quote the estimate of the Secretary of the Treasury showing a deficit of $21,000,000 for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1899. It points out that his estimate of expenditures is the aggregate of the estimates of the department officers, who always ask for more than they expect to get, notably in the river and harbor estimate.

Congress in session a week and not a single catastrophe yet in evidence; the record is not what Wall Street for months has been predicting and worrying over. Here and there are still prophets dealing out gruesome forecasts of dreadful things which may yet come to pass at Washington; but professional Wall Street has quit its nervousness on such account.

There is a City Hall library of between four and five thousand volumes which comparatively few person know anything about. The greater part of this library is now piled up helter-skelter in the Governor's Room, but as soon as the alterations in progress at the old City Hall, are completed these books and documents will have better quarters than they have ever had before.

Augustine Washington, like most scholarly Virginians of his time, was a deist. The only one of his children who appears to have been christened was George, which, may have been a concession to his second wife. According to his relative, Mrs. Throckmorton, George was prayerful in childhood, and there are two or three quotations from hymns in one of his earliest copybooks written in a childish hand.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11. -- Some Chicago people have begun a fight to get rid of the terrible odors that originate in the stock yards, and, as one of the fighters puts it, "hang in clouds over the city and at times are so dense that they have to be cut with axes."

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Dec. 11. -- The Faribault syndicate of New York capitalists, headed by James York of England, has made a contract with the Faribault-Orinoco Company of this city under which it will engage in mining iron ore, for which large contracts have been made in England. The Faribault Company has a concession embracing 14,000,000 acres from the Venezuelan Government, and from this land the ore will be taken.

Certain young artists and very young, unsophisticated actors who lodge in boarding houses or studios spend much time in telling their respectable friends how delightful it is to live in Bohemia. They think they live in Bohemia -- but they don't. They have been told that they don't many times; still they persist in declaring that they do.

-- The announcement that the United States cruiser Marblehead arrived at Port au Prince to protect American interests after the trouble with Germany was all over must have been extremely gratifying to all patriots. But that is the way it generally happens. A disturbance breaks out in some such place as Greytown, and a cruiser is ordered to go there at once.

LONDON, Dec. 11. -- Although the week has witnessed a marked abatement in the popular disorder in Austria, the less exciting but graver symptoms of the impending break-up of the Hapsburg empire make themselves more apparent day by day. As foreshadowed last Sunday, the stop-gap Premier, Baron Gautsch, ignominiously failed to secure any working compromise between the embittered parties of the Reichsrath, and all attempts to do so have been definitely abandoned.

The North Sea continually encroaches upon the beaches and cliffs on both its east and west shores. Nearly the entire coast of the Counties of Norfolk and Suffolk, England, is melting away before the waves in greater or less rapidity. The sea slowly but surely removes the bluffs, which slip and slide, carrying with them villages and towns that, in the olden time, were among the more important of the kingdom.

We are glad to see that Postmaster General Gary is to continue the effort, so vigorously made by his predecessor, to put an end to the fraud committed upon the law and the postal service through the abuse of the privilege of cheap postage charged for the transmission of second-class mail matter.

She was talking about cats. "Isn't he handsome," she said, looking at the family pet. "I am going to get a kitten while I am here to take home, I didn't expect to be here just at this time, but I did not go away in the Summer as I expected. We were going down to the end of Long Island and had our rooms all engaged.

BERLIN, Dec. 11. -- It is reported that Prince Henry of Prussia, who has been appointed to the command of the second German Squadron, on the coast of China, will visit Pekin, where the Chinese Emperor will receive him as an equal, an unusual honor. Prince Henry, it is announced, is the bearer of a message from Emperor William to the Chinese Emperor, in which is included a programme of Chinese reforms.

Mrs. Frances Fisher Wood lectured yesterday morning before the League for Political Education, at 509 Fifth Avenue, on "Our Destructive Classes." The address was, in part, a continuation of the one read by Mrs. Wood the Saturday before on "Unproductive Philanthropy."

Some time ago there was a street fight in one of the small country villages of the South. When the smoke cleared away it was discovered that two prominent citizens and three noted desperadoes had been killed.

CAMDEN, N.J., Dec. 11. -- Francis Lingo, a negro, of Merchantville, was arrested early this morning on a charge of using the mails to aid him in a criminal proceeding in attempting to entice Miss Catherine V. Berry of 2044 Twelfth Street, Philadelphia, from her home to Merchantville.

Mrs. Edward J. Ratcliffe, wife of the actor who is now on trial for assaulting her, yesterday made a statement to Assistant District Attorney Lloyd, who is handling the case for the people, in which she gave an account of her experiences with Ratcliffe since the time she made his acquaintance, and of her unhappy life with him and the brutal treatment she says she received from him after their marriage.

CANTON, O., Dec. 11. -- This, the tenth day of Mrs. McKinley's illness, has been marked by a number of material changes, none of which has permanently improved the condition of the patient, and as darkness approached it was felt by those around her that she had finished the last day of her life's journey. She was resting comparatively easy at that time, but a great deal weaker.

That the present awakening of interest in American history cannot fail to exert a powerful influence upon this generation is certain. Exactly what that influence will be it is not so easy to determine. A generation of men and women cannot be greatly addicted to any one class of reading without being cast into trains of thought that are peculiar to the literature so studied and absorbed.

THE most recent acquisition to the list of sopranos at the Grand Opera in Paris is Mlle. Ackte. About six months ago rumors of her achievements began to float across the Atlantic to this country, and those who are supposed to know all about the doings of the world of music began to speculate on the possibility of her having made a genuine success.

LONDON, Dec. 11. -- The big schooner yacht, designed by George L. Watson, which is building at Henderson's yards, and which was supposed to be for the Prince of Wales, is for Charles L. Orr-Ewing, member of Parliament for Ayr Burgs, who has traveled extensively in the East, and who takes great interest in yachting.

So far depleted has become the Engineer Corps that not an officer can be detailed for duty to inspect the iron and steel furnished for ordnance; only one is detailed for inspection of armor; but two are to be found at the Boston Navy Yard, only seven at League Island, and a baker's dozen or so at the New York yard.

NEWPORT, Dec. 11. -- By June 1 next Mr. and Mrs. Stuyvesant Fish will take possessession of their new villa now in course of erection on the Ocean Drive, near Bailey's Beach, upon a hill that gives a magnificent sight of the ocean, the city, and the island. The contractor, Mr. Curry, with a large force of men, is now at work under the personal supervision of Architect Dudley Newton.

Mr. ELIHU ROOT told the alumni of Williams College at their banquet the other night that boys were kept too long, or at least too late, in school and college. It was a danger to be guarded against in the college system. The preparation for work when so prolonged consumes time that ought to be given to work itself.
Hon. John H. Reagan, in a letter addressed to a member of the Democratic County Executive Committee who resides in Sherman, states his position in several matters as follows:

There is a possible fortune in store for somebody who will start a laundry for flannels. Not a cleaning establishment, beyond the means of ordinary folk, but just a place where somebody will make it a business and aim to laundry flannels, to cleanse and press them properly. It is not only possible to do it, but it would prove profitable.

Mayor Wurster yesterday vetoed the "grab" resolutions passed by the Brooklyn Board of Aldermen. He vetoed the grant of many streets to the East River and Atlantic Ocean Railroad Company, the resolutions extending the plants of the Municipal Electric Light and Flatbush Gas Companies, and the resolution authorizing the issue of water bonds for the Milburn reservoir.

No member of the canine family has been more persistently maligned than the bulldog. Writers who have no intimate knowledge of the dog and his attributes have described him as stupidly ferocious, and illustrators have pictured him as a sort of semi-wild beast, till the general public has come to look upon him as dangerous.

The French, always more alert than ourselves in matters gastronomical, are attempting to add another dish to the table. They have already tried to acclimatize the American wild turkey, but with little success. Now an experiment, and with much more promising results, has been made with a bird called the Red Tinamou, from South America.

At the Broadway Theatre to-morrow night De Koven and Smith's new romantic comic opera. "The Highwayman," will be presented by the Broadway Theatre Opera Company, lately organized by Andrew A. McCormick. The action of "The Highwayman" takes place in England about a hundred years ago -- "the stage coach period," as it is generally called.
LONDON, Dec. 12. -- Discount rates were well maintained last week. The supplies of money promise to continue scarce well into January.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Dec. 12. -- A lawsuit was tried before Justice Barnard yesterday growing out of the settlement of the estate of Morgan A. Dayton, who died at Milton in 1891. Mr. Dayton had a decidedly old-fashioned family. At the time of his death he had been the husband of five women and the father of thirty-two children.

There was a happy family gathering last evening at the Harlem Lyceum, One Hundred and Seventh Street and Third Avenue, the occasion being the sixtieth anniversary of the wedding of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard H. Cohen, old and respected residents of Harlem. Four generations were represented at the celebration, which was the more enjoyable from the fact that it was a complete surprise to the old folks.

MANASQUAN, N.J., Dec. 12. -- While witnessing a baptism in the Manasquan River this afternoon several people were thrown suddenly into the river. No one was injured. The ceremony which attracted the spectators was the baptism of eleven candidates for admission to the Baptist Church of this place. The Rev. Henry B. Cross officiated.

MADRID, Dec. 12. -- Lieut. Gen. Weyler arrived here this afternoon. He was received at the railway platform by Gen. Azcarraga, the former Premier; Gen. Borrero, the former Commander of the Sixth Army Corps, and a number of Republicans, Carlists, Conservatives, and Robledoists.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- The National Board of Trade, which numbers among its members the principal Boards of Trade and kindred commercial bodies of the country, will meet here to-morrow to organize for its regular session, which will open Tuesday. A number of important matters will be brought up for consideration.

CHICAGO, Ill., Dec. 12. -- It seems that Champion Miller had another incentive besides the prize at Madison Square. In fact, there is quite a romance behind the German's exertions in the six-day race. His main idea was to stand well in the eyes of a young woman, whose name is not given for publication, but who lives at Twelfth Street and Ogden Avenue, near Miller's home.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 12. -- Although church-going was not the main mission of the two hundred or more representatives of the Tammany Hall Democracy congregated here to-day, they did their share of it manfully, to the delight of the local pastors and the advantage of the contribution boxes.

No one will regret Mr. BRYAN'S cordial reception in Mexico or misunderstand it. That relatively enterprising nation produce a good deal of silver which it sells as merchandise on the markets of the world. If Mr. BRYAN could have his way, whatever demand for their silver would arise by free coinage of 48 cents into a dollar by the mints Of the United States would be to the advantage of the Mexicans.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- The funeral of Gardiner Green Hubbard will be held at the Church of the Covenant to-morrow afternoon. Services will be conducted by the Rev. Dr. Hamlin. Mr. Hubbard was President of the Board of Trustees of the Church of the Covenant from the time it was organized.

The Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott last night delivered in Plymouth Church the last of the four introductory sermons in his course on St. Paul. Next Sunday he will take up the teaching of the apostle. The sermon dealt with the early church, and after it was over the usual question meeting was held, at which persons in the congregation questioned the preacher on the subject of Paul's life and teaching.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- If the present programme is carried out Congress will adjourn for the holiday recess next Saturday.

The topic of the Rev. Dr. Charles Eaton's lecture last night in the series which for some time he has been engaged in delivering on current fiction was "The Beth Book" and "The Evolution of a Woman's Character." The congregation of the Church of the Divine Paternity assembled as usual in the edifice of St. Stephen's Church, in West Forty-sixth Street, near Sixth Avenue.

It seems to me that the appointment of Capt. J.M. Dickey of Newburg to the position of Shipping Commissioner at the Port of New York has not received at the hands of the newspapers the consideration it deserves. You may recall that the Washington dispatches announcing the appointment assured us that the Captain had the indorsement of Senator Platt and Congressman Odell.
At the obvious risk of departing from the excellent rule laid down by the Rev. Dr. Potter, will you kindly permit a final word regarding "Washington as a Churchman?"

The Republicans of the Fifty-fifth Congress are in no humor to restrain the growth of the pension list and the expenditure that must be the inevitable result of packing that list full of unworthy objects of Government benevolence. The House has just passed a pension appropriation bill that confessedly does not provide the amount of money that will be necessary to pay the pensioners for twelve months.

TACOMA, Washington, Dec. 12. -- The steamer Glenlochie, just in, could not get coal at Morroan, the Japanese coaling station, for her voyage to Europe, securing only enough to last her to Tacoma, where she loads wheat. Capt. McGregor reports that the prices of Japanese coal have been advanced 40 per cent. in consequence of the approaching exhaustion of the Japanese mines.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 12. -- Investigation regarding the bottle of old Bourbon which Miss Harriette Bainbridge Richardson sent to ex-Secretary Herbert to be used in christening the Kentucky shows that it was presented to Miss Richardson by Major B.G. Thomas, the noted turfman who bred Domino. The Major is extremely angry because the bottle has been lost. To-night he gave out the following interview:

It is reported that the Republican organization managers are disturbed over the reports received as to the situation up the State. As is well known, it was the belief of the country leaders that the Republicans had no chance of success in the Mayoralty campaign without fusion with the other anti-Tammany forces.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Dec. 12. -- A very bad freight wreck occurred on the New York Central Railroad at 4:30 o'clock this morning, at a point five miles north of this city, from an apparently trivial cause. A small section of slate rock, weighing in the aggregate only a few hundred pounds, fell from the inland side of a rock cut upon the north-bound track.

Charles Zanoli, the German barber who is suspected of having killed four wives and three other persons for the purpose of collecting insurance money on their lives, maintained at Police Headquarters yesterday his protestations of innocence, and defied all the ingenuity of Capt. McClusky's efforts to get him to admit his guilt.

The Rev. Father Thomas J. Ducey of St. Leo's Catholic Church, whose advanced ideas on political and economic subjects have caused him more or less trouble with his ecclesiastical superiors, preached a stirring sermon yesterday morning against the prevailing social order.
The Rev. Minot J. Savage, at the Church of the Messiah yesterday morning, preached a sermon explaining why Unitarians have no creed.

Nothing could be more appropriate to the place and time and circumstances than the address which Prof. WOODROW WILSON made on Friday evening at the invitation of the City History Club. The proposition that "patriotism begins at home" is very good one for all the people of the United States in the presence of schemes of expansion.
Representative JOHNSON'S proposition that we exterminate the seal herd is not proper or permissible. We hope he will not introduce the bill.

ROSLYN, L.I., Dec. 12. -- The School Board of this place is in a peculiar position once more, owing to the act of the voters of the district, five years ago, in separating the white and colored children and establishing a special schoolhouse for the colored children.

Heads of important concerns in trade and finance express confidently their opinions that the recent improvement in business is but the beginning of an era of National prosperity. There is agreement among them that, barring legislative interference, an onward course of profitable business must result from the development of American resources.

All the contestants in the six-day bicycle race, which closed Saturday night at the Madison Square Garden, who could be seen yesterday, seemed to show but slight effects from the severe strain they had undergone for the past week. Some were in fact totally unaffected, while those who suffered most, were on the road to complete recovery.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 12. -- Frederick D. Carmon is under arrest at Police Headquarters for theft of goods from the Adams Express Company, and his wife and mother-in-law are also in custody for receiving stolen goods.

HAVANA, Dec. 12. -- The plans of the insurgents to strike a blow near the city have been checked, according to the official account, but the concentration of their forces is such as to make it unlikely that the local insurgent bands will surrender, as the Spanish authorities have been hoping.

YONKERS, Dec. 12. -- An explosion which startled the residents of Yonkers last evening, and which resulted in the destruction of a tenement house on John Street and damaged several other houses in the vicinity, furnished the police and Chief Mulcahey of the Fire Department cause for a searching investigation.

-- Attention is called by The Engineering Record to what looks like a serious blunder in the new charter. Section 578 of that instrument provides for weekly tests of the gas supplied to New York consumers, and, in case the gas of any company falls, for three consecutive weeks, below what is known as 20-candle power, a fine of $100 is to be imposed.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12. -- Fred L. Lavanburg, of New York City, yesterday filed a bill in the Superior Court asking for an injunction to restrain Collector John Ernst from levying on certain personal property in Chicago. Lavanburg has a branch office at 7 Monroe Street.

The news that "Col." Michael J. Dady has joined the Booth Dramatic Society has caused a considerable flutter in Brooklyn political circles. The Booth is one of the leading organizations of the city. There is a rumor that Chairman De Levante of the Dramatic Committee is trying to get Lieut. Gov. Woodruff to join, but it cannot be verified.

NASHVILLE, Dec. 12. -- Nearly all the delegates to the convention of the American Federation of Labor have arrived. The convention will meet in the hall of the House of Representatives to-morrow morning.

If the plans of the Evangelical Alliance for the United States do not miscarry, a great army, numbering, perhaps, a million or more, will soon be engaged in prosecuting a campaign on behalf of good citizenship from one end of the land to the other, by distributing patriotic literature broadcast. It is believed that the bicycle will prove a most effective agent in such distribution.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- All the members of the Cabinet whose official duties will permit them to leave Washington at this time will start for Canton to-morrow evening to attend the funeral of Mrs. McKinley. The party will include Secretaries Alger, Bliss, and Wilson, Postmaster General Gary, Attorney General McKenna, and Secretary Sherman, if the latter is feeling well enough to make the trip.

A divorce suit in which both the plaintiff and defendant are members of noble and distinguished families of the Austro-Hungarian Empire is now pending in the Supreme Court in this city, and will probably be called for trial this week. The plaintiff, known here as Mrs. Helen Banffy, was born Baroness von Ziegfeld.
I appreciate every word in your editorial of this morning. The need of additional means of transit is a crying one and demands the attention you give it.

Our readers are familiar with the complaint of the New York Stock Exchange before the Inter-State Commerce Commission against the railway companies composing the Joint Traffic Association. The complaint rests on the relative loss of export trade in grain, flour, and provisions by the port of New York, and the relative gain in that trade by the so-called "outputs," from Boston on the north to Newport News on the south.

CANTON, O., Dec. 12. -- The funeral of Mrs. McKinley will be held in the First Methodist Episcopal Church of this city at 1 o'clock Tuesday afternoon. Interment will follow in West Lawn Cemetery, just west of the city, and Tuesday evening President and Mrs. McKinley and the officials from Washington who attend the funeral will leave for the Capital, reaching there about noon Wednesday.

The district members of the National Association of Manufacturers of the United States, who are Warner Miller, Augustus G. Paine, Charles E. Locke, Pliny Jewell, Benjamin Atha, Charles A. Schleren, and Charles A. Moore, are arranging for the third annual convention of the association, which is to be held in New York City Jan. 25, 26, and 27 next.

GLOVERSVILLE, N.Y., Dec. 12. -- Two years ago last August Samuel Mills of Johnstown, in a fit of jealousy, shot his wife and then attempted suicide by cutting his throat. Both recovered, and Mills was sent to the Albany penitentiary. He was released recently, and returned to Johnstown.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- The bill to establish the University of the United States will be introduced again in both houses of Congress to-morrow. The bill in general terms provides for an institution of the highest possible type for the graduates of accredited colleges and universities only, with special reference to the work of original research and investigation in all important fields of inquiry.

We commend to the youth of this country the solid, hard-headed, North American good sense of the remarks of Mr. NELSON MORRIS of Chicago on taking his son IRA into the firm. "A million men can write books," he said, "but few have the opportunity that my son enjoys to become great in the business world."

In the Church of Sts. Peter and Paul, South Second Street and Wythe Avenue, Brooklyn, of which Father Sylvester Malone is rector, mass was celebrated yesterday morning by a well-known priest, who was the subject of much talk while a child, forty years ago, in the City of Rome. This priest is the Rev. Edgardo Levi Montara, who arrived in New York from London on Wednesday last.

ROME, Dec. 13. -- An official note announces that the Marquis di Rudini, having so far failed to form a Cabinet, visited King Humbert at 11 o'clock this evening to acquaint his Majesty with the state of affairs.

The stockholders of the Galveston Chamber of Commerce have provided for a committee to arrange for a meeting of land-owners and cultivators of the surrounding country to begin a systematic movement toward enlarged cultivation of sugar cane and concert of action in securing seed cane, freight rates, grinding mills, and such other matters us may be deemed necessary to the successful production of sugar in the Texas Gulf coast country.

Fifty members were elected at the November meeting of the Board of Governors of the New York Athletic Club. The movement to fill the membership roll before taking possession of the new clubhouse was started at a recent meeting. The advantages of non-resident membership have appealed to the residents of other cities, and there were eleven elections to that class.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12. -- At an early day, but probably not before the holiday recess, the House of Representatives may consider bankruptcy legislation. The sub-committee of the Committee on the Judiciary assigned by the Chairman, Representative David B. Henderson of Iowa, to undertake the preliminary work, has been devoting careful attention to the subject, and a report from the sub-committee, and possibly two reports from the entire Judiciary Committee, may be looked for.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12. -- Judge Grosscup of the Federal Court has ordered the books of the General Electric Railway Company produced in court and a full showing made of all money expended. This is the result of the efforts of Charles Austin Bates of New York to throw the company into the hands of a receiver.

In the July (1897) issue of The North American Review, Pages 43-51, there appeared a statistical discussion of the Southern States of this Republic, by Michael G. Mullhall, the English statistician, author, and educator. In the course of this article the writer makes several erroneous statements; he draws some absurd conclusions; he institutes some misleading comparisons.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 13. -- Richard Croker was left almost alone in his glory to-day. Mayor-elect Van Wyck and a numerous company of Tammany district leaders and followers left here for the city on the early morning train and the afternoon express bore away another large squad, so that the hotel lobbies wear to-night an almost deserted air.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala, Dec. 13. -- Five thousand tons of Alabama iron have left the Port of Pensacola for Kobe and Yokohama, Japan, in the last two days. The shipments are the outcome of a number of trial orders that have gone to the Japanese Empire this past few years. The Alabama operators have established connections with brokers in the far East, and made arrangements for a regular trade.

There is no abatement in the storm of injunctions against the Brooklyn Board of Aldermen. Two more were launched at the Board yesterday, one of which was secured in the United States Court. The papers were referred to Corporation Counsel Burr, who flatly told the Aldermen that he would not defend the suits, and gave them their choice of getting some one else or allowing him to appear without defending.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- The outlook for changing the civil service law is being canvassed actively among Republican members of the House, as a result of the conference held Saturday night.

I have read with great satisfaction your editorials on the pension question, and as this is a subject which cannot be too extensively agitated I desire to express my views, which perhaps may merit a space in your valuable paper.

A press dispatch from Philadelphia reports that the managers of the Pencoyd Iron Works "are not greatly disappointed" at the rejection of their bid for building a bridge over the river Ysel in Holland, although it was the lowest bid. They knew that "great objection had been made by the citizens of Holland and the local bidders to allowing a Gov ernment contract to go out of the country."

The Brooklyn Board of Audit has been investigating the accounts of Raymond Street Jail, with the result of finding shortages. Last Spring Sheriff Buttling privately re-quested an examination of his accounts. They were found to be perfectly straight, but Auditor Sutton found some figures which aroused his suspicions concerning the administrations of past Sheriffs, and the investigation was continued.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 13. -- The committee to which had been referred Senator Barksdale's anti-football bill to-day decided to report the bill favorably, the vote standing 5 to 4. There were a number of young women present during the discussion of the bill by the committee, and they applauded vigorously everything that was said in behalf of football.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13. -- The criminal and civil proceedings brought by John H. Metzger against Richard Mansfield have been compromised. Metzger will not prosecute the actor in the criminal courts and the suit in Common Pleas will be withdrawn. Metzger was Mansfield's dresser, and sued for alleged assault and battery.

One of the chief difficulties of getting any clear notion about the progress of affairs in Cuba has for a long time been the tremendous amount of lying that was done on both sides. It is only fair to say that since BLANCO superseded WEYLER there has been a marked diminution in the Spanish official output of untruth from Havana.

Speaking to a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday of stock market conditions and the general financial outlook, Mr. Clarence H. Wildes of the Wall Street firm of Clarence H. Wildes Co. said:

The announcement that more than a thousand men left Dawson during the latter part of October to make their way backward over the mountains to the sea might have been expected. The fear of starvation must be imminent indeed to make men incur again the hardships and dangers of a passage which they had made with so much trouble, and to throw away their time and their labor in the hope of saving their lives.

L.J. Phillips Co. have sold for Abraham H. Hummel his former residence, 207 East Seventeenth Street, a three-story brick dwelling, 23 by 92. The buyers, Thomas Ball and William Couper, the sculptors, will occupy the building as a studio after the completion of alterations.

QUIGG knows what ails the Republican Party, but he persists in handing down the wrong bottle of medicine. Its groans and struggles proceed from internal miseries occasioned by PLATT and QUIGG. Their withdrawal would remove the offending matter and restore the party to health.

-- Whether or not the price of so-called standard typewriting machines is to be cut in two next year is, of course, a question whose answer depends upon the degree to which the new and cheaper instruments have encroached upon the field formerly occupied exclusively by those of established reputation.

VICTORIA, B.C., Dec. 13. -- By steamer Topeka, from Dyea, news is received that more than 1,000 ill-provisioned men stampeded from Dawson during the latter part of October, and, impelled by fears of famine, are now forcing their way over the mountains.

The one subject in which racing men of this city were interested yesterday was the sale of Hamburg. The rumor was circulated that Hamburg was to reach Jersey City over the Pennsylvania Road last night, and many racing men and curious people who wanted to see the great horse that is said to have brought $60,000 were on hand.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- Chaplain Milburn in his invocation at the opening of the Senate to-day made a touching reference to the death of Mrs. McKinley, mother of the President.

SEATTLE, Dec. 13. -- Gales have been raging on the Northern Pacific coast for the past twenty-four hours, and have caused the relatives and friends of the passengers of the steamship Cleveland, now six days overdue from San Francisco much concern.

ROME, Dec. 13. -- Gen. William F. Draper, the United States Ambassador to Italy, was present to-day at the casting of the Simmonds bronze monument to Gen. John A. Logan, which will be set up in Washington.
HAVANA, via Key West, Dec. 13. -- It is announced semi-officially that Gen. Sanguily, the insurgent leader, has written to Marshal Blanco, offering the latter his services unconditionally.

Official measurements of the wooden track in Madison Square Garden, used for the six days' cycle race, showed that the course was short 277.26 feet to the mile. The distance in each of the two surveys made was at eighteen inches from the pole, as prescribed by the League of American Wheelmen rules governing the measurements of tracks.

The leaders of the anti-Platt movement assert that County Chairman L.E. Quigg is impossible as a "unifying force"; that harmony is out of the question under his leadership. They say that this might as well be understood first as last. It is further declared that there will be no reply made to Mr. Quigg's letter published yesterday morning, and that there can be no further negotiations with the Platt organization on the present basis.

CANTON, Ohio, Dec. 13. -- The casket containing the body of Nancy Allison McKinley is nearly buried in flowers. All day express wagons have been delivering loads of floral offerings at the house, and many thousands of telegrams and letters conveying messages of condolence have been received by the President and other members of the family.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- The blind Chaplain of the House, in his invocation to-day, referred eloquently and feelingly to the death of the President's mother.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- Prof. David Starr Jordan of Stanford University, who was the leading expert for the United States Government in the seal negotiations here last Autumn, has given his verdict strongly against any such proposition as that presented in the bill introduced by Representative Johnson of North Dakota, looking to the immediate killing of all the seals as the readiest manner in which to prevent further friction between the United States and Canada.

Application for seats and boxes for the exhibition to be given by the Merchants' Association at Carnegie Hall to-night, have come in very rapidly. The Merchants' Association placed a box at the disposal of each of the fifty-two or more exchanges, commercial, mercantile, and labor organizationc of the city.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13. -- There were no premonitory symptoms to-day of the rumpus in December wheat that shook the pit to its centre for fifteen minutes about an hour from the close of the session. That delivery was, worth from $1.04 1/2 to $1.05 most of the morning, but all at once it began to show decided weakness. Before the crowd could realize what was happening it was being offered at 97 1/2 cents.

There is one thing that is admitted by everybody, that the blood must be kept moving if the brain is to be clear and the health good. No one ever questions this, and yet how few people have good circulation. Sometimes the pulse seems to be running away, and again, it can hardly be felt. This is all wrong.

When attention has been duly called to these facts in the history of our expansion by the annexation of territory contiguous to our domain, Alaska excepted, we trust that some one will read to the caucus in a clear and sufficiently loud voice some wise utterances of the statesmen mentioned by The Sun which we shall proceed to quote:

Contractor Patrick Farrell yesterday set nearly fifty Italians to work in the old Union Cemetery of Williamsburg, removing the 30,000 dead that have been interred there for more than fifty years. The cemetery belonged to the Trinity Methodist Protestant Church Society of Williamsburg, and after several years' litigation in the courts the property was recently sold to Henry Batterman, who will sub-divide it into 180 building lots.
A big batch of stakes, to be run at Sheepshead Bay next season, will close with Secretary Cornelius Fellowes of the Coney Island Jockey Club on Jan. 10. The events are as follows:

" Our Amusements in the Light of the Bible and Pacts" was the subject of the Rev. Dr. A.C. Dixon's lecture at Cooper Union yesterday afternoon. It was the last of the Monday afternoon meetings for this year, and the doctor availed himself of the approach of the holidays to warn his audience against the alluring amusements of the season.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 13. -- Mrs. Alice Hartley, who killed Senator Foley at Reno several years ago, created a great deal of excitement in the Emanuel Baptist Church last night. At the conclusion of the Rev. J. George Gibson's sermon she dramatically declared that she had a message from God to the effect that Durrant's life should be saved and it was the duty of the congregation to save him.

Having noticed in yesterday's issue a short paragraph relating to the action of the National Wholesale Druggists' Association on the Torrey Bankruptcy bill at the annual convention at Richmond last October, I send you the text of the resolution passed at the meeting, and would add that it was the generally expressed opinion of the members of the trade that a National bankruptcy law is a matter of the most urgent necessity.

A committee representing the joint committee appointed by the mass meeting held at Terrace Garden in October in furtherance of the movement for out-door gymnasiums for the public, went before the Park Board at yesterday's meeting at the Arsenal, in Central Park and recommended a proposition for the establishment of an open-air gymnasium playground in East River Park.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- In the United States Supreme Court to-day an opinion was handed down by Justice White in the case of Thomas Bram, under sentence of death by the United States Circuit Court, for the Massachusetts District, for the murder of Capt. Charles I. Nash of the bark Herbert Fuller, and indicted also for the murder of Mrs. Nash and Mate A.W. Blomberg, at sea in July, 1896.

The body of Jennie Suhmer, the last wife of Charles Zanoli, was dug up in St. Michael's Cemetery, Astoria, yesterday, the autopsy was made, and the work of the chemical analysis was begun on which nearly all of the hopes of the police to convict their prisoner are based.

That London society "imposes itself" upon foreigners as well as upon natives has for some time been almost a commonplace of Anglo-American fiction. Whether the foreigner finds it charming or not, he finds it very powerful. In no other European capital in which he is likely to domesticate himself would he find himself so much constrained by the pressure of social conventions.

It was announced yesterday at the office of Robert Appleton, Jr., 11 Pine Street, that Mr. Appleton's son, William, who, at the imminent risk of his life, stopped the runaway horse of his friend, Lawrence Knickerbocker, and saved the latter from serious injury, and perhaps death, was not regarded as seriously hurt as a result of his brave act, and that no internal injuries are feared.

A brilliant company gathered at the annual banquet of the Presbyterian Union in the banquet hall of the Hotel Savoy last evening. Covers were laid for about 250 persons. The Rev. Dr. Howard Duffield presided in the absence of the President, John J. McCook, and introduced the speakers. There were no toasts.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 13. -- James H. Eckels, Controller of the Currency, when asked to-day if he agreed with the recommendations as to the currency made by President McKinley in his recent message to Congress, said:

Robert A. Van Wyck took the oath of office of Mayor of the Greater New York in the City Court yesterday morning before Chief Judge Fitzsimons. Mr. Van Wyck swore to support the Constitutions of the United States and the State of New York, and promised faithfully to perform the duties of the office to the best of his ability.
NASHVILLE, Dec. 13. -- President Samuel Gompers, in his report to-day at the opening of the convention of the American Federation of Labor, speaking about the eight-hour movement, said:

Mr. Reginald De Koven and Mr. Harry B. Smith have provided this public with some of its most satisfactory entertainment. Certainly we have had no more pleasing operetta than "Robin Hood" from any writers except Gilbert and Sullivan. It was therefore quite natural that a large audience should assemble in the Broadway Theatre last night when their latest operetta, "The Highwayman," was produced.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Dec. 13. -- The British steamship Kildonia, Capt. Roberts, arrived in port this morning from Shields, having on board Capt. H.N. Nymann and Andreas Michaelsen, Elbert Ellingsen, Sugure Nilson, Vaidemar Linler, Juan Vila, Andrew Varges, and H. Karpp, the crew of the Norwegian bark Njemmett, which was lost in mid-ocean Sunday, Dec. 5.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13. -- In answer to a Senate resolution calling for such information as the War Department possesses relative to the lack of food supplies on the Yukon River, Secretary Alger to-day submitted a letter reciting his action in sending Capt. Ray, Eighth Infantry, to that country to investigate, and inclosing copies of that officer's reports, the features of which have already been published.

O.H. Budlong, attorney for Thomas C. Enos, announced to Justice Cohen, in the Supreme Court, yesterday morning that his client desired to withdraw from the case in which he had begun to defend a suit brought against him by Sarah A. Knight of New York.

VIENNA, Dec. 13. -- Unrest continues in Bohemia. To-day the troops have patrolled the streets of Prague and special guards are stationed at the German theatres, owing to the fact that a bomb was found last Thursday evening near the Royal German Theatre.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday took up the consideration of the charitable institutions which were not provided for at the public hearing given last Wednesday, when the doctors of the New York Medical League objected to giving city money to institutions connected with medical hospitals.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- The National Board of Trade met here to-day for its twenty-eighth annual session, ex-Gov. Stanard of St. Louis presiding in the absence of Frederick Fraley of Philadelphia, who has been President of the board since its organization in 1868, and who was re-elected again to-day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- Secretary Gage will appear before the House Committee on Banking and Currency on Thursday and submit in the form of a general bill his recommendations recently made to Congress.
I see in your issue of Dec. 10 an account of a woman who had been bitten by a cat, and subsequently developed something resembling hydrophobia.

SIMLA, Dec. 14. -- According to official dispatches from the northwestern frontier, the march of Gen. Westmacott's brigade from the camp at Sher-Khel into the Sturi-Khel country was one continuous action.

We take little stock in the story that the President's assent has been secured in advance to a bill restricting the operation of the civil service rules which he has approved and extended. The mere proposal of such legislation is a studied and deliberate insult to him as President and as official chief of the party in power.

An unfailing indication that the great masses of the people are employed and to some degree prosperous is to be found in the records of the consumption of grocery products. New York's wholesale grocers are now doing the largest business they have known for years, and prompt settlements are everywhere met with.

BERLIN, Dec. 14. -- In the Reichstag to-day Count Posadowsky. Minister of the Interior, said that negotiations were now pending between Germany and the United States with regard to tariff, but that at present it would be inexpedient to give the House any detailed information on the subject.
PORT TOWNSEND, Washington, Dec. 14. -- The steamer Alki arrived at 1 o'clock this morning with forty passengers, nearly all of whom are from Dyea, Skaguay, or Sumdum.

BRIDGEPORT, Dec. 14. -- Charles A. Bonai, the alleged murderer of George M. Nichols of Daniels Farms in July last, went on the stand in his own defense to-day and recounted the whole story of his life. His narrative of the murder corroborated that of his wife and her brother, David Weeks, in every particular, except that Bonai denied that he had fired the fatal shots, and alleged that Weeks was the real murderer.

The New York and East River and the New Amsterdam Gas Companies did not, at meetings held yesterday, adjust conditions in the way of a consolidation between the New Amsterdam and the East River and Equitable Companies. The stockholders of the Equitable ratified an agreement of consolidation last month.

Charles Griffith Moses has sold for the Ernst-Marx syndicate to Thomas Alexander the plot, southeast corner of One Hundred and Seventy-second Street and Eleventh Avenue, 95 by 100, together with three adjoining lots on the south side of One Hundred and Seventy-second Street.

ALBANY, Dec. 14. -- Albert S. Warner, the New York lawyer who was the chief of the gang which kidnapped little Johnny Conway from his home in this city Aug. 17, was arrested at Riley, Kan., to-day by Detective Joseph McCann of the Albany police and will be brought to Albany for trial when extradition papers are obtained.

Charles Zanoli was arraigned before Magistrate Kudlich, in the Centre Street Police Court, yesterday morning on the charge of homicide. Deputy Assistant District Attorney Van Wyck told the Magistrate that, in view of the evidence which had been obtained in the last day or two, he felt justified in making such a charge.

More women than men were in the small audience which last night filled the library room of St. James's Protestant Episcopal Church, at Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street, to listen to the reading of an address by Miss Georgiana I.S. Andrews on "Thought as a Force."

A novel plan for alleviating the lot of people who have grown too old to be welcome in social circles is about to be tried in Brooklyn. The following advertisement, which appeared in a newspaper yesterday, tells the story:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- A new code of rules for the House of Representatives will be presented by Speaker Reed and his associates on the Committee on Rules after the holiday recess. At present the House is proceeding under the rules of two years ago, these having been adopted pending the framing of new rules.

Conway W. Sams, Chief Consul of the Maryland State Division of the League of American Wheelmen, has announced an intended step which it is believed will insure the re-election of Isaac B. Potter as President of the league against any possible opposition. Sterling Elliott, the Chief Consul of the Massachusetts State Division, recently elected by an overwhelming majority, is considered Mr. Potter's strongest opponent for the executive chair.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Dec. 14. -- The much-talked-of Metropolitan Police bill, which is to be submitted to the Legislature at the present special session, and which is expected to take the Chicago Police Department from the control of the present Democratic administration, was made public to-night.

Virtually no Opposition developed at the Platt organization primaries last night to the regular tickets. The anti-Platt Republicans generally remained away from the polls, and the vote cast, out of an enrollment of 85,000, was said to be about 20,000. A large majority of the delegates who will be returned to the County Committee favor the re-election of Chairman L.E. Quigg.
