Mayor STRONG got hold of the wrong corpus delicti. That was the fatal defect of his proposition to mark by some ceremonial observance the night of the consolidation of the cities. He asked some seventy-five gentlemen of inventive minds to help him organize a wake for New York City.
The exports of principal articles for the eleven months ending with November are stated in the latest bulletin of the Bureau of Statistics for the last three years as follows:

Edward Everett Hale was the central figure in a distinguished gathering of literary men at the rooms of the Aldine Club, 75 Fifth Avenue, last evening. The occasion was a dinner given in his honor by the club, and among the other notable guests were W.D. Howells, Bishop Potter, Paul Leicester Ford, Col. George E. Waring, and the Rev. Henry M. Field, D.D.

The meeting of the Interscholastic Athletic Association, held at De La Salle Institute, 108 West Fifty-ninth Street, yesterday afternoon, was productive of some animated discussion over several amendments to the constitution and by-laws offered at last month's meeting, and which came up for final action yesterday.

Thomas A. Phelan of this city, who was one of the most active members of the Board of Tea Experts appointed by the Treasury Department under the act of March 2, 1897, received a letter from Secretary Gage yesterday expressing satisfaction with the work of the board, and saying:

There was a large attendance at the sixty-third regular meeting and dinner of the Quill Club of New York at the Windsor Hotel last evening. J. Cleveland Cady presided. The topic was "Patriotism in Time of Peace; or, the Duty of Living for One's Country," and the speaker was Prof. Woodrow Wilson of Princeton University.
PRINCETON, Dec. 14. -- The football team held a meeting to-night to elect a Captain for the season of 1898. John Baird of the Class of '99 was the unanimous choice for the place.

It was reported yesterday that at a dinner of the Phi Delta Phi Law Club at the Marlborough Hotel on Monday evening, Justice Edward Patterson of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, speaking to the theme, "The Practical Lawyer," declared that the legal profession is degenerating. The published report of his speech attributed these words to him:
SEATTLE, Dec. 14. -- It was announced on authority, of G. Gates, financial agent of J.D. Rockefeller, that the Everett and Monte Cristo Railroad, recently destroyed by floods, would not be rebuilt.

PRINCETON, Dec. 14. -- The Faculty of Princeton University has under consideration the wrecking of the gymnasium last Wednesday evening. The matter was kept quiet for several days, but it was learned to-day that certain seniors after dinner on Wednesday went to the gymnasium, tore down hooks, rings, and bars, broke windows, and otherwise damaged the interior of the building.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- The Senate was in session just fifteen minutes to-day, adjournment being taken until to-morrow out of respect to President McKinley, who was to-day in attendance upon the funeral of his mother. The motion to adjourn was made by Mr. Hoar, (Rep., Mass.,) who said:

There seems to be no good reason to distrust the semi-official announcement from Havana that Gen. JULIO SANGUILY has been "reconciled" by the Spanish Government, and has offered to Marshal BLANCO his unconditional surrender. Of course all Cuban news, semi-official or otherwise, is overhung with a dense cloud of suspicion.

LONDON, Dec. 14. -- The House of Lords has rendered judgment in the case of Allen vs. Flood, a case of much interest to trades unions, and has sustained the appeal. Lords Herschell, MacNaeghton, Shand, Davey, and James, forming the majority, and Lords Halsbury and Morris composing the minority.
CANTON, Ohio, Dec. 14. -- There was a general suspension of public and private business in this city to-day on account of the funeral of Mrs. Nancy Allison McKinley, the mother of President McKinley.

It is plain that the House will take up the Bankruptcy bill promptly. As stated by Judge HENDERSON of Iowa, Chairman of the committee, to our correspondent, the committee will be ready to report immediately after the holiday recess, if not before. Its measure will be substantially on the line of the Henderson bill introduced at the opening of the session and in agreement with the Torrey bill.

ALBANY, Dec. 14. -- The Court of Appeals to-day handed down a decision refusing to hear a reargument in the case of the Colonial Traction Company against the Kingston Street Railway Company. Oct. 5 the Court handed down a decision refusing to allow the Colonial Traction Company to operate on the tracks of the Kingston Company unless the permission of the latter was obtained.
Your editorial of the 13th inst. entitled "Literature and Hog Products" was clever and to the point, although I think some of the hog and pork of it might have been generously omitted.
I have been requested to give my views on the question, "Would the purchasing power of gold depreciate if the supply of gold should be increased"?

-- In these days of swift and easy communication between almost every part of the world, men would be apt to forget, were it not for an occasional episode like this in which the Klondike miners are involved, that the gratification even of material needs is dependent on more than the possession of money.

Your correspondent, D.T., asks one pertinent and snappy question in his letter of Dec. 13 -- "Why should a man be paid for doing his duty -- fighting for his country -- or receive a premium for his patriotism?"

The sale of trotters and pacers which Peter C. Kellogg, the auctioneer, opened at Madison Square Garden yesterday morning was well attended, in spite of the weather, but prices did not rule high throughout the day.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 14. -- Judge Severens of Kalamazoo, Mich., sitting in the United States Circuit Court here, to-day, rendered a decision in the case of the Inter-State Commerce Commission against the East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia Railroad Company and other railroads entering Chattanooga.
FALL RIVER, Mass., Dec. 14. -- After being in session the greater part of this afternoon, the Manufacturers' Committee concluded its labors and adjourned.

The death of Dr. Armand J. De Rosset at Wilmington, N.C., on Thursday last brought to an end a life of great activity and removed from the South one of its prominent figures. He was one of the original subscribers to the stock of the Wilmington and Weldon Railroad, (now a part of the Atlantic Coast Line,) and for fifty-five years was one of its Directors.

The Republicans of Kings County, at the meeting of their County Committee last night, took action which indicates unmistakably their intention to keep from being swallowed up by the regular organization in this city. A plan introduced by Assemblyman Brennan for forming the next City Committee was laid on the table after it had been attacked as a scheme to merge the Kings County organization with that of New York.

The Rainy Day Club held a special meeting yesterday. There did not appear to be any particular reason why a special meeting should have been called, and only a good baker's dozen of the members responded to the call, but each was attired in the regulation short skirt!

" Exceedingly gratifying as a testimony to the credit of the city. That bid of 108.47 is high-water mark on the 3 1/2 per cents," said Controller Fitch yesterday afternoon after he had opened and read the proposals for $6,243,070.55 of city bonds and stock recently advertised for sale.

Hamburg, the great two-year-old, son of Hanover and Lady Reel, arrived from the South yesterday, in a padded box car, which would have made a luxurious traveling apartment for a wealthy man, so closely was the comfort of the occupant looked after.

Chicago continues to furnish practical illustrations of important sociological principles. Two days ago we had occasion to commend the good sense of Mr. NELSON MORRIS in persuading his son IRA to abandon the literary career and go into the more lucrative business of pork packing.

ALBANY, Dec. 14. -- The Court of Appeals handed down an order to-day, appointing Joseph A. Welch of New York City a member of the State Board of Law Examiners for the term of three years from Jan. 1, 1898. Mr. Welch is an Assistant District Attorney of New York County. He will succeed Austen G. Fox of New York City on the State Board of Examiners.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 14. -- Judge Sanborn last evening granted the request of the Government for a continuance for sixty days of the sale of the Kansas Pacific Railroad. This will make the date Feb. 15. The extension was granted to enable Congress to take further action to protect the Government's interest of about $13,000,000 in the property.
Five-year franchises for the running of six established ferries will be sold in the Controller's office at noon next Tuesday, the franchises to run from that date. The properties to be sold are:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- The House to-day went into Committee of the Whole and proceeded to the consideration of the Legislative, Executive, and Judicial Appropriation bill.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Dec. 14. -- The trial of the Rev. David T. Howell, an Episcopal rector of this place, was held to-day. He is charged by his wife with having choked and beaten her, and she asked that he be put under bonds to keep the peace. The trouble arose over a pet cat, which Mr. Howell was feeding in the dining room while he ate his dinner.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14. -- The caucus of Democratic members of the House of Representatives to-night resulted in the adoption of resolutions defining the party policy on the questions of Cuba, finance, and bankruptcy. The caucus was attended largely, 101 of the 125 Democratic members being present, despite the stormy weather.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Dec. 15. -- The steamer Howard Cossard, the peculiar construction of which caused so much comment in maritime circles and which proved an absolute failure on her trial trip on Chesapeake Bay three years ago, is being transformed in this city so as to meet the requirements of a vessel necessary for the Klondike trade.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- The Inter-State Commerce Commission issued to-day its eleventh annual report. Following is a summary of its contents.

Deputy Assistant District Attorney Van Wyck, who is doing a good part of the work on the Charles Zanoli case for the District Attorney's office, said yesterday: "We are now almost positive that Jennie Suhmer, the fourth wife of Zanoli, did not die from natural causes, judging from the reports of the experts.

The first Assembly of this season was danced last evening at the Germania Club, in Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn. These dances are among the most important social functions of the year in Brooklyn. Last night's affair was probably the best Brooklyn has ever seen.

When Wyndham Walden brought his scheme of organizing the Horsemen's Protective Association to a head last Fall he held out to owners, trainers, and jockeys a dazzling prospectus of the beneficial influence the association would soon bring to bear on racing. He induced many prominent trainers and jockeys to join, and John J. Hyland, who has charge of the horses of August Belmont, President of the Jockey Club, was made President.

ROCHESTER, Dec. 15. -- The annual banquet of the Rochester Clearing House Association was held this evening in the Genesee Valley Clubhouse. J. Edward Simmons, President of the New York Clearing House Association, was the guest of honor, and made the address of the evening. Speaking of the need of currency reform, he said: ...

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 15. -- Mrs. Elizabeth Gunn was murdered last night in her home on the outskirts of the city. The murder was committed by burglars who were searching the little house for money which was supposed to be hidden in it.

Lenox S Lake has come back. That is to say, he is at home once more at 140 Perry Street. Mr. Lake deals in oysters at the foot of Charles Street. Last Friday evening he told his wife he was going to Madison Square Garden. He evidently kept his word, for two of his friends saw him there at 4 A.M. Saturday morning.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- The House Committee on Banking and Currency held an animated session to-day. It had been planned to report to the House at once a bill embodying the President's financial recommendations, and Mr. Brosius from a sub-committee made a favorable recommendation on this course of procedure.

In the Essex Market Police Court, before Magistrate Hedges, yesterday Martin Engel, Tammany leader in the Eighth Assembly District and member-elect of the Municipal Council of Greater New York, took the witness stand in his own behalf to testify concerning a series of accusations brought against him by Norbeth Pfeffer, a Republican saloon keeper of the district.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 15. -- Charles A. Bonai, the alleged murderer of George Marcus Nichols of Daniels Farms, was cross-examined by Samuel Fessenden as State's Attorney to-day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- The convention of business men which met in Indianapolis last January and authorized the appointment of the Monetary Commission will be called together again for the purpose of considering the commission's report. This was decided upon to-day at a meeting of the Executive Committee of the convention at the Arlington Hotel.

The anthracite coal situation has been discussed in Wall Street for several weeks, and more than once the announcement has been made that all interests had agreed to a plan for improvement and the adjustment of all differences. Yesterday it was reported that plans had been completed and were on the point of adoption.
For comprehensive stupidity nothing could surpass the unanimous action of the Democratic caucus of the House of Representatives in what was done and in what was left undone.

In the letter signed "Retailer" in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 10 all the statements in reference to the Torrey Bankrupt bill are false, with one exception, and the converse true. It is true that the bill does not attempt to equalize exemptions. It would be impossible to do it, and would be folly to attempt it.

Robert S. Roosevelt, George M. Van Hoesen, Warner Van Norden, Dr. D.B. St. John Roosa, and Charles H. Truax, ex-Presidents; John W. Vrooman, President, and Theodore M. Banta, Secretary, of the Holland Society, sent to Mayor-elect Van Wyck, on Nov. 22, the following letter: ...

The National Civil Service League, through its Secretary, George McAneny, has addressed to Congressman C. H. Grosvenor of Ohio, under date of Dec. 15, an open letter in reply to his address printed in the Congressional Record of Aug. 11 last, and which he entitled "Civil Service Reform Run Mad.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- The first matter which came before the National Board of Trade at its session to-day was a resolution favoring the establishment of postal savings banks, which was introduced by the Chicago Board of Trade. It was stated in that resolution that the people should be encouraged to deposit their savings in a department of the National Government.

The offer of autonomy and amnesty is having its natural effect upon the Cuban insurgents, and even upon the leaders of the insurrection. The announcement of SANGUILY'S surrender, upon which we commented yesterday has already become the subject of the denials and reaffirmations and statements and counterstatements which make it so difficult to get at the truth of any incident whatever of the Cuban insurrection.

The organization in this city of a new surety company, in which John C. Sheehan and other prominent Tammany politicians are known to be interested, has led to the inference that the enterprise is to be to the incoming Democratic city administration what the Fidelity and Deposit Company of Maryland, of which Senator Platt's son is the local manager, has been to the State Republican machine.

Edward J. Ratcliffe, the actor, met another disappointment after the adjournment for the day of his trial for assaulting his wife, at 4 P.M. yesterday. The day before, much to his surprise, he had been sent to the Tombs, and he went into court in the morning looking miserable after a restless night in a cell.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 15. -- The Southern Bankers' Convention, which met here to-day on call of the Clearing House Association, to consider currency reform and recommend measures to give an elastic currency and to take the Government out of the banking business, adopted, without debate, by unanimous vote, the following resolutions:

HAMBURG, Dec. 15. -- Emperor William of Germany, accompanied by Prince Adalbert, his third son, arrived here to-day on his way to Kiel. His Majesty inspected the Town Hall and attended a lunch given in his honor at the Rathskeller. There were 180 guests present. The Emperor occupied the centre table, with the six senior Senators and General Count von Waldersee, the Commander of the Ninth Army Corps.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Dec. 15. -- After a two days' trial, the jury to-night brought in a verdict finding N.J. Dippold, proprietor of the Oriental Hotel, a near-by Summer resort, guilty of selling wine, whisky, beer, and other intoxicants on Sunday, June 6 last, to Mayor Henry E. Wieber and others.

Frederick Southack Co. have sold for Mrs. Lee Gwynn Lawrence and Joseph B. Bass, trustees of the Lawrence estate, for $225,000, the five-story business buildings 498 and 500 Broadway, 47 by 100. The purchaser's name is withheld, but it is said that other improved property is given in part payment.

PORTLAND, Me., Dec. 15. -- The schooner Susan P. Thurlow, bound from Hillsborough, N.B., for New York, with a cargo of plaster rock, went to pieces on Cushing Island, three miles from this city at 8 o'clock last night, and the Captain and five members of the crew were lost. The only survivor is a sailor named E. Reimann.
PADUCAH, Ky., Dec. 15. -- Another bloody chapter has been added to the famous Shelby-Jenkins-Taylor feud of Ballard County, this State.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15. -- The Tribune to-day says: "There are just seventeen days left to make or unmake the December wheat deal. The chances for fireworks and old-time corner prices are scarcely so bright as they were some time ago. Leiter is learning something about the possibilities of Chicago as a receiving market and about the resources of Armour.

Permit me to say in answer to your correspondent "Leonard Street," that if the hundreds of thousands of dollars already subscribed by merchants in behalf of the now expurgated Torrey bill had been divided among the legal profession, they might have retained a very brilliant array of counsel.
The leaders of the Republican Party hold firmly these common beliefs:

Seven Columbia sophomores were kidnapped yesterday afternoon by freshmen after some lively fighting in the streets. The freshmen thought that the sophomores were going to hold their dinner last night and determined to break it up. They gathered in small bands in the haunts of the older boys and lured them into the street, capturing seven.

It is probably of very little interest to the readers of THE TIMES whether George Washington was a communicant of the Church or not, or whether he took his whisky straight or not; both questions have been more or less in dispute for half a century, but if we rely on contemporary evidence to attest facts, we must assume that Washington did both.

ALBANY, Dec. 15. -- District Attorney Burlingame obtained from the Governor's office to-day the blank forms upon which to make up requisition papers for Albert S. Warner, the kidnapper, who was caught in Kansas City, and to-morrow morning he will ask for the Governor's signature to them.
The Executive Committee of the National Association of Manufacturers met at the rooms of the association, Times Building, yesterday.

CARSOA-, Nev., Dec. 15. -- A communication has been received from Dan Stuart stating that a fight is being arranged between Corbett and Fitzsimmons as well as other pugilist to be held in Carson in July, 1898, and adding that definite arrangements would be completed within a fortnight. Stuart also promises to offer $30,000 In purses for the best Eastern horses to race for during the proposed fistie carnival.

Arguments were presented before the Board of Classification of the United States General Appraisers yesterday for and against the discriminating duty clause of the new tariff act. About forty protests against the application of this discriminating duty of 10 per cent. have been filed by importers.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 15. -- At a meeting this afternoon of the Arkwright Club, which is composed of the Treasurers of all the cotton mills of New England, the report of the committee appointed a month ago to consider Southern competition was presented. This committee consisted of expert managers of mills, and they have considered the matter thoroughly.

You publish in your issue of to-day a long letter from John Henry Piper on the relative value of gold, from which he surprisingly omits all reference to cost of production. It is this cost that makes gold precious. Could it be picked up in the street men would not have to brave the terrors of a Klondike Winter and starvation to obtain it, and it would be relatively valueless.
TRONDHJEM, Norway, Dec. 15. -- An agent of the United States Government named Kjeltberg, has arrived here to buy reindeer for the Klondike relief expeditions.

At the close of the hearings before the Supreme Court Rapid Transit Commissioners, Charles Sooysmith said that a syndicate had been formed to bid for the contract of constructing and operating the underground road, if the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court should make a favorable decision upon the Commissioners' report.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15. -- Very little business was done to-day in the December delivery of wheat, and May did not fare much better. The latter month was well sustained, as a rule, and at the close was selling one-half a cent higher than the final figures of yesterday. Shorts covered freely late in the session. Provisions were strong throughout.

YONKERS, N.Y., Dec. 15. -- The will of Eleanora Iselin was admitted for probate to-day in the Westchester County Surrogate's Court, before Surrogate Theodore H. Silkman. The petition says that the value of her real estate is less than $2,000, and that it is impossible at present to ascertain the value of the personal property. The first clause of the will bequeaths the entire estate to her husband.

-- Though the Cuban leaders gave full warning that they would hang anybody who entered a rebel camp with propositions from Spain for the establishment of autonomy yet it is hard to believe that they have really carried out the savage threat. If they have done so, the act amounts practically to a slaughter of men holding the semi-sacred rank of what used to be called heralds.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- At the opening of the session of the House to-day a resolution for the holiday recess, from Saturday, Dec. 18, to Wednesday, Jan. 5, offered by Mr. Dingley, from the Committee on Ways and Means, was adopted.

The Hudson County Grand Jury met at the Court House in Jersey City yesterday to investigate the charges of bribery made by a local newspaper against Joseph M. Noonan while he was Assistant Prosecutor of the Pleas, and Alexander Simpson. Elmer Rappleye, managing editor of the newspaper in question, was the first witness called.

The Manuscript Society gave the first concert of its ninth season at Chickering Hall last night. The following works were produced: Symphony in F, by Henry K. Hadley of Garden City; "Rhapsodie Erotique" for strings, harp, and horn, by Ernst Lent, Washington; festival overture, "Russia," Platon Brunoff, New York; aria, "Hero and Leander," A. M. Forster, Pittsburg, and symphonic overture, "Sardanapalus," E. R. Kroeger, St. Louis.

Some remarks which Justice PATTERSON of the Appellate Division did not make the other evening and some that he probably made have caused much talk among the lawyers of New York. The discussion has turned chiefly on two questions -- whether the law has degenerated from a profession to a trade, and whether the cross-examiners of to-day are as great as those of former times.

ALBANY, Dec. 15. -- For several years there has been talk of reorganizing the National Guard, so that its form of organization would be more nearly like that of the United States Army. Two successive lational Guard Association conventions have urged putting the Guard on a more permanent basis by having a ;fajor Ceneral to command the Guard and make one division of the whole.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- Senator Lodge to-day read in the Senate a letter from Carroll D. Wright, United States Commissioner of Labor, in which Mr. Wright discussed the methods of taking the next census. Mr. Lodge used this letter in a speech in which he antagonized the provision of the Census bill which permits employes of the Census Bureau to be selected without regard to the civil service rules.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15. -- In the Senate to-day Mr. McBride, (Rep., Oregon,) called up his resolution authorizing the Secretary of War to purchase food and supplies, and to transport such supplies as may be offered, for the relief of the American miners and other sufferers in the valley of the Yukon River in Alaska, and appropriating $250,000 to defray the necessary expenses.
LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 15. -- Richard Croker returned here this afternoon, looking tired and weary after his night trip from Washington to New York.

The fifty-second competition for the Abeel Trophy, which is a match decided each year by the members of the Seventh Regiment at the armory ranges, by authority of the Board of Officers and under the direction of the Regimental Inspectors of Rifle Practice, began last night, and will come to a close to-night.

MADRID, Dec. 16. -- An extraordinary number of the Gazette, issued to-day, publishes dispatches received from Manila, capital of the Philippine Islands, saying that the insurgent chief, Aguinaldo, has ordered all his followers to submit, and that he and the entire insurgent Government will be allowed to go to Hongkong.

Even our pension-loving contemporary, The Poughkeepsie Eagle, admits that on general principles the pension list appears "too large," and that "there may be something done to prevent the further enlargement of the system." Such admissions from stanch Republican newspapers are significant of a great change in public sentiment.

ATHENS, Ga., Dec. 16. -- One of the most peculiar forewarnings of death on record is told by Mrs. John Howard of Bostwick, Morgan County, whose husband died Sunday last. Mr. Howard was of excellent health, and was in comfortable circumstances. On the Monday night preceding his death he dreamed that he would die on the following Sunday night.

Myron L. Bernard, who was President of the E.S. Dean Company, when that firm of discretionary pool operators was closed up by United States postal officers, was arrested yesterday morning at his home, 332 East Fifty-seventh Street, by Post Office Inspectors Jacobs and Shopp.

The Richmond County Board of Canvass met at Richmond yesterday, and in accordance with the decision presented to them as given by Justice Dykman certified the result. The certificate of election as President of the Borough was granted to Dr. John L. Feeny, and a messenger was at once dispatched to New York to file the long delayed return with the Police Board.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Secretary Gage, in appearing to-day before the Committee on Banking and Currency of the House to present the bill embodying his views for a revision of the currency, which later in the day was introduced in the House, said, in opening:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Attorney General McKenna's nomination for Justice of the Supreme Court must undergo the scrutiny of the Committee on the Judiciary of the Senate before being submitted for confirmation or rejection. While it is possible to obtain many Senatorial opinions about the advisability of confirming the nomination, no Senator will be quoted on the subject.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Mr. Hanna of Ohio, after an illness of a week, appeared in the Senate to-day and was cordially greeted by his colleagues.

It is well that the Secretary of the Treasury has decided to put all his recommendations into one bill and submit it to the House Committee on Banking and Currency. One advantage is that reduced to the form of a bill the essential features of his plan stand out more clearly than in his explanation of them in his annual report.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16. -- As the guests invited to attend the wedding of Miss Florence Shepherd to Thomas Lee De Shong alighted from their carriages at the entrance of Christ Episcopal Church at Woodlawn last evening they were met by an announcement posted on the door to the effect that the marriage ceremony was not to be performed.

Parties interested in the sale of 678 Broadway admitted yesterday afternoon that the negotiations were all but closed. The seller of the property, which consists of a six-story iron-front business building, 28.6 by 130, is Thomas E. Davies. The reported price is $130,000.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 16. -- Jils Johnson, a bay stallion foaled in 1876, by Longfellow, dam Fannie Wells, by imp. Sovereign, second dam Reel, by imp. Glencoe, died at the home of his owner, Frank B. Harper, to-day of colic. As a race horse Jils Johnson was one of the best of his famous sire's get.

Senator Platt will not be unopposed in the selection of a Republican member of the Board of Police Commissioners. The anti- Platt Republicans intend to ask Mayor-elect Van Wyck to appoint their preference, on the ground that they, and not Mr. Platt, represent a majority of the Republican Party.

Edward J. Ratcliffe told his own story yesterday at his trial for assaulting his wife. He denied every accusation that has been brought against him, and threw upon his wife the blame for the troubles which broke up their home and which resulted in his arrest.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- The President to-day sent the following nominations to the Senate:

BERLIN, Dec. 16. -- In the Reichstag to-day the debate over the bill for the reform of military judicial procedure was commenced. The Imperial Chancellor, Prince Hohenlohe, declared the measure corresponded with the ministerial statements of last year. It introduced, he continued, the system of oral, direct procedure and, while separating the duties of the Judge, Prosecutor, and defending counsel, it afforded means of redress by way of complaint, appeal, or revision.

With the merging of the several districts into the greater city, the question of augmenting the local Consulate of the League of American Wheelmen to embrace all sections of the municipality has been much discussed. The Consuls recently appointed by Chief Consul Walter S. Jenkins do not favor enlarging their present number, considering that if they admit thirty-five others, to represent Long Island and Staten Island, their body will be too bulky for effective service.

The Rev. Dr. Edward L. Stoddard, rector of St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church, Jersey City, has under consideration a plan for establishing a dancing school under the direction of the church officials. He said yesterday that the school was as yet a dream, but he believed it would be realized.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- The Currency bill framed by the Secretary of the Treasury was introduced in the House to-day by Chairman Walker of the Banking and Currency Committee immediately after a hearing at which Secretary Gage explained the measure to the members of the committee. Following is the full text of the bill:

KIEL, Dec. 16. -- The German cruiser Gefion bound for China left her moorings at 8 o'clock this morning amid salutes and cheers from the crews of all the warships present. The weather was glorious and the harbor presented a most animated picture. The shores were thronged with people and a number of naval officers, including Admirals Knorr, Tirpitz, Koester, Thomsen, Bendemann, Oldekoppe and Armin, occupied the Barbarossa Bridge.
CHICAGO, Dec. 10. -- Joseph Letter, who is at the head of the December wheat deal, said to-day he expected to pay cash for all the wheat delivered to him and ship it out of Chicago.

The second concert of the twelfth season of the Boston Symphony Orchestra in this city, which took place at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, was one which gave music lovers abundant food for thought. The programme, which was extremely generous in its length, contained two novelties, one of them of a nature to make people sit up and think, which is not a congenial occupation to most concert-goers.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 16. -- The Lake submarine boat Argonaut, built for the purpose of exploring the bottoms of rivers, lakes, and other bodies of water, and doing all manner of submarine work, was given her first public trial to-day. The place selected was "Ferry Bar" just outside of Baltimore in the Patapsco River.

It is a notable fact that while everybody knows what good money is in the everyday transactions of buying and selling and making contracts for its future payment, there is a great diversity of opinion as to what good or true money is, among those who talk and write about it for the instruction of others or for influencing legislation.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment interrupted its public sitting yesterday afternoon and went into the Mayor's private office to consider the bids for the new Hall of Records and to examine the accompanying samples of stone. The board then awarded the contract for the building to John Pierce of this city, whose bid of $1,997,900 was the highest.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 16. -- The National Civil Service Reform League is holding its sixteenth annual meeting in this city. Carl Schurz, President of the League, made an address to-night at Odeon Hall upon the present condition of civil service reform. He was enthusiastically applauded throughout his speech. He said, in part:

TACOMA, Washington, Dec. 16. -- Prospectors have just returned to Whatcom with small flasks of gold washed from newly discovered placer fields on the South Fork of the Nooksack River, Whatcom County. Great excitement prevails at Whatcom, and a stampede is in progress to the scene of the new gold discoveries.

It was reported yesterday that John C. Sheehan might not be deposed from the Chairmanship of the Finance Committee of Tammany Hall. It was said that Richard Croker had, through the good offices of Senator Edward Murphy, become so far reconciled to Mr. Sheehan that he would not humiliate him at present by putting some on else in the finance Chairmanship.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- In the House to-day Mr. Hitt, (Rep., Ill.,) Chairman of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, secured unanimous consent for the consideration of the bill passed by the Senate yesterday to prohibit pelagic sealing by citizens of the United States. He explained its scope and purpose and the necessity for its enactment, in view of the pending negotiations with Great Britain.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Dec. 16. -- Beverley Ward, Jr., was found dead in his bedroom at the Baltusrol Golf Clubhouse, near here, this morning under circumstances that give color to the theory that he committed suicide. Gossip, sprung from no one knows where, goes so far as to declare that he killed himself because a young woman to whom he had been attentive for some months had announced her betrothal to another.

The police are rapidly obtaining more evidence against Charles Zanoli outside of that which they hope to be forthcoming from the chemical analysis of parts of Jennie Suhmer's body. Yesterday they secured another important witness, whose story goes a long way toward strengthening the chain of evidence which they are striving to forge around the man in their effort to convict him of the murder of his wives.

Again yesterday the stock market showed a decidedly strong undertone until the last hour, when the traders made a concerted raid on prices. In fact, it seems to have become the fashion of Wall Street's professional bears to make a drive on the market toward the close of a day in which any strength has previously been shown.
VANCOUVER, B.C., Dec. 16. -- Chinese papers brought by the Empress of India thus describe the taking of Kiao-Chau by Germans:

Testimony regarding the contested will of De Witt C. Lawrence was heard before Surrogate Arnold yesterday. The Rev. Robert Collyer, Charles L. Tiffany, the jeweler; Horace M. Barry, Dr. Cotton, the father-in-law of Mr. Lawrence, and Mrs. Lawrence were examined.

Many good people are suffering from the apprehension and misapprehension that the New York Medical League is opposing charity to the sick poor. This is entirely foreign to the purposes of that body; therefore, we are directed to communicate to you, and, by courtesy, through you to the public, the following statement:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- The following fourth-class Postmasters have been appointed for New York offices: Burlington Flats, Edward Mayne; Cooperstown Junction, Burdell Chase; East Bloomfield, Thomas W. Peeling; Elk Creek, Nettie B. Webster; Laurens, Austin S. Gray; Roseboom, William F. White; South Edmeston, Leon S. Page; South Valley, John M. Lovejoy; West Edmeston, Adolph M. Nichols.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- Ticket scalping was discussed to-day in the Inter-State Commerce Committee of the Senate, chiefly from the scalpers' point of view, but with some interruptions from George H. Daniels of the New York Central Railroad. George M. McKenzie, a scalper and the official spokesman of the scalpers, justified the business of the brokers as one that pays nearly six million dollars annually to travelers.

RIPLEY, W. Va., Dec. 16. -- John Morgan was hanged here this afternoon for killing Mrs. Edward Greene, seventy years old; her son. James Greene, and Matilda Pfost, her daughter by her first marriage. The murders were committed Nov. 5. Apparently there was no motive for the terrible crime.

LONDON, Dec. 16. -- William Terriss, the well-known actor, was assassinated as he was entering the stage door of the Adelphi Theatre to-night for the performance of "Secret Service." Mr. Terriss had alighted from a cab at the stage door in Maiden Lane only used by himself and the principal members of the company.

-- Sixty-eight sailors lost their lives while navigating the great lakes this season, and, as the Western papers prefix "only" to the number, it is to be assumed that the record is a satisfactory one, all things considered. Not a single passenger on the lake steamers was the victim of accident, but one did jump overboard and drown himself.
MEXICO CITY, Mex., Dec. 16. -- President Diaz yesterday accorded an audience to Mr. Bryan and party. Later they visited the Cathedral and the Academy of Fine Arts.

Every public appearance of the Emperor of Germany increases the wonder that, at the end of the nineteenth century, an otherwise intelligent man should be able to regard himself as "The Lord's Anointed" and to hold that Governments derive their just power from the consent of the governors.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- The National Board of Trade adjourned to-day after a three days' session. The most important action of to-day's session was the indorsement of a pooling measure which would place this question under the supervision of the Inter-State Commerce Commission. There was a strong sectional division on the question, the East for and the West against the measure.

The first Assembly Ball of the season was held last night in the grand ballroom of the Astoria Hotel, and society turned out in full force to attend it, nearly 200 couples occupying the floor when the signal was given for the first dance.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- A bill for the appropriation of $175,000 for the relief of the miners in the Yukon River district was passed to-day by the House, and a resolution was adopted by the Senate appropriating $250,000 for the same purpose. It is understood a conference will be held with the view of agreeing on a measure that will be satisfactory to both houses.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16. -- John W. Foster, ex-Secretary of State, gave out last night for publication an argument in favor of the annexation of Hawaii. He says in the argument:

CITY OF MEXICO, Dec. 16. -- Some time ago when it was rumored that a British warship had seized Clipperton Island, the local papers took the matter up, and there was some agitation over the reported forcible occupation of Mexican soil. The Foreign Relations Department asked the War Department to send an expedition to the island to investigate if the British really had taken possession.

BUFFALO, Dec. 16. -- The Revs. Byron H. Stauffer and W.A. Pattison, acting for the Methodist Ministers' Association, succeeded in breaking up a boxing tournament that was to take place to-night before the members of the Live Stock Exchange Athletic Club.

It seems that Gen. WEYLER is very much agitated in his mind about President MCKINLEY'S "unjustifiable insults" to Spain and the Spanish Army. He has been expressing his indignation to the Queen, and he seems to have been stimulating a protest by Spanish officers against the "insults," although, for prudential reasons, he has thus far withheld from it his own signature.

Prof. Mommsen, the distinguished German historian, attained his eightieth year on Nov. 30. His friends wished to celebrate the day, but he left Berlin in order to avoid becoming the object of testimonials and congratulations. In some hiding place he joined his wife. Not even his own children knew where he was.

" Morts et Vivants" is the title of a volume of literary studies by M.A. Mezieres from the press of Hachette, which includes, besides an appreciation of the work of contemporary writers, interesting chapters on Lamartine, Guizot, Prevost-Paradol, Edgar Quinet, et al., on French drama of the eighteenth century, on the politics of the same epoch, on Fenelon, Mme, de Maintenon, Dirot, on King Stanislas, Marie Leczinska, et al.

In Peek Slip, just below Pearl Street, there still stands the house in which the First Reformed Presbyterian Church of New York was organized exactly 100 years ago. The congregation now worships in Twelfth Street, just west of Sixth Avenue, and is to celebrate its centenary during a period of five days in the last week of the current year.

Miss Jenkins of Bath, England, has much to answer for. Long since dead, the potency of her example is now abroad in very appreciable degree. In 1820 she had become a devout collector of book plates -- the first of a long and expanding line -- and, while others might have taken up the pursuit had she failed to do so, the opprobrium of founding this industry seems to belong to her.

Messrs. Raphael Tuck Sons' Company, of 368 Broadway, New York, have produced for the coming holiday season and the approaching new year a very handsomely adorned collection of calendars and Christmas cards. Certainly the most elaborate colored work of the kind ever made is the calendar called "Pretty Polly." Polly's wings unfold and on the plumes are the months of the year. The bird is life size.

All the preliminary arrangements for Newark's new public library building have been practically completed, and within a short time bids for the work will be called for. The plans have been made and approved, but it has been decided not to begin actual work on the building until early in the Spring. The site chosen is on the Washington Street side of Washington Park.

Out in old Roxbury, one of the most interesting and important parts of Boston, dwells the author of the immortal "Yawcob Strauss" ballads and other world-popular German dialect verses, Mr. Charles Follen Adams. His home is on historic ground, a region that gave Gens, Warren, Heath, Dearborn, and Greaton to the Revolutionary armies.

ATLANTA, Ga. Dec. 17. -- De Wolf Hopper and his beautiful wife have not yet become reconciled, according to reports circulated concerning their recent engagement here. It seems that Mrs. Hopper insisted on riding in the same car with her husband in opposition to his wishes, and Wednesday, when the company played here, Hopper posted the following signed orders in prominent places:

For cover, Harper's Weekly, for the holiday season, has Maxfield Parrish's best work. How complacent are the beruffled lady and the gentleman with the queue, who sit bolt upright at the table! The imaginative Mr. Parrish discards art, and seeks for lasting effects. In this number Mr. Howard Pyle has a story, illustrated by himself.

It is hardly possible to realize that twenty years have elapsed since the Russo-Turkish war, which happily marked the climax, thus far, in its fierceness and terrible bloodshed, of the great wars of modern times. It seems hardly yesterday since Christendom was shocked and horrified by the dramatic tales of the war correspondents at Plevna and the other great battlefields of the war and of the conflict which brought the Russian eagles to the Bosporus.

Although in America bookplate collecting and even the general use of plates has come about in the last few years, yet the first plate known to us is that of St. Christopher of 1423, found in the Carthusian Monastery of Buxheim, in Suabia. Thus Germany may claim not only the invention of printing from moveable metal type, but also the first use of the bookplate.

HAVANA, Dec. 17. -- The reunited Central Committee of the Reformist Party has approved of the action taken by the commission in accepting the autonomist propositions. The Reformists will publish a manifesto early next week, and electoral commissions will be appointed before Dec. 24.
Lowenfeld Prager have sold, to Jacob Fishel, for improvement, the old buildings northeast corner of Clinton and Madison Streets, 47.3 by 68.

The judgment of the Court of Appeal in Paris in the action between Sir William Eden and "Jimmy" McNeil Whistler is satisfactory to artists in general and to Whistler in particular. The significance of the judgment is that a painting belongs to the artist until it is delivered, but that the client who does not get the picture may sue for damages, but not for the picture.

This is a story of much incident and interest. Beginning in the England of 1701, the scene soon shifts to New York. The various characters, Dutch, English, Puritan, French, and negro, are cleverly conceived and well sustained throughout.
FRANKFORT, Ky., Dec. 17. -- Millions of dollars' worth of property, mostly in Louisville, was declared to-day not subject to taxation in a decision made by the Court of Appeals.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court handed down a decision yesterday confirming the report of the special commission which approved the general scheme and plans of the Rapid Transit Commission. Justices Rumsey, Patterson, and Williams concurred in the opinion written by Presiding Justice Van Brunt.

A casual glance at the many biographies and monographs on the first Emperor of France might cause one to say that all the known facts of his life have been told over and over again. But not a single work is recalled where the youth of Napoleon is treated in a trustworthy manner by an unprejudiced historian.

DOBBS FERRY, Dec. 17. -- John C. Wright, a constable, and Harry Barton, a newspaper reporter, fought here last night as the result of an article alleged to have been written by Barton. Wright attempted to arrest Barton and was knocked down. The constable finally inveigled the reporter into a near-by saloon, where Judge Lang was sitting, but not holding court.

Among the most quaint and charming of last year's holiday books was Miss Manning's "Household of Sir Thomas More," and now we have in the same series the best-known of all the author's works, "The Maiden and Married Life of Mary Powell," and its sequel, "Deborah's Diary."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- In the House to-day the Speaker announced the appointment of Messrs. Hitt, (Rep., Ill.,) Adams, (Rep., Penn.,) and Wheeler (Dem., Ala.,) as Regents of the Smithsonian Institution.

American shares were irregular in the London market. The principal changes were: Advanced -- Canadian Pacific, 1/8, to 84 1/2; Illinois Central, 1/3, to 107 1/3, and New York Central, 1/8, to Ill. Declined -- Reading, 3/8 to 11 5/8; Pennsylvania, 1/4, to 58; Louisville and Nashville, 1/4, to 58 1/4, and St. Paul, 1/4, to 98. Atchison sold at 13 3/8, Erie at 15 1/2, and Erie first preferred at 39.

Importers from this city, Philadelphia, Pittsburg, San Francisco, and other cities were present at the hearing on embroideries and embroidered articles before the Board of Classification of the General Appraisers yesterday. Protests against various acts of the customs authorities were on file from John Wanamaker, Arnold, Constable Co., Mills Gibb, Muser Co., Dickerhoff, Roffloer Co., Voss Stern, Goldenberg Brothers, and other firms.

The Board of Street Opening yesterday decided to lay out a small park west of Eleventh Avenue, between Fifty-second and Fifty-fourth Streets to Twelfth Avenue. The cost of opening will be assessed at the rate of three-quarters upon the city and one-quarter upon an area of assessment bounded by Forty-eighth Street, Fifty-sixth Street, and Ninth Avenue.

BOSTON, Dec. 17. -- The Directors of the Amoskeag Manufacturing Company of Manchester, NH., at a meeting held at the Boston office of the company this afternoon, voted to reduce the wages of its employes about 10 per cent. Jan. 1. The Amoskeag plant is one of the largest engaged in the manufacture of cotton in the country.
Stock market irregular.

SOUTH NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 17. -- Connecticut's latest horror is reported to-night from Wilton, a village about eight miles from here, and one more murder is added to the already large list that the State's epidemic of crime has occasioned.
The opinion written by Justice Van Brunt is as follows:

In the midst of a group of officers, who were striving to fray a passage for their Generals, the presence was noted or the Emperor Francois Joseph, who had remained to the end upon the field of battle so hardly disputed. At this moment Napoleon III. rode up at a gallop to the battery to judge of the havoc it was causing.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Thus far Secretary of State Sherman is the only prominent member of the Administration who has been willing to give a direct answer to inquiries as to the authority by which the Wolcott Commission offered to guarantee a ratio of fifteen and one-half to one if other nations would unite with the United States to bring about the free coinage of silver.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- Secretary Gage resumed his exposition of his comprehensive currency bill before the House Committee on Banking and Currency to-day. Chairman Walker had left the city, and Mr. Brosius of Pennsylvania presided.

The concrete discussion of a poet's qualities, especially of such a master as was Tennyson, is always unsatisfactory. Mr. Harold Spender, in The Fortnightly Review, fully appreciating the Tennyson memoir, pays most attention to that part which treats incidentally of the poet's development.

ALBANY, Dec. 17. -- For the last time Chief Judge Charles Andrews of the Court of Appeals occupied his seat as a member of the court to-day. When the court adjourned he had completed his term of office by reason of having reached the age limit of seventy years. He will be succeeded in January next by Chief Judge-elect Alton B. Parker, at present a Justice of the Supreme Court in the Third Judicial District.

The rifle match for the Abeel Trophy ended at the Seventh Regiment Armory last night, after a most successful competition. Company G, whose first team made a score of 617 on Thursday night, was the winner.

The Christmas numbers of the leading London illustrated papers, The Graphic, The Illustrated London News, The Figaro, and The Ladies' Pictorial, appear for the holiday season, with all their colored splendor, and may be had from the International News Company. Each journal has its special offering in the guise of a large and handsome print.

The belief of the friends, intimate associates, and parents of Beverly Ward, Jr., is that his death was caused from the careless use of a prescribed medicine containing chloral. The stories that he committed suicide and that he was moved to the deed by disappointment at the announced engagement of a young woman were not believed by his friends.

When Senator ELLSWORTH introduced last year his bill to prevent the publication of portraits without the consent of the originals, his apparent purpose commanded the sympathy of many persons who doubted both the efficacy and the legitimacy of the means by which he proposed to attain his end. That end was apparently the protection of privacy, which is in much need of protection.

The development of club life is one of the most striking things in New York to a person who has been absent long, a development not merely in number but in character. Clubs have invaded the business part of the city. The Merchants', Down Town, Lawyers', and other clubs now take the place of the informal gatherings of merchants over their claret at some favored hotel forty years ago.

LAKEWOOD, Dec. 17. -- Incoming trains to-day brought additions to the Democratic colony here, and with the arrivals expected to-morrow the indications are that practically the Tammany organization, as represented in its chosen leaders, will be assembled under the roof of the Lakewood.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 17. -- The Alabama Baptist Convention, which adjourned at East Lake to-night, devoted the afternoon and evening sessions to consideration of the course of Dr. W.H. Whitsitt, President of the Southern Baptist Theological Seminary, at Louisville, whose declaration that baptism by immersion was not practiced in England prior to 1641, has caused much criticism.

The proposal to establish an open-air gymnasium in the East River Park is one of those frequent applications which show how much people in general are in need of education upon the proper uses of public parks. The seriousness with which it appears to be taken by the Park Board is a proof how much Park Commissioners in general are in need of the same instruction.

Less than a decade ago in the "Chap Book" was introduced a series of pseudo-dilettante periodicals which have increased abundantly in numbers and eccentricities and given to educated writers of polite sensational literature a vent for their diseased imaginations. These publications are now fast disappearing. Something has failed to make them go; either readers failed them or advertisements didn't come in.
MUSKOGEE, Indian Territory, Dec. 17. -- A treaty between the United States and the Seminole Nation has been concluded and signed by the Dawes and Seminole Commissions.
The New York Sun says of Secretary GAGE'S currency bill:

The relation of the Erie Canal to the development of the Port of New York has not ceased to be an important one. It was the canal that definitely turned the flow of Western commerce in our direction. In 1825 a boat carrying sixty tons at the rate of one and a half miles per hour marked a tremendous advance in transportation facilities over a wagon carrying one ton twenty miles per day.

This is a very entertaining little book about one of the loveliest islands in the world. There were numberless temptations to rhapsody and digression, but the author has avoided them and has told ornamental truths with matter of fact directness. During her stay in Java her eyes and mind were open to everything, and her report contains history and tradition, statistics and the gleanings of personal observation.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 17. -- The Railroad Commissioners to-day issued a report, giving the result of their investigation into the train wreck, which occurred at King's Dock, near Garrison's, Oct. 24, on the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad.

-- Thursday was the anniversary of Boston's most famous "tea party," and many patriotic residents of the city gathered in the old South Meeting House to celebrate the achievement of their departed fellowtownsmen. There were speeches and poems by Sons and Daughters of various sorts, and not one of them hinted disapproval of the act commemorated.

As we approach Christmastide I feel like giving some of my more serious recollections of the charming days spent in Europe by collecting the more religious memories -- the legends and the fables, perhaps, which bear upon that sacred season. I spent a Christmas in Rome; I went to see the Passion Play at Ober-Ammergau, in June, 1890. I collected with care the lovely legends which accumulate in Catholic countries.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- The first regular meeting of the National Association of Freight Commissioners was held here to-day for the general purpose of effecting a permanent organization. The members of the association represent commercial bodies in their respective cities, and are charged with the duty of securing equal justice for shippers in their dealings with transportation companies.

Tammany's agony will soon be over. Unless plans which have been matured at Lakewood are changed at the last moment, the names of the men who are to be honored with the chief offices within the gift of the new Mayor will be given out to-morrow for publication in the Monday morning papers.

ALBANY, Dec. 17. -- Adjt. Gen. Tillinghast gave out the following statement to-day: "The repeated and seemingly authentic rumors regarding the proposed early retirement of Brig. Gen. Louis Fitzgerald from his connection with the National Guard of the State, have naturally suggested to the State authorities the propriety of crowning his forty years of service in military life with a substantial recognition of their appreciation of his long and faithful service therewith.

At Bangs Co.'s recently was sold a collection of books, especially notable for some rare editions of Goldsmith, and the more important of the Grolier Club publications. The "Decree" and the "Rubaiyat" did not bring the prices other copies fetched last Winter and Spring, but the present was a small sale.

The general domestic education of the members of the Household Economic Association was continued yesterday at a regular meeting of the society by a lecture upon domestic architecture by R.L. Daus. The members of the Domestic Science Department of the Brooklyn Institute united with the association for the occasion, and there was a large gathering present.
For two weeks Capt. McClusky and several of his detectives have been busy running down a gang of burglars and safe crackers.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- The Monetary Commission reached the conclusion of its deliberations to-day and the Chairman, Senator Edmunds, declared the commission adjourned without day.

PARIS, Dec. 6. -- M. Lucien Descaves is an artist in spite of himself. He has the painstaking principles of Gustave Flaubert, and he is a living example of Carlyle's theory that genius is an infinite capacity for taking pains. He might be described as the George Moore of modern French literature, and that is, I think, very high praise.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, Dec. 17. -- The Nations Civil Service Reform League to-day adopted the following resolutions:

Thaddeus Murphy, a policeman attached to the Oak Street Station, was arraigned in Centre Street Police Court yesterday morning, on a charge of homicide, preferred by Capt. Vredenburgh. He is accused of having caused the death of Thomas McCarthy of 16 Batavia Street, who died of erysipelas on Wednesday, in Bellevue Hospital.

All the more important athletic clubs of New York and the neighboring cities and several of the larger colleges contributed to the army of athletes who competed in Madison Square Garden last night in the first half of the two-day Winter carnival of sports of the New Jersey Athletic Club.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 17. -- Articles of incorporation of the American Pegamoid Company, with an authorized capital of $5,000,000, were filed with the Secretary of State this afternoon. The company is incorporated to import, deal in, and manufacture paper, paper material, and paper substitutes of all kinds; also raw substances, pulps, preparations and mixtures, and all articles to be made from paper or paper substitutes.

BERLIN, Dec. 17. -- The German cruiser Deutschland arrived at Brunsbuettelroog at 3 o'clock. Princess Henry of Prussia stood at the lock-gates awaiting the vessel's arrival, and waved her hand to her husband, who was on the bridge. Prince Henry landed and then re-embarked with his wife and son, Waldemar, who remained on board until 5 o'clock, when the Deutschland resumed her journey, and the Princess and her son returned to Kiel.

The title of the exceedingly handsome volumes of "The People' Standard History of the United States" is well sustained by an xamination of the text. The reputation of the author, Mr. Edward S. Ellis, was acquired with the writing of a former history, but on a more restricted scale. In the present work his ability ts fully shown. This is indeed a history made for all classes of readers.

To the Editor of The New York Times:I was much surprised, and I cannot tell you how much gratified, to see my almost forgotten reminiscences so honorably placed in THE REVIEW OF BOOKS AND ART of THE NEW YORK TIMES of Saturday. To be sure there is some personal gratification, especially as it awakened me from a slumber fallen into about a year ago -- from paralysis -- a feeling that my race was run.

The long-expected decision in the underground rapid transit matter was handed down yesterday. The news reached Wall Street shortly after 1 o'clock. Before that time it was generally known in the Street that the decision was to come before the close of business, and it seemed to be the general belief that it would prove to be favorable to the underground project.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17. -- The Appellate Court in a decision holds that a certification of a draft, in effect, is the setting aside money by a bank for the payment of the instrument. The decision affirms the decree of the County Court in the case of Strauss H. Smith against the American Exchange National Bank of New York.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 17. -- Miss L. Miller, a modiste, of 91 Crew Street, was fined $25.75 by Recorder Calhoun to-day for refusing to be vaccinated. She was unable to pay the amount, and was ordered to serve twenty-five days in the city prison. After having been in the prison for three hours Miss Miller said she would allow her family physician to vaccinate her.

PRINCETON, Dec. 17. -- Three members of the senior class at Princeton University were suspended this afternoon by the Faculty. This action was taken because the three were caught by the college Proctor in the act of hazing. Their names are Meredith, Wyckoff, and Scott.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17. -- George B. French, the recognized agent of the Leiter interest, has issued a statement imparting a bit of information which wheat speculators have been anxious to obtain. He also ventured a prediction on the future of May wheat.

District Attorney Olcott said yesterday that he had on his hands a case of possible murder, which might rival that of Charles Zanoli in sensational interest. The particulars of the case he declined to give. He said that his reason for keeping the facts from the public was that their disclosure might defeat the ends of justice. Neither would the police give any information in regard to the case.

Lord Alvanley followed Sheridan and Brummell as a sayer of good things, but those most generally quoted have a touch of sarcastic malice, for cynical talk was a fashion of the time. When Brummell made his midnight flitting to Boulogne at the suit of the Jews, he remarked complacently, "Brummell has done quite right to be off; it was Solomon's judgment."

LONDON, Dec. 17. -- Richard Arthur Prince, known as "Mad Archer," the impecunious singer who stabbed and killed William Terriss, the actor, was arraigned at Bow Street Police Court to-day, charged with the crime, and was remanded until Wednesday next.

Few even of the lovers of Charles Dickens are aware, says a London paper, that a portion of the old Marshalsea Prison yet stands hidden away behind the Borough High Street and St. George's Church; but the remaining wards of the prison, which once was the hence of Mr. and Mrs. Micawber when that gentleman's affairs had arrived at a "crisis," are about to disappear.

Readers of "Down the Islands" are aware that there is no better traveling companion than Mr. Paten. That book had the best result, in one way, that any book of travels can have, by greatly stimulating journeyings to the scenes it described. It will be singular if the present volume does not have a much greater effect of the same kind, for the subject is out of all comparison more interesting.

CLINTON, Ark., Dec. 17. -- As the family of Farmer Patterson, one of Van Buren County's most respected citizens, were seated at the supper table, at Culpepper Mountain, six miles from here, two men, heavily masked, ruthlessly threw open the front door of the house, and presenting rifles, commanded those at the table to remain perfectly quiet, under pain of death.

Through the quick action of Midshipman Graham and a number of men from the battleship Iowa, the dispatch boat Dolphin was saved from being destroyed by fire on Thursday night. As it was, considerable damage was done to the interior of the vessel.

A more frankly critical spirit is shown in Lieut. Gen. Schofield's memoirs, just published, than in anything of like nature that has appeared from the pen of any officer of equal rank in our army since the civil war. It will be difficult to find clear ground for censure of Gen. Schofield's motives in passing judgment upon the operations of his brother commanders in the field.

Tennyson said, "Somehow water is the element I love best of all four," but in the recent memoir he is also credited with saying that he "never cared greatly for the sea on the south coast. It is not a grand sea, only an angry, curt sea."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17. -- The President to-day sent the following nominations to the Senate:
It was in the smoking room of the hotel. There was one big fellow who was blustering a great deal, and telling of how many duels he had fought, and behind him sat a small man, reading a magazine.

The Cunard Line steamship Lucania and the American Line steamship Paris, which arrived yesterday, reported exceedingly boisterous passages, in which they were confronted throughout by westerly gales and head seas.

When the plant was introduced, about 1840, It was only the small daisy-like flower, now only seen as a rule in cottage gardens, which was highly prized as a novelty. The taste for growing and showing it began early, and before 1860 there were many chrysanthemum societies in existence, among them the Stoke Newington, which formed the nucleus of the National Society.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 18. -- A farmer digging "muck" at Robins Springs, Walker County, yesterday unearthed the bones, since identified as those of John Maynos, who disappeared suddenly and mysteriously ten years ago. Officers went to work on the case and secured from a woman well known in the community a confession in which the woman says that Maynos was murdered at the house of his wife at the time of his mysterious disappearance.

Although Christmas falls on Saturday this year, and is consequently nearly a week away, the spirit of the Christmastide is already in the air, and the usual entertainments of the Winter season will this week lose their interest while old and young, rich and poor, will devote themselves from now until Friday evening to preparations for the great festival.

SOUTH NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 18. -- The horror of last evening, when David Lambert, a well-to-do resident of Wilton, a neighboring village, was deliberately shot down by robbers whom he had surprised plundering his house, after having previously gagged and bound Mrs. Lambert, is the one topic of conversation to-day, and has awakened a feeling of uncertainty of safety.

-- The story of the Princeton Inn will probably amaze future historians if they ever get hold of it. For many years the authorities of the university struggled to solve the problem of how to prevent drunkenness among the students. At first they clung firmly to the tenets of the Presbyterian Church and used all their authority to establish local prohibition.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 18. -- Windowglass factories throughout the United States will be able to resume work just as soon as they can get the furnaces hot enough to begin. This will be in about three weeks and mean work for about 15,000 men.

The Professional Woman's League expects the returns from its annual sale, held last week, to do much toward putting it in the way of getting a clubhouse of its own. The league has more of a clubhouse now than any other purely woman's club in New York, with the exception of that of the Metropolitan Nurses' Association, where nurses are in residence.

NEWPORT, Dec. 18. -- Mrs. E.H.G. Slater has had Architect J.D. Johnson prepare plans for a villa to be erected on the cliffs next Spring near the villa "Ocean Lawn," owned by the late Mrs. William Gammell. The plans are understood to call for a French chateau.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 18. -- The jubilee of the discovery of gold in California on Jan. 24 will be observed in a manner befitting the occasion. The day has been officially declared a holiday, and the Supervisors have appropriated $3,000 for the celebration, while private subscriptions to the fund are expected to aggregate $15,000.

LINCOLN, Neb., Dec. 18. -- The Lincoln street railway system has been sold under foreclosure and was bid in by first and second mortgage bondholders, represented by the New York Security and Trust Company and the New York Guaranty and Indemnity Company, the price paid being $60,500, subject to paying taxes of not less than $40,000.

The Indian Mohammedans heard that the Khalif had triumphed over the infidel, and the news went to the heads of the Mohammedans of Delhi and Oudh, just as now it has gone to the heads of the tribesmen of the frontier. In both cases it urged them, regardless of all consequences, to strike a blow for the faith.

THE new building for the library of Congress has for some months been the show building of the capital. Its main front is considerably shorter than that of the Capitol, which it confronts across a strip of park, which secures to each building such detachment that it can be seen all at once.

MR. F. MARION CRAWFORD, after a long absence, returned to the United States some weeks ago, having been detained in Rome longer than expected by the death of his mother, Mrs. Terry, whose illness called him there, and where his wife is staying at present with Mr. Terry.
LONDON, Dec. 18. -- " Choppy" Warburton, the trainer of "Jimmy" Michael, the Welsh bicycle ride, is dead.

When her sister Mary, nineteen years old, refused her permission to go to a ball in Sulzer's Harlem River Park, last night, Lizzie Schaeffer, fifteen years old, of 347 East One Hundred and Fourth Street, concluded that life was a blank, for her, at least, and she proceeded to end it.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 18. -- The most important political move of the week in the South is the determination of many of the Populist leaders to adopt a new party policy, which is intended to break party lines and cause a cataclysm in Southern politics.

Judged by our terrestrial experience, which is all we have to go by, the magnitude of a planet, if it is to bear life resembling that of the earth, is limited by other considerations. Even Jupiter, which, as far as our knowledge extends, represents the extreme limit of great planetary size, may be too large ever to become the abode of living beings of a high organization.

Charles Zanoli was taken into the Centre Street Police Court yesterday morning for examination on the charge of homicide. After he was arraigned, however, it was decided to put off the examination to Dec. 28. This decision was the result of a conference between Deputy Assistant District Attorney Van Wyck and Stephen O'Hare, the prisoner's counsel. Both wanted more time for preparing the case, and wanted to wait for the report on the chemical analysis.

Claude J.D. Goldie of Cambridge, who rowed for Leander in the race for the grand challenge cup at the Henley regatta this year, and W.J. Fernie, who stroked the Trinity Hall, Cambridge, crew, arrived here yesterday on the steamship Lucania. It had been rumored that they were going to New Haven to look into Yale's rowing and possibly to coach the Yale crew.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Dec. 18. -- Commissioners James R. Willets and Timothy M. Griffing, who were named by Supreme Court Justice Garretson nearly a year ago to look into charges against the officials of Hempstead, filed their report to-day.

The adoption of human infants by wild and carnivorous quadrupeds has obtained more or less credence among the vulgar from the earliest ages, and, while such today are for the most part pooh-poohed as idle tales, the skeptics have little idea of the evidence that has been offered in substantiation thereof.

There were numerous entries in the two matches decided by the members of the Seventh Regiment Rifle Club at the armory ranges last night. The prone class match, for which entries were unlimited, brought about a keen, competition. Private J.D. Thees of Company B won through his superior marksmanship at 500 yards, at which distance he made a clean score of seven "bulls."

A feature of the cotton market last week was the presentation by Mr. Thoman, who has hitherto devoted himself to grain crop statistics, of statistics on this year's cotton crop, roughly estimated before it was fully grown at 10,000,000 bales. His estimate is an acreage of 25,714,674 and a crop of 11,209,000 bales, and that the producers hold back 5,200,000 bales, or 47 per cent. of the yield.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- In reply to a question Senator Teller said to-day that he would oppose the confirmation of the nomination of Charles Page Bryan to be Minister to China.

LAST year all the sculptors of Germany were invited to send in models of a monument to the great Iron Chancellor, to be erected in front of the new Reichstag Palace. The result was a sad sight, and the best thing under the circumstances was done, namely, about a dozen of the most prominent sculptors were invited to enter a narrower competition.
