If the Rapid Transit Commissioners were a scheming "combine" and the road they have planned a private "grab," the city would be grateful to the Appellate Division for erecting a bulwark against the intended depredation. But must we conclude, putting private judgment and all misgivings aside, that the court is right and the Commissioners wrong?

"I guess heaven will be a place where we don't give people what they need, but what they don't need," says Miss Susan, in one of Alice Brown's remarkable stories. Apart from the tale you hardly get the wisdom of these homely words. They are Miss Susan's protest against the utilitarianism that makes us give yarn socks and dark calico dresses to our fellow-men and fellow-women as Christmas tokens of our good will.

In view of the fact that there is a super-abundance of peanuts raised every year in Virginia, North Carolina and other parts of the South, the suggestion is made that peanut oil be used more extensively in pharmacy, and be permitted to take the place, to a certain extent, of olive oil. Prof. S.P. Sadtler recently produced an experimental soda soap from the oil extracted from American peanuts.

Mrs. Williston Walker read a paper entitled "A Glance at Colonial Housekeeping" at the twenty-ninth general meeting of Ruth Wyllys Chapter, Daughters of the American Revolution, in Hartford, Conn., on Thursday, Dec. 9. In the course of it she said, as reported in The Courant of that city:

Most people probably imagine that vegetarianism is principally concerned with what we should eat and what we should drink, but this is to take a very low view of the question. The aesthetic side of vegetarianism formed the subject of an interesting address given yesterday afternoon by Mrs. McDonall at a meeting held at the Pioneer Club by invitation of Miss Campbell-Lang, under the auspices of the Women's Vegetarian Union.

VIENNA, Dec. 7. -- The American who visits Vienna for the first time is struck by the number of cafes to be seen everywhere, giving one the impression of an Oriental tour. They number upward of 500. As Vienna was the first European city to introduce the modern cafe, it has, perhaps, a better right than other towns to have such an extraordinary number of these resorts.

Up to about 300 years ago "greyhounds" were the shaggy, gray-colored dogs used in the chase of large game. After that the name was transferred, sufficiently absurdly, to the black, white, blue, and yellow, but generally spotted or bi-colored and never gray, dog that is now so popular for coursing hares.

PATERSON in New Jersey suggests to most people factories for the weaving of silk and thread, but at Paterson the factories are not the most interesting things. Just above the town, on the ridge of hills that look across the broad valley of the Passaic and Hackensack Rivers to the towering buildings of Manhattan, lies the castle, as it is termed in that region -- Belle Vista, as it is called by the owner.
CHICAGO, Dec. 18. -- The men who are engaged in organizing a combination of the wire manufacturing interests of the country have issued the following explanation of the enterprise:

FALL RIVER, Mass., Dec. 18. -- Secretary Rounseville of the Cotton Manufacturers' Association has notified Secretary O'Donnell of the Operatives' Conference Committee that Monday afternoon at 2:30 o'clock will be an acceptable time to the manufacturers for the conference on the labor situation.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- In speaking of the present situation of the New York money market, Mr. Coffin, Acting Controller of the Currency, to-day said:
Wallace Putnam Reed in The Atlanta Journal. The last Confederate Christmas in Atlanta was in 1863.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Dec. 18. -- Gov. Stephens to-day honored the requisition of Gov. Black for the return to New York of Albert S. Warner in jail at Kansas City. The Assistant District Attorney of Albany, N.Y., left here at noon for Kansas City with the necessary papers for the return of Warner to New York for trial on the charge of kidnapping.

CITY OF MEXICO, Dec. 18. -- The Bryan party visited several manufacturing establishments yesterday, among them the silk and chocolate factories. Mr. Bryan last evening gave a dinner at the School of Mines, which had been placed at his disposal by the Government. He was accompanied by ex-Gov. Crittenden of Missouri, Major Gorsch, the representative of Huntington's interests in the City of Mexico; Mr. Tomlinson, and many other prominent persons.

Golf will be played with considerable activity on all the links in the vicinity of New York during the coming holidays, but the only regular tournament thus far announced is that of the Richmond Hill Club, Long Island. This will only be a members' tournament, but it will be one of the most important that the club has ever held.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18. -- Despite predictions that this would be a day full of surprises on the Board of Trade, the bull clique headed by Joseph Leiter had smooth sailing, and seemed capable of doing what it had promised.

A bottle dispatched from the steamship Guildhall on May 31, 1894, when in 46 degrees north, 31 degrees west, almost midway between Brest and Newfoundland, was picked up on Feb. 13, 1896, at Antigua, after a drift of about 4,500 miles. It had evidently passed close to the Azores, the Canary Islands, and the Cape Verdes on the way.

William Taylor, the venerable retired missionary Bishop of the Methodist Episcopal Church, arrived home on the Lucania yesterday afternoon from a tour in the Transvaal, Cape Colony, Natal, and Rhodesia. With Bishop Bowman and Foster he was retired on account of the age limit in June, 1896.

EASTON, Penn., Dec. 18. -- Pardee Hall, the magnificent four-story stone structure that stood on the brow of College Hill, this city, and was the pride of Lafayette College, was badly damaged by fire early this morning. Only the east wing was saved from the flames.
LONDON, Dec. 18. -- The general opinion in England of the ceremonies at Kiel is voiced by a diplomat's remark:

Heavy iron window bars in the rear of Henry Holler's jewelry store at 66 Broadway, Williamsburg, were sawed in two by burglars early yesterday morning, who would probably have succeeded in getting into the place but for Henry Botsford, the agent for the property. Botsford has an apartment over the rear of Holler's store. He was awakened at 3 A.M. by a noise, and saw three men sawing the bars.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 18. -- If something important in the process of making a slate for the first Greater New York administration does not develop here to-morrow, the expectations of most of the Tammany men gathered here to-night will be disappointed. There are not more braves on the scene than on previous Saturday nights since Mr. Croker came, but the gathering is more representative.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 18. -- Ida Weinstein, a fifteen-year-old girl, after a quarrel with her stepmother last evening, took the matter so much to heart that she drank carbolic acid with the intention of committing suicide. She was discovered in frightful agony, and is now in the City Hospital in a critical condition.

Sir -- In this decadent month, after the great sea serpent has usually risen once more to the surface of the press -- only, perhaps, to be choked in a far from unseasonable effort to emulate the digestion of other contributors by swallowing the gigantic gooseberry -- no sensible man will feel and no honest man will affect surprise at the resurrection of a more "ridiculous monster" than these.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18. -- A local paper says that the opinion is gaining ground in railway and financial circles that neither Edwin W. Winter nor Horace G. Burt will be the President of the Union Pacific. The man now most prominently mentioned for the position is C.S. Mellen, President of the Northern Pacific.

HAVANA, Dec. 18. -- The news, telegraphed to the United States, via Key West, that Lieut. Col. Joaquin Ruiz has been executed has been confirmed. Ruiz, an aide de camp of Marshal Blanco, the Captain General of Cuba, was recently sent to confer with the insurgents. He proceeded into the country on Monday last, having previously written a letter to Aranguren.

No doubt admirers of Mr. Anton Seidi are puzzled by the conduct of the musical department of this paper. Sometimes it praises him in warm terms and at other times it condemns him in terms equally warm. When people give themselves up to admiration of any conductor they are straightway satisfied that whatever he does must be right.

Deshabille can be impressive, as we learn in a letter of Charles Dickens to the late James T. Fields, the American publisher. Dickens wrote: "I dreamed that somebody was dead. It was a private gentleman, and a particular friend; and I was greatly overcome when the news was broken to me (very delicately) by a gentleman in a cocked hat, top boots, and a sheet.

LONDON, Dec. 18. -- When Bismarck declared in his wrath that the Germans were a nation of valets he uttered one of those dangerous half truths which is most easily misunderstood. There is more of candid, well-rooted, intellectual liberalism in Germany than in any other country of the European continent, France by no means excepted.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- The views attributed to ex-Secretary Foster in a recent interview in relation to the alleged danger of Japanese domination in Hawaii in the event of the failure of annexation, have occasioned much comment among the Japanese officials in this city. The Japanese Minister said to-day that, in his opinion, it was hardly fair to attempt to draw Japan into the annexation controversy in this matter.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 18. -- At to-day's session of the American Federation of Labor Samuel Gompers was re-elected President by 1,845 votes to 407 cast for Ernest Kraft of Philadelphia. The other officers elected were James Duncan, Second Vice President; Robert Askew, Third Vice President; M.M. Girland, Fourth Vice President; George B. Lennon, Treasurer, and Frank Morrison, Secretary.

Mr. JAMES M. BRECK of Philadelphia improved the occasion of the complimentary dinner given the other evening to Mr. GEORGE B. POST to lecture New York upon the "traditional contempt and scorn" with which New Yorkers regard, of course not Philadelphians, but Philadelphia.

Joseph Leiter is the king of the wheat pit. He went into the deal six months ago a novice. The veterans who in other times have won through sheer force of money, and have slaughtered opponents in the grain arena without mercy or pity, find themselves face to face with a new giant, whose check covers one of the richest estates of he world.
BOSTON, Dec. 18. -- At the meeting of the New England Free Trade League, held at the United States Hotel to-night, Thomas G. Shearman of New York, discussing the "Future of Free Trade," remarked:

During the last few years the demand for pedigree English cattle for Argentina has been enormous. Shorthorns, Herefords, and Devons have been imported weekly, and a cross-bred English stock now fills the "corrals" of the great beef and bovril companies of the River Plate. In North America this Anglicizing process has spread to all the States of the Union.

The speech of the Rev. Minot J. Savage at the banquet of the Law Alumni of the University of the City of New York, on Thursday night, was remarkable in fervor and in variety of opinion and sentiment. It was heard with close attention, and was more applauded even than Justice Edward W. Hatch's caustic defense of the bar. Mr. Savage, in his opening, said:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Secretary Wilson has transmitted to the House of Representatives the report of the commission which last Summer was sent to Alaska to investigate the question of the feasibility of establishing agricultural experimental stations in that country for the better development of the products of the soil.

We have received from an eminent clergyman of this State a friendly note of criticism in which he says: "I am, as you know, a thorough 'TIMES' man, but let me inquire why you give us 'in extenso' on Monday mornings the sermons of the men who belong to the smallest denominations or of no denomination at all?

ALBANY, Dec. 18. -- State Commissioner of Excise Henry H. Lyman to-day published statistics showing by comparative statements the number of licensed saloons in the several cities of the State and the revenue derived therefrom under the old and the new excise laws.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Dec. 18. -- The several fish protective associations of New Jersey and the anglers of Monmouth County will ask the Legislature this Winter to pass a law prohibiting the setting of pound nets along the Jersey coast. It is alleged that the stock of food fish is being exhausted by the operations of the net fishermen

TACOMA, Washington, Dec. 18. -- New York and New England men will furnish funds for the extension of the Tacoma and Columbia River Railroad to the Columbia River opposite The Dalles, Oregon, beginning in January.

During the week just closed a fairly active stock market has been maintained and conspicuous stocks have advanced. There have been some net declines, but almost uniformly the recessions represented special and temporary influences. Of the week's developments, four out of five have been of an encouraging character.

Every United States naval station, whether it be in the United States or in foreign lands, has its little cemetery. Not only do the sailors and marines who die away from home find their last resting place there, but many officers of high rank lie beside men who had only the lowest rating in the service.

Our contemporary The Irish World declares that "under McKINLEY the Irish have been worse treated than by any Administration since the days of FILLMORE, the 'Native American' President." The appointment of Mr. McKENNA to the bench of the Supreme Court of the United States had not been announced when our contemporary made this assertion.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 17. -- A building of physical science will be erected by Syracuse University upon its campus, the intention being to complete it before the opening of the next college year. Ground will be broken immediately after the holidays. A course in electrical engineering, which is one of the latest courses established in the university, will be taught in this building, together with the regular course in physics.

The taxation of wheelmen in several of the counties of New York for road improvements has led to a proposition that each cycler in the State be required to contribute for road construction and improvement, and a promiment wheelman is authority for the statement that a bill of such tenor will be brought before the next Legislature.

BOSTON, Dec. 18. -- Mary Welch, sixty-five years old, homeless and benumbed with the cold, applied at the home of the Little Sisters of the Poor on Dudley Street to-night for shelter. She was admitted to the reception room, where she removed her scanty wraps.

One more important step has been taken by M. Witte in the gradual process of consolidating his monetary reform and regulating the new Russian currency, which is now finally established on a gold basis. Russia, for the first time in her history, has now become a gold country, with all the advantages which this change means for the development of foreign trade and the attraction of foreign capital.

Every recruit must be a British subject; the enlistment of an alien is, of course, contrary to international law. He must be unmarried. Shrewish wives have driven many men into the ranks, but not with the consent of the authorities. The married man who represents himself a bachelor is liable to two years' imprisonment with hard labor.

Last night's entertainment which wound up the two-day athletic carnival of the New Jersey Athletic Club at Madison Square Garden was productive of some well contested events, but the crowd which attended it was equally small with that of Friday night.

MADRID, Dec. 18. -- An official note issued to-day says that the dispatch of an American squadron to the Gulf of Mexico has not made a bad impression here, as the Government is aware that in the present season the Gulf of Mexico is the only sea, where naval manoeuvres are possible, and that these Winter manoeuvres have not occurred for two years past on account of a desire to avoid wounding Spanish susceptibilities.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- In response to a resolution introduced by Mr. Allen, (Pop., Neb.,) the Secretary of the Treasury to-day reported to the Senate that there are no supernumerary employes in his department, and that no employes have been retired upon pay except some members of the revenue cutter service, who have been retired according to law.

THE unregenerate playgoer! That is a fine, high-sounding phrase often seen in print nowadays -- which indicates the existence of some kind of a playgoer who is enlightened, refined, of purged vision, and those few persons whose calling compels them to give up nearly all their waking hours to looking at theatrical performances and writing about them are justified in doubting, sometimes, if that kind of a playgoer exists.
BOSTON, Dec. 18. -- The Railroad Commissioners have approved the terms of the new lease of the West End Street Railway to the Boston Elevated Company.

Indicative of the amours of Russia and France, somebody in Germany has had struck off a medal in bronze. On the obverse are a Cossack and a figure representing France. The Russian has the pronounced Kalmuk profile, with much beard and mustache. La Belle France, fairly decolletee, sports the Phrygian cap. Evidently she begs a kiss. Around the figures this legend runs: "Andenken an die denkwurdigen tage Paris, Oktober, 1896 -- St. Petersburg, August, 1897."

Until the Columbian Exhibition, four years ago, people on our Atlantic seaboard had a patronizing way of regarding Chicago as on the extreme outskirts of civilization, much as complacent Europeans are apt to regard the most established parts of America. The exhibition opened many eyes that saw it to the fact that Chicago is fast becoming an important centre of intellectual as well as material activity.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- The conference report on the emergency measure for the relief of the miners in the Yukon River country and other mining regions of Alaska, compromising the amount of relief at $200,000, was agreed to by both the Senate and House to-day and signed by the President.

Edward Rice has long been hard at work upon the preliminaries of the production of "The Ballet Girl," a new English "musical comedy" of the "Girl from Paris" and "French Maid" brand, which will be seen and heard at the Herald Square Theatre to-morrow night. James T. Tanner built the play and wrote all the prose part of it; Adrian Ross wrote the songs, while the music was composed by Carl Keifert and Edward Rice.

The body of a man of fifty-five years or more, well dressed, of apparent respectability, and believed to be that of Philip Stein, a rich retired liquor dealer of 1,685 Madison Avenue, was found late yesterday afternoon in a vacant lot in the rear of the Odd Fellows' Home, Avenue B and Ninth Street, Unionport.

Miss Sybil Sanderson is at length Mme. Antonio Emmanuel Eusebio Terry. This eminent cantatrice is a native of Sacramento, in California. Mr. Terry is a wealthy Cuban, and eleven years her senior. The marriage took place quite privately at a side altar at the Church St. Honore d'Eylau and then at the Mayoralty of Passy. The bride wore a brown walking dress trimmed with fur.
County Chairman Quigg, at the Madison Avenue headquarters yesterday, in commenting on the appointment of the anti-Platt Committee of Fifty-three, said:

The Citizen Jurors' Committee, of which Hiland Flowers is Chairman, is working energetically to procure the revision of the laws affecting jurors. Letters have been sent to every commercial association in Greater New York asking their co-operation in the framing of a law that will be more satisfactory to those who are called upon to perform jury duty.

BERLIN, Dec. 18. -- The past week's sittings of the Reichstag were interesting. The Government throughout was on the defensive, and Herren Bebel, Richter, Lieber, and other Oppositionists flaunted the fact in Prince Hohenlohe's face that he had broken his word to the Reichstag in not securing for the workmen the right of coalition and in failing to secure the right of interafflliation for political clubs. The Chancellor's replies were decidedly lame.

The Rev. Dr. Joseph Silverman preached yesterday in Temple Emanu-El on the need of another Maccabeean uprising, choosing for his text, "There were giants in those days." Genesis vi., 4. He said, besides other things, that the Jews had lost to a great extent, the conception of God and religion.

SIOUX FALLS, S.D., Dec. 13. -- Situated at the extreme limit of the eastern boundary of South Dakota are the famous red pipestone quarries, for whose existence scientists seem to be at a loss for an explanation. This is the only quarry of the kind known to exist on the American continent, or for that matter, in the world.

I heard that the Bedouins gave me the name of the walking Englishman, and once or twice were kind enough to say that I was one of themselves. Trifles like these are important when dealing with men who have the minds of children. With them whether you are to live or die depends so often on a trifle that it is as well to have as many trifles as possible in your favor.

"The pretended efforts of the State authorities to preserve the Adirondack forests," said James MacNaughton recently "would be as ludicrous as a farce if they were not so destructive of such a wide extent of beautiful woodland that should be a source of revenue and a great pleasure and health resort for the people."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18. -- President McKinley is observing the Congressional agitation for the repeal or modification of the civil service law with the greatest composure and resolution, according to excellent authority, and also with confidence that Congress will not attempt by legislation to constrain him to "take any backward step" which would not be justified by what he said in his annual message.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 18. -- Major B.G. Thomas, who furnished Miss Richardson the bottle of old whiskey which was to christen the Kentucky, writes the following caustic answer to one of the many letters he has received this week.

Anciently great ingenuity was exercised in the making of ornamental sweetmeats for table decoration. At great banquets a "subtilty," or "sotelty," or "sotillee," as it was variously termed -- an elaborate device in sugar or pastry, or in both -- closed each course, and this device usually bore some reference, humorous or otherwise, to the occasion of the entertainment.

The growing interest in the subject of mycology has attracted more than usual attention to the death which occurred last month of Count Achilles de Vecchi, or Vecchj, in Washington from mushroom poisoning.

LONDON, Dec. 18. -- The indications point to a passage in the Queen's speech at the opening of Parliament referring to the sugar interests of the colonies. It will probably announce that the Government has decided to propose a conference of the powers interested in sugar bounties. The Government, it is understood, is prepared to announce at such a conference that unless the bounty system is abandoned Great Britain will impose countervailing duties.

Fears that cycle racing sport had received a severe setback from the six days' race and the unfortunate incidents arising in connection with it have been freely expressed the past week. That harm might eventually come to the League of American Wheelmen has also been frequently hazarded, and the action of Mr. Mott of the Racing Board is awaited with impatience by cyclers.

Liquid blacking, such as is now used, was invented early in the present century. Previously, various mixtures were used. There are many allusions in last century literature to shoeblacks and blacking. In The World of Jan. 31, 1754, Edward Moore, describing the miseries of an author, says that he would rather have started in life as a shoeblack had he but had the money to buy, or credit to procure, "a stool, brushes, and black-ball."

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 19. -- Alfred Kendrick, leading man in Julia Marlowe's company, which has just closed a week's engagement at Macauley's Theatre, fainted on the stage during the third act of "Ingomar" last night. He was cast for the title role, and as he did not rally quickly it was necessary to omit the fourth act, while in the fifth act Mr. Kendrick was barely able to repeat his lines.
Your editorial this morning on rapid transit decision is surprising.

TRENTON, Dec. 19. -- The manufacturing potters and their employes are still at odds over the matter of a scale of wages to go into effect on Christmas, the time when the manufacturers promised they would restore the 12 1/2 per cent. cut made on the wages of the men at the time of the passage of the Wilson Tariff bill.

Christian Stumpf, a baker, of 313 Madison Street, Hoboken, was arrested yesterday on complaint of his wife. Amelia, who charged him with attempting to commit suicide. Stumpf has been out of work for about three months. He tried to obtain employment, but his efforts were fruitless, and his wife and four children were on the verge of starvation.

" John the Baptist was a sensational preacher," said the Rev. Dr. John P. Peters in his morning sermon in St. Michael's Protestant Episcopal Church, in Amsterdam Avenue, yesterday, "and it is no wonder that his dress, manners, and method of teaching created a decided sensation among the people of his time.

Father Ducey, at St. Leo's Roman Catholic Church, Twenty-eighth Street, near Fifth Avenue, yesterday based his sermon on the asseveration that "the present social conditions exist in contradiction of the teaching of Jesus Christ." He took for his text, "I am the voice of one crying in the wilderness, make straight the ways of the Lord."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- The first report to the State Department from Consul General Goodnow, at Shanghai, contains a warning to American railroad men not to go to China for employment. Says he:

We hope our readers clearly understand the nature of the opinion handed down by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court on Friday -- that it was not a law opinion, but a business opinion that may be freely discussed and, without disrespect to that bench as a court of law, may be assailed, disputed, and picked to pieces precisely as if it had emanated from the Sinking Fund Commissioners or the Bcard of Aldermen.

The first branch of the new Free Public Library in Brooklyn will be opened this evening in the old public school building at Jefferson and Bedford Avenues. The intention is to establish branches of the library all over the city. At the opening this evening the rooms will be decorated with palms, potted plants, and flowers, and there will be music.

SEATTLE, Dec. 19. -- Jack Dalton, the pathfinder of Alaska, whose experience on the trails and ice fields of that country have made him a recognized authority, believes the War Department will make a serious mistake if it attempts to take food to the starving miners of Dawson by reindeer teams, on the theory that the animals can subsist largely off the country.

The readers of THE TIMES have come to look to it for clean and honorable journalism, elegant, but vigorous Anglo-Saxon, and disinterested advocacy of all measures tending to the public welfare. Permit me, then, to ask your aid and co-operation in a matter of vital importance. I refer to the alarming increase of suicide, both here and in Europe, during the last decade.

The popular concert at the Metropolitan Opera House last night drew an audience which crowded the auditorium, and which was quite as enthusiastic as any well-regulated Sunday night audience could possibly be. And that is saying a good deal, for a Sunday night audience has a reserve power of enthusiasm which might move a world if exerted for that purpose.

" How Justice Exalteth a Nation" was the title of the sermon preached by the Rev. Dr. Gustav Gottheil at Temple Emanu-El yesterday. In the course of his sermon Dr. Gottheil made passing reference to the recent municipal election. The greater city, he said, would soon outstrip all municipalities of the Old World.

In Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, last night, the Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott preached the fifth in his series of sermons on "The Life and Teachings of St. Paul." In this sermon he treated of the epistles to the Thessalonians. He declared that the apostles, including Paul, expected, like Miller and the Millerites in this century, the second coming of Christ to take place in their own lifetimes.

There are two sides to the popular reception in Germany of the Kaiser's recent utterances at Kiel and the amazing response of his brother. It is of course depressing that a people in some ways the most advanced in Europe should be politically so backward that they should not be moved to horror and resentment by the tone of the speeches at Kiel.

Despite the fact that the temperature dropped several degrees yesterday morning and there was a good stiff breeze blowing, the officers and men attached to the vessels at the navy yard were called to quarters shortly after 9 A.M. The assembly was sounded for the purpose of having the officers and crews of the vessels attend the reading of the Articles of War.

The Hon. William C. De Witt, in his lecture on the Charter of Greater New York in Historical Hall, May 20, 1897, made the following statement: "By the enforced surrender her system of collecting annual taxes in advance and the substitution of the system of New York, which makes the collection at the end of the year, Brooklyn escapes all taxes in 1898, and thereby receives an ante-nuptial present of $15,000,000."

CHICAGO, Dec. 19. -- With the motto "Varium et mutabile semper femina" the young men of Irving Park have formed an anti-marriage association for the purpose of discouraging matrimony. The member who violates the cardinal principle must pay $25 and give a banquet to the members.

Nineteen hundred of the 3,000 paupers who live in tile almshouse on Blackwell's Island assembled yesterday afternoon in the chapel belonging to their institution to hear Bayne's Sixty-ninth Regiment Band play and the People's Glee Club of New York sing. Forty or fifty well-dressed people from this city were there to see the queer assemblage.
