A daring robbery was committed at 10:10 o'clock last night at the drug store of Goetzhoff Bakst, at the southwest corner of Pike and Madison Streets. The clerk, Harry Davidson, was threatened with a revolver, and $20 in currency was taken from a desk.

The Miscellaneous and Building Trades sections of the Central Labor Union have been pulling against each other of late. At yesterday's meeting of the central body a Chairman -- William H. Farley -- from the latter section was elected, No sooner had the minutes of the previous meeting been read than Delegate Brown of the Cigarmakers, who belongs to the Miscellaneous Section, objected to the latter part and wanted it altered.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Senator Chandler of New Hampshire has written a letter to The Washington Post, in which he says:

The Canadian trade and navigation returns for the last fiscal year have not yet been published, but an abstract of the leading features of these trade returns has been obtained from the Customs Department. From this statement it appears that Canadian trade for the year 1897 has been healthy, and that a gratifying increase in exports to Great Britain has taken place.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 19. -- So many sensational reports have been circulated recently, charging gross neglect of the widow of Bishop Peck by Syracuse University, the beneficiary of his property, that Chancellor James R. Day has prepared an official statement concerning the matter.

There is an old adage as to how honest men come by their due, which, with all possible respect, applies to the members of Congress who are trying to break down the merit system. The bolder ones wish to repeal outright the civil service law of 1883. The less bold desire to weaken it.
INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 19. -- H.H. Hanna returned to-day from Washington, where he attended the meeting of the Monetary Commission.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 19. -- The curtain was not raised on the Tammany slate to-daly, as had been anticipated; only a little corner was lifted when it was given out that the appointment of James P. Silo as Sheriff's auctioneer had been practically decided on. The place, though not of high rank, is one of profit, and as there are a number of applicants, it is possible that even this announcement may be changed later.

County Chairman Quigg, Frederick S. Gibbs, District Attorney W.M.K Olcott, John P. Windolph, and Thomas L. Hamilton called on Senator Platt yesterday afternoon and discussed with him the selection of a Republican member of the Police Board. Mr. Windolph and Mr. Hamilton are candidates for Commissioner, and it was said last night that one of them would become the Republican choice.

The Rev. R. Heber Newton preached at All Souls' Church, Sixty-sixth Street and Madison Avenue, yesterday morning on "The Moral and Religious Aspects of Henry George's Land Doctrine." He first called attention to a circular in the vestibule of the church which gave the names of the firms in the shopping district that furnished supper for their employes during the Christmas rush, and suggested that such action should be encouraged.
Several clergymen of the city yesterday, in their morning sermons, spoke in defense of the Apostles' Creed. Extracts from their remarks are given herewith:

There seems to be no abatement in the fight which is being waged between certain theatrical managers, a number of individual stars, and the publisher of a New York dramatic weekly on one side, and an alleged theatrical combination which its enemies assert has been formed for the purpose of monopolizing the business on the other.
LONDON, Dec 20. -- The correspondent of The Times at Peking says:
The Rev. Dr. Minot J. Savage preached in the Unitarian Church of the Messiah, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, yesterday morning on "The Unitarian Story of Jesus."

There is hardly any phrase more constantly used by politicians than "Her Majesty's Opposition." It is accepted by both sides; and has been employed by both of the great parties when in that "position of greater freedom and less responsibility" which it serves to designate. It is very rarely that any one objects to it as illogical.

Samuel H. Evans, a lawyer, of Rosebank, S.I., was arrested late Saturday night, charged with disorderly conduct. The arrest was made on complaint of an Inspector of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company, who alleges that Evans and five companions boarded a Madison Avenue car at Ninety-fourth Street and Madison Avenue, and persisted in smoking inside the car and in otherwise creating a disturbance.

The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Eaton delivered last evening, in St. Stephen's Shurch, another of his series of lectures on recent novels which are having or have had a great vogue. The title of his discourse was "'A Lady of Quality,'; or, the Power of a Great Love."

The new Church of the Strangers, on West Fifty-seventh Street, is a dark brick edifice, covered in almost every part with ivy. It is closely hemmed in by houses on both sides. The tower is small as compared with the square one of the Mercer Street building. The interior is spacious, the seating capacity being at least twice that of the Mercer Street building.

The Maritime Exchange is advised from Grand Turk that a contract has been entered into between the Direct West India Cable Company, Limited, and the British Government, to lay a cable from Bermuda to Grand Turk, and thence to Jamaica. The cable ship Britannia had arrived at Turk's Island from London on Nov.3 to make initial arrangements.

PORTLAND, Oregon, Dec. 19. -- The Portland Chamber of Commerce yesterday, through Brig. Gen. Merriam, Commander of the Department of the Columbia, tendered to the Government 1,000 tons of provisions for the relief of the Yukon miners.
Following are topics which yesterday received Wall Street attention:
I supplement my recent report of District Governor von Tiedemann's lecture on Prince Bismarck by the following passages:

PENSACOLA, Fla., Dec. 18. -- There was considerable activity on board the cruiser Montgomery yesterday owing to information having reached her commander to the effect that several suspected filibusters were in the harbor. Subsequently the cruiser started fires and made preparations for getting under way, if necessary at a moment's notice.

BUFFALO, Dec. 20. -- Charles Daniels, ex-Justice of the Supreme Court of New York and ex-Representative in Congress, died this evening at his home in this city from the effects of a stroke of paralysis which he suffered earlier in the day.

The anti-Platt Republicans of the Twenty-first Assembly District, at a meeting in Lion Park, Columbus Avenue and One Hundred and Eighth Street, last night broke away from the regular organization, and, by a vote of 84 to 9, decided to cast their fortunes with the new movement. They will enlist under the Committee of Fifty-three and attempt to win the district away from Abraham Gruber, the Platt leader.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- Secretary Alger to-day cabled to William A. Kjellmann, the chief Government reindeer herdsman, who is now in Alten, Norway, to inform the War Department immediately how soon 600 reindeer can be shipped to this country. These are wanted for use as draught animals in getting supplies to the miners in the Klondike region.

The trial was begun yesterday in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn of a suit in which two deaf-mutes are plaintiffs and their father is defendant. The plaintiffs charge their father with keeping them out of their property by fraud. The two deaf-mutes are Charles J. Sanford, 19 years old, suing by his guardian ad litem, and Millie L. Knox, aged twenty-six.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- Representative Brosius of Pennsylvania, Chairman of the House Civil Service Committee, had an extended conference to-day with the President about the operation of the civil service law. The President is availing himself of the opportunity to talk freely with Senators and Representatives concerning the law and the effort that is now being made to secure its modification.

SUN COOK, N. H., Dec. 20. -- Notices have been posted at the China, Pembroke, and Webster cotton mills here announcing reductions of the wages of the operatives about 10 per cent. Jan. 1. The cut-down will affect the Superintendents and overseers and, in fact, all of the employes of the three corporations -- nearly 1,500 operatives.

Sir James Sawyer has been confiding the secret of longevity to a Birmingham audience. Like so many other secrets, it consists in "paying attention to a number of small details." Here is a schedule of them, collected from the reports of Sir James Sawyer's lecture:
LONDON, Dec. 20. -- Parsons Pasha and other officers have arrived at Kassala to arrange to take over the place from the Italians.

J.J. Hearns, Agency Superintendent of the New York Life Insurance Company, issued a statement yesterday denying the report that Joseph Clarke of Louisville was short $50,000 in his accounts with the company. He says Clarke was only a solicitor and was dismissed for misconduct and rebating.

A meeting of canalboat men was held yesterday afternoon at the Mission Rooms, at Coenties Slip and Front Street, to protest against what are called the excessive and unlawful grain elevator and port charges at Buffalo and New York. These charges, it is claimed, enable the Railroad-Standard Oil Trust systematically to discriminate against the commerce of this city and State.

At the meeting of the Park Board yesterday Sergt. Hugh Fitzpatrick was made a Captain. Capt. Collins has had full charge of the Park force for five years, since the death of Capt. Beattie, and the Commissioners made the appointment because they decided that one Captain was net suffcient to look after the 300 men of the department.

The first opportunity the Tammany organization has had to express collectively and officially its exultation over the result of the recent election was afforded by the meeting of the General Committee last evening. The occasion did not turn out to be of the "hurrah" type, however, and the address offered as embodying the sentiments of the society was read amid comparative silence and adopted without a spontaneous shout.

The defense in the trial of Edward J. Ratcliffe, the actor, charged with assaulting his wife, the daughter of Peter De Lacy, yesterday followed up the defendant's testimony by swearing witnesses who testified that Mrs. Ratcliffe bore no marks of violence on her face when they saw her soon after the assault is alleged to have been committed.

-- Reference was made in this column recently to the steady diminution in the number of deaths by accident among those who navigate the great lakes, and credit was given to the life-saving service for the fact that, while the lake marine is increasing rapidly, disaster less and less often overtakes those employed in it.

That is rather a dark saying of The Cologne Gazette that the occupation of Port Arthur by Russia "is merely a continuance of the co-operation of Germany with Russia in Eastern Asia." In fact, as readers of THE TIMES already know, Russia's taking of whatever she can get from China is her payment for having interfered to prevent the Japanese from reaping the fruits of their victory.

LONDON, Dec. 20. -- The officials of the Chinese Embassy here do not conceal the belief that the powers are intending to seize Chinese ports, and they discredit the report that Great Britain has been requested to assume a protectorate over the Yang-Tse Valley and the West River, saying they have no information on the subject, and would know if the rumor was true.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20. -- Interest in the big December wheat deal was increased to-day by the arrival from Washington of Levi Z. Leiter, the millionaire ex-merchant of Chicago, and the substantial admission by him that his millions were at his son's command in his struggle with other interests.

Max Meirovitz and Mitchell Weiss, who formerly were in the clothing business and failed last year, were arrested yesterday morning on the charge of forgery in the third degree. The arrests were made on a warrant obtained by Frederick Victor and Achelis, Libby Co. and Bacon Co. all of this city, who are creditors of the old firm.

The enforcement of a paragraph of the new tariff law which imposes a specific duty on foreign-made watch movements has caused much dissatisfaction among the importers of such movements in this city, and protests have been filed with the general Appraisers with a view of obtaining a legal construction of the new law.

LONDON, Dec. 21. -- According to a dispatch to The Daily Mail from Madrid, the Spanish Government has issued a semi-official note, stating that the official investigation disproves the alleged torturing of Anarchists at Montjuich Fortress, and that there is no ground for a revision of the sentences.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20. -- Weeping because he was unable to find employment and support his mother, Anton Kwislek, fourteen years old, led his mother before Justice Sabath, at the Desplaines Street Station, this morning, and pleaded with his Honor to assist him. Kwislek for several years has been his mother's only support.

One of the most significant announcements, with reference to the struggle between England and France in Central Africa, is that of the dispatch of a native regiment from Bombay to Mombasa. Such a movement of British troops is not altogether new. Twenty years ago, at the time of the Berlin conference, BEACONSFIELD ordered troops from India to reinforce the garrison at Malta.

LAKEWOOD, Dec. 20. -- Another addition to the staff of Sheriff-elect Thomas J. Dunn was made public here to-night, that of Charles J. McKeon to be private secretary to the new Sheriff. Mr. McKeon has held minor official positions under previous Democratic administrations, and his selection is another instance of the "return of the (Tammany) native."
Detectives were at work yesterday trying to solve the mystery of the theft of $2,875 in Mexican silver currency, from a specie consignment on the Ward Line steamship City of Washington.

Georgia has embarked on the doubtful experiment of authorizing State bank notes for general circulation. A bill passed on the eve of the adjournment of the Legislature provides that any State bank may issue notes payable to purchaser or bearer up to one-half of its unimpaired capital, the notes being redeemable on demand in silver bullion at its market value.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20. -- A response has been received to a recent letter from Secretary Gage to the Canadian Commissioner of Customs, requesting information as to the bonding of miners' outfits through Canadian territory en route from Janeau, Alaska, by way of the Chilkoot Pass and the Yukon River to Circle City, Alaska.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20. -- Frank T.W. Palmer, son of Anna M. Benedict, deceased, has filed a bill in the Circuit Court asking that his mother's will be set aside. Mrs. Benedict, formerly Mrs. A.R. Palmer, died in France a little less than a year ago, leaving an estate estimated at $600,000.

A meeting of the Committee on Contracts of the Board of Rapid Transit Commissioners was held yesterday morning at President Orr's office in the Chamber of Commerce. The Commissioners -- A.E. Orr, C.S. Smith and G.L. Rives -- discussed for more than two hours the practicability of fulfilling the fifteen-million-dollar bond stipulation called for in the decision approving the scheme of rapid transit handed down by the Appellate Court on Friday.

New York is peopled with average sensual men, each bent on money or pleasure, each therefore working for the Nemesis which has overtaken them, of a corrupt oligarchic rule of the most tyrannous order. But it will be said that London and Paris also are full of average sensual men, and yet that, while not free from grave scandals, there is nothing in the experience of either city which compares with that of New York.

Charles Stewart Davison, as attorney for August Belmont Co., has sold the dock property comprising about sixty-five lots on the north side of the Harlem River, and bounded by Railroad Avenue on the west, One Hundred and Thirty-fifth Street on the north, and the Mott Haven Canal on the east.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20. -- Detectives Brown and Buggie of the Central Station have been asked through a letter from Fond du Lac, Wis., to search for Miss Hattie Inman, who, according to the epistle, is an heiress to an estate valued at nearly $500,000. A few years ago Miss Inman left her home in the Wisconsin city and since that time her whereabouts have been a mystery.

FALL RIVER, Dec. 20. -- A conference of labor leaders and manufacturers was held this afternoon to consider the wage question. The representatives of the labor unions submitted three propositions, and each of the delegates made some comment thereon. The manufacturers took the propositions under consideration and will give a written answer to-morrow afternoon.

ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 20. -- The Cornell Athletic Council was in session for five hours to-night, during which time an extended discussion of the rowing situation was held. No definite decision was reached, but the following statement was given out by the Secretary:

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 20. -- The trial of Solicitor O'Neill in the police court this afternoon for striking Editor Stein of The Looking Glass was the most highly sensational ever had in an Atlanta court, and if it does not lead to tragic results all who attended it will be surprised. Harvey Johnson, attorney for Solicitor O'Neill, in his speech for the defense denounced Editor Stein in the most scathing terms possible.

If the pension list were, in truth, a roll of honor, its publication would be a tribute of respect and appreciation to pensioners too long withheld, but the fact of its being kept hidden away is a sufficient indication of its character.

PARIS, Dec. 20. -- The debate on the bill increasing the customs duties on pigs, pig products, and lard, was opened in the Chamber of Deputies to-day. M. Charles Gruet, Republican, representing the Second District of Bordeaux, opposed the measure, saying he did not think it would fulfill the expectations of the agriculturists and would cost the consumers 60,000,000f.

KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 20. -- The United States training ship Alliance left this port to-day for Tompkinsville, Staten Island, New York. Target practice was completed on Saturday last and both the men and the apprentices made good records, comparatively, as to finish up this work in eleven days is quite rapid.

BOSTON, Dec. 20. -- The municipal campaign closed to-night with rallies by the supporters of all three of the leading candidates in various parts of the city. Tomorrow the voters will elect a Mayor, seven Aldermen, eight members of the School Committee, a Street Commissioner for three years, and three Councilmen from each Ward.

James E. Hackett, the actor, who has been lying dangerously Ill at his mother's home, 28 East Twenty-sixth Street, for the past eight days, with typhoid fever, was in no better condition the greater part of yesterday, but late last night his doctor reported that the patient had slightly improved.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20. -- Polish Catholic seceders from the Roman Catholic Church, who have organized the independent "Polish Catholic Church of America," with three parishes, located in Chicago, received Bishop Anthony Kozlowski, leader of the revolt, as the spiritual head of the Church in America yesterday.
-- Several peculiarities of human nature are illustrated by a brief notice addressed "To the Public," which appears in The Chattanooga Times. It reads:

FARGO, N.D., Dec. 20. -- The final report of J.A. Hanway, stockholders' agent for the National Bank of North Dakota, which was the financial head of the many institutions run in this State by Banker E. Ashley Mears, whose conduct is under consideration before Judge Amidon of the United States Court was to-day declared by the court to show a shortage of $10,000.

Assistant Prosecutor William M. Klink yesterday applied to Judge Lippincott, at Jersey City, for a rule to show cause wily Elbert Rappleye, managing editor, and Joseph A. Dear, publisher, of a local newspaper, which recently charged Joseph M. Noonan, ex-Assistant Prosecutor, with bribery, should not be adjudged in contempt for refusing to surrender a receipt given for the money paid as the alleged bribe, at cuff button, and a railroad pass belonging to Mr. Noonan.

ALBANY, Dec. 20. -- Gov. Black has re-designated Justice Willard Bartlett of Brooklyn as an Associate Justice of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Judicial Department for a further term of five years from the first of January next, and has designated Justice John Woodward of Jamestown as an Associate Justice in the same department for a similar term.

ALLENTOWN, Penn., Dec. 20. -- The Court of Common Pleas to-day sustained the finding of Referee John Rupp, declaring valid and collectible the mortgage of $200,000 given by the Allentown and Bethlehem Rapid Transit Company to the Old Colony Trust Company of Boston. A contest was made on the charge of fraud.
The following cross-examination of a witness in a court in Western North Carolina is sent us as an actual occurrence:

Unlike most of the Republican press, our neighbor, The Sun, looks the deficit in the face. It does not try to conceal it by juggling with figures, and it wastes no time with the delusive phantoms of hope. The Dingley act does not now yield revenue enough, and it does not promise to yield enough to pay the bills of the Government.

Mrs. James Speyer of 257 Madison Avenue, the Treasurer of the Woman's Auxiliary of the Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association, reports the following contributions to the Woman's Fund of the general collection. The contributions so far received indicate that the fund will be the largest in the history of the auxiliary:

CHICAGO, Dec. 21. -- The Chicago branch of the W.F. Shaw Publishing Company of New York, at 86 Wells Street, was closed this morning by Deputy Sheriff Harry Hall under three attachments aggregating $1,700. Bruno L. Cardeno, the local manager, was the first attachment creditor, with a claim for $400. The two other claimants are Edward A. Stegen for $500 and Lorenz Goetzelman for $800.
The lot of the stewards, cooks, and waiters in the navy is not a happy one; neither is that of the officers who come in contact with them, and, like all other human beings, naval officers must eat.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 21. -- John Hepner, an agent for the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, was robbed by two footpads this evening, as he was on his way home, after making his round of collections. One of the highwaymen struck Hepner across the face with a club and felled him. The other then bound a cloth about his face.

MEMPHIS, Dec. 21. -- The American Cotton Growers' Protective Association formed a permanent organization and elected these officers: President -- Hector D. Lane of Alabama; Secretary -- Richard Cheatham of Memphis.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 21. -- Just before the close of court to-day there was a scene in Supreme Court, Justice Dickey sitting. The case on trial was the suit of Mrs. Sanford Hill against Sarah Griffin for $5,000 for alleged alienation of Mr. Hill's affections. Mr. Couch, of counsel for the plaintiff, practically charged that one of the jurors had been "fixed" by counsel for the defense.

Some spirited argument arose at yesterday's session of the Board of Aldermen between Alderman Goodwin and President Jeroloman when a resolution was introduced to refer to the Finance Committee a request from the Dock Department to be permitted to install an electric lighting and heating plant for the Twenty-fourth Street Pier Garden at a cost of $34,000 without public letting.

SEATTLE, Washington, Dec. 21. -- With the sailing of the steamer Corona to-day, loaded to the gunwales with both freight and passengers, begins the midwinter rush of fortune hunters and Alaska boomers. The ship is bound for Dyea and Skaguay, two mushroom towns on the coast, that stand at the entrance to two overland routes to the Yukon.
The French Government has largely increased the duties on imported pork and hog products, with the avowed object of raising prices in France.

The Russian occupation of Port Arthur is, on the face of it, the exaction by Russia of the "equivalent" which Russia some weeks ago announced that she would require for the German occupation of Kiao-Chau. Russia had already established a hold upon China by saving China from the terms which the Japanese, in the absence of Russian intervention, would have imposed, and she had already received an ample equivalent for her interposition.

NORRISTOWN, Penn., Dec. 21. -- The hearing of James A. Clemmer and Elizabeth K. Dekalb, the two alleged accomplices of Charles O. Kaiser in the murder of his wife, Emma P. Kaiser, on Oct. 28, 1896, took place before Magistrate Lenhardt this morning. Mrs. Kaiser was shot while riding with her husband on a lonely road near here.

TRENTON, Dec. 21. -- The writ of certiorari allowed by Justices Dixon and Collins of the Supreme Court in the Anti-Gambling Amendment case reached the Secretary of State's office to-day. The writ directs the Secretary of State to make a return to the Supreme Court within three days of all the papers in the case.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Dec. 21. - P.W. Leary of Chattanooga, Assistant General Superintendent of the Southern Express Company, four division Superintendents, and a squad of Pinkerton men from Philadelphia are camped here to-night trying to unravel the mystery of a robbery committed in the express office here at some time on Sunday night, when a package containing $10,000 was taken from the safe in the company's office.

Deputy Sheriff Lipsky received an attachment yesterday against the Copper River Mining and Development Company, which has an office in the Arbuckle Building, Brooklyn, for $5,000, in favor of Thomas Webb Taylor, on a claim for damages. The company is a Klondike enterprise, and has been fitting up the brig Agate for a trip to the gold regions.

BOSTON, Dec. 21. -- Josiah Quincy was re-elected Mayor to-day. He defeated Curtis, the Republican candidate, by a plurality of about 4,000. The city, which was Republican at the State election last month, is again Democratic.

LONDON, Dec. 21. -- Charles Helmbold, son of the late Dr. Helmbold of New York City, the well-known patent medicine proprietor, has been locked up and is awaiting trial at Bow Street Police Station, on a charge of threatening to kill United States Consul General William McKinley Osborne.

No city government ever made better promises and pledges than Tammany on the eve of its assumption of power. "An honest, efficient, and popular government worthy of the greatest municipality of the Western World" is as good a government as any citizen could ask for or any Mayor give.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 21. -- There is an important meeting of bridge manufacturers at the Weddell House. The primary purpose is the formation of a combination, and the other object, which is secondary, contemplates the construction of an immense rolling mill for the common use of all the manufacturers of bridges.

Mr. HARBURGER, the former Excise Commissioner, made a speech on Sunday in which he attributed to the Raines law the Tammany victory in the municipal election, or, at least, the sweeping character of that victory. He explained that he had prepared a bill for the entire repeal of the law, and added the expression of his belief that "saloons, concert gardens, theatres, and all places of amusement should be open on Sunday."

Richard Croker's candidate for Governor is Perry Belmont. Ex-Senator David B. Hill favors the candidacy of John B. Stanchfield, the Chemung County leader. Elliot Danforth, Chairman of the Democratic State Committee, is in the field, and among his supporters are said to be many of the country leaders who remained regular during the Bryan and Sewell campaign.

Charles Coghlan had a noteworthy "first night" at the Fifth Avenue Theatre. "The Royal Box," his new adaptation of that eccentric romantic drama by the elder Dumas called "Kean" is free from some of the worst extravagance of the original, and while it is not likely to be taken very seriously, it is all thoroughly entertaining.

NEWPORT, R.I., Dec. 20. -- The masonry work on the fortifications at Dutch Island, which is to guard the west passage of Narragansett Bay and the entrance to Newport Harbor, is now completed save for a few minor details which it will not take twenty-four hours to finish.

As a result of the circumstances which led up to the shooting of Richard Mandelbaum by J. Waldere Kirk in the Hotel Gerard on Nov. 13 last, Mandelbaum has brought an action in the Supreme Court, through his attorneys, Howe Hummel, for divorce against his wife, Winnie, naming Kirk as co-respondent.

HAVANA, Dec. 21. -- At to-day's meeting of the Conservative Party, over 300 delegates, said to represent 80 per cent. of the wealth of the island, being present, several of the speakers insisted that the President, the Marquis of Apezteguia, should explain his conduct and utterances as published in the newspapers of Madrid.

Martin J. Oakley, Jr., a fireman of Engine Company No. 5, and a brother of Alderman John T. Oakley, was killed at a small fire last night. Three other firemen were badly hurt. They were Assistant Foreman Thomas E. Head of 284 Pleasant Avenue, and Firemen James E. Davis of 438 East Fourteenth Street and Peter Donnelly of 406 Second Avenue.

TRENTON, Dec. 21. -- There were filed with the Secretary of State to-day the articles of incorporation of the Farm and Dairy Product Company of Jersey City. The company is to issue capital stock to the amount of $15,000,000. It is authorized to buy and sell milk, butter, and other farm products and manufactures.

ST. PAUL, Dec. 21. -- President C.S. Mellen returned to St. Paul to-day from New York with the settled purpose of remaining at the head of the Northern Pacific. Mr. Mellen, in an interview to-day, said:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- Secretary Alger is confined to his house by a heavy cold, but expects to be out in a day or two.
Vanhorne, Griffen Co., importers of glass of this city, have received the following letter from one of their customers, Alexander A. Knight of Ionia, Mich.:

The trial of Edward J. Ratcliffe, the actor, for assaulting his wife is drawing to a close. All the evidence is in, Mirabeau L. Towns has summed up the case for the defense, and all that remains is the summing up by Assistant District Attorney Lloyd for the prosecution this morning, and Judge Newburger's charge to the jury.

The debut of Miss Eva Barbey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry I. Barbey of 17 West Thirty-eighth Street, which was the occasion of a ball at Delmonico's last night, was probably the most important social event devoted to the younger members of New York society of the season. Mr. and Mrs. Barbey are in mourning and could not be present.

The New England Society of Brooklyn held its eighteenth annual dinner last night in the Pouch Mansion, on Clinton Avenue, that city. The banquet was served in the main ballroom and the attendance of 140 included about an equal number of men and women, seated at eighteen small tables.

Everybody who is in position to know anything of the affairs of the late Joseph Richardson, the builder of the famous "spite house," in Lexington Avenue, maintains the curious reticence that has surrounded the queer old man's life and property for years. Efforts are now in progress, in behalf of the administrator of the estate, to trace the great fortune which Mr. Richardson was supposed to own.

Gov. Frank S. Black arrived in New York from Albany yesterday afternoon, Mrs. Black accompanied him. Gov. Black will leave the foot of East Twenty-sixth Street this morning at 9 o'clock to investigate the institutions for the insane on Hart's, Blackwell's, Randall, and Ward's Islands. George W. Aldridge, Superintendent of Public Works, and Louis F. Payn, Superintendent of Insurance, came from Albany with the Governor.

We advise the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court to withdraw altogether its requirement that the Rapid Transit Commissioners exact a bond of $15,000,000 from the contractor, leaving that matter to the discretion of the Commissioners, as provided in the Rapid Transit act, and that it then enter an order approving without conditions the report of Messrs. WILLIAMS, SMITH, and YOUNG.
For its third entertainment in the Waldorf-Astoria ballroom last evening the Society of Musical Arts presented a varied programme.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 21. -- Mayor-elect Van Wyck to-night announced the appointment of Alfred M. Downes as his private secretary. Mr. Downes is well-known in New York newspaper circles, having been a member of the staff of THE NEW YORK TIMES from 1888 until the opening of the recent municipal campaign.

LONDON, Dec. 22. -- A Germano-Chinese commission has been arranged, according to a dispatch from Shanghai to The Daily Mail, to settle the boundaries of the occupied district at Kiao-Chau, and it is evident, therefore, that the occupation will be permanent. The same dispatch says it is rumored in Shanghai that the British intend to occupy Ta-lien-wan, south of Port Arthur, in order to guard the Gulf of Pe-chi-li.
We do not like to believe that Senator WOLCOTT is angry with the Administration because of its attitude regarding the currency. He certainly has no right to be.

A circular sent out from the Agricultural Experiment Station at Geneva warns the farmers of the State to be on their guard against a class of swindlers who have succeeded in victimizing many a rustic community. These fellows go to a village and dazzle the inhabitants with stories of the profits that can be made out of an up-to-date creamery.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21. -- The Hide and Leather Bank will go into liquidation to-morrow. The stockholders will meet to-morrow afternoon for the last time, and will formally vote to transfer the assets of their institution to the Union National Bank.

The disappearance for a week of Thomas C. Long, the head accountant of the Brooklyn Dime Savings Bank, made it necessary for the bank officials to break open a vault in which Mr. Long had been ordered to place $22,000,000 in securities. Mr. Long, who has been in the bank's employ for more than thirty years, disappeared on Saturday, Dec. 11, and did not return until Sunday last.

At its meeting in January, the Century Road Club of America, it is expected, will undertake the control of road racing and manage it on a plan similar to that by which the League of American Wheelmen exercises jurisdiction over track racing. A majority of the influential members of the Century Road Club are said to favor the step which will be the most momentous undertaking into which the big road club has ever entered.

Arthur R. Parsons has sold for John Coar to J. Carlyle Raymond, for about $84,000, the three new four-story dwellings, 251, 257, and 259 West Ninety-eighth Street, each 18 by 60 by 100. In payment of $60,000 on this purchase, Mr. Raymond gives the five-story brick factory, with two-story stable at the rear, 227 and 229 East Fifty-sixth Street, 50 by 100.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21. -- The action of the French Chamber of Deputies yesterday, in passing a Government bill increasing the duties on hogs, hog products, lard, , is regarded here as indicating the failure of the reciprocity negotiations which have been proceeding between France and this country for some time.

There was no change yesterday in the complexion of rapid transit affairs. The Committee on Contracts of the commission held no formal meeting, but there was a conference of counsel, and it was decided to hurry up the preparation of the application to be made for an entry of the order as contained in the decision of the Appellate Court.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 21. -- A smooth little swindler came to Cleveland to-day and attempted to work the hotels. He succeeded, but he ran into the arms of a hotel officer and was compelled to disgorge what he had stolen. Afterward he was taken to the police station and closely questioned, and then he was released.

At a meeting of the National Civic Club in Brooklyn last evening George Foster Peabody, a member of the Commission of Eleven appointed by the Indianapolis Monetary Convention to prepare a plan of currency reform, delivered an address on the labors of that body.

Judge Lippincott, in Jersey City, yesterday heard argument in the contempt proceedings instituted by Assistant Prosecutor William M. Klink against Elbert Rappleye for refusing to give evidence and to surrender to the Grand Jury certain exhibits connected with the charge of bribery made against ex-Assistant Prosecutor Joseph M. Noonan and Alexander Simpson.
The Chicago Federation of Labor has taken a dangerous step in requesting all trades union men in affiliation with it to resign from the National Guard.
LONDON, Dec. 22. -- The Egyptian troops have arrived at Kassala, and the Egyptian flag has been hoisted over the fort by the side of the Italian.

While the methods and results of the newly incorporated "Milk Trust" are matters for the future to determine, some of the criticism of it already made is not founded on accurate knowledge. For instance, a large city dealer, in a statement which you print this morning, says: "The farmers get 3 cents per quart in the Winter months and 2 1/2 cents in Summer, and in this they find a profit."

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 22. -- William Sauer, who claims to be a son of W.G. Sauer, a Detroit publisher, and a graduate of Trinity College, in Michigan is under arrest here, charged with complicity in a bank robbery at Vermillion, Kan., some time ago.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22. -- The dinner of the New England Society of this city was held in Horticultural Hall to-night, in celebration of Forefathers' Day. An interesting feature of the celebration was the presentation to the society of the three-hundred-year-old poor box from the ancient pilgrims' church at Delftshaven, Holland.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Dec. 22. -- J.E. Perrins, until recently President of the New England Whip Company, started from this city yesterday with a party of fifteen others for a new gold field in the Northwest Territory, said to extend over fifteen miles along a tributary of the Stikeen River, and to be richer than the Klondike country.

That the plan for a consolidation of the chief cracker manufacturing companies of the country is practically an accomplished fact is shown by their announcement of a general and marked advance in the prices of their product. The three largest corporations engaged in the cracker business, the American Biscuit and Manufacturing Company, the New York Biscuit Company, and the United States Biscuit Company, have been negotiating for a combination for some time.

The Rev. Ross Taylor of this city has among his correspondents Dr. Emil Holub, the scientist and traveler. Dr. Holub has spent much of his time of recent years in South Africa, and is a student of the development of the British Empire there. He is in close touch with events in that part of the world, and is an ardent admirer of Cecil Rhodes.

The Democratic Party in Boston appears to have got together. Less than 3,000 votes were cast for RILEY, the candidate of the Bryanite Democrats, while Mayor JOSIAH QUINCY polled nearly 40,000 votes and was elected by 4,000 plurality over CURTIS, the Republican candidate. At the election for Governor in November Boston was carried by the Republicans.
Mr. LOUD of California is confident that he can secure the passage of his postal bill at this session, and that it will do away with the deficit in the revenue of the Post Office.

According to the correspondent of The Evening Post, the Democrats in the House have quietly agreed to refuse all aid to the Republican opponents of the merit system in amending the law, though they will help in its unconditional repeal. The motive for this is said to be the hope that the civil service rules will prevent negro officials in the South from appointing negro subordinates.
In your paper of Sunday you quote from a clergyman who asks in a friendly way why you devote so much time to certain "so-called" unorthodox preachers to the exclusion of others.

CAMDEN, N.J., Dec. 22. -- Since Surrogate S. West of Camden County appeared at his home late at night a few days ago with a story that he had been beaten, robbed, and thrown into the river, rumors have circulated that he is an embezzler. One story has it that he has taken $25,000 of other persons' money.

It is encouraging to learn in an extract from The London Mail, printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 21, that the increase of madness in England may be counteracted by marriage. Statistics, it appears, prove that "the odds are against the single man's retaining his senses." All this is extremely gratifying to my sex.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 22. -- The university musical clubs started on their annual Christmas tour at noon yesterday in their special train, made up as follows: Car No. 100, loaned by S.G. De Coursey, President of the Western New York and Pennsylvania Railroad; the Maryland, loaned by the Garrett family of Baltimore; the Delaware, loaned by the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, and a twelve-section Pullman sleeper and a baggage car.

What is evident in the political situation of Italy is that a majority of sixteen votes in a total vote of nearly 400 is not a working majority. It might be in a government of parties like that of Great Britain. It cannot be in a government of groups, such as those of the Continental countries which have the forms of Constitutional and representative government, and of which Italy is one.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- Secretary Gage has written the following letter to President Gompers of the American Federation of Labor:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- Further details of the killing of the two American sailors attached to the United States fleet in Japan have been received by the Department of State. Montgomery, it appears, was killed in Yokohama Sept. 2 last. He was not intoxicated, but was murdered by boatmen. Epps's case was similar, except that he was killed at Nagasaki during the present month.

The managers of The Journal's New Year's eve celebration of the inauguration of the greater city announced last night that the prospective pageant is assuming great proportions. Two miles of the procession have already been pre-empted and will be taken up by the various societies in fantastic costumes, both mounted and on foot.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- Capt. Brainard of the Subsistence Department of the Army arrived in Washington this morning, and, although Secretary Alger is confined to his home by a severe cold, he sent for the officer and had a conference with him respecting the execution of his plans for the relief of the miners in the Yukon country.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Dec. 22. -- A new edifice has just been taken possession of by the Brookhaven Methodist Episcopal Church, and in order that the church may be clean at all times the Trustees have issued the following:

BOSTON, Dec. 22. -- A discussion of the Hawaiian question between ex-Senator George S. Boutwell and Rear Admiral George E. Belknap took place to-night before the Boston Boot and Shoe Club at Young's Hotel. Ex-Gov. Boutwell was the first speaker. He opposed annexation, and in his remarks said:

About half a dozen of the stained-glass windows in Grace Chantry, the little chapel adjoining Grace Protestant Episcopal Church, on the south side, at Broadway and Tenth Street, were broken by an explosion yesterday morning, arising from the mistake of a photographer's assistant. He used an explosive powder as an ingredient of the magnesia powder which furnishes the illumination for flash-light pictures, and the result was a general surprise.

KEY WEST, Dec. 22. -- Schooners leaving port last night that were unaccustomed to the summary methods adopted by Uncle Sam in intercepting filibusters were treated to a surprise. The battleship Maine's launch fired a shot as a command for them to halt. Not understanding the signal they proceeded on their course, but another shot brought them to.

On board the steamer Hovelins, which arrived here from Brazilian ports yesterday, were Chief Officer Hooper, Second Mate Bently, and three seamen of the American bark Marion S. Harris, which went ashore Nov. 10 on a coral reef near Capt St. Roque and became a total loss. The vessel struck the reef about six miles off shore.

The Navy Department has been at a loss for several years to make necessary provisions to supply crews for the vessels now on the active list so that they could be made ready for service, according to the naval regulations, within six hours.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 22. -- A party of hunters, consisting of A.H. Dolphin, Sam H. Sevier, John W. Bright, and W.H. Hughes, and claiming Chicago as their home, fitted out here for a big hunt up in the Northwestern portion of this State a couple of weeks ago. They said they were going after big game, turkey, deer, and bear, and passed through Marshall, Learcy County, early last week bound for the Boston Mountains.

BOSTON, Nov. 22. -- Dr. Heber Bishop, ex-President of the Megantic Fish and Game Club, and a prominent New England sportsman, accompanied by his friends, Mr. Seth Perkins and Mr. Charles C. Williams, arrived home to-day with an enormous bull moose, which fell to the doctor's rifle while on a hunting trip for moose and caribou in the Crooked Deadwater region of New Brunswick.

Latest among marvelous discoveries is "La Femme Rontgen," a woman who is described as being able to read with ease through opaque bodies. Such, at least, is the story gravely related to-day. We are told that Dr. Ferroul of Narbonne has found and has introduced this phenomenal lady to his colleague, Dr. Grasset, professor at the Medical Faculty at Montpelier.
" I have nothing to explain, and still less to alter, as to my remarks of last night," said George W. Smalley, yesterday.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 22. -- The schooner Frank A. Rackliff, commanded by Capt. George F. Kane, left East Boston to-day for Seattle, Washington. The Rackliff carries a party of twenty, who will operate in the Yukon region. Philip Stingle of the Boston Athletic Association, the well-known jumper, is in the party.

LANSING, Mich. Dec. 22. -- Hundreds of tax titles in Michigan have been rendered worthless by a decision of the Supreme Court in the case of the Connecticut Mutual Fire Insurance Company against Wood, the effect of the decision being that when lands are bid off to the State for taxes of one year, and are still held by the State, such lands cannot again be sold for the delinquent taxes of succeeding years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- A number of New York manufacturers of fur garments and importers of furs called at the Treasury Department to-day and had a conference with Assistant Secretary Howell in regard to the regulations which will be necessary to carry out the provisions of the bill recently passed by Congress prohibiting the importation of what are known as pelagic sealskins.

Mayor-elect Van Wyck, his newly appointed private secretary, A.M. Downes, and District Attorney-elect Asa Bird Gardiner came from Lakewood yesterday. The Mayor-elect spent last night with his brother. Justice Van Wyck, in Brooklyn. He will not return to Lakewood before Monday. Mr. Van Wyck came to town to do some Christmas shopping, and not with reference to any political matter. He would not discuss politics.

As the sifting and probing into the affairs of the late Joseph Richardson, builder of the "spite house," goes on, and men who knew the dead man most intimately talk of what they know, the conviction that an enormous fortune gathered by the shrewdness, capacity, and energy of youth and maturity melted under the gaming passion of old age, becomes stronger.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 22. -- Seventy-one cadets of the third class are restricted to quarters for insubordination. It is one of those incidents when the juvenile spirit gets the better of the military judgment of a cadet until the Academy authorities have given a few turns to the screw of discipline.

PASSAIC, N.J., Dec. 22. -- A freight train crashed into a big stage loaded with women and men at the Delawanna crossing of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad at 7 o'clock this evening. Thirty-five persons were on the stage. They had no warning of their danger, the curtains being drawn on account of the stormy weather, and were singing gayly when the catastrophe occurred.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- It is understood that the authorities here have been unofficially sounded as to the attitude of the United States toward the complications in the far East, with a view to learning whether American interests in China were regarded as sufficient to warrant any active step by this Government.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- Representations have been made to the Navy Department in behalf of certain European inventors, which, if true, would invalidate all patents now covering the Harvey process of armor manufacture.

Among the many excellent distinguishing features of THE NEW YORK TIMES is that of not arrogating to itself the credit of being the author of every public improvement or reform or the preventor of the many abuses that are perpetually cropping up within its limits. This was exclusively the privilege of yellow journalism.

TOLEDO, Dec. 22 -- On the morning of Dee. 11, a well-dressed young man walked into the Hotel Henry and registered as Leslie M. Folger. He gave Baltimore as his home. He was assigned to a room and soon after a well-filled trunk and valise and other baggage came up from the station. After breakfast the morning of the 12th, he disappeared, and nothing further has been seen or heard of him.

The officers and employes of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad Company will, on Saturday, see the realization of an idea that had its origin among them a year ago, when they will present to Samuel Sloan, on the occasion of his eightieth birthday, a magnificent solid gold, 18 carat tea service.

ALBANY, Dec. 22. -- The State Department of Public Instruction has about completed the compilation of the biennial school census recently taken, and it shows the school population in cities and villages of the State having a population of more than 10,000 inhabitants to be approximately 925,000.

DOVER, N.J., Dec. 22. -- Mrs. Thomas O. Bullock, whose husband obtained considerable notoriety a short time ago because of his fight with the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad over what he claimed was his right to carry packages on the trains of the company, was arraigned before Justice C.B. Gage here to-day charged with assault and battery.

LONDON, Dec. 22. -- Vladimar Bourtzeff, editor of the Naro do Voletz, (The Will of the People,) the Russian who was arrested at the British Museum and remanded at BOW Street Police Court on Dec. 16, charged with endeavoring to persuade several persons on various occasions to assassinate the Czar, was brought up on remand to-day, in company with a man named Weirzbecki, printer of the paper mentioned, who had since been arrested.

WILTON, Conn., Dec. 22. -- David S.R. Lambert, who was shot by masked burglars at his home here last Friday night, died this morning. He did not regain consciousness from the time he was shot until his death.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- The reciprocity negotiations between the United States and Germany are practically suspended. They never got beyond the initial stage. There appears to have been a willingness on the part of both governments to look into the subject, but the inquiry did not develop any prospect of material concessions on either side.

Percival Chubb delivered a lecture in the Brooklyn Institute course, at the Art Museum Building, on Montague Street, yesterday afternoon. His subject was: "How Literature Can Be Made to Influence the Moral Character of Children."

As a regular attendant at the course of lectures delivered on art at the Metropolitan Museum, I have been struck with one feature of the management which seems to me particularly objectionable. I refer to the custom of allowing persons to enter the hall after the lecturer has begun his discourse; frequently the interruptions continue to the very end.

Business at the office of the Department of Buildings during the month has been at almost a standstill as compared with the business of other months, and the holding back of plans by architects is taken as evidence that better and more liberal treatment is expected under the new administration, which will act under the Greater New York Charter.

For the ninety-second time in its history the New England Society of New York celebrated last evening the landing of the Pilgrims on Plymouth Rock. An elaborate dinner was given at the new Delmonico's, Forty-fourth Street and Fifth Avenue. Four hundred covers were laid, and not a single seat at either the speaker's table or the eight long tables placed longitudinally across the great ballroom was unoccupied.
CHICAGO, Dec. 22. -- The Railway Age makes the following statement of new railway lines built in the year 1897:

FISHKILL LANDING, N.Y. Dec. 22. -- There is considerable excitement around the hamlet of Farmer's Mills, just across the line in Putnam County, because some men who were at work tearing down buildings have dug up a considerable sum of money.

A large and representative gathering of Jews and Christians assembled at the Tuxedo, Fifty-ninth Street and Madison Avenue, Tuesday night, on the occasion of the dinner given by the Judaeans in honor of the Rev. Dr. Thomas Kelly Cheyne, Canon of Rochester, England, and Oriel Professor of Interpretation of the Holy Scriptures at Oxford University.

A provisional site for the Soldiers and Sailors' Monument was decided on yesterday at a meeting of the Monument Commission, the former plan of erecting the monument at the plaza, Fifty-ninth Street and Fifth Avenue, being abandoned. The site which found favor with the commission and its advisers is about 1,000 feet north of the Grant Tomb, on Riverside Drive, and the erection of the monument there would necessitate the removal of the Claremont Hotel.

Edward J. Epstein, a man of respectable connections and good training, deliberately killed himself with drugs in Mills Hotel No. 1, Bleecker Street, yesterday morning. He died at St. Vincent's Hospital, West Eleventh Street, an hour after he had been taken from his room. Nothing could be learned of him last night, except what he chose to tell in the abbreviated obituary of himself that he left.

Gov. Frank S. Black inspected yesterday the Manhattan State Hospital on Hart's Island, as well as the Reformatory on Randall's Island, and some of the buildings on Ward's Island. For the last two he had nothing but praise and commendation. The condition of the hospitals on Hart's Island, he declared, was deplorable, the wards overcrowded, the roofs leaky, the air in the rooms heavy, and all the apartments sadly in need of ventilation.

VALLEY VIEW, Ky., Dec. 22. -- There were two fights over Dora Clay last night. Immediately after Will Richardson had emptied his revolver at his brother Clell, and had been chased away by Clell with a knife, John Richardson and Will Bryant, Clell's brother-in-law, met on a bridge spanning a creek and had a hand-to-hand encounter, with scantlings for weapons.
CHICAGO, Dec. 22. -- The Chronicle's Washington correspondent sends the following:

William H. Kent, a lawyer with offices in the Continental Insurance Company's building, was arrested yesterday by Policeman Maloney of Justice Brenner's court, Brooklyn, on a warrant issued by the Justice. He is a well-known member of Plymouth Church, where he taught Sunday school for years, and performed valuable service some months ago in reorganizing the penny-savings system in the Bethel Mission of the church.

Suspicion of murder was aroused yesterday in regard to the death of Arthur Maurice, who died suddenly at the Hotel Winthrop, Seventh Avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, some time in the early morning. Mr. Maurice, with his wife, son, and daughter has lived in the Winthrop for more than ten years.

Mrs. Freda Schlintz, a crippled woman, fifty-three years old, was suffocated early yesterday morning while attempting to escape from the fifth floor of the apartment house at 235 East Ninety-fifth Street, where a fire was in progress. A number of other tenants narrowly escaped with their lives, being rescued by police and firemen.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 22. -- Mr. Croker will return here on Monday. He will give a smoker and vaudeville entertainment on Tuesday. Anna Held will take part. Among the arrivals here to-day were President-elect Guggenheimer of the Council, Charles H. Knox, Ferdinand Levy, Andrew Freedman, Patrick Keenan, Martin F. Donohue, and William S. Andrews.

HAVANA, Dec. 22. -- Last Sunday the military commander at Jaguey sent a number of concentrados, under the protection of local guerrillas, to bring vegetables into the town. They were surprised by the insurgents, who macheted sixty-three.

Probably no letter in the whole world in all time has been traveling for so long as that of the class of '44 of Yale College. Some fifty years ago some of the members undertook to keep a letter circulating, each man receiving it adding whatever he considered would interest the others, and when the epistle got around to him again removing his previous effort and replacing it with a new one.

At the New England dinner in Brooklyn there was a passage between Senator HAWLEY and Mr. GEORGE W. SMALLEY which possesses an interest and significance not confined to the company to which the words were spoken. Responding to the toast "New England and Old England," Mr. SMALLEY praised the virtues of both in warm terms, from which few will dissent.

The jury in the case of Edward J. Ratcliffe, the actor, who has been on trial on the charge of assault in the second degree for beating his wife, the daughter of Peter De Lacy, the wealthy bookmaker, came in at 1 o'clock this morning with a verdict of guilty of assault in the third degree and a recommendation to mercy.

NEWPORT, R.I., Dec. 22. -- On Friday, the 31st inst., the entire naval training system will await with much interest the result of the examination of the two smartest naval apprentices, who have been in the service for one year, for on that day the contest for the ownership of the Bailey Medal will take place at the naval training station here, with four naval officers as the Examining Board.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22. -- It was a holiday market in wheat to-day, the price of May keeping within less than a cent range. Bears had a trifle tho better of it, the close showing 1/4 3/8c decline. December was weaker and declined l 5/8c on the selling of about 250,000 bushels.

Eight Presbyterian churches of New York are having the unusual experience of more or less difficulty in finding pews for all who wish to worship in them. At the Brick Church, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street, the Rev. Dr. Henry Van Dyke, pastor, the demand for seats is so great that it has become necessary to increase the seating capacity.

A parliamentary paper has been circulated among the members of the Reichstag with reference to an item of 300,000 marks (15,000) which will appear in the estimates in support of a German deep-sea expedition. This document passes in review the successful efforts made by other maritime nations in this direction, and notably by Great Britain, with the remarkable Challenger expedition, the results of which fill forty-two stout volumes.

In the City of New York 44,000 men, between the ages of twenty-one and seventy years, are subject to jury duty, for which each may receive $2 a day or not a cent. They may be summoned to courtrooms for terms of fifteen or thirty days, of which the greater part is likely to be wasted, as they will lose the time from business, and in the majority of cases get no compensation for it.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 23. -- Julia Marlowe, the actress, will leave for New York tomorrow. Her physician, Dr. Mitchell, reports that she is greatly improved to-night and able to travel. Her week's engagement here has, however, been canceled.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 23. -- The stockholders of the Omaha, Kansas City and Eastern Railway to-day voted to increase the capital stock of the road from $1,500,000 to $2,000,000. The action in issuing first mortgage bonds at the rate of $20,000 a mile and second mortgage bonds at the rate of $15,000 a mile was ratified.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Assistant Secretary of the Treasury Vanderlip, in speaking to-day of the heavy payments to be made by the Government on Jan. 1, said:

Richard O. Davis, one of the most noted forgers in this country, who is alleged to be at the head of a gang that has been robbing mail boxes and altering and raising checks throughout the West, was arrested here yesterday by Inspector Jacobs of the Post Office Department ad Detective Buetler of Pinkerton's Agency, on an indictment found against him in Toledo, Ohio for robbing the mails.
In a basement at 431 West Fifty-second Street, Catherine Massett, sixty years old, died last night, and the physician who examined her body said that death was due to exposure.

Following are some of the special musical programmes arranged for the services at the principal Protestant Episcopal and Roman Catholic churches to-morrow. All the churches of these denominations in Greater New York will be opened to-morrow morning, and in most cases the musical programmes here given will be repeated at the morning service on Sunday.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23. -- John J. Burns, who was yesterday sent to prison in default of $3,000 bail for trial, on a charge of perjury, committed suicide by hanging in his cell some time during last night.

Mr. OLNEY was right in saying on Tuesday evening that a general arbitration agreement with Great Britain would be, in the language of Wall Street, an "immense saving in the operating expenses" of running the relations of this Republic with the rest of the world. Almost at the same moment, Mr. CHAUNCEY M, DEPEW, in Washington, was emphatically enforcing a like view. He said:
TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 23. -- A charter for the Kansas City, Lawrence and Topeka Electrical Railway and Power Company was filed here to-day, the capital being placed at $3,000,000.

The plea of the Senator from Colorado for a broad and catholic American feeling, which shall make Eastern men and Western men regard each other with mutual respect as citizens of a common country and not of the section they happen to abide in, is timely. No man can do more to spread that feeling than Senator WOLCOTT.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23. -- Fire was discovered shortly after 4 o'clock this afternoon in the basement of the five-story building at 104 Madison Street, the first floor and basement of which were occupied by the Tosetti Cafe and Restaurant Company, and the second floor by the billiard parlors of Frank Mussey.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 23. -- Felix T. Brown, a drummer for Bettman, Bloom Co. of Cincinnati, wholesale clothiers, was shot and mortally wounded in Rosenthal's jewelry store on Twentieth Street at 5 o'clock this evening. Twenty women were in the establishment buying Christmas presents when Brown entered the store, closely followed by Thomas T. Ashford, who is an Alderman and President of the Birmingham Paint and Glass Company.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 23. -- One more as sertion of State rights will find its way into the halls of Congress. It is Gov. Atkinson's veto of the National quarantine resolution introduced into the Georgia Legislature by Mr. Knowles of Fulton and strongly indorsed by the Atlanta Chamber of Commerce.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Dec. 23. -- Amid scenes of riotous disorder and intense excitement, the House to-day passed the Republican Senatorial Apportionment bill by a vote of 79 yeas to 54 nays. There were but two votes to spare. It was a hairbreadth escape from defeat for the Republican managers.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 23. -- A fire which began in the business centre of the city at 5 o'clock this afternoon destroyed property worth nearly a million dollars. The Power Block on Frankfort Street, owned by J.B. Perkins, a brick structure six stories high, was consumed above the second story, and the rear of the brick Wilshire Block, six stories high, also owned by Mr. Perkins, and fronting on Superior Street, was burned.

The New York and Knickerbocker Athletic Clubs will hold cross-country runs to-morrow. The Knickerbocker athletes will hold their run at William's Bridge, while the " Mercury foot" runners will travel over a ten-mile course in Westchester. A large list of entries has been received for both runs.

In your editorial this morning, under the heading, "More Beer, Less Spirits," you give the per capita beer consumption for every fifth year from 1870. It may not be uninteresting to give the per capita of each of the last five years:

ALBANY, Dec. 23. -- Albert S. Warner, the last of the kidnappers of Johnny Conway to have justice meted out to him, will be lodged in Clinton Prison within twenty-four hours with a term of fifteen years to serve. This sentence was passed by Judge Alden Chester, in the Supreme Court this afternoon, after he had listened to a plea for mercy from the criminal himself.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- The findings of the British-American Commission Chosen to assess the damages for seizures of British ships in Bering Sea have been received by the State Department and the British Embassy. The strictest reticence is maintained, however, on the general character of the findings, thought it is admitted that the total of the award against the United States is $464,000, which includes principal and interest.

-- News comes from Lafayette College that the fire which on Saturday almost destroyed Pardee Hall spared a considerable portion of the famous Porter herbarium. This has long been known as containing the best collection of the plants of Pennsylvania that ever was made, and the thought that it had been burned had caused real sorrow in botanical circles. It seems that

In the matter of the Loud bill, to which you give so commending a word this morning, if it is indispensable, or even desirable, that the Post Office should be self-supporting, and if the present rates of postage are not sufficient to meet the expenses, the dictate of common sense is, raise the rates. The deficit arises from second-class matter, which is carried for 1 cent a pound.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23. -- The Chestnut Street National Bank did not open its doors for business this morning. The reason therefor was stated in a notice posted on the door, which read as follows:
ELMIRA, N.Y., Dec. 23. -- The jury in the trial of George A.C. Orme to-day rendered a verdict of not guilty of murder. The defense contended that X rays killed the victim.
ALBANY, Dec. 23. -- The Railroad Commissioners have granted the application of the Prince's Bay Railroad Company to construct an electric railroad on Staten Island.

Father Power was the principal witness in the Johnson will contest, which was continued yesterday, in Surrogate Arnold's court. He said that he had known Mrs. Johnson for ten years, and emphatically denied having applied to her for a loan of $10,000. He said, however, that Mrs. Johnson had loaned his church $3,000, and that the debt on his church and school had decreased from $174,000 to between $150,000 and $160,000 since 1894.

The examination in the case of Emanuel J. and Max J. Laser, the diamond dealers of 24 Maiden Lane, and Mrs. Emanuel J. Laser, wife of one of the prisoners, all accused of smuggling diamonds worth $90,000 into this country, was begun yesterday afternoon before United States Commissioner Shields.

We think it is a mistake for Democrats to oppose the bankruptcy bill of the committee on the ground that it provides for involuntary bankruptcy. It is not consistent with that ideal of equality among all classes which is the basis of Democratic doctrine, and it is against the interest of the people of the sections most largely represented by Democrats.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Some surprise was expressed at the report which reached here this morning, that Senators Wolcott, Shoup, Warren, Clark, Carter, and Wilson were about to abandon the Republican Party in consequence of the failure of the Administration to manifest a more friendly spirit toward bimetallism.

BOSTON, Dec. 23. -- Mrs. Viola Swarnsbourne was found to-day at her home in Warren Street, but refused to be seen. Her present husband, to whom she was married about a year ago, is a member of the Boston Symphony Orchestra. She has placed the alleged kidnapping case in the hands of her lawyer, and says she has no fear of arrest. She will not give the boy up unless compelled to.

President David M. Morrison of the Washington Trust Company talked yesterday to a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES on the general business and financial outlook. Mr. Morrison believes that existing conditions are of an encouraging character and that increased stock values continued business improvement may be looked for. He said:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Senator Platt called upon the President this morning, but, while it has been learned that the subject of his conversation with the President was Federal offices in New York, and presumably the offices of the District Attorney, United States Marshal, and Judge for the Eastern District, Mr. Platt's reticence has battled all inquiries.

John P. Kirwan has sold for Ruth A. Wallace, to P.J. Sweeney, the entire block, consisting of about sixty-four lots, bounded by Fifty-third and Fifty-fourth Streets, Eleventh and Twelfth Avenues, about 800 by 200.10. Mrs. Wallace purchased the greater part of this block only a few days ago from the Washington Life Insurance Company.

Nothing more significant or instructive has come to light, in the course of the complications following the German seizure of Kiao-Chau Bay, than the article which the cable brings us from the Novosti of St. Petersburg. It must always be borne in mind that every publication in Russia is official, in the sense that it would not be published unless it were officially approved.
TOULON, Dec. 23. -- The French cruiser Pascal sailed for China to-day.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23. -- It is believed by the bear element of the Board of Trade that Joseph Leiter will be unable to dispose of the tremendous flow of wheat which Armour is directing toward him. Within four days the receipts of wheat in this city have amounted to 1,026,000 bushels, and during the same period not more than 28,000 bushels of wheat have been shipped out of the city.

If some of the Customs Inspectors who examined the baggage of passengers arriving Wednesday on the big North German Lloyd Line steamship Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse could have their way, the Treasury Department would adopt a new system for the landing of passengers.

The full text of the decree of the Spanish Government which purports to establish self-government in the Islands of Cuba and Puerto Rico has been received here. Commander SHAW of the New York Department of the Grand Army of the Republic announces that legislation is to be asked for this Winter to provide facilities for "patriotic exercises" in the schools of the State. We give his own explanation of the purpose of the measure:

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23. -- Commenting on the strained relations between Japan and Russia over Korea, the Chinese papers report that the Japanese Army is full of Russian spies disguised as Japanese, and that the Russian Army is being tampered with by Japanese emissaries, who are doing all they can to stir up disaffection.
BUFFALO, Dec. 23. -- Although the snowfall in this city was light to-day, engineers and firemen running on roads south and southeast of Buffalo report much trouble with heavy drifts.

LAKEWOOD, Dec. 23. -- Only three Tammany leaders were left here to-day when the last train for the city had borne away its contingent of braves, but as they were the most conspicuous of them all -- Messrs. Croker, Carroll, and Grady -- the hotel did not lose its Tammany atmosphere in consequence.

The teams representing the New York Athletic and St. Nicholas Skating Clubs of the Amateur League gave a rare exhibition of hockey before 3,000 enthusiastic spectators at the St. Nicholas Ice Rink last night, and when time was called, after fifty minutes of actual play, each team had scored two goals.

SEATTLE, Dec. 23. -- The Russian Bear has laid a heavy arm on the fighting material and the army of little Korea. Not content with practically seizing the finance and customs systems of the country, M. Despeyer, the new representative of the "Land of Everlasting Turmoil," has caused the appointment of Russian subjects to the command of the army, and Russians are now in charge of the arsenal.

Gen. PANDO, it seems, has reported to his chief, Marshal BLANCO, that all the Cuban leaders in the field have declined even to consider the project of autonomy. In one case, as we know, a Cuban leader has gone so far as to have summarily executed the Spanish envoy who came to his camp, in defiance of an express warning, to have a talk about it with one of his subordinates.
