CANTON, O., Dec. 24. -- President McKinley is named with his brother, Abner, as executors of the last will of Nancy Allison McKinley, their mother. The will was filed in the Probate Court to-day. It bears the date of May 20, 1895, and has as witnesses W.K. Miller, deceased, and Charles R. Miller, his son.

England was fortunate about the middle of the century in having not only many painters of great note but a growing number of art patrons, among whom there are three who stand out conspicuously from the rest by reason of their collections, accumulated with great taste and judgment, becoming eventually the property of the nation.

In two bulky volumes, of 600 pages each, Mr. Wilfrid Ward presents the life and times of Wiseman. It would have been impossible to present the life of this noted ecclesiastic without explaining in all details the period in which he lived, and to the latter the author devotes so great a space that sometimes the Cardinal himself is in a measure lost.

An issue involving the construction of Section 32 of the new tariff act was raised before the Board of Classification of the United States General Appraisers, by a protest filed by the firm of Hoeninghaus Curtiss, importers, of this city. Under the section in question the Collector assessed certain so-called penal duties on an importation of goods composed of silk and cotton.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24. -- Fire to-night destroyed the Coliseum Building, at Sixty-third Street and Stony Island Avenue, in which the Democratic National Convention was held last year. The fire was one of the quickest ever seen in Chicago. From the time the fire originated by the crossing of two electric light wires, until the Coliseum was a pile of twisted iron and hot bricks, was not over twenty minutes.

In the "Odyssey," the important episode of the swineherd Eumaeus throws a flood of light on the economy of a large estate. Eumaeus was the son of an island King, or petty chief, but was kidnapped by his nurse, a Phoenician slave-woman, who escaped with him on board a Phoenician ship. She died on the voyage, and the ship having been carried by the wind to Ithaca, the sailors sold the boy to Laertes.

An explosion, or series of explosions, in the works of the United States Liquefied Acetylene Distributing Company in Jersey City yesterday morning killed the Superintendent and the chief engineer, demolished the works, and wrecked buildings and smashed windows for several hundred feet around.

The report in Albany dispatches that Gov. BLACK intends to ask for legislative authority to appoint a commission to examine the tax laws and report upon the advisability of revising them will excite at once interest and apprehension. The tax laws stand in need of revision. They are acknowledged to be in large measure impracticable and inequitable.

LOUISVILLE, Dec. 24. -- Announcement is made to-day that the Illinois Central Railroad Company is preparing to acquire what is known as the Cecilian Branch of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad. The branch is 40 miles long, extending from Louisville to Cecilia, and over it the Illinois Central reaches Louisville, operating it under a ninety-nine year lease.

The letter "q" is a superfluous alphabetical appendenda -- a nondescript of the worst sort, and of no more real value for helping express our thoughts in writing than one of the Chinese word signs would be. It never ends an English word, and cannot begin one without the aid of the letter "u," being invariably followed by the mentioned letter in all word belonging to our language.

As a subscriber for many years, it pleases me to call your attention to the existence many years ago of the New York Gallery for Fine Arts at No. 100 Broadway. It was opened in 1827, and became the centre of the dilettanti and connoisseurs in art at that early day.

Some of the sub-editors begin work as early as 5 o'clock, in order that there may be "copy" ready for the compositors when they start an hour later. But the busiest hours in the room are between 9 and 1 o'clock. Messengers come in frequently with bundles of the familiar buff telegraph envelopes containing dispatches from the news agencies or from the correspondents of the paper at all points of the compass.

MARION, Ind., Dec. 24. -- Armour Co., the Chicago and Kansas City packers, established a distributing station here about two years ago The Trades Council of this city placed a boycott on their meat, and local dealers were compelled to quit handling it. Armour petitioned the Trades Council to raise the boycott, but they refused.
Taste is the secret of the appropriate tact, of the opportune.

BREAKWATER, Del., Dec. 24. -- The steanboat James ...Carney, from iIoblie for New' ''ork, 'went ashore on the beach oplsite the larine Hospital last night. She is .lying easy s. nd probably wtll float. with high tide if the wind moderates.

According to the report prepared by the City Superintendent of School Census J.J. Symes for submission to the State Superintendent of Public Instruction, there are 391,482 children in this city of school age -- between four and eighteen years. The biennial census taken two years ago by the police was unsatisfactory to the State Superintendent and this year it was decided that the State and not the city should supervise the work.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 24. -- Four children named Maedbalski were suffocated by smoke this morning in an attic room occupied by the family at 17 Christian Street. Their parents were both away when the house caught fire from an overheated stove, and before the little ones could be rescued they were rendered unconscious by smoke, and all were dead when carried out of the house.

The growth of the annual collections on Hospital Saturday and Sunday in behalf of the free work of the associated hospitals of the city is a proof alike of the spirit of benevolence of our people and the systematic and persevering work of the body under whose auspices the collections are made.

The worst King of a country is not in every case the most wicked or most vicious. Louis XV. was expert in vice, but he was rarely, if ever, guilty of what may be called the heroic types of wickedness -- those that cause the nations to stand aghast or to concentrate their intensest hatred upon the depraved one.

Civil Justice Van Wart of the Second District Civil Court, Brooklyn, yesterday had his attention called to the destitute condition of the family of the late John Bodine, for a half century the Captain of an Albany steamboat. The widow, who is eighty-five years old, has a third flat at 2,100 Atlantic Avenue, where she lives with her sixty-five year old daughter and a son who is fifty years old.

Walter White for many years occupied in England the important position of Assistant Secretary of the Royal Society. Born in 1811, the son of a provincial cabinetmaker, White's opportunities were not many. But he seems to have been fired at an early age with the determination to educate himself.

FORT SMITH, Ark., Dec. 24. -- Judge John H. Rogers of the Federal Court handed down a decision to-day in a case involving the construction of the Civil Service law. It was that of W.J. Fleming against S.F. Stahl. Fleming was an office deputy under ex-Marshall J.G. Crump. Stahl was appointed by President McKinley to succeed Crump.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 24. -- Whatever may be the personal predilections of the Hawaiian Cabinet, the members regard themselves as the trustees their political party has placed in office, purely and simply to obtain annexation. It is the impression that the Legislature will meet as usual in February.

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 24. -- Mr. and Mrs. Wesley McBride of Stanton were killed and their daughter Carrie, aged six years, was fatally injured this morning at the Stanton crossing of the Philadelphia, Wilmington, and Baltimore Railroad, five miles below this city. They were driving to the Wilmington market and started to cross the railroad tracks just as the Washington and New York express, due here at 2:55 A.M., reached the crossing.

The last number of The London Spectator (Dec. 11) contains an article which brings into relief the beauty of our century-end civilization. It is entitled "Deeds That Have won the Empire," and is an extravagant eulogy of a book of the same name. Here is one of the tit-bits which The Spectator picks out for special commendation from the volume:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- This country's attitude toward what appears to be an effort on the part of the powers of Europe to dismember China was the principal topic of discussion at to-day's meeting of the Cabinet. All the Cabinet members were present, except Secretary Alger, who is ill at his home.

The opposing forces were within fifty feet of each other, and Lord Charles Hay, advancing in front of his regiment, (the English Guards,) pulled off his hat to the French officers, who politely returned the salute.

Followers of cycle racing believe Jimmy Michael, the small-sized lad from Wales, who has hitherto been well-nigh invincible, will contest one of the hardest speed duels of his life to-night at Madison Square Garden where he is scheduled to ride against Arthur A. Chase, England's-middle distance champion, in a thirty-mile event behind pact.

Mr. S.E. Shipp, in your paper of the 16th, is inexact in saying that I inferred Washington's deism from the absence of the name of Christ, or any reference to Him from his thousands of letters. I inferred it from "contemporary evidence" from Jefferson's citation of Gouverneur Morris, and from a private letter of Gen. Tallmadge on Washington's death, deploring his great friend's lack of faith in the redemption and other doctrines.

It is curious to note that in some parts of Bavaria a method of procedure which is called Haberfeld treiben still prevails, and is practiced by the people in case of offenses which do not come within the pale of the ordinary law. Neither person nor property is injured. People assemble with black or masked faces in front of the offender's house, and howl, fire rifles, and beat pots and kettles.

Following are the special musical programmes arranged for the Christmas services to-morrow in a large number of churches in this city and in Brooklyn. Nearly all Protestant and Roman Catholic churches will have services to-day, and the musical programmes for Christmas, printed in THE TIMES of yesterday, will be repeated to-morrow.

TACOMA, Washington, Dec. 24. -- Among the passengers from Dawson who came down on the City of Seattle are Col. Lamphere and M.P. Gregory of Chicago, D.P. Quinlan of Seattle, T. Gardner of Oconomowoc, Wis., and T.B. Denny of Roslyn, Washington.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- The preliminaries of the Klondike relief expedition are being rapidly arranged by the War Department.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 24. -- Through his attorneys, Stephen A. Jenks, a stockholder, made application to United States Judge Adams to-day for a receiver for the Herring-Hall-Marvin Company, manufacturers of safes. Judge Adams named Leonard Matthews as receiver.

Mr. Savage, and in that connection expresses himself thus: "Nearly everything is to be gained and almost nothing lost by a fair and open discussion of truth," (the "nearly" and "almost" are amusingly ecclesiastical, as well as theologically inscrutable.) Mr. Stoddard complains that on some occasion Mr. Savage expressed his views in thee words:

Unusual activity exists among the churches in preparation for the opening of the season in Alaska. Within the week the Baptists have decided to send two missionaries to the Klondike, providing them from Seattle with a complete church, capable of being packed in ship, transferred to small boats on the Yukon, and set up complete on whatever site the missionaries on their arrivel deem best.

BOSTON, Dec. 24. -- Sterling Elliott, Chief Consul of the Massachusetts Division, has returned from his little trip to Philadelphia, but is saying nothing about the plans laid for the coming Presidential campaign of the League of American Wheelmen, nor has he yet announced whether he or George D. Gideon is to run in opposition to President Potter.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24. -- The National Christian Citizenship League, in accordance with its annual custom, recently requested several well-known men for expressions appropriate to the Christmas holiday. The following are extracts from some of the replies received at the headquarters of the league in this city:

The Academy was started in London more than twenty years ago by Dr. Appleton of St. John's College, Oxford, to oppose The Athenaeum in the field of literary criticism and to become the exponent of the idea of signed reviews. The rivalry between the two great London literary weeklies was keen, and the battle between signed and unsigned criticism was vigorously fought out.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- To Representative Hitt largely belongs the responsibility for causing the Government an expense in the settlement of the Bering Sea claims that it has just secured, instead of saving $53,000, as the Treasury would have done by accepting the settlement proposed in 1894 by President Cleveland.

A word of praise is due THE TIMES for its SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS AND ART on Dec. 11. There were twenty-four pages in this supplement, to which Prof. Harry Thurston Peek and Messrs. H.W. Mabie, Charles de Kay, Rarrett Wendell, and Noah Brooks contributed. Prof. Peek's article was on "Automatic Authorship." and in it he said many things worth saying.

The novel sight of Congressmen, Assemblymen, and Councilmen acting as waiters to the men who helped elect them is rarely witnessed, even on the Bowery, but that was what took place at the rooms of the Metamora Club, 207 Bowery, last night.

The Baptist Temple, Third and Schermerhorn Streets, Brooklyn, is to be enlarged. This action has been decided upon, although changes will not be begun before Spring. Some months ago, when it was seen that more room was needed in order to accommodate people and Sunday school, announcement was made that the pastor, the Rev. Cortland Myers, favored enlargement, but that the trustees were opposed to it.

There is one particular part of the dress belonging to the order of the colf -- the black cap -- which the Judges in England always put over their wigs when passing sentence of death. Little is known concerning this black cap, and many mistakes have been made about it.
LONDON, Dec. 25. -- The Daily Mail publishes a dispatch this morning from Tokio, which, it claims, evaded active censorship. The dispatch says:

" The lover is an idealist. He is not in love with a living reality, though he thinks he is. His happiness, as an idealist, consists in believing a poem to be not only poetical, but a fact. True love is a religion, that is, a believed poem, but it is inferior to the celestial religions in expecting its ideal fruition on the earth.

A movement is on foot to revive the waning fortunes of the Democratic Club of this city, and make it a sort of Fifth Avenue Tammany Hall, by inducing Richard Croker to establish his headquarters there. The plan has gone so far that Mr. Croker has consented to make the club his headquarters, though he has declined the offer of the Presidency of the organization.

Dr. Guthrie of London, the author of a celebrated treatise on gunshot wounds, married a lady who had two daughters, one of whom was Margaret Gordon, Carlyle's "Blumine." Mr. Walker saw her in 1833 when she was married to a notable Aberdonian, Sir Alexander Bannerman. He remembers her again in 1851, "fair in looks, handsome in person, and accomplished in manner," and a niece of Lady Bannerman says that she had the sweetest of tempers.

Upon the whole, the findings of the commission appointed to assess the damages for American interference with Canadian seals tend to vindicate the course of Mr. GRESHAM. The Paris tribunal having decided that the seizures were illegal, he offered the lump sum of $425,000 in settlement of the Canadian claims.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Dec. 24. -- The Board of Health of Esopus has enjoined the Nitro-Powder Company from manufacturing dynamite and other explosives, under a penalty of $100 for every day it manufactures hereafter.

A remarkable inquest before Coroner Tuthill was finished at 9:45 A.M. yesterday, when the jury, which had been up all night and had threatened to go on strike unless breakfast was provided for them, came in with a verdict to the effect that James Kennedy came to his death from a fractured skull caused by a blow from a club in the hands of Policeman Henry Woodley.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24. -- Judge Ewing to-day grated a decree of divorce to Jennie W. Banks, the wife of Judge Elmore S. Banks, who presides in the Probate Court of Fairfield, Conn.

It is human nature to feel the kindly emotions strongest in times of prosperity. When things go wrong the calmest philosopher will not be prompted to generosity, and his family are lucky if he does not avenge his misfortunes on their convenient heads. But if things are going more than usually well the impulses of such a season as Christmas take ready hold.

Hesiod was a verista, a rather morose verista who had not kept a single illusion. His advice is the essence of plain common sense tinged a little with pessimism. He makes the Bocotian peasant stand before us as clearly as the Dutch peasants in the "Village Fete" of Teniers. Many of his precepts are no less sound now than they were in his own day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- The Inter-State Commerce Commission has issued a circular to the railroads promulgating the order extending for two years the time within which the railroads shall equip their cars and engines with automatic couplers and driving brakes as required by the act of March 2, 1893.

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 24. -- The veterans of the war in this city are signing a petition to Congress, asking that the United States settle with the pensioners on what the petition terms "a twenty year plan."

-- What are the circumstances which justify insurrection? In his new book on South Africa, JAMES BRYCE discusses this question as raised by the situation of affairs at Johannesburg, but his remarks are susceptible of application to Cuba also. "Some eases," he says, "are too clear for argument.

In your last Saturday's REVIEW OF BOOKS AND ART, "The Boston Correspondent" writes: "There is no doubt that the people of Massachusetts and of all the other States in the Union will continue to send their children to the normal schools as long as they are free, but they cannot well 'patronize' institutions of which they and their children are beneficiaries."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- The Inter-State Commerce Commission has just issued its ninth annual report on the Statistics of Railways in the United States for the year ending June 30, 1896.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec, 24. -- The Chestnut Street Trust and Saving Fund Company, which closed its doors yesterday, made an assignment to-day for the benefit of creditors to George H. Earle, Jr., President of the Tradesmen's National Bank, and Richard Y. Cook, President of the Guarantee Trust and Safe Deposit Company.

All incoming vessels yesterday bore evidence of the wintry weather that now prevails at sea. Some of them were particularly picturesque in their coats of ice. The Clyde coaster Seminole was white from her stem half way to amidships, her rigging was a latticework of frozen spray, and her funnels were crusted with salt.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24. -- An official dispatch received here states that the Spanish authorities at Havana have granted permission to Sylvester Scovel to accompany Rafael Madrigal, the United States Consular Agent at Sancti Spiritus, to the camp of the insurgent commander in chief, Gen. Gomez.

WAUKEGAN, Ill., Dec. 24. -- One of the nursery farmers here has been in correspondence with the Agricultural Department concerning the purchase by the Government of a large stock of evergreen trees, which it is designed to plant in the deserts of the far West and Southwest. An order has been received for several thousand trees.

Dr. DEPEW's rushing journey of 450 miles to dine with the Congregational Club of Washington on Forefathers' Day was well worth making if we consider what he had to say to his hosts. He might well have gone across the continent to announce his acceptance of doctrines so different in important regards from those he has long sustained that his acceptance of them is equivalent to a conversion.

Works which are greedily sought after in one generation are neglected in the next. Booksellers now rarely think it worth while to give the height of an Elzevir or to devote a note to an Aldus. The first editions of the classics, which in the days of our grandfathers were the collector's chief pride, are now fallen from their high estate.

The American flag was taken down, by order of Bishop Charles E. McDonnell, in the presence of an immense congregation, at St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church, Brooklyn, last Sunday. The affair caused considerable comment in church circles at the time, but the history of the incident did not become public until yesterday.

From "The Memoirs of Alfred, Lord Tennyson." Alfred Tennyson's largeness of mind and of heart was touchingly illustrated by his reverence for Wordsworth's poetry, notwithstanding that the immense merits he recognized in it were not, in his opinion, supplemented by a proportionate amount of literary skill.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24. -- Joseph Leiter is determined, if he is to be made the repository of the visible supply of wheat, that it will have to be up to the grade called for by the contract. He is, moreover, prepared to back up his demand in this particular with the authority of the State Inspection Board of Illinois.

I think it remarkable that amid all the collective pressure in the bookselling business, and the easy and familiar way in which writers are quoted by dry goods houses that have the earth on sale, and the especially loud cries regarding the half-nothing prices at which novels can be purchased, from Fielding to Corelli, one never, or hardly ever, sees the name of Henry Kingsley quoted. Charles enjoys the entire monopoly of the name.

Gold imports are to be resumed after a lull in such operations, so far as Europe is concerned, of two months. Of 209,000 in American eagles withdrawn yesterday from the Bank of England, Heidelbach, Ickelheimer Co. are to import $500,000. There was talk that the balance of the gold is to come here for the account of another firm, but it is probable that it will go to Germany.

With slight deductions here and there, it might be said that the whole of what is now the County of London was then open country. A man could walk westward along Holborn, and by the time he reached St. Giles's Church, where now is Shaftesbury Avenue, it would be fields. If he went from Holborn up Gray's Inn Lane by the time he reached King's Cross he would have left London behind him.

Before Judge Newberger, in Part I., of the General Sessions Court yesterday, Abraham Gruber made a motion to dismiss the indictment against Koppel Friedlander, one of the many persons arrested at the time of the wholesale round-up of alleged firebugs in June, 1895. Mr. Gruber gave as a ground for the dismissal of the indictment that no effort had been made to try Friedlander by the District Attorney.

Even great, big, broad-minded Samuel Johnson was wrong when he said, "Babies don't want to hear about other babies; they like to be told of giants and castles, and of somewhat which can stretch and stimulate their little minds." Then he added, "You can teach your daughters the diameters of planets, and wonder when you have done that they do not delight in your company."

Percy W. Smith and William Taylor, who were arrested early in the morning accused of striking Miss Lillian Shuter and robbing the cash drawer of the Kosciusko Street station of the Brooklyn Elevated Road in Brooklyn, where she was agent, were arraigned in the Gates Avenue Police Court yesterday before Justice Worth and held for examination in default of $3,000 bail each.

An actual operation officially and scientifically reported by able surgeons and the indisputable life and presence of a human being seem to nullify all the theories of the learned men of all ages regarding the human stomach. They tend to prove that the stomach is not a vital organ, and that people cannot only live, but can thrive without stomachs.

THE NEW YORK TIMES has recently begun to publish every Saturday a supplement, consisting of sixteen pages of reviews of literature and art, somewhat on the lines of the weekly literary number of the Paris Figaro. The result is bright and readable, but not, we think, quite deserving of the praise contained in the following letter to the editor, printed in the copy which has just reached us.

Mayor Strong yesterday made public the reports of President Sheffield of the Fire Board, Chief Bonner, and Engineer Crowell, who recently returned from an extended tour of several Western cities, where they went to examine an auxiliary water-pipe system in vogue in those places and to investigate, with the idea of introducing a similar system in New York.

From Macaulay a very large assortment of bests, biggests, and greatests might be culled; a few will suffice. The theatrical novelties of holiday week will both be trifles. At the Casino another musical farce or burletta, with an elaborately pictorial dress, will be produced. It is called "The Telephone Girl," and was taken from the French of two expert farce and vaudeville writers, Antony Mars and Maurice Desvalliers, by "Hugh Morton," while Gustave Kerker composed the new music.

If a woman is ever to retain her present position in the business world, she must look to it that she makes her value felt. She has many advantages, she is punctual, painstaking, patient of monotony, amenable to discipline, ready, and willing; indeed, she errs as a rule rather from excess of zeal than from its defect.

This is a busy season of the year for the Consumers' League. The particular work that has been done recently has been an effort to provide supper money for shop girls. In some of the shops the girls working overtime are provided with supper. This is as it should be, the league says, and it is working for that or an equivalent for the supper in all the shops.

Taking a desperate chance to avoid hurting a woman, a child, and a doll, James F. Calnan, driver for Engine Company No. 34 of the Fire Department, was killed yesterday morning at Thirty-ninth Street and Tenth Avenue.

Shipkeeper Francis Wallace had finished his work of putting the old United States frigate New Hampshire in order after the drills of the First Naval Battalion had been concluded a few nights ago. He was seated in his quarters smoking his pipe and surrounded by several young amateur tars, who, after drill, find pleasure in the stories the sea which Mr. Wallace tells.
NEWPORT, Dec. 25. -- Mrs. John Clinton Gray is having her pretty villa on Kay Street enlarged and the lower portion of the addition will be used as a study.

PARIS, Dec. 14. -- To pile scandal upon scandal has been the fate of this hapless country for some years past. No sooner does the interest in the subject of ex-Capt. Dreyfus begin to flag than a new sensation must needs arise in connection with those two ancient fishlike scandals which derive their names from Panama and the Southern of France Railway Company.

When Congress reassembles after the holidays those Senators and representatives who call themselves Republicans, but who are opposed to the merit system, which has been so strongly indorsed by Republican National Conventions, will renew their assault on that system. They will endeavor to destroy it in order that they may become spoils distributors and be able to reward their henchmen.

CHICAGO, Dec. 25. -- Albion W. Small, head Professor of Sociology at the University of Chicago, returned to-day from a five months' trip abroad. He said that American diplomacy had made us the laughing stock of Europe.

What, indeed, do we understand nowadays by the term "opera"? Had the question been asked a dozen years ago -- in this country, at any rate -- the answer would have been much more simple, for then it could have been said that Wagner alone had written opera, and that the works written by other composers and designated by the same name were not opera at all.

Patrick H. Concannon, a carpenter, forty-five years old, of 696 Wythe Avenue, Williamsburg, was probably fatally injured last evening while trying to get on a moving elevated train at the Kosciusko Street station in Williamsburg.

Col Thomas Wantworth Higginson observed his seventy-fourth anniversary at his home, 25 Buckingham Street, Cambridge, yesterday. All through the day visitors came to congratulate the venerable historian and offer their best wishes for the continuance of his good health. The Cantabrigla Club, in accordance with its custom, sent some beautiful flowers in honor of the day.

IN 1861 Dr. Edward Everett Hale wrote for The Atlantic Monthly an article descriptive of the London Workingmen's College, then six years established. In it he quoted the founders as saying "that if either rank or knowledge is not held as a trust for men, if any one of these things is regarded as a possession of our own, it must perish."

Difference of religion. -- The Austro-Hungarian Empire contains Catholics, (Roman Catholics and Greek Catholics,) Protestants, (Lutherans and Evangelical Calvinists,) Orthodox Greeks, Jews, and Mussulmans. The Roman Catholic are in a preponderant majority, (27,000,000,) but they also, as well as the members of the other creeds, are locally not united, but divided and spread over both parts of the monarchy.

MARSEILLES, Dec. 8. -- Five hundred miles, and forty over, from Paris to Marseilles, and the warm blue waters of the Mediterranean. Just about the distance from New York to Buffalo. It is a trifling journey to look forward to, with the cold becoming dense in Paris and the fires refusing in their polite French way to warm the house.

OTTAWA, Dec. 25. -- Clifford Sifton, Minister of the Interior, who will leave to-morrow for Washington, will be accompanied by J.A.J. McKenna, Secretary of the Department. Mr. Sifton will discuss with the United States Government the question of ingress to the Yukon, the customs regulations, and a variety of other subjects.

PORTLAND, Oregon, Dec. 25. -- The Portland Chamber of Commerce has sent the following telegram to Secretary of War Alger: "It is feared by the people of the Northwest that the Government relief expedition cannot reach the Yukon in time to prevent suffering.

The Knickerbocker Athletic Club had an ideal day for its cross-country run, which was held over the William's Bridge course yesterday. The thinly clad athletes who ventured out in the cold were compelled to move at a lively gait to keep warm, and several of them were bruised about the legs and arms as a result of their journey.

Herman F. Dale, a well-connected young insurance broker, died last night at his home in the Gramercy Apartments, from carbolic acid poisoning. His mother, Mrs. Eugenie E. Dale, widow of John G. Dale, found him semi-conscious on her return from a Christmas dinner party at the home of a friend.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Dec. 25. -- One of the cleverest swindles on record by means of forged checks has been perpetrated recently on the bucket shops and commission houses of Toledo, Detroit, Chicago, and St. Louis. At last that is as far as the returns have come in.

It is easy to sweep them out. In 1893 the Democratic managers did it by nominating MAYNARD. The Republicans had a majority of 100,000 that year. In 1894 the sweeping out was even more complete. The Democratic organization adhered firmly to the policy that proved so successful the previous year, and the Republican majority was raised to 156,108.

The Directors and officials of the Metropolitan Museum of Art are frequently asked regarding the authenticity of many of their original pictures and sculptures. The famous painting of Rosa Bonheur, "The Horse Fair," is the object of constant inquiry, as reports are continually gaining currency that the original exists in some foreign collection, and that the picture which Mr. Vanderbilt purchased for the Metropolitan Museum from A.T. Stewart's collection, is a copy.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 25. -- There is, indeed, a merry Christmas in Lakewood. The jovial temper and bounty of the day is shared by all classes and circles, and the population of the village is largely augmented by visitors who have come to enjoy the pleasures of the resort and the companionship of friends.

LONDON, Dec. 25. -- "Peace on earth, good will to men," has even a more metaphorical, not to say ironical, sound this year than usual. It is the most disturbed and agitated Christmas of my time in Europe. One hesitates to say that the general public is particularly moved, but certainly the newspapers everywhere are raising almost an unparalleled hubbub of excitement over the crisis in the far East.

Signor Mancinelli has been busily engaged during this season conducting the operas at the Madrid Opera House, and he has been especially praised for a performance of "Lohengrin" which he conducted there.

ZARATHUSTRA spoke Gotham in vain. The heathen raged and the people imagined a vain thing. But it was not quite so vain a thing as that which Richard Strauss imagined when he wrote "Thus Spake Zarathustra." Emil Paur, conductor of the Boston Symphony orchestra, deserves a certain amount of gratitude for producing this work here and letting those who care to think about musical art reflect on the possibilities of absolute music without text.

Dr. Evans was more than a friend of the late Emperor Frederick and his wife. But he was annoyed at the confidence they placed in Sir Morell Mackenzie, about whose treatment he had strong views. Evans's opinion greatly influenced the opinion of the old Emperor and Empress, of Bismarck, and of the Berlin physicians, about the throat doctor from London. Evans was originally a Quaker.

Mrs. James Speyer, 257 Madison Avenue, the Treasurer of the Woman's Auxiliary of the Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association, reports the following additional contributions to the "Woman's Fund" of the General Collection:

LANSING, Mich., Dec. 25. -- After ten years of litigation the United States Supreme Court has decided against the Michigan Land and Lumber Company of this city in its suit to eject Charles A. Rust of Saginaw from certain lands which he claimed.

HAVANA, Dec. 25. -- During last month numerous robberies and stabbing affrays are reported to have occurred in Havana. These outrages are ascribed to the return from the Ceuta Prison of the "Nanigos," who have been pardoned for political offenses under recent decrees. It is officially stated that many canefields in the Havana Province have been burned by the insurgents.

Jimmy Michael, the little Welsh racer, defended his title as the world's champion at middle distance riding by defeating under adverse conditions Arthur A. Chase of England, who is considered the best racer of England in middle distances, in a thirty-mile contest last night at Madison Square Garden, in the attempt to break the world's records for this class of racing from 1 to 13 miles.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- The sixteenth general meeting of the American Chemical Society will be held in this city, Dec. 29 and 30. The headquarters for the meeting will be at the Columbian University. At the opening of the first session there will be a brief address of welcome by President B L. Whitman of Columbian University, and a response in behalf of the Society by the President Charles B. Dudley of Altoona, Penn.

A general alarm was sent out yesterday from Police Headquarters for George F. Boulard, a civil engineer employed by the New York Central Railroad Company, who has been missing since Friday, Dec. 17, when he left his office after his day's work.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 25. -- This is the coldest Christmas here for many years, During the past week California and the entire Pacific coast have been visited by frosts the like of which, old residents affirm, has not been experienced since 1859. In Southern California the cold has been especially severe, with the result that the orange crop has suffered greatly.

IN addition to those foreign aristocrats who visit this country with the avowed intention of bartering an ancient name and title for the dollars of some American heiress, there are others more manly and honorable who take up their residence in the United States for the purpose of repairing by means of hard work fortunes that have been shattered through misfortune.

QUEBEC, Dec. 22. -- The glory of old Quebec is departed. Its quaintness, its quietness the torpor which has distinguished it among the cities of the New World, the atmosphere of old associations and historic reminiscence -- the full measure of their inspiration is gone. In a brief quarter of one solar year the uniqueness of the ancient capital has disappeared.

Howard Gould and Miss Katherine Clemmons gave an elaborate dinner last night at the Holland House, in honor of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Kemble, who have just returned from their wedding trip. After the dinner had been finished the guests adjourned to Miss Clemmons's private parlor in the hotel, where a Christmas tree celebration of a novel character was given.

Under this title Mr. J.A. WHEELOCK contributes to Harper's Magazine an article that will well repay the careful attention of every reader in the East who cares to know the mighty empire built up within, practically, the last twenty years.

PULASKI, Va., Dec. 25. -- A west-bound Norfolk and Western freight train and east-bound passenger train No. 6 collided at about 10:30 o'clock last night at Wygals Bridge, four miles west of this town.

It is about decided that the Brooklyn baseball team will again take its preliminary practice in the vicinity of Charlotte, N.C. Manager Barnie has a big kindergarten class this year, and he will take the men South about March 20. This will give the players nearly four weeks to limber up.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Dec. 25. -- A crowd of 100 or more men and boys were firing a Christmas salute from an old cannon on the outskirts of town to-day when a can of thirty pounds of powder exploded in the thick of the crowd. Thirty or forty persons were injured, but none, it is believed, fatally.

Mr. James C. Tawes, the State Fish Commissioner for the Eastern Shore, lives in Crisfield. He is an active and progressive business man, and unusually bright and intelligent. He has spent his life as a dealer in marine productions, such as fish, crabs, oysters, and terrapin, and is alert to note anything affecting that industry.

To satisfy his children's cravings, Hyman Gottseyer, although an orthodox Jew, resolved to celebrate Christmas, not exactly like his Gentile neighbors, but still in a manner that would afford an opportunity to make his three little ones less envious of their Christian playmates. Besides it was Chanuka, a Jewish feast also, and he would celebrate that at the same time.

CHICAGO, Dec. 25. -- The fire which last evening destroyed the Coliseum, at Sixty-third Street and Stony Island Avenue, claimed only one victim. He was N.H. Johnson, whose charred body was recovered from the ruins to-day. Johnson was a fireman employed about the building. He had evidently remained at his post until the last moment.

LONDON, Dec. 13. -- James M. Macdonough and Aemillus Jarvis, who were appointed to represent the North American Yacht Racing Union and to confer with the Yacht Racing Association of Great Britain, have had a conference with the Council here, and the British yachtsmen regard their propositions favorably.

All Paris regrets the retirement of Baron de Mohrenheim from the post of Russian Ambassador to France. He has endeared himself to the French by many acts which have cemented the friendship between the republic and the empire. To him more than to any one else is due the success of the sojourn of the Czar and Czarina in Paris a year ago, and the subsequent events turning to the advantage of the French.

HAVANA, Dec. 25. -- As is customary here on Christmas Eve, large crowds of Spaniards assembled in Central Park and indulged in dancing, singing, and other forms of amusement. A large number of those present becoming intoxicated began to make demonstrations and to shout "Viva Weyler," "Viva Espana," "Viva Union Constitutional," "Down with autonomy," and other disturbing cries.

Nowhere on my travels so far have I seen so much warm-blooded rejoicing life as in this grand Arctic reservation by so many regarded as desolate. Not only are there whales in abundance along the shores, and innumerable seals, walruses, and white bears, but great herds of fat reindeer on the tundras, and wild sheep, foxes, hares, lemmings, whistling marmots, and birds.

LONDON, Dec. 25. -- The alleged attempt of the Prince of Monaco to "bleed" the Casino Company has led to the publication of a pamphlet by a group of shareholders, full of interesting reading. While everybody is aware that the Casio contributed largely to his revenues, few people knew that, besides the subsidy of the Prince, the establishment keeps up the Judges, police, lighting, water, Post Office, clergy, and charitable institutions.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 25. -- A Kansas genius who is handy with mathematics and geography has been making some calculations about the great crops grown in the State this year. The array of figures is startling, especially if one should picture an exodus of all the people of the State, taking with them their wheat, corn, oats, potatoes, and cattle.

Perhaps the most significant piece of news that has come from China since the German seizure is that the Russians have taken charge of the Chinese Army in North China. This operation is reported to have the assent of the Chinese Government.

The political hiatus which Christmas is always expected to produce was not complete yesterday in the case of Richard Croker and Mayor-elect Van Wyck. Holiday as it was, they could not escape wholly from talk with and about candidates for office.

President William McKinley loves music. His life has been a busy and serious one, not given to accomplishments in music or art, save the art of political success. Yet nothing delights him more in the hours of recreation than sweet, simple music. At church services his baritone voice is heard in the congregational singing of the old familiar hymns.

The most interesting, and perhaps the most important, week in 1897, to all interested in American breadstuffs, be they speculators or manipulators or dealers in actual grain, or holders of it, ends next Friday afternoon. Then the gigantic dealings in December wheat at Chicago will have been settled and much of their true character will be known.

ATHENS, Dec. 25. -- As the Greek gunboat Actium was leaving the Gulf of Ambracia to-day a shot was fired at her by the Turks at Fort Prevesa on the north side of the entrance to the gulf. The Actium and several other gunboats which were following her were compelled to return to their anchorage.

By the census quite enough is known to convey a true and startling idea of what the Russian Empire actually is and what it is capable of becoming under normally sanitary conditions. The natural increase of the population is kept down to a relatively low figure by an abnormally large death rate, which is mainly due to avoidable causes.

A prolonged sitting was held by the L.A.W. Commission at the Grand Union Hotel yesterday to place the responsibility of the short track used in the six-day race at Madison Square Garden. In addition to the oral testimony of a number of persons identified with the race in verious capacities, a large mass of documentary evidence was submitted and considered.

The movement for the reform of the jury system in the County of New York, of which we gave an account Friday, is both needed and promising. It is begun in the right way by collecting all the laws governing the system, bringing out in this way both their incongruities and defects. That must be the basis of any change really for the better.

The temper of the Spanish people is marvelous indeed. A firm Government -- firm with the just intention of doing right -- they are slow to recognize and tolerate, but tyranny they readily swallow, making a wry face, perhaps, but no resistance. The more merciless the force opposed to them the more they find in it to admire and make obeisance to.

Coroner Nason of Williamsburg yesterday requested Coroner Coombs to conduct the investigation and hold the inquest in the case of the aged miser, Mrs. Josephine Bose, who was found dead on Friday in rooms she occupied on the top floor of a frame tenement at 41 Spencer Street.

THE HAGUE, Dec. 10. -- Every line of produce is a specialty in Holland. A butcher sells fresh meat only, and a pork butcher only pork, ham, and sausage. Poultry and game belong together, and milk, butter, cheese, and eggs; coffee, tea, and sugar. Special shops for flour, meals, and grains; beautiful they are, too, with the snowy bags of ground and unground grain, exposed for sale.

THE HAGUE, Dec. 5. -- "Nowhere in all the calendar," says de Onde Heer Smid, "is there a saint's day marked that can call forth the reverence and love as does that of Sinter Klaas. For centuries has he made his yearly visit with the unfashionable regularity of country friends, and long before the day set aside for him arrives, his reception is prepared throughout the Christian world."

Water is the most precious and exclusive drink you can order in Paris. Imagine that, you who let the water run to cool it! In Paris they actually pay for water in their houses by the quart. Artichokes and truffles and mushrooms and silk stockings and kid gloves are so cheap here that it makes you blink your eyes.

The New York City Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution will hold its annual celebration of the anniversary of Washington's wedding day on Thursday afternoon, Jan. 6, from 4 to 7 o'clock, in Sherry's large ballroom. The speakers will be man prominent in public affairs.
Emma Juch will sing for the first time this season next Tuesday afternoon in the Guilmant recital.
In all probability the majority of the members of the gay world feel this morning with the boy who objected to Christmas falilng upon Saturday because it made Sunday so flat.

THE Junior League of small patrons and patronesses of the Messiah Home for Little Children is just coming to the fore with its annual entertainment for the institution which is the beneficiary of the work. The organization is an interesting one, and, considering the size and age of its members, all of whom are under fourteen, does a large amount of valuable work. It is a "children's charity for children."

The leading topic in National Guard circles last week was the reorganization question, and the selection of the board to decide upon a scheme. The detail for the board comes in for a great deal of criticism. The absence of such officers as Gens. Fitzgerald and Doyle, as well as of an artillery officer, from the board, is much commented upon.

LONDON, Dec. 25. -- So soon as Jackson, the explorer, has completed the work connected with his Franz Josef Land expedition, he will start for the north pole. He informed a reporter that his original plans were identical with those of Lieut. Peary, except that he intended to take the east coast of the island, instead of the west, mapping out undiscovered land en route.

The morning after the ceremonies attending the celebration of the one hundredth anniversary of the launching of "Old Ironsides" the writer watched, from a favorable vantage point, our magnificent fleet of floating fortresses steam past Boston Lighthouse to sea. It had been blowing a heavy gale from the northeast all the previous day and a very heavy sea was piling in on Egg Rock and Point Allerton.

The row in the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen, which started over resolutions passed by the Schuylkin Navy, censuring Secretary Fred Fortmeyer for using the influence of his office to defeat the election of the Schuylkin Navy candidate to the Executive Board has taken a serious turn, and William G. Jupp of Detroit, President of the association has appointed a committee to straighten out the matter.

Christmastide will be more observed in the New York clubs, from all indications this year, than for many past. There were suppers at several of the leading clubs last night, and a New Year's Eve supper is scheduled at almost all of the more prominent clubhouses. Twelfth Night, which has been for many years peculiarly the Century Club's own, will also this year be celebrated by the Lotos, St. Nicholas, St. Anthony's, and other clubs.

We have a very flourishing (so-called) "temperance society" in the village, and the result is seen in the increased comfort of the cottagers. I used sometimes to show my interest in the cause by taking the chair at a meeting now and then, but I have given it up since ladies have begun to appear on platforms, for ladies recognize no rules of the game.

LONDON, Dec. 25. -- The week has been the coldest of the season, 10 to 20 degrees being registered, and skating has commenced. All who could do so have exodused to the country, where Christmas house parties are more numerous than usual. Of the United States Embassy, the United States Ambassador, Col. John Hay, and Mrs. Hay alone remained in town.

Florence's last joke was one of his best, and was also peculiarly pathetic and prophetic. He came to New York from Boston at the close of an engagement there, and was on his way to Philadelphia. At the Fifth Avenue Hotel, where he always stopped, he was told that the barber who had shaved him for many years had died that Sunday morning, and was to be buried the next afternoon.

With fragrant balsam and red-berried holly, Santa Claus perfumed and decorated the Greater New York yesterday. Christmas bells and Christmas carols gave a joyous greeting to the day, and with varied emotions and under widely differing circumstances, the millions of souls which make up the community enjoyed their Christmas as much as they were able.
The Westchester Wheelmen have leased the building in Mount Vernon now occupied by the City Club, and will take possession in the Spring.

We are within a Week now of the greatest disbursements in the history of the American investment world. To an appreciable extent the New York Stock Exchange market has recently reflected this approaching release of funds; especially has the influence been shown in the market for bonds of the higher class, every such issue having advanced materially through the absorption processes of almost unprecedented reinvestment.

During its investigation of pension frauds in 1895 THE TIMES found a pensioner, whom we will call S.C., living on a farm near the City of Ogdensburg. He draws $12 a month. His pension was granted for the alleged disabilities of "disease of the liver and respiratory organs," constituting "incapacity to perform manual labor."

The hurried recall of the Military Attache of the German Embassy in Paris caused deep speculation as to its cause. Coming, as it did, with the most conspicuous elements of the Dreyfus affair fresh in mind, the conclusions arrived at were that the retirement of Lieut. Col. von Schwartzkoppen was the result of a sharp request from the French Government.

The task undertaken by the Central Committee was in the highest degree formidable; rooted prejudices had to be overome, inarticulate suspicions removed -- the half-civilized nomads have an insuperable dislike to answer questions of the Tshinovniks -- the confidence of the people gained, languages mastered, routes studied, badges prepared for the officials, millions upon millions of census papers printed and distributed over the length and breadth of the empire,

" The Queen's Lace Handkerchief" is undoubtedly one of the most melodious and scholarly of the works of Johann Strauss. Its revival yesterday afternoon at the American Theatre brought up memories of a certain damp and discouraging night in the dim past when the Casino first opened its doors to the public, and this operetta was offered for public delectation by John A. McCaull.

Saffron would strike an ordinary observer as decidedly expensive at 56s. per pound, until told that it is composed of the central small portions only of the flowers of a species of crocus, 70,000 of which it takes to yield the material for one pound. The wonder then becomes that it is so cheap, that it can pay to grow and gather it at the price.

New York has acquired an unknown quantity of trouble and expense by its increase of population and its enlarged boundaries. In its relation to the new municipality of Greater New York, the present City of New York bears a significant resemblance to the rich business man, who, partly from expediency and partly from pride of acquisition, takes into his big establishment several lesser concerns in the same line of business.

HAMILTON KING, who is to be our Minister at Siam, is an example of what natural ability and industry will accomplish. Mr. King was borne in 1853, and spent his boyhood in Maine, where he received a public school education.

BOSTON, Dec. 25. -- The North End was again the scene of a terrible tragedy tonight, and, as usual, the Italian quarter furnished the participants. As a result, Guiseppe Cattula, forty-four years of age, was almost instantly killed, his head being nearly severed from his body with a long carving knife.

CENTRALIA, Mo., Dec. 25. -- Last Sunday morning Mr. Robert McNair, accompanied by Miss Hattie Jennings and her mother, of this place, went to Columbia to get a marriage license and be married in order that she might escape from the persistent attentions of William McGraw, who was determined to marry the girl, having the father's consent, but not the mother's.

At a meeting of the Royal Photographic Society, held in the rooms of the Society of Arts last night, Prof. Gabriel Lippmann described his system of color photography, whereby a photograph showing the colors of nature is obtained by a direct process and with one exposure of the plate. The film, which might be of any sensitive substance, he explained, was exposed, developed, and fixed in the usual way.

It is a safe prediction that of whatever prosperity is in store for the United States a large relative share will fall to this New Northwest, for it is yet in its infancy of development. In 1890 the total acreage of Minnesota farms, improved and unimproved, was 18,603,654, leaving at least 20,000,000 acres of fertile soil still unoccupied.
DENVER, Col., Dec. 25. -- The Overland Cotton Mills of this city have carried the war "into the enemy's country" with a vengeance by securing contracts which will place their product in Boston, Mass.
The big International Health Exposition to be head in New York in January is beginning to assume something like definite proportions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25. -- Great curiosity has recently been aroused in an old subject by the ladies of the Washington University Association, which met here about the middle of the month. The association was formed by ladies who have set about promoting the effort to secure the establishment in Washington of a National university.

ORANGE CITY, Iowa, Dec. 25. -- A party of Orange City youths honored David Hooper, a Quaker, with a charivari recently on his wedding night. When the din they made failed to elicit any sign of annoyance, they tried to force an entrance into the house through a window to drag him forth.

Now that Alphonse Daudet has passed on to the unknown that is the end or the beginning of all things, his Parisian critics may receive all inspiration from some source and tell us exactly what they mean by designating the dead author's works as belonging to the school of real-idealism. Do they mean that the style of "Sapho" is the real Simon-Pure article, or that it is realistically ideal or ideally realistic.

PLAINFIELD, Conn., Dec. 25. -- One of the best-known dancing masters in Eastern Connecticut a few years ago was Gurdon Cady. He was one of the best fiddlers and prompters in the State. No festive occasion where dancing was a feature could be carried out in fashion without Mr. Cady to superintend the figures.

In common, doubtless with many others I had been in sore fear during the latter days of his life that the great orator, jurist, and statesman would pass away without chance given me to hear or even see him. But the opportunity came, and it was the last afforded any one to hear him in public address, for then was made his last public speech.

AMONG the many charity organizations of this city devoted to the care and welfare of the children of the city, it is safe to say that few, if any, show better results than those achieved by the New York Juvenile Asylum.

Without knowledge volubility of words is, as Cicero says, "empty and ridiculous." The vice of the earlier rhetoricians, Georgias and other Greek sophists, lay here. They made words a substitute for knowledge. They boasted that their at enabled a man to speak well on every topic, and so it did in a shallow, superficial way, which Socrates justly held up to ridicule.

MR. G.E. MANIGAULT of Charleston, S.C., has contributed the accompanying reproductions of twelve miniatures on ivory by Edward Malbone and one by Charles Fraser of Charleston to THE NEW YORK TIMES'S Illustrated Weekly Magazine.

In the very centre of a crowded Columbus Avenue cable car stood a short but heavy man, with a cinder in his eye. Although the cinder evidently gave him serious annoyance, he was good natured about it, and in spite of the fact that his fellow passengers manifested the utmost indifference to his personal affairs, he bubbled over with information about that cinder.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 25. -- Mrs. Mary Burger of 63 Madison Street seemed to be one of the merriest of her family as she sat down to the Christmas dinner at her home to-day. She was suddenly seized with convulsions and expired soon after.

A facetious hotel proprietor hung up this sign in his rooms: "Indian clubs and dumbbells will not be permitted in any of the rooms. Guests in need of exercise can go down to the kitchen and pound a steak."

At last the leash has been cut and the dogs of political war have left their kennels. Isaac B. Potter has modestly signified that he is a candidate for re-election to the Presidency of the League of American Wheelmen. The 102,242 members of that puissant body are slowly convalescing from their fear that Mr. Potter might not desire again to hold down the executive chair.

The lion tamer Letort was last night nearly killed in the presence of the numerous spectators who always fill M. Pezon's menagerie. It was the last performance at the fair, held at the Place de l'Italie. The lion tamer, who was seriously mauled, has nevertheless been able to give a description of what occurred.

Hardly a day passes that Shipping Commissioner Tolman does not have two or three applications from boys who want to ship as sailors. The most of these boys are between the ages of fifteen and eighteen and have never been out of the sight of land or seen a vessel larger than a small coaster.
LONDON, Dec. 27. -- The Madrid correspondent of The Standard says: ...

One of the most notable surgical operations performed recently, and one which may furnish a precedent for the treatment of apoplectic cases in which the pressure of a clot of blood formed on the brain can be localized, took place at the New York Post-Graduate Hospital, Twentieth Street and Second Avenue, eleven days ago.

The Irish and Irish-Americans of this city and Brooklyn who are interested in the Irish cause assembled in large numbers at the Empire Theatre, Williamsburg, last evening, to tender a reception to Miss Maude Gonne, "Ireland's Joan of Arc," upon the occasion of her first visit to Brooklyn.

When an old-timer visits Washington he finds it interesting to sit a while in the galleries of the Senate or the House and recall the men and the scenes with which he was familiar during the years, let us say, beginning with Lincoln's first Presidential term and ending with the accession of Andrew Johnson to the office of President.

The fifth of the series of Sunday night concerts at popular prices at the Metropolitan Opera House last night was attended by an audience of moderate size. Those present, however, appeared to enjoy the evening's proceedings and demanded encores after long concertos just as resolutely as other audiences do after shorter displays.

It is the consensus of opinion among the dealers in the horse and carriage trade in this city that the outlook for 1898 is brighter than it has been for ten years. The dealers believe that the demand will be larger, that prices will rule higher, and that many people who have never cared about owning a good horse will become owners, now that the new speedway offers them a suitable place to drive.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Dec. 26. -- The British steamer Lambert's Point, Capt. Humphreys, seven days from Norfolk, Va., and bound for Liverpool with cattle, cotton, grain, and a general cargo, has arrived here with her cotton on fire and the ship in a bad state.

William H. Welch, a taxpayer living at 20 Lenox Road, Flatbush, is about to bring a suit against President Adolph Simis of the Brooklyn Board of Charities to compel the latter to restore the salary paid him as Charities Commissioner during portions of the years 1894, 1895, 1896, and 1897. In all the sums which Mr. Welch wishes to have restored to the city amount to $5,000.

State Superintendent Kincannon of Mississippi is busily engaged upon his biennial report to the Legislature. He takes a progressive step in advocacy of the newspaper in the public schools. On this important subject he will say:

PROVIDENCE, Dec. 26. -- A Camp Street electric car ran wild this afternoon and rushed down the heavy grade on Olney Street hill with great speed, and shot across North Main Street and into the corner of a frame building.

All kinds of opinions are expressed as to the ability of the Naval Reserves to maintain the Yantic in her present condition. The opinion seems to be shared by many that she will prove a white elephant on their hands; that, as her hull is thirty-three years old, the cost of keeping it up to its present standard will be much more than her new owners can sustain.

Long Island City has two Justices, Charles T. Duffy and James Ingram. They transact about all the legal business done in the city, outside of the County Court House. They act as Police Justices and Civil Justices. They alternate in sitting in different ends of the town, and are on the best of terms.

But little activity is looked for in Wall Street during the coming week. The interval between Christmas and New Year's Day is always attended by "holiday markets," and many Wall Street men left their offices last Friday night with the intention of staying away until next Monday.

It is understood that the Right Hon. Joseph Chamberlain, Colonial Secretary, has remonstrated with the Canadian Government for infringing the rules of the Universal Postal Union by undertaking to reduce the postage on letters from Canada to the United Kingdom without consulting other members of the union.
The following letter was written to a gentleman in Montreal by his son, who left for the Klondike last June, and came back, leaving Dawson City on his return voyage in September:

CHICAGO, Dec. 26. -- The Tribune this morning printed a two-page article on "Absentee Landlords of Chicago," the intent of which is to show that over $5,000,000 earned yearly in Chicago is spent elsewhere by the beneficiaries.

One of the obviously submerged divines pathetically asks THE TIMES why it gives so much space to the "so-called" unorthodox preachers to the exclusion of others, whom I dare say he considers of the right sort. Your reply, because for one reason it leads to discussion, I trust is not primarily your purpose in doing so.

We do not like Lord SALISBURY'S timid and inactive policy in the East. It is not by such complacency that English history has been made. It is not as a looker-on in those times of change that remake the map of the world that she has come to be the powerful mother nation of great colonies.

Those who think that President McKINLEY will yield to the pressure of the spoilsmen of his party forget two facts. One is the tremendous pressure he has already resisted; the other is that to abandon or seriously to weaken the merit system now would be to give up wholly all hopes of a decent name for his own Administration.

ALBANY, Dec. 26. -- The annual report of Adjutant-General Tillinghast to Gov. Black will be submitted this week, and will include the reports of each brigade commander, the Inspector-General, the Inspector of Rifle Practice and other minor officers. The report of the Inspector-General, unlike that of Gen. McLewee last year, which caused so much comment, will not be given to the press or public except so far as statistics are concerned.

There has been correspondence looking to the visit of the Confederate Veterans, uniformed rank, of this city, to New York. Major Withers explained at the Monday night meeting what has occurred in the way of discussing the matter.
In the letter of the Rev. Mr. Stoddard, criticising Mr. Savage, he makes this assertion, asking to be corrected if wrong:

While so much is being said nowadays as to the deficiencies of college students in English composition, a word ought to be said by way of suggestion that those who are in the position of exemplars in such matters ought to be cautioned lest they lay, themselves open to the charge of carelessness in their writings.

Although Speaker Reed presides over the House and Senator Frye, as President pro tem., frequently presides over the Senate, this by no means exhausts the supply of good presiding officers in the Maine delegation. Ample proof of this was had last week, when one day Senator Hale was the presiding officer of the Senate and Representative Dingley the presiding officer of the House

With a territory as large as Europe, a population double that of Great Britain, and domestic industries nearly equaling the aggregate of those of Great Britain, France, and Germany, the foreign trade of the United States is much smaller than that of any of these countries. But in twenty years France increased her foreign trade 3 per cent., Germany 11 per cent., the United Kingdom 17 per cent., and the United States 66 per cent.

The children of the stage held the stage at Tony Pastor's Theatre and in Tammany Hall last night, enjoyed a Christmas celebration, of their own, and promoted the enjoyment of a large number of older people, most of whom are connected with the theatres.

Some of the more radical papers in England condemn very severely the course of the employers in the long dispute in the engineering trade, and accuse them of seeking to break down the trade union system by attacking its central principle of "collective bargaining." This is hardly just.

Some House Democrats are viewing the Congressional campaign of next Summer with indifference. Among a considerable number there is little disposition to pursue an aggressive policy that would likely place the present minority in control of the lower branch and place upon them the responsibility of legislation for two years preceding what promises to be an exceedingly hard-fought Presidential campaign.

While two members of a church relief society were visiting among the poor on Christmas Day they came upon a peculiar and pathetic case. They had been told of a poor girl, destitute and almost alone in the world, who was dying of an incurable malady. Without much difficulty they found this unfortunate person in a cheerless room on the fourth floor of a tenement in Thirty-ninth Street, near Ninth Avenue.
At the Madison Square Presbyterian Church yesterday morning the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst preached from the text: "Jesus answered, 'My Kingdom is not of this word.'" Dr. Parkhurst said in part:
Mgr. Paul Bruchesi, Archbishop of Montreal, was a passenger on the French Line steamship La Champagne, which arrived yesterday from Havre.

ALBANY, Dec. 26. -- State Engineer and Surveyor Campbell W. Adams, in response to an inquiry from R.R. Hefford, Chairman of the Executive Canal Committee, appointed by the Chambers of Commerce of the State, regarding the present status of the work of improving the canals of the State, has made a report which has been approved by Superintendent George W. Aldridge of the State Department of Public Works.
"' The Angel of the Tenement.' or, Our Duty to Shadowed Lives" was the topic of the evening lecture of the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Eaton, pastor of the Church of the Divine Paternity yesterday. He said:

The farmers of the West have had a striking object lesson the past season in the causes which produce prosperity. Never before in that part of the country have so many farm mortgages been paid off in the space of a few months, and that, too, without a dollar of cheap money.

A correspondent recently criticised the bill of Chairman LOUD for meeting the deficit of the postal revenues on the ground that it did not proceed on the right principle. This principle he held to be that the Government should charge just the cost of carrying mail matter and then admit all sorts.

One of the most entertaining papers yet read before the Plattsburg Institute was on birds, and more especially those frequenting this Adirondack region, presented by Senator Chahoon. The Senator summarized his own personal observations of the birds of the Adirondacks during a period exceeding a quarter of a century, doing so in a most entertaining and instructive manner.

The celebration of the one hundredth anniversary of the Reformed Presbyterian Church in America by the First Reformed Presbyterian. Church in West Twelfth Street was begun yesterday in that church, and will be continued during the week.

The barbecue feature of the National Stock Growers' Convention next month promises to be one of the biggest affairs ever held in the West. The committee in charge of the arrangements held a meeting yesterday afternoon and divided up the work of preparation. It was estimated that there would be at least 10,000 people at the barbecue to be fed, and the arrangements are being made upon this basis.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Dec. 26. -- Edward McMichael, twenty years of age, and Miss Mary C. Van Barber, twenty-two years of age, both of Rifton, lost their lives while skating on Christmas Day. McMichael might have escaped if he had not attempted to rescue his companion, who had broken through the ice.

We printed the other day the news about the cable from Bermuda to the West Indies. Of course there is no commercial excuse for it, for commercial business would never support a second line when there is not enough for the existing facilities. They are adequate, even though the West Indies were thriving instead of decadent.

The attacks made upon the Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott for his utterance last Sunday to the effect that an agnostic might enter heaven drew forth a reply from him yesterday morning. In this sermon in Plymouh Church he reaffirmed his belief and gave an exhaustive exposition of his opinions on faith and salvation. His text was "He that believeth on Me believeth on Him that sent Me."

Despite the confidence of local rowing authorities that Yale and Cornell will come to an amicable agreement relative to a race this year, there is still some doubt about the matter. Reports from the Cornell Navy say that even the most conservative members of the council are becoming antagonistic to Yale because of her dictatory terms.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- The recent tragic death of Miss Leila Herbert, the daughter of the ex-Secretary of the Navy, is given as the reason for the suicide which occurred to-day of Miss Annie Virginia Wells, an accomplished young society woman and the daughter of Lewis S. Wells, a well-known attorney.
" Who Is Our Savior?" was the subject of the Rev. Dr. Joseph Silverman's address yesterday at Temple Emanu-El before a large and interested congregation. The preacher said:

The lake navigation season just closed was one of the most active on record, and the statistics now published give their own evidence of the restoration of prosperity. The first part of the season business was lighter than usual, but the deficiency was more than compensated for in the later months.

INDIANA, Penn., Dec. 26. -- Milton Neal and his aged wife were shot to death by an unknown person at their home, near Jacksonville, nine miles southwest of this place, some time on Christmas Day. They were found dead at 9 o'clock last night by their son Henry, who was passing the house and stopped to pay them a Christmas call.

Those who did not get up early yesterday morning found, when they looked out of their windows, the air filled with snow-flakes and the roofs and trees and ground covered with a mantle of white. The flakes were thick and large and pretty, if not promising, for large flakes do not always mean good sleighing.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26. -- Friday, which will witness the close of the great Leiter deal in wheat on the Board of Trade, bids fair to prove memorable to the trade. No great excitement is expected in the wheat pit, but in oats a squeeze of shorts may take place.
LONDON, Dec. 27. -- A special despatch from Shanghai says:

J. Havelock Wilson, who is a labor Member of Parliament and also President of the Firemen's, Sailors' and Dock Workers' Union of England, called yesterday on the Central Labor Union. He had just returned from Nashville, Tenn., where he went as fraternal delegate from his union to the convention of the American Federation of Labor.

A train on the Sixth Avenue elevated line left Chambers Street Station at 11 o'clock last night after eight Greeks, all more or less intoxicated, had boarded the third car. In passing through the car the men stumbled over a number of women and created considerable disturbance among the passengers.

At the last annual meeting of the General Society of the Daughters of the Revolution it was suggested that interest in the society and its principles might be increased by the organization of a junior rank to take in those who by reason of youth are not eligible to the older body. A resolution was adopted Auxiliary.

Revivified, rejuvenated, "born again," bright-eyed, and as full of good humor as an egg is of meat, Dr. Frank W. Gunsaulus has returned from the sanitarium at Alma, Mich., where he has spent some pleasant and profitable months. He was stricken with sciatic rheumatism. He came back as quietly as he had gone.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Dec. 26. -- City Judge Schatz refuses to move from his present courtroom to the handsome courtroom provided for him in the new quarters of the municipal government. He contends that it is not legal for him to sit in a building where liquor is sold. In the building recently acquired for municipal purposes there is a saloon.

The wildcats of the Rio Grande country are of two kinds -- the ordinary, dirtily colored "bobtail," which is a sneak thief and a robber, and the beautifully marked "leopard," which is a warrior born. There is nothing in nature exceed the ferocity of this small animal when it turns in the open, facing a dozen hounds, and gives battle for its life.

HAVANA, Dec. 26. -- This evening Capt. Gen. Blanco gave a banquet to the officers of the German corvette Stein. Forty guests were present, including the Spanish Admiral, the Mayor of Havana, and other naval and civil authorities.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26. -- An attractive and useful work will be distributed soon from the War Department. It is a quarto of 133 pages, entitled "Medals of Honor Issued by the War Department Up To and Including Oct. 31, 1897, with the Laws, Orders, and Regulations Relative to the Medal, the Ribbon to be Worn with the Medal, and the Knot to be Worn in Lieu of the Medal."

The will of the late Daniel W. Powers was admitted to probate in the Surrogate's Court by Judge Benton yesterday afternoon. No mention is made of the Art Gallery, and therefore that fine piece of property is lost to the City of Rochester unless Mr. Powers made some secret agreement in regard to it when he placed his building in the hands of a corporation.

Chairman Henry A. Goulden of the Jeffersonian Democracy Conference Committee has appointed the following Committee of Twenty to report on a plan of organization: Benjamin Doblin, Twenty-ninth Assembly District, Chairman; First Council District, E.M. Klein and E.J. McCarthy; Second Council District, J.L. Murphy and R. Schlaekenbach; Third District, T.B.

LONDON, Dec. 26. -- The stringency in the money market slightly increased last week. The Bank of England did a large business in bills at 3 per cent., and loans at 3 1/2. A rise in the bank rate is considered possible. The gold demand continues strong, but the prevailing discount rates are expected to prevent withdrawals for the Continent and the United States.

Two men, brothers, though known by different names, lay side by side at the Morgue yesterday in fulfillment of their last request, that they be in death as they were in life -- inseperable. They were Terrence Brady, sixty years old, and Michael McDermott, sixty-two years old. Ever since they could remember they had been always together, and to-day they will be laid to rest for their joint eternal sleep.

The burletta called "The Telephone Girl," in its present condition, will not greatly help the "managing directors" of the Casino to solve any grave problems that may be staring them in the face concerning the policy of their place of public entertainment. They have expended a deal of money on this thing for stage furniture and dresses, and they have contrived some very handsome pictures.

TRENTON, Dec. 27. -- The New Jersey State Teachers' Association opened its annual session here this afternoon. There were nearly 300 teachers in attendance. To-day's session was devoted to the reading of various papers and educational subjects.

In lightly assuming the contagious nature of rheumatism, the doctors presume on the forbearance of the people. It is not a disease about which anything new can be affirmed without an appearance of reckless audacity. Upstart diseases of modern origin, less common, less painful, and less dangerous to life, reveal under the microscope fantastic germs as their source.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27. -- The Coliseum, which was burned on Christmas eve, was set on fire by an explosion of gasoline. Lolita, a dancer in the Cuban village, said to-day that Frank Murphy, an employe in the X-ray booth, confessed to her that he caused the explosion. She said:

One of the most significant indications of the importance attached in Japan to the new situation created by Russia and Germany is the return to power of Marquis ITO. He is undoubtedly the most complete master of world-politics, as well as the most prevailing political personality, that the new Japan has known.
The five-story brick building at 72 Duane Street was destroyed, with its contents, about 1 o'clock this morning.

Richard Croker, at the Murray Hill Hotel last night, said that he expected to go to Lakewood to-day. He went yesterday morning to Woodlawn Cemetery to attend the burial of his brother there.
