He preserved his wonted reticence with regard to appointments, and said that many changes might be made in the slate.

SCRANTON, Penn., Dec. 27. -- Six men were injured seriously by an explosion of gas to-day in the Bellevue shaft of the Delaware and Lackawanna Company. John Alexander, a laborer, and John O'Brien were hurt so badly that they may die. The explosion, which is thought to have been caused by a naked lamp, occurred in a gangway of a fourteen-foot vein, where eighteen men were working.

MONTREAL, Dec. 27. -- Because they did not get ,the usuaJ Christmas delicacies this year, the convicts at St Vincent de Paul Penitentiary for the last two nights have kept up an lneoant howl. There were no religious services yesterday, and no work was done to-day. VVardcn Foster has -threatened tO use the lash if quiet is not restored.

Mayor STRONG would have difficulty in justifying to himself, or to anybody else, his failure to "hold up" the bill for the bridging of the Manhattan valley by a viaduct. He has done the next best thing in frankly owning that he was remiss in letting the bill go past him last year.

The report that the Mutual Reserve Fund Life Association was calling in the issue of ordinary life policies and compelling the holders to take a new form of policy at greater cost or lose the money paid on the old ones was denied at the company's office, at 309 Broadway, yesterday by the officials.

James Flannigan of 401 East Forty-eighth Street died Sunday afternoon from the effects of a mouthful of roach poison, taken from a jug which he supposed contained whisky. Patrick McNulty, John Hyland, and Victor Lindenholm, who were employed with him by John Lynch, a van man of 779 Third Avenue, also drank from the jug and were rendered very ill.

When the case against Norberth Preffer, charged with criminal libel, came up in the Centre Street Police Court yesterday, the defendant failed to appear. Magistrate Hedges created something of a sensation by announcing that he had received a letter from Pfeffer, stating that he was unable to secure the witnesses necessary to prove his case, and that he had left the city.

Horace G. Burt, Third Vice President of the Chicago and Northwestern Railway Company, succeeds S.H.H. Clark as President of the Union Pacific Railway Company. Mr. Clark's retirement was decided on by himself, because of his failing health, during the Autumn. He is now prostrated by illness at San Antonio, Texas.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27. -- The conferees selected to formulate a plan of settlement of the affairs of the Chestnut Street National Bank and the Chestnut Street Trust and Savings Fund Company, of which William M. Singerly, proprietor of The Record, was President, and which closed their doors last Thursday, to-night presented that plan for the consideration of depositors and creditors.

It was reported yesterday that the Milk Trust, or Farm and Dairy Product Company, will, in addition to controlling the milk supply of the Greater New York, also go into the butter business. It is to build creameries and make the surplus milk into butter, and sell the butter in the milk wagons. This, it is said, will be an additional cause for the grocers to oppose the new trust.

Mr. CREMER, the English apostle of arbitration, took occasion the other day to remark that the Chinese incident afforded a splendid example of the advantages of an Anglo-American alliance. If only Great Britain and the United States would speak together, he said, the plundering of the heathen would be stopped.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- The most profound distress prevails among many thousands of people in Cuba. Starvation not only impends, but is an actual fact. The President has been informed of the facts from sources whose credibility cannot be doubted. He has gone to the length of his Constitutional power in calling the state of affairs to the attention of the American people.

The hearing of evidence in the contest over the will of De Witt C. Lawrence was resumed before Surrogate Arnold yesterday. The contestants are the five children of the deceased by his first wife, who desire the will providing for the widow to be set aside.
Following are topics which yesterday received Wall Street attention:

At a meeting of the Board of Governors of the Democratic Club last-night Richard Croker was by a unanimous vote elected a member of the board. John Fox, Perry Belmont, and Vice President O'Dwyer were appointed a committee to inform Mr. Croker at the Murray Hill Hotel of his election. It was said at 11 o'clock that Mr. Croker would accept the place.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 27. -- The famous Hilton Trophy, which was won by the Georgia Rifle Team, at Sea Girt last September, has never reached the winners, and the statement is made to-day that the prize has, in all probability, been lost in shipment.

LONDON, Dec. 27. -- There was a fire this evening in the dry goods store of Messrs. Jermyn Perry, High Street, King's Lynn, (Lynn-Regis,) Norfolk. The local fire engine collapsed and the flames spread rapidly.

Charles Ray, the colored janitor of the colored tenement house at 139 West Thirty-third Street, yesterday gave to Policeman Reid of the West Thirtieth Street Station four pieces of lead pipe, sealed at each end and tied together. Ray said that he had kicked them out of a dark corner in the cellar and expressed the opinion that if they were dynamite bombs something might have broken loose when he kicked.

All hail to you for giving the laity an opportunity to discuss the question of theology. Heretofore it has been theirs to listen, but now that they may speak it is to be hoped that the growing unanimity among the laymen of all churches may find expression, in spite of the old and narrow limits within which it is the province of most clergymen to endeavor to confine them.

During the halcyon days of the Democratic Party in old York County, Penn., some time in the forties, when to get the nomination for the county office was the main thing to insure an election, the party leaders had much to do, many consultations among themselves and with prominent men in several townships.

The long-standing claims against the city of the contracting firms of Brown, Howard Co., (now represented by Walston H. Brown as receiver,) and O'Brien Clark, to whom the contracts for building the new Croton Aqueduct between the Gate House at Croton Park and the Jerome Park Reservoir were let in 1884, for extra work in its construction were settled yesterday.

A handsome stone, commemorating the beginning of work on the North River water front improvement, was unveiled at the foot of Bethune Street yesterday before Mayor Strong and other city officials and a party of prominent citizens and representatives of various commercial bodies and shipping interests.

LONDON, Dec. 28. -- The Daily Chronicle this morning prints a letter, a column and a half long, signed by Adjutant General John E. Ballaine of the State of Washington, denouncing Mr. William T. Stead's book "Satan's Invisible World" and Mr. Stead himself as "displaying the densest ignorance of everything American."

TACOMA, Dec. 27. -- Russian domination of Korea has been the leading topic of discussion in the Japanese newspapers for weeks. Ever since Japan overthrew China's claims of Korea by the late war, Japan and Russia have been struggling for ascendency in Korea. Last February Russia allowed the publication at St. Petersburg of the secret Russian-Japanese treaty regarding Korean affairs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27. -- Clifford Sifton, Canadian Minister of the Interior, and J.A. McKenna of the same department, by invitation of Secretary Alger arrived here tonight to confer with the Secretary relative to Klondike relief measures. The Secretary originally intended to go to Ottawa, but has been suffering from an attack of grip, which confines him closely to his home.

The Intercollegiate chess tournament in which Columbia, Harvard, Yale, and Princeton are engaged was begun yesterday at 2 P.M. in the hall of the Columbia Grammar School, 34 and 36 East Fifty-first Street. All of the regular representatives of the four universities were present, except Seward of Columbia, and his place was taken by G.R. Jacobus.

Everybody can understand the hilarity of the English populace over the announcement that the two old-fashioned German ships which were dispatched to Chinese waters there to "preach the gospel of his Majesty's anointed person" have brought up at Spithead to take in coal.

The proceedings which seemed of deeper interest to more members of the Medical Society of the County of New York, at its stated meeting last evening, than any other were the final report of the Committee on the Abuse of Medical Charity, accompanied by the text of an amended Dispensary bill, and action thereon.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27. -- All the activity of to-day's grain market was confined to the morning. During the afternoon all the advance in wheat caused by smaller world's shipments and the Oriental war talk was lost, May closing at 1/4 to 3/8 cent decline. Corn and oats were both very strong and advanced 1/2 and 3/8 cent respectively.

NEW ROCHELLE, Dec. 27. -- Two arrests were made to-day by the police in connection with the murder of Frank Feyo on Friday night. One was that of Mrs. Amelia Lembo wife of the suspected murderer. She was arrested at the home of relatives at 127 Christopher Street, New York, by Sergeant Cody, and brought here with her two-year-old daughter.

-- It is more than a little strange that so much comment should have been excited in medical and other circles by the case of that Swiss woman who survived the removal of a part of her digestive apparatus. Human beings long ago demonstrated the power to get along well enough without organs that make much more pretension to utility than stomachs do.

The second of the subscription dances held under the auspices of Mrs. Hiram Cleaver Kroh of 114 West Seventy-ninth Street took place at Sherry's last night. Almost all the members of the class were present, and there was an unusual number of guests.

UTICA, Dec. 27. -- The Rev. Gilbert Reid, who is in this country in the interest of the International Institute to be located in Pekin, China, and specially sanctioned by the Chinese Government, gives his views on the present crisis in China. He says:

OMAHA, Dec. 27. -When the news of the appointment of Horace G. Burr to be President of the new company became public there was a general expression of satisfaction. General Manager Dickinson said: "I 'consider it a most excellent appointment and have all along looked for it. Mr. Burt is an accomplished railroad man." There is much uneasiness concerning a general impression that some sweeping changes will be trade.

One of the unfortunate results of an over-stocked market of turkey is that the surplus has to be put into cold storage at an expense of about 1 cent per pound, and the fowl becomes dry. This Christmas the surplus is unusually large, and between fifteen and twenty tons are being put into cold storage by the commission houses, but the quality is also remarkably good.

FALL RIVER, Dec. 27. -- The Cotton Manufacturers' Association considered to-day and declined to accept the proposition drawn up last night by the Operatives' Conference Committee. The proposition to the manufacturers was that, instead of the cut of 11 1-9 per cent. in wages recently announced to take effect in January, the reduction be 5 1/2 per cent. until March 1, when another conference should be held to adjust differences between employes and employers.

A Christmas tree, illuminated for the delectation of the little ones of Mrs. John Tiesdale's family in the basement of the five-story double apartment house, at 341 East Forty-first Street, took fire yesterday morning and resulted in injury to two persons, $5,000 damage to property, and any number of hairbreadth escapes and heroic rescues.

WICHITA, Kan., Dec. 27. -- The mutilated body of Charles Drake was found by the roadside a few miles west of Medford, Oklahoma Territory, and Ed Freeman, George Thomas, and three women, who refused to give their names, are under arrest, charged with the murder. On Christmas Drake was in Medford and displayed a roll of bills in the presence of Freeman and Thomas, who were strangers to him.

PORT TOWNSEND, Washington, Dec. 27. -- By the steamer City of Topeka, which has arrived from Juneau, it is learned that the Nowell Gold Mining Company and Berner's Bay Mining and Milling Company have passed into the hands of a receiver. The receiver is E.F. Cassel of Juneau, formerly of Seattle.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 27. -- Frank Barbian, an Italian, and Harry McCullum, colored, prisoners in the Essex County Penitentiary, at Caldwell, attempted suicide this morning. Barbian will recover, McCullum is dead.

Official announcement was made last night that George D. Gideon of Philadelphia will not be a candidate for the Presidency of the League of American Wheelmen. He has issued a statement that he is not and has not been a candidate.

As we foreshadowed a few days ago, the Lords have given their final decision in favor of the legality of trade-union methods by allowing the appeal in the critical case of Allen versus Flood. It is impossible to overestimate the importance of that result, and the lucid judgments delivered by Lord Herschell and the other Law Lords of the majority mark a turning point in a great social history.
James H. Fitzgerald has sold, for about $26,000, the plot, 274 and 276 Mott Street, 40 by $6.11 1/2.

Following the statement of George D. Gideon of Philadelphia declining to stand for the League of American Wheelmen Presidency, strife over which the organization is greatly agitated has narrowed to contests for the minor offices. Isaac B. Potter, the candidate for re-election to the executive chair, is working on the assumption that the contest has ended in his favor.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Dec. 28. -- The jury in the case of Herman Sachse, charged with murdering Bertrand L. Hotchkiss, at his home, in Killingworth, Aug. 27, returned a verdict of not guilty this afternoon.
Primaries for the election of delegates to the Tammany General Committee and the Assembly District Committees were held last night.

WICHITA, Kan., Dec. 28. -- At El Reno, Oklahoma, this afternoon Gustav Thelan, President of the Stock Exchange Bank; Michael Eichhoff, cashier; Charles A. Newman, assistant cashier, and Louis Eichhoff, a member of the Board of Directors, were arrested on the charge of receiving deposits when the bank was known by them to be in a failing condition.

NEWARK, Dec. 28. -- T.J. Purdy, a New York lawyer who appeared before Vice Chancellor Emery to-day as counsel for the defense in the suit brought by J. Edward Addicks and John Bacot against the Fidelity Title and Deposit Company of this city, created somewhat of a sensation by the vigorous allegations made in an affidavit submitted by him.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- The suggestion of Representative Lacey of Iowa, in an interview printed here this morning, that the suspension of the Chestnut Street Bank of Philadelphia constituted an argument against the plan of Secretary Gage for the issue of a certain proportion of bank notes upon commercial assets, excited some surprise among Treasury officials and others who have studied the plan of the Secretary.

Barred windows in the rear of a Delancey Street store to prevent burglars gaining an entrance came near being the cause of the death by burning of two men. The bars were screwed to the woodwork of the windows, and could easily have been wrenched off with a jimmy by a burglar of ordinary intelligence.
LONDON, Dec. 28. -- The Globe this afternoon says a private telegram reached London yesterday evening, announcing that over twenty British warships have arrived at Port Hamilton, Korea.

Edward J. Ratcliffe, the actor convicted of assaulting his wife, who, since his conviction and the jury's recommendation to mercy, has been keeping up his spirits by the hope that sentence in his case would be either suspended or would be only a fine, was sentenced by Judge Newburger, in General Sessions, yesterday morning to six months in the penitentiary.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Secretary Gage was seen to-day on his return from New York and questioned as to the truth of the published report that he had tendered his resignation to the President, and that it had been firmly declined with many expressions of confidence and appreciation of his ability as shown in his administration of the Treasury Department.

On the "news" of Secretary Gage's resignation, which Wall Street traders magnified into a Cabinet crisis, the stock market during the first few hours yesterday showed weakness. The bears picked out certain stocks and hammered away industriously during the morning, and as a result generally lower prices were registered.

TACOMA, Washington, Dec. 28. -- The peculiar and remarkable contract under which Russia seized the Korean finances and customs and thereby forced out J. McLeavy Brown, the representative of English interests recently, and which so offended England that the British Pacific squadron has been dispatched to Chemulpo, near Seoul, the capital of Korea, has been translated, and for the first time is now made public.

The last meeting of the old-charter Common Council, or Board of Aldermen, (unless a special meeting should be called,) was held yesterday afternoon in the newly finished room adjoining the present Aldermanic chamber, which will be used as a committee room of the new Council of the Municipal Assembly.

The play in the Intercollegiate Chess Tournament improved considerably yesterday. At every table the games were more closely contested, except at the one where Southard of Harvard met Seward of Columbia. The Harvard representative soon won an advantage in position and scored the game in rather brilliant style.

LONDON, Dec. 29. -- A dispatch to The Times from Kobe, Japan, says the dissolution of the Diet has greatly angered the political parties. It is probable that the Marquis Ito, former Premier, and Count Okuma, a former Foreign Minister, will form a coalition Ministry, with a vigorous foreign policy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- The Japanese Minister has not yet been advised of the resignation of the entire Cabinet, and he feels that while the resignations may have been tendered, the Emperor will not accept them until it becomes apparent that an entirely new Cabinet under Marquis Ito can be framed.

John Healey died at the Harlem Hospital yesterday and his friend of many years, George H. Linconln, is a prisoner accused of inflicting the stab wounds that caused his death. The men were reared together at Clinton, Mass., and when Healey came to New York he went to live with Lincoln and his wife at 301 East One Hundred and Twenty-third Street, until he obtained work in a restaurant at 2,403 Second Avenue.

While it may not be graciously nor intelligently doubted that the truest and gentlest and best matchmaking in the world is generally practiced and successfully conducted in parlors, parks, watering places, dancing academies, and other respectable and delightful resorts, yet there is another kind of matchmaking (my reference here being to lucifer matches, and not to matrimonial matches,) in regard to which I now desire to submit a few brief remarks.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Controller of the Currency Eckels to-day expressed his approval of the plan for the voluntary liquidation of the Chestnut Street National Bank of Philadelphia. He said:

Mrs. Thelka Keyes of 45 Frost Street, Williamsburg., was acquitted, in the Lee Avenue Police Court, yesterday, of the charge of stealing a spool of thread and a pair of stockings from the dry goods store of John J. Gorman, at 225 Grand Street, Williamsburg.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Dec. 28. -Mayor Fiske was arrested this afternoon upon the order of City Judge Schatz. After holding the fort until this morning, the Judge, who, since Monday morning, has been resisting the removal of the furniture of his courtroom to the new municipal quarters, was apparently bested to-day.
We are not surprised that there is an anti-civil service reform society started in Kentucky, and still less that it is secret.

The centre of interest in the Far East is suddenly transferred to Korea. The Russian seizure of Kin-Chau, at the north end of the Gulf of Pe-chi-li, gives Russia the entire control of the Eastern shore of the gulf, which her control of Korea would extend to the open Pacific. Her action in taking possession of Korea seems to be quite as piratical as that of Germany in the seizure of Kiao-Chau.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- The Canadian Minister of the Interior, Mr. Sifton, and his secretary, Mr. McKenna, were waited upon at their hotel this morning by Assistant Secretary Meikeljohn of the War Department and welcomed in the name of Secretary Alger. They were then driven around the suburbs until noon, when Secretary Alger, who had arisen from his sick bed, entertained his visitors at luncheon.
The first annual dinner of the New York State Society of Certified Accountants was given at the Waldorf-Astoria last night.

The announcement in our columns yesterday morning that some of the larger savings banks of this city will give notice at the opening of the new year that a slightly lower rate of "interest" will be paid in the future should give the Postmaster General something to think about in regard to his plan for postal savings banks.

The action of the Brooklyn Board of Aldermen in handing over a number of important streets to Patrick H. Flynn and his East River and Atlantic Ocean Railroad Company received a blow yesterday in the shape of a decision from the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the Second Department.

A nice distinction in tariff classification came up for adjudication before the Customs Board of Classification yesterday. Among the numerous protests filed against rulings of local customs officers in the matter of importations of agricultural products,fruits, provisions, , was one relating to damaged pineapples.

LAKEWOOD, Dec. 28. -- The reception parlor of the Lakewood Hotel was the Mecca to-day of most of the Tammany Hall leaders. On the early afternoon train there came Richard Croker, Mayor-elect Van Wyck, John F. Carroll, Senator Thomas F. Grady, Nathan Straus, and Andrew Freedman. A later train brought Bernard J. York of Brooklyn, John J. Ryan, Senator Timothy D. Sullivan, and a number of others.

Sixteen years ago, in The Brooklyn Eagle, I proposed (by way of amendment to Mr. Duncan C. McMillan's plan of a voting by "canvasses," so called,) that "nominations" be made at regular nominating elections, each voter stating on his "nominating ballot" what "party," if any, he desired to support, and also what person he (the voter) wished to have nominated as that party's candidate.

The twenty-fifth annual report of the New York County Visiting Committee of the State Charities Aid Association is in some important respects a dismal story of the charitable institutions of this city. Perhaps the most startling declaration is that officially made in the report of the Visiting Committee that of 366 children under six months old admitted to the Infants' Hospital on Randall's Island during the year 1896, 354 were dead by April 15, 1897.

Whitehouse Porter have sold for Natalie Alexandre the four-story brownstone-front dwelling, 2 West Sixteenth Street, 35 by 83 and irregular, together with a stable at the rear and the right of way to Fifteenth Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- The Spanish Minister has received a dispatch from Havana, stating that the Autonomist Mayors of Bejucal and Juanabacoa had been inaugurated amid great enthusiasm, the people receiving them with shouts of "Long live Spain."
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 28. -- Kathryn Kidder, the tragedienne, is ill at the home of friends in this city. Her company has been disbanded and sent back to New York.

Gossip was busy yesterday in the Wall Street district with the affairs of the Equitable Gas Light Company, the New York and East River Gas Company, and the New Amsterdam Gas Company. The plan of union and the agreement with the Central Trust Company of the Equitable and East River have been carried out by the depositing of the necessary amount of stock with the trust company to effect their consolidation.

It was the opinion yesterday of the New York representative of the Overman Wheel Company, which assigned for the benefit of its creditors Monday afternoon, that the embarrassment was temporary and that business would be resumed within a few days. Cycle makers and dealers of this city shared the same opinion, as well as Ernest R. Franks, Secretary of the National Board of Trade of Cycle Manufacturers.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28. -- The statement of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company and the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company for November shows gross receipts for the railroad company of $1,924,717; expenses, $992,307; net receipts, $932,410, a decrease compared with November, 1896, of $48,867.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28. -- A goat with long, flowing beard, sharply pointed horns, and a head like a battering ram amused a crowd of nearly 300 newsboys and street loiterers, and incidentally blocked all forms of traffic in State Street, near Monroe, this morning. An army of street arabs fell upon the goat.

The National Sculpture Society and its President are to be congratulated upon their successful defense of the aesthetic interests of the city. The action of the society makes it certain that the monument will not be erected upon the same plateau with the Grant Monument. It gives occasion also for a period of deliberation upon the question involved, and this is in itself a good thing.
Following are topics which yesterday received Wall Street attention:

CAMDEN, N.J., Dec. 28. -- Supreme Court Justice Garrison to-day ordered the Camden County Grand Jury to return at once an indictment against Eli Shaw, charged with killing his mother and his grandmother. The Court then fixed Jan. 3 as the date on which the trial of the young man should begin.

NEW BRUNSWICK, Dec. 28. -- An intoxicated motorman imperiled seventeen lives besides his own on the line of the Brunswick Traction Company, between Milltown, three miles away, and this city, about 11 o'clock last night. Conductor James Wright noticed that Tom Miller, the motorman, was in no condition to run the car when they left Milltown, but thought that there was no danger.

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 28. -- Five hundred representatives of the Republican Party in Indiana, outside of Indianapolis, attended a conference here to-day. The meeting was for talk and little else, and was the largest "off year" meeting the party ever held. The meeting was held a little later in the year than usual, in order that the Republican United States Senator from the State and the Republican Representatives might be here, and they all came.

St. Leo's Roman Catholic Church, in East Twenty-eighth Street, was filled at noon yesterday with witnesses of the marriage of Miss Mabel Grant Hatch, daughter of Roswell D. Hatch of this city, and Eugene Kelly Austin. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Father Nevins of the Church of St. Paul the Apostle, at Columbus Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, assisted by the rector of St. Leo's, the Rev. Father Thomas J. Ducey.
Following is a list of reappraisements of merchandise announced by the Board of General Appraisers yesterday:

BOSTON, Dec. 28. -- Frederick Cook was arrested here to-day charged with having set fire on two occasions to the Hotel Tontine, at New Haven. The last time was on Christmas morning. Cook admitted having set the fire when under cross-examination at Police Headquarters. He claims that five years ago Manager White of the hotel did him a wrong, and out of revenge he ignited the fires.

The master barbers want the Legislature to come to their aid to check the ever increasing army of barbers, which has resulted in many places in reducing the price of a shave to 5 cents, and sometimes with a shine thrown in.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28. -- Consul Wiesike, at Managua, in a report to the State Department, dated Oct. 19, says:

-- Some new name should be invented for contests like that in the Madison Square Garden last Saturday evening and the one to take place on the same track at the end of this week. To call such events "bicycle races" is a misuse of language for which there is hardly the shadow of an excuse, unless, indeed, the pacemakers are regarded as the principals, and even then the shadow is somewhat vague and faint.

Charles H. Contoit, a member of one of New York's oldest families, who died on Dec. 5, at his residence, 728 Fifth Avenue, has left his estate, estimated to be worth considerably over $1,000,000, to charity. His will, which was executed on June 9, 1886, and two codicils dated March 15, 1887, and Jan. 17, 1893, have been filed for probate with the Surrogate.

NEWPORT, R.I., Dec. 28. -- Residents of the "Hill Colony" and army and navy officers stationed here and their families gave a subscription dance in the rooms of the Casino Club last evening, the first of a series to be held this Winter. The rooms, used by the permission of the Casino Governors, were decorated tastefully with Christmas hangings.

The wedding of Miss Sarah Desier Pattison, daughter of the late Elias J. Pattison, and Frederick Nichols of Boston, took place in Christ Protestant Episcopal Church, West Seventy-first Street and the Boulevard, at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The rector, the Rev. Dr. Jacob S. Shipman, officiated, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Cornelius B. Smith of St. James's Protestant Episcopal Church.
CHICAGO, Dec. 28. -- Martin Julian to-day, on behalf of Robert Fitzsimmons, made the following signed statement:

CHICAGO, Dec. 28. -- Joseph Leiter apparently has won a victory in his fight with George A. Seaverns, the grain elevator owner, as to the quality of wheat to be delivered on Leiter's contracts. Leiter's commission men, Alexander Geddes Co., sent the steamer Iron King last week to Seaverns's elevator, the Alton, to load with No. 2 red Winter wheat.

FRAMINGHAM, Mass., Dec. 28. -- John Reed, who has been successively arraigned in Clinton, Lowell, and Cambridge as an alleged gold-brick swindler, was brought here to-day by a State officer and charged with the larceny of $1,500 from Selma D. Hardy of this town in May, 1896. Reed was held in $2,500 bail, and the hearing continued until Jan. 4.

OTTAWA, Dec. 28. -- The Trades and Navigation Returns, soon to be issued, will show the total imports entered for consumption were $111,294,021, as against imports of $110,587,480 the preceding year. The duty collected amounted to $19,891,997, as against $20,219,037 the preceding year.
The New York County Medical Society as we understand its action, proposes to put the regulation of dispensaries in the hands of the State Board of Charities.

SEATTLE, Washington, Dec. 28. -- The steamer Alki arrived here to-day, bringing advices from Dawson City up to Nov. 25. The Alki's passengers included thirty persons who left Dawson between Nov. 22 and Nov. 25. All, without exception, say there will be no starvation at Dawson this Winter or next Spring.

The Catholic Child-Study Congress, which was determined upon at the Champlain Summer School, was begun in Columbus Hall, in West Sixtieth Street, last evening, and will continue to-day and to-morrow. Many school teachers from this city and Brooklyn were in the audience, as well as others of both sexes who are under the guidance of the Paulist Fathers, who are in charge of the congress.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 29. -- Despite denials that any new form of agreement has been made by the coal-carrying railroads and the owners of Ohio soft coal mines, it is asserted by a gentleman well posted in railway and coal matters that an agreement has been made which is "not a trust, but simply an arrangement."

CHICAGO, Dec. 29. -- Adolph Moses, a prominent Jewish lawyer, of this city, delivered an address before the Associated Lodges of the B'nai B'rith this evening, in which he reviewed the evidence in the case of former Capt. Dreyfus of the French Army, saying that the only conclusion to be drawn from it was that the accused was innocent.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 29. -- That the anti-Hanna Republicans, led by Charles Kurtz, will test the strength of their forces in the organization of the Legislature was indicated by the unofficial announcement today that Mason of Cleveland would oppose Boxwell of Warren County for the Speakership.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 29. -- In January the Atlantic Coast Line will add to its system an important line by securing the Charleston and Western Carolina Railroad.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Dec. 29. -- Samuel Gompers, President of the American Federation of Labor, has replied in an open letter to Secretary Gage's recent letter, taking exception to the resolutions passed by the federation in reference to Gage's financial bill.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 29. -- The convention of the American Economic Association opened to-day in the Chamber of Commerce Building, with an address of welcome by Prof. F.H. Giddings of Columbia University, who presided. He eulogized the late President of the association, Gen. Francis A. Walker, who died during the present year.

William A. White Sons have sold for Meyer Gruhn, the nine-story business building 7 Lafayette Place, 25 by 100. It is said that the buyer is an investor and that the consideration is wholly cash, but further particulars are withheld for the present.

There were some remarkable circumstances connected with the death of three-year-old Howard Polster and the attempted suicide of the mother yesterday morning at their home, 436 East One Hundred and Twenty-first Street. The parents had lost four children. The fifth was dying. The parents were in despair. The father and a doctor went out to get something to relieve the infant.

Several important facts and additions to the history of the Jewish people, both in this and other countries, were brought out at the sixth annual meeting of the American Jewish Historical Society, which held its first day's session yesterday in the assembly rooms of the Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Forty-third Street.

The outgoing Police Board held its last regular meeting yesterday. Patrolman James J. Scanlan of the East Twenty-second Street Station, who was dismissed on a charge of intoxication several months ago, was reinstated and fined thirty days' pay.

A wedding that created special interest among musical people was that of Miss Alice Garrigue, the well-known soprano and vocal teacher, and Prof. Lewis Freeman Mott, who is at the head of the English Department in the College of the City of New York. The ceremony was performed at 8 o'clock last night, in the bride's music room, in the home of her sister, Mrs. Ettore Montecchi, at the Strathmore, Fifty-second Street and Broadway.

The carnival planned by The New York Journal to celebrate the birth of the Greater New York to-morrow at midnight promises to be worth attending. The procession is expected to be two miles long, and to furnish a notable display of floats and gay costumes. It will contain half a dozen bands.
I read last week your editorial on the Loud bill for postal reform, also the letter by Mr. Green which you published on Friday morning, and your editorial of yesterday.

BOSTON, Dec. 29. -- By order of the United States District Court, the remaining assets of the defunct Maverick National Bank were sold at auction to-day by R.L. Day Co. The securities, which were in the nature of unpaid notes, executions, and judgments, amounting to $1,095,890, brought just $429.

When the Board of Education yesterday adjourned the last meeting for 1897 it adjourned to reconvene Jan. 3, to take up the discussion of the long-pending and much-disputed salary schedule. Some doubts were expressed as to the wisdom of fixing that date. Seven members begin new terms by reappointment and one by appointment on Jan. 1.

LONDON, Dec. 29. -- Inspector Corry of the Scotland Yard detective department is making inquiries at Oldcastle, County Meath, Ireland, in connection with the death of Peter Doggett, who was cut to pieces in a dough-mixing machine in New York City last August.

LAMBERTVILLE, N.J., Dec. 29. -- Chief of Police Morse was notified to-day that two strangers had victimized many residents in this place and vicinity. The two men came here on Monday and put up at a hotel. The following day they hired two carriages and started out to sell soap about the town and country districts at $5 a box.

The Church Club of New York held its regular monthly meeting at the clubrooms, 578 Fifth Avenue, last night. The subject under discussion was "The Churchman's Civic Duties," and among the speakers were Bishop Potter, Everett P. Wheeler, and Gen. Wager Swayne. Many men prominent in church circles of this city were guests of the club.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- Clifford Sifton, the Canadian Minister of the Interior, accompanied by Assistant Secretary Meiklejohn, called upon Attorney General McKenna and Secretary of the Treasury Gage this afternoon. In the course of Mr. Sifton's visit to both these Cabinet officers the question of getting supplies into the Klondike was discussed.

The publication yesterday of a synopsis of the twenty-fifth annual report of the New York County Visiting Committee of the State Charities Aid Association disturbed the serenity of some of the officers of the institutions which were criticised in the report.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 29. -- The miners' strike in the coal fields along the line of the Cincinnati Southern Railway in Kentucky and Tennessee, which began last May over a reduction of wages of 10 per cent. inaugurated by the operators of the various mines in the territory, was to-day declared off by the men.

" C.W.L.," in his excellent article on "Careless Writing," published in your issue of Dec. 27, says: "While so much is being said nowadays as to the deficiencies of college students in English composition, a word ought to be said by way of suggestion that those who are in the position of exemplars in such matters ought to be cautioned lest they lay themselves open to the charge of carelessness in their writings.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 29. -- George R. Hodgdon, the well-known proprietor of the Tremont Hotel here and of the Haynes House in Springfield, Mass., was arrested in the latter place last night in connection with the attempt to burn the Hotel Tontine, in this city, on Christmas morning. He was brought into the police court this morning, together with Frederick Cook, who was arrested in Boston yesterday.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 29. -- The Legislature will meet in extra session on Jan. 17, a call to that effect having been issued this evening by Gov. Taylor. The Legislature is asked to consider bills to authorize Memphis to extend its corporate limits and issue bonds for the purchase, building, or extension of water works, and to build schools and complete its sewerage system.

MOUNT VERNON, Dec. 29. -- The victory of Mayor Fiske over City Court Judge Schatz was made complete this morning. Judge Schatz, seeing that he was beaten, capitulated and gracefully as possible under the circumstances held court in the new municipal quarters in the Lucas Building.

The fact that, in the union which is to result in the Greater New York, Brooklyn will figure as a bride not only dowerless but actually with a deficit, has been troubling the officials of that municipality for several weeks, and their distress was aggravated yesterday by the publication of a statement attributed to Controller-elect Coler that an extra tax would have to be laid to square this account.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29. -- The Board of Appeals appointed jointly by the Board of Trade and the State Grain and Warehouse Inspection Commission, to-day decided for the second time that the wheat delivered by George Seaverns, the elevator owner, to Joseph Leiter from the Alton elevator to the store steamer Iron King is graded No. 2 red Winter wheat.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 29. -- Uncas, the last surviving son of Lexington, the celebrated racehorse, died suddenly near Crescent, Mo. His death was due to the rupture of a blood vessel. He was twenty-two years old.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 29. -- The oil well cordage manufacturers and dealers formed an association here to-day to advance the price of cordage in the oil well supply trade. Another meeting will be held at the Monongahela House Jan. 19. About 100 dealers and manufacturers, representing 95 per cent. of the trade, were represented by 27 representatives and letters.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 29. -- In answer to numerous letters and inquiries asking for statistics showing the proportion of saloons to each 1,000 inhabitants in the distinctively rural districts of the State, as compared with the cities, Commissioner Lyman has had the following table of averages prepared:

A policy holder in the Mutual Reserve Fund Life Association complains to THE NEW YORK TIMES that a change made in the form of its policies by the association alters the value of her policies, directs her to change the entire scheme of her insurance, and demands from her premiums nearly 100 per cent. in excess of what has previously been asked from her.

It is plain that the Republicans of Indiana are much more intelligent and more honest than their brethren in Ohio. The conference at Indianapolis at which 500 representatives from all parts of the State declared that the majority in Congress should take a decisive step toward sound money and give the party firm ground on which to fight the Democrats, who will declare for free silver, is a most encouraging sign.
The discussion, recently renewed in the New York press, as to how far ignorance is an important factor in the production of crime, is one of deep interest.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- The lumber and other interests which might be affected by reciprocity treaties are watching closely through their representatives here all that concerns their special interests. The principal representative of the lumbermen is Theophilus Tunis, Chairman of the Executive Committee of the National Lumbermen's Association.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 29. -- Robert J. Cook, Yale's veteran boating coach, speaking to-day of the Yale-Cornell situation, said:

HAVANA, Dec. 29. -- Many friends of Senor Canalejas and Mr. Sylvester Scovel, a correspondent, went to the railroad station to-day to meet them and were disappointed at their non-arrival. They are confidently expected to-morrow. News has arrived here ahead of them this evening that Mr. Scovel is back from the field after having presented President McKinley's letter to Gen. Maximo Gomez.

The annual report of the Brooklyn Bridge Trustees was published yesterday by President William Berri. It shows that the receipts from tolls during the year were $1,240,861.24, divided as follows: Carriage ways, $90,797.16; railroad, $1,150,064.08. During the twelve months 45,542,627 passengers were carried upon the railroad.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Dec. 29. -- The heirs of Robert Morris, who during the Revolution, it is claimed, loaned the patriots $1,500,000, are going to try and have Congress settle with them. Robert Morris died in a debtor's prison, which his heirs claim was brought about by his giving his money to the Continental Government.

As the training of Jimmy Michael and Edouard Taylore on the Garden track for their twenty-five-mile contest Saturday has afforded reliable means of comparison, the racing men and followers of cycling who have watched the two fliers have reached the interesting conclusion that Taylore is the faster racer.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29. -- The State Department has just received a copy, through United States Minister Denby, of the recent curious decree issued by the Emperor of China to fend off the wrath of Province as indicated in the eclipse predicted for New Year's Day.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29. -- Depositors and shareholders of the Chestnut Street National Bank and the Chestnut Street Trust and Savings Fund Company continue to sign agreements declaring their approval of the plan for the voluntary liquidation of the affairs of the two institutions devised by Messrs. Earle and Cook, the assignees of the trust company.

Do the people of this State realize that the $7,121,812 of their money which has been spent on the canals during the past two years under the direction of CAMPBELL W. ADAMS and GEORGE W. ALDRIDGE is absolutely lost, that it lies at the bottom of the canal, and that they can never get it back or get any good whatever from it except by borrowing seven millions more to put with it?

Nothing is more mischievous just at this hour than that there should get abroad in New England the idea that a high civilization is to be endangered by a low civilization, or that brains are not power. Our New England manufacturers, before the present stampede, agreed that the mills of New England were better off in product in profit at ten hours than they used to be in eleven and twelve hours or more.

What is the precise difference between the views of the President and those of Secretary GAGE, so far as they have been made public? Unquestionably there is a difference, and the rumor that Mr. GAGE had tendered his resignation grew out of the recognition of that fact, either by the parties directly in interest or by the news gatherers.

A meeting of preferred stockholders of the Herring-Hall-Marvin Company, safe manufacturers of 31 Chambers Street and Hamilton, Ohio, was held yesterday at the Astor House with a view or reorganizing the company. About 2,000 shares out of 18,000 were represented. W.C. Taylor was Chairman.
Although several unknown friends have come to the defense of certain positions which I have taken, it seems to me worth while to ask the attention of your readers to one or two points.

The present law relating to the press in France was passed in 1881. For sixteen years writers and editors and publishers in France have worked under the same responsibility and no other which attaches to publications in "Anglo-Saxon" countries. That is to say, the pretension of the Government to a censorship of publications in advance was entirely abandoned.

DENVER, Col., Dec. 29. -- The owners of some of the undeveloped asphalt beds on the borders of the Uncompaghre Indian Reservation, residing in this city, are negotiating with the Title Guarantee and Trust Company of Chicago with a view to securing money to develop the deposits.

The third day contests in the intercollegiate chess tournament proved interesting because of exceedingly close play. In all of them the issue was doubtful almost to the end. Young, who had to face Southard, played a fine game, and at one time had a draw in hand, but lost through a blunder.

Justice Van Wart, in the Second District Court, Williamsburg, yesterday gave judgment for $10 with costs in favor of Miss Hannah Hughes in a suit she brought against John D. Cook, a dentist. The suit was caused by a set of upper false teeth, which she had directed the dentist to make. The teeth were to cost $10, and when they were finished and delivered to Miss Hughes she discovered that they did not fit.
DALLAS, Texas, Dec. 29. -- Ex-Gov. R.B. Hubbard of Texas former Minister to Japan to-night said:

Mgr. Conaty, rector of the Catholic University, Washington, presided at last evening's session of the Catholic Child-Study Congress in Columbus Hall, and made a few remarks before introducing Dr. G. Stanley Hall, President of Clark University.

MADRID, Dec. 29. -- The Queen Regent to-day received M. Jules Patenotre, the new French Ambassador to Spain, with great ceremony, seated on the throne and surrounded by the members of the Cabinet and the dignitaries of her Court. The Palace Guard rendered military honors.

Detectives Belton and Hefferon of Chief of Detectives McClusky's staff were searching yesterday for Henry Oliver Goldsmith with a bench warrant for his arrest. He is wanted as one of the parties responsible for the alleged swindling of Oscar E.A. Wiessner, who is a manufacturer of hats in New York and a maker of bedsteads in Brooklyn.

BRUNSWICK, Ga., Dec. 29. -- P.H. Mabry, the local agent of the Southern Express Company, has disappeared, and $14,500, which was in his charge, is missing. The money was in two packages, one of which was consigned yesterday by the Citizens' Bank of Savannah to the Merchants and Traders' Bank of this city.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 29. -- If the statement made to-night by Richard Croker means all that some of the wiseacres here construe it to mean, there will be much ado in the Democratic camp for some time to come, and many a well-planned ambition will be nipped in the bud.

DENVER, Dec. 29. -- Gov. Adams to-day sent a letter to Gov. Black of New York explaining why he denied the requisition from New York for William H. Griffith, who was arrested here Monday charged with grand larceny in securing from Richard J. Bolles money on notes, through fraudulent representation.

The heads of several departments seem to be exerting themselves, during the closing days of their official lives, to prevent their fellow-citizens from experiencing any regrets for their departure. Their efforts, we are bound to say, promise to be completely successful.

MATAWAN, N.J., Dec. 30. -- Mr. and Mrs. John Stewart, who live on a farm near this place, are now on speaking terms for the first time in twenty years. Almost ever since their marriage Mr. and Mrs. Stewart, by mutual agreement, have not spoken to each other.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- Some facts of value to business men contemplating an extension of trade into China are afforded by United States Consul Covert, at Lyons, France, in a special report to the State Department.
SYDNEY, N.S.W., Dec. 30. -- The official estimate of the wheat yield is 9,745,000 bushels. There will be a small surplus available for export.

Five men were descending on a hoist from the sixth story of the Grand Central Station to the ground, about 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon, when the car suddenly shot downward, from the fifth floor, and precipitated them all in a heap at the bottom of the shaft in which the mechanism runs. Four of the men were hurt, but one escaped unharmed. The injured men are:
LONDON, Dec. 30. -- A news agency announces that the British Naval Reserves will be mobilized.

When The City Record appeared yesterday as a picture paper it seemed to the remnant who have not hitherto despaired that the last bulwark had been swept away and that the foundations of the old order had caved in. This headlong plunge of our official and respectable contemporary into those revolting practices that have made modern journalism the shame of the age gave the community a painful shock.

The letter of Mr. Romeike in THE TIMES of this morning carries the suggestion that the sentences which he enumerates, and which might be multiplied indefinitely, voice the sentiment of England against wife beaters.

A question between a tailor and a stock broker resulted in the introduction of a human form and a suit of clothes as evidence, before Civil Justice Roesch, in the Fourth District Court yesterday, and in the unusual spectacle of a gentleman, entirely sober, wearing a dress suit in public in the forenoon hours at 30 First Street, which is the courtroom.
The final arrangements for the demonstration arranged by The New York Journal in honor of the birth of Greater New York include some extraordinary sights and sounds.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- Assistant Secretary Roosevelt has submitted to Secretary Long an exhaustive report upon the personnel of the navy. He was charged by a special board to consider the report upon means to break up the present stagnation in promotions, to settle the long standing differences between the line and Engineer Corps, and to devise a method for the betterment of the condition of the enlisted men aboard ship.

LONDON, Dec. 31. -- The Daily Mail has received telegrams from Hongkong and Tonquin denying the French occupation of the Island of Hai-Nan, but it regards it as morally certain that Hai-Nan was occupied about a fortnight ago, when Port Arthur was occupied by the Russians, the coincidence forcing the suspicion that France and Russia were acting in concert.

VERSAILLES, Ky., Dec. 30. -- The most romantic wedding in Versailles history was solemnized at 2 o'clock this afternoon, when J.B. Haggin, the New York millionaire and turfman, led to the altar Miss Pearl Voorhies of this city. Mr. Haggin is a white-bearded veteran of seventy-four, while his bride is only twenty-eight. Miss Voorhies was married in a simple but exquisite costume of blue cloth and white silk, trimmed with point lace.

James A. Reilly, manager of the American Estates Association, with an office at 152 Broadway, discovered yesterday morning that his clerk, Joseph Lockley, had secured thousands of dollars by means of raised checks on the association, besides stealing all the title deeds, books, and papers belonging to the association from the office safe, the combination of which he plugged so that it could not be opened.
John N. Golding has sold, for the Trustees of Columbia University to a firm of builders, the plot northeast corner of Park Avenue and Seventy-fourth Street, 100 by 102.2.

Although Capt. G.S.D. Trask, Governor of the Sailors' Snug Harbor since May, 1883, has not sent in his resignation or given any assurance that he purposes resigning, the Board of Trustees has received no fewer than seven applications for the place. It is understood that the resolution passed by the Trustees on Wednesday after a consideration of the charges against Capt. Trask is a practical demand for his resignation.

Mr. EDWARD M. SHEPARD writes for the January number of The Atlantic Monthly an article on the "Political Inauguration of the Greater New York." It is so clear and calm, so searching and uncompromising and at the same time so hopeful that it should be studied by all those who fought for sound municipal government in the late campaign and by the very many who ought to have done so and did not.

Col. WARING has signalized his departure from the Department of Street Cleaning by a general report of the operations of that department. It includes reports from his chief subordinates on the relations of street cleaning to paving, on the utilization of various components of the street sweepings and household refuse, and on the final disposition of what is not capable of utilization.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- It has been known here that Pension Commissioner Evans favored some sort of executive order or legislation to get rid of pension attorneys who promote pension applications and allowances. It also has been known to many friends of the Commissioner that he would consider that a reformation had been effected if the attorneys could be dispensed with on the day that a check was given to the manufacture of soldiers widows.
CALCUTTA, Dec. 30. -- Col. Sawyer, commanding the British forces at Fort Ali-Musjid, telegraphs:

About fifty children, ranging from two to twelve years of age whose parents are employes of the Holland House or in the service of Howard Goud were royally entertained at the Holland by Miss Katherine Clemmons yesterday afternoon. They were taken empty handed to the hotel in carriages and taken to their homes after the Christmas festival was over, their arms loaded with present and with the supreme consciousness of having had a good time.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- The arrangement effected to-day between Mr. Sifton, the Canadian Minister of the Interior, and the War Department contemplates that the relief expedition shall be executed jointly by the United States Army and a force of the Mounted Police of Canada, which constitutes the military arm of the Dominion.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30. -- Charles T. Yerkes, George H. Wheeler, and other street railway managers of Chicago hurl defiance at Mayor Harrison and the City Council. They refuse absolutely to give certain information desired by the City Council for use in the consideration of the proposed street railway extension ordinances. These refusals from the principal companies were received to-day by the special committee appointed to make the investigations.

TRENTON, Dec. 30. -- The annual report of the Bureau of Labor Statistics for 1897 contains figures showing the condition of the building and loan associations in New Jersey. It is asserted that the losses from poor investments or dishonesty have been less than in other financial enterprises -- for example, in National and State banks, savings institutions, and insurance companies, which are presumed to be under strict official State supervision.

Job E. Hedges, ex-secretary to Mayor Strong, resigned his place on the City Magistrates' bench yesterday at 4 P.M., and Willard H. Olmsted was appointed his successor for the unexpired term of nine years and six months. The yearly salary is $7,000. Magistrate Olmsted's first assignment is to the Morrisania district, and he will sit at One Hundred and Fifty-eighth Street and Third Avenue this morning.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 30. -- This has been a day of conferences with the anti-Hanna Republicans, and, from the best information obtainable, the results have not been altogether encouraging, although the claims of the faction have not been modified in the least. These conferences have been with the leaders of the Democracy who are in favor of a fusion with anti-Hanna Republicans to defeat Mr. Hanna.

Elizabeth Lawrence, who is at present putting up a legal fight known as the Baroness Blanc suit, was examined in supplementary proceedings yesterday. This time, she says, her creditors are not trying to collect debts of her contracting, but those contracted by her former husband, Frederic N. Blanc and by Frederick D. Yuengling, the brewer.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 30. -- James J. Corbett's challenge to fight Robert J. Fitzsimmons contains some flattering offers to the Australian. Corbett states that Fitzsimmons's declaration that he must prove himself worthy of another chance must have been intended as a joke, since "Fitz" promised him another chance if he entered the ring again.

A rival of the American Cycle Racing Association yesterday announced its formation. The concern is planning to construct cycle track at Ambrose Park, Brooklyn, to be known as the National Cycledrome and to promote races on a large scale during the coming season. W.J. Morgan, an old-time racer, and now identified with The League of American Wheelmen Bulletin, is to be manager.

The hitch in the deal for the consolidation of the Equitable and East River Gas Companies is still unsettled, and from present appearances the matter will find its way into the courts. The Central Trust Company, it is expected, will be the dependant in a suit.

The closing half hour of the Catholic Child-Study Congress, which adjourned finally late yesterday afternoon, was enlivened by some decided exceptions expressed by the Rev. James P. Kiernan of Rochester to the views of several teachers with respect to the public schools and by the defense of those teachers.

LONDON, Dec. 1. -- The Times, in its review of the events of the year this morning, after saying it is disagreeable to be obliged to record the failure of the long efforts of Lord Salisbury and Mr. Cleveland to bring about an arbitration treaty, observes:

Brig. Gen. Louis Fitzgerald, First Brigade, of this city, sent in his resignation yesterday, after forty years' service in the National Guard. This fact the General announced last evening at a dinner at his home, to which he had invited the members of his staff and all the commanding officers, of the First Brigade.
Stock market dull and irregular.

The gospel of killing the goose for its eggs is preached in its full rigor by Mr. THEOPHILUS TUNIS, spokesman of the National Lumbermen's Association. He protests vehemently against any reciprocity arrangement with Canada which would take off the duty of $2 a thousand on white pine. "Don't touch the lumber duty until we have skinned our country of its forests" is the perpetual cry of the lumber interest.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. -- The Secretary of the Treasury, with the approval of the President, has issued regulations under the act of Congress signed yesterday prohibiting the taking of sealskins by American citizens, except on the Pribilof Islands, and inhibiting the importation into this country of pelagic sealskins.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30. -- At the close of a dull but nervous and irregular wheat market to-day, May wheat showed 1/2 5/8c, decline, and December was 2c. lower. Practically no support was given the market, and very little selling was sufficient to cause sudden and sharp breaks.

Commissioner Waring stated yesterday that he had called the American Transfer Company to account or the filthy condition of the streets following the snowfall of Sunday last, and that as a result there would be a wholesome change in the manner of removing the snow and dirt which had accumulated, and which accumulation, he said, was due entirely to the failure of the contractors to do their duty properly.

Permit me to correct a slight error in the otherwise careful, accurate, and interesting article upon "The Passing of Bible Chronology" in last Sunday's TIMES. The writer, Mr. John Denison Champlin, states that "the number of generations" in Genesis v. and xi., according to the Hebrew canon and the Greek Septuagint, "are identical."

OTTUMWA, Iowa, Dec. 30. -- Further particulars from Pleasant Ridge Township, Lee County, regarding the attempt last night to punish the Balm boys for alleged ill-treatment of their father, state that "Abe" Balm, who was shot, is still alive, but cannot recover.

Justice Bischoff of the Supreme Court was again in the witness chair yesterday afternoon, in the proceedings before the Sheriff's Jury, to determine the mental condition of his brother, Franklin J. Bischoff. Justice Bischoff testified that his brother's wife had complained to him two or three times that her husband had beaten her, and she had shown bruises to substantiate her statement.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 30. -- There was a joint session this morning of the American Historical Association and the American Economic Association at the Hatch Library, Adelbert College. Prof. Giddings of Columbia College and President Schauler of the American Historical Association presided jointly. A paper on "Rate-making and Taxation -Their Resemblance and Difference," was read by Prof. Arthur P. Hanley of Yale.

TACOMA, Dec. 30. -- According to advices received to-day per steamer Victoria, China's military department is to have a Russian advisor, to be followed by the employment of Russian officers to drill the Chinese Army. The Japan Times is responsible for this statement. The China Mail says Russia is already in possession of Manchuria, and is grasping for a large share of the entire empire.

The report that Senator Morgan has even hinted any objection on the part of this country to the seizure and partition of China by Russia, Germany, and France seems almost incredible. When France seized the Island of Madagascar and proceeded to shut out, as far as possible, all American commerce, Senator Morgan offered a resolution of congratulation and rejoicing in the United States Senate.
ALBANY, Dec. 30. -- Superintendent of Public Instruction Skinner to-day issued his annual statistical statement relating to the schools.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 30. -- Baltimore was surprised to-day by the report that Miss Beth Franklin, who plays the ingenue parts in the Lyceum Theatre stock company, had been married to Richard Wallach, of Washington, a member of a family prominent in the social life of the National capital.

The press of the interior of the State has taken up the canal scandal in a way that bodes disaster to the attempt to screen ADAMS and ALDRIDGE and get $7,000,000 more from the people without showing for what it is needed and how the money already used has been spent. The Utica Observer, replying to a lame defense of State Engineer and Surveyor ADAMS by The Herald of the same city, says:

MADRID, Dec. 30. -- The announcement of the intended departure of the American correspondents from Cuba, together with the change of attitude of the United States, gives rise to the opinion that the question is about to be peacefully settled, and that, with the granting of autonomy, the war no longer has a raison d'etre.

HAVERHILL, Mass., Dec. 30. -- Charles E. Wiggin, formerly President of the Haverhill Savings Bank, but now a resident of Augusta, Ga., is here. He has given much time and attention to the study of economic conditions in the South, and especially to the cotton manufacturing interests.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Dec. 30. -- By the explosion of a stick of dynamite to-day, George Washington Green, colored, a contractor, who is wealthy and the best-known colored man in Westchester County, is likely to die, while his son, William, will be laid up for some time with hurts he received.

LONDON, Dec. 30. -- In aid of the Restoration Fund of St. Mary's Church, Woodstock three performances, consisting of tableaus and theatricals, have been given at Blenheim Palace: last night by invitation to the tenants of the Duke of Marlborough on the estate: this afternoon for the county families in the neighborhood, who paid half a guinea a seat, and this evening for the gentry, who paid a crown.

The games in the intercollegiate ches tournament yesterday were short and snappy, only one of them being long enough for adjournment at 6 P.M. All the others had ended sometime before that hour. The play, however, was not so good as that of the day before.
LONDON, Dec. 31. -- A dispatch to The Daily Mail from Shanghai, dated Thursday, says:

There has been laid before the Roman Catholic Archbishops and Bishops of the United States and Canada a request to consider the formation of affiliated fraternities of the Archconfraternity of Our Lady of Compassion, which has its headquarters in the Church of St. Sulpice, Paris, and for its object the conversion of England to the Roman Catholic faith.

Referring to your recent article, "Collectors Who Are Vandals," let me say the reputable booksellers have keep their hands clean, yet it is only the higher grade that have any discriminating power. The stall men rip and near everything. I know a bookseller who sold a book of Buckle the other day, with manuscript notes and his book plate.

In THE SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS AND ART of Dec. 11 a notice appeared of Audubon's journals, treating more particularly of the work carried on by this our most distinguished naturalist. In the article there were references made to his European journals.

From the first moment when the result of the municipal election was known there has never been the slightest doubt that the Mayor's nominations would be substantially such as are announced this morning. The people of the city voted Tammany into power. It was an organization victory, with no admixture of any other element.

The painters have long protested against any judgment of their work in accordance with the principles of another art, and at last they have succeeded in convincing the more open-minded of us that what is of prime importance in a picture is the way in which it is painted, and that its merely literary merit is quite secondary.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 31. -- Capt. S. Sakuzzi, Assistant Chief Naval Constructor of the Japanese Government, who is now in this country superintending the building of the cruiser Chitose at the Union Iron Works, has made a statement concerning the feeling of the naval and military officers of Japan over the late actions of Germany and Russia with regard to the occupation of Chinese ports. He said:

Being in attendance at the convention of the Association Litteraire Internationals, and wishing more to see Tourgueneff than to behold all living Frenchmen. I begged the ever kind Secretary, M. Zaccone, to introduce me to him after the adjournment. He led me to a man of magnificent bearing, who towered above all the Frenchmen, and was on the whole, the noblest and most attractive literary man whom I have ever encountered.

HAVANA, via Key West, Fla., Dec. 31 -- Details just received here from Spanish sources of the conspiracy against Spanish rule, said to have been discovered in the Province of Pinar del Rio, show that 1,500 men employed in the fields of Clay, Brock Co., tobacco growers, and who had been disarmed, conspired to join the insurgents. Their leaders have been imprisoned in Morro Castle.

The late Olin H. Warner was commissioned to model the two side doors of bronze for the triple portal that forms the main entrance to the Library of Congress, at Washington. MacMonnies modeled the central door, which represents the general idea of Printing; he designed this work and had the bronze cast in Paris.

On page 14 of your valuable SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS AND ART you quote -- apparently with approval -- an item "from the Philistine" about the letter "q" being superfluous. Therein it says: "The man doesn't live that can tell the why of the peculiar relation of the letters 'q' and 'u,' or why the former was given its curious name."

An interestimg album has been disposed of auction in London, containing several of Thackeray's drawings. among these was the novelist's idea of the "Marquis of Steyne" There where many authographs in the album -- those of Mrs. Howitt, Wilkie, Mcready, Opie, Mark Lenon, Tenniel, Lenon Plain, catermole, Landseer, and others. The album brought INI.

When the Church shall come to fulfill the idea and purpose of Christ it will be the centre of ceaseless holy activities and overflowing benevolence. It will be in the forefront of all real reforms, and be the pioneer of all right progress. It will be a refuge for the oppressed, a home for the poor, a place of consolation for the sorrowful.

When we speak of reading the Bible we generally have in mind the Old Testament (or ancient covenant) Scriptures of the Hebrews. Copies of the Bible are issued from the presses of the publication societies in greater numbers than ever, and in almost all living and dead languages. It is widely distributed every year, gratuitously or very cheaply, and sold in many forms and at various prices.

So much has been said and felt recently on the subject of the growing evil of the multiplication of books, and poor books, that to add anything more might seem useless, and yet, by looking at the question from many different sides, we may chance to get a grain of comfort from an unexpected quarter.

The controversy, as indicated in your column, concerning the merits of various systems and methods of drawing for the schools, brings vividly to my mind a trial made here some twenty years ago of what was then a new system of form study. At that time the undersigned was in charge of a district school of 1,500 pupils, with a corps of teachers to correspond.

" He [Pugin] visited 'Sant Andrea della Fratte,' the scene of the miraculous conversion of Abbe Ratisbonne, the Jew. Abbe Ratisbonne entered the church a Jew and came out a Christian, having seen there, he stated, a vision of our Lady. 'The story,' Pugin said, after seeing the church, is demonstrably false. The man could not have said a prayer in such a hideous church.
MADRID, Dec. 31. -- The Imparcial calls upon the Government to "repel every action of the United States savoring of intervention in Cuba," and adds:

Not only did traditions exist in the minds of the people, but many of the old Indian families still preserved their books, the remnants of once extensive libraries, in of the people were recorded. All these books that the Spanish priests could lay their hands upon they burned.

PITTSBURG, Dec. 31. -- The largest order for Mesaba iron ore ever placed by any firm has just been received by Warner, Stuart Co. of Cleveland from Sir Lothian Bell, the English iron king. It is the first instance of American ore entering Europe, and if this order is worked successfully it is predicted that the American product will soon completely shut out Spanish and African ore..

CHARLOTTE, N. C., Dec. 31. -- The cotton mills in the South will not cut wages with the new year, os has been stated. Col. D. A. Tompkins, the best authority on the Southern mill situation, gave out the following signed statement to-day:

Mr. Andrew Carnegie has one hobby -- it is libraries. He has founded six free libraries in this country and in Scotland, and the library in his New York house is the most spacious and luxuriously appointed room in the establishment.

The Grand Central Palace was a scene of rare brilliancy last night, when the large hall was transformed into a Hungarian village. The occasion was the third annual Peasant Ball, given under the auspices of the Hungarian Literary Society. Almost all those present were in native costume, correct to a point, and made bright with a profusion of the national colors -- red, white, and green.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- The swearing in of the new Cuban Cabinet at Havana tomorrow is awaited with interest in official and displomatic circles. Minister Dupuy de Lome takes the view that with the induction into office of the Cuban Cabinet under the plan of autonomy, a full synopsis of which was printed Dec. 24, there will be full realizazation of a Government of Cuba by the Cubans.

PROVIDENCE, Dec. 31. -- After delaying their decision to the last in the hope that conditions might change so as to render the step unnecessary, the agents of the leading cotton manufacturing corporations in this State decided to-day to reduce wages. The cut-down will average about 11 per cent. and will take effect Jan. 17.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 31. -- Nearly all the members-elect of the Legislature have arrived in the city to-night, and the Senatorial skirmish is at its height. Not since the Senatorial election of six years ago, when the Sherman-Foraker contest was on, have there been so many politicians in the city at one time.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Dec. 21. -- The recent difficulty between Germany and Haiti was not understood by the outside world. Near as Kingston is to Port au Prince, and intimate as are the commercial and social relations maintained between the two cities, not an inkling of the real facts was known here until the arrival of the mail on Friday, and then it was contained in confidential commercial correspondence.

There were many grave and anxious faces in the groups that waited in the corridors of the Murray Hill Hotel last night for some sign or word from Richard Croker, which would resolve their doubts as to the first appointments under the charter of the greater city.

The American Revolution formed an excellent subject for which to secure material for a calendar with each day marked by some event. The struggle extended over a long period; its events, personal, political, and military, were many; so that there is no lack of material for making a complete assignment of events for the 365 days.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- Chairman Dingley of the Ways and Means Committee furnishes the following statement of the revenue outlook:

The Board of Park Commissioners met yesterday afternoon, and the business transacted was a great surprise to the members of the park police force, who supposed the old board would retire without making any changes in the personnel of the force.

The Appellate Division yesterday, by a divided court, vacated the injunction granted by the Special Term of the Supreme Court restraining the construction of surface railroad tracks on the New York City terminus of the Brooklyn Bridge pending the action brought by William R. Hearst, as a taxpayer, against William Berri and others, the Bridge Trustees.

The little church of St. John's, at Fort Hamilton, in which Gen. Robert E. Lee was a vestryman, and in which Gen. "Stonewall" Jackson was baptized, is now no more. Its place is taken by an artistic house of worship to be consecrated Wednesday morning by the Bishop of Long Island, the Rev. Richard F. Putnam, clergyman in charge, and the Rev J. Russell Townsend, of Brooklyn.

The year may see great changes in the Orient. The press of European countries, agreeing now with that of Japan, regard the recent action of Germany in China and of Russia both in China and Korea as notice of their intention to extend their power in the Northern Pacific and practically a challenge to all other powers there interested.

L.J. Phillips Co. have sold for J. Watts De Peyster to a builder for improvement the lot, southwest corner of Ninety-ninth Street and Central Park West, 25.2 by 100, together with the adjoining lot on Ninety-ninth Street, 25 by 100.11.

ALBANY, Dec. 31. -- The failure of Alton B. Parker to send his resignation as Justice of the Supreme Court to the Secretary of State has caused considerable speculation about the capital, in view of the mistake Justice Parker made in taking the oath of office as Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals before the vote was canvassed by the State Board of Canvassers.

" There was an amusing incident in my early Waterbeach ministry which I have never forgotten. One day a gentleman, who was then Mayor of Cambridge, and who had more than once tried to correct my youthful mistakes, asked me if I really had told my congregation that if a thief got into heaven he would begin picking the angels' pockets.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Dec. 31. -- The creditors of the Overman Wheel Company, which made an assignment early in the week, held a meeting at Chicopee Falls this afternoon, and decided upon a policy which will result in placing the company back upon its feet once more and the resumption of work in the big factory early next week.

-- Alderman-elect HIXON of Chelsea, Mass. -- which is almost the same as saying of Boston, same State -- has already managed to acquire considerable fame for himself, and incidentally to cast some light on the sort of intelligence that finds its way into Municipal Council Chambers. Mr. HIXON and his fellow-Aldermen-to-be met this week to draw lots for seats in the board room.

" All hard labor, all rough and unskilled labor, is, and, owing to the heat of the climate, must be, done by blacks; and in a new country like Matabeleland the blacks, though they can sometimes be induced to till the land, are most averse to working underground. They are only beginning to use money, and they do not want the things which money buys.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- It has been discovered upon a careful inspection of the permit granted by the British Government for the taking of supplies into the Klondike country free of duty that the exemption extends only to such goods as are gratuitously distributed.
I was glad to see the courteous letter of the Rev. Mr. Savage in your issue of to-day and with your permission I would like to add a word to help clear up some misapprehensions.

A report of the Police Department was made yesterday to Mayor Strong by Police Commissioners Moss, Andrews, Parker, and Smith. It contains a list of the personnel of the department, gives the number of deaths, retirements, resignations, promotions, and other changes, and the names of officers who have received honorable mention for heroic service.

LONDON, Jan. 1. -- According to a special dispatch from Shanghai a sudden stiffening has taken place in the attitude of the Tsung-li-Yamen toward Germany, resulting in a demand for the evacuation of Kiao-Chau and leading to the belief that Great Britain is bringing pressure to bear upon Pekin.
