It was successfully tested as to its capabilities in hauling heavily loaded freight trains between the railroad terminals and the wharves of the transatlantic liners on the Hoboken side of the North River.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 4. -- The political future of Senator Hanna is as much in doubt to-night as ever. While there are eleven bolters among the eighty Republican members of the Legislature, yet the really doubtful list is limited to two or three. Some of the dissenting Republicans are not likely ever to be reconciled to Senator Hanna.

Charges of bigamy and perjury are to be made against Edward J. Ratcliffe, the actor now in the Tombs under sentence of six months in the penitentiary for assaulting his wife, the daughter of Peter De Lacy. In addition to these new difficulties which have suddenly risen around him, his wife is to bring suit for divorce.

It is a matter for grave concern that the friends of the gentleman who has been nominated United States Minister to China are making a strong fight to induce President MCKINLEY to reconsider his recent action withdrawing from the Senate that nomination. The case may be regarded as a typical one -- one likely to arise at any time under the present slipshod policy of filling important foreign diplomatic and Consular appointments.

Perhaps the most surprising suggestion that has emanated from Russia since the beginning of the attempts upon the integrity of China is that which the cable brought us yesterday from the Novosti of St. Petersburg. This is the journal which the Russian Government appears to choose, from among those at its disposal, for the launching of "trial balloons."

EGG HARBOR CITY, N.J., Jan. 4. -- Dr. J.W. Green, who for a number of years lived the life of a recluse and hermit near Wading River, died early this morning in his shanty. He was alone at the time with a young man whom he took to live with him about two years ago.

The case of the People against Charles Zanoli on the charge of killing his fourth wife, Jennie Suhmer, has fallen to pieces. It was reported in the District Attorney's office yesterday on good authority that the alleged insurance swindler now in the Tombs will not be placed on trial for homicide, as a result of the chemical analysis made by Dr. Witthaus on the parts of Jennie Suhmer's body.

Let me repeat that when Dr. M.J. Savage insists that the Prayer Book form for baptism "plainly implies the damnation of infants" he evidently does not know what he is talking about. He is putting upon the language of Holy Scripture, quoted in the Prayer Book, one of those "straw" constructions, entirely gratuitous and without shadow of justification, from which he derives most of his pulpit eloquence.

All of the departments of the municipal government were in fair working order yesterday. The Public Improvements Department, however, has not yet found a home, and for this reason President Holahan of the board called a meeting yesterday afternoon in the private room of the Mayor. The Mayor, who is a member ex-officio, was not present, but there were no other absentees.

LEROY, N.Y., Jan. 4. -- Miss May Thompson, aged twenty-five years, of Dallas, Texas, who since last August has been visiting at the residence of M.F. Thompson, set fire to her hair and clothing this morning, bent on ending her life.

Signs of increase in the volume of importations at this port are so strongly marked that United States Appraiser Wilbur F. Wakeman was moved yesterday to say: "I predict that the receipts from customs for this month will exceed the receipts of January, 1897, by $4,000,000, doubtless more."

FRANKFORT, Ky., Jan. 4. -- The convening and organization of the two legislative houses to-day were without incident of note. A failure to complete the organization of the lower branch precluded even the beginning of business. The biggest fight among the Democratic majority of the House, the caucus of which was not concluded till to-night, was over the determination of a majority to limit the candidates for one of the minor places to Negro Democrats.

Paul Potter's new play, "The Conquerors," which was produced, with a fine pictorial display, at the Empire Theatre last evening, begins agreeably with Schubert's "Erl Konig" and ends, violently, with an interrogation point. The play serves to bring back to town the actors (or some of them) who are regularly employed in Mr. Charles Frohman's handsome theatre, including Viola Allen, William Faversham, Ida Conquest, and W.H. Crompton, and for that reason it is welcome.

MONTREAL, Jan. 4. -- The increase of this year's gross earnings of the Canadian Pacific Railroad over last year, per official statement, is $3,465,796. The increase of gross earnings of the Grand Trunk Railroad during last month over the same period last year was $111,736.

A cablegram received in this city yesterday from Paris brought the news of the death in that city on Monday of Mrs. J.C. Ayer, the wealthy American widow, who has for some years been a prominent figure in the American colony resident in the French capital.

The much-talked-of dance in the annex of the Metropolitan Club, planned by twelve young matrons of the exclusive set, took place last night. The entire annex had been turned over to the dancers, the carpets having been taken up and the floor waxed.

Indianapolis was formally chosen as the locality of the 1898 National League of American Wheelmen meet at a meeting of the Executive Committee of the League of American Wheelmen yesterday afternoon in the office of President Isaac B. Potter, in the Potter Building. Park Row. There has been little doubt as to the choice for months before, as Boston was the only other place mentioned, and Mr. Potter's hostility to Boston precluded its selection.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- The cause of arbitration in the settlement of claims between nations has received a severe check in the award by the arbitrator in the case of Oberlander and Messenger, who claimed $50,000 and $25,000 respectively for ill-treatment by the Mexican authorities. The arbitrator was the Argentine Minister at Madrid, Senor Quesada, and his decision was in favor of the Mexican Government and against the American claimants.

August Schubble, twenty-five years old, of 215 West Sixtieth Street, came near being decapitated last night. He is an oiler in the employ of the Metropolitan Traction Company, and his work is to lubricate the pulleys which carry the cable of the Columbus Avenue line.

The Merchants' Association held its first annual meeting yesterday at the Broadway Central Hotel. President William F. King was in the chair, and opened the session with an address on the work of the association.

CAMDEN, Jan. 4. -- The trial of Eli Shaw on the charge of murdering his grandmother, Mrs. Emma Zane, was brought to a sudden and unexpected termination this morning. Immediately after the appearance if Judges Garrison and Armstrong in the courtroom they retired to an anteroom, and County Prosecutor Jenkins and Harry S. Scovel, leading counsel for the defendant, joined them in a private conference.

ALBANY, Jan. 4. -- The Democrats of the Assembly gathered in the Assembly Parlor shortly after 8 o'clock. Assemblyman P.F. Roche was chosen to preside, and Assemblymen Cullen of Kings, and Malony of Erie were named as Secretaries. Mr. Roche, in accepting the Chairmanship, alluded to the big difference in numbers of the minority between this session and last.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 4. -- A delegation of 350 Republicans from Springfield, the home of Gov. Bushnell, visited the State House to-day and called on the Governor. Congressman Weaver, the spokesman of the delegation, in addressing Gov. Bushnell, said:

ALBANY, Jan. 4. -- Some pointed remarks made by Senator Cantor and Assemblyman Donnelly, the leaders of the Democrats in the Senate and Assembly, respectively, afford evidence that the session of the Legislature will be a troublesome one for the Republicans, and that it will be strung out ad infinitum unless the Democrats get certain concessions that they are demanding, including favorable action on some of their pet measures, Senator Cantor to-day said:

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 4. -- That the properties of the Wisconsin Central Company and the Wisconsin Central Railway Company will within a comparatively short time be entirely reorganized and that they will pass into other hands than those of the men who control the old company, is said to be almost certain.
ALBANY, Jan. 4. -- A number of extra appropriations for State Normal Schools are to be asked for at the present session of the Legislature.

SYRACUSE, Jan. 4. -- Safe crackers broke into the office of the Standard Oil Company in this city at 12:30 o'clock this morning. They overpowered the watchman -- C.O. Brown -- as he was passing from the boiler shop, a short distance from the office, to the latter building, and bound and gagged him They then carried him into the boiler shop and returned to the office, the door of which was unlocked.

Harris B. Fisher has sold, for Henry Adriance, to Brown Brothers Co., the three-story brick building 3 Hanover Street, on a triangular plot 20.4 by 46.2 by 45. This property was sold at auction on May 11 for $24,000.
LONDON, Jan. 6. -- The Times says editorially this morning:

In a recent article (NEW YORK TIMES, Dec. 28,) something was shown of our late progress in exports of manufactured products and especially of iron and steel and manufactures thereof, and the opinion was ventured that the story of the recent past gives us reasonable hope for the immediate future, and a promise was made to point out some special reasons for thinking that our exports of the products of manufactures will go on increasing.

The bill which Senator NUSSBAUM is about to press in the Legislature for a State bankruptcy law proceeds on general sound principles. It is, in fact, on the same lines as the bill now pending before the House of Representatives, introduced by Judge HENDERSON of Iowa, Chairman of the Judiciary Committee.

Following the discontinuance of Good Government Club B, there has been organized in the Twent-first Assembly District, on similar lines, a club which will be called the "Independent Club." This organization, on Tuesday night, elected its officers for the year as follows: Ex-Assemblyman William B. Ellison, President; S.P. Carmichael and the Rev. Dr. John P. Peters, Vice Presidents; A.C. Dodman, Treasurer, and Charles S. Patteson, Secretary.

LONDON, Jan. 5. -- Six thousand persons, most of them members of the Salvation Army, took part at Albert Hall to-night in a demonstration of farewell to Gen. William Booth, who is about to sail for the United States to "assist in organizing great additions to the army." Three brass bands led the music, and in the body of the hall were 1,000 Salvation lassies, who performed theatrical movements with red, white, and blue scarfs.
ALBANY, Jan. 5. -- The annual report of the Board of Railroad Commissioners was presented to the Legislature to-day. In the course of the report the Commissioners say:

MONTREAL, Jan. 5. -- It is officially announced that the total increase of the gross earnings in 1897 of the Grand Trunk Railway system both in Canada and the United States over those of 1896 is $768,509.

The fifth auction sale of wool took place in the Wool Exchange, at West Broadway and Beach Street, yesterday afternoon. In anticipation of it, many out-of-town manufacturers of woolen goods and dealers from other cities were present, and most of them figured as buyers.

The Sheriff's jury selected to inquire into the sanity of Franklin J. Bischoff, the brother of Supreme Court Justice Bischoff, last night found that the defendant was insane, and had been so for a period of about five years. They decided that he is incompetent to manage his affair, but admitted that he had lucid intervals. The inquiry lasted far into the night.

ALBANY, Jan. 5. -- There was a comparatively large attendance of politicians and a number of ladies who showed interest in the preliminary proceedings in the Assembly this morning. Gigantic floral horseshoes stood on the desks occupied by Assemblymen Crabtree, F. Schmid, Fitzgerald, and Hachemeister.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- The bill for the reform of the civil service law which has been drafted by a special committee of Republican members of the House opposed to the system in its present form makes sweeping changes in the present system, the most important of which is the establishment of a five-year tenure of office for those Government employes who are brought within the terms of the bill.

Capt. Trask, for the last fourteen years Governor of Sailors' Snug Harbor, yesterday sent his resignation to the Board of Trustees, to take effect as soon as his successor is appointed. A meeting of the Trustees was called for to-morrow to consider the resignation and to discuss the merits of the different applicants for the place.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- Secretary Gage to-day sent a reply to the Senate resolution of Dec. 18, calling upon the heads of the executive departments for information as to what positions in their respective departments should be excepted from the civil service laws and rules. Secretary Gage's reply in part is as follows:...

Gov. BLACK dodges the canal scandal. No one would imagine from his matter-of-fact and perfunctory observations on the subject of the improvement that it was one which perturbs the minds of the chiefs of his party with grave anxieties. "The nine-million-dollar appropriation was voted by the people," he says; "if a further sum is to be expended for the continuance of this work it also should first receive the people's sanction."

ALBANY, Jan. 5. -- An amendment to the charter of the City of New York was presented to-day by Senator Jacob A. Cantor, which, it is understood, is indorsed by the new authorities of the greater city. It amends the section in relation to the collection of unpaid taxes and assessments, known as Section 937.
ALBANY, Jan. 5. -- The wheels of the big Legislative machine at the Capitol moved off to-day without priction or a hitch, ran smoothly for a couple of hours, and then stopped again for a week.

Both office holders and office seekers who have been under the impression that the new administration is going to make sweeping changes in the various departments for the benefit of adherents of Tammany Hall, according to a statement formulated by George McAneny, Secretary of the Civil Service Reform Association, seem to have overlooked the civil service rules governing appointments to subordinate positions.

BERLIN, Jan. 5. -- The Reichsanzeiger this evening announces that, according to a telegram from Pekin, an understanding has been reached between Germany and China regarding the cession of Kiao-Chau Bay to the former. The arrangement, it is added, is substantially as follows:
The following list of reappraisements of merchandise was announced yesterday by President Charles H. Ham of the Board of United States General Appraisers:

FAIRBURY, Neb., Jan. 5. -- The pursuit of an assassin was concluded to-day when William Baker was run to earth and forced to kill himself to avoid summary execution. When the mob closed in on its victim, the man blew out his brains with the same weapon with which he yesterday assassinated his brother, George Baker, and his wife.
Jackson Stern have bought from Hannah Silverstone the three-story brick dwelling 228 Clinton Street, 25 by 93.5.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- Senator Davis, Chairman of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations, gave notice in the Senate to-day that he would call up the Senate Hawaiian annexation treaty in executive session Monday next and ask the Senate to consider it each day thereafter until the treaty should be disposed of.

Richard Croker and his friends held another levee at the Democratic Club last night. Mayor Van Wyck, John F. Carroll, Congressman Sulzer, Nathan Straus, Perry Belmont, Senators Grady and Cantor, Assemblyman Donnelly, and other leaders of the Democratic organization were there, and forty more names of candidates for admission to the club were posted on the bulletin board.

Mayor Van Wyck arrived at the City Hall at 9:30 yesterday morning and left it at 4:30. His first visitor was Salem H. Wales of the East River Bridge Commission. Commissioner Wales is a close friend of ex-Mayor Strong, and is also a friend of Mayor Van Wyck, having known the Chief Executive as a boy. Mr. Wales had been deputed to ask the Mayor to attend the meeting of the commission that afternoon.
PORT SAID, Jan. 5. -- The German warships Deutschland and Gefion, under command of Prince Henry of Prussia, have arrived here on their way to China.

ALBANY, Jan. 5. -- Lieut. Gov. Timothy L. Woodruff called the Senate of 1898 to order at 11:10 o'clock this morning. The galleries were occupied by only a few spectators. A handsome bouquet in the form of a basket upon Senator Brackett's desk was the only floral display.

Three children and two women had a narrow escape at a fire which occurred yesterday at 505 East Eighty-eighth Street, a five-story tenement house. The children were those of Adam Wunner, the janitor of the house, who, together with his wife, rescued them after crawling on their hands and knees through dense smoke. The women were Mrs. Mary Sweeney and Mrs. Sarah Jacobs. They were rescued by Police August J. Christ.

BOSTON, Jan. 5. -- The Massachusetts Legislature, officially known as the Great and General Court, convened at the State House to-day, the two branches meeting in their respective chambers, where, after the members were sworn in by Gov. Wolcott, the officers for the ensuing year were chosen.

Bishop Potter is certainly a most polished and intelligent man of the world, and his public utterances have generally been characterized by much good sense. For example, he has always been consistent in opposing deals with corrupt political adversaries, and for taking such position in the local campaign of 1895 he was violently attacked and abused.
ALBANY, Jan. 5. -- Senator Cantor's Anti-Trust bill, as drafted this morning, reads as follows:

PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 5. -- Capt. B. Eldridge, Second Lieutenant E.W. Clark, and fifty enlisted men of the Fourteenth Infantry have been detailed for duty in Alaska by Gen. Merriam, department commander.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- An unusually large number of Senators occupied their seats to-day at the opening session of the Senate after the holiday recess.

BELMAR, N.J., Jan. 5. -- Mrs. A.T. Green, widow of Dr. J.W. Green, the hermit who died at Wading River, was seen to-night at her home on Fifth Avenue. She said that Dr. Green died of tobacco heart. He had been an invalid for some year, and during the last years of his practice in New York had been somewhat eccentric in his habits.
ALBANY, Jan. 5. -- The following bills were introduced in the Senate to-day:

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 5. -- The Legislature has adjourned till Monday. But both parties to the Senatorial contest will remain in conference daily and nightly at the Neil House and the Great Southern Hotel, respectively. The secret work will continue till next Tuesday, when the two branches of the Legislature will vote separately for Senator and the roll-calls will show whether any changes have been made.

HARTFORD, Jan. 5. -- A decision has been handed down by the Supreme Court, now in session in this city, confirming the decision of Judge Prentice of the Fairfield Superior Court, in the celebrated "conspiracy" case of Timothy H. Porter of Stamford vs. Thomas G. Rich, Schuyler Merritt, Richard Bolster, and Henry E. Sherek.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5. -- Rumors which were persistently circulated last night that Joseph Leiter had closed contracts for the disposal of the greater part of his vast accumulation of wheat to New York and Baltimore exporters, who had placed it in Europe, were positively denied to-day by Broker George B. French, who represents the Leiter interests.

" Children's Home Reading" was the subject of a highly interesting lecture delivered by Prof. J.E. Russell of the Teachers College, at a regular monthly meeting of the League of Parents and Teachers, held yesterday afternoon in Barnard College, on Morningside Heights. There was a large attendance, and after some routine business had been transacted, Miss Lois A. Bangs, President of the League, introduced Prof. Russell.

The life of Henry Patterson, janitor of the Albemarle apartment house, at 361 East Twenty-seventh Street, was saved on Tuesday evening by the unusual strength and courage of Mrs. Alice Boothroyd, a tenant.

" Sir," observed Dr. JOHNSON, upon the appearance of MALLET'S edition of the works of Lord BOLINGBROKE, "the man was a scoundrel and a coward; a scoundrel, because he charged a blunderbuss against religion and morality; a coward, because he had not resolution enough to fire it off himself, but left a half a crown to a beggarly Scotchman to pull the trigger after his death."

CHICAGO, Jan. 5. -- W. Ray Smith, a nephew of Judge Oliver H. Horton of the Circuit bench and a bailiff in his uncle's court, and Edward M. Hunt, a former Deputy Sheriff, fought a duel with pistols this evening on the streets of Woodlawn.

That was an extraordinary explosion of the Mayor's, on the occasion of the visit to him of two members of the Board of Education. These gentlemen had made an appointment with Mr. VAN WYCK to talk over the affairs of their department. It is the Tammany contention that the Mayor has the right to remove the members of the board.

ALBANY, Jan. 5. -- A power of removal bill for Mayor Van Wyck of New York, aimed at the School Board, was introduced by Assemblyman Donnelly, the Democratic leader in the House, this morning. It has the distinction of being the first bill dropped in the box this session.
It is an extremely encouraging sign that the scheme for securing jury reform is being taken up by the Chamber of Commerce and other business organizations.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- The police officers at the White House to-day arrested a middle-aged German named Jacob Clements, who said he lived near William's Bridge, N.Y.

ALBANY, Jan. 5. -- Senator Grady of New York this morning offered the Democrats a substitute for the present excise law. It provides for the restoration of local Excise Boards and has been fully detailed before. It gives power to the local boards to fix the license fee and regulate the hours.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 5. -- Mrs. John E. Griffith, wife of the Representative from Union County, charges that Senator Hanna offered her a bribe if she would induce her husband to vote for Boxwell, the Hanna candidate for Speaker of the House. She says Depeck and Chapman came to her hotel at midnight and told her that Griffith had decided to change his quarters to the Neil House, and wanted her to come to him.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 5. -- The split in the ranks of the Republican members of the House of Delegates, which developed at last night's caucus, continued to-day, with the result that the House was compelled to adjourn until to-morrow without having organized, and there seems to be no immediate prospect of a settlement of the difficulty.

Work on the new loops at the entrances of Brooklyn Bridge was begun early yesterday afternoon. If the promises of the Presidents of the Nassau and Brooklyn City Railroads are fulfilled, the cars will be running on a thirteen-second headway within three weeks. The plans accepted by the former Bridge Commission, or Board of Trustees, will be used, subject to such modifications as Commissioner Shea, after advice from his engineers, may deem necessary.

LONDON, Jan. 6. -- According to a special dispatch from Peshawur, Major Gen. Arthur Godolphin Yeatman-Biggs, in command of the Second Division of the Tirah expedition, on the northwest frontier of India, died on Tuesday of dysentery.

If the Monetary Commission is as anxious for currency reform as it seems to be for the permanent establishment of the gold standard, holding, as it does, that our "legal monetary standard is whatever a majority * * * of the voters say it shall be," would it not have been wise for it in its report to, so far as it honestly could, have tried to attract, not repel, voters?

The stewards of The Jockey Club held a meeting yesterday and allotted dates to the various racing associations for the coming season. Those present at the meeting were August Belmont, J H. Bradford, James Galway, F.R. Hitchcock, James R. Keene, Andrew Miller, and F.K. Sturgis.

VALETTA, Island of Malta, Jan. 5. -- Four members of the Council have cabled to the Marquis of Salisbury renewing their offer to assist in the military requirements of Egypt, by raising a thousand Maltese for general military service.

After three days of conference and discussion of things literary and otherwise appertaining to the teaching of the languages, the members of the Modern Language Association of America closed their fifteenth annual convention Thursday, and most of the delegates left the city to resume their work in the various colleges and universities with which they are connected.

Some of the recommendations Gov. BLACK makes to the Legislature impress one by their quaint and homespun quality. The proposition that "the public money is too freely spent" is not only indisputable but is put tersely and with such point that it may become a quotable axiom.

Henry Lawrence Burnett, nominated for United States District Attorney in New York, is a lineal descendant of William Burnett, Colonial Governor of New York and New Jersey in 1720. He was born in Youngstown, Ohio, sixty years ago. When but fifteen years old he ran away from home, and walked nearly 100 miles to Chester Academy, where James A. Garfield was a student.

So few of the heads and deputies of departments comparatively have found headquarters that the Mayor's office has become the repository of numerous bundles of mail addressed to "The Honorable the President of Manhattan Borough," "Chief of the Board of Statistics," "President of the Board of Public Improvements,"

The funeral of Adolph and Emma Reich, their daughters, Matilda and Ida, and their sons, Albert and Gustave, who were victims of the fire at their home, 317 Germania Avenue, last Sunday, took place yesterday from the Hudson City Turn Verein Hall on Webster Avenue, near Griffith Street.

A significant meeting of the Boards of Local Improvement in Brooklyn was held yesterday. These boards consist of the Councilmen and Aldermen elected from Brooklyn, each acting in his own Senate district. Combined, they can exert great influence on appropriations in the Municipal Assembly if they choose, and yesterday they agreed to vote and work as a unit.
ALBANY, Jan. 5. -- Senator Pavey introduced the proposed Primary Election bill this morning, and gave this explanation of it:

The remarks of Mr. Rathborne, published in your issue of Jan. 1, upon my criticism of C.W.L.'s English, remind me of the man who, when looking for his friend's house, found that he had the right street and number, but was in the wrong city. Mr. Rathborne seems to forget that an author's meaning and his use of words must be judged, and that, too, without presumption, from the context, attendant circumstances, or known facts.
ALBANY, Jan. 5. -- To the annual meeting of the State Legislature, which began here at noon to-day, Gov. Black sent his annual message. It reads as follows:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- There was a large attendance in the Hall of Representatives when the House reconvened to-day after the holiday recess. The galleries were crowded.

LONDON, Jan. 5. -- There is a general feeling in England, and it is reflected on the Stock Exchange, that the situation in the Far East is improving. It is believed the proposed Chinese loan of 16,000,000 ($80,000,000) will be guaranteed by the British Government, although the final decision is not likely to be reached until the meeting of the Cabinet on Monday next.

HAVANA, via Key West, Fla., Jan. 5. -- Se+/-or Canalejas was coldly received at Santiago de Cuba. The Spanish Casino refused to tender him a banquet, and he was hissed on the street. It is understood that the opposition to him is due to the fact that he is the editor of El Heraldo de Madrid, which has violently attacked Gen. Weyler.

ALBANY, Jan. 5. -- The Third Appellate Division has decided against David C. Robinson, and for the Mutual Life Insurance Company, in the ten cases involving $1,500,000. In five of the cases the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York was plaintiff, and the charges are that Col. David C. Robinson, a son of former Gov. Robinson, is an embezzler and defaulter.

ALBANY, Jan. 5. -- Senator Featherson introduced a bill in the Senate to-day prohibiting gas companies from receiving over $1 per 1,000 for illuminating gas. The local officers at present authorized to contract for gas in the respective cities of the State under the provisions of the bill become a Gas Board, which is given power of contracting, supervising, and investigating and of making ordinances necessary for the carrying out of the act.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 5. -- Although the attorneys for W.H.T. Durrant, the condemned murderer of Blanche Lamont, were considerably disconcerted by the denial of their application for a writ of habeas corpus and permission to appeal therefrom in the United States Circuit Court this morning, they have yet two more moves, by means of which they hope to prevent the execution of their client on Friday next.

Golfers in this city were considerably exercised yesterday over the statement sent from Chicago to the effect that Findlay Douglas of the Fairfield County Golf Club, at Greenwich, Conn., had made statements reflecting upon the sportsmanlike conduct of the Chicago Golf Club during the championship tournament there in September.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 6. -- Charles Dayton, who is supposed to have lived at 115 Fourth Avenue, in New York, was found dead under a railway trestle across Cahokia Creek, in East St. Louis, Ill., to-day. He is supposed to be one of two robbers who were thrown from an Illinois Central train last night after attempting to rob a passenger in the smoking car.

It is on the strength of a torn and crumpled letter which had been hidden away in a bureau drawer since last October that a middle-aged woman and her sister, a pretty young girl, who were on trial all day yesterday before Recorder Golf, in the General Sessions Court, on a charge of shoplifting, hope to prove their innocence.

Ten Eyck Wendell, in your issue of Dec. 30, claims that in the case of the two uses of "ought to," which he cites from "C.W.L.'s" communication, "C.W.L." should have written "should" instead of "ought to." Mr. Wendell says that "ought to" denotes an obligation of duty, but that "should" denotes merely an obligation of expediency or propriety.

George R. Read has sold for John Howard Wright to a client for investment the four-story building, 1,168 Broadway, between Twenty-seventh and Twenty-eighth Streets, about 26 by 58. The price could not be learned, but it was said that the consideration was all cash.

In your paper of Jan. 4 "an old-fashioned Churchman," Mr. S.B. Bennett of Pittston, Penn., says, of the Prayer Book, "the thirty-nine articles are a part of it." I also am "an old-fashioned Churchman" and a seeker after knowledge, and for both reasons I would like to ask Mr. Bennett for his authority for the statement, and when they became "a part of it."
President Charles H. Ham of the Board of United States General Appraisers announced the following reappraisements of merchandise yesterday:

I.B. Potter, President of the League of American Wheelmen, accompanied by Secretary-Treasurer W.S. Bull of the New York State Division and others, took a trip to Philadelphia yesterday, to endeavor to clear the political atmosphere. It is reported that the party called on Mr. Gideon and asked him for a statement of his position, and that a conference with the officials of the Quaker City was held.

LONDON, Jan. 7. -- According to a special dispatch from Shanghai, the existence of an Anglo-Japanese alliance is openly asserted there in well-informed quarters -- an alliance to maintain the status quo in China and Korea and to declare the independence of Korea under the joint guarantee of England, Russia, and Japan.
ALBANY, Jan. 6. -- The annual report of Inspector General Hoffman was to-day transmitted to Gov. Black. In the course of his report the Inspector General says:

CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 31. -- A report has reached here that two legal experts who were commissioned by the Government of Great Britain to go to British Guiana to collect evidence in the boundary dispute are returning to England with many volumes of testimony bearing upon the question, which will simplify the work of the commission when it meets. The wonder here is that this testimony has not been unearthed at an earlier date.

If your columns be open still to the discussion of the misuse of "shall" and other auxiliaries as now exhibited by Mr. Wendell, or C.L.W., I should like to reply to the letter printed in your issue of Jan. 6.

Clark Braden, night clerk in the American Express Company's office at Forty-eighth Street and Madison Avenue, disappeared about 5 o'clock yesterday morning, and at the same time $5,582 in cash and $5,000 in bonds of the Consumers' Gas Company of Chicago also vanished. General Manager Julier of the company says there is a connection between the simultaneous disappearances and that Braden is a thief.

The American Bankers' Association believes that in the arrest of Samuel Strauss yesterday, they have landed the leader of gang of mail-box robbers and check raisers, who have, for three or four months, been looting the mail boxes in apartment and private houses at this city. Letters containing checks were sought.

William T. Buckley, who until a week ago was a member of the large dry goods firm of Dunham, Buckley Co., shot himself in the head at his home at Wave Crest, L. I., yesterday morning. The members of his family and the Coroner who has charge of the case maintain that the shooting was accidental.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- The bill of the Monetary Commission, intended to embody in law the plan of currency reform made public by the commission on Monday, was introduced to-day in the House by Mr. Overstreet of Indiana. It was referred to the Committee on Banking and Currency. The bill is the work of a sub-committee, of which ex-Senator Edmunds, ex-Secretary Fairchild, and C. Stuart Patterson were members.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 6. -- A call was issued to-night by the Republican State Executive Committee for a mass convention of Republicans, to be held in this city next Monday afternoon, to protest against the attempt to defeat Senator Hanna. The call follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- The Post Offices and Post Roads Committee of the House of Representatives has resolved to cut down postal expenditures, and one of the directions in which it will undertake to make reductions is in the carrier service. The appropriation for free delivery service for the year ending June 30, 1898, was $12,539,000.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 6. -- Conservative estimates to-night place the Senatorial vote in the Legislature at 74 to 71 against Hanna. The Hanna men, however, claim 72 votes, with assurances of the necessary one additional vote, and possibly three more. The opposition leaders insist that Hanna will never have 70 votes on joint ballot, and that they have gained two votes since the Legislature adjourned over till Monday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- The Post Office Department has found it necessary to issue a notice that the recent consolidation of the cities and towns comprising the City of New York did not change the postal arrangements as affecting the several localities. This notice was found necessary because of the many mistakes made by persons addressing mail matter to friends in various parts of the metropolis, and designating the city location simply as "New York."

A party divided against itself is in a predicament that may, for the industrious legislator, have its advantages. The Republican Party in Ohio is now in that parlous state. There are two claimants for the honors and emoluments of bosshood. We do not remember that either party in this State has thus been torn since the remote days when CONKLING and FENTON struggled for the mastery.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 6. -- The wholesale drug firms of Arthur Peter Co. and Samuel Bauer were consolidated to-day and incorporated as the Peter Bauer Drug Company, the capital stock being $150,000. The firm of Arthur Peter Co. was founded in 1817, while Bauer has been in business for eight years.

ROCHESTER, Jan. 6. -- Right Worshipful William A. Sutherland, Grand Master Mason of New York State, issued a general edict to-day, directed to the masters of all the Masonic lodges in the State. He dissolves all relations with the Grand Lodge of Peru, on the ground that that body has "committed Masonic suicide and vanished from existence." Mr. Sutherland says:

John McCullagh was made Chief of Police by the unanimous vote of the Commissioners at a meeting held yesterday afternoon in President York's private office. The appointment was made in executive session, and, it was said, no other name was considered. The action of the board was generally expected, and occasioned no surprise. The place is worth $6,000 a year, and is held at the pleasure of the board.

The new Administration having become a four-days' old story, affairs at the Mayor's office have resolved themselves into routine, and business at the City Hall yesterday was transacted almost as smoothly as though Mayor Van Wyck had been in office for months instead of days. Among the Mayor's early callers was Col. H.C. Gibson, ex-Street Cleaning Commissioner Waring's deputy.

Two other prominent Tammany Hall men tendered their resignations as members of the Manhattan Club yesterday. One of them was Police Commissioner John B. Sexton, the leader of the Nineteenth Assembly District, and the other John B. Doerr, a prominent Tammanyite of the east side.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- Counsel for Durrant, the condemned California murderer, to-day made an unsuccessful effort to have Justice Brewer of the United States Supreme Court interfere and stay the proceedings. Attorney Boardman arrived here from California to-day and made two applications for interference.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- While the contest in Ohio for the Senatorship is watched here with intense interest, all Republicans are not feeling the same sort of concern about the success of Senator Hanna. The proceedings of each day at Columbus are discussed every night at the hotels and elsewhere, and much speculation is indulged in as to what will happen on the day of the vote in the separate houses of the Legislature.

PASSAIC, N.J., Jan 6. -- David Westervell and George Thompson, both prominent residents of Clifton and members of the Township Committee were seriously injured today in a driving accident. They started to drive to the meeting of the committee this afternoon in a buggy. The horse was spirited one.
Stock market strong.

While politicians would not last night permit themselves to be quoted with regard to the report that an attempt will be made at the present session of the Legislature to turn the City Magistrates out of office, it is the general understanding among them that such a thing will be done if possible.
SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 6. -- The Columbia Theatre was gutted by fire this evening and is a total loss. The fire was confined to the theatre building. No one was injured.

ALBANY, Jan. 6. -- Paul Lablanche, an insane alien who arrived in this country about two months ago from France will be deported on Saturday next by the United States Commissioners of Immigration at the request of the State Commission in Lunacy.

Jonathan ("Jock") Darling, the hunter, guide, and woodsman, died on Wednesday in Lowell, Me. He was well known, not only in that State, but to sportsmen throughout the country. He could teach the oldest woodsman that ever followed a trail or took a course by the stars: The forests and bogs, lakes and wildernesses, and wilds of Maine formed his book, and he studied it attentively for sixty years, and added daily to his lore.

It is claimed by the Adams Express Company that a man giving his name as T. Francis Sanders has obtained a large amount of money in small sums from the wives and relatives of persons recently deceased by sending valueless packages cash on delivery.

Prof. George E. Hale, Director of the Yerkes Observatory, lectured last evening before the Department of Astronomy, Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences, on that observatory and the work planned for it. The lecture was illustrated by photographic views and was largely devoted to a description of the observatory and its big telescope, and the methods and appliances designed to make the best possible use of its powers.

The annual ball of the Bachelor Circle of the Liederkranz, the important social event for most of the younger German social set, took place in Liederkranz Hall, 115 East Fifty-eighth Street, last night. There were six or seven hundred persons present, and a notable feature of the ball was the fact that the President of the Circle, Franz Brickelmaier, led the grand march, which opened the ball, with his fiancee, Miss Unger.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- William R. Weedin of Providence, a writer on political economy, in a letter just received here says:

-- Thanks to generous contributions, chiefly from citizens of Baltimore, the Trustees of Johns Hopkins University were able in the year just closed to avoid any curtailment of the institution's work. The annual report of the President says, however, that great anxiety is still felt in regard to that part of the university funds which was placed by the original benefactor in the stock of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad.
LANSING, Mich., Jan. 6. -- The death of Frank T. Daniels, a Pension Examiner, who was located at Reading. Penn. for several years, has disclosed the fact that he had two wives and children by each.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- The Bureau of Foreign Commerce of the Department of State has sent out an abstract of the laws of British Columbia relating to joint stock companies and trading corporations, which will be of interest to those who are launching out into enterprises in the Klondike district.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- The minority report of the House Committee on the Judiciary on the Bankruptcy bill was submitted to the House to-day. It is signed by Messrs Terry of Arkansas, De Armond of Missouri, Underwood of Alabama, and Smith of Kentucky.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- The House today continued to debate the civil service question. The discussion was opened by Mr. Grosvenor (Rep., Ohio.) Mr. Grosvenor disclaimed any leadership of the anti-civil service reform forces, and any purpose to speak for any officer of the Government -- Executive, Legislative, or Judicial.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 6. -- From an anti-Hanna Republican close to those who are conducting the fight against Senator Hanna, and who has just returned from the State capital, it was learned to-night that Congressman Stephen A. Northway of Jefferson, Ashtabula County, may be the candidate of the anti-Hanna forces for United States Senator.

BUFFALO, Jan. 6. -- Assemblyman Henry W. Hill of Buffalo will introduce next week at Albany a primary election bill putting registration for and the conduct of the primaries into the hands of the regular election officers. The bill is the result of an investigation recently made by the Buffalo Republican League, and in nearly all of its details has been taken from statutes in force in other States.

John E. Redmond, member of the British House of Commons from Waterford City, Ireland, and the successor of Thomas Parnell, arrived here yesterday morning on the Teutonic from Queenstown. Edward O'Flaherty, Chairman of the Reception Committee which has been organized for the purpose of welcoming Mr. Redmond to this city and looking after him while here, boarded the ship at Quarantine.

ALBANY, Jan. 6. -- The possibilities of the canal scandal as a political weapon are not to be monopolized by the Democrats, if the action of State Controller James A. Roberts, himself a member of the Canal Board, in repudiating the course of his colleagues, Messrs. Adams and Aldridge, is any index of what the next campaign may bring forth.

Objections have been filed against the probate of the will of the late Henry A. Hurlbut, who died suddenly on Nov. 11 last, and the case is down for hearing before the Surrogate on the first Tuesday in February. The contest is between William Henry Hurlbut, the School Commissioner, on the one hand, and his brother, Henry A. Hurlbut, Jr., and Mrs. Bolton Hall, a granddaughter of the decedent, on the other.
BERLIN, Jan. 6. -- The North German Gazette to-day in a semi-official article says:
BERLIN, Jan. 6. -- At the New Palace yesterday evening Emperor William personally decorated Baron von Bulow, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, with the Order of the Red Eagle.

On Sunday a mover in a prairie schooner passed through this city going west. He had a small drove of mules and several horses, all loose, following the wagon, and among them was a beautiful sorrel horse, with bridle and saddle on, but no rider. People on the streets noticed that the sorrel seemed to be overseeing, the herd, and would round them up occasionally.

The childlike and trustful attitude of THE TIMES and other metropolitan newspapers in hoping for a fine administration from Mayor Van Wyck and his fellow-braves of the Wigwam, or at least in deprecating all criticism in advance of performance, and all mistrustful prophecy, suggests to me a fable which seems to cover the case.

Piracy is not made more respectable by false pretenses. When Germany seized Kiao-Chau Bay she made a pretext of the murder of German missionaries in China. But the pretext was so ludicrously irrelevant that even the Consecrated Person cannot have meant it to be taken seriously.

Mayor VAN WYCK's outburst of indignation at the members of the Board of Education for having employed a small number of teachers from outside of the city, to which we have already alluded, deserves criticism from another point of view; it shows a much stronger interest in New Yorkers seeking employment as teachers than in the vastly greater number of New Yorkers seeking the best schooling for their children.

The Chamber of Commerce at its monthly meeting yesterday discussed the proper maintenance of the canals. Delegates were chosen for the Indianapolis Monetary Conference. An important report on the commercial business of this port, which refutes the general idea of loss of prosperity in this regard, was received, and a committee was appointed to obtain relief for Cuban sufferers.

TRENTON, Jan. 6. -- The Republican Senators of the New Jersey Legislature held a caucus to-night at the Republican Club, and selected the officers who will be chosen when that body meets next Tuesday. Senator William M. Johnson was Chairman of the caucus, and will be the leader of his party on the floor of the Senate.

When the Geneva award of $15,500,000 in gold was paid by Great Britain twenty-five years ago, the payments were made to extend through a period of several months and there was considerable apprehension, in England at least, lest the transfer of so large a sum should produce disturbances in the money market.
BOSTON, Jan. 6. -- Thomas Pettit, ex-champion court tennis player of the world, gave out to-day the following answer to the challenge issued by Peter W. Latham, champion of England:

Controller ROBERTS has burned Gov. BLACK'S bridges for him. After his courageous action in suspending the canal contracts and stopping the sale of the bonds there is no possible retreat, no hope of escape from an investigation of ALDRIDGE and ADAMS and a full revelation of the truth.

Anthony Comstock, Secretary of the Society for the Suppression of Vice, was awarded six cents damages by a jury in the United States Circuit Court yesterday in a suit before Judge Lacombe for defamation of character. He had sued for $50,000, the defendant being Dr. Montague R. Leverson of Fort Hamilton, who had called Mr. Comstock "a notorious blackmailer" in public.

The big patronage wheel of the new administration has not been turning fast enough to suit some of the Tammany braves who are anticipating their reward. Among the anxious ones are more than a score waiting for City Clerk Scully to announce the selection of clerks to the Board of Aldermen.

As English is the quarry of every man who aspires to be thought of as a thinker, it seems wonderful that so few, if any, of our volunteer authorities make any preparation, or even adopt any vigilance, to validate their doctrines. I ask space to illustrate briefly some recent precipitated pretensions.

PARIS, Dec. 21. -- M. Zola's speech at Alphonse Daudet's grave yesterday was not only full of point, but it was replete with delicately expressed tenderness and affection for his deceased friend. It is but too true that with the death of Alphonse Daudet the great epopee of French romance writing which began with Balzac and included Flaubert and de Goncourt, now comes to an end.
LONDON, Jan. 7. -- Lady Henry Somerset has again tendered her resignation of the Presidency of the British Women's Temperance Association, on account of prolonged ill health.

The full text of the report of the Railroad Commissioners is not yet available. But it seems to be agreed in Albany that the recommendation of the Commissioners for an amendment to the law limiting the number of passengers upon surface cars amounts to a recommendation that the number of passengers on a car shall be no greater than its seating capacity.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7. -- The indications are that grain rates east from Chicago will take the liveliest kind of a tumble whenever Joseph Letter or his agents announce hat he is ready to send his large pile of wheat to the seaboard.

In 1871 at the Scott Centenary Exhibition at Edinburgh there were on view over fifty Scott manuscripts. In the last number of Chambers's Journal the statement is made that between 1851 and 1890 there had been issued 3,000,000 volumes of the cheaper editions of Walter Scott. Previous to that there had been printed 2,000,000 copies. Since 1890 it may be said that fully 3,000,000 more copies have been issued.

-- At last the shipping authorities of England have given ear to the complaints of commercial associations and individual merchants in New York, Philadelphia, Boston, and other Northern ports in the United State, regarding the unreasonable discrimination made against them by the present load-line regulations.

I have been reading Marie Corelli's "Sorrows of Satan" and am somewhat curious to learn how this book was received by critics and reviewers generally in this country, and especially in London, (a great many of whose papers and periodicals she scores so roundly in this work.) Tell me something of Marie Corelli, and how are her works taken as a whole?

Over 35,000 shares of Manhattan Elevated stock were traded in yesterday, and an advance of over a full point was scored. In Brooklyn Rapid Transit about 22,000 shares were dealt in, and there were transactions in about 4,000 shares of Metropolitan Street Railway, the two latter declining fractionally. On sales of les than 500 shares Third Avenue stock rose nearly five points.

BOSTON, Jan. 6. -- The attitude of self-gratulatory virtue recorded by history as having been assumed by Mr. John Horner after the fruition of his Christmas toils is precisely that of the typical Boston publisher during the present holidays: He knows that he is good because he has been successful.

Ex-Mayor Hugh J. Grant called at the City Hall yesterday morning about 10 o'clock to congratulate Mayor Van Wyck. It was his first visit to the new Chief Executive, and they chatted some time about the new order of things. Shortly after Mr. Grant departed, Alexander E. Orr came in to talk with the Mayor about the Sailors' Snug Harbor.
Vice Chancellor Reed heard evidence yesterday, at Jersey City, in the case of Clara Deders of Union Hill, who is suing her husband, William H. Deders, for divorce, on the ground of cruelty.

LONDON, Jan. 8. -- A special dispatch from Shanghai says that a Japanese fleet of three battleships, ten first-class cruisers, and numerous smaller vessels has received orders practically placing it at the disposal of Sir Alexander Buller, Commander-in-Chief of the China Station, this step being taken "in case Russia persists in ignoring the joint interests of England and Japan."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- The Inter-State Commerce Committees of the House and Senate listened to additional arguments on the Anti-Scalping bill to-day. The principal argument in favor of the bill was made by George H. Daniels, General Passenger Agent of the New York Central Railroad. He represented, he said, not only the New York Central, but practically all the railroad lines of consequence in the country.

As a sort of absinthe prelude to its French ball of Jan. 28, Le Cercle Francais de l'Harmonie gave its thirty-second annual banquet last evening in its clubhouse, at 24 West Twenty-sixth Street. Les Soixante Immortels, composing the club, had invited about forty guests to taste the viands and drink its wines.

Hiram Rinaldo Brother have sold for the estate of Dr. Aaron Wise, to Solomon Loeb of the firm of Kuhn, Loeb Co., the property at the southeast corner of Second Avenue and Twenty-first Street, adjoining the Post Graduate Hospital. The lot is 65 by 90 feet, and is now occupied by a piano factory.

These three attractive volumes are fair types of the stories poured forth in bewildering profusion for childhood, for boyhood, for romantic youth. While possessing no salient points of special merit, they are interesting, wholesome, and, upon the whole, instructive -- just the books universally recommended as pabulum for the opening minds and hearts of the young.

I noticed a very savage attack on the collectors of book plates in a recent issue of your SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS AND ART, in which it was set forth that the collecting of door plates, even coffin plates, was a more honorable and understandable pursuit. The term vandal was certainly used therein, that of ghoul implied, and the grangerite extolled as a better and less destructive individual than a book-plate collector.
Hall J. How Co. have sold for Mrs. Eliza M. Bailey to Adolph M. Bendheim, for improvement, five lots on the north side of One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, 225 feet west of Amsterdam Avenue.

In 1895 the discovery of a treasure of silverware was made at Bosco Reale, between Torre del l'Annunziata and Pompeii. There were fifty pieces of silver, and their preservation was due to their having been enveloped in woolen stuff. The probability is that they were secured in this manner when in 79 Vesuvius first threatened Pompeii. The entire collection was purchased by Edward de Rothschild and presented by him to the French National Museum.

Maurice Grau, since his last return to Europe, has accomplished considerable toward perfecting his company for the first season of grand opera, under the management of the Maurice Grau Opera Company, which will open on or about Dec. 12 next.

Mr. A.J. Balfour, the English statesman, was the principal guest at the fourth annual dinner of the Edinburgh Sir Walter Scott Club, which took place in Edinburgh a fortnight ago. Lord Stormonth Darling, who presided over a company numbering about 270 gentlemen, gave the toast of "The Memory of Sir Walter Scott." Mr. Balfour, on rising to propose the toast of "Literature," said:

Although the Arabs will occupy an enduring place in the grateful recollection of posterity, yet it is worth noting that their historians never woke to the consciousness of their higher responsibilities. Their conception of history was that of a specious panorama, in which we may distinctly see the events carefully noted year by year, with reference to the causes which brought them about or the influence which they exerted on society.
You can't meet a deficit by cutting down paying business.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- An interesting compilation bearing on the civil service of the Government from the early part of this century has been prepared by the Civil Service Commission. It consists mainly of extracts of reports made by Congressional committees from time to time from speeches in both houses of Congress and messages of Presidents on the subject.

With the death of William James Linton last week in New Haven passed away a man once at the head of his profession, and who was one of the striking personalities of his generation. He had long since passed out of the ranks of modern leaders, and he was known and loved only by an older generation. But he always kept in touch with the world and knew what the younger men were doing.
I approached Chambord after a contest and a bloodless victory over my courier which put me in that frame of mind with which one should visit the more blood-stained Chateau of Blois later on.
HAVANA, Jan. 7. -- The exportation of leaf tobacco free of duty began to-day.

TROY, Jan. 7. -- George H. Morrison, who is serving a term in Clinton Prison for misappropriating the funds of Rensselaer County while he was its Treasurer, was examined to-day in connection with a suit of the county against the National Bank of Troy for the recovery of $205,165.39 of county funds deposited in the bank and alleged to have been converted to his own use by Morrison when cashier.

After the adjournment of the trial of Mrs. Mary Bowers and Gertrude Barbero, the pretty young girl she says is her sister, charged with shoplifting, before Recorder Golf in General Sessions, yesterday afternoon, Mrs. Bowers became hysterical. She burst into tears and wrung her hands. "Why didn't you get Mrs. Alexander? Why didn't you? Why didn't you?" she cried to Miss Barbero.
The will of George Barlow, who died at 405 Clermont Avenue, Brooklyn Borough, on Jan. 2 last, was filed yesterday in the Kings County Surrogate's office. Among the bequests are the following:
Stock market strong.

I was surprised to see such a slip in your issue of Jan. 1 (p. 11, last paragraph,) as "There always stands in the foyer of the Comedie Francaise Houdin's bust of Voltaire, and singularly effective is it."

Much has been written and more thought upon the subject of book prices, remuneration to the writer, and profit to the handlers as publishers and retailers. The question of a fair price to the public, commonly called the consumer, may be left out, for it will always have to pay as much as it will pay.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 7. -- This was a quiet day among the army of political workers enlisted in the Senatorial contest, and, while Senator Hanna's managers were apparently more cheerful, the cause for it was not apparent. They have adopted quite a different policy in their canvass from that followed at the beginning of the contest.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- The feature of the Senate session to-day was a speech delivered by Mr. Teller, (Sil. Rep., Col.) regarding press reports that the recent efforts to make it appear that Secretary Gage had tendered his resignation as a member of the Cabinet to President McKinley were a part of a conspiracy of the silver men to disrupt the Cabinet and create dissension between the President and his advisers.

Whether the performance of "Cinderella" to be given at the Metropolitan Opera House, beginning this afternoon and to-night, will or will not be interfered with by the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children remains in doubt. Mrs. A. Benton Barnes, who has had the general supervision of everything in connection with the production, said last night that at the outset her first thought was of the Gerry society.

Mr. CHARLES G. DAWIS of Illinois, a young man who is said to have rendered valuable assistance in securing a majority of the votes of Illinois for President McKINLEY, was sworn into office as Controller of the Currency on Friday last. He did not begin business until Monday. His first reported act was the appointment of Gen. JOHN C. McNULTA as receiver of the National Bank of Illinois.

What is evidently a swindle of gigantic proportions perpetrated on the Government has just been brought to light in the Brooklyn Navy Yard concerning the construction of the new timber dry dock, which is officially known as No. 3.

Your editorial of yesterday does great injustice, unwittingly, I am sure, to the memory of Henry M. Taber. Mr. Taber had been for many years an outspoken agnostic. He had not only made no secret of his religious views, but had published several writings setting forth his reasons for disagreeing with Christian orthodoxy.

Somebody has written that there are traits of resemblances among well-bred and educated people the world round, and that before our Revolution a man in comfortable circumstances was pretty nearly the same, whether he drank his punch in Boston, New York, Philadelphia, or Charleston.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment held its first meeting yesterday afternoon in the Mayor's office. The Board organized by electing Mayor Van Wyck President and Thomas L. Feitner, President of the Tax Board, Secretary. Controller Coler, Corporation Counsel Whalen and Council President Guggenheimer, the other members of the Board, were present.

We suppose that Mr. CANTOR'S purpose, in his anti-trust bill, is really to do what the Lexow law pretended to do. There still remains the question whether the thing is worth doing, whether, in fact, it is not mischievous to the interests of the whole community, and especially to those of the working class.

Our neighbor The Sun publishes a list of the names and addresses of all pensioners, 3,568 in number, who draw pensions of more than $45 a month. There are 2,519 pensioners who draw $72 a month for total and permanent disability necessitating the regular aid and attendance off another person. Nearly 1,000 are pensioned at $50 for total disability for manual labor, the pensioner requiring frequent but not regular attendance.

The officials of the trolley line over the Brooklyn Bridge laugh at the idea that there will be serious danger to people crossing the bridge on foot from the running of the trolley cars, and the bridge authorities seem to be inclined to laugh with them.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- Chairman Lacey of the Committee on Public Lands of the House introduced in the House to-day a bill extending the homestead laws to Alaska, and providing for right of way for railroads in that district.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 7. -- The Republican members of the Lower House of the Maryland Legislature, after more than two months of "deals" and "promises," failed to agree upon a Speaker for the House of Delegates, and to-day twelve of their number, assisted by forty-one Democrats, elected Louis Schaefer of Baltimore to the position of presiding officer.

A discovery of Roman silverware made recently at Tarentum is exciting the attention of archaeologista. If the collection is not as large as the famous Hildesheim one, some of the Tarentum pieces excel the German find in beauty. Some few of the objects have not escaped the effects of time, but the majority of the vases and paterae are still in good condition. The forms are Greco-Roman, but of the best period.

Sir James Sawyer has been making quite a little sensation here by lecturing to a Birmingham audience on the subject of human longevity. Nineteen in number are the commandments of Sir James, and he tells us that if we obey them we have an admirable chance of becoming centenarians. Here they are:

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Jan. 7. -- Rufus B. Stillman, who murdered a hotel porter in Rochester in 1876, and was sentenced to prison for life, left Clinton Prison to-day a free man. His son-in-law, whom he had never seen before, brought the pardon signed by Gov. Black to the prison to-day, and the two men left for Troy to-night.

SIOUX FALLS, S.D., Jan. 7. -- Prof. Mason of the Smithsonian Institution and Prof. Giddings of Columbus College have been here to study the peculiar phases of three boys, four, six, and eight years of age, who were rescued by the authorities of the Children's Home from an inland town.

The address of Mr. Balfour, printed elsewhere in this issue, offers a striking example of the talents which many eminent men in Britain show for intellectual performances outside their special vocations. Mr. Balfour, by profession and long experience, is a statesman. As Lord Salisbury's chief lieutenant in Parliament, he long since gave evidences of marked capacity for leadership in great affairs.

TACOMA, Washington, Jan. 7. -- The steamer City of Seattle arrived here to-day bringing thirty-five miners from Dawson, one party of which left there Dec. 5. Nothing startling had transpired at Dawson since the last reports, when it was said that some food had been obtained by trading companies from Forty Mile.

In Mrs. Sherwood's very interesting paper entitled "Memories of Holland House," which appears in your SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS AND ART of Dec. 31, occur references to the wife of the third Lord Holland which, if warranted in some measure by the facts, at least, should not stand alone.

The congregation of the Broadway Tabernacle, Sixth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, is to hold its annual meeting on Wednesday evening, Jan. 19, when its members expect that its Committee on Pulpit Supply will report in favor of extending a call to the Rev. Dr. John Henry Barrows of Chicago.

The New York League of Unitarian Women held its regular monthly meeting at All Souls' Church, Twentieth Street and Fourth Avenue, yesterday morning. The associated branches of this city and of Brooklyn were represented, and a large number of other women, interested in ethical and philanthropic work, attended the meeting. Mrs. John W. Chadwick of Brooklyn presided.

Stephen J. Thompson died in this city on April 27 last, at the age of thirty-two years, after having lived a fast life on an income derived from a trust bequeathed to him by his granduncle, William D. Thompson, a millionaire merchant, who died in 1874. Young Thompson's fast pace brought him continually into financial difficulties, from which his relatives, who are prominent in social circles in Philadelphia, Baltimore, and abroad, frequently extricated him.

The future home of the Democratic Club is to be the New York Athletic Clubhouse, at Sixth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street. At a meeting of the Board of Governors of the Democratic Club last night the preliminary agreement for the acquisition of the property was sanctioned, and it remains only to draw up the deed and pay, over the money.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- Auditor Castle of the Post Office Department has discovered irregularities in money-order accounts which may possibly result in a loss to the Government of a considerable sum. They were brought to light as the outcome of a new system of checking accounts by Postmasters which went into effect on the first of the year.

Mr. Stillman having been so long a resident of Rome, his professional study of the city as the correspondent of The London Times, his profound interest in the historical and artistic sides of Rome, and, moreover, his American nationality, Mr. Stillman having been born in Schenectady, give peculiar interest to the paper on Rome, with which his new volume of collected papers opens.

At a meeting of the Winchester Art Exhibition, the Dean of Winchester being the President, and the Vice Presidents Canon Warburton and the Earl of Northbrook, Sir Seymour Haden, who was present, made an interesting speech.

T. Francis Sanders has not yet called at the offices of the Adams Express Company for the checks which represent collections made by the company for him on packages containing stock certificates of the "Monterey Mining Company," which he ordered delivered at the residences of men whose death notices he had seen in newspapers.
In a large silk mill, where the looms were thrumming and all was noise and bustle, a woman, skilled in manufacturing and dyeing delicate silks, was toiling. She looked tired and dejected.

The Committee of Fifty-three of the Republicans of the County of New York, the title which has been selected by the new anti-Platt organization, met at the Windsor Hotel last night, adopted a constitution and by-laws, and issued a report to the voters.

Cromwell kept quiet during the years in which Charles was governing without a Parliament. He is not heard of as resisting the payment of ship money, nor even as setting at defiance the ecclesiastical courts. Clearly he was no ambitious firebrand, but a man under authority, whose aim it was to carry obedience to the utmost limits consistent with his personal duty.

I always enjoy reading THE REVIEW OF BOOKS AND ART, but sometimes you puzzle me. To-day, for example, after correcting some obvious errors in a so-called "Calendar of the American Revolution," you go on to say: "Massachusetts was not 'State' during the Revolution, but still a province." "The Declaration of Independence was not signed by representatives of 'thirteen States,' but thirteen Colonies."

I have read Mr. A.K. Fiske's article in THE SATURDAY REVIEW OF BOOKS AND ART twice. It expresses in the clearest possible manner the prevailing feeling among thousands. Now, will Mr. Fiske tell us what books we ought to begin to read in order that we may have a truer insight as to the meaning of the Old Testament?

It was reported yesterday that Tammany Hall, through the Department of Police, intended to attempt to solve a difficult problem and to localize vice, after the methods in vogue in Paris and Vienna. It was a matter of general knowledge among the leaders of Tammany so early as last August that the controlling heads of the organization had determined that, should Tammany win in the municipal fight, they would attempt a solution of this problem.

The extraordinary change in novels and their heroines is due, in a great measure, to the change in women themselves. These have ceased to be the romantic, sentimental, artificial beings they were even thirty years ago, and their reflex in fiction has been discontinued. We will not read of the languishing, empty, mawkish, flavorless Sybils, Angelinas, and Arabellas that our mothers and grandmothers hung over and wept over.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- The Ways and Means Committee will give early attention to the customs administration law, with a view to presenting a bill embodying numerous reforms. The present law went into effect with the McKinley tariff law, and the recent Dingley tariff law, while revising tariff rates, did not go into the question of administering the tariff laws.
The Board of Police Commissioners made several important appointments in an executive session of an hour's length yesterday afternoon The four Commissioners were present.

GREENFIELD, Mass., Jan. 7. -- John O'Neil, Jr., who last July was found guilty of the murder of Mrs. Hattie Evelyn McCloud in Buckland, Jan. 8, 1897, and sentenced to death, was hanged in the Franklin County Jail this forenoon. The drop fell at 10:41 o'clock. O'Neil declared his innocence on the scaffold.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Jan. 7. -- James Dealey, a Trustee of Sleepy Hollow School District of Mount Pleasant, died last night. His death, it is believed, will seriously complicate matters in the district. Some time ago Mr. Dealey, together with Trustees Seifert and Hutton, fixed the tax rate of the district, in opposition to Trustees Lant and Erdman.

The third public rehearsal of the Philharmonic Society took place yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. It is unnecessary to say that the house was packed. That seems to be a settled condition at all Philharmonic concerts, and it may be taken as an evidence that there are at least 6,000 persons who love music of the highest order for its own sake and are willing to go to hear it fairly well played.

GREENFIELD, Mass., Jan. 7. -- John O'Neil, Jr., who last July was found guilty of the murder of Mrs. Hattie Evelyn McCloud in Buckland, Jan. 8, 1897, and sentenced to death, was hanged in the Franklin County Jail this forenoon. The drop fell at 10:41 o'clock. O'Neil declared his innocence on the scaffold.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Jan. 7. -- James Dealey, a Trustee of Sleepy Hollow School District of Mount Pleasant, died last night. His death, it is believed, will seriously complicate matters in the district. Some time ago Mr. Dealey, together with Trustees Seifert and Hutton, fixed the tax rate of the district, in opposition to Trustees Lant and Erdman.

A woman who had often read with a feeling of terror that familiar sign, "Beware of Pickpockets," but who had never seen a member of the fraternity to which it refers, had an experience the other night. She was not frightened It was on the eve of the birthday of Greater New York. She was at the bridge station on her way to Brooklyn late in the evening.

Jackson's Day, the anniversary of the Battle of New Orleans, was celebrated last night by the Business Men's Democratic Association of New York with a dinner at the Hotel Savoy. Covers were laid for 175 guests at five long tables placed at right angles to the speakers' table in the red, drawing room.

PARIS, Dec. 28. -- Christmas in Paris has been celebrated with the accustomed good will by the American colony here. The banquets, both public and private, have been too numerous to mention in detail, and as for the menus, the spirit of the occasion being eminently traditional, they have not differed greatly from one another.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 8. -- The attempt of the Western Turf Congress to prevent Lexington from racing this Spring will be futile, to judge from the following message which was wired hero to-night by J.H. Davidson, President of the Kentucky Association, who is in New York:
Marcella was Felicia's most intimate friend. No one knew why Felicia called her Marcella. Perhaps Felicia herself did not know. It had all come about years before, as Felicia would have said.

The board having in charge the revision of the Military Code in connection with a reorganization of the National Guard it is expected will complete its labors this week. The board will meet again to-morrow morning in the Twelfth Regiment Armory, and have considered thoroughly the various points at issue which have concerned Guardsmen for many years.

The fashionable residents of Garden City are up in arms against the Carteret Gun Club, which erected shooting grounds almost in the centre of the town. They claim that the firing of guns and slaughter of birds is a public nuisance, and should be abolished. Several residents claim that after every shoot dead pigeons are found on their grounds and porches.

TORONTO, Jan. 8. -- The last session of the present Legislative Assembly of Ontario is now in progress, and the general election for the province is near at hand, as dissolution will take place and an appeal be made to the country, it is generally believed, immediately upon the prorogation of the House.
A drunken fireman named William O'Toole who fell into the East River at the foot of Ninety-seventh Street on Friday night, was rescued by Bicycle Policeman Fogarty after a hard struggle.

FALMOUTH, England, Jan. 8. -- The tug Triton landed here to-day the Captain, mate, cook, and a seaman of the British steamer Clarissa Radcliff, which was abandoned Jan. 1 near Cape Finisterre in a sinking condition.

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 25. -- The latest news from Germany has produced a genuine sensation in St. Petersburg, particularly in diplomatic and official circle. The great mass of the Russian public, unable to master the barbarous names of Asiatic cities, are as yet but little interested in the conflict between Kaiser William and the "Son of Heaven."

BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 8. -- After defeating Baltimore's strongest hockey team, the Maryland Hockey Club, 3 to 2, the Montclair Athletic Club team of Montclair, N.J., last night at the North Avenue Ice Palace gave way to the Northampton Hockey team, a minor aggregation, by a score of 2 goals to 1. Max Hornfeck scored the goal for Montclair, Poe and Wagner being responsible for the scores made by Northampton.

Five new armory records were established at the annual Winter games of the Seventy-first Regiment Athletic Association, held in the armory, Thirty-fourth Street and Park Avenue, last night. New figures were made in the 440-yard run, putting the sixteen-pound shot, half-mile run, one-mile run, and relay race. Fully 4,000 persons watched the games, which were run off with precision.
AUGUSTA. Ga., Jan. -- Major Moses P. Handy died at noon to-day at the Hotel Bon Air in this city. His body will 1 t -- ken to Berlin, Md., for burial.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- The following proclamation was issued to-day:

LONDON, Jan. 8 -- The tacit development of England's position in the Far Eastern question, which is, briefly, that she will grab nothing herself, but will fearlessly employ her overwhelming naval power to prevent any obstruction to free Chinese trade on the part of others, has had a remarkable and quieting effect on the Continental excitement.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8. -- Alderman John Powers has been "vindicated." In the face of several indictments for criminal offenses he has been re-elected President of the County Democracy. In his inaugural address, Mr. Powers took occasion to pose as a martyr, and to denounce the press and his other alleged enemies, as well as to boldly defy those whom he accuses of being bent upon accomplishing his ruin..

Julius Harburger has drafted a bill for presentation to the Legislature to amend the system of collecting small debts by the imprisonment of the debtors on body executions. On the lower east side, where many of the tenement residents purchase furniture or ornaments for their rooms on the installment plan, that process of law, it is claimed, has been enforced to un unjust extent.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 8. -- The towboat Percy Kelsey, owned by W.H. Brown's Son of this city, blew up on the Ohio River, near Glenfield, Penn., this morning. Four of the crew are reported killed and seven others injured, three of them fatally, it is feared.

During the last hours of the reporters' night watch in the Tenderloin the warmth and comfort of the West Thirtieth Street Station are much sought after. From mid-night until 2 A.M. time drags heavily to the workers on the morning newspapers, who can usually be seen sitting in a circle around the stove.

The New York Kindergarten Association is quietly doing a good work which costs a good deal of money. It has established and carried on fifteen kindergarten schools in various parts of the city, chiefly in quarters where there is most need of some provision for the moral, physical, and educational care of the young children of a swarming population.

Korea, once the Hermit Kingdom, is apparently about to pay the penalty of her position, a defenseless peninsula separating mighty and progressive nations. For many years the only tales of her people and customs which reached the ear of civilization came from shipwrecked sailors, a few of whom were fortunate enough to escape from her remote shores and powerful inhabitants.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 8. -- Capt. Robert J. Cook, the Yale coach, does not let an opportunity pass to correct any false impressions that may prevail at Cornell University.
