The recent statement of one of the boating officials of the Ithaca college intimating that there was too much eelgrass on the New London course was promptly shown by Capt. Cook to be a statement not founded on fact.

COLFAX, Washington, Jan. 8. -- Marshal Chadwick, the suspected murderer of Young Hayden, near Farmington, on the night of Oct. 22, was taken from jail by a mob this morning and hanged to the west wall of the Court House.

SKAGUAY, Alaska, Jan. 2, via Seattle, Washington, Jan. 8. -- Capt. Wood, in command of the detachment of the Northwest Mounted Police in the district which extends from the White Pass Summit to Lake Tagish, warns all persons en route to the Klondike that they will not be permitted to pass Tagish House unless each person has at least 600 pounds of provisions.

John Graham Brooks lectured before the League for Political Education at Mendelsohn Hall yesterday morning on "The Relation of Economic Science to Modern Life." There was an unusually large attendance.

WEST POINT, Jan. 8. -- The most aristocratic tramp in the United States holds a first mortgage on the route from Garrison's to Rhinecliff. For more than a dozen years Henry Madison, known to every schoolboy in the towns between these places as "Buttons," has journeyed along the Hudson and levied tribute on the kitchens of the millionaires whose homes crown the hilltops of the Highlands.

NEW BRUNSWICK, Jan. 8. -- A Neilson Street grocer discovered recently that a rat had taken up its abode in his place and was committing nightly ravages among his provisions. He got a cat and some traps, but the rat declined to be caught, and his raids became more destructive than ever.

One of the most important social events of Brooklyn will be the Ihpetonga ball. The event will take place in the assembly rooms of the Academy of Music on Jan. 18. The affair will mark the thirteenth anniversary of the society, and elaborate preparations have been made to make the event the finest ever given in the City of Churches.

ONE of the most memorable events that has happened in the New York National Guard for years was the dinner given by Brig. Gen. Louis Fitzgerald, commander of the First Brigade, to the members of his staff and the commanding officers of his brigade.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 8. -- Two of the best-known warriors in the South passed away this week. One was distinguished on two continents as an Indian fighter; the other was a gallant Confederate, whose career during the war has been the subject of so much criticism since that his name is familiar to all who are acquainted with the memorable incidents of the early sixties.
LONDON, Jan. 8. -- The case of Mrs. Florence Maybrick will perhaps be reopened shortly in another form.

THE spectacular "fairy operetta," "Cinderella," which was given yesterday afternoon and evening at the Metropolitan Opera House, and which will be produced there to-morrow night and on the four evenings following, in the cause of charity, is said to be the most stupendous entertainment ever given by amateurs in this country, and it is certainly one of the most brilliant.

CHARLESTON, West Va., Jan. 8. -- Representative miners of the Kanawha Valley met here to-day and organized a State association, the main feature of which is the settlement of all strikes by arbitration. A full set of officers were elected. This organization is in opposition to the United Mine Workers.

Improvement in coal trade conditions is already marked, and there are early prospects of much further improvement. On this subject no other authority outranks Frederick A Saward, editor and proprietor of The Coal Trade Journal, who to a representative of THE NEW TORK TIMES yesterday said:

It is reported that Japanese engineers are preparing plans for the construction of a bridge across the Straits of Shimonoseki, so as to unite the main line of the Kin Sun Railway with that of the Sanyo Railway from Shimonoseki to Hiogo. The straits, at the point referred to, are about one mile in width, and the current through them is very rapid.

-- The project of arranging a special course of physical training for the freshmen at Harvard is very good, as far as it goes, but it does not go anything like far enough. The general impression among the great body of persons unfamiliar with the conditions of undergraduate life in our big universities is that athletic sports run rampant and are the dominating element.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- The Navy Department has decided to award to the Winchester Arms Company of Connecticut the contract for supplying the additional 5,000 small rifles needed for the navy and marine corps.

AUSTIN, Texas, Jan. 8. -- Railroad Commissioner Reagan, who up to to-day has been an avowed candidate for United States Senator against Gov. Culberson and Senator Roger Q. Mills, has issued a formal card withdrawing from the race. He says that private business affairs and other personal reasons cause his action.

Two horses attached to a coach in which were Mrs. George Falk, her daughter, and her son, George, aged twenty-three years, all of 21 East Eighty-first Street, dashed down Park Avenue from Eighty-first Street to Fifty-ninth Street last night about 8:20 o'clock, overturning two bicycle policemen, and spreading terror among the pedestrians along their course.

The announcement of an Anglo-Japanese alliance is not exactly official, and yet there is no reason for doubting it. Nor is there any for doubting the supplementary announcement that Japan has placed a powerful squadron not only at the disposal of Great Britain, but under the orders of the British Admiral on the Chinese station.

PITTSBURG, Kan., Jan. 8. -- Six lives are supposed to have been lost by an explosion probably of dust or gas at 6:40 o'clock this evening in Shaft No. 5 of the Mount Carmel Company mine, six and a half miles south of here, near Chicopee.

Sheppard Homans, Consulting Actuary for the Mutual Life Insurance Company and President of the Provident Savings Life Assurance Society, died suddenly, probably from heart failure, within a block of his home, 48 West Fifty-ninth Street, last night on his return from business.

For a long time many of the best equipped and successful educators in this city have declared that there must sooner or later be a reaction of the craze for psychology in pedagogics that seemed to be sweeping all before it, placing the so-called soul-individuality and psychic tendencies above the simple transference of knowledge to an alarming degree.

Senator Thomas C. Platt arrived from Washington yesterday morning, and in the afternoon there was a gathering of a number of up-State politicians, members of the Legislature, and some of the local leaders at the Fifth Avenue Hotel. Charles W. Hackett, the Chairman of the Republican State Committee; Edward Lauterbach, Lemuel E. Quigg, Speaker James M.E. O'Grady, Louis F. Payn, Senators Ellsworth, Raines, and Lexow, Collector Bidwell, and Lieut. Gov. Woodruff were present.

NEWPORT, Jan. 8. -- Considerable has been said in newspapers about the mortar battery at Fort Adams being troublesome for the Summer residents after next Spring. It has been suggested that the firing of the mortar guns will cause a breakage of windows, glassware, and light furniture in the cottages about the neighborhood of the fort.

THE display of dogs, cats, rabbits, cavies, , at all the great shows in Great Britain and Continental Europe is not entirely confined to the commoners, as is generally supposed, but Princes, Dukes, Lords, and others high in the charmed circle of nobility enter their pets in open competition against all comers, be they of the royal house or the laboring man.

Little is known of the new play to he produced at the Knickerbocker Theatre to-morrow night, save that it is the work of Rudolph Stratz, a German dramatist, and is called in the original "Der Lange Preusse." Achim von Lohde, to be impersonated by Bassett Roe, is presumably the title role in the German.

In many ways the stock market during the week past has broadened materially. The volume of business is largely increased. The market's strength has been much emphasized. At the start it looked as if this betterment might be confined to a few special groups of securities, but as the improvement has progressed it has grown more comprehensive, until finally practically every part of the market is embraced in the improvement.

Dr. Joseph D. Bryant, the family physician of ex-President Cleveland, was operated upon yesterday afternoon in Bellevue Hospital. A tumor had been bothering Dr. Bryant for some time on the side of the head, and he determined to have it removed. He had just finished an operation on a patient when he lay down on the table himself.

IN its task of relieving the miners of the Yukon region from the sufferings incidental to a Winter passed without adequate provision in a climate of arctic severity, the Federal Government chiefly relies upon the knowledge and efforts of the Rev. Sheldon Jackson.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan 8. -- Those madmen who are now rushing toward Alaska will have cause bitterly to regret their haste. Nothing can be gained by daring the fierce storms, intense cold, and indescribable privations that lie in wait in every pass and mountain trail from tidewater to Dawson City.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Jam 8. -- The postponed game of the shooting match at the traps of the Ocean County Hunt and Country Club to-day was a disappointment. The day opened with a strong wind and promise of rain, which accounted for the absence from the competition of many wing shots who had entered for the event.

GUTHRIE, Oklahoma Territory, Jan. 8. -- Reports reach here of a threatened lynching near Maud, Oklahoma. Territory, where Mrs. Julia Leard was murdered on Tuesday last. A crowd of highly excited white men have in their custody Lincoln McGelsy, a half-breed negro Seminole, who is suspected of the crime.
It would be difficult to tell from the appearance of a certain pleasant little parlor uptown exactly the character of the woman to whom it belongs.

Edgar H. Holbrook fell from the fourth to the ground floor of the New York Life Insurance Company's building, at Broadway and Leonard Street, yesterday noon, and received injuries which, it is feared, will prove fatal. Both his legs were broken, and his body was badly bruised in many places.
SEATTLE, Washington, Jan. 8. -- T.B. Corey of Seattle, one of the men who arrived here from the Klondike on the steamer City of Seattle, says:

It is not surprising that many persons should be found in San Francisco to declare their belief that DURRANT, who was hanged on Friday, was innocent of the crime for which he suffered. That will always be the case when a conviction has been had upon circumstantial evidence and the prisoner persists in protesting his innocence.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- A careful poll of the Republican members of the House of Representatives is being made with a view to learning exactly how many may be depended on to vote for a repeal or material modification of the Civil Service law. The work is being done by the steering committee recently appointed at a Republican conference.

Our English friends' habit of eschewing logic and system has been of great service to them in many ways, but it has its drawbacks. Some 20,000 soldiers leave the English service each year, of whom three-quarters at least are between the ages of twenty-five and thirty. They are obviously at some disadvantage in obtaining employment, as they are as a rule without specific trades, or have lost the skill they may have had.

According to a local Ovid a man who calls on a girl who preference for him is marked, and who attempts to outstay the other fellow is a fool who hazards his prospects by his persistency. If he is pretty sure of her, he should withdraw early, apparently leaving the field in posssession of his rival.

The Ohio Society of New York turned its twelfth annual banquet, held last night in the Astor Gallery of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, into a grand demonstration in honor of ex-Mayor William L. Strong. It was essentially a Strong affair. The invitations proclaimed the fact, and the menus bore an excellent likeness of the ex-Mayor done in halftone.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- New York will not have to bear the entire loss of the carrier service to be dispensed with in order to enable the Post Office Department to save $100,000 between this date and June 30. It will share its inconvenience, if any reduction is made, with Boston and Philadelphia.

MACON, Ga., Jan. 8. -- The answer of the Southern Railway in the case of the Dunlop Hardware Company et al. against the Southern Railway was filed in the United States court this evening. This is the case in which merchants and business men of Macon are attempting to break the alleged unlawful combination of railroads made by the Southern Railway, which combination, they allege, is for the purpose of stifling competition.

The store of E.B. Meyrowitz Co., at 104 East Twenty-third Street, was robbed for the third time early yesterday morning. One of the show windows of the place was broken and about $600 worth of goods are reported as massing. The firm deals in field and opera glasses and spectacles. How the robbery was committed cannot be explained.

Through Cardinal Ledochowski, Prefect of the Congregation for the Propagaiton of the Faith, in Rome, Pope Leo XIII. has issued a decree concerning the faithful of the Eastern rite who live in North America. For years the relations of Oriental Catholics in this country to the authorities of the Church of Rome here have been a constant source of trouble.

The unnatural behavior of the January stars portends a year of sore trouble for Mr. THOMAS C. PLATT. The political fruitage of the Autumn will be of extraordinary richness. A Governor and Lieutenant Governor, State officers, both branches of the Legislature, and thirty-four members of Congress will be chosen.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- The civil service debate was continued in the House to-day until 2 o'clock. The remainder of the session, under a special order, was devoted to eulogizing the memory of Representative Wright of Massachusetts.

THE longer I live the more I am impressed with the greatness of Verdi. Not the Verdi of the long-signing and mellifluous "Traviata" period, when he made operas for people who insult the art of opera by their conception of it, but the Verdi of "Aida," "Otello," and "Falstaff " -- that is the Verdi I reverence.

January of the present year of grace seems likely to be marked upon the record of New York society with a red letter. Its opening week, which closed last night, was pleasantly gay and brought a crowding number of incidents and events, while the programme for its remaining three weeks is better filled than has been that of its predecessors for the past ten years.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 8. -- Senator Hanna thinks to-night his election is sure. His managers say they see the necessary 73 votes for him, and that the tide of popular sentiment will make his vote larger than is necessary next Tuesday. The Senator's managers claim if there was a ballot to-night Hanna would be elected by a vote of 75 to 70.

CHICAGO, Jan 8. -- A host of Democrats, quite a number of them from Iowa, Indiana, and Wisconsin, celebrated Jackson Day by a banquet at the Tremont House this evening. William J. Bryan was the principal guest. He reached Chicago from Lincoln this morning, being met at the station by National Committeeman Gahan and others selected to welcome him.

With no interference by the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children and with no interruption, save now and then a delay in scene shifting, the first performance of the operetta "Cinderella" took place yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House.

The joy with which I hail the statement in this day's TIMES, that the anti-vivisectionists, with their harrowing details of midnight prowlings, with grim visage and tallow dip, in search of trembling little dogs to anti-vivisect, have betaken themselves to Baltimore and secured quarters there for the Winter, is not quite without alloy, for -- there are others.

The New York Cooking School has reached a height this season that it has never before attained in all its past years of successful work. It has risen literally two stories in the air, and many degrees in scientific arrangements.

THE question of what is and what is not immoral in plays will never be settled until art is either altogether banished from the theatre or again prevails in it above commercialism, expediency, and the amiable desire to employ the drama for the entertainment of children and fools.

For the last indoor race meet of importance for New York this Winter, an evening of well varied sport was provided last night at Madison Square Garden. Local enthusiasm was aroused by a tandem team pursuit race between cycle club representatives of the city, and much interest centred in an international team pursuit event; exciting events for amateur riders and those of the professional class were added.

LAKEWOOD, Jan. 8. -- The ball given in the Laurel House New Year's Eve eclipsed in beauty and attractiveness any previous ball given in that house. The decorations of greens were artistic, and graceful. The office, sun parlor, reading room, audience room, and ballroom, had each received the same careful attention, and the result was a veritable bower of green.

READING, Penn., Jan. 8. -- An extraordinary coal discovery has been made near Tower City, Schuylkill County. In 1820 John Seeley Son of New York visited that section prospecting for coal. The tunnel from which the large bed of red shale was taken out, and that now stands as a small mountain north of Tower City, was opened by them.

FRITZCHEN drew a long breath of delight. It certainly was a glorious day, and how could it be enjoyed more than on a bicycle -- and a Christmas bicycle at that -- on the Brooklyn Bridge on a crisp winter's morning? It seemed as if all the air in the world was there.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 8. -- Four colored men have been lynched in the vicinity of Bearden, Ark., within the last few days, two for assault and the others for murder. The first two, Devoe and Huntley, were swung up near Harlow Mill Branch, about three miles north of Bearden, while the murderers met their fate near the town of Little Bay, a few miles south of Bearden.

People who follow with interest what is going on in the art world are looking for signs from the Eternal City. It is there that the American Academy of Fine Arts hires the quiet premises of the Villa Ludovici; it is thither that the Academy has sent two architects, two sculptors, and a painter.

At the National Assembly of the League of American Wheelmen last February political strife obstructed the introduction of many measures of a reform tendency. As the time for this year's gathering approaches, the shades of the year old reform fabrics and propositions of more or less novelty fill the air.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 8. -- The police are investigating a most mysterious murder here. Wednesday night a well-dressed white man of middle age was found in an unconscious condition in a freight car in the Iron Mountain yards, in North Little Rock. The man was taken to the hospital, where he died without regaining consciousness.

THERE has been a scene of strife and warfare in Kansas, during a period of almost three month, in which battle after battle has been fought and in which every condition of actual warfare has prevailed, save one -- the use of ball cartridges.

The thirteenth anniversary of the organization of the New York Post-Graduate Hospital was celebrated yesterday and several hundred people visited the institution, at Second Avenue and Twentieth Street, it being thrown open for visitors all day.

READING, Penn., Jan. 8. -- Sadie Muldrew, a young woman, who says she lives near Wheeling, West Va., is in jail here on the charge of shoplifting. Her confederate, also in prison here, is Frank Willard Childress. They are a mysterious couple, and Chief of Police Albrecht has been investigating their records.
Waldo G. Morse, a member of the New York and New Jersey Palisades Commission, has issued the following:

BOSTON, Jan. 8. -- The annual reorganization meeting of the Democratic State Central Committee, which was held at the American House this afternoon, resulted in a split, the anti-Williams men, headed by ex-Senator George P. Cooke of Milford and Daniel H. Coakley of Boston, leaving the meeting in a body.

A question the decision of which, it is said, will be of the greatest importance to attorneys and litigants was brought up before Justice Cohen, in the Supreme Court, yesterday, and will be argued to-morrow. The decision will set at reset the question of whether the old Civil District Courts or the Municipal Courts created by the new charter now hold.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- A short time ago it seemed certain that the majority in the next Congress must be Democratic and for free silver. Many prominent Republicans have been quoted as holding that opinion, and Silver Democrats, including Mr. Bland, are still very confident that they will "sweep the country."

BOSTON, Jan. 8. -- Chief Consul Sterling Elliott of the Massachusetts Division of the League of American Wheelmen to-day gave out the following interesting opinion on the power of divisions to instruct their National delegates on questions at issue:

BERLIN, Jan. 8. -- The Reichstag will reassemble on Tuesday, and the Budget Commission will forthwith begin its deliberations. The chances of the Naval bill are materially improved. The Conservatives, with the exception of the Agrarian wing, the National Liberals, and a fraction of the Radicals new generally favor the measure, while a split among the Centrists is in process of formation.

The story of "Alice in Wonderland" was told and acted by a score or more of young children at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday afternoon in a most interesting and fascinating manner. It was in the nature of a play, and was given under the direction of Miss Amy Baker.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- The Inter-State Commerce Commission new has under consideration the question of enforcement of Section 3,006 of the Revised Statutes, with special reference to Section 6 of the Inter-State Commerce act.

VIENNA, Dec. 24. -- The deadlock in the Austro-Hungarian Empire, as foreshadowed in previous letters of mine, has actually come about and the situation is graver than ever. There is a threefold crisis: an Austrian crisis, a Hungarian crisis, and an imperial crisis. The terrific storms in the Austrian Parliament, the disgraceful scenes of uproar and violence unprecedented in any European assembly, finally swept away the reactionary Badeni Ministry.

Dobbins, who as a two-year-old ran a sensational dead heat with James R. Keene's great colt Domino, and who afterward went to England to race, is to go into training again. Dobbins is entered in the City and Suburban of the Epson Spring meeting, and in the Jubilee Stakes to be run at Kempton, England.

That colored folks have a florid taste in nomenclature is well known. The finer the name, the more certain the dusky mother is of bestowing it on her offspring. Nancy and Betsy have had their day, and in their stead appear Lilian, Gladys, Stella, and Mabel. However, it sometimes happens that the owner of an uncommon name is not pleased to be thus singled out from the vulgar herd of Johns and Janes.

TACOMA, Wash., Jan. 9. -- Large ledges of copper and gold ore have lately been uncovered on Gravina, Annette, and Revillagigedo Islands, on the Southeastern Alaska Coast. Prospectors declare that these, together with Mary and Prince of Wales Island, contain mountains of rich ore that will make their ultimate possessors immensely wealthy.

At the meeting of the Druggists' League for shorter hours to be held on Wednesday at the Gramercy Lyceum, the Executive Committee of the League will lay the evidence from certain accidental poisoning cases before the meeting and ask the consent of the members to bring the whole question before the Grand Jury.

BOSTON, Jan. 9. -- Wallace Ross, the well-known oarsman, in an interview here describes the English and American styles of rowing and watermanship, and has this to say of Mr. Lehmann, the Harvard coach:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- Interest in the Senate this week will centre probably in a debate of the treaty for the annexation of Hawaii, which will be taken up Monday. Senator Davis has given notice that he will move an executive session of the Senate for consideration of the treaty each day until the treaty shall be disposed of.

Dr. Lyman Abbott continued his series of sermons on St. Paul last night in Plymouth Church. He treated of the Epistles to the Corinthians, and declared that Paul inculcated the doctrine that Christ brought liberty to every man, but it was to be used righteously. Every man had the right to decide for himself whether he would drink liquor or not, whether he would ride a bicycle on Sunday or not.

-- It is all very well for the postal authorities to reprove the people who are already addressing letters to the outlying sections of this city without indicating what particular section the letters are intended to reach, but it is really rather humiliating for our new townsmen, and rather confusing to their correspondents, that the only instruction they get is to go on doing exactly as in the past.

" The Meaning of Temperance as an Aid to Spiritual Life" was the subject of Prof. Felix Adler's address yesterday before the Society for Ethical Culture at Carnegie Music Hall. A large audience was present.

RAHWAY, N.J., Jan. 9. -- Louis O'Neil, ten years old, was injured to-day at the railroad station here, and died a few hours later in the Elizabeth Hospital. The boy's father, with his two sons, aged ten and twelve years, went to the station to take the Perth Amboy accommodation train. They reached the station just as the train was pulling out, and ran to catch it.

PITTSBURG, Kan., Jan. 9. -- The bodies of John Possing, Charles Winters, and Antoine Weinberger, the miners who last night were thought to be still alive in the Mount Carmel Coal Company's mine, were brought up at noon to-day. Neither Weinberger nor Winters's body showed signs of having suffered any violence, and it is believed they were suffocated.

FORT SMITH, Ark., Jan. 9. -- On the Oklahoma border Friday night Marcus McGeisey and Palmer Simpson, two Seminole Indians, were burned at the stake by a mob. They were charged with murder, their victim being Mrs. James Simmons, an Oklahoma farmer's wife.
They who are in closest touch with the business world are most confident of the security of the situation and the brightness of prospects.
BOSTON, Jan. 9. -- The National Executive Board of the Mule Spinners' Union met in Boston this morning to consider the recent cuts in the wages of cotton mill operatives in New England.

ALBANY, Jan. 9. -- The preparations for the annual gathering of organized labor representatives are well under way, and the indications point to a larger attendance at the State convention here Tuesday than has ever before been seen at these assemblies.
The Rev. Dr. John Hall, who has been pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church more than thirty years, announced his resignation at the morning service in the church yesterday.

Dwight L. Moody, the evangelist, began yesterday at 3 P.M., in Carnegie Hall, a series of meetings that will continue throughout the week and be held twice daily. The object of these meetings, which are a sequel to the ones held last Winter in Cooper Union, is announced to be "the deepening of the spiritual life" of this city.

PRINCETON, Jan. 9. -- Princeton University's prohibition order went into effect Thursday with the reopening of college after the Christmas recess. The basis of this much-talked-of order has been on the books for many years, but the words "nor shall any student frequent any place where intoxicating liquors are sold as a beverage" have been interpreted liberally by the Faculty to mean a habitual frequenting or drinking to excess.
TYRONE, Penn., Jan. 9. -- George Haverty, a teamster, after an unsuccessful attempt to murder his sister, Mrs. Kate Hull, and nephew, Bert Hull, to-day, committed suicide by shooting himself.

PARIS, Jan. 9. -- Comte Ferdinand Walsin Esterhazy of the French Army, who is accused of the authorship of letters published recently in The Figaro reflecting upon France and the army, surrendered to-night at the Cherche-Midi Prison for trial by court-martial, ordered by Gen. Saussier, Military Governor of Paris.

ALBANY, Jan. 9. -- P.H. McDonald, E.C. Bald's manager, who is in this city, says Bald will ride paced exhibitions next season. He will have from twenty to thirty men under contract throughout the year. A number of important match races will be on Bald's programme.

The new faction of the Liberty Dawn Association of Coach Drivers that is opposed to Assemblyman John F. Maher applied for admittance to the Central Labor Union yesterday, and this almost precipitated a row in the meeting of that body.

TRENTON, Jan. 9. -- There is an order of varnish about the State House, and everything is fresh and bright for the coming of the Legislature next Tuesday afternoon. Senator Forster M. Voorhees, who is to become Acting Governor, is authority for the statement that the coming session of the Legislature will be the shortest on record.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Jan. 9. -- Alfred Roberts of this place has presented to the local board an itemized bill for $313.15. This is for damage done by water to goods in his store during a recent fire.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- It is believed at the Navy Department that the showing made not only by Constructor Bowles, but by the Board of Civil Engineers recently appointed, as to the faulty character of the work in the construction of Dry Dock No. 3, Brooklyn Navy Yard, will result in steps being taken to court-martial Civil Engineer A.G. Menocal.

I have been waiting for fully six months to see if some friends of the late Joseph Richardson would not make some reply to the sensational articles that have frequently appeared in the "yellow journals" touching the "Spite House" and other exaggerations.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 9. -- The Senatorial situation has not changed to-day. The conferences continue day and night, and the doubtful members are given no rest, but no such flops were announced to-day as those of the previous two days in favor of Hanna. The workers for the Senator say they now have enough votes.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9. -- George B. Van Fleet, whose failure as a partner in the firm of Van Fleet Brothers, proprietors of a general store at Wakeman, Ohio, ten years ago impoverished Huron County, is behind the bars of the county jail, with the penitentiary in prospect. With charges of conspiracy to defraud a county, bigamy, and obtaining money under false pretenses in the background, he is under indictment for forgery.

Workmen were busy yesterday on the big auxiliary steam yacht Narada, which will join the American yachting colony in the Mediterranean, leaving this port Jan. 15. Carpenters and painters were giving the finishing touches to the craft, which has been thoroughly overhauled at Robin's shipyards, Erie Basin.

A new primaries election law was the subject at last night's conference of Senator Platt and his lieutenants at the Fifth Avenue Hotel. Those present at the deliberations were ex-County Chairman Edward Lauterbach, Congressmen Quigg and Odell, State Chairman Hackett, Senators Ford and Ellsworth, and John Sabine Smith.

PORTLAND, Oregon, Jan. 9. -- Action has been taken in the city looking to the union of all the free-silver forces at the coming State election in June. The State Central Committees of the Democrats and the free-silver Republicans have decided to hold State Conventions in this city March 23. It is understood the Populists and the Union Party also will call their State Conventions in this city for the same date.
" I met a gentleman on the street today whom I have not seen for some time, but the moment my eyes rested upon him. I could see that he was doomed."

SUMMIT, N.J., Jan. 9. -- George Manshanda, who is now in the Union County Jail at Elizabeth, detained as a witness against Louis Rosell, who is in the same institution charged with assaulting Mary Davis and suspected of murdering James C. Pitts at his home near this place on the night of Sept. 9, has made a full confession.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- "I am deeply interested in the progress of monetary reform, and desirous of prompt action by Congress."

Company C won the first match for the Capt. Henry S. Steele Trophy, which was introduced at the Seventh Regiment on Saturday night. The competition takes the place of the team-of-five match, which ended last season, when Company F, for the third time, won the prize, it becoming the company's personal property.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Jan. 9. -- Frank Beckwith, a watchman in the employ of the Ontario and Western Railroad, while in the performance of his duties last night about 9 o'clock, noticed a man acting suspiciously in the freight yard near the station. He ran up behind the man and grasped him about the arms, but the man broke loose and drawing a revolver, shot Beckwith twice through the lungs. Beckwith died this morning.

Mr. WILLIAM J. BRYAN has evidently taken up the encouragement of ignorance and the spreading of misinformation as his life work. At the Jackson banquet in Chicago on Saturday evening he was allowed to speak, and for an hour or more the truths of remote and current American history fell all gnarled and shapeless from his perverting tongue.

ALBANY, Jan. 9. -- The admission of State Engineer Adams that he was persuaded by political pressure to keep silent about the probable cost of the canal improvements while the question was before the people has produced a sensation about the Capitol second only to his letter of a few weeks since to Chairman Hefford.

We pointed out on Friday that the money with which the Union Pacific Railroad was bought, with the exception of about $5,000,000 of European subscriptions to the syndicate, was American capital. It was subscribed and paid in by members of the Reorganization Committee and by bankers and individual capitalists, chiefly in New York, who have confidence in the future of the property.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9. -- W.J. Bryan, in concluding a speech before the Bryan League, at the Tremont House, at a banquet held after the Auditorium meeting early this morning, made some remarks which are interpreted as showing his intentions if he is nominated for the Presidency in 1900. In speaking of the next Presidential election Mr. Bryan said:

MONTREAL, Jan. 9. -- The Iroquois Indians have decided to return to the methods of government which prevailed among their forefathers. Some years ago the Dominion Government brought them under the provisions of the Indian Advancement act, which provided municipal government on virtually the same system as in white settlements.

John E. Redmond, M.P., the Irish leader, who was one of the trusted lieutenants and a confidential friend of Charles Stewart Parnell, last evening drew an immense gathering of enthusiastic Irishmen and other friends of Ireland to the Broadway Theatre, Broadway and Forty-first Street, where he lectured on "Ireland in '98."
The lamented death of Sir Frank Lockwood has resulted in a tremendous crop of stories concerning him. Here are a few:

It was the greatest of poets whose ignorance or carelessness of geography led him to bound Bohemia by the sea. Luckily for mankind, SHAKESPEARE was not an Emperor. Unluckily for the German part of mankind, the Kaiser is a poet. The unities of time and place are no more to him, when he is laying out a policy, than they were to the author of "The Winter's Tale" when he was designing a drama.

It is a striking fact that the three most conspicuous plans authoritatively proposed for the improvement of the currency by the gradual withdrawal of a part at least of the Government notes and the extension of bank-note issues provide for what is called an "elastic" currency.
LONDON, Jan. 10. -- A dispatch from Copenhagen to The Daily Mail says:

The first week of the new year proved an auspicious one in the stock market. At its beginning there was discouragement, but before its end there was again hope everywhere and renewed confidence in early attainment to a much higher level of security values.

PLAINFIELD, Jan. 9. -- The rim of one of the big six-foot driving wheels of the engine drawing the Royal Blue Line Express for Baltimore and Washington, which left Communipaw at 11:30 this morning, burst as the train was rushing past the Netherwood station at 12:10. The wheel went to pieces, and the heavy sections of the rim flew in all directions.

The outlook for the coming season of grand opera at the Metropolitan Opera House under the management of Damrosch Ellis, which opens next Monday night, is very promising, and if the demand for seats placed on sale for the first week at the box office and the agents, Fifth Avenue Hotel and Rullman's, is any criterion the season will be the largest ever in the history of Walter Damrosch's career.

The annual competitions for the Edward Kemp and Col. Emmons Clark Trophies began at the Seventh Regiment ranges last night. Company G occupied the butts, and in the Kemp match, which is contested for by teams of twenty-five officers and enlisted men, each to fire five shots standing and five prone, its team scored 1,023.

The Opera House of Vienna has been considering a question of propriety. The legs of the ballet, are they in harmony with the scruples of the age? The verdict has been that the flesh-colored coverings are more or less unseemly, and that the corps de ballet, which as the Irishman said, is "like the Manx arms, essentially legs," must cover the said legs with roomy white satin stockings.
CAMDEN, N.J., Jan. 10. -- The trial of Mrs. Florence McCusker, charged with the murder of her husband, Michael McCusker, began to-day before Judges Garrison and Armstrong.

The Mothers' Congress met at the Broadway Tabernacle yesterday afternoon to listen to a paper by Mrs. Harry Hastings, President of the Society for the Study of Child Nature, on that subject, read, in the absence of Mrs. Hastings, by Mrs. Theodore Einstein. The paper said that the society, in its researches, had run upon the rock which has been the stumbling block of the women of the century.
Mayer S. Auerbach has sold 58 East Eleventh Street to Frank Brettell, who will erect an eight-story business building there.

A slight error in the certification of a check for $18,112,50, given to W. Hawley Co. of 28 Broad Street for 100 shares of Consolidated Gas stock yesterday, aroused the suspicions of the brokers after the stock had been delivered and hypothecated, and led to the exposure of a cleverly planned swindle and an arrest.

DUNKIRK, N.Y., Jan. 10. -- Gideon Granger, who was on his way to this place, in custody of an officer, to answer the charge of forgery, jumped through the window of a car closet, as the train on the Lake Shore Railroad was approaching Derby, a few miles west of Buffalo, this morning, and has not been recaptured.

ALBANY, Jan. 10. -- The announcement made in New York that the Republican leaders will introduce in the Legislature a Primary Election bill which will receive the support of the organization in both branches is confirmed here on the authority of representatives of the administration. That such a measure was in contemplation has been known for some time.
Mrs. Augusta Nack, indicted for the murder of William Guldensuppe, appeared in the Queens County Court yesterday and received a sentence of fifteen years in Auburn Prison.

When the battleship Iowa arrived at Hampton Roads on Saturday the forward turret with its pair of twelve-inch guns was crippled to such an extent that they could not be used, and one of the men attached to the powder magazine was confined to the "sick bay" with a badly injured head.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- The Republican member of the House opposed to the civil service law presented a bold front when efforts were made to-day by members of the Committee on Rules to learn when the pending civil service debate could be brought to a close.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 10. -- Senator Hanna is believed to be short one vote of the number necessary to elect him. The opposition is not sure of 73 votes for any one man, as against 72 for Hanna, but they feel confident at least of preventing Hanna's election.

Members of the Alumni Association of Wesleyan University are enjoying the fuss that is being made over the wine at their annual dinner, Dec. 10, at the Hotel Savoy. On that occasion, it appears, some of the alumni ordered wine and drank it, and Voice, the prohibition organ, has had a great deal to say about the matter ever since.

ALBANY, Jan. 10. -- Secretary George McAneny, of the Civil Service Reform Association, with headquarters at 54 William Street, New York, was at the Capitol to-day, examining the records of the State Civil Service Commission. Mr. McAneny was in search of data for a report on the operations of the State law as enforced by Gov. Black, which will be made public, he says, within a few days.

On behalf of the cycle and good-roads organizations of the city the committee of delegates from these bodies met yesterday at the headquarters of the League of American Wheelmen, State Division, in the Vanderbilt Building, to consider measures toward continuing the demand for a pathway over the bridge.

Washington, Jan. 10. -- M de Routkowsky, financial agent of Russia and attached to the legation here, at the request of Assistant Secretary Howell has given an account of the reform of the Russian currency as established during the year just closed. The statement substantially is as follows:

HAVANA, Jan. 10. -- Gen. Ruiz, while operating near Pozos, in the vicinity of Sancti Spiritus, encountered 200 infantry and 300 cavalry under Gen. Maximo Gomez. The insurgents were entrenched in the Hoyo Hills.

By the courtesy of Hon. Edward Atkinson, I have received a copy of your issue of the 28th containing his views on pensions. These views were so clearly stated, were so patriotic in spirit, and so just to the veterans, that I at once wrote to thank him in the name of my comrades for writing the article, and now in the same behalf wish to thank you for publishing it.

The police of the West Thirty-seventh Street Station were informed that a man had attempted to commit suicide last night at 273 West Thirty-eighth Street and a detective was sent there at once. It was found that Dr. Arthur H. Smith, who lives at that address, was suffering from an overdose of laudanum.

The annual meeting of the Young Women's Christian Association was held yesterday afternoon in the assembly hall of the association building, 7 East Fifteenth Street. The meeting was largely attended by persons interested in social and charitable questions. The annual reports were read and the Board of Officers for the present year announced.

In his second day's meetings, held yesterday morning and afternoon at Carnegie Hall, Dwight L. Moody devoted himself more to revivalist work than he had done on Sunday. The audience at the morning service was rather small, but a tremendous gathering of people greeted the evangelist in the afternoon.

WORCESTER, Mass., Jan. 10. -- News of a triple murder, of which Francis D. Newton, a prosperous farmer of Brookfield, has wife, Sarah, and their ten-year-old adopted daughter, Ethel, were the victims, reached this city at an early hour this morning. They were killed in their house, about two miles from Brookfield Canter, on the road to Sturbridge.

LONDON, Jan. 10. -- The Right Hon. Arthur J. Balfour, First Lord of the Treasury and Government leader in the House of Commons, addressed his constituents at Manchester this evening. It was expected that he would make an important announcement of the Government policy in China, but he confined himself to generalities.

BOSTON, Jan. 10. -- John Drew and his company presented here to-night "One Summer's Day," an English comedy by H. V. Esmond, which never before had been played in America. Mr. Drew has a congenial part -- that of a half-pay Major, lazy and yet noble. Miss Elsie De Wolfe as a gypsy finds full opportunity for picturesque and dramatic work.

The jury in the case of Mrs. Mary Bowers and her sister, Gertrude Barbero, charged with petit larceny in stealing a feather aigrette from a Fourteenth Street department store, considered the evidence four hours, and gave a verdict at 10:30 o'clock last night of guilty, and made a recommendation for mercy.

" Indigestion is the curse of this country," says a New York medical journal in a recent editorial. "Both men and women suffer from this distressing complaint and it causes a tremendous amount of misery." This is all very true, but there is no reason why any man or woman should suffer from indigestion when there is a ready means of preventing it.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- Messrs. Dittenhoefer, Lauterbach Limburger, counsel for Dr. Cornelius Herz, to-day appeared before Solicitor Penfield at the State Department and presented a claim for indemnity in the sum of $5,000,000 against the French Government for an alleged illegal attempt to persecute Dr. Herz.

The annual meeting of the New York Kindergarten Association was held last night at Carnegie Hall. There was a large attendance addresses were made by Hamilton W. Mabie, President of the organization; Bishop Henry C. Potter, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, Richard Watson Gilder, Alfred Bishop Mason, Treasurer of the association; Miss Runyon of the Teachers College, and Miss Locke of the Pratt Institute.

SING SING, Jan. 10. -- Hedley Adolphus Sutherland, the mulatto murderer, was executed at the State Prison here to-day. There was no hitch in the proceedings, the condemned man keeping up to the end, and meeting his doom with a prayer on his lips.

A firm believer in the existence of improved conditions of general business, and hopeful of a continuance of them under the still brighter outlook which he sees ahead, Mr. H.T. Carey of the Stock Exchange house of H.T. Carey Co. yesterday expressed the opinion that a further advance in the price of stocks will be only natural, and that activity in speculation may be looked for.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 10. -- The American Turf Congress Board of Appeals met here this afternoon, but transacted no business until to-night, when it was decided not to reinstate John Brannon and the others who had been pulled off for cause, but it did reinstate all trainers, owners, and jockeys who have raced over outlawed tracks west of the eighty-first meridian.

HAVANA, Jan. 10. -- The insurgents are besieging and have attacked the Port of Mayari, on the north coast of the Province of Santiago de Cuba. Troops have left Gibara, the northern port in the same province, to relieve the garrison of Mayari.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- Senator Chandler had a conference with President McKinley to-day upon the subject of bimetallism, and he said after the close of the interview:
It is not financial strength, but financial uncertainty, that causes this unprecedented condition.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- Postmaster General Gary has sent to the Senate a reply to the resolution asking what positions should be exempt from the civil service rules. He says:

Frederic P. Olcott, President of the Central Trust Company, will to-day issue an official statement of an amended plan of union in the matter of the consolidation of the Equitable Gas Light and the New York and East River Gas Companies. The Directors of the two companies have agreed on the new plan. By a two-thirds vote the stockholders must ratify it.

Miss Blanche Burnell has been asked for a bill of particulars in her suit against William F. Coles, a reputed millionaire and well-known society and club man in this city and Boston. The suit is to recover $50,000 damages for breach of promise of marriage.

Mayor Van Wyck's second week in office began with none of the rush and excitement that characterized his first days as Mayor. Most of the important posts have been filled, and as a consequence few office seekers called on the Mayor yesterday. Assemblyman Julius Harburger was his first visitor, and talked with him about excise matters.

The new play produced by Julia Marlowe at the Knickerbocker Theatre last evening deserves its place in her repertory. It is a sound, well-made romantic drama, with a possible story, effective climaxes, and some sort of historical interest. "The Tall Prussian" is the name of the original play, which was written in German by Rudolph Stratz.

The trial of ESTERHAZY seems to have reached a lame and impotent conclusion almost before it has been begun. The trial has been compelled by public opinion in consequence of the increasing doubt in the French mind of the guilt of Capt. DREYFUS. If the trial of ESTERHAZY is not ordered for the purpose of removing that doubt then it has no visible purpose at all.

A protest by Sartorius Co., importers of leaf tobacco, against the action of the customs authorities in imposing "wrapper" duties on bales of filler tobacco, will come up for public hearing before General Appraiser George H. Sharpe to-morrow morning. Tobacco importers generally regard this as one of the most important issues yet raised against the ruling of the Treasury Department on tobacco importations.

The Engineering Record has made what it calls "a careful study" of the charges against State Engineer ADAMS and Superintendent ALDRIDGE in connection with the canal estimates and concludes that the "attack" upon these officers is unjustifiable. Our technical contemporary evidently misunderstands the matter.

ALBANY, Jan. 10. -- Gov. Black to-night issued a proclamation ordering that the nuisances which exist on Barren island, Kings County, be abated on or before April 1 next. This means the wiping out of the conditions that have formed the subject of many complaints to the State and local Boards of Health.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10. -- The Western New York and Pennsylvania Railway Company to-day re-elected its old Board of Directors. The report submitted by President De Coursey showed the gross earnings from July 1 to Dec. 31 to have been $1,850,622, an increase of $179,4S6 .compared with the same period in 1896.

The most serious obstacle to stable currency reform, so far, has been the narrow partisan feeling of a few extreme Republicans. These men -- and unfortunately they are in a position strongly to influence the course of the majority in Congress -- have reasoned that their party would make a better showing in a fight with out-and-out free coinage than in any other contest.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- Naval Constructor Bowles, attached to the New York Navy Yard, came to the Navy Department to-day to consult with Secretary Long and Assistant Secretary Roosevelt respecting the work upon the big dry dock at the yard now under repair.
VICTORIA, Jan. 10. -- Richard Morgan, just from Dawson City, throws new light on the food situation there, and also on the general conditions and present necessities of the camp.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Jan. 10. -- The headless body of an infarct was found to-day in Montclair by two school boys. The police are led to believe that the child was carried alive to where it was found, and then its head cut off with a knife, while the murderer placed the child upon m log to obtain the necessary purchase to sever the head.

Those interested financially and in many other ways in the affairs of the musical firm of R.E. Johnson Co. met yesterday afternoon in their office, in the Decker Building, Union Square, for the purpose of perfecting a reorganization. The small receipts from the concerts given at the Metropolitan Opera House every Sunday night have caused an embarrassing tangle in the firm's affairs.
Mr. AMOS CUMMINGS presumes on the ignorance of New York affairs that prevails in Washington when he says in the House of Representatives:

The Police Commissioners held a meeting yesterday afternoon and decided that all applications for employment must he made in writing, and shall be published in the City Record, as well as all appointments. The rules of the police of the Borough of Manhattan were made applicable to the whole force, but a committee, composed of Chief McCullagh, Deputy Chief Mackellar, Inspector Brooks, and Capts. Allaire and Donald Grant, was appointed to revise the rules.

MARIETTA, Jan. 10. -- An interesting question in railroad ligitation submitted to the Court of Common Pleas here today was argued by C. Elliott Minor of New York and F. A Durban of Zanesville, Ohio. The question arose on the foreclosure of a mortgage for $1,500,000 executed by the Toledo Ohio Central Extension Railroad Company.

The first of the Tuesday evening dances, a series of interest to the most fashionable people of this season, brought the exclusive set in force to Sherry's last night. After the Assembly these are the most important subscription dances of the season.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- Commissioner Martin A. Knapp was to-day elected Chairman of the Inter-State Commerce Commission to succeed Col. William R. Morrison, whose term of office expired Dec. 31.

Judges are in the habit of deploring the popular failure of respect for the administration of justice. As a matter of fact the mass of people desire to respect the courts and to believe that the article in which they deal is justice, and that they dispense it with reasonable promptness and certainty. But this is a belief hard to maintain with respect to all courts in the face of the facts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- The Senate Committee on Judiciary had the nomination of Attorney General McKenna to be Justice of the Supreme Court under consideration for two hours to-day, but adjourned without reaching a conclusion upon it. The committee adjourned with the understanding that the Chairman should call another meeting for the purpose of taking up the case in advance of the next regular meeting.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- When the attention of Assistant Secretary Howell was called to the difficulties experienced at Detroit and Suspension Bridge by tourists and others in the matter of the detention of their sealskin garments, he immediately sent the following telegram to the Collectors of Customs at those ports:
I desire to call attention further to the urgent need of postal reform, made so plain by recent action of the department in reducing daily deliveries in New York from seven to four.

The more ALDRIDGE and ADAMS confess the blacker the canal scandal looks. ALDRIDGE'S letter to Controller ROBERTS reads like one of TWEED'S defiant challenges to his accusers. He meets not one single point of the Controller's argument for stopping work until the people, deceived and hoodwinked by ALDRIDGE and ADAMS, have had a chance to express their will at the polls.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- Consul Wiesike, stationed at Managua, Nicaragua, calls the attention of holders of mortgages on coffee plantations in that country to a recent decree which makes preferred creditors of persons advancing money to coffee planters to move their crops. The Consul thinks the decree will prove a hardship to Americans holding plantation mortgages, and will further tend to complicate business conditions.

SOUTH McALESTER, I.T., Jan. 11. -- A telegram received here at 6:40 o'clock this evening by the train dispatcher of the Choctaw, Oklahoma and Gulf Railroad states that a band of 150 Seminole Indians is on the war path and is leaving behind it a trail of blood.

The sixteenth annual meeting of the Church Temperance Society, a Protestant Episcopal working organization, was held in this city yesterday, and was divided into two sessions. The more important and interesting of these was the evening session, which was held in the Astor Gallery of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, and had Bishop Henry C. Potter for its Chairman.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 11. -- George Spencer, alias Reed, alias Greenhalge, of New York, an alleged bunko operator, was arrested at the Reading Railroad Station last night, charged with the larceny of $3,500 from Charles Sweitzer, an aged farmer, of Chelmsford, Mass. After a hearing this morning he was held to await requisition papers from Massachusetts.
The Frank L. Fisher Company has sold for James Livingston, for about $100,000, the seven-story apartment house Orienta, 153 and 155 East Seventy-second Street, 39.11 by 102.2.
There was a large attendance of members of the Bar Association last evening at the annual meeting in the clubhouse, in Forty-third Street, near Fifth Avenue. These officers were elected:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- In the Senate to-day Mr. Gallinger, (Rep., N.H.,) Chairman of the Committee on Pensions, reported adversely from the committee a bill to grant a pension of $100 a month each to Margaret Butler Meade and Henrietta Meade, daughters of the late Major Gen. George Gordon Meade, and asked that the bill be postponed indefinitely.

A demand for concerted action on matters affecting all wheelmen within the immediate neighborhood of New York led to the projection of the United Cycling Associations, composed of the Associated Cycling Clubs of New York, of New Jersey, and of Long Island, together with the Westchester Cyclers' League. New Jersey diffidence was ascribed as the failure of the enterprise.
We fear that Mr. McKINLEY has been trifling with Senator CHANDLER. It would be better for all concerned if he had not.

Unless Edward Gittle of 236 Wyckoff Avenue, Brooklyn, changes his programme touching the hour of parting from his fiancee, Miss Marguerite Cappler, who lives at 299 Jefferson Avenue, he is liable to get a drenching with hot water. Judge Lemon suggested in this form of punishment yesterday when Gittle was arraigned in the Ewen Street Police Court on a summons obtained by Miss Cappler's mother who accused Gittle of striking her.

Mr. GEORGE GOULD announces through The Sun that the Manhattan Elevated Railway Company has decided to introduce electric motive power on the elevated roads. "I wish it understood," he says, "that we purpose to work energetically along the lines indicated in Mayor VAN WYCK'S message and leave nothing undone to adapt our accomodations in the fullest possible degree to the requirements and comfort of the public."

A motion was made yesterday before Judge Lacombe, in the United States Circuit Court, by Judge G.H. Yaeman and Roger Foster, representing the Leavenworth, Topeka and Southwestern Railway, to stay the sale of $16,000,000 of securities of the insolvent Union Pacific Railroad, which was set for this afternoon.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Oklahoma Territory, Jan. 11. -- There is an uprising in the Seminole nation, and 100 armed Indians have killed twenty-five citizens of Pottawatomie County, this Territory.

J. Havelock Wilson, member of Parliament and General President of the Sailors and Firemen's Union of Great Britain, gave an address last evening before the Social Reform Club, in which he compared the treatment of sailors on American vessels with that of those on British vessels, and showed that the English sailor's lot is much more pleasant.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- In contradiction of almost daily reports here that the President is about to nominate Mr. Bowers of West Virginia to be Fish Commissioner, at the request of Senator Elkins, it is learned from a man connected with the Administration that the President, who has had his attention directed to the fact that the candidate of Mr. Elkins does not answer the requirements of the law, may not appoint him after all.

As was told in this paper a week ago, the case of the People against Charles Zanoli on the charge of homicide has practically fallen to pieces. This was officially shown yesterday by a verbal report made to District Attorney Gardiner by Dr. Witthaus, who has been conducting the analysis of parts of the body of Zanoli's fourth wife, Jennie Suhmer.

LONDON, Jan. 12. -- A special dispatch from Monte Carlo says that a meeting of the shareholders of the Casino Company has accepted the exorbitant terms of Prince Albert of Monaco for the renewal of the Casino lease.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- Miss Helen Long, daughter of the Secretary of the Navy, will christen the first Japanese warship to be launched in the United States. The ceremony will take place at Cramps ship yards, in Philadelphia, on the 20th instant. The Japanese Minister, Toru Hoshi, requested Miss Long to perform the ceremony of naming the ship, and, with her father's assent, she has accepted the invitation.

The evidence accumulates that the City of New York has made a huge mistake in the Manhattan Valley viaduct. Engineers of experience in like work seem to agree that the so-called "specification" under which the contract has been let is so vague that the contractor is at the mercy of the engineer, unless indeed the engineer puts himself at the mercy of the contractor.

Hawaiian Sugar made a new record for itself yesterday, selling up to 31 1/4. The stock was traded in to the extent of over 5,000 shares. Washington houses were large buyers, and this fact strengthened Wall Street's belief in the probability of the Senate's speedy agreement to the Hawaiian an nexation project.

The Rev. Herman Paul Faust, formerly a Jewish rabbi, was last night ordained into the ministry of the Presbyterian Church in the Allen Street Presbyterian Church, in Forsyth Street, near Delancey Street. The sermon of ordination was preached by Prof. Brown of the Union Theological Seminary. The Rev. Dr. Lawrence and the Rev. Dr. Gage assisted in the ceremony of ordination.

ALBANY, Jan. 11. -- Speaker O'Grady and Thomas F. Donnelly, the Democratic leader in the Assembly, returned to the capital today. Mr. Donnelly came up early to look after the assignment of members of the minority to committee places, but he so far has failed to secure an audience with the Speaker, who has remained in seclusion since his arrival.

Dwight L. Moody speaks to a larger audience at each meeting in Carnegie Hall. Probably 2,500 persons gathered to hear him yesterday morning, while not more than 1,000 had heard him the morning before. In the afternoon meeting yesterday the hall was filled from floor to loft, and there were almost as many persons assembled as had come out on Sunday, and many more than had attended the meeting Monday afternoon.

-- They have been taking a careful census in Japan lately -- as, indeed, they do every year -- and it is announced that MUTSUHITO'S subjects now number 42,708,264. The population of "Everlasting Great Japan," therefore, is about the same as that of the United States in 1874, a date at which we considered ourselves quite numerous enough to do most things we had a mind to undertake.

GREYTOWN, Nicaragua, Jan. 3. -- The Nicaragua Canal surveying parties have gone into the jungle and work has begun all along the line of the proposed route. Lieut. G.C. Hanus will make soundings in the river and lake to or below Tambor Grande. He will note the stages of water and gauge it.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- Except for a few minutes given to a controversy over some minor Post Office confirmations, the entire time of the executive session of the Senate to-day was consumed by Senator Davis of Minnesota in a speech in support of Hawaiian annexation. Mr. Davis is Chairman of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations, and his speech was generally accepted as the semi-official utterance of the majority of the committee.

Stockholders of National banks met yesterday in this city and elected Directors, and in some instances officers, for 1898. In the majority of cases the outgoing Boards of Directors were re-elected. The changes were, as a rule, unimportant, and in no instance was there a contested election.
TRENTON, Jan. 11. -- Gov. Griggs sent to the Senate this afternoon the following nominations:

WEST POINT, Jan. 11. -- The regular examinations of the corps of cadets began a week ago yesterday, and the Academic Board this afternoon made known the results. Thirty-nine cadets were discharged from the academy. Of those found deficient one belonged to the second class, thirteen to the third class, and twenty-five to the fourth class, as follows:

CHICAGO, Jan. 11. -- At the annual meeting of the North Chicago Street Railroad to-day it was announced that the receipts from all sources were $2,911,552.41. The operating expenses were $1,319,926.63, a decrease of $75,000. The net earnings amounted to $1,591,625.78. The percentage earned on stock was 14.47; the percentage of operating expenses, 46.83, and the number of passengers carried, 56,354,147.

BUTTE, Mont., Jan. 11. -- Patrick A. Largey, President of the State Savings Bank and one of the best known citizens of Butte, was killed in the bank this afternoon by Thomas J. Riley. Riley called Largey to the cashier's window, where the two talked for five minutes.
MADRID, Jan. 11. -- In his first optimistic dispatch to the Government, received today, Gen. Blanco says harvest has commenced in Cuba and the customs receipts have increased.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- Charles W. Russell, assistant attorney in the Department of Justice, returned to-day from Cuba, where he has spent two weeks investigating the conditions prevailing on the island.

According to the forthcoming annual report of the Chamber of Commerce for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1897, the total value of foreign imports in 1896-7 was $880,278,419, of which $556,948,811 was entered at the port of New York. The total value of domestic exports was $1,127,701,948, of which amount New York is credited with $467,624,856.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 11. -- Senator Hanna has won his fight. On the first ballot for United States Senator, which was taken in both houses of the Legislature to-day, he received 73 votes -- 17 in the Senate and 56 in the House. Nineteen Senators and 49 members of the House voted for Mayor McKisson of Cleveland, and 3 members of the House scattered their votes among three other candidates.

Tariff protests docketed under the head of "Laces, lace articles, nettings, veilings, " had a public hearing before ex-Judge Henderson Somerville, Charles H. Ham, and George C. Tichenor, comprising the Customs Board of Classification, yesterday. Several samples of goods were submitted by the protesting importers, and very little testimony was taken.

The new timber dry dock at the navy yard, officially known as No. 3, is in a far more dangerous condition than was at first supposed. Several new leaks have been discovered, and faulty and weak construction has been found in unexpected places.

TRENTON, Jan. 11. -- The one hundred and twenty-second session of the New Jersey Legislature began this afternoon. The Senate organized by the election of the officers selected by the Republican caucus. The House also elected the Republican caucus candidates. Assemblyman-elect Simpson of Hudson County, who is under indictment, was not in his seat.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- The provision in the Legislative, Executive, and Judicial Appropriation bill for the maintenance of the Civil Service Commission remains in the bill, and the Legislative Appropriation bill has passed the House.

PARIS, Jan. 11. -- The court-martial of Major Count Ferdinand Walsin Esterhazy acquitted that officer to-day. The proceedings were secret. Col. Picquart continued his testimony, and it is said there was great excitement in court when Col. Picquart was confronted with Gen. Gonse, Sub-Chief of the General Staff. It is alleged that sensational incidents followed, Col. Picquart making revelations of exceptional gravity.

The second meeting of the Municipal Assembly began yesterday afternoon at 1 o'clock. Large audiences were present to witness the proceedings, and a dozen policemen were on hand to preserve order. The Board of Aldermen met at 11 o'clock, but took a recess till 1 o'clock, the time of the opening of the Municipal Council. Only a few members were absent from each body when the rolls were called.

ALBANY, Jan. 11. -- A delegation of labor organization representatives waited on Gov. Black this afternoon and urged him to appoint P.F. Keefe of Rochester a representative of the Brotherhood of Railroad Conductors, a member of the State Railroad Commission, to succeed Commissioner Frank M. Baker, whose term of office will expire on Jan. 29.

The celestial mind of our neighbor The Sun is moved to wrath by the preparations now openly making for the defeat of Mr. PLATT'S candidates next Fall. It attributes to the "bitter and irascible spirit" of Mugwumpery THE TIMES'S approving comment on the plans of the anti-Platt Republicans to hold conventions and nominate a full ticket, and it calls the leaders in the movement "scheming traitors."
The various Cabinet officers are engaged in writing a series of letters to the Senate about the President, which are very unpleasant reading.

It might be unfair, and it certainly would be a profitless task, to subject the performance of "The Merry Wives of Windsor" at Daly's Theatre last evening to stern criticism based on serious study of Shakespeare and a comparison with other performances of the same coarse comedy, which is essentially vulgar and overcharged with animalism.
President Charles H. Ham of the Board of United States General Appraisers announced the following reappraisements of merchandise yesterday:
The New York Sun is hardly fair to the advocates of currency reform. It accuses them of seeking chiefly the advantage of "the banks."

The Civil Service Commission, it is said, has decided that under the charter the local provisions supersede the provisions of the Black law. President Knox does not concur wholly in this opinion. It is understood that the Commissioners will formulate the new civil service rules along the lines of this decision.

A rumor was started in Wall Street yesterday that the Second National Bank was to go into liquidation and that its business would be absorbed by the National City Bank. The absorbing corporation, the story went, would make the banking house of the Second its up-town branch, and A. Barton Hepburn, Vice President of the City, would have charge of it.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12. -- A new outfit of equipment of the Pennsylvania's "Pennsylvania Limited" train was on exhibition to-day in the Union Station. It went into active service this afternoon and will continue in use from this time forth. The new equipment is fresh from the Pullman car shops, and it is claimed for it that it is the finest ever turned out by that company.

The Ernst-Marx syndicate has purchased from Bernhard Mahon a tract of about sixty lots, having a frontage of about 430 feet on Third and Fulton Avenues, extending from eighty feet south of One Hundred and Seventy-third Street to 100 feet north of One Hundred and Seventy-fourth Street. Excepting the plot at the southeast corner of Third Avenue and One Hundred and Seventy-third Street, already taken by the city for a school site.

JAMAICA, L.I., Jan. 12. -- There was a collision this afternoon at the entrance of the Jamaica yards between a rapid transit train and one of the big double driver engines of the Long Island Railroad's main line. The big engine crushed the smaller one, and about twelve or fifteen persons were more or less bruised. No one was seriously injured.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Jan. 12. -A sensational incident occurred in the Richmond City Court this morning during the trial of the case of Whitton versus the Augusta Southern and South Carolina and Georgia Railroad.

John Shea, the Commissioner of Bridges, in a statement yesterday, indicated the attitude of the new Administration toward affording a safe and convenient means of transit across Brooklyn Bridge for wheelmen. In a general way Commissioner Shea asserted that he was very friendly to cyclists, and would do all he could within reasonable bounds to advance their convenience.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- An arrangement has been perfected by which Charles Page Bryan of Illinois, nominated to be Minister to China, and ex-Representative Conger of Iowa, our Minister to Brazil, will exchange posts. In accordance with this, these nominations were sent to the Senate to-day:
ALBANY, Jan. 12. -- The following bills of interest to the greater city have been introduced in the Assembly:

Old New Yorkers were busy with fog reminiscences yesterday, and differed in opinion as to the comparative density of the fog then everywhere present. There were disputes as to whether it was the thickest fog New York has experienced in many years, and some bets were made on it. These bets are safe, as there is no way of deciding them.

Yesterday's stock market was notably active and strong. Over 500,000 shares were traded in, the largest total for many weeks. It was a buoyant market, in which many substantial gains were recorded. Bonds as well as stocks were active and strong, and in both the investment and speculative departments there was a pronounced broadening.
It is reported from Washington that the majority of the House Committee on Banking and Currency will report a bill to carry out the President's recommendation in his message and nothing else.
ALBANY, Jan. 12. -- The following list of committees was announced in the Assembly to-day, and was regarded, on the whole, as satisfactory. The first named is Chairman:
It is possible that there might have been another outcome of the Ohio election as bad as the choice of HANNA. It is not possible that there could have been another much worse.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 12. -- Marcus A. Hanna was to-day elected to represent Ohio in the Senate for seven years and two months. Including both the short and the long term. Mr. Hanna's term as Senator will expire in March, 1905.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12. -- Crazed by grief over the recent death of her little daughter, Hazel, and the subsequent suicide of her mother, Mrs. Sarah Cress of Peoria, Mrs. May C. Campbell ended her existence to-day by jumping from a third-story window at the residence of W.J. Burdsell, 3,546 Forest Avenue.

There was a dramatic scene in General Sessions yesterday when Recorder Goff sentenced the two sisters, Mrs. Mary Bowers and Gertrude Barbero, convicted on Monday of stealing an aigrette, valued at 84 cents, from a Fourteenth Street department store, to two months in the penitentiary.

One of the most creditable points in the President's public career has been his early, persistent, and unflinching devotion to the cause of civil service reform. Here, his candid detractors have been forced to admit, is an opinion which the President holds firmly and holds understandingly. He may not understand the tariff, they say, he evidently does not understand the currency, but he does understand the merit system.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Jan. 12. -- Mrs. John Graper of East Toledo died, or was supposed to have died, Friday night. Later events prove it to have been a case of suspended animation. The story, as told by a daughter of the victim, is as follows:

HAVANA, Jan. 12. -- At 10 o'clock this morning about a hundred army officers, incensed by the violent attacks made by some of the local papers on the General in Chief and the principal officers of the Spanish Amy in Cuba, went to the printing offices of the daily journals La Discusion and El Reconcentrado and began smashing the windows and destroying the printing outfit as well as cuffing the employes.

If the descent of the German ships upon the Chinese coast and the subsequent lease of territory to Germany, be judged by the rules which govern the relations of civilized states, they are certainly a very extraordinary performance. A Chinese mob killed two German subjects -- missionaries -- and destroyed property.
LONDON, Jan. 12. -- The Canadian Minister of Militia, Mr. F.W. Borden, sailed for New York to-day from Liverpool on board the White Star Line steamer Majestic.

Your dispatch from Niagara Falls of this morning places the seal question in the glaring light of ridicule so justly due to it. It has nothing to recommend it to the attention bestowed upon it but sentiment, and when it is duly considered even this emotion should vanish into thin air.

ALBANY, Jan. 12. -- A lively discussion took place in the Senate to-night over a resolution moved by Senator Brush for the appointment of a committee of seven from the Chambers of Commerce of New York, Buffalo, Rochester, and Syracuse, to investigate the matter of the canal improvement and proposed estimates for the completion of the work.

The Good Samaritan, and the lawyer's question. Who is my neighbor? in reply to which Jesus told the parable, formed the subject of Dwight L. Moody's talks at Carnegie Hall yesterday. In spite of the bad weather, there was a large audience at the morning meeting and a tremendous one in the afternoon.

The charge of homicide against Charles Zanoli was dismissed by Magistrate Flammer in the Centre Street Court yesterday, and District Attorney Gardiner announced that he had no intention of causing the exhumation of the bodies of any of the man's other dead wives. On the charge of grand larceny Zanoli's lawyer waived examination for him, and asked that bond be fixed at $1,000.

CALCUTTA, Jan. 12. -News has been received from Mekran, the largest province of Baluchistan, of a serious outbreak against the British survey party there. Capt. Burn and Lieut. Turner of the Royal Engineers and Messrs. Hickie and Prunty, their assistants, with 200 carriers and signalers, were attacked.

FORT SMITH, Ark., Jan. 12. -- At least forty persons were killed and property worth over a million dollars was destroyed by a tornado which burst upon this city a few minutes after 11 o'clock last night. Men, women, and children, asleep in their homes, were without a moment's warning awakened to meet death under falling walls or in the flames which soon engulfed many of the wrecked buildings.

PARIS, Jan. 12. -- The Aurore will publish to-morrow an open letter from Emile Zola to President Faure pointing out irregularities and illegalities in the Esterhazy court-martial and formally accusing Gen. Billot, Minister of War; Gen. Mercier, Major Ravary, the investigating officer, and Major Patydeclam of perjury and challenging the Government to prosecute him.

NEW BRUNSWICK, Jan. 12. -Peter A. Sebring, a contractor of Bound Brook, who is employed by the New York and Philadelphia Traction Company, had a desperate struggle for his life last night with a man who attempted to rob him.

A hearing was begun yesterday before Gen. George H. Sharpe, representing the Customs Board of Classification, which, according to some of the tobacco importers present, is destined to determine whether imports of tobacco from Cuba shall cease, or whether they shall be permitted to continue under more liberal terms than the Treasury Department is at present disposed to concede.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- In the executive session of the Senate to-day Senator Davis continued and completed his speech in favor of ratifying the Hawaiian annexation treaty. Senator Allen of Nebraska spoke in opposition to ratification.
The metropolitan agency of the Howard Insurance Company of Baltimore has been transferred to Ogden Katzenmayer.

LONDON, Jan. 12. -- A Parliamentary by-election was held in Plymouth to-day to fill the vacancy caused by the death on Dec. 24 of Mr. Charles Harrison, the Radical member.
