It resulted in the election of the Conservative and Liberal Unionist candidate, the Hon. Ivor Churchill Guest, who defeated the Liberal and Radical candidate, Mr. S.F. Mendl, by 1,836 votes.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 12. -- Senator I-Ianna .%as received over 2,000 congratulatory telegrams since the vote taken yesterday in the House and Senate. Among the telegrams are the following:
LONDON, Jan. 12. -- The case of Jay vs. Sykes was opened before the Lord Chief Justice, Baron Russell of Killowen, in the Queen's Bench Division of the High Court of Justice to-day.

ALBANY, Jan. 12. -At a meeting of the State Board of Charities to-day President Stewart presented for consideration a communication from the managers of the House of Mercy, a reformatory in the City of New York under private management, requesting an investigation of the management of the institution, in view of the charges brought against it in an article published in a New York paper.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- While the House to-day was considering the Urgent Deficiency bill, Mr. Bell (Pop., Col.,) opposed the provision attached to an appropriation of $25,000 for the transportation of bullion between the assay offices and the mints. This provision required the depositor of gold at the assay offices to pay the cost of transportation hereafter.

-- Bishop SATTERLEE'S story, contrasting the 400 responses which a man's advertisement for a typewriter received with the four which came to the same man's wife when she advertised for a cook, may possibly be true, though the nice balancing of the figures is calculated to awaken suspicion, and to suggest that the Bishop's authority may not have been under oath.

Acting for the Directors of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company, President H.H. Vreeland yesterday wrote to the Rapid Transit Commissioners withdrawing from further consideration of the construction of the underground road projected by the commission and approved by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court. In his letter, dated Jan. 12, Mr. Vreeland said:

Bishop Thomas Underwood Dudley of Kentucky has been nominated to the office of General Secretary of the Domestic and Foreign Missionary Society of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the United States, to succeed the Rev. Dr. William S. Langford, whose death last July left the General Secretaryship vacant.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12. -- Although Receiver of Taxes is the only city officer to be chosen at the coming municipal election in February, with one Police Magistrate to fill a vacancy, the struggle of the past few months between factions of the Republican Party to obtain control of the nominating convention has been the fiercest political contest in this city for many years.

ALBANY, Jan. 12. -- A dinner will be given to Gov. Black by the members of his military staff on the evening of Jan. 31 in the Astor Gallery of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, New York City. Elaborate preparations are being made for the affair. The dinner will be very exclusive, only the members of the staff being in attendance, and no post-prandial speeches will be permitted.

LONDON, Jan. 13. -- The Daily Chronicle in a description of the experiences in Thibet of Henry Savage Landor, the artist, writer, and traveler, who narrowly escaped death at the hands of the Thibetans, when endeavoring last Autumn to reach Hassa, the capital of Thibet, says:

The Holland Society of New York held its thirteenth annual dinner last night at the Waldorf-Astoria. It was the most successful affair of its kind in the history of the organization, and one of the best attended public dinners ever held in the city. Nearly 500 were served at the seven tables placed at right angles to the guest table in the large banquet hall.

ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 12. -Capt. Frederick D. Colson of the Cornell 'Varsity crew gave out a statement to-night outlining Cornell's rowing policy and the position which the navy assumes in college aquatics of 1898.

Our neighbor The Journal insists that Capt. MAHAN is a higher authority upon the military value of Hawaii to the United States than "the Napoleons and Farraguts of the Mugwump newspaper offices." We concede it without argument. Capt. MAHAN'S knowledge of the sea power and its use is unsurpassed.

ALBANY, Jan. 12. -- The publication in The Syracuse Herald this morning of an interview with Attorney General Hancock, which seems to indicate a change of attitude on his part toward the canal question, has occasioned much surprise here.
The Bryanites are getting tired of BRYAN. He proves to be a man of one idea, while the really convinced supporters of the Chicago platform have their heads full of ideas.

England was much cheered by reports of its stupendous foreign trade in 1897. Never before was there such a total of exports and imports as $3,722,115,000. But upon analysis it appears that exports declined $28,975,000. The increase was due to imports of produce, chiefly foodstuffs from the United States, amounting to $573,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- Commissioner Jones of the Indian Office received a dispatch from Wewoka, Seminole Nation, this afternoon from W.S. Field, who says that the report of the Seminole troubles are untrue. The whites, he said, burned a probably innocent man, and the Indians are indignant, but will make no trouble. A few shots were fired in the darkness by practical jokers in the neighborhood of Earlborough.
